title: Sparring for Liberty
description: THE STORY OF AMERICAN FREEDOM

title: Murray Hill to Cooperstown
description: Yankee Stadium swells with excitement as an outfielder crouches, waiting for the play to unfold. An array of billboards hovers over the stands. The Bronx skyline peeks over the stadium walls.

title: Advocate for Women
description: Observing that every 15 seconds an act of domestic violence occurs in the United States, County Executive Andrew J. Spano announced late last month that he would put into effect a ''zero tolerance policy'' for that type of crime in Westchester.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Sign Language Signs

title: Angling for a Pay Raise, State Lawmakers Tiptoe Around Pataki
description: Ah, fall in New York, when the leaves turn, the apples ripen and legislators' thoughts turn to a pay raise. Not that anyone will say so openly, of course.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I think I'd really like to have a second, a girl. When the time comes, if we really want another and we can afford it, we will pay.''

title: Sounding Off on Sex Clubs; Tour Buses Damage Health And Block Roads
description: To the Editor:

title: Arm-Wrestler Loses Matches
description: THINGS did not go the way Glenn Terracciano of Pleasantville wanted in the World Arm-Wrestling Championships, which ended 10 days ago in Thunder Bay, Ontario.

title: The Music of Youth Rebellion Embraces the Family
description: I AM a child,'' sang Neil Young in 1968. ''I'll last awhile.'' It was the flash point of a rock-and-roll-fueled youth explosion, and fans identified more with Mr. Young's naive protagonist than with the father figure making rules in the ballad's last verse. ''I Am a Child'' magnified rock's romanticization of childhood -- and of adolescence, which to most rockers means childhood plus sex. The song traced a legacy of teen-age rebels and sweet little 16-year-olds to its origins in an emotional Never-Never Land.

title: Mail-Order High for Students on the Go
description: After bouncing in and out of so many schools in Europe, Africa and the United States that he can't remember all their names, Simone S. Liverani found himself in Kolokani, a town in Mali, the west African country where his mother worked for a company drilling water wells. There was no diplomatic or international school anywhere nearby, so he tried a local high school.

title: Jennifer Kolber, Charles White
description: Jennifer Lynn Kolber and Charles Welsh White are to be married today at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y. Judge Harold Tompkins of State Supreme Court in Manhattan is to officiate.

title: Sharon Isaksen, Eric Goodman
description: Sharon Michelle Isaksen, the daughter of Susan Isaksen of Calabasas, Calif., and Leif Isaksen of Burlingame, Calif., was married in Calabasas last evening to Eric Goodman, a son of Lottie and Ira Goodman of Baldwin Harbor, N.Y. Rabbi Brian Zachary Mayer officiated at the Calabasas Inn.

title: 'Lexington and Concord' Of Sex Clubs Is Shut Down
description: When offering examples of how an Islamic school and a strip club don't make good neighbors, Ali Sabzalian tells the story of a student who was asked by her teacher to name three cities around the world.

title: Ted Durkin and Meg Chianese
description: Merigo Carroll Chianese, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony P. Chianese of Larchmont, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Thomas Edward Durkin, a son of Mollie R. Durkin of Philadelphia and the late Thomas A. Durkin. The Rev. Joseph DeSanto performed the ceremony at St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Oui, They Agree the Subway Isn't a French Lavender Field
description: Could it be a romantic evocation of a medieval sewer system? Or is it a health hazard? Dr. Peter Homel mulls these questions daily at the Atlantic Avenue subway station in downtown Brooklyn as a pipe sends a stream of malodorous water along the tracks of the Manhattan-bound D and Q trains.

title: Gen X'ers Need a Hero Like John Glenn
description: To the Editor:

title: Christopher Dennis, Joanne Magro
description: Dr. Joanne M. Magro and Dr. Christopher Robert Dennis, medical residents in New York, were married on Friday evening at Oheka, the Otto Kahn house in Cold Spring Hills, N.Y. The Rev. Luis L. Gioia, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Civil War Sweethearts' Letters That Paint Life on the Home Front
description: A new book, ''After Chancellorsville: Letters From the Heart,'' consists of 100 letters found in an attic in California. They were written by Pvt. Walter G. Dunn, a central New Jersey native who enlisted in the Union Army in 1862, and Mary Emma Randolph, 17, who was waiting for him back home. The book, published by the Maryland Historical Society and edited by Judith A. Bailey and Robert I. Cottom, presents a portrait of Baltimore, where Walter Dunn recovered from war wounds. But to Jean Mattson, president of the Historical Society of Plainfield, who helped research the book, the most important details are in Emma Randolph's descriptions of life in central New Jersey.

title: Bizarre and Sad
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: URNINGS
description: Wanted: the rightful owners of an urn full of cremated ashes that are known only as ''Uncle Buck.'' The ashes, stored in a cedar canister with a tight lid, reside in a glass case at the Arkansas Auditor's Office in Little Rock. They arrived in 1993. After no one claimed them in a safe deposit box in northwest Arkansas, they became government goods under the state's Unclaimed Property Act. Now they're part of the Great Arkansas Treasure Hunt, a search to connect Arkansans with long-lost property -- antique watches, silverware, etc. The ashes, naturally, are considered special. ''Next year we will have an auction and get rid of this stuff,'' says Sharlett Craig, the state's deputy auditor. ''But it would really be hard to sell Uncle Buck.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Bad Bet

title: At Queens College, Shaking Up Is Hard to Do
description: Last summer, Allen L. Sessoms, the president of Queens College, came up with the kind of radical, out-of-the-box proposal you don't often hear from officials at the City University of New York: a merger between his college and nearby Queensborough Community College to form the University of Queens, a new entity with remedial students at the bottom and doctoral candidates at the top.

title: INVESTING WITH: William A. Oates Jr.; Northeast Investors Growth Fund
description: FOR the past 26 years, William A. Oates Jr. has picked his stocks from the same 10th floor office at 50 Congress Street, in the heart of Boston's historic financial district. The holdings in his Northeast Investors Growth fund are almost always proven, successful companies, often with blue-chip pedigrees. Many people might call his approach to investing old-fashioned or stodgy, even unsophisticated. But he calls it plain old common sense.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TANNER, SHARON
description: TANNER-Sharon. How fast the year has gone. You'll always be in our hearts and our souls, and we'll never forget you. Love, Robin, Micky & Emily

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Yankees Go With Option B And Bring Back Girardi
description: Joe Girardi was told last Monday that the Yankees would not pick up their $3.4 million option on his contract for 1999, and he said goodbye to the principal owner George Steinbrenner. Girardi, essentially a backup to catcher Jorge Posada, was seemingly as good as gone, probably headed to the Chicago Cubs or the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Style; Naomi Balks
description: I feel bad for Jay McInerney. He must be a pretty insecure character. Working out his obsession with models in his new novel, ''Model Behavior,'' he dusts off a stereotype that makes me laugh, the Model-as-Bimbo. Although I am not a critic, it strikes me that McInerney has forgotten to step back and ask, Is Philomena, the model at the heart of his story, real? Does she have a life behind what she looks like and what she does for a living? I don't think so.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTWIG, DARRELL FURST VON GUSSICH
description: HARTWIG-Darrell furst von Gussich. Born April 2, 1939. Died at home in Hell's Kitchen on Saturday afternoon, October 17th, 1998. If desired, contributions in Darrell's memory may be made to Gay Men's Health Crisis Inc., 119 West 24 Street, New York, N.Y. 10011-1913. Darrell, you will always be with me. I love you so. R.V.

title: Molting His Royal Plumage
description: ADAM COOPER looks more like a young club hipster than an elegantly refined ballet prince, despite his shining pedigree as a principal dancer who played such regal roles at England's Royal Ballet. He is dancing a lead in ''Swan Lake'' these days once more, but not as the ballet's lovesick prince.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on Oct. 11 about St. Petersburg museums misidentified an icon in the Russian Museum. It is of St. Nicholas, not the Archangel Gabriel.

title: Lenox Avenue Station Reopens in Harlem
description: The last phase of a seven-month, $135 million renovation project along the No. 2 and No. 3 subway lines was completed yesterday, as the Metropolitan Transportation Authority officially reopened the 116th Street Station on Lenox Avenue in Harlem.

title: A Levee Is Still a No-Show
description: It is not the capriciousness of nature that gets her down, says Jackie Nielsen; it is the inscrutable ways of homo bureaucratis. In Ms. Nielsen's telling, nature is the full-moon tides and storm surges that have sent the waters of New York Harbor flooding into her neighborhood, Oakwood Beach, four times in six years. And the bureaucrats, according to Ms. Nielsen, work for the Army Corps of Engineers, which recently announced yet another delay in its plan to replace a shattered wooden seawall with a 730-foot-long levee.

title: October 25-31; Modern No Longer, Four Drawings Are Evicted
description: When she died in 1948, Abby Aldrich Rockefeller left four important drawings -- two by van Gogh and two by Seurat -- to the Museum of Modern Art but with an unusual stipulation. As one of the founders of the Modern, she believed passionately that the museum should be devoted exclusively to art of the new. So after 50 years the drawings were to go to rival institutions with collections from many eras.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, ARTHUR
description: KAPLAN-Arthur. Age 83. On October 29, 1998. Devoted husband of Phyllis for 53 years. Beloved father of Joanne & father-in-law of James Handloser. Dear brother of Philip Kaplan & brother-in-law of Eleanor Kaplan. Adored uncle of four nieces and nephews. Arthur was a WWII veteran, 349th Batallion, 88th Division, serving in Italy. He was awarded the Bronze Star. May his memory live forever.

title: Time and Again: New Year's at Versailles
description: With all the focus on ushering in the 21st century, travelers to France can celebrate a New Year's Eve this year that takes them to the 18th century instead. The event is called Le Bal du Roy, the king's ball, and it will take place in the palace at Versailles in what the organizers say is the first New Year's Eve party there since the French Revolution. There will be 650 guests dining in the Galerie des Batailles on a meal inspired by Louis XV's table, to be prepared by Gerard Vie, of Les Trois Marches restaurant in Versailles, which has two Michelin stars. After dinner, guests will stroll through the private quarters of the king and queen. As the king and queen did at midnight of Jan. 1, from the Hall of Mirrors they will view fireworks over the gardens. Then they will repair to the King's Chapel for a Baroque music concert. Throughout the festivities, costumed dancers will demonstrate the latest moves of the 1780's (contemporary guests will wear black tie).

title: Q&A/Marisa L. Boyle; Hearing Loss Leads to Career Inspiration
description: ''WHAT does a person usually sit in, Marisa?'' asked the speech pathologist.

title: Sarah Lawrence Is Site For Songs and Arias
description: THE vocal art is well represented today, with three of this afternoon's recitals beginning at 4 o'clock. At Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers, the baritone Gabriel Alfieri and the pianist Richard Cumming collaborate on American art songs and arias by a number of composers, including Chester Biscardi, director of the music program at the college. Sing We Enchanted, a nine-member a capella choir based in northern Westchester, goes south to West Center Congregational Church in Bronxville to perform madrigals and folk songs, along with ''an eclectic mix of jazz and barbershop standards'' under Nell Detko. And Rye Presbyterian Church is host to a number of international songs and readings for All Saints' Day, with performances by Susan Chassagnoux, Wanda Brister, Enoch Sherman and Paul Johnson, singers; Maggi Heilweil and Davidson Gordon, narrators, and accompaniments by Kevin Walters, music director and organist at the church.

title: Suffolk Jail Overcrowding Sets Off Alarms
description: OVERCROWDING, and bickering among officials over how to deal with the problem, are combining to create a dangerous situation in Suffolk County's jails, corrections officials and legislators say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUCHINCLOSS, HUGH
description: AUCHINCLOSS-Hugh, MD of Westwood, MA and Manchester, MA, formerly of Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ, died on October 25, 1998 at the age of 83. His death resulted from complications of Alzheimer's Disease. Dr. Auchincloss was born in New York City, the son of Dr. Hugh Auchincloss and Frances C. (Newlands) Auchincloss. He attended Groton School, graduated from Yale in 1938 and from the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1942. After service in the Navy during World War II, he finished his residency and joined the faculty at Columbia as Associate Clinical Professor of Surgery at Columbia. He was also Attending Surgeon at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, NJ for 39 years prior to his retirement in 1992. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Katharine Lawrence (Bundy) Auchincloss, three daughters, Katharine A. Corbin of Phoenix, AZ, Margaret A. Strachan of London, Elizabeth L. Auchincloss, MD of New Rochelle, NY, his son, Hugh Auchincloss, Jr, MD of Newton, MA, two sisters, Maria A. Look of West Tisbury, MA and Barbara A. Thacher of New Canaan, CT, eleven grandchildren and one great grandson. Services and interment at Mount Auburn Cemetery in Cambridge will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Valley Hospital, N. Van Dien Ave, Ridgewood, NJ 07450. For information, The J.S. Waterman and Sons-Waring Funeral Home, Wellesley, MA.

title: Sounding Off on Sex Clubs; Rumba Dancers Need Public Space, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: And the Winners Are . . .
description: Corporate directors are at times a hunted lot. The teamsters' union has a list of ''least valuable directors.'' The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has published a report asserting that compliant boards too often overpay chief executives. But Director's Alert, a newsletter for Fortune 1000 chief executives and directors, has assembled a list of America's top 10 directors, based on the opinions of more than 100 other directors.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Marxism's True Believers Pay Tribute to an Icon
description: The grand ruinous experiment that he inspired, the late Soviet Union, has collapsed upon itself. His statues have been consigned, if not to the dustbin of history, then to countless musty warehouses and scrap yards in what once was called the Communist bloc. At least in this country, his opus is studied, if at all, as a dusty relic of a time and circumstance long past.

title: The Cameo Appearance
description: Q. As if meetings didn't already dominate my workday, my company often organizes food- and drink-filled social events in the evening. A shy person, I find these after-work gatherings exhausting, yet realize that failing to attend could hurt my career. Any survival tips?

title: October 25-31; U.S. Ex-Sergeant Charged In Bin Laden Conspiracy
description: Law enforcement officials said secret charges have been filed against a former sergeant in the United States Special Forces who is suspected of joining a global campaign to attack Americans mounted by Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile.

title: Don't Laugh. That Sitcom Might Spell Bad Times.
description: WORK has always been a problem for television.

title: Peripheral Figure Feels the Heat of Starr's Investigation
description: Julie Hiatt Steele is only a peripheral figure in the investigation of President Clinton. But she is still attracting a lot of attention from Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel.

title: R-Rated Theater
description: To the Editor:

title: Yugoslav Wields Ax in 'Pacification' of Academia
description: Vladimir Vodinelic has been teaching law at Belgrade University for 27 years, and his own experience, reinforced by reading the history books, tells him that times have never been so bad in Yugoslav academia.

title: Legal Help for Poor Is Caught in Political Chokehold
description: William Gregory Blackwell says he began doing drugs when he was 7 or 8 and as an adult was arrested more than 40 times and bounced in and out of jail for at least six years.

title: Cars Getting Penalized As Offsides at Giants Stadium
description: The penalties weren't confined to the field during the Jets' win at Giants Stadium last Sunday. East Rutherford Police officers issued 515 $43 parking tickets to cars parked illegally along Route 3 and the service road, apparently by fans trying to avoid the $10 stadium parking fee and the post-game crush.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, YVETTE
description: EISENBERG-Yvette. We are deeply saddened at the passing of our dear friend. Heartfelt sympathy to Alfred and the family. Audrey and Jimmy Goodman and family

title: Global Crisis for Coca-Cola, Or a Pause That Refreshes?
description: THE World of Coca-Cola, which on the cultural scale falls somewhere between legitimate museum and Disney-style extravaganza, is one of M. Douglas Ivester's hangouts. Once a month or so, he likes to pop in, gaze at the exhibits of Coke ephemera and eavesdrop on the tourists crowded around.

title: Russian Champions on the Stamford Ice
description: AMONG the victims of the recent economic collapse in Russia have been public buildings, left in decline as more urgent problems clamor for fixes. One of those is the Yubileiny Palace of Sports ice rink in St. Petersburg, where the reigning Olympic gold and silver medal-winning pairs of skaters trained.

title: SOAPBOX; Down the Bunny Trail
description: WHAT do you do when a younger member of the family finds an abandoned bunny rabbit just days old, that, after a few more days in a cardboard box and with cows' milk for nourishment, wakes up sick?

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 47 of the Arts & Leisure section today about the artist Kim Dingle misstates the closing date for her exhibition at the Sperone Westwater Gallery in SoHo. It is Dec. 19, not Nov. 19.

title: On Language; Where's the Poetry?
description: Have you noticed the paucity of poetry in American public life, especially in headlines? The Poetic Allusion Watch (PAW), once an annual event in this space, has been shut out for lack of examples. The last good entry submitted is from Donald Marks of New York, citing a headline in the science section of The New York Times over a story about snakes in Venezuela: ''Splendor in the Mud: Unraveling the Lives of Anacondas.''

title: Three-Time Rivals at Odds on Record
description: There is a certain feeling of deja deja vu about the Congressional campaign here, north of Boston, in the Sixth District of Massachusetts.

title: It's the Hair, Stupid
description: Let's lay the blame where it belongs. It is not an act of God. It is not an affliction; it is not even genetic. Bad hair is a result of ignorance, of a refusal to keep abreast of the great technological strides in the hair-grooming industry. Americans spend $40 billion a year on their hair. For that money we should be a nation of bouncy, springy locks from sea to shining sea. Instead (according to shampoo ads at least), there's a pandemic of lifeless, dry and dull. Not to mention split ends.

title: The Candidates' Views
description: Alfonse M. D'Amato

title: Yankees May Look But Not Touch
description: The Yankees' victory parade ended and another parade immediately began -- the parade of superstars supposedly linked to the Yankees' future, from Barry Bonds to Roger Clemens to Albert Belle to Randy Johnson to Kevin Brown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, IRWIN
description: POLLACK-Irwin ''Irv.'' 77, of Seattle, died October 16 of heart failure. He was Business Manager at Yale University, graduate of CCNY, a progressive activist. He will be sorely missed. We might have had him longer if he were able to stop smoking. He is survived by his son Jordan of Port Townsend, WA, sister Miriam Weintraub of NYC, ex-wife Clarice of New Haven, niece Sherry Mestel of Brooklyn NY, grandnieces and devoted friends Lisa Morrow and Scott McClay of Seattle.

title: Defense Comes Through Again as Devils Go Above .500
description: The Devils usually win when they score more than two goals. They scored three goals tonight against the Florida Panthers for a 3-1 victory that gave the Devils a winning record for the first time this season at 5-4.

title: Making 'The Nutcracker' Symphonic
description: FOR most of us, Tchaikovsky's ballet ''The Nutcracker'' probably means one of two things: the perennial magic of the stagework itself or a purely musical encounter with the beloved little dances that pepper the second act. But who would pause over the whole of Tchaikovsky's musical work, every scene and transition, without the stagecraft and dancing? After all, ''The Nutcracker'' isn't exactly the ''Pathetique'' Symphony.

title: A Style Perennial: Dirty Old Sweats
description: Harvard and Yale may be America's most prestigious universities, pantheons of scholarship and yada yada yada, but as far as marketers are concerned, they are brands, trademarks that can really move the merch.

title: In Aiding the Aged, Some Doctors Do Care
description: To the Editor:

title: A Writer's Layered Rome
description: IN the late 19th century, no self-respecting American tourist would think of visiting Rome without taking along Nathaniel Hawthorne's novel ''The Marble Faun.'' Sightseers folded handsomely illustrated editions into their luggage to use as a guide, and even as late as 1958, almost 100 years after the novel's publication, enthusiasts said it was as if Dostoyevsky had written a Baedeker.

title: DNA Test Finds Evidence Of Jefferson Child by Slave
description: DNA tests on the descendants of Thomas Jefferson's family and of Jefferson's young slave, Sally Hemings, offer compelling evidence that the nation's third President fathered at least one of her children, according to an article in the scientific journal Nature.

title: Trees Will Squeeze, Farmers Say
description: James R. Durr was driving his pickup truck on his southern New Jersey flower farm and worrying about the fate of the Union Square Greenmarket. ''It appears that this new plan is going to severely restrict the market,'' said Mr. Durr, one of some 70 farmers who sell their wares at the market four days a week.

title: More Intimate 'Cats'
description: CATS

title: Soul of the Age
description: SHAKESPEARE

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HARTIG, HERBERT
description: HARTIG-Herbert, Nov 1, 1991. I feel your absence now as strongly as I felt your presence. Bon Voyage. Naomi

title: Judge Blocks City's Plan to Send Brooklyn's Garbage Out of State
description: A state judge granted a temporary stay Friday against the exporting of Brooklyn's garbage for out-of-state disposal as part of the city's plan to close the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island in 2001.

title: SOAPBOX; Uncommon Problems
description: MORE than 20 years have passed, and the school is now the Maplewood Middle School. But at that time, it was Maplewood Junior High School. And of all the teachers I had, I remember one most clearly. To protect his privacy, I'll call him Mr. Jessup.

title: The New Church Social
description: ''HEY, want to get some cake?'' William Gelman whispered to a blonde who caught his eye at an evening of Bible readings the other day.

title: Angel Rivera Jr., Julie Reynolds
description: Julie Anne Reynolds, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Reynolds of Jupiter, Fla., was married yesterday to Dr. Angel Luis Rivera Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rivera Sr. of the Bronx. The Rev. Thomas Neilson performed the ceremony at the main altar of St. Patrick's Cathedral in Manhattan.

title: Santa Fe Chefs Refine a Sturdy, Lusty Cuisine
description: SANTA FE in autumn is restive. The busy summer season has ended, and the city's high tide of tourism ebbs until the Thanksgiving and Christmas waves. Yet, ask residents about the most beautiful time of the year, and they are likely to cite the fall, when the clear, crystalline light that illuminates the high desert seems polished to an even higher degree of purity by the crisp mountain air.

title: In the State of Contentment, We're Happy, Happy, Happy
description: THE economy is still strong. The leaves have been breathtaking. The Bluefish had a winning season. What is there to be unhappy about?

title: Despite Bluster, Qaddafi Weighs Deal for 2 Bombing Suspects
description: Outwardly at least, nearly everything on display in Libya these days seems calculated to project defiance.

title: Even Pretty Cities Have Their Dark Sides
description: Never mind New York. And forget about downtown Detroit. When it comes to crime that is truly peculiar to its own little corner of the U.S.A., there's livelier action in Biloxi, Miss., and Salt Lake City -- two of the locales in ''City Confidential,'' a new A&E documentary series about regional crimes that reflect the singular character of their settings.

title: Man Is Robbed At Knifepoint In Central Park
description: An 18-year-old man was robbed at knifepoint in Central Park last night by three men wearing Halloween masks, the police said. It was the eighth knife attack in the park in just over a month.

title: Pinochet: New Round of Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHLARSON, LINDER
description: CHLARSON-Linder. 62. October 27. Son of Lewis and Erma. Composer, director, teacher. The world will yearn for more of his music. Many friends will miss him. Donations to American Music Center.

title: For the Wild Turkey, Not a Fair Fight
description: Let me get this straight. According to the article ''The Return of the Turkey, Wild in Style'' (Oct. 11), the contest between turkey hunter and turkey is ''something of a fair fight.'' The hunter employs a turkey-calling device, camouflage, a blind to hide behind and, of course, a bow or shotgun. At 50 yards, a legal bow in Connecticut can put an arrow clear through a deer, never mind a turkey. A shotgun is lethal at several times that distance.

title: Are Computers Teaching Students Or Solitaire?
description: SOMEWHERE in the western Pacific, the cargo ship California Galaxy is steaming to port. Thousands of miles away, a group of sixth graders in Bayonne is tracking it closely on the Internet.

title: An Election, Yes, But Congressional Races, Not Really; Some Hard Words In the 4th District
description: MRS. McCARTHY got a laugh out of the actress Laurie Metcalf's efforts to master the Long Island accent in her portrayal of Mrs. McCarthy in a recent made-for-television movie.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: The Right Stuff, Finally; Jets Give Unbeaten Testaverde the Support He Needs to Excel
description: For the first time in a pro football life that would harden the heart of most quarterbacks, a mellow Vinny Testaverde will take the field here Sunday undefeated and ranked by any measure as one of the top quarterbacks of the season.

title: 'You're Just Like Bill Clinton'
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: An Election, Yes, But Congressional Races, Not Really; Clinton Becomes An Issue on L.I.
description: AS well as he can, Mr. Pinzon, a Republican from Floral Park, Queens, is making an issue of President Clinton's behavior in the Oval Office and his testimony before grand juries.

title: In Late Twist, A Pataki Ad Takes Aim At Golisano
description: Gov. George E. Pataki made a sudden strategic shift in the final weekend of his re-election campaign today, broadcasting his first television advertisement attacking B. Thomas Golisano, the third-party candidate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOXER, WALTER
description: BOXER-Walter. 82. Beloved husband of Shirley. Devoted father of Henry and Louis. Adored grandfather of seven. President of the Wholesale Florist Association. Services Monday, 11:30 AM, Boulevard-Riverside, Hewlett, NY. He will be terribly missed by all who knew him.

title: How to Win Big in Court And Never See a Lawyer
description: EVER wish you could get a piece of a major lawsuit? You can, in the form of some wildly esoteric securities that track the outcome of three billion-dollar suits.

title: A Drug Company's Promise
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends: Heavenly Rewards; Shilling the Right Stuff
description: THE European Space Agency labored in obscurity for many years, achieving dozens of feats in the heavens that were ignored by most Europeans. Then, in 1983, Europe's first astronaut soared into space aboard a shuttle. Suddenly, millions of television viewers across the continent were glued to their sets, watching a good-looking European explorer risk life and limb on the high frontier.

title: SoHo's Got A Brand New Bag Store
description: The handbags are French, and they come in hues other than bleu. Regardless, the new store is on this side of the Atlantic, at 266 Elizabeth Street, between Houston and Prince Streets, and is called Blue Bag. Marni Legrand, an owner along with her husband, Pascal, likened Blue Bag, which opened three weeks ago, to a ''little atelier in Paris.'' Though they do not have a workshop in which to make custom satchels, they say that most of their bags are not available in department stores and that they never stock more than five of any style at once. Totes -- some leather, others nylon -- are $90 to $100, evening bags, some with beads, $75 to $150. In December, the Legrands plan to begin marketing a line of lambskin luggage carrying the shop's name. Blue Bag is open daily from 11 A.M. to 7:30 P.M.

title: At Christie's, Master's in the House
description: Education has become the weapon of choice in the war between the two titans of the art market, Christie's and Sotheby's. Over the last decade, both auction houses have opened special divisions offering a range of courses about the history and appraisal of fine art and decorative objects. Both even offer advanced degrees in their London headquarters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINMAN, KENNETH R.
description: KLEINMAN-Kenneth R. Age 77, of NYC, died October 30, 1998. Beloved and cherished husband of Elaine for 56 years, inseperable companion, soulmate and confidant for 63 years. Graduate of Alfred Univeristy, one of the youngest Captains in the US Army-Air Force during WW II. Known in business for his acumen and scrupulousness. He is also survived by his adoring children Jill, David and Joan, his treasured grandchildren Jennifer, Jonathan, Alexandra and Emily, and his beloved sons-in-law Judd Shanker and Richard Cohen. Precious husband, father and grandfather who loved his family more than life itself. Tireless reader and unapologetic liberal, lover of science and human inquiry, imbued with wonder and awe, humble, honest, true; an exemplar of loving kindness, patience, understanding, fortitude, selfless devotion, and steadfast support. Kind to a fault, a guileless, unassuming man of grace, intelligence, gentle sweetness, with contempt for ridgid fundamentalism and false promises, with the courage to embrace uncertainty in the truthfulness of his unfailing spirit. He will never be forgotten. Forever in our hearts. Funeral services at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Ave and 76th St, today, at 12:30 PM.

title: Absence of Basketball Is a Window for Hockey
description: Four short years ago, hockey was hot. The Rangers won the Stanley Cup and rap artists wore National Hockey League jerseys, even if they couldn't name many players. National sports magazines and business publications proclaimed the ascendancy of the N.H.L., comparing its growth potential to that of the National Basketball Association, Major League Baseball and the National Football League.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: BEHIND THE RED MIST

title: A Troupe's Jete Into Lingerie
description: Itchy seams. Extra fabric that chafes between breasts. Multiple straps restricting movement. No one is more intimate with the problems of stretchy workout gear than a ballerina. That's why when Felissimo, a New Age department store, planned to introduce a line of ''innerwear,'' they invited members of the San Francisco Ballet to help brainstorm. ''We all sat around and moaned and groaned about sports bras and seams and how uncomfortable everything is,'' said Sarah Sessions, a dancer with the company. ''I think the whole session felt more like a support group.''

title: October 25-31; Stock Promoters Charged
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused 44 stock promoters of fraudulently promoting more than 235 tiny companies on the Internet. It was the first nationwide sweep of stock fraud on the Web.

title: Linda Broudy, David Eggers Jr.
description: Linda Broudy and David L. Eggers Jr. are to be married this afternoon by Rabbi Chaim Stern at the John Jay Homestead in Katonah, N.Y.

title: Let It Be
description: PRINCIPLES FOR A FREE SOCIETY Reconciling Individual Liberty With the Common Good. By Richard A. Epstein. 360 pp. Reading, Mass.: Perseus Books. $30.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 18 about Edward Windsor's television career misstated the designation of the uncle of his who abdicated the throne of England and became the Duke of Windsor. It was Edward VIII, not Edward VII.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 1, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Political Briefing; What's That Noise? It's That Debate -- Again
description: Remember the auto insurance legislation that Governor Whitman signed into law last May?

title: War Games
description: THE NEXT WORLD WAR

title: My Scud
description: Jacques Littlefield, a prosperous Californian, wants to make a few things clear about why he purchased two Scud missiles and their launching vehicles. He doesn't intend to cause trouble. He's just an avid collector of military hardware, a simple man who, um, owns more than 140 tanks, jeeps and armored personnel carriers on his ranch south of San Francisco.

title: IN MY . . . SATCHEL: LARRY MILLER
description: Larry Miller is the chief operating officer of A2B Music, a unit of AT&T that is battling to become the dominant force in selling music over the Internet. Though music distribution on the Web is still in its infancy, it is showing enormous potential, and Mr. Miller says he intends to convince music store owners that the Internet can enhance their profits while helping artists thwart the illegal copying of music, which robs them of royalties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWRENCE, BARBARA CHILDS
description: LAWRENCE - Barbara Childs. Died peacefully at her home, South Pole Farm in Norfolk, Connecticut on October 23, 1998 at the age of 86. She was the widow of James F. Lawrence and was predeceased by two children, Peter F. Lawrence & Jane Lawrence Mali. She is survived by four children: Barbara L. Garside, J. Vinton Lawrence, Suzannah L. Wood all of Norfolk; and Starling R. Lawrence of New York City and 13 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at The Church of Christ Congregational in Norfolk at noon Saturday, November 21. Please omit flowers., Contributions in her memory may be made to the Norfolk library.

title: Backtalk; Running a Brother's Race to Find Out Why He Stopped
description: Everyone told my brother Gary he should run a marathon someday. We all knew he had it in him. He'd run two hours in the morning to warm up for an all-day bike ride through the mountains around Salt Lake City, where he lived. He ran in the dark, and in the snow, and in the blazing heat. He pushed his body hard to see where he could take it.

title: Jacqueline Sherman, Bennett Gross
description: Jacqueline Sue Sherman, the daughter of Barbara and Lawrence M. Sherman of La Jolla, Calif., was married last evening to Dr. Bennett Raymond Gross, a son of Grecia and Ronald M. Gross of Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Martin N. Levin officiated at the Four Seasons Hotel in Carlsbad, Calif.

title: Christopher Gable, 58, Dancer Who Made Switch to Acting
description: Christopher Gable, an English ballet star who made an unusually successful transition to film and theater, died on Oct. 23 at his home near Halifax in Yorkshire. He was 58.

title: A Fresh Face Narrows Gap in Congressional Race
description: Kevin J. O'Connor is a 31-year-old Republican who quit his job at a Hartford law firm to run for Congress in a district that hasn't voted for a Republican representative in 42 years.

title: Aid Groups Press U.N. for New Effort to End Sudan's Civil War
description: Private aid groups, currently sending millions of dollars worth of food and medicine to relieve starvation and suffering in Sudan, are pressing the United Nations to make a vigorous new effort to end the nearly 30-year civil war there instead of merely feeding its victims.

title: Peace, Love and 'Zoom': More Power to the (Little) People
description: LISTEN up, Zoomers and Ubbi Dubbi linguists of all stripes, childhood pleasures are coming around again.

title: Switching Channels
description: WELCOME TO THE WORLD, BABY GIRL!

title: Fight Over Water Plant Heats Up
description: With the city a month away from deciding where to build a 20-acre water filtration plant, residents of the northwest Bronx turned out by the hundreds last week to oppose its construction at any of the four proposed sites in their borough.

title: Guila Franklin, Nathan Siegel
description: Guila Sharon Franklin, the daughter of Dorothy and Sherwood Franklin of Brooklyn, is to be married today to Nathan Ellis Siegel, a son of Judith Siegel and Dr. Lewis Siegel of Chapel Hill, N.C. Rabbi Donald Tam is to perform the ceremony at the Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Center in East Rockaway, N.Y.

description: To the Editor:

description: Nureyev:

description: King Philip II Exhibitions

title: Designers' Imaginations Meet the Challenge of Small Spaces
description: THERE are house tours and show houses, but rarely has a historic church offered its space to a decorator's showcase.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOSKEY, SHIRLEY ECKER
description: BOSKEY-Shirley Ecker. Age 80 on October 13, 1998. Survived by husband Bennett Boskey, her brother Allan B. Ecker of New York City, her sister Laura Ecker Ludwig of New York City, her nieces Lisa Ludwig Kahn of San Francisco, Amy Ludwig of Chicago, and Sarah Rice Ecker Cooper of Houston, and her nephew Andrew Ludwig of New York City. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to and would be welcomed by Recording For The Blind & Dyslexic of Metropolitan Washington, 5225 Wisconsin Avenue, N.W. Washington, D.C. 20015, a significant charitable activity for the benefit of vision-disadvantaged individuals and one of Mrs. Boskey's abiding interests.

title: Joining Mainframes to the Internet
description: ''I was so impressed with the software engineering concept that six months before the first release of the product, I gave up a good job, took a big hit in salary and became the third company employee, vice president of sales -- at what was a start-up software shop in Elmsford,'' Scott C. Nevins said.

title: For Vacationers, La Nina Previews Are Mixed
description: LAST May, climatologists noted an abrupt cooling of the water in the tropical Pacific Ocean, clearly signaling the end of last year's infamous El Nino and the beginning of this year's La Nina, the latest swing of the planet's climatic pendulum. They predicted correctly that the hurricane season that officially ends Nov. 30 would be much worse than last year's. Hurricane Bonnie, which sent tens of thousands packing when it swept across the Carolina shores in late August, proved them right, as did Georges, which ravaged parts of the Caribbean and the Gulf Coast of the United States a few weeks later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIMPSON, ELEANOR ROSEMARY
description: TIMPSON-Eleanor Rosemary of Essex Fells, N.J. and Chatham, MA. With great sadness her family mourns her death on October 22, 1998. Rosemary was born in Orange, N.J. on May 16th, 1911. She attended Vassar College, where she was involved with the Vassar Experimental Theatre. After graduation, she studied landscape design at Radcliffe College, and continued her interest in Theatre as a lighting specialist. Rosemary was married in 1940 to her husband, James Timpson, a Montclair architect, with whom she had two children, Anne Timpson Fuglestad and James L. Timpson. She is survived by her three brothers, Roger B. Charlesworth, Robert E. Charlesworth, Richard L. Charlesworth, two grandchildren, one nephew and many nieces. Her professional life of fifty years as an interior designer leaves behind a rich visual tribute to her talents. For fifteen years she opened a seasonal museum and shop in Chatham, MA, called the ''Ten O'clock Scholar''. During World War II, Rosemary served as canteen chairman in the Red Cross caring for wounded soldiers. Her generous contributions of time and service to Vassar Club of Essex County, Essex Fells School, Essex Fells Garden Club and St. Peter's Opportunity Shop, where she volunteered for forty-three years, will not be forgotten. She gave generous gifts, her time, and her creativity to many museums, sharing a great love and knowledge of social history. These include the Montclair Art Museum, where she curated and designed three exhibitions, The Crane House, where she restored the Revere room, The Toy and Miniature Museum of Kansas City, The New Jersey Historical Society, S.P.N.E.A. and The Peabody Museum, where resides her gift of a 12 ft. riggers model, the U.S.S. Pennsylvania. She was loving and compassionate to her family and friends and will be remembered for her warmth, humor and grace.

title: Parties Race To Get Out The Vote On Tuesday
description: AS Election Day 1998 draws near, the attention of candidates and their political parties focuses now on making sure their supporters get out to vote.

title: Other People's Money
description: Created Unequal The Crisis in American Pay. By James K. Galbraith. Illustrated. 350 pp. New York: The Free Press. $26.

title: Cheap Thrills, Seriously
description: Diane Cardwell raised the question of whether shocking graphic images of violence in films and on cable TV have a socially redeeming quality, in that they force us to acknowledge and address problems we might otherwise ignore (Culture Zone, Oct. 11). One crucially important point, which Cardwell did not examine, is how the victim is portrayed. Does the audience meet the victim as a person with feelings, dreams and relationships, or merely as an object of abuse? This distinction will go a long way toward determining if the graphic scenes are meant to raise awareness and spark a social outcry, or simply shock, overwhelm and desensitize us.

title: Say What?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Finding a Full Democratic Dance Card
description: The floor-to-rafters crowd at the Democrats' Get Out the Vote rally was already in a buoyant mood, having heard a rousing rendition of ''Lift Every Voice and Sing'' and the Stevie Wonder tune ''Living for the City.''

title: At Parade in Village, Ghouls and Cats, and a Message or Two
description: Everyone who was anyone was there -- in triplicate. Multiple Bill Clintons and Monicas, swarms of people dressed as insects and Metrocards and ghouls, people wearing things that glowed and twinkled and went boom in the night. There were some who brought their children dressed as cats and ghosts and some who brought their dogs dressed as cats and ghosts, too.

title: A Thousand Miles of Hell
description: RUNNING NORTH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TONG, DIANE
description: TONG-Diane. Author and photographer. Beloved daughter of Beatrice and Harold Deitchman. Sister of Robert Deitchman. Services at Parkside Chapels, 98-60 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, 10 AM, Sunday, November 1.

title: Pet Need Help? Hail the Traveling Vet
description: HOUSE calls are a thing of the past, unless you order pizza or call one of the small group of veterinarians who treat their canine, feline and porcine clients in their owners' homes.

title: Now, Municipal Bond Investors Can Shop Before They Buy
description: For years, municipal bond investors had no way to tell if the price of a bond quoted by a broker was good, bad or indifferent, unless they canvassed other brokers. That will end this month when the Bond Market Association, a trade group, begins daily postings on its World Wide Web site of 1,000 muni transactions tracked by the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board. The data will be available free at www.investinginbonds.com. The site will include credit ratings, insurance data and yields, courtesy of J. J. Kenny, the muni bond brokerage subsidiary of Standard & Poor's. ABBY SCHULTZ

title: Taxing Roth: A Tighter Loophole
description: New Internal Revenue Service rules, effective today, phase out a maneuver that some investors have been using to reduce 1998 taxes in converting their traditional individual retirement accounts into new Roth I.R.A.'s.

title: In the Region / Westchester; Two Soaring Proposals for Low-Scale New Rochelle
description: THINGS are definitely looking up for this city on Long Island Sound as it considers two proposals that have nothing in common, except their height. At more than 200 feet, they would be the tallest structures in the city.

title: Going Down Screaming
description: I can't recall when I have read an article that so accurately expressed my own feelings. In these times, when every publication feels the need to take a hard line on impeachment hearings and on politics in general, the public is left with a choice between self-righteous Republican moralizing and the mindless parroting of the Democratic Party line. In this context, Sullivan's article is refreshingly objective as well as intelligent and historically informed.

title: Integration's Casualties
description: Over the last year, as President Clinton's race advisory board wound toward its inconclusive report on America's most enduring social tension, MaVynee Betsch, a black woman in her early 60's who lives in self-imposed austerity in the little town of American Beach, Fla., was wrapping up a race initiative of her own. She was leading the struggle of some Beach residents to protect their historic black community from the expansion of a neighboring (and almost exclusively white) golf resort, the Amelia Island Plantation.

title: Schooled for Scandal
description: A high-profile crime and murder trial involving a distinguished French family focuses on a children's maligned governess (Bette Davis) in Anatole Litak's ALL THIS AND HEAVEN TOO (1940), derived from a Rachel Field book. The picture is a beautifully handled costume drama set in 19th-century France with Charles Boyer perfectly cast as a passionate aristocrat and Barbara O'Neil as his tempestuous, neurotic mate. Incidentially, the governess tasted a kind of justice, for she married into New York aristocracy and became a leading figure in Manhattan society - WEDNESDAY at 10 P.M. on TURNER CLASSIC MOVIES.

title: October 25-31; English Court Blocks Pinochet Extradition
description: An international effort to hold Gen. Augusto Pinochet accountable for the more than 3,000 people who died during his 17-year rule in Chile was blocked in London. England's High Court ruled that he could not be extradited to Spain to face charges of genocide and torture because he is immune from prosecution as a former head of state.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: The 80's? That Was High School
description: THE SETTING -- A flock of young professionals enjoying cocktails, flirting and business chitchat Tuesday night at Life, a nightclub on Bleecker Street. The event was organized by Peter Conti, a former nightlife dean turned college professor who decided it was time to revive the ''networking parties'' of the 80's.

title: Wrestling With God
description: CARTESIAN SONATA

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RULNICK, DORIS
description: RULNICK-Doris. November 1, 1992. Always in loving memory. Your dear daughter, Joyce

title: Sharp Cat's Career in Doubt
description: Sharp Cat, the leading filly in the country and the heavy favorite for Saturday's Breeders' Cup Distaff, experienced an intense inflammation of a muscle in her back today and was certain to be withdrawn from the $2 million race.

title: INSIDE
description: Russia's New Recovery Plan

title: Senate Rivals, Skirting Issues, Cap Bitter Race
description: With a bus trip across upstate New York and a visit to a bustling kosher delicatessen on Manhattan's Lower East Side, Representative Charles E. Schumer and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato wrestled through the final weekend of their campaign yesterday, closing out a contest notable for its absence of discussion on the policy differences between them.

title: Samuel Blum, 70, Book Club Executive
description: Samuel Blum, a writer and a former editor in chief of the Doubleday Book Club, died on Oct. 22 at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 70 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Adm. John Hyland, 86, Dies; Championed Naval Air Power
description: Adm. John Joseph Hyland Jr., a veteran test pilot and champion of naval air power who commanded the American armada off Indochina at the height of the Vietnam War, died last Sunday at a hospice in Honolulu. He was 86 and lived in Honolulu.

title: Paying Up, or Else
description: At least one resident was not prepared for New Rochelle's new policy on scofflaws, James Generoso, chief clerk of the city's court, said. A list of the 10 top scofflaws appeared in a local newspaper in September, and that resident found the list enlarged and posted at her place of employment. The offender in question quickly paid up the outstanding fines on her traffic tickets, Mr. Generoso said. In all, three of New Rochelle's worst parking-ticket offenders are paying off their debts, he said.

title: NOTICED; A Stylish Joe and His Joe's Magazine
description: STYLISTS are the pillow-plumpers of the fashion industry. They make models and celebrities look their best by dressing them for catwalks, awards shows and magazine shoots. But there is also an elite corps of super stylists too important to merely accessorize. They work with photographers and designers to create a concept or a vision.

title: October 25-31; In the Land of the Cracked Head
description: Italian mothers, who run screaming into the ocean to pluck out children who dare to swim less than an hour after lunch, seem to lose all their caution once they hit the road.

title: Song of Ourselves
description: A LARGER MEMORY

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Katherine Ramsland; Every Day Can Be Halloween
description: THE bouncer had gold fangs and blood-tinged eyes, the barmaid had gore spilling down the sides of her mouth and nearly all the patrons looked as if they hadn't slept in weeks. It might have been two days before Halloween, but the costumed crowd that gathered at the Greenwich Village club Mother was not indulging in some fleeting holiday masquerade. It was the weekly gathering of the Fang Club, where vampires -- and the men and women who love them -- dance, drink and engage in sanguinary socializing.

title: Violence an Issue
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Quiet Quarter and its Crown Jewel
description: JUST as there are New Yorkers who don't know the wonders of Brooklyn and the Bronx, so there are Parisians who know nothing of the 19th arrondissement, a district with an eventful history, colorful neighborhoods and -- its crown jewel -- Les Buttes-Chaumont, one of Paris's loveliest parks.

title: See Dick and Jane Type
description: Another reason to be afraid, very afraid, of the world's elementary school children: not only do they lack the grace to act confused around computers, but an increasing number will also be able to churn out term papers with the speed of court stenographers by the time they reach the sixth grade.

title: Going Back to the Past At Fort Tryon Overlook
description: THE high cliff had been an Indian shrine, a Revolutionary War battle site and home to none other than Boss Tweed. But John D. Rockefeller Jr. had special plans when he bought the rocky northern Manhattan bluff in 1917. ''I will spare no expense to build a great park for the city,'' he declared.

title: Dana Lichty and Jim Weikart
description: Dana D. Lichty and Jim R. Weikart were married yesterday by the Rev. Joseph Gilmore at the South Presbyterian Church in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Emily Seigel, Philip Friedman
description: Emily Jane Seigel and Philip Warren Friedman were married last evening by the Rabbi Richard S. Chapin at the Pierre in New York.

title: Sylvia Kimball, Christopher Perry
description: Sylvia Kneeland Kimball, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Kimball Jr. of Millbrook, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christopher Drake Perry, a son of Rachel C. Claflin of Boston and A. Wade Perry of Lincoln, Mass. The Rev. Louise Conant performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIKOV, SGT. ALEXEI
description: NIKOV-Sgt. Alexei. Yeshivat Sha'alvim in Israel mourns Sgt. Asher Nikov, alumnus of the Lycee Sha'alvim in Kharkov, Ukraine, a joint project of Yeshivat Sha'alvim and the Orthodox Union. There, and at the Joseph K. Miller Torah Center in Kharkov, Asher developed his love for Torah heritage and Israel. His army jeep intercepted a Palestinian terrorist attack on a school bus with forty Israeli children. He made the supreme sacrifice. Our condolences to his parents. Yeshivat Sha'alvim

title: PULSE; Making Scents Of the Past
description: It used to be possible to tell magazines apart by smell alone: women's glossies reeked of perfume; respectable science periodicals did not. But this month, National Geographic features a story, ''Perfume, the Essence of Illusion,'' illustrated (aromatized?) with the signature fragrances worn by Napoleon Bonaparte and Cleopatra. The Emperor's citrusy cologne (a sort of eau de Lemon Pledge) was recreated by Jean Kerleo, the chief perfumer at Jean Patou (creators of Joy). The formula for Napoleon's scent survived in his valet's estate, and was loaned by the Osmotheque, a fragrance museum in Versailles, France. An Italian chemist mixed Roman unguents to reconstruct what Cleopatra might have doused the sails of her barge with when receiving Mark Antony. Readers have been asking to buy the scents, but National Geographic has no plans to develop them commercially. In France, no one seems to want to cheapen Bonaparte's name by reducing it to a marketing campaign. And Cleopatra's scent, with its rare alchemy of myrrh, balsam and saffron, is roughly 10 times as expensive to produce as Napoleon's, let alone a few ounces of Gucci Envy. ELIZABETH ANGELL

title: Habitats / Queens; Leaving Manhattan for the Wide Open Spaces
description: FOR 15 years, Eric and Melanie Mache lived in a small rent-stabilized two-bedroom apartment on the Upper East Side. As the years went by, the apartment grew ever more crowded. What with a desk and a wardrobe and a sewing machine, there were only two tiny aisles for walking around their bed. The second bedroom, which served as Mr. Mache's office, was even more cramped.

title: Bay Area Books
description: To the Editor: I was disappointed that readers of ''Bay Area Bookstores for the Purist'' (Sept. 27) missed learning of yet another special bookstore in the Bay area. The Bookmark Bookstore at 721 Washington Street in Old Oakland is operated by the Friends of the Oakland Public Library. All proceeds benefit Oakland's main library and 16 branches.

description: LEVINE-Mayer. Passed away peacefully at the age of 94 years. Beloved husband of the late Louise. Loving father of Herman and Ruth (Greenwald). Adored brother of Molly Feuer and the late Jack. Cherished grandfather of Susan, Peter and Alison. Great-grandfather of Morgan and Jared Levine. He will always be remembered for his honesty, integrity and devotion to all. Services Sunday, 10:45 AM at Gutterman's Funeral Home (Parkside building) 2576 Flatbush Ave, corner Ave V, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Time Is Not of the Essence, But Strategy Certainly Is
description: For her first New York City Marathon in 1994, Tegla Loroupe of Kenya received some simple, prescient advice from Anne Roberts, the race coordinator:

description: To the Editor:

title: Vanessa Kerner, Bruce Wolfowitz
description: Vanessa Elaine Kerner, the daughter of Sylvia and Brian P. Kerner of London, is to be married today to Bruce Robert Wolfowitz, a son of Linda and Paul Wolfowitz of New York. Dr. Jonathan H. Sacks, the chief rabbi of the United Hebrew Congregations of the Commonwealth, is to perform the ceremony at the Golders Green Synagogue in London.

title: Sports of The Times; For N.B.A. Players Union, What Goes Around Comes Around
description: THREE years ago, the same pro basketbll superstars who are currently negotiating a luxury tax with David Stern tried to decertify their union after learning their representatives were negotiating a luxury tax with David Stern.

title: 'Smart Cards' For Licenses Emerge 'Digital' And Resurface In the Assembly
description: An effort to replace driver's licenses with ''smart cards'' that store information on microchips -- dropped in July because of widespread opposition -- was resurrected in a milder form last week in the Assembly and faces far better prospects.

title: With Money at Stake, Challengers to Incumbents Are Fighting Uphill Battle
description: If there ever was an underdog, it is Lawrence A. Klemens, a Democratic high school principal in western Pennsylvania seeking the Congressional seat of the Republican incumbent, Representative Phil English.

title: Kristen Morrow, Bradley Johnson
description: Kristen Rose Morrow, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Brian R. Morrow of Valhalla, N.Y., was married yesterday to Bradley Joseph Johnson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay S. Johnson of Woodbine, Md. The Rev. Thomas Collins performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Chapel of Our Lady of Good Counsel in White Plains.

title: Workshops On Tornadoes And Terrorism
description: After fatal shootings over the last school year in Oregon, Arkansas and other parts of the nation, the mantra among educational administrators is gun preparedness. The Federal Emergency Management Agency, noting the prevalence of gangs and other dangers in schools, has added a segment on violence to its multihazards training course, which teaches education staff techniques to evacuate and protect children in the event of an earthquake, high winds or, now, a gun-toting intruder or student.

title: In America; D'Amato's Ethical Vacuum
description: Four years ago he was a king-maker, anointing George Pataki as the G.O.P. candidate for Governor and joking that Betsy McCaughey Ross should make the Mayor of New York an offer he couldn't refuse.

title: Life After Home Schooling
description: They are pioneers, in a way: the first wave of the modern home-schooling movement, the first generation of children to be taught primarily by their parents.

title: The Impeachment Breather
description: Until a few days ago, the possible impeachment of President Clinton was the campaign issue of which few dared speak. Republicans have been afraid to be seen exploiting the subject. Democratic candidates did not want to be seen defending the President or even standing near him, except in a few party strongholds. Both parties seemed to believe that voters wanted a respite from the scandal. Now, however, Republicans have injected the issue into several races, and Democrats have responded with ads calling for Congress to move on. There is some logic to putting Mr. Clinton back on the agenda. The 106th Congress, after all, will have no more urgent priority than deciding his fate.

title: Clinton Backer on Judiciary Panel Is in Tight Race
description: Like President Clinton, Representative Melvin L. Watt is a graduate of the Yale Law School, and he ranks among the President's most steadfast defenders in Congress.

title: U.S. Lawyer A Champion Of Victims In Rwanda
description: It was the gruesome pictures of bodies and bones that caused Pierre-Richard Prosper to give up a comfortable lawyer's life in Los Angeles for the rigors of Rwanda, a war-ravaged country with unreliable electricity and water. Mr. Prosper, a New York-bred lawyer, said he wanted to ''make a difference,'' and he did.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LAUMONT, SOPHIE
description: LAUMONT-Sophie. Happy birthday. Thinking of you always. Sarah, Anna, Eric and Amy

title: Undercurrents Of London History
description: MANY cities have a buried river or two. London has 11. London lies in the lower part of the Thames valley, where the river is joined by another tributary every two or three miles.

title: Susan Kane, David Bloom
description: Susan Beth Kane and David Bloom are to be married today by Rabbi Moshe Samber at Studio 450, a loft space in New York.

title: Commercial Property / The Market; As Financing Pool Dries Up, Some See Opportunity
description: TRADITIONAL real-estate lenders, largely forced to the sidelines in recent years by Wall Street firms, are moving to take advantage of the virtual shutdown of the public market for commercial mortgage-backed securities. These lenders, which include banks and insurance companies, had been largely displaced by Wall Street concerns such as Lehman Brothers, Credit Suisse First Boston and Nomura Securities.

title: MaryAnn LaGreca, Peter Brumbaugh
description: MaryAnn Elizabeth LaGreca, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Angelo A. LaGreca of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Peter Coppock Brumbaugh, a son of Carol Sweeterman Shiff of Westport, Conn., and Fred Brumbaugh of Dayton, Ohio. Msgr. Edward M. Connors performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Church in Scarsdale.

title: Pinochet: New Round of Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Voices of Experience; Dodging Cliches
description: As a member of a family that loved and honored its elders, I have long rebelled against the term ''aging.'' When I was 6 or 7, my great-great-aunts were playmates I called by their first names, Mamie and Betty. I see my parents as forever young, though my mother died at 74 and my father at 94.

title: Silence, S.V.P.
description: To the Editor: My wife and I recently spent three marvelous days in the very pleasant town of Pau, capital of the Bearn region of France in the Pyrenees, birthplace of Henry IV. The antique stores have a sophisticated eye and excellent taste, the people are very helpful to outsiders, and the hotels and restaurants were superb. There are many features dating from medieval times.

title: TV APPEALS GROW FRANTIC AS THE END OF CAMPAIGN NEARS
description: A midterm election in search of a moral drove toward a close today in a final, frantic round of television advertisements, get-out-the-vote efforts and coast-to-coast partisan bickering over everything from President Clinton's character to health care and the safety of Social Security for his baby-boom generation.

title: A Troubled Place, But It Was Theirs; Fear and Boredom for Residents Evacuated From Nursing Home
description: The pleasures of their lives were admittedly simple -- baking peanut butter cookies, growing tiny plants in window boxes, making the occasional trip to the mall. Others were no longer able to bake or even read, and contented themselves in wheelchairs on the boardwalk.

title: Tough Odds As Casinos Multiply
description: MARK GREENBERG, portfolio manager of the Invesco Leisure fund, stayed at the new Bellagio Hotel in Las Vegas last week, while attending the Salomon Smith Barney Leisure Conference. Widely considered the city's most luxurious and spectacular resort, the Bellagio boasts Picasso paintings on its walls, Italian marble on its floors and a man-made lake with 1,200 fountain spouts on its grounds.

title: Lives; Foreign Relations
description: 'It's Mummy here. How are you, sweetheart?'' The static on the answering machine told me that the call was from far away and that those more-clipped-than-the-English tones belonged to Usha, my future mother-in-law. After a longish pause, she added, ''How's Amy?'' We had never met or talked except for one brief, circumspect phone conversation.

title: The Funniest Italian You've Probably Never Heard Of
description: Roberto Benigni is indeed one of the funniest men on earth. Surely others must have roared, as I did, over his role as a mildly manic cab driver, confessing his turgid sexual sins to his rider, an ailing priest. It was a highlight of his film ''Night on Earth.''

title: Parador Visits
description: To the Editor: Robert Packard's article ''Paradores on the Plain'' (Sept. 20) provided excellent descriptions of five 15th- and 16th-century castles and towns within driving distance of Madrid. Reservations for the 85 pa radores throughout Spain can be made in this country through three companies -- the two mentioned in the article, plus P.T.B. Hotels, a division of Petrabax, of which I am president. P.T.B. is at 19710 Ventura Boulevard, Woodland Hills, Calif. 91304; (800) 634-1188.

title: To Train, So We Will Never See/A Poor Job Pruning of a Tree
description: ''WE don't yell 'Timber!' '' Gary Lovallo said. '' 'Timber!' is a forester's term. Here in New Jersey we yell 'Headache!' or 'Heads up!' Those are arborists' terms.''

title: The Value of Values
description: ''Values'' is a word that is particularly loaded these days. The President and his apologists parse the definition of sex to a faretheewell, while William Bennett and his fellow moralizers say Mr. Clinton and his ilk are what's wrong with America today. Along comes a book by Bill Bradley. On the cover the word ''VALUES'' is about three times larger than the rest of the title, ''of the Game.'' These are values the former Democratic Senator from New Jersey learned in his basketball career with Princeton and the Knicks: discipline, selflessness, respect, courage, leadership. You know, values. No mention of marital fidelity or truthfulness, though there is a chapter on passion. There is a also a chapter on responsibility, but it's about an athlete's responsibility to keep himself in top condition. The handsome book, loaded with photos, is a pleasant enough respite from talk about sex, lies and videotape. Mr. Bradley is appearing at a bookstore near you (he was in New Jersey at a signing in Ridgewood late last month) and on radio and television, talking about values. The last stop of the tour, not surprisingly, is Washington.

title: October 25-31; Blame for Both Sides In South Africa
description: Wrapping up more than two years of hearings into apartheid-era atrocities, South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission unveiled 3,500 pages of its final report, finding that the overwhelming blame for human rights abuses lay with the former white supremacist Government.

title: Mayfield Heights Journal; As the Suburbs Crept Out, He Dug In
description: Even though Joseph Tomaro is the last, defiant holdout in a rural neighborhood gone urban, he enjoys the serendipitous camaraderie that commercialism brings his way. He knows the names of the office workers who walk by his house and swaps news with the merchants down the street.

title: Robin Cohen, Kenneth Fischer
description: Robin Lynn Cohen, a lawyer, and Kenneth Lee Fischer, a special-effects photographer and computer-graphics animator, were married last evening by Cantor Elliot Levine at the 200 Fifth Club in New York.

title: Sounding Off on Sex Clubs; Sex Law Carries Perils For Other Merchants
description: To the Editor:

title: In New Canaan, Fresh Start, Fresh Menu
description: THE little house on Cherry Street in New Canaan -- recently Bogey's, then Mulligan's -- is now home to Logan's Restaurant. And it appears that the house has finally found a winner. The dining room has been lightened and whitened, the menu is innovative and fresh.

title: Casualties of War
description: A mute, amnesiac British solider is the focal point of a mystery and a romantic triangle that define the tragic parameters of THE UNKNOWN SOLDIER, a two-part drama on MASTERPIECE THEATER based on actual cases of thousands of World War I soldiers suffering from memory loss whose identifies could not be established.

title: New Party Is Courting Liberal Constituencies
description: It was an unseasonably warm fall Saturday, but Imani Webb had donned her Teflon coat. Impervious to indifference, ignorance and outright hostility, she was spreading the word in the Ingersoll Houses, a public housing project in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, about an unlikely road to salvation.

title: Sure, Banks Are Lending, But Will They Keep It Up?
description: AS everyone surely knows by now, the global financial crisis has frightened lenders, making them very reluctant to buy corporate America's I.O.U.'s. Unless a company is among the elite -- an I.B.M. or a General Electric or an AT&T -- borrowing money has become an ordeal.

title: Weekend Of Work To Decide A Dream
description: It was an appropriately cold and drizzly weekend last month for 30 would-be round-the-world sailors meeting on Thompson Island, Mass., a 157-acre preserve in Boston Harbor. The gathering was no picnic. Far from it.

title: A Drug Company's Promise
description: To the Editor:

title: Bergen Museum Cuts Hours And Plans to Move
description: Eric David Laxman's sandstone sculptures of human hands suspended on steel rods are among several works by New Jersey artists installed just two weeks ago at the Bergen Museum of Art and Science. But viewing hours have been cut back since then, to Friday, Saturday and Sunday, and within a month or so, trustees said last week, the museum will close completely while it moves from a rent-free space in a county-owned building in Paramus to an undecided location.

title: Steady and Waiting for the Fed
description: After a month of wide movements, mortgage rates settled down last week. While rates at individual banks in specific markets still showed volatility, a survey of 200 lenders by Bank Rate Monitor, the tracking service in North Palm Beach, Fla., found that the average 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage rose just 0.01 percentage point, to 6.79 percent.

title: Brushwork With a Certain Fine Madness
description: CAROL RAMA's remarkable paintings were last seen here in 1996, in ''Inside the Visible,'' a sprawling group show of 36 female artists. Featuring such subject matter as masturbation and bestiality, Ms. Rama's small, delicate watercolors from the 1930's and 1940's were displayed in quaint, old-fashioned frames.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICK, ROSE
description: GLICK-Rose. The board and staff of the Jewish Association for Services for the Aged note with sorrow the passing of the inspiring mother of Carl Glick, Chairman Emeritus and esteemed leader of the JASA Board for more than two decades. We extend our deepest sympathy to Carl, to his sister Rita Moskowitz, and to their children and grandchildren. Marilyn Friedman, President Steven M. Jacobson, Chairman David J. Stern, Exec. VP

title: Going Down Screaming
description: As Sullivan notes, Ronald Reagan's vision of America was a joyous, hopeful one to which all Americans were invited. But the current crop of neo-conservative scolds have reduced that celebratory panorama to a gloomy test of orthodoxy, from which all who deviate are excluded.

title: Mask or No, Life's a Ball
description: Celebrating Halloween, Jackson Pollock, Kofi Annan and community service.

title: WHEN ABUSE WEARS BLUE: A special report.; New York Police Lag in Fighting Domestic Violence by Officers
description: In the fall of 1995, Officer Anthony Nieves was accused of two offenses that could hardly have been more different.

title: Hamed Retains His Title And Moves
description: Prince Naseem Hamed came here to the Atlantic City Convention Center to wow the crowd. He wanted to do it in spectacular fashion with one of his patented knockouts, but Wayne McCullough's heart, head and pride would not oblige. He would not be the straight man for the Prince's vaudeville act.

title: A New Chelsea and the Evanescence of Chic
description: THE other day, an artist who will remain nameless for obvious reasons told me she was worried about her forthcoming show, not because the work was causing her more than the usual anxiety but because her gallery happens not to be in Chelsea.

title: Ideas & Trends; The Littlest Astronaut
description: They may be the first septuagenarian action figures ever. As John Glenn prepared to be catapulted into space aboard the Discovery shuttle last week, miniature John Glenns began landing on toy-store shelves.

title: CUNY Names President Of New York City Tech
description: The City University of New York has named Fred W. Beaufait, a former dean of engineering at Wayne State University in Detroit, as the new president of New York City Technical College in Brooklyn.

title: The Last Picture Show: Regency Will Close Its Curtains
description: Uptown and down, the city used to be full of them: movie theaters specializing in revivals. In their heyday, the 1970's and 1980's, few were more beloved than the Regency, on Broadway near 65th Street.

title: 2 Teachers Tear Down the Wall
description: Allen Milford is extra protective of his son Steven, who has Down's syndrome, so he was hesitant to place him in a class with mainstream students. But when the teachers knocked the walls down, he didn't have much of a choice.

title: No Winners In N.B.A. Dispute
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Minnesota's North
description: To the Editor: We-noh-nah owners around the world cringed as Daisann McLane wrote ''dragged my canoe ashore over rocks.'' Kevlar canoes are extremely light and easily carried over rocks or anything that would otherwise puncture or damage their strong but vulnerable exterior.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Not One of the Boys
description: Scholars have had a difficult time reconstructing the life and career of the painter Mary Cassatt, an American expatriate who settled in Paris in 1874 and showed her work with the inner circle of the French Impressionists throughout that decade. Not only was the genteel, Pittsburgh-born Cassatt intensely private (she did not keep a diary and destroyed most of her letters), but she was routinely neglected by the fiercely nationalistic French art press, who belittled her as a foreigner and an unmarried woman. She was also undervalued at home by a still tradition-bound art audience, who did not appreciate her unconventional use of color and asymmetrical compositions until late in her career. Cassatt's access to fresh experience was similarly restricted by her sex and class. Unlike her male contemporaries, who could paint scenes from the Parisian dance halls and brothels, Cassatt's subject matter was confined to that which befitted her lofty upper-middle-class station: mothers and children, and women in domestic settings. Despite these impediments, argues Judith A. Barter, curator of American arts at the Art Institute of Chicago in MARY CASSATT: Modern Woman (Art Institute of Chicago/Abrams, $65), Cassatt managed to present an image of women that reflected their growing self-sufficiency and responsibilities. Cassatt's friendship with her mentor, Edgar Degas, her innovations in work with pastels and her critical role as art adviser to the Havemeyers, the wealthy American benefactors of the Metropolitan Museum, are also examined. This book, while by no means revolutionary, expands upon what has been a limited, sentimentalized view of Cassatt. Andrea Barnet

title: Secretary of the Treasury Selects New Jersey's Quarter
description: Treasury Secretary Treasury Robert Rubin has selected Emanuel Leutze's classic painting of George Washington standing in a boat crossing the Delaware River to be imprinted on the back of 700 million quarters that will be minted this summer to commemorate New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAILEY, ESTHER
description: BAILEY-Esther. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Esther Bailey, beloved mother of Morris Bailey, a generous supporter and dedicated leader who is past chair of our Syrian Sephardic Campaign, and founding president of the Sephardic Community Center, a UJAFederation beneficiary. May your family be comforted among the mourners of Zion in Jerusalem. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: In the Eyes Of the Beholder
description: RECENTLY I took a splendid trip to a mirage. This is how I think of it: a place so beautiful or so improbable or so far exceeding the limits of reasonable expectation that, 10 minutes after you've left it, you cannot believe that you saw what you saw. That's what I call a mirage.

title: A Regional Favorite Gains Prominence
description: QUICK, name the most often performed full-length American opera. It's not ''Porgy and Bess,'' which was banished from the opera house for decades and branded a highbrow musical. It's not ''West Side Story,'' which was intended for Broadway despite the fact that Bernstein, late in life, gave it some operatic trappings. And it's not ''Amahl and the Night Visitors,'' which, since it was commissioned by a television network, could not run longer than an hour.

title: Going Down Screaming
description: Why didn't Sullivan note that William Kristol, in 1996, spoke positively of Colin Powell, a pro-choice moderate, as a prospective Republican Presidential nominee? Why no mention of opinion polls, in which the coarsening of our culture shows up as one of the most persistent concerns? And what of the societal consequences of the data showing increased drug use among the country's youngest cohort?

title: Bitter Harvest
description: WITH THESE HANDS

title: Kristin Kelley, Barry Lax
description: Kristin Jane Kelley, the daughter of Kathleen M. Corrigan of Southport, Conn., and Brian H. Kelley of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Barry Richard Lax, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lax of Englewood, N.J. Rabbi Roger Ross officiated at a nondenominational ceremony at Le Chateau, a restaurant in South Salem, N.Y.

title: Hazardous Waste
description: The County Board of Legislators recently passed Westchester's latest Hazardous Waste Point of Sale Notification Law, the first of its kind in the state.

title: Whispering Pines: (800) 836-4662
