description: Preface: Nostalgic rusticana life-style catalogue started six years ago by Mickey Kelly and Susan Panian, sisters who live in Connecticut. The family-run operation (children and cousins model; Ms. Panian's husband, Ed, is the art director), sells folksy wares for the upscale cabin dweller -- and those who want to look like one.

title: Juris Cojones
description: Trial lawyers have always been taunted as the pit bulls of the legal world, but now they can plead that their pugnaciousness is determined by body chemistry. In a study published earlier this year, James M. Dabbs Jr., a psychology professor at Georgia State University, found that trial lawyers have higher testosterone levels than their counterparts who toil outside the courtroom. This difference held true for groups of both male and female attorneys who provided saliva samples for hormone testing.

title: Dealing With Termite Infestation
description: TERMITES are voracious insects that can literally eat a person out of house and home. Sometimes termite activity is apparent when it appears as mud tubes on walls. Often, however, the infestation goes undetected until the homeowner discovers serious damage in wooden studs, beams and joists. That's why it is important to have a termite inspection conducted every year by an experienced pest control technician.

title: Rusty Reynolds and Teri Furr
description: Teressa Lee Furr and Langdon Bentley Reynolds, actors in New York, are to be married this afternoon by the Rev. Thomas H. Schmid at the Mechanicsburg (Pa.) Presbyterian Church.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PASNER, FANNIE SCHMIDT
description: PASNER-Fannie Schmidt. October 30, 1948. Memories of 50 years fade but my love for you remains everlasting. Your surviving daughter. Mathilde Christatos

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALBERT, PAULINE
description: HALBERT-Pauline. Beloved wife of the late David and beloved mother of Michael. Funeral service Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, NY, today at 9 AM. Interment at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Francis X. Larkin, 71, President of Fieldcrest Mills
description: Francis X. Larkin, who built a career in home furnishings and helped lead Fieldcrest Mills Inc., a maker of home-furnishing textiles based in Eden, N.C., died last Monday at Brick Memorial Hospital in Brick, N.J. He was 71.

title: Robert Bly's Weekends
description: To the Editor:

title: October 25-31; AIDS Virus Resurges When Drugs Are Cut Back
description: Scientists announced bad news for people infected with the AIDS virus who had hoped to escape the drug ''cocktail,'' a prescription of 20 to 30 pills a day that can cost $15,000 a year and that is causing unusual and dangerous side effects in more and more patients.

title: At Prisons, Are Fences the Best Neighbors?
description: For years, some residents in Maurice River Township have felt secure enough to leave their cars unlocked, an unusual phenomenon in a place where there are two state prisons.

title: An Election, Yes, But Congressional Races, Not Really; Challenger Making Money an Issue
description: IT bothers Congressman Forbes that his Democratic opponent, Mr. Holst, a Suffolk County legislator, is bringing up contributions Mr. Forbes received from tobacco companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASON, JUNE
description: MASON-June. (nee Lockman). On Saturday, October 24, 1998, in Boynton Beach, FL. Beloved wife of Leon. Loving mother of Steven, Roger and Daniel; cherished sister of Ned, Richard, and the late Samuel. Adoring grandmother of six grandchildren. Interment was on October 26, 1998, Boynton Beach, FL. Contributions may be made to UJA or American Cancer Society.

title: For REIT's, a Future According to Darwin
description: SINCE the mid-90's, Wall Street has had two main ways to invest in real estate: mortgage-backed securities for big institutional investors and real estate investment trusts for retail investors. Now, the mortgage-backed market is paralyzed, as is much of the world of bond investing. What about REIT's?

title: Sports of The Times; Zawoluk, Onetime Prince of the City, Comes Back to a Campus
description: WHEN the weather was good, Bob Zawoluk would leave his rented room and exercise his aging athlete's body. He had lived all over New York in his turbulent life -- had even spent two years ''upstate,'' as the euphemism goes -- and now he was in the Bronx, strange territory.

title: Not Always a Clown, Schickele Shows a Serious Side
description: ON a sunny Sunday afternoon last month in Montclair, N.J., an affluent suburb of New York, a capacity crowd packed a high school auditorium for what looked to be a mixed bag of chamber music: very serious string quartets by Beethoven and Brahms, and a piano quintet by Peter Schickele, a k a Prof. Peter Schickele, the musical satirist and ''discoverer'' of the abominable music of P. D. Q. Bach, the ''last and least'' of the sons of J. S. Bach.

title: Subtext of Clinton's Fate Dwarfs Election Issues
description: The candidates may be waging their final campaign appeals over education, Social Security and tax cuts. But the ultimate stake in Tuesday's midterm election is the issue most Congressional candidates have been trying not to mention: the fate of President Clinton in the face of threatened impeachment.

title: Perhaps Nassau's Oldest House, if Saved
description: LOCAL preservationists are scrambling to save one of the oldest houses in Nassau County from demolition by its new owner.

title: Fall Colors: Why Look Past Your Backyard?
description: THE ferry from Connecticut was packed last Sunday evening. Exhausted families lay slumped all over the boat. It was well past the summer touring season, but not yet Thanksgiving or ski resort time. The ferry should have been empty, and these families should have been in their suburban homes, watching TV.

title: In the Offing: Where to Place A Bet on a Post-Embargo Cuba
description: A play on Cuba? Sure. Thomas J. Herzfeld, an investment adviser in Miami, plans to offer a closed-end Cuba fund that would invest primarily in companies permitted to do business there. If the trade embargo against Cuba is lifted, the fund will also invest directly in Cuban businesses, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Great Neck Estates, L.I.; Elegance With a Protected Tranquillity
description: HALF the roads in Great Neck Estates are laid out to resemble an English garden, gently curving and lined with gnarled old trees. And landscaped islands help to create a relaxing maze of streets that never seem to end.

title: Victor? Villain? Victim? Microsoft on Trial
description: The epic courtroom battle between the Justice Department and Microsoft has now ground through eight days in court, and the defense's strategy seems to take new twists daily.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: DAVE BARRY TURNS 50 By Dave Barry. Crown, $22.

title: In Newark, Exotica From Cultures Far Away and Closer to Home
description: 'Cuba: Ambos Mundos'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANZIG, MAX
description: DANZIG-Max. Age 98, on October 31, 1998. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Loving husband of the late Edith Danzig. Devoted father of Dorothy Danzig Masch and the late Judith Danzig. Much loved grandfather of Julia, Jason and Rachel Masch. A kind and caring leader in his community, and a true gentleman. His ready smile, infectious laugh and melodic voice will be greatly missed. Funeral service November 1, 1998, 11 AM, at Hellman's Memorial Chapels, 15 State St., Spring Valley, NY.

title: October 25-31; Piazza Sets the Bar At $91 Million
description: Is Mike Piazza worth $91 million? The Mets fervently hope so. They signed the catcher to a seven-year contract that made him the highest-paid baseball player ever -- for now. ''When you're not successful here, it's tough,'' the former Dodger said. ''But when you win here, it's twice as good as anyplace.''

title: Going Down Screaming
description: Sullivan's article is a thinly disguised attack on pluralism and true diversity. If Sullivan had his way, conservatives would agree with liberals on the major social issues like abortion, homosexuality, condom distribution, school prayer and gun control. What exactly would be the point of having a free society and a Democratic government when all the political parties, think tanks and publications have only minor disagreements? Sullivan's article represents another attempt by the left to control the debate it has been losing.

title: The Future Isn't What It Was
description: IT was a moment of national nostalgia. Cynicism was put on hold for the five minutes it took the spacecraft to vanish from our television screens. We prayed as we watched CNN last Thursday, remembering the last time so many took such interest in a NASA launch. This one, thank heaven, seemed to work.

title: Culture Zone; Black to The Future
description: I've been reading fantasy and science fiction since I was a child. From '' Winnie-the-Pooh'' to ''Tom Swift and his Jetmarine''; from Marvel Comics to Ray Bradbury to Gabriel Garcia Marquez. Any book that offers an alternative account for the way things are catches my attention -- at least for a few chapters. This is because I believe that the world we live in is so much larger, has so many more possibilities, than our simple sciences describe.

title: Baltimore Rail
description: To the Editor: ''London: A New Train to the Plane is a Traveler's Dream'' (Sept. 13) prompts me to write of sampling Baltimore's light rail system from and to Baltimore-Washington International Airport.

title: Name That Grad
description: They've won Nobel Prizes, Pulitzer Prizes, Oscars, Tonys and countless other awards -- and they got their start in New York City's public schools. Test your knowledge of some of the distinguished alumni of the nation's largest school system, which is celebrating its 100th anniversary this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'MALLEY, WILLIAM
description: O'MALLEY-William. The Board of Directors and the Board of Governors of the Whitehall Tenants Corp extends its deepest sympathies on the passing of William O'Malley and its gratitude and appreciation for the many years of service Bill gave to the Whitehall. Sincere condolences are sent to Connie and the O'Malley family. Horace Bullard, President Ludwig Bravmann, Vice President

title: Renting Cars in Europe: How to Pay Less
description: Travelers to Europe with uncertain itineraries may benefit from Kemwel Holiday Autos' new Carpass, a three-day voucher that circumvents the high cost of renting cars locally.

title: Poetic Power, Reverence for Reason
description: HISTORIANS of all stripes find in the fusion of Bertolt Brecht and Galileo Galilei -- in Brecht's ''Galileo,'' written in 1938 -- what in 1959 Kenneth Tynan called ''an incomparable theatrical statement of the social responsibilities of the intellectual.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXLER, HARRY
description: WEXLER-Harry. Beloved husband of Renee. Devoted father of Gary and Rhonda. Dear father-inlaw of Philip Karlin. Adored grandfather of Jonah Karlin. Services Monday, 12 noon, ''Schwartz Bros.Jeffer Memorial Chapel,'' Queens Blvd. and 76th Rd., Forest Hills.

title: A New Chef at Equus in Tarrytown
description: THEY say that a man's house is his castle. In the case of Gen. Howard Carroll, the son of a Civil War general, this castle happened to be his home. The general clearly had a taste for the grand; a crenelated tower alone rises 75 feet. But sandwiched among the magnificent Hudson Valley homes of the time -- Glenview, Kykuit, Lyndhurst -- Carrollcliffe, as the general's home was originally called, might simply have been the Carrolls way of keeping up with the Trevors, Rockefellers and Goulds.

title: A Manhole Not Fit for Men
description: Neighbors of Riverside Park between 78th and 79th Streets say they have a monster in their backyard. Just feet from a temporary dog run and a playground, a rusted manhole cover regularly pops up and discharges fetid liquid and debris into a small patch of weeds.

title: Political Briefing; Shy About Ambition Gov. Thompson Isn't
description: Every so often, Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin comes right out and says it. No subtlety. No beating around the bush.

title: Rabbit Punch
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Stylish Suggestions for the East River
description: AN exhibition of more than 50 entries from an international design competition to envision the future of the East River will open at the Van Alen Institute on Friday.

title: Ideas & Trends; Energy Addicted in America
description: IT was during the oil embargo era of the 1970's that Patricia Nelson Limerick, who is now a leading historian of the American West, announced to her students at Yale that Americans' outlook and behavior had gone through a momentous change. No more vistas of limitless resources. No more endlessly rising consumption. The Era of Scarcity had begun.

title: Catherine Park, Wilder Fulford
description: Catherine Mikyung Park and Dr. Wilder Dwight Fulford were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. Walter F. Modrys performed the ceremony.

title: Bad Dude at Black Rock
description: Wall Street is ever searching for corporate executives upon whom it can pin hopes of miraculous jumps in stock prices. Back in 1996, for example, before Al Dunlap was unmasked as a mere pretender to the title of corporate turnaround king, investors bid up shares of the Sunbeam Corporation on news that Mr. Dunlap was riding to its rescue.

title: Package Deal For College
description: In these boom times, with part-time jobs going begging in the service economy, college students can afford to be picky. That's why United Parcel Service in Louisville, Ky., the company's busiest package-processing hub, began its own version of the G.I. Bill this fall: free tuition at three local colleges -- the University of Louisville, Jefferson Community College and Jefferson Technical College -- in exchange for a semester-by-semester commitment to work 20 hours a week on U.P.S.'s most-difficult-to-fill shift: midnight to 3 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WYDEN, PETER
description: WYDEN-Peter. A memorial service to celebrate the life of Peter Wyden will be held at 11 AM, Monday, November 9, in the auditorium of the Graduate Center of City University, 33 W. 42 St., NYC. He is much loved and greatly missed.

title: With a New Western Arrival, Moscow Rocks
description: IS Russia ready for ''Beavis and Butt-head''? The Government may be in turmoil, the economy falling faster than last week's music video on the charts, but want it or not, Russians now have their MTV, and two of the most obnoxious, sex-obsessed teen-agers on American television to go with it.

title: Memory and Invention
description: Not long after my book ''Sir Vidia's Shadow'' was sent to the printer I was fossicking among some papers and found an old notebook labeled ''Diary,'' with a date and a sort of title, ''When I Was Off My Head.'' This was an unexpected discovery because, except for some letters and a few notes, I had depended on memory alone for my book.

title: ART REVIEWS; Stories Told From Many Points of View
description: 'Magnum Cinema'Sag Harbor Picture Gallery, 66 Main Street, Sag Harbor. Through Nov. 9.725-3100.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Music of Silent Films

title: Permutations of Love, Devised by I. B. Singer
description: LOVE is strange, and ''Meshu gah'' is a strange and crazy -- love story

title: October 25-31; Yeltsin Skips Summit, Heads for Sanatorium
description: Nearly three weeks ago, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia got bronchitis in Uzbekistan. He rushed home to rest up for a summit in Vienna with the head of the European Union.

title: A Day of Uncertainties Finds Singh Still Ahead
description: It was another unusual day at the Tour Championship, the kind when nobody knew what would happen next.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HINRICHS, MARION MCDONALD
description: HINRICHS-Marion McDonald. 87, of Greenwich, CT and Quogue, NY died peacefully at her home in Greenwich on October 29, 1998. Mrs. Hinrichs was born in Evanston, IL in 1911. She was a graduate of Wellesley College, and had been an active volunteer at Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, NY, the American Heart Association and Wellesley College. She was preceded in death by her husband Hans Hayo Hinrichs. She is survived by her son, Richard Dimes Buckley and his wife, Connie of Greenwich, CT; a daughter, Martha Ann Fahnoe and her husband, Norman of Camarillo, CA; two granddaughters, Jennifer Buckley of Greenwich, Patricia Jay of San Mateo, CA, and a grandson, Eric Dimes Fahnoe of Anaheim Hills, CA. A memorial service will be held at the Gallagher Funeral Home, 31 Arch St., Greenwich, Tuesday, November 2 at 10 AM. Burial will be private in Quogue, NY. In lieu of flowers, it is suggested that memorial contributions be made to the Greenwich American Red Cross Disaster Relief Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAMMEN, WILLIAM J.
description: MAMMEN-William J., Sr. Age 84, of Mt. Laurel, NJ (formerly of Massapequa, NY) on October 29, 1998. Cherished husband of the late Elizabeth (nee Carrington). Beloved father of the late William J., Jr.; Elizabeth Sheehan of Manhattan; Thomas C. of Clarksville, NY; Robert P. of Wynants Kill, NY; Julia Lund of Marlton, NJ and Ellen T. of Manhattan. Adored grandfather of seven. Reposing after 2 PM Sunday, November 1, 1998, Charles J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 603 Wantagh Ave. (exit 28N SS Pkwy), Wantagh. Funeral Mass Monday, 10:30 AM, Maria Regina R.C. Church, Seaford. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale. Family will receive friends on Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: At the Opera, Words to Laugh By
description: WORDS, words, words: opera finds it hard to do without them. In the 1950's, the German composer Boris Blacher wrote a wordless ''abstract opera,'' to which he gave the imposing title ''Abstract Opera No. 1,'' though he never repeated the experiment. He left that to Gyorgy Ligeti, who in the next decade wrote ''Adventures,'' followed by ''New Adventures,'' for three singers who communicate with one another and with their audience by nonverbal means: muttering, cajoling, shrieking in surprise. And in the decade after that, Philip Glass, in ''Einstein on the Beach,'' and Karlheinz Stock hausen, in ''Thursday,'' dispensed for long stretches not only with words but also with onstage singers, to create opera as mime.

title: Giants Are Finding a Return to Swagger
description: The swagger went out of the Giants' defense on Aug. 20 in a very public moment of vulnerability.

title: Postings: Council of Co-ops Workshops; Local Law 11 On the Agenda
description: Experts will decipher the ins and outs of the city's tightened requirements for facade inspections to detect loose masonry under the new Local Law 11 in ''Local Law 10 Goes 360 Degrees,'' one of 62 workshops being offered on Nov. 15 by the Council of New York Cooperatives at its 18th Annual Cooperative Housing Conference. ''It adds to the budget, it adds responsibilities and we want our New York co-ops and condos to be alert,'' said Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the group, which serves a membership of 2,032 co-ops and condominiums.

title: Editorial Observer; When a New York Tough Guy Feels Fear, He's Got to Strike Out
description: If there is a definition of political panic, it's Senator Alfonse D'Amato running ads attacking an opponent for ethics violations. At a time in the election cycle when most candidates are reverting to warm and fuzzy pictures of their families, Mr. D'Amato has decided to bring up an 18-year-old charge that his opponent, Representative Charles Schumer, once put members of his Assembly staff to work on his first Congressional campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHWALD, MARSHALL
description: BUCHWALD-Marshall. Formerly of NYC. Devoted father of Daniel, Seth, Richard and Dina. Dear brother of Bernard. Dear brotherin-law of Evelyn. Loving grandfather of six grandchildren. Services ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engle St., Englewood, NJ, on Sunday at 9:30 AM. For information: 800-322-0533.

title: Fly on the Wall
description: ''See the Girl! Amazing! Teensy.'' A circus come-on? No, just an accurate description of 17-year-old Katie Brown (pictured), one of the world's best competition rock climbers and -- at five feet tall and only 85 pounds -- a sort of human mosquito. Brown, who will participate in a national competition later this month on a fake rock face at Manhattan's Chelsea Piers sports complex, may well represent the physique of the future in a sport that has grown in popularity over the last decade -- a sport that, like gymnastics, is so difficult and precise it favors litheness and lightness over bulging muscle. Here's a look at what makes a young champion today.

title: King Hussein Ails. His Brother Waits.
description: When King Hussein of Jordan appeared at the White House to place his personal seal on the Palestinian-Israeli agreement last week, it was a moment of pathos and pride for many of his distant people: his presence magnified his prestige as a peacemaker; his appearance, made spectral by chemotherapy, drove home to many for the first time just how severely cancer has stricken him.

title: Corrections
description: The table of contents on Oct. 18 omitted a credit for interviews with eight athletes -- Tony Gwynn, Cynthia Cooper, Tim Green, Shane Gunderson, Brett Hull, Doc Rivers, Lindsay Davenport and Jerome Bettis -- whose lengthy quotations appeared throughout the issue. The interviews were conducted by Chuck Salter.

title: Kiev Camerata Joins Recital Schedule at Yale
description: BETWEEN faculty and student concerts, it is generally a busy week at Yale, but this afternoon at 3, the university is also host to the 32 players of the Kiev Camerata at Sprague Memorial Hall. Virko Baley will conduct, and the pianist Mykola Suk plays the Fourth Beethoven Concerto. The program also includes Prokofiev's ''Classical'' Symphony, Schoenberg's ''Transfigured Night'' and the Concerto-Triptych for Strings by Ivan Karabyts.

title: Pinochet: New Round of Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: An Arsenal of Education?
description: Each weekday morning Isabel Colon walks past the Kingsbridge Armory, a hulking, brick fortress. Largely vacant, the medieval-looking Romanesque landmark, among is caked in spray paint and has fallen into disrepair.

title: Food; The Wild Bunch
description: The first time i tasted a wild mushroom, I understood the flavor of fear and how, when you think you're about to die, you can slow down and parse complex sensations into a series of discrete and indelible impressions.

title: If There Is Drama, Jordan Is in Middle
description: At what moment the season had a decent chance of being salvaged, no one can be sure. But when word got out that a stretch black limousine parked outside a Manhattan law firm late Wednesday night was idling until 1 A.M. for Michael Jordan, any wild scenario seemed possible.

title: Leave It Alone
description: To the Editor

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLAUSNER, MILDRED
description: KLAUSNER-Mildred ''Mickey'', formerly of Jersey City, N.J. passed away 10/16 in Palm Beach, two weeks after her 97th birthday. Married to the late David Klausner who passed away in 1984, Mickey is survived by sons Robert and William; brothers Dr. Seymour Miller and Stanley Miller. She was a loving and devoted wife, mother, grandmother and great grandmother. Her family and friends will forever miss her very personal unique brand of wisdom and style. Services were held.

title: Take a Walk!
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Who's Running for Congress or, in Some Cases, Walking
description: In four of New Jersey's 13 Congressional districts, challengers are mounting campaigns strong enough to give the incumbents some sleepless nights, while the other nine incumbents seem to be walking toward victory on Tuesday.

title: Trailblazer in the Silicon Jungle
description: IN her first year at Stanford University's business school, Ann Livermore submitted the winning plan to manage the student snack bar. Soon she was persuading corporate recruiters to buy doughnuts from her to serve at presentations. The companies thought nothing of paying 50 cents for doughnuts that cost her a nickel.

title: Blueprint for the Sound
description: Save the Sound, a nonprofit environmental group with offices in Stamford and Glen Cove on Long Island, recently released ''The Conservation Blueprint: A Citizen's Guide for Habitat Restoration in and Around the Sound.'' The Blueprint is a comprehensive how-to manual for community groups, local governments and individuals interested in habitat-restoration projects, which is one of the major focuses of Federal and state plans for restoring Long Island Sound.

title: In South Africa, A Defining Moment
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RILEY, WILLIAM DAVID PETER
description: RILEY-William David Peter. Died suddenly on October 20, 1998. Devoted husband of Norma Bezrod Cooperman Riley. Impresario and business executive; Captain, United States Army.

title: Going Down Screaming
description: Sullivan highlighted the real tragedy of the Lewinsky affair for the American public. By behaving as he did, Clinton allowed the conservatives featured in Sullivan's article not only to seize the moral high ground, but also to move the debate back to the divisive areas they love so much. We will all suffer as a result.

title: It's Bottom of 9th for Ball Club
description: As the Yankees ask the city to build them a stadium, a predominantly black sandlot baseball organization is being forced out of its $900-a-month clubhouse and is scrambling for another cheap rental.

title: Lauren Skopov, Richard Koffler
description: Lauren Ilene Skopov, a daughter of Marc and Maxine Skopov of Orangeburg, N.Y., and Richard William Koffler, a son of Anne Koffler and Dr. Nicholas Koffler of Norwood, N.J., were married last evening in Rockleigh, N.J. Rabbi J. Rolando Matalon officiated at the Rockleigh Country Club.

title: Even When Furious, the Vikings Stay Focused on Winning
description: Dennis Green picked up a copy of The Minneapolis Star Tribune on Wednesday and couldn't believe what he was reading. Green's players saw the same article and were also infuriated. In the past, such strong emotions over something in the news media have distracted the team and hurt its play on the field.

title: Unquiet Journey
description: To the Editor: Nancy B. Finley writes (Letters, Sept. 20) of finding a passenger sleeping on the floor behind her seat on a Virgin Atlantic flight from Kennedy to Heathrow.

title: A Hedge Fund Puts Its Cards On the Table of Its Web Site
description: Not all hedge funds are hush-hush. Consider the tiny Loring Fund, with $1 million in assets, managed by Patrick O'Neill of Loring Investments in Minneapolis. The fund's strategy and holdings are disclosed on his Web site.

title: Monica Vitenson, Andrew Ostroy
description: Monica Felice Vitenson and Andrew Bennett Ostroy were married last evening at the TriBeCa Grill in Manhattan. Justice Karla T. Moskowitz of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: In a Compromise, Congress Revives Arms Panel
description: In a last-minute compromise, Congress has revived the independent commission charged with streamlining the efforts of 96 Federal agencies that deal with the threat of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons, as well as the means to deliver them.

title: Ms. Cooper, Mr. Dunleavy
description: Amy Cooper, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Cooper of Ardsley, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to Anthony Stephen Dunleavy, a son of Bridget Dunleavy of White Plains and John Dunleavy of Pelham, N.Y. Walter Schwartz, the Ardsley village justice, is to officiate at the Canyon Club in Armonk, N.Y.

title: A Wake-Up Call for Truants
description: Teachers can recite the excuses in their sleep: ''The bus broke down,'' ''I thought I was going to be sick ... but I guess I'm not!'' and the old standby: ''My alarm clock didn't work.''

title: What the Folkies Felt
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting Pain on Paper to Heal Their Hearts
description: TRUE confessions.

title: Correction
description: The Word for Word column and its headline last Sunday, with excerpts from a Web site praising activities of the ruling Taliban movement of Afghanistan, referred incompletely to the site's relationship to the Afghan Government. There is no connection, according to Taliban representatives in the United States, who say that the official Web site is www.taleban.com.

title: Prosecutors Bar Lewinsky From Talking To Reporters
description: After weeks of fruitless negotiations, aides to the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr recently told lawyers for Monica S. Lewinsky that she was not allowed to talk to any reporters about any aspects of the investigation of her relationship with President Clinton, lawyers and others involved in the inquiry said today.

title: The Apple Juice That's Certainly No Drink for Children
description: FOR 10 weeks each fall, when the leaves in Old Mystic turn pumpkin gold and cranberry red, the Miner family cranks up a century-old, steam-powered apple press -- thought to be the last of its kind in the United States -- to produce one of the nation's least-known but fastest-growing libations: hard cider.

title: Not for Sailors Only
description: WHEN the peacoat first appeared on the backs of mod Londoners in the early 1960's, it was an integral part of the biggest fashion revolution of the decade. Reaching only to mid-thigh, its brief shape was in keeping with what Vespa-riding Italians had ordained to be the new length for outerwear.

title: On the Early-Decision Bandwagon
description: The senior-year obsessing had the quality of timeless ritual as eight top students at Great Neck South High School gathered to discuss their college application plans one morning in September.

title: On 110th St., Heritage and a New Plan for Grandeur
description: When Bettijean Miller moved to Broadway and 159th Street from Arkansas in 1945, she often marveled at the canopied apartment buildings on 110th Street, bordering Central Park, from her bus seat.

title: The World; Israelis Get an Eerie Reminder That Words Do Kill
description: LIFE in Israel has the jangled energy of a bad traffic jam, and public debate is led by the guys who lean on their horns.

title: Hawaii
description: When leaf-peeping northeasterners begin retiring their binoculars for the year, Hawaii residents start dusting theirs off. November opens the unofficial season of rubbernecking, a time when migrating whales and big-wave riders turn the ocean into the site of the islands' favorite spectator sports.

title: Lots of People Take His Word for It
description: FOR more than two decades, Hal Friedman's advertising campaigns have led people to rinse with a certain mouthwash, choose a particular tomato sauce, stop at one kind of fast-food restaurant or put a certain brand of tire on the family car.

title: Stop, You're Killing Me
description: To the Editor:

title: A Printmaker's Preoccupation With the Order of Things
description: THE 1930's and 40's were such an active and fertile period in American printmaking that some of the most able artists are now but faces in the crowd. Though Armin Landeck is one of these, an exhibition at Connecticut Graphic Arts Center in Norwalk allows him to step forward.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-21

title: Malevolent Babies Busting Up Walls, Sharpening Darts
description: KIM DINGLE was 40 in 1991 when she burst upon the art scene here, a fully developed painter with a lithe touch and yeasty content. She painted George Washington sporting her mother's 1950's hairdo, a characteristically hunched Ed Sullivan wearing her own face as a young girl, a ham-fisted composition constructed of maps of the United States drawn from memory by real Las Vegas teen-agers.

title: Coach Shifts Course, Following His Halfback to Victory
description: Today at Rutgers Stadium, Jacki Crooks did not look like a man who should share playing time. With his legs churning, his hips shifting and his body spinning, Crooks displayed the skills of a featured runner, a 30-carries-per-game back.

title: Bringing Downtown to the Waterfront
description: TIMOTHY CHUANG shakes his head as he considers how different life might have been had he bought one of the rundown buildings on Main Street in Flushing, Queens, 20 years ago, when he first arrived in this country.

title: Broadway's 'Cats': Restaged for Eternity (And We Thought They Were Kidding!)
description: It was love at first sight-reading. ''I was in Andrew's home, back when I was still playing Evita,'' Elaine Paige recalled, ''and he pulled out this little box of tunes, and this was one of them. And I thought: 'Oh, it's fantastic. I want to sing this.' It did something to me. I thought it was the most glorious melody. So I feel in some respects I was fated to sing it.''

title: No Exit
description: Anne Frank

title: An Election, Yes, But Congressional Races, Not Really; Strong Incumbent And Realistic Foe
description: FOR years, Mr. King of Seaford had been talking about peace in Northern Ireland to anyone who would listen.

title: 'Swan Lake': A Jolt for the Needy
description: POOR Broadway. Of three recent arrivals, the one production to become a critical hit is not only in for a limited run, but also isn't really a Broadway show at all.

title: The Novel as Indictment
description: It is curious that the same issue in which Andrew Sullivan is allowed 10 pages for fear-mongering about the dangers of moral authoritarianism, Sarah Kerr fills three pages waxing rhapsodic over Barbara Kingsolver (Oct. 11).

title: The New American Consensus; Government of, by and For the Comfortable
description: The other day, while Washington was going up in flames, the two candidates for what is probably the most important office at stake in the 1998 elections, the governorship of California, held a debate in Sacramento. Gray Davis, the Democrat, is a veteran liberal politician whose fate it is to be known for the goodness of fit between his first name and his mien. Dan Lungren, the Republican, is a hearty, easy-talking guy whose reputation over the years has been as something close to a movement conservative. The debate, their third in a series of five, had a disorienting quality. The candidates had obviously decided in advance that they were going to ''go negative,'' so they tried to be mean, sarcastic and vicious toward each other.

title: The Folly of The Trolley's Demise
description: The dismantling of Connecticut's trolley lines may have been, in retrospect, one of the state's more shortsighted deeds. (''When Mass Transit Was an Amiable Beast,'' Oct. 18.) Ironically, I was one of the perpetrators of this folly although I was only a schoolboy at the time.

title: Marian Kuhn, Richard Browning
description: Marian Kuhn and Dr. Richard Emmett Browning were married yesterday in Salisbury, Conn. The Rev. Jesse Y. Bingham Jr. performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: Saturn's Long Wait For Some New Wheels
description: AT the Boston auto show on Friday, the Saturn Corporation pulled the wraps off a new model. While such an introduction is routine for most auto manufacturers, it is a rare occurrence for Saturn.

title: Lending Without a Net; With Wall Street as Its Banker, Real Estate Feels the World's Woes
description: THE stylized map of Manhattan's skyscrapers on the wall behind Andrew D. Stone's desk at Credit Suisse First Boston is peppered with tiny yellow dots, each representing a real estate deal in which he had a hand.

title: Directing More Dollars Toward Keeping Things Green
description: Market turmoil may be causing some companies to tighten their belts, but environmental spending appears to be escaping the cost-cutter's ax. A survey of corporate environmental managers found that American industrial companies planned to increase environmental spending next year by an average of 6 percent. The BTI Consulting Group, which does the survey annually, said it was the first time in seven years that industry planned to increase its environmental budget. BTI suggested that companies might feel they finally have other costs under control and are more comfortable budgeting for cleanup, and that many may be sprucing up properties and divisions that they hope to sell.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS

title: The View From/Ardsley; Students Find Parallels To Life in 'The Crucible'
description: THEY are much too young to remember the McCarthy hearings, but they are just the right age to understand the destructive power of innuendo, peer pressure and accusation. The students at Ardsley High School here are producing ''The Crucible,'' Arthur Miller's 1953 play about the Salem witchcraft trials and, as Election Day approaches, they said they see the show as relevant to things political and personal.

title: Pinochet: New Round of Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Following Guidelines When Hiring Nannies
description: BEFORE buying a car, savvy shoppers comb through stacks of ratings, keep track of every recall and study dealerships as if they were brokerage houses. But when hiring a nanny -- someone who has the run of their house and near total control over their children -- parents can do little more than close their eyes and hope for the best.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, GORDON
description: GRAHAM-Gordon. Peacefully on October 22, 1998 in Vero Beach, FL. He would have been 75 on Christmas Day. Devoted husband of Kirby Smith, loving father of Dianne Graham Kandiah, Jennifer Graham Haskell, and Gordon Jr. Proud grandfather of Olivia, Harrison and Ava. Dear uncle of Caroline, Vicary, Hilary and Christina. He was a retired communications executive and a graduate of Yale University, Class of 1945. He served in both WW II and Korea as a pilot in the US Marine Corps, attaining the rank of Captain. He was a member of the Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York, the New England Society in the City of New York, the Yale Club of New York City, the New York Athletic Club, Doubles, the City Island Yacht Club, Lawrence Beach Club in Atlantic Beach Long Island and the Riomar Bay Yacht Club in Vero Beach, Florida. He was a Trustee Emeritus of the Bar Harbor Music Festival. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, November 17, at 11AM at the City Church, New York in the Ethical Culture Building, 2 West 64 Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Yale Alumni Fund, Class of 1945, 265 Church Street, PO Box 1890, New Haven, CT. 06508.

title: Study Offers New Insight On Homeless
description: After following hundreds of homeless families in New York City to determine if social disorders prolonged their situation, a new study by New York University suggests the real problem is the city's scarcity of subsidized housing.

title: Going Down Screaming
description: Sullivan's elegant and far-reaching essay on the rise of a ''scolding, moralizing conservatism'' deserves a follow-up. He focuses on national politics and broad cultural issues. But the sort of public finger wagging that characterizes the current state of the moral right is arguably a more serious problem at the local level, where organized political activism can have a more tangible and immediate impact. The phenomenon of school boards dominated by religious conservatives, who use the authority of government to codify what other people's children may be permitted to learn in public classrooms, is perhaps the most obvious example.

title: PRIVATE SECTOR; The New A.T.M. Card Is in the Mail
description: Charles K. Gifford, chief executive of BankBoston, loves to escape to Nantucket, with its cobblestone streets and calm harbors. Or at least he used to. Lately, he has been getting an earful from the locals about the service they have been getting at the venerable Pacific National Bank since it was acquired by BankBoston late last year. A chastened Mr. Gifford apologized in an interview in Nantucket's Inquirer and Mirror newspaper in September, saying the acquisition ''didn't live up to my expectations.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGELMAN, RUTH
description: ENGELMAN-Ruth. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and sister. Services Monday, 1 P.M. at ''Parkside'' Chapel, 66th Ave and Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: Italian Food: Large Portions, Good Prices
description: SOME restaurants are chosen for this column because they are exciting new spots, others because they are established, well-thought-of places or have acquired a notable chef. Bella Notte was suggested by a reader from Hewlett who praised its ''great food at reasonable prices.''

title: To Russia, Without Love
description: THE LADIES FROM

title: Getting Tough on Teachers
description: Faculty members at Medgar Evers College in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, huddled one morning this semester in the education department's Africana Resource Center, a small conference room lined with stacks of multicultural books.

title: Mets Quickly Respond To a Push From the Bronx
description: For George Steinbrenner to say anything even remotely critical about the Mets' $91 million signing of Mike Piazza is disingenuous. The devil didn't make the Mets do it; George did.

title: Conductor Comes Home, Bearing a New Work
description: NEITHER Hugh Wolff, the music director of the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra, nor Michael Torke, the composer whose new piece opens the ensemble's New Jersey concerts next week, would bruit it about that they are on the brink of wider horizons. But these private hopes have already taken form in the minds of admirers, who are happy to blow their cover.

title: Alone With 'Alone,' Or What 'Is' Is
description: Safire says that ''small-breasted'' versus ''flat-chested,'' as indicated in the President's testimony, ''is both more anatomically accurate and less cruel and pejorative.''

title: The Funniest Italian You've Probably Never Heard Of
description: I really enjoyed Alessandra Stanley's portrait of Roberto Benigni (Oct. 11). Being Italian, I have had plenty of chances to see his comic genius, and I've seen most of his movies. With his latest one, ''La Vita Bella,'' he has tackled a difficult and painful subject with sensitivity and humor. Guido's love for his son and his playful effort to shield him from the horror of the concentration camp are at the core of the movie. The subject of the Holocaust is not treated lightly. It is a very powerful and poetic movie with many comic moments. I took my son to see it while we were in Italy on vacation. I urge parents of children 9 years old and over to see this movie.

title: Patricia Minniece, George Benington
description: Patricia Minniece was married yesterday to George Arthur Benington at St. John the Divine Episcopal Church in Houston. The Rev. Randall W. Trego performed the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOREIN, SARAH
description: KOREIN-Sarah. The Boys Town Jersualem family mourns the passing of Mrs. Sarah Korein, a respected philanthropist committed to the ideals of her sacred Jewish heritage. She accompanied her grandfather when he left Dresden to live a life of sanctity in Jerusalem. Though she left Israel 70 years ago to come to these shores, she remained imbued with the aspirations that the people of Israel would ultimately subscribe to the Torah ideals of her greatgranduncle, the sainted Rabbi Benzion Yadler. Mrs. Korein established a major scholarship endowment at Boys Town, providing disadvantaged Israeli youth with a Torah/Technology education. The achievements of Boys Town's 5000 graduates, role models of Torah im Derech Eretz, will serve as a living memorial to Mrs. Korein. Her good deeds will endure as an everlasting blessing. May her family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Josh S. Weston, Chairman Michael J. Scharf, President Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Rabbi Ronald L. Gray, Exec VP

title: Once Divisive, Immigration Now a Muted Issue
description: It is the weekend before the elections, and immigration, the source of much national angst in years past, has disappeared from the election debate, although not from lawmakers' political agendas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORMAN, LOUISE
description: FORMAN-Louise. Your loving friends of the E.W.P.F. are saddended by the loss of our loving Secretary, Louise Forman. Our condolences to Howard and the children. Beverly Weston, President Marcia Winikoff, Vice President

title: Building Boom at Institutes of Health
description: The National Institutes of Health used to feel like a bucolic college campus. Now it is a giant construction project, with cranes and bulldozers erecting new laboratories, a new research hospital and a new center for vaccine research.

title: Alanis Morissette Explores The Healing Power of Song
description: THE woman who sings Alanis Morissette's new album sounds like a mess. In the 17 songs on ''Supposed Former Infatuation Junkie'' (Maverick), which is to be released on Tuesday, she has been attached to abusive men, she has been stuffing and starving herself, she has taken too many antibiotics, and she has been working herself to the point of collapse. She has felt jealous, misunderstood, worthless; nothing, from shopping to sex to wealth and worldwide popularity, has made her happy. And every bit of trauma and frustration comes out in her voice: in its harried vibrato and sudden yelping breaks, in its banshee wails and caustic nasal turns. While her litany of self-doubt is set in the past tense, the wounds still sound raw.

title: Horse Racing; Silver Charm Is Star of His Own Fairy Tale
description: Skip Away, the heavyweight champion of race horses, was back home at Belmont Park in New York one week before the fight of the decade. But his chief challenger, Silver Charm, was reigning in Barn 33 here at Churchill Downs and his trainer, Bob Baffert, saw classic drama gathering under the twin spires of the grand old race track.

title: Bookstore-Restaurant With Imaginative Fare
description: WHY do you review some restaurants more than once is a question I am often asked. The answer is change. Restaurants that retain their names and remain in the same locations become different places by hiring new chefs, introducing innovative menus, altering their decor, offering all-inclusive set price meals, staging special events and expanding their hours. The Book Mark Cafe, at 1 East Main Street in Oyster Bay (922-0036), is just such a spot. Three years ago when I first reviewed it, dinner was offered on Friday and Saturday nights only. Now it is served six nights a week. The three-course, $19.95 Tuesday-through-Thursday prix fixe dinner did not exist then nor was the menu or wine list in the same class as it is now. At that time chefs and celebrities, like Julia Child, Andre Soltner, Ruth Reichl and Mary Higgins Clark, had never heard of the Book Mark Cafe. Now they beat a path there for book signings and special dinners (Lidia Bastianich of Felidia in Manhattan will appear on Nov. 11).

title: Going Down Screaming
description: Sullivan's thoughtful analysis and skillful writing were a relief in this atmosphere of mud-and-smut slinging. His perspective allowed me to step back and understand this current phenomenon, rather than just react to it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLEHER, M. EILEEN
description: KELLEHER-M. Eileen. 79. Of Norwich, CT. Beloved wife of the late Dr. James H. Kelleher. Died October 29, 1998 after a brief illness. Devoted mother of Michael of Chevy Chase, MD; Kathleen Belinga of Columbia, SC; Colleen Halloran of Dover, MA; Jane Sobolov of Goffstown, NH; Sara Ann Klemmer of Sherborn, MA; Mary Courtney Kelleher of Groton, CT. Loving ''Gam'' to 13 grandchildren. Also survived by her sister Jean Duffy of Norwich, CT. Mrs. Kelleher formerly of Brooklyn and Manhattan, NY, was the daughter of the late Francis V. and Mary Courtney Duffy. She is predeceased by her brothers Hugh V. and Francis P. Duffy. She was a graduate of Manhattanville College and Fordham University School of Social Services. The family will receive friends at the Cummings-Gagne Funeral Home, 82 Cliff Street, Norwich from 24PM on Sunday, November 1. A mass of Christian Burial will be on Monday, November 2 at 10AM at St. Patrick's Cathedral, 213 Broadway, Norwich. Interment will follow at St. Joseph's Cemetery in Norwich. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Association of Retarded Citizens of New London County, 1616 Route 12, P.O. Box 361, Gales Ferry, CT 06335, attn: Greg McMahon; or Easter Seals of Southeastern Connecticut, Norwich-New London Turnpike, Uncasville, CT 06382.

title: Correction
description: A report on Sept. 27 about the marriage of Lisa Michelle Miller and Deric Michael Angelettie, referred incorrectly to the occupation of the bridegroom's stepfather, Jeffrey Wallace. He operates an office-equipment repair service, and the business is in St. Albans, Queens, not in Brooklyn.

title: 25 Happy Years Spent in a Dark Room
description: IF an arts organization is known by the company it keeps, then the Cinema Arts Center has arrived.

title: Jason Koral and Euny Hong
description: Youn-Kee Euny Hong, a daughter of Dr. Hwi-Shin Chun-Hong and Dr. Sung-Woong Hong of Seoul, South Korea, is to be married today to Jason Mark Koral, the son of Jacqueline Koral and Dr. Kurt Koral of Orange, Conn. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert is to officiate at the Manhattan Penthouse.

title: Sidetracking the Locomotive of Capital America
description: ARE you going to write that I'm an arrogant guy?'' the real estate financier Ethan Penner asked a reporter, calling from his car phone one afternoon in mid-October. ''I mean if you ask a lot of my close friends, they'll tell you I'm not arrogant at all. It's just when someone meets me for the first time that they think that.''

title: Art Collectors Travel to Headwaters of Talent
description: ON a day meant to introduce artists to art collectors, Patricia S. Miranda displayed her medievally inspired paintings, Gail Resen talked about her relief sculptures, Mildred Stone explained the lure of figure painting and Michael Thornton-Smith answered a slew of questions.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHANZER, BEN
description: SCHANZER-Ben. November 2, 1984. In loving memory of our dear husband, father and grandfather.

title: In Microsoft Case, a Lot Of Not Very Much
description: MOORE'S LAW -- which holds that the speed of computing doubles every 18 months -- is a concept that is hopelessly alien to the practice of law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, LEONARD M.
description: GOLD-Leonard M. On October 29, 1998. Beloved husband of Lois M. Adored father of Eric M. Devoted son of Martha R. and the late Samuel M. Loving brother of Martin R. & uncle to David and Jonathan Gold and Joshua Stephens. A man of great sensitivity and love for his family and friends, he will be greatly missed by all of us. Service on Monday, November 2, at 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Donations in his memory may be made to the American Brain Tumor Association, 2720 River Road, Des Plaines, IL 60018-4110 or a charity of your choice.

title: WEDDINGS: VOWS; June Azoulay, George Kalinsky
description: ON their first date two summers ago, June Azoulay and George Kalinsky talked for so long, they closed the restaurant. Afterward, in the dark parking lot, the awkward parting moment arrived. ''George had just lost his wife, and he looked so sad,'' Ms. Azoulay, 52, said. ''So, I did something uncharacteristic. I stood up on my tippy-toes and gave him a little hug.''

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: Back to Andy's Field

title: Depression In Children Prompts Concern
description: THE idea of childhood as a carefree time, full of happiness, security and cheerful innocence, is a cherished notion. It is also far from the reality for many children, whose lives are marked by hopelessness, grief and despair. Yet while many parents and professionals are quick to spot and treat a physical illness in a child, like chicken pox or strep throat, they are far more likely to dismiss warning signs of emotional trouble with attitudes of ''he'll grow out it'' or ''it's just a phase.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAGENDORS, STEVEN
description: JAGENDORS-Steven. You were special and your departure is and will be greatly missed by those close to you and those who loved you. I too will miss our pleasant phone chats and whatever bits we shared during our brief friendship. You are now in peace I pray and can share this peace with the few beautiful people you have joined. Love, Claire

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: DIALOGUES AND DISCOVERIES James Levine: His Life and His Music. By Robert C. Marsh. Lisa Drew/Scribner, $27.50.

title: Avoid Virtual Hangover: Just Click 'No'
description: Like many schools around the country, the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign had tried the usual panoply of dormitory room discussions and classroom lectures to educate students about the dangers of binge drinking.

title: Sounding Off on Sex Clubs; Sex Law Carries Perils For Other Merchants
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Time Off For Good Excuses
description: Almost everyone appreciates a little time away from the job, but some people take more than their fair share. In some cases, fate takes a hand and extends a vacation or otherwise accounts for an absence. But sometimes an employee's sheer creativity carves a few extra days from the work calendar.

title: A Builder Embarks In a New Direction
description: AFTER devoting 30 years to building upscale homes, Toll Brothers, based in this Philadelphia suburb, has formed a real estate investment trust to build and manage apartments, offices and stores in and near its communities.

title: Claire Rogers, James Morris Jr.
description: Claire Marie Rogers, the daughter of Jule M. Rogers of Southbury, Conn., and the late Benjamin F. Rogers, was married yesterday to James Michael Morris Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Sr. of Eugene, Ore. The Rev. Philip J. Geogan performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Catholic Church in Stonington, Conn.

title: The Quiet Bomb
description: ISRAEL AND

title: Deals and Discounts
description: REYKJAVIK ON THE CHEAP -- A three-day midweek trip to Reykjavik costs $299 with a Midweek Madness package offered by Icelandair Holidays. The price is per person, double occupancy, and includes round-trip flights leaving the United States on Sunday night and returning on Wednesday night, or departing Monday night and returning Thursday night; two nights' hotel with Scandinavian buffet breakfast, and airport-hotel transfers. The single supplement is $35. No additional nights may be added. Airport taxes are extra. The program is available through March 29 except for Dec. 14 to Jan. 5. Reservations: (800) 223-5500, extension 4.

title: Why Must Peace Be So Hard to Find?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEDLMAYR, MARY LOUISE
description: SEDLMAYR-Mary Louise. 76. On October 25. Of Port Washington, NY. Survived by sister Laura Belle; sons Chris and Timothy; grandson Theodor; daughters-inlaw Susan and Dana; and Hirschell. We will miss your humor. Services will be held privately.

title: Ms. O'Shea, Mr. Cheever
description: Regina Kristin O'Shea, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene K. O'Shea of Bedford Hills, N.Y., was married yesterday to Charles Emmett Cheever 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cheever Jr. of San Antonio. Msgr. Thomas P. Leonard performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: The New American Consensus; Our Hollow Hegemony
description: Sometime this summer the post-cold-war world ended. It was a brief, giddy age. We were thrust into it headlong barely 10 years ago, when the Berlin wall cracked, Eastern Europe freed itself and the Soviet Union disintegrated. Suddenly the United States became not just the sole surviving superpower but the repository of the sole surviving ideology. Countries around the globe fell over themselves to embrace capitalism, democracy and the American way -- from mutual funds to Madonna. As if conscious of the need to play its part, the American economy surged to historic highs.

title: A Winter Haven for Birds And Frontier Historians
description: BOB MILES, an Arizona Game and Fish agent, peered at his watch and announced with the authority of an air-traffic controller: ''They should be taking off in a few minutes. It's almost 7:15.'' I was standing with a group of 20 other visitors on the edge of Willcox Playa, a 50-square-mile dead lake in southeast Arizona. We were waiting for first light and the first cranes.

title: Ideas & Trends; It's Just Fine to Boldly Go
description: FOR grammarians, lexicographers and linguists, it's the Thing That Will Not Die. Just when they think it's buried once and for all, the corpse rises again to haunt a new generation.

title: Pinochet: New Round of Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Marathons That Offer Exotic Gain For the Pain
description: THE 32,000 runners in today's New York City Marathon will be cheered by 2 million spectators, serenaded by 40 bands, hydrated at 24 water stations and tinctured at two dozen medical stations. But, alas, there will be no oyster tent at Mile 25.

title: Whom You Gonna Call? Bad-Grammar Busters!
description: Need help positioning an adverb? Having an existential tussle with ''me'' and ''I''? Elisabeth Piedmont-Marton, purveyor of the grammar hot line at the University of Texas at Austin, will lend a sympathetic ear. And she's heard it all.

title: Streetscapes /Barrow Street; A Block That Reflects Greenwich Village's History
description: BARROW STREET, just off Sheridan Square, is a typical Greenwich Village street. Each house represents a layer of the Village's special architecture and history. A few of the buildings are a bit bedraggled; others are noble, and some are both.

title: Thanks to MTV
description: To the Editor:

title: As Teamsters Near a Vote, Hoffa Makes a Final Push
description: As soon as James P. Hoffa entered the smoke-filled bar in South Philadelphia, 80 teamsters burst into wild applause, with several rushing up to ask him for an autograph.

title: Silent Bond
description: I found David Biro's Lives essay chilling (Oct. 11). I was appalled by his statements that his sister's ''internal workings are a pleasant mystery'' and that the experience they shared (she as donor, he as recipient of a bone-marrow transplant) ''faded to a wisp of memory.''

title: A Man of Few (Very Catchy) Words Stretches His Legs
description: HAL FRIEDMAN can turn to his wife in earnest and ask, ''Which Ragu tonight?''

title: As Hunters Stalk Deer, Critics Take Their Shots
description: THIS morning, John Sferazo will be up a tree. Perched in a stand about 15 feet off the ground in the middle of the woods, he will sit very still for hours, huddled against the autumn chill and having the time of his life.

title: Voices of Experience; The Sharpest Pain
description: This morning I took a taxi from Lenox Terrace in Harlem, where I've lived since retiring as an Air Force major in 1962, down to 62d Street, near Columbus Circle, for an hourlong session of water therapy. I had spinal surgery a couple of years ago and have tried every form of therapy. Nothing worked. I'm hoping this will do the trick, because my schedule is busier than ever.

title: Typical; The Likes and Dislikes of Today's Everyfamily
description: When Americans go to the polls on Tuesday, don't expect seismic shifts -- or even loud noises. Things are comfy right now, and even with background worries about the economy, the Zeitgeist seems to be: We like where we are. Pass the microbrew. As surveys indicate, middle America is more upscale than it used to be -- liberal socially, conservative economically. In the following data stream, moderation reigns, strikingly so, perhaps explaining why Bill Clinton and his poll-tested policies have stayed popular during this Presidential annus horribilis.

title: Crossing the Threshold
description: THE LOVE OF

title: Sounding Off on Sex Clubs; Woe to Those Who Live Where City Workers Work
description: To the Editor:

title: 'I Will Not Retreat'
description: ALL ON FIRE William Lloyd Garrison and the Abolition of Slavery. By Henry Mayer. Illustrated. 707 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $32.50.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the music listings on Oct. 18 misidentified the instrument played by David Grisman. It was a mandolin, not a guitar.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LAMBERTSEN, ELEANOR C.
description: LAMBERTSEN-Eleanor C. A Memorial service for Dr. Eleanor C. Lambertsen, former Dean of the Cornell University-New York Hospital School of Nursing, Senior Associate Hospital Director and Director of Nursing Services at The New York Hospital, will be held on Tuesday, November 3, 1998, at 4:30 p.m. at the Weill Medical College of Cornell University, Uris Auditorium, 1300 York Avenue, at 69th St in Manhattan.

title: Jennifer Veridiano, Jonathan Love
description: Jennifer Perez Veridiano, the daughter of Dr. Norma Veridiano and Dr. Leon Veridiano of Manhattan, was married last evening to Jonathan Andrew Love, a son of Susan Wilker and a stepson of Stanley Wilker of Glen Cove, N.Y. The Rev. Eric Andrews, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at Windows on the World in Manhattan.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Fiber

title: Versatile Buckeyes Turn Back Hoosiers
description: In 1996, Ohio State clinched a Rose Bowl berth here in Memorial Stadium, sending a wave of Buckeyes fans onto the field to tear down the south goal post. Insulted, Hoosier players sprinted to the other end, circled the north post and dared anyone to come get them.

title: When Testing Reaches Its Limits
description: IN response to poor results on state tests, the Amityville school district has resurrected the discredited practice of tracking 6-year-olds by ability. Based upon a locally administered test, these very young children have been assigned to different ability level classes, a practice called ability grouping or tracking. By segregating its first-graders in this manner, the district hopes that these children's statewide test scores will exceed those of prior test scores taken. Thus, the questionable educational practice of tracking returns due to test results was implemented by utilizing test results, and has as its motivation the improvement of test results.

title: Rate Cut May Help Small-Company Stocks
description: October was yet another month when small-capitalization stocks lagged behind large-cap ones. But here is a reason that small caps might soon come around: the Federal Reserve's cuts in the discount rate last month.

title: October 25-31; China Tightens Reins On Political Speech
description: Political discussion in China these days may be looser than it has been for years, but last week there were reminders of just how narrow the limits remain. A few weeks after China signed an international covenant on political rights, a new research center exploring democracy and development, started by a 42-year-old former businessman, Peng Ming, was shut down.

title: A Brawler Ought to Brawl, Not Struggle to Be Subtle
description: Some defenses are known to be inoffensive. When they appear on the board, you can usually hear some spectators murmuring, ''It's headed for a draw.'' But in chess, nothing can be taken for granted.

title: Ideas & Trends: Women's Work in Japan; Serving Tea, Swallowing Insults
description: THEY take pictures of her long thighs as she climbs into limousines. They capture shots of her sitting in revealingly short skirts, and they dub her the Madonna of the Cabinet.

title: Knocking Socks Off
description: To the Editor:

title: An Election, Yes, But Congressional Races, Not Really
description: OVERSHADOWED by the fierce Senate race between Alfonse M. D'Amato and Charles E. Schumer, candidates in Long Island's five Congressional districts have had to struggle for attention this fall.

title: As Spirits Rise, So Does a Troupe
description: ''BEFORE ''A Jersey Cantata,'' the penultimate play of the 12 Miles West season, opened in Montclair in March, Jacqueline Knox, then the company's producing artistic director, talked to the audience about the harmony and common mission among the theater company's resident artists, as if they were one big happy family. Perhaps in theater, happy families are all alike: they split. Three months later, Ms. Knox announced her resignation.

title: The Funniest Italian You've Probably Never Heard Of
description: The comic genius Mel Brooks distinguishes between comedy and tragedy in this way: Comedy is when someone else falls into a pit and dies. And tragedy is when I hurt my little finger. Now we see how cynically that definition has been applied by Roberto Benigni, who finds comedy in the worst human tragedy of all time.

title: Longtime Tenants' Group Splits Just as Ownership Nears
description: Twenty years ago, tenants of 14 city-owned buildings between West 87th Street and West 95th Street united to save their homes from demolition and to manage them under a city program that promotes low- and middle income housing.

title: In the Region / New Jersey; Developer Named for a Key Hoboken Riverfront Site
description: WITH a small, timeworn gatehouse and piles of rubble inland from a 700-foot-long pier that is sinking into the Hudson River, the waterfront block between Third and Fourth Streets in Hoboken is not much to look at. But that may soon change.

title: Laundry-Room 'Education'
description: Having long since saturated every mass medium and most public places with ''brand awareness messages,'' marketers constantly search for fresh opportunities to stuff an ad into the few remaining unsold seconds of a consumer's waking hours. Usually that means finding a new way to invade the home -- and a rationale to make the incursion go down easier with a suspicious public.

title: Traces of an Outfielder Who Stumbled
description: ON a warm late afternoon in August of 1920 a bunch of boys stood outside Comiskey Park in Chicago, waiting under the stands for their heroes, the White Sox players, to emerge after a game. One of those boys would become an important American novelist, James T. Farrell. Young Jim, then 16, was an avid fan and he, like several of the others, couldn't believe the headlines that had just broken.

title: South Africa's Stinging Truths
description: The 3,500-page report of the South African Truth and Reconciliation Commission, released on Thursday, is the most comprehensive and unsparing examination of a nation's ugly past that any such commission has yet produced. Drawing from the commission's own investigations and the testimony of hundreds of applicants for amnesty and 20,000 victims, the report is a detailed look at the crimes of the apartheid era, and blames successive white governments for the vast majority. It has fulfilled its mandate of telling the fullest truth possible, which is one reason that every political party in South Africa has denounced it.

title: Music and Performer, an Unstable Compound
description: THE delicate dance between performer and performed has played out in a number of places this young season. It is a dance in the form of a competition, for what is it we go to hear? The pianist or the piano sonata? The singer or the song? To say that the second cannot exist without the first is only partly true. The perfect interpretation of Beethoven's ''Waldstein'' Sonata does not reside in a collection of past impressions but grows inside our heads. It is fertilized by all the performances we have heard of it but raised to full flower only by our own imaginations.

title: Ideas & Trends: You're Like, Duh, So Two Weeks Ago; Where Father Doesn't Know Best
description: SEVERAL years ago, George Kirgo, a respected 72-year-old television writer who had worked on such shows as ''Mary Tyler Moore'' and ''Wagon Train,'' proposed a movie-of-the-week idea to his agent, who took it to a network executive.

title: Flex Time for Everyone? It's Closer Every Day
description: That 9-to-5 workday is in little danger of going the way of the long-vanished six-day workweek. But employers are increasingly trying to provide their workers with alternatives to traditional schedules.

title: Apple and Caramel Desserts Make for Gooey Goodness
description: THERE is nothing like the flavor of local apples, grown for taste not storage. They are now at the peak of their season and you can find up to 40 different kinds in farmers' markets.

title: Sounding Off on Sex Clubs; Sex Law Carries Perils For Other Merchants
description: To the Editor:

title: Going Down Screaming
description: The scolding finger on the magazine cover did not remind me of either Ken Starr or of the conservative movement, but rather of President Clinton. He was the one who stood before the television cameras wagging his finger at the American people, declaring that he had never had sexual relations with ''that woman, Miss Lewinsky.'' It seems to me he was scolding all of us for doubting his credibility.

title: For Sales of Second Homes, No Vacation
description: THIS is a busy time for real estate brokers in the picture-perfect small towns of the Northeast as they race from closing to closing, getting customers into weekend houses in time to inaugurate the new lodgings with a Thanksgiving turkey. It is also, by and large, a rich time. Some brokers have had their best year ever as affluent buyers have increasingly come to view the second home as an integral part of life, an accessory as necessary as a sports utility vehicle.

title: The Post-Khomeini Generation
description: In February, Iran's revolution will turn 20 years old. And among the country's many problems, what troubles Iran's clerical leaders the most is that they are losing -- or have already lost -- the generation that has come of age since then.

title: A Theater Company Changes Its Name
description: NINE years ago, Cara Caldwell Watson formed a theater company and named it Wordplay. The word part stood for writing, which is how Ms. Watson once earned her living. Yes, real estate advertising copy counts as writing, Ms. Watson said. As for the play part, ''My whole life is theater,'' she added. ''The money came in from words and went out on plays. We were always nonprofit.''

title: Stark White Paper: Those Were the Days
description: There are good reasons to create a personal Web site, besides having a place to display photographs of your cat and Bon Jovi. It can also be an electronic portfolio, featuring essays you've written, scores you've composed, scenes you've acted in.

title: DATABANK: October 26-30; Nearly Everything Came Up Roses
description: Buoyed by a report on Friday that showed the economy growing at an altogether respectable annual rate of 3.3 percent in the third quarter, stocks closed out their best month in more than a decade and left many wondering if August and September really happened.

title: Before the Curtain At Lincoln Center
description: BRASSERIE AMERICAINE +++

title: Catskill Trout Rivers Recover, With Help
description: On Jan. 19, 1996, heavy rains and melting snow caused ruinous flooding in the Catskill Mountains. The many fine rivers that make the Catskills the heart of Eastern trout fishing, among them the East and West Branches of the Delaware, the Beaverkill and the Esopus, rose to claim their natural flood plains and everything unnatural that lay within them.

title: An Election, Yes, But Congressional Races, Not Really; Lazio Is Confident, But Still Working
description: FOUR years of work on a landmark measure for low-income housing came to fruition for Congressman Lazio in time to add a major accomplishment to his record as Election Day neared.

title: Deconstructing Life
description: THE REVISIONIST

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: OFFBEAT fare enlivens this week's lineup of films on television, including a sunlit Hitchcock thriller, an adaptation of a Broadway hit, a classic Bogart melodrama and its less famous follow-up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, HELEN
description: KATZ-Helen. Passed away October 29, 1998. Of Delray Beach, FL. Loving wife of the late William, adored mother of Marlene (Marvin) Padover, George (Evelyn) Katz and Adele Katz. Cherished grandmother of Roger, Craig, Kenneth, Mitchell, Richard and Douglas. Most cherished greatgrandmother of her beautiful ten. Beloved sister of Ted Barrett and Selma Goldman. Services Sunday November 1, 1998, 11 AM at Gutterman's Inc., 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Backtalk; The Cooler, Balder Head Prevailed
description: This was always the line on Bobby Rahal: He didn't look like a racing driver. In response, the balding, bespectacled, slightly professorial Rahal would ask: What is a racing driver supposed to look like?

title: One Teacher's Lesson Plan: Home Visits
description: RESPLENDENT in a purple satin tunic and pants set that sparkled with gilt threads, Josephine Valdes perched on the edge of her family's sofa in their living room here, smiling shyly at a visitor.

title: Deerfield Museum Depicts Rural Refinements
description: The western Massachusetts museum village of Historic Deerfield has added something to its 18th- and 19th-century museum houses: the Flynt Center of Early New England Life, named for the Greenwich family that founded Historic Deerfield. The inaugural exhibition, ''Pursuing Refinement in Rural New England: 1750-1850,'' tells of Deerfield families who strove, in the words of the Rev. Jonathan Ashley, an 18th-century Congregational minister, to embrace ''useful improvements,'' while avoiding pride and vanity.

title: No Veggie Burgers. No 49 Brews.
description: When Wendy Wasserstein, the playwright, was asked to write an article for America Online's Digital City New York Web site earlier this year, she was startled. ''Well, I don't exactly surf the Web,'' Ms. Wasserstein said. ''I'm not Miss Computer or Miss Information -- or, come to think of it, maybe I am,'' she said, laughing at the wordplay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAU, GINA
description: BLAU-Gina. Artist, dancer, teacher and loving friend. Dancing with Shiva. Karen Flaherty

title: Printmaker's Preoccupation With Finding the Order of Things
description: THE 1930's and 40's were such an active and fertile period in American printmaking that some of the most able artists are now but faces in the crowd. Although Armin Landeck is one of those, an exhibition at the Connecticut Graphic Arts Center here allows him to step forward.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Westchester Briefs column on Oct. 18 about an effort by a White Plains lawyer, Doris Sass ower, to reinstate her license referred incorrectly to her professional status. She has been suspended indefinitely, not disbarred.

title: Fashion's Quick Fade, From Black to White
description: There they go again. The high priestesses of fashion have swung from one extreme to another, trading their practical all-black clothes for most impractical all-white. Chalk white was worn last month by many spectators at the spring collections in Paris. One woman said of her coat, ''I've had it cleaned four times in two months, at $30 a cleaning.'' In 1963, Andre Cour reges's modernist manifesto proclaimed white the ultimate luxury. This time, the styling is not space age but a range of looks, from Edwardian long skirts to sportswear.

title: Isles, Behind Salo, Keep Turning It Up Against Flyers
description: With timely goals, solid defense and superb goaltending, the Islanders are making up for their lack of a bona fide goal scorer.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 18 about bus tours of Long Island referred imprecisely to the ownership of one tour company. Carole Lucca is a founder, not the sole founder, of All Around Long Island Tours; Louise Grinere was a founding partner but is no longer associated with the company.

title: At Banks, the Fees Just Keep On Coming
description: CONSUMERS have long complained about unexpected bank and credit-card fees. But far from scaling back their assault on householders' pockets, banks are apparently dipping their hands in even deeper.

title: Russia Approves Plan for Tighter State Control of Economy
description: Seven weeks after it took office in the midst of a deepening financial crisis, the Russian Government today approved the first draft of a recovery plan that calls for more public spending and tighter Government control of the economy.

title: Our Towns; Where Justice Is Served With Mercy
description: ONE night a week, Justice Michael McElroy, in long black robes, takes the bench in Village Justice Court here and renders judgment on a parade of suburban offenders, many of them neighbors and friends.

title: Ahead of the Winter Garden
description: Tie long rose canes securely to fences and arbors to prevent snapping or splitting in winter winds. Cut out diseased or damaged wood, but don't do major rose pruning now. If you've had black spot, mildew or other rose diseases, scrupulously remove fallen leaves.

title: Political Briefing; Kind Word for Greens From Republicans
description: Call it ''reverse English'' political advertising, or some such. Whatever it is, it is a different kind of spin that is being used in the Congressional campaign in New Mexico's Third District.

title: Pinochet: New Round of Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Ossining Waterfront
description: In contrast to several other municipalities lining the shore of the Hudson River, Ossining is finally moving ahead on plans to rebuild its waterfront. After reviewing several sets of plans, the village designated Cappelli Enterprises of Valhalla as the developer to build stores and housing on the waterfront at an estimated cost of $70 million.

title: Caribbean Limbo
description: The Pagoda

title: ANGRY WICCANS
description: * The witches of Salem, Mass., are miffed at the state's Republican Governor, Argeo Paul Cellucci, who ran an ad ridiculing his Democratic challenger for defending witches from harassment. * Witches (who call themselves Wiccans) have called in to protest the ad's depiction of a black-hatted sorceress and vowed to picket campaign events. * Wicca is a Federally recognized religion; the United States is home to an estimated 50,000 to 300,000 believers. * Last month the A.C.L.U. aided a witch in suing Republic, Mo., to remove a Christian symbol from the city seal. During the fracas, the witch's daughter was taunted in school as a Satanist. * Laurie Cabot, author of ''The Witch in Every Woman,'' says attitudes are improving but adds: ''We haven't come far enough. They're still doing movies like 'Practical Magic.'''

title: Postings: $18-Million Makeover at New Jersey Institute of Technology; New, Expanded Home for School of Architecture
description: A seven-story brick academic building on the campus of the New Jersey Institute of Technology in downtown Newark has been transformed and expanded into a distinctive new home for the institute's School of Architecture. In the process, it has also become the gateway for the 52-acre urban campus.

title: The World: Saddam Hussein, Tactician; Dividing Is One Thing. Conquering Is Something Else.
