description: DIVIDE and conquer'' is an ancient tactic that Saddam Hussein refined into an art form as a dictator in Iraq.

title: Ideas & Trends: Yawning in America; Politicians Curse the Darkness as the Sun Shines
description: REPRESENTATIVE JOHN LINDER of Georgia, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, perhaps said it best, and certainly most succinctly, when he was asked last week which issue was dominating the elections on Tuesday.

title: The Seven Lives (and 36 Costumes) of Sid Caesar
description: IN the early fall of 1962, a group of New York theater artists ventured down to Philadelphia to try out a new musical comedy, ''Little Me,'' based on a racy novel by Patrick Dennis. In terms of comedy and drama, they found, offstage events sometimes rivaled those in the show: a bathroom sink untimely ripped from a wall, a police officer commandeered to arrest the creative team, and a world teetering on the brink of nuclear annihilation.

title: When Phone-Company Veterans Punch the Redial Button
description: It was once uncommon to find telephone-company executives anywhere but phone companies. Nowadays they are increasingly crossing over into senior jobs in other businesses. Raymond W. Smith, who is due to retire as chairman of Bell Atlantic at the end of the year, said last week that he would take his experience acquiring Nynex and GTE to the investment banking world, where he will head up the Rothschild Group's North American holding company. But some don't stray so far: Alex J. Mandl, who quit as president of AT&T in 1996 when it became clear he wasn't in line to become chairman, said his wireless telecommunications start-up, Teligent, was now open for business in 10 cities. . . . Sprint decided to hold off taking its wireless operations public until markets calm down.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about investing in companies that combat the Year 2000 computer problem misstated the date one of them, Computer Horizons, went public. It was in 1972, not the mid-1990's.

title: How to Be Seen if Voters Aren't Looking
description: LIKE students who frantically wave their hands so their teachers will notice them, candidates for the General Assembly are vying for voter attention in the closing days of the campaign.

title: Michele Aronberg, Todd Simmens
description: Michele Beth Aronberg, the daughter of Sheila Aronberg of East Brunswick, N.J., and the late Alvin Aronberg, is to be married this morning to Todd Carl Simmens, a son of Joyce and Harvey Simmens of Wyndmoor, Pa. Rabbi Leonard Gordon is to perform the ceremony at the Germantown Jewish Center in Philadelphia.

title: The Museum Show Has an Ego Disorder
description: Margaret Talbot appears to regard the motives of those who protested the originally planned Freud retrospective as ideological. By construing them this way, she draws a strained analogy between criticisms of the Freud exhibition and protests over other recent exhibitions. There is, however, an essential difference between the Freud exhibition and the others. Freud advocated his theory as a ''scientific'' account of the mind and its operations. Such a claim must be taken seriously and evaluated with care. This seems to have been the point of those who criticized the retrospective: that the scientific and philosophical merits of Freud's project be addressed in a serious manner, surely an appropriate goal.

title: Princeton Stops Columbia to Stay Tied for Ivy Lead
description: Princeton kept its share of first place in the Ivy League with an easy 20-0 victory over Columbia yesterday at Wein Stadium in Manhattan. The Tigers, Harvard and Pennsylvania remained tied, each with a 3-1 league record and each with three games remaining.

title: Seeking Mature Judgment, U.N. Sets Minimum Age for Its Troops
description: Looking for greater maturity and more experience in the soldiers it sends into peacekeeping operations, the United Nations set minimum age limits this week for troops and police trainers.

title: Where the Conflict Over Abortion Is an Everyday Drama
description: Two teen-age girls in puffy down coats stared at the ground and walked toward the Ambulatory Surgery Center of Brooklyn, on 43d Street and Third Avenue. As an officer watched, three people behind a police barrier said the rosary before an image of the Virgin Mary and a photograph of a bloody fetus.

title: Alone With 'Alone,' Or What 'Is' Is
description: William Safire refers to the locution ''alone together'' as ''a seeming oxymoron'' (On Language, Oct. 11). It is also the title of a very fine popular song by Howard Dietz and Arthur Schwartz from a Broadway musical of the early 1930's, ''Flying Colors.''

title: Marking 'White House' No. 1
description: It is an area rich in history: St. George Square, as it was then known, at the intersection of Frankfort, Dover, Pearl and Cherry Streets in lower Manhattan. William Walton, an 18th-century merchant, lived there, his opulent home cited by Parliament as proof of the ability of the colonists to pay taxes. John Hancock lived nearby, at 5 Cherry Street, as, later, did Capt. Samuel Chester Reid, a War of 1812 hero whose home at 27 Cherry Street became the first in the United States with gas lighting.

title: Alas, Ye Olde (Slash) Canada Goose (Thwack) Solution
description: THIS being the Year of the Public Apology, I'd like to apologize for New Jersey's goose problem, which appears to be more or less my fault. I shall fall on my sword, a two-handed Scottish claymore with round pommel, as soon as it arrives in the mail.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: The Recovery Car: Red and Rockin'
description: If you need a reminder that life is short and you better grab it when you can, there is nothing like a diagnosis of advanced ovarian cancer, and this is how I come to call my mother in Daytona Beach, Fla., and ask her to find me a sports car.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Fencers, Drinkers and Sausage Makers
description: The beasts in Magnus Mills's dark and funny first novel, THE RESTRAINT OF BEASTS (Arcade, $22.95), are its three central characters: the nameless narrator, a rather unassertive English foreman for a fence contractor in rural Scotland, and his assistants, Tam and Richie, slacker metalheads and lifelong drinking buddies. Previously assigned to build a fence for Mr. McCrindle, a local dairy farmer, Tam and Richie have done a predictably negligent job, and when the narrator joins them to complete the work, things begin to go hilariously, fatally wrong. The first of many dire work-related accidents occurs, killing Mr. McCrindle; the luckless band of fence builders simply buries him and moves on to the next job. Things only get worse. More accidents, more deaths, more nonchalant burials, a brutish and unvarying routine of working by day and drinking by night -- the plot seems as suffocating and claustrophobic as the apparently ubiquitous fencing that's mysteriously going up everywhere. When the narrator and his two henchmen meet with and are employed by the sinister Hall Brothers -- rival fence-builders who are also ranchers and sausage makers (a skill of which they are ominously proud) -- the narrative takes on an even more nightmarish aspect. In the process, ''The Restraint of Beasts'' slyly reveals itself to be much more than a black comedy about mind-numbed laborers building an endless series of fences; rather, it is a witty, intricate fable about a working-class hell constructed by its own inhabitants. Mills, himself a former fence builder and bus driver, writes merciless deadpan dialogue. And he uses it to create a clever, uncompromising fever dream, similar in mood to the Coen brothers' film ''Barton Fink,'' with its increasingly compromised central character and escalating atmosphere of unseen menace. Anthony Bourdain

title: Hey, Kids, Please Say Hello to Officer Mentor
description: There always came a time in elementary school when the teacher hammered home the lesson that went something like this: the police officer is always your friend. Today that officer could also be a storyteller or a counselor.

title: A Clown and a Comedy Made for Each Other
description: THERE is a song-and-dance number on Martin Short's 1989 television special, ''I, Martin Short, Goes Hollywood,'' that his friend Dave Thomas believes exemplifies a central truth about Mr. Short. It is a number in which the comic actor appears as an unpainted wooden fence, wearing little more than a fig leaf and a few slats.

title: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1998: Questions For; Bernard Goetz
description: In 1984, Bernard Goetz shot four black teen-agers on the subway because he believed they were about to mug him. He plans to run for Mayor of New York in 2001.

title: Going Down Screaming
description: The greatest value of Andrew Sullivan's article, I believe, is its refutation of the common misconception that the conservative moralists are just a fringe bunch, with little, if any, power (Oct. 11). By explaining how the Christian right influences America's policies on the United Nations, China and ambassadorships, Sullivan brilliantly explodes this myth.

title: Reveling in a New World Vegetable, Corn
description: GARDEN shops, farm stands, florists, even supermarkets are selling clusters of ornamental corn. These colorful bunches of so-called Indian corn are hung on doors to symbolize the hope for a bountiful harvest. At least that is the tradition. But many homeowners just hang the corn because it is so decorative.

title: Opening Acts With Flair
description: The ideal aperitif for Picholine's Mediterranean-French cuisine is nonvintage San Leon manzanilla (a best buy at $6 a glass), sipped languidly. This dainty, salty, bone-dry sherry from Herederos de Argueso, a Spanish boutique, is perfect with the signature spiced green picholine olives. A bottle costs about $14 at 67 Wine and Spirits, 179 Columbus Avenue; keep it refrigerated and drain in a week.

title: The Nation; At the O.K. Corral, They Mythed
description: ONE hundred sixteen years ago last Monday, at about 2:47 in the afternoon, Virgil, Wyatt and Morgan Earp, accompanied by a young, tubercular dentist-gambler from Georgia named John Henry (Doc) Holliday, turned left off Fremont Street (now Highway 80) in the sprawling silver-boom camp of Tombstone, Ariz., and into a vacant lot in back of the O. K. Corral. Virgil Earp, the town marshal, said, ''Boys, throw up your hands -- I want your guns,'' after which two quick shots were heard. Thirty seconds later, every man in the fight was dead or wounded except Wyatt Earp.

title: Sports of The Times; Lawrence Taylor, the Phantom of L. T., and the Hall of Fame in Canton
description: INSTEAD of understanding who and what he is now, Lawrence Taylor thinks of himself too often as what he was.

title: Going Down Screaming
description: It's too bad that Sullivan sprinkled the word ''intellectual'' so freely throughout his article, without a hint of irony. An intellectual explores and evaluates new ideas. Sullivan's subjects have no new ideas, only revealed ''truths.'' ''Ideologue'' would have been more accurate than ''intellectual.'' What's great about America is the freedom these ideologues have to express their beliefs. Their attempts to force the rest of us to live by them is most un-American.

title: Save Social Security? From What?
description: WHEN the new Congress convenes early next year, one of the major issues it will tackle -- after it tears itself away from Bill and Monica -- will be Social Security.

title: Colleges Join the Lobbyists
description: IN the spring, Yale University traditionally sets about selecting a new crop of junior professors and postdoctoral researchers for the school's classrooms and laboratories. But this summer a dozen faculty posts stood vacant.

title: Ho! Ho! Ho! Boohoo-hoo!
description: The holiday season seems to bring out the best and the worst in bosses. We've all heard stories about workers who are fired on Christmas Eve, but then again, Scrooge himself ended up giving the long-suffering Bob Cratchit a raise. What holiday horror stories have emerged from your workplace? Or, to give the management world's guardian angels their due, how have the holidays melted the coldest corporate hearts? Send your anecdotes to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Jennifer Levine, Charles Geller
description: Dr. Jennifer M. Levine, a daughter of Anita and Gary Levine of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Dr. Charles M. Geller, a son of Muriel and Leon Geller of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Melvin Sirner officiated at the Plaza in Manhattan.

title: For One-Child Policy, China Rethinks Iron Hand
description: China's family-planning system, notorious for the harsh rules and punishments it employs in its quest to limit births, has quietly started urging its workers to soften their approach, hoping to improve its often tense relationship with Chinese women.

title: Here's Advice He Can Use
description: It's not easy to change a reputation, and few people know this better than George Steinbrenner. He is still the go-to guy for comedy writers when they need an easy punch line, even though recent profiles of him suggest that he may be softening slightly around the razor-sharp edges. Still, his choice of management books signals that he may indeed be trying to refine his leadership style. According to USA Today, his current reading includes ''Cigars, Whiskey & Winning: Leadership Lessons from General Ulysses S. Grant'' (Prentice Hall; 1998). Section headings include: ''Avoid Humiliating Your Subordinates,'' ''The Organization Doesn't Revolve Around You,'' ''Recognize the Limits Of Your Authority'' and ''Know When to Keep Your Mouth Shut.'' ADAM BRYANT

title: In the Region / Long Island; In Maxi-Mansion Furor, Echoes and Portents?
description: ON Sept. 8, the Town of Southampton passed a new zoning ordinance restricting residential dwellings to a maximum of 20,000 square feet of residential space, excluding basements. The measure was a reaction to the furor raised by a 58,000-square-foot residence with large outbuildings under construction on a 63-acre parcel of former farmland in the Sagaponack area of the town.

title: Safeguarding the Elderly From Abuse
description: THE days are long and often lonely for Miriam Demme, a 77-year widow who lives in what will most likely be her last home, a skilled-care nursing institution on a hill overlooking this city. Sometimes she looks out her window; often she naps. The former homemaker, a stroke victim who is unable to dress herself, is sustained, physically and emotionally, by the nurses and aides who care for her at the 245-bed Schnurmacher nursing center here.

title: Leigh Goldman, Scott Balber
description: Leigh Stacey Goldman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael D. Goldman of Wilmington, Del., was married last evening to Scott Sonny Balber, a son of Roberta S. Balber of Bay Terrace, Staten Island, and the late Eugene D. Balber. Rabbi Peter H. Grumbacher performed the ceremony at Congregation Beth Emeth in Wilmington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESHOME, DR. TEWODROS
description: TESHOME-Dr. Tewodros. The Medical Staff of Coler-Goldwater Hospital expresses great sorrow at the loss of our much respected colleague who passed away on October 28, 1998. A member of the Medical Staff since 1988, officer of the Medical Staff and Vice President of Roosevelt Island Medical Associates; he distinguished himself with his selfless devotion to patients and residents and his willingness to share his expertise with his colleagues. His cheerful demeanor, kindness, leadership and wisdom will be missed. The Medical Staff expresses its heartfelt condolences to his family and its gratitude for his outstanding contribution to patient care.

title: God's Ear
description: Revere Beach Boulevard By Roland Merullo. 320 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $23.

title: In Their Own Words
description: ALFONSE M. D'AMATO

title: Minnesota's North
description: To the Editor: Daisanne McLane's brief first encounter with the wonders ''In Minnesota, Due North'' (Sept. 6) coincided with my recent visit in several ways. I also went to Poplar Lake in August. My sister and her husband own land next to the Rockwood Lodge, where Ms. McLane spent her first night. The lodge lies less than four miles from Canada by a rugged trail recommended for experienced wilderness hikers. Ms. McLane might respond to this challenge on her return trip.

title: Political Briefing; And They Like Those Democrats, Too
description: There is a different kind of spin on the advertising in the Wisconsin Senate race, too, a race that has already taken more than one curious turn.

title: Going Down Screaming
description: Thank you for Andrew Sullivan's article. When I finished reading it, I immediately telephoned The Weekly Standard to subscribe.

title: Spanning Generations
description: To the Editor:

title: Split in Endorsements Deprives Candidates of Advantage
description: Labor unions in New York State are badly divided over their endorsements in this year's Senate race, depriving Alfonse M. D'Amato, the incumbent, and Representative Charles E. Schumer prized endorsements that could give them an edge in their neck-and-neck race.

title: Birthday Puffery
description: The videotaped invitation to the 29th birthday party for Sean (Puffy) Combs, the rap impresario, is one of the most unconventional of the season. It features an eclectic parade of celebrities delivering snippets of information about the fete this Wednesday. Ellen DeGeneres suggests arriving fashionably late -- ''at 2 o'clock the next day.'' Penny Marshall warns, ''Security will be tight.'' Also appearing are Oprah Winfrey, Sammy Sosa and Danny DeVito, who emerges from under a blanket. Many of the faces, like those of Ronald S. Perelman and Robin Leach, are regulars on the party circuit. It now includes Mr. Combs, who bought a house in East Hampton, N.Y., last summer. For the party location, invitees must call an 800 number. ANDREW JACOBS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAGLIARDI, THE HON. LEE P.
description: GAGLIARDI-The Hon. Lee P. On October 30, 1998. Beloved husband of Marian S. (Selden). Loving father of Elisabeth Tobin and the late Marian. Dear brother of Diana Collins, Gloria M. Gagliardi, Mary Ann Dugan and the late Judge Joseph Gagliardi, Phenina Forbes, and Anthony L. Gagliardi. Adoring grandfather of Christopher J. Tobin, Keith C. Tobin, Katherine E. Tobin & Timothy L. Tobin. Visiting Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, New York. Mass Tuesday 10 AM at St. Augustine Church in Larchmont. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Memorial donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Penn State Makes Leap With Its Stingy Defense
description: The achievements of Penn State's defense should come with an asterisk and this footnote: ''Played Illinois.''

title: Going Down Screaming
description: Robert Bork, William Kristol, Mark Helprin and their colleagues manifest a classic symptom of clinical depression -- fears that bear little relation to facts. Sullivan says it best when he notes their inability to take yes for an answer, to see that even a Democratic President passed most of their agenda. The American public is divorcing, aborting and drinking less; welfare rolls shrink and the budget is balanced. I suggest Prozac in the water coolers of The Weekly Standard.

title: The Birnbaum Chronicles
description: Like Never Before By Ehud Havazelet. 268 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $23.

title: On L.I., Voters Play 'Who Is A Democrat?'
description: It is the one of the most competitive Assembly races on Long Island. It is also one of the most confusing.

title: 2d-Hand Smoke in A Co-op
description: Q. I own an upper-level apartment in a co-op. The people who rent the unit below are nonsmokers; however, their family and friends are all smokers. The odor of cigarette smoke is constant in my apartment when they have visitors. What at first was a nuisance is now a health risk, as I have allergies and the smoke is affecting my breathing. What is the co-op board's responsibility as far as my rights and quality of life are concerned? If nothing is done, what can I do legally? . . . Kathy Harris, Bellerose, Queens.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in the Neighborhood Report pages on Oct. 11 listing programs by ethnic groups on WKDM, a small AM station, misstated the name of one. It is a Croatian-language program, Radio Jadran, not Radio Jordan.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Guilford Church Fair

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: The Farewell Symphony

title: The Designer Tries On Another Image
description: DIANE VON FURSTENBERG surely had the most photographed cheekbones of the 1970's. A woman who could flirt with the camera in ways that helped shape her career, she flaunted her formidable bone structure for the leading image makers of her day: Francesco Scavullo, Ara Gallant and, most memorably, Andy Warhol. Warhol snapped the Polaroid that would become the model for his well-known serial portrait of Ms. Von Furstenberg, capturing her with lips slightly parted and one arm flung dramatically over her head.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MANNES, EVELYN SABIN
description: MANNES-Evelyn Sabin. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, November 17th at 1PM, at Mannes College of Music. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to the Evelyn and Leopold Mannes Memorial Scholarship Fund at Mannes College of Music, 150 West 85 Street, NY, NY 10024.

title: Groundbreaking Is Set For Atlantic City Tunnel
description: The 1.6-mile tunnel to link the Atlantic City Expressway with casinos in the city's marina district cleared its last bureaucratic hurdle this week, receiving a construction permit from the state Coastal Area Facilities Review, and groundbreaking is scheduled for Wednesday.

title: Ms. Angelone And Dr. Morris
description: Elizabeth Angelone and Dr. James R. Morris were married yesterday at the Black Point Inn in Prouts Neck, Me. Melissa A. Seader, the bride's sister and a justice of the peace in Portland, Me., officiated. The Rev. James E. Dunne, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Voices of Experience; Gingerly, Trying On Superman's Shoes
description: I am (approximately) John Glenn's age and immediately asked myself (who would not?) would I do this? Well, what is it you wonder about, in space flight environment, after stepping into your 70's? I have a terrible time remembering names, and I know that John Glenn has a little of that. In the hearings early last year on Democratic fund-raising activities in 1996 he had a hard time remembering the names of donors. But I shouldn't think that would stand in the way of remembering the names of cockpit instruments, though remembering such things is not taken for granted in air travel.

title: Why Must Peace Be So Hard to Find?; Religion's Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: New Generation Affirms the Life Of a Synagogue
description: Leo Chester's voice broke ever so slightly as he talked about the first bar mitzvah at Ramath Orah in 18 years. ''I felt 10 feet tall,'' said Mr. Chester, who survived Auschwitz to become a diamond cutter and the president of this Orthodox synagogue on 110th Street near Broadway. ''It means that the people who started this 50 years ago -- it is still going on in their memory.''

title: Gen X'ers Need a Hero Like John Glenn
description: To the Editor:

title: PULSE; Vintage, Writ Small
description: Call them hand-me-downs and no one wants them. But label old children's clothes vintage, and you can sell them instead of giving them away. Debbie Deitering, a fashion model, recently opened Little O's, which she says is New York's first vintage store exclusively for children. The tiny boutique, at 1 Bleecker Street (at Bowery), is crammed with Superman pajamas, pint-size cowboy boots, a shiny red tricycle and polyester disco shirts small enough for a Smurf. There are delicately embroidered christening dresses that date back to the early 1900's, but most items are polyester goodies, ranging in price from $10 for an early 1980's pink unicorn T-shirt to $80 for a 70's-style red and white vinyl jacket. But who knows where they've been? Ms. Deitering does a lot of her buying when on location for photo shoots, at flea markets and estate sales, from Palm Springs to Paris. She dry-cleans and washes the items before selling them, but her shop attracts moms who are more hip than hygiene-obsessed. ''I grew up in the 70's,'' said Suda Kaseguma, who was shopping there recently with her 8-month-old son, Max. ''So these clothes bring back a lot of nostalgic feelings.'' AMY SYNNOTT

title: Corrections
description: A picture of Bob Dylan on Oct. 11 with an article about his 1966 European tour carried an incorrect credit. The photographer was Art Kane, not Jerry Schatzberg. Mr. Kane's gallery is Great Modern Pictures.

title: Hollywood Now Plays Cowboys and Arabs
description: THe Arab-American actor Sayed Badreya has had no problem finding work in Hollywood. With his dark beard and his accented English, he has had his pick of parts as terrorists, hijackers, kidnappers and Islamic militants.

title: Paris Transit Plans Halts In Response To Violence
description: Yves Sauz, a motorman on the Paris rapid transit system, says he likes everything about the job except the increasingly tough customers.

title: At Stake, Clinton Fate
description: The overwhelming view among Democrats and Republicans on Capitol Hill is that the outcome of the nearly yearlong drama of President Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky will be decisively shaped by the results of the midterm Congressional elections on Tuesday.

title: The Museum Show Has an Ego Disorder
description: There may be a useful parallel between the answer to the ques-tions ''Does psychoanalysis work?'' and ''Does a museum exhibition about psychoanalysis work?'' (Margaret Talbot, Oct. 11). Psychoanalysis does not tell people what to think nor does it make them happy. But it does help people think more freely and respects the individual's autonomy and authenticity. It sounds as if the current exhibition seeks to mirror these goals of psychoanalysis by helping the museumgoer to learn not only about psychoanalysis's past, but also to think freely about its present and future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOBBE, GEORGE
description: NOBBE-George, Jr. Died at Pawling, NY, of cancer, serenely and surrounded by friends, October 31, 1998. Born NYC, September 19, 1935. He attended St. Luke's School, New Canaan, CT; St. George's School, Newport, RI; Harvard College (Class of 1956); and Columbia University School of Journalism. Distinguished feature writer and editor at The New York News. Newspaperman, conservation journalist, gifted professor of English, champion of wildlife particularly bears. We rejoice in the privilege of having known George and mourn him privately, according to his wishes. The Loving Friends of George Nobbe

title: For Brothers, Trail in Mother's Slaying Led Home
description: For 27 years, Maylon Johnson's two sons had been frustrated that their mother's killer was never caught. So earlier this month, they asked the Newark Police Department to reinvestigate the case, not knowing where the trail would lead.

title: Secret Services
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANN, HELEN H.
description: MANN-Helen H. On October 30, 1998. Dear sister of Joan Wickert and Elfriede Bernstein. Loving aunt of Michael and Victor Bernstein. She will be profoundly missed and always remembered by her family and friends. Graveside service Tuesday, 2 PM, at Beth El Cemetery.

title: In New Challenge to the U.N., Iraq Halts Arms Monitoring
description: In its most serious challenge to the United Nations in more than a year of intermittent crises, Iraq said today that it was ending all cooperation with international arms inspectors and would close their long-term monitoring operations immediately.

title: Correction
description: The Streetscapes column on Oct. 18, about four mansions on East 80th Street, misstated a broker's reference to a record sales price. The broker said that the house at No. 116, sold for $11 million a decade ago, holds the record for the highest sales price of a house on the block, not in the city.

title: A Film That Raced From Manuscript To a Scorsese Set
description: PERCHED on a director's chair at Eighth Avenue and 44th Street one recent midnight, Martin Scorsese is somewhere he never expected to be: directing a movie again on his native city's mean streets. Nor did he ever expect to be working again from a script by Paul Schrader, with whom he collaborated on cinematic landmarks like ''Taxi Driver'' and ''Raging Bull,'' and with whom he believed he would never work again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIGIACINTO, ROSE
description: DiGIACINTO-Rose. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the physicians and staff of the Hyman-Newman Institute for neurology and neurosurgery (INN) in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Rose DiGiacinto, beloved mother of George V. DiGiacinto, M.D., Director of the Division of Neurosurgery, at our partner institution, St Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. To Dr. G. DiGiacinto, his entire family and all of his mother's loved ones, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Matthew E. Fink, MD, President and CEO Fred J. Epstein, MD, Co-Chairman Department of Neurosurgery and Director INN Eugene S. Flamm, MD, Co-Chairman Department of Neurosurgery

title: Sherese Robinson, Randall Lee
description: Sherese Lynece Robinson, a daughter of Vicki Ann Robinson of the Bronx, was married yesterday to Randall Hung Kong Lee, a son of Mary Lou Lee and Dr. Mathew H. M. Lee of Holliswood, Queens. The Rev. Dr. Arthur Caliandro, a minister of the Reformed Church in America, officiated at Masterview Studio, a loft in Manhattan.

title: Refinancing: Pluses and Minuses
description: REMEMBER when home buyers took out a mortgage and kept it until they sold the house? Well, those days are gone.

title: For Trade's Sake, Honing Etiquette
description: THE chief executive of the Long Island aerospace company arrived at the airport to meet the foreign businessman who was about to sign a contract with her company. After she greeted the businessman, the chief executive escorted him to her limousine.

title: Hiring Your Own Apartment Painter
description: To the Editor:

title: Fordham Finds Villanova Far Too Much to Handle
description: One thing was certain when Fordham met Villanova at Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx yesterday: someone's three-game losing streak would end.

title: The View From/Old Lyme; Uncovering Pollution's Truths in the Mummichog
description: HER classmates cheering her on -- ''Come on, Shay, you can do it!'' -- Sunscherray Bronson made a third attempt to cast a wire minnow trap past the marsh grass and into the channel where, presumably, the mummichog swam. The trap's yellow nylon tether line slipped out of Shay's grasp, eliciting a chorus of ''Ooh' '' and a round of tittering laughter.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: EARTHLY JOYS

title: Cold Winds Needn't Put an End to the Season
description: SEVERAL years ago, flowering kale enjoyed a period of vogue among my gardening neighbors. It was as common a sight in the fall as chrysanthemums, lined up in front of the foundation shrubs or clustered around the mailbox post.

title: Check Offered To Resolve Jones Lawsuit
description: Abe Hirschfeld, who injected himself into the Paula Corbin Jones lawsuit, withdrew and then re-entered the picture today before television cameras here, where he made a symbolic presentation to Ms. Jones of a $1 million check as an incentive to help settle her sexual harassment lawsuit against President Clinton.

title: The Growing Factoring Factor: An Option for the Cash-Hungry
description: WITH credit tight and the market for initial public offerings bone-dry for all but the biggest deals, cash-starved small and midsize companies are hunting for alternative sources of money. Galloping into the breach are firms called factors, which buy companies' accounts receivable or lend against them.

title: Where Spanish Is Optional but Helpful
description: Fluency in Spanish is not required of customers at El Sur, the bookstore that opened two weeks ago at Bleecker Street and the Bowery, but it might help. The owner, Ernesto Mora, a former photojournalist who was born in Peru, said he hoped that El Sur would ''catch the interest of Latin American writers and readers,'' and that it was ''aimed at bilingual people.'' Many of its books are by Latin American writers and are published in Spanish, although the store also sells some English translations. Mr. Mora said he tried to feature writers not well known in the United States, including the Argentinian novelist Maria Granata and the journalist Martin Caparros, and the Mexican novelist Elena Poinatowska. El Sur also has children's books and CD's, including Latino jazz and rock, Spanish bands and traditional Cuban and Mexican recordings. ALEXANDRA McGINLEY

title: Italy Is Swamped by New Waves of Boat People
description: By day, this seaside resort town in southern Italy is a shuttered ghost town, with fewer than 700 inhabitants in the off-season.

title: 'Swan Lake': Is It Theater Or Dance, Gay Or Straight?
description: MATTHEW BOURNE's production of ''Swan Lake'' opened on Broadway as something of an anomaly. Word from Los Angeles, where the production played last year, was that the show was touching but campy. Earlier reviews in England, where the show originated, tended to dwell on what this ''Swan Lake'' was not, particularly among the older dance critics.

title: Getting Help Getting There
description: ONE of the most important things travelers buy with their vacation dollars is time -- the precious weeks, days or even hours in which they get to explore undiscovered horizons. That is why it is so annoying to become lost while on a driving trip: it's a particularly expensive waste of time.

title: Getting Attention
description: INSIDE TERRORISM

title: Not a Ghost Story
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CLINTON; New 'Jewel,' but at What Cost to the Homeless?
description: Teresa Mattia has witnessed many changes in the neighborhood since moving to West 39th Street from England 30 years ago. She's seen families, restaurants and entire buildings come and go.

title: Going Down Screaming
description: What a powerful message for the American electorate. Strong voter turnout is usually a disadvantage for any radical element with a cause. Those who do not exercise their right to vote this Election Day may wake up and find Representatives eager to roll back Roe v. Wade. They may also find Representatives who are against gun control, against protecting the environment, against financing for the International Monetary Fund and who think Ken Starr has done the country a great service. Heaven help us!

title: Finding Factoids, Made Easy
description: As long as he is traveling on official business, Robert W. Pittman, president of America Online, flies his own plane at company expense.

title: BEST SELLERS: November 1, 1998
description: Weeks

title: The Final Refrains of 'Dixie'
description: Not so long ago, it would have been considered an act of cultural treason: Allison Grisham, a white sorority sister at the University of Mississippi, stood onstage at Fulton Chapel and explained to a hushed crowd why it was so important for students and alumni at football games to stop waving the Confederate battle flag and singing ''Dixie.''

title: Sushi, Just the Way They Do It in Osaka
description: Although Roni Flancraich chose the name Osaka for the restaurant he opened three weeks ago, at 272 Court Street, near DeGraw Street, in Cobble Hill, he said he did not name it after the Japanese city, but for a type of sushi. Osaka-style sushi, Mr. Flancraich said, consists of large pieces of fish on smaller beds of rice. Tokyo-style sushi reverses the size of the portions: smaller pieces of fish on larger beds of rice. Though sushi is the house specialty, Osaka also features cooked selections including soba, udon and tempura dishes. Appetizers, including fluke with ponzu sauce and miso eggplant, are $3.95 to $9.95; entrees, among them sushi deluxe, buckwheat noodles with shrimp tempura and fish cakes, range from $9.95 to $29.95. Mr. Flancraich also owns the Bagel Point Cafe, at 231 Court Street near Baltic Avenue.

title: Trisha Perez, Michael Kennealy
description: Trisha Denise Perez, a daughter of Myrna and Luis Andres Perez of Lexington, Mass., was married yesterday to Michael John Kennealy, a son of Terese and Paul Kennealy of Reading, Mass. Rabbi Benjamin Z. Rudavsky officiated at the First Unitarian Parish Church in Lexington. The Rev. Daniel M. Graham, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: October 25-31; Apparent Starr Leaks Cited
description: Newly released documents showed that a Federal judge has ruled that prosecutors in the office of Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel investigating President Clinton, apparently leaked grand jury testimony or other secret information. The ruling by Judge Norma Holloway Johnson was based on a review of 24 news accounts about the inquiry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRINE, RUTH
description: BRINE-Ruth. Journalist, former senior editor TIME magazine and violinist in chamber music groups in New York City and Pawling, N.Y. On October 22, 1998 at home in Greenwich Village. Devoted wife of the late John K. Hutchens. Beloved mother of Brigid Gollogly and Kevin and Duncan Brine. Cherished mother-in-law of Gene Gollogly, Madeline Brine and Julia Brine. Loving and involved grandmother ''Uma'', of Lila, Mumu, Jamie and Colette Gollogly, Alexis and Lindsay Brine and Kyle and Alden Brine. memorial service on Thursday, November 19, at 6 P.M., at New York University Fales Library of the Elmer Holmes Bobst Library and Study Center, 3rd Floor, 70 Washington Square So.

title: An Apple For the Miracle Worker
description: When my younger son was in fourth grade, his music teacher invited him to play in the grade-school jazz band. The drummer, a sixth grader, was graduating to junior high, and the teacher, with whom my son was studying the clarinet, asked if he could learn drums in a hurry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLEN, BETTY
description: GALLEN-Betty, died peacefully at her home Friday, October 30, 1998. Beloved wife of Herbert for 61 years, loving mother of Joan Megibow and Nancy Scheriff, dear sister of Doris Konner, devoted grandmother to Terri and Andrew Megibow, Michael, Adam and Todd Runyon, Tracy and Megan Scheriff, adoring great-grandmother to Melissa and James Megibow, Jordan and Abigail Runyon. Services Sunday, November 1st, 9:30AM, Gutterman Musicant Funeral Home, Hackensack, NJ.

title: Silent Bond
description: I know from experience that illness can shift one's focus from the larger world to the smaller world. But so small that a man cannot verbalize his gratitude for his sisters' gift of caring -- not just Michele, who had matching marrow, but Lisa and Debbie for their unquestioning willingness, even eagerness, to help their brother?

title: October 25-31; Not Happy? Just Wait.
description: Ha! Those twentysomethings thought the world was their own private banana split, didn't they -- with their perfect skin, functioning knees and forests of silky hair. They thought the over-50 set was just drooling with envy.

title: The New, Unsinkable Stock Options
description: PAYING corporate employees with stock options is promoted as a way to align the interests of executives and other workers with those of shareholders. But while investors are encouraged to stick with a stock for the long term and to hold on tight if prices slide, many companies have developed a hair-trigger response to market dips when it comes to options pricing.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about investing in convertible bonds misstated their typical cost. It is $1,000 a bond, not $10,000, though it is usually practical to buy convertible bonds only in lots of $10,000 or more.

title: Hoffa Moves Closer To Life's Ambition
description: James P. Hoffa Jr., the favorite in the race for the teamsters presidency, is on the final leg of a feverish campaign that could make him one of the nation's most powerful union leaders. With a victory this week, he will achieve his life's ambition, taking the helm of the union that his famous father once headed.

title: Andrea Bergman And Craig Weiss
description: Dr. Andrea J. Bergman and Craig G. Weiss are to be married today by Rabbi Arthur Schwartz at the de Seversky Culinary Arts Center in Old Westbury, N.Y.

title: Safety Comes First
description: A Gallup poll conducted this year for Phi Delta Kappa, a professional association of educators, asked 1,151 Americans to make a list of the biggest problems confronting their local public and private schools. (The margin of error was plus or minus 4 percentage points.) Concerns about violence led the list. 1998 1997 % % Fighting/violence/gangs 15 12 Lack of discipline/ more control 14 15 Lack of financial support/funding/ 12 15 Use of drugs 10 14 Overcrowded schools 8 8 Concern about standards/ quality of education 6 8 Difficulty getting good teachers 5 3 Pupil's lack of interest/ attitudes/truancy 5 6 None 3 2 Don't know 16 10

title: Caesar's Other Palace
description: His mother cringes. His friends are horrified. And many visitors are flabbergasted at first, even if they warm up to it later. But Anthony Baratta doesn't care. It's his apartment and he'll overdecorate it if he wants to.

title: Uncommon Stories of Common People
description: THE story behind Diane Smith's weekly series on television station WTNH developing into a book is the kind of upbeat tale of Connecticut Yankee ingenuity that Ms. Smith would report herself, if she could.

title: When The Ends Don't Meet; In a City of Fat Cats, Some Wallets Are Paper Thin
description: IT was over in a flash. But to Amelia Garcia, the dream felt almost real, another painful moment from her waking life.

title: AT THE GATE: Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York; An Insurer's Transformation Is a Modest Bet
description: AFTER 155 years as a life insurance company that concentrated on providing policies at low cost rather than on turning a profit, the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York is preparing to enter the turbulent world of publicly traded companies.

title: In Peter Weir's Whodunit, an Otherworldly Force Did
description: A sweetly knowing look crosses the face of the lovely young Miranda. ''You must learn to love someone else apart from me, Sara,'' she says to a schoolmate. ''I won't be here much longer.'' It never becomes clear how Miranda knows that, but in Peter Weir's ''Picnic at Hanging Rock,'' as mysterious as ever in two new video editions, just about everything keeps us guessing.

title: Voices of Experience; What Old Age Is Really Like
description: The extraordinary attention paid to John Glenn's return to space is attributable to his status as an aging legend while his six fellow crew members are much younger ''heroes.'' This gallant act of his, despite what must be to him the distressing signs of an old body, has provoked celebratory writing about the glories of old age. Cameo biographies of elderly achievers have appeared, as if old age in itself was a preferable period of life.

title: Corrections
description: The front-page contents listing in the Arts & Leisure section today misstates the page number for a review of a video version of the Broadway musical ''Cats.'' It appears on page 12 of the section.

title: Word for Word/ESPN; Connectamundo! Or Pop! Go the Sports Anchors
description: MILLIONS of sports addicts tune into ESPN's ''SportsCenter'' for their daily fix of highlights, but it's a good bet not all of them fully understand everything the anchors say.

title: Cassatt Retrospective Opens in Chicago
description: ''No woman has the right to draw like that,'' said Edgar Degas of Mary Cassatt. Visitors can take the measure of her talent themselves when viewing ''Mary Cassatt: Modern Woman,'' her first major retrospective for nearly 30 years, at the Art Institute of Chicago. The exhibition, which opened on Oct. 13 and runs through Jan. 10, brings together about 100 paintings, pastels, drawings and prints from more than 40 museums and private collections.

title: Q&A/Karen Pollard; Public-Private Gains at New Waterbury Mall
description: FOR years, the drive past Waterbury on Interstate 84 was marred by the decrepit and decaying Scovill Manufacturing plant, where brass products once were made. Then Homart Inc., of Minneapolis, bought the site, proposing a mall. General Growth Properties Inc. of Chicago, in turn, bought out Homart in December of 1995. Last September, aided by $36 million in state and Federal funds, it completed the $160 million, 1.1 million-square-foot Brass Mills Center Mall and Commons on the site.

title: Parties Step Up Drives To Get Out Voters
description: STATE party leaders, worried that the lackluster gubernatorial campaign of Representative Barbara B. Kennelly and the impeachment investigation of President Clinton would discourage Democrats from going to the polls, intensified their efforts to get out the vote last week.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WILD ABOUT HORSES

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Ballot Issues in Tomorrow's Election; Vote Yes for Open Space in New Jersey
description: New Jersey residents will vote tomorrow on a proposed constitutional amendment that would allow $1 billion in borrowing to protect half of the state's remaining two million acres of undeveloped land over the next 10 years. We urge them to approve this measure, which represents Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's latest effort to preserve the state's threatened farmlands and other open space.

title: Five Boroughs and Thousands of Stories
Jefferson the Contradiction
description: The age of innocence is over, and none too soon. DNA evidence strongly suggesting that Thomas Jefferson fathered at least one child by his slave mistress, Sally Hemings, has seen to it. For centuries, through schools of clashing revisionist historians, the way Americans viewed themselves, their heritage and their times has been dominated by a simplistic vision that sharply distinguished between good and evil, freedom and slavery, heroes and villains, the noble of character and the hopelessly flawed.

title: Deadline Extended For Strawberry
description: The Yankees have extended the deadline for deciding on Darryl Strawberry's $2.5 million option from midnight last night until midnight Nov. 11. Because the 36-year-old outfielder and designated hitter underwent colon cancer surgery last month and is set to begin six months of chemotherapy treatments, it is a delicate decision for George Steinbrenner, the principal owner.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The complicated issue is: If a full week is 60 to 80 hours, what is part time?''

title: Hit by Hail and Imports, Apple Growers Leave New York's Eden
description: When a thunderstorm began swirling over the Slate Hill Orchard here late last spring, and the first pellets of hail struck, Jerre Telgheder thought his family-run business might still dodge disaster.

title: Media Talk; Men's Health: Versions 1 and 2
description: Sure, sex sells. But it sells better on the newsstand than it does to subscribers.

title: Five Boroughs and Thousands of Stories
Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFARB, DAVID B.
description: GOLDFARB-David B. On October 30. Husband of Barbara. Beloved father of Mark, Eric and Mary Ellen. Cherished grandfather of Sara, Spencer and Jamie. A dedicated attorney, CPA, accomplished musician, photographer and avid golfer who always had a funny word to brighten everyone's day. He will be terribly missed. Services Tuesday, 10 AM, at ''RiversideNassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to North Shore Child Guidance and Family Association.

title: Brazil Bailout: Too Soon to Worry
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELLS, HERTA G.
description: WELLS-Herta G. Beloved and loving mother of Nora (Ted) Weinreich, Peter (Joan) Wells; adored and adoring grandmother of Karen, Elizabeth, Ralph, David, Jennifer and Rebecca; and pre-deceased by her husband Egon F. Wells, died at her home in Miami, Florida, peacefully at 6 AM, Sunday, November 1, 1998. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Temple Emanu-El, New York City, Dayton Jewish Federation, or Miami City Ballet. Services Tuesday, November 3, 1 PM, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Saturday about a threat to contaminate Midwestern abortion clinics with anthrax mischaracterized the nature of anthrax. It is a bacterium, not a virus. The threat was found to be a hoax.

title: NBC Again Finds Itself on the Downside of Dominance
description: Only 18 months ago, NBC's executives were riding a wave of prime-time success that had raised the network to record-setting profits. The executives were so confident that they were occasionally suggesting that they did not merely want to be the No. 1 network; they wanted to be the only network.

title: A Doctor Whom Only A Cadaver Could Love
description: At the start of the premiere episode of the new sitcom ''Becker,'' Ted Danson defines the cantankerous title character by delivering the first of many diatribes. The subject of this first harangue is the abysmal state of television programming: ''It's like America stepped in something, and it's scraping off its shoe directly over my TV set.''

title: Five Boroughs and Thousands of Stories
BMC Is Expected to Buy Boole & Babbage
description: BMC Software Inc., a Houston-based software company, is expected to announce today that it is acquiring Boole & Babbage Inc., one of Silicon Valley's older companies, for nearly $1 billion in stock, people close to the companies said yesterday.

title: More Colleges Plunging Into Uncharted Waters of On-Line Courses
description: Spurred by fierce competition for students, colleges and universities from Florida State to New York University are plunging headlong into the rapidly evolving world of on-line education, a world that barely existed five years ago.

title: The Big City; Low Turnout? Try Free Food and Agitators
description: TODAY, millions of New Yorkers are preparing to exercise their precious constitutional right not to vote. Turnout in the city, traditionally lower than in the rest of the state and the nation, is expected to be no better tomorrow, with perhaps only a third of the electorate voting. This is entirely understandable to anyone who has gone to the polls here.

title: Shore Leave With Plenty of Bounce
description: American Ballet Theater's performance of ''Fancy Free'' on Friday night at City Center was the first time a ballet by Jerome Robbins had been performed in New York since he died in July.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: ROCK
description: Cranking Up the Shock Value And Making Sound to Squirm By

title: In Campaign for Governor, A Bitter Fight to the Finish
description: The ''victory tour'' buses glided into the Quincy town center this nippy, yellow-leaved afternoon, parked right near the 17th-century burial ground whose iron gate reads ''Dust thou art & unto dust thou shalt return,'' and disgorged dozens of very much alive Republican stalwarts.

title: This Year, the Wall Had Some Give
description: The Wall is the point in a marathon when the energy reserves empty and the body breaks down. Yesterday, in the New York City Marathon, the Wall had some give to it.

title: Editorial Observer; Jefferson and Sally Hemings, Together at Last?
description: Historians are spinning in their armchairs over the news that geneticists have turned up a match between a descendant of Thomas Jefferson and an offspring of Sally Hemings, the slave rumored for two centuries to have had a long-running affair with America's most celebrated President. Hero worshipers argued violently that the affair had not taken place, seeing Jefferson as pristine and above sex -- not just with a slave, but with anyone other than his wife. Faced with rumor and innuendo -- and no physical evidence -- even historians who believed in the affair took the position that we would never know the truth.

title: On Budget Surplus, A Hollow Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: A Trial as Mirror Reflecting Blacks' Self-Image
description: Barbara Montgomery sets the tone in the first minute of ''The Trial of One Shortsighted Black Woman vs. Mammy Louise and Safreeta Mae.'' Marcia L. Leslie's play is set in a courtroom, and the opening sentence is a marshal's call, ''All rise!'' Ms. Montgomery, as the judge, strides to the lip of the stage, glares at the audience and says: ''What kind of court is this? Now, I am going back out and when I return you will behave.'' Of course, everyone laughs, but when she returns, the audience members do rise. They then pay close attention to this often funny but deeply serious trial, and two hours later, when the last word is said, they rise again, with a great roar.

title: After Crackdown, Militant Group Threatens Arafat's Forces
description: Lashing back at a crackdown by the Palestinian Authority, the armed wing of the militant Islamic group Hamas warned today for the first time that it might turn its guns on Yasir Arafat's police force.

title: The Fight to Become Muhammad Ali
description: KING OF THE WORLD

title: Families Also Serve, Waiting to Give Hugs
description: Fred and Tina Blanchard had driven some 250 miles from Fairfax, Va., to watch their oldest daughter, Kimberly, run in her eighth New York City Marathon yesterday.

title: Media; The urban newspaper column flourished when the city was king. Times have changed.
description: NEWSPAPER column about newspaper columnists is not simply a self-referential exercise. It is an almost inevitable act of reverence, done when a notable columnist dies or retires or even quits under fire. The death in 1997 of Mike Royko of The Chicago Tribune and the recent disgrace of Mike Barnicle of The Boston Globe -- who made his final farewell on The Globe's Op-Ed page last week -- created an almost Pavlovian response, sending journalists scurrying back to the collected works of New York's Damon Runyon or Baltimore's H. L. Mencken.

title: China Blocks Chief of Independent Research Group From Traveling
description: The founder of an independent research group that was closed down by the Government last week has been refused permission to leave China, and his passport has been confiscated.

title: SPECIAL TODAY: THE NEW YORK CITY MARATHON
description: ONE SPRINTS, ONE ROMPS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, SIMON
description: GREENBERG-Simon. 84 years old. On October 31. Activist for progressive causes, attorney, and business executive. Sixty-year husband of Ruth. Father of Heywood, Eric, Roy, and Jon. Grandfather and great-grandfather. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Rabin's Lot Is Rancor, In Death As in Life
description: Three years after the assassination of Yitzhak Rabin, Israel held its first nationwide memorial for the former Prime Minister today, signaling a concerted effort to transform him from a partisan hero into a figure of consensus -- a national symbol of peace.

title: Green of an Unexpected Sort; Nature Carves a Niche in the Financial District
description: Autumn holds the tiny meadow in its thrall. Late-blooming asters carpet the field with flecks of white, while the last bursts of goldenrod sway in an ever chillier breeze. Plump warblers on their way south for the winter bob nervously around a black cherry sapling.

title: Media Talk; Former Esquire Editor May Move to Daily News
description: Edward Kosner, the former editor of Esquire magazine, has been negotiating with Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the owner of The New York Daily News, to become the editor in charge of revitalizing The Daily News's Sunday newspaper, according to people with knowledge of the discussions.

title: Egg Thrown on Halloween Sparks Fatal Fight
description: It has become a deadly Halloween tradition: pranksters toss eggs, their targets get mad and angry words are followed by shootings, stabbings and, sometimes, death.

title: On Budget Surplus, A Hollow Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: Struggling With Idea of a Modern Museum
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Briefing; This Runaway Race Is Now a Dead Heat
description: Iowa has not had a Democratic governor in 30 years. And when the current Governor, Terry E. Branstad, announced that he would retire this year and Jim Ross Lightfoot, a former Republican Congressman, said he would seek to succeed him, state Republican leaders figured they had a strong candidate who could keep the job under the party's control.

title: The Next Trouble Spot in the Balkans: Montenegro
description: As the white launch cut around the breakwater and made for the deep waters of the Adriatic Sea, the wind tangled a Yugoslav flag flying from the rigging. Krsta Niklacevic, who said he was on his way to help his elderly father bring in fish for their restaurant, leapt to clear the tangle and set the flag flying proudly again.

title: A Betrayal The Art World Can't Forget; The Battle for Rothko's Estate Altered Lives and Reputations
description: When the Whitney Museum of American Art entertained a crowd of 200 collectors and friends a few days before the official opening of its Mark Rothko retrospective in September, Dr. Kate Rothko, the artist's daughter, was one of the speakers. Trying to avoid controversy, she only alluded to the convoluted battle over her father's estate, a long-ago case of underhanded greed that bared the inner workings of the supposedly genteel art world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSBLATT, IDA
description: WEISSBLATT-Ida. Age 80. Died October 31, 1998, at home. Retired elementary school teacher. Wife of the late Paul Weissblatt. Survived by daughter, Rita Weissblatt of Pomona, NY, and son, Steven Weissblatt (Cindi), New City, NY. Grandmother of Paul and Wayne Weissblatt. Burial services at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

title: Internet Users In Germany Protest High Phone Rates
description: Joining a protest by Internet users that is gaining popularity in Europe, thousands of people and hundreds of World Wide Web site operators waged a one-day boycott of Germany's dominant telephone company today to object to high telephone and Internet access charges.

title: New Chill in China
description: A few months back there was reason to hope that Chinese authorities were modestly expanding the limits of acceptable political debate. Those expectations have been dashed by a new burst of arrests, detentions and censorship.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JOSEPH, PETER T.
description: JOSEPH-Peter T. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, November 5, at 4:00 PM, at City Center, W. 55th St., NYC. Contributions may be made to the Peter T. Joseph New Choreography Fund, American Ballet Theatre, 890 Broadway, NYC 10003.

title: Mexico City Journal; Let's All Do Lunch the Modern Way: Make It Fast
description: It's 3:30 P.M. and the Mexico City state's attorney, Samuel del Villar, is seated at a conference table in a meeting with a dozen subordinates. Nobody has eaten since breakfast, if then. Stomachs are growling.

title: Compressed Data; Cigarette Maker Gives Web Lesson in Quitting
description: It's not often that a tobacco company tries to teach people how to quit smoking. Still, Brown & Williamson, a unit of British American Tobacco P.L.C., which makes Kool cigarettes and other brands, has a section called ''Quitting Smoking'' on its Web site (www.brownandwilliamson.com) alongside information on matters like organizing your community to prevent smoking bans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, SHEILA
description: KAYE-Sheila. October 31, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Abner. Loving mother of Bruce. Dear sister of Lee, Sally and Morris. Cherished grandmother of Chelsea. Esteemed aunt of Joan, Eleanor, Sonny, Leonard, Freddie, Larry, Brian, Joyce and Roger. Sheila will be deeply missed by all those who knew her and loved her. Service Tuesday, 9:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: JAZZ
description: An Introspective Spirit Plays Harmonic Improvisation

title: Censure May Face Hurdle: The Constitution
description: As Congress ponders how to deal with the charges against President Clinton, several prominent legal scholars are warning that some of the proposals to censure the President in a compromise to avoid impeachment may be unconstitutional.

title: The F.C.C. Faces Internet Regulation
description: The emergence of the Internet is making intellectual contortionists out of people who try to regulate the communications industries in a fair and consistent manner.

title: Patents; Laboratory reproduction of patients' immune cells holds substantial therapeutic potential.
description: THE front-line soldiers of the body's immune system are the T-cells, which identify, attack and eradicate infection or disease. But like troops facing an enemy in battle, T-cells can be outnumbered. Cancerous cells or such viruses as H.I.V. can multiply and overwhelm them; once the immune system is thus disarmed, disease or infection can spread freely.

title: Sports of The Times; Impotent Play of Giants Puts Fassel on the Spot
description: HALFWAY through the season with a 3-5 record, there's no way the Giants will qualify for the Super Bowl XXXIII playoffs.

title: Counsel for Life?
description: To the Editor:

title: When Facts Alone Won't Do
description: My former colleagues at ABC News are upset that their parent network has asked Oliver Stone to develop a prime-time special on the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800. They fear that viewers might mistake some of Mr. Stone's notions -- say, the idea that the plane was brought down by missiles -- for the conclusions of the news department.

title: On Budget Surplus, A Hollow Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, MARIAN
description: SIEGEL-Marian. Of Great Neck and Boynton Beach. Died Saturday, October 31. Beloved wife of Jack. Loving mother of Henry, Marilyn, Janet and Jonathan. Grandmother of Lori, Kathryn, David, Zachary, Joshua, Jonah and Deborah. Memorial services were held in Florida.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: $1 Billion Acquisition Seen in Software Industry

title: Byron Janis, Back Onstage, Celebrates an Anniversary
description: In the 1950's and 60's, the pianist Byron Janis was regarded as one of the most powerful and eloquent interpreters of the Romantic repertory. He had an ironclad technique, a gargantuan sound, and his recordings from the time show a special connection to the music's emotional core. In the early 70's, psoriatic arthritis forced him to abandon the stage, and only in recent years has he reclaimed his technique sufficiently to return to performing.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Skip Away Heading Out With Impressive Time
description: Skip Away held his final workout today at Belmont Park before leaving for Kentucky and the final race of his career in the Breeders' Cup Classic on Saturday.

title: Space Makes His Faith Stronger, Glenn Says
description: Senator John Glenn said today his return to space has strengthened his religious faith and illustrated the benefits of cooperating with other nations in space instead of competing with them, as was the case in his first flight three decades ago.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paul Misraki, 90, a Composer of Songs and Soundtracks
description: Paul Misraki, a prolific French composer of songs and also of the soundtracks for over 150 films made by Orson Welles, Jean-Luc Godard, Roger Vadim and others, died on Thursday in Paris, where he lived. He was 90.

title: Bulldog Turner, 79, a Star For Bears and Hall of Famer
description: Bulldog Turner, the Chicago Bears Hall of Fame center and linebacker who played on four National Football League championship teams in the 1940's, died Friday at home in Gatesville, Tex. He was 79.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOREIN, SARAH
description: KOREIN-Sarah. On October 29, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Isidor. Loving mother of Julius and Elysabeth. Dear sister of Esther. Adoring grandmother of James, Jonathan, Beth and Peter; nine great-grandchildren. Private services.

title: Toddler Shoots Himself, And Parents Are Charged
description: A 2-year-old boy accidentally shot and wounded himself with a shotgun in his family's Bronx apartment yesterday, and his father was arrested last night on charges of weapons possession and child endangerment, the police said.

title: Ballot Issues in Tomorrow's Election; Vote No on New York City's 'Reform'
description: On tomorrow's ballot in New York City, there will be only one referendum proposal -- a hastily contrived campaign reform measure proposed by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's Charter Revision Commission. We strongly urge a ''no'' vote on this proposal. The City Council has recently enacted a far better, more balanced set of reforms that could be damaged or even ruined if the Mayor's charter proposal is approved.

title: On Budget Surplus, A Hollow Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in some editions on Thursday about arts events in New York marking the 150th anniversary of the Communist Manifesto misspelled the given name of Karl Marx's collaborator on the manifesto. He was Friedrich Engels, not Frederick.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, YVETTE
description: EISENBERG-Yvette. Our dear friend and former member of the Woodmere Club. Our deepest sympathy to the family. The Woodmere Club

title: TECHNOLOGY: Digital Commerce; In a society dependent on technology, reliability is paramount. Problem is, today's technology isn't reliable.
description: AS the romantic lead in that unfolding epic ''The New Economy,'' the technology industry's stage makeup may finally be melting under the hot lights.

title: Companies from drug makers to coffee sellers changed agencies at the end of October.
description: OCTOBER ended with tricks for some agencies and treats for others, as advertisers made decisions on accounts with total billings estimated at $210 million to $230 million.

title: Five Boroughs and Thousands of Stories
Flutie (5-9) Keeps His Record Perfect (5-0) in Buffalo
description: Every time Buffalo quarterback Doug Flutie makes your jaw drop with some fantastic play, which seemed like every five minutes against Miami this afternoon, the National Football League turns another shade of red. The league must be embarrassed by its banishing of Flutie to Canada for some 10 years because he is vertically challenged.

title: Ammirati Puris Reorganizes an Office
description: Ammirati Puris Lintas, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has announced a sweeping reorganization of its New York office that includes the replacement of the top creative executives and the shuffling of several other managers. The changes come two months after the appointment of Richard J. Hadala as chief executive of the office and Ammirati Puris North America.

title: Part-Time Work for Some Adds Up to Full-Time Job
description: Working part time used to mean afternoons at home or two or three days off a week. But as many Americans find themselves working weeks that stretch to 60 or more hours, ''part time'' can mean something very different: the ability to leave the office most nights at 5 or schedule a half-day off every other week.

title: Citigroup President, Heir Apparent to Top Job, Quits Abruptly
description: James Dimon, the president of Citigroup, the world's largest financial services company, said yesterday that he would leave the company, a surprising move that raises questions about who will ultimately be tapped to manage the sprawling giant created by the recent merger of Citicorp and Travelers Group Inc.

title: Heisman Chase in 4th Quarter
description: It is a slick calling card, a glossy photo with Ohio State's colors of crimson and silver nicely pulling out Joe Germaine's laser-locked brown eyes from behind his face mask. Heck, actors get auditions for television pilots with far less glamorous head shots. The copy on the 8-by-11 Heisman flier is concise. It pulls at blue-collar heartstrings.

title: A Fractured Fairy Tale: Redskins Tame the Giants
description: When it was over, when this wayward Giants season had sagged to a new low with the 21-14 loss to the heretofore victoryless Washington Redskins, Giants Coach Jim Fassel's face was blank of expression.

title: A Bicycle Path From Wall Street to Vietnam
description: In a steamy, windowless office at the United States Embassy in Hanoi in the summer of 1997, a top media investment banker helped negotiate a very different kind of deal.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: ROCK
description: Still Kinky and Corny After Fighting Personal Angst

title: Busy Treasury Sale Schedule This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week comprises today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and auctions of 5-year notes tomorrow, 10-year notes on Wednesday and 30-year bonds on Thursday.

title: Another Kind of Courage
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, JACK
description: BERNSTEIN-Jack. On November 1, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Sara. Loving father of Nathan. Dear brother of Debra and Evelyn. Service Tuesday, 11 AM, at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: In New Jersey, Tax Increases Get a 2d Look
description: New Jersey voters nearly ousted Gov. Christine Todd Whitman last year partly because they were unhappy about paying the highest property tax rates in the nation.

title: Fiber Optic Data-Transmission Technology Arouses Skepticism in the Industry
description: The telecommunications industry is expressing curiosity and skepticism about a little-known San Diego start-up company that says it is ready to market a technology that significantly increases the amount of data that can be sent over fiber optic cables.

title: Negotiations Resume Today
description: With the start of the season still in the balance, the National Basketball Association's commissioner, David Stern, and his legal team are scheduled to meet today with Billy Hunter, the union's executive director, and his legal team in Manhattan.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Warning to Iraq

title: Compressed Data; Motorola Organizes Cable Modem Conference
description: If you thought the cable industry was confusing enough already, hold on to your remotes. Sometime early next year, an assortment of companies will start hawking data cable services and technology at your local consumer electronics store, a move sure to stir things up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWRENCE, BARBARA CHILDS
description: LAWRENCE - Barbara Childs. Died peacefully at her home, South Pole Farm in Norfolk, Connecticut on October 23, 1998 at the age of 86. She was the widow of James F. Lawrence and was predeceased by two children, Peter F. Lawrence & Jane Lawrence Mali. She is survived by four children: Barbara L. Garside, J. Vinton Lawrence, Suzannah L. Wood all of Norfolk; and Starling R. Lawrence of New York City and 13 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at The Church of Christ Congregational in Norfolk at noon Saturday, November 21. Please omit flowers., Contributions in her memory may be made to the Norfolk library.

title: 49ers Find A Nemesis Lurking in Green Bay
description: It used to be Dallas.

title: Web Spreads the Word at a Speed Pheidippides Never Dreamed Of
description: Thousands of people, including many overseas, who could not follow the New York City Marathon yesterday on television or radio were able to read personal messages from their friends, relatives and loved ones sent from the course with a bit of digital derring-do.

title: Sports of The Times; Testaverde And Jets Still Keep Bubble Intact
description: EVERYBODY has been waiting for the Jets' bubble to burst; Vinny Testaverde's bubble in particular. Nothing personal, it's just that the residue of so many years of grimy play, grimy coaching is so thick that it can't all be scraped away in one season.

title: Fiacconi Chases Down Loroupe
description: Franca Fiacconi looks as if she had just stepped off the cover of an Italian fashion magazine. But she runs with the fierceness of Orlando Pizzolato, Gianni Poli and Giacomo Leone, countrymen who have won the New York City Marathon.

title: On Budget Surplus, A Hollow Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: Victim of Imperfection
description: To the Editor:

title: Happy National Apathy Day
description: Don't vote. You don't have to. No one's going to make you. This isn't the Soviet Union in the 50's. You won't be forced from your bed and dragged to the polls against your will. Relax. None of your friends are voting. And things are pretty good the way they are, right? If it ain't broke, don't fix it. What do you care if some barren deserted beach does or doesn't get blanketed by a thick film of 30-weight because of offshore drilling? Find another beach. What's the big deal?

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Thursday about negotiations between the National Basketball Association owners and their locked-out players misstated the age of Abe Pollin, owner of the Washington Wizards. He is 74, not 78.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVENTHALL, DONALD I.
description: LAVENTHALL-Donald I. On October 31, 1998, in New York, NY, after a long illness bravely borne. Beloved husband of Susan. Dearest father of Donald, Max, Danielle and Gillian, and stepfather of Tamar. Father-in-law of Cliff, Mark, Jeff, William and Donna. Adored grandfather of Sarah, Clint, Alyssa and Caroline. Dear son of Mary and brother of Frank. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Tuesday, November 3 at 3 PM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Five Boroughs and Thousands of Stories
Political Briefing; A Suicide Measure? Not for Kevorkian
description: It is Dr. Jack Kevorkian's home state, but in Michigan a ballot measure that would legalize physician-assisted suicide seems headed for defeat on Tuesday.

title: Five Boroughs and Thousands of Stories
All Ears on an Opera Recently Linked to Mozart
description: It was almost ''Man Bites Dog.'' Listeners who had filled Jordan Hall at the New England Conservatory here on Friday to savor newly discovered Mozart not only endured but also applauded at every opportunity a long evening of music by obscure figures like Johann Baptist Henneberg, Benedikt Schack, Franz Xaver Gerl and Emanuel Schikaneder.

title: Man Refuses to Talk to Police About Missing Student
description: A man who went out with a pregnant Baruch College student on the afternoon she vanished 10 days ago has hired a lawyer and refused to talk to the police about her disappearance or her family's assertions that he fathered her unborn child and, against her wishes, wanted it aborted, investigators said yesterday.

title: Five Boroughs and Thousands of Stories
Kagwe Wins in 2d-Closest Finish
description: After 26 miles of distance running accelerated into a grimacing sprint to the finish yesterday, John Kagwe of Kenya repeated as champion of the New York City Marathon. And for that, he can thank the British Royal Family.

title: Five Boroughs and Thousands of Stories
Paid Notice: Deaths  NOBBE, GEORGE, JR.
description: NOBBE-George, Jr. Died at Pawling, NY, of cancer, serenely and surrounded by friends, October 31, 1998. Born NYC, September 19, 1935. He attended St. Luke's School, New Canaan, CT; St. George's School, Newport, RI; Harvard College (Class of 1956); and Columbia University School of Journalism. Distinguished feature writer and editor at The New York News. Newspaperman, conservation journalist, gifted professor of English, champion of wildlife particularly bears. We rejoice in the privilege of having known George and mourn him privately, according to his wishes. The Loving Friends of George Nobbe

title: Next Year Finally Arrives, And It Proves Quite Painful
description: Everything hurts.

title: Police Make Arrest In Sexual Attack in Park
description: A Bronx man was arrested and accused of sexually assaulting a 47-year-old woman in Central Park yesterday, the police said.

title: Rowland Campaign Begins an Early Victory Tour
description: Gov. John G. Rowland strode triumphantly among Republicans twirling New Year's-style noisemakers at rallies in three packed halls today, while his challenger, United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, motored across the state to thank her supporters for their loyalty.

title: Leery of Backfiring TV Ads, Interest Groups Return to Doorbell, Phone and Pamphlet
description: On the third floor of an old house here, Boyd McCamish unfurled a computer sheet listing his fellow members of Local 204 of the United Food and Commercial Workers Union. And he started dialing the phone.

title: O'Connor Speaks on Abortion but Makes No Endorsements
description: In a carefully worded appeal to Catholic voters, John Cardinal O'Connor yesterday accused abortion rights groups of capitalizing on the killing of a Buffalo obstetrician by making political candidates who oppose abortion ''appear to be a threat to freedom and to human life.''

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption yesterday about DNA tests that offer evidence that Thomas Jefferson fathered a child by a slave misidentified the hometown of John Jefferson, a man believed to be one of the child's descendants. He lives in Norristown, Pa., not Norrisville.

title: Struggling With Idea of a Modern Museum
description: To the Editor:

title: Cheating Theatergoers
description: To the Editor:

title: Eyes on the Prize
description: Meghan Howell said she was taught never to look over her shoulder in a race. Had she done so in yesterday's pre-marathon high school competition, she would have seen practically no one.

title: Sports of The Times; Reaching Back to the Past, Samuelson Hits Her Goal
description: ALMOST out of thin air and certainly right out of the glory days of American marathoners, Joan Benoit Samuelson appeared at the finish line early in Central Park yesterday afternoon, a cramping inspiration to the aging athlete and to the graying soccer mom.

title: Five Boroughs and Thousands of Stories
Paid Notice: Deaths  BOSKEY, SHIRLEY ECKER
description: BOSKEY-Shirley Ecker. Age 80 on October 13, 1998. Survived by husband Bennett Boskey, her brother Allan B.
