Ecker of New York City, her sister Laura Ecker Ludwig of New York City, her nieces Lisa Ludwig Kahn of San Francisco, Amy Ludwig of Chicago, and Sarah Rice Ecker Cooper of Houston, and her nephew Andrew Ludwig of New York City. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to and would be welcomed by Recording For The Blind & Dyslexic of Metropolitan Washington, 5225 Wisconsin Avenue, N.W. Washington, D.C. 20015, a significant charitable activity for the benefit of vision-disadvantaged individuals and one of Mrs. Boskey's abiding interests.

title: Market Place; Time Warner's Magic Kingdom
description: Suddenly on Wall Street, it's the wonderful world of Time Warner.

title: Brazil Bailout: Too Soon to Worry
description: To the Editor:

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: A Zany Food Fight To Music By Beethoven

title: Devils Improve as Andreychuk Displays His Old Form
description: Fourteen goals in 75 games is not the kind of goal production that supporters of Dave Andreychuk have been accustomed to, but that was what he got last year. It was his worst goal production in 15 full seasons in the National Hockey League.

title: Five Boroughs and Thousands of Stories
Seoul's Luckless Feel Pain And Look to Orphanages
description: Crouching by the door in his brown pants and pink hand-me-down shirt, Han Seung Ghil might have been preparing for his first day of kindergarten as he stared around the brightly painted room at the tangle of other boys jumping around him.

title: Planned TV Channels Raise Gender Stereotype Worries
description: Decades after the rise of feminism, America still has a few dozen all-women colleges, hundreds of all-girls schools, the Girl Scouts and scads of magazines, books, movies and toys made especially for girls. Why not a television network?

title: Clinton and Gingrich Press Cases
description: In his final barnstorming trip of the campaign year, President Clinton today invoked Newt Gingrich, Martin Luther King Jr. and Rosa Parks in an impassioned plea that was part of a full-scale drive by Democrats to spur turnout by black voters in the election on Tuesday.

title: Talks on Global Warming Treaty Resuming Today
description: International negotiators will resume talks on Monday in Buenos Aires over details in the treaty to fight global warming, but with their expectations sharply lowered.

title: Runners Used Minds, Not Just Bodies, to Reach Finish
description: Lynne Madison of Portola Valley, Calif., stood past the finish line of the 29th New York City Marathon yesterday in a state of blissful fatigue. She'd run 3 hours 48 minutes, close to her best time, and had reveled in the good, clear weather while feeding off the cheers of the spectators.

title: Short But Sweet
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Five Boroughs and Thousands of Stories
Golisano May Lag in Polls, But His Stock Is Way Ahead
description: B. Thomas Golisano, a wealthy Rochester businessman, is spending $20 million of his fortune on a third-party campaign for Governor that nobody seems to think he can win.

title: Wringing Hands But Wringing Jokes From Clinton Saga
description: A gray-wigged Bill Clinton impersonator wobbles and lurches, bug-eyed and horrified, from one sexual malapropism to another. He sings ''If I Was a Rich Man,'' from ''Fiddler on the Roof,'' in a suggestive Yiddish-sounding muddle of imaginary body parts. Two reporters happen upon Monica Lewinsky and Paula Jones, and they all break into a randy version of ''Chattanooga Choo Choo'' about seeing something other than a train. Can this still be funny? Apparently so, if the reaction of audiences at the Chicago City Limits comedy review ''Subpoenas Envy'' is any indication. The question that arises is if everyone is so sick of Washington's endless sexual soap opera, how come there is always room for one more good cigar or dry cleaning joke at the expense of the Big He?

title: 26 Miles in Words and Pictures
description: Thanks to pleasant weather, yesterday's New York City Marathon production on Channel 11 went smoothly. Only a few times did the transmission from the on-course cameras that transmit their signals to hovering helicopters break up.

title: Troubling Ties That Bind
description: Marcus Camby has confined himself to the grounds of a rambling estate he has rented near the Knicks' practice facility in Purchase, N.Y. Barely visible from the road, a stone-and-iron gate marks the passage to the walled-off world Camby seldom leaves at night.

title: Vallone Debates Alone as Pataki Draws Fire from Golisano for Ad Campaign
description: Peter F. Vallone, the Democratic candidate for Governor, debated what he called ''an empty chair'' yesterday, participating in a televised forum without his Republican opponent, Governor George E. Pataki, who skipped the event and stumped upstate.

title: Step by Step, Inch by Inch, Jets Are Finding Ways to Win
description: The Jets learned something else about Vinny Testaverde today. He can carry them even when Curtis Martin struggles.

title: Insider and Outsider Advise Hyde Panel
description: Representative Henry J. Hyde is counting on an insider and an outsider in the impeachment investigation of President Clinton.

title: Japan Financial Institutions Weigh Merger
description: Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd., Japan's third-largest lender, and Fuji Bank Ltd., the sixth largest, have said they are considering joining forces with the Yasuda Trust and Banking Company in a trust-banking venture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWYER, BERNARD J.
description: DWYER-Bernard J. Age 77, of Metuchen, NJ, on October 31, 1998. Former U.S. Congressman from 1980-1993. Former N.J. State Senator, Majority Leader, 1973-1980. Husband of the late Lilyan (1993). Father of Pamela D. Stockton of Harrison, NY. Grandfather of Nicholas and Hope Stockton. Brother of Bernice Dwyer of Edison, NJ. Funeral Wednesday, 9:15 AM, from the Flynn & Son Funeral Home, 23 Ford Ave., Fords, followed by a 10 AM Mass at St. Mary's R.C. Church, Perth Amboy, NJ. Interment will follow in St. Gertrude's Cemetery, Colonia, NJ. Visitation Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to J.F.K. Medical Center Foundation, 80 James St., Edison, NJ 08818-9972.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERZON, HAROLD
description: BERZON-Harold. Devoted husband of Kaye. Loving father of Steven, Laura and Alison. Cherished grandfather of Stephanie and Daniel. Dear brother of Shirley Kochmann. Service 1 PM today, ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYPOLITE, OSMOND
description: HYPOLITE-Osmond. On October 30, 1998. Beloved husband of Ellen (nee Pierce). Loving father of William, Roslyn (Patricia), Claire (Ella), Cecil and Judith Salisbury. Fond brother of Cynthia McAuley and Kathleen Hypolite. Also survived by three grandchildren, one great-granddaughter and many nieces and nephews. Funeral from the McManus Funeral Home, 2001 Flatbush Ave., on Wednesday, 9 AM. Funeral Mass 9:45 AM, Mary Queen of Heaven Church. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery. Visiting hours Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: AUTO RACING: ROUNDUP
description: AC Delco 400

title: Wheelchair Athletes Get an Unwanted Break
description: A controversy broke out involving top wheelchair athletes at the New York City Marathon yesterday when all but the first two of the wheelchair racers, who started 10 minutes in front of everyone else, were stopped by police at the 15-mile mark for up to 35 minutes to allow the lead packs of men and women -- and the 30 trucks, motorcycles and police vehicles accompanying them -- to cross the Queensboro Bridge first.

title: Nancy Van Norman Baer, 55, A Curator of Dance and Theater
description: Nancy Van Norman Baer, the curator of theater and dance at the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, died on Tuesday at the California Pacific Medical Center in San Francisco. Ms. Baer was 55 and lived in San Francisco.

title: Corrections
description: The ''Making Books'' column on Thursday, about the popularity of cookbooks, misspelled the surname of the author of ''A Spoonful of Ginger,'' a book of recipes applying tenets of traditional Chinese medicine that is to be published in the spring by Knopf. She is Nina Simonds, not Simond.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about ethnic theater in the New York region misspelled the given name of the founder of the Pan Asian Repertory. She is Tisa Chang, not Tisha.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: New Ideas About Old Signals
description: There are some 200,000 serious players in North America, but probably not one in a hundred has noticed an obvious fact about the hands they pick up: Every 13-card hand has either three suits with an odd number of cards and one with an even number, or vice versa.

title: In the Battle Over Affirmative Action, Telephones Are Ringing Off the Hook
description: With a recent poll suggesting that the battle over whether to end most state affirmative action programs here in Washington was tightening, forces on both sides of the issue hit the streets on this final campaign weekend. But to a much greater degree, it seemed, they hit the telephones.

title: Media Talk; A War Photograph Leads to False Trail
description: For three decades, a Vietnam War photograph taken by Frank Johnston had been a famous image of a nameless man. But in July, The Washington Post published 15,000 words about an ex-marine's search for his dead brother's war. It was built around the belief of the man, Rob Sutter of Atlanta, that Mr. Johnston's image showed his brother, Richard.

title: Equity Offerings Listed
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Five Boroughs and Thousands of Stories
description: 8000 Lonieski, K, 30M 3:50:49

title: Where the Candidates Stand
description: B. Thomas Golisano

title: U.S. Asserts It Will Consider Raids Unless Iraq Backs Down
description: The Clinton Administration said today that it would consider military strikes against Iraq if President Saddam Hussein does not back down from his decision to halt all cooperation with United Nations weapons inspectors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, SIDNEY
description: GROSSMAN-Sidney. Of Greenwich, CT, and Palm Beach, FL, died October 31, 1998. He is survived by his wife Rose, daughters Dale Claman and Marlene Green, and son Lee, and his sister Freida Olim. Also survived by five grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Memorial service today at 10 AM, Temple Sholom, Greenwich, CT.

title: Popularity of Ballot Initiatives Leads to Questions
description: For Washington State residents who step into the polling place here on Tuesday, deciding whom to vote for may be the simple part. Then there are the whethers: whether to ban most forms of state-sponsored affirmative action; whether to approve the use of marijuana for medical purposes; whether to make it a felony crime to terminate ''a fetus's life during the process of birth''; and whether to raise the state's minimum wage and, for the first time in any state, require automatic future increases tied to the inflation rate.

title: Sinn Fein Leader Says He'll Urge I.R.A. Not to Retaliate for Killing
description: Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, said today that he would appeal to the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic guerrilla organization not to retaliate for the killing, apparently by Protestants, of a Catholic man in Belfast early Saturday morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBLATT, DONALD H.
description: WEINBLATT-Donald H. Age 72. Of Highland Park, IL. Beloved husband of Sharon. He was a chemical engineer and Director of Environmental Affairs at Aimcor and a graduate of Cooper Union in NYC. Memorials to the Cancer Wellness Center in Northbrook, IL. For information, 815-886-2000.

title: Parties Pushing Message: Your Vote Counts
description: In a day of old-style politicking, Representative Charles E. Schumer campaigned for the Senate in black, Jewish and Hispanic neighborhoods across New York City yesterday, bringing in Vice President Al Gore in an attempt to rally support in tomorrow's election. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato went to Orthodox Jewish communities in Brooklyn, portraying himself as an underdog in the final weekend of the bruising race.

title: With Poise and Precision, Sutton Wins Playoff
description: It has been a long road back for Hal Sutton, but today his journey was both memorable and rewarding.

title: Five Boroughs and Thousands of Stories
Mayor's Campaign Finance Plan Challenges the Council's
description: Less than two weeks after the City Council adopted new campaign finance rules, residents will vote tomorrow on an entirely different system.

title: IN THE CAMPAIGNS
description: REVERSAL IN IOWA? In a state that has not had a Democratic governor in 30 years, Republican leaders figured they would keep the job. But that is now in question. Page A20.

title: Compressed Data; Lifetime Internet Access Faces Uncertain Future
description: Just how long is a lifetime on the Internet? About 21 months, if you ask Atbigger.net. In early 1997, the San Jose, Calif., Internet service provider promised unlimited lifetime Internet access for a one-time fee of $59, plus another $10 for a lifetime E-mail account. Nearly 20,000 people believed it, hoping to rid themselves forever of those pesky $19.95-a-month access fees. But as it turns out, the company did not have the technology, or the management, to succeed. Last week, company executives filed for bankruptcy. But at the last minute, a buyer appeared: Brigadoon.com, an Internet service provider in Bellevue, Wash., paid an undisclosed sum for the company's assets and has vowed to keep the company alive. LAURIE J. FLYNN

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSSI, FRANK P.
description: ROSSI-Frank P. A retired President and Chief Operating Officer of the Sperry and Hutchinson Co., died Thursday at home. Beloved husband of the late Dolores Gill. Dear father of Caroline Carroll and Sarah Gindel. Grandfather of nine, great-grandfather of four. Funeral will be private at the request of the family.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Democratic Governors Risk Further Decline
description: Building on his background as a popular Democratic Mayor of this Sunbelt city, Martin Chavez would like to picture himself as New Mexico's future governor. But with his wire-rimmed glasses and the beleaguered status of Democrats in the region, political cartoonists might sketch him as a New Mexican spotted owl.

title: Limits on Parole Dash Refugees' Hopes
description: It was an unusually grim October at the immigration detention center in Jamaica, Queens.

title: By Unanimous Decision, Hamed Was Mediocre
description: It did not take long for Prince Naseem Hamed to recover from the boos that rained down on him from the crowd of 8,138 at the Atlantic City Convention Center on Saturday night. Only an hour after his unspectacular 12-round unanimous decision over Wayne McCullough, Hamed was threatening to knock out Angel Manfredy, the junior-lightweight dynamo who will fight Floyd Mayweather Jr. on Dec. 12.

title: Toronto's Newspaper War
description: When Conrad Black, one of the world's most powerful media barons, decided to start a national daily newspaper in Canada, he knew he had to do it in Toronto, the country's largest city and one of the most competitive newspaper markets in North America.

title: Five Boroughs and Thousands of Stories
Peter Griffin, Solver of Blackjack, Dies at 61
description: Peter Griffin, who called himself a simple algebra teacher but had such a winning way with numbers that he unlocked the mathematics of blackjack with a wink and became a cult figure to a generation of casino card counters, died on Oct. 18 at a hospital near his home in Sacramento, Calif. Mr. Griffin, who wrote the authoritative ''Theory of Blackjack,'' was 61 and had taught algebra and a good deal more as a professor of mathematics at the California State University there.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Oct. 17 about Brandeis University referred incorrectly to a trustee committee in the late 1980's that examined strategic planning, including ways to attract more non-Jewish students. The committee had no student members and no formal name; ''dejudification'' was a pejorative term used by critics.

title: After Stumping in House Races, Gore Has a Good Word for 2 Senate Candidates
description: After spending much of the fall campaigning for Democrats locked into close House races, Vice President Al Gore widened his reach today to help two Democrats who are fighting to secure seats in the Senate.

title: Compressed Data; Dell Edges Out Compaq In Business Market
description: Market research figures released last week showed that the Dell Computer Corporation has pulled ahead of its archrival, the Compaq Computer Corporation, in America's business computer market. Dell's 18.9 percent share in the third quarter edged out Compaq's 18.4 percent. Though that may look like a measly spread, it is huge for Dell, which has been coming in second for years.

title: Political Briefing; Pushing the Race For Crossover Voters
description: With the governor's race in Georgia too close to call, both the Republican candidate, Guy Millner, and the Democratic candidate, state Representative Roy Barnes, are scouring about for every possible vote, especially crossover votes.

title: To a Man, the Jets Feel the Thrill
description: Make no mistake not only Coach Bill Parcells, but also every Jet player felt yesterday was their biggest victory of the new era.

title: Five Boroughs and Thousands of Stories
description: 4000 Marcotullio, J, 32M 3:30:56

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALOMON, ROSALIND
description: SALOMON-Rosalind. Died peacefully on October 30, 1998 at the age of 93. She was the beloved wife of the late Gustav Salomon, M.D. The loving mother of Alice and Seymour Rothman and Caryl and George Bernstein. Grandmother of Ellen and Richard Passov, Mark and Phyllis Terry, Alexander Rothman and Nina Sayer, Catherine and David Brous, Jr., and greatgrandmother of Gus Passov and Noah Rothman. Services were held on Sunday.

title: All in the Family: Avoiding the Boredom of Normality
description: If, like me, you saw Todd Solondz's ''Happiness,'' Tracy Letts's ''Killer Joe'' and the Farrelly brothers' ''There's Something About Mary'' in one week, you, too, might be tempted into some portentous sociological phrase-making.

title: Montgomerie Gains Sixth Vardon Trophy in a Row
description: If the Scotsman Colin Montgomerie looked and sounded triumphant today, it was not because he had won the Volvo Masters.

title: Antitrust Case Is Highlighting Role of E-Mail
description: The outcome of the Microsoft antitrust case may be a long way off, but one thing is already clear: this is the first major E-mail trial.

title: Elgar With a Difference, As Played by Kennedy
description: The buzz at the New York Philharmonic this weekend was over Kennedy, the British violinist who, like artists before him as different as Madonna and Midori, has dropped his given name (Nigel). His performance with the orchestra as soloist in Elgar's Violin Concerto, conducted by Leonard Slatkin, was his first concert appearances in New York since 1992, and the first since his five-year self-imposed exile from classical music, during which he mostly played in rock clubs.

title: Last-Minute Frenzy Of Crucial Nagging And Tele-Pleading
description: By last night's end, Michael P. Leone, a bank loan coordinator who is working on the side as a Democratic Party organizer, had sent a battalion of more than 500 volunteers marching across Rochester and its suburbs to pass out 70,000 fliers urging voters to go to the polls and vote for Representative Charles E. Schumer and other Democrats.

title: Strahan's Back Acts Up Again
description: The Giants' Pro Bowl defensive end, Michael Strahan, left after the second play of yesterday's game with what the team at first termed a strained lower back and later called back spasms.

title: Still in Debate: Shostakovich, Loyal Son or Not?
description: The stage was set for a donnybrook, academically speaking. The American Musicological Society held its annual meeting here this weekend for the first time since the 1981 gathering, with its great debate between Joshua Rifkin, who argued that Bach would have performed his ''choral'' works with only one singer to a part, and Robert Marshall, who vehemently disputed any such notion. That session almost came to blows, current myth holds, though Mr. Rifkin denies it.

title: Man, Shot by the Police, Is Charged With Assault
description: A homeless man who was stopped by the police while trying to break into a Queens home early yesterday was shot in the ankle by officers after the man threatened them with a sharpened screwdriver, the police said.

title: All the Latest Polls Showing Schumer and D'Amato Tied
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and his Democratic challenger, Representative Charles E. Schumer, remain virtually tied in the race for United States Senate, according to the latest polls, while Gov. George E. Pataki maintains a substantial lead over his Democratic challenger, Peter F. Vallone.

title: SUNY Taking Step to Court More Out-of-State Students
description: Nearly a decade ago, the New York Board of Regents barred Whittle Communications's Channel One news program from the state's public schools because of its advertising content. The ban still stands.

title: Essay; Sallygate
description: Of all the journalists in history, the one most heatedly maligned by historians is James Thomson Callender.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Circuits on Thursday about an anti-spamming lawsuit misstated the jurisdiction. It was Washington, not Oregon.

title: Disunited Rebels Share One Goal: Ousting Kabila
description: There is not much in their resumes to unite the leaders of the three-month-old rebellion in this huge, and hugely combustible, nation at Africa's heart.

title: Sandwiching Bartoks Between Stravinskys
description: In an age of thematic programming, here was a concept waiting to happen: an in-depth comparison of pivotal works by Bartok and Stravinsky. The two composers, who used to be mentioned in the same breath, have drifted apart of late, with Bartok tending to be seen as a feisty yet isolated and vaguely antiquated folklorist, Stravinsky as a lofty, clearheaded international modernist. But as the music historian Richard Taruskin has repeatedly shown, the difference was not as great as an older Stravinsky, grown scornful of his Russian roots, liked to pretend.

title: Flood Toll Estimate Rises Above 1,000 In Central America
description: Intense and widespread flooding in the wake of Hurricane Mitch has killed more than a thousand people in Central America, with hundreds more still missing, their villages buried under huge mudslides, relief and government officials said today.

title: Five Boroughs and Thousands of Stories
description: 18000 Boulanger, D, 46M 4:28:36

title: Spitzer Takes His Campaign to Black Congregation in Queens
description: Trying to play to his strengths as the election approaches, Eliot L. Spitzer, the Democratic candidate for state attorney general, campaigned at the Cathedral of the Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church in Queens yesterday and urged the black congregation to go to the polls on Tuesday.

title: Getting Out the Vote Amid Spirited Cries of 'Amen!'
description: When Georgia's Democratic nominee for governor, Roy E. Barnes, took his seat early this morning in the historic old sanctuary at Ebenezer Baptist Church -- the pulpit once occupied by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., his father and his grandfather -- the parishioners were already swaying to the pulse of a favorite hymn.

title: In a Boneyard for Paupers, Signs of Honor and Respect
description: In a graveyard where rows of crosses lean left and right, where one-inch-thin headstones bow to the dirt or tilt toward the sky and misspelled missives to the dead are inked onto rotted plywood markers, Cleveland Cobb spent a long time making sure he got the flowers just right.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, LEONARD M.
description: GOLD-Leonard M. On October 29, 1998. Beloved husband of Lois M. Adored father of Eric M. Devoted son of Martha R. and the late Samuel M. Loving brother of Martin R. & uncle to David and Jonathan Gold and Joshua Stephens. A man of great sensitivity and love for his family and friends, he will be greatly missed by all of us. Service on Monday, November 2, at 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Donations in his memory may be made to the American Brain Tumor Association, 2720 River Road, Des Plaines, IL 60018-4110 or a charity of your choice.

title: U.S. Signs Accord to Protect Israel From Mass-Destruction Arms
description: President Clinton and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyhau signed an agreement this weekend that officials in both countries described as a significant strengthening of the American commitment to safeguard Israel's security from the threats of a post-Soviet world.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FURST, HARVEY
description: FURST-Harvey, 78 years. On November 1st, 1998. Beloved father of Mark and Toni. Cherished grandfather of Elizabeth & David. Devoted companion of Ray Lahnstein of 18 years. Services today at Mount Carmel Cemetery, Queens, New York, at 11 A.M.

title: When Part-Time Work Is Really Full Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Red Storm Prevails In Overtime
description: St. John's needed five minutes of overtime to pull out a victory in an exhibition game over Marathon Basketball last night. And Mike Jarvis needed nearly a half hour in the Alumni Hall locker room with his team afterward to get across the message that there is still a lot for the young team to learn.

title: A Bookish Advocate for His Union's Rights
description: IT was, Ray Markey admitted, a ''typical librarian thing to do.'' When a long series on the troubling allegations surrounding the municipal labor movement was recently printed in The Village Voice, the staff of the librarians' union, ever the dutiful researchers, snatched it off the Internet, printed it out, and sent it to the union's 1,850 members.

title: Officers in Louima Case Seek to Move Trial
description: The lawyer for the police officer accused of playing the prime role in the reported torture of Abner Louima at a Brooklyn police station asked yesterday that his client's trial be held outside New York City and that he be tried separately from other officers charged in the case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIMMO, RICHARD F.
description: NIMMO-Richard F. ''Dick'' 82, of NYC, formerly of Stamford, CT. Passed away peacefully Sunday, November 1, 1998 at the Actor's Home in Englewood, NJ. Beloved husband of the late Joan (nee Etchinson). Loving father of Robert of River Vale, NJ, Joan of West New York, NJ and the late Richard F., II. Cherished grandfather of Diana and Richard. Dear father-inlaw of Elyn, dear brother of the late William. Dick retired in 1997, he was a 51 year member of Theatrical Protective Union, Local One I.A.T.S.E. He began his career in the infancy of television and served, with distinction, as Television Business Manager for Local One for 26 years. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Richard F. Nimmo Scholarship Fund, c/o Local One, I.A.T.S.E., 320 West 46 Street, NY, NY 10036. Family will receive friends Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9 at Buckley Funeral Home, 445 West 43 Street, NYC. Service Wednesday 10AM followed by interment at Fairfield Memorial Park, Stamford, CT.

title: CELESTICA TO ACQUIRE ANOTHER COMPUTER PARTS MAKER
description: Celestica Inc., a maker of parts for computer and electronics companies, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire International Manufacturing Services Inc., a smaller rival, for about $160 million to gain plants and customers in Asia. The price includes the the assumption of $20 million in I.M.S. debt and its stock options. Celestica, which is based in Toronto, is a former unit of the International Business Machines Corporation and employs 10,000 people. I.M.S. is based in San Jose, Calif., and employs 3,500. Shares of Celestica fell $62.5 cents, to $17.6875, on the New York Stock Exchange. I.M.S. soared $1.6406, to $6.7656, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, SIDNEY
description: GROSSMAN-Sidney. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Sidney Grossman. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Rose, and their family. Morton West, President Daniel Amster, Secretary

title: Special Effects at Sea and Elsewhere
description: If you've been wondering how the vaunted special effects of ''Titanic'' were produced, tonight's ''Nova'' should satisfy your curiosity. As one of the assembled whizzes observes, ''The art of visual effects is the art of what you can get away with.'' And given the advent of supercomputers, movie makers these days can get away with almost anything.

title: A.F.C. East Goes From Feeble to Formidable
description: As Doug Flutie walked off the field on Sunday, fresh from leading the Buffalo Bills to a big victory as quarterback for a franchise that has had a lot of big victories, he was surrounded by a mob of people. The team's public-relations man walked with his arm around Flutie, playing the role of a blocker watching Flutie's backside, protecting him from the news media throng. There were dozens of microphones jammed into Flutie's face, cameras rolling, questions yelled at him as if he were campaigning for governor.

title: Breeders' Cup Attracts 11 European Stars
description: Eleven of the classiest race horses in Europe boarded flights in Dublin and in London today and headed for Churchill Downs on a mission that has frequently been fruitless but promises greater success this time: carrying the colors of Europe's best racing stables in the Breeders' Cup.

title: Glenn Eclipses a Rich Array of Shuttle Experiments
description: Although eclipsed by the attention given John Glenn's return to space, one of the most ambitious and diverse programs of scientific and commercial research yet attempted on a nine-day mission is being conducted by the crew of the shuttle Discovery.

title: French Bottler of Water Buying a U.S. Rival
description: Widening its reach in the bottled-water business, Groupe Danone announced yesterday that it was buying the Aqua Penn Spring Water Company for $112 million, or $13 a share.

title: Cut Prices Or Else, Libya Tells Its Shops
description: The boutique owner said he had been lucky.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Media Talk column of Business Day yesterday about negotiations over a new Sunday editor at The Daily News misspelled the given name of the paper's editor in chief. She is Debby Krenek, not Debbie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERSTER, MIRIAM FOGEL
description: KERSTER-Miriam Fogel. Died peacefully on November 1, 1998. Loving sister of Aviva and Herschel. Her unique, personal style and joie de vivre will be greatly missed. Family will mourn privately. A celebration in memory of Miriam will be held January 9, 1999. Contributions in her memory may be made to Gay Mens Health Crisis. Many thanks to Sharon.

title: Review/Fashion; The Off Seventh Avenue Sass
description: Marathoners weren't the only ones running around New York on Sunday. A hardy band of fashion professionals spent the day dashing from the West 50's to Chelsea to SoHo to the Lower East Side to Greenwich Village. They were winding up a three-day weekend of shows by young, mostly downtown designers to open the final week of the American spring 1999 fashion season.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a review of a concert performance of ''The Philosopher's Stone,'' an opera that some scholars say was partly composed by Mozart, misidentified the performer shown and her character. The picture was of Judith Lovat (as Nadine), recoiling from a magic bird, not of Jane GieringDeHaan (as Lubanara).

title: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: Political Briefing; If Primary Plan Loses, California May, Too
description: Political contests, by definition, typically have a winner and a loser. But in California, if final polls have it right, one of Tuesday's contests is going to produce two losers: the Democratic and Republican parties and, beyond that, maybe the whole state.

title: Hot and Cold
description: Q. It seems that women are more sensitive to temperature changes than men. Is this true?

title: Mitchell and Dylan Among Friends
description: Bob Dylan is at that stage of cuddly sainthood that Jerry Garcia reached in the 1980's: when he's having fun, the audience is having fun. Mr. Dylan looked modestly happy as he surveyed the Madison Square Garden audience through his deeply sunken eyes on Sunday night, and he talked to the crowd a little more than usual. He dug extensively into his lead-guitar playing, his recent ploy to change his group sound, and he danced gingerly, with self-conscious awkwardness, like an eccentric grandfather doing his impression of Chuck Berry to entertain children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESSE, BERNARD
description: TESSE-Bernard. On Sunday, November 1, 1998 of Rego Park, NY, formerly of Staten Island, NY. Beloved Husband of the late Ernestine Tesse. Devoted Father of Marcel Tesse; Loving Grandfather of Suzanne Griffin and Eric Tesse. Great Grandfather of Zachary Griffin. Funeral services conducted from The Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, NJ, on Wednesday, November 4, 1998, 11:30 AM. Interment United Hebrew Cemetery, Staten Island, NY.

title: D'Amato and Schumer End Campaign on High, Hoarse Notes
description: With one last burst of spending and one final intervention by the White House, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and Representative Charles E. Schumer ended yesterday one of the most competitive and expensive political races in the nation this year, with Mr. D'Amato pleading with New Yorkers to re-elect him because ''Al D'Amato delivers,'' and Mr. Schumer proclaiming himself ''on the verge of an historic victory.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABLEY, PETER C.
description: HABLEY-Peter C. Died at the Lenox Hill Hospital on October 30, 1998 at the age of 55. The husband of Andra Habley, he is also survived by sister Ann Felker, sister Gail Brownlee and brother Stuart Habley. He was a senior Human Resources Executive with Pfizer Inc., having served in overseas assignments in both Africa and Asia during his twenty-four year career. He held assignments as the senior Human Resources Executive for both Pfizer's Animal Health and Medical Technologies Groups. A graduate of the University of the Pacific with BA and MA degrees in Psychology, he was well-known in international professional circles. Services will be held Thursday, November 5, at 10:00 AM, at Saint James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue at 71st Street. A reception will follow at the New York Yacht Club, 37 West 44th Street between 5th and 6th immediately following.

title: Paper Votes Could Decide A Close Contest for Senate
description: With polls showing the United States Senate race in New York a virtual dead heat, the outcome could be decided by the fewer than 75,000 absentee ballots that were returned to state election officials by midafternoon yesterday. And those officials are taking unusual steps -- including having the unopened ballots impounded by the police -- to insure that this year's paper votes are counted fairly.

title: When Part-Time Work Is Really Full Time
description: To the Editor:

title: A Double Victory At UConn
description: The University of Connecticut had a unique achievement this season with its men's and women's teams each capturing the regular-season conference title. This was the first time in Big East history that a single school accounted for double first-place finishes. Both UConn teams are seeded first in the conference tournament, which starts with the women today.

title: Giants Start to Reassess a Faltering Kanell
description: Midway through their 1998 season, the Giants are unconvinced that a slumping Danny Kanell is their quarterback of the future, and team officials view the remainder of the season as an eight-game tryout that could decide Kanell's long-term fate with the team.

title: Getting Older: What's the Alternative?
description: To the Editor:

title: More Are Viewing Car Pool Lanes as a Failed Experiment
description: Car pool lanes on the Long Island Expressway were supposed to bring cleaner air and faster traffic. But many drivers and local politicians are now questioning whether the experiment was a waste of time -- and hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Moseley-Braun, Trailing, Pushes Hard
description: Senator Carol Moseley-Braun stuck close to her hometown today, playing to her Democratic political base in an 11th hour effort to keep her job.

title: Holocaust Film Offends History
description: To the Editor:

title: Light Trucks Face Tougher Air Standards
description: Environmental regulators in California and Washington are preparing to require steep reductions in air pollution from cars and want to apply similar rules to sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and minivans.

title: New Hope for the Losers in the Battle to Stay Awake
description: It is midafternoon on the eastern coast of a chronically sleep-deprived nation and if you listen carefully, you can hear the whoosh of cappuccino makers and the ripping open of No-Doz boxes and the yawns of night-shift workers and the sighs of pilots as they check their watches to see how much longer they must keep their aircraft aloft.

title: Artists Get Rush Order For 8 New Rembrandts
description: The preferred way of filming the lives of great painters, it seems, is to focus on their lives and ignore their paintings. This at least may explain why movie directors keep returning to van Gogh, Toulouse-Lautrec, Modigliani and Rembrandt and avoiding the more prosaic careers of, say, Monet, Mondrian and Magritte. Alcoholism, madness and tragedy are evidently easier to portray on screen than mere genius.

title: A Holocaust Memoir in Doubt; Swiss Records Contradict a Book on Childhood Horror
description: Until Binjamin Wilkomirski's truth came into conflict with his own legal identity, the slim memoir of his Jewish childhood in the concentration camps of Poland was hailed as a ''small masterpiece,'' a searing sketch of death and horror -- rats rummaging among corpses, starving babies sucking fingers to the bone, a dying mother's last glimpse of her son.

title: SERVICEMASTER IN STOCK AND DEBT DEAL FOR LANDCARE
description: The Servicemaster Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Landcare USA Inc. for more than $250 million in stock and assumed debt and that it would combine the acquisition with its Trugreen-Chemlawn unit to create the country's largest commercial landscaping company. Landcare shareholders will get a fraction of a share of Servicemaster's stock, valued as high as $11, for each Landcare share. Servicemaster will also assume an undisclosed amount of Landcare debt. Landcare is based in Houston. Servicemaster, whose businesses range from pest control to laundry service, is based in Downers Grove, Ill. Its shares rose 75 cents, to $21.875, while Landcare jumped $1.6875, to $9.6875.

title: Irish Leader Urges Restarting Ulster Peace Drive
description: Two days after the killing of a Roman Catholic man here, Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of the Irish Republic conferred today with Catholic and Protestant leaders of the new Northern Ireland Assembly in an attempt to restart the stalled Ulster peace effort.

title: AT&T to Add 1,000 Sales Jobs
description: The AT&T Corporation expects to hire more than 1,000 people to sell phone and data services to corporate customers as it tries to increase revenue, Robert Annunziata, president of AT&T business services, said yesterday.

title: Rudolph Melone, 73, Founder of California's Gilroy Garlic Festival
description: Rudolph J. Melone, whose career as a college administrator was overshadowed by his founding of the famed Gilroy Garlic Festival in Gilroy, Calif., died on Sept. 17 in San Francisco. He was 73.

title: Corrections
description: A music review yesterday about a concert by the Budapest Festival Orchestra on Wednesday at Carnegie Hall included an incorrect given name, provided by a tour official, for a concertmaster. He was Gabor Takacs, not Peter.

title: BEAZER HOMES TO BUY MOST OF TRAFALGAR HOUSE PROPERTY
description: Beazer Homes USA Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy most of Trafalgar House Property Inc., the American home-building business of the Norwegian engineering group Kvaerner A.S., for about $100 million. Kvaerner announced the planned sale last week but declined to identify the buyer. The Atlanta-based Beazer has operations in the South and the West. Trafalgar House operates in the Washington area and in Virginia, Maryland and New Jersey. The rest of Kvaerner's United States home-building business, a 6,000-plot land development project in Virginia known as South Riding, is being bought by a consortium led by Gregory Cox, South Riding's president.

title: BP Amoco Sees $2 Billion Charge
description: The British Petroleum Company's $61 billion purchase of the Amoco Corporation is expected to result in $2 billion in restructuring charges for the new entity, BP Amoco P.L.C., in the two years after it is formed.

title: Norbert Wollheim Dies at 85; Sued Over Forced Nazi Labor
description: Norbert Wollheim, a tenacious Auschwitz survivor who went on to sue the Germans for compensation for his work as a slave laborer, then devoted his life to building a spirited movement of Holocaust survivors, died on Sunday at Long Island Jewish Medical Center. He was 85 and lived in Fresh Meadows, Queens.

title: OFFICIALS PREDICT HURRICANE'S TOLL WILL EXCEED 7,000
description: As rescue workers throughout Central America struggled to reach scores of remote peasant settlements left battered and isolated by a hurricane, authorities in Nicaragua and Honduras said today that the combined death toll from the storm and its aftermath was likely to pass 7,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUMAN, DR. ARTHUR
description: BAUMAN-Dr. Arthur. On Nov. 1, 1998. Beloved husband of Caroline. Loving father of William, Andrew and Amy. Proud grandfather of Alissa, Laura, Jennifer, Jeremy, Brittany and Alexander. Internist and Endocrinologist. Services Tuesday 2PM at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchster, Westchester Ave, Rye N.Y. Inquiries Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, White Plains, N.Y. 914-949-0566. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to White Plains Hospital Ctr Bldg Fund, Davis Avenue, White Plains, New York 10601.

title: District Clears Teacher After Pupil Is Threatened
description: The vice principal of an elementary school used an inappropriate expression when she threatened to kill an unruly pupil, but she meant no harm, an Elizabeth school district inquiry has found.

title: Once Devils' Franchise, MacLean Is the Enemy
description: If the sport were baseball, this would be like Bernie Williams deciding to leave the Yankees as a free agent, signing with the crosstown Mets and returning to Yankee Stadium for the first time. Instead, it is hockey and this is John MacLean, a cornerstone of the Devils for almost 15 seasons, returning to the Meadowlands on Tuesday night in the uniform of the rival Rangers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 13 about American Catholic seminarians misstated the given name and the order of a priest who teaches at the Pontifical North American College of Rome. He is the Rev. Peter Cameron, not John, and he is a Dominican, not a Franciscan.

title: Dow Up 114.05 as Stocks Gain for Fourth Straight Session
description: Stock prices continued to plow ahead yesterday as investors gained more confidence that the days and weeks of instability that were the norm from mid-July until late September are over.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIOTT, CHARLOTTE
description: ELLIOTT-Charlotte. November 2, 1998. Beloved wife of Robert. Devoted mother of Howard, his wife Lydia, & Richard Elliott. Cherished grandmother of Erika, Ben, Emily, Alex and Bianca. Cherished by many loving nieces and nephews. Reposing at Schwartz BrothersJeffer Memorial Chapels, 76th Road and Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York, Tuesday from 7-9:30PM. Funeral services are on Wednesday at 1:00 P.M., from Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels. Interment New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Accounts
description: Sega Gameworks, Universal City, Calif., to the Idea Shop, New York, to handle the creative portion of its account, which had been handled by Deutsch Inc., Marina del Rey, Calif. The media portion is handled in-house and by Focus Media, Los Angeles. Billings were estimated at less than $3 million. Sega Gameworks is owned by Sega Enterprises, Dreamworks SKG and Seagram's Universal Studios unit.

title: Moose Come Calling
description: To the editor:

title: May Stores to Settle Lawsuits On Debt-Collection Tactics
description: The May Department Stores Company has agreed to pay up to $27 million to settle lawsuits and consumer complaints accusing the third-largest American operator of upscale department stores of illegally collecting credit-card payments from bankrupt customers.

title: Steady Goaltending and Offense Put Islanders Over .500
description: Tonight's 6-2 victory over the Florida Panthers was worth more to the Islanders than 2 points in the standing. It also made them a winning team for the first time in almost a year at 6-5-0.

title: An Animal Fable Not for Children Only
description: I wonder how many of the parents who brought their children to the New York City Opera's ''Cunning Little Vixen'' on Sunday afternoon quite realized the burden being placed on innocent eyes and ears. There were indeed the anthropomorphic pleasures of Maurice Sendak's cuddly forest creatures and the fairy-tale whimsy of the production's painted cutouts and backdrops. But Janacek's opera, small in stature yet transcendent in tone, is anything but a children's piece.

title: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: Political Briefing; Two Candidates For the Price of One
description: No election contest in the country has been more topsy-turvy this fall than the Alaska Governor's race. And the confusion seems likely to continue through Election Day -- and beyond.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHTENSTEIN, EVELYN STONE
description: LICHTENSTEIN - Evelyn Stone. Formerly of N.Y.C. On November 1, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Mark Stone and Murray Lichtenstein DDS. Cherished mother of Alan Stone, Judith Ghoneim and Caryl Pareja. Also survived by six grandchildren and six great grandchildren. A memorial service will take place at the Oelker & Cox Funeral Home, 262 Main St, Mount Kisco, N.Y. (914-666-5891) on Tuesday (today) at 8 P.M.

title: Suspect in 1971 Killing Is Called a Flight Risk
description: A 41-year-old woman charged as a juvenile in her mother's slaying in 1971 was ordered held without bail yesterday pending a report on her risk of fleeing prosecution, officials said.

title: French Major Held in Spying At NATO Panel
description: A French military officer at NATO headquarters in Brussels has been arrested on suspicion of telling Serbia about targets that the alliance was planning to bomb if Serbian forces did not stop attacking civilians in Kosovo last month, French officials said today.

title: Taking in the (Web) Site Of This Virtual Defense
description: In the dry paper trail of depositions, it was simply Government exhibit No. 1,400, recorded in August. But on the Internet of real life today, No. 1,400 turned out to be the man himself, William H. Gates, Microsoft mogul under fire, suddenly appearing in watery living color, his recorded image slightly dreamlike but definitely in motion above the keyboard, his voice firm in fencing with his inquisitors for all the world's surfers to witness, virtually.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, JACK
description: ADLER-Jack. On November 1, 1998. Beloved husband of Frances, loving father of Gloria (Michael) Feldman, and Paul (Janet) Adler. Adoring grandfather of David, Deborah, Mark and Bethany. Funeral services Wednesday, 11:30 AM, November 4, at Riverside North Shore Chapel, 55 Great Neck Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: The Day After, Mementos and Memories Remain
description: Looking like the runner he is in Adidas warm-ups and Asics athletic shoes, Jose Cruz was strolling down Seventh Avenue yesterday morning in search of a few souvenirs to carry home to Bayamon, P.R. The day before, the 59-year-old Cruz had completed his second New York City Marathon in 3 hours 14 minutes -- good enough to qualify in the 60-and-over age group for next year's Boston Marathon, which he plans to run.

title: In Mix-up, Network Calls Races Early
description: The Internet was supposed to speed up the pace of journalism, but this was really pushing the envelope: last night the ABC News Web site carried what purported to be the results of some of today's elections.

title: Gore Tours West Coast to Whip Voters Into a Poll-Going Frenzy
description: Vice President Al Gore ended his long and labored campaign season today with a long and laboring day on the West Coast, joining major Democratic candidates for a rally in Sacramento, Calif., and along a four-stop, 130-mile bus tour through western Washington.

title: An Older Woman Chooses an Unlikely Love Over Loneliness
description: Why do fools fall in love? ''The Old Settler,'' John Henry Redwood's lonely-hearts comedy set in the Harlem of the early 1940's, addresses the question through a pair of romantic dunces: an old fool, desperate for affection and eager to believe in anyone who can supply it, and a younger one, unschooled in affairs of the heart and a terrible judge of when they might be practical.

title: Patterns
description: Now, Tents for Men

title: A Secret Gypsy With Bad Luck but a Slim Chance
description: ARMADILLO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLENBERG, HAROLD L.
description: ELLENBERG-Harold L. On November 1, 1998. Devoted husband of Lenora Beck. Loving father of Michael, Ethan and David, and father-in-law of Karen, Barbara and Lisa, and adoring grandfather of Noah, Delilah, Manya, Ezra, Lily, Ruby and Iris. Bural will be private at the request of the family.

title: Gates on Tape: Scant Memory Of Key Details
description: The William H. Gates on the courtroom screen this afternoon was evasive and uninformed, pedantic and taciturn -- a world apart from his reputation as a brilliant business strategist, guiding every step in the Microsoft Corporation's rise to dominance in computing.

title: Painting Old Songs in New Colors
description: The alto saxophonist Greg Osby's live sets with his new band of the last two years have become liquid, nonstop events, acquiring a growing reputation among watchers of the New York jazz scene.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK -- METS
description: Having signed Mike Piazza, the Mets are turning to two of their next most pressing needs: a third or second baseman and a good bat behind Piazza in the lineup. It looks as if General Manager Steve Phillips will attempt to solve both problems by making a strong run at either Ken Caminiti or Robin Ventura.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOREIN, SARAH
description: KOREIN-Sarah. On October 29, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Isidor. Loving mother of Julius and Elysabeth. Dear sister of Esther. Adoring grandmother of James, Jonathan, Beth and Peter; nine great-grandchildren. Private services. No flowers, please. The family of Sarah Korein wishes to thank you for all your good wishes. If you wish to make a contribution in her memory, donations may be sent to: Appeal of Conscience Foundation, 119 West 57 St, NYC 10019; Florida Stage, 262 South Ocean Blvd, Manalapan, FL 33462; Central Park Conservancy, NYC.

title: Ballets Come to Life As Casts Devour Their Frisky Roles
description: Two ballets, one new, one old, took on vivid extra color in performances presented by American Ballet Theater last weekend at City Center. The first was John Selya's ''Disposition,'' a premiere this season, which looked like a thoroughly different ballet, as danced by Ashley Tuttle and Marcelo Gomes on Sunday night. The second was Agnes de Mille's ''Rodeo,'' that enduring and sometimes unendurable Americana classic, which was performed on Saturday afternoon.

title: For Loroupe, New York Is 26 Miles of Trouble
description: The trouble began on Saturday night for Tegla Loroupe of Kenya, but she shrugged it off as tension. After consecutive victories, she had finished seventh at the 1996 and 1997 New York City Marathons. Now she was returning as the world record-holder and a heavy favorite. Her stomach bothered her, but she was sure it was just nerves.

title: Fighting Crime in Central Park
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELDIN, DR. S. DANIEL
description: SELDIN-Dr. S. Daniel. November 2, 1998 at the age of 89. Beloved wife of the late Sybil. Devoted father of Barbara S. Bray and Margaret J. Altizer. Loving grandfather of 3. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, November 4 at 12 noon at The Reformed Temple of Putnam Valley. For further information Heritage Funeral Home, 35 Morrissey Drive, Putnam Valley, N.Y.

title: Ever Elusive, Privacy Slips From Grasp Of Patients
description: On my desk at the hospital sits a computer terminal I use to check my patients' blood tests and X-ray results. I could also, were I so inclined, use it to browse through the blood tests and X-rays of thousands of complete strangers, tracking biopsy results, guessing at life expectancies and generally shattering every known code of medical privacy and confidentiality to smithereens without ever leaving my chair.

title: Excerpts From Videotape of the Gates Deposition Played in the Courtroom
description: Following are excerpts from two hours of videotaped testimony shown today in United States District Court during antitrust proceedings against the Microsoft Corporation. David Boies, a trial lawyer for the Justice Department, questioned the chairman and chief executive of the company, William H. Gates.

title: Holocaust Film Offends History
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, LEONARD M.
description: GOLD-Leonard M. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York note with sadness the passing of Leonard M. Gold, beloved brother of Martin Gold, and brother-in-law of Billie Gold, both extraordinary supporters and cherished friends, who are devoted to maintaining a strong and vital Jewish community through their efforts on behalf of Jewish education and our Jewish Continuity Commission. We extend our sincerest condolences to the entire Gold family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: A Muscle Builder Or Purse Shrinker?
description: An infomercial for Bodyblade, a 4-foot by 1.75-inch blade with a rubber hand grip at the center, hit the airways earlier this year, its makers hoping to follow in the lucrative footsteps of fitness products like ab rollers and butt blasters. The infomercial, which claimed that Bodyblade offered ''a complete and total body workout in as little as six minutes a day,'' enticed fitness buffs to snap up 100,000 of the $99 gadgets.

title: BOWATER TO SELL MAINE TIMBERLAND FOR $155 MILLION
description: Bowater Inc., the largest United States producer of newsprint, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 656,000 acres of timberland in western Maine for $155 million to the McDonald Investment Company of Birmingham, Ala. Bowater said it expected to record a $75 million gain from the sale. Last month, the company, which is based in Greenville, S.C., agreed to sell a million acres to J. D. Irving Ltd. of Canada. It said it would use the proceeds from both sales to repay debt and repurchase shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, ELEANOR
description: KATZ-Eleanor. The Officers, Members and Staff of the American Jewish Committee are deeply saddened by the death of Eleanor Katz, who had served as AJC's Director of Personnel for more than 20 years when she retired in 1977. We send our heartfelt condolences to her family. Bruce M. Ramer, President David A. Harris, Executive Dir. Shulamith Bahat, Assoc. Exec. Dir.

title: Once He Devised Germ Weapons; Now He Defends Against Them
description: Standing in his study, a waltz playing in the background, Bill Patrick reached into an old green duffel bag, pulled out a garden sprayer and pointed out an inconspicuous detail at its tip.

title: Astra's Earnings Decline As Drug Pact Is Revised
description: Astra A.B. of Sweden, Europe's seventh-biggest drug maker, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit fell 7.6 percent after it took control of a joint venture with Merck & Company and started paying Merck royalties on sales of Losec, an ulcer treatment that is the world's leading prescription drug.

title: For Gorilla Troops in the Bronx, a Touch of the Congo
description: Sometime in mid-December, Timmy and Dan, two silverback male gorillas, and their respective troops will move into new quarters at the Bronx Zoo, in an environment designed by scientists and animal experts to resemble a central African rain forest, the animals' natural habitat.

title: Races to Watch
description: HOUSE RACES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, JACK
description: SILVERMAN-Jack. Age 81, of Hollywood, FL., and New York. Passed away Nov. 1, 1998 after a sudden illness. Beloved husband of the late Florence. Loving father of Bonnie and Jeffrey Silverman and Joan and Ronald Silverman. Dear brother of Francine Edelson. Cherished grandmother of Susanna, Valerie, Daniel and Hallie. Devoted companion of Jean Cantor. World traveler, bon vivant. He will be missed by all of us. Services are at Levitt-Weinstein Memorial Chapels, Hollywood, Florida, 1-800343-5400.

title: Getting Older: What's the Alternative?
description: To the Editor:

title: Republicans Hope Ads Turn Out Vote for an Underdog
description: Over a steaming plate of baked beans and Southern-style barbecue, Mark Penny, a Republican precinct chairman here, was shaking his head today over new Republican attack ads that seek to exploit President Clinton's sex scandal.

title: Power Line Makes Use Of a Miracle Of Physics
description: After 87 years of alternating exuberance and disappointment, and a decade after a famous conclave of physicists at which the key to success seemed to be within reach, the world's first superconducting power line is about to become a reality.

title: Woman Faces Charges In Death of Foster Child
description: A woman described by her lawyer as borderline retarded was charged yesterday in the shaking death and severe injury of two foster children she was baby-sitting for in August.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: King of Binge Eaters

title: Cowboys See Eagles Discover New Lows
description: Call the National Football Conference East what you wish: lousy, lame, weak, ghoulish. But the Dallas Cowboys do not want to hear it. Just call them the front-runners. With half the season over, they are first in the N.F.C. East.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a technical error, the Chess column on Sunday was a reprint of one published on Oct. 28, 1997. The correct column appears today, on page B10.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORNISH, STANLEY D.
description: CORNISH-Stanley D. On November 1, 1998. Of Rye, N.Y. Beloved husband of Lee Cornish. Brother of Richard and Dudley. Loving grandfather of Andrew S. Borrok. Graveside service will be held Wednesday, 10 A.M. at Mount Hope Cemetery, Hastings on Hudson, N.Y.

title: Fed Up, Berkeley Begins Crackdown on Homeless
description: The young street people were leaning against a store window, watching the police watching them from a second- floor window across the avenue.

title: Players Heave Air Ball in Boycott
description: NBC and Turner Sports are not quaking at the prospect of National Basketball Association players boycotting interview requests during the lockout and then during the season, whenever it is to begin.

title: World Briefs
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, I.R.
description: FISHER-I.R. ''Brownie'' 77. Husband of Jeannette Simmons Fisher. Died November 1 in Greenwich, CT. A memorial service will take place at 2 p.m. Thursday November 5, at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 200 Riverside Ave. Riverside, CT. Memorial Contributions may be made in his memory to the Greenwich Hospital or the Leukemia Society.

title: TEXACO AND CHEVRON COMBINE SOME OPERATIONS
description: Texaco Inc. and the Chevron Corporation, the United States oil giants, said yesterday that they had combined their marine fuels and lubricants operations in a joint venture, called Fuel and Marine Marketing L.L.C, to reduce costs and gain market share. The venture, proposed in March, received approval from European regulators on Friday, a Chevron spokeswoman said. No American regulatory approval was needed. Texaco owns 69 percent and Chevron 31 percent of Fuel and Marine Marketing, which will have annual revenue of $2 billion on sales of 170 million barrels of fuel and 80 million barrels of lubricants, the companies said. It will have its headquarters in White Plains, where Texaco is based, and it will have 25 offices worldwide and serve customers in more than 100 countries, the companies said.

title: Index of British Industry Plunged in October
description: British manufacturing activity shrank at its fastest rate in more than six years in October, dropping to record lows, according to the latest survey, released yesterday, from the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply.

title: Iraq Yields Slightly in Monitoring Dispute
description: Two days after vowing to cut off all cooperation with United Nations arms inspectors, Iraq allowed a small team of maintenance technicians to change film and make repairs on some surveillance cameras today in the company of Iraqi chaperones.

title: Russian Olympians Slip By American Team at the End
description: The Russian team squeaked by the Americans to take the gold medals in the World Chess Olympiad, held from Sept. 26 to Oct. 12 in Elista, Kalmykia. The Americans had been leading throughout, but in the last round, after the Russians defeated the Netherlands 3 1/2- 1/2 and the Americans had been held to a 2-2 tie by China, Russia reached the overall total of 35 1/2-16 1/2 and the Americans' 34 1/2-17 1/2 won the silver.

title: Ultra Adds Raytheon Unit
description: Ultra Electronics Holdings P.L.C., a British military electronics concern, has agreed to buy the Raytheon Company's submarine sensor business for $21.6 million. It makes electromechanical devices for aerospace companies and military contractors. Raytheon is based in Lexington, Mass.

title: Makers of Surgical Devices in Stock Deal Valued at $3.6 Billion
description: In a strategic shift, Medtronic Inc., the biggest maker of heartbeat regulators, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Sofamor Danek Group for $3.6 billion in Medtronic stock.

title: Fedex Chief Sees Losses Now in Threat of Strike by Pilots
description: The top executive at Federal Express warned over the weekend that the company was on the verge of losing several large customers during the peak holiday season because of a threatened strike by its pilots.

title: Corrections
description: The News Summary yesterday included an entry erroneously in some copies for an obituary of Rudolph J. Melone, founder of the Gilroy, Calif., Garlic Festival. It appears today, on page B11.

title: Exquisitely Opaque Scrolls And a Very Stubborn Peony
description: Nothing that followed equaled the astonishing opening of ''Empty Tradition/City of Peonies,'' on Friday night at the Asia Society. The mixed-media piece was the creation of Yin Mei, a Chinese choreographer and director; Tony Prabowo, an Indonesian composer, and Xu Bing, the Chinese artist and set designer who made the work remarkable.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PRO & CON; Paying the Price For Phone Advice When a Child Is Ill
description: Q. Should pediatricians charge patients for telephone advice? JOHN O'NEIL

title: Getting Older: What's the Alternative?
description: To the Editor:

title: Holocaust Film Offends History
description: To the Editor:

title: Kosovo's Health System Dies And Civilians Are Casualties
description: The climate of fear in Kosovo during the Yugoslav Government's offensive against ethnic Albanian rebels has caused the rural health system to collapse, aid workers and the few remaining health workers say, and hundreds of civilians may have died as a result.

title: PHARMACIA & UPJOHN SETS UP TO $1 BILLION STOCK BUYBACK
description: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc., the drug maker, said yesterday that it would repurchase as much as $1 billion more of its stock by 2000 as new drugs and increased marketing for older ones bolster its sales. The company has already spent $262 million to buy 6.75 million of its shares since 1996, said a company spokesman. Last week, Pharmacia said third-quarter profit rose 19 percent as sales increased 9.5 percent, to $1.67 billion. Shares of the company, based in Bridgewater, N.J., rose $2.125 yesterday, to $55.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUS, MSGR. EDWARD A.
description: FUS-Msgr. Edward A. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the pastor emeritus of Holy Cross Church, 61-21 56th Rd., Maspeth, on Nov, 1. Reposing at Megiel Funeral Home, 64-18 Flushing Ave., Maspeth, Tuesday, Nov. 3, from 2-5 and 7-9 P.M., and Wednesday, Nov. 4, from 2-5 P.M. Mass of Transferral at Holy Cross Church at 7:30 P.M. Funeral Mass, Thursday, Nov. 5, at 10 A.M. All priests' are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society.

title: Monthly Sales Fall 33% For Samsung Motor
description: Samsung Motor Inc., South Korea's newest auto maker, said yesterday that sales were 33.5 percent lower in October than in September, the biggest decline since Samsung entered the auto business in April. The company said it sold 4,035 of its SM5 sedans last month, compared with 6,071 in September, bringing total sales so far to 37,770. Samsung's annual capacity is 80,000 vehicles.

title: Metro Business; New Managers at Cendant
description: The Cendant Corporation, the franchiser and direct-marketing company stung by accounting fraud, named new managers yesterday for the division where the fraud occurred.

title: 10 Win Writing Prizes
description: Five poets, two fiction writers, two nonfiction writers and one playwright are this year's recipients of the annual $30,000 awards given to young, emerging writers by the Mrs. Giles Whiting Foundation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the Halloween parade in Greenwich Village referred incorrectly to the role of Snapple, the beverage company, in the parade. Snapple has been a corporate sponsor of past parades, but was not this year.

title: As Netanyahu Stalls, Arafat Quickly 'Accepts'
description: With their new interim peace accord stopped in place the day it was formally to begin, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, both insisted today that the carefully sequenced security-for-land plan can still proceed nearly on schedule.

title: Tower Realty Says Crescent Cancels Deal
description: The Crescent Real Estate Equities Company, an investment trust controlled by the billionaire Richard E. Rainwater, and the Reckson Associates Realty Corporation have called off their $734 million joint purchase of the New York office developer Tower Realty Trust, Tower said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREGMAN, DR. STANLEY M.
description: BREGMAN-Dr. Stanley M. Of South Orange, NJ, a devoted and beloved practitioner in optometry died Sunday in St. Barnabas Medical Center, Livingston, NJ. He was 75. Dr. Bregman was a world traveler, a gourmet cook, a gifted pianist and a patron of the arts. Dr. Bregman is survived by his wife of 52 years, Dorothy, four children: Peter, Dr.Sally, Daniel and Emily, a son-on-law Mark Nedostup, daughters-in-law Susan Zimmer and Valorie Petrak and four grandchildren: Nicholas and Matthew Nedostup and Andrew & Laura Bregman. Funeral services Wednesday, November 4, 12 noon Apter-Bernheim-Goldsticker, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to the charity of your choice.

title: Sangstat Drug Is Cleared By the F.D.A.
description: The Sangstat Medical Corporation said today that the Food and Drug Administration had approved its immune-suppressant drug, Sangcya, for preventing organ rejection in transplant patients, and for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and psoriasis. Sangstat said it would bring out the drug within a month.

title: Man Accused of 5 Rapes Is Investigated in Slayings
description: A man suspected of abducting and raping five women in Orange and East Orange over the last 15 months confessed to the charges and made additional statements that might link him to other crimes, officials said yesterday.

title: Nasdaq and Amex Close to Deal To Move to Single Times Sq. Site
description: New York City and state officials are close to a deal to provide Nasdaq and the American Stock Exchange with a $200 million subsidy package to build a new joint headquarters, probably in a skyscraper a block from Times Square, people involved with the talks said yesterday.

title: Wyse Is Selected By Sherwin-Williams
description: The Sherwin-Williams Paint Stores Group in Cleveland said yesterday that it had named Wyse Advertising in Cleveland to handle the creative portion of its account, which had been handled since 1995 by J. Walter Thompson Detroit. Billings were estimated at $32 million.

title: Treasuries Again Off Sharply As 30-Year Yield Hits 5.25%
description: Bonds tumbled for a second session yesterday, and the yield on the 30-year bond rose to a six-week high as gains in global stocks, a weaker dollar and sales of $79 billion of new Government debt this week dampened demand for Treasuries.

title: The Fat Cats Keep On Purring
description: To hear pollsters and pundits talk about individual races, you might sense a lot of suspense in the air this Election Day. True, a handful of contests may still be in doubt -- notably Alfonse D'Amato vs. Charles Schumer in New York. But the reality is that truly competitive races are rare these days. Follow the money and you can see why.

title: Births Fall and Abortions Rise Under New Jersey Family Cap
description: New Jersey's so-called family-cap policy, which cuts off extra cash benefits to welfare recipients who have more children, has led to an overall decline in birth rates among welfare recipients and has also contributed to a temporary increase in abortions, according to the final version of a Rutgers University study released today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WROBLEWSKI, STELLA
description: WROBLEWSKI-Stella. Formerly of Sayreville, New Jersey. Died Sunday, November 1, 1998. Funeral is Thursday, Russin Funeral Home, Wilkes-Barre, PA.

title: Humor, Sparks and an Eerie Beauty
description: The Halloween treat that the chamber orchestra Orpheus delivered at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night was a sparkling and sparky performance -- the first in the city -- of Elliott Carter's Clarinet Concerto, with Charles Neidich the soloist. For a conductorless ensemble to be attempting music of this rhythmic complexity looked risky, but Orpheus made it work brilliantly.

title: Who Are These Guys? Jets' Defense Sparkles
description: In the Jets' resurgence to a four-way tie atop the American Football Conference East, the unheralded defense is playing a critical role. But exactly who are these guys who baffled the Kansas City Chiefs and a national television audience on Sunday?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVENTHALL, DONALD I.
description: LAVENTHALL-Donald I. On October 31, 1998, in New York, New York, after a long illness bravely borne. Beloved husband of Susan. Dearest father of Donald, Max, Danielle and Gillian, and stepfather of Tamar. Father-in-law of Cliff, Mark, Jeff, William and Donna. Adored grandfather of Sarah, Clint, Alyssa and Caroline. Dear son of Mary and brother of Frank. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Tuesday, November 3 at 3 P.M. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAW, OTHO STOKES
description: SHAW-Otho Stokes, 74, of New York City and Hampton Bays, L.I. Partner in Shaw & Draper, Inc., Interior Designers; Fellow American Society of Interior Designers; Past President Alumni Association of Parsons School of Design. Beloved friend and partner of Dede Draper. Beloved brother of Lavon Morrow. Adored Uncle of Lester Morrow of Minneapolis, MN. He will be greatly missed by his dear friends in England and this country. Friends may call Wednesday 10-12PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZOLA CAHN, LENORE
description: ZOLA CAHN-Lenore. The Village Temple mourns the passing of one of our long-time members, Mrs. Lenore Cahn Zola, 91 years old. Our condolences to children, Edgar S. Cahn and Mary Cahn Schwartz, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Lenore was an active and beloved community member. She will be remembered for her kindness, elegance and outstanding achievements. Funeral on Tuesday, November 3 at the Village Temple, 33 East 12 Street New York City at 11 A.M. Rabbi Dennis N. Math Rabbi Burt Siegel Sheryl Harawitz Joan Brancaccio Co-Presidents

title: Beijing Journal; Tide of Traffic Turns Against the Sea of Bicycles
description: Every day this city's wide boulevards are marred by a million ugly battles between ''gas vehicles,'' as cars are called in Chinese, and ''self-propelled vehicles,'' a.k.a. bicycles.

title: Rediscovering a Writer Through Her Own Words
description: At first, the claims of the stooped over, clearly down-and-out old woman in the bus station seem ludicrous. She sets down her cheap suitcase and declares, ''I was the queen of the Harlem Renaissance.''

title: Computer-Obsessed
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Informed Decisions
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: For Foot Care Tips, Don't Ask Mama
description: Heels are out, athletic shoes are in, at least among teen-age girls. And orthopedic researchers believe that this trend may explain why young women have fewer foot problems than their older counterparts.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE RISES 8.8 PERCENT. Prices rallied for the biggest one-day gain since March 1997 on export disruptions in Central America caused by Hurricane Mitch. The December contract rose 9.7 cents, to $1.197 a pound.

title: Election Day Choices
description: Here is a summary of our recommendations for noteworthy local races and ballot proposals in today's elections. Poll hours in New York State are from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M., in New Jersey from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M., and in Connecticut from 6 A.M. to 8 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HONIG, LAWRENCE M., ESQ.
description: HONIG-Lawrence M., Esq. Attorney, gardener, tennis champion, loving sweetheart. On October 18, 1998. Miss you. L.S.P.

title: Sports of The Times; Testaverde vs. Flutie: Fates Crossing Paths
description: DO not ask Vinny Testaverde to expound on the symbolism of Doug Flutie, the Orange Bowl and 1984, other than to refer to a game he watched from the sideline as ''one of the greatest'' he ever saw and that, during the third quarter, he turned to one of his teammates to say, ''The team with the ball last is going to win.''

title: Abroad at Home; Is This America?
description: ''How can this be in America?'' Julie Hiatt Steele asked. ''It's not the country I thought I lived in.''

title: Fighting Crime in Central Park
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILLIPS PETROLEUM IN COKER VENTURE WITH VENEZUELA
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company said yesterday that it had completed an agreement with Petroleos de Venezuela S.A., Venezuela's state oil company, to build a $450 million coker at Phillips's refinery in Sweeny, Tex. The Venezuelan company will supply as much as 165,000 barrels a day after the coker is completed in late 2000, Phillips said. Construction is to begin this year at the refinery, where 205,000 barrels of oil can be processed daily. Under the plan, first announced in August 1997, Phillips, of Bartlesville, Okla., and Petroleos de Venezuela will each own half of the coker, which will separate heavy materials from crude oil and convert them into petroleum coke.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLLHEIM, NORBERT
description: WOLLHEIM-Norbert. On November 1, 1998. Husband of Charlotte, father of Ruth Wachter and Peter Wollheim, grandfather of Toby Wachter, stepfather of Peter and Jeffrey Sprung. Passed away surrounded by family and the respect and love of Holocaust survivors around the world, including those he helped save from death and those on whose behalf he obtained some measure of justice and compensation. Memorial service at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, at noon, Tuesday 3 November. Interment at Mt. Carmel Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name may be made to the American Gathering of Jewish Holocaust Survivors Education Fund, 122 West 30 Street, New York, NY 10001.

title: Game manufacturers are starting to look at a long-forgotten market: younger children.
description: PITY poor Pac-Man.

title: ABC Workers Stage 24-Hour Strike; Lockout Is Response
description: About 2,000 employees of ABC walked off their jobs without warning yesterday for a 24-hour strike, and the television network's management responded by saying it would lock out any striking workers who try to return today.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Williams Is in No Hurry for an Offer
description: The Yankees began their organizational meetings yesterday in Tampa, Fla., but did not immediately emerge with an offer for Bernie Williams. That's all right. Scott Boras, Williams's agent, said he was not in a hurry to receive an offer.

title: Bored, Dispirited, Disgusted, Most Won't Vote
description: Since casting a ballot for Harry S. Truman in 1948, Harold Hiles, a World War II veteran, has always deemed it an honor and a duty to vote.

title: Districts Outline Plans For Early Education
description: Under a court-ordered plan to improve academic performance in poor urban areas, the state's 28 special-needs districts submitted plans yesterday to enroll 67,000 children in preschool and full-day kindergarten classes.

title: Clinton Says Iraq's Balking Over Weapons Will Backfire
