description: President Clinton predicted today that Iraq's decision to end all cooperation with United Nations weapons inspectors would backfire. He said the move had unified the international community in condemnation of President Saddam Hussein's Government.

title: POCO PETROLEUMS AGREES TO ACQUIRE PAN EAST PETROLEUM
description: Poco Petroleums Ltd., the oil and natural-gas exploration company, agreed yesterday to buy the Pan East Petroleum Corporation for about $163 million (Canadian), or $106 million (United States), in cash and stock to expand its natural-gas holdings in western Canada. Both companies are based in Calgary, Alberta. The deal would allow Pan East shareholders to exchange each common share for $2.65 (Canadian) in cash or 0.1797 of a Poco common share. The cash offer represents a 2.7 percent premium over Pan East's closing price yesterday of $2.58 (Canadian) a share.

title: Iraq's Audacious Defiance
description: Emboldened by its past successes in curtailing United Nations arms inspections, Iraq has now virtually banned all monitoring efforts. Before Saddam Hussein will let this vital work resume, he unreasonably demands that the Security Council guarantee an early end to international economic sanctions against Iraq. Such a commitment would relieve Baghdad of its obligation to prove it has eliminated all illegal biological, chemical and nuclear weapons and missiles that can deliver them.

title: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: Political Briefing; Happy Appalachian Bids a Warm Hello
description: Good humor has not been one of the hallmarks of this fall's politicking, and in the final hours of the campaign, there has been some downright mean television advertising.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINES, CELIA
description: MINES-Celia. Of Hempstead, NY, on October 31, 1998. Beloved mother of Joel and Lynn Mines and Dr. Martin Mines. Cherished grandmother of Edward, Steven, Ivan, Judy, Daniel, Julia, Emily and Richard. Devoted great grandmother of Jennifer, Heather, Alexander and Max.

title: Slaying Spotlights Fear as Abortion Access for Poor Is Cut
description: The slaying of Dr. Barnett A. Slepian in his home last week eliminated the mainstay of the only abortion clinic here, but it has not eliminated women's access to abortion.

title: Getting Older: What's the Alternative?
description: To the Editor:

title: Close Races and Wild Cards as U.S. Votes
description: WASHINGTON  American voters headed into the midterm elections Tuesday with local issues generally uppermost in their minds but with the White House sex scandal making predictions dicey.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Agree to Resolve Dispute Out of Espy Case Regarding Law on Gifts
description: The law that prohibits giving ''anything of value'' to a Federal official, the unlawful gratuity statute, criminalizes conduct that falls somewhere in the zone between outright bribery and the innocent exchange of gifts between friends, one of whom happens to be a public official.

title: By Design; Knit, Purl and Glamour
description: Knitwear is an indispensable component of a fall-winter wardrobe, especially this season when sportswear rules. A sweater and skirt or pants make a basic outfit, but there's no need to settle for a basic pullover when you can make a more striking statement with a knit top.

title: FRENETIC PACE SET IN FINAL APPEALS BEFORE ELECTIONS
description: After a campaign season that lacked any raging national issue greater than President Clinton's tribulations, Americans are expected to trickle, if not stream, to the polls on Tuesday in a midterm election that will inevitably be interpreted as a referendum on the fate of the President.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUMIN, DOROTHY
description: SUMIN-Dorothy. on November 1, 1998. Much loved mother of Barbara and Stephanie. Sister of Esther Ross and Julius Gurevitz. Dear sister-in-law of Sally. Remarkable grandmother of Paul, Jason and Richard. Fiercely devoted to her family, friends and the causes she believed in. Memorial service on Thursday, at 3PM at Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Serial Killer in Connecticut May Have Tried Suicide With Drugs
description: A convicted serial killer who had asked to be executed apparently attempted to commit suicide early this morning, officials said.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Another Violetta For Met 'Traviata'

title: F.D.A. Approves a New Drug to Relieve Arthritis
description: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved the first drug developed by biotechnology for rheumatoid arthritis, opening a new approach to treating the debilitating disease of the joints that afflicts more than two million Americans.

title: An Internal Memo Shows Microsoft Executives' Concern Over Free Software
description: An internal memorandum reflecting the views of some of Microsoft's top executives and software development managers reveals deep concern about the threat of the free software movement and proposes a number of strategies for competing against free programs that have recently been gaining in popularity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILKES, MARGARET
description: WILKES-Margaret, 48. Of NYC and Greensboro, N.C., on October 17, 1998 from ovarian cancer. She led a long and successful career as a director in apparel and advertising. She is survived by husband, Allen Holt Gwyn, her son Stephen Denslow of Sandusky, OH., and brothers, John Wilkes of NYC and Timothy Wilkes of Milan, OH.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CHOICEPOINT INC., Alpharetta, Ga., a provider of employment screening and drug testing services, agreed to buy the closely held Customer Development Corp., Peoria, Ill., a data base marketing company, for $86 million in cash.

title: Our Towns; A Bake Sale With Tradition In the Recipe
description: WHEN the ''For Sale'' sign went up at Landolfi's Italian Pastry Shop, grown men cried.

title: EMPIRE TO BUY A RIVAL CANADIAN GROCERY CHAIN
description: The Empire Company, Canada's fourth-largest supermarket chain, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Oshawa Group, a Canadian food distributor and grocer, for about $1.5 billion (Canadian), or $972 million (United States), in cash and stock. The purchase would allow Empire to expand in Ontario and Quebec, and would make it the second-largest seller of groceries in Canada. Empire, which operates the Sobeys markets in eastern Canada, will pay Oshawa's controlling Wolfe family $116 a share (Canadian), or $79.5 million (Canadian), for their voting shares. Oshawa's chains include I.G.A. The purchase is the second grocery combination in a week in Canada; it follows the agreement on Friday by the Loblaw Companies, the industry leader, to buy the third-largest Canadian grocery chain, Provigo Inc., for $1.56 billion (Canadian).

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: A Dark New Production Illuminates 'Salesman'
description: The darkness is always waiting for Willy Loman. It laps away at the edges of even his sunniest memories. It clouds his vision to the point that he cannot trust himself to drive. It keeps pulling him back, with gravitational force, whenever hopes, however small, are rekindled. The darkness terrifies Willy. You can sense that in the lost, panicked expression that abruptly takes over his face. But there is never any doubt that he is going to surrender to it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TASCH, RALPH JOSHUA
description: TASCH-Ralph Joshua, 86, of Palm Beach, formerly of New York City, passed away November 1, 1998. He served his country during World War II, then started a long career as CEO of Vita Food Products. He is survived by his three daughters, Wendy, Melissa and Amanda, with two loving grandchildren. Services will be Wednesday, November 4, 1 PM, graveside, at Mount Carmel Cemetery. For further information call Riverside Gordon, West Palm Bch., Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLEN, BETTY
description: GALLEN-Betty. Daughters of Miriam Center/The Gallen Institute, a long-term care and rehabilitation facility located in Clifton, NJ, lost a close friend and benefactor with the passing of Betty Gallen. A champion of the elderly and steadfast supporter of the Center, Betty and her husband Herbert, endowed the subacute program. In recognition of their generosity, the facility is named The Gallen Institute for Subacute Care. Currently, the 36-bed unit is undergoing an expansion. At the conclusion of the renovation, the state-of-the-art institute will be able to accomodate 66 patients and will serve as a model in the delivery of subacute services in northern New Jersey. Betty Gallen's legacy will serve as an inspiration to the many lives she touched.

title: Holocaust Film Offends History
description: To the Editor:

title: No Clues to Missing Student As Her Friend Is Questioned
description: The man who went out with a pregnant Baruch College student on the day she vanished last month was questioned by the police for the first time yesterday, but there were no indications afterward that investigators were any closer to solving the mystery of her disappearance.

title: London Futures Exchange to Reorganize
description: Under pressure to make its trading system faster and cheaper, the London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange announced a sweeping reorganization today intended to cut its operating costs in half by the end of next year. The changes will mean a loss of 600 of its 1,000 jobs.

title: Boston Leading a Renewal of Old Northern Cities
description: Boston, of course, would never do anything so uncouth as to boom.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WHEELER, FRANK R.
description: WHEELER-Frank R. November 3, 1989. With loving memories of life at its fullest. We miss you so send us a laugh, Geep. Sis, and The Kid

title: Bulldozers Raze a Student Garden in Harlem
description: Tom Goodridge, a special education teacher, arrived at work as usual yesterday morning, dropped his compost in the community garden across the street, picked up a few candy wrappers left over from Halloween and was at his post at Public School 76 in Harlem by 7:40.

title: Eye on 2000, National Parties Donate to State Races
description: National political parties have been steadily pumping money into critical state races, in part because whoever controls the statehouses and governors' mansions will have a hand in redrawing the Congressional districts after the 2000 census.

title: Clinton Tunes Up His Pitch For Heavy Minority Turnout
description: President Clinton is not on the ballot Tuesday and Speaker Newt Gingrich faces only token opposition for re-election to the House. But both used the final hours to stir turnout by party loyalists and to draw contrasts between their visions of the nation's future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBINSKY, PESSIE BAYLA
description: LUBINSKY-Pessie Bayla. The Metropolitan New York Coordinating Council on Jewish Poverty mourns the loss of Pessie Bayla Lubinsky, mother of our esteemed Chairman of the Board of Directors, Menachem Lubinsky. Pessie Lubinsky was an inspiration to her family and to the Jewish community as a whole. Her ongoing acts of loving kindness and charity grew from her survival of the ashes of the Holocaust. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Merryl H. Tisch, President William E. Rapfogel, Exec Dir

title: Pittsburgh Plant to Expand
description: Fore Systems Inc. said today that it would expand its Pittsburgh plant by at least 60 percent and hire about 1,000 workers as it increases manufacturing capacity to meet demand for its new computer-networking products. The company now has three buildings totaling 300,000 square feet at its Pittsburgh headquarters. Fore has had strong demand for its new ASX-4000 computer switch, used by telephone companies and Internet service providers for voice and data traffic.

title: Paid Newspaper Circulation In U.S. Continues to Decline
description: After a small hiccup upward last spring, daily and Sunday newspaper circulation continued to decline, according to figures released yesterday, but the group that has kept these unflattering industry measurements is on the verge of giving publishers a chance to supplement the old numbers with new data about their sales and readership.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, ANNA BUNIN
description: STERN-Anna Bunin. The Officers, Board of Trustees, Affiliates, and Members of Temple Beth El of Cedarhurst express their deep sorrow on the passing of Anna Bunin Stern, the mother of our esteemed Rabbi, Sholom Stern. We extend our sympathy to our Rabbi, his sisters and their entire family. Shiva will be observed in Tel Aviv, Israel. It is our fervent hope and prayer that the Almighty comfort the mourners together with all other mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Richard Holland, President

title: That Was No Walrus
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Taped Gates Testimony Shown at Microsoft Trial

title: Cigna Earnings Decline by 8%
description: The Cigna Corporation said today that its third-quarter earnings fell 8 percent as the insurance company paid out claims for damages related to Hurricane Georges. The company's profit for the quarter, excluding investment gains, fell to $241 million, or $1.14 a diluted share, compared with $262 million, or $1.17 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Cigna, which bolstered its per-share earnings by buying back stock, was expected to earn $1.12 a share based on the average estimate of analysts polled by the First Call Corporation, which tracks company earnings.

title: Air France Pilots Accept Rules on Stock Purchases
description: The biggest pilots' union at Air France has agreed that pilots must buy at least 4 percent of the airline's shares before they can win representation on its board, setting a floor for the level of equity participation deemed acceptable when the state sells shares early next year.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN GAINS. The currency rose after three big Japanese banks said they might merge some businesses to cut costs, a sign that Japan's banking system could improve. The dollar cost 114.73 yen, down from 116.14.

title: Surprising Russian Stir on Unsurprising Issue: Corruption
description: Russia's capital city, which has seemed unwilling to muster even medium dudgeon anymore on questions of politicians and politics, is suddenly buzzing over an allegation that virtually all Muscovites regard as a given: that the Government is corrupt.

title: Science of Centerfolds
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, SHEILA
description: KAYE-Sheila. October 31, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Abner. Loving mother of Bruce. Dear sister of Lee, Sally and Morris. Cherished grandmother of Chelsea. Esteemed aunt of Joan, Eleanor, Sonny, Leonard, Freddie, Larry, Brian, Joyce and Roger. Sheila will be deeply missed by all those who knew her and loved her. Service Tuesday, 9:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam.

title: Downfall of a Peacemaker; Heir Apparent's Departure May Signal Strain at Citigroup
description: On Thursday, Oct. 22, about 150 top executives of Citigroup, the financial services titan created by the recent merger of Citicorp and Travelers Group, set out with their spouses for what was billed as four days of golf, corporate planning and managerial bonding at the tony Greenbriar resort in West Virginia.

title: BOOLE & BABBAGE SOARS ON PLANNED PURCHASE BY BMC
description: Shares of Boole & Babbage Inc. jumped $3.50 yesterday, or 13 percent, to $30.125, after BMC Software Inc. announced it would buy the company for about $877 million in stock to expand its global business. It was the highest stock price for Boole & Babbage since the company went public in 1985. Both companies sell software that makes computer networks run smoothly and that manages data bases on mainframe computers, but Boole & Babbage, of San Jose, Calif., gains 58 percent of its revenue from international sales, while the Houston-based BMC gets 35 percent of its revenue from such sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTHAL, HENRY
description: WEINTHAL-Henry, October 30, 1998 in Rochester, NY. Survived by his wife, Silvia; children, Erika Weinthal of Jerusalem, Israel, Benjamin Weinthal of Bronx & Lois Weinthal of Bloomfield Hills, MI; brother, Sigfried (Joyce) Weinthal of Pittsford, N.Y.; several nieces and nephews. Funeral services were held in Rochester, NY. In lieu of flowers, friends wishing may contribute to the Rochester General Hospital Hematology Unit, Blood Research & Educational Fund, 1425 Portland Ave., Rochester, N.Y. 14621 in his memory. A period of mourning is being observed at the family residence. For information Parsky Funeral Home, Inc., Rochester, NY.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: '' We have before us a panorama of death, desolation and ruin throughout the entire country.''

title: INSIDE
description: New Emission Rules Sought

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, GERTRUDE F.
description: MURPHY-Gertrude F., 93 years old. Of Pt. Lookout and Bayside Hills, NY. Died October 31, 1998. Mother of Jack, Chris and Claire Curtin. Beloved grandmother of Paul, Maura & Elizabeth. Beloved great-grandmother of Michael, Brendan and Conor.

title: Union Official Expects No Games Before January
description: On the day before the season was supposed to start, Billy Hunter, the executive director of the National Basketball Players Association, said yesterday that no agreement was imminent in the labor impasse and that he thought the season would not begin until next year.

title: Sister Travelers
description: To the Editor:

title: Fighting Crime in Central Park
description: To the Editor:

title: Mood Heats Up in Malaysia as Leader's Rival Goes on Trial
description: Former Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim went on trial today in a corruption case that has gripped the region and come to symbolize the political convulsions that can flow out of economic distress.

title: Harry Weese, 83, Designer Of Metro System in Washington
description: Harry Weese, a Chicago architect whose design for the Washington Metro system produced some of the most powerful public spaces of our time, died on Thursday at a veterans' home in Manteno, Ill. He was 83.

title: IN THE CAMPAIGNS
description: HOME STRETCH IN NEW YORK -- As the race between Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and his Democratic challenger, Representative Charles E. Schumer, drew to a close, each called on political celebrities for help. Mr. Schumer was accompanied by Hillary Rodham Clinton, and Mr. D'Amato countered with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a former Mayor, Edward I. Koch, and a lesser celebrity : Mr. D'Amato's mother. Page B1.

title: No Lightweight Duty For Macy's Helpers; Rigorous Drills and New Rules For Balloon Crews After '97 Accident
description: With Clifford, the Big Red Dog, hovering above, nearly 100 volunteers for Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade struggled recently toward a degree in ''balloonology.'' In unison, they took five steps to the right, then three to the left. They unrolled their spools of line exactly six revolutions, then five more.

title: The 1998 Elections
description: Today is Election Day. Polling places will be open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. in New York State, where all 31 House seats, the posts of governor, attorney general and comptroller, State Senate and Assembly seats and county and local offices are at stake. For polling-place information, the New York Public Interest Research Group and Common Cause/NY will run a telephone help line: (212) 349-0352 from 7 A.M. TO 8 P.M.

title: Lasers May Soon Be Used to Treat Farsightedness
description: Sharon McCormack of White Salmon, Wash., loved windsurfing the Columbia River Gorge, but she had a problem on the big jumps: Her contact lenses washed out. ''Or I got dust under a lens,'' she said. ''That's incredibly painful.''

title: Chef of Former Le Chantilly Is Accused of Credit Theft
description: A former boxer who rose from the streets of Brooklyn to become one of New York City's most flamboyant celebrity chefs -- with his own restaurant, cookbook and cable television show -- was charged yesterday with stealing $190,000 from a credit card company by falsifying credit card receipts for payment, in one case by as much as $30,000.

title: Learning Pilates, One Stretch at a Time
description: It is called pilates, and I had been hearing about it for some time but dismissed it as a faddish 90's workout. It fit the mold perfectly: It had the requisite exotic name (pronounced puh-LAH-tees), you had to go to a gym to do it, and celebrities hailed it as a miracle workout that managed, with perfect 90's perversity, to give shapely women the bodies of 12-year-old boys.

title: Novell Awarded Damages
description: Novell Inc., the world's largest maker of computer networking software, was awarded $25.9 million in damages from Network Trade Center Inc., now defunct, which used Novell's trademarked software without the company's authorization. Novell, which is based in Provo, sued Network Trade, based in Sandy, Utah, in 1995 in Federal court in Salt Lake City, accusing it of using ''deceptive and misleading practices'' to sell Novell Netware upgrade software. A special master appointed by the court ruled that Network Trade had wrongly advertised and sold the software.

title: Metro Business; Madison Sq. Garden Signs Ticket Deal
description: Ticketmaster and Cablevision's Madison Square Garden -- which includes the arena and the Theater at Madison Square Garden; Radio City Music Hall, and the Hartford Civic Center -- have announced an exclusive, long-term ticketing agreement in which Ticketmaster will provide ticket services for all events held in each of those sites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARTOVI, ROBABE
description: PARTOVI-Robabe. Died peacefully in San Diego, California, on November 1, 1998 at the age of 91. Loving wife of the late Mohammad Ali Partovi and beloved mother of Nader, Homa, Hooshang, Roshanak, Manouchehr, Banoo and Zahra.

title: Negative Rate For Savings In September
description: United States manufacturing was weaker last month than at any time in more than two and a half years, and consumers saw their incomes weaken in September as the savings rate turned negative for the first time in 40 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAY, DORA
description: MAY-Dora died peacefully at her home at the age of 87. A holocaust survivor who with her deceased husband Joe saved her infant son by fleeing into the woods. Her courage and devotion to her family will never be forgotten. Loving mother of Marcia May, Sanford and his wife Louise. Cherished grandmother of Barry and Scott. Devoted aunt of Max Shor. Funeral services Wednesday at 12 noon from Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 76 Road and Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: Keeping Clinical Depression Out of the Aging Formula
description: Depression among older people is an often unrecognized and untreated problem that can tarnish the golden years for millions of people who might otherwise find joy, not anguish, in their old age. That includes older people in nursing homes as well as those living independently. Experts estimate that as many as 90 percent of depressed elderly Americans are not being treated.

title: Good Times Mean Hard Sell for the Military
description: Christopher Thompson was a prime target for the two older men roaming the St. Charles Towne Center mall today dressed in black uniforms. He was young. He looked fit. He was in the mall in the middle of the morning.

title: Why Jefferson Scholars Were the Last to Know
description: The release of DNA evidence that Thomas Jefferson fathered a child by his slave Sally Hemings should bring about a re-evaluation not only of Jefferson but also of the many generations of historians who have written about him.

title: Guilt Trips, and the Art of Blaming Mom for Everything
description: This summer I suffered a miscarriage. Although I had no particular reason to worry that I might miscarry, it probably featured more prominently as a possibility in my mind than it would for most women.

title: The Vacant Commission
description: The United States Sentencing Commission is a small, independent Federal agency with a big job -- setting sentencing guidelines for Federal crimes. Right now, the agency has one other distinction. It has no members, the absurd result of months of partisan bickering in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLIS, NICHOLAS J.
description: CARLIS-Nicholas J. On October 31, 1998 in Boca Raton, Florida. Formerly of NYC. Beloved brother of George and other family members. Reposing at Harden Funeral Home, 208-17 Northern Blvd, Bayside. Visiting hours Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral services at St. Demetrios Church, Jamaica, N.Y., 1 PM Thursday. Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, EDGAR, J.
description: MOORE-Edgar, J. of Great Neck, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Helen, devoted father of Wendi Quest, Walter, Jimmy and Tom. Father-in-law to Stephen Neubert, Danice Gomien, Janis Moore, and Cathi Moore. Beloved grandfather to eight grandchildren, noted composer and performer and former educator at Hofstra University and Bethpage Public Schools. Memorial service to be held at a later date.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Acquirers take on greater risks to become more competitive in a new-era utilities business.
description: GROUP of major utilities announced a number of costly transactions yesterday aimed at helping make them more competitive in a deregulated market. But the deals also demonstrate how shareholders in these companies are facing greater risk and may have to wait longer for a payoff.

title: The Crimes of Apartheid, in No Particular Order
description: The final report of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission -- a 3,000-page verdict on the entire apartheid era that was released on Friday -- appeared to have done something for truth but very little for reconciliation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, IRWIN R. ''PETE''
description: BROWN-Irwin R. ''Pete'', 71. Of Lake Worth, Florida. On October 31, 1998. Survived by Anita (nee Bronowitz), his adored wife of 48 years and by a family that loved and cherished him: daughter Cici Callahan of Cary, North Carolina, son Jeffrey of Palo Alto, CA. Sister Ann Stern of Boynton Beach, FL. Grandchildren Matthew, Michael, Jordan and Talia, son-in-law Paul, daughter-in-law Debbi & brotherin-law Marty. His life will be celebrated at a memorial service on Friday, November 6 at 11:30AM at Dorsey Funeral Home, 3525 South Congress Avenue, Lake Worth, Florida. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations in his name to the American Heart Association.

title: OHIO
description: The Taft name is gold in Ohio, where Secretary of State Bob Taft, the Republican candidate for governor, defeated former Attorney General Lee Fisher. In 1990, Mr. Taft, the great-grandson of President William Howard Taft, ceded the Republican nomination for governor to George Voinovich, then Mayor of Cleveland. But this year, with Governor Voinovich barred by law from re-election and pursuing the Senate seat vacated by John Glenn, Mr. Taft had a clear shot at the governorship.

title: NEW YORK
description: Representative Charles E. Schumer defeated the incumbent Republican, Alfonse M. D'Amato, marking the end of 18 years in the Senate for the emotive ''Senator Pothole.''

title: With Explosion in Data Networking, Companies Readjust Strategies to Meet New Demands : Equipment Makers Race to Get Right Products
description: LONDON  Ever since the introduction of the World Wide Web began triggering explosive growth of Internet use earlier this decade, technology gurus have been predicting a convergence between conventional voice telephony and the rapidly evolving market for transmitting data.

title: Chrysler Sales in October Increased 20% Over a Year Ago
description: The Chrysler Corporation reported today that its October car and truck sales rose 20 percent over a year ago, indicating yet another strong month for vehicle sales industrywide despite waning consumer confidence.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR STRENGTHENS. The dollar rose after Spain, Portugal and Sweden cut interest rates, arousing expectations that rates in Europe would drop faster than in the United States. The dollar traded at 1.6601 marks, up from 1.6533.

title: For Young Blacks, Decency vs. Crime
description: A mountain of style buries a molehill of wishful thinking in the Hype Williams film ''Belly.''

title: Greenwich Hits the Jackpot: $93,608 From the State for Powerball Troubles
description: The town of Greenwich has made the Connecticut Lottery Corporation pay for inflicting Powerball mania on the suburb: $93,608.03, to be precise.

title: Rethinking Jefferson, the Man and President; What 'Affair'?
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Races for Governor and U.S. Senator
MISSOURI
description: In the race for Senate, Christopher Bond, the Republican incumbent, held off the Democratic challenger, Attorney General Jay Nixon. Polls had showed the contest tightening over the closing days of the campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERMAN, ARTHUR
description: ZUCKERMAN-Arthur. On November 3, 1998 in NYC. Loving husband of Faye, dear brother to Stanley & brother-in-law to Renee. Devoted father to Marc, Russell, Jeffrey and Kenny. Also survived by seven grandchildren and three great - grandchildren. Service Thursday, November 5, 12:15PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, VITA M.
description: GALLAGHER-Vita M. On Saturday, October 31, 1998, Vita ''Toddy'' Gallagher, of Silver Spring, MD. Beloved wife of William J. Gallagher. Mother of Bonnie L. and John J. (Patti) Gallagher. Grandmother of Emily and Brian Gallagher. Sister of John C. Hall, Jr. Relatives and friends may call at the Collins Funeral Home, 500 University Boulevard West, Silver Spring, Maryland, on Wednesday, November 4, from 2-4 PM, where a prayer service will be at 3 PM. Interment Friday, Nov. 6, at 1 PM. Pinelawn Memorial Park Huntington, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to Baltimore Washington Institute and Society for Psychoanalysis, 14900 Sweitzer Lane Laurel, MD. 20707.

title: Los Angeles Times To Cut Work Force
description: With its advertising revenue falling short of projections and three resource-intensive news initiatives just getting under way, The Los Angeles Times announced yesterday that it would cut its 6,400-member work force by 250 people, or nearly 4 percent.

title: MAINE
description: When Angus King, an independent, was elected Governor of Maine in 1994, Democrats and Republicans agreed that he would not be able to govern effectively -- and certainly never win a second term. But in his bid for re-election, Mr. King, a former talk show host, proved the naysayers wrong.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, JACK
description: ADLER-Jack. On November 1, 1998. Beloved husband of Frances, loving father of Gloria (Michael) Feldman, and Paul (Janet) Adler. Adoring grandfather of David, Deborah, Mark and Bethany. Funeral services Wednesday, 11:30 AM, November 4, at Riverside North Shore Chapel, 55 Great Neck Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Korean Conglomerate Proposes a Bailout Deal
description: Ssangyong Group, a struggling South Korean conglomerate that has already sold stakes in its debt-laden auto, securities and paper businesses, asked creditors to bail out its two construction companies yesterday to avert bankruptcy. In exchange, the company will sell the Ssangyong Oil Refining Company, one of its most profitable businesses, and the cement-making operations of the Ssangyong Cement Industrial Company, as well as other assets by the first half of next year.

title: Keyspan to Buy Part Of Natural Gas Unit
description: Keyspan Energy, the owner of Brooklyn Union Gas, has agreed to buy half of the natural-gas gathering and transport business of Gulf Canada Resources for $189 million in cash and a $65 million, three-year loan.

title: Feingold Defies Party And Retains Senate Seat
description: Senator Russell D. Feingold, who defied conventional political wisdom and the wishes of his own Democratic Party by sharply limiting the campaign money he would accept, was re-elected today in one of the country's most closely watched races.

title: Doubleheader For Baseball Account
description: Major League Baseball named two agencies to handle its 1999 national advertising assignments, with spending estimated at $10 million to $20 million.

title: At the Polls, Tolerance For Clinton Runs Deep
description: The voice of the people had a decided edge of exasperation to it on Election Day when voters were asked whether the threatened impeachment of President Clinton was a factor in their ballot decisions.

title: Milutinovic Signs Two-Year Contract
description: The MetroStars, as expected, have named Bora Milutinovic as their next head coach and have signed him to a two-year contract.

title: Examining Mexico's Zapatista Uprising
description: Sorting through the political and social mess portrayed in Nettie Wild's clear-eyed documentary film ''A Place Called Chiapas'' is not easy. Nor do there seem to be any simple solutions to the simmering conflict examined by the film between disenfranchised Mayan Indians in the southern Mexican state of Chiapas and the ruling Government against which they have been waging a fitful guerrilla rebellion.

title: The Urbane, Gay Father of 'Frankenstein'
description: ''Gods and Monsters'' was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 26. The film opens today in theaters.

title: Democrats Retain Hold On Assembly In Albany
description: The balance of power in the New York State Legislature remained relatively unchanged yesterday, as Democrats retained their firm grip on the State Assembly despite a strong victory by the Republican Governor, George E. Pataki.

title: Indonesian Army Is Blamed For Role in Spring Violence
description: Members of the Indonesian military helped to instigate the violence and looting in the Indonesian capital in May that killed nearly 1,200 people and led to the resignation of President Suharto, a fact-finding team concluded in a report released today.

title: DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA
description: The name missing from the ballot, Marion S. Barry Jr., was still far better known in the capital than that of the man who will replace him: Anthony A. Williams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIFFITHS, CAROLYN
description: GRIFFITHS-Carolyn. The Birch Wathen Lenox School mourns the loss of Carolyn Griffiths, a beloved, talented, and respected member of our administrative staff. We share in her family's bereavement and will remember Carolyn, John and Henrietta in our prayers. Frank J. Carnabuci, Headmaster The Birch Wathen Lenox School, New York City.

title: Late Count Shows Spitzer Virtually Tied With Vacco
description: The race for attorney general of New York State hung on a razor-thin margin early this morning, with the Democratic challenger, Eliot L. Spitzer, holding a lead of 33,000 votes out of 3.6 million cast over the Republican incumbent, Dennis C. Vacco.

title: Incumbents Prevail in 12 of 13 Districts Amid Very Low Voter Turnout
description: Democrats regained a one-seat majority in New Jersey's Congressional delegation today, as Rush Holt capitalized on Republican Representative Mike Pappas's vocal support of Independent Counsel Kenneth Starr to win a narrow victory in the 12th District.

title: When the Only Possible Interpretation Is Self-Serving
description: His talk show is off the air, and his life is in free fall after entering that show business dark zone known as ''between jobs,'' but Larry Sanders is still every inch the slightly off-kilter celebrity his fans came to know so intimately in ''The Larry Sanders Show'' on HBO. But he remains a man who hides nothing embarrassing, as we discover in his soon-to-be-released book, ''The Autobiography of Larry Sanders: Confessions of a Late Night Talk Show Host'' (Simon & Schuster), which tells all and then some.

title: Barbara Boxer Wins Hard-Fought Race for Senate Seat in California
description: In one of the most closely watched Senate races in the country, Barbara Boxer, the junior liberal Democratic Senator who won her first election in a hard-fought squeaker, won an even harder-fought race against her Republican challenger, State Treasurer Matt Fong.

title: Liberties; Day of the Dauphins
description: I got a call from Duffy.

title: Under the Toque; 'Here's Emeril!' Where's The Chef?
description: EMERIL LAGASSE, restaurateur, author, cult figure -- was carving turkey on the Thanksgiving episode of his hit cooking show, ''Emeril Live.''

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Autumn Leaves In That Pasta Bowl

title: Dodd Coasts To Victory And 4th Term In the Senate
description: Senator Christopher J. Dodd coasted to a fourth term tonight over former United States Representative Gary A. Franks, a widely expected outcome that seemed to be a reflection more of the incumbent's personal popularity in the state than a referendum on President Clinton or a barometer of the state's views on any particular issue.

title: OTHER HIGHLIGHTS
description: CALIFORNIA

title: With Friends, Clinton Views Returns as Positive for Him
description: President Clinton watched the election returns roll in tonight much the same way that he had campaigned: from the White House, in the company of loyal friends and quietly.

title: Shift Seen in London to Use of Euro Sooner
description: With subtle shifts of tone and emphasis, the British Government is signaling new warmth toward the soon-to-be introduced European single currency, promising to divulge a ''national change-over plan'' for the euro earlier than many people had previously thought.

title: Rethinking Jefferson, the Man and President; Character Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SILVER FALLS SHARPLY. The price plummeted as the dollar rose against major currencies, making silver more expensive to buy and more attractive to sell. Silver fell 11 cents, to $4.92 an ounce in New York.

title: A Pinch Hitter Displays a Vigorous and Eager Voice
description: Nicholas McGegan arrived from San Francisco at the 92d Street Y on Thursday evening with his chamber ensemble, the Arcadian Academy, but without his intended soloist, David Daniels, who was ill and had been scheduled to sing a couple of the Alessandro Scarlatti cantatas he has recorded with these musicians.

title: Sprucing Up a Shadowy Office Tower
description: The old Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield headquarters building at 622 Third Avenue is undergoing more than $10 million in renovations to turn its shadowy and forbidding public spaces into open, sunny and people-friendly destinations. The building's new owner says he expects that the changes will help attract new tenants by better connecting the building to the street and the neighborhood.

title: Middle East Accord in Peril As Both Sides Appeal to the U.S.
description: The fragile peace agreement between the Israelis and the Palestinians was severely tested today as both sides appealed to the United States to salvage the land-for-security accord, underscoring the central role of the Americans as arbiter and guarantor of the memorandum signed at the White House a week and a half ago.

title: Justices Question Iowa Law Allowing the Police to Search Cars in Traffic Violations
description: The State of Iowa asked the Supreme Court today to uphold a state law that gives the police essentially blanket authority to search a car after issuing the driver a citation for speeding or another routine traffic violation.

title: Journal; A Tale of Two Churches
description: If you walk into the Gothic shade of Grace Cathedral, at the top of Nob Hill here, you will find the last work created by Keith Haring as he was dying of AIDS, at age 31 in 1990. It's one of his typical gyrating graffiti cartoons -- and yet far more muted. Cast in bronze and drained of color, it is a triptych telling the story of Christ.

title: At a Time of Great Triumph, A Smile as Big as the Ritz
description: There was an impossibly gaudy crystal chandelier above him, a who's who of prominent New York Democrats around him and hundreds of wildly clapping, hoarsely cheering supporters at his feet.

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: Two incumbents, a Republican Senator and the Democratic Governor, handily won re-election.

title: Rethinking Jefferson, the Man and President
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUNS, MARY C.
description: BRUNS-Mary C. On November 2, at age 97. Adored wife of the late Thomas Bruns. Beloved mother of Patricia Ann Clark, loving grandmother of James, Russell, Robert and Kenneth Clark. Great grandmother of Caroline, Taylor, Jennifer and Christopher Clark.

title: An Outsider Is Elected Mayor of Washington
description: Anthony A. Williams started life as an abandoned infant in Los Angeles. Today, 47 years later, he was elected mayor of the nation's capital.

title: Lesbian Couple Awarded Joint Custody of Child
description: In the first ruling of its kind in the state, a Superior Court judge has awarded a lesbian couple joint custody of a child conceived through artificial insemination. The judge, Vincent J. Grasso of Ocean County Superior Court, found that one of the women, the nonbiological mother, who was identified only as R.E.M., had an emotional bond with the couple's 2 1/2-year-old son as strong as that between the boy and the other woman, the biological mother, identified as S.L.V.

title: WISCONSIN
description: Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, a Republican with a national reputation for welfare reform in his state, solidly defeated his Democratic opponent, Ed Garvey, a lawyer and former executive director of the National Football League Player Association. Mr. Thompson, first elected in 1986, was seeking a fourth term.

title: De La Hoya's Postponement Upsets Quartey Camp
description: The highly anticipated World Boxing Council welterweight championship bout between Oscar De La Hoya and Ike Quartey, scheduled for Nov. 21, was postponed yesterday, three days after De La Hoya cut the top of his left eyelid during sparring at his training camp at Big Bear, Calif. The fight has been rescheduled for Feb. 13 in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Democrats Boxer and Schumer Cruise, Although Republicans Retain Control
description: Republicans retained solid control of the Senate tonight, but struggled to pick up gains that would help advance their legislative agenda or a possible impeachment trial of President Clinton next year.

title: Sports of The Times; The Lockout Reminds Us: Get a Life
description: LAST night should have been the opening game in Madison Square Garden, the Knicks against the Celtics, but the entire National Basketball Association has been shut down.

title: Outspoken Union Leader Is Suspended
description: A union leader who is one of the most outspoken critics of Stanley Hill, the executive director of the giant union that represents 120,000 New York City municipal workers, has been suspended by his local's executive board in a move that he says is retribution for criticizing Mr. Hill.

title: Trader Vic Drank Here
description: AS John Glenn was orbiting the earth for the first time, his fellow Americans were deep into the long-lived craze known as tiki. This gaudy life-style package -- a blend of Polynesian kitsch, fake island food and lethal rum drinks -- began in the late 1930's and early 40's with Los Angeles restaurants like Don the Beachcomber and Trader Vic's, and gradually spread to the suburban patio before fizzling out in the early 1970's.

title: Malaysia on Trial
description: The trial of Anwar Ibrahim, which opened Monday in Malaysia, is a battle for the future of Southeast Asia. Mr. Anwar, once Malaysia's Deputy Prime Minister and leader-in-waiting, faces charges of interfering with investigations of his alleged sexual misconduct. More charges await him. All are questionable. The more likely reason for his arrest is that Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, worried by the fall of President Suharto in Indonesia, felt threatened by Mr. Anwar's popularity and reform agenda. But Dr. Mahathir has miscalculated. His attack on Mr. Anwar, the most important of a new generation of Asian leaders, is fueling support for reformist ideas across the region.

title: Spain Making Contact With Basque Rebels
description: Spain's Prime Minister said today that he had authorized his Government to talk with people close to the leading Basque guerrilla group to test the trustworthiness of the rebels, who announced what they called an indefinite cease-fire six weeks ago.

title: Central Americans in New York Scramble to Help Hurricane Victims
description: Central Americans in New York stepped up their efforts yesterday to help the victims of Hurricane Mitch, the killer storm that has swept up entire villages and cities in Central America and caused the deaths of more than 7,000 people.

title: New Faces In the Congress
description: NEW YORK

title: Devils Still Dominate Rangers
description: Scott Niedermayer was on top of Mike Richter on his first two shifts of the season, sending a loud signal to the Rangers that he would upgrade the Devils' offense.

title: Business Travel; Customer complaints about airlines and hotels are on the rise, but don't expect many changes.
description: THERE is nothing new about complaints of crowded airplanes, cramped airline seats and high-priced hotel rooms that do not allow guests to check in before midafternoon -- and which, when they do finally check in, they frequently find dirty. But the complaints have grown louder in each of the last five or six years since the airline and hotel industries struggled back from the financial brink.

title: RHODE ISLAND
description: Governor Lincoln C. Almond, the Republican incumbent, beat Myrth York, the challenger, in a civil -- almost boring -- rematch that lacked any galvanizing issue.

title: Con Ed Union Negotiates Extension of Its Contract
description: The union representing 9,500 workers at Consolidated Edison has negotiated a tentative two-year contract extension that includes unusual job security provisions and a wage increase of 3 percent in 2000 and again in 2001.

title: MARYLAND
description: The governor's race was a rematch of 1994, with a narrow victory by Parris N. Glendening, the Democrat and a former county executive, over Ellen R. Sauerbrey, the Republican and a former minority leader in the State Legislature's lower house. Mr. Glendening won his first term by fewer than 6,000 votes; he won his second, but the outcome was in doubt until Election Day.

title: In Hollywood, a Coffee Shop Can Be a Star
description: Brad Pitt eats pancakes there. Sandra Bullock asks for huevos rancheros. Nicolas Cage shows up with his family for brunch. And Vince Vaughn and Jon Favreau, over numerous cups of coffee, worked out the plot of the movie ''Swingers'' and actually filmed a crucial scene there.

title: KENTUCKY
description: One of the year's pivotal races was the campaign to fill the seat of the state's retiring Democratic Senator, Wendell H. Ford. It was close and rough: the Republican, Representative Jim Bunning, ran an advertisement picturing his Democratic opponent, Representative Scotty Baesler, gesturing frantically while the music of Richard Wagner played on the soundtrack. Democrats, noting that Wagner was one of Hitler's favorites, furiously said the advertisement tarred Mr. Baesler as ''Nazi-esque.'' Each man accused the other of lying about issues like Social Security and health care.

title: Emerson Raises Dividend
description: The Emerson Electric Company, a manufacturer of electronic equipment, motors and industrial components, said yesterday that it would increase its dividend 10.1 percent. A quarterly dividend of 32.5 cents, increased from 29.5 cents, will be paid on Dec. 10 to shareholders of record as of Nov. 20. Emerson, which is based in St. Louis, had annual revenue of $12.3 billion last year. In May, Emerson agreed to acquire the Westinghouse process-control operations of the CBS Corporation in a deal worth $265 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMER, FRED
description: ZIMMER-Fred. Died peacefully on Nov. 2, 1998. Devoted husband of Anna ''Honey''; beloved father of Dr. Harold Zimmer and Phyllis Arn Zimmer of Bellevue, WA.; Sarah Chapman and Sam Chapman of Greenbrae, CA.; and Bonnie Zimmer and Jim Ptacek of Cambridge, MA. Proud grandfather of Allegra and Sabina Chapman and Alex Ptacek Zimmer. Cherished brother of Marilyn Heischober and Rosalie Soladar. His sense of humor and love of nature created his second career as a craftsman and was the source of much joy to all. Contributions to a charity of your choice or The Rice Public Library, Kittery, ME. 03904. Service will be held Thursday, 1 PM, from Kirschenbaum, 1700 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Embattled Democrats Pull Through as Republicans Appear to Fall Short of Predictions
description: Republicans in the House seemed to be falling short last night of the gains they had predicted, as one embattled Democrat after another won re-election in the face of the yearlong scandal over President Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: The Bland, the Bitter and the Furry
description: ABOUT 50 varieties of edible mushrooms are available commercially in the United States, though not at all seasons. I tried eight of the most commonly available cultivated mushrooms alongside their wild cousins -- tasting them and cooking with them. Note: health experts suggest cooking exotic mushrooms thoroughly to neutralize the enzymes that can cause stomach pains.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, ELEANOR
description: KATZ-Eleanor. On November 2, 1998. Sister of the late Edith Rosston. Beloved aunt of Susan Rosenberg and great-aunt of Mara and Heather Rosenberg. Longtime devoted friend of many. She will be missed by all who knew her.

title: Details Doom Assisted-Suicide Measures
description: Last November, when Oregon voters reaffirmed their support for doctor-assisted suicide, some commentators called it a turning point for the ''right to die'' movement. But the lopsided defeat of a similar proposal in Michigan yesterday is a better barometer: in general, assisted suicide continues to fare badly in the political arena.

title: PENNSYLVANIA
description: Gov. Tom Ridge and Senator Arlen Specter, both Republicans, cruised to easy victories. But as the polls closed, it was unclear whether they had long enough coattails to carry Republicans to victory in three highly competitive Congressional districts that run northwest from Philadelphia through Scranton.

title: No More Child Soldiers
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Where Parents (at Home) Can Go for Expert Advice on Child Rearing
description: Are there rules of thumb to guide parents checking a baby sitter's references? How does one get a preschooler to clean her room? Are there ways to make a new teen-age driver safer?

title: MONTANA
description: In the race for the state's only House seat, the first-term Republican incumbent, Rick Hill, had a slight edge in the polls over the Democratic challenger, Robert Deschamps, who served as the Missoula County prosecutor from 1971 until September of this year. The race tightened up in the final weeks of the campaign.

title: Voters Back End to State Preferences
description: Giving a major lift to critics of affirmative action, Washington State voters tonight appear to have soundly approved an initiative that would ban most state-supported forms of the policy. They did so two years after California voters made theirs the first state in the nation to do so, and the vote is almost certain to spur efforts in other states.

title: Jurassic Banquet Or Just a Snack?
description: Fox used some giant dinosaurs to take a bite out of NBC last week, but considering how much Fox paid for the meal, it might be questioning how much bite it got for its buck.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: All four of the Congressmen who faced serious challenges in their bids for re-election won another term.

title: 2,000 at ABC Who Struck Are Barred From Studios
description: Two thousand ABC employees who went on a 24-hour strike on Monday were not allowed to return to work yesterday morning. Signs were posted on doors of ABC's offices and studios in five cities -- New York, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Chicago and Washington -- announcing a lockout of workers.

title: Sounds of Silence Echo in N.B.A.
description: Just across the street from Madison Square Garden, Paul Vellios was sitting with a dozen of his regulars at the bar of Cafe 31 last night, with his eyes fixed on an empty dining room.

title: A Departure At Angotti, Thomas
description: Rochelle Klein, executive creative director at Angotti, Thomas, Hedge in New York since 1993, is leaving that agency to join Tierney & Partners in Philadelphia as its chief creative director, effective Dec. 1.

title: Marks & Spencer Profit Hurt by Slowing Sales
description: Reporting its first profit decline in seven years, Marks & Spencer P.L.C., Britain's largest clothing retailer, warned yesterday that earnings would deteriorate further as waning consumer spending erodes sales. Its shares plunged, falling 45 pence, to 404. Profit in the six months that ended on Sept. 26 fell below analysts' forecasts, to $:180.5 million ($299.6 million), down 44 percent from $:321.4 million a year earlier. The decline came as sales dropped and company spending rose.

title: IDAHO
description: Representative Helen Chenoweth, one of the most conservative Republicans in the House, was in a tough fight for a third term against Dan Williams, a Democrat. Mr. Williams, a lawyer from Boise, had been ahead in the opinion polls.

title: Yankees Awaiting Johnson And Cone
description: While David Cone's future with the Yankees remained unclear yesterday, the Yankees' chances of luring Randy Johnson to New York, if their interest is sincere, may be more clear.

title: WYOMING
description: In the Governor's race, the major issue was Wyoming's weak economy. But the Republican incumbent, Jim Geringer, won re-election. The state's only Representative, Barbara Cubin, a Republican, was also favored to keep her seat.

title: Walnuts: Every Guise Imaginable
description: THE annual walnut harvest, a bountiful one, is under way in California, this country's walnut headquarters.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Madison, on the Park

title: Power Loss Interrupts Train Service for Hours
description: Railroad service between New York and Kearny was disrupted for more than three hours yesterday after a loose cable fell from a construction site on a bridge over the New Jersey Turnpike and onto overhead lines that provide power for the trains, officials said. The power loss started about noon and lasted until 3:20 P.M., delaying 13 New Jersey Transit commuter trains and 15 Amtrak trains carrying 5,000 to 10,000 passengers between New York and Kearny, said Rick Remington, a spokesman for Amtrak.

title: Use of Force On Bicyclist Is Investigated
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office and the Police Department's Internal Affairs Bureau are both investigating the case of a 36-year-old man who fell into a coma last week after a police officer chasing him down a Harlem street threw a police radio at him, knocking him off his bicycle, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: STC BROADCASTING BUYS FIVE NORTH DAKOTA TV STATIONS
description: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. said yesterday that its television broadcasting affiliate, STC Broadcasting, had acquired five television stations in North Dakota from the closely held Meyer Broadcasting Company for $63.8 million. Hicks, Muse, a Dallas investment firm, said the stations, all affiliates of the NBC network, were KFYR-TV of Bismarck; KVLY-TV of Fargo; KUMV-TV of Williston; KMOT-TV of Minot, and KQCD-TV of Dickinson. STC Broadcasting was formed in 1996 by Hicks and the closely held Sunrise Television Corporation, based in St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: League Official Calls Talks 'Dead in the Water'
description: After a week of bargaining and optimism, the two sides in the National Basketball Association's labor dispute are now faced with a sobering obstacle: they can't agree on the mechanics of a basic economic issue, a development that may soon lead to canceling more games.

title: From Boston to New York, Cities Are Changing
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats Retain Both Houses, Keeping Balance of Power
description: Democrats withstood the re-election of Gov. John G. Rowland today and kept control of both houses of the Connecticut Legislature despite a feverish effort by Republicans to capture the Senate, where Democrats hold a bare majority.

title: OREGON
description: If Oregon voters faced a relatively quiet election, it was due to the popularity of two Democratic incumbents, Gov. John Kitzhaber and Senator Ron Wyden, in statewide races.

title: SOUTH DAKOTA
description: Bill Janklow, the populist Republican Governor, told South Dakota voters that his re-election race was ''a referendum on me -- you are going to fire or rehire me.'' Mr. Janklow was rehired, easily.

title: British Petroleum Profit Falls 36%
description: The British Petroleum Company said today that its operating profit fell 36 percent in the third quarter, which was less than expected, as it made more money from refining, blunting the impact of a slump in oil prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOREIN, SARAH
description: KOREIN-Sarah. We mourn the loss of a remarkable woman and valued client. Our heartfelt condolences to Julius, Elysabeth, James, Jonathan, Beth and Peter and her great grandchildren. Lawrence N. Friedland Samuel P. Roth Warren Gleicher Hoffinger Friedland Dobrish & Stern, PC

title: MINNESOTA
description: The Democratic candidate for governor, Hubert H. Humphrey 3d, had several assets. As the son of the former Vice President, he carried a name revered in Minnesota politics, and as State Attorney General, he recently obtained a $6.1 billion settlement of a lawsuit against the tobacco industry, which bans the marketing of cigarettes to children in the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEISSNER, KATHARINE HYDE (NEE WORMELLE)
description: MEISSNER-Katharine Hyde (nee Wormelle). Reading specialist, age 86, in Rowley, MA, November 1, 1998. Former resident of Wellesley Hills and West Falmouth, MA. Wife of the late John Niemeyer Meissner. Graveside service at Mt. Auburn Cemetery, Cambridge, Mass. In lieu of flowers, donations to Alzheimers Association, P.O. Box 8036638, Chicago, IL. 60680-8984. For information: Elliott, Woodworth & Rogers, 35 Green Street, Newburyport, MA. 01950.

title: Referendums on Horse Racing And Open Spaces Approved
description: New Jersey voters gave approval today to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposal to borrow $1 billion to help preserve half of the state's 2 million acres of remaining farmland and woodlands over the next 10 years.

title: Classical Labels Shoot for Superstars; The Crossover Artist Is Becoming A Lifeline for Record Companies
description: Ten years ago, Gregory Barbero's career at Polygram Classics and Jazz, the recording branch of the international Polygram corporation, was taking off as rapidly as the company's sales of classical compact disks.

title: MASSACHUSETTS
description: The close fight for governor, between Acting Gov. Argeo Paul Cellucci, a Republican, and Attorney General Scott Harshbarger, a Democrat, grew so contentious that commentators described their final debate as a ''brawl.''

title: GEORGIA
description: State Representative Roy E. Barnes, a conservative-leaning Democrat, defeated his Republican opponent, Guy Millner, in the race to succeed Zell Miller as Governor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNN, CHARLES F.
description: DUNN-Charles F. Suddenly on November 2, 1998. Beloved husband of Mary (nee Kearns). Reposing Wednesday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM at Henry McCaddin & Son Funeral Home, 24 7th Avenue, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Church of St. Augustine, Thursday, 10:15AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLLHEIM, NORBERT
description: WOLLHEIM-Norbert. The Officers and Members of the Kindertransport Association mourn the passing of Norbert Wollheim who escorted many of us on the rescue trips from Nazi Germany to England. We extend our sincere sympathy to his family. Kurt Goldberger, President

title: VERMONT
description: Howard Dean, who has been Governor since 1991, won another two-year term in this year's race against the Republican candidate, Ruth C. Dwyer, a member of the state House. Mr. Dean had a huge advantage in opinion polls last month and was even endorsed by some moderate Republicans.

title: NEBRASKA
description: In the governor's race, Mike Johanns, the Republican Mayor of Lincoln, completed a remarkable political story. Mr. Johanns came to prominence in May when he was the surprise primary winner over Representative Jon Christensen and John Breslow, a businessman.

title: Popular Ex-President Announces Plans to Run Again in Nigeria
description: Surrounding himself with supporters in his home village who call him ''father,'' Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo announced here today that he would seek the presidency of Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation.

title: New Jersey's Congressional Races
description: Results as of 12:02 A.M.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SCHOOL SPECIALTY INC., Appleton, Wis., a supplier of non-textbook education products, said it was eliminating 300 jobs, or 14 percent of its work force, and closing distribution and customer-service centers.

title: Neighbors Pitch in to Help a Farmer Become Something Else
description: The classified advertisement was tucked away on page 22 of the Addison County Independent, the twice-weekly paper serving 7,000 readers in the shadow of the Green Mountains.

title: It's Glossy and Flashy, A Vietnam Must-Read: FOR WOMEN IN ASIA, A NEW ERA STILL RAISES QUESTIONS
description: HO CHI MINH CITY  The runaway success of a recently launched Western-style women's magazine has government officials here lamenting a moral decline and has raised accusations of illegal foreign investment, but Vietnamese women just can't get enough of Phu Nu.

title: New Orleans Seeks Millions In Gun Suit
description: The City of New Orleans last week became the first city to sue firearms manufacturers, seeking millions of dollars for the cost of gun violence, and several more are expected to follow in the next few months, city officials and gun control advocates say.

title: George W. and Jeb Bush Are Easily Elected Governors in Texas and Florida
description: George W. Bush set down his peanut butter and raspberry jelly sandwich and wrinkled his nose, as though the aide on the other side of the tiny campaign plane had tossed him liverwurst by mistake. But it wasn't the sandwich. It was that word someone just said.

title: A New Iron Gives Waffles Character
description: THE electric waffle iron is one appliance from the 1950's that never really evolved. While newer items like the food processor combine the tasks of many tools and gadgets, the waffle iron still does just waffles. It must be pulled out of the closet and plugged in, it does only a couple of waffles at a time and it is difficult to clean. And at about $40, it seems a bit high for something people do not use very often.

title: CALIFORNIA
description: It has been 16 years since the nation's most populous state had a Democratic governor. The last one was Edmund G. Brown Jr. And the next will be Mr. Brown's former chief of staff in Sacramento, Gray Davis.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOORE, LOUISE LANE
description: MOORE-Louise Lane. Born May 29, 1898. Died peacefully September 9, 1998. She was married to the late Harry A. Moore. She was a past President of Phi Mu Fraternity, active in AAUW and Marble Church. Memorial service at Marble Church, 29th St and 5th Ave, New York City, November 7, 1998, 12:30PM. Contributions to Phi Mu Foundation or Marble Church

title: THE CHEF
description: CHI-CHI, beignets, glace et boissons fraiches,'' the French vendors would call out along the beach in Nice: ''Crullers, beignets, ice cream and cold drinks.'' The sing-song phrase is engraved in my memory from summer days playing along the Mediterranean. I can't recall how we managed to eat those beignets -- thin slices of apple dipped in batter and fried -- with sandy, salty fingers. But I know we did, because each time I make one I can see the beach.

title: Leading Index Is Unchanged Once Again
description: The index of leading economic indicators was unchanged in September for a second consecutive month, according to figures released today, suggesting that the economy may be slowing at a time when Federal Reserve policy makers are considering whether to cut interest rates again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPHAM, JANE FOSTER
description: LAPHAM-Jane Foster. Age 87, on October 27 in her home in Greenwich, CT., after a short illness. Devoted wife of the late Lewis A. Lapham. Beloved mother of two sons, Lewis H. and Anthony A. Loving grandmother of Nicholas, David, Andrew, Delphina and Winston Lapham. A memorial service will be held at 11AM on December 4, at the Round Hill Community Church, Greenwich, CT.

title: NEW MEXICO
description: Gov. Gary E. Johnson, a Republican, staved off a challenge from Martin J. Chavez, a Democrat and former Mayor of Albuquerque. A critical issue was taxes: Mr. Chavez said they might need to be raised. The two also differed on education, with Mr. Johnson favoring charter schools and tuition vouchers.

title: With a Dacquoise, It's What's on the Inside That Counts
description: SITTING in the glass case at Patisserie Bonte, surrounded by the desserts that made the bakery famous -- perfectly frosted cakes suffused with Grand Marnier and luscious raspberry chocolate mousse tortes -- the dacquoise looks rather unprepossessing. It is round, rather flat, and has only three layers of meringue and filling. There are no flamboyant architectural spears, and on its top is nothing more than a dusting of powdered sugar.

title: Some Queens Machines Refuse Democrat Votes
description: Voting in a section of southeastern Queens was disrupted yesterday when poll workers discovered that all the machines had malfunctioned in the same way: the levers for Charles E. Schumer and Eliot L. Spitzer, the Democrats in the tightest statewide races, were disabled.

title: Pataki Wins Election to a Second Term by a Hefty Margin
description: George Elmer Pataki swept to a second term as Governor of New York yesterday, defeating his weak and splintered opposition by one of the largest margins in history, a victory so resounding that it is certain to raise his national profile.

title: DELAWARE
description: Representative Michael N. Castle, a Republican, coasted to victory in his quest to win a fourth term as the holder of Delaware's at-large seat, defeating the Democratic challenger, Dennis E. Williams, an accountant.

title: Excerpts From Speeches by Schumer and D'Amato
description: Representative Schumer

title: U.S. Says It Is Able to Strike Iraq From the Persian Gulf
description: As the United States pressed an intense diplomatic campaign to isolate President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, Administration and Pentagon officials said today that they had sufficient forces and firepower in the Persian Gulf to launch a strike on Iraq within days.

title: McCall Solidly Re-elected to Second Full Term
description: H. Carl McCall, who climbed from an impoverished childhood to become the first black candidate elected statewide in New York, easily won re-election yesterday to a second full term as State Comptroller.

title: ARKANSAS
description: Blanche Lincoln, a Democrat, defeated State Senator Fay Boozman in the race for the Senate, ending Republican hopes of winning a second Senate seat.

title: DEMOCRATS HOLD OFF G.O.P. ADVANCE, WEAKENING IMPEACHMENT PROSPECTS; SCHUMER OUSTS D'AMATO; PATAKI WINS
description: Democrats roared back in the midterm elections yesterday, winning impressive victories in crucial Senate and gubernatorial races around the country despite months of dire predictions by Republicans and Democrats that President Clinton's scandal would drag down his party's candidates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, EDGAR J.
description: MOORE-Edgar J. To Helen, Wendi, Walter, Jimmy, and Tommy: We share your pain and sorrow. The Pachts and Brickmans

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROHRLICH, EDITH
description: ROHRLICH-Edith. November 3, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Chester, dear mother of Adele Rohrlich and Elinor Koeppel, devoted grandmother of Gerard (Diane) and Constance Koeppel, and loving great-grandmother of Jackson, Harry, and Katherine. Contributions to the Jewish Child Care Association.

title: A Gala That Shows Off Why It Is
description: The Lar Lubovitch Dance Company celebrated its 30th anniversary on Monday with a one-night gala at City Center that offered a selective retrospective of Mr. Lubovitch's choreography.

title: For Mondavi, It's Still Full Speed Ahead
description: NO one has been more closely associated with the California wine revolution than Robert Mondavi. Probably because he started it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINSTEIN, ABE
description: MINSTEIN-Abe. Loving husband, father, grandfather, died of Alzheimers Disease in Tucson, Arizona, October 30, 1998.

title: The public passes a drive-by quiz that mixes the science of biology with the art of billboarding.
description: EVEN in a nation where researchers have found that many adults do not know whether the earth revolves around the sun or the sun around the earth, a Houston advertising agency is betting that people driving down the highway or flipping through a magazine in these days after the O. J. Simpson trial and Kenneth Starr report will know what DNA is.

title: Rethinking Jefferson, the Man and President; Accept the Truth
description: To the Editor:

title: UTAH
description: Voters in Utah, long a conservative stronghold, were expected to re-elect most Republican incumbents overwhelmingly.

title: ILLINOIS
description: Carol Moseley-Braun became the first black woman elected to the Senate when she won in 1992, but this year was among the Senate's most endangered incumbents.

title: A Bure-for-Palffy Deal Is What the Isles Need
description: Evaluating hockey standings a month into the season is like surveying indicator precincts on election morning. The early numbers might accurately predict the final results; or they might seriously mislead. An example might be the pecking order of the Eastern Conference and the Atlantic Division last night when the Rangers lost to the Devils, 3-1, in the Meadowlands. Before the game, both Hudson River rivals looked north in the standings to the first-place Islanders, who have won little since the first Reagan Administration.

title: Jets Cut Hansen, Punter, for a Second Time
description: Bill Parcells, in the final minutes of his news conference on Monday, expressed a bit of confidence in the ability of his punter, Brian Hansen, commenting that he did not believe he would bring in another punter to try to displace him. But, pained as he seemed by the reality of the situation, Parcells has always let his players know where they stood, and Hansen was on tenuous ground.

title: Parsley Moves To Plate's Center
description: PARSLEY is, without a doubt, the most underrated herb in the United States. We fuss over basil, fall in and out of love with cilantro, experiment with lavender and nearly ignore parsley.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I voted against the Republicans for being such pinheads, for not getting down to issues. It's a dangerous time in this country when people start prying into peoples' private lives and not taking care of business.''

title: Beyond the Schumer Victory
description: Splitting their tickets with practiced skill, New Yorkers picked Representative Charles Schumer, a Democrat, for their new Senator while overwhelmingly endorsing the Republican Governor, George Pataki, for a second term. The great drama of the night, however, was Senator Alfonse D'Amato's fall. It seemed to epitomize the surprising difficulties his party found in holding onto the Congressional majority, and suggest a public verdict on the bare-knuckle style of Republicanism that has become the fashion in Washington since 1994.

title: MICHIGAN
description: Gov. John Engler, the Republican, won a third term in a campaign made lively, if not competitive, by the outspokenness of the Democrat, Geoffrey Fieger. The Engler campaign suggested that Mr. Fieger was running against his own mouth. Mr. Fieger called Mr. Engler a ''moron.''

title: VIRGINIA
description: Virginia's Governor and two Senators were not up for re-election, and few of its 11 House races were contested. Every House incumbent, Democrat and Republican, won by a big margin.

title: Potholeville Laments Loss Of the Island Park Senator
description: As soon as the clock on the wood-paneled wall struck 9 tonight -- marking the close of polling across the state -- the volume of the television set at the American Legion hall here rose, and the nervous murmuring of the gathered D'Amato faithful died. This just in: the 18-year tenure of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Island Park's favorite son, had just ended.

title: Disney Quarter Net Falls 24%; Weakness in Films Is Cited
description: The Walt Disney Company said today that its fiscal fourth-quarter net income fell 24 percent because of weak films such as ''Holy Man'' and ''Beloved'' and lower demand for its consumer products in places like Japan.

title: All Incumbents Re-elected; Party Makeup Is the Same
description: All 27 of the incumbents seeking re-election to the House of Representatives from New York State sailed to victory yesterday, and four open seats went to two Republicans and two Democrats, leaving the makeup of the delegation unchanged.

title: Meeting on Plant Closing
description: GPU Nuclear Inc. of Parsippany, N.J., moved closer to shutting down its Oyster Creek nuclear power plant yesterday when company officials and the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission met to discuss preliminary steps to dismantle the plant safely.

title: NEVADA
description: With thousands of people relocating to this state each year, the incumbent Senator and his challenger faced the same problem -- making themselves known to voters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAKE, VINCENT P.
description: BLAKE-Vincent P. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Vincent P. Blake, a life Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. William J. Cronin, President Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Reorganization of Debts Is Urged for Indonesians
description: When the director of a small property company here went in search of financing for a hotel he planned to build in central Java four years ago, he found banks at home and overseas lining up to give him money.

title: After the Portobello, It's Mushroom Mania
description: SECURITY checkpoints ward off uninvited visitors as they approach some of the mushroom farms that have long been part of this rolling Andrew Wyeth country south of Philadelphia. Corporate secrets are taking root in the nation's mushroom capital, and competition is accelerating the bucolic pace in an area where horse-drawn wagons still slow traffic along winding roads.

title: NORTH CAROLINA
description: In the race for senator, John Edwards, a telegenic trial lawyer who specializes in personal injury cases, defeated a two-term Republican incumbent, Lauch Faircloth, who made an emotional concession speech.

title: Israel's Nuclear Arms
description: To the Editor:

title: Equitable Reports A 23% Fall in Profit
description: The Equitable Companies reported a 23 percent decline in third-quarter earnings yesterday, largely because its investment business was hurt by the summer upheavals in global stock and bond markets.

title: For Israeli, All's Well That Ends Well
description: Nili Abramski, the Israeli women's marathon champion, achieved her personal best by three minutes in Sunday's New York City Marathon, but only after a wild adventure that nearly left her unable to begin or finish the race.

title: TEXAS
description: Gov. George W. Bush, a Republican who campaigned hard among Hispanic voters, won re-election by a decisive margin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCKER, LYMAN B.
description: TUCKER-Lyman B. Former ITT Executive died Oct. 26, 1998 in Sao Paolo, Brazil. He was 94. Also Managing Director, Fruehauf Trailer, S.A. and President AMF do Brazil, Lt. Col. U.S. Army, W.W. II, U.S. Military Representative, Allied Control Commission, Bucharest, Executive with ADELA, Sao Paolo. Graduated Yale 1925. Survived by second wife Ana R. Tucker & daughter Cristina Martorana of Sao Paolo, brother William E. Tucker, Old Saybrook, CT., also a son, Thomas Tucker of Broken Arrow, OK., and daughters June Lael of Boynton Beach, FL., and Jean Tomko of Hinsdale, IL.

title: On a Nicaraguan Road a Flow of Human Misery
description: In one way or another, every part of Nicaragua has been devastated by the relentless floods and landslides that followed Hurricane Mitch and were estimated to have killed as many as 9,000 people throughout Central America. But the real disaster zone begins here.

title: Norwegian Shipbuilder Warns of Weak Results
description: Shares in Kvaerner A.S. of Norway, Europe's largest shipbuilder, tumbled by as much as 19 percent yesterday after the company warned of a significant weakening in its third-quarter financial results. Kvaerner, which also has substantial interests in oil and gas and in construction, said its third-quarter results would be hurt by losses on certain projects, write-downs of assets and weak markets in nearly all its major businesses.

title: LOUISIANA
description: In the only statewide race, Senator John B. Breaux, a Democrat, cruised to a third term, running against State Representative James J. Donelon. Mr. Breaux outspent Mr. Donelon by more than 100 to 1, according to mid-October campaign finance reports. Beyond television advertisements, he barely campaigned.

title: Mayor's Campaign Finance Plan Is Approved
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's referendum proposal to revamp campaign financing for candidates for New York City offices easily won approval last night.

title: The Principal as Gulliver; Rule-Bound School Leaders Rely on Clever Diplomacy
description: When New York City school principals complain about a lack of power, they are talking about situations like the one Alexander Corbluth confronted the other day at the High School for Environmental Studies in midtown Manhattan. After running out of hallway lockers for some 200 students, he came up with what he thought was a simple solution: assigning them lockers in the back of classrooms.

title: Sarah Korein, 93, Whose Dainty Bearing Masked a Tough Property Investor, Is Dead
