description: Sarah Korein, who acquired some of the choicest real estate in Manhattan through bare-knuckle tactics cloaked by grandmotherly charm, died on Thursday at the North Division of Beth Israel Medical Center. She was 93 and lived in Manhattan.

title: D'Amato Fails, Finally, To Confound Rivals
description: For most of his 18 years in Washington, Alfonse M. D'Amato has been the Senator who never quite fit in. He was a conservative from a state of moderates and liberals, a machine-bred politician in an institution sprinkled heavily with Ivy League-trained debaters, a colorful showman whose predecessors and colleagues, from Herbert H. Lehman to Daniel Patrick Moynihan, were more muted and highbrow.

title: The Races for the U.S. Senate
description: Results as of 01:16 A.M.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a possible deal to provide Nasdaq and the American Stock Exchange a subsidy for a new headquarters near Times Square misstated the location in some copies. As noted in the related article, the site is at the northwest corner of 42d Street and the Avenue of the Americas, not the southeast.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Euro: Prenatal Force to Contend With
description: Currency traders attacked the lira in August, and were repelled when the central bank intervened to make it clear that it would maintain Italy's link to the euro, the single continental currency that comes into official use on Jan. 1.

title: A Luxurious Room With Big Ambitions
description: PEOPLE keep discovering La Fourchette.

title: Rethinking Jefferson, the Man and President; Half a Constitutency
description: To the Editor:

title: Rethinking Jefferson, the Man and President; A Job for Starr
description: To the Editor:

title: TENNESSEE
description: As expected, Don Sundquist, the Republican incumbent, easily won another term as governor, a job he came to in 1994 after 12 years in the House, where he served on the Ways and Means Committee. Governor Sundquist was so heavily favored that it was hard to find a challenger, and even when John Jay Hooker, who had the Democratic nomination in 1966 and 1970, stepped up for a third shot, it was never an all-out campaign.

title: Rowland Wins Overwhelming Re-election
description: Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut, a Republican, rode an economic recovery and a listless opposition to a landslide re-election today, overwhelming United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly in every region of the state, including her own Congressional district.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: MISSISSIPPI
description: The state's most interesting House race was for the Fourth District seat being vacated by Representative Mike Parker, a Republican. Ronnie Shows, a conservative Democrat, had name recognition as an elected highway commissioner and former state senator. Democrats saw this contest as one of their best opportunities to win a Congressional seat in the South. But Mr. Shows faced a difficult fight against the Republican candidate, Delbert Hosemann, a tax lawyer in Jackson, who tried to portray Mr. Shows as a liberal.

title: Calendar
description: Fusion or Not?

title: The Races for Governor
description: Results as of 12:45 A.M.

title: Nonvoters: Too Busy, Forgetful Or Skeptical
description: Rafael Rivera, a welder, was too busy working. Marty McCarthy, a maintenance man, forgot and never registered. Anna Kang, a bank manager, felt she did not have enough information about the candidates.

title: Rethinking Jefferson, the Man and President; Another Time
description: To the Editor:

title: FOUNDATION HEALTH SYSTEMS TO TAKE $117 MILLION CHARGE
description: Foundation Health Systems Inc. said yesterday that it would take $117 million in charges in the third quarter as it moves to leave unprofitable businesses and concentrate on increasing the profit of its largest health plans. Foundation, which is based in Woodland Hills, Calif., and is one of the largest American managed-care companies, also said it expected to report on Nov. 10 that its third-quarter profit from continuing operations was 24 cents a share, less than analysts' estimates. The company is moving to shed unprofitable units, close money-losing health-maintenance organizations and concentrate on its H.M.O.'s in California and the Northeast. The charges total $175 million before taxes. Foundation shares fell 50 cents yesterday, to $11.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: ARIZONA
description: Gov. Jane Dee Hull, the Republican incumbent, cruised to her first full term, despite the faction of state Republicans who felt that she was not conservative enough. Ms. Hull, a former junior high school teacher, state legislator and secretary of state, became Governor in September 1997, when Gov. Fife Symington was convicted of financial fraud. Her Democratic opponent, Paul Johnson, the former Mayor of Phoenix, tried to spark interest by promising tax cuts.

title: CANANDAIGUA BRANDS TO BUY MATTHEW CLARK OF BRITAIN
description: Canandaigua Brands Inc. has agreed to acquire the British beverage group Matthew Clark P.L.C. for $:215 million, or $359 million. Canandaigua, based in Fairport, N.Y., markets alcoholic beverages including Almaden wines, Corona beer and Barton's gin and vodka. It had sales of $880.2 million in the six months that ended Aug. 31. Matthew Clark, based in Bristol, England, produces cider products, wine and bottled water. It had sales of $:570.7 million in the year that ended April 30. Matthew Clark has suffered amid competition from brewers with deeper pockets.

title: Schumer Uses D'Amato's Tactics To Win Senate Election Handily
description: Charles E. Schumer, a Representative from Brooklyn with a tenacious political spirit and a huge campaign war chest, won election to the United States Senate last night, toppling Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and ending his reign as one of the most imposing figures New York Republicans have produced in 50 years.

title: NORTH DAKOTA
description: The power of negative advertising got a test in the race for North Dakota's House seat. The Republican challenger, Kevin Cramer, blitzed the state with advertising in an unsuccessful effort to unseat the Democratic incumbent, Earl Pomeroy. The advertising said Mr. Pomeroy ''supports Clinton's view that you shouldn't know if your own little girl is having an abortion.'' Pomeroy supporters noted Mr. Pomeroy had backed the state's parental notification law.

title: In Nassau, a Sense of Urgency About Every Vote
description: From dawn to well past dusk, Andrew Parise, the Mayor and Republican leader in this Long Island village, worked the phones ceaselessly today, trying to churn out a vote for Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a colleague and a close personal friend.

title: INSIDE
description: Mideast Accord Is Tested

title: A Trip to the South Pole On a One-Way Ticket
description: A FIRST RATE TRAGEDY

title: Rethinking Jefferson, the Man and President; Missing Chromosome
description: To the Editor:

title: Houston Ousts 6 Police Officers in Fatal Raid
description: In a case that has angered Hispanic residents of Houston, police officials here have dismissed six officers involved in a botched drug raid in which a Mexican landscaper was killed by police gunfire in his bedroom.

title: Festival Seeks Next Big Thing
description: Beginning tonight and ending Saturday, the CMJ Music Marathon -- an annual festival of concerts and seminars -- will sponsor some 1,000 bands at Manhattan clubs. Though rock, college music and alternative musical styles are at a commercial ebb, this is oddly one of the festival's strongest lineups in several years. Perhaps, with audiences thinning, bands are more likely to look at music-industry-oriented events like CMJ as a career advantage instead of a distracting obligation.

title: WASHINGTON
description: Patty Murray, a Democrat, became the state's first female Senator in 1992 -- and made a nationwide name for herself -- campaigning as the ''mom in tennis shoes'' who understood family issues. This year she had tough competition from another woman, Representative Linda Smith, a Republican with backing from the Christian right who got to the House in 1994 by unseating another Democratic incumbent. And in this, the third woman-versus-woman Senate race in history, Ms. Smith had the down-to-earth sound bites about ''fighting against leches in the workplace who hit on young women,'' making President Clinton an issue.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: An Architect Gives a Library Spaces to Read And to Dream
description: Manhattan has many libraries, big and small, young and old, and at least two of them are now much in the news. In the renovated Rose Main Reading Room at the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue at 42d Street, the very act of bending over a book now has a built-in majesty. Even first-time users may feel that they have been co-opted among Shakespeare's ''potent, grave and reverend seigniors.''

title: LOCKHEED PLANS CHARGE OF AT LEAST $300 MILLION
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation said yesterday that it would take a charge of $300 million to $400 million related to accounting changes involving development costs and that a $7 billion contract for fighter planes might be delayed. The company did not announce the timing of the charge or the impact on earnings. Lockheed Martin, the military contractor based in Bethesda, Md., mentioned the charge and the order during an update for industry analysts and shareholders in Fort Worth. The company also indicated that a potential sale to the United Arab Emirates of F-16 planes might not be completed as soon as expected. Lockheed's stock fell $2.8125 a share, to $109.0625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Chrysler Posts 20% Rise For Sales in October

title: Connecticut's Congressional Races
description: Results as of 12:12 A.M.

title: George W. Bush Is Re-elected in Texas; His Brother Jeb Is Victorious in Florida
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas was re-elected yesterday, and his brother Jeb was elected governor of Florida, meaning that brothers will be serving simultaneously as governor for only the second time.

title: IOWA
description: Tom Vilsack, a state senator, came from far behind in the campaign's final weeks to defeat Jim Ross Lightfoot and give Democrats the Governor's seat in Iowa, long controlled by the Republicans. Mr. Lightfoot, who two years ago almost unseated Senator Tom Harkin, found his erstwhile foe financing Mr. Vilsack's bid from a political action committee nicknamed ''Revenge PAC.''

title: Last Year's Best Take Different Routes
description: How is this for a head-turning change in the cast: Patrick Byrne became an instant success in horse racing one year ago when he saddled Favorite Trick and Countess Diana and won both the Breeders' Cup Juvenile and the Juvenile Fillies, then won Trainer of the Year when Favorite Trick was voted Horse of the Year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARLIN, ROBERT
description: KARLIN-Robert. We note with sorrow the sudden passing of a dedicated volunteer and dear friend. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Hilary Chilton, Auxiliary President North Shore University Hospital/ Manhasset

title: ALASKA
description: Gov. Tony Knowles, a Democrat elected in 1994 by a margin of just 536 votes out of more than 213,000 cast, was a solid favorite to win re-election. John Lindauer, a businessman, was the Republican nominee. But the race became utterly confused in late October, when the Republicans endorsed a write-in candidate, State Senator Robin Taylor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TILT, VICTORIA P.
description: TILT-Victoria P. Devoted daughter of Albert and the late Mary C. Born 1939, Vicki graduated from Miss Porter's School in 1957 and completed her studies at Briarcliff College in 1959. Vicki spent over 20 years in the travel business with Fredric Helton in Manhattan, NY. She was a woman of great love and thoughtfulness to her friends and family, aunt of four, greataunt of five, and godmother of twelve. Vicki will be deeply missed. Memorial service at St. John's, Salisbury, CT, 11:30 A.M., on Saturday, November 14. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Bide-A-Wee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHRANK, HERB
description: SCHRANK-Herb. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club mourn the loss of their esteemed Member, Friar Herb Schrank on October 31st, 1998. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Private services were held. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Exec Director

title: Got a Dime? Citibank and Chase End Test of Electronic Cash
description: Electronic cash may be joining jet packs, video phones and other world's fair wonders that never move from the future to the present.

title: Democrats Buck 20-Year Trend, Faring Well in Once 'Solid' South
description: In a remarkable night for a once dying breed, Southern Democrats regained governorships in Alabama and South Carolina, held on to the governorship of Georgia, defeated an incumbent Republican senator in North Carolina, and kept a Senate seat in South Carolina, according to partial vote tallies and surveys of voters leaving the polls.

title: James Day, 73, Hero in Battle for Okinawa
description: James L. Day, a former Marine Corps squad leader who belatedly won a Medal of Honor earlier this year for almost single-handedly killing more than 100 advancing Japanese at the height of the Battle of Okinawa and went on to become an unofficial ambassador of good will on the island, died on Oct. 28 at his home in Cathedral City, Calif. He was 73.

title: Widening a Career
description: Anderson Cooper, an ABC News correspondent, may have grown a bit restless after three years reporting more often for the lower-profile weekend news broadcasts than for ABC ''World News Tonight.'' His contract expired recently, and he had an intriguing offer from a cable network.

title: Kanell Not Only Giant Facing a Re-evaluation
description: As the reeling Giants face the toughest part of their onerous schedule, quarterback Danny Kanell is not the only player who will be under scrutiny. There is an expansion draft at the end of the season to fill the roster of the reconstructed Cleveland Browns and the Giants must decide who is expendable.

title: Relief Effort In Honduras In Dire Need Of Resources
description: Honduran authorities struggled today with meager resources to deal with catastrophic damage from torrential rains and floods spawned by a hurricane, as the official death toll for Honduras climbed, to 583. Experts expect that figure to go far higher.

title: When Willpower Isn't Enough: Decline of Ray Rhodes's Eagles
description: Talk radio, Philly style. Flak jacket required. One recent afternoon, the Philadelphia Eagles' owner, Jeffrey Lurie, a common target for fed-up Eagles fans, was again being savaged by callers. ''You know what I want, I want the Eagles to lose the rest of their games,'' one raspy-voiced man said, ''so Lurie will give up and sell the team.''

title: Games Children Watch
description: Add to the toy cupboard of children's television a new network devoted entirely to games children play. Nickelodeon announced yesterday that it will offer a new digital channel next year called Nickelodeon GAS, short for Games and Sport for Kids (minus the 'K').

title: OKLAHOMA
description: The state's Republican Senator, Don Nickles, the majority whip, easily won re-election. He had been so confident about his lead that in recent weeks he had gone to Georgia, to campaign for Senator Paul Coverdell.

title: The Wrath of Hurricane Mitch
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Long Ride Down From Penthouse
description: It wasn't a speech he was looking forward to making, but Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato had a good excuse for being late to concede to Representative Charles E. Schumer: He was stuck in a penthouse elevator for 25 minutes.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Nonreactive Pots

title: GENERAL RE TO BUY DP MANN HOLDINGS, A BRITISH INSURER
description: Jumping into the British insurance market, the General Re Corporation, a reinsurance giant, has agreed to acquire DP Mann Holdings Ltd. of Britain. General Re, based in Stamford, Conn., and involved in property and casualty insurance worldwide, was acquired in June by Berkshire Hathaway, which is controlled by the closely watched investor Warren E. Buffett, for $22 billion. DP Mann is one of the largest remaining independent agencies operating at Lloyd's of London. The companies did not disclose the purchase price.

title: HAWAII
description: A flagging economy and a ballot initiative on same-sex marriages roiled the normally languid political climate in the state this year.

title: Taking the Fad Out of Fashion
description: If glam is sweeping the fashion world, Marc Jacobs, Hussein Chalayan and Geoffrey Beene have not been told. And thank goodness. A more contrived trend there never was. Designers are in too much of a reflective mood to embrace anything as confrontational and wildly ersatz as glam-rock fashion -- a trend hailed by a few style-setters as the next big thing. Think of 1970's David Bowie, and glam-rock style suggests some ripe possibilities. But stretch the ruminations to present-day vestiges of glam like Kiss, and it quickly becomes clear that the possibilities are not so attractive after all.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about political contributions from the casino industry misstated the amount contributed by Hilton Hotels to the Republican National Committee. It was $150,000, not $250,000. The article also referred incorrectly to the relative amounts spent on the ballot referendum in California regarding Indian casinos in the state. The Indian tribes spent more than twice the amount spent by the casino industry; they did not merely match it.

title: U.S. Plans To Provide Food Relief To Russians
description: The United States is planning to provide millions of tons of food to help Russians stave off hunger and endure a bitter winter.

title: Growing Up With Il Duce The Deli Man
description: ON a darkened stage, Marco Greco breathed slowly, rolled his shoulders and prepared to transport himself back to 1975 and Arthur Avenue. A spotlight vanquished the void, rendering his face into a chiaroscuro mask of a wide-eyed child. ''Pop,'' he said in a pleading little boy voice, ''I don't like to make the mozzarella. I just like to eat it.''

title: A Menu That Would Stretch All the Way to Shanghai
description: IF there were prizes for menu writing, Evergreen Shanghai Restaurant might win one for length alone. This plain, bright restaurant, which opened on Mott Street almost a year ago, has a menu so long that you could start reading at lunch and finish at dinner, which would at least allow you to enjoy two delicious meals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAW, OTHO STOKES
description: SHAW-Otho Stokes, 74, of New York City and Hampton Bays, L.I. Partner in Shaw & Draper, Inc., Interior Designers; Fellow American Society of Interior Designers; Past President Alumni Association of Parsons School of Design. Beloved friend and partner of Dede Draper. Beloved brother of Lavon Morrow. Adored Uncle of Lester Morrow of Minneapolis, MN. He will be greatly missed by his dear friends in England and this country. Friends may call Wednesday 10-12PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St.

title: COLORADO
description: With their candidate traveling across the state on horseback, Colorado Democrats waged an intense and creative battle to keep one of their own in the governor's office, which Democrats have held since 1975.

title: Former Wife Given 29 Years for Ordering Gucci Slaying
description: The former wife of Maurizio Gucci, heir to the leather goods fortune, was convicted today of ordering his murder and sentenced to 29 years in prison.

title: Felons Don't Belong in the N.F.L.
description: Leonard Little, a St. Louis Rams linebacker, was charged last week with involuntary manslaughter after he slammed his sports utility vehicle into a car. The other driver died, and tests showed that Little's blood-alcohol level was nearly twice the legal limit.

title: Citigroup Is Facing First Law of Megamerger: The Inertia of Mass
description: Nearly 10 years ago, Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. merged to form Time Warner Inc., promising that the creation of the world's largest media concern would result in hefty profits from synergies among distinct products like magazines, films, music, books and cable television.

title: From Boston to New York, Cities Are Changing
description: To the Editor:

title: Slowly but Steadily, Democrat Overcomes Rivals for Governorship
description: Lieut. Gov. Gray Davis, a cautious career politician once dismissed as an uncharismatic underdog, gave Democrats the single biggest prize of this midterm election, defeating State Attorney General Dan Lungren tonight to become the 37th Governor of California, according to surveys of voters leaving the polls.

title: Shea Will Be Back In 1999
description: RUTGERS

title: From Boston to New York, Cities Are Changing
description: To the Editor:

title: Romantic Thunder With a Classical Polish
description: At his recital at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening, the pianist Maurizio Pollini gave his enthusiastic audience what it had come for: the high-powered, stunningly polished Apollonian readings that have long been his artistic signature, tempered by the earthy, almost theatrical emotionalism that has become part of his sound in recent seasons. His program, split evenly between Schumann and Chopin, supported that amalgam.

title: Holocaust Film Isn't About History
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOATZ, ANGEL OSCAR, M.D.
description: KOATZ-Angel Oscar, M.D. Beloved husband of Clara. Devoted father of Fernando and Catherine Koatz, Ronald and Caroline Koatz. Dear brother of Mario & Santiago Koatz. Adored grandfather of Benjamin, Gabriel, Sarah, Justin and Ashley. Services Wednesday, 9:30 A.M. at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd. and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: KANSAS
description: Bill Graves, the popular, moderate Republican Governor, won a second term against his Democratic challenger, Michael Sawyer, a State Representative who never caught up after waiting until the eve of the filing deadline to declare his candidacy.

title: ALABAMA
description: Don Siegelman, the Democratic Lieutenant Governor, defeated the incumbent Republican, Fob James, in the race for governor. Mr. Siegelman had tabbed Mr. James as someone more interested in issues like school prayer than actually doing anything to improve Alabama's schools.

title: Defending the Defenders of Abortion Rights
description: JANET L. BENSHOOF, the lawyer who heads the Center for Reproductive Law and Policy, did not know Dr. Barnett A. Slepian, the Buffalo obstetrician who was murdered, apparently because he performed abortions. But years ago, she represented his clinic.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about plans to build a superconducting power line in Detroit misstated the nature of the achievement for which Dr. K. Alex Muller and Dr. Georg Bednorz received the 1987 Nobel Prize in Physics. Their prize was awarded for their discovery of a new class of superconducting substances, which conduct electricity without resistance at temperatures much warmer than liquid helium, minus 452 degrees Fahrenheit -- not for discovering a substance that becomes superconducting at liquid nitrogen temperatures of minus 320 degrees.

title: Voters Show Own Agenda
description: The votes Americans cast in yesterday's midterm elections will inevitably have an impact on the impeachment proceedings against President Clinton and hence on the remaining months of his Presidency. But according to a survey of voters leaving the polls, that was not what most had on their minds.

title: WEST VIRGINIA
description: Solidly Democratic West Virginia gave its voters little to get excited about this year. There was no race for governor or the Senate, and as in 1996 Bob Wise, an eight-term incumbent, was the only House member to draw a Republican challenge.

title: Rethinking Jefferson, the Man and President; Comparing Scandals
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Thinking Ahead on Traffic
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's plan to open the underutilized car-pool lanes on Interstates 80 and 287 to all vehicles may well pacify irate motorists in northern New Jersey. But it is a short-term response that can only delay the kind of creative experimentation necessary to improve traffic flow in the New York metropolitan area, which is notorious for dirty air, bottlenecks and rush-hour jams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OXENBERG, ARTHUR
description: OXENBERG-Arthur. On November 2, 1998. Adored, cherished and loving husband of Susan, devoted father of Carla Israel, Jonathan and Philip. Dear grandfather of seven grandchildren. Services Wednesday 12 noon at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made in his memory to The American Heart Association.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA
description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings, a Democrat, beat back a strong challenge to win a sixth term. But Gov. David M. Beasley, a Republican, lost his re-election bid to former State Representative Jim Hodges, a Democrat.

title: FINGERHUT TO ACQUIRE POPULAR CLUB PLAN UNIT OF J. CREW
description: The Fingerhut Companies, the second-largest American catalogue retailer, agreed yesterday to buy the J. Crew Group Inc.'s Popular Club Plan unit for about $43 million to expand its presence in the Northeastern United States. Popular Club, which is based in Garfield, N.J., and sells general merchandise through a catalogue, has 660,000 moderate-income customers and annual sales of about $180 million. The purchase will be Fingerhut's third acquisition in four months as it aims to consolidate a fragmented industry with more than 8,000 companies. Fingerhut is based in Minnetonka, Minn. The majority owner of J. Crew, an apparel catalogue retailer, is the Texas Pacific Group, an investment fund led by the Texas financier David Bonderman.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: The Nightmare Of Election Night

title: Staying in Vogue; Clothing Designers Adjust to a Vastly Changed World
description: Walk inside any major department store, and the troubles that have torn the fabric of the fashion industry are evident.

title: Subordination Breaks Ankle
description: The 4-year-old colt Subordination, one of America's best hopes in the Breeders' Cup Mile against a strong European contingent, fractured his left ankle while galloping at Churchill Downs this morning and will race no more.

title: How to Succeed in Politics (by Really Trying Hard): Charles Ellis Schumer
description: Representative Charles E. Schumer's election yesterday to the United States Senate was more than the crowning achievement of a political career that has spanned nearly a quarter of a century. It was a testament to his own tenacity, to the high expectations he set for himself long before his election to the New York State Assembly when he was only 23.

title: Farm Chores and College Classics
description: On the brink of dawn, when almost any other college undergraduate would expect the right to sleep undisturbed, Emily Seifert slipped stoically out of her warm bed, pulled on boots and a snug jacket and trudged into the bracing chill of a New England autumn to lend a hand with the farm chores.

title: Paper Maker Cuts Output
description: The Stone Container Corporation has temporarily closed a mill in Montana, the company's second-biggest plant, as sagging Asian economies sharply reduce demand for the paper used to make cardboard boxes. Stone Container, based in Chicago, closed the plant in Missoula last Wednesday and expects to resume production by the end of this month. The shutdown will remove as much as 55,300 tons, or 1.1 percent of the company's total annual capacity, of containerboard, the thick paper used in boxes. About 540 of the mill's 670 workers were laid off.

title: Wanted: Goal Scorer. Apply Today at the Garden.
description: The Rangers score 1.55 goals a game whether they need to or not. While getting only one tonight, they lost by 3-1 to the Devils, ending their undefeated streak at six.

title: USN COMMUNICATIONS, BATTLING LOSSES, WILL DISMISS 650
description: USN Communications Inc., a provider of local telephone service, plans to dismiss 46 percent of its work force and take a $6 million fourth-quarter charge. USN said it would eliminate 650 positions, including nearly all of its direct-sales force and other business-development positions, and would consolidate sales offices. USN, based in Chicago, is trying to reorganize and deal with losses totaling more than $150 million since 1994. The company said that unless it was able to obtain financing to provide it with working capital ''in the very near term,'' there would be ''a material adverse effect.''

title: INDIANA
description: Evan Bayh, a Democrat whose campaign emphasized his political independence and shunned his party, won the seat in the Senate that was once held by his father, Birch. His Republican opponent was Paul Helmke, the Mayor of Fort Wayne.

title: Treasury Issues Climb Amid Signs That Economy Is Slowing
description: Bond prices rose for the first time in three sessions yesterday amid signs that the economy is slowing and as the highest yields in nearly two months attracted buyers.

title: No G.O.P. Sweep, Despite Rowland Broom
description: Connecticut Republicans had hoped that a landslide re-election victory by Gov. John G. Rowland could sweep G.O.P. candidates into the House of Representatives in two hotly contested districts. But their optimism proved unfounded.

title: Folkways of Spoiled, Dissolute West Side Teen-Agers
description: ''This Is Our Youth'' is back, and not a moment too soon. In a season in which some of the wise men of the theater have been trying to force-feed insipid fare like ''Stupid Kids'' and ''Footloose'' to young audiences, it's sheer relief to celebrate the return of a rambunctious and witty play about wayward teen-agers and post-adolescents that doesn't turn youthful travails into plastic rap.

title: New York's Congressional Races
description: Results as of 12:50 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, MILT
description: GOODMAN-Milt, on October 23, 1998. Beloved husband of Estelle. Dear father of Robert and Helen. Formerly Vice President of Columbia Pictures. Retired Major, U.S. Army.

title: Dow Ends Day Unchanged, In a Mostly Sluggish Session
description: Stocks were narrowly mixed in fairly sluggish trading yesterday as investors resisted pushing prices, which are now at levels not seen in nearly three months, any higher.

title: FLORIDA
description: Jeb Bush, the son of the former President and brother of the Texas Governor, won in his second attempt to become governor of Florida, a job he narrowly lost in 1994 to Lawton Chiles, who is retiring.

title: How to Assist Victims of the Flood
description: Many aid agencies are accepting contributions to help Central American flood victims. Here is a list of some of them:

title: Japanese Sales Were Inflated, U.S. Medical Company Says
description: Less than a month after the Boston Scientific Corporation was forced to recall a new medical device because of severe safety concerns, the company announced yesterday that its Japanese subsidiary had improperly inflated sales by millions of dollars.

title: Buyback by Cooper
description: Cooper Industries said today that it would repurchase about 10.6 million of its common shares, or $500 million in stock. The buyback represents about 9 percent of the company's 117 million shares outstanding. The shares rose $1.3125 today, to $47.0625. Cooper Industries, based in Houston, makes electrical products, tools and hardware. The company had 1997 revenue of $5.29 billion.

title: CONNECTICUT
description: Republicans thought they had finally come up with a campaign powerful enough to oust Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a three-term Democratic incumbent. But he proved his enduring popularity among voters and won re-election.

title: Top Official Wins Re-election, Defeating Former Newark Mayor
description: The Essex County Executive, James W. Treffinger, a Republican, scratched out a victory to win a second term tonight, frustrating the comeback hopes of Kenneth A. Gibson, who made history in 1970 when he became Newark's first black mayor.

title: Just Add Water: The Case for Dried Over Fresh
description: FRESHNESS is so sacred these days that a sometimes misguided reverence for it leads cooks to use fresh pasta no matter what, even when dried is more suitable. And with all the exotic mushrooms sold fresh in markets, they may ignore the dried. Big mistake.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday listing races to watch in the elections misstated the surname of the Republican candidate for the House from the Fifth District of Connecticut. He was Mark Nielsen, not Nelson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIRA, MOLLY
description: SPIRA-Molly. Died peacefully on November 3, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Bernhard Spira. Loving mother of Steven and Gale, Robert and Naomi. Dear sister of Eva. Adoring grandmother of Jennifer and David, David and Michele, Avi, Daniele, Etan and Benjamin. Great-grandmother to Max, Lily, Sarah-Golda and Yaakov. Funeral service will be held at 11:15AM at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SATTINGER, MAX
description: SATTINGER-Max. Aged 91, on Nov. 3, 1998. Formerly of Kew Garden Hills. Beloved husband of Ethel. Devoted father of Sam and Gilda Sattinger, Shirley and Seymour Rubin. Adored grandfather of Lisa and Lee Einbinder, David and Tori Sattinger, Richard and Beth Rubin. Cherished great grandfather of James, Russell, Willa and Jackson. Services are today 1:30PM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Trial in Malaysia Provokes Political Crisis
description: Two trials are under way in this suddenly fractious Southeast Asian country.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Anthony J. Celebrezze, a former Mayor of Cleveland who served as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare in the 1960's, misidentified a survivor, Mildred Ragucci. She is a sister, not a daughter.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICK, ROSE
description: GLICK-Rose. The Board of Directors and staff of The New York Association for New Americans, Inc. (NYANA), extend heartfelt condolences to our esteemed Board Member, Carl Glick and his family on the passing of his beloved mother, Rose. Our thoughts and prayers are with you in this time of sorrow. Laura G. Ross, President Mark Handelman, Executive V.P.

title: Yoshii and Nomo Status Holds Up Mets' Strategy
description: In theory, General Manager Steve Phillips has an abundance of starting pitching to deal from in his search for help in the Mets' outfield and at either second base or third base. But Phillips still needs to decide how much he wants to work out deals with Masato Yoshii and Hideo Nomo, all while he negotiates with Armando Reynoso's representatives.

title: Hewlett-Packard Plans Java Push
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company is planning to introduce several software development products based on the Java computer language for embedded microprocessor systems.

title: Wong Doody Wins Battle for Fit TV
description: Fit TV, a 24-hour cable television network with life-style and fitness programming aimed at women, said yesterday that it had named Wong Doody in Seattle to handle its account, which had been in-house. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: While Children Take the Day Off, Teachers Take Notes
description: The first time that Enid Gross, a former pharmaceuticals saleswoman, walked into a New York City classroom as a teacher, she was on her own.

title: Jerry L. Schwartz, Journalist
description: Jerry L. Schwartz, a journeyman journalist who was equally comfortable writing about baseball and Beethoven, died on Sunday at Northside Hospital in Atlanta. He was 51 and lived in Atlanta.

title: MELLON AND ABN AMRO FORM VENTURE IN CUSTODY SERVICES
description: ABN Amro N.V., the big Dutch banking company, formed an alliance yesterday with the Pittsburgh-based Mellon Bank Corporation to provide global custody services in a joint venture that will initially focus on financial institutions worldwide. The venture, to be called Amro Mellon Global Securities Services, will market its services worldwide except in Mellon's home market, the United States, and the markets where Mellon has existing alliances, including Canada, the Scandinavian countries, Spain and Portugal. The new company will provide financial institutions with custody services like compliance monitoring, investment accounting, performance measurement and analysis. Mellon's shares rose $1.625, to $62.4375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUZDOVACIC, DAMIRA
description: BUZDOVACIC-Damira. Nov. 1, 1998. Loving daughter, sister, aunt & friend to all who came into her path. Exceptionally gifted, deeply religious & profoundly benevolent, she left us too young and too soon. Her guiding light and generosity of spirit will be dearly missed. May she rest in peace. A Memorial Mass will be held Saturday, Nov. 7 at Church of Notre Dame, 405 114th St. at Morningside Drive, NYC, at 9:45 AM. All are welcome. Buzdovacic Family and her Loving Friends

title: Religious Conservatives, Stung by Vote Losses, Blame G.O.P. for Focusing on Clinton
description: For Christian conservative leaders, Tuesday's election was a pivotal test of their political power. They poured millions of dollars into key races, blitzed churchgoers with voter guides and helped persuade Republican leaders to make the election a national referendum on President Clinton's moral fitness for office.

title: Behind Smart Bathroom Fixtures: No Genie, Just Technology
description: SINKS, toilets and urinals in many public restrooms use infrared sensors to detect the presence of a person and activate the plumbing. There's no creepy voyeur lurking behind that small, dark sensor panel, just a lot of circuitry.

title: End Sanctions on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: ARKANSAS
description: In an important victory for Democrats, Blanche Lambert Lincoln won a seat in the Senate.

title: J&L SPECIALTY STEEL THINKS AGAIN ON USINOR TAKEOVER BID
description: J&L Specialty Steel Inc. said yesterday that a special board committee had withdrawn its recommendation supporting a $113 million proposal from Usinor S.A. to buy the 46.5 percent of J&L it does not already own because of unspecified additional information received from Usinor. J&L, a maker of flat-rolled stainless steel based in Pittsburgh, said the committee, composed of directors who do not work at either company, would study the new information and assess the company's options. Usinor, a steelmaker based in Paris, had agreed to buy 18 million shares of J&L for $6.25 a share, after having first offered $5.75 a share. J&L fell 12.5 cents, to $5.9375.

title: KLM Profit Plummets 59% in the Quarter
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said yesterday that its profit plunged 59 percent in its second quarter because of weaker business conditions in Asia and a damaging 15-day strike by pilots at its United States partner, Northwest Airlines. KLM said profit for the three months that ended Sept. 30 fell to 361 million guilders ($193 million) from 884 million guilders a year earlier. Sales were little changed from a year earlier at 3.7 billion guilders.

title: CAR 54, WHERE ARE YOU?
description: Police-scanner fans who are bored with the local airwaves can now go on line to hear police palaver from other cities. Broadcast.com offers live feeds of scanners from New York, Los Angeles and Dallas.

title: New Order for New York's G.O.P. and Democrats
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato has long reigned as the undisputed king of New York's Republican Party. He chose the party chairman, swayed votes for local committees and county leaders, raised money and labored to build a party machinery in every corner of the state that was effective and loyal to him.

title: Laptops on the Shuttle: Age Does Not Matter
description: WHEN the company sent them on a nine-day, round-the-world business trip last week, Curtis Brown Jr. and his six colleagues took along their laptop computers and a new color printer. Like many other business travelers, they are using the laptops to send and receive files, transmit digital pictures back to the home office, turn strings of drab data into colorful graphs and perform calculations.

title: Emergency Housing in a Hurry
description: WHEN a friend needed to find emergency housing, Marina Rodriguez made a quick stop at a new electronic kiosk at the Camden Transportation Center in Camden, N.J. By simply touching the screen, she could instantly view listings of temporary shelters and other housing programs. ''This is a great way to reach people,'' Ms. Rodriguez said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRASER, BERT H.
description: FRASER-Bert H. Died Nov. 3, age 58 in New York. Actor, comedian, singer, dancer, raconteur, boon companion, loyal pal. Dear Bertie, farewell from all your friends at the Amateur Comedy Club and the Snarks, who loved you and will remember you always. Viewing hours 5-9PM Friday and Funeral Service 11AM Saturday at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue. Memorial Celebration at 2PM Sunday at the ACC Clubhouse, 150 East 36 Street, New York, NY.

title: First Union Buyback Plan
description: The First Union Corporation said today that it planned to repurchase up to 50 million of its common shares, or $3 billion in stock. The buyback represents about 5 percent of the company's 990.4 million shares outstanding. The shares rose $2.125 today, to $61, on the New York Stock Exchange. First Union, the bank and financial services holding company based in Charlotte, has assets of about $235 billion.

title: French Youths Strike for the Right to Study Hard
description: Thousands of the 2.3 million high-school students in France plan to resume protests against poor study conditions with a demonstration in Paris on Thursday. But at the Lycee Gaston Bachelard in this Paris suburb students are torn about how hard they should keep pushing.

title: WEST VIRGINIA
description: West Virginia confirmed its status as a loyal Democratic state, re-electing three Democratic incumbents who faced either token or no Republican opposition. Representative Alan Mollohan and Nick Joe Rahall easily beat Libertarian candidates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBER, ROBERT, M.D.
description: SILBER-Robert, M.D., age 67, on November 3, 1998 in Durham, North Carolina. Formerly of New York City. Beloved husband of Barbara Kamhi Silber. Devoted father of Andrea (Phillip) Dickey, Jeffrey (Linda) Silber, Laura (Dusan Knezevic) Silber, and Michael Silber. Caring stepfather of Jay (Cathy) Kamhi, Katherine (Tony Coghlan) Kamhi & Adam Kamhi. Proud grandfather of Jack, Olivia, Aaron, & Mila & step grandfather of Emma, Madeleine, and Ivy. Cherished brother of the late Erich Silber and brother-in-law of Rita Silber. Dear uncle of Denise Silber, Mark (Alexandra Nicholson) Silber, and Ken Silber. Dedicated physician, researcher, professor and friend. A memorial service will be held Thursday, November 5th at 11 AM, at Howerton-Bryan Funeral Home in Durham, NC. A memorial service will also be held on Sunday, November 8 at 1:15 PM at The Riverside Chapel, 76th St & Amsterdam Ave., New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Department of Hematology, Duke University Medical Center or the Division of Hematology, New York University School of Medicine.

title: LUND TO ACQUIRE AUTO VENTSHADE FOR $66 MILLION IN CASH
description: Lund International Holdings Inc. agreed to buy the Auto Ventshade Company of Lawrenceville, Ga., for $66 million in cash to expand its line of light-truck accessories. Lund, in Anoka, Minn., said it would keep Auto Ventshade's operations intact and upgrade its Georgia plant, which makes window shades, hood shields, light covers and other accessories for trucks and cars. Lund makes bug shields, running boards, visors and other accessories for pickup trucks, sport utility vehicles and minivans. Lund bought the Deflecta-Shield Corporation for about $90 million in December, raising its estimated 1998 revenue to $130 million. Its shares were unchanged at $6.625. The announcement was made after the close of United States trading.

title: On Refugees, Italy Is No Ellis Island
description: To the Editor:

title: The Big City; Stargazing, As It Were, On Broadway
description: AS usual, the people walking up Broadway stared suspiciously at Tom McIntyre and his ''Sidewalk Astronomy'' sign. They knew the basic street hustles -- fake Rolexes, bogus cashmere, counterfeit videos, stolen books, rigged monte games -- and they had heard the old stories about guys selling a bridge. But selling the sky?

title: B. J. Dwyer, New Jersey Congressman, 77
description: Bernard James Dwyer, a former Representative from New Jersey, died Saturday in Edison, N.J., at the John F. Kennedy Medical Center, which he had served as a trustee. He was 77 and, a longtime Edison resident, had lived in Metuchen, N.J., for the last few years.

title: Long Live the Five-and-Dime
description: While most American towns just mourned their dead dime stores, the Historical Society of Delaware raised more than $5 million to turn a 1940 Woolworth's in Wilmington into a museum. In a city of du Pont mansions, this is a homage to daily life. On Dec. 9, the museum, called the Delaware History Museum, will open a $1 million permanent installation covering 400 years of the state's history, including 10 abstract environments, like a 17th-century Swedish log cabin. (Sorry, the soda fountain is gone.) The museum is at 504 Market Street; (302) 655-7161.

title: REYNOLDS METALS STOPS TALKS ON SALE OF UNIT TO SEQUA
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said it had agreed with the Sequa Corporation to stop negotiating a sale of its can-making machinery unit and that it would try to sell the unit to other companies. Reynolds said on June 15 that it had agreed to sell the unit to Sequa for an undisclosed price. The company said yesterday that a letter of intent to sell the unit had expired. Reynolds, which is based in Richmond and had $6.88 billion in sales last year, has been shedding assets to concentrate on packaging, smelting, bauxite mining and aluminum processing. Sequa, based in New York, makes industrial products. Reynolds rose $1.375 a share, to $58.50, while Sequa fell 6.25 cents, to $64.

title: Privacy for Police
description: To the Editor:

title: Livent Drops Times Square Theater Plans
description: Three months after agreeing to redevelop the last unclaimed historic theater on 42d Street, the financially troubled Canadian production giant Livent Inc. announced yesterday that it was dropping the project.

title: Military Recruiting
description: To the Editor:

title: OKLAHOMA
description: The solid victory by Gov. Frank Keating, the popular Republican, immediately provoked supporters to say he was a prospect for Vice President or even President. Governor Keating, who worked in the Reagan and the Bush administrations, did little to quiet such speculation. The defeated Democratic candidate, Laura Boyd, a family therapist from Norman, told supporters: ''We were drowned in a sea of money.''

title: Network Has Less Glitz, Fewer Glitches
description: WWW.NETRADIO.COM

title: As a Campaign Sign, It Was a Failure
description: Sheriff Jay Alpert of Bergen County was sharply criticized last month by his opponent in Tuesday's election for having jail inmates paint a wall sign in Hackensack, N.J., that included his name in big red letters.

title: Police Chief Defends Tribute to D'Amato the Day Before Election Day
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir yesterday defended his decision to hold a ceremony to lavish praise on Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato the day before Election Day, saying that the gathering on Monday was ''a police event, not a campaign event.''

title: Finding Opponents on Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping Internet Safe For Young Chatters
description: PERHAPS Bill Teel's job is an ingenious punishment for something diabolical he did as a child. He must concentrate carefully on hunted-and-pecked lines like these cascading down his computer screen: ''I'm 11 but I'll be 12 in 5 months,'' ''I look like the singer Jewel or Buffy the Vampire Slayer'' and, ''Do eney of you like Leonado Deicapreo.''

title: Maximizing 3-D Games
description: Q. What do I need to get proper images in 3-D video games for my PC? Or does that depend on only the game software?

title: And Then Along Came Jones
description: Unsure about defensive end Michael Strahan's injured back, the Giants this week have turned to his replacement, Cedric Jones, a player with a familiar story who finally believes he has something new to reveal about himself.

title: October Sales Of Vehicles Still Surprising
description: The strength of car and truck sales in October continued to surprise Wall Street analysts and auto industry executives as more figures were released today. October turned out to be one of the strongest months in history and puts the industry on track for its best year in a decade.

title: FOREST OIL TO TAKE $125 MILLION CHARGE IN THIRD QUARTER
description: The Forest Oil Corporation of Denver said yesterday that it would take a third-quarter charge of $125 million to account for lower oil and natural gas prices, reducing net income by $2.80 a share. The book value of Forest's reserves is $125 million too high based on prices it received for oil and natural gas at the end of the quarter. Oil prices on the New York Mercantile Exchange averaged 28 percent less in the third quarter than in the period a year earlier. The company expects to lose about 19 cents a share before gains and charges in the quarter, in line with estimates, its chief financial officer, David H. Keyte, said. It earned 2 cents a year ago. Securities and Exchange Commission rules require Forest Oil to take the charge, Mr. Keyte said.

title: Music Business Helps to Ease Decline in Seagram's Profits
description: The Seagram Company reported today that fiscal first-quarter profit fell a less-than-expected 18 percent as its expanding music business partly offset weak liquor sales in Asia and soft box-office results for its films.

title: G.O.P. IN SCRAMBLE OVER BLAME FOR POOR SHOWING AT THE POLLS
description: Stunned by the Democratic resurgence in the midterm elections, Congressional Republicans tore into one another yesterday over who was to blame for their failure to make the traditional opposition party gains in an off-year election.

title: Counting Swords With the Enemy at the Gate
description: A GERMAN company, SAP, produces the best electronic inventory-control software in the world. Another German company, Joymania, produces Knights and Merchants, a strategy game that involves managing a medieval economy from the village up, fighting off marauding armies from neighboring provinces, building roads, maintaining efficient supply lines and maximizing serf productivity.

title: The Unknown Quarterback Is Well Known to the N.F.L.
description: Daunte Culpepper squeezed his 6-foot-4-inch, 240-pound frame into an office chair and talked about the evolution of quarterbacking. He has played the position since 10th grade, when he innocently threw a ball 50 yards in practice after being overthrown on a pass pattern. Now at age 21, Culpepper is the quarterback at the University of Central Florida.

title: Dissent on Mac OS
description: To the Editor:

title: Step by Step
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKE, BEN R.
description: BERKE-Ben R. Beloved husband of Norma, loving father of Rhoda Kasner (Martin) and Dr. Stanley (Martha Krisel). Dearest brother of the Honorable Nathan, Jack, Rose & Ida. Cherished grandfather of Spencer, Nina, Carly, Jeremy and Brittany. Services Friday 11AM, Park Side Chapels, Queens Blvd. at 66 Ave, Forest Hills.

title: Metro and Sports In Section D Today
description: Metropolitan news, aside from election coverage, begins today on page D1, with a second part starting on page D13. SportsThursday begins on page D5.

title: Who's to Blame for Low Turnout?
description: To the Editor:

title: Web Radio Expands Listening Horizons
description: I WAS taught not listen to the radio while I worked. One of the fastest-growing Internet industries, Web radio, is based on breaking that very rule.

title: Hiding Smiles, White House Aides Say It's Time to Return to Work
description: Out of the exhaustion, relief and controlled euphoria, a White House post-election strategy emerged of putting on a visible show of attending to the nation's business while letting Republicans engage in noisy political bloodletting.

title: Objects of Alternative Delight
description: Is it subversive, or is it harmless fun? The traveling retrospective at the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts, in Richmond, is both. The exhibition, ''Designed for Delight: Alternative Aspects of 20th-Century Decorative Arts,'' shows off 200 objects from the Montreal Museum of Decorative Arts, like an armchair shaped like a person, by Niki de Saint-Phalle; a cabinet decorated a la Kandinsky, by Alessandro Mendini, and a wildly glazed vase (left), by Maurice Paul Chevallier. A 336-page catalogue is $45. The show runs from Nov. 13 to Jan. 31. Information: (804) 367-0844.

title: Job Cuts at Alcoa Plant
description: The Aluminum Company of America said today that it would reduce its primary aluminum output at its Eastalco Works in Frederick, Md., and cut 150 salaried and hourly positions. Alcoa, the world's largest producer of aluminum, said it would raise output at other plants to offset the reduction. The adjustment will lower production at Eastalco by 30,000 metric tons a year.

title: TENET HEALTHCARE IN $75.1 MILLION BOSTON-AREA DEAL
description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation disclosed yesterday that it would pay $75.1 million to buy the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation's 80 percent stake in a medical system near Boston. Tenet, which is based in Santa Barbara, Calif., agreed to acquire the Columbia interest in Metrowest Medical Center, which operates hospitals in Framingham and Natick, Mass. Tenet signed a letter of intent to acquire the center in June but did not disclose the price then. Tenet, which already owns four hospitals in Massachusetts, said it had agreed to spend at least $18.1 million in capital improvements at Metrowest.

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: All the state's incumbents -- a Republican Senator, the Democratic Governor, and both Republicans in the House -- handily won re-election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDSON, JOHN I., M.D.
description: SANDSON-John I., M.D. The Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University mourns the passing of our former associate dean for health services, who served as a distinguished medical educator and administrator during the school's first two decades. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Sandson family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D., Dean

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIRO, BETTY
description: SPIRO-Betty. Beloved wife of William, devoted mother of Barbara Davis and Dr. Joel Spiro, adored grandmother of Jonathan, Susan, Adam, Scott and Jason, greatgrandmother of Emma, Abigail, Rebekah and Sarah. Services today 2PM at Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial, Queens Blvd and 76th Rd, Forest Hills.

title: NORTH CAROLINA
description: Lauch Faircloth, a two-term Republican incumbent, lost his Senate seat to a political newcomer, John Edwards, after portraying Mr. Edwards as a ''Clinton liberal.''

title: McCarthy Is Re-elected by a Slim Margin
description: Winning an election as a Democrat is never easy in Mineola, the front yard of the Nassau County Republican machine.

title: The Experts Examine Their Miscalculations
description: For weeks, the opinion polls showed that the race was tantalizingly close, a suspenseful stalemate that would be decided only when the final batch of votes was counted. But in the end, Representative Charles E. Schumer defeated Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato by a wider margin than expected, causing pollsters yesterday to examine why their assessments were off.

title: On Refugees, Italy Is No Ellis Island
description: To the Editor:

title: Prosecution Is Nearing the Finish In a Slain Teacher's Murder Trial
description: In an unexpected move, prosecutors said yesterday that they have nearly completed their case against a 20-year-old man who is accused of killing Jonathan M. Levin, a popular Bronx high school teacher. The judge said the trial could go to the jury as early as Monday, two weeks sooner than expected.

title: A Jeffersonian Lesson
description: To the Editor:

title: New Faces In the House
description: NEW MEXICO

title: Small Strides for Democrats Could Be Big After Census
description: After a decade of mainly losing to Republicans in state legislative races, Democrats managed a small comeback in Tuesday's voting. In doing so, they strengthened their party's hand a bit looking toward the crucial Congressional redistricting process that will begin after the 2000 Federal census.

title: Who's to Blame for Low Turnout?
description: To the Editor:

title: Netanyahu, After Delay, Will Offer Wye Pact to Cabinet
description: After intensive efforts by Washington to resolve a dispute over when the Palestinians will arrest 30 people wanted by Israel, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will present the withdrawal agreement he reached last month with Yasir Arafat to the Israeli Cabinet on Thursday morning, American officials said today.

title: Places to Do Business on the Fly
description: AS the English author George Moore once wrote, ''A man travels the world over in search of what he needs and returns home to find it.'' For business travelers, those needs may be as simple as an AC outlet, an incoming phone line, a chair and a flat surface for spreading out papers. But just try finding them near most airport departure gates. Instead, you're likely to encounter a business employee in a suit, sitting on the dusty carpet between the Coke machine and the utility closet, typing away on a recharging laptop.

title: Colombian Rock Gathers No Moss
description: Aterciopelados

title: Vallone and Giuliani Resume Their Talks
description: Proclaiming that ''the politicking is over and the business of government is at hand,'' Peter F. Vallone returned to his job as Speaker of the City Council yesterday and met with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for the first time since the two broke off budget negotiations last spring.

title: Listeners Take On Role Of the Deejay
description: WWW.IMAGINERADIO.COM

title: U.S. Enlists Russians to Spot Nuclear Smuggling
description: In an effort to prevent nuclear weapons and materials from being smuggled out of Russia, the United States announced plans yesterday to train Russian customs agents in identifying and arresting smugglers.

title: Middle of the Road Led to Victory in Races for Governors
description: Across the country in Tuesday's elections, governorships were won by pragmatic politicians who spurn the hard-edged ideology that dominates both parties in Congress.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: Without a New Tune to Whistle, G.O.P. Kept Humming 'Scandal'
description: Politicians in both parties said the unexpected Democratic successes on Tuesday stemmed from a fundamental misreading of the electorate by Republicans: In the face of polls for nine months showing that voters were not particularly exercised by the White House scandal, Republicans were utterly convinced that it would ultimately play to their advantage.

title: Lee P. Gagliardi, 80, Nixon Aides' Judge
description: Lee P. Gagliardi, a senior judge of Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York who presided over the historic trial of two former Nixon Cabinet members, John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans, on criminal-conspiracy charges in 1974, died on Friday at his home in Manchester, Vt. He was 80.

title: Rate Cut Expected at Bank of England
description: The Bank of England is expected to cut its benchmark interest rate on Thursday for the second time in a month, in the wake of cuts by Spain, Portugal and Sweden on Tuesday.

title: Paula Jones Lawyers Are Said to Be Annoyed, and Quitting
description: The lawyers representing Paula Corbin Jones in her sexual misconduct lawsuit against President Clinton have grown annoyed with her settlement demands and have told her they will soon withdraw from the case, a friend of Ms. Jones and lawyers involved in the discussions said today.

title: No G.O.P. Coattail Effect In Rowland's Big Victory
description: Despite a commanding re-election victory on Tuesday, Gov. John G. Rowland may be finding that it is lonely at the top.

title: Israeli Diplomat Urges Vatican to Delay Beatification of Pius XII
description: The Israeli Ambassador to the Vatican has urged it to wait 50 years before moving ahead with any plan to beatify Pope Pius XII, who has been criticized by Jewish groups and others for remaining silent about the Holocaust while it was going on.

title: SAUDI IS INDICTED IN BOMB ATTACKS ON U.S. EMBASSIES
description: A Federal grand jury in Manhattan returned a 238-count indictment yesterday charging the Saudi exile Osama bin Laden in the bombings of two United States Embassies in Africa in August and with conspiring to commit other acts of terrorism against Americans abroad.

title: PENNSYLVANIA
description: Incumbency and Republicanism ruled the day as Gov. Tom Ridge, Senator Arlen Specter and virtually every sitting House member won.

title: Blast at the Kremlin Hurts Three Guards
description: What was evidently a car bomb exploded just outside the Kremlin this evening, wounding three security guards and the driver and rattling windows in Russia's traditional seat of power.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: New Faces In the Senate
description: ARKANSAS

title: Groups Reach Agreement For Curtailing Sweatshops
description: After more than two years of debate, a group of human rights organizations and apparel manufacturers, including Nike, Reebok and Liz Claiborne, has reached an agreement intended to curtail sweatshops by setting up a code of conduct and monitoring system for overseas factories used by American companies.

title: A Dream Lover Intrudes on a Too-Real Life
description: Christine has a dream lover who can come to her at any time, sometimes right in the middle of the biology class she teaches. He strokes her hair and her body, whispering sweet nothings in Cajun French and brings to mind (but doesn't live up to) images of Dennis Quaid awakening Ellen Barkin's repressed sexuality in the film ''The Big Easy.'' When Christine (Barbara Gulan) and her dream lover, Xavier (Al Espinosa), embrace, this is the way Stella and Stanley Kowalski might have wrapped themselves around each other onstage if the standards of the time (the late 1940's, when ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' was on Broadway) had allowed it. Christine's real life, the subject of Julie Hebert's inconsistent play ''The Knee Desires the Dirt,'' is nothing like that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WENIG, JEROME
description: WENIG-Jerome. Beloved husband of Dolores. Loving father of Debra and Howard Ross and Howard and Tracy Wenig. Cherished grandfather of Leslie, Amy, and Andrew Ross and Laura and Rachel Wenig. Service today, 10:00 AM at Beth El Synagogue, North Avenue and Northfield Road, New Rochelle, New York.

title: If You Can Spell Subpoena, You Can Play the Game
description: Name calling, duplicitous plotting, coercing family and friends. It's the kind of all-American fun that is sweeping Washington, and now just about anyone with a modem can join in.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Chinese company close to default raises issues about how reliable a borrower China may be.
description: WITH a Chinese company set to default on a foreign bond payment for the first time since the Communists took power 50 years ago, some bankers worry that a looming credit crunch could weaken China's immunity to the financial turmoil that has already hit most of its Asian neighbors.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Vines to Fill the Indoors

title: On-Line Shoppers' Attitudes: A Case of Bahhumbug.com?
description: On-line shoppers evidently haven't grasped the concept that it is better to give than to receive.

title: Pay Attention: Reinvention; No Prevention
description: First he made seven Top 10 albums, as the producer and mastermind of the Wu-Tang Clan. He came up with one of the rawest, spookiest, most widely imitated musical styles of the 1990's. Then Robert Diggs, better known as the RZA, decided it was time to study music.

title: Netanyahu to Submit Pact to His Cabinet
description: After a new push by Washington, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel will present the agreement reached last month on a further Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank to his Cabinet this morning, American officials said.

title: CALIFORNIA
description: Democrats swept powerfully through the nation's most populous state, seizing the governorship and other statewide offices, retaining a Senate seat and gaining a major advantage when California's huge House delegation, making up about an eighth of the House of Representatives, goes through redistricting after the 2000 census.

title: New Jersey's Congressional Races
description: KEY:

title: Police Task Force Recovers 2 Torahs Stolen From New Jersey Synagogue
description: The New York Police Department's Torah Task Force, a little known but highly effective squad that investigates thefts of the sacred Jewish scrolls, recovered two Torahs and their precious ornaments that were stolen last month from a synagogue in Englewood, N.J., the police said yesterday. The task force charged a man with possessing stolen property after he tried sell the scrolls on Tuesday night to an undercover detective in Manhattan.

title: MASSACHUSETTS
description: Acting Gov. Argeo Paul Cellucci, a Republican seeking a full term in office, gained a narrow victory over his Democratic challenger, Attorney General Scott Harshbarger. Mr. Cellucci, a fiscal conservative and social moderate, ran on a record of tax cuts and budget surpluses and benefited from the state's strong economy.

title: Who's to Blame for Low Turnout?
description: To the Editor:

title: COLORADO
description: In race that was so close that some are calling for a recount, a Republican, Bill Owens, was elected Governor of Colorado. The victory was a stunning upset for Democrats, who have held the office since 1975.

title: From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak
description: In a vote expected to have national reverberations, Washington State residents dealt a stinging defeat to state-sponsored affirmative action. Voters in five Western states gave a resounding yes to the medical use of marijuana, while Alaska and Hawaii voters said a clear no to the idea of same-sex marriages.

title: Wedding Blues
description: To the Editor:

title: No Fury Like a Woman Who Had to Fetch Lunch
description: A LIKELY STORY

title: Approach Is Eclectic and Hip
description: WWW.MACRORADIO.NET

title: NORTH DAKOTA
description: The incumbent Democratic Senator, Byron L. Dorgan, breezed to re-election. Mr. Dorgan had virtually ignored his opponent, Donna Nalewaja. and outspent her, raising more than $1.7 million to her $150,000. Ms. Nalewaja had billed the campaign as ''Donna vs. Goliath.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONANNO, JOSEPH
description: BONANNO-Joseph. On November 4, 1998 of Valley Stream, NY. Past proprietor of Danny's Haven of Baldwin and Joe's Place of Rockville Centre, NY. Beloved husband of Flora (nee Rainone), loving father of Lucille Iconis and her husband Arthur, cherished granfather of Joseph and Philip Iconis, dear brother of Rose Guddemi, Gerry LePorin and Sam and Charles Bonanno. Reposing at The Moore Funeral Home, 54 W. Jamaica Ave, Valley Stream, NY. Family will receive friends today and Friday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Sat., 9:45AM at Holy Name of Mary RC Church. Entombment Pinelawn Memorial Park.

title: HAWAII
description: Backed by a strong union showing, the incumbent Democrat, Ben Cayetano, narrowly defeated his Republican challenger, Linda Lingle, the Mayor of Maui. Ms. Lingle was trying to become Hawaii's first elected Republican governor since it became a state 39 years ago. A struggling economy that was being dragged down by the crisis in Asia nearly allowed her to succeed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCLAUGHLIN, HELEN G. (GROGAN)
description: McLAUGHLIN-Helen G. (Grogan) 83 years of Charlottesville, VA on November 3, 1998. Formerly of Queens, NY. she was a 38 year employee of the Exxon Corp NYC. For information call M. David DeMarco Funeral Home 732-521-0555

title: WISCONSIN
description: Although he seemed at times about to be swamped by his Republican opponent's heavy television advertising, Senator Russell D. Feingold, a Democrat nationally known as an exponent of campaign finance reform, won a close victory over Representative Mark W. Neumann.

title: After Nullified Election, Same Candidate Is Victor
description: A candidate for the State Assembly whose election last year was nullified because of a faulty polling machine won the seat on Tuesday.

title: The Call of the Wild Apple
description: ALL the way in the back of the New York State Agricultural Experiment Station's orchard here stand several jumbled rows of the oddest apple trees you've ever seen. No two are alike, not in form or leaf or fruit: this one could pass for a linden tree, that one for a demented forsythia. Maybe a third of these six-year-old trees are bearing apples this fall -- strange, strange fruit that look and taste like nothing so much as God's first drafts of what an apple might be.

title: Injustice And Death: A Comedy
description: If there is any play that cries out for unbridled imagination in the director and good-humored rebellion in the cast, it is ''The Time of Your Life.'' On the page the play is a confusing mess -- dashed off in six days in 1939 by William Saroyan and then, according to contemporary accounts, doctored into shape by the producers, especially by Tom Dowling who also took the role of Joe, the unaccountably lucky drifter. That it won the Pulitzer Prize still seems startling; nowadays you have to wonder whether the prize would go to a play that ends with the characters' cheerfully hailing as a hero a man who has just murdered a policeman -- even though he was a bad one, to be sure.

title: TEXAS
description: Gov. George W. Bush, a Republican who campaigned hard among Hispanic voters, was re-elected by a landslide, the first Texas governor to win consecutive terms in 25 years.

title: Incumbent, a Republican-Turned-Democrat, Retains Assembly Seat
description: The Republican-turned-Democrat beat the Democrat-turned-Republican in Suffolk County's 3d Assembly District.

title: OREGON
description: Two incumbent Democrats, Gov. John Kitzhaber and Senator Ron Wyden, racked up big margins in their victories. But the contest for the state's First Congressional District remained too close to call.

title: N.F.L.: ROUNDUP
description: NEW ORLEANS

title: The Full Results
description: National and metropolitan races, and the outcomes state by state: section B, pages 1-16.

title: VERMONT
description: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Democrat, won election to a fifth term with almost three-quarters of the vote. Mr. Leahy, an outspoken advocate of civil liberties and farm and nutrition programs, did not face a serious challenge. His Republican opponent, Fred Tuttle, a 79-year-old retired dairy farmer who received the nomination after he was featured in a political spoof film, spoke well of Mr. Leahy and said he did not really want to go to Washington.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about plans to redevelop Theater Row on West 42d Street misidentified the manager of a proposed 499-seat theater and misattributed a comment by him. The manager and co-owner would be Ben Sprecher, who owns the Variety Arts and Promenade Theaters and manages the Lucille Lortel, all Off Broadway -- not Fred Papert, president of the 42d Street Development Corporation. It was Mr. Sprecher, not Mr. Papert, who said he expected the new theater to become ''the flagship of Off Broadway.''

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: MISSISSIPPI
description: Ronnie Shows, a conservative Democrat, won the state's most interesting House race, for the Fourth District seat being vacated by Representative Mike Parker, a Republican. Mr. Shows had name recognition as an elected highway commissioner and former state senator. He defeated Delbert Hosemann, a tax lawyer in Jackson, who tried to portray Mr. Shows as a liberal.

title: Police Seek to Question Man About Slaying of Obstetrician
description: Federal authorities investigating the murder of an obstetrician who performed abortions have identified a Vermont man as a material witness to the sniper attack last month and issued a warrant for his arrest today to bring him in for questioning.

title: INSIDE
description: Anti-Abortion Protester Sought as Slaying Witness

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GROUP MAINTENANCE AMERICA CORP., Houston, a provider of heating, air-conditioning, plumbing and electrical services, agreed to acquire Trinity Contractors Inc., Grand Prairie, Tex., a closely held mechanical and electrical contracting company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: MARYLAND
description: Parris N. Glendening won his first term as Governor four years ago by a mere 6,000 votes out of 1.4 million cast over his Republican opponent, Ellen R. Sauerbrey. She tried again this election, but it was a good year for incumbents in Maryland. Mr. Glendening won again, this time by more than 160,000 votes.

title: Court Hears Selective Deportation Argument by 'L.A. Eight'
description: With the Government's effort to deport a group of supporters of the Palestinian cause now approaching its 12th year, the Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether the seven Palestinians and one Kenyan are entitled to go before a Federal court with their claim that they were unconstitutionally selected for deportation because of their political views and lawful activities.

title: Stainless Steel, Warm and Gentle
description: Brushed stainless steel is the basic black for architect-designed kitchens: functional, timeless, honest. And conformist. Why not a warmer, gentler stainless steel? IWC International offers custom titanium-coated stainless steel in copper and a variety of other finishes (right from top): brushed gold; textured with circles in rose-gold or steel; matte gray, or etched with patterns or words. (Recipes on kitchen cabinets, perhaps?) To the trade; for inquiries on prices: (800) 330-4311.

title: MISSOURI
description: Christopher Bond, Missouri's Republican Senator, defeated his Democratic challenger, Attorney General Jay Nixon. The Democratic candidate, a proven statewide vote-getter, had assailed what he called the Senator's ''Washington life style.''

title: Gore Friend Is Charged With Campaign Fund-Raising Violations
description: A Federal grand jury returned a 42-count indictment today against a prominent Tennessee real estate developer accusing him of defrauding the Government through an illegal scheme to funnel $80,000 in donations to President Clinton's 1996 re-election and other political campaigns.

title: Southwest Airlines to Offer Low-Cost Flights From Islip, L.I.
description: Betting that New Yorkers will flock to flights with steerage prices despite steerage service, Southwest Airlines plans to enter the New York market by early spring.

title: The Southern Surprise
description: Since Lyndon Johnson signed the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the Democratic Party has been declining in the South. The Republicans picked off senators, governors and members of the House one by one, like rotating ducks in a carnival game.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Composers Win a Stay In Copland's Old Home
description: In 1960, Aaron Copland, searching for a new place to live as he approached his 60th birthday, found a six-room house on a hilly three-acre site in Cortlandt, N.Y., about an hour's drive north of New York. One room, separate from the main house, had two glass walls that overlooked forests, gardens and, in the distance, the Hudson River.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about Citigroup misstated the reaction to the requested resignation of its president, James Dimon, among Citigroup employees, securities analysts and investors. The move was met with disapproval, not approval.

title: This Might Be What You Need For Those Papers, Mr. Bond
description: The latest innovation from the Hewlett-Packard Company should come with a disclaimer that it is not necessary to be an international spy to use it.

title: Essay; No Third Term!
description: In the wake of their midterm triumph, the permanent campaigners in the White House must be thinking: Will nobody rid us of this troublesome 22d Amendment? Why should superpopular Bill Clinton be denied the chance to run for a third term?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VISHNIAC, LEA (LUTA).
description: VISHNIAC-Lea (Luta). Much beloved mother, mother-in-law, grandmother and great grandmother died in her sleep at home, November 4, 1998. Memorial Services to be arranged. Mara Vishniac Kohn and Walter Kohn, Santa Barbara Naomi Schiff Benjamin Schiff Helen Vishniac Ethan Vishniac Ephraim Vishniac and all their children with love

title: Jets Prepare to Counter Flutie's Creative Tactics
description: It was 20 years ago, when he was tutoring collegians, when Bill Parcells last coached against a quarterback as daring as Doug Flutie is these days with the Buffalo Bills. And, while playing at Oklahoma State, the Jets' rookie free safety Kevin Williams faced quarterbacks who tried to move like Flutie -- but ''none as good or as smart.''

title: Stability in Financial Markets Weakens Treasury Note Sales
description: The United States bond market suffered the biggest decline in almost a month yesterday, driving yields to an eight-week high, as signs of stability in world financial markets sapped demand at the Treasury's $12 billion note sale.

title: ILLINOIS
description: Carol Moseley-Braun, the nation's first black female Senator, was defeated by Peter Fitzgerald, a wealthy conservative Republican who attacked her for ''six years of scandal and controversy.''

title: In America; The Landscape Shifts
