description: Some unsolicited advice for the Republican Party: Give up on the politics of meanness. It's killing you.

title: National Thrives Again With Garden as Setting
description: At the turn of the century, the National Horse Show survived the upstaging of the horse by the automobile, and in 1915 the show survived a wink at tradition when Eleanora Sears became the first woman to shelve her sidesaddle and ride astride like a man.

title: Shares Rise, Fade, Recover, With Dow Gaining 76.99
description: Apparently buoyed by election results, stock prices jumped early yesterday but then faded after investors showed little enthusiasm for an offering of Government bonds.

title: Going Resource-Picking
description: IF you are interested in growing antique varieties of apples, you can order trees from the Southmeadow Fruit Garden in Baroda, Mich., (616) 422-2411, or from the Sonoma Antique Apple Nursery in Healdsburg, Calif., (707) 433-6420.

title: Dutch Make Bikes Smarter Than Thieves
description: Amsterdam is reviving an idealistic 1960's program to allow residents to share hundreds of bicycles in the spirit of communal commuting. But the city is using a 90's technology to insure that, this time, thieves don't try to take advantage of the goodwill.

title: Cry of Wealthy in Vail: Not in Our Playground!
description: What does it take to get a job this winter at the Daily Grind, a coffee shop on Bridge Street, this resort town's internationally renowned shopping street?

title: 5 States Vote Medical Use Of Marijuana
description: Defying Federal officials, and often state legislators, voters approved initiatives on Tuesday to legalize the medical use of marijuana in Alaska, Arizona, Nevada, Oregon and Washington State.

title: Not Going Gentle Into Off-Line Night
description: IF I may say so, the E-mail I was writing to my brother the other night was a sibling-to-sibling classic: a delicate balance of wheedling, teasing and reminders of embarrassing childhood moments. ''What do you mean you have to work on Thanksgiving?'' I typed. ''You just want to avoid seeing us because you get flashbacks to 1976, when you locked yourself in your bedroom after being denied a drumsti----.''

title: Robinson Views Tapes For His Gatti Rematch
description: Ivan Robinson watches the tape of his Aug. 22 lightweight fight against Arturo Gatti, a 10-round war of nonstop action that Robinson won on a split decision, at least twice a day. Some would call that an obsession, but Robinson calls it great viewing.

title: Who's to Blame for Low Turnout?
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Time for Those Naughty Tories to Snigger at a Sex Scandal
description: For most of its 18 months in office, Prime Minister Tony Blair's Labor Government has managed to avoid the sex scandals that plagued the previous Conservative Governments, whose members seemed almost comically prone to ill-conceived extramarital affairs, three-in-a-bed romps and kinky escapades with tabloid-friendly prostitutes.

title: Aleksandr Bogatyrev, a Director And Former Star of Bolshoi Ballet
description: Aleksandr Bogatyrev, a former star of the Bolshoi Ballet who was its acting artistic director until this spring, died in Moscow on Oct. 11. He was 49 and lived in Moscow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUSHKEVITCH, NINA
description: YOUSHKEVITCH-Nina. On November 3, 1998. Beloved teacher and friend. We will miss you and love you always. Helen and Sophie

title: A 'Bad Boy' Wrestler's Unscripted Upset
description: He doesn't body-slam Hulk Hogan anymore. He has quit wearing a pink feather boa and glitter tights. He no longer pummels alien invaders with Arnold Schwarzenegger or plays characters who snarl things like ''I ain't got time to bleed.''

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Vital Signs column of Science Times on Tuesday citing arguments about the advisability of pediatricians' charging for telephone advice misstated the given name of the doctor arguing against the charges. He is Dr. Edward J. Saltzman, not Edwin.

title: Microsoft Said to Pursue On-Line Deal
description: In a further refinement of its on-line media efforts, the Microsoft Corporation plans to acquire Linkexchange Inc., a closely held Internet-advertising firm, in a stock deal valued about $250 million, according to people close to the companies.

title: News With a Decidedly British Accent
description: This week brings a couple of niche-news imports from Britain to PBS. At 5:30 P.M. on weeknights on 44 stations comes ''World News for Public Television,'' produced in Britain by the Independent Television Network and slightly adapted to American interests. Meanwhile, WLIW/Channel 21 on Long Island and a few other PBS stations are carrying bulletins from the BBC World News three times a day, seven days a week.

title: An Upset Is Traced, in Part, to a Partisan Song
description: In the end, the upset in New Jersey's 12th Congressional District yesterday may have come down to a piece of doggerel, sung on the floor of the House of Representatives by Michael Pappas, the district's conservative Republican incumbent.

title: OHIO
description: The Taft name is gold in Ohio, where Secretary of State Bob Taft, the Republican candidate for governor, defeated former Attorney General Lee Fisher. Eight years ago, Mr. Taft, the great-grandson of President William Howard Taft, ceded the Republican nomination for governor to George Voinovich, then Mayor of Cleveland. But this year, with Governor Voinovich barred by law from re-election and pursuing the Senate seat vacated by John Glenn, Mr. Taft had a clear shot at the governorship.

title: GEORGIA
description: State Representative Roy E. Barnes, a conservative Democrat, won the Governor's office by a surprisingly solid margin in a race that had been widely expected to be far more competitive. Mr. Barnes, whose Cobb County district incorporates Atlanta's northwest suburbs, emphasized such issues as health-care reform and reducing property taxes in defeating the Republican Guy Millner, a wealthy businessman, in the race to succeed Zell Miller as Governor.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Sunday with an article about the campaign in North Carolina's 12th Congressional District included outdated boundaries and demographic information. The district, redrawn this year by court order, is 34 percent black, as the article said, not 53 percent. Correct boundaries are shown today in the national map on pages B8 and B9.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELD, JUDITH
description: FIELD-Judith on November 3, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Mother of Robert & Anne. Grandmother to David, William, Eleanor and Jonathan. Services Thursday, 12 PM, ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Jewish Theological Seminary in furtherance of educational programs in memory of Judith Field, Box 62, 3080 Broadway, New York City 10027.

title: Cendant Reports 19% Increase in Profits
description: The Cendant Corporation said today that its third-quarter operating profit rose 19 percent on higher revenue from Ramada hotels and other travel-related businesses and its real estate businesses, including Coldwell Banker.

title: Honduras's Capital: City of the Dead and the Dazed
description: Selvin Joynarid Perez was standing under the awning of his small house on a bluff overlooking the Choluteca River early Saturday morning, keeping an uneasy watch on the torrential rain and the rising waters below .

title: U.S. Indictment: 'Detonated an Explosive Device'
description: Following is an excerpt from the indictment returned yesterday in a Federal District Court in Manhattan against the Saudi exile, Osama bin-Laden:

title: Taming the Exotics
description: MUCH has been written, some of it by this writer, warning about the invasive tendencies of hardy exotic plants. But tender exotic plants will die in the cold unless stored or propagated from cuttings, so they do not pose a threat to native populations.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: The Democrats gained a seventh seat in the state's 13-member House delegation with the defeat -- for a time, wrongly called a victory -- of Representative Michael Pappas, a conservative first-term Republican. He was unable to fend off a challenge by Rush Holt, a physicist who got contributions from 16 Nobel Prize winners and strong financial support from the Democratic Party.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Hard Feelings From Softer Times

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIPKIN, MILDRED
description: ZIPKIN-Mildred. Beloved sister of Aaron and Sylvia Zipkin. Services on Friday 12:15 at Gutterman's, 180 West 76th Street, corner Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: BMW and Volkswagen Deny Talks of Alliance
description: Volkswagen A.G. and BMW A.G. denied a report yesterday that they were in talks over VW's supplying BMW's British Rover unit with technology as a precursor to a possible merger of the companies, Germany's largest and second-largest car makers. The newspaper Braunschweiger Zeitung said VW would provide technology to Rover and eventually build Rover cars on VW Golf underbodies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIFFITHS, CAROLYN
description: GRIFFITHS-Carolyn. The Birch Wathen Lenox School mourns the loss of Carolyn Griffiths, a beloved, talented, and respected member of our administrative staff. We share in her family's bereavement and will remember Carolyn, John and Henrietta in our prayers. Frank J. Carnabuci, Headmaster The Birch Wathen Lenox School, New York City.

title: Pepsi-Cola North America hopes its overhaul will sweeten relations with stores and consumers.
description: IN a key reorganization intended to make Pepsico a more focused company, the company's North American beverage operations announced a restructuring yesterday of its sales and marketing divisions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, BLANCHE K.
description: GOLDBERG-Blanche K. On November 3, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Murray Goldberg. Cherished aunt and great aunt. Services today, November 5th. 1:15PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: From Yakety-Yak to Clackety-Clack
description: WITHIN three seconds of logging on to America Online from her room on the Upper East Side in Manhattan, Debbie Shapiro, a junior at Stuyvesant High School, got an instant message from her best friend's brother's college roommate, who was on his dormitory room computer.

title: Gingrich Is Admitting His Vision Is Blurred
description: This was what Newt Gingrich was supposed to do well. The planning. The strategy. The big picture. The vision.

title: Bulldoze a Garden? Only in New York; Save Wall Street
description: To the Editor:

title: DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA
description: Anthony A. Williams, a Democrat and the city's former financial control officer, outpolled the Republican nominee, Carol Schwartz, by 2 to 1 in the mayoral race.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The Japanese currency declined as the dollar rallied on election results that suggested the drive to impeach President Clinton might falter. The dollar cost 116.60 yen, up from 115.33.

title: DELAWARE
description: Voters gave Representative Michael N. Castle, a moderate Republican with a reputation for bipartisanship, an easy ride to a fourth term as the holder of Delaware's at-large seat. Mr. Castle, a former two-term Governor, overwhelmed the Democrat, Dennis E. Williams, an aviation company accountant who mounted an unsuccessful effort against Mr. Castle two years ago.

title: Slipping Your Chair Into Something Comfortable
description: SLIPCOVERS are like window dressing,'' Mario Buatta said. ''They're the easiest and least expensive way to celebrate the change of seasons.'' And as the holidays approach, one newly dressed chair can make the difference between a room's being ready for guests or not.

title: Gay 'Marriages' Make Church Review Its Code
description: In the last four years, the ministers at the South Presbyterian Church here had quietly performed church services to bless the unions of 15 homosexual couples. Then in August, a local newspaper ran a front-page photograph that referred readers to an article with a headline that read ''Gay Couples' Marriage Welcomed in Dobbs Ferry.''

title: The Full Nelson in Minnesota
description: I angrily snapped off the television late Tuesday when the anchorman announced with an expression implying the world had just ended that our next Governor would be a former professional wrestler with the stage name of Jesse (The Body) Ventura. As a lifelong fan of pro wrestling, I was disappointed we'd chosen a ''rassler,'' as we say here, who'd been so unentertaining in the ring.

title: Wishing on a Star, Computer in Hand
description: Two young lovers head out to look at the stars. They have all the proper amenities: a blanket, a bottle of wine, crystal glasses -- and a handheld computer.

title: Rhetorical Tricks Rendered Invisible
description: Take 6

title: Microsoft Defends Tactics In 1997 Talks With Apple
description: The Microsoft Corporation argued in court today that it had every right to tell Apple Computer last year that it would stop producing word processors and other software for Macintosh computers unless Apple adopted Microsoft's Internet browser as the default choice on all its computers.

title: Slow Digital Cameras
description: To the Editor:

title: VIRGINIA
description: There was no close race in Virginia, and no voting for Governor or Senator this year. Independents tried unsuccessfully to unseat several House incumbents, and three Democrats in the House ran unopposed. Republicans and Democrats squared off in only four of the state's 11 districts. Every incumbent was re-elected.

title: Economic Scene; Deflation is frightening, but toothless, for 90's Americans.
description: DEFLATION is scary. The last time prices nose-dived throughout the economy was during the Great Depression. Then Government stood by helplessly as wages and prices plummeted and over a quarter of the labor force stood desperately in unemployment lines.

title: Fed Survey Finds Economy's Growth Slowing
description: The economy was growing at a slower pace and inflation was benign at the start of the fourth quarter, the Federal Reserve's latest survey of regional conditions showed.

title: IDAHO
description: Representative Helen Chenoweth, one of the most conservative Republicans in the House, initially trailed in opinion polls as she sought a third term -- her last, she promised. But she defeated Dan Williams, a Democrat, with 55 percent of the vote.

title: Microsoft's Latest: A Telephone
description: THE MICROSOFT CORPORATION does not go softly into hardware. When it decides to enter a hardware niche, it typically has a good reason. The rise of graphical user interfaces like the Windows shell demanded a mouse, and Microsoft is now the big cheese in computer mice. Microsoft's game-software division is a powerhouse, so the company is trying to conquer the market for game paraphernalia like joysticks, steering wheels and stereo speakers. William H. Gates became a daddy, and now there is the Microsoft Actimates Interactive Barney doll.

title: What's Hot and What's Not in Modernism? The Triple Pier Show Will Tell the Story
description: THANKS to the hard kiss of fashion, midcentury modern design seems to be more ubiquitous now than when it was mass-produced in the 1940's, 50's and 60's. The young, hip and home-furnished of the 1990's have brought the revolution of ''good design'' full circle, moving in its household names -- George Nelson, Ray and Charles Eames, and Harry Bertoia, among others -- as if they were putting up their parents.

title: Schumer Showed Strength Across the State, Even in Some of D'Amato's Strongholds
description: Representative Charles E. Schumer cobbled together a surprisingly easy victory in the Senate race by piling up a huge plurality in New York City, keeping it competitive upstate and battling to a near draw in the suburbs, the very heart of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's political base.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COTTER, WILLIAM J.
description: COTTER-William J. In Mansfield, Connecticut. Formerly of New York City, on October 23rd, 1998, after a brief illness. Dearest and beloved friend of Elaine Landry. Associated for many years with TWA in Sales and Marketing; also with Hilton Hotels. In retirement, volunteered with the International Executive Service Corp. in Eqypt and Central America. Loyal friend to many. Services are private. Good Night, Sweet Prince.

title: WYOMING
description: Gov. Jim Geringer, the Republican incumbent, won a second term saying voters approved of his economic policies. His Democratic opponent, State Senator John P. Vinich, tried to make an issue out of the fact that the state missed out on the prosperity of the 1990's.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA
description: Former State Representative Jim Hodges, a Democrat, was elected governor in a surprise victory over David Beasley, the Republican who has held the office for the last four years.

title: Democrat, Loser in Senate Race, Forgoes Recount
description: After one of the closest and most bitterly fought Senate races in the country, Representative Scotty Baesler, the Democrat, all but conceded defeat today to his Republican rival, Representative Jim Bunning.

title: The O.E.D. Adds the Web to Its Lexicon
description: FILED carefully away in the offices of the Oxford English Dictionary are millions of handwritten index cards, many dating back to James Murray, the master lexicographer who presided over the dictionary's first edition at the turn of the century. For decades these cards, which document the appearance in English literature of words from abacination to zumbador, were the raw material from which the dictionary was made.

title: For Gentlemen, a Stunning Roll of the Dice
description: ''If you're going to be a little crazy,'' Dick Mandella said, considering the biggest gamble taken in the 15-year history of the Breeders' Cup, ''you might as well be real crazy.''

title: Christmas, This Year, From Cleveland; Ice Storm Leads to Wide Search For a Spruce for Rockefeller Center
description: The Tree grows in Cleveland.

title: Sports of The Times; The Silence Of the Nets' Sweatshop
description: IN his blue-and-white warm-up suit and sneakers, John Calipari resembled the Nets' basketball coach he will be once the National Basketball Association's labor dispute ends. But yesterday, the more he talked, the more he sounded like a real-estate salesman showing off a shiny new $2 million home.

title: RHODE ISLAND
description: Governor Lincoln C. Almond, the Republican incumbent, beat Myrth York, the challenger, in a civil, almost boring, rematch that lacked any galvanizing issue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRITZ, DAVID
description: FRITZ-David. Age 78. Of Great Neck, died suddenly, at peace, on November 3. Economist, scholar, reader, writer, walker, world traveler. Father of Paul and Norma. Husband of the late Blanche Asher. Greatly loved.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Get Early Boost From Election but Fade

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUTLER, ANNE (HOFFMAN).
description: CUTLER-Anne (Hoffman). Of Palm Beach, Florida, November 1st. Daughter of the late William Wickham Hoffman and Katherine (Miller). Mother of Peter W. Cutler of Concord, David S. Cutler of Belmont and Starr Gilmartin of Trenton, Maine. Cousin of Lindley Hoffman of Palm Beach, FL. Also survived by six grandchildren and one great grandson. Interment St. Ann's Cemetery, Lenox, Mass. Memorial Service on Saturday, November 21 in Bethesda by the Sea Church, Palm Beach, FL.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'd love to get him in the ring one time before he becomes President.''

title: INDIANA
description: Talking the talk of a conservative, and even at times shunning his own party, Evan Bayh, a Democrat, decisively won the seat in the Senate that was once held by his father, Birch. Commercials for Mr. Bayh, who resigned from the governor's office in 1996 with an 80 percent approval rating, repeatedly called him ''bipartisan'' and a ''fiscal conservative'' and never mentioned the word ''Democrat.''

title: Executive Shifts At DeWitt Media
description: DeWitt Media Inc. in New York has announced a series of executive changes.

title: New Outlook On 2000 Race
description: The Presidential campaign of 2000 began yesterday, like it or not. The millennial election will be fought on a political playing field whose rough outlines, if not its exact boundaries, were drawn by the voters in Tuesday's elections, which delivered a crushing disappointment to the giddy hopes of the Republicans and an unexpected elixir to the recently ailing Democrats.

title: Every Microchip Sings: Flat Is Beautiful
description: FROM Swatch's super-thin Skin line of watches, each barely a membrane with display wrapped around the wrist, to flat-front computers and television sets, flatness is the hardware quality of the moment. Laptop computers from Sharp and Sony, with cases of semiprecious magnesium, brag of being ''no thicker than a magazine,'' and business gurus celebrate ''flat'' organizations, with fewer layers of management. Managerial efficiency is abetted by flat devices like Rex, a credit-card-size Rolodex, a quarter-inch thick, with a flat set of round buttons used to call up 6,000 addresses, numbers or appointments.

title: The Races for the U.S. Senate
description: KEY:

title: Truck Driver Gets Summons After Boy Dies In an Accident
description: The driver of a truck that ran over a Brooklyn boy on Tuesday has been given a summons for taking the 18-wheeler on a street where commercial traffic is banned, the police said.

title: TENNESSEE
description: As expected, Don Sundquist, the Republican incumbent, easily won another term as governor, a job he came to in 1994 after 12 years in the House, where he served on the Ways and Means Committee. Governor Sundquist was so heavily favored that it was hard to find a challenger, and even when John Jay Hooker, who had the Democratic nomination in 1966 and 1970, stepped up for a third shot, it was never an all-out campaign.

title: Looking Jubilant, if Bleary-Eyed, Schumer Sets His Priorities for the Senate
description: Still exultant from his victory in the bruising Senate race, Representative Charles E. Schumer said yesterday that education, health care and campaign finance reform would be among his top priorities in Washington next year, and he vowed to keep his family in Brooklyn because he did not want to lose touch with his constituents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, ELIZABETH
description: ROSNER-Elizabeth. Age 86. Of Union City, N.J. Beloved wife of Miklos. Devoted mother of Frank Rosner (Hoboken, N.J.), Janci, Lindey (La Calmette, France). Dear sister of Emilia Krauss (Canoga Park, Calif). Loving grandmother of Cassandra and Oliver. Service will be held GuttermanMuslcant, Hackensack 10:30 AM, on Thursday, November 5. Call for information 1-800-522-0588.

title: Vatican and Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, MARY ANN
description: JOHNSON-Mary Ann. Resident of Summerlin, Las Vegas, NV, at home on November 3, 1998, after a brief illness. Wake Friday, November 6, 8:30 P.M. at St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Catholic Church, in Summerlin, Las Vegas, NV. Funeral Mass of Christian burial, Saturday, November 7, 12:30 P.M. Born in Taunton, MA., Mary Ann Webster September 20, 1943, she is survived by her husband of 30 years, Andrew, four sons: Andrew, Peter, Cyrus and David; a stepson, Rupert Harris Johnson III, in addition, two brothers and six sisters: David and Robert Webster, Helen Oaks, Madlyn Kobryn, Carol Slattery, Joan Donelan, Patricia Webster, Audrey DeStephan and numerous nieces and nephews. She lived and worked in the New York area for 20 years where she met and married her husband, Andrew Rupert Johnson, retired founder and manager of the Franklin Templeton Municipal Fund Department, the largest of its kind in the world. Moved to California in 1975 to raise a family. She is a Lady Commander With Star in the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem, a Papal Order of the Catholic Church, having made a Pilgrimage to Israel and Jerusalem in 1989. For the past 8 years in May, she traveled to Lourdes, France, with the Sovereign Order of the Knights of Malta, as a volunteer serving the sick and poor. She had a life long love affair with golf and children. Her great enthusiasm, good humor, kindness, extensive community service and charities earned her many tributes and awards which she always minimized. Living a life ever infused with love, Mary Ann brought a special light with her wherever she went that shone through as Ladies Captain at Presidio Golf Club, first and only Woman Soccer Commissioner of the Hillsborough Soccer Association, CCD teacher for 15 years, PTA president, school secretary and teacher of handicapped and non-English speaking children, charter member of the Serra Club of Las Vegas West, life member of the United States Navy League, Sun City and TPC Ladies Golf Association, Legatus International, Catholics for Truth and Justice and numerous others. Contributions in lieu of flowers are suggested for Catholic Charities of Las Vegas, San Francisco or NY

title: Man Sentenced to Prison In Slaying of Firefighter
description: A 22-year-old Long Island man who was convicted of murdering an off-duty New York City firefighter who was out for a jog was sentenced yesterday to 25 years to life in state prison.

title: Bulldoze a Garden? Only in New York; Housing Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Victory Shines Light on Shift In Population
description: Lieut. Gov. Gray Davis, the Democratic Party's first white male nominee for governor of California since 1978, won that prize for his party for the first time in those 20 years on Tuesday by piecing together a broad coalition that cut across virtually all voter groups, including two-thirds of moderates and half of whites.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Neither Slippery Nor Cold, but Just Like Ice
description: Joel Berman's cast glass is like a frozen lake -- thick, textured slabs that you can walk on. Now that he has rights to a transparent glass paint, there are 2,000 colors to choose from.

title: As Israel and Arabs Bicker, Settlers Stake New Claims
description: The new Israeli-Palestinian agreement has already hit its first snags, but Yitzhak Sapir isn't waiting around for it to unravel.

title: Crew Would Create Strong Parent-Teacher Teams
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew proposed yesterday that parents and teachers be given strong new powers to help run New York City's 1,100 public schools, including the power to consult with principals on major decisions -- from budgeting to curriculum -- and even to block a decision by principals.

title: Recovered, Restuffed, Otherwise Unchanged
description: It's alive!

title: For Bills, X's, O's and Z's: Phillips Wakes Buffalo
description: Listen to Wade Phillips long enough and he will lull you to sleep. He has an easy voice and an easy demeanor and he is so calm and so comfortable that it appears he is sleepwalking. Far from it, though. Don't sleep on Phillips. Or his team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTLER, JOHN K., M.D.
description: BUTLER-John K., M.D. Of Orange, NJ. Formerly of Vailsburg, Newark, NJ on November 4, 1998. Beloved husband of Claire (nee Gravey), devoted father of John K., Jr., Jane (and George) Kendall, Amy (and Christopher) Grant, Charles, Edward, Claire (and Mark) Bernstein, Mary (and Jeffrey) Plaza, Meg Butler and also survived by eight grandchildren. Friends are invited to attend the Funeral Mass to be offered at Our Lady of the Valley Church, 510 Valley St, Orange, NJ on Saturday at 9:30am and the interment following at St. Catharine's Cemetery Sea Girt. Visitation at the QuinnHopping Funeral Home, 145 E. Mt. Pleasant Ave, Livingston, NJ on Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Please omit flowers, but memorial contributions to Our Lady of the Valley Church would be appreciated.

title: Spare the Trees
description: To House & Home:

title: WASHINGTON
description: Patty Murray, a Democrat who made a nationwide name for herself in 1992 campaigning as the ''mom in tennis shoes,'' won a second term in a tough race against Representative Linda Smith, a Republican who had backing from the Christian right.

title: Talks, Exhibitions and Sales
description: Designing Museums

title: Yankees And Cone Will Keep Talking
description: For the second time in the last week, David Cone and the Yankees have extended the pitcher's deadline for deciding about a $5.5 million contract option, agreeing yesterday to push the deadline back until midnight next Wednesday. It had been switched to midnight yesterday, but both sides have been negotiating amicably and agreed to continue talks.

title: ALABAMA
description: The defeat of Gov. Fob James represents more than loss for the Republicans. It also represents a stunning setback for the Christian right.

title: KANSAS
description: Except for a surprising upset in one of the state's four Congressional districts, incumbents did very well with Kansas's voters.

title: SOUTH DAKOTA
description: Bill Janklow, the populist Republican Governor, swept to a record fourth term, despite lingering concerns about his health. He was hospitalized in March after he developed a life-threatening infection.

title: MICHIGAN
description: Gov. John Engler, the Republican, easily won a third term in a campaign in which the Democrat, Geoffrey Fieger, seemed to be running not so much against the incumbent as against his own very feisty mouth. Among other things, Mr. Fieger had called Mr. Engler a ''moron.''

title: CONNECTICUT
description: Proving his enduring popularity among Connecticut voters, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Democrat, won a fourth term by a landslide.

title: Hondurans Sift A Storm's Debris
description: Throughout the Honduran capital, Tegucigalpa, victims of the floods and landslides spawned over the weekend by a hurricane were trying to reconstruct their lives, though most had little left besides the clothes they wore and a thin thread of hope.

title: Accounts
description: * Robert A. Becker Inc. Euro RSCG, New York, part of Havas Advertising, was awarded two accounts with combined billings estimated at more than $10 million: Wyeth-Ayerst International, Radnor, Pa., to handle the worldwide introduction of Rapamune, a new drug for the prevention of organ transplant rejection, and Centour Inc., Malvern, Pa., to handle advertising for Retevase, a drug for the treatment of heart attacks. The advertising for Retevase was previously handled by Torre Lazur Health Care Group, New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos.

title: A Masterstroke of Defense By the Master Point Champ
description: One of the world's great players has just reached one bench mark and may soon set a record of another sort. In late September, Paul Soloway of Mill Creek, Wash., acquired his 50,000th master point, a plateau nobody else has ever approached. For 30 years -- most of his bridge career -- he has averaged nearly 1,500 master points a year. Since he is only 57, he is likely to keep going for a long time.

title: Dissent on Mac OS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK
description: New Yorkers said 18 years was enough for Alfonse M. D'Amato, as they handed Representative Charles E. Schumer a decisive victory in the Senate contest.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of aid agencies yesterday for donations to help Central American flood victims misstated the telephone number for Doctors Without Borders. The number, toll-free, is (888) 392-0392. A corrected list appears today, on page A3.

title: The Races for Governor
description: KEY:

title: Rangers Suffering From Lack Of Offense
description: The scoring-challenged Rangers have been looking for that new face who can put the puck in the net, and they found him last night at Madison Square Garden. He was Jose Theodore, the masked Montreal goalie, who accidentally put one over his own goal line when he tried to clear a loose puck that had trickled behind him into the crease.

title: Glenn E. Nielson, 95, Builder Of Oil and Asphalt Business
description: Glenn E. Nielson, who built a petroleum and asphalt empire from a single leased oilfield and a closed oil refinery it served in Cody, Wyo., died on Oct. 19 at his home in Cody, according to Margaret Ruth Bullock, his daughter. He was 95.

title: MINNESOTA
description: Jesse Ventura, a onetime professional wrestler running as a third-party candidate for governor, stunned the state's political establishment by defeating the nominees of the two main parties.

title: Bulldoze a Garden? Only in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: LOUISIANA
description: The campaign was sleepy even by the standards of off-year elections. In the only statewide race, Senator John B. Breaux, a Democrat, crushed State Representative James J. Donelon, a Republican.

title: MONTANA
description: Rick Hill, a Republican, won a second term as Montana's only member of the House of Representatives.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report about New Jersey in the state-by-state election roundup yesterday reversed the result for the 12th Congressional District in some copies. Rush Holt, the Democrat, defeated the Republican incumbent, Michael Pappas.

title: Browser Memos Pose Challenge To Microsoft
description: The Microsoft Corporation was so worried about the Netscape Communications Corporation's lead in Internet software last year that its senior executives wanted to delay an upgrade of the Windows operating system to gain an edge in the browser battle, according to internal Microsoft documents released this week by the Government.

title: Get It Wholesale on the Net: A Web Site for Coupon Clippers
description: Note to fans of the coupon: it's time to fire up the printer.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BINGHAM, ALFRED M.
description: BINGHAM-Alfred M. 93, of Clinton, New York, died Monday, November 2, 1998 at his home. A memorial service will be held Saturday, November 28 at 11 AM at the Hamilton College Chapel, Clinton. For information OwensPavlot Funeral Service, Inc.

title: IOWA
description: In a stunning upset, Tom Vilsack, a state senator, became the first Democrat in a generation to be elected Governor of Iowa. It was the second disappointment in a row for Jim Ross Lightfoot, who two years ago had come close to unseating Tom Harkin, the state's Democratic Senator.

title: Viacom's Operating Profit Surges on Paramount Hits
description: Viacom Inc. said yesterday that its third-quarter operating profit rose more than fivefold, helped by domestic video sales of the hit movie ''Titanic'' and the theatrical release of ''Deep Impact'' and ''The Truman Show.''

title: U.S. Works to Win Allies' Support for Using Force Against Iraq
description: The Clinton Administration, steadily and quietly, built support today for the use of military force against Iraq if President Saddam Hussein continues his defiance of United Nations weapons inspections, American officials said.

title: A Mexican Troupe Evoking the Capital
description: Tiempo de Bailar

title: Stern Says Agents Sabotaging The Talks
description: On a day that represented more bitterness and less hope for an agreement, talks between the National Basketball Association and the players union broke off after less than two hours of negotiations yesterday, with Commissioner David Stern accusing prominent agents of sabotaging any chance of ending the dispute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIKER, JOHN L.
description: RIKER-John L. Of Locust, N.J. and NY, NY., on Nov. 3, 1998. Brother of Richard Riker and Cornelia Chehab. Mass of Christian Burial Sat. 10 A.M. at Holy Cross R.C. Church, Rumson, N.J. Visitation Friday 2-4 & 7-9 P.M. at the John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Avenue, Red Bank, N.J. Interment at Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Ctr. 1275 York Ave., NY, NY. 10021.

title: FLORIDA
description: Jeb Bush, the son of the former President and brother of the Texas Governor, won in his second attempt to become Governor of Florida, defeating Lieut. Gov. Kenneth H. MacKay and leading the Republican Party.

title: Metro Business; State Begins Building Atlantic City Tunnel
description: At a groundbreaking ceremony yesterday for the $330 million road-and-tunnel project to link Atlantic City's marina district to the rest of the city, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said that the plan would create more than 6,000 construction jobs.

title: Mary Donohue Introduces Herself and Her Job
description: As Mary O. Donohue, the Lieutenant Governor-elect, campaigned in each of New York's 62 counties during the last six months, she seemed unfazed by her own relative anonymity, not to mention that of the office she sought.

title: Time for Monticello To Open the Gate
description: ACCORDING to recent news reports, I have a cousin by the name of Julia Jefferson Westerinen who lives on Staten Island. Next year, when the Monticello Association has its annual meeting, I'm going to invite Julia and her family to be my guests. We'll be welcomed to the main house late in the afternoon for a family reception. We'll be able to go upstairs to rooms that have long been closed to the public.

title: ALLIED SIGNAL'S MOVES ON AMP STILL DELAYED
description: A judge said yesterday that he did not have the power to decide whether Allied Signal Inc. had resolved conflict-of-interest questions in its bid to expand the board of AMP Inc. as part of a $9.8 billion takeover. The judge, James T. Giles of United States District Court in Philadelphia, said he could not lift his order blocking Allied Signal's so-called consent solicitation of AMP shareholders on the board-packing plan while it was under appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The decision throws another block in front of Allied Signal's $44.50-a-share bid for AMP, the largest maker of electrical connectors. Allied Signal officials want AMP shareholders to vote to expand the board to 28 directors, adding 17 officers and directors of Allied Signal. AMP shares rose $2.3125, to $42.125, while Allied Signal was unchanged at $41.125.

title: On Spinner, Wide Range Of Choices
description: WWW.SPINNER.COM

title: NEBRASKA
description: After an eight-year absence, Republicans captured the governor's mansion as Mike Johanns, the two-term Mayor of Lincoln, easily beat Bill Hoppner, a former aide to Senator Bob Kerrey. Mr. Johanns's victory completed a remarkable political rise for him that began in May, when he was the surprise winner in a primary against Representative Jon Christensen and John Breslow, a businessman.

title: Lords in London Hear Appeal on Pinochet Immunity Decision
description: England's highest court was asked today to overrule a decision that granted Gen. Augusto Pinochet immunity from prosecution for ''savage and barbarous crimes'' in the 17 years that he ruled Chile.

title: Marking the Parts Work Together
description: Ann Hampton Callaway

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNOR, IDA
description: TANNOR-Ida. Loving wife of the late Theodore Tannor. Dear mother of Richard and Neil, and mother-in-law of Susan and Eileen. Proud grandmother of Caren, Daniel, Lauren, Jeremy and Gregory. Funeral service Thursday, Noon, at Gutterman's, 175 N. Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, N.Y.

title: Busy Week for the Man Behind the Runway
description: KEVIN KRIER produces fashion shows for a living, so yesterday, in the middle of Fashion Week in New York, he was up at 4:30 A.M. for an 11 A.M. show he was doing for Elizabeth Fillmore, a young designer, at Monzu, the restaurant in SoHo. He arrived at 6. There was a lot to do: Check the sound, check the seating, check the food, rehearse the models -- i.e., ''the girls.''

title: Review/Fashion; Ralph Lauren's Tempting Vision
description: Fashion is about seduction, although it may sound crass to come out and say it. Dressing to be sexually seductive is obvious, but that is not the issue. The point is that fashion exists to seduce customers into buying something.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUSS, BEN
description: RUSS-Ben. 25th Yahrzeit. In my soul for all eternity. Marion

title: Who's to Blame for Low Turnout?
description: To the Editor:

title: D'Amato's Hometown Prepares for a New Era
description: The sun still rose in the east this morning, and the waters still rushed through Reynolds Channel. As always, the morning traffic backed up a bit on Long Beach Road. As always, the trains bound for Manhattan pulled into the Island Park station, then pulled out.

title: How to Assist Central America's Flood Victims
description: Many aid agencies are accepting contributions to help Central American flood victims. Here are some of them:

title: Poetry in Light And Pigment
description: Did you know that the very best paint becomes a different color depending on the light and time of day? Donald Kaufman and Taffy Dahl, artists and color consultants, have made a career of the poetry of pigments. For clients like the architects Richard Meier and Philip Johnson and the designer Philippe Starck, the couple mixes full-spectrum paints that contain 7 to 12 pigments; mass-produced paint has about 3. They sell 37 pre-blended colors like those at left, which are available for $39.95 to $70 a gallon from the Color Factory in Englewood, N.J.; (201) 568-2226. A new book by Suzanne Butterfield, ''Color Palettes: Atmospheric Interiors Using the Donald Kaufman Color Collection'' (Clarkson N. Potter, $40), shows 26 beautifully spare interiors, like the one above, painted in the sparely named DKC-17.

title: ARIZONA
description: Gov. Jane Dee Hull, the Republican incumbent, cruised to her first full term, despite the faction of state Republicans who felt that she was not conservative enough. Ms. Hull, a former junior high school teacher, state legislator and secretary of state, became Governor in September 1997, when Gov. Fife Symington was convicted of financial fraud. Her Democratic opponent, Paul Johnson, the former Mayor of Phoenix, sparked little interest in his tax-cut plans.

title: Net Traffic in Asia:Where Every Line Is a Detour
description: KUALA LUMPUR  It remains a peculiar fact about the Internet that an electronic mail message sent from Thailand to the Philippines will likely zip across the Pacific Ocean and back instead of crossing the South China Sea separating the two countries.

title: Prospect of Gramm Reign Worries Wall St.
description: The defeat of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York means that Senator Phil Gramm, a Texas Republican with a combative streak, is expected to become the next chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, a prospect that is sending shivers through many on Wall Street and in the financial services industry.

title: RUSSIA CANNOT PAY ITS FOREIGN DEBTS
description: The Russian Government said today for the first time that it will not pay its foreign debts next year, and will seek to renegotiate the loans.

title: Records Portray Witness As Avid Abortion Protester
description: James C. Kopp, the man the F.B.I. is seeking as a material witness in the sniper slaying of Dr. Barnett E. Slepian, is known to abortion rights leaders as an aggressive anti-abortion protester, and law enforcement officials say he has been arrested several times in demonstrations at abortion clinics.

title: Aetna Profit Hurt by Costs of Year 2000 Bug
description: Aetna Inc., the biggest United States health insurer, said today that its third-quarter operating profit fell 6.1 percent because of costs to fix its so-called year 2000 computer software bug.

title: Can't Program That VCR? Just Click for Help
description: If a New Jersey Internet company has its way, the telephone will no longer be the only means for seeking assistance from corporations' technical support or customer service lines.

title: Election '98; Counting Winners and Losers
description: It was an Election Day that had a bit of everything. Senate bullies like Alfonse D'Amato and Lauch Faircloth were humbled. Earnestness triumphed in forms ranging from bland (George Pataki) to the slightly nerdy (Russell Feingold). Some sons (Skip Humphrey) were setting, but some (see Bush, George W., and Bush, Jeb) were rising. A party long regarded as being on life support (the Democrats) came tap-dancing out of intensive care. A nation that seems never to weary of seeing Newt Gingrich get his comeuppance watched him pile chips on the impeachment card and then let Hillary Rodham Clinton sweep them off the table.

title: NEVADA
description: It took most of the night, but Senator Harry Reid, a Democrat, emerged as the victor in a close fight against Representative John Ensign. When the count was complete, Mr. Reid's victory margin was fewer than 500 votes.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER TO CUT 800 MILL JOBS IN 4 STATES
description: The International Paper Company will eliminate at least 800 jobs at mills in four states as part of a reorganization announced last month to cut 1,500 jobs, or 2 percent of its work force. International Paper, North America's biggest forestry company, said the cuts would include 450 jobs at Mobile, Ala.; 50 at Selma, Ala.; 170 at Ticonderoga, N.Y.; 100 at Bastrop, La., and 30 at Lock Haven, Pa. The five plants are among the company's nine in the United States that make paper for copiers, printers and magazines. The company expects changes at the plants to save at least $200 million by the end of next year.

title: Alfred Bingham, 93, Dies; Once-Radical Intellectual
description: Alfred Mitchell Bingham, a well-born, well-heeled radical who made a broken field run through 20th century intellectual history, coming of age as a rock-ribbed Republican in the 1920's, veering left in the 1930's as a leader of the quest for an American-style collectivism, then returning to the capitalist fold in the 1940's as a straight-ticket Democrat, died on Monday at his home in Clinton, N.Y.

title: New York's Congressional Races
description: KEY:

title: KLA-TENCOR DISMISSES 200 WORKERS AND EXPECTS A LOSS
description: The KLA-Tencor Corporation said late on Tuesday that it had dismissed about 200 workers, or 5 percent of its work force. KLA-Tencor, based in San Jose, Calif., said it would take an unspecified charge in its second quarter in association with the restructuring, resulting in a net loss for the quarter. Semiconductor makers are scrapping plans to upgrade equipment and build new factories as they grapple with an oversupply of chips amid declining sales. Last month, KLA-Tencor said new orders in the first quarter, which ended on Sept. 30, were lower than expected. KLA-Tencor shares rose $1.625 yesterday, to $32.4375, after falling $3.75 on Tuesday.

title: Cisco Systems' Operating Profit Rises 34%
description: Cisco Systems Inc. said today that its fiscal first-quarter operating profit rose 34 percent as the top computer-networking company kept its lead in the corporate market and sold more Internet equipment to phone companies.

title: Rhett (and Pat Conroy) Aim to Have the Last Word
description: For several years St. Martin's Press and the trustees who control the rights ''to protect and exploit'' the imperishable ''Gone With the Wind'' have been hungering for a chance to do a second sequel to the novel. That's been no secret, since the publisher is reported to have paid $4.5 million for the privilege. But the stunning coup they believed they were going to pull off was to enlist the talented best-selling novelist Pat Conroy, who very much wants to write the book.

title: Liberal Party Holds Its Own, as 10 Small-Party Candidates Total Nearly a Million Votes
description: ''He lives for another four years to terrorize the political world,'' Raymond B. Harding, the leader of the Liberal Party, said yesterday.

title: Lighter Does It
description: Medium-density fiberboard usually hides under Formica and, despite its name, is heavy. Now comes Trupan, billed as the ''ultra light MDF,'' a wood, resin and wax board that is made in Chile and resembles halvah. Trupan's smooth and consistent texture makes it better for cabinetry, and it holds a more refined edge. Information on distributors: 011-56-2-639-2555.

title: KENTUCKY
description: With a razor-thin margin, the Republican Jim Bunning claimed victory in one of the country's hardest fought Senate races. The campaign was to fill the seat of the state's retiring Democratic Senator, Wendell H. Ford. The defeat of the Democratic candidate, Representative Scotty Baesler, was a victory, too, for Kentucky's Republican Senator, Mitch McConnell, who recruited Mr. Bunning, a Congressman and Hall of Fame pitcher, and was deeply involved in the campaign.

title: Lenore Cahn Zola, 91, Advocate for Elderly
description: Lenore Cahn Zola, whose aid to a relative she did not know indirectly helped document the horrors of the Holocaust and who became an advocate for the elderly and sick, died on Nov. 1 at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. She was 91.

title: The Backyard as Tropical Hot Spot
description: JOHN BEIRNE looks a bit like a missionary in his plantation whites, sipping a cola as he strolls through his tropical garden. But the nearest island is Manhattan, 10 miles away. With evangelical zeal, Mr. Beirne is bent on convincing the uninitiated that equatorial plants are the perfect autumnal alternative to mounds of mums and heads of flowering kale. He's got a point. Other gardens have closed for the season; his glows like a supernova until November's killing frost.

title: ALASKA
description: Gov. Tony Knowles, a Democrat elected in 1994 by a margin of just 536 votes, cruised to victory this year, thanks in part to infighting among Republicans.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Hard Money for a Softer Europe; Leftist Politics Complicates the Job of the Euro's Banker
description: Wim Duisenberg will not acquire his full powers for another eight weeks, but he is already enduring his baptism by fire.

title: Mail Ballots Will Dictate The Outcome Of Close Race
description: The outcome of the hard-fought New York State attorney general's race will not be known until, at the earliest, after absentee ballots are counted next week, but both sides maintained yesterday that they were edging closer to victory.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: MAINE
description: Gov. Angus S. King Jr. made history, becoming the first independent governor in Maine's 178 years of statehood to win a second term.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR RISES. The price of sugar jumped to its highest level since August after storms damaged crops in Australia and Central America. Sugar rose 0.18 cent, or 2.3 percent, to 8.05 cents a pound in New York.

title: From Sneaky to Cheerful: The Complexities of Weill
description: Those of us who crossed the Atlantic in the early jet-plane era will remember flying to London on the Boeing 707 and returning from Heathrow Airport on the Rolls-Royce 707. The same airplane, to be sure, but with a new load of patriotic baggage in the cargo hold. The images of a nation's worth are as real to its aspirations as its balance of trade, and here were two countries asserting their primacy: the United States, which built the 707's body, and Britain, which made its engines.

title: Siemens to Sell Big Units in Bid to Shore Up Profitability
description: Siemens A.G., the German electronics conglomerate that has struggled for years with mediocre profits, announced sweeping plans today to sell off businesses with combined sales of more than $10 billion.

title: Open for Travel In Realms Of Gold
description: HENRY MILLER thought of dancing, even skating, atop its 22-foot golden-oak tables. Joan Didion called it ''a convent for those who live in the world.'' Richard Eberhart, the poet, found an unlikely love, ''all gaudy pelt, and sleek, gracefully moving'' among the tables, and Bill Blass donated enough money to have his name set in stone outside its main door. Since it opened on May 23, 1911, the main reading room of the New York Public Library has lent itself to fancy flights of literacy. And when it reopens on Nov. 16, after a year of restoration and a week of previews, its curious mix of gaudy hauteur and inviting domesticity will be more evident than ever.

title: Not a Babe in the Woods Anymore
description: The script said, ''Babe looked out at this vast habitat, and wondered when he would see his first sheep.'' Babe is back, in ''Babe: Pig in the City,'' which opens on Nov. 25. But he's not in Manhattan, or Sydney, Australia, for that matter. George Miller, the director, requested an Everycity. Babe ''thinks he has a purpose -- to herd sheep -- but the city just batters him,'' he said. From a hotel window (above), Babe sees some of the world's most beloved landmarks: the Golden Gate Bridge (right), the Sydney Opera House (just past Babe's right ear) and the World Trade Center (in the clouds at right), plus others out of range, like the Eiffel Tower and the Kremlin. Mr. Miller, who sees global urbanization as Manhattanization, ordered up the megalopolis, which is computer-generated, from his production designer, Roger Ford. Concerns about the trademarking of buildings (like the Flatiron Building, used in ads for the film but not in the scene above) may have made them blur or erase some sites. But isn't that the Seagram Building, near the Golden Gate Bridge? Edgar Bronfman Jr., the chairman of Seagram (which owns Universal Studios, which is releasing the movie), said emphatically: ''No. Those buildings are, I believe, composites.''

title: N.B.A. Players Have a $20 Million War Chest Available
description: The National Basketball Players Association has built a cash hoard of $20 million for the current owners' lockout, a financial security blanket that exists because of a significant change in its most recent labor agreement.

title: The Case of the Born-Again Buyer
description: BACK last spring, Samuel N. Levin, a 39-year-old money manager and investor, was looking for just the right million-dollar co-op apartment in one of the doorman-bedecked buildings lining lower Fifth Avenue or facing Gramercy Park.

title: Publisher Sells U.S. Unit
description: The British newspaper publisher Trinity P.L.C. has sold its United States operations, Trinity Holdings Inc., to a management-led group for $57 million. The Trinity Holdings management team was backed by affiliates of Hoak Capital Corporation, a Dallas-based private equity investment firm. Trinity Holdings, based in Monroeville, Pa., publishes community newspapers and shoppers in Pennsylvania, Ohio and Illinois, and it operates two commercial printing businesses in Illinois.

title: Biederman Agency Revises Its Name
description: Biederman, Kelly & Shaffer in New York has changed its name to Biederman Kelly Krimstein & Partnersto reflect comings and goings among the partners.

title: C.I.A. Plan for Covert Iraq Action Was Reportedly Turned Down
description: Late last month Congress secretly rejected a plan by the Central Intelligence Agency for new covert action against Iraq, Congressional and Administration officials say.

title: UTAH
description: Voters in Utah, long a conservative stronghold, re-elected most Republican incumbents by overwhelming margins.

title: NEW MEXICO
description: Gov. Gary E. Johnson, a Republican, staved off a challenge from Martin J. Chavez, a Democrat and former Mayor of Albuquerque, to become the state's first two-term governor.

title: A Premiere Brings Out a Hidden Brando
description: Any new work by Twyla Tharp for American Ballet Theater is an event. She knows how to surprise and to reveal the unsuspected about virtuoso classical dancers. ''Known by Heart,'' given its premiere by the company on Tuesday night at City Center, is no exception.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies yesterday about Representative Charles E. Schumer's victory celebration in New York misstated the party affiliation of former Senator Jacob K. Javits. He was a Republican who also ran with the Liberal Party endorsement, not a Democrat.

title: Israel to Prosecute Informer in Rabin Killing
description: The Israeli Attorney General announced today that an informer for the Shin Bet security service who had befriended the assassin of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin would be charged with failing to prevent the killing.

title: Democrat's Climb to Treasurer Ends With 2,000 Votes to Spare
description: No other candidate in Connecticut had a tougher time getting on the ballot than Denise L. Nappier. She had to battle for her party's nomination for state treasurer at the Democratic convention this summer, and then fight a rematch in the September primary. Then on Tuesday night, when most other candidates left post-election parties knowing their fates, Ms. Nappier still had to wait -- her race was too close to call.

title: Amour and High Dudgeon in a Castle of One's Own
description: As when Leonardo DiCaprio (in ''The Man in the Iron Mask'') and Isabelle Adjani (in ''Queen Margot'') reigned in France, the captivating Cate Blanchett rules England in ''Elizabeth'' as if the monarch's principal responsibilities were being bejeweled, choosing consorts and saying ''Leave us!'' with a wave of the hand.

title: NBC's Law of Gravity: Future Is With Youth
description: If form holds, half the viewers watching the Breeders' Cup races on NBC tomorrow will be at least 50 years old. Not that there's anything wrong with being 50 or older, but this age group would not be a television programmer's dream unless Angela Lansbury and Buddy Ebsen were co-favorites in the Classic.

title: Ruling Japan Party Weighs A Cut in the 5% Sales Tax
description: The ruling Liberal Democratic Party is reluctantly discussing a temporary reduction of the nation's 5 percent sales tax in an effort to win support from the opposition Liberal Party.

title: Rival Players Woo the Most Loyal of Nets
description: Michael Jordan telephones him with invitations for golf and a night out in downtown Chicago. Grant Hill peppers his mind with thoughts of bringing championship trophies back to Detroit. Gary Payton and Jason Kidd promise to use all of their passing skill and wizardry to get him more points than ever.

title: Ex-Head of Justice Dept. Inquiry Is Barred From 2 Talks on Topic
description: Charles G. La Bella, the former head of the Justice Department's Campaign Finance Task Force, has been ordered by aides to Attorney General Janet Reno not to speak at two conferences on campaign finance law.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Laura Owens

title: Long Dispute Ends as Berlin Court Backs Islamic School Lessons
description: After a long dispute, a Berlin court has ruled that the city's 35,000 Muslim children will be allowed to receive Islamic religious instruction in schools for the first time.

title: After Giuliani's Success With Campaign Finance Referendum, a New Battle Looms
description: Fresh from the election victory of his referendum creating new campaign finance restrictions, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is waging a new battle over the issue, once again pitting himself against the City Council, the city's Campaign Finance Board and a civic coalition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, PAULINE
description: PETERS-Pauline. The Board of Directors of Our Lady of Mercy Healthcare System, Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center, and Saint Agnes Hospital extend their deepest sympathy to Arlene Peters Horan, and to her husband, our President and CEO, Gary Horan, on the death of her beloved mother. Edwin S. Mruk, Chairman, Board of Directors, Our Lady of Mercy Healthcare System Chairman, Board of Directors, Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center William F. Harrington, Esq., Chairman, Board of Trustees, Saint Agnes Hospital

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFSON, GEORGE
description: WOLFSON-George, 61. Of Darien, CT., and Del Mar, CA. A retired broadcasting executive with Viacom Radio International, he died suddenly Wednesday, November 4 in Key Biscayne, FL. A graduate of Brown University and Lt. Junior Grade in the U.S. Navy, he is survived by his wife, Mornie; a daughter and son-in-law, Keri and Kinson Craft of Hanover, NH; a son and daughter-in-law, Gregg and Sandy, and two grandsons, Caden and Cole of Del Mar, CA; his mother, Elsie; a brother, Murray and sister, Judith Farney. Service Sunday, November 8, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment at Spring Grove Cemetery, Darien, Conn. In lieu of flowers the family requests contributions be made to the American Heart Association, Dallas, TX.

title: In Jefferson, Black View of History Gets Due
description: To the Editor:

title: Tests May Underrate Women's AIDS Risk
description: A study of a benchmark blood test used in measuring the levels of H.I.V. in people indicates that women may be at a more advanced stage of infection and at a higher risk of developing AIDS than men with identical test results. The researchers at the Johns Hopkins School of Public Health, in Baltimore, suggest that official treatment guidelines, used for both sexes even though they are based on research only in men, should be changed to recommend earlier treatment for women.

title: CONSOLIDATED CIGAR CONSIDERS POSSIBLE MERGER OR SALE
description: Consolidated Cigar Holdings said yesterday that it had retained Chase Securities to explore strategic opportunities. The company, an 80-year-old cigar maker based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said its options included a merger, recapitalization or sale of the company. Consolidated Cigar reported that its net income for the three months that ended on Oct. 3 fell to $8.3 million, or 28 cents a diluted share, compared with a net of $16.8 million, or 54 cents a share, a year earlier. The company's stock fell $1.6875, or 13.5 percent, to $10.8125 on the New York Stock Exchange. At that price, the company's market capitalization is more than $112 million. The stock traded above $39 last November.

title: Astronaut's Adventure on Earth: Luge
description: When the space shuttle Discovery touches down tomorrow, the tallest astronaut, Scott Parazynski, a strapping, 6-foot-1-inch blond who looks like an actor and is a doctor, will have completed his third mission in space. But for all his achievements, Parazynski will land with his greatest dream still unfulfilled: to be a United States Olympic luger.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; Through Purgatory to a Better Place
description: MY YEAR OFFRecovering Life After a StrokeBy Robert McCrum231 pages. W. W. Norton. $23.95.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Witness in Trial on Levin Slaying Testifies That She Hears 'Voices'
description: A crucial prosecution witness in the trial of a 20-year-old man accused of murdering Jonathan M. Levin, a popular teacher at Bronx High School, testified in court yesterday that she hears voices and has received psychiatric care in the past.

title: Even Without Major, Sorenstam Makes Run
description: Annika Sorenstam enjoys Las Vegas, but when it comes to golf, she leaves very little to chance.

title: U.S. Diplomat Pleads for Political Solution to Civil War in Congo
description: A top American diplomat ended a weeklong trip to Africa today by again urging a political solution to the war in Congo, which has drawn in neighboring countries and threatens to widen into a larger regional conflict.

title: Rapp Collins Chief To Start New Shop
description: G. Steven Dapper, chairman and chief executive of Rapp Collins Worldwide in New York, said yesterday that he would resign after seven years to help form a new marketing communications company, effective at the end of the year.

title: Safeway Replaces Chrysler
description: The Chrysler Corporation will be replaced in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index by Safeway Inc. effective at the close of trading on Nov. 12, the Standard & Poor's Corporation said. That is the day Chrysler, the No. 3 United States auto maker, is to complete its merger with Daimler-Benz A.G. of Germany. S.& P. said on Oct. 1 that the merged company would not be in the index because it would be based in Germany, and the index was designed to represent the United States stock market. The CBS Corporation will replace Chrysler in the S.& P. 100 index, S.& P. said.

title: Growth in Jobs Slowed Sharply Last Month
description: The United States economy is still expanding, but much more slowly than in the first half of the year.

title: Judiciary Chairman Asks Clinton To Admit or Deny 81 Findings
description: Forging ahead with an impeachment inquiry that most Americans say Congress should drop, Representative Henry J. Hyde today asked President Clinton to say flatly whether he lied under oath, tampered with witnesses or obstructed justice.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about New York's new Lieutenant Governor, Mary O. Donohue, misstated the circumstances under which Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson became Governor in 1973. Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller resigned to head the National Commission on Critical Choices for Americans. It was in 1974 that he was nominated by President Gerald R. Ford to become Vice President.

title: Brazil's Austerity Plan Clears Important Hurdle on Pension Cost
description: Congress approved measures late Wednesday intended to reduce imbalances between the public and private pension systems, a preliminary success for the austerity plan the Government announced last week.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS SOARS. The price of natural gas increased as below-normal temperatures in the Midwest and Northeast bolstered heating demand. Gas for December delivery rose 15.8 cents, to $2.553 for each 1,000 cubic feet.

title: 7-Month Labor Dispute Is Over At 8 Jewish Cemeteries in Area
description: About 350 workers at eight Jewish cemeteries in Queens and Brooklyn and on Long Island are expected to start returning to work today after ratifying a contract to end a labor dispute that lasted for more than seven months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WENIG, JEROME
description: WENIG-Jerome. Dear Jerry, our friendship was special, socially our good times were many and competing on the golf course for over 35 years provides us with the pleasant memories we shall always treasure. Rest peacefully dear friend, we shall miss you and will always remember you. Terry and Sey Sobel Barbara and Arthur Levy

title: Diner's Journal
description: People walk into L-Ray snapping their fingers. It's the kind of slightly funky, laid-back place that makes you want a shot of tequila and a bowl of guacamole and chips.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIPLEY, MADELEINE S.
description: SHIPLEY-Madeleine S. Beloved wife, mother, mother-in-law, grandmother, friend, Realtor nonpareil and fifth-generation New Yorker died November 4, 1998 at her home, of complications from emphysema. She will be sorely missed by all those whose lives she touched so profoundly. A memorial service will be held November 14th, 1PM at the Church of the Heavenly Rest. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Madeleine's name to the Hassenfeld Children's Center for Cancer and Blood Disorders, c/o NYU Medical, 317 East 34 St, NY NY 10016.

title: Drivers Know Marathoners Have It Easy
description: THREE years ago, as a selfless public service, the proprietor of this column put himself through the rigors of the New York City Marathon. He did it again the other morning to see what, if anything, had changed. Not much, as it turned out.

title: It's Time To Panic, But Giants Ignore Sign
description: Practice was over and some Giants players were walking off the practice field smiling, laughing and flipping footballs in the air. Coach Jim Fassel, though, was tight-lipped and looked grim. Like the Giants' season, something was very wrong with this scene.

title: Sky Is Falling for Skip Away; So Is His Rider
description: Skip Away found out again that the road to racing riches is strewn with craters. In today's adventure, the richest active race horse in the world threw his exercise rider during a morning gallop on the crowded track at Churchill Downs and broke loose before being collared and returned to the safety of his barn.

title: 11 Charged in Slayings Of Two Gang Members
description: Eleven men who prosecutors contend are members of the New Jersey branch of the Latin Kings were charged yesterday in the killings of two gang members.

title: Sports of The Times; Even Athletes Get Benefit Of the Law
description: ONE of the first things you have to know about football players is that if they truly cared about the health and welfare of others, they wouldn't be playing football. Breaking someone's bones, after all, is an aspect of the job description.

title: Corrections
description: The Bank Money Accounts chart in Business Day yesterday misstated the yield for the 6-month certificate of deposit offered by Summit Bank. It is 4.65 percent, not 5.65.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIROLA, ANA
description: SIROLA-Ana. Mother of well known film, television and theatre performer Joe Sirola. Died November 4 at the age of 97 after a brief illness. Born in Croatia on July 23, 1901, she came through Ellis Island in 1927 pregnant, with her husband Anton. Anton worked 20 hours a day as a carpenter. Ana ran a boarding house in Chelsea cooking for ten men and cleaning 15 rooms a day. They put both their children, daughter Vera and son Joseph through college. In recent years, she became famous in the entertainment industry for her homemade zeppoles, which her actor son Joe would serve at his annual gala champagne and roses party. She is survived by her son and daughter, three grandchildren Stewart, Andrea and Susan, seven great-grandchildren, Lauren, Diana, Tony, Tim, Peter, Natalie and Gina. Viewing at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 W. 72 St, New York, Friday, November 6, 10AM to 1PM and 3PM to 9PM. Saturday, November 7, 9:30-10:30AM. Services Saturday, 10:30AM. Interment Maple Grove Cemetery.

title: In South Africa, Truth and Justice?; Spiritual Dimension
description: To the Editor:

title: Porsche Unit Narrows Review to 5 Agencies
description: Porsche Cars North America said yesterday that it had narrowed the review on its account to five agencies from 12. The account, with billings estimated at $10 million to $15 million, was previously handled for almost five years by Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, a unit of Omnicom Group, until that agency and Porsche agreed to part ways in January.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; On-Off Rhone-Hoechst Merger Talks Said to Be On
description: Talk about an on-and-off affair. The French drug maker Rhone-Poulenc S.A. and Hoechst A.G. of Germany are again pondering a merger that would create one of the largest sellers of pharmaceutical and agricultural products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, JOSEPH
description: ROTH-Joseph, Born May 28, 1913, Nemerov, Ukraine. Died Nov. 4, 1998, Brooklyn, New York Lawyer, businessman, social worker, volunteer. Husband for 54 years of the late Sylvia Kirschbaum Roth. Father of Linda Futterman, Phyllis Selter & Mark Roth. Grandfater of David, Daniel and Matthew Futterman, Jared, Elihu & Jonathan Selter, Erica, Amanda and Aaron Roth. Great-grandfather of Megan Sylvia Lewis and Cole & Catherine Futterman. Funeral service Friday, November 6, 1998, 11 A.M. at Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, New York. Per aspera ad astra. (through adversity to the stars)

title: GTE PLANS TO SELL 7% OF ITS LOCAL PHONE LINES
description: The GTE Corporation said yesterday that it would sell 1.6 million, or 7 percent, of its local telephone lines as part of a plan to raise $2 billion to $3 billion to invest in faster-growing businesses. GTE, the No. 3 United States local phone company, said it would sell or trade all of its lines in Alaska, Arkansas, Arizona, Iowa, Minnesota, Nebraska, New Mexico and Oklahoma. It will also sell some businesses in California, Illinois, Missouri, Texas and Wisconsin. The company, based in Irving, Tex., said the sales were not related to its agreement to be bought by the Bell Atlantic Corporation. GTE's shares rose $1.8125 each, to $62.9375.

title: Editorial Observer; Why Newt Gingrich Is in Deep, Deep Trouble
description: Just four years ago, it was a good bet that Newt Gingrich would be the pivotal figure in American politics at the turn of the millennium. Seemingly overnight he had taken a moribund minority party and turned it into a pumped-up, issue-driven House majority. With a promise to balance the budget, end welfare and represent more conservative social values, he appeared to have rearranged the political map for Congress just as Ronald Reagan had done for the Presidency.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Joel Shapiro

title: Bronx Man Kills His 3 Children and Himself
description: A Bronx man who killed his three young children before committing suicide on Wednesday night had a history of psychiatric troubles and wrote a suicide note explaining that he knew he was about to die and did not want his children to grow up with a stepfather, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Wolfgang Tillmans

title: Judge in Microsoft Case Tries to Cut Through Jargon as He Questions Witness
description: Exhibiting increasing frustration with the slow pace of the antitrust trial against the Microsoft Corporation, and with the sometimes incomprehensible techno-jargon, the presiding judge stepped forcefully into the courtroom proceedings today, repeatedly rebuking Microsoft's lawyer and then asking the witness, an Apple Computer Company executive, a long series of questions that went directly to the heart of the case.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Al Held

title: Nina Youshkevitch, 77, Dancer in Nijinska Ballets and Teacher
description: Nina Youshkevitch, a Russian-born American ballerina who was a leading dancer in Bronislava Nijinska's ballets and a longtime ballet teacher in New York, died on Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital. She was 77 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Strip Clubs for Minors? Giuliani Objects
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday ridiculed a court ruling that allowed a strip club operating within 500 feet of a church to remain open because it admitted minors, saying it was ''one of the jerkiest rulings'' he had seen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNETT, ROBERT FRANCIS.
description: BENNETT-Robert Francis. On November 5, 1998. An early supporter and life member of The National Liturgical Conference and National Pastoral Musicians. Beloved brother of Helen O'Connor, Ruth Reithmayer, Andrew and William Bennett and the late Jeanette Danaher. Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday, 9:30 AM at the Oratory Church of St. Boniface, 109 Willoughby Street, Brooklyn, NY. Visiting hours Friday, 4-7 PM at St. Boniface. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery. For information contact McManus Funeral Home, 718-377-5200.

title: State Delays List of Failing City Schools After Crew Quarrels With Selections
description: The State Education Commissioner has prepared a new list of failing schools in New York City, setting off intense negotiations with Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, who has argued that some of the schools do not deserve to be on the list.

title: Labor Fight Becoming a Falk-Stern Clash
description: Keith Glass recalled the time a few years ago when David Falk was talking about how Michael Jordan needed to be financially rewarded by the Chicago Bulls. As a low-profile agent who represents a much more modest clientele than the agent Falk, Glass finally interjected.

title: Inside Art
description: Musical Chairs At the Whitney

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRITZ, DAVID
description: FRITZ-David. Age 78. Of Great Neck, died suddenly, at peace, on November 3. Economist, scholar, reader, writer, walker, world traveler. Father of Paul and Norma. Husband of the late Blanche Asher. Greatly loved.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 14.

title: Sprint Offers Monthly Plan for Unlimited Long-Distance Calls
description: For decades, consumers have paid a little more with each passing minute they spent on the phone making a long-distance call. This weekend that will begin to change.

title: New Video Releases
description: The Horse Whisperer

title: Buildings That Serve And That Are Served
description: The architect Louis Kahn had a radical idea about the relationship between ''servant'' spaces and spaces that are ''served.'' According to Thomas H. Garver, an art curator who wrote the introduction to the book ''Invisible New York,'' Kahn wanted not only to make sure each kind of space was clearly articulated but also to raise the status of ''servant'' spaces. A furnace room should get as much consideration as a lobby.

title: Brooklyn Haven For Art Heats Up
description: The struggling gallery scene in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn is either reaching critical mass or is about to contract a serious case of nostalgia for ''the good old days.'' Maybe both.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEITZENBERG, ANN
description: WEITZENBERG-Ann, on November 4, 1998, died peacefully at her home in Scarsdale after a brief illness. Predeceased by her husband, Nat. Survived by her children, Sheila, Irene, and Stanley, and her grandchildren, Randi and Laurie. A most dignified, gracious and courageous woman. May she forever be bound up in the arms of God with her husband.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERT, ETHEL
description: ALBERT-Ethel. On November 5, 1998. Beloved mother of Elizabeth and Andrew. Devoted grandmother of Teddy and Robby. Services private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the New York Chapter, Alzheimers Disease and Related Disorders Assn.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Getting 'Scarlet' Out of the Red

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANK, BRANDES, ESTHER
description: BLANK-BRANDES-Esther. Died October 30th. Beloved mother of Deena, Jeffrey, grandmother of Shani and Joshua, great-grandmother of Michal and sister of Sam. We all loved you. You will be in our hearts always.

title: A Congressional First
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOTBALL: SMALL COLLEGE REPORT
description: DARTMOUTH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHRANK, HERB
description: SCHRANK-Herb. A gentleman and a scholar. Carol Dudley Katzka

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Malaysia to Be Unlikely Host at Economic Meeting
description: In little more than a week, the world's leaders will converge on this businesslike city in the heart of Southeast Asia for the annual meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. They could hardly be meeting in a more provocative place.

title: Beijing Loses if Bikes Disappear
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Awards $96,000 To Police Whistle-Blower
description: A Federal jury yesterday awarded $96,000 in damages to a police sergeant whose lawsuit against the city charged that he was subjected to retaliation for complaining that black and Hispanic officers had been discriminated against at a Brooklyn police station.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: The Print Fair

title: On Upstate Tour, Schumer Vows to Help
