description: Bearing a post-election message of gratitude and state unity, Representative Charles E. Schumer hopscotched triumphantly across upstate New York today, outlining priorities for his first year in the United States Senate that include cutting electric rates, property taxes and air fares.

title: Exiles Sue Castro in Spain
description: A Cuban exile group from Miami filed a suit here today against President Fidel Castro of Cuba, charging him with genocide and terrorism.

title: Now the Falling Leaves, Later the Frisky Spring
description: ''Spring and Fall,'' a ballet that John Neumeier choreographed in Europe several years ago, had the misfortune to be sandwiched between works by Frederick Ashton and Jiri Kylian at American Ballet Theater on Wednesday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEYDON, REVEREND FATHER WILLIAM M.
description: LEYDON-Reverend Father William M. On November 5, 1998. Beloved uncle of John Messenger. Devoted priest at St. Monica's R.C. Church. Reposing at Krtil Funeral Home-Yorkville Funeral Service, Inc., 1297 First Avenue, NYC, on Saturday 2-9 P.M. & at St. Monica's R.C. Church, 413 E. 79 Street, NYC, Sunday, from 5-7:30 P.M., followed by Mass of the Holy Eucharist. Mass of Christian Burial Monday at 10 A.M. Entombment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS: WEEK 10
description: Game of the Week

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOORE, LOUISE LANE.
description: MOORE-Louise Lane. Born May 29, 1898. Died peacefully September 9, 1998. She was married to the late Harry A. Moore. She was a past President of Phi Mu Fraternity, active in AAUW and Marble Church. Memorial service at Marble Church, 29th St and 5th Ave, New York City, November 7, 1998, 12:30PM. Contributions to Phi Mu Foundation or Marble Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTSON, ANNE MCKILLOP
description: ROBERTSON-Anne McKillop died at Rosedale Hospice in Calgary, Alberta, Canada on November 1, 1998 after a brief illness. Anne is survived by her three daughters, Leslie (Peter Mikols) with granddaughter Lauren of Harvie Heights, Alberta, Joan DeMello (Jimmy) of Syracuse, N.Y. and Pamela of Stamford, CT. Anne was predeceased by her husband William, her son William Jr. (Robin), foster daughter Patricia Cola and her only brother Donald McKillop. Anne was born January 8, 1918 in Regina, Saskatchewan. She completed her B.A. and B.Ed. in Canada, and in 1945 began graduate studies at Columbia University, Teachers College, earning her Ph.D and continuing at TC on the Educational Psychology faculty until retirement in 1982. In 1992 she returned to Canada and was active in Calgary on the Board of Directors at Kerby Centre and as an Elder on the Session at Valleyview Presbyterian Church. Anne is remembered by colleagues, students and friends as a gifted educator who inspired others with her love of both teaching and learning. Her joy of life touched all who knew her, even in her final days. A memorial service in celebration of her life will be held Saturday, November 14th 3 P.M. at Valleyview Presbyterian Church, 7655 26th Ave S.W., Calgary. In lieu of flowers, donations in Anne's memory may be made to Rosedale Hospice, 920-7A Street, Calgary, Alberta T2M 3J3.

title: Hangman, Spare That Ideology
description: ''It is good to hang an admiral from time to time, to encourage the others.'' So Voltaire said after the Royal Navy hanged Admiral Byng for losing a battle in 1756, and already you can see the nervousness in the eyes of the commanding officers on the Republican quarterdeck.

title: Fatal Surgery Leads to Fine For Hospital
description: One day last November, a 30-year-old woman went to Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan for a routine outpatient procedure -- the removal of a benign fibroid tumor in her uterus, a procedure performed 237,000 times a year in hospitals throughout the country. By the end of the day, she was dead.

title: Comedy Whose Barbs Just Won't Go Away
description: Esteemed members of the American Theater Wing, devoted patrons of the Drama League, lunchtime habitues of Sardi's, lend me your ears! Sandra Bernhard has alighted in our sacred midtown midst and, well, she is showing absolutely no respect!

title: Audio by Schubert, With Visuals Added
description: The lieder singer is a narrator, serving if not as storyteller at least as a setter of scenes. The opera singer takes part in a larger transaction and thus assumes a smaller role. Opera re-enacts stories for the benefit of eyes and ears. The song recital remembers stories through the sounds of a single voice.

title: Metro Business; Outlet Center Planned
description: Prime Retail Inc. and the developer Hartz Mountain Industries Inc. are to build an upscale outlet center in Secaucus, N.J.

title: Md Dogs! Mud Dogs! Rah Rah Rah!
description: That ''amazing 31-year-old freshman'' tearing up the football field is none other than the former ''water distribution engineer,'' Bobby Boucher (Adam Sandler). Bobby is a simple soul from bayou country. He comes from a swampy home sweet home where Mama (Kathy Bates) proudly cooks snake roast (the apple in its mouth is a nice touch) and where Steve the pet mule is right at home in the living room.

title: Accounts
description: * South Nassau Communities Hospital, Oceanside, N.Y., a partner of the Winthrop South Nassau University Health System, to Robert Martin Advertising Inc., Hauppauge, N.Y., to handle its account, which had been handled in-house. Billings were estimated at more than $1 million.

title: The 81 Impeachment Questions Sent to Clinton by the Judiciary Panel's Chief
description: Following are the 81 questions Representative Henry J. Hyde, the Illinois Republican who is chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, sent to President Clinton, requesting that they be answered under oath in an affidavit. In a letter accompanying the questions, Mr. Hyde wrote that they were ''for purposes of the inquiry of impeachment only and the responses you provide shall not be considered to have any bearing or effect on any subsequent or prospective action by the executive or judicial branches of the United States that may be related to this matter.''

title: Bloodsucking With Sensitivity
description: This week the horror genre got a boost with the announcement by Anchor Bay that Werner Herzog's ''Nosferatu the Vampyre'' (1979) will be released for the first time on video in January. A faithful and eerily beautiful remake of F. W. Murnau's 1922 silent classic, ''Nosferatu,'' the film stars Klaus Kinski as the Count, Isabelle Adjani as the pure Lucy Harker and Bruno Ganz as her husband, Jonathan.

title: A Magazine Gives Its Picks
description: It has just become easier to buy important lots at auction.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Loewen Group's Founder Sells His Stake
description: The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce has acquired almost 14 percent of Loewen Group's common stock for about $91 million (United States) from Raymond Loewen, the founder of the company, which is the world's second-largest funeral operator.

title: A Relative of 'Roots,' in the South
description: The proper old lady sitting on the bus is clearly riding in from the past, with her Sunday hat, neat white gloves and perfect posture. Arriving in Baltimore in 1970, Flora (Cicely Tyson) hauls her dissolute granddaughter, Diana (Queen Latifah) and Diana's toddler son back to the wholesome air of Stockton, Tenn., where she will restore their bodies and spirits and tell the multi-generational tale that is ''Mama Flora's Family.''

title: Nonpizzeria Pizzas
description: Pizzerias are usually good spots for a quick informal meal. But more complete meals and nicer surroundings are no reason to forsake pizza. Here are full-service restaurants that offer pizzas in quite a few forms, along with other dishes. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: On-Line Broker Will Offer Its Own Funds
description: E*Trade Group Inc., a brokerage firm that allows customers to trade stocks over the Internet, plans to sell its own mutual funds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, SIDNEY
description: FISHMAN-Sidney. Of Dover, NJ. Past Executive Vice President of Save-Mart, Inc. President of Video Theater, Wayne, NJ. Devoted father of Adam Fishman, John Fishman and Ivonne Vaughn. Dear brother of Dorothy Epstein. Loving grandfather of Sophie M. & Ivy Louise Fishman and Andrew & Scott Vaughn. Services at Louis Surburban Chapel, Dover, New Jersey, on Friday at 12:30.

title: Arrests Made in Slaying of Popular East Harlem Handyman
description: Jason Adams, 34, was such a well-liked fixture in East Harlem that last month he was interviewed on a local school's cable television show. He talked about his love for the area, his outlook on life and his compassion for friends and neighbors who had gone astray.

title: 6 CUNY Workers Claim Sex Harassment
description: Six female employees in the accounting office at the City University of New York have filed a Federal lawsuit accusing the CUNY controller, Anthony Hladek Jr., of sexual harassment and fostering a climate of sexual harassment in his office.

title: Ramon Grau Alsina, 75, Cuban Who Aided Children's Escape
description: Ramon Grau Alsina, who helped organize an undercover operation code-named Pedro Pan that smuggled thousands of children to the United States from Cuba in the early years of the Castro Government, died Tuesday night in Miami, his home for the last 12 years.

title: With N.B.A. Idle, A.B.L.'s Hopes Soar
description: BLIZZARD 72, RAGE 63

description: WOLLHEIM-Norbert. We mourn the loss of our friend and Secretary, a Holocaust survivor and dedicated fighter for justice and the rights of Nazi victims. American Federation of Jews from Central Europe

title: Greenspan Sees Calming Of Markets
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today that investors and lenders appeared to be calming down after the fright thrown into them by global financial turmoil, suggesting that the central bank is less concerned than a few weeks ago that a credit squeeze could derail the economy.

title: Small Company Gains High Profile in the Scientific World
description: For a small biotechnology company, the Geron Corporation sure knows how to make headlines. For the second time this year, it has electrified the scientific world.

title: Israel's Nuclear Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The ''Making Books'' column yesterday, about negotiations with the writer Pat Conroy for a sequel to ''Gone With the Wind,'' misidentified the publisher of his novel ''The Prince of Tides.'' It was Houghton Mifflin, not Nan A. Talese/Doubleday.

title: On My Mind; Killing U.N. Inspection
description: The United Nations arms inspection system in Iraq is near death. Even if Saddam Hussein lifts his new bans on inspection imposed three months ago, Iraq and its friends at the U.N. have so eviscerated the system that there is no realistic hope it can be revived, with or without bombing, except as a thin facade.

title: Damage Moderate as Storm Hits Florida
description: After devastating Honduras and Nicaragua as a hurricane, the tropical storm struck Florida on Wednesday night, causing only moderate damage as the fast-moving system crossed the state in less than 24 hours.

title: Corrections
description: A map in the World Briefing column yesterday with a report about fighting in Tajikistan was published in error. (It duplicated one appearing elsewhere, showing the hometown of French high school protesters.) A correct map appears today, on page A10.

title: Larry Ellis, Olympic Coach For U.S. Track, Dies at 70
description: Larry Ellis, the head coach of the 1984 United States Olympic men's track and field team, the first African-American head coach in any Ivy League sport and the former president of track and field's national governing body, died Wednesday at his home in Skillman, N.J. He was 70.

title: Beijing Loses if Bikes Disappear
description: To the Editor:

title: Outlines of Energy Define de Kooning
description: In a nice piece of timing, three substantial gallery exhibitions of drawings by Willem de Kooning -- at the Drawing Center in SoHo, Matthew Marks in Chelsea and Mitchell-Innes & Nash on Madison Avenue -- have coincided with the enthralling Jackson Pollock retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Taking the Children; Bobby-Soxers and Dinos Brought Back to Life
description: Pleasantville

title: Metro Business; Increase in Exports From Region's Ports
description: The value of goods shipped overseas from the New York metropolitan region rose 4.6 percent, to $10.6 billion, for the first half of 1998 despite a 7.5 percent drop in exports nationwide over the same period, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced yesterday.

title: Review/Fashion; Design Sorcerers And Apprentices
description: Spin, spin, spin, spin, spin. The jump-suited model turned at the end of the runway like a human disco ball, silver sequins flashing, her pleated gray chiffon overblouse flying. This display was just a flash of what is left of the fading Bob Mackie showmanship.

title: Agency Tangled in Web By Early Release of Data
description: In an embarrassing blunder that illustrates the pitfalls facing the Government in the Information Age, the Bureau of Labor Statistics inadvertently posted part of its closely guarded jobs report on the Internet a day before the report's scheduled release.

title: For Nicaraguan Victims, Not Even a Grave
description: Where just a week ago there were fertile fields of corn, beans and peanuts almost ready for harvest, there are now only discolored corpses, swelling grotesquely in the tropical sun. Where the simple thatched houses of peasants have always stood, all that remain are clusters of ripped and shredded clothing and a few scattered kitchen utensils.

title: Corrections
description: A Calendar listing in the House & Home section yesterday about ''Modernism/Photography: A Century of Art and Design,'' an antiques show at the Seventh Regiment Armory from next Thursday through Nov. 15, misstated the number of dealers who will participate. It is 81, not 18.

title: Tour Guides at Monticello Field New Questions About Jefferson
description: In the office of Daniel P. Jordan, president of the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Foundation at mountaintop Monticello here, a stark black and white drawing of Jefferson stares from the wall. The nose is thin, aristocratic, the eyes dark, enigmatic, the mouth sealed in a thin line, offering nothing.

title: Early Release of Sensitive Job Data Roils the Markets
description: A premature release by the Labor Department of sensitive job figures brought down interest rates yesterday just as the Government was about to borrow $10 billion, upsetting much of Wall Street.

title: Bookstore's Charm Isn't Any Mystery
description: I had lived in the Yorkville area, on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, for more than 20 years when I unaccountably decided, on a frosty November day, to vary my usual route home from the subway and walk east on 81st Street instead of on 79th. Even so, I might have missed the Black Orchid Bookshop -- tucked away in a five-story walk-up -- had I not noticed a small dog wagging longingly on the stoop. The door to the shop opened and a mysterious redheaded woman beckoned us in with a plate of cookies. It was fate.

title: High Anxiety Behind Buttoned-Down Airs
description: Well-wrought solos dominated ''Fresh Tracks,'' the program by new choreographers offered on Tuesday night at Dance Theater Workshop.

title: In Jefferson, Black View of History Gets Due
description: To the Editor:

title: Helping the Hurricane Victims
description: Washington is doing far too little to help Nicaragua and Honduras deal with one of the worst natural disasters in recent history. The Clinton Administration pledged $70 million yesterday in food aid and Pentagon help, and American soldiers have rescued 600 people. But Honduras and Nicaragua urgently need helicopters to get food, safe water and medicine to those stricken by the torrential rains from Hurricane Mitch. Flooding and mudslides have killed at least 7,000 people, perhaps double that, in a region just a few hundred miles from the United States. To prevent more death, President Clinton needs to galvanize his Administration, coordinating a much larger effort that overcomes bureaucratic obstacles and gives the desperate people of Central America a level of assistance that matches their travail.

title: Democrats' Gains Dispel Notion That the G.O.P. Benefits From Low Turnout
description: Fewer eligible Americans 36 percent -- voted on Tuesday than in any election since 1942 when the nation was at war, according to a study made public today based on unofficial voting figures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHORIN, PHILIP PETER,
description: SHORIN-Philip Peter, age 74, born September 11, 1924, died November 4, 1998. Devoted husband of Iris for nineteen years. Loving father of Greg, Sara, Jayme, Stacey and Romeo. Adoring grandfather of Sophia. Dear brother of Robert, Alene and the late Joan Hart. Many nieces and nephews. Beloved son of the late Abe and Fay Shorin. Beloved son-in-law of Lillian Klugerman and the late Louis. Dear brother-in-law of Marsha and Don Workman. A true friend to all. A more kinder, generous person the world will never know. Graveside services today, November 6, 1998, 1:00 PM at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmindale, New York.

title: U.S. Moves Ahead With Preparations for Strikes on Iraq but Sets No Deadline
description: As the Security Council declared President Saddam Hussein in ''flagrant violation'' of United Nations resolutions, the Clinton Administration moved ahead today with preparations for air strikes against Iraq, Administration and other Western officials said.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Scientists Cultivate Cells at Root of Human Life
description: Pushing the frontiers of biology closer to the central mystery of life, scientists have for the first time picked out and cultivated the primordial human cells from which an entire individual is created.

title: Mr. Hyde's Impeachment Schedule
description: Suddenly Representative Henry Hyde looked as if he really meant it when he said he was not enjoying himself. Guiding the impeachment process is a constitutional duty, Mr. Hyde said, but ''I'd like to have it behind me.'' With that the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee committed himself to an accelerated timetable for a committee vote and perhaps even a full House vote on impeachment by the end of the year. In addition he set plans for calling Kenneth Starr as the first and perhaps only witness, on Nov. 19. No less important, he sent the White House a list of 81 questions to be answered yes or no, giving President Clinton a chance to speed up the fact-finding process.

title: Black Turnout in the South Led to Surge by Democrats
description: When it came to getting out the black vote for Tuesday's election, Roy E. Barnes did not leave much to chance.

description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JORDAN, RANDY
description: JORDAN-Randy, 33, New York, NY. Bassist, songwriter and arranger Mark Randall Jordan who had been a founding member of the New York based alternative pop band, PAXTON, died peacefully in his sleep on October 30th following a 2 year battle with liver cancer. He was 33 years old. The Lamar, MO native first moved into the national music spotlight in the late 80's with his band ''Donnie and the Rock'' while touring with the ''The Kinks.'' In the early 90's Randy appeared on two widely successful albums with Sony Record's ''The Front'' and ''Baker's Pink'' and had toured extensively throughout The United States and Europe sharing the bill with music superstars including Alice Cooper, Aerosmith, and Lenny Kravitz. In 1995, Mr. Jordan co-founded the band ''PAXTON'' with his close personal friend and confidant Jann Paxton. Although most known for his bass playing, Randy was instrumental in the arranging, mixing and songwriting of the band's recent debut album on Nemperor/Razor and Tie Records and his song ''Which Way Do You Go'' was the band's first release. A private memorial service was held yesterday at the home of Underdog Music, CEO, Christopher H. Browne. In lieu of flowers, it was Mr. Jordan's request that a small contribution be given in his name to God's Love We Deliver or City Meals on Wheels. Mark Randall Jordan was baptized at The Grace Lutheran Church in Lamar, MO and is survived by his mother, Mrs. Erma Lee Jordan and his beloved sister Judy Jordan. He will be missed by all his band mates and fans, past and present. ''Randy was know for his kindness and generosity by all who were privileged to know him. Although his career was short, his talents were highly respected within the recording industry, and his contributions to pop music will continue to touch the hearts and lives of millions.''

title: GINGRICH IS UNDER SIEGE IN STRUGGLE FOR SPEAKER'S JOB
description: A struggle for control of the House is under way, with Representative Robert L. Livingston conducting a telephone campaign that could lead to his running against Newt Gingrich as Speaker. But in a counter-campaign, Mr. Gingrich is trying to make members think twice about ousting him.

Dear sister of Andrew Stuart, M.D. Reposing at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 West 72 St, NYC, on Friday, 79PM. Religious services will be conducted at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral, 319 E. 74 St, NYC, on Saturday, 9:45 AM. Interment, Mt. Olivet Cemetery.

description: State regulators and the medical branch of the H.I.P. Health Plan of New Jersey have reached a ''standstill agreement'' that will stave off a state takeover of H.I.P., New Jersey's fourth largest health maintenance organization, for at least two weeks.

description: Steven Schick was just in town for three concerts at Christ and St. Stephen's Church that provided a quick course in the solo percussion repertory -- quick and, to judge by the program on Tuesday, exhilarating.

title: Shenzhen Journal; Hot-Selling Book Lights a Fire Under the Chinese
description: The nation is in a state of decay. The old moral code has broken down. Corruption is rampant. Crime is rising. The underpinnings of civil society are collapsing, and gloom is filling the void.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, MARY ANN
description: JOHNSON-Mary Ann. Resident of Summerlin, Las Vegas, NV, at home on November 3, 1998, after a brief illness. Wake Friday, November 6, 8:30 P.M. at St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Catholic Church, in Summerlin, Las Vegas, NV. Funeral Mass of Christian burial, Saturday, November 7, 12:30 P.M. Born in Taunton, MA., Mary Ann Webster September 20, 1943, she is survived by her husband of 30 years, Andrew, four sons: Andrew, Peter, Cyrus and David; a stepson, Rupert Harris Johnson III, in addition, two brothers and six sisters: David and Robert Webster, Helen Oaks, Madlyn Kobryn, Carol Slattery, Joan Donelan, Patricia Webster, Audrey DeStephan and numerous nieces and nephews. She lived and worked in the New York area for 20 years where she met and married her husband, Andrew Rupert Johnson, retired founder and manager of the Franklin Templeton Municipal Fund Department, the largest of its kind in the world. Moved to California in 1975 to raise a family. She is a Lady Commander With Star in the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem, a Papal Order of the Catholic Church, having made a Pilgrimage to Israel and Jerusalem in 1989. For the past 8 years in May, she traveled to Lourdes, France, with the Sovereign Order of the Knights of Malta, as a volunteer serving the sick and poor. She had a life long love affair with golf and children. Her great enthusiasm, good humor, kindness, extensive community service and charities earned her many tributes and awards which she always minimized. Living a life ever infused with love, Mary Ann brought a special light with her wherever she went that shone through as Ladies Captain at Presidio Golf Club, first and only Woman Soccer Commissioner of the Hillsborough Soccer Association, CCD teacher for 15 years, PTA president, school secretary and teacher of handicapped and non-English speaking children, charter member of the Serra Club of Las Vegas West, life member of the United States Navy League, Sun City and TPC Ladies Golf Association, Legatus International, Catholics for Truth and Justice and numerous others. Contributions in lieu of flowers are suggested for Catholic Charities of Las Vegas, San Francisco or NY

title: Stalking a Lindy or Tango, You Might Find the Blues

title: CENTRAL RESERVE AGREES TO BUY CONTINENTAL GENERAL
description: The Central Reserve Life Corporation has agreed to acquire the Continental General Corporation, an insurer, from the Western and Southern Life Insurance Company for $84 million. The acquisition would give Central Reserve total annual revenue of more than $600 million. Central Reserve, based in Strongsville, Ohio, is the holding company for the Central Life Insurance Company, a provider of insurance products to individuals and midsize businesses. Continental General is the parent of the Continental General Life Insurance Company, based in Omaha. Western and Southern is based in Cincinnati.

Ted the donkey, Nina the camel and other domesticated stars of the show's ''Living Nativity'' scene are camped out in a room just off stage right, and an odor common to rural environs is wafting among the electricians, dancers and dwarfs who are scurrying about for an impending dress rehearsal.

Survived by his son, Anthony Corcoran and his wife, Sandra Towl Corcoran of Pinehurst, NC and his daughter Carel Corcoran of NYC, father of the late Charles D. Corcoran and father-in-law of his wife, Jane Roesler Corcoran of East Norwich, NY, grandfather of Clinton, Kevin, John and Andrew Corcoran and great-grandfather of Abigail, Alexandra and Patrick Corcoran. title: No Holds Barred

Damn It!,'' which played in the Village last season and opened last night at the Booth Theater. The show is not for the faint of heart, as Ms. Bernhard mercilessly trashes fellow celebrities and generally shows no respect for anyone or anything. But those in the mood for some delicous after-dinner vitriol will find it at this show, which takes comedy to the edge and maybe even over it.

title: COSTCO SAYS ACCOUNTING CHANGE WILL LOWER EARNINGS
description: The Costco Company, a warehouse-club retailer, has agreed to change its method of accounting for membership fee income in a move that will lower first-quarter earnings by $118 million. The Securities and Exchange Commission told the company that it would soon require membership fee income to be recognized on a deferred basis. Costco, which had accounted for the fee income on a cash basis, said yesterday that it would change to the new method in the current quarter, which ends on Nov. 22. The S.E.C. has begun mandating such changes in the wake of accounting fraud at the Cendant Corporation. Costco, based in Issaquah, Wash., also said it would buy back up to $500 million, or 3.8 percent of its stock. The stock rose $3 a share, to $62.75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, MAYO P.
description: SMITH-Mayo P. of Chappaqua, Executive Vice President Finance and Administration for Independent Television Network, Inc. (ITN) died of lung cancer on November 4th, 1998 at Northern Westchester Hospital Center. He was 59. Mr. Smith previously held positions at Eastman Radio, Inc., Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co., and was Co-Founder of Ryan, Smith & Associates. Mr. Smith was a graduate of Manhattan College and served in the U.S. Marine Corps. Mr. Smith was an Usher at the Church of St. John and St. Mary in Chappaqua, Cub Scout Master and Member, Board of Managers, Applehill Farm Condominium. Mr. Smith is survived by his wife Virginia, sons Mayo Thomas and Edward Patrick, his mother Ella Marie Smith and Brothers Gary, David and Kevin. Resting, Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY where family will receive friends Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Sat. 10 AM The Church of St. John and St. Mary. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Donations would be appreciated to the American Cancer Society, Westchester Division of The Church of St. John and St. Mary.

title: Cabaret Guide
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: UNION PACIFIC SELLS SKYWAY FREIGHT UNIT TO GENSTAR
description: The Union Pacific Corporation sold its Skyway Freight Systems unit yesterday to Genstar Capital L.L.C. for an undisclosed amount, as Union Pacific, the nation's largest rail company, followed through on plans to divest itself of the freight services contractor, based in Watsonville, Calif. Genstar is a closely held investment company with $220 million of capital under management. The companies would not disclose Skyway's purchase price. Union Pacific also plans to sell its Overnite trucking unit in an initial public offering when market conditions improve.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUCHS, REA
description: FUCHS-Rea. On November 5, 1998. Pre-deceased by husband Max and son Richard. Survived by daughter Barbara, son Daniel, beloved grandchildren and great grandchildren. Services Weinstein Funeral Home, Central Ave, Yonkers, Sunday, 12 Noon. 914-793-3800

title: Beijing Loses if Bikes Disappear
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOREIN, SARAH
description: KOREIN-Sarah. The Board of Trustees, Medical Staff and Administration of the Hospital for Special Surgery mourn with profound sorrow the death of Sarah Korein. Mrs. Korein was a long-time and devoted friend of the Hospital for over 12 years, whose tremendous generosity in establishing The Korein-Wilson Professorship of Orthopedic Surgery at HSS, will ensure the very finest quality orthopedic care for generations to come. She will be greatly missed by all fortunate enough to have known her. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her children Julius and Elysabeth, and to her entire family. Richard L. Menschel, Chairman Aldo Papone, Co-Chairman Board of Trustees Russell F. Warren, M.D. Surgeon-in-Chief Korein-Wilson Professor of Orthopedic Surgery Philip D. Wilson, Jr., M.D. Surgeon-in-Chief, Emeritus

title: Tracing the Path of a Hard-Line Foe of Abortion
description: In July 1988, when Randall Terry drove through the night from his home in Binghamton, N.Y., to Atlanta to start the series of anti-abortion protests that would finally put his new hard-line group, Operation Rescue, onto America's front pages, James Charles Kopp was in the van riding alongside him, said former leaders of Operation Rescue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARNSTEIN, RICHARD
description: ARNSTEIN-Richard. On November 5th at home at age 94. Beloved husband of the late Charlotte, father of Walter and Laura (Altschuler), devoted grandfather of four and great grandfather of six.

title: Family Fare
description: Little Theaters, Big Ideas

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEWITT, MRS. MARTHA,
description: HEWITT-Mrs. Martha, 93. Longtime resident of Denver, NY, died November 4, 1998. Mrs. Hewitt was born Martha Mary Sutter, 152 W. 52 St., NYC, on Oct. 8, 1905. For over 40 years Mrs. Hewitt and her late husband, John B. Hewitt, Sr., ran the Catskills vacation boarding house, Crystal Spring Farm in Denver, NY. She is survived by her younger son, Joseph B. Hewitt, nine grandchildren, 13 great grandchildren, and countless dear friends. Visitation will be Friday, November 6 at the Sacred Heart Catholic Church, Margaretville, New York. Funeral November 7.

title: FERTILIZER COMPANY SAYS IT WILL ELIMINATE 530 JOBS
description: IMC Global Inc., one of the world's largest fertilizer companies, said yesterday that it would cut 530 jobs, or about 5.9 percent of its work force, as part of a drive to reduce costs, increase profit and accelerate growth. IMC will immediately begin to cut 180 jobs, primarily at its phosphate operations and administrative offices, through a combination of dismissals and early retirement. An additional 350 positions will be cut in the next nine months as IMC shuts plants and mining operations in Florida and Louisiana. IMC, which had 1997 sales of about $3 billion, said the moves were part of a revamping started in September. IMC, based in Northbrook, Ill., had about 8,950 employees as of the end of last year.

title: Clinton Pressed for Curbs on Steel Imports
description: President Clinton came face-to-face today with the political costs of the world economic crisis, meeting with steel executives and union leaders who are demanding that Washington cut off the import of extremely low-cost steel -- much of it from Brazil, Russia and South Korea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRASER, BERT H.
description: FRASER-Bert H. We mourn the loss of one of our most delightful members. He was terrific company in The Grill, a wonderful story teller and a great guy. He will be missed. The Players

title: Real People With Real Problems in a Midwestern Place
description: There's a good little movie playing at the resurrected Thalia Theater. It has no dazzling special effects or big-name stars, but James Rosenow's ''Crossing Fields'' has memorable characters in provocative situations that revolve around marriage, infidelity, sexism, parent-child relationships and race.

title: British Cut Interest Rate by Unexpectedly Big Half-Point
description: After a slew of European interest-rate reductions, the Bank of England ordered a larger-than-expected cut in a key rate today, half a percentage point, to 6.75 percent. It was the second reduction in a month, reflecting heightened anxiety over slower economic growth both in Britain and abroad.

title: Georgetown to Open Against Temple
description: Georgetown and Temple will be among four college basketball teams to tip off their regular seasons in the Coaches vs. Cancer IKON Classic at Madison Square Garden next Tuesday and Wednesday nights.

title: Clinic Fire in New Paltz Ruled Accidental
description: A suspicious fire in a building being renovated by Planned Parenthood was ruled accidental by local, state and Federal officials in New Paltz, N.Y., who conducted a rare joint investigation because of concerns about anti-abortion violence.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ESPOSITO, ESTELLE (BOOS).
description: ESPOSITO-Estelle (Boos). Dear mom, I miss you so much. Love, Annie

title: INSIDE
description: Israeli Cabinet Gets Accord

title: Op-Art
Mixed Tally for Foe of Finance Overhaul
description: He was not on the ballot, but Tuesday's election was a referendum of sorts on Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican who is chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee and a staunch foe of revising the campaign finance laws. The results were decidedly mixed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDSON, JOHN, M.D.
description: SANDSON-John, M.D. Dr. Sandson, a distinguished 1953 graduate of the Washington University School of Medicine, had postgraduate training at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center from 1953-56, and then came to the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, in time becoming a Professor of Medicine in recognition of his distinction as a physician, teacher, and a researcher in arthritis. In the early 1970's Dr. Sandson was the Acting Chairman of Einstein's Department of Medicine, then an Associate Dean, and in 1974 he became the Dean of the Boston University School of Medicine. John was a fine physician, an excellent leader, and an effective and trusted administrator. We mourn his passing. James Scheuer, M.D. Baumritter Professor & Chairman Department of Medicine Milford Fulop, M.D. Gertrude & David Feinson Professor & Vice Chairman Department of Medicine

title: Interpublic Group agrees to acquire Gillespie, adding a link to a chain of specialized agencies.
description: THE frenetic Madison Avenue takeover spree keeps going and going and going as yet another well-regarded independent agency is being acquired.

title: Brosius and Yanks Agree as Others Test the Waters
description: If all free-agent situations were as easy to resolve as Scott Brosius' status with the Yankees, today would be an insignificant day in the 23d year of Major League Baseball free agency. But the Yankees' new agreement with Brosius is an exception, which is why it is time to let the offers begin.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the blessing of same-sex union ceremonies by two ministers at the South Presbyterian Church in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., misidentified the body that is investigating what the ministers did. As reported in the article, it is the regional Hudson River Presbytery, not the South Presbyterian Church itself.

title: Cone Says He's Trying To Remain A Yankee
description: David Cone said he would have preferred to be talking about Lou Gehrig's disease. And last night, he was on his way to fulfill a decade-old promise to a Long Island Little League organization.

title: New York as Battleground of Terrorists and Troops
description: Attention, class: Would it be a good thing to see United States Army troops marching over the Brooklyn Bridge? Should we imprison those of foreign descent if they have putative links to terrorism? In the event of martial law, would anyone actually want Bruce Willis to be in charge? And if there was, quite literally, a bomb in a Broadway theater, wouldn't it be sporting to let us see what was on the marquee?

title: Lawyers Offer Arguments On Detention Of Pinochet
description: Lawyers who are seeking to overturn a High Court ruling last week that granted Gen. Augusto Pinochet freedom from arrest argued today that legal decisions around the world had long denied people charged with crimes like genocide and torture the protection of sovereign immunity.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Two More Unions Reject Agreement for Curtailing Sweatshops
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. and a large union of department store workers announced yesterday that they were rejecting an agreement that a group of apparel manufacturers and human rights groups had reached to curtail sweatshops.

title: If No Guarantee of Victory, Money Sure Makes It Easier
description: Even though the Republican Party outspent the Democrats by $110 million in the midterm elections, the strong Democratic rebound illustrates the point that money isn't everything.

title: Bethlehem Journal; John Updike Returns to His Source
description: John Updike has lived in Massachusetts so long more than four decades -- that it is hard to remember he was born and raised in eastern Pennsylvania. This area is, he says, still his emotional and literary home, the setting of his four ''Rabbit'' books and the yeasty source of much of his keen observation of the American middle class.

title: A Tenor Who Lives a Drama
description: When the American tenor Anthony Dean Griffey portrayed the hulking, half-witted Lennie in Carlisle Floyd's opera ''Of Mice and Men'' at the Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, N.Y., in 1997, he inhabited the role so thoroughly it was almost frightening. The composer himself was deeply moved and mightily impressed.

title: Brooklyn Judge Is Subject of Federal Inquiry
description: Federal agents have taken records from a state court in Brooklyn to determine whether a judge did illegal favors for lawyers and litigants, Federal and state officials said yesterday.

title: CYCLING: NOTEBOOK
description: TOUR DE FRANCE

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: ONEOK TO SELL SOME RESERVES AND PLANTS TO DUKE ENERGY
description: Oneok Inc. agreed yesterday to sell oil and gas reserves and a number of processing plants and gathering systems in Louisiana, Oklahoma and Kansas to the Duke Energy Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. Oneok, based in Tulsa, Okla., is a natural-gas utility. It had revenue of $1.8 billion in the year that ended on Aug. 31. Duke Energy, based in Charlotte, N.C., provides electric service to two million customers in the Carolinas. It had revenue of $5.3 billion in the quarter ended Sept. 29.

title: Far From Kosovo, Anguished Vigils And Mourning; Concern for Family Members Reshapes Immigrants' Lives
description: Nearly every week, all summer long, Ismer Mjeku, a Bronx entrepreneur from Kosovo, attended at least one wake, as one Albanian compatriot after another learned of relatives back home killed by Serbian soldiers. By late August, it was practically routine. He would meet his uncle and cousins at one of the small, dim clubhouses where Albanian men sit, smoking cigarettes and drinking tiny cups of sweet Turkish coffee and where traditionally, they have also held wakes.

title: In South Africa, Truth and Justice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEVELL, ELEANOR
description: SHEVELL-Eleanor. November 4, 1998. Of Hollywood, FL. Formerly of Rockville Centre, NY. Devoted mother, grandmother, great grandmother, and special friend. Graveside services will be Sunday November 8, 1PM at Beth Moses Cemetery in Farmingdale.

title: Metro Business; Recall by Haagen-Dazs
description: Haagen-Dazs is recalling all of the frozen yogurt and sorbet bars produced at its plant in Woodbridge since April because an undetermined number of the snacks became contaminated with salt that makes them taste bitter and turn brown, company officials said yesterday.

title: BANKAMERICA CUTTING UP TO 150 JOBS AT FUTURES BUSINESS
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the largest United States bank, said yesterday that it was cutting between 140 and 150 brokers in its exchange-traded futures business as it scales back on some international units. The jobs are in Chicago, London, Singapore, Hong Kong and Tokyo and involve people who take trade orders, which will now be done electronically. The bank will keep a 50-member futures clearing staff and offer some brokers other jobs. Analysts said the bank, whose third-quarter earnings declined 50 percent, was looking to cut back in some of its overseas trading-related capital markets businesses. BankAmerica's stock rose $2.375, to $62.75.

title: France Offers To Lead Force Sent to Kosovo With Monitors
description: Dismissing doubts about France's support for NATO in Kosovo after a French officer was charged with passing bombing plans to Serbia, the French Government offered today to lead the allied force that will protect international observers in the Serbian province.

title: Observer; Where the Pork Is Tax-Free
description: The big election issue in Burgville was the meals tax. Would the people approve a tax on restaurant meals to help pay for building schools? Burgville's cry of ''No!'' was resounding.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Media Talk column of Business Day on Monday about the changing headlines on the cover of Men's Health magazine misstated the total circulation of Men's Journal magazine. It is 566,943, not 490,723.

title: After Taking 3-0 Lead, Isles Give Up 6 Straight Goals
description: The Islanders' biggest problems this season have been inconsistency and costly mistakes. They can't seem to play mistake free for 60 minutes.

title: Big Food Marketer Splits With Y.& R.
description: International Home Foods Inc. said yesterday that it had consolidated the creative responsibilities for its brands among two of its roster agencies, Fogarty Klein & Partners in Houston and Northlich Stolley LaWarre in Cincinnati. As a result, Young & Rubicam Advertising in New York was eliminated from the company's roster after 62 years.

title: At the Movies; Encouragement For Black Films
description: Cornel West is well known as an expert on social issues and as a professor of the philosophy of religion and of African-American studies at Harvard University. But for a few hours on Sunday evening, Mr. West (above) became confessor, revivalist preacher and coach to black filmmakers and entertainment executives at a gathering here at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. What was most striking about his appearance was the difficulty he faced in offering hope to those frustrated by the Hollywood industry.

title: Clinton Lawyer Declines Offer Of Settlement
description: Lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones told the White House today that she would agree to withdraw her sexual misconduct lawsuit against President Clinton for $950,000, but Mr. Clinton's lawyer swiftly and firmly declined, lawyers involved in the negotiations said.

title: Journal; Dewey Defeats Truman
description: Newt Gingrich isn't a total fool.

title: The Boston In Bartok And Mahler
description: The seasonlong celebration of Seiji Ozawa's 25th anniversary with the Boston Symphony Orchestra started inauspiciously a few weeks ago, when the ailing Mr. Ozawa had to yield the podium on opening night to Robert Shaw. But the revelries seemed to be back on track by the time the orchestra arrived at Carnegie Hall this week, offering Bartok's ''Miraculous Mandarin'' Suite and Mahler's ''Lied von der Erde.''

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: MATCHUPS
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Religion Journal; Church Seeks to Allay Fears of New Millennium
description: With the numerically interesting date of Jan. 1, 2000, less than 14 months away, there is growing evidence of widespread anxiety that the change of calendar may be traumatic. Will the date coincide with a global computer crash? some have wondered. Or will the New Year be accompanied by something truly apocalyptic?

title: Election Brings Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: No Shortage of Possible Candidates For Senate Seat
description: Before word had leaked very far today, before Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan had confirmed that yes, he would retire at the end of his term in two years, the jostling for position was under way by potential successors and their surrogates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREY, PHYLLIS RUTH
description: FREY-Phyllis Ruth (nee Nayer). 1928-1998. Beloved daughter of the late Abe and Lena. Succumbed to lung cancer after a valiant struggle. Our exceptional and beloved cousin, confidante, dearest friend and most charismatic personage. Her death leaves a profound rent in the lives of the entire Sanders family including Adam, Emmanuel, Susan, Erika, Jessica, Miranda, Michele, Sophie, Carolyn and Martin. Deeply mourned by her friends Diane, Nilda, Elaine, Shirley, Joanne and Laura. Jerusalem was her love.

title: SOFTBANK EXPANDS ITS STAKE IN BUYCOMP.COM BY 9.9%
description: The Softbank Corporation, Japan's largest distributor of computer software, has purchased 9.9 percent of the closely held Buycomp.com for $40 million as it expands its investment in the world's largest Internet computer retail outlet. Softbank bought the stake in Buycomp.com, which is based in Aliso Viejo, Calif., on Sept. 30, Buycomp said, adding to the 10.25 percent stake purchased in August by Softbank's technology unit for $20 million. Buycomp, which sells computer software, hardware and related products on the Internet, said it would use Softbank's investment to expand into new on-line markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, BENJAMIN
description: JACOBS-Benjamin. Beloved husband of Hinda, loving father of Helen, Jack and Feygele. Dear brother of Leon, cherished grandfather of Mikhl, Louis, Aaron, and Neshama. Father-in-law of Susan Milamed and Michael CholdenBrown. Services Sunday at 10AM, at Hirsch and Sons, 1225 Jerome Ave, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to: YIVO at 555 West 57th Street, New York, New York 10019.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RACHLIN, MARTHA
description: RACHLIN-Martha. November 5, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Jerry Rachlin. Adored mother of the late Barton and Susan. Best friend and confidant of daughter Phyllis. Cherished grandmother of Jonathan and Mindy; Douglas and Harriet; Stacey and Seth; and Jimmy. Great grandmother of Bradley, Nicole, Amanda and Brett. The proud matriarch of our family, deeply loved and respected for her wisdom and strength. You will forever remain in our hearts. We will miss you always.

title: A Model for Russia
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Low-Key Louisianian Leads Speaker Pack
description: All year long, Representative Robert L. Livingston made no effort to mask his lean and hungry look.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLER, ABRAHAM
description: KELLER-Abraham. The Officers and Staff of Israel Bonds mourn the passing of Abraham Keller, our first comptroller and chief administrator. He was a founding father of development Corporation for Israel. Our condolences to his family. Gideon Patt, President & CEO Burton P. Resnick, Chairman of the Board Irwin Hochberg, National Campaign Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFSON, GEORGE
description: WOLFSON-George, 61. Of Darien, CT., and Del Mar, CA. A retired broadcasting executive with Viacom Radio International, he died suddenly Wednesday, November 4 in Key Biscayne, FL. A graduate of Brown University and Lt. Junior Grade in the U.S. Navy, he is survived by his wife, Mornie; a daughter and son-in-law, Keri and Kinson Craft of Hanover, NH; a son and daughter-in-law, Gregg and Sandy, and two grandsons, Caden and Cole of Del Mar, CA; his mother, Elsie; a brother, Murray and sister, Judith Farney. Service Sunday, November 8, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment at Spring Grove Cemetery, Darien, Conn. In lieu of flowers the family requests contributions be made to the American Heart Association, Dallas, TX.

title: City Council Moves to Close Loophole in Limits on Sex Business
description: The New York City Council is moving to repeal the adults-only clause of the law restricting sex-related entertainment to thwart a recent court ruling allowing a topless club to stay open by saying it would admit minors.

title: A Suspect Is Set Free By Mistake
description: The Queens District Attorney's office said yesterday that partly because of its own errors, a man charged with trying to murder his wife was mistakenly freed from jail nearly two weeks ago.

title: Move to Speed Clinton Inquiry Could Prolong It
description: What is Henry J. Hyde up to?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILLFALDT, PATRICIA J.
description: BILLFALDT-Patricia J., 75, died on October 27, 1998. Survived by her sisters, Elizabeth Ann Billfaldt of Houston, Texas, and Jeanne V. Billfaldt of Asheville, North Carolina. Previously Assistant Curator, Museum of Fine Arts in Houston, Texas, and feature writer for The Houston Post on the Arts. Miss Billfaldt was Assistant to the Secretary of the University of Columbia University, then Assistant Secretary to the University of Columbia University. She retired to work on her Ph.D. thesis on the history of the Trustees of Columbia University. She was a lover of art and music, a person of outstanding intellectual curiosity and vivacity; she was also a mentor to younger scholars at Columbia University. Memorial service will be held on Saturday, November 21, 1998, at 10:30 AM, at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street, New York, NY. Contributions may be made to the Great Organ Restoration Fund at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY 10025.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YANOVER, GORDON H.
description: YANOVER-Gordon H. died suddenly at the Kingston General Hospital on Thursday, November 5th, in his 88th year. Husband of the late Katherine Brown and Grace Layzell. Beloved father of Judy Elman (Michael) of Montreal, Gail Yanover of New York, Jerry Yanover of Ottawa. Stepfather of Pat Ainslie and Shelly Walsh of Kingston. Grandfather of Kenny (Orly), Kayla (Tony) of Montreal, Lawrence of London, England, Norma Jane, Theresa (Daryll), Jodie and Casey of Kingston & great grandfather of Kayla & Joshua. Brother-in-law of Anne Yanover of Toronto and Rose Yanover of Ottawa and predeceased by siblings Jack, Norman, Lou, Ben & Rose. Fondly remembered by his many nieces and nephews. Funeral Services were held at Beth Israel Synagogue Kingston, Ontario on Friday, November 6. Interment in Son's of Jacob Memorial Garden, Belleville. In lieu of flowers, donations to a charity of your choice would be appreciated. Shiva is private.

title: Barnes & Noble Rattles Industry By Buying Top Book Wholesaler
description: In another shift in the landscape of the book industry, Barnes & Noble, the nation's largest bookseller, announced the $600 million purchase yesterday of the leading wholesaler, Ingram Book Group. An organization of independent booksellers immediately denounced the deal as ''devastating,'' and an authors group compared it to a wedding of Godzilla and King Kong.

title: Parcells: How to Be, or Not to Be, in First Place
description: You cannot separate the man from his words. Bill Parcells has given his midseason soliloquy to the Jets. He laid out for them how this pennant race is going to unfold, and then today he put them in pads, a rarity for a Friday.

title: Fans' Hoop Dreams Tainted by N.B.A. Rift
description: On a nippy November afternoon, when he would ordinarily be leaping toward the basketball rim trying to imitate the aerodynamic glide of his hero, Michael Jordan, 11-year-old Jonathan Figueroa grimaced at the mention of basketball.

title: Food Crisis Forces Russia To Swallow Its Pride
description: The burning question for the Kremlin these days is not the future of capitalism, the lack of a national program or NATO's creeping to the East.

title: Trenton Cites Inadequate Care In Ordering H.M.O. Changes
description: Saying that New Jersey's 12 largest health maintenance organizations fail to provide adequate preventive health care, the state's Health Commissioner ordered the companies today to improve services like cancer screenings and childhood immunizations by 2000.

title: Giants Aim to Keep Heads Up and Sanders Down
description: The Dallas Cowboys' Deion Sanders spent more time in the Giants' end zone than any Giants player during the first meeting between the teams this season.

title: Talks to Resume For Unification Bout
description: The negotiations for the Evander Holyfield-Lennox Lewis heavyweight unification bout, stalled for the last two weeks, have heated up again.

title: USX-U.S. STEEL OFFERS EARLY RETIREMENT TO 540
description: USX-U.S. Steel Group Inc. offered early retirement yesterday to 540 managers and nonunion employees, or 12 percent of its salaried work force. The company, the biggest United States steelmaker, said it would take a fourth-quarter charge of less than $10 million to account for the buyouts. U.S. Steel's sales and earnings have been weakened in the last year. The company, a unit of the USX Corporation, made the offer to selected managers at its steel plants and to USX Engineers and Consultants Inc. employees.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HOGS RISE 1.9 PERCENT. Prices strengthened from four-year lows after the United States said it would donate pork to Russia. The December contract for lean hog carcasses rose 0.65 cent to settle at 35.85 cents a pound.

title: For Lukas, the More Entries (Eight) the Merrier the Outcome May Be
description: On the eve of the Breeders' Cup, it was not clear whether D. Wayne Lukas would win any of Saturday's seven races with their prize money of $13.2 million. But it was absolutely certain that he would outnumber everybody else at Churchill Downs, as he has done in his record-setting past.

title: Program Chief Quits Mediaone
description: Mediaone Group Inc., one of the nation's largest cable-television companies, said today that its top programming executive, Jedd Palmer, had left after less than a year on the job amid a realignment.

title: U.S. Banks Grow Cautious On Scope of Aid to Brazil
description: With a $30 billion international rescue package for Brazil nearing completion, American banks, already battered by global financial turmoil, are sitting on the sidelines. Only a few weeks ago, some United States bankers, including those with the Chase Manhattan Corporation, talked openly about the possibility of bolstering the lending efforts of agencies like the International Monetary Fund by adding their own funds to any rescue package.

title: ALLIANT TECHSYSTEMS TO BUY BACK UP TO 23% OF ITS STOCK
description: Alliant Techsystems Inc. said yesterday that it would buy back as many as 2.8 million shares, or 23 percent of its common stock, in a Dutch tender offer. Alliant, the leading United States munitions supplier, will buy the shares for $67 to $77 each. Under a Dutch auction, each shareholder is given an opportunity to specify a price, within the stated range, at which he would tender his shares. The company then identifies the lowest price that would enable it to buy all the shares it is seeking and purchases all the shares at that price. The buyback could be worth as much as $215.6 million. Shares of Alliant, based in Hopkins, Minn., rose $1.875 each yesterday, to $75.75.

title: In Desperation, an Odd Play Can Appear to Be Inspired
description: Many will recall the complaint of Lewis Carroll's young man: ''You are old, Father William . . . and yet you incessantly stand on your head. Do you think, at your age, it is right?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EMERY, ADELE HAMMOND OLYPHANT
description: EMERY-Adele Hammond Olyphant. Peacefully at home on November 6, 1998. Wife of the late John K. Olyphant Jr. and John J. Emery. Mother of Adele O. Miller, David Olyphant and J.V. Bevan Olyphant. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to The Visiting Nurse Association of NNJ, 38 Elm St., Morristown, NJ, 07960. Funeral service will be private.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Indonesia Car Maker Offers Tough Choice to Creditors
description: PT Astra International, Indonesia's largest auto maker, offered its creditors two choices today: cash out and take a sizable loss or join its debt-revamping plan and hope for an improvement in the languishing Indonesian economy.

title: Chase Reviews Nazi-Era Role
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it is investigating allegations that it froze accounts of Jewish customers in Paris during the Nazi occupation of France before formal orders to freeze the accounts were issued.

title: Worker Saves Attendant Who Drove Car Into River
description: A construction worker dived into the Passaic River in downtown Newark yesterday to rescue a parking lot attendant who had accidentally driven a car into the water, the police said.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose after Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers said Europe's single currency would help the United States. The dollar rose to 119.10 yen from 117.67, and 1.6738 marks from 1.6601.

title: Sports of The Times; A Far Cry From the Fun Of the Derby
description: THIS is Churchill Downs, but somehow the place has a different feel and texture this week. Not so light and effervescent, as when it is host to the event for which it is so widely known -- the Kentucky Derby.

title: With an Unlimited Voice And an Unfettered Mind
description: Rachelle Ferrell

title: Zen Banking: Japan's Negative Interest Rates
description: Japanese interest rates were already the lowest on record, so it had seemed impossible that they could go any lower. But they have: some interest rates are now dancing into negative territory.

title: U. of Washington Will End Race-Conscious Admissions
description: In the first concrete result of Tuesday's passage of an anti-affirmative-action referendum in Washington State, the University of Washington said it was regretfully suspending its 30-year practice of race-conscious admissions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, IVAN
description: SHAPIRO-Ivan. The New York Society for Ethical Culture records with sorrow the death of their former President, Trustee and member on November 4, 1998. Mr. Shapiro was a much respected lawyer and civil libertarian. We extend our sympathy to his wife Maria and his family. A memorial service will be held November 16, 11AM at The Society, 2 W. 64 St. Dr. Judith D. Wallach, Pres. Dr. Bob Kaufmann, Interim Senior Leader Trustees and Staff of The New York Society for Ethical Culture

title: FACING A REVOLT, GINGRICH WON'T RUN FOR SPEAKER AND WILL QUIT CONGRESS
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich, who orchestrated the Republican takeover of Congress in 1994 and presided this year over what at times seemed like the political destruction of President Clinton, was himself driven from office today by a party that swiftly turned on him after its unexpected losses in Tuesday's midterm elections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAACSON, ROBERT L.
description: ISAACSON-Robert L. On Nov. 5, 1998 at home in Manhattan. He was an urbane figure well-known to enthusiasts of 19th-century academic painting. A Requiem Mass will be held at Saint Ignatius Loyola on Park Avenue, November 10th at 11:00 AM. Donations in his memory may be made to the Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Medical Center, 1st Avenue at 16th Street, NY, NY 10003.

title: World War I Sets Off A New Battle In France
description: A day after France's Socialist Prime Minister called for the rehabilitation of French soldiers executed for refusing to fight in a World War I battle that cost 300,000 French lives, the country's Gaullist conservative President, Jacques Chirac, today called the Prime Minister's remarks ''inopportune.''

title: Luther Jerstad, 61, Alpinist Who Scaled Everest in 1963
description: Luther Jerstad, an Oregon mountain guide and member of the first American team to reach the top of Mount Everest, in 1963, died last Saturday in Nepal on a trek up Mount Kala Pattar, a much lesser cousin in the Great Himalayan Range. He was 61 and lived in Portland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUKSIN, JACK
description: DUKSIN-Jack. Beloved husband of Lynn. Devoted father of Joshua, Jeremy and Callie. Adored brother of Sherry. Cherished son of Eva. Service Sunday 10AM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Closing Sweatshops
description: To the Editor:

title: California Examines Brutal, Deadly Prisons
description: There was lots of celebrating in this cotton-growing town in the San Joaquin Valley when a maximum-security prison opened here 10 years ago.

title: Clinton Makes Visit to Site of His First Race for Federal Office
description: With his shiny blue and white jet parked behind him, President Clinton appeared today in the district where he lost his first race for Federal office. He reflected with a nostalgic smile on how he and Arkansas had changed in the 24 years since, ignoring the tumult among his Republican opponents in Washington.

title: Talks Hit Stalemate And Break Off for Now
description: The chances of ending the National Basketball Association's labor conflict grew more bleak yesterday. Talks between the chief negotiators broke off indefinitely, another week of games was stricken from the schedule and the union's executive director, Billy Hunter, again accused the league of trying to shatter the players' solidarity.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GROSSMAN, LOUISE S.
description: GROSSMAN-Louise S. In memory of Louise Steefel Grossman. 1898-1969

title: Israel and Vatican: Improper Request?
description: To the Editor:

title: Goma Journal; One Rebellion Too Many for War-Weary Congolese
description: The dusty stalls and roadside shops are open until late afternoon now, and people are less afraid to wander out after dark. But learning to live with the second rebellion here in two years is not the same as loving it, as Gilbert Kombi, an unemployed cabdriver, bluntly pointed out.

title: Don't Make N.F.L. Judge and Jury
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARD, TED M.
description: WARD-Ted M. The New York Financial Writers Association regrets the passing of its longtime member and former president. The Association wishes to express its deepest sympathy to his family and friends. Susan Lisovicz, President

title: Questions for Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: A Ban on Cells That Could Heal
description: The breakthrough in growing human stem cells in the laboratory with private funding is not only a remarkable achievement, it is a rebuke to Congress for banning Federal funding of this exciting research. Scientists are now poised to explore new therapies for dreaded diseases. Yet, thanks to a Congressional ban on Federal funding for most research on embryos, the Government may find it hard to accelerate a promising field or monitor its ethics.

title: Bob Kane, 83, the Cartoonist Who Created 'Batman,' Is Dead
description: Bob Kane, the cartoonist who created Batman the Caped Crusader and his sidekick, Robin the Boy Wonder, died on Tuesday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 83 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Disputed 'Lolita' Spinoff Is Dropped by Publisher
description: In an abrupt reversal that ends a tangled legal and literary confrontation, Farrar, Straus & Giroux said yesterday that it had canceled plans to publish a retelling of ''Lolita'' from the nymphet's point of view, in part because of copyright concerns by some of the publishing house's own writers.

title: Senator Moynihan's Decision
description: Daniel Patrick Moynihan grew up in Hell's Kitchen on Manhattan's West Side, trained as a teacher and scholar and served four Presidents as a domestic adviser and diplomat before running for the Senate in 1976. The Almanac of American Politics describes him as ''the nation's best thinker among politicians since Lincoln and its best politician among thinkers since Jefferson.'' The formulation seems a little over the top, but it also fits a man who always liked to surround his serious concerns with extravagant language and gestures. Now, at 71, he has announced his intention to retire in 2000, depriving the Senate of one of its most distinctive, elegant and independent voices.

title: A Violin Teacher Shows Off His Students
description: Valery Gradow, violinist, and students

title: FOAMEX AGREES TO LOWER BID OF $162 MILLION FROM TRACE
description: The polyurethane-foam maker Foamex International has agreed to accept a lower offer to be acquired by Trace International Holdings Inc., for $12 a share, a total of $162 million. The price is below Foamex's closing share price on Thursday. The stock fell 93.75 cents yesterday, to $11.4375. Trace offered $17 for each Foamex share outstanding in March, then raised its offer to $18.75 a share in June. Trace cut the offer after it failed to obtain debt financing, citing deteriorating conditions in capital markets. Trace, which is based in New York, and its units now own about 11.5 million Foamex common shares, or about 46 percent of the company. Foamex, based in Linwood, Pa., makes foam products, automotive products and technical products.

title: F.B.I. Gets Tape of '93 Protest at Buffalo Abortion Clinic
description: A videotape of a 1993 protest outside an abortion clinic here was turned over to the Federal Bureau of Investigation today because several of the clinic's workers believe a man at the event strongly resembles James Charles Kopp, who is wanted for questioning in the shooting death two weeks ago of the clinic's doctor.

title: Don't Make N.F.L. Judge and Jury
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. to Lift Some Sanctions Against India and Pakistan
description: President Clinton will use his new authority granted by Congress to waive some sanctions on India and Pakistan because of their promises to stop nuclear testing, a senior American official said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: No. 1 Bookstore Chain To Buy Top Wholesaler

title: Relief Efforts Reaching Rural Areas In Nicaragua
description: With the flood waters generated by by a huge hurricane finally receding, now that nearly two weeks of torrential rains appear to have ended, relief workers and international aid groups today stepped up their efforts to reach survivors in isolated rural areas across Central America and to rush food, medicine and other vital supplies to them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTER, SHIRLEY
description: KANTER-Shirley, 88. Of NYC. Widow of George. Mother of Adelyn, Vivien and William. Grandmother of Daryl, Lindsey, Sam, Marc, Alisha, Melissa and Greg. Four great-grandchildren, Scott, Jessica, Nicholas and Claudia.

title: Autumn Rally Taking Stocks Back to Highs
description: The stock market has spoken. Its tidings: Happy days are here again.

title: Rwandans Confirm They Are Helping the Rebels in Congo
description: Rwanda acknowledged today for the first time that it had troops helping rebels in Congo, an admission that could smooth the way for a cease-fire in that troubled country.

title: Race True to Its Name: It's a Classic
description: In the backstretch barns across the infield from the twin spires of Churchill Downs, the world's greatest race horses were stabled today on the eve of their all-star showdown in the $5.1 million Breeders' Cup Classic, the richest thoroughbred race ever, the best since the cup series was started 14 years ago and one of the best in the long history of the sport.

title: Jack Hartman, 73, Longtime Kansas State Basketball Coach
description: Jack Hartman, who led Kansas State to more basketball victories than any other coach in school history, and who coached the Knicks' great Walt Frazier at Southern Illinois, died yesterday morning at St. Vincent Hospital in Sante Fe, N.M. He was 73.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOTWIN, ROSEMARIE
description: LOTWIN - Rosemarie. Dearest Mother, remembering you on your birthday and every day. In our hearts forever and ever. Love, Sean, Kelle and Dakota

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The Republican conference needs to be unified, and it is time for me to move forward.''

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Monday with a front-page article about part-time workers who put in full-time hours mislabeled figures representing the growth in dual-career couples. The figures represented the number of members of such couples, not the number of couples.

title: Parents Urge Crew to End Dispute on 'Failing' List
description: Parents and community organizers were sharply critical of Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew yesterday, saying he was quibbling over how many New York City schools should be placed on the state's list of failing schools.

title: Protestors Say A New Movie Likens Islam To Terrorism
description: A group of Arab-Americans gathered outside a Times Square movie theater last night to protest the debut of a new thriller, ''The Siege,'' saying that the movie equates Arabs and Islam with terrorism. But after the film received tepid reviews this week, other Arab-American groups decided to cancel their protests for fear of giving the film free publicity.

title: Don't Make N.F.L. Judge and Jury
description: To the Editor:

title: ABC Says It Is Dropping Plans For Stone Special on Flight 800
description: Citing the potential for confusion among viewers between ''fact-based entertainment and hard news,'' executives of the ABC television network said yesterday that the network had dropped plans to broadcast a prime-time special, produced by the film maker Oliver Stone, about the theory that long-range missiles caused the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 off Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAROT, GRACE C.
description: SHAROT-Grace C. On November 6, 1998 of Manhattan, NY. Beloved mother of Joan Carter, dear grandmother of Heather Goldman and Nikki Leopold, also survived by three great grandchildren. Reposing at The Moore Funeral Home, 54 W. Jamaica Ave, Valley Stream, NY. Family will receive friends Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Monday, 10AM with interment to follow in Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, NY.

title: The Fall of Gingrich, an Irony in an Odd Year
description: It seemed somehow the ultimate irony of this strange political year, the year stigmatized by President Clinton's affair with Monica S. Lewinsky. Instead of Bill Clinton being the one to fall, it was Newt Gingrich.

title: A Writer's Fantasy: Who I Wish I'd Been
description: Arts and Ideas asked authors what book, besides their own, of course, they would most like to have written. Mary B. W. Tabor compiled their answers.

title: Jones Case Settlement Likely Despite Setbacks
description: Advisers to both Paula Corbin Jones and the White House said today that they believed it was still possible to agree to a settlement sometime in the next few weeks in which she would withdraw her sexual misconduct lawsuit against the President.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, EDWARD POWIS
description: JONES-Edward Powis. On November 5th. Husband of Anne. Father of Elizabeth Jones White, Edward Powis Jones, Jr., and Peter C. Jones. Brother of Frances H. Jones and the late Henry McNeven Jones. Grandfather of David C. Landreth, Sarah P. Landreth, and Daniel M. Jones. Services private. Contributions in his memory may be made to: St. Benedict's Monastery, 1012 Monastery Road, Snowmass, CO. 81654

title: U.S. Weighs Extradition Of Pinochet
description: Justice Department officials are discussing whether to seek the extradition of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former dictator of Chile, in connection with four killings that took place under his regime more than 20 years ago, Justice Department officials said tonight.

title: Peace and Terror in the Mideast
description: It is a depressingly safe prediction that terrorism will haunt peacemaking between Israel and the Palestinians in the months ahead. That was shown again yesterday when two suicide bombers detonated a car bomb in a crowded Jerusalem market. Fortunately, the device went off prematurely and only the bombers were killed, although more than 20 innocent people were wounded.

title: 'X-Files' Tries to Keep Its Murky Promise
description: Anyone who turns on the ''The X Files'' is bound to be struck by the distinctive look: murky, mysterious and just a little bit threatening.

title: New York's Congressional Freshmen Are New to the House, but Not to Politics
description: Two years ago, it was the election to Congress of Carolyn McCarthy, with her grass-roots organization, status as a political neophyte and crusade for gun control, that took center stage in New York State. The victory of Ms. McCarthy, a Mineola Republican who ran on the Democratic line, and her transformation from housewife and nurse to politician dominated any discussion about the changing faces in the state's Congressional delegation.

title: No Compromise on Glacier
description: India and Pakistan failed today to make progress toward peace in a place where their armies are now killing each other: a wretched, freezing, thin-aired border spot 24,000 feet above sea level known as the Siachen Glacier.

title: VINTAGE PETROLEUM IN $39.7 MILLION DEAL FOR COMPANY
description: Vintage Petroleum Inc. purchased Elf Acquitaine's Ecuador unit yesterday for $39.7 million in cash and stock. In a statement, Vintage said it had paid $13.2 million in cash and issued 1,325,000 common shares, valued at the guaranteed amount of $20 a share, or $26.5 million. Its stock closed yesterday at $14.0625, down 18.75 cents a share. The legal transfer of the oil and gas unit of the French energy group Elf Acquitaine to Vintage, which is based in Tulsa, Okla., is subject to approval by the Ecuadorean Government.

title: U.S. Says Storm Aid Could Cost Billions
description: The Clinton Administration said today that rebuilding the four Central American nations devastated by a hurricane would cost hundreds of millions, if not billions, of dollars and last for several years.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about two new cable channels planned by the Fox Family Channel misspelled the surname of the head of programming at Nickelodeon. She is Cyma Zarghami, not Zhargami.

title: 3-Way Effort Seems to Slow Bombings By Terrorists
description: At a news conference in Gaza last month the leader of the militant Islamic movement Hamas, Sheik Ahmad Yassin, made an uncharacteristic admission.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Oct. 28 about ''Leonard Bernstein: Reaching for the Note'' on PBS misidentified the conductor of Bernstein's ''Mass'' at the opening of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington in 1971. It was Maurice Peress, though Bernstein was present.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CARBIDE/GRAPHITE GROUP, Pittsburgh, a maker of graphite and calcium-carbide products, said it planned to dismiss 100 workers and close some operations at a plant in St. Marys, Pa., by January.

title: Court Grants Office Access To Police Files
description: In a ruling embraced by Public Advocate Mark Green as confirmation of his mandate as a city watchdog, a state appellate court has ruled that the New York Police Department must grant the Public Advocate's request -- nearly two years old now -- to review the case files of hundreds of police officers suspected of misconduct or brutality.

title: McCarthy, Still Unredeemable
description: The history of American anti-Communism is being rewritten as we speak. The impetus is the emergence of recently declassified files in Russia and the United States that were secret for decades. These documents have confirmed that Soviet intelligence gained a foothold in the American Government in the 1930's and 40's, and that Russian spy masters could count on their comrades in the United States for support.

title: U.S. Team Soars In Nations Cup
description: Paced by Eric Hasbrouck's faultless ride aboard Miss Fio in the second round, the United States Equestrian Team won the Samsung Nations Cup international jumping competition last night at the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden.

title: When the Mind Is the Matter; Mental Disability Cases Pose Painful Workplace Issues
description: John Olson, an engineer at the General Electric Company, was hospitalized for depression for four months in 1991. Soon after he returned to his job at the company's astrospace unit, he was laid off in a widespread downsizing.

title: Mitterrand's Last Whim Struggles With Reality
description: In late March 1995, just weeks before leaving office, President Francois Mitterrand inaugurated the $1.5 billion complex that would house the new National Library of France.
