The last of what are known as the ''Grands Travaux,'' or great works, that would mark Mr. Mitterrand's 14 years in power, it was also his favorite, so much so that he picked the design and rushed its construction in just 19 months.

title: Spinning and Turning, As if Moving on Ice
description: American Ballet Theater

title: East Side Heliport Ceases Operations on Weekends
description: After 25 years of enduring the clatter of helicopters on weekends, residents of Manhattan's East Side are finally getting a few days of quiet. Prompted by longstanding complaints from residents, the city has ended weekend operations at the East 34th Street Heliport.

title: The Enigma Of Jefferson: Mind and Body In Conflict
description: For contemporary historians, Thomas Jefferson has always been an enigma, and the new DNA evidence that he fathered at least one child by his young slave Sally Hemings simply deep ens the mystery of the man. On the one hand, Jefferson was the author of some of the most glorious sentences in the English language, his ringing affirmation of the equality of all men in the Declaration of Independence. On the other, he was a slaveholder who wrote some of the vilest sentiments of racism in his only book, ''Notes on the State of Virginia,'' published in 1785. Blacks, Jefferson wrote, have ''a very strong and disagreeable odor,'' they are incapable of uttering more than ''a plain narration.'' Jefferson also said that racial amalgamation ''produces a degradation . . . to which no one can innocently consent.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITT, IRA J.
description: WITT-Ira J. November 5, 1998. Former President Handbag Association of America and catcher on 1927 James Madison City Championship Baseball Team. Beloved husband of Evelyn. Loving father of Stuart and grandfather of Jennifer. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street, Sunday 11:00 AM.

title: Florida Files Suit Accusing Sweepstakes Company of Preying on the Elderly
description: American Family Publishers, one of the nation's two largest sweepstakes companies, was accused by the Florida Attorney General today of preying on the elderly through deceptive magazine solicitations and by selling names of senior citizens and retired people who enter sweepstakes to operators of other contests.

title: U.S. Plans New Rule to Install Child Safety Seats in New Cars
description: The Department of Transportation plans to publish a rule next month to establish, for the first time, a uniform system for installing child safety seats in cars without using seat belts.

title: Morrison Is a Proven Scorer Who Has Much to Prove
description: After Scott Niedermayer, Brendan Morrison is the player with the highest expectations on the Devils. From the first day of training camp, Morrison was viewed as the player to fill the biggest void for the loss of center Doug Gilmour to free agency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FASSETT, CHARLOTTE C.
description: FASSETT-Charlotte C., 85, of Kennebunk, formerly of Rochester, NY, died in ME., widow of David Fassett, MD. Mother to Matthew, Myra Fassett-Hickenlooper and Clara Carter, six grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Visitation 2-4 PM Sun at Bibber Memorial Chapel, Kennebunk, ME. Funeral 10 AM, Mon. at St. David's Church. Memorials to Laudholm Trust, PO Box 1007, Wells, ME 04090 or Brick Store Museum, 117 Main St., Kennebunk, ME 04043.

title: Call for Disaster Relief
description: To the Editor:

title: Aid in Dying: Mercy Is Required
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel and Vatican: Improper Request?; Difference of Opinion
description: To the Editor:

title: Listening to Dr. Prozac; From Depression to Separation, a Therapist Resists Easy Answers
description: The wildfire success of ''Listening to Prozac'' made Peter Kramer possibly the best-known psychiatrist in America -- and, with the headlines pigeonholing him as the ''Pied Piper of Prozac,'' possibly the most misunderstood.

title: DiMaggio Worsens in Fight Against Pneumonia
description: Joe DiMaggio's condition has worsened and the former Yankee star is expected to remain hospitalized for at least another six to eight weeks, according to Morris Engelberg, his lawyer and friend.

title: A Year Later, a Couple's Disappearance Remains a Mystery
description: A year after Camden Sylvia and Michael Sullivan disappeared, their loft in lower Manhattan is silent and unchanged, as if awaiting their return. Their bed, their watercolors, the table and chairs, stand in the dusty shadows like stage props. A vase wants fresh flowers. The clothes still hang neatly, unused.

title: Williams's Suitors Cover Themselves
description: If the Yankees are concerned about Bernie Williams showing up in center field at Fenway Park next season -- wearing the home uniform -- they should not breathe a sigh of relief just because the Red Sox re-signed their own center fielder, Darren Lewis.

title: Mitsubishi Posts Loss
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, Japan's fourth-largest car maker and largest truck maker, today reported another large loss because of poor sales across Asia and said it would take further cost-cutting measures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, GEORGE
description: BROWN-George, MD, formerly of Riverdale, NY, and Marlboro, VT, passed peacefully in Lenox, MA, after a prolonged illness. He leaves his wife Jeanne; two children, Richard and Hillary; a sister Gertrude, and two grandchildren, Eliot and Nicholas. Services will be private. Donations may be sent to HospiceCare in the Berkshires, 369 South Street, Pittsfield, MA. 01201

title: Disappointment Greets News of Gingrich, Symbol of Independence in His Self-Reliant District
description: In other places, perhaps, Newt Gingrich stands for other things, for fervidly conservative political ideals that seem to exclude some Americans. But here in Roswell, where the suburban sprawl has etched itself deep into the mountains, Mr. Gingrich stood mostly for independence.

title: 24 in Jerusalem Injured by Blast From Car Bomb
description: A red Fiat belching smoke sent shoppers fleeing moments before it exploded outside a bustling marketplace this morning, killing the two bombers, wounding 24 other people and disabling the United States-brokered peace effort.

title: Man Steps on Glass Panel And Falls Seven Stories
description: A trainer at the New York Health and Racquet Club on 57th Street in Manhattan was in critical condition yesterday after falling seven stories through a glass panel, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REY, EUGENE C.
description: REY-Eugene C. May 15, 1900-Nov. 2, 1998. Left this garden for the next to join his beloved wife, Antoinette, leaving a large, thriving and loving family tree. Children Eugene Rey and wife Margaret, Lenore Rey and husband Marc Stoller; grandchildren Victoria and Eddie Hayes, Peggy and Steve O'Malley, Loretta and Armand DiPardo, Janine and Lou Assentato, and Jason Stoller; great-grandchildren Edward, Kristen and Brian Hayes, Erik and Schuyler Ann O'Malley, Steven, Lisa, and Jake DiPardo, Jordan and Austin Assentato; brothers Augustine, Salvadore, Antonio and numerous nieces and nephews in Spain and the U.S.; and honorary members of his clan including Mark and Linnean Gorelick, Lucien Flotte, Sal Laduca and many wonderful friends and neighbors. Poppy, although we miss you greatly, we have 98 years' worth of wonderful memories and life lessons and an eternity's worth of love.

title: MOYNIHAN SAYS HE WON'T RUN AGAIN FOR SENATE SEAT
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who for five decades has been a fixture of American politics as a Presidential adviser, scholar and member of Congress, announced yesterday that he would not run for re-election when his fourth term ends in 2000.

title: Carolina Keeps Rolling
description: HURRICANES 3, CAPITALS 2

title: Instead of Hoops, the Blame Game
description: As the National Basketball Association strike drags on, more and more attention has turned to the players and their greed. This is understandable. Many players make salaries far larger than the ordinary fan ever has an opportunity to achieve.

title: Punching a Clock To Fight Abortion; For the Foot Soldiers, Protest Means Prayer and Persuasion
description: Rosina Lotempio was standing outside abortion clinics here before Operation Rescue stormed into town in 1992 for the rowdy Spring of Life rallies, in which hundreds were arrested.

title: The Speaker's Parting Gift
description: Two numbers symbolize why we need a new Speaker of the House in 1999: 8 dollars and 20 billion dollars. The first is the per-person annual tax cut passed this year; the second is the amount of money raided from the budget surplus to pay for so-called emergency spending.

title: Moving From Nonchalance To a New Emotionality
description: Nina Persson

title: Pirates to Head 'Em Off at the Pass
description: There are times when Shaheen Holloway is too good. Times when he sees things that only the outstanding ones can see. Times when he delivers impeccable no-look passes to unsuspecting teammates, only to have the ball bounce horribly off their arms or chests.

title: While Ballots Trickle In, Rivals Wait
description: The waiting began Tuesday night, when 10 P.M., then 11, then midnight, then 1 A.M. came and went with no result in the New York attorney general's race. At the Waldorf-Astoria, the Democratic candidate, Eliot L. Spitzer, and his aides watched reporters drift off and cheese cubes grow stale. In the wee hours of Wednesday morning, Mr. Spitzer finally addressed the holdouts, but he had little to tell them.

title: Don't Make N.F.L. Judge and Jury
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A profile on the Public Lives page on Sept. 30 about Jeanne Fleming, director of the Greenwich Village Halloween Parade, misidentified the Livingston descendant still residing on the upstate New York estate built by his family, where Ms. Fleming is a tenant. He is Richard Aldrich; John Winthrop Aldrich is his brother and a neighbor. John Aldrich telephoned about the error late in October, and this correction was delayed for confirmation.

title: A Model for Russia
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELDOLA, ROSEMARIE
description: MELDOLA-Rosemarie M.D. The Faculty and Staff of New York University School of Medicine deeply mourn the loss of Rosemarie Ingeborg Meldola, MD, age 89. A dedicated pediatrician and longtime faculty member of the Department of Pediatrics. A native of Germany, Dr. Meldola received her medical degree in 1934 from the University of Hamburg. The rise of the Nazis interfered with her medical education-as a Jew she couldn't obtain an internship in a recognized hospital. She spent the next four years assisting her father Eduardo, also a physician in his medical practice. In 1938 she immigrated to Holland and worked underground in two hospitals in Amsterdam during the Nazi occupation until she was deported to the concentration camps of Auschwitz Bergen Belsen and Buchenwald where she also served as a physician. Dr. Meldola immigrated to the United States in 1947. After completing a research fellowship in tuberculosis at Bellevue Hospital, an affiliate of NYU Medical Center, she became a faculty member in the Department of Pediatrics in 1953. She was also in private practice for many years in New York City. She retired in 1983. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family. Robert M. Glickman, MD Dean New York University School of Medicine Wade Parks, PhD, MD Pat and John Rosenwald, Professor of Pediatrics and Chairman of the Department and Professor of Microbiology

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCFADDEN, RUTH NEILSON
description: McFADDEN-Ruth Neilson. Wife of the late Louis E. Died peacefully at home on November 5th at age 81. Formerly of NYC, Peekskill, NY and New Canaan, CT. Survived by her six children, Josephine N., Barbara M. Sirna of NYC, Katherine M. Whitmore of Belfast, ME, Neil A. of Oak Park, IL, Lucy-Ann A. of Bethesda, MD, and John A. of Wynantskill, NY; her sister, Brita N. Blauvelt of Hightstown, NJ, and brother, John E. Neilson of Lompoc, CA; and 10 grandchildren. Graham Funeral Home, Rye, NY, 914-967-0129.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORCORAN, FRANCIS L.
description: CORCORAN-Francis L. On November 4, 1998, of Locust Valley, New York, (Princeton, Class of '22) retired Executive Vice President and Director of Rockefeller Center, Inc., died peacefully at home in his 100th year. Husband of the late Carel DeBevoise Corcoran, survived by his son, Anthony Corcoran and his wife, Sandra Towl Corcoran of Pinehurst, NC and his daughter Carel Corcoran of NYC, father of the late Charles D. Corcoran and father-in-law of his wife, Jane Roesler Corcoran of East Norwich, NY, grandfather of Clinton, Kevin, John and Andrew Corcoran and great-grandfather of Abigail, Alexandra and Patrick Corcoran. He lit up our lives with wit, intelligence and integrity.

title: Clinton Says Latest Bombing Should Not Derail the Accord
description: President Clinton expressed sympathy to Israel today after a car-bomb explosion in a Jerusalem market wounded 24 people but said the attack should not derail the recent land-for-security deal between Israel and the Palestinians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOCK, KATHLEEN I.
description: STOCK-Kathleen I. On November 6, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Lloyd Stock, beloved companion of the late Vito Fidanque, dearest friend of many. Memorial service Tues., Nov. 10, 2:30PM Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Av, 81 St.

title: Former Louisiana Governor Is Indicted in Extortion Case
description: After an investigation that lasted more than two years, a Federal grand jury indicted former Gov. Edwin W. Edwards, his son Stephen and four associates today in a racketeering conspiracy to extort millions of dollars from businesses seeking to win lucrative riverboat casino licenses in Louisiana.

title: Bob Trow, 72, of 'Mister Rogers'
description: Bob Trow, an actor who helped usher two generations of children through their formative years as a member of the cast of ''Mister Rogers' Neighborhood,'' died on Monday at his home in New Alexandria, Pa. He was 72.

title: In a Wide-Ranging Rebound, Some Big Losers Bounce High
description: The sharp run-up in the stock market over the last month, which has returned the Dow Jones industrial average to within striking distance of the 9,000 level, has given almost every major stock group big gains.

title: Don't Make N.F.L. Judge and Jury
description: To the Editor:

title: AIRTOUCH AND NORTHERN TELECOM ARE IN LOS ANGELES DEAL
description: Airtouch Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would replace its Los Angeles wireless phone system built by Motorola Inc. with equipment from Northern Telecom Ltd. Airtouch, the world's largest cellular phone-service provider, said it planned to move the Motorola equipment to other markets. Financial terms were not disclosed, though Airtouch said the new contract would not change its capital spending projections. Airtouch denied speculation that it had problems with the Motorola equipment. Motorola equipment is used in 40 percent of Airtouch's United States wireless markets. Northern Telecom accounts for about 40 percent, and Lucent Technologies Inc. and Ericsson A.B. products are used in the remaining 20 percent.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: LET'S PUT ON A SHOW
description: Despite the death of his mother, the burning of his house and the failure of his kidneys, George C. Wolfe hasn't lost his nerve. He is betting the Public Theater's endowment on a high-cost, high-risk revival of ''On the Town.'' A report by Alex Witchel, in the Times Magazine.

title: Aid in Dying: Mercy Is Required
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESCH, RAE
description: LESCH-Rae, On November 5, 1998. Loving mother of Bernice Levy and Sandra and Leonard Pariser. Cherished grandmother of Douglas, Michelle, Mark, Wayne and Craig. Devoted sister of Paul and Jan Meyrowitz.

title: Pace of Consumer Credit Rose in September
description: Borrowing by United States consumers rose in September at a pace that was faster than expected as credit card debt and personal loans accelerated, according to Federal Reserve figures released today.

title: MEDTRONIC TO BUY 3.5% STAKE IN MINIMED FOR $30 MILLION
description: Medtronic Inc., the world's largest pacemaker company, said yesterday that it was buying a 3.5 percent stake in the diabetes-supplies developer Minimed Inc. in two phases for $30 million. The Minneapolis-based Medtronic has bought 233,334 Minimed common shares for $60 each, or about $14 million, and plans to buy another 266,666 shares at $60 for approximately $16 million, subject to regulatory approvals. Minimed, based in Sylmar, Calif., makes high-technology infusion systems for insulin that permit more effective treatment of diabetes. Minimed rose $4.75 a share, to $65.75, and Medtronic rose 18.75 cents, to $64.0625.

title: Historic Baseball Is for Sale
description: When Christopher Scala decided to dress up as Babe Ruth for a school project two years ago, it brought back memories for his great-grandmother. Viola Bevilacque recalled that her late husband, Charles, had been given a ball bearing Ruth's signature back in 1927.

title: About New York; Birds' Haven Is Headache for Tenants
description: Too bad pigeons don't head south for the winter. Then Silvia Medrano's family could get a good night's rest. Unfortunately, a brood of cooing birds poked and clawed their way into a part of the roof that hangs over her third-floor apartment in a Brooklyn housing project.

title: INSIDE
description: Russia to Buy American

title: The Gingrich Coup
description: House Speaker Newt Gingrich was swept away by the Congressional equivalent of a barracks coup, and it happened with a speed that actually merits one of the most overused adjectives in the political dictionary. It was, in fact, stunning. Our guess is that earlier in the day, Mr. Gingrich was himself stunned as he measured by telephone the erosion of his support in the Republican conference that he and such hard-handed deputies as Dick Armey had run with harsh efficiency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSCHUTZ, POLA
description: LIPSCHUTZ-Pola. On November 5, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Max. Mother, grandmother and friend. Services Sun. November 8, 10:45AM, at''Riverside'', 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave., New York City.

title: Another Visit to King Arthur's Court
description: Though the story has been updated repeatedly on film, the basic plot of ''A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court'' has remained intact: a present-day Everyman (or Everywoman) is whisked back in time to give the Arthurians, for better or for worse, a taste of modern life. What changes with each film is ever-advancing modern life. In the latest movie based on Mark Twain's classic, Whoopi Goldberg arrives with what appears to be an armful of merchandise from Nobody Beats the Wiz, and soon has Camelot doing the twist.

title: Colgate's Vena Is Confident Leader
description: After his final high school football season in Littleton, Colo., no college recruiters were knocking on Ryan Vena's door. So his father, who had a friend who was handy with video equipment, put together a highlights tape. Out it went to 50 colleges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLZSAGER, ROSE
description: HOLZSAGER-Rose. On November 4, 1998, of Silver Spring, MD, formerly of New York City. Wife of the late Edward Holzsager of NYC. Beloved mother of Richard Holzsager and the late Donald Holzsager. Devoted grandmother of Keith Holden, Daivd Holzsager, Laura Zebrowski, Adam Holzsager and Craig Holden and the late Seth Holzsager. Survived by several great grandchildren. Graveside services will be held at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY on Sunday, November 8 at 1 P.M. Memorial contributions can be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: 3 Arrested at Cemetery After Break-In at Crypt
description: Three people were arrested in a Queens cemetery yesterday after groundskeepers noticed a woman crawling out of the back window of a crypt with a claw hammer in her hand, the police said.

title: Tapas Goes Worldwide And Dishes Out Jazz, Too
description: Call it pan-tapas. The cuisine at Session 73, a lounge and restaurant at 1359 First Avenue (at 73d Street), deviates from the Spanish and Mediterranean fare that is traditionally associated with tapas.

title: Is Solitary Confinement Driving Charlie Chase Crazy?
description: As I enter the interviewing room, Charlie Chase is standing there alone, dressed in his tan prison scrubs and slip-on sneakers. We circle each other, and I'm a little wary at first, vaguely conscious of keeping the steel rectangular table between us in case he makes a sudden move in my direction. It's a feeling that's not eased by the circumstances of our visit, or by his record. Owing to what the authorities characterize as his ''poor interpersonal management skills,'' evidenced by a series of assaults on prisoners and guards, I have been advised not to get too close to Charlie, probably a poor idea to shake his hand, they said. A corrections officer has been posted just outside the smashproof glass door with orders to keep his eyes glued on our encounter. Not that Charlie appears able to do much damage at the moment. His feet are shackled by leg irons, and he's cuffed to a belly chain, so when I offer my hand finally, by instinct, he can extend his own only a few inches away from his body, in the manner of a flipper.

title: In Foodie Heaven With the Nabob of Nosh
description: I WENT to Paris to escape. I wanted to lose myself in paintings I had been too cool to queue up for in New York, clog my arteries by eating dinner at my usual bedtime while second-hand smoke got in my eyes, then dance home at dawn around all the little sidewalk monuments to the liberte of dog owners.

title: Diana Strauss, Michael Norwood
description: Diana Kathryn Strauss, a daughter of Laura and Peter Strauss of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Michael John Norwood, a son of Patricia and Frederick Norwood of Kearsley, England. Judge Miriam Cedarbaum of Federal District Court officiated at the Harvard Club in New York.

title: Back to Prague
description: To the Editor: Perhaps Walter Nicklin (''When a Return Is Sweet Sorrow,'' Oct. 18) will be able to return to Prague in a decade or so, when finding his past self might be a little less compelling. He might have the time to examine more closely that mysterious borderland between the West and Asia that we call Eastern Europe. He may also spend days or weeks there getting some sense of the lives of the new Europeans.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a review in the Book Review last Sunday, about ''Created Unequal: The Crisis in American Pay,'' a book by James K. Galbraith, referred incorrectly to Arthur F. Burns, one of three Federal Reserve chairmen (along with Paul A. Volcker and Alan Greenspan) whom Mr. Galbraith criticized. Mr. Burns, who served as chairman from 1970 to 1978, was not one of ''the last three Fed chairmen.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREY, PHYLLIS R.
description: FREY-Phyllis R. The Partners and Associates of Goldberg Weprin & Ustin express profound sadness at the untimely passing of Phyllis R. Frey, dear cousin of our close friend Martin Sanders. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Mr. Sanders and the entire family.

title: Ahead of His Time at Harvard
description: Ted Seides is downright proud of winning the contest for worst-dressed student at the Harvard Business School.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: EX LIBRIS

title: More Than a Stone Wall
description: To many, the rotting waterfront in Greenwich Village is an eyesore that should be demolished to make way for the new Hudson River Park. But to preservationists, the granite river wall is a historic treasure.

title: Margaret Hilpman, Jonathan Reasoner
description: Margaret Wiley Hilpman, a daughter of Edith and John Hilpman of Weston, Conn., was married on Friday to Jonathan Andrew Reasoner, a son of the late Kathleen Carroll Reasoner, who lived in Westport, Conn., and the late Harry Reasoner, the television journalist. The Rev. Kevin Pleas, a Congregational minister, officiated at the Cobbs Mill Inn in Weston.

title: Sex-Change Industry a Boon to Small City
description: Perched for the last century on the sandstone facade of the First National Bank building here, three impish gargoyles have watched the changing foot traffic on Main Street, as this small plains city reinvented itself again and again.

title: By Taking Liberties, the Devils Get Away With One
description: The Devils found themselves today reveling in the new-found excitement of winning a scoring duel while wondering about their old calling card, defense.

title: William R. Johnson
description: William R. Johnson, the chief executive of H. J. Heinz of Pittsburgh, carries a briefcase with a red-and-blue Star Kist logo on the side. Many Americans may associate his company with ketchup and pickles, but Mr. Johnson doesn't want anyone to forget its other products, including pet food, frozen dinners, baby food and Star Kist canned tuna. The contents of his briefcase show just how hard-charging he is about getting his message out.

title: Youngsters Get a Taste of the Actor's Life
description: LONG rehearsals that run past midnight followed by seven performances a week -- that's the life of professional actors in regional theater. And four youngsters are getting a taste of that life with roles in Bertolt Brecht's ''Galileo,'' playing through Saturday at the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven.

title: Parlous Times in Russia
description: With food stocks dangerously diminished by a disastrous harvest and the economy still reeling, Russia is headed into a winter of deprivation and discontent. The critical question is whether Russians will stoically endure another season of hardship, as they have so many times before, or strike out in anger against the political order.

title: Pigeon Poison Spreads Worry
description: Is someone killing squirrels and finches in Gramercy Park? Some residents blame the chairwoman of the Gramercy Park trustees, Sharen Benenson, for what they say is the indiscriminate poisoning of the creatures. But Ms. Benenson insists that she is only trying to control the park's pigeon population.

title: Carolyne Allen, David Gold
description: Carolyne Gann Allen and David Deren Gold were married last evening in Newport, R.I. The Rev. Charles F. Flagg, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Channing Memorial Church.

title: Plotting a Thrifty Course in Tokyo
description: WHILE pouring hot water into a pot of green tea in my Tokyo hotel room, I suddenly noticed that the label on the thermos proclaimed, in elaborate pink script: ''Chic Modernity.'' Managing not to spill the bottle as I chuckled, I added the phrase to my growing list of Strange Tokyo English. The list overflowed with such gems as ''Pocari Sweat'' -- a perplexingly named canned soda sold in vending machines all over the city -- and ''Match: A Synchrotonic Drink'' -- ditto. Sometimes Tokyo's odd juxtapositions were visual rather than linguistic, like the startlingly lifelike Colonel Sanders mannequin I saw standing, hands outstretched, greeting fashionable shoppers on a boulevard in Aoyama, Tokyo's Madison Avenue-ish boutique district. Readymades awaiting a Duchamp, these little masterpieces dotted the city landscape, and what I enjoyed most about my visit to Tokyo in late September is that I never knew when or where I'd stumble across the next one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HONIG, LAWRENCE M., ESQ.
description: HONIG-Lawrence M., Esq. On October 18th. In the courts and in life itself, a Special Master and true radical: he actually believed in justice, fairness and friendship. H.E.S. and Friends

title: Menu With No Gimmicks (Except for 3's)
description: ON the way to Thirty Three & 1/3 in Ridgefield, we speculated about the name. Later we learned it reflects a three-partner ownership, a fact reinforced by having every dish on the reasonably-priced menu end with 33 cents: $3.33, $7.33, and so on.

title: Laid Low, but Often Jumping Very High
description: She cuts such an elegant figure in her second-skin jodphurs and knee-high riding boots, a bejeweled dragonfly clip adding a whimsical teen-age touch to her blond hair, that it's hard to imagine she suffers, along with 1.4 million other Americans, from an incurable disease that kills many thousands of them every year.

title: Orchard Night Life Wears on Some
description: Milton Grosbard had no customers. He was sitting by the register of his little shop, G & B Total Fashion, and watching ''Judge Judy.''

title: Tyson's New Crew Expects Calmer Waters
description: IN recent years, Tyson Foods Inc. has had almost as many misadventures as the man its executives helped to propel into politics -- Bill Clinton. Not only has it made business missteps, but even its political clout seems to have brought it little but trouble.

title: Focusing on Glam Rock's Blurring of Identity
description: ANYONE who watches ''Velvet Goldmine,'' Todd Haynes's extravagant, silver-spangled, $7 million valentine to glam rock, is bound to wonder if the filmmaker was himself once a glitter-crazed teen-age rebel who hennaed his hair, experimented with cross-dressing, and pranced around in six-inch platform shoes. The answer is no.

title: The Patron Saint Of Paradox
description: When she died, a multitude came down to the old dwelling off the Bowery to pay their respects, the way people had come to Catholic Worker houses for soup ever since the Depression. There were Catholic Workers, social workers, migrant workers, the unemployed; addicts, alcoholics, anarchists; Protestants, Jews and agnostics; the devout and the strident and the curious, there to see what a saint looked like.

title: IAN McKELLEN; Not a Sexual Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINCOLN, ASHE Q.C.
description: LINCOLN-Ashe Q.C. The officers and staff of Plaza Memorial Chapel extend sincere condolences to Rabbi David Lincoln on the loss of his beloved father. May his memory be for a blessing. Andrew Fier, Pres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHORE, MIMI
description: SHORE-Mimi. Of New York City, died October 24, 1998. She is survived by a sister, niece, two great nieces and many friends. Contributions may be made to Hospice.

title: Vassar Miller, 74, Texas Poet; Her Infirmity Inspired Her Art
description: Vassar Miller, whose lifelong struggle with cerebral palsy made the simplest tasks arduous yet who wrote 10 volumes of searing and highly regarded poetry, died on Oct. 31 at Houston Methodist Hospital. She was 74.

title: The Flutie Factor Is 6 Feet High
description: Yes, Doug Flutie eats Flutie Flakes.

title: The Revolution? Here, It Looks an Awful Lot Like Civil War.
description: GREENWICH played a significant role during the American Revolution. Adjacent to British-controlled Westchester County and less than an hour's sail from Long Island, also in British hands, the town was in a vulnerable position, subject to frequent raids and incursions designed to rob and demoralize the population.

title: Corrections
description: A short article on page 38 of the Arts and Leisure section today listing Broadway musicals with strong dance components omits the long-running show ''Chicago,'' which was choreographed by Ann Reinking in the style of Bob Fosse.

title: Newark's Toxic Tomb; Six Acres Fouled by Dioxin, Agent Orange's Deadly Byproduct, Reside in the Shadow of an Awakening Downtown
description: THE crook in the Passaic River affords a view of downtown Newark to the left and lower Manhattan to the right. All around, the life of the city's Ironbound section proceeds for the 40,000 or so residents and thousands more workers on its industrial rim. Everyone agrees that this makes an especially poor site for storing hazardous waste.

title: A Winning Team (And Not Basketball)
description: THOUGH the college basketball season is still weeks away, sports sections in the state's newspapers have already been filled with articles about the University of Connecticut men's and women's basketball teams which are expected to be among the best in the country. Indeed, the men's team is likely to be a favorite, with Duke, to win the national championship, while the women's team is said to have the most talented group of freshmen players ever to enroll at Storrs.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report in the Diary column of the Investing page last Sunday about the performance of small-capitalization stocks misstated the actions taken in October by the Federal Reserve. The central bank reduced the discount rate once in the month and trimmed the Federal funds rate twice; it did not cut the discount rate more than once.

title: A World of Celebration; New York City: Kwanzaa
description: Kwanzaa means ''first fruits of the harvest'' in Swahili. From Dec. 26 through New Year's Day, up to 18 million African-Americans will celebrate the richness of their African heritage by observing the holiday of Kwanzaa.

title: Anne Gorfinkle, J. D. Merriman 4th
description: Anne Ilene Gorfinkle, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert J. Gorfinkle of Hingham, Mass., was married last evening to James Douglas Merriman 4th, a son of Prof. Mira Pajes Merriman of Wichita, Kan., and the late Prof. Merriman 3d. The Rev. Kenneth H. Read-Brown performed the ceremony at the Old Ship Unitarian Universalist Church in Hingham.

title: November 1-7; Come Back, Jerry
description: At NBC the days of ''Must-See TV'' may be turning into ''Must See What Else Is on TV.'' The dominant network of the 1990's is seeing big declines especially among younger men: no N.F.L., too many shows on single female media executives and the departure of Jerry Seinfeld. BILL CARTER

title: Midterm Elections: A Vote for Moderation?; End of Monopoly
description: To the Editor:

title: Plantings Old and New Are Still Thirsty
description: Rainfall is below normal, but roots are still taking up water. So established gardens, new plantings and container gardens should be given sufficient water as they head into winter.

title: Good Fortune Comes in Threes
description: When Georgetown University named its business school after Robert Emmett McDonough last month, it was not the first time a McDonough was so honored. Both Georgetown's gymnasium and a main building at its law school are named after McDonoughs, the first a Jesuit priest and the other an industrialist.

title: Editorial Observer; New York: On the Politics of Getting Out While the Getting Is Good
description: It was one of the standing jokes of New York politics that Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan had written more books than Senator Alfonse D'Amato had read. But all the royalties from all those books would not equal the amount of money Mr. D'Amato could raise in one phone call. You have talents, and then you have talents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNEAD, H. SCOTT
description: SNEAD-H. Scott. On November 4, 1998. Beloved father of Katherine, loving brother of Virginia. Retired director of pension funds and investments for Johnson & Johnson. Service November 13, 11 AM, Trinity Episcopal Church, Southport, CT. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to St. Andrew's School, 350 Noxon Town Rd., Middletown, DE 19709 or St. Vincent's Medical Center Foundation, 2800 Main St., Bridgeport, CT 06606.

title: Voting In Co-op Elections
description: A FACT of co-op life is that a board of directors is responsible for the sometimes complicated business of running the building. Co-op bylaws guarantee that the board must be elected by the shareholders -- but provide no guarantee that the election process will be easy.

title: Getting a Kick Out of the Arts
description: When Cyndie Bellen-Berthezene moved to New York from Philadelphia a few years ago with her husband and daughter, she decided to start a business. But what to do?

title: A Trainer Works His Magic Again
description: Regardless of the odds it is not wise to dismiss any horse trained by Michael Dickinson.

title: The Novel Is Alive, On the Stage, Anyway
description: SUITCASES pour forth steam to suggest a train station, even as later in the evening actors attired as peasants become the train that bears down upon -- and kills -- the title character, Anna Karenina. Two high-stepping women form a carriage, while rows of bentwood chairs function as seats as well as weapons of sorts, debris and, at one point, items of clothing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEFFER, LOUIS
description: SCHAEFFER-Louis. Beloved husband of Ella. Devoted father of Alice Nadelman & Nancy Braman. Cherished grandfather of Rachel, Joel, Jonathan and Daniel. Dear brother of Bill, Jack, Ray, Nettie, Sara, Rosie and Norma, and the late Julie, Harry, Al, Joey, Sophie, Ettie and Lilly. Services today 10:45 AM ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

description: 'Poets and Artists'

title: It's How You Run, Not How You Look
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Assignment in Southeast Asia
description: JANE HAMILTON-MERRITT said she knew that when she went to Asia as a journalist and photographer during the war in Vietnam that the experience was likely to be profound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, IRIS K
description: JONES-Iris K Of Heritage Village, Southbury, CT. Wife of Wolcott B. (Bud) Jones. She is survived by a son, Jeffrey M. Jones and his wife Susan, a daughter Amy M. Jones and a sister Margaret Ness. Funeral services will be held in Connecticut.

title: Portuguese Provincial, With Signs in Chinese
description: For a peninsula measuring only nine square miles, little Macao has had multiple personalities. This ''city of indulgence,'' as W. H. Auden called it, has been, variously, the Western gateway to China, the busy nexus of international trade in the 17th century, the center of education for the Jesuits' Far Eastern missions, a sleepy summer retreat for 19th-century Hong Kong tycoons and, lately, a rather louche spot best known for triad wars and gambling.

title: BENEFITS
description: A Movie Premiere

title: November 1-7; Few Get Fewer
description: A quarter century after the draft ended, the armed services are getting too few good men and women. In the fiscal year just ended, the Army and Navy fell short of recruitment goals. With the economy producing opportunities and more youngsters than ever going to college, the Pentagon plans to spend more on recruiters, bonuses and ads. STEVEN LEE MYERS

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: THE HIGHER JAZZ

title: Side Dish Now a Centerpiece
description: Cabbage, the mainstay of coleslaw and borscht, isn't known as fancy party fare but lately it's been turning up on elegant tables. Floral designers and party decorators around the city have been incorporating ornamental cabbage in bouquets and arrangements to freshen up the usual posies.

title: Armor, Wooden Horses At Tower of London
description: The White Tower, the part of the Tower of London complex containing the Royal Armories' collection of armor and armaments of Britain's kings and queens, will reopen Friday following a three-year renovation. For the first time in 30 years, the White Tower will now be devoted exclusively to the display of the collection historically connected to the tower.

title: Political Memo; Moynihan and D'Amato Put Their Differences to Work
description: One is a towering Democrat with a mane of white hair, the other a medium-built Republican with a bald pate. One speaks in the pinched cadences and flowery language of the university, the other in the earthy phrases and nasal tones of Long Island subdivisions. One spends his spare moments writing books and giving lectures, the other raising campaign cash and playing cards.

title: Elizabeth Morrone, Frederick Ferront
description: Elizabeth Jean Morrone, the daughter of Jean and Peter Morrone of Huntington, N.Y., was married yesterday to J. Frederick Ferront, a son of Genevieve Huertas of Nice, France, and Jocelyn Ferront of Toulouse, France.

title: Caroline Ranald and John Curvan
description: Caroline Margaret Ranald and John Thomas Curvan are to be married this afternoon by Msgr. Thomas P. Leonard at Holy Trinity Church in Manhattan.

title: Holiday Vigil For Fedex Customers
description: IF the pilots at Federal Express carry out their threat to strike during the holiday shipping season, it won't be just traditional mail-order houses that are grounded.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Before He Was Elvis
description: Two months after Elvis Presley released his first album in March 1956, a photographer for Seventeen magazine named Marvin Israel caught him on tour at the University of Dayton. ELVIS PRESLEY 1956 (Abrams, $17.95), a gritty compilation of dozens of previously unpublished black-and-white photos, was the result. Seventeen probably passed because the photos of the rising teen idol were too raw: the black-rimmed, raccoon-like eyes, the pitted skin and the electric current that seemed to ripple through Presley's spine. We also see his natural charm: a picture of a smiling Elvis, en pointe, knees splayed, cradling his leather-embossed guitar; a gauzy picture of his Pharaonic features that makes him look like a god from ancient Memphis. Portraits of the fans capture an era: girls in their Junior League best with polka-dot bows, and their gape-mouthed, sullen dates; a leather-jacketed Natalie Wood look-alike scowls in front of a 30-foot-tall cutout of Presley at the premiere of ''Love Me Tender,'' his first film, at the Paramount in Times Square. Israel, who went on to become one of the most influential photo editors of the 1960's, commissioning work by Diane Arbus, Robert Frank and Lee Friedlander, had an intimate access to Presley before he became a superstar that comes across in the photos. The text is perfunctory (''in 1956 Elvis was a rocket'') and identifying captions would help, but the images speak for themselves. Eric P. Nash

title: Penn Drops Princeton To Remain At the Top
description: Penn buried Princeton with 21 points five minutes into the game today and watched as the Tigers struggled to dig their way out. The Tigers couldn't do it, so Penn, which entered the game tied with Princeton and Harvard for first place in the Ivy League, walked away with a 27-14 victory before a crowd of 20,230 at Princeton Stadium.

description: To the Editor:

title: Facing Oblivion, Rust-Belt Giants Top Russian List Of Vexing Crises
description: Ten years ago, when economic reform began its uneven march through Russia's industrial heartland, the most visible landmark in this steel town was a deadly multicolored plume that hung over the vast Magnitogorsk Metal Works.

title: Peacemakers Converge on Campus to Reverse Apathy
description: That wispy but stubborn ideal ''world peace'' attempted a comeback here on the cold asphalt outside a college football stadium.

title: Minority Journalists Settle a Quiet but Fractious Debate
description: A coalition of minority journalists' groups has ended one of the most fractious, if least visible, civil rights debates of the year, agreeing to keep its convention in Seattle despite Washington State's vote against affirmative action.

description: In the 1970's I used to run into Edwin Denby during intermissions of the New York City Ballet at Lincoln Center. I was reminded of him and everything he stood for in New York cultural life by ''Dance Writings & Poetry,'' a new selection of his work edited by Robert Cornfield and published in both hardcover and paperback by Yale University Press.

title: Rising Russian Imports Fuel Dispute With U.S. Steel Makers
description: A new cold war has broken out between Russia and the United States, this time over hot-rolled steel.

description: Long Island

title: Music Producer Takes Time to Stage Benefit
description: AT the National Mentoring Partnership benefit concert in Madison Square Garden recently, many performers, including Aretha Franklin, Natalie Cole, Boyz II Men and Barry Manilow, donated their services and shared the stage to help raise $1.8 million for mentoring programs across the United States.

title: INVESTING: QUOTABLE
description: ''What fund does Peter Lynch run? Peter Lynch does not manage a fund and does not set policy at Fidelity. He speaks as an informed individual. Peter does not represent the Fidelity viewpoint.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALSOP, MCLALLEN
description: ALSOP-McLallen. On October 29, 1998. Son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Wilson E. Alsop. Devoted husband of Carolyn. Beloved father of Kirstin, Ian, and Galen, and loving brother of Suzanne Mugler. Contributions in his memory may be made to Trinity Presbyterian Church, Fairhope, AL. 36532.

title: Whose Lifetime?

title: Ode to a Violin And the Man Who Made It
description: When burglars broke into Jacqui Carrasco's Park Slope apartment three weeks ago, they took the predictable loot: fax machine, camera, laptop. But what upset her most was that they also swiped her violin, which was no ordinary instrument.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, ANNE B.
description: GOULD-Anne B. Beloved sister of Shirley Kalusin and Lucille Allen and Auntie Anne to all of her nieces and nephews. World War II Navy Lieutenant, astute businesswoman, respected by all. Graveside service on November 8 at Riverside Cemetery, Lodi, N.J.

title: Fassel Poses Questions To Himself and Giants
description: Jim Fassel knows what they are saying about him as his unraveling Giants lurch into the second half of their season.

description: An article last Sunday about congressional races misstated the town where Representative Steven R. Rothman used to be mayor. It was Englewood, not Fair Lawn.

title: Etched in Stone, Words From Great War's Dead
description: Georges Lievin, 57, was not even alive when World War I, the Great War, ended 80 years ago this month, but he, too, became its victim.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLENBERG, ARDEN C.
description: ELLENBERG-Arden C. Beloved daughter, sister and aunt. Private services.

description: HARDCOVER

title: Air Force Holds Off Army
description: When Army crept to within 7 points today, Air Force's Dylan Newman sprinted by the Cadets' confused defensive backs and cradled in a 74-yard touchdown pass.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation; Working Out With a One-Armed Bandit
description: AMID the hundreds of exhibits at the recent World Gaming Congress and Exposition, no new products better summed up gambling's place in the American psyche than the ''Pedal 'N Play'' cycle and the ''Money Mill'' treadmill.

title: A Low-Key Rebel at the Whitney
description: TO understand Maxwell L. Anderson, the new director of the Whitney Museum of American Art, you need to know something about the rarefied world of Manhattan private schools. ''I went to Collegiate up through eighth grade,'' he said the other day, ''and had the usual concatenation of classmates who were affluent East Siders, like Edgar Bronfman Jr. and Henry Grunwald's son, Peter, and all the other power brokers' kids. And that was exciting. But I felt constrained. I was rambunctious. I was a rebel.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Away From His Desk? Sure.
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Spot for Italian Dishes in Pelham
description: DESIGNATED Wolfs Lane, the southern end of this village's main street has long seemed more a service route than a meeting-greeting-eating one. The Pelham Picture House, a gem from way back, beckons in the evening, but there have been scant choices for lunch or late-night dining, because gas stations and hardware stores have predominated. Now La Fontanella joins what appears to be a downtown renewal: coffeehouses, antiques shops and other restaurants have made this corridor a lively destination.

title: A Reason to Run
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Software That Can Make A Grown Company Cry
description: CORPORATE root canal.

title: Amy Dzija, Timothy Driscoll
description: Amy Dzija, a daughter of Marcia and Alan T. Dzija of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Timothy Sean Driscoll, a son of Janice and Timothy J. Driscoll of East Meadow, N.Y. The Rev. Robert P. Longobucco performed the ceremony at St. Raphael's Roman Catholic Church in East Meadow.

title: On the Doctor Shows, Public Health Enemy No. 1
description: YOU know who I want to meet?'' the good doctor asks. ''The sick, twisted little bean counter who came up with the health maintenance organization.'' As a prickly but secretly noble physician who spouts outrageous truths, Ted Danson's John Becker is no more believable than the saintly Marcus Welby was. But here, in a promotional spot for the new CBS sitcom ''Becker,'' he sounds oddly realistic, echoing opinions heard more and more often, on and off television. Under the heading ''Becker on H.M.O.'s,'' the harangue continues: ''You go in with a headache; they do a credit scan before a CAT scan. Need surgery? They biopsy your wallet. H.M.O.'s, you know what H.M.O.'s stand for? Have money or die.''

title: Q&A/Dr. Martha P. Nochimson; The Soaps: First You Cry, Then You Write
description: IT was by accident that Dr. Martha P. Nochimson became a fan of soap operas. She was home taking care of her young children in the late 1960's, writing a dissertation, and needed a distraction.

title: Backtalk; Female Harassment Is Still Widespread in Sports
description: In a recent television advertisement, a young girl rebukes the Women's National Basketball Association star Cynthia Cooper for executing plays that the girl finds less than cutting edge. She has her own plays worked up, and offers them so that Cooper can dazzle the competition next time with magical execution and breathtaking technique.

title: Coming to a Hotel Near You: Golden Door
description: Forty years ago, the Golden Door Spa started toning the bodies of affluent women in Southern California and went on to become a top name in luxury health and fitness. Now, the spa is doing the stretching. It was recently acquired by Grand Bay Hotels and Resorts -- operated by Patriot American Hospitality -- which plans to open a Golden Door Spa for both men and women in each of its resorts and hotels. It starts with Las Casitas Village in Puerto Rico on Dec. 1.

title: Bizball
description: As the director of athletics at Haverford College, I encourage Varadarajan to stop eating his heart out on subway platforms and instead take the train to Philadelphia, where cricket is appreciated. Haverford College has had a varsity cricket team for 134 years, and our teams have defeated the best Oxford and Cambridge teams on visits to England.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NORWICK, DOUGLAS J.
description: NORWICK-Douglas J. Your star shines brightly and your spirit dances on. Always love. Herbert J. Baker

title: Boeing's Man in the Line of Fire
description: LAST year, after airplane production at the Boeing Company became so fouled up that the aerospace giant was forced to halt assembly of its 747 and 737 jets for several weeks, the company's top executives began holding monthly teleconferences for reporters and Wall Street analysts.

title: A Regional Effort
description: Yonkers and Mount Vernon, with support from the county, have forged an alliance to obtain $100 million in Federal funds for economic development. Mayor John D. Spencer of Yonkers and Mayor Ernest D. Davis of Mount Vernon joined County Executive Andrew J. Spano at City Hall in Yonkers on Oct. 27 in announcing an application to be designated as an Empowerment Zone.

title: Sports of The Times; Racing's Splendid and Bizarre Day
description: IN the crazy moments following a great day of racing, the jockey room at Churchill Downs was a frenzied intersection of jockeys -- jockeys coming, jockeys packing gear and leaving, jockeys talking about what should have been, buzzing about the recently completed Breeders' Cup Classic.

title: A Skyline of Souvenir-Shop Keepsakes
description: DAVID WEINGARTEN, a principal at Ace Architects, says there's a professional reason his firm owns more than 3,400 miniature buildings. He recalls, for example, that looking at hundreds of tiny bank buildings helped him design a bank. But he's quick to add that the buildings are also a lot of fun. More than 140 of the firm's finest New York keepsakes, many of them gift-shop souvenirs, go on display Saturday at the Museum of the City of New York. The show contains objects dating from 1810, including structures from each borough, some of which no longer stand and others that were never built. At left are three buildings in the show, the Empire State Building, Gotham Bank (which was on Broadway at 59th Street) and the Chrysler Building.

title: Novels Had the Idea
description: To the Editor:

title: Bright Hopes for Florida Republicans
description: Helen Cluett remembers the indignities.

title: Top Executives Bilked Camden Hospital of Millions
description: Cooper Hospital-University Medical Center in Camden was bilked out of as much as $21.8 million over seven years by a group of employees including two high-level executives, according to a report made public by the hospital last week.

title: Lives; House of Dreams
description: Yes, I should have known better than to go home again. But hounded by curiosity, I set out on a damp and clingy June morning to revisit the farmhouse in upstate New York where I grew up.

title: FORT MAILBOX
description: In Fayette County, Ga. (south of Atlanta), ''fortress'' mailboxes made of brick and concrete are a common accent to grandiose homes. They're also illegal -- hitting one in a car is like hitting a brick wall -- but a county ordinance banning them is unenforceable. Lately, pro-banning forces have started demanding action, partly because of lawsuits that grew out of the 1996 death of a 17-year-old who was riding in a car that struck a fortress mailbox. As county commissioners weigh the matter, pro-mailbox people are being heard, too. ''Maybe none of us can really appreciate having a leviathan mailbox until we lose it,'' a resident recently wrote in The Atlanta Constitution. ''Maybe it's time we all cried, 'Give me vanity or give me death!'''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORRIERO, ROBERT
description: TORRIERO-Robert on October 30, 1998 in Stuart, Florida. Beloved husband of Lily Munford, loving father of Dolores (Lori) and John. Dear grandfather of Steven. A memorial service will be held at 2 P.M., on November 14th, at The Unitarian Church of All Souls in Manhattan.

title: Depressing Displays
description: From its perch over the Hop Won Express restaurant on Sixth Avenue in New York City, between 42d and 43d Streets, the National Debt Clock has been bumming out pedestrians since 1986. It is a computerized billboard, consisting of 305 light bulbs, that keeps track of America's outstanding loans, adding an average of nearly $10,000 a second to a number that has topped $5 trillion.

title: Sports of The Times; For the Love of What? (It Can't Be the Game!)
description: SHORTLY before noon on Friday, a visitor to Yankee Stadium did a double-take. Walking through the press gate in a Detroit Tigers' uniform, his spikes clacking on the sidewalk, was a familiar face. Kevin Costner.

title: For a Day, Russians Are United In Nostalgia
description: In the sea of red banners and angry faces that flowed through an overcast Moscow today to mark what used to be the premier feast of Soviet Communism, Revolution Day, one of the few slogans with a constructive bent was the old chestnut from 1917: ''All Power to the Soviets.''

title: November 1-7; Moving Fast on Terror
description: The United States Government has charged the Saudi exile Osama bin Laden in the bombings of two American embassies in Africa and with conspiring to commit other terrorist acts against Americans abroad. The Government is offering $5 million each for information leading to the arrest and conviction of Mr. bin Laden and his associate, Muhammad Atef. But it is uncertain whether either man will ever stand trial here. BENJAMIN WEISER

title: Going Down Screaming
description: This is almost too funny! Now that the issue of the day does not surround a Clarence Thomas or Bob Packwood, now that the issue is this liberal President, now you come up with the silly concept of ''the Scolds'' and get Andrew Sullivan to write it for you. I say the premise seems phony because for the last 40 years I have been unable to turn around without being hectored by pious scolds from the sanctimonious left: don't smoke, don't litter, don't own guns, use condoms, save whales, conserve wetlands, protect moms, help moms protect abortion, conserve energy, wear ribbons (pink, yellow, red -- I lose track). All in the name of public policy, foisted on us at a private level, or private behavior, dragged into the arena of public policy, to be shamed, promoted or ridiculed -- by scolding.

title: Still Battling an Illness, Jarrett Ends His Silence
description: TWO years ago, Keith Jarrett found himself, as he put it, ''completely drained of energy'' midway through a concert tour of Italy. It wasn't one of the short-lived spells of exhaustion with which touring musicians are often afflicted, but something far more drastic. ''I don't know what fuel I was using to do those concerts,'' he recalled, ''but I felt as if aliens had entered my body, and that perhaps it would be the last time I'd be able to play. At the last concert, I actually played a dirge -- for myself.''

title: Midterm Elections: A Vote for Moderation?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bizball
description: If it is true that ''sports is no game'' but is rather ''a hot, global entertainment product,'' as your cover suggests, then why should anyone root for a team in the first place? Why should the accomplishments of professional athletes be a source of pride? Who are they to us?

title: Richest Race Won By Awesome Again
description: Awesome Again won the $5.2 million Breeders' Cup Classic at Churchill Downs, beating Silver Charm by three-quarters of a length in a wild finish. Skip Away, the favorite for Horse of the Year, faded to sixth in the last race of his career and missed out on his chance to set a record for career earnings. SportsSunday

title: Karen Lin and Edwin Su
description: Dr. Karen Kerlon Lin, the daughter of Dr. Joanne Lin and Dr. Chen-jung Lin of Houston, was married last evening to Dr. Edwin Philip Su, a son of Dr. Wen-Huey Su and Dr. Philip Su of Huntington, N.Y. The Rev. Steven Fogel officiated at the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, N.Y.

title: Modernizing British Law: Suits of Armor Now Allowed
description: BRITAIN may have passed for the moment on joining Europe's new currency, the Euro, but this doesn't mean Brits are immune to the winds of change. Even the Royal Family will feel the bite of progress this month when the monarchy loses its centuries-old right to all whale carcasses found on England's beaches.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LETO, ANDRE
description: LETO-Andre. 59. Of Fort Lauderdale, FL. Died November 2, 1998 at home. Son of the late John J. and Helen Leto of Port Washington, NY. After a courageous battle with acute leukemia. A former resident of Manhattan and Vice President of Prudential Bache Securities. Mr. Leto was an alumni of New York University. He leaves a brother and sister-in-law, John and Mary Lee Leto of Manhasset and his devoted companion of 36 years, Richard Eskilson.

title: On Piping Out Caspian Oil, U.S. Insists the Cheaper, Shorter Way Isn't Better
description: Soon after dawn each day, the promenade that runs along the shore of the Caspian Sea here fills with Americans and other expatriates out for a morning run.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NASH, LILI
description: NASH-Lili. Died peacefully October 17 in Naperville, IL. She was the loving mother of a son, Thomas Nash, and daughter-in-law, Madeleine Nash, of Warrenville, IL, and wife of the late Edward Nash. A longtime resident of New York City, she was an art historian specializing in old masters. She was born in Kassa, Hungary, August 12, 1908. Memorial service, December 19, 10:30 AM, Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. For information please call 630-355-0213.

title: An Imagist With a Camera in Hand
description: WHEN Christopher Doyle shows up to shoot a film, the director had better not expect ''coverage,'' the standard Hollywood practice of capturing the action from every possible angle. '' 'Coverage' is a horrible word,'' said Mr. Doyle late one recent Saturday night. ''It means you're not sure what you want.''

title: No More Rotten Odors, Sewage Protesters Say
description: ON a recent Sunday when fall was in the air, about 150 residents of Seaford and Wantagh put on surgical masks and hoisted protest signs, mobilizing against something else that they say is often in the air: odors from a local sewage treatment plant.

title: A Talk Show for an Indelicate Age
description: AN exchange many viewers probably never expected to hear from the likes of Meredith Vieira and Barbara Walters occurred the other day on network television.

title: Choices for a Sunday Afternoon
description: CHORAL programs, chamber recitals, orchestral concerts can all be heard at 3 P.M. today.

title: 'SoHo, TriBeCa And Now Dumbo'
description: To the Editor:

title: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; Revenge of the Insured
description: MANY people have at least two jobs. One is doing whatever they do all day; the other is fighting their insurance companies.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LICHTER, JESSE S.
description: LICHTER-Jesse S. July 12, 1909-November 8, 1994 Remembered with love.

title: POSTINGS: New Rental Project in Bergen County; 214 Apartments In Westwood
description: A large, empty dry-cleaning store along Old Hook Road in Westwood, N.J., has been bulldozed to make way for a $27 million apartment community, ending a 10-year drought in rental construction in the Bergen County suburb.

title: Hot Stones, Tamales And a Little Zen
description: IT looked like a typical dinner party -- 12 guests seated around a table set with linen and cut glass, but there was a difference: No one uttered a word. The only sounds were the tinkling of silverware, the clink of teeth against glass and some nervous throat-clearing. A tight-lipped waiter served tamales, but when a woman held up a flashcard with the word ''pasta'' on it, he left the room, returning with a plate of fusilli in tomato sauce.

title: Holt's Star Began to Rise When Pappas's Starr Fell
description: So Rush Holt won in the 12th Congressional district after all, and now passes from being the third-place primary loser two years ago to a man with an amazing number of brand-new best friends, grinning and slapping him on his back and offering free advice. It is the kind of transformation that only show biz and politics can perform, and Mr. Holt did it with a little luck, and a lot of money and a lot of work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCFADDEN, RUTH NEILSON
description: McFADDEN-Ruth Neilson. Wife of the late Louis E. Died peacefully at home on November 5th at age 81. Formerly of NYC, Peekskill, NY and New Canaan, CT. Survived by her six children, Josephine N., Barbara M. Sirna of NYC, Katherine M. Whitmore of Belfast, ME, Neil A. of Oak Park, IL, Lucy-Ann A. of Bethesda, MD, and John A. of Wynantskill, NY; her sister, Brita N. Blauvelt of Hightstown, NJ, and brother, John E. Neilson of Lompoc, CA; and 10 grandchildren. Graham Funeral Home, Rye, NY, 914-967-0129.

title: Artist's Odd Endurance Tests; American Revolution in Clothes
description: THE heavy gray facade of the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford gives no clue to the kind of adventurous art that the museum has often embraced. Surrealism was given its first major exhibition in the United States at the Atheneum, and more recently the museum has presented Conceptual Art of a particularly difficult sort, that which doesn't always have a physical embodiment.

title: A Long Journey
description: For three-quarters of this century, the length of skirts dominated fashion news -- until skirts met their match: women's trousers. Now, on the threshold of the millennium, the newest look is the revival of the full belle-epoque skirt and the pencil-slim Edwardian skirt, both floor-length and worn in the day. The difference now is the way they are worn, with sportswear jackets or sweaters on top of pleated skirts, or pants underneath skirts of printed chiffon. The look -- a favorite of young women attending the spring fashion shows in New York last week -- captures the nostalgic longing of a new generation and marries the polar ends of a century of fashion.

title: For the Republicans, Mitch Berkey
description: 6/3/98 -- The day after our primary victory. We receive numerous phone calls from friends, relatives and neighbors offering congratulations, good wishes and help in the campaign. For me and my running mates, Mark Fusari and Armond Forcella, the real work has just begun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ANDREW LEE
description: SCHWARTZ-Andrew Lee. On November 7, 1998, of Mahnattan. Beloved husband of Tina. Devoted father of Daisy. Adored brother of Richard and Karin. Cherished son of Eleanor and Martin Leff. Service to be announced. Please call Riverside, 76th and Amsterdam.

title: PERSONAL BUSINESS; Prices That Don't Fit The Profile
description: LOW inflation, a driving force behind the nation's economic boom, is having the perverse effect of making life harder for millions of elderly Americans.

title: Sinatra 101: Scholarly Treatment for a Star
description: THE first subject was George Sand. That was in 1976.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Acura 3.2TL; The Luxuries Add Up, Except on the Sticker
description: HONDA -- more to the point, Acura, Honda's luxury-sport division -- has a problem. While the company's smaller cars, everything from the Honda Civic and Accord to the Acura Integra and NSX, are class beaters, its offerings in the hot ''entry level'' luxury market have been greeted with yawns. The now-forgotten Vigor struck few customers as superior to the less expensive Accord. And the 2.5TL that replaced the Vigor proved to be an overpriced, underpowered bore.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: THE BOOK OF JOB Translation, introduction and notes by Raymond P. Scheindlin. Norton, $23.95.

title: 'Tis a Gift
description: Requests for donations are hardly unusual at a house of worship. But next weekend, the appeal from the pulpit in church, mosque or synagogue may be surprising: congregants will be asked to donate tissues and organs. Nov. 13 to 15 is National Donor Sabbath weekend. The New Jersey Organ and Tissue Sharing Network, which organizes donations and transplants in the state, has asked the clergy to speak about the need for donation.

title: A Wave of Post-Election Exuberance
description: Results of the Congressional elections, which have led pundits to presume that the nation will not get bogged down in a protracted impeachment inquiry, seemed to buoy the stock market. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has not used his irrational exuberance phrase in a long time. He may have to dust it off again soon.

title: Keeping Up With Appetites
description: David Chan has a blunt explanation for what has been happening to the restaurants along Seventh Avenue. ''You have to get updated,'' said Mr. Chan, who is the manager of Zen East, a new sushi bar and vegetarian restaurant just north of Berkeley Place. ''If you don't get updated you get kicked out of the game.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: A MASTERPIECE OF REVENGE By J. J. Fiechter. Arcade, $21.95.

title: Word for Word/The History Books; The Content of Jefferson's Character Is Revealed at Last, Or Is It?
description: AS voters reaffirmed democracy last week, a report was released that seemed like lab results on a 200-year-old paternity suit against one of the Founding Fathers. DNA tests matched descendants of Thomas Jefferson with those of his beautiful slave, Sally Hemings. This turned Jefferson scholarship on its ear; from the 19th century on, most historians insisted that a man of Jefferson's character could not have had a sexual relationship with Hemings.

title: BEST SELLERS: November 8, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Failings of Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILL, ROBERT E.
description: HILL-Robert E. Of Rumson, NJ on November 6, 1998. Aged 83 years. Beloved husband of Carolyn Anderson Hill; father of James of Arlington, MA and Robert Jr. of Hamburg, NY; grandfather of eight. Mr. Hill retired in 1982 after 50 years of service as VP of Trust Department for United States Trust Co. of NY. For more information call John E. Day Funeral Home, Red Bank, NJ, 888-747-0332

title: Ms. Keating, Mr. Buchenholz
description: Tara Maureen Keating and Christopher David Buchenholz were married yesterday by the Rev. Clarke K. Oler at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in New York.

title: The Unlikely Liveliness of a Yellowstone Winter
description: Max Morgan rotated his head like a compass needle and thrust his jaw into the wind.

title: Social Security's Higher Ceiling
description: The bar keeps rising. The amount of wages subject to Social Security taxes will jump to $72,600 next year from $68,400 this year, an increase of 6.1 percent. That means the maximum tax withheld from a worker's paychecks will rise by $260.40, to $4,501.20, according to CCH Inc., a publisher of tax and pension information.

title: November 1-7; Russia in Deep Debt
description: After months of hedging, Russia acknowledged that it will default on its foreign debt next year and seek to renegotiate the loans. Its coalition Government put the blame on a collapsing currency. But the looming default also reflects Prime Minister Yevgeni Primakov's failure to put together an economic plan that would advance market reforms -- and win funds from the International Monetary Fund. Russia will also get 1.5 million tons of wheat and $600 million from the United States to buy more American-grown food next month, the United States Agriculture Department said. Russia's food stocks, its Government says, have fallen sixfold, to two or three weeks' reserve. MICHAEL R. GORDON

title: Aid Trickling From the Sky To the Isolated In Honduras
description: The helicopter descended on this village in southern Honduras like some giant insect of the Apocalypse, ratcheting the air and sending a whirlwind across the muddy soccer field where it alighted.

title: Ms. Mautner, Mr. Garlinghouse
description: Kristen Elizabeth Mautner, a daughter of Barbara H. Mautner of Ossining, N.Y., and Hans C. Mautner of New York, was married last evening to Bradley Kent Garlinghouse Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Garlinghouse of Topeka, Kan. The Rev. Janet B. Kraft performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Deejays Make The World Go Round
description: WHEN Tommy Hilfiger gave a birthday party for his brother and business associate, Andy, he filled a rented penthouse studio overlooking the Hudson River with a well-buffed, ultrastylish crowd that seemed to have stepped from a Hilfiger bus advertisement.

title: Voters Return Incumbents To Albany
description: THE Westchester electorate generally did what voters statewide did on Tuesday: they voted for incumbents, except for Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and State Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco.

title: In Poland, Invisible Others
description: Perhaps we are unduly nervous. (I'd even had a small anxiety attack, waiting for my connection at O'Hare.) The problem is not the Poland we've come to, but the Poland my brother, Steven, and I have brought with us, the one we carry with us as Jews. Inherited from our grandparents, this Poland is a dark gravescape, a terrifying labyrinth of memory, filled with pogroms and blood libels.

title: Chicago
description: Michael Jordan and the Chicago Bulls aren't playing basketball, at least not during the National Basketball Association's labor strife, and Oprah Winfrey is on screens around the country in her ''Beloved.'' But back home their neighborhood is alive with a new restaurant row.

title: Q. & A.
description: The Rights To a Roof Terrace

title: For Herbs, Windowsills In Winter
description: HERBS have become so much a part of food preparation these days that many cooks like to keep the plants indoors over the winter months. Although fresh herbs can now be found in many markets, there is no harm in trying the grow-it-yourself way.

title: A Portrait of New York State's Shifting Ballot Blocs
description: In defeating Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato by nine percentage points on Tuesday, Charles E. Schumer gathered the support of many traditional Democratic demographic groups, some of whom had deserted Democratic candidates in the previous two contests for this seat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLER, ABRAHAM
description: KELLER-Abraham. You will live in our hearts forever. Your loving children, Sheila, Allen and Merritt. Your grandchildren, Stacey, Mitchell and Robert. Your great grandchildren, Rebecca and Bradford. Shiva will be held at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Merritt Roher, 608 East Bay Drive, Long Beach, 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM.

title: On Broadway, a Lot of Dancing's Going On
description: Dance has rarely been seen in as many Broadway shows as it is now. In fact, a list of productions without dance would be quite short. Here's the long list. VALERIE GLADSTONE

title: Liberties; Lovers & Haters
description: There's a new spirit wafting through the land.

title: The First Syllable
description: KA

title: Early Mornings On Horseback
description: GALLOPING through the Sonoran desert, we were all horse hoofs and dust, stirring fragrant creosote and mesquite as we pulled up at the edge of a cool cottonwood grove in Coronado National Forest to admire the green Rincon Mountains in the distance.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: One Man's America:

title: Surprising Strength In Auto Sales Figures
description: October turned out to be one of the strongest months in the car industry's history, with big sales gains in the United States market for nearly every auto maker. Over all, consumers bought 1.37 million cars and light trucks last month, nearly 10 percent more than in October 1997; Chrysler's 20 percent sales increase led the league. But the biggest surprise may have been General Motors, which rebounded from summer strikes faster than analysts had expected, selling 6 percent more vehicles than in the same month last year. Why such strong sales? Analysts mentioned low interest rates and cheap gasoline as reasons.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article and a subheading on page 12 of the Arts and Leisure section today about Shared Experience, a British theater troupe, misidentifies Levin, a character in the play ''Anna Ka renina,'' based on Tolstoy's novel. Levin is a landowner, not the title character's lover.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, RUTH C.
description: MARKS-Ruth C. On November 6, 1998. Beloved wife of Alfred M. Marks. Dear mother of Erica (David) Panush and John (Sara) Marks. Adored grandmother of Zerlina and Lucy. Cherished sister of Sydney Croog, George Croog, Shirley Berger and Richard Croog. Graveside services today November 8, 1:45 PM, at Maimonides Cemetery, Elmont, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Ruth's name to Dances Patrelle, 126 Fourth Place, Brooklyn, NY 11231 or Project Ezra, 197 East Broadway, NYC 10002.

title: The Man Who Would Be Papp
description: It is the last hour before lunch, the longest of the rehearsal day. Thirty-three people are in the room, the entire cast of George C. Wolfe's revival of the Broadway musical ''On the Town,'' though from the way they're behaving you might think it was junior-high recess. As the actors in the scene keep muffing their lines, the ones watching jiggle in place and roll their eyes. Each touches the person next to him, for no reason at all. One pokes a stomach, another grasps a thigh. An actress hunches over a crossword puzzle, a dancer moans with hunger. ''My eyes are turning red,'' she exclaims, examining herself in the mirror. ''I'm getting that low-blood-sugar thing.''

title: Irish Stop Eagles Just Short of an Upset
description: Boston College had lost five straight games while yielding an average of 35.3 points, and it seemed likely that the Eagles would be overmatched today against Notre Dame.

title: Reclaiming A Rich History Of New Opera
description: WHEN ''Ravenshead,'' a new opera by Steven Mackey, is performed on Thursday evening at the Miller Theater of Columbia University, Jack Beeson, the avuncular 77-year-old composer and former Columbia professor, will be in attendance. Mr. Beeson's presence will meaningfully connect the university's new commitment to contemporary opera, which ''Ravenshead'' represents, to its important role in opera history more than four decades ago. This story has mostly been forgotten, though many of the operas generated at the time have secured places in the repertory.

title: Work on the Future of Pennsylvania Station Unearths a Bit of Its Past
description: Under a light drizzle on the morning of Oct. 28, 1963, demolition crews began dismantling the mighty pink Milford granite walls of Pennsylvania Station.

title: Bizball
description: In ''David Stern's Full-Court Press,'' Bruce Schoenfeld overestimates Stern's ''14 years of public-relations wizardry.'' The article treats the fact that both Stern and Michael Jordan came to the N.B.A. in 1984 as almost coincidental. But isn't it possible that it is Jordan (and his charisma and his marketing machine) who has made Stern a success, and not the other way around?

title: Ellen Kratzer, William Rose
description: Ellen Kratzer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roland H. Kratzer of Branford, Conn., was married yesterday to William Brian Rose, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald V. Rose of Cobourg, Ontario. The Rev. Andrew E. Fiddler performed the Episcopal ceremony at Trinity Church on the Green in New Haven.

title: Madison Square Park to Regain Its 19th-Century Luster
description: Drug dealers used to ply their trade openly there. And homeless people took up residence. But thanks to a police crackdown, those problems have abated.

title: Executive Cash Machine; How a Pliable System Inflates Pay Levels
description: BACK in 1993, Reuben Mark, chief executive of Colgate-Palmolive, received two million stock options in addition to his salary and bonus. Colgate's board explained that the huge grant was the only one Mr. Mark would receive until 1998.

title: A Tale of Daring American Submarine Espionage
description: One of America's most daring acts of piracy took shape late one night in 1970 as Capt. James F. Bradley Jr. of the Navy sat in his Pentagon office, meditating on how to achieve a nearly impossible goal.

title: Megan McKee, Jeremy Healey
description: Megan Marie McKee, the daughter of Judith M. Gharis of Sherman, Tex., and Timothy C. McKee of Bethesda, Md., was married in Washington yesterday to Thomas Jeremiah Healey 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Healey of New Vernon, N.J. The Rev. Joseph Healey, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Dahlgren Chapel of the Sacred Heart at Georgetown University.

title: Laura Klein, David Green
