description: Laura Ellen Klein and David Lawrence Green were married last evening at Temple Israel in West Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Howard Shapiro performed the ceremony.

title: Blame Yourself, Fans
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Our Towns; The Pleasures Of a Real-Life Pleasantville
description: EVER since they flocked to a preview of the movie that has the same name as their hometown, Pleasantville's citizens have been self-consciously comparing notes on what about their village is the same as the movie's darkly comic locale and what is different.

title: The Task of Turning Dodger Blue to Gold
description: In the statistical ranking that determines the level of draft-choice compensation for free agents, three teams each had 15 players emerge as Type A players. One, the Yankees, won the World Series. Another, the Cleveland Indians, lost to the Yankees in the American League Championship Series. The third was the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Horse Sense
description: Andrew Beyer has never owned a horse. He has never ridden a horse and has scarcely ever looked one in the eye. In fact, despite spending nearly every day at the racetrack, he almost never even sees horses anymore, except as images on a television monitor.

title: Back From Staten Island, With a Broader Character
description: Choosing a restaurant for a lunchtime interview with the creators of ''Exiled: A Law and Order Movie'' was a snap. Da Marino, on West 49th Street in Manhattan, makes a cameo appearance in this two-hour film, which has its premiere tonight at 9 on NBC. More significantly, it is the spot where the idea for the movie was born.

title: Visiting Bali
description: To the Editor: I read ''In Bali, $3 Goes a Long Way'' (Aug. 2) with interest, since my husband and I had a trip planned there a few weeks later. We live in Tokyo and were eager to get away from it all.

title: The Nation; Why Both Parties Wooed Black Voters This Year
description: WHAT a difference a decade makes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIS, LARRY
description: ELLIS-Larry. The New York Road Runners Club mourns the passing of our friend Larry Ellis, a pillar of the sport of track and field and long distance running. A runner of star quality, he used his talents to develop and coach generations of new runners and Olympic athletes. His administrative skills helped bring this sport to a new level. We and the entire running community will miss him greatly. Allan Steinfeld, President and CEO New York Road Runners Club

title: Winning Whites
description: Got chardonnay fatigue? Try rkatsiteli (pronounced er-kotz-uh-TEL-ee). Dr. Konstantin Frank's Vinifera Wine Cellars in the Finger Lakes region is the nation's premiere producer of this versatile white made from Russia's most most widely planted grape.

title: A Playwright Knows Whereof He Writes
description: IT is sad, it is stupefying, but it is so. Because theater subscribers have bought more tickets to a series of speakers than to the repertory of plays, some regional theaters and arts centers are actually doing away with theater and turning into just another stop on the lecture circuit.

title: On the Barricades
description: THE SIXTIES

title: Abortion Internet Site
description: A Westchester doctor who provides fertility and abortion services and a former police chief are listed on an Internet site that tracks doctors who perform abortions, along with their staffs, law enforcement authorities and others who have supported abortion. It is the same Internet site that listed Dr. Barnett A. Slepian of Buffalo and then crossed out his name when he was shot and killed.

title: Janet Smith and John Costello 3d
description: Janet Erlene Smith, a vice president of advertising sales at USA Today in Arlington, Va., and John H. Costello 3d, the senior executive vice president of Sears, Roebuck & Company in Hoffman Estates, Ill., were married on Oct. 17 in Charlottesville, Va. The Rev. John M. Richardson, a Disciples of Christ minister, officiated at Keswick Hall, a country manor hotel.

title: A Microphone on the Margins
description: ONE afternoon in 1988, when David Isay was 22 years old and just stumbling into a passion for radio, he paid an unannounced visit to the Manhattan office of his father, a psychoanalyst. There he encountered a man who seemed to be living in an anteroom of the professional suite. At first, Mr. Isay's father explained away the stranger as a patient. Then he told the truth: he was gay and the man was his lover.

title: Building Her Own Boat, In Tune With Tradition
description: EACH of us was going to build a kayak so attuned to its environment, so highly evolved, so sturdily elegant, that it could withstand 30-foot seas, hurricane winds and bashings from the claw of a hammer. In doing so, we would be joining an ancient tradition from the Aleutian Islands, the cold Alaskan chain where nothing grew beyond knee height, where no one had ever seen a living tree and where the boat makers thought the driftwood they used was a gift from the sea gods.

title: Dr. Szeming Sze, 90, U.N. Health Official
description: Szeming Sze, a former director of the United Nations Health Service who helped build the World Health Organization into a specialized United Nations agency, died on Oct. 27 at Presbyterian Senior Care, at Presbyterian Medical Center in suburban Pittsburgh. Dr. Sze was 90 and most recently lived in Hillsboro Beach, Fla.

title: At Play With Space and Its Ideal Proportions
description: ELIZABETH DILLER and Ricardo Scofidio, the New York architects, once took issue with the conventional wisdom that mass tourism, with its comfort, ease and homogenization, has replaced the hardy travel of yore. Actually, they suggested, tourism inflicts an enormous amount of stress, risk, and discomfort. Delayed flights, mixed connections, metal detectors, lost luggage, toddler-size airplane seats, crying infants, pestilentially recycled air and inquisitorial customs officials: this is a new kind of travel, but not a less taxing one.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on Oct. 25 about the British trip-hop band Massive Attack reversed the names of a singer. He is Horace Andy. The article also misstated the title of a science fiction film in which Massive Attack appeared on the soundtrack. It is ''Pi,'' not ''Phi.''

title: Sinatra 101: Scholars Reach for a Star
description: THE first subject was George Sand. That was in 1976.

title: Tara Behling, Eric Butcher
description: Tara Elisabeth Behling, a daughter of Elaine and George Behling Jr. of Ossining, N.Y., was married yesterday to Eric Kent Butcher, a son of Inger Beckwith of Lacey, Wash., and Budd H. Butcher of Colorado Springs. Msgr. James K. Vaughey performed the ceremony at St. Theresa's Roman Catholic Church in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

title: After Al: L.I. Politics Enters an Unsettled New Era
description: SHATTERED but not altogether surprised by the defeat of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republicans on Long Island are surveying a vastly changed political landscape that without Mr. D'Amato's commanding presence seems suddenly wide open.

title: An Earlier Era
description: To the Editor:

title: Mirror Imagery
description: IT was Lever House, on Park Avenue, that began the trend nearly 50 years ago. Now they are everywhere: glass-walled skyscrapers, giant mirrors reaching for the sky and the soul of New York. By day, they shimmer, reflecting the sunlight; by night, like a million Roman candles, they flash with the color of the neon blazing around them. Curved, straight or angled: like fun-house mirrors, the city's countless windows distort the world around them and, in doing so, bring it into ever sharper relief.

title: Must-Have: Ugly Shoes -- Hers
description: Health care workers and Naval Academy midshipmen have been wearing the Bates shoe for years. They've had to. Now the white rubber-soled lace-up has become a coveted fashion accessory, ever since Helmut Lang put a nurse's shoe on the runway last spring with his hospital-white winter ensembles.

title: Will Harmony Follow Campaign Discord?
description: WHILE they are not quite ready to stage a love-in, Democrats and Republicans say they are expecting to work for common goals in the next General Assembly session after elections last Tuesday in which candidates in both parties ran on similar issues: tax cuts, improving public education and increased liabiliy for health maintenance organizations.

title: George Washington Sleeps Here
description: 'You can tell a lot about a leader by his final resting spot,'' Manus Hand writes in your Sunday pages (Oct. 11). This goes for Presidential losers, too. Consider Samuel J. Tilden, the victim of the ''stolen election'' of 1876, who lost the Presidency to Rutherford B. Hayes despite winning the popular vote. History books report that Tilden accepted the decision magnanimously. His ornate sarcophagus, perched six feet above ground in a secluded cemetery in New Lebanon, N.Y., suggests otherwise. For all the monument's ostentation, it bears a very simple message: ''I still trust the people.''

title: November 1-7; Cultivated Cells
description: Each of the body's 210 types of tissue is derived from a few all-purpose, primordial cells created in the early embryo. These embryonic stem cells were isolated for the first time by two groups of university scientists. The Geron Corporation, which paid for the research, hopes to grow tissue for transplants and introduce genes internally to remedy inherited disease. NICHOLAS WADE

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm going to reprise a statement that I made a long, long time ago, except this time it is, 'One-G and I feel fine.'''

title: Bizball
description: Tunku Varadarajan's Lives column resonates with the deprivation we cricket (and in my case, rugby, as well) addicts feel living in the land of the World Series. Strange that Varadarajan and I, both from the colonies (he from India, I from South Africa), have cricket in our blood and that the millions of American colonials don't care a whit for that very English pastime. This may be understandable, given the languid and almost mystical nature of the game. But it is less comprehensible to me why rugby, that most virile of contact sports, is virtually unheralded here. At least I can get a rugby fix Sunday mornings, at 1 A.M., on Fox Sports World.

title: She Doesn't Make Trains Run on Time
description: ''ATTENTION Princeton Junction passengers. Good day to you.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Carver in Short
description: The novel Raymond Carver occasionally spoke of writing never materialized. Who can say, had he escaped death from lung cancer at the age of 50, whether it ever would have? Carver was disposed to the short form, and if he is the story writer of Teacher's Scotch and domestic dissolution, then in ALL OF US: The Collected Poems (Knopf, $27.50) he is their poet as well. The four volumes collected here by William L. Stull (who also provides ample biographical material, a chronology and exhaustive appendixes) were mostly written in the 1980's, during the final decade of Carver's life; they capture in verse much of the same pared narrative power that distinguishes his fiction. Throughout the book, simple declarative sentences pile up like collection notices as Carver's plain-spoken diction lends immediacy to his characters' downward spins and sporadic redemptions. As an offshoot of his desire to blur the lines between poetry and prose, Carver even arranges passages from the stories of his beloved Chekhov, lining them up like verse. For Carver himself, however, the strongest poems begin where his own stories end, in moments of lyrical insight that leave narrative to one side. In ''September,'' ''Near Klamath'' and ''Late Fragment,'' for example, he discovers his own perfect music and density of expression. Other poems, while sharing the melancholy humanity of his stories, never quite realize their potential as verse. Still, their willed artlessness and unflinching emotions commend them to us. Like the fresh rolls a baker offers to grieving parents in one of Carver's stories, each of them is ''a small, good thing.'' David Yezzi

title: Bizball
description: I would like to see an entire issue of the magazine devoted to education and teachers that is as comprehensive as your issue devoted to ''Bizball.'' I'd also like to know how the values of our country got so lopsided that sports as entertainment has become more important than education -- so much money is spent for the one and hardly anything, by comparison, for the other.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, BENJAMIN
description: JACOBS-Benjamin. Beloved husband of Hinda, loving father of Helen, Jack and Feygele. Dear brother of Leon, cherished grandfather of Mikhl, Louis, Aaron, and Neshama. Father-in-law of Susan Milamed and Michael CholdenBrown. Services Sunday at 10AM, at Hirsch and Sons, 1225 Jerome Ave, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to: YIVO at 555 West 57th Street, New York, New York 10019.

title: Why Christmas Waits Until January
description: IT has all the makings of an investing whodunit. The so-called January effect -- the tendency of small-capitalization stocks to thrash their large-cap siblings in the first month of the year -- has occurred with such regularity over the last century that even hard-nosed statisticians are impressed.

title: The Pornographer and His Wife
description: AT HOME WITH THE MARQUIS DE SADE

title: INVESTING WITH: William H. Gross; Pimco Total Return Fund
description: WILLIAM H. GROSS may never be popularly seen as challenging Peter Lynch's or Warren E. Buffett's status as America's pre-eminent market sages. After all, what are the chances of hitting investing grand slams -- with their attendant publicity -- in boring old bonds?

title: Lynn Harris
description: Harris is the co-creator (with Chris Kalb) of Breakup Girl, a superhero who dishes out on-line advice to the lovelorn.

title: Slowing the Money Train
description: WHAT will slow the rise in executive pay?

title: Efforts Fail to Save Historic Plandome Site
description: THE historic Plandome Manor House, one of the oldest homes on Long Island, was demolished on Monday by its new owner despite efforts by local preservationists to save the house..

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: UPPER WEST SIDE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMAN, MILTON, D.D.S.
description: HYMAN-Milton, D.D.S. Of Aventura, Florida, formerly of Queens, New York. Past Chairman of the Oral Diagnosis Dept of New York University Dental School. Beloved husband of Elsie. Devoted father of Leonard Hyman and Deborah Braverman. Dear brother of Victor Hyman. Loving grandfather. Services Monday, 11 AM, Temple Beth Abraham, Tarrytown, N.Y. For information, call Weinstein Memorial Chapel 914-793-3800.

title: Word & Image; Pay-Pay-Pay-Per-View
description: I get 93 channels on my tv screen and not one treats me as a caring citizen. Not even the half-dozen stations that pretend an interest in local news showed any interest in helping me cast an intelligent vote last Tuesday. They got rich from selling political ads but gave the candidates and issues the back of the hand.

title: Kids Going Along
description: To the Editor: There are incredible benefits to taking young children traveling, far beyond the memories of specific places or things learned. Two years ago, we were fortunate to have two and a half months to travel with our children, 9 and 6. They have many irreplaceable memories from our odyssey, but they have much more than that. They have an understanding of the world as a real place.

title: The Nation: Grand Old Problem; The Republican Middle Looks for an Edge
description: AFTER a year of misery and distraction, White House aides repeated this joke with unabashed glee, given their surprising good fortune in last Tuesday's elections: ''The Monica Strategy: It worked.''

title: A Windowsill in Winter for Fresh Herbs
description: HERBS have become so much a part of food preparation these days that many cooks like to keep the plants indoors over the winter months. Though fresh herbs can now be found in many markets, there is no harm in trying the grow-it-yourself way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFINCH, ELIZABETH CANALES
description: GOLDFINCH-Elizabeth Canales. On November 2, 1998. Beloved mother Anne Goldfinch Locascio. Cherished grandmother of Lisa & Julia Locascio. She was a noted performer with the Robert Shaw Chorale whose career spanned both Europe and the United States. Mrs. Goldfinch was a distinguished member of one of the founding families of South Texas. A memorial service will be held in South Carolina at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPE, THEODORE S.
description: HOPE-Theodore S. Age 95, formerly of New York City and Danbury, NH on October 9, 1998, in Asheville, NC. Practiced corporate law in New York City for over 50 years. Beloved husband of the late Emily Blanchard Hope. Survived by son Peter, 5 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Contributions may be made to the Society for the Protection of New Hampshire Forests, 54 Portsmouth Street, Concord, N.H. 03301.

title: The Price of Silence
description: To the Editor:

title: At Island Garden, New Life for Old Arena
description: WHILE the debate rages on about constructing a new complex to replace the aging Nassau Coliseum, part of the building that preceded it as Long Island's mecca of indoor entertainment has been given another life.

title: Q & A
description: Cruising Irish Waters

title: Melbourne Zoo
description: To the Editor: In writing of the charms of one of Australia's most attractive cities in ''What's Doing in Melbourne'' (Sept. 20), Susan Gough Henly rightly praised its varied neighborhoods and cultural landmarks. But one of our favorite joys wasn't mentioned: the Melbourne Zoo.

title: To Counter Stigma, Hyundai Bolsters Warranty
description: IN an effort to bolster public confidence in the quality of its Korean-made cars, Hyundai Motor America last week announced what it calls the best warranty in the auto business.

title: Hey, Guys, Can't We Just Get Real? Sincerely, Bill
description: Later this week, President Clinton heads for the annual meeting of the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, which this year, by quirky fate, is being held in Malaysia, a country that has denounced the West, rejected the International Monetary Fund's approach to the Asian crisis and tried to stop all trading in its currency. While in Kuala Lumpur, Mr. Clinton will also be seeing the President of China and the new Prime Minister of Russia.

title: Fighting H.I.V., but Their Way; Group Shuns New Treatments, Despite Doctors' Pleas
description: On a recent Tuesday night, a dozen H.I.V.-infected men headed to the back of a cluttered office suite on West 26th Street. They made their way past a table blanketed with fact sheets on the latest anti-AIDS drugs, past an extensive library that included all the established scientific journals and a computer that was available for Internet surfing on treatment and services. A list of AIDS-related symptoms was visible on an office desk.

title: Unconverted
description: TURBULENT SOULS

title: Some Politics Is a Lot More Local Than Others
description: FORGET, for a moment or more, those political campaigns that took place under the glare of television lights, with reporters ready to pounce on and parse every sentence uttered by the candidates.

title: Experts to Give Interpretation of What Warrants Impeachment
description: The question has unleashed a stream of constitutional experts, acid-tongued opinion makers and endless chatter from television pundits.

title: You Don't Need Barbie To Get Girls to Play Chess
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCKERMAN, RACHEL. A
description: TUCKERMAN-Rachel. A remarkable human being. Passionate, ardent and dedicated editor, dog owner, student of the arts and music. Sister of George Tuckman, aunt of Henrietta, Virginia and Deborah Tuckman, Martha Heuer, and Rowena Howe. Dear friend to many. A memorial to be held November 11, 6:30 PM; call 212227-1834.

title: Talking Heads' Post-Mortem: 'All Wrong, All the Time'
description: Newt Gingrich may have emerged the biggest loser in Tuesday's election, but Washington's political pundits are running a close second, many of them having predicted since late January that the American public would sooner or later turn on President Clinton.

title: A Triumphant Role Befits Her
description: WHO is the greatest living British actress? Maybe the question is silly, since it makes an infinitely demanding art sound like a steeplechase for mature fillies, and maybe it is meaningless.

title: Stockholders Reject Plan to Move British Auto Supplier to U.S.
description: After a trans-Atlantic tug-of-war over whether LucasVarity P.L.C., the British-based auto components and aerospace company, should move its headquarters to Buffalo, small shareholders delivered a remarkable rebuff to both management and big American investors, voting by a hair's breadth for the company to remain in Britain.

title: Missed The Boat? Climb Onto Junk
description: Impressive indeed, this John Glenn rally in the stock market. In the seven trading days since Mr. Glenn was lifted into space, the Dow Jones industrial average has rocketed 7.2 percent. Even more remarkable, the Dow has rallied 19 percent from its Aug. 31 low.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: A Benefit for Carnivores

title: Bent Out of Shape by Flexibility
description: CONSIDER the option offered to many working parents in the brave new ''flexible'' workplace: the right to earn a part-time salary for the privilege of leaving promptly at the end of a full day.

title: Lynn Rabinowitz, Michael Fisher
description: Lynn Judith Rabinowitz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Rabinowitz of Northport, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to Michael Jacob Fisher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Fisher of Somers, N.Y. Rabbi Stanley Urbas is to officiate at the Hamlet Country Club in Commack, N.Y.

title: Volumes That Let Fingers Do the Touring
description: SINCE changes to the city's landscape can and do happen in a New York minute, tracking them might seem to be an intimidating task. Relax. Three authors have done some of the work for you, and present it in these books, each of which explores the architecture and history of a different corner of Manhattan.

title: Models Without Runways
description: A JET plane roars across the screen. The camera cuts to a speeding Gillette razor, which flies into the outstretched hand of a handsome, towel-clad actor. After shots of the shaving actor and a close-up of the razor's triple-blade system, the razor zooms through the air again and lands in its package.

title: Sophie Bell and Joseph Sacca
description: Sophie Bell, the daughter of Nicola and David Bell of Chicago, was married yesterday to Joseph Nicholas Sacca, the son of Winifred and Joseph R. Sacca of Garden City, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. J. Barrie Shepherd officiated at the First Presbyterian Church in New York, and the Rev. Charles Murr, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: O Pioneers!
description: THE ROAD HOME

title: Grief Awaits Refugees Returning Home in Kosovo
description: Sanije Millaku, the mother of six children and a proud homeowner, fondly remembers the new bedroom set and the pots of yellow roses arranged on the window sill before the start of the terrible summer.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KNOPF, MARILYN
description: KNOPF-Marilyn. Gone eight years today. We miss you. Lovingly remembered by your family.

title: Correction
description: Because of a computer entry error, the Dining Out column last Sunday, about Logan's Restaurant in New Canaan, carried an incorrect rating. It should have said ''Very Good,'' not ''Good.''

title: U.S. SET TO GIVE UP ARMS INSPECTIONS FOR CURBING IRAQ
description: Seven years after the Persian Gulf war, the Clinton Administration has concluded that the United Nations inspections regime is no longer an effective instrument for restraining President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, senior American officials said.

title: Bruegger's Fell Short Of the Chicago Version
description: To the Editor:

title: How I Got That Story
description: TRIAGE

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Education Life section last Sunday about raising standards at teachers colleges misstated the estimated number of new teachers needed within the next 10 years. It is two million, not 200,000.

title: Bizball
description: Your all-sports issue gives the reader a sample of all facets of the sports business (Oct. 18). But its scope is too narrow. The military-industrial complex of the cold war era has been replaced by the media-entertainment complex of the 1990's. ''Bizball'' is just a part of the vast media-entertainment machine that dominates our lives and influences our tastes, attitudes and leisure-time choices. Most important, it tells us all how to spend our money.

title: Transformed by Passion and Politics, Breast Cancer Movement Gains Power
description: A giant pink ribbon was ceremonially cut and Long Island breast cancer activists hugged and applauded. A 240-year-old landmark, Hewlett House, was being rededicated as the nation's first comprehensive community education and resource center for breast cancer patients and their families.

title: Murphy Wins Rider Title
description: Lacoste H. jumped all six fences on the jump-off course in 31.35 seconds to win the $10,000 Amateur-Owner Jumper Stake at the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

title: Jennifer Leonard, Kenneth Barnes
description: Jennifer Irene Leonard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Leonard of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Kenneth John Barnes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Barnes of Savannah, Ga. The Rev. John Denniston performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Huntington, N.Y.

title: Like the World, Casting Is Going Multinational
description: A NEW recipe for an Elizabethan feast: take a rich slice of British history; add an Indian director making his first English-language film; place two Australian actors in leading roles, and mix in three French performers (including the soccer star Eric Cantona) and four English actors, two of whom are cast against type.

title: He Does Windows
description: Simon Doonan -- Barneys' window dresser extraordinaire -- waves his glue gun and evening clothes appear.

title: Cormac's Cinematic Trash
description: Rafe Greenlee's film career began in 1996, when he and his wife, Mylene Moreno, moved to El Paso, Tex., home to Cormac McCarthy, the famously reticent author of ''All the Pretty Horses.'' One afternoon, Greenlee spotted the novelist carrying trash out of his house. Greenlee and Moreno (who had produced PBS documentaries and had just bought a 16-millimeter camera) filmed the scene on a whim.

title: Midterm Elections: A Vote for Moderation?; Veto Prevention
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Jets
description: There's coach, business and first class. But for some, even those won't do. So Intrav offers an 18-day southern Europe tour on a Boeing 737 reconfigured to seat 44 passengers instead of the usual 120. Stops include Geneva, Biarritz, Bilbao, Granada, Madeira, Capri, Santorini and Istanbul, although the itinerary is flexible. There's an open bar on the jet, and a crew of six flight attendants serves meals on china. Departures are May 16 and June 6; the price of $25,800 a person, double occupancy, includes business-class trans-Atlantic flights and all meals, sightseeing and accommodations. Information: Intrav, 7711 Bonhomme Avenue, St. Louis, Mo. 63105; (800) 456-8100.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUKSIN, JACK
description: DUKSIN-Jack. Beloved husband of Lynn. Devoted father of Joshua, Jeremy and Callie. Adored brother of Sherry. Cherished son of Eva. Service Sunday 10AM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: How the Voices of One Continent Influenced the Culture of Another
description: IT'S as if some terrible anniversary of slavery -- or some danger of its its resurgence -- were at hand. Film, television, science and music are turning to it as a theme. Slavery-bashing, though evidently no guarantee at the box office, has gathered the momentum of a trend.

title: Some Painkillers for the Start-Up
description: THE pitfalls of installing enterprise resource planning programs -- software packages that coordinate a manufacturer's entire operation -- are legion. Technology and operations workers may find themselves working at cross-purposes, for example, or management may fail to set or enforce deadlines. Or maybe the company is biting off more sweeping changes than it can chew.

title: Undertaking a Search For the Vanishing Clam
description: On a recent crisp autumn morning, making a trip to Robert Moses State Park to do some surfcasting, I had to pass over the bridge named for him. As I slowly crossed over, I watched workers rebuilding the south-bound bridge. As I looked out across the Great South Bay, east and west, I realized something was missing. Then it hit me. Those familiar flat-bottom boats with the little cabin that rock back and forth with that one solitary person aboard were not in sight. The clam digger and his loyal canine companion, who it seems is usually part of the equipment to keep the digger company, are gone -- not one in sight. Those quahogs that millions love to eat from the Great South Bay are soon to be a memory.

title: Zingaro Gallops Back Into the Arena
description: ECLIPSE

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on the Evening Hours page last Sunday about a preview of the exhibition ''Jackson Pollock'' at the Museum of Modern Art misidentified one woman present. She was Jill Anson Szarkowski, not Janie C. Lee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITT, IRA J.
description: WITT-Ira J. November 5, 1998. Former President Handbag Association of America and catcher on 1927 James Madison City Championship Baseball Team. Beloved husband of Evelyn. Loving father of Stuart and grandfather of Jennifer. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street, Sunday 11:00 AM.

title: Watercooler Watch
description: In offices and on the Internet last week, people were passing along this suggestion for a large-scale practical joke: before John Glenn's return from space, everybody dress in ape suits and bury the Statue of Liberty up to her head.

title: For the Democrats, Bill Williams
description: 7/14/98 -- On a quick jog after work I see an unfamiliar car with our campaign bumper sticker on it; this makes me happy and the rest of the run goes a little bit easier.

title: Glenn Back on Ground, Head Still Above Clouds
description: The space shuttle Discovery returned safely to the Kennedy Space Center today after a nine-day mission with the world's oldest astronaut, Senator John Glenn, who reassured Mission Control that he felt as good on Earth as he had in space.

title: Carla Fine and Allen Oster
description: Carla Fine and Allen Oster are to be married today in Manhattan. Rabbi Abraham B. Eckstein is to officiate at the 24 Fifth Avenue Ballroom.

title: When Politics Is Local, and Polite
description: Every two years for the last 24, voters here went to the polls and gave the job of tax collector to James Branca. A gentle man, Mr. Branca did little to keep pace with technological advances, but treated residents with the warmth and deference to which they are accustomed. But in June, he died of pneumonia with 18 months left in his latest term, leaving town officials with the sticky question of whom to appoint to dog their 58,000 constituents for money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STINNETT, CASKIE
description: STINNETT-Caskie. Travel editor, writer, humorist, nature and animal lover. On November 5, 1998 at home, of cancer. Survived by wife Joan, son Jim, daughters Karen (Aschi) and Savannah, sisters Happy and Thelma and grandsons Jonathan, David and Nathaniel. Private ceremony will take place on his beloved island in Maine. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to Fund For Animals, 200 West 57th Street, Suite 705, N.Y., N.Y. 10019.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLORY, MARGARET P.
description: MALLORY-Margaret P. On November 3, 1998, age 87 in Santa Barbara, CA. Beloved sister of Clifford D. Mallory and Barbara Hathaway. Her love and knowledge of art and music touched many lives as did her generosity and energy which she devoted to many worthwhile causes. A celebration of her life and accomplishments will be held in Santa Barbara in January. Friends may remember the University of California at Santa Barbara Art Museum, Music Academy of the West, Mystic Seaport Museum, or the Santa Barbara Art Museum.

title: Midterm Elections: A Vote for Moderation?; Broken Record
description: To the Editor:

title: Edward Grey and Nancy Gallagher
description: Dr. Anne Marie Gallagher, a daughter of Barbara and Terence Gallagher of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday in New York to Edward Andrew Grey, the son of Bernice J. Grey of Westport, Conn., and Edward Andrew Mosca of St. Louis. John Cardinal O'Connor performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Preservation Laws Approved in Suffolk
description: While much attention was focused on the results of the United States Senate race, voters in Suffolk County approved major environmental initiatives. In a countywide vote, they approved selling $62 million in bonds to protect farms, preserve open space and improve parks. In the Town of Huntington, voters overwhelmingly approved the sale of $15 million in bonds for open space and town parks.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: Like Being Killed

title: Someone Has To Be an Adult
description: Q. I belong to two work teams that can't seem to get along. I am frequently asked to choose sides in their disagreements. Sometimes, all I have to do to raise the ire of somebody on one team is to mention the name of a member of the other. Any suggestions?

title: Benched Knicks, Lowly Rangers No Ball for Scalpers
description: Last Tuesday evening, when the New York Knicks were supposed to open their 51st season against the Boston Celtics at Madison Square Garden, more than a few commuters on their way to Penn Station noticed that nobody was asking them a question they so often hear on the streets around Madison Square Garden before Knick games: ''Need a ticket?''

title: More at Home Abroad
description: SINCE his death in 1970, William H. Johnson has slowly gained recognition as an outstanding African-American artist, which is to say, simply one of America's outstanding artists. That recognition received its strongest impetus in 1991, when the National Museum of American Art in Washington, which owns a vast majority of his surviving work, organized the exhibition ''Homecoming: William H. Johnson and Afro-America, 1938-1946.''

title: Seth Kaller and Lyn Vinnick
description: Dr. Lyn Adi Vinnick, a child psychologist, and Seth Todd Kaller, a dealer in historical manuscripts, are to be married today by Rabbi Joseph Ehrenkranz at the Carlyle in New York.

title: Adviser Stokes Interest Of Congress on Fund Fees
description: Lots of investors complain about high mutual fund fees and the poor job that fund companies do of disclosing them. But Harold R. Evensky, the ubiquitously quoted financial adviser in Coral Gables, Fla., wants to make a Federal case of it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRASER, BERT H.
description: FRASER-Bert H. Died Nov. 3, age 58 in New York. Actor, comedian, singer, dancer, raconteur, boon companion, loyal pal. Dear Bertie, farewell from all your friends at the Amateur Comedy Club and the Snarks, who loved you and will remember you always. Memorial Celebration at 2PM Sunday at the ACC Clubhouse, 150 E. 36 Street.

title: Still Standing Tall Over Country
description: IF there has been a gravitational center to country music since World War II, Hank Williams occupies it. As a performer he had few peers; as a songwriter he had none. In the roughly six years in which he recorded commercially, he scored a staggering number of country hits. His nasal, impassioned vocals and cleverness as a lyricist made him one of the most popular country music performers of his time.

title: A Slight Climb in Rates
description: Mortgage rates began to move up again last week. A survey of 200 lenders by Bank Rate Monitor, the tracking service, found that the average rate on a 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage rose 0.05 percent, to 6.84 percent, while the 15-year rose 0.09 percent, to 6.49 percent. The biggest move was in one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, up 0.13 percent, to 5.60 percent.

title: Going Down Screaming
description: Sullivan's thesis -- that modern conservatism has gone astray by aligning itself with the religious right -- is disingenuous, since he is the one doing the aligning. His entire article is an exercise in ascribing guilt by association, beginning with Kenneth Starr and ending with -- who else? -- Robert Bork. According to Sullivan, anyone who seriously entertains an opinion espoused by the religious right is, ipso facto, extreme, dogmatic and dangerous.

title: Plaints for a Day-Care Center
description: Politicians and advocates for the elderly have lately focused their attention on the Health and Hospitals Corporation's decision to evacuate the 282 patients from the Neponsit Health Care Center and then permanently close the seaside nursing home. Meanwhile, the agency has also closed an adult day-care center in a nearby building, leaving 100 clients and their spouses in the lurch.

title: English as a Second Language
description: THE PRACTICE

title: Backtalk; N.B.A.'s Silent Season Is Giving a Voice to Others
description: Listen to the daunting questions in the silence of the hoops, questions we never have time to ponder because the beat of a bouncing basketball is usually so insistant this time of year. Is Doug Flutie too short, is Bill Bradley too tall, is Katarina Witt too naked, is Mike Tyson too crazy, and should the pro football conglomerate be renamed the National Relony League?

title: VOWS; Jennifer Brody and Jeffrey Kohn
description: YOU'VE heard of passion sealed with a kiss. Well, this romantic tale is different: it's love sealed with an oyster.

title: New Jerseyans Rank Among Least Charitable
description: New Jersey consistently ranks as one of the richest states in per-capita income, but it also ranks as one of the least charitable, according to a ''generosity index'' released late last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'REILLY, DANIEL J.
description: O'REILLY-Daniel J. On November 3, 1998. Husband of Barbara Adelman. Father of Michael and Timothy. Brother of William. Mass Monday, 9:30AM, St. Thomas Aquinas Church. Reposing at the Chapel of Joseph G. Duffy, Inc., 9th St. between 4th and 5th Avenues, Brooklyn. Viewing Saturday and Sunday, 2-5PM only.

title: Soaring Cost for Young Disabled
description: PROGRAMS to help handicapped newborns to 5-year-olds will cost the county $68 million next year, up more than $6 million from this year and equivalent to a 2 percent increase in property taxes, officials preparing next year's budget say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADES, ANTOINETTE
description: ADES-Antoinette, 72. On 5 November, 1998. Beloved wife of Wally Linder. Loving mother of Isaac Ades and Andrea Ades Vasquez, mother-in-law of Gerald Markowitz and grandmother of Isa and Anton.

title: Q&A/Angela Ramirez; Peers Taking the Pressure Off Peers
description: WHEN Angela Ramirez was a high school freshman, she thought being a member of a popular, but tough, group of girls was the best way to fit in at school. That is, until the group beat up a pregnant classmate and left Ms. Ramirez -- the only one the victim could identify -- to take all the heat.

title: A Cherished View
description: To the Editor:

title: Bizball
description: Don't Americans have anything better to do with their limited free time than become sports-watching addicts (Culture Zone: ''Life Is a Camel Race,'' by Allen St. John)? Manoel Felciano's obsession with televised sports reflects our transformation into a nation of spectators. That trend has been accompanied by rising levels of obesity and cardiovascular problems. Everyone says exercise is important, but we seem only to be talking (and watching) a good game.

title: The Proof Is in Winning As Rutgers Beats Navy
description: The Rutgers football team has something to prove to everyone who thinks of it only as the team that had no victories in 1997. It has something to prove to the people who compile the preseason rankings at Sports Illustrated, who ranked them 112th -- last -- in Division I-A. And it has something to prove to everyone who doubts Coach Terry Shea's ability to turn around the program.

title: The Gingrich Whirlwind
description: A Ph.D. in history, a futurist and a street fighter, a careful, sometimes eloquent planner and an impulsive loudmouth, Newton Leroy Gingrich often seemed to have more ideas, all at once, than the 49 men who served before him as Speaker of the House.

title: November 1-7; Bomb in Jerusalem Threatens The Peace Accord
description: A car bomb outside a busy marketplace in Jerusalem killed its two bombers and wounded at least 24 other people. The Israeli Cabinet suspended deliberations on the Wye peace memorandum, calling on the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat to crack down on terrorists.

title: The Nation; Jesse the Body, Jesse the Mind, Jesse the Governor
description: IN one campaign ad, Jesse Ventura wore only gym shorts and posed as Rodin's ''The Thinker.'' In another, a Jesse Ventura action figure battled Evil Special Interest Man.

title: Paging Mr. Barnum
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: This Marriage Seems More Like a Merger
description: She liked him so much, she decided to marry him. Robin L. Kiam, the founder of a start-up shampoo maker and the daughter of Victor K. Kiam 2d, chairman of Remington Products, Ronson and a slew of other ventures, and Ellen Kiam, who for years ran a company that imported artifacts from China, is tying the knot with Jonathan E. Aviv, 38, a head-and-neck surgeon. Wait -- he's an entrepreneur too, the inventor of a device that prevents aspiration pneumonia in the elderly. ''This is going to revolutionize the health care industry,'' Ms. Kiam, 37, exclaimed of his product. As for hers -- Sterling Solution -- she says it makes gray hair glisten and prevents yellow streaking in white hair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLMES, WALTER S., JR.
description: HOLMES-Walter S., Jr. Financier, age 79, retired Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of CIT Financial Corporation, died on November 3, 1998, at Delray Beach, FL, where he retired in 1984. Holmes also served as corporate trustee of Lehigh University, Bethlehem, PA from 1974-1994, when he was named a Trustee Emeritus. Mr. Holmes is survived by his wife of 57 years, Jean Pringle, his two sons, Stephen of Ross, CA and Richard of Las Vegas, NV, and his two granddaughters, Lesley and Laura, both of San Francisco, CA. A private family service will be held. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Lehigh University as additions to the HolmesPringle Memorial Fund, which provides financial aid to Lehigh Business School Students.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAACSON, ROBERT L.
description: ISAACSON-Robert L. On Nov. 5, 1998 at home in Manhattan. He was an urbane figure well-known to enthusiasts of 19th-century academic painting. A Requiem Mass will be held at Saint Ignatius Loyola on Park Avenue, November 10th at 11:00 AM. Donations in his memory may be made to the Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Medical Center, 1st Avenue at 16th Street, NY, NY 10003.

title: Some Would Rather Sail the Sound to Work
description: THIS is what it's like on the days that Richard Grigoritus must drive from his home in West Hartford through Manhattan to see his architect in Nassau County and then on to Patchogue, N.Y., where he manages construction of a shopping center: He leaves his house about 6:30 A.M., coffee cup sloshing as he steers, newspaper folded and unread. Traffic builds and occasionally stalls. Three hours later he arrives at his job.

title: Midterm Elections: A Vote for Moderation?; Blaming the Right
description: To the Editor:

title: A Vote on Impeachment
description: Judging by a vote at Iona College in New Rochelle late last month, the outlook for President Clinton is poor.

title: George Washington Sleeps Here
description: Hand can ''only guess at'' why obelisks are associated with graves. They are not, as he speculates, ''phallic symbols.'' Rather, the obelisk is one of the most stable building forms (surpassed only by the pyramid). Pointing heavenward, it symbolizes eternity. As for the ''dank, cold crypt in the basement of a church'' in which John and John Q. Adams lie, for centuries in Europe and America burial within a church crypt was an honor, accorded V.I.P.'s of the parish or town.

title: A War for the Republican Future
description: The modern Republican Party seems to define itself through revolution. In 1980, Ronald Reagan overthrew the bland, accommodating style of the party's old guard, and then Newt Gingrich stormed the Capitol in 1994. Now that Mr. Gingrich has been booted, the House Republicans have to decide whether the 1998 election dictated that yet another fundamental shift is in order. The religious right says Mr. Gingrich erred by going soft. Yet the voters picked moderate Republican governors as the party's stars of the future. It promises to be a gory sorting out.

title: Markets and Economy Alike Come Off Adrenaline Highs
description: Had enough of ''interesting times''? They may be abating for a while. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, told the Securities Industry Association on Thursday what many analysts have been observing: Investors and lenders seem to be calming down after weeks of turmoil, easing the threat of a credit crunch and reducing market volatility.

title: SOAPBOX; Over Over There
description: ROB CARLISLE, who lives in Chatham, Mass., was born in Passaic, as were his mother and her two older brothers. One of his uncles, Robert Granger Benson, was killed in World War I soon after graduating from Princeton. Mr. Carlisle recently wrote a poem about him, ''The Uncle I Never Knew,'' which refers to a memorial fountain built in Passaic in 1919 by Robert Benton's father, Robert Dix Benton. Soon after Mr. Carlisle finished the poem, he learned that the fountain, which had fallen into disrepair, had been restored. (The renovated fountain is pictured here.) Some of Mr. Carlisle's poem was read at the rededication ceremony in July. Here are some excerpts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, FAITH
description: ROSS-Faith. On November 6, 1998. Beloved wife of Stanley Ross. Dear mother of Julie Ross, Stacey (Bruce) Cohen and Shari (Henri) Ross Altarac. Adored grandmother of Brian, Gabrielle, Amanda and Kelsey. Loving daughter of Betty Lang. Cherished sister of Bertie Kleinkopf and Ricky Navarre. Services today, November 8th, at 12:15 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, ANNE B.
description: NEWMAN-Anne B. Age 63, died peacefully at her home in Scarsdale, NY, on November 7, 1998. Beloved wife of Dr. Herbert A. Newman. Cherished mother of David, Peter and Tracy. Devoted grandmother of Michael. Sister of Ellen Davis. Anne was a caring, compassionate, special person whose motto was ''That's what friends are for.'' She will be sorely missed. Services private. Memorial contributions may be made to Corporate Angel Network, 1 Loop Rd., White Plains, NY 10604.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIPLEY, MADELEINE S.
description: SHIPLEY-Madeleine S. Beloved wife, mother, mother-in-law, grandmother, friend, Realtor nonpareil and fifth-generation New Yorker died November 4, 1998 at her home, of complications from emphysema. She will be sorely missed by all those whose lives she touched so profoundly. A memorial service will be held November 14th, 1PM at the Church of the Heavenly Rest. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Madeleine's name to the Hassenfeld Children's Center for Cancer and Blood Disorders, c/o NYU Medical, 317 East 34 St, NY NY 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, BARBARA
description: LEVINSON - Barbara. Beloved wife of Jerome. Loving mother of Robert Scott. Service Sunday 1:30PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The American Cancer Soceity.

title: Ms. Amerasinghe And Mr. Perlson
description: Marie Nilanthi Amerasinghe, a daughter of Wimala and Chittharanjan Amerasinghe of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Douglas Jon Perlson, the son of Sharon and Michael Perlson of Great Neck, N.Y. The Rev. Percy D'Silva performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Shrine of the Most Blessed Sacrament in Washington.

title: A Damning Review
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM; Revealing an Iran Where the Chadors Are Most Chic
description: IN the sweepstakes for the title Most Interesting and Accomplished Filmmaker the United States Has Never Heard Of, Dariush Mehrjui has certain obvious advantages. While still in his 20's, the Iranian director made ''The Cow'' (1969), a film so powerful that it not only was credited with launching Iran's modern cinema but also, a decade later, made a fan of the Ayatollah Khomeini and thus helped assure that country's cinema of having a post-Revolutionary phase. Cosmopolitan and ever-controversial, Mr. Mehrjui has had films banned by the Shah's regime and the Islamic Republic, and almost surely is the only filmmaker reared a devout Muslim who counts the novelists J. D. Salinger and Saul Bellow as major influences on his work. He's even made a film of Mr. Salinger's ''Franny and Zooey,'' called ''Pari,'' set in contemporary Iran.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, JEANNE WHITE
description: MILLER-Jeanne White. Resident of West Palm Beach, FL, wife of the late Andrew O. Miller, died on October 30, 1998, at the age of 77. She was born in Boston, MA, daughter of the late Loring and Arlene White, of Cohasset and Palm Beach. She was a wonderful mother, a loving wife, a beautiful person, an artist and an accomplished athlete who excelled at tennis and golf. She is survived by her children Constance M. Bergh of MA, Deborah M. Lalor of VA, Jeffrey C. Miller of CT, Dwight A. Miller of MO, and Bradford P. Miller of FL, her brothers William and Frederick White and sister Anne Bedford, nine grandchildren, and numerous nephews and nieces. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, November 22, 1998, at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, NY at 1 PM. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to the Arthritis Foundation, 1330 W. Peach Tree St, Atlanta, GA 30309.

title: A Play Takes The Space Once Given To Dancers
description: DUSK had lowered its blue velvet curtain, but inside the converted barn known as Barnspace the heat was rising. Young actors, some from as far as New Brunswick, N.J., were fervently rehearsing the performance piece they had helped write. Called ''Swim,'' it was the story of a drowning, and the term was both literal and metaphorical.

title: DiMaggio Is in Intensive Care
description: Joe DiMaggio remained in intensive care at Memorial Regional Hospital today, sedated and using oxygen equipment to help him breathe easier as he battled pneumonia and a lung infection.

title: Sports of The Times; Cherbet's College QB's Knew He Could Do It
description: WHEN he turns on his television this afternoon and sees Vinny Testaverde drop back to pass against the Buffalo Bills, Carlos Garay will think, ''Lucky man.'' He knows whom the Jets' quarterback will have the pleasure of looking for, particularly on third down-and-trouble. Somewhere in the defensive backfield, he knows Wayne Chrebet will be waiting for the ball that does not have to be targeted like a jump shot, or a pitcher's precise delivery, mound to mitt.

title: A Role Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Stacey Winston, Dan Levitan
description: Stacey Rae Winston, a gallery owner, and Dan Levitan, a financial executive, were married last evening in New York. Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg officiated at the St. Regis.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY; Oberammergau Plans For the Millennium
description: The year 2000 will draw almost half a million visitors to the small Bavarian village of Oberammergau for the Passion Play, which will be performed from May to October. Every 10 years, the production, which begins with Christ's arrival in Jerusalem and ends with the Resurrection and Transfiguration, is held outdoors in the Alpine village. This production faithfully follows a tradition of more than 350 years, though the play itself has been revised in recent years to eliminate anti-Semitic stereotypes. In 1633, the town elders vowed to perform the Passion if God spared the village from a plague.

title: G.I. NO
description: Call it ''Shelving Private Ryan.'' A G.I. Joe action figure depicting Tom Hanks as he appeared in ''Saving Private Ryan'' has been canceled. Hasbro unveiled the figure at the International Toy Fair in February, but the director Steven Spielberg's Dreamworks production company ultimately put the kibosh on its release, reportedly because the World War II epic was deemed too violent for toy purposes. ''It was obvious after we started showing the film, and after veterans were thanking us for doing it, and after the critical reaction, that you couldn't do a toy based on it,'' says one Dreamworks marketing exec. ''It was a taste matter as much as anything else.'' The figure has been refashioned as a generic Army Ranger who fought at Normandy, to be sold for $58.

title: The Wrong Battle
description: To the Editor:

title: Pioneer Spirit
description: John Ford's STAGECOACH (1939) remains one of the screen's towering westerns, despite its pointless gun-duel postscript. The rest of the film is a compact and atmospheric narrative, marked by a birth, an Indian attack and even a cavalry rescue. The cast is varied and fine: John Wayne and Claire Trevor (above), Berton Churchill, Donald Meek, John Carradine, George Bancroft, Louise Latimer and several others, whose plights give the jounrney color and tensions. Dudley Nichols's splendid scenario is a model of character and story development. Dusty and a bit rusty, perhaps, around the edges, Ford's old four-wheeler still reigns supreme of its kind - SATURDAY at 12:15 P.M. on AMC.

title: The Woody Allen of Fashion Joins the Club at Saint Laurent
description: LAST week, on the night before his first day as the new designer for Yves Saint Laurent's ready-to-wear collection, Alber Elbaz laid out his clothes on a chair like a nervous schoolboy. The gesture was purely ceremonial. Mr. Elbaz usually wears an all-black ensemble so rumpled it may as well have been slept in. But the glamour and prestige of his job was unnerving. ''I asked them at Saint Laurent, 'Are you sure it's not a mistake? You can still change your mind,' '' the designer said, with characteristic self-doubt.

title: Marching Through Georgia
description: A Man in Full

title: Neighborhood's Sore Thumb
description: Don Wollner said he and his wife moved to Park Slope eight years ago to raise their son, Preston, in a nice neighborhood. What they did not realize, he said, was that they were moving next to an island of urban decay.

title: The Nation; Gambling: Married to the Action, for Better or Worse
description: WHEN California voters approved a measure last week giving Indian tribes broad permission to run casinos unhampered by state control, it was a big loss for the Coalition for Unregulated Gambling, one of the measure's fiercest opponents.

title: Ophelia Fights Back
description: RAISING THEIR VOICES The Politics of Girls' Anger. By Lyn Mikel Brown. 259 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $24.95.

title: It Was a Beastly Celebration
description: Leave it to David C. McCourt to enlist bones in his battle with the Bells. Mr. McCourt is the high-energy, low-reverence chairman of the RCN Corporation, whose ads for its integrated phone, video and data services paint old-line phone companies as anachronisms. For meetings in New York last week with investors and analysts, Mr. McCourt pulled out the stops. RCN's welcoming reception at the American Museum of Natural History on Wednesday evening was held in, you guessed it, the dinosaur room. Dinner, in the entrance hall, was dominated by another set of extinct creatures. Obvious? Perhaps. But hordes of top finanical players showed up, and the attendance of 160 was twice what the company had expected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOGEL, EDWARD A.
description: FOGEL-Edward A. Died November 6, 1998. Partner, Pryor, Cashman, Sherman & Flynn. Trustee, Camp Isabella Friedman, American Jewish Society for Service, Fund for Peace, Hoff Barthelson Music School, and Chess-in-theSchools. He was active in the NYC Bar Association. A former adjunct professor at Pace College and enthusiastic volunteer at P.S. 68. He is deeply mourned by his wife Barbara, son Jim, daughter Jan, sonin-law Bob Schlegel, daughter-inlaw Beth Jacob, grandchildren Dana and Sarah Schlegel, Jeffrey, Anna and Miriam Fogel. We will miss his wisdom, love and humor. Memorial service, Riverdale Temple, Monday 11 AM. Contributions may be made to Chess-inthe-Schools, 353 W. 46th St., NYC 10036 designated to P.S. 68.

title: Going Down Screaming
description: The picture of American ''conservatives'' drawn by Andrew Sullivan is disturbing (''Going Down Screaming,'' Oct. 11). Their dream for America is a totalitarian one, and presents as dire a threat to our freedom as any foreign enemy has. It is true that there have been, and will continue to be, excesses in the name of liberty; people of good will are striving to work out correctives that are fair to all. But the mix of extreme intolerance and aggression that characterizes the agenda of today's conservatives is precisely what our Founding Fathers were at such pains to preserve us from. If enough voters can be led to mistake this revenge of hypocrites for the path of righteousness, all is lost.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-17

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: CULTURAL CALISTHENICS Writings on Race, Politics and Theatre. By Robert Brustein. Ivan R. Dee, $26.

title: Now Playing: A Grand Movie House Restored
description: The marquee of the Loew's Jersey has been beckoning passers-by for 70 years. But the lure is no longer first-run Hollywood films seen in luxury; now it calls out for volunteers to scrape off decades of paint, dirt and petrified chewing gum to restore the movie palace.

title: The World: Reconciling in South Africa; Next Up for Amnesty: The Unrepentant
description: THE deal that South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission offered was simple enough: Confess your crimes, apply for amnesty and you will go free. If you don't come forward, you will be prosecuted.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAPALDO, LOUIS A.
description: CAPALDO-Louis A. 28 years ago, Nov. 8, 1970 Louis passed away. Memories of love and devotion never die. Always alive in my heart. Susan

title: Colorful, Mellow Risotto for Autumn
description: AUTUMN produce counters and farm stands brimming with bright but sturdy vegetables offer inspiration for risotto. The basic risotto principle -- gradually adding stock to the plump, short-grain rice that absorbs it and becomes toothsome -- applies no matter what.

title: Check the Calendar
description: Some human brains seem to be having as much trouble with the impending turn of the millennium as date-impaired computers are expected to.

title: Books, Yes; Reading, Maybe
description: AH, Fashion Week, with its nonstop round of model sightings, runway shows, paparazzi evasions and . . . literary parties.

title: Putting a Dream in Storage: the Reality
description: FOR years, I had a recurrent dream. I had just moved to a new house, and as I walked through, I kept discovering rooms I had never before noticed. Each time I had this dream, the house was completely different, but the experience was always the same: new rooms, hidden rooms, empty and available to a multitude of uses.

title: Records Shattered
description: The local real estate market set all-time records in the spring and early summer, the Westchester County Board of Realtors reports.

title: The Big Calamari
description: THE SEARCH FOR

title: In the Region / New Jersey; In Long Branch, an Anchor for Redevelopment Area
description: OVER the last decade there have been several proposals to turn a shoreline tract in Long Branch into housing. But none materialized and the site, a small portion of which is used as a parking lot for beachgoers, has remained undeveloped.

title: Democrats Mourn Loss of Ideal Foil
description: Their wish finally came true: Democrats helped topple Speaker Newt Gingrich. But rather than celebrate, many of Mr. Gingrich's toughest foes are now lamenting the loss of the politician they most liked to demonize.

title: Phone Upstarts Scramble for Capital
description: NOT long ago, raising money for a minor communications company was almost as easy as, well, picking up the phone.

title: Dangerous Game
description: Alfred L. Werker's HE WALKED BY NIGHT (1948) is a solid throwback to the old days of the Hollywood criminal manhunt. It gets right down to business with a severely wounded fugitive (Richard Basehart) tracked to a suburban Los Angeles neighborhood. The picture then grimly follows his self-inflicted surgery and his subsequent undoing by a nosy neighbor. The director has used a score of effective players in key scenes that produce a gripping balance between dramatic and documentary styling. The picture looks at the crime itself in an almost impersonal way, adding to the strong overall flavor of realism - FRIDAY at MIDNIGHT on CHANNEL 21.

title: Midterm Elections: A Vote for Moderation?; A Moral Question
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUECKER, GUNTER
description: RUECKER-Gunter. On October 21, 1998 in Greenwich, Connecticut after a short illness. Gunter was a fashion designer and teacher at The Fashion Institute of Technology in New York City. Mourning his premature passing are his wife Helga and daughter Tanya, son Oliver and family, sister Anne and family and friends.

title: Awesome Again Breaks Through a Classic Crowd
description: On a day when Skip Away ran out of the money and lost his chance to become the world's richest race horse, Awesome Again won the world's richest race when he rushed through the pack in a blanket finish and snatched the $5.2 million Breeders' Cup Classic by three-quarters of a length over Silver Charm.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 25 about celebrity promoters of international organizations misspelled the surname of an Assistant Secretary General of the United Nations who said actors and rock stars help widen the agencies' appeal. She is Gillian Sorensen, not Sorenson.

title: . . . And There's That Lilt at Penn Station
description: ''I sometimes imagine the passengers go home with a smile on their face, thinking that there's some nice young Irish thing doing the announcements,'' said Margaret McGowan, with a hearty laugh. ''Now they're going to find out it's an old Irish bat, and they're going to want to get off the train!''

title: Library's 20th Year of Concerts
description: FOR two decades, the Ossining Public Library has filled its reading room with listeners and brought artists to play ''Great Music in a Great Place,'' while not charging admission or asking for a donation.

title: Wall Street Plays Relocation Card, and City Pays
description: Even as city and state officials were clinching a deal last week to keep one financial market in Manhattan, the New York Stock Exchange increased the pressure for its own generous deal by talking to developers about building a new trading floor in Jersey City.

title: Car Plan Not Practical
description: The arguments of conservationists notwithstanding, International Business Machines has rejected a proposal -- sometimes referred to as a cash-out plan -- to pay workers to use public transportation or join car pools. At least at its Somers offices, where workers travel from different suburban spots, driving one's own car to work seems to be the most efficient mode of transportation, Jim Ruderman, an I.B.M. spokesman, said last week.

title: Bizball
description: Tunku Varadarajan left out a quirky detail about Americans and their sports. Even though most other countries abstain from playing baseball, gridiron football and basketball, Americans proclaim their victors as world champions or World Series winners.

title: Inviting Hunters Home To Cull the Deer Herd
description: IN light of their town's self-proclaimed nickname -- ''The Next Station to Heaven'' -- it is not surprising that many residents of New Canaan think theirs is a very special place indeed, characterized by affluence and elegance, spacious parks, a nature center, good schools and a strong sense of community.

title: Holiday Safety Zones
description: THE holidays are coming and with each one comes the chaos of children's excitement, party plans and food preparation. It is the time of year when little things can slip the mind: the closing of a door, tidying up the house. It is the hardest season to find extra time for our pets.

title: Now in Citigroup's Past: James Dimon and E-Cash
description: A week ago, Citigroup had a president-troubleshooter to make its founding merger play out smoothly and an ambitious pilot project to test consumer acceptance of electronic cash. Now both are gone.

title: Sexual Harassment Surging on the Island
description: IN December 1997, a computer programmer at a small company on Long Island complained about the stream of sexual comments and inappropriate touching she had been enduring from male colleagues, including an owner, for six months. The company did nothing and the harassment continued.

title: Overlooking the New
description: To the Editor:

title: A New generation Revels in Bel Canto
description: IT is an exaggeration to claim, as some do, that the bel canto operatic repertory languished completely during the post-World War I decades until Maria Callas and Joan Sutherland arrived on the scene in the 1950's and 60's to revive it.

title: Easy Transfers at Orly May Be a Memory
description: TRANS ATLANTIC and other long-haul flights to and from Orly Airport south of Paris may soon be a thing of the past. Airlines that use the historic field and the French Ministry of Transport agree that a decision on rerouting flights of more than 3,125 milesto Charles de Gaulle airport north of the city will be made soon.

title: Getting the Lowdown On a Serial Showoff
description: IN January 1986, Ian Gibson received a message he had awaited for years: Salvador Dali was ready to see him. An Irish-born author, Mr. Gibson was writing a biography of Federico Garcia Lorca, the Andalusian poet, and Dali had finally agreed to talk about his intimate friendship with Garcia Lorca, forged during their school days in Madrid. Mr. Gibson sped to the Teatre-Museu Dali in the Catalan town of Figueras. He was led to an imposing chamber with an interminably long red carpet. At its end was the celebrated Surrealist, bedecked in a white silk cloak, perched on a throne.

title: From the Tax Form To On-Stage Art Form
description: LET me get off the phone with my broker,'' said Jerry Sterner, who was on one of his other lines when an interviewer called at a designated time. The subject was his new play, ''1040,'' which is to open at the Rich Forum of the Stamford Center for the Arts next Sunday and run through Nov. 22.

title: INSIDE
description: Inquiry on Welfare Policies

title: Kids Going Along
description: To the Editor: In Seth Margolis's delightful ''On Your Mark, Get Set, Duomo!'' (Aug. 16), he confesses that his family had to ''forgo the Uffizi.'' My family was in Tuscany this spring and I have a tip, particularly for parents who want to squire their kids to the Uffizi but don't want to squander time in line: Call (39-055) 294-883 for reservations.

title: Commercial Property / 325 Hudson Street; Seeking Tenants for a Telecommunications Center
description: THE building at 325 Hudson Street, at the intersection of Vandam Street south of Greenwich Village, is not much to look at. The brick facade shows the dirt of decades, some windows are broken and the lobby is small and unimpressive.

title: Navigating Without Map or Compass
description: WHAT is it about music? If Milton Babbitt were a painter, and not a composer, his work would be a familiar part of the mental landscape. By now, at 82, he would have had a major retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum. Tableware decorated with his imagery would be available at the Museum of Modern Art gift shop. No museum would be able to consider its collection of contemporary American art adequate if it did not own an earlyish example of his work.

title: An Artist's Adobe
description: ''I'VE never made a religious pilgrimage, but the trip my wife and I took recently to Georgia O'Keeffe's 18th-century adobe house in Abiquiu, N.M., was, for us, a journey to a shrine.

title: The Worlds of Los Angeles; Asian Aspects
description: Lucy and I went in search of Asian Los Angeles -- and found it, or the first taste of it, in the sushi bar on the concourse at the airport, right next to our arrival gate. Sushi is easier to find than a hot dog here: strip malls, airports, Dodgers games, drive-throughs, rock bars -- you're never more than 50 feet from raw fish. We had toro and maguro and California roll in a fancy hotel restaurant, in a couple of mom-and-pop streetside joints, in a tourist trap in Little Tokyo and in an elegant spare room in the brick-and-razor-wire warehouse district south of downtown. None of it was bad, some of it was great. We even tried to find laser-light sushi -- a sushi bar all in black, illuminated by black lights and lasers -- though we never quite tracked it down.

title: Ho! Ho! Ho! Boohoo-hoo!
description: The holiday season seems to bring out the best and the worst in bosses. We've all heard stories about workers who are fired on Christmas Eve, but then again, Scrooge himself ended up giving the long-suffering Bob Cratchit a raise. What holiday horror stories have emerged from your workplace? Or, to give the management world's guardian angels their due, how have the holidays melted the coldest corporate hearts? Send your anecdotes to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Bizball
description: If ''live'' televised sports, as opposed to ''taped family entertainment,'' has an enormous impact on network ratings, then why can't we rely on media moguls to provide live coverage of the Olympic Games? The delayed drama of taped events, broadcast over a four-hour period (coupled with melodramatic biographies of every athlete), lowers ratings and revenue. Let us deal with time-zone issues all by ourselves. Give us what we want: live competition.

title: Return of the L-Word?
description: It seems incredible now that Lionel Trilling could have written in 1950 that ''liberalism is not only the dominant but even the sole intellectual tradition'' in America. This wasn't true even then: Trilling blithely ignored the vigorous life of American conservatism and radicalism.

title: A Visionary Architect, With Blind Spots
description: In his lifetime, Frank Lloyd Wright was many things to many people. To his disciples he was a visionary who single-handedly created the first truly American style of architecture. To his wife Catherine, he was a two-timer who skipped off to Europe with the spouse of a client, leaving behind six children and a stack of unpaid bills. He was also a braggart who once said, ''I don't build a house without predicting the end of the present social order''; an occasional liar who once claimed that a Louis Sullivan building was his own design, and a spendthrift not only with his money, but also with that of his clients. (''It was my misfortune,'' he remarked, ''that everybody was willing to trust me.'')

title: Midterm Elections: A Vote for Moderation?; Social Conservatism?
description: To the Editor:

title: What I Don't Need: Mirrors and Hair Loss
description: MOTEL chains are all reassuringly alike. I particularly enjoy the cookie-cutter architecture of Hampton Inns, which makes me feel at home as soon as I step through the door. Whether I'm in Selden or San Francisco, the layout is so predictable that I can safely go to the bathroom with my eyes shut in the middle of the night.

title: My Elephant Could Paint That
description: In Thailand, a slowdown in logging has left hundreds of domesticated elephants unemployed. No longer in as much demand to haul teak out of the jungle, many elephants and their handlers now wander the streets of Bangkok, homeless and hungry. The solution? Well, they could be sent to a new art school for Thai elephants that opens with a gala party and exhibition on Nov. 19. The school is designed to help Asian elephants break into a growing international market. (One female elephant at the Phoenix Zoo, named Ruby, has hauled in $500,000 from the sale of her paintings.) The nonprofit academy is the brainchild of two Russian-born collaborative artists, Vitaly Komar and Alex Melamid, who are known for conceptual projects that spoof the art world. According to Melamid, the team has recently been ''trying to find esthetic connections to the animal world'' by ''collaborating'' not only with elephants but also with chimpanzees, beavers and termites to create works of . . . something or other. Here's a look.

title: Of Youth, Twitching Toward Epiphany
description: DO you know where your children are?

title: A City And Its Soldiers; A Hotel for the Military Reflects a Bond That Has Been, by Turns, Wary and Warm
description: THE highlight reel of New York City's volatile relationship with the military during this century is a montage of indelible images. Start with the sepia flicker of doughboys saluting the Statue of Liberty as they sail home from the War to End All Wars. Cut to scenes full of fancy-free sailors at liberty in the 1944 Broadway classic ''On the Town,'' followed by the Alfred Eisenstadt image of that delirious V-J Day kiss in Times Square. Soon, visions of fresh-faced Korean War inductees are replaced by waves of Vietnam War protesters, who yield to the incongruous spectacle of a worshipful city proffering its heart, and ticker tape, to Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf in the Desert Storm parade. The finale? The recent sight of fiber-tough New Yorkers weeping at the conclusion of ''Saving Private Ryan.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, BOBO
description: LEWIS-Bobo. On Friday morning, October 30th. A long revered actress equally at home on stage and in front of the camera. Ms. Lewis enjoyed a long career that encompassed an astonishing variety of work. Among her Broadway credits are 42nd Street, Musical Comedy Murders of 1940, Twigs, and Working, for which she won a Drama Desk Award. Film credits include Le Sauvage, The Wild Party, The Paper, and just recently, One True Thing. TV viewers remember her fondly for many guest appearances such as Bewitched and That Girl, and to a new generation of viewers, she is Midge Smoot of Shining Times Station. Ms. Lewis was very proud of her work with Circle Repertory Theatre in new plays such as The Diviners and The Runner Stumbles. Last year she was nominated for a Joseph Jefferson Award for her appearance as Stella in Light Up the Sky. A world-traveling lover of life and the arts, Bobo Lewis is survived by her cousin, Susan Lero of Florida, and her many, many friends. She will be missed.

title: Stirring Thoughts of Springtime, Answer Lively Hangs On in Juvenile
description: Answer Lively cast a lengthening shadow toward next year's Kentucky Derby by winning today's $1 million Breeders' Cup Juvenile by a head over the 76-1 long shot Aly's Alley. And he did it at Churchill Downs, where the Derby will be run on the first Saturday in May.

title: Stan Wright, a U.S. Olympic Track Coach, Is Dead at 78
description: Stan Wright, the track coach who took the blame for the disqualification of two American sprinters who showed up late for their races in the 1972 Munich Olympics, died on Friday night at St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital in Houston. He was 78.

title: Correction
description: A report last Sunday about the marriage of Jennifer Lynn Kolber and Charles Welsh White misidentified the school where the bride is a teacher. It is the Far Hills (N.J.) Country Day School, not the Cathedral School in New York.

title: GURU: Yefim Shubentsov; A Rasputin for Smokers
description: CALL directory assistance in Massachusetts and ask for ''the mad Russian'' and chances are they'll know who you're trying to reach. Address an envelope with the same name and the Boston post office knows where to deliver it: a brownstone in Brookline, whose stoop is often crowded with smokers furiously puffing away before entering the offices of Yefim Shubentsov, a Soviet emigre renowned for curing nicotine slaves of their cravings in an hour.

title: In the Region / Connecticut; Bridgeport Turns to Waterfront to Spur Economy
description: AFTER more than 30 years of grinding depression, failed attempts at urban renewal and dashed hopes for a casino, Bridgeport is now reclaiming its decaying waterfront in an effort to stimulate its economy.

title: Kindred Spirits, Though Separated by Centuries
description: THE main exhibition at the Morris Museum now is the visual equivalent of meringue or puff pastry. ''Henri Matisse: 'Florilege des Amours de Ronsard,' a Celebration of French Renaissance Poetry'' is light, airy and delicious. Although 'Florilege,' a limited-edition artist book from 1941 through 1948, is simply composed of off-white sheets of paper marked with few brown lines, its display will satisfy viewers who come for something substantial: Matisse once said he considered an artist book -- that is, a book whose production is controlled by the artist -- the equivalent of a painting, and it is evident that he invested this project with much thought and a lifetime of experience.

title: A World of Celebration; Amsterdam: St. Nicholas Day
description: Hark! this is the story of a Santa Claus who really did exist. In November, the Dutch start busily preparing to celebrate their own St. Nicholas on Dec. 6; he is a national institution more beloved than their royalty and one that makes for the jolliest feast of the year.

title: P.C. 101
description: THE SHADOW UNIVERSITY

title: For Veterans Of Britain, Top Honors In France
description: Some live in nursing homes, as you might expect of men who are pushing 100 years old, and few can walk without help. But today, on the 80th anniversary of the end of World War I, a dozen or so surviving British veterans gathered here at a museum devoted to the memory of war to receive one of France's highest distinctions and to hear, in the most ringing tones, that they have not been forgotten.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, IRVING
