description: LEVY-Irving. On November 6, 1998, of Valley Stream, NY. Beloved husband of Janet for 61 years. Devoted father of Ben (Marcia), Morton (Joanne), Herb (Lynn), and Stewart (Fran). Dear brother of David. Cherished grandfather of Sharon and Marc; Gayle and Cara; Alana and Daniel; Rebecca, Matthew, and Jonathan. We mourn the passing of an exceptional man whose generosity and kindness enriched the lives of all who knew him. Shalom.

title: Ms. Drennan, Mr. Brautigan
description: Adrienne Drennan, a daughter of Alvina Drennan of Manhattan and the late Capt. John J. Drennan, was married yesterday to Jude Brautigan, a son of Kathleen and John Brautigan of South River, N.J. Msgr. Michael J. Alliegro performed the ceremony at the Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J.

title: Elizabeth Tan, Hari Bezwada
description: Dr. Elizabeth Listiani Tan, a radiologist, and Dr. Hari Prasad Bezwada, an orthopedic surgeon, were married on Friday in Basking Ridge, N.J. The Rev. Mary Tiebot, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Old Mill Inn.

title: A World of Celebration; Mexico City: Day of the Three Kings
description: Mexicans like to keep their Christmas revelries going well past the New Year. They close out the season with a final round of family visits, presents and hot chocolate on Jan. 6, the Day of the Three Kings, when, according to St. Matthew, the wise men arrived in Bethlehem to worship the newborn Jesus.

title: November 1-7; Surprise Announcement
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a Democrat, said he would retire when his fourth term is over at the end of 2000. He is 71. The announcement is more good news for New York City's Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a possible successor. On Tuesday, his sometime foe, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato (a fellow Republican whom Mr. Giuliani supported this time) was defeated by Representative Charles E. Schumer, which means New York will have two Democratic senators for the first time in 52 years. Other possible successors to Mr. Moynihan: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall and Andrew Cuomo, the Secretary of Housing and Urban development, both Democrats.

title: The Nation; The Price of a Vote
description: Two headlines collided in the midterm elections: More money than ever was raised by Congressional candidates; voter turnout was the lowest since 1942.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARR, MADELEINE (NEE SCHOEN,
description: BARR-Madeleine (nee Schoen- feld). Age 72, of Boynton Beach, Florida. Formerly of Hartsdale, New York. Passed away November 6, 1998. She is survived by her loving husband Aubrey and sister Naomi Freedenfeld.

title: Verbier: Bracing Runs and Serious Food
description: In the long, testing descent from the 10,800-foot Mont-Fort to the restaurant at Tortin, the charm of Verbier is revealed. The piste first enchants the skier with an extraordinary 360-degree view of peaks, including the distant Matterhorn, then provides a sometimes heart-stopping challenge as it plunges more than 4,000 feet down the glacier before ending in a secluded sun trap, where a sense of achievement may be savored over a fondue or a raclette prepared with the wonderful local Bagnes cheese. Verbier pampers, as any ski resort should, but it also invigorates.

title: Lessons Learned From Drinking While at College
description: ON Friday, many Rutgers students head off to party in New York City, others to do their laundry at home, so Thursday night is the big bar night on Easton Avenue. The dance floor is packed at the Knight Club, where a pitcher of beer costs the same as a pint. The chatter is deafening at the Scarlet Pub, where patrons down Muscle Relaxers (Crown Royal, amaretto and Bailey's Irish Cream) and Sicilian Kisses (amaretto and Southern Comfort). And the lines run 10 deep at the door by midnight at the Olde Queens Tavern, where the endless beer is enlivened by test-tube shooters of Southern Comfort for $1 each.

title: Anti-Semitism Rears Its Head In Parliament Of Russia
description: Russia's Communists went looking this week for someone to blame for the nation's economic morass, and after an extraordinary discourse freighted with memories of the Soviet past, they found a candidate: the Jews.

title: Chance for Minority Students to Learn How C.E.O.'s Are Made
description: WHEN the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., was assassinated in the spring of 1968, many blacks wept. Others took their sorrow and anger into the streets.

title: A Longtime Builder Carries His Style to 39th Street
description: HOW nice for a landlord to have a tenant like Chet Borgida, a partner in the Grant Thornton accounting firm.

title: A Splendor of Caves
description: It is to an elusive tiger that we owe our rediscovery of the cave temples of Ajanta. A party of British officers, out hunting in 1819, pursued their quarry into a gorge in the thickly wooded Sahyadri Hills of west-central India. The animal retreated into the dense jungle, but the dazzling sun revealed, through the seemingly impenetrable foliage, the outlines of a horseshoe-shaped cave. The British officers followed, crossing a river to investigate -- and soon forgot all about their hunting.

title: A Broadway Newcomer Goes Stride for Stride With Giants
description: THE listing above is fictional, but its contents are not. In 1944 ''On the Town'' introduced the talents of Leonard Bernstein, Jerome Robbins and the writers Betty Comden and Adolph Green to the Broadway stage. Five years later, Hollywood made it into a popular film starring Gene Kelly and Frank Sinatra. While the Public Theater's production in Central Park in the summer of 1997 won mostly favorable reviews, the dances of Eliot Feld were generally considered awkward and conventional. Consequently, George C. Wolfe, the producer of the Public Theater and the musical's director in its current Broadway incarnation, went shopping for a new choreographer.

title: On Language; The E-Lancer Eats a Bagelwich
description: How are new words created? What's the logic behind neologisms? How can you, working at home, coin your own words for fun and profit?

title: Belgium's Window on Staten Island
description: STAPLETON, Staten Island, resembles nothing so much as a Tennessee Williams diva: a faded beauty critically short on cash. The Art Nouveau buildings in its business row are anchored by an O.T.B. parlor, a discount sneaker store and a methadone clinic; the municipal parking lot is a botanist's dream of weed types, and the former Paramount movie palace is now a sporting goods store.

title: POSTINGS: Services and Care for the Elderly; $4 Million Center on First Avenue
description: A two-story building -- in the final stages of a gut-renovation at 1484-86 First Avenue on a tenement-lined block between 77th and 78th Streets -- recently began providing community-based outpatient medical and social services to the elderly.

title: A Palace of Dance Takes Up With a More Practical Muse
description: CITY CENTER used to be a place where, as one critic complained, a cloud of dust rose when Tosca stamped her foot.

title: What Has Celtics' Shares Jumping Through Hoops?
description: Is the stock market telling us that the start of the National Basketball Association season is closer than people involved in the labor fight are letting on?

title: Baby's Own Scent
description: In a city of redundancy, people buy fur coats for their dogs and subscribe to call-forwarding for their cell phones. And now there's infant perfume.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Changes in Medical Science

title: Steaks and TV's Ready Whenever the Knicks Are
description: If the Knicks ever play basketball again, fans will be able to watch them on one of 25 television screens at the Porterhouse Grill, recently opened at 192-13 Union Turnpike (between 192d and 193d Streets) in Fresh Meadows, Queens.

title: Fears of Expansion Pit Neighbors Against Hospital
description: This time last year, Mayra Rivera heard rumors that her apartment was one of five first-floor units at 709 West 169th Street that would have to be demolished to make way for expansion of a day-care center in an adjoining building.

title: Two, With Too Much, For the Road
description: IN the beginning, there was no packing. There weren't even any clothes. If Adam and Eve had not gotten themselves banished from the Garden of Eden, their children and their children's children would not have to decide between taking one pair of underwear and rinsing it out every night, or packing seven, thereby taking up space that might better be used for an all-purpose antibiotic, a current adapter, or an alternate pair of walking shoes. We would all still be naked in Paradise. There wouldn't be any need to get away from it all. As it is, in our fallen state, we must travel endlessly throughout the world collecting frequent-flier points, doomed never to know if we've packed the right stuff.

title: Michigan Humiliates Penn St. and Bewilders Paterno
description: MICHIGAN 27, PENN STATE 0

title: Party Looks to Where It Went Wrong
description: It was a wild week at the office for House Republicans, who, being Republicans, talked a lot after a bruising midterm election, about re-evaluating their company's sudden loss of market share, ''looking at everyone from the C.E.O. to the janitor,'' as Representative J. C. Watts of Oklahoma put it.

title: Finding and Fixing Stair Problems
description: STAIRS tend to creak and squeak over time. This happens when the house settles or the wood ages and shrinks. The noises may seem like a minor nuisance at first, but they can be an indication that structural members have moved out of alignment.

title: Violation for Mishap Is Dropped
description: A Manhattan company, BFC Construction, has been cleared in connection with the near-collapse of a residential building last spring. The city had cited BFC for failing to adequately protect 182 Avenue B (near 12th Street), a tenement next to one site at Del Este Village, a subsidized, six-building, 98-unit condominium development being built for first-time home buyers.

title: Bizball
description: In ''Ryan's Song'' (by Lynn Hirschberg), Leigh Steinberg rationalizes why he can never make his clients as commercially popular as their counterparts in other sports by saying: ''Football is complicated.. . .Basketball is an easier game for women and children to understand.'' I wonder if Ryan Leaf, Troy Aikman, Steve Young and others might be better served by an agent who wouldn't write off half the adult population as less capable than the other half of appreciating the intricacies of a football game. His remark lacks both taste and business sense. Really now, who's calling whom simple-minded?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREENBERG, ABRAHAM H.
description: GREENBERG-Abraham H. Memorial service will be held at the 5th Ave Synagogue, 11 E. 11 St, Nov. 15, 1 PM. He was a two term Chairman of SCORE, teacher of entrepreneurship in the high schools of New York City, philanthropist, father, family mentor.

title: The Worlds of Los Angeles; Dream Design
description: What has always appealed to me about Los Angeles is that this is a city in which one can virtually live outdoors. Especially in the winter, when we New Yorkers encapsulate ourselves in layers of clothing to make brief external forays, Los Angeles can seem like paradise. Yet after earthquakes, riots, traffic and smog, the image of paradise has got a little tarnished. The Los Angeles I wanted to see when I vacationed there recently was mostly built in earlier days, when newcomers were reveling in the freedom from cold and building their dream houses to celebrate that freedom. Since I was going to be seeing buildings that blurred the distinction between inside and outside, I decided it was essential to rent a Mustang convertible. Unfortunately, when I arrived, the weather was freakishly hot, so I kept the top up and the air-conditioning blasting as I headed east to Pasadena.

title: After 120 Years, the Last Apple Falls, and a Family Business With It
description: As always in November, the last of the apples have been picked and crated and the rows of trees visible from Milltown Road in East Brunswick are losing their leaves. But this fall is different from those of the last 120 years, when L. J. Smith Farms sold apples and cider and got ready for another growing season in the spring.

title: Trying to Sway the Vote In Lieu of Negotiations
description: David Stern authorized team officials to explain the owners' proposal to players last week, lifting a moratorium that began July 1. Depending on whose side you are on in the National Basketball Association's labor dispute, it was either a gesture on the league commissioner's part to educate the masses or a scheme to divide the players union.

title: The Capitalist; Dr. Mabuse Returns
description: Fritz Lang's classic 1922 movie, ''Dr. Mabuse, the Gambler,'' begins by showing the arch-villain of the title at work: masterminding robberies, fomenting riots, practicing psychoanalysis and -- of course -- engineering financial-market panics. Economists knew even then that the economic chaos of Weimar Germany had little to do with market manipulation and was basically the fault of a weak government that printed money to cover its deficit. But at the time, the figure of the evil speculator was a powerful cultural icon; everybody believed that such men existed and were the source of many of the world's ills.

title: Nothing but Net
description: Extra Life

title: Issue Passes On School For Disabled
description: By a two-to-one margin, Atlantic County residents on Tuesday approved a nonbinding referendum that will permit freeholders to raise taxes to build a $24 million school in Mays Landing for 650 disabled pupils, ages 3 to 21, now in the three schools of the county's Special Services District.

title: Dr. Neu, Dr. Middlesworth
description: Dr. Natalie Monserrate Neu and Dr. William Middlesworth, assistant attending physicians at Babies and Children's Hospital in New York, were married yesterday at St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Church in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. The Rev. James Smythe performed the ceremony.

title: Lehigh Now Stands Alone
description: Nick Martucci and Brian Wolovich, Lehigh's defensive ends, did not believe that Ryan Vena, Colgate's heralded quarterback, could walk on water. They chased him and chased him today, and caught him often enough to contain the Red Raiders' high-octane offense in a stunning 41-22 victory for the Mountain Hawks before a crowd of 13,432 at Goodman Stadium.

title: Crime
description: There's this boat, see, all sparkly bright and gleaming in the sun, sailing up the Hudson River to Albany. To the New York State legislators who voted to give it a trial run as a riverboat casino, the pretty cruise ship represents a legitimate source of new revenue. But to the bold thieves standing on the shore in Richard Stark's dazzling crime caper Backflash (Mysterious Press/ Warner, $20), the Spirit of the Hudson looks like ''a big shiny white empty box, going upriver to be filled with money.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FOGLER, WILLIAM A.
description: FOGLER-William A. A memorial service to celebrate the life of Dr. William A. Fogler will be held on November 14, 1998 at 11AM at Memorial Hall, Pratt Institute, 200 Willougby Avenue, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLER, RAINER
description: MULLER-Rainer. Friday, December 13, 1941-Friday, October 30, 1998. Passed away in Toronto in the presence and love of his wife Marilyn and his daughters Veruschka and Bianca. He will be dearly missed.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Show of Drawings

title: F.Y.I.
description: Doors of Perception

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EMERY, ADELE HAMMOND OLYP,
description: EMERY-Adele Hammond Olyp- hant. Peacefully at home on November 6, 1998. Wife of the late John K. Olyphant Jr. and John J. Emery. Mother of Adele O. Miller, David Olyphant and J.V. Bevan Olyphant. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to The Visiting Nurse Association of NNJ, 38 Elm St., Morristown, NJ, 07960. Funeral service will be private.

title: A Sudden Case Of Confidence And Relief As Inquiry Looms
description: With Republicans in fratricidal disarray, the White House is preparing a new winter policy offensive and approaching the impeachment inquiry with new confidence that President Clinton can emerge with little or no further damage.

title: Going Down Screaming
description: I am a conservative. But not the kind that supports the moralistic views that the conservative leadership in this country represents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNBACH, LOUIS
description: STERNBACH-Louis, age 90, died on November 1, 1998. He resided in Westport, CT, and Delray Beach, FL, and was both an attorney and CPA. He was married to Ruth Sternbach, recently deceased. He had three children, Dorothy Sternbach, Julia Sternbach, and Willa Rosenberg. He founded the Manhattan Accounting Firm of Louis Sternbach and Company. Funeral arrangements are private.

title: A Pop Post-Modernist Gives Up on Irony
description: BECK sees dead ends everywhere on his new album, ''Mutations.'' Creativity and culture are played out, love has faded away. There aren't even any new jokes to be told. ''Who wants to be there to sweep the debris, to harness dead horses?'' he sings.

title: Top Mouse
description: Work in Progress

title: Recipe for an Upset: Schumer's Sureness, D'Amato's Missteps
description: Fourteen days before Election Day, Charles E. Schumer's campaign manager learned of an article that would appear in the next day's issue of The Jewish Week: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, in a private meeting with supporters, had described Mr. Schumer with a Yiddish vulgarism and mocked another lawmaker from New York City for being overweight.

title: Fantastic Voyagers
description: Six intrepid pre-jet setters. Match letter and number

title: Risotto Made Colorful and Mellow With Vegetables
description: AUTUMN produce counters and farm stands brimming with bright but sturdy vegetables offer inspiration for risotto. The basic risotto principle -- gradually adding stock to the plump, short-grain rice that absorbs it and becomes toothsome -- applies no matter what.

title: Queens Man Is Charged In Sex Assaults on Girls
description: A Queens man was arrested yesterday on charges of sexually assaulting three girls over a period of months, the police said.

title: November 1-7; In Search of Identity
description: A prize-winning memoir of Holocaust survival has ignited an international debate about the legal identity of the author, Binjamin Wilkomirksi. His book, ''Fragments,'' recalls a childhood in concentration camps, but his adoption records say he is Swiss born, and not a Latvian Jew. He has declined DNA testing, saying it is inaccurate. DOREEN CARVAJAL

title: Mussels, Frites and Beer, Belgian Style
description: THE culinary dictionary defines waterzooi as a ''creamy-rich fish stew.'' Long Islanders are beginning to know it as a splendid new Belgian bistro in Garden City. Here its namesake dish is offered along with almost every food that visitors to Belgium encounter: mussels, french fries, endive, carbonade flamande (beer-spiked beef stew), brussels sprouts, asparagus, waffles, chocolates and, of course, beer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOHL, HENRY H.
description: WOHL-Henry H. January 4, 1922October 25, 1998. Ave atque vale. Farewell to ''The mayor of Cherry Grove''. Gadfly for all the right reasons, we loved your sense of humor, your politics and your understanding of how the world works. We will miss your irreverent opinions & your wise counsel. Barry Burros and Vincent Menill

title: Yankees in the Belfry
description: MY FIRST COUSIN ONCE REMOVED Money, Madness, and the Family of Robert Lowell. By Sarah Payne Stuart. Illustrated. 244 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $25.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   REACH, BARBARA
description: REACH-Barbara November 8, 1992. Lovingly remembered. Deeply missed E

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: In the Region / Long Island; Quality Rentals for Aging Moderate-Income Tenants
description: VISITORS at the 156-unit Riverhead Landing under construction here in a pastoral setting on Middle Road often do a double take. Even though the entrance sign clearly states that the 50-acre development is a ''senior rental community'' many feel there must be some mistake.

title: Without Focus on Gingrich, Rivalries Engulf the G.O.P.
description: A day after Speaker Newt Gingrich's abrupt resignation, the race for House Speaker was far from settled and Republicans predicted today that the roiling competition would soon engulf most of the top positions in the House Republican hierarchy.

title: More Bullishness From the Dean of Bulls
description: The stars seem to have fallen back into alignment for Abby Joseph Cohen, the Goldman, Sachs investment strategist. Ms. Cohen, the bard of the bull market, was promoted to partner at her firm last month. And, for the first time since summer, her relentlessly upbeat forecasts for stock prices seem in tune with investor sentiment.

title: November 1-7; Parenting Help Is Just a Click Away
description: The moment comes to every parent. The baby won't sleep. The toddler won't toddle. The middle-schooler can't get herself out the door to school on time. The high-schooler demands to be taken to the mall -- again. And the parent, heaving a sigh and searching the ceiling for answers, wails, ''What do I do now?''

title: Ideas & Trends; Monticello's Other Children
description: IF family trees are sometimes truncated by missing dates or ancestors, think about last week's discovery that Thomas Jefferson had neatly sawed off a branch. A report in last week's issue of Nature said Jefferson did father at least one child, Eston Hemings, with Sally Hemings, his black and comely slave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEAKE, F.R. ''ROBIN''
description: PEAKE-F.R. ''Robin'' Age 85. Died of cancer on November 1st in Tequesta, FL. Born in Racine, WI, the eldest son of William W. and Betty R. Peake, Robin spent his early life in Rye, NY, where he attended Rye Country Day School. He later graduated from the Hotchkiss School, from Yale College in 1935, and Yale Law School in 1938, when he commenced his life-long career with Union Carbide Corporation. Entering military service in 1940 as a Second Lieutenant, he served with the 187th Field Artillery in France and Germany, he rose to Lt. Colonel and earned the Bronze Star. Resuming his career, he lived in Chicago for several years before returning to New York, when he took residence in Pelham Manor, NY. Following his retirement he established seasonal homes in East Dorset, VT and Tequesta. Besides his beloved wife, the former Gertrude Bradford Preston, he leaves two stepsons, Frederick and William; two brothers, Cameron and David; a sister, Alison Henning; and a host of friends in East Dorset, Chicago, Camden, SC and the NY area. Burial will be held in the family plot in Aurora, NY at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please send any memorial donations to The Hotchkiss School, Lakeville, CT. 06039.

title: Holiday Lights Will Twinkle Only When Town Says They Can
description: It won't begin to look a lot like Christmas in Bedminster Township until 30 days before the holiday and it will stop looking that way 20 days later, if the Township Committee enacts an ordinance introduced last week.

title: Trees That Dazzle Not Once but Twice
description: I CALL them two-season trees. They are the kind whose foliage is aflame at this time of year and whose branches are decked with beautiful, often fragrant flowers in spring or summer. They offer shade and splendor, providing a handsome return from a horticultural budget.

title: November Deal Undercuts Fares
description: IN July, a researcher in the Travel Section came up with a question. Sabena was offering a restricted ticket for a round trip to Brussels for $904, which qualified as the best price on that route. However, he said Sabena also had a package trip, with hotel, for $830. How can this be, he asked.

title: Style; The Display's the Thing
description: Plenty of creative people are tragic neurotic exhibitionist psychos. How many boast about it on their resumes? Born in the permanent drizzle of Reading, England, circa 1952, Simon Doonan was raised in a family replete with absurdist potential. Sharing a house with his parents and sister were a lobotomized grandmother, a blind aunt with a succession of Seeing Eye dogs and a schizophrenic uncle who kept a souvenir three-inch toenail under the bed. The young Doonan's aspirations were, as he explains in his delirious new memoirs, ''Confessions of a Window Dresser,'' neither professional nor unprofessional. A self-proclaimed ''gay half-wit with no future,'' he had just two goals: ''Not to go raving mad like the rest of the family and not to end up working in one of the local factories.'' Doonan narrowly escaped the latter fate by heading for New York, by way of London and L.A. It wasn't until hitting Manhattan, however, that he stopped shirking his psychic legacy and embraced his destiny as the fox-crazy impresario of Barneys' notorious windows.

title: Midterm Elections: A Vote for Moderation?; Impeachment's Status
description: To the Editor:

title: Amy Cooper and Joshua Klaris
description: Amy Lynn Cooper, a daughter of Inga and Richard Cooper 3d of Medford, N.J., was married last evening to Joshua James Klaris, a son of Alice B. Klaris and Harvey J. Klaris, both of New York. The Rev. James Only, a Congregational minister, officiated at the Park View restaurant at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman took part in the ceremony.

title: PULSE; Must-Have: Ugly Shoes -- His
description: From the ankles up, Derrick Torres dresses like the average 16-year-old -- in loose jeans and an untucked shirt. His feet, however, look as if they belong to a social studies teacher in the 1970's. He wears sand-colored Wallabees, the boxy suede moccasins introduced in 1965 by Clarks and favored by librarians and other wearers of ''sensible shoes.''

title: The View From/The Norwalk River; Big Plans to Improve A Watershed's Health
description: WEARING knee-high boots and wielding sledgehammers, Ed Vallerie and Todd Bobowick pounded a 10-foot-long log into the subsoil beneath the Norwalk River near what is known as Schenck's Island in Wilton, close to the town's main business center.

title: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY; Dreams of Working At Very Different Desks
description: Having second thoughts about your chosen occupation?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAGLEY, FAYE
description: BAGLEY-Faye. The Board of Directors, Administration, Medical Board, and staff of Peninsula Hospital Center are saddened by the passing of Faye Bagley. Sincere condolences are extended to her daughter, Nancy Vardakis, distinguished member of the Board of Directors, and to the Vardakis and Tsatsis families. Joel A. Miele, Sr., P.E., Chairman, Board of Directors Robert V. Levine, President & Chief Executive Officer Leonard E. Schiffman, DMD, President, Medical Board

title: November 1-7; As States Took On Tobacco, Cities May Go After Guns
description: The battle over gun control entered a major new phase as New Orleans became the first American city to sue firearms manufacturers, seeking millions of dollars for the cost of gun violence. Philadelphia, Chicago and Los Angeles are expected to follow. This novel way to combat crime may put the gun industry under the kind of pressure tobacco companies have been facing from states. FOX BUTTERFIELD

title: Streetscapes / 19-25 St. Marks Place; The Eclectic Life of a Row of East Village Houses
description: IN the cavernous former Electric Circus discotheque on St. Marks Place, the Rev. Joyce Hartwell is locked in an unusual battle against social problems as she seeks a developer to build a hotel tower.

title: Ian Rosenthal and Kathleen Tait
description: Kathleen Mavis Tait, a daughter of Emily Stevens Tait of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., and Eric V. Tait Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Ian Anthony Rosenthal, a son of Lavinia Rosenthal and Alan Rosenthal, both of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Anthony Roberts, an Anglican priest, performed the nondenominational ceremony in Warwick, Bermuda.

title: Energy Plan Gets a Lift In California
description: DEREGULATION of the electricity industry dodged a bullet when California voters thumpingly defeated Proposition 9 last Tuesday, 73 percent to 27 percent, to the industry's great relief. The complex model of competition introduced in California last year is now free to proceed there and in other states.

title: New Shelf Life: 2 Libraries Closing for Renovations
description: On a recent Monday evening, Julio C. Carela sat at the far end of the Inwood Regional Library, his back turned toward a group of children doing homework, his head tucked in a book about Eva Peron.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Jude A Pilgrimage to the Saint of Last Resort. By Liz Trotta. HarperSanFrancisco, $24.

title: Midterm Elections: A Vote for Moderation?; Campaign Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets Try to Put Special Back Into Special Teams
description: Their reputation seems to have outrun them.

title: From Lebanon, Generous and Affordable
description: YUMMY'S is a restaurant that lives up to its name. This uniquely Long Island Lebanese storefront spot, at 591 Main Street, Islip (224-1663), is the creation of Nick and Heldie Assaly, who came to this country from Beirut. About five years ago, they opened a deli and grocery in Islip and three years later the modest Yummy's Cafe began doing business next door. In an adjoining kitchen, the deli churns out its kebabs, gyros, souvlakis, moussakas and spanakopitas, all of which can be prepared to take out.

title: Bizball
description: As an English ex-patriot, and a mad-eyed zealot for cricket who has lived and worked in the American South for the past five years, I thoroughly enjoyed Tunku Varadarajan's amusing reflections on cricket aficionados who choose to live stateside (Lives: ''A Sticky Wicket''). I, too, have engaged in the tawdry ritual of stalking fellow ex-pats and begging them to ''talk cricket'' with me. I am grateful to know that there is at least one other person who aches for the sound of leather on willow!

title: A Power Racer Is Rolling Into Key West Title Event
description: It was two years between barrel rolls for Matt Alcone, the champion offshore powerboat racer. But a repeat of the 100-mile-per-hour boating accident that broke his resolve in 1996 did little more than make him mad nine days ago. Now it's on to the world championship this week in Key West, Fla., and with not much of a backward glance.

title: A Not So Merry-Go-Round?
description: Rather than the nostril-flaring steeds of yore, the hand-carved figures on a wooden carousel being built in Willowbrook Park will represent endangered and wild animals. Tigers, gorillas, leopards and giraffes will chase each other on the carousel, which is to open next spring.

title: Honoring Those Who Once Were Warriors
description: THE near-life-size wood carving of a Maori warrior exudes raw power. The eyes, made of shells, gleam white with seeming rage against the tatooed face, and the large, claw-like hands and the short, thick, muscular legs project brute strength. The figure depicts an ancestor of a Maori chief and symbolizes the pride of a tribe.

title: Mycology Today
description: Inevitably, the mushroom at the bottom of the cloth bag that a forager wears slung across his chest is an indestructible one. Not only must it bear the weight of all the other mushrooms piled on top of it, it must also withstand the heat of an open fire. The delicate chanterelle will wither and disintegrate. But the porcini, the shiitake, the puff ball and the hedgehog will not disappoint.

title: Surprises at the Polls, And a Ripple Effect
description: Ramifications of the most surprising midterm election in recent memory are still sinking in. Even as the voters were yawning at Washington's yearlong obsession with the President's sex life, they opened a host of unexpected new questions about the future political climate for business and the economy.

title: Happy Rappy Birthday
description: Parties for the arts, a record impresario and more: a city opens its heart and its wallet.

title: Should You Bristle at These Hedges?
description: IT'S not the sort of thing they are likely to trumpet in newspaper ads or in 30-second television spots, but increasingly, mutual fund companies are muscling into the hedge-fund business.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Oct. 25 listing New York places that are said to be haunted misidentified Benjamin Sonnenberg, who owned one such site, a mansion at 19 Irving Place. He was a corporate public relations consultant, not a theater publicity agent.

title: SOAPBOX; The Five-Borough Anniversary Tour
description: MAYBE it's because we were married ''late in life'' (we were both approaching 40) that we have always sought memorable ways to mark our anniversary.

title: Regents Exam Draws Murmurs And Preparation
description: SOME cheered. Others booed. But few disagreed that education standards in the state need to be raised. So it went at Mount Vernon High School and other schools in Westchester last week as students and educators prepared for the two-day, six-hour language arts Regents exam to be given in the spring -- the first test in a phase-in of higher graduation standards set by the state.

title: The Education of 35,000 Landholders
description: ON a chilly fall afternoon, with the shadows lengthening across the northwest hills, 30 Connecticut landowners found themselves bouncing over miles of rough logging roads in the Great Mountain Forest near Norfolk, bound for the Yale School of Forestry summer camp. They came equipped with sleeping bags, hiking boots, and extra pens and lined notebooks, ready for a free four-day crash course in timber and wildlife management offered the Coverts Project.

title: ASIANITUDE
description: * This weekend, New York University plays host to Public Displays of Asianness, the first conference devoted to the influence of Asian-Americans on American pop culture. * P.D.A. kicks off Friday night with a round table at the hip Joseph Papp Public Theater; speakers include Richard Fung, a filmmaker, and Rekha Malhotra, a famed deejay. * Saturday panels plumb topics like Filipino-American tattoos and the party circuit of South Asian immigrants. * The conference wraps up with a party, called ''Pleasure Principles,'' at the Cooler. There, the Asian drag ''king'' Selena Whang will strut her stuff. * Why is Asian gender-bending of scholarly interest? ''Cross-gender performance is a venerated genre of art in many ancient Asian traditions,'' says Andrew Ross, an N.Y.U. professor, who cites Chinese opera. ''It is certainly not something of recent vintage.''

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: What About Team?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Michelle Alpert, Saul Wisnia
description: Dr. Michelle Joyce Alpert and Saul Ethan Wisnia were married last evening by Rabbi Efry Spectre at Adat Shalom Synagogue in Farmington Hills, Mich.

title: Office Politics
description: THE FATE OF THE UNION America's Rocky Road to Political Stalemate. By Robert Shogan. 332 pp. Boulder, Colo.: Westview Press. $27.95.

title: Hats Off to New Idea, A Park and Fly Lot
description: THE budget was tight, and so are some of the loops performed on the blacktop surface, but a grass-roots campaign has turned the Mount Kisco Skate Park into a reality.

title: OPINION; D'Amato's Fall, and the Cost to L.I.
description: FOR 18 years, voters and the media have become accustomed to Long Island's Senator Al Alfonse M. D'Amato arriving at a news conference with a large oversize check under his arm, a symbol of the latest Federal grant he was able to bring home. His ability to shake the Capitol Hill money tree became legendary, creating political alliances with Democrats that included New York's Edward I. Koch and those who ran Albany and Buffalo. On Long Island, we saw Federal dollars for everything from roads and rails to beach replenishment and cancer research.

title: Sarah Mitchell, Keith Legins
description: Sarah Otis Mitchell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Mitchell of Irvington, N.Y., was married yesterday to Keith John Legins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth E. Legins of Plymouth, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Charles R. Colwell performed the ceremony at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Irvington.

title: Ministering to the Flock at a Racetrack
description: JUST before 11 on a crisp Sunday morning, cars trickled into the parking lot at Belmont Race Track. At the grandstand, gamblers were waiting to place their first bets. Over in the barn area, freshly groomed horses whinnied in their stalls. Finished with his morning chores, Phil Horn, a trainer from Floral Park, hurried from the stables to the recreation hall. A jockey agent, Ralph Theroux Sr., conditions book stuffed in his pocket, was already there, seeking salvation on the backstretch before the races began.

title: Ideas & Trends; For Finance Ministers, These Are Perilous Times
description: THIS is supposed to be the Age of the Finance Minister. In the mythology of the 1990's, they are the titans of this unnamed era following the post-cold war. In many countries these days, the guardians of the treasury are running the show.

title: In America; In the War Zone
description: There are times when Dr. Warren Hern feels more like a combat veteran than a physician. Here is what he says about a normal workday: ''I walk out of my office and the first thing I do is look at the parking garage that the hospital built two doors away and see if there is a sniper on the roof. I basically expect to be shot any day.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, IVAN
description: SHAPIRO-Ivan. The Graduate School and University Center of The City University of New York mourns the passing of Ivan Shapiro, a mainstay and former Vice Chairman of the GSUC Board of Visitors. We benefited greatly from his faith in the larger vision, his generosity of spirit, his commitment and his support. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Frances Degen Horowitz, Pres.

title: Lots of 'Yes' Votes for Open Space
description: In Morris County, residents of Jefferson Township had been rallying against plans to build a 650-unit senior citizen development at the edge of forested highlands. In Hopewell, many people opposed a nine-mile sewer pipeline that would allow an office park to be built where cornfields now lie. In Colts Neck and Middletown, residents were hoping to protect scenic horse country from an onslaught of new construction.

title: A World of Celebration; Jerusalem: Hanukkah
description: Jerusalem always has a special relationship with light -- the sun glancing off soft white stone by day and floodlights bathing its monuments by evening.

title: For Borrowers, Low Rates Pique Interest
description: WITH the recent cuts in interest rates, these have been intense, nerve-jangling times for mortgage shoppers and lenders alike.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Hudson Heights; High Above Hudson, a Crowd of Co-ops
description: TWO new restaurants are the talk of this neighborhood running along the hills overlooking the Hudson River in the northwest corner of Washington Heights.

title: A Remote Shore
description: To the Editor: I went to Tofino, British Columbia, in September, with ''Rambles Along a Remote Shore'' (July 19) in hand. I want to add a few recommendations to the article's excellent information.

title: At the Heart of Protests to Con Ed: The Schools
description: IT was not the first protest march against the Indian Point nuclear power plants here. But for this small village, which is home to three of the four nuclear plants in the state, the 800 or so people who turned out recently were not shouting warnings about radioactive meltdown or demanding that the plants be shut down. Instead, among the slogans shouted and the signs carried were these: ''Con Ed Is a Tax Dodger,'' ''Con Ed -- Con Men,'' ''Don't Nuke Our Taxes'' and ''Con Ed -- Don't Turn the Lights Out on My Education!''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: THE ROAD TO THE ISLAND

title: A World of Celebration; New York City: Christmas
description: In my childhood memory of Washington there is a whole field of Christmas trees between the White House and the Washington Monument; and I've long imagined that Nome, Alaska, has real, live reindeer. But New York City has itself. Here, buildings become full-size holiday ornaments, with red-and-green bows creating festive street-level cornices. The skyline-in-a-paperweight look is enhanced by lavish displays of mechanical figures, toys and other delights for children in department store windows. And an outsized snowflake of sparkling white lights hangs above the intersection of Fifth Avenue and 57th Street. From a block or two away the bulbs seem to float in the air. That's the point: The snowflake is not a Christmas decoration, it's part of the cityscape.

title: Midterm Elections: A Vote for Moderation?; Marriage on the Ballot
description: To the Editor:

title: Habitats / Bedford Corners, N.Y.; Bringing a House Back To the Way It Was
description: MOST people would have just fixed up the big old house and moved into its sun-filled rooms.

title: Corrections
description: A caption in the matching quiz in the Education Life section last Sunday about New York City public school graduates misidentified the alma mater of Bess Myerson, shown as No. 1, and of Diahann Carroll, No. 3. It was the High School of Music and Art, not the High School of Performing Arts. Another section of the quiz misstated the graduation year of Arthur Mitchell, founder of the Dance Theater of Harlem, from the High School of Performing Arts. It was 1952, not 1963.

title: Uncovering Lost Pages of Jewish History in New Jersey
description: WHO -- Harry Gershenowitz, professor emeritus of biology at Rowan University who is an amateur archeologist specializing in lost Jewish communities in New Jersey.

title: The Speed Demon Anand Leaves His Rivals Behind
description: The top players of every epoch, particularly the world champions, have almost certainly been as gifted in speed play as in standard time-limit games. The records are fragmentary, mostly anecdotal, and there were no formal championships, indeed hardly any transcripts of the moves. Still, contemporaries agree that Emanuel Lasker was the best before Capablanca came along at the beginning of the 1920's and that Reuben Fine was dominant in the 40's, Tigran Petrosian in the 50's and 60's, Bobby Fischer in the early 70's (he won the world five-minute championship in 1970), Anatoly Karpov in the 70's after Fischer left the field, and Gary Kasparov from the late 80's on.

title: U.S. Inquiry Asks if City Deprives Poor
description: Federal officials say New York City's new welfare policies may improperly deprive thousands of poor people of access to food and medical assistance, and they have begun reviewing the public assistance programs to determine whether they violate Federal law.

title: The World; How Nations Run: Disasters as a Guide
description: ANATURAL disaster as terrible as Hurricane Mitch, which killed more than 10,000 people in Central America in the past two weeks and left nearly a million more homeless, teaches a lot about the way a society does or does not work. Some institutions and individuals rise to the occasion; others topple like palm trees in the wind. But the nations of the region always seem to respond in ways that illuminate their history and character.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: The Specter of Hitler in the Music of Wagner
description: MORE than a century after the death of Richard Wagner, his achievements bristle, unabated, with the most controversial associations. Witness the Overture to ''Rienzi,'' which opens Giuseppe Sinopoli's Wagner program with the Dresden Staatskapelle on Friday evening at Carnegie Hall.

title: Julia Pirkey, Gordon Stone
description: Julia Hope Pirkey, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Thomas Pirkey of Austin, Tex., was married there yesterday to Gordon Franklin Stone, the son of Louise Schrade Stone of Wayne, Pa., and Jerry L. Stone of Greenville, Del. The Rev. Dr. Laura Mendenhall performed the ceremony at Westminster Presbyterian Church.

title: If You Like the Sound, Check Out the Clothes
description: Here's a new approach: a store named not for a geographical region, for the owner or even to inform.

title: Rangers Have Enough Offense, but Defense Rests
description: The Rangers' six-goal explosion tonight doubled their previous high for offense this season. But it still was not enough to beat the Maple Leafs.

title: Well-Drilled Indiana Overwhelms Seton Hall in Opener
description: Within minutes, the first game of this National Collegiate Athletic Association men's basketball season became a camp clinic. The Indiana Hoosiers played the role of teacher and, with all the tenderness of a military commander, forced the Seton Hall Pirates into the role of the aggravated pupil.

title: Tommy Flowers, 92, Dies; Broke Nazi Codes
description: Tommy Flowers, a British civil servant with a genius for electronics whose pioneering Colossus computers enabled the Allies to decode top-level German military communications in World War II, died on Oct. 28 at his home in London. He was 92.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture last Sunday, showing Amelia Garcia and her children, carried an incorrect credit. The picture was by Thomas Dallal for The New York Times, not for The Daily News.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAGENDORF, STEVEN
description: JAGENDORF-Steven. You were special and your departure is and will be greatly missed by those close to you and those who loved you. I too will miss our pleasant phone chats and whatever bits we shared during our brief friendship. You are now in peace I pray and can share this peace with the few beautiful people you have joined. Love, Claire

title: With a New Grand Central, Memories of the Old
description: Want to memorialize your personal recollections of Grand Central Terminal for all to see on the World Wide Web? Then hasten to the station, where -- through this Thursday -- the Municipal Art Society is co-host of a multimedia exhibition that will let you do just that.

title: Islamic Group Says It Set Car Bomb In Jerusalem
description: The militant Palestinian movement Islamic Holy War said today that it carried out the suicide bombing in a Jerusalem market on Friday, which prompted arrests by the Palestinian Authority overnight.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 8, 1998
description: Weeks

title: The View From/Mamaroneck; A Doctor Whose Giving Doesn't End at the Office
description: DR. KEVIN MALONEY is an anachronism. In an age when doctors seem increasingly impersonal and difficult to reach even on the telephone, 47-year-old Dr. Maloney is just this side of startling. He loves to talk -- in fact, he talks a lot; he is friendly and casual; he gives his home phone number to patients. He even concedes to a couple of personal weaknesses; he is hooked on cigarettes (''I tell people never get started because it is really a terrible addiction,'' he said) and in a day consumes five or six extra-large Coffee Coolattas from the Dunkin' Donuts near his office here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRITZ, DAVID
description: FRITZ-David. Age 78. Of Great Neck, died suddenly, at peace, on November 3. Economist, scholar, reader, writer, walker, world traveler. Father of Paul and Norma. Husband of the late Blanche Asher. Greatly loved.

title: Fish Size Limits And the English Patent
description: I wish to clarify two points contained in an article concerning the defense of my rights to fish according to the Nicoll and Dongan Patents for East Hampton Town [''Is This Guy a Threat to the Rules, or the Fish?'' Oct. 18].

title: A World of Celebration; Scotland: Hogmany
description: Hogmanay, the Scottish New Year, is as precious to the celebration-loving Scots as Burns Night, that great winter evening devoted to singing, eating haggis and toasting the immortal Bard, as Robert Burns is called. Dating from pagan times, when it was a commemoration of the winter solstice and a festival of gratitude toward the sun, Hogmanay was great in stature during the mid-17th century, when the Puritan government banned Christmas and the Scots turned to New Year's Eve as an alternative midwinter partying date.

title: A Piling-On Penalty
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRYER, RICHARD
description: BRYER-Richard. 33 years ago you went away. You live in my heart always and forever, my precious son. Mom

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULVIHILL, CHARLES J.
description: MULVIHILL-Charles J. 84, October 15, 1998. Detroit musician, Golden Gloves medalist, Ford Motor Company administrator. Husband of Esther Byrne. Father of Charles, Daniel (Virginia), Maureen (Daniel R. Harris), Karen, Lawrence, Thomas, James, John (Sandra), Francis (Susan). Grandfather of Myles, Shanley, Maria, John, Anna. ''A man in his eighth decade takes stock,'' wrote Mulvihill. ''My capital is large. Not because of what I've accomplished, but for what I leave behind. My legacy is seven sons and two daughters, many quite successful.'' A man of broad talent and enterprise, the deceased was a successful pugilist in the 1920's; the manager of and drummer in the Blue Notes, a Detroit society band, 1930's-1950's; and, for 38 years, an administrator at Ford. His life was celebrated, with pipers, at a well attended wake, Livonia, Michigan. Memorial Mass, Lady Chapel, St. Patrick's Cathedral, Manhattan, November 12, 1998.

title: Dining Preludes For Show at BAM
description: ACADIA PARISH +

title: Big Collective Push Preceded Gingrich's Big Fall, Some Republicans Recall
description: By midday Friday, having tried everything from cocky optimism to naked threats, Speaker Newt Gingrich sounded uncharacteristically desperate in private pleas to his once euphorically loyal House troops that they not abandon him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNER, MARJORIE H.S.
description: TURNER-Marjorie H.S., 87 of Palm Beach, Florida, on November 5. Beloved mother of James A. Harris, Charles Schlesinger, Jr., and Lewis Turner, Jr. Loving grandmother of Theodore and James Harris, Jennifer and Emily Turner, and John Schlesinger. Born in NYC, graduate of the NY School of Fine Arts. During WWII, served as a volunteer ambulance driver for the Red Cross. A John Powers model, and long time Board member of Irvington House in NY. Former President of the Quills of Palm Beach. Memorial service to be arranged. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Hospice of Palm Beach, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL. 33407.

title: Wendy Stone, Arthur Long
description: Wendy Elizabeth Stone and Arthur Scott Long were married yesterday at the United Church of Christ in Keene, N.H. The Rev. Robert C. Hamm performed the ceremony.

title: Hold 'Em Or Fold 'Em: Betting On Pairs
description: DEALS, deals and more deals. Despite the summer riot in financial markets, 1998 may be remembered as the Year of the Deal.

title: Mary Howard, Keiron Hylton
description: Mary Frances Howard and Keiron Eyre George Hylton were married yesterday by the Rev. John W. McHugh at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Branford, Conn.

title: Dawn Adelson and Gerald Brunk
description: Dawn Starr Adelson was married yesterday to Gerald Albert Brunk in Sandwich, Mass. The Rev. William S. Geertz performed the ceremony at the First Church of Christ.

title: November 1-7; A New Arthritis Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved the first drug created by biotechnology to treat rheumatoid arthritis. Enbrel, developed by Immunex Corporation of Seattle, seems more effective than existing drugs and with fewer side effects. ANDREW POLLACK

title: A Fertile Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: Jessica Alecci, Sean Cunningham
description: Jessica Merritt Alecci, a financial consultant for Merrill Lynch & Company, was married on Friday to Sean Bryan Cunningham, an executive vice president and the media director of Ammirati Puris Lintas, the advertising agency in New York. Mayor Eileen Pilla of Tarrytown, N.Y., officiated at Tappan Hill there.

title: Image Enhancement
description: Anyone who has ever sat through a show of someone's vacation slides will appreciate the value of a new free guide, Magellan's Passport to Travel Photography. The 16-page booklet includes advice on avoiding postcard views, telling a story in pictures and shooting better travel videos.

title: N.F.L. Finds Labor Peace That Eluded Others
description: Early last week, as National Basketball Association union members were exchanging venom with Commissioner David Stern because of their league's 100-day-plus lockout, their National Football League counterparts were signing off on the collective-bargaining agreement players and owners ratified months ago. It took that long to pore over, paragraph by paragraph, a 140-plus page document that guaranteed labor peace in football through 2003.

title: November 1-7; A New Pill for Staying Awake
description: Sleep may be, as Samuel Coleridge once observed, ''a gentle thing,'' but Americans don't get nearly enough of it. And in a perpetually sleep-deprived country, staying awake is big business, lining drugstore shelves with wake-up pills and sleeping potions, and filling the cash registers at Starbucks.

title: For Problem Stairs, Quick and Not-So-Quick Fixes
description: STAIRS tend to creak and squeak over time. This happens when the house settles or the wood ages and shrinks. The noises may seem like a minor nuisance at first, but they can be an indication that structural members have moved out of alignment.

title: Small but Voracious Beetle Threatens Chicago's Trees
description: A small, black, tree-killing beetle, first detected in New York more than two years ago, has found its way to Chicago, where agriculture officials say it has infested hundreds of trees. It is only the second known infestation in the United States.

title: Treasures From Ancient Edo in Washington
description: Japan, 1615-1868: For the first time in centuries, the country was united under the Tokugawa shoguns, who governed during a period of unprecedented peace and prosperity from their new capital, Edo, which grew into the world's largest city in the 18th century and is now Tokyo.

title: Wrap's New Beat
description: Once the signature of elegant Upper East Side matrons strolling on a breezy autumn day, the cashmere cape has lowered its age and status requirements. This fall, wool capes have been surfacing everywhere, on the shoulders of uptowners and downtowners, the cool and the merely chilly.

title: Use What Works
description: To the Editor:

title: The Price of Silence
description: To the Editor:

title: On Malta, History Is Carved in Stone
description: LIKE the map of a storybook country: that was my first thought. I was standing on a high cliff on the southwest coast of Malta, looking across the gently tilted landscape toward Valletta, nine miles away. Here and there, the spires and domes of ancient towns rose up. To the north, stood the twin cities of Rabat and Mdina and the turreted, square Verdala palace sitting jauntily above Malta's only forest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULTZ, ABRAHAM
description: SHULTZ-Abraham, November 5, 1998. Beloved husband of Cecile, loving father of Ellen and Stuart and his wife Cherida. Cherished and beloved grandfather of Simon and Oliver, devoted brother of Meyer and Manny Shultz. Service Sunday, November 8, 1998 10:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, ISIDORE
description: STRAUSS-Isidore. Died November 7, 1998, at age 86. Beloved father, grandfather, husband, companion, brother and friend. Dearly loved by all whose lives he touched. We all cherish his memory and know he will be in our hearts forever. Poppa, we miss you and love you. Services today, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: City to Speed Applications For Welfare
description: A Federal inquiry into Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's new welfare policies has prompted his administration to speed up the granting of applications for food and medical benefits, the city's top welfare official said yesterday.

title: Palestinians Must Vote to Revoke Charter
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIZZARRI, LOUISE T.
description: BIZZARRI-Louise T. Age 92, on November 6, 1998. Lifetime City resident and 33 year employee of Fox Wells & Co. Survived by her nephew Walter Bender and two nieces, Winona Johnson and Marilyn Nelson. For information, contact Robertaccio Funeral Home, Inc., Patchogue, NY.

title: Jailed Israelis: A Spy Fiasco Or a Warning By Cyprus?
description: The arrest of two Israelis on suspicion of spying on a military installation in Cyprus had a comic caper element that immediately raised questions here about whether it was the latest in a series of bungles by the Israeli intelligence agency Mossad.

title: Steinbeck's Ill-Fated Gathering Of Lost Souls
description: Like all of contemporary music, American opera has many currents and tributaries, and any blanket assertions about it will quickly draw shouts of contradiction. But an important school of thought about this repertory, rooted to some extent in a Germanic and Russian conception of opera, holds that American opera will resonate most strongly if it is linked to American literature. This philosophy was eventually supplanted by one in which recent news events attained primacy as operatic subject matter, but between the 1940's and the 70's, several works were based on American novels, plays and short stories.

title: Freeways Are the 'Field of Dreams' for Special Interests
description: To the Editor:

title: A Look at Voting Patterns of 115 Demographic Groups in House Races
description: After a year dominated by scandal in the White House and an inquiry into the impeachment of the President, Democrats made unexpected Congressional gains on Election Day, picking up five seats in the House and not losing any ground in the Senate.

title: Men Behind the Scenes Of Antiquity's Carnage
description: GATES OF FIRE

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Vigor and Clarity

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORENS, ROSELLE ROEMER
description: ORENS-Roselle Roemer. Of New York City, formerly of Paterson, NJ. Widow of Mitchell A. Orens. She is survived by two daughters, Sheila Rowe of New York City, and Lydia Bos of Norwich, VT; grandchildren Jacqueline Witmondt, Douglas Rowe, Erica Callahan and William Bos; sisters Belle Harrison, Claire Blazer; as well as nieces, nephews and grand-nieces and grand-nephews. Service will be private.

title: Angels Said to Surpass $72 Million for Vaughn
description: While the Anaheim Angels, with an offer to Mo Vaughn, have shown that huge contracts will be available for the elite free agents this winter, those contracts will not be forthcoming from one team that had been expected to be a player in the market.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in ''Straight to Video'' in Weekend on Oct. 30 misstated the title of Christian Faber's film about Broadway dancers. It is ''The Next Step,'' not ''The Last Dance.''

title: Francisco Sainz, 75, Painter In Abstract Expressionist Mode
description: Francisco Sainz, an artist and member of the Abstract Expressionist circle in New York City and East Hampton, N.Y., died on Oct. 20 in East Hampton. He was 75.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: From Twists and Turns

title: A Distinguished Instructor Is as Close as Your Mouse
description: Nowadays the Internet provides almost everything. Bridge players can play the game, on OKbridge and other networks, get information on Web sites, and now take lessons to sharpen their skills. Bridge Today University offers courses via E-mail that permit students to ask questions of the professors. The charge is $49 for 11 lessons. Information is available at (800) 525-4718 or by E-mailing matt@bridgetoday.com.

title: Glitch Not Due to ABC Strike
description: The glitch that caused Channel 7's transmission of Saturday's Michigan State-Ohio State game to go blank and then to go to a commercial break late in the fourth quarter was not a result of the strike by technicians against ABC-TV, a spokesman for ABC Sports said yesterday.

title: Disarming a Giant: U.S. Case Stresses Anticompetitive Pattern by Microsoft
description: As its antitrust trial moves into the fourth week, the Microsoft Corporation finds itself trying to deflect a flood of charges of threats and bribes. The litany of shameful misconduct, according to the Government, was directed not only at Microsoft's rivals but just about everyone in the industry -- including personal computer makers, Internet service suppliers and others.

title: Patents; New blood test is reported to measure the severity of jaundice in newborn babies.
description: AS many as 80,000 infants in the United States are hospitalized annually for the treatment of jaundice -- a condition common among newborns and one known for the yellow cast it gives it to the skin.

title: In Jefferson-Hemings Tie, a Family's Pride; Tenable Conclusions
description: To the Editor:

title: Candidate for Speaker Takes Cautious Impeachment Stance
description: The front-runner to be the next Speaker of the House said today that lawmakers should consider public sentiment that President Clinton has not committed impeachable offenses, even as a House panel prepared to begin impeachment hearings on Monday.

title: Montclair's Endless Film Festival; Drawn to Quaint Town, Ad Makers Spark Complaints
description: This town is so picture perfect, the houses have booking agents.

title: Magazine's 'Little Joke' Has Promoter Fuming
description: When does a magazine go too far?

title: Sports of The Times; What Went Wrong? Too Many Mistakes
description: THE Giants can relax now, with their quest for a second straight dream season all but ended yesterday in a 10-point loss to Dallas. This was a good enough effort, but still a loss. After the game, Percy Ellsworth said, ''They won, but they didn't walk over us.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOGEL, EDWARD A.
description: FOGEL-Edward A. The Board of Directors and staff of Camp Isabella Freedman and the Jewish Retreat Center are deeply saddened by the passing of Ed Fogel, a longtime member of our Board. Our sincere condolences to his wife Barbara, his children Jim and Jan, and the entire Fogel family. Marilyn Marcus Alper, President Board of Directors Avital Rech, Executive Director

title: First Class to Cost a Pretty Penny
description: To ease customers into the new postal rates that take effect Jan. 10, the United States Postal Service will start today to flood the country with its new H for Hat stamp, 14,692,520,000 of them, to be exact.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIZZ, RUBEN
description: SPIZZ-Ruben. Devoted husband of Rachel for more than 60 years. Loving father of Norman, Mara, Gwendolyn and the late Lynn. Loving brother of Conrad, Sally, Lynn, the late Jack and the late Rene Bergstein. Irving Bergstein, Rene's husband was a very good friend. He leaves nieces and nephews, Harvey and Valerie, their children, Hayley and Erica; Sheldon, his children, Jason, Reyna and Jason's wife Suzanne; David and Susan Stollwerk, their children, Alissa and Alan; Warren and Susan Bergstein, their children, Robin and Sammy; Kenny and Joan Novatt, their children, Shawn and Jennifer; Scott and Susan Brier, their children, Ross and Clay; and Lynn's daughter, Renee. He was 81 on May 20. He died in Fort Myers, Florida. He was cofounder, with his brothers Conrad and the late Jack, of Rego Smoked Fish Co. He was very controversial. He was very honest. He paid his dues. He earned his keep. He will be missed. Services 11 AM, Monday, November 09, at the Parkside Memorial Chapel, 9860 Queens Blvd, Rego Park, Queens.

title: Back to the City's Budget
description: Before the elections interrupted, the Mayor and the City Council were trying to resolve their differences over New York City's $34 billion budget. Despite quiet talks by staff members in the last few months, many of those differences remain. In particular, about $150 million, mostly to pay for city services provided by nonprofit groups, has been on hold as Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and City Council Speaker Peter Vallone dug in for the hissing season.

title: Patrick Frawley Jr., 75, Ex-Owner of Schick
description: Patrick J. Frawley Jr., a high school dropout who made millions of dollars in business, gave millions to conservative causes and candidates, then made it his business and his life's work to combat alcohol and drug addiction, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 75 and lived in Agoura, Calif.

title: Where It Goes From Here
description: Tuesday's election results have reduced the chances that the House of Representatives will file articles of impeachment against President Clinton. But it will not be easy to wind down the inquiry process that the House Judiciary Committee has already begun. Today, a Judiciary subcommittee is scheduled to conduct public hearings on what the standards for impeaching a President should be.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SIMMONS, HELEN E.
description: SIMMONS-Helen E. We love you and miss you. Deirdre, Maud, and Charle

title: Media Talk; Hate That Story, Love That Story
description: The Republicans' poor showing in the elections last week reinforced what public opinion polls have indicated for months -- people are sick and tired of the Clinton-Lewinsky investigation. But evidently not that sick and tired.

title: Some Consumer Magazines Are Getting Real
description: Page through the most recent issue of More -- a magazine introduced last year by the Meredith Corporation -- and you will find the fashion spreads, advice columns and lush cosmetics advertisements favored by most glossy women's magazines.

title: 4 Families Left Homeless By Fire on a Main St.
description: A five-alarm fire sped down this town's main street early yesterday, destroying five businesses and the apartments above them. No one was injured.

title: As Skip Away Fades, Awesome Again Rises
description: ''They come once in a lifetime,'' Sonny Hine said after the final curtain had been lowered on Skip Away. ''Sure, I'm unhappy to lose him. For the last three years, he's been our life.''

title: Closing Sweatshops
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Trail of Global Capital
description: What are the five largest financial centers in the world? Many will name New York, London, Tokyo and Hong Kong. But how many will guess the fifth? It's the Cayman Islands -- or so, at least, its Government claims on its Web site.

title: A Long, Gray Winter
description: If you think the graying of America refers to our aging population, you obviously don't read fashion magazines. Or shop.

title: Kazakhstan's Empty Election
description: One of the candidates in Kazakhstan's presidential elections in January claims to be clairvoyant, but anyone can predict that the winner will be the incumbent, Nursultan Nazarbayev. Mr. Nazarbayev is a thinly disguised dictator who stages elections he has no chance of losing. Few Western leaders complain because he is seen as the guarantor of stability in an oil-rich nation.

title: Phillips Takes Leave as He Admits Affairs and Faces Possible Suit
description: Two weeks after the Mike Piazza signing triggered what they expected to be a productive off season, the Mets announced today that Steve Phillips, their general manager, was taking a leave of absence to deal with an allegation of sexual harassment as well as the repercussions of a series of extramarital affairs.

title: No Sign of an End To N.B.A. Stalemate
description: The National Basketball Association lockout enters its 18th week today, with no talks planned and no sign of a settlement between players and owners.

title: As Dalai Lama Woos Beijing, Tibetans Pray for His Return
description: On an old stone stairway beside the Potala Palace, the empty fortress where the Dalai Lama once presided over Tibet, an elderly woman navigated her way down a long procession of steps after coming here to pray.

title: Painter Injured In 45-Foot Fall From a Bridge
description: A painter who had unhooked his safety harness was seriously injured when he fell from the Triborough Bridge yesterday, just two and a half weeks after another accident left one painter dangling from the bridge and another bobbing in the Harlem River.

title: Blaming Beth Israel Hospital and Doctors in Woman's Death, Family Says It Will Sue
description: The family of a woman who died after routine outpatient surgery last year at Beth Israel Medical Center is suing the hospital, three physicians and a medical supply company, for medical malpractice and negligence, the family's lawyer said last night. The suit, which calls for punitive and compensatory damages but does not name an amount, will be filed today in New York State Supreme Court, the lawyer said.

title: Compressed Data; Under a Technology Strain, Egghead Remakes Itself Again
description: It has been almost a year since Egghead Software, a fallen leader in software retailing, announced that it would close the last 80 of its stores to begin anew as an Internet-only operation. Now the company says it is ready to start over -- again. While on-line sales on its three Web sites have been brisk all year, Egghead said its technology could no longer handle the load.

title: Woman Is Assaulted On the Lower East Side
description: A man raped and sodomized a 28-year-old woman in an alley on the Lower East Side early yesterday, then forced her to withdraw $800 from bank machines before she escaped, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILOFSKY, JOSEPH
description: BILOFSKY-Joseph. Age 81, beloved husband of Pearl, devoted father of Walter and Ellen, adored grandfather of Jessica and Alexander. A lifelong resident of NYC, he was a veteran of World War II, combat medic, for many years a leader in the taxi industry, vice president of the League of Mutual Taxi Owners. Service Monday, November 9, 12:30 PM, at Boulevard Riverside Chapels, 312 Coney Island Ave at Prospect Park.

title: Merrill Lynch to Sell Market Unit to Fleet
description: Fleet Financial Group plans to announce today that it will buy Merrill Lynch & Company's firm of specialists who work on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A New Drama on Broadway And a New Son in Turmoil
description: Talk about a play with legs: ''Side Man'' has been using them on a veritable walking tour of Manhattan. The production's unusual journey began last spring with a brief, acclaimed run in a little Off Broadway theater and continued with a successful move for the summer to the main stage of the normally revival-driven Roundabout Theater Company.

title: Investment Maverick Navigates the Internet
description: He seemed to be where all the new-media financial wannabes would want to be. But last April, Robert H. Lessin quit his successful career as a vice chairman of one of the country's bigger investment banks to devote his time and money to the Internet -- and to the many new companies he believes it can still spawn.

title: Sports of The Times; How the Jets' Defense Turned Flutie Flakes Soggy
description: IN a philosophical moment last week, Bryan Cox, the Jets' no longer inflammable linebacker, was discussing Doug Flutie.

title: Victories by Veterans and Teens Cap National
description: No more sleeping in stalls for the humans who performed valet duties for the 200 horses, certified prima donnas regardless of sex, who turned Madison Square Garden into a glorified barn for the duration of the 115th National Horse Show. No more dancing and prancing beneath the spotlights for the 20 horses from the New York City Police mounted unit who were sprung from their day jobs directing traffic and keeping order in the Big Apple and allowed to explore their inner artist at this event.

title: Baby Boomers With Gray Hair and Humor
description: ''Another song about death and decay,'' joked Loudon Wainwright 3d from the stage of Town Hall on Saturday evening after performing his song ''The Doctor,'' in which he described with pointedly self-deprecatory humor a physical examination of his middle-aged body. Mr. Wainwright, the 52-year-old singer, songwriter and humorist was the opening act for Kate and Anna McGarrigle, the Canadian sisters whose exquisite homemade folk music cuts to the bone in much the same way that Mr. Wainwright's songs do, minus the comedy.

title: Testaverde Wins Duel as the Jets Bring Flutie to His Knees
description: It began with the fanfare of a ''Sunset Boulevard East,'' with two aging stars from another era in their comeback saga.

title: Texas Youth Slain at Job in Brooklyn Grocery
description: A teen-ager who arrived in New York City just over a month ago to stay with his uncle's family and earn money before returning to Texas was shot to death on Saturday night while working at a Brooklyn grocery store, the police said yesterday.

title: Low Totals For Martin
description: Curtis Martin has now had consecutive ineffective running games -- at least until the fourth quarter. He had 21 carries yesterday for 54 yards, a 2.6 average, although he was able to get off a 6-yard touchdown run to complete the scoring in the Jets' victory over Buffalo. Last Sunday, in very bad weather in Kansas City, Martin averaged 1.4 yards a carry.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Oct. 16 about a reorganization of the Anglo American Corporation in South Africa misidentified the board seat held by James Motlasi, president of the National Union of Mineworkers. It is on the board of Anglogold, the gold mining subsidiary of Anglo American, not on the board of Anglo American.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAY, MARIE MCCAFFERTY
description: FAY-Marie McCafferty. A longtime Bedford resident died at her home in Bedford on Saturday, November 7, 1998. She was 68. Mrs. Fay was born September 6, 1930, to William J. McCafferty and Ann Curry McCafferty at Fort Slocum in New Rochelle, NY. She graduated from the Ursuline School and the College of New Rochelle. Mrs. Fay was a self-employed real estate broker and a parishioner of St. Patrick's Church in Bedford. On January 29, 1955, she married Lawrence F. Fay at the Church of the Annunciation in Crestwood, New York. She is survived by her loving husband, Lawrence F. Fay of Bedford, dear mother of Kathleen Fay Tell of Point Pleasant, NJ, Kevin J. Fay of Bedford, NY, Jennifer Fay Rice of Seattle, WA, Brian P. Fay of Bedford, NY. Cherished sister of Patricia Walter of Hilton Head, SC, William J. McCafferty, Jr. of Bronxville, NY, Joan Lahey of Southport, CT. Adored grandmother of Caroline and Elizabeth Tell, Ashley and Lyndsey Fay, and Kayleen Rice. Friends may call at the Oelker & Cox Funeral Home, Inc., 262 Main Street, Mt. Kisco on Monday, from 7 to 9 PM, Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 10 AM, St. Patrick's Church, Bedford, NY. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, RUTH
description: MARKS-Ruth. My dedicated and devoted colleague of many years. She will be much missed by me and my family and friends, all of whom knew that the way to get something done was to call Ruth. My deepest sympathy to Erika, John, Al and the little girls. Mary Jean Tully

title: In Jefferson-Hemings Tie, a Family's Pride; Unhappy Echo
description: To the Editor:

title: Compressed Data; One Trademark Lawsuit That Microsoft May Avoid
description: Bob Kerstein, a former McCaw Cellular Communications executive who is now an Internet entrepreneur in Falls Church, Va., says he has no interest in tangling with Microsoft over use of the term ''Windows 2000.'' But there are plenty of people who want to help him try.

title: P.& G. to Test Compensation Options
description: As part of Procter & Gamble's previously announced plan to reinvigorate its advertising, the company said that instead of a policy of straight compensation on media billings, it would test alternative pay options on all of its roster agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUTTLETON, JAMES W.
description: TUTTLETON-James W. Died November 6, 1998. Beloved husband of Patricia, devoted father of Sarah, loving brother of Margaret Nicholson and Marylyn Lupton. Professor of English at NYU, esteemed lecturer, essayist and literary critic. Private funeral services.

title: 'Springer' Returns to Its Antics
description: In April, after a well-publicized wave of protests against the lewd language and fisticuffs on ''The Jerry Springer Show,'' its owner, Studios USA, announced that it would eliminate all physical violence from that daily television talkfest.

title: Bookstore Goliaths Fax to the Finish
description: Bookselling heavyweights are reaching for their slingshots and bon mots.

title: Wendell Chino, 74, President Of New Mexico Tribe, Is Dead
description: Wendell Chino, the longtime president of the Mescalero Apache Nation who helped to lift his tribe from tar-paper shack poverty with his persuasive style of ''red capitalism,'' died on Wednesday at the Santa Monica-U.C.L.A. Medical Center in California. He was 74.

title: Widow and a School Board Clash Over Her Farm
description: When Rosalind Selzer walks down the double-rutted tractor path each morning toward the open fields behind her tiny farmhouse, she sees a 28-acre plot that has been profitably planted with soybeans, corn and flowers for nearly 50 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ANDREW LEE
description: SCHWARTZ-Andrew Lee. On November 7, 1998, of Mahnattan. Beloved husband of Tina. Devoted father of Daisy. Adored brother of Richard and Karin. Cherished son of Eleanor and Martin Leff. Services Tuesday 12 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Visiting hours Monday, 7-9 PM.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNER, MARJORIE H.S.
description: TURNER-Marjorie H.S., 87 of Palm Beach, Florida, on November 5. Beloved mother of James A. Harris, Charles Schlesinger, Jr., and Lewis Turner, Jr. Loving grandmother of Theodore and James Harris, Jennifer and Emily Turner, and John Schlesinger. Born in NYC, graduate of the NY School of Fine Arts. During WWII, served as a volunteer ambulance driver for the Red Cross. A John Powers model, and long time Board member of Irvington House in NY. Former President of the Quills of Palm Beach. Memorial service to be arranged. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Hospice of Palm Beach, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL. 33407.

title: Corrections
