description: A picture caption on Thursday about Carolyn McCarthy's re-election to Congress from District 4 on Long Island carried an incorrect credit. The picture was taken by Chris Maynard, not Vic DeLucia.

title: Reading a Cather Book With a Director's Eye
description: As Joanne Woodward talked about her favorite book, Willa Cather's ''Lucy Gayheart,'' it was as if she were directing a movie based on the novella.

title: Changing Social Security
description: To hear the politicians' post-mortems, you might conclude it was Social Security, not impeachment, the economy or anything else, on which the midterm elections were fought. In fact, exit polls showed that Social Security was on the minds of many voters, and that the issue worked better for the Democrats. But there was little in the way of informed debate on the issue from either side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POWERS, REV. MSGR. RAYMOND T.
description: POWERS-Rev. Msgr. Raymond T. Age 71, pastor of St. John the Evangalist Church, Mahopac, NY, November 7, at his residence. Son of Edward J. and Mary McCann Powers. Brother of Edwin J. and John V. Powers; also survived by several nieces, nephews, grandnieces, and grandnephews. Born in the Bronx, on January 21, 1927, he graduated from Regis High School in Manhattan. He attended Cathedral College and graduated from St. Joseph's Seminary at Dunwoodie in Yonkers. He studied at North American College in Rome and earned his doctorate of Sacred Theology from Gregorian University. He also earned a Master's Degree in Psychology from Fordham University. He was ordained a priest on December 8, 1951, in Rome. After an assignment at St. Patrick's Cathedral in 1952, he was stationed later that year in Rome and served as Vice Rector of North American College. In 1959, he became professor of Moral Theology and Canon Law at St. Joseph's Seminary. In 1972 he was appointed Secretary to the Apostolic Delegate in Washington, DC. In 1977 he was appointed adminstrator to St. Paul's Church in Congers, NY, and on July 1, 1978, became its pastor. In 1990 he returned to St. Joseph's Seminary to serve as Rector. On July 1, 1993, he was appointed pastor of St. John the Evangalist Church in Mahopac. Msgr. Powers will repose at Our Lady Queen of the Angels Chapel at St. John's, today (Monday) 2-4 and 7-9 PM, and Tuesday 2-4 PM. A Mass of the Resurrection will be celebrated Tuesday evening at 7:30 PM, at St. John the Evangalist Church. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Wednesday, 10 AM, at St. John's. Interment to follow at Gethsemane Cemetery in Congers. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Msgr. Raymond Powers Seminarian Fund, St. Joseph's Seminary, 201 Seminary Ave, Yonkers, NY 10704.

title: 2 Asian Tigers Gird for Battle to Get Lion's Share of Financial Trading
description: HONG KONG  A battle is intensifying between two of Asia's largest financial centers as a rapidly liberalizing Singapore and an increasingly interventionist Hong Kong seek to gain the upper hand in lucrative financial sector trading.

title: Prospectus; For start-up companies looking for corporate investors, it pays to know that philosophies differ from East to West.
description: WHEN two New York entrepreneurs, Damon C. Torres and Tom G. Goldsworthy, outlined a plan to capitalize their Silicon Alley company, Robocast Inc., they hoped to attract the interest of a blue-chip company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDER, WILLIAM
description: BENDER-William, 69, of Fort Pierce, Fla., died November 5, 1998. A native of New York, he came to Ft. Pierce from NY 10 years ago. He was an apartment building manager in New York City. Survivors include sister, Lillian Bender of NY; niece, Deborah Egan of Sayreville, NJ; nephews, Richard and Timothy Egan and brother in law, Mickey Egan, all of New York City, and long time companion Charles Brink of Ft. Pierce. He was predeceased by his parents William and Lillian Bender and sister Joyce Egan. HaisleyHobbs Funeral Home, Fort Pierce, Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIEFBERG, HENRIETTA (HENNY)
description: RIEFBERG-Henrietta (Henny). On November 7, 1998. Of Roslyn Heights, LI. Beloved mother of Helen and Warren Franz, Paul and Nancy, Jack and Nadine and Robbie and Sue. Cherished sister of Ann Pollack and Florence Bellock. Loving grandmother of David, Elizabeth, Michael, Libby, Sandy, Lee and Darin. Adored sister of Sweet Adelines, whose heart was always filled with a song. Services today, 10 AM, at Temple Sinai, 425 Roslyn Rd., Roslyn Heights, LI. In lieu of flowers, kindly direct your contributions to Cantor's Fund of Temple Sinai.

title: Dispute Over New Wrinkle In Problem Of Year 2000
description: Did a history teacher from Michigan and an obscure Canadian programmer discover a twist to computing's Year 2000 problem that the experts had missed?

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CABARET

title: Special Elections for City Council Are Ahead

title: A Busy Man of Opera Gets Even Busier; Domingo, Artistic Director in Washington, Is 'Upgrading' His Job in Los Angeles
description: Even by his own standards, Placido Domingo has accomplished an extraordinary hat trick in recent weeks. At the same time he was discussing extending his contract at the Washington Opera, where he has been artistic director since 1996, he was also meeting individually with members of the board, and with the entire executive committee, to explain why they should not be alarmed at his decision to become the artistic director of the Los Angeles Opera while continuing to hold the reins in Washington.

The troubled, soft-spoken son of working-class parents, Christopher Vasquez was blamed by his wealthy and privileged co-defendant for a slaying that stunned the city because of its gruesomeness and the age of the defendants -- 15.

title: Smith Runs Past Dorsett
description: Dallas running back Emmitt Smith became the Cowboys' career-leading rusher, passing Tony Dorsett's total of 12,036 yards. Smith ran for 163 yards on 29 carries against the Giants, his biggest rushing day in three years. He increased his career rushing total to 12,105.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the videotaped testimony of William H. Gates, chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, seen via the Internet, referred incompletely to his role in the evolution of the Net. While he has helped propagate it in recent years, Mr. Gates was a late and reluctant convert. Until 1996, he tried to thwart the Internet's growing popularity by developing a private on-line service and software for it.

title: An Opera's Myriad Reflections Both Reveal and Delude
description: The focus of Jonathan Miller's attention in his new book, ''On Reflection'' (Yale University Press), is light. That is, luster and gleam and splendor, shimmers and surfaces and deformations, windows and mirrors and water: light as it comes to us off the surface of objects and is captured in pigment and image. The glint in the eyes of Durer's ''Self- Portrait'' is not just a reflection but a revelation of an inner world; the glassy flare that blurs an image on the wall in Velasquez's ''Las Meninas'' tells us it is a mirror, reflecting figures standing where we stand, looking.

title: After a Sound Sleep, Glenn Says He Feels Fine
description: John Glenn, the world's oldest space traveler, said today that he slept ''like a log'' his first night back on Earth after a nine-day shuttle mission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ANDREW. AEGIS REAL
description: SCHWARTZ-Andrew. Aegis Realty Corp. mourns the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Andy. His dedication, humor and friendship will be sorely missed.

title: Lawmaker Claims to Have The Speaker's Job Sewn Up
description: With the endorsements of top Republicans in his pocket, Representative Robert L. Livingston of Louisiana all but declared himself Speaker of the House today, two days after the abrupt resignation of Speaker Newt Gingrich.

title: Agency Report Hails Switch to Managed Care for Inmates
description: As investigations continue into whether poor medical care played a role in the deaths of at least four Rikers Island inmates this year, New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation has released a report praising the recent shift to a managed care system in most city jails.

title: After Elections, the Republicans Are on Top, of the Mountains, That Is
description: One day in January, Bill Owens will shuttle cardboard boxes down a hall of the State Capitol here, moving from the treasurer's office to the governor's. For the first time since 1974, the year President Nixon resigned, Colorado is to have a Republican governor.

title: The Big City; Monkey Business: Strippers, Testosterone and the Dow
description: IN late July, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani began shutting down strip clubs, and over the next month, the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 1,500 points. In September, a court ruling gave some clubs a partial reprieve, whereupon the market began to recover. Last Wednesday, a strip club won another round in court, and the Dow surged 250 points the rest of the week.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday of Alfred M. Bingham, a onetime political radical, misstated the publishing status and the publication date of a book he wrote about his family. The book, ''The Tiffany Fortune,'' was published in 1996 by Abeel & Leet and is still in print.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, GEORGE, JR.
description: PARKER-George, Jr. Of San Antonio and Dallas, TX. Died on November 7, 1998, in Dallas, TX. He is survived by his brothers Joseph B. Parker and wife, Mary Anne, John M. Parker and wife, Patricia, William A. Parker and wife, Camilla; sister-in-law Mrs. Harry J. Parker; and numerous nieces and nephews. Mr. Parker was a parishioner of Christ the King Catholic Church. He was born in Tulsa, OK, on July 4, 1920, and graduated from Cascia Hall, Tulsa, OK, Philips Academy at Andover, MA, Princeton University and University of Michigan Law School. He served in the United States Navy as an officer at sea during World War II. He practiced law for a number of years in Dallas, after which time he engaged in petroleum exploration and served as a director of Texaco, Inc. for 32 years. Mr. Parker founded the Western European Architecture Foundation and was decorated by the French government and the Chevalier de L'Ordre des Arts et les Lettres and Officier Dans L'Ordre National de Merite. He was a Knight of The American Society of The Most Venerable Order of The Hospital of St. John of Jerusalem. He was also a member of Regnum Christi-Legionaries of Christ. Mr. Parker was a Trustee of the University of Dallas. He was a member of the Brook Hollow Country Club, Knickerbocker Club (NY), The Brook (NY), San Antonio Country Club and The Argyle and Golf du St. Cloud in Paris. The Rosary Service will be at 7 PM, Tuesday, November 10, at Christ the King Catholic Church, 8017 Preston Road, Dallas, TX. The Funeral Mass will be conducted the following morning at 10 AM. Private interment services will be in San Antonio. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorials be sent to the Christ the King Community Fund. For additional information, contact Porter Loring, 1101 McCullough, San Antonio, TX 78212; 1-800460-2704.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, ANNE F.
description: SIEGEL-Anne F. Peacefully at the age of 81, at Mt. Sinai Hospital on November 8, after many years of illness. Beloved wife of Marc Siegel. Devoted mother of Peter K. Siegel. Mother-in-law of Susan Carlson Siegel and cherished grandmother of Rachel Carlson Siegel. Devoted sister of Essie Lang and Irving Fishman of Boca Raton, Florida, and sister-in-law Celina Fishman. Loving aunt of Joshua and Jeremy Lang. Private funeral services at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 12:15 PM, today. A memorial service is planned by former students and colleagues of Bank Street College of Education at a later date.

title: Acting Out Parables Of Longing And Loss
description: P.J. Harvey kept coming back to a certain sound when she led her band on Wednesday night at the Hammerstein Ballroom. It was the sound of a simple drumbeat, a lone guitar and Ms. Harvey's voice, alone and exposed, circling through a single phrase again and again. An organ note might loom in the background; a second guitar might kick in with an expansive chord, then disappear back into silence. The music seemed to clear a space around her, mapping solitude instead of providing support.

title: Essay; New G.O.P. Leaders
description: In the 1920 Presidential campaign, the Democratic ticket was James Cox and young Franklin Roosevelt. The Latinesque call to vox populi, the voice of the people, was in this doggerel:

title: Turin Journal; The Militant Epicures: Even the Barricades Groan
description: The English will kill each other to protect animals. The French fight to the death to preserve the purity of their language. Italians, however, rarely get indignant about anything, except food. Few other nations, for example, have so passionate a grass-roots movement to preserve endangered species of cheese and protect vegetable rights.

title: Clinton's Envoy to the Internet Will Resign by Year's End
description: Ira C. Magaziner, the author of the Clinton Administration's ill-fated national health plan, who most recently has led Government efforts to foster the growth of the Internet and electronic commerce, said on Friday that he would leave the White House before the end of the year.

description: Walter George Berl, a chemist whose research included high-energy ram-jet fuels and international firefighting programs, died on Oct. 24 while vacationing in Durango, Colo. He was 81 and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: Voters and the Environment
description: Tuesday's election results cheered not only Democrats but conservationists as well. Montana voters banned the use of cyanide leaching at open-pit gold mines, a technique lethal to rivers and streams. Colorado and South Dakota imposed tough new restrictions on giant hog farms, which can generate as much pollution as a small city. New Jersey's approval of a $1 billion plan to save vanishing farmland was one of many successful state and local initiatives aimed at protecting open space from commercial development.

But when she talks about the midterm elections, the abrupt resignation of Speaker Newt Gingrich and the scramble for top Republican posts over the weekend, she sounds discouraged.

title: A Rapper Goes to the Hoop
description: On Oct. 30, children, teen-agers and adults packed the balcony overlooking the gymnasium floor at the Indiana Institute of Technology to watch the Fort Wayne Fury practice. Excited fans jockeyed for position, standing on tiptoe and pushing one another aside to videotape and photograph the action on the court. The Fury is one of the strongest teams in the Continental Basketball Association, but the crowd had not gathered to watch it run through its plays -- they were there to see the Fury's newest and already most popular player, the platinum-selling rap artist Master P.

title: Louis Daniel, 77; Popularized Classic Bistro Dining
description: Louis P. Daniel, who tried to bring the food and atmosphere of the best bistros of Paris to Le Chambertin, the classic French restaurant he operated for many years in Manhattan, died at his home in Phoenicia, N.Y., on Oct. 29. He was 77.

title: The Brass of Broadway From All Over the World
description: Peter Schickele's boldly titled Symphony No. 1 provided the New York Philharmonic with a showpiece and an entertaining, colorful close for Thursday night's concert, conducted by Leonard Slatkin. Mr. Schickele is, of course, less well known for his own music than as the amanuensis of P. D. Q. Bach, but I doubt that the high spirits of his symphony were meant to be understood in the same ironic light as his work on behalf of that long-surviving, long-suffering composer. The piece just sounded like a gifted musician having fun.

title: 2 U.S. Options For Iraq Strike: Swift or Larger
description: As the Clinton Administration once again considers using force against Iraq, the Pentagon has drafted separate plans for a sharp, swift strike that could begin at any time and a larger, more punishing assault that would require sending more forces to the region, officials say.

title: Midwestern Hospitality No Comfort To Pirates
description: Sooner or later, Seton Hall will find a defense it can score effectively against. It could be a box-and-one, maybe a triangle-and-two, or perhaps a fullcourt press. But, for now, it will not be a halfcourt man-to-man or a 2-3 zone. Against those two sets, the Pirates currently appear powerless.

title: An Imbroglio For 'Figaro,' Its Director And Bartoli
description: There is a long tradition of conductors and opera houses catering to the whims of prima donnas. The tradition continues at the Metropolitan Opera, where Cecilia Bartoli, a singer of sensational popularity and, consequently, clout, is performing Susanna in the Met's new production of Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro.''

description: The Devils awoke today from the high of Saturday's fourth victory in five road games to find two of their most productive players unavailable to improve that record against the Tampa Bay Lightning.

title: Title Game Picture Has a Florida Look
description: In six short days, Ohio State's Joe Germaine went from much-hyped Heisman Trophy candidate to a quarterback entrusted by his coach only with handing the ball off during a critical fourth-quarter drive. In less than four hours on Saturday, the Buckeyes lost all national title hopes when Michigan State pulled the upset of the season.

title: Financial Times Picks Avrett Free
description: The Financial Times, which is published by Pearson P.L.C., named Avrett Free & Ginsberg in New York as the first agency to handle its account in the United States. Billings were estimated at $3 million.

title: British Airways Profit Is Below Expectations
description: British Airways P.L.C., Europe's largest airline, said yesterday that its second-quarter profit rose 41 percent, less than expected, as an economic slowdown caused business travelers to favor cheaper tickets. Net income rose to $:216 million ($358 million) from $:153 million a year earlier, when a three-day strike cut profit. Analysts had expected profit in the quarter, which ended on Sept. 30, to rise 50 percent, to $:229 million.

title: An Intel Executive Testifies of a 'Credible and Fairly Terrifying' Threat by Microsoft
description: The Microsoft Corporation repeatedly threatened its key ally in the computer industry, the Intel Corporation, as part of its campaign to stifle any challenge to its business posed by the rise of the Internet, an Intel executive testified in court today.

title: Rangers Will Rest Richter, Maybe Twice
description: The Rangers plan to rest Mike Richter for Tuesday's game against the Tampa Bay Lightning. No surprise there, because Richter was peppered for four goals in two periods in Saturday's 6-6 game with Toronto. What is surprising is that Richter may watch Dan Cloutier start Wednesday's game against the Florida Panthers.

title: G.M. Plans Renovations
description: The General Motors Corporation plans to make at least $1 billion of renovations to its research and development center in Warren. The renovations to the Warren Technical Center, which was built in the 1950's as a suburban Detroit research campus for G.M., are expected to take as long as five years.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article yesterday about the mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli's use of two alternative arias by Mozart for the character of Susanna in ''Le Nozze di Figaro'' at the Metropolitan Opera this season misstated the timing of Ms. Bartoli's arrival for rehearsals and referred incorrectly to her contract. Joseph Volpe, general manager of the Met, says Ms. Bartoli arrived four days before the production's director, Jonathan Miller, not after rehearsals had begun. Although Ms. Bartoli did sing the arias, her contract does not stipulate that right, he said.

title: Projected Costs of Year 2000 Bug Jump
description: Spending in the major Western nations on the Year 2000 computer bug has jumped 93 percent since April to $494 billion from $256 billion, according to the latest survey by a leading Year 2000 consulting firm.

Parker and wife Patricia; William A. Parker and wife Camilla, his sister-in-law Mrs. Harry J. Parker and numerous nieces and nephews. Mr. Parker was a parishioner of Christ the King Catholic Church. He was born in Tulsa, Oklahoma on July 4, 1920 and graduated from Cascia Hall, Tulsa, Oklahoma, Philips Academy at Andover, Massachusetts, Princeton University and University of Michigan Law School. title: Samsung Repays a Sixth Of Its Foreign Debt
description: The Samsung Electronics Company of South Korea said yesterday that it had repaid one-sixth of its $6.5 billion foreign-currency debt, using in part money raised through five domestic bond sales. Samsung, the world's biggest maker of computer memory chips, sold more than 1.3 trillion won ($1 billion) of bonds this year. It used $300 million of that to repay foreign debt, with the remaining $700 million coming from existing savings and recurring profits.

title: Youth Playing With Gun Fatally Shoots Himself
description: A 14-year-old boy accidentally shot himself in the head yesterday while playing with a gun at a friend's apartment in Harlem, the police said. The boy, Mark Byrd, of West 138th Street, died instantly.

title: Local Elections in Israel: A Virtual Free-for-All
description: Early one recent morning, a neighbor knocked on the door of Yigal Yanai, a candidate for Mayor in this town of mostly Yemenite Jews, where clan-based rivalries permeate local politics. When Mr. Yanai opened the door, the neighbor blanched as if he had seen a ghost.

title: NATIONAL-OILWELL ACQUIRING A BUSINESS FROM WESTBURNE
description: National-Oilwell Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Westburne Inc.'s oil and natural-gas field-supply business for about $58.6 million in stock and debt securities to expand its services in Canada and to cut operating costs. National-Oilwell will give the Montreal-based Westburne three million shares of its common stock and will issue a short-term note for $6.5 million. The debt will be recouped through the sale of the Westburne division's excess inventory. National-Oilwell, based in Houston, makes equipment for oil and gas drilling and production. Its shares fell $1.4375, to $15.9375, on the New York Stock Exchange. Westburne's shares rose 5 cents, to $14 (Canadian), in Toronto.

title: Salo Helps Isles Win in Farewell to Maple Leaf Gardens
description: A month of the season has passed and Islanders goalie Tommy Salo is tied for the league lead in victories. The Islanders have played 14 games and Claude Lapointe leads the team in goals scored. Who would have guessed?

title: Metro Business; Court Dismisses Suit Over ATM Charges
description: A Federal appeals court dismissed a lawsuit yesterday by Fleet Financial Group Inc. that sought to let Fleet continue charging $1 fees on certain automated teller machine transactions.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about United States food aid for Russia misstated the terms. Russia will get $625 million of food, much of it free. It is not buying food worth $625 million.

title: Gingrich Loses, Republicans Gain?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Player At Home in Front Office
description: Cautious and thorough have been the words most likely to be associated with Mets General Manager Steve Phillips when describing his dealings with agents and other general managers.

title: Democrats Full of Glee At Hearing
description: Fresh from his nuanced dissertation on whether President Clinton's sex-and-mendacity scandal merits impeachment, the Rev. Robert F. Drinan put his House committee statement in laymen's terms as he hurried off to the cafeteria.

title: A Shadowy Fairy Tale Driven by Dark Rumblings
description: Tchaikovsky had as much trouble with his last opera as we do. ''Iolanta,'' he said in 1892, ''captured my imagination but not my heart.'' Misty, mystical castles and princes had inspired balletic marvels like ''Swan Lake'' and ''Sleeping Beauty,'' but ''Iolanta'' with its blind princess, amorous count and Middle Eastern healer inevitably trips over the cliches and awkwardnesses put in its path. It is left to the occasional flash of great beauty to pick up a limping opera, dust it off and make ''Iolanta'' presentable.

title: More Faith, More Pounds, More Secure
description: Though gluttony is cited in the Bible as a sin and a sign of moral weakness, religious people in the United States are more likely to be overweight than nonreligious people, researchers from Purdue University have found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARR, LOUIS
description: STARR-Louis. Age 91. Died on November 8, 1998. He is survived by his wife, Abbey Kissel Starr of Far Hills, N.J. and his brother, Ogden Parrish Starr of Antigua, W.I. Mr. Starr is also survived by his daughter, Frances Starr Todd and her children, Mary Starr and Christopher Bray and his daughter-inlaw Elizabeth Nelson Starr and her children, Christopher Parrish and Elizabeth Abbey. Mr. Starr was pre-deceased by his son, Dillwyn Thorn Starr, who died in 1988. Mr. Starr was associated with Laidlaw & Company in New York City. He was a Trustee of the Upper Raritan Watershed Association, a Trustee of Purnell School in Pottersville, N.J. and he belonged to Holland Lodge, New York City. Mr. Starr was a member of the Squadron A Association in New York and was a veteran of World War II in which he served as Lt. Colonel of the 8th Air Force in England. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Upper Raritan Watershed Association, Box 273, Gladstone, New Jersey 07934 or to the Tewksbury Foot Bassets, Box 31, Pottersville, N.J. 07979. A memorial service will be held on Friday, November 13, 1998 at the Lamington Presbyterian Church, Bedminster, N.J. at 10 A.M. Interment will be private.

description: Placebo

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WANDERER, BRUNO
description: WANDERER-Bruno. 94. Of New York City died Saturday, Nov. 7, 1998. Beloved father of Susan W. Uram and proud grandfather of Alison and Michael Uram. He is also survived by his sister, Jetty Richter and his brother, Max Wanderer. Incredibly devoted to his family and to The West Side Institutional Synagogue, he will be missed dearly. Contributions may be sent to the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale, NY.

title: Lord Hunt, 88, Everest Trek Leader, Dies
description: Lord Hunt of Llanfairwaterdine, who led the expedition in 1953 in which Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay became the first people to reach the top of Mount Everest, died on Sunday at home in Henley, England, his family said. He was 88.

title: Abroad at Home; The Trial
description: In a column 15 months ago I told the story of Baxter Thompson, a building contractor in Alexandria, La., and the young woman from Germany whom he had married, Martina Diederich Thompson. The Immigration and Naturalization Service held her in the New Orleans Parish Prison for a week and then put her on a plane back to Germany.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WACHSBERGER, ENTLA (KAROLLA)
description: WACHSBERGER-Entla (Karolla), Motzai Shabbat November 7, 1998 after a full and rich life, spanning continents and countries. Beloved mother of Miriam and Carl, Isaac and Chaim and Liz. Loving grandmother of David and Debbie, Edna, William, Samuel, Nell, Kaitlin, Sam and Sylvia. Adoring greatgrandmother of Jenna, Joshua and Matthew. Services were held November 9, 1998. For information regarding Shivah please contact Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 718-263-7600.

title: Gingrich Urges Support for His Challenger
description: In a conciliatory address, Newt Gingrich said tonight that he had resigned as House Speaker because he did not want to be ''an excuse for divisiveness and factionalism.'' And he called on Republicans to unite behind his ''good friend'' Representative Robert L. Livingston, whose challenge drove Mr. Gingrich out of the Speaker's chair.

title: Time for New York to Act on Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIZZ, RUBEN
description: SPIZZ-Ruben. Son Michael was left out. Uncle Conrad apologizes for this error.

description: McCANN-Margaret R. age 90 years, of Port Washington, NY & Lake Park, Florida, on November 8, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Vincent. Dear mother of John, Christopher and Vincent. Survived by ten grandchildren and nine+ great grandchildren. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 9:30 A.M. St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington, New York. Burial Private.

title: Corrections
description: A listing yesterday of agencies that are helping victims of the hurricane in Central America misstated the zip code for Quest for Peace, Hurricane Relief Fund. Its address is P.O. Box 5206, Hyattsville, Md. 20782.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROBST, MICHAEL L.
description: PROBST-Michael L. On November 7, 1998. The New York University School of Continuing and Professional Studies is saddened by the passing of Michael Probst who died peacefully at home following a long illness. His devotion and exemplary performance as an employee of NYU since 1978, was recognized when he received the NYU Distinguished Administrator Award. Michael will leave a major void for his colleagues and friends. Sincere condolences are extended to his family. We will miss you. Gerald A. Heeger, Dean Frances Gottfried, Vice Dean

title: G.M. Signs 10-Year Pact to Buy Aluminum From Alcan
description: The General Motors Corporation announced today that it had signed a 10-year agreement to buy aluminum from Alcan Aluminium Ltd., using a complex financial arrangement to shield the giant auto maker from the highly volatile price of aluminum in commodity markets.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary headline yesterday about the painter Francisco Sainz characterized his style incorrectly. His work drew on traditional portraiture and folk art; it was not Abstract Expressionist, though many of his friends painted in that style.

title: Pinochet Lawyer Asks Britain To Recognize Chile's Wishes
description: A lawyer for Gen. Augusto Pinochet said today that his arrest and detention here last month threatened to destroy the ''delicate balance between the interests of justice and state stability'' in Chile, which, she argued, had made its peace with its former dictator.

title: MGM GRAND IN $276 MILLION DEAL FOR PRIMADONNA
description: In a further sign of casino industry consolidation, MGM Grand Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Primadonna Resorts Inc. in a stock transaction valued around $276 million. MGM Grand will also assume about $325 million of Primadonna debt. MGM Grand, whose 5,000-room flagship hotel and casino is the largest in Las Vegas, Nev., will gain complete ownership of a second property there, the New York-New York Hotel and Casino, which it now owns jointly with Primadonna. Primadonna shareholders will receive 0.33 share of MGM Grand common stock for each of their shares. MGM will issue about 9.5 million shares of stock. MGM rose 93.75 cents today, to $29.0625, while Primadonna fell 25 cents, to $8.75.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Lawyers Are Awarded $144 Million From Class-Action Stock Suit
description: In what may be the largest payday of its kind, a Federal judge has awarded more than $144 million in fees and $4.4 million in expenses to a team of class-action lawyers who negotiated a record-breaking $1 billion settlement from more than three dozen Wall Street brokerage houses that the lawyers had accused of illegally fixing prices on stocks traded on the Nasdaq market.

title: With No Time to Spare, Cashen Is Returning to the Game
description: If people were confused before, oh boy.

title: East 40, West 40, All Around the Farm; High School Agriculture Program Thrives in the Heart of Queens
description: Walk up the steps of John Bowne High School one chilly fall morning and you'll find a familiar tableau: school safety officers roving the grounds, portable classrooms parked out back, teen-age boys and girls with their bulky parkas and fuzzy dreams about the future.

title: Political Briefing; Arizona Sets Record For a Year of Women
description: Arizona voters made a little-noticed but nevertheless special kind of political history in last week's election. They picked women to fill the state's top five elective offices.

title: GPU Sells 23 Power Plants to a French-Linked Company
description: GPU Inc., a holding company that owns utilities serving large parts of Pennsylvania and New Jersey, announced the sale yesterday of 23 power plants to Sithe Energies, a major independent power producer and affiliate of Vivendi S.A. of France.

title: Victorious Preference Foes Look for New Battlefields
description: Buoyed by their victory in Washington State, whose voters decided last Tuesday to ban state-sponsored affirmative action programs, opponents of racial preferences are exploring new battlegrounds where they hope to place similar measures on the ballot, among them Nebraska, Michigan, Florida and the city of Houston.

title: Stair Climbers and Leaning: Tilt Penalty
description: Like tilting a pinball machine, leaning on the rails of a stair climber comes with a penalty -- even if it is just for a short rest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASSAR, JACK
description: LASSAR-Jack. On November 9, 1998 at age 91. Beloved husband of Rose for 58 years. Loving father of Anne and husband Jonathan. Devoted grandfather of Jillian and Debra. Dear brother of Emanuel Lassar and Henrietta Karasick, and the late Philip Lassar and Dorothy Katz. Lawyer for 59 years. Schwartz Brothers, Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, 1:30 PM November 10.

title: 34 Arrested at Stadium, Mostly on Drug Charges
description: In a crackdown on quality-of-life offenses at New Jersey's arenas, undercover officers arrested 34 people, 21 of them on charges of smoking marijuana, during the Jets-Buffalo Bills football game Sunday at Giants Stadium, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRARA, EUGENE V.
description: FERRARA-Eugene V., on November 8th, 1998, of Old Tappan, NJ (formerly of Dumont, NJ). Beloved husband of Francine (nee Tozzi). Devoted father of Dr. Vincent Ferrara, Dr. Lisa Ferrara Guzzo and Eugene F. Ferrara. Dear father-in-law of Joseph Guzzo, Elizabeth and Maria Ferrara. Also survived by five grandchildren. The Funeral Mass Wednesday, 9:30 AM, at St. Mary's R.C. Church, Dumont, NJ. The family will receive friends Tuesday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM, at the Frech Funeral Home, 161 Washington Ave., Dumont, NJ. Entombment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Those who wish may give memorial gifts to St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital, PO Box 50, Memphis, TN 38101. Eugene, a friend to all.

title: Administration Loses Two Legal Battles Against Starr
description: The Supreme Court today rejected two appeals brought by the Clinton Administration that sought to block the grand jury testimony of Secret Service agents and President Clinton's lawyers in the Monica Lewinsky inquiry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOLNICK, VIVIAN (NEE TANNENBAUM)
description: SCOLNICK-Vivian (nee Tannenbaum). Beloved wife of the late Alfred B. Devoted mother of Vickie (and the late Michael) Abrutyn of Potomac. MD., and Tony (Andrea) Scolnick of NYC. Dear sister of Alice Willis. Loving grandmother of Stephanie, Daniel, and David (Robin) Abrutyn and great grandmother of Allison. Services Tuesday 11AM at Temple Emanu-El, Bayonne New Jersey. Contributions to Temple EmanuEl, Bayonne or B'nai Israel Congregation, Rockville MD would be appreciated. For information ''Wien & Wien'' 1-800-322-0533

title: A First-Person Study of Polio's Painful Legacy
description: Dr. Nancy Frick, one of the world's foremost experts on the long-term psychological effects of childhood polio, says she has a classic Type-A personality: driven to succeed, often to the point of exhaustion, and unduly afraid of failure.

title: Study Links Food Desire To Memory
description: Hopeful of finding clues to a better understanding of obesity and other disorders, scientists have long been interested in why people start and stop eating.

title: Ciba Is Set For a Merger With Clariant
description: Ciba Specialty Chemicals and Clariant, already two of the largest players in the rapidly growing specialty chemical industry, are merging in a share swap valued at about $7 billion.

title: Hurricane Victims: Is U.S. Doing Enough?
description: To the Editor:

title: Guidelines Offer an Earlier Blueprint for the Battle Against Bone Loss
description: Osteoporosis is a silent disease. Just as a heart attack is often the first clue to the existence of atherosclerosis, a fracture is usually the first indication that a person's bones have become dangerously weakened. But it doesn't have to be that way. According to guidelines issued last week by the National Osteoporosis Foundation, it is now possible to determine a person's propensity for fracture far in advance and offer preventive treatments for most people at risk of developing osteoporosis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE PAUR, LEONARD
description: de PAUR-Leonard. It is with great sadness that The Board, staff and friends of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc. mourn the passing of Leonard de Paur, former Director of Community Relations for Lincoln Center, a position he held for 17 years. His creative vision and commitment to making the arts available to everyone lives on in the programs he created. Twenty-eight years ago Mr. de Paur founded Lincoln Center Outof-Doors which today thrives as one of the largest free public performing arts events in the country. Each summer Lincoln Center Outof-Doors makes accessible the highest caliber of dance, music, and performance artistry from around the globe to over 200,000 people. Mr. de Paur leaves an unparalleled legacy of passion for and devotion to the arts. His enlightening wisdom and guidance will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Norma, his son Leonard C., his daughter Norma Lynn and his three grandchildren. Beverly Sills, Chairman Nathan Leventhal, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc.

title: Quick Settlement To Dispute Unlikely
description: With no negotiations scheduled and neither the National Basketball Association nor the players union budging, the chance of ending the stalemate and putting a starting date on the season this week seem extremely remote.

title: Gingrich Loses, Republicans Gain?
description: To the Editor:

title: Female Bodybuilders Discover Curves
description: When the history of women's bodybuilding is written, 1998 will emerge as the year that the weights tipped in favor of the sport's old nemesis, femininity.

title: J. P. Morgan's New Cut Is 4.5% of Staff
description: J. P. Morgan & Company, squeezed by the global financial turmoil that has battered many Wall Street firms, will cut its work force by 740 people, through either layoffs or job eliminations, by the end of the year, according to people at the company.

title: GLOBAL MOTORSPORT AGREES TO TAKEOVER BY STONINGTON
description: The Global Motorsport Group agreed yesterday to be acquired by Stonington Partners Inc. for $19.50 a share, or a total of $101.4 million. The sale, approved unanimously by Global's board, apparently short-circuits a rival effort by Golden Cycle L.L.C. to unseat Global's directors and buy the company for $19 a share. The shares closed at $18.75 yesterday, up $1.875. Global, of Morgan Hill, Calif., provides accessories and parts for Harley-Davidson motorcycles. Stonington Partners, based in New York, is a private equity investment firm that manages a $1 billion investment fund. Golden Cycle, a private company in Wynnewood, Pa., sells Harley-Davidson parts.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Stephen King's books referred incorrectly in some editions to the publisher of Robert Jordan's ''Path of Daggers,'' which had higher opening sales at the Barnes & Noble chain than Mr. King's ''Bag of Bones.'' The publisher is St. Martin's Press, not Tor/Doherty.

title: On the Trail of Treasure and Tragedy in Lakes' Depths
description: ABOARD THE OBSESSION TOO, off Port Austin, Mich. -- Something was down there, under the cold, steel blue waters of Lake Huron, just off the Thumb of Michigan, but David Trotter wasn't sure what he had found.

description: To the Editor:

description: LEVINSON-Sol R., November 15, 1903 to November 9, 1998. Beloved husband of 67 years to Belle. Devoted and deeply loved father to his two daughters Bonnie Joan (Liebmann) and Marcia Audrey (DiMartino). Loving and respected grandfather of Marc, Douglas and Michael (Hochlerin) and David and Adam (DiMartino). Proud great-grandfather to Samuel Albert. Revered Chairman of the Board of A.J. Contracting Corporation for 30 years. Sol R. Levinson will be greatly missed by many. Chapel services will be held on Thursday, November 12th, 9:30 AM at the ''Riverside Chapel'', 180 West 76 Street, NY NY 212362-6600. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Multiple Sclerosis or Juvenile Diabetes Association would be greatly appreciated.

description: To the Editor:

title: City Ends Plan To Speed Up Welfare Aid
description: In an abrupt reversal, the Giuliani administration decided yesterday to drop plans, just announced over the weekend, to speed up the distribution of applications for food stamps and medical assistance to the poor.

title: Deal Is Reached For Lippo Bank
description: The Indonesian businessman at the center of the controversy over campaign donations to the Democratic Party is selling the California bank that is his main business in the United States.

title: Time for New York to Act on Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: DiMaggio Improving, His Doctor Says
description: Joe DiMaggio has an excellent chance of recovery from complications of pneumonia that have kept him in a Hollywood, Fla., hospital since Oct. 12, his doctor said yesterday.

title: Veterans Day
description: The holiday is observed tomorrow.

title: Dow Falls 77 Points, Taking a Breather After an 8-Day Run-Up
description: Stock prices slid for the first time in nine sessions yesterday as investors took some profits after the market's recent surge and they became more concerned that the Federal Reserve would not cut interest rates at its meeting next week.

title: Review/Fashion; For Dancing the Night Away
description: By the time the New York spring shows ended on Friday, it was clear that fashion was heading in two directions: sporty-military-functional for day, and feminine for evening.

title: Lou Gehrig's Disease Is Diagnosed in Hunter
description: When Jim (Catfish) Hunter was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame on a sunny Sunday in July 1987, he recalled growing up in the small farming community of Hertford, N.C., and learning to pitch. ''My three brothers taught me to throw strikes,'' he said, ''and thanks to them, I gave up 379 home runs in the big leagues.''

title: 2 Unbeaten Little Guys Square Off in Big Bout
description: Boxers in the lighter weight divisions often get lost among their larger counterparts, particularly in the United States. But boxing fans who want to see two of the very best boxers in the lightest division, 105 pounds, can check out the straw-weight rematch between Ricardo Lopez and Rosendo Alvarez at 10 P.M. Friday on Showtime.

title: Some Ailments Found Guilty of Sex Bias
description: The question, Henry Higgins, is not ''why can't a woman be more like a man'' but why isn't a woman more like a man. That is what medical researchers want to know so that they can become better equipped to head off health problems to which woman are especially vulnerable.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN WEAKENS. Japan's currency fell to its weakest level against the dollar since Oct. 7 on speculation that the Federal Reserve will not lower rates at its Nov. 17 meeting. The dollar cost 121.57 yen in New York, up from 119.10.

title: Resolved: Science Is at an End. Or Is It?; 'Nobody Can Tell What Lies Ahead'
description: Few books have caused as much consternation among scientists as John Horgan's ''The End of Science'' (Helix Books, 1996), in which the author, then a writer for Scientific American, argued that science was nearing the limits of what could be learned about the natural world. Among those dismayed by Mr. Horgan's argument was Sir John Maddox, who in two stints as editor of the British journal Nature (from 1966 to 1973 and from 1980 to 1995) provoked controversy himself with commentaries on everything from the Big Bang to homeopathy. Now he has published ''What Remains to be Discovered?'' (Free Press), his own forecast of the future of science and, in effect, an answer to Mr. Horgan. The two authors debated the issue recently in Manhattan. Here are their excerpts of what they said. DENNIS OVERBYE

title: Muslim Schools in U.S. a Voice for Identity
description: The school year is already in full swing and still the parents come, crowding into the principal's office at Al Noor School in Brooklyn, painstakingly filling in forms, proffering checks and pleading in Arabic and English for a chance to enroll their children in the New York area's biggest Islamic private school.

title: Fast and Compulsive Wins a (Senate) Race
description: JOSH ISAY, the 28-year-old worrier who waged Charles E. Schumer's relentless campaign for the United States Senate, has crucial rules about what to do when things are going well in a race: ''You wake up at exactly the same moment. You snooze at the same time. You get out of the shower at exactly the same time. You go the same route to the subway, and buy the same newspapers in the same order with the same amount of change.''

title: Loungers Dreaming Of Bygone Days
description: Every pop revival is a kind of retreat, a determination that the past offered more wisdom and comfort than the present. And no revival is more ambivalent about that feeling than the 1990's rediscovery of 1950's and 60's lounge music, which even in its day was derided as pablum for people who weren't listening anyway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SECCI, ERALDO PETER
description: SECCI-Eraldo Peter. On November 1, 1998. Survived by many relatives in Italy. Longtime restaurateur and owner of A-Buongusto NYC. Reposing Krtil Funeral Home-Yorkville Funeral Service, Inc., 1297 First Avenue, NYC, Tuesday, 6-8 PM. Interment Wednesday, 11 AM, Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: HOUSTON EXPLORATION BUYING PROPERTIES FROM CHEVRON
description: The Houston Exploration Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire offshore producing properties for $85.3 million from the Chevron USA unit of the Chevron Corporation, the oil and gas giant. The acquisition provides additional drilling opportunities and a 100 percent working interest in three offshore blocks. Houston Exploration, a Houston-based natural-gas and oil company, had 1997 revenue of $117.6 million. Its stock slipped 56.25 cents a share, to $18.5625. Shares of Chevron, based in San Francisco, fell 87.5 cents, to $82.4375.

title: First An Unusual Selection, Then an Unusual Contrast
description: Chamber Music Society Two

title: Stewart Finally Gets in Gear As Steelers Hold Off Packers
description: When quarterbacks Kordell Stewart and Brett Favre are on the same field, a defender is going to look silly and the game is guaranteed to be interesting.

title: Letters Threaten Opponents of Abortion
description: A Catholic church near Buffalo, a Catholic elementary school in Indianapolis and an anti-abortion group's office in Chicago received letters yesterday claiming to contain deadly anthrax bacteria. At least 15 people, including three priests, were decontaminated and treated with antibiotics as a precaution, but there was no immediate indication that anyone had been exposed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALAJIAN, ROXY
description: KALAJIAN-Roxy. At certain times, life has a way of confounding the wise among us in yielding a startling alchemy among warring elements in our nature. Such a thing happened some 30 years ago while anguished, despairing Moms and Dads dropped off their young at our doorstop at Daytop Village. Their failure as parents was engraved on their faces. It was for them the end of the road that is, until a lone figure began to stand tall against the tide of selfsympathy, with her own failedparenting scars clearly visible and with a passion for gentle confrontation, she led generations of parents to the hard-ground of vital, responsible parenting. And Daytop overnight became ''A Family Repair Station'' with Roxy both teacher-extraordinaire and role model. Tennyson phrased it aptly in his mourning over Maud: ''There has fallen a splendid tear from the passion-flower at the gate!'' Her memory is deeply cherished; her footprints a lasting guide. May she revel in God's love! May her beloved Berge and the Family feel the strength of our prayers. (Msgr.) William B. O'Brien President Daytop Village, Inc.

title: A Sound That Defies Easy Characterization
description: Furslide

title: 'On the Town,'Retooling Some Dances, Delays Opening
description: In a flurry of last-minute moves, the Joseph Papp Public Theater yesterday postponed the opening of its troubled big-budget revival of ''On the Town,'' canceled two preview performances and brought in a seasoned Broadway choreographer to retool several dance numbers.

title: With Speaker's Job Settled, Fight Shifts to Lesser Posts
description: Representative Robert L. Livingston of Louisiana locked up the votes today to become the next Speaker of the House, as the Republican jockeying for power moved down the ladder and intensified over the majority leader's position, the second-ranking post.

title: Mr. Livingston, at Center Stage
description: Almost as quickly as Newt Gingrich's power base collapsed last week, Representative Robert Livingston has moved to pick up the pieces. But the ascension of Mr. Livingston to the post of Speaker of the House will not end the struggle among Republicans for a new message, style and sense of balance in Congress. The scramble for leadership positions is healthy, and Republicans would do well to change as many positions as possible. On the theory that a losing team does more than change its coach, the party should look hard as well at replacing Dick Armey, John Boehner and other lawmakers in the leadership cluster who led the party over the cliff in the last election.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PARK-OHIO HOLDINGS CORP., Cleveland, a maker of fasteners and other industrial components, agreed to buy the closely held Metalloy Corp., Hudson, Mich., a manufacturer of aluminum automotive parts with annual sales of about $90 million, for an undisclosed price.

title: Pilots Move 2 Steps Closer to a Strike at Federal Express
description: Pilots at the Federal Express Corporation began refusing to fly on overtime yesterday, and their union mailed strike authorization ballots, increasing the chances that the world's largest air-freight service could be crippled during the peak season between Thanksgiving and Christmas.

title: DIALOGUE: Is That a Story or a Stereotype on the Big Screen; In the Hurt Game, Honesty Loses
description: ''Insidious, incendiary and dangerous.''

Contributions to the American Heart Association or to the Keeler Tavern Preservation Society, 132 Main St., Ridgefield, Connecticut 06877.

description: Ethan Canin cannot be called a Wunderkind anymore. Ten years ago, at 27, he was anointed for his critically acclaimed book of short stories, ''Emperor of the Air,'' and became an instant media darling because he was a graduate of Harvard Medical School and a handsome bachelor to boot.

title: Confusion Seen in a Departure at Citigroup
description: Michael A. Carpenter, Citigroup Inc.'s new co-head of investment and commercial banking, spent days last week convincing Steven D. Black, 46, to remain as a vice chairman of Salomon Smith Barney, the firm's investment bank unit, and head of its global equity business, according to Citigroup executives who spoke on condition of anonymity.

title: British Company Sells Canadian Property Unit
description: The British property company Hammerson P.L.C. said yesterday that it would sell its Canadian business, Hammerson Canada Inc., to the Omers Realty Corporation for a net sum of $:238 million in cash, or $394.8 million (United States), after allowing for repayment of local debt. Omers Realty is a subsidiary of the Ontario Municipal Employees Retirement System, the pension plan for employees of local governments in the province.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSLER, EVELYN
description: WEISSLER-Evelyn. On Nov. 9, 1998. Beloved wife of Murray, adored mother of Renee Chilton and Paula Newman. Loving grandmother and great grandmother. Dear sister. Services Parkside Chapels, Flatbush Avenue at Avenue V, Brooklyn, New York, at 1 P.M. Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HINDEN, GERTRUDE S.
description: HINDEN-Gertrude S. Devoted mother of Daisy Nass and Vera Frankel. Cherished grandmother of Heidi, Andy, Valerie and Karen. Great grandmother of Evan, Chloe, Samuel, Daniel and Emily. Service today, 2PM at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, L.I. In lieu of flowers donations to the Alzheimer's Foundation 382 Main St. Port Washington, NY. 11050

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROCHSTEIN, SAMUEL
description: BROCHSTEIN - Samuel. Loving husband of Esther, loving father of Lois and Arnold, and Phyllis. Cherished grandfather of Nancy and Susan, great grandfather of Maxwell. Beloved brother and brother-in-law of Harry and Leah. Funeral services Tuesday, 1 PM at Temple Israel of Great Neck, 108 Old Mill Rd., Great Neck, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, LEAH A.
description: WEISS-Leah A. 90, of Southbury, CT, formerly of NY, died Monday, November 9, 1998. She was the devoted wife of Burt and a loving mother to Edward.

title: Arming the Public Advocate
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has a propensity to keep arguing even when the law and good sense go against him. This has been particularly true in cases involving the release of information. For nearly two years his administration has refused to hand over relevant police files to the Public Advocate, Mark Green, who wants to review New York City's handling of police misconduct cases. Last week a four-judge panel of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court ruled unanimously that Mr. Green was entitled to the records to fulfill his independent duties under the City Charter.

title: German Utility Expects Decline in Earnings
description: Viag A.G., Germany's No. 3 utility, indicated yesterday that its third-quarter pretax profit fell 7.2 percent, held back by start-up costs at its telecommunications business and by a drop in global aluminum prices. Its implied quarterly pretax profit fell to 634 million marks ($378 million) from 683 million a year earlier. Nine-month pretax profit rose 17 percent, within analysts' expectations. Viag expects 1998 operating profit to rise about 5 percent.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS 3.5 PERCENT. Prices slumped after the International Energy Agency in London said world demand was growing at its slowest rate in five years. The December contract fell 49 cents, to $13.38 a barrel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, RUTH
description: MARKS - Ruth. Congregation Rodeph Sholom records with sorrow the passing of our long time member Ruth Marks. Our deepest sympathy is extended to her husband Alfred, their children Erica and John, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, Senior Rabbi Mark Biderman, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWISON, THOMAS
description: LEWISON-Thomas, on November 7th, 1998, at age 56, in Boca Raton, FL. Beloved husband of Nancy. Devoted father of Rebecca, Deborah and her husband, Steve. Loving brother of Richard and brother-in-law, Stuart Teicher. Funeral services will be held in Florida on Tuesday, November 10th. A memorial to be held in New York will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, kindly direct contributions in memory of Tom Lewison to the Scleroderma Foundation, 89 Newbury St., Suite 201, Danvers, MA 01923.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATTELL, HAROLD
description: ATTELL-Harold. Central Synagogue of Nassau County sorrowfully announces the passing of its longtime member and past president and extends to his beloved family its sincerest sympathy. Rabbi Julian I. Cook Judith D. Race, President

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''My father's family survived in Bosnian society as a minority for centuries. To survive, you have to know who you are.''

title: Defense in Central Park Case Says Friend Was the Killer
description: The lawyer for a teen-age boy on trial in a gruesome slaying in Central Park in 1997 said yesterday that his companion, a teen-age girl who gave evidence against him under a plea bargain, was actually the killer.

title: The Best Mathematician
description: To the editor:

title: VITAL SIGNS: SIDE EFFECTS; TV Teen-Ager: High Alcohol Content
description: Teen-agers are drowning in drink, at least on television. Two new studies have found that when teen-agers watch television, the teen-age characters they see are shown with alcohol more often than with any other food or beverage.

title: Gingrich Loses, Republicans Gain?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HERZ, JOHN W.
description: HERZ-John W. A memorial service will be held at the Ethical Culture Society of Westchester, 7 Saxon Woods Road, White Plains, New York, at 2 PM, Wednesday, November 11th, 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANSON, JULIUS
description: MANSON-Julius. Deeply caring and loving father of Paul Manson, David Manson and Carol Bier; adoring grandfather of Ezra, Jenny and Elisha; beloved brother of Ceil Mofenson; admiring uncle of Laura Zeitlin, Jane Henderson and many others. Contributions in his memory to Hebrew Free Loan Society, 205 E. 42 St, NY NY 10017, Humanist Society of Metropolitan New York and Universal Esperanto Assn, 777 U.N. Plaza, NY NY 10017. Memorial, Sunday, November 29, 2 P.M., New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 W. 64 St.

title: Conde Nast Rehires Consultant Who Was Convicted of Bribery
description: Sixteen weeks after he was sent to prison for his leading role in a scheme to rig bids on office construction work in Manhattan, a top buildings consultant has gone back to work, supervising construction on the Conde Nast tower in Times Square as part of his work release program.

title: Accounts
description: * Voss of Norway, Oslo, to Frierson Mee & Kraft, New York, as the first agency to handle advertising for the Voss bottled water brand in the United States. Billings were estimated at $6 million.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BONHAM, WILLIAM R.
description: BONHAM-William R. 11/27/2111/10/87. I still think of you every day as I have since the day I last saw you all those years ago. It is still impossible for me to think of you as gone. To me you will never be gone. Mo

title: PRI Reverses Fortunes and Wins Crucial Mexican Governorships
description: The governing party won the big prizes in three state elections on Sunday, closing out an election year in which it has repeatedly humbled its bickering opposition rivals. The results fuel the party's hopes of extending its 70-year domination of Mexican politics into the next century.

title: Jury Deliberates Levin Murder Case and Asks Questions
description: After three weeks of testimony from more than 70 witnesses, prosecutors and defense lawyers presented their closing arguments yesterday in the trial of a 19-year-old accused of the May 1997 murder of Jonathan M. Levin, a Bronx high school teacher.

title: Renault and Fiat Plan To Merge Foundry Units
description: Renault, the French auto company, said yesterday that it intended to merge most of its foundry operations with those of the Italian car maker Fiat S.p.A. The merger will be carried out through Fiat's foundry subsidiary, Teksid S.p.A.. Fiat and Renault will be shareholders in a new Teksid, holding 66.5 percent and 33.5 percent, respectively. Renault's foundry operations will become Teksid subsidiaries.

title: Q & A
description: Ticklish Subjects

title: When the People Decline to Be Spun
description: It is fitting that Newt Gingrich, an early booster of the new media of the information age, has become the first politician brought down by them. He made a mortal calculation: he assumed that the public would be more easily manipulated than it used to be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERBER, JOSHUA B.
description: GERBER-Joshua B. Died suddenly on November 7, 1998 at age 24. Loving son of Paul and Anita and brother of Amanda. Interment is private. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Gingrich Loses, Republicans Gain?
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: A Reversal on Welfare

title: Settlement on Breast Implant Claims
description: The Dow Corning Corporation filed a bankruptcy reorganization plan yesterday that included $3.2 billion to settle claims from women over its silicone breast implants and $1.3 billion in payments to commercial creditors.

title: Hospital Accused of Hiding Details of Woman's Death
description: The husband of a woman who died during a routine surgical procedure at Beth Israel Medical Center last year charged yesterday that the hospital tried to keep the circumstances of her death from both state regulators and family members. He also contended that members of his wife's family repeatedly asked for explanations that never came.

title: Resolved: Science Is at an End. Or Is It?; 'We Are Down To the Details Now'
description: Few books have caused as much consternation among scientists as John Horgan's ''The End of Science'' (Helix Books, 1996), in which the author, then a writer for Scientific American, argued that science was nearing the limits of what could be learned about the natural world. Among those dismayed by Mr. Horgan's argument was Sir John Maddox, who in two stints as editor of the British journal Nature (from 1966 to 1973 and from 1980 to 1995) provoked controversy himself with commentaries on everything from the Big Bang to homeopathy. Now he has published ''What Remains to be Discovered?'' (Free Press), his own forecast of the future of science and, in effect, an answer to Mr. Horgan. The two authors debated the issue recently in Manhattan. Here are their excerpts of what they said. DENNIS OVERBYE

title: State to Ask Congress For River Tunnel Funds
description: The Assembly Transportation Committee voted yesterday to ask Congress for $5 million to design a new railway tunnel under the Hudson River to link New Jersey's main commuter line with Grand Central Terminal and Penn Station in Manhattan.

title: All That Glitters Isn't Gold; Charlotte Area Feels Ill Effects From the Asian Crisis
description: The downtown skyline comes suddenly into view just over a rise on Interstate 85. In the distance, the morning sun sparkles on the glass and polished-stone office towers, which seem to rise straight up from the green countryside. More than one visitor, catching sight of the skyline for the first time, has compared the experience to Dorothy's wide-eyed first glimpse of the Emerald City.

title: Blockbuster Shows And Prices to Match; Museums' Costs Just Keep on Rising
description: Visiting Boston this weekend? You can have tea at the Ritz-Carlton for $14.50 (including scones, fruit bread and fruit tart), eat a roast beef dinner at the landmark Durgin Park Restaurant for $12.95 (for a 16-ounce cut) or visit the aquarium for $11.

title: DEATH BY ARSENIC: A special report.; New Bangladesh Disaster: Wells That Pump Poison
description: This fall, the young mother found out that her own slow dying was nothing unusual, that tens of thousands of Bangladeshi villagers were suffering the same ghastly decay, with their skin spotted like spoiled fruit and warts and sores covering their hands and feet.

title: Brazil's Slump Sends Car and Beef Exports Down in Argentina
description: In the first concrete sign that recession in Brazil may be slowing Argentina's economy, leading auto makers here have temporarily idled plants and are reporting a drop in car sales.

title: Gingrich Loses, Republicans Gain?
description: To the Editor:

title: DIALOGUE: Is That a Story or a Stereotype on the Big Screen; Again, Islam Is An Easy Villain
description: Producers of ''The Siege'' would have us believe that art is merely imitating life in the film's portrayal of crazed Muslims killing hundreds of innocent New Yorkers. I'm afraid that it is life that may imitate art, however, as moviegoers are yet again introduced to Islam through a relentless barrage of terrorism and violence.

title: Excerpts From Testimony Before Panel on Grounds for Impeachment
description: Following are excerpts from testimony before a subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee today on what constitutes grounds for impeachment. The speakers were Representative Charles Canady, Republican of Florida, the chairman of the subcommittee; the Rev. Robert F. Drinan, a professor of law at Georgetown University Law Center and a former Congressman who sat on the House Judiciary Committee during the Watergate impeachment inquiry; and Gary L. McDowell, director of the Institute for United States Studies at the University of London. The testimony was transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company:

title: Primordial Cells Fuel Debate On Ethics
description: Officials of the National Institutes of Health are seeking legal advice as to whether the Congressional ban on fetal research applies to the primordial human cells that scientists announced last week they had isolated and grown in the laboratory for the first time.

title: Babies on Sideline as Mothers Work Out
description: Ten mothers with babies nearby in strollers jumped up and down in unison on the steps around the Alice in Wonderland statue in Central Park, as their babies slept. Sweat poured off Elizabeth Firestone as she peered into the stroller at her sleeping 3-month-old twins, Henry and Jack. ''This is the only time in my day that they'll sleep at the same time,'' she said, out of breath.

title: Another Confrontation With Iraq
description: Even as it considers air strikes against Iraq, the Clinton Administration seems ready to abandon the seven-year-old United Nations weapons inspection program there. That would be a premature and costly decision. Though slowed by Baghdad's obstructions and evasions, the international weapons specialists working inside Iraq have provided an effective first line of defense against Saddam Hussein's efforts to produce and hide usable germ and nerve gas weapons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRASNER, DAVID H.
description: KRASNER-David H. A former Schenley Industries marketing executive. Died on November 5 at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 86. During his lengthy retirememt, he volunteered with the International Executive Service Corps as a consultant helping businesses in developing countries and the privatization on the Eastern Bloc. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Sandra, four children Carla, Shelley, Philip, and Dr. Julia; a sister Cecil Jaffe, a brother Harry, 3 sons-in-law, and 8 grandchildren. Contributions may be made in his memory to the American Heart Association and designate them for research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, HELEN K.
description: FISHER-Helen K. Age 77, Doylestown, PA., & Westchester County NY, on November 6 1998. Survived by husband Lewis, children Frances & Luke, brother Robert Kohn, grandchildren Amelia and Sam. Memorial donations: Children's Center Bedford Hills Correction Facility, Harris Road, Bedford Hills, New York 10507.

title: Caspian Oil Pipeline
description: To the Editor:

title: Can Scientists Discover a Limit to Discovery?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Political Briefing; Political Family Tree Branches Out in West
description: Roosevelts . . . Kennedys . . . Rockefellers . . . Bushes . . . .

title: Campbell Soup Revamps Roster
description: The Campbell Soup Company announced a sweeping realignment of its agency roster yesterday that included the elimination of two of its four principal shops.

title: Patterns
description: Early Shows, Late Gala

title: Anniversary Sets Germans To Quarreling On Holocaust
description: Germany marked the 60th anniversary of the Nazi rampage against the Jews known as Kristallnacht today with ceremonies that reflected a country divided over how to balance the duties of memory with a new thirst to move beyond the shadow of the Holocaust.

title: PHARMERICA HIRES ADVISER TO WEIGH ALTERNATIVES
description: Pharmerica Inc., one of the biggest United States pharmacy services companies, said yesterday that it had hired Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette to advise it on strategic alternatives. The company, based in Tampa, Fla., said that it had eliminated 46 jobs as part of a streamlining and that its chief operating officer, Robert Della Valle, had resigned. Pharmerica also reported a third-quarter loss of $127.4 million after a pretax charge of $149.7 million. The shares fell 65.625 cents, to $4.4375, giving the company a market capitalization of almost $400 million.

title: Hurricane Victims: Is U.S. Doing Enough?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Microsoft Rebuttal but Nothing to Rebut
description: Expecting the Government to play a damaging videotape in Federal court today, executives of the Microsoft Corporation summoned reporters to an early morning news conference to offer an advance rebuttal in the form of their own videotape.

title: Expanded Tourney Set to Begin
description: N.C.A.A. WOMEN

title: 6 European Hotels Sold
description: A joint venture of Servico Inc. and the investment bank Lehman Brothers Holdings has acquired six hotels in Belgium and the Netherlands from City Hotels S.A. The properties have a total of 1,200 rooms. The purchase price was 3.04 billion Belgian francs ($87.9 million), City Hotels said. Servico, based in West Palm Beach, owns or manages 90 hotels with 18,300 rooms in 24 states. City Hotels is a Brussels-based operator of hotels and a fledgling budget airline, City Bird.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMSON, MATTHEW STEVEN
description: ABRAMSON-Matthew Steven. On Nov. 9, 1998. Beloved son of Dr. David and Stephanie Abramson, brother of Hilary. Services private.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AMORY, CLEVELAND
description: AMORY-Cleveland. A memorial service for Cleveland Amory will be held at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 111th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Thursday, November 12 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Fund for Animals.

title: Baby Cuckoo's Tricks Are Unmasked
description: Hearing the insistent peeps of a nest full of hungry chicks, a reed warbler dutifully flies off in search of more food. But researchers report that what may sound like a brood of starved warbler nestlings may actually be a single huge cuckoo chick imitating the calls of the baby birds it long ago threw out of the nest.

title: Judge in the Paula Jones Case Strongly Urged the Two Sides to Reach a Settlement
description: The judge who heard Paula Corbin Jones's sexual misconduct suit against President Clinton strongly urged the parties twice to settle and suggested in January that Ms. Jones would most likely lose her case if she proceeded.

title: Rumer Godden, an Author Who Evoked Her Childhood in Colonial India, Is Dead at 90
description: Rumer Godden, the prolific British author of ''Black Narcissus'' and ''The River,'' and a writer of children's books that are enjoyed throughout the world, died on Sunday at her home in Dumfriesshire, Scotland. She was 90.

title: Steinbrenner's Emotions Can Be Worth Millions
description: George Steinbrenner wept after the Yankees won the World Series last month, and his tears surprised many who know the team's principal owner as ruthlessly obsessed with victory. But Steinbrenner's sentimentality has always been a factor in the way the organization operates -- perhaps never more so than in the aftermath of the 125-victory championship season.

title: Updated Fable Turns Brecht, and Life, Inside Out
description: The play in an East Berlin theater, a story of economic negotiation between Chinese peasants and American capitalists, has obviously pleased no one. The rich-looking blonde from America, who admits she prefers ''warmth'' in her dramas, politely chirps about the troupe, ''Aren't they just different?'' And the outraged East German cultural secretary fulminates: ''I thought we were going to see a play by Brecht. I don't think this is it at all.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, EDWARD
description: JONES-Edward. The staff, Board and Advocacy Council of Citizens' Committee for Children of New York are deeply saddened over the death of Edward Jones, husband of our longtime board member Anne Jones. We send our sympathy and condolences to Anne and her family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TINDEL, SEYMOUR, M.D., J.D.
description: TINDEL-Seymour, M.D., J.D. 70 years old. Of Kings Point, NY. On November 8, 1998. Beloved husband of Barbara, proud and loving father of Michael and Nathaniel, and cherished brother of Martin. Dr. Tindel practiced medicine and surgery in the Bronx for over 30 years and taught at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. A renaissance man, he became a lawyer in 1989. Loved by family, friends, and patients alike, he will be truly missed by all those fortunate enough to have made his acquaintance. Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, NY, November 10, 1998, at 10:00 AM.

title: A Classic Republican: Robert Linlithgow Livingston
description: The man who would be Speaker is in many ways a classic Republican. He is a hawk on defense. He is an advocate for business, especially the oil and gas industries in his home district in Louisiana. He opposes abortion. His formative political years were spent reading Ayn Rand and George Orwell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIEFBERG, HENRIETTA
description: RIEFBERG-Henrietta. The officers, trustees and members of Temple Sinai of Roslyn record with profound sorrow the passing of Henrietta Riefberg. Our condolences to the family Rabbi Michael A. White Rabbi Norman Kahan, Emeritus Daniel S. Reich, President

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Hillary for Senate?

title: Justice Dept. Questions President In '96 Campaign Finance Inquiry
description: President Clinton was questioned at the White House today by Justice Department prosecutors investigating whether he circumvented campaign finance laws to promote his re-election in 1996 with a barrage of television advertisements.

title: Lawyers for Bombing Suspects Say Jail Rules Violate Rights
description: Lawyers for two men being held in connection with the bombings of the United States Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania said yesterday that they had complained to the Government that harsh prison restrictions in Manhattan were violating their clients' rights and making it extremely difficult to prepare their defenses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUGGAN, STEPHEN PIERCE, JR.
description: DUGGAN-Stephen Pierce, Jr. Died peacefully on November 8, 1998 in Cornwall-on-Hudson, NY. Husband of the late Beatrice Abbott Duggan, brother of the late Mary Hodder, Laurence Duggan, and Sally Duggan Webb, father of Stephen Pierce Duggan III, Marianne Bell O'Brien, Peter M. Duggan, Hayden A. Duggan, and the late Betsey Duggan, grandfather of twelve grandchildren, six greatgrandchildren and uncle of nieces and nephews, all of whom loved and admired him. Mr. Duggan was a founder and the first chairman of Natural Resources Defense Council, a former trustee of the Institute of International Education, which was founded by his father, and a member of the boards of Scenic Hudson, Phillips Exeter Academy, Vassar College, New School for Social Research, Walter Reade Foundation and Collegiate School. He also served as Chairman of the Board of The Dalton and The Storm King Schools, and was a member of the Century Association. He was a Senior Partner at Simpson Thacher & Bartlett until his retirement. A private family service will take place on Friday. Information regarding a future memorial service will be announced. Memorial contributions may be made to the Stephen P. Duggan Fund at Natural Resources Defense Council, 40 W. 20th St., NY NY 10011.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, GLADYS
description: BLUM-Gladys. On November 7th, 1998. Mother of Jake and Liz, grandmother of Yami, Katrina, Sarah, Pallo, Joseph and Jackson, sister of Blanche Sultan. Lifelong activist for peace and justice. Civil engineer. Wife of the late Tippy Blum. We all loved you. You will be with us always. The Blum Family

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page on Thursday about an advertising account awarded to Robert A. Becker Inc. Euro RSCG, New York, misspelled the names of the client and the product. The client is Centocor, not Centour, and the product is Retavase, not Retevase.

title: AT LUNCH WITH -- Margaret Edson; Colors, Numbers, Letters and John Donne
description: The lunch menu at Centennial Place Elementary School on Thursday included square slices of cheesy pizza, a lettuce-only salad, syrupy fruit cocktail and corn. And so it was not entirely unexpected when corn kernels began to fly shortly after the two dozen members of Margaret Edson's kindergarten class took their seats at a long cafeteria table. Some of the projectiles were lobbed by hand by kindergartners at a neighboring table. Others were fired with slingshot force of a plastic fork.

title: Anonymous Donor Pays For Lawyer in Retrial
description: A Garden City lawyer who represented a white man charged with attempted murder in the beating of a black man has unexpectedly re-entered the case. The lawyer, Bruce A. Barket, said yesterday that a person or group he declined to identify had paid him a retainer to represent Austin Offen of Floral Park, Queens, in his retrial, which is to begin on Jan. 4.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Oct. 25 about Dr. Mary S. Calderone, who battled political and religious groups to take sex education to schools, misstated her political affiliation. She was a Democrat, not a Republican. The list of survivors also misidentified the public health degree held by a daughter, Francesca Calderone-Steichen, a gerontologist. It is a master's, not a doctorate.

title: Pathfinder Probe Transforms Red Planet Into the Whistling Planet
description: Mars is windy. It has tattered clouds, dust storms, jet streams and dunes of windblown sand. In daytime, the sky can look salmon pink because of red dust in the air. In southern areas during the summer months, strong winds can occasionally stir up enough dust to cloak the entire planet. In general, fierce winds appear to have carved much of the Martian surface.

title: Sequencing the Malaria Protozoan
