description: Biologists have taken a first step toward cracking the code of the parasite that causes malaria and using the information to explore all the deadly organism's biological weaknesses.

title: Strivers, Scramblers and a Sales Plan Gone Awry
description: SOFT!

title: The Mets Leave Options Open on General Manager
description: Saying that extramarital affairs are not necessarily a reason to fire a general manager, the Mets' admittedly disheartened owners nevertheless left open the possibility that Steve Phillips would not return from his leave of absence to resume his role as the team's No. 1 baseball executive.

title: Malaysian Central Bank Cuts a Lending Rate
description: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara, cut the rate at which it lends to commercial banks yesterday to 7 percent from 7.5 percent in an attempt to revive credit growth as the nation struggles with a recession. The bank said the rate cut was effective immediately.

title: Two Teams Moving In Opposite Direction
description: Take the records and flip them.

title: Time for New York to Act on Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: Patriot American Selling Some Holdings
description: Patriot American Hospitality Inc., which has $1.2 billion in loans due by 2000, agreed today to sell hotels and equity interests in two separate deals for $206.5 million.

title: 'A Man in Full'
description: In the Norton Simon Museum, in Pasadena, Calif., there hangs a self-portrait of the 18th-century French painter Maurice Quentin de La Tour. The artist wears an expression of intense self-satisfaction and the foppish attire of the flaneur. Just below him is a note from the curators that tells you who he was and why he looks so pleased with himself. Unlike most academy painters of his day, the note explains, Quentin de La Tour chose to work in pastels rather than oils. Pastels were widely dismissed as superficial by the oil painters, but the effects this artist achieved were so powerful that the oil men were forced to take notice. And with each new pastel the oil painters became more fearful that Maurice Quentin de La Tour would put them all out of business.

title: Kosovo Crisis Strains Relations Between the U.S. and Europe
description: When Richard C. Holbrooke reached an agreement last month with President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia to avert NATO air strikes in Kosovo, the German Government waited two days for a copy of the accord before finally squeezing one out of the Yugoslav Embassy in Bonn.

title: Favorable Trials of 2 Drugs Push Centocor Shares Up 9%
description: Shares of Centocor Inc. rose 9.26 percent today after researchers at separate medical conferences reported positive results from clinical trials of the company's two major drugs.

title: Jean Marais, 84, Dashing French Movie Star
description: Jean Marais, who became one of France's most popular movie and theater actors thanks to his close friendship with the Surrealist poet and artist Jean Cocteau, died on Sunday at a hospital in Cannes. He was 84 and lived in Vallauris on the French Riviera.

title: A Visionary's Dreams, Disguised as Buildings, Altered the Landscape
description: The glowing photography that enriches Ken Burns and Lynn Novick's new biography of Frank Lloyd Wright catches the spirit of the work and the man. The contributions of critics, scholars, associates and others are eloquent and enlightening, but it is is the camera that presents his buildings as he wanted them to be seen. The viewer is invited to feel what it must have been like first to come on a Wright masterpiece and then to live and work in one.

title: AFFILIATED MANAGERS TO BUY RORER ASSET MANAGEMENT
description: Affiliated Managers Group Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Rorer Asset Management, a Philadelphia-based money manager, for about $65 million in cash, making its 13th investment in a fund-management firm. The Boston-based Affiliated Managers will buy 65 percent of Rorer, leaving 35 percent with Rorer's principals, led by its chairman, Edward Rorer, and its president, James Hesser. Affiliated Managers' 12 fund-management affiliates oversaw a combined $53 billion of assets as of Sept. 30. Rorer, which has 62 employees, manages about $3.7 billion of assets for institutional investors and wealthy individuals. Mr. Rorer and Mr. Hesser signed employment agreements that will keep them in place at the firm for at least the next eight years.

title: Neighbor Admits Firing Gun Into Home of Paroled Rapist
description: The 23-year-old neighbor of a paroled sex offender admitted yesterday that he fired five bullets into the parolee's Linden, N.J., home last June in hopes of frightening him into moving out of the neighborhood.

title: Novartis Loses Suit Over Its Corn Patent
description: Novartis A.G., the world's largest agricultural products company, lost a bid today to collect $194 million from the Monsanto Company and the DeKalb Genetics Corporation when a jury invalidated a Novartis patent on corn seed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIDMANN, EDMONDS, LORETTA
description: EIDMANN - EDMONDS - Loretta, November 8th, 1998. Beloved mother of Loretta, Donald, and Frederick (Teresa). Loving grandmother of Marc. Viewing Wednesday, November 11th, 1998, 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM, at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 West 72nd St. Funeral Mass Thursday, November 12, 1998, 10 AM, at Blessed Sacrament Church, 152 West 71st St.

title: Stronger Policies Are Needed to Stem Police Brutality, Council Committee Report Says
description: Fifteen months after the Abner Louima case put a new spotlight on the issue of police brutality in New York, a City Council panel issued a report yesterday that attributed such misconduct in part to inadequate policies and procedures within the Police Department.

title: Olbermann to Join Fox Sports, Leaving News Role at MSNBC
description: Keith Olbermann, who left ESPN in a blaze of acrimony last year to become host of a nightly news program on MSNBC, will leave that cable news service to become the main anchor for Fox Sports News, a job similar to the one he had at ESPN.

title: Resolved: Science Is at an End. Or Is It?
description: Few books have caused as much consternation among scientists as John Horgan's ''The End of Science'' (Helix Books, 1996), in which the author, then a writer for Scientific American, argued that science was nearing the limits of what could be learned about the natural world. Among those dismayed by Mr. Horgan's argument was Sir John Maddox, who in two stints as editor of the British journal Nature (from 1966 to 1973 and from 1980 to 1995) provoked controversy himself with commentaries on everything from the Big Bang to homeopathy. Now he has published ''What Remains to be Discovered?'' (Free Press), his own forecast of the future of science and, in effect, an answer to Mr. Horgan. The two authors debated the issue recently in Manhattan. Here are their excerpts of what they said. DENNIS OVERBYE

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Sports of The Times; For Now, Mets Stand By Their Man
description: ''A BUMP in the road,'' said David Howard, the Mets' senior vice president for business and legal affairs, including those extramarital. But bumps are typically rolled right over, as opposed to being navigated around with a doctored spin.

title: 2 Indictments and 3 Guilty Pleas In Sterling Foster Brokerage Case
description: Two people affiliated with Sterling Foster & Company, a defunct brokerage firm, were indicted yesterday on charges of cheating investors out of $100 million by manipulating the prices of stocks the firm underwrote and sold. Three others have already pleaded guilty in the case.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOROWITZ, MAX
description: HOROWITZ-Max. November 10, 1972. I miss you

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREY, PHYLLIS R.
description: FREY-Phyllis R. To have a good friend is to know we've being truly blessed. You will walk by my side always. Forever with love, Diane.

title: Red Sox Have Made New Offer To Vaughn
description: The sputtering yearlong negotiation between Mo Vaughn and the Boston Red Sox spurted to life today when the team made a new offer to its free-agent first baseman. Neither side disclosed details, so it was not known if the offer was close to the six-year, $72 million offer the Anaheim Angels made to Vaughn last weekend.

title: Political Memo; Pataki's Luck On the Road To Triumph
description: Successful politicians make their own luck, and on that score, give Gov. George E. Pataki his due. He did what he promised -- cut taxes and reinstated the death penalty -- and he has shown a knack for taking advantage of what fate and Wall Street have handed him.

title: BERGEN BRUNSWIG TO ADD STADTLANDER DRUG
description: The Bergen Brunswig Corporation will acquire the Stadtlander Drug Company from the Counsel Corporation for about $300 million in cash and stock. It will also assume $100 million in debt. Stadtlander, based in Pittsburgh, provides pharmaceutical care to high-risk patients with chronic diseases and conditions. It has annual revenue of about $500 million. Counsel is a holding company based in Toronto with units in Canada and the United States. Bergen Brunswig, the Orange, Calif., distributor of pharmaceuticals and other health care products, will reimburse Counsel for costs of about $28 million to allow Bergen to treat the acquisition as a purchase of assets for tax purposes. Shares of Bergen Brunswig rose 75 cents, to $56.0625. Counsel's United States shares rose 31.25 cents, to $8.8125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GULKIN, ANITA KURMAN
description: GULKIN-Anita Kurman. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, Inc., in acknowledging with sadness the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Anita Kurman Gulkin, President and CEO of Greenwich House. Highly regarded for her dedication to the community, Ms. Gulkin started her distinguished career as a social worker in Beth Israel's substance abuse services program and went on to serve Greenwich House for nearly 30 years. To her brother, Beth Israel attending physician, Martin Kurman, M.D., the Kurman and Gulkin families and all who loved her, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Robert G. Newman, MD, President and CEO, CHP Matthew E. Fink, MD, President and CEO, BIMC Beverly L. Richman, MD, Chief Medical Services Methadone Maintenance Treatment Program, BIMC Addie Corradi, Administrative Director MMTP, BIMC

title: A Broad Range Revealed As a Season Closes
description: American Ballet Theater

title: Out of State, Giuliani Will Tell Of Civility Drive and Raise Funds
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will travel to Iowa and Michigan this weekend to speak at a university and a fund-raising dinner for a synagogue, his aides said yesterday.

title: Adweek magazine is commemorating its 20th anniversary with a record 232-page special issue.
description: HERE'S a question for Robert Stack and ''Unsolved Mysteries'': Why did so many advertising trade publications start in years ending in 8?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, JEROME
description: BERKOWITZ-Jerome. Age 70, on November 9, 1998. Professor of Mathematics at the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences, New York University. Beloved husband of Lori, devoted father of David and Susan. Grandfather of Jeffrey and Dana.

title: School Vouchers Survive as Justices Sidestep a Debate
description: The Supreme Court today sidestepped for the time being the national debate over whether taxpayer-financed vouchers may be used to send children to parochial schools. The Justices let stand a state court ruling upholding the constitutionality of such a program in Milwaukee.

title: Expectation Aside, Water Use in U.S. Is Showing Decline
description: In a little-noticed environmental turnabout, Federal analysts report that Americans' use of water declined by about 9 percent from 1980 to 1995 -- even as the United States' population grew by 16 percent over the same period.

title: High Jinks on the High Seas, and a Little Shakespeare, Too
description: In the hustle department, you can't beat the cast of ''Pericles.'' The actors are over the stage like worker ants, helping the stagehands (those all-too-visible guys with the rock-concert headsets) to batten down the retractable units of Mark Wendland's triple-decker Erector set.

title: Giants' Goals Are Intangible in an Unfathomable Season
description: The Giants today found themselves in a new place with an old feel.

title: White House Is Said to Favor a Swift Move Against Iraq
description: Senior Clinton Administration officials said today that they were leaning toward using force against Iraq sooner rather than later and were making contingency plans about how President Clinton's trip to Asia might be curtailed, or even canceled.

title: By Design; Vests to Fit Any Moment
description: As jackets fade into the fashion background, the vest is stepping forward as an alternative to layer over a shirt or turtleneck. It can look businesslike or sporty, dressy or even streetwise, depending on how it's worn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, IVAN
description: SHAPIRO-Ivan. Urban Pathways notes with sorrow the death of Ivan Shapiro, its esteemed past President. Through his active leadership and enthusiasm, Ivan Shapiro played an important role in the growth of Urban Pathways. We will continue to strive to meet the high standards he set for honesty, ethics and quality of work. We feel the loss of our warm friend and advocate for the homeless and extend our deep sympathy to his wife, Maria, and his daughters, Lisa J. Kubiske and Alexandra Shapiro. Gerald W. Blume, President Joan E. Ohlson, Exec Director

title: For Testaverde and Johnson, the Play Was the Thing
description: Some of the current Jets think this has never happened before on this team -- a 6-3 record, a share of first place. And actually, first place has not been a place to look for the Jets at season's end in all the years since the National Football League and American Football League merged in 1970.

title: After a Struggle, Women Win A Place 'on the Ice'; In Labs and in the Field, a New Outlook
description: Twenty years ago, when Julia Uberuaga first began working in Antarctica, she was one of only a few women among hundreds of men. They stared at her, or leered at her, or otherwise let her know she was unwelcome on the job.

title: Robert Livingston, The Heir Apparent With a Black Belt
description: Representative Robert Linlithgow Livingston is in some ways a typical Republican -- pro-defense, pro-business and anti-abortion. But Mr. Livingston, the Louisiana Republican who is expected to replace Newt Gingrich as Speaker of the House, also has a black belt in karate and moods to match. When angry, he is known to shout, turn red and flail his arms. Friends and adversaries alike say these outbursts are usually done for effect, and when they are over, he will catch someone's eye and laugh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOTTE, FRANK
description: BOTTE-Frank. Of New York City and Easthampton. Died on November 8 at New York Hospital at the age of 56. The beloved son of Marie Amerosa, he is also survived by his devoted companion of many years, Stacy Charles. ''You are a child of the universe, no less than the trees and the stars...be at peace with God.'' Reposing at Prospero and Son Funeral Home, 2444 86th Street, Brooklyn, Tuesday and Wednesday. Visiting hours are 2-5 and 7-9:30 P.M. Funeral service will be held on Thursday at 10 A.M. at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, 1157 Lexington Avenue, between 79th and 80th Streets. Donations to God's Love We Deliver.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Microscopic Iron Men

title: Drug Testers Turn to 'Virtual Patients' as Guinea Pigs
description: Medical researchers have long done experiments either ''in vivo'' (living organisms) or ''in vitro'' (in glass or test tubes). Now they are starting to work ''in silico,'' or in computers.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Ski Association Picks Leagas Delaney
description: The National Ski Areas Association, a trade organization that represents 333 ski resorts, has named Leagas Delaney in San Francisco as the first agency to handle a campaign to increase participation in skiing and snowboarding. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: Evening of Stars and Surprises
description: The 23d annual benefit concert of the Richard Tucker Music Foundation, on Sunday night at Avery Fisher Hall, was even longer than the substantive 22d gala last year: it lasted 3 hours 15 minutes. And though the energy of some generous musicians from the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra, who spent a night off from the Met playing for this good cause, understandably started to flag toward the end, the conductor Leonard Slatkin was tireless. He led the orchestra, the New York Choral Society and a roster of distinguished singers in a program to celebrate the foundation, which grants awards to operatic artists at crucial stages in their careers.

title: Accused Pleads Case as Murder Trial Opens
description: James Allen Gordon stood confidently in a Queens courtroom yesterday, asked the jury to bring a skeptical eye to the murder charges filed against him and calmly pleaded for his life.

title: Hershey to Sell Pasta Business And Focus on Sweeter Profit
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation is shopping for a buyer for its pasta business, saying it wants to stick to making chocolate and candy.

title: IT'S IMPEACHMENT OR NOTHING, PANEL IS TOLD BY EXPERTS
description: Constitutional scholars on both sides of the impeachment debate warned members of the House Judiciary Committee today that a compromise like a vote to censure President Clinton had no basis in the Constitution and could dangerously weaken the institution of the Presidency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREGG, WILLIAM KIRKER
description: GREGG-William Kirker. Of Keene Valley, NY (formerly Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ), died November 7th after a long illness. Mr. Gregg was born July 11, 1921, to Juliette (Kirker) and Otis Gregg in Hackensack, NJ. He was a World War II veteran and industrialist, manufacturing railroad cars for The Gregg Company, Brussels, Belgium. He served on the Boards of the Hackensack Hospital, YMCA, Rotary Club. After his move to the Adirondacks, he was President of the Good Samaritan Counseling Center, on the Board of Directors for the Neighborhood House and the Elizabethtown Community Hospital. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Louise (nee Lydecker); daughters, Susan, Juliette, Janet and Dorothy; granddaughters, Stephanie and Jessica DeBiasio; sons-in-law, Richard Latimer and Daniel DeBiasio; and brother, Richard. Donations may be made to the Neighborhood House, Keene Valley, New York 12943.

title: LEVEL ONE IN STOCK DEAL FOR JATO TECHNOLOGIES
description: Level One Communications Inc., a maker of computer networking chips, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Jato Technologies Inc., which offers network accelerator chips, for $80 million in stock to acquire products that send data over phone wires at high speed. Level One said it would issue new shares for all the shares of Jato, which is based in Austin, Tex. Shares of Level One, based in Sacramento, Calif., rose 43.75 cents, to $25.75. The company's announcement came after the market closed.

title: Giuliani Says He'll Veto Bill on Weekly Recycling
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would veto a bill passed unanimously by the City Council to restore weekly recycling pickups in many parts of the city, declaring that proponents of the measure think of recycling as ''a religion or supernatural thing.'' Council members said they expect to easily override the veto.

title: Silencing the Pundits
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Official Visits a Site Of Executions In Kosovo
description: The senior American official concerned with war crimes visited a mass execution site in Kosovo today and urged the Serbian Government to allow investigators of the international tribunal in The Hague to visit the province.

title: Female Inmates Sue Over 'Pat Frisks' by Men
description: Six female inmates in New York State prisons filed a Federal lawsuit yesterday seeking to prevent male correction officers from frisking clothed women inmates, a practice the women said was degrading and sexually abusive and that violated their constitutional protection against cruel and unusual punishment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMSON, MATTHEW STEVEN
description: ABRAMSON-Matthew Steven. On Nov. 9, 1998. Beloved son of Dr. David and Stephanie Abramson, brother of Hilary. Services private.

title: The Gift Is in the Mail, Savory and Sweet
description: AFTER 17 years of tasting and testing mail-order food for the holidays, I think I have gotten choosing favorites down to something of a science.

title: City and State to Pay $49 Million To Settle Foster-Care Fraud Suit
description: New York City and New York State agreed yesterday to pay $49 million to settle a civil lawsuit brought by a city employee who charged that New York fraudulently collected hundreds of millions of dollars in Federal funds between 1990 and 1994 for required foster care services that were not provided.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: From Carpets to Caviar: The New ABC Food Hall

title: Players Gather Today For a Strategy Session
description: Thirty-five players are scheduled to attend a stategy meeting today in New York to decide whether to present a new proposal to the owners.

title: Paramedic Is Charged With Groping Patient
description: A city paramedic was charged yesterday with groping an 18-year-old woman in the back of an ambulance as she was being taken to the hospital.

title: Fox on NBC's Tail
description: Now maybe it's time for NBC to get worried. Far from dominating, as usual, a ratings sweep month, those all-important ratings competitions, NBC finds itself in an all-out struggle with Fox among viewers between 18 and 49 -- the only race those two networks count -- and with CBS among viewers of any age.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHKIN, JERRY
description: RICHKIN-Jerry. He was a devoted, caring husband, father and grandfather. He was also our beloved dear friend. We followed his acting career and cheered all his successes. His memory will be with us always. We extend our love to the family. The Wellfleet Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILTON, ROBERT E.
description: HILTON-Robert E. Of Bronxville, NY on November 9th, 1998. Husband of Ruth, father of Deborah Timmermann and Susan Bartlett, grandfather of three. Memorial service at the Reformed Church of Bronxville, on Friday, November 13th at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: The Elixirs Of Life Style; Drugs Can Spark Sex Lives and Grow Hair, So Why Are Some Sales Listless?
description: Ben Boucher looked in the mirror several months ago and decided that he did not want to be bald like his father. So, like millions of other balding men, Mr. Boucher, a 25-year-old animator in Montreal who is a long way from losing his hair, picked up a prescription for Propecia, Merck & Company's hair growth pill, and awaited the results.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUTTERMAN, KATE
description: FUTTERMAN-Kate. Beloved wife of the late Moe; mother of Jack (Estelle), and the late William. Revered grandmother of Stacy La Victoire, Susan Kaplan, Robert, Rick, and Roy Futterman. Beloved great-grandmother of Max, Rachel, Sara, Danny, & Marc. Services will be held Thursday, Nov. 12, 1998, 9:45AM, at The Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76 St, NY City.

title: G.O.P.'s Frenzied Alarm Obscures Its Real Gains
description: The frenzy of hand-wringing and upheaval in the Republican Party has obscured an important and unmistakable reality: While the party suffered a defeat in last Tuesday's election, it was not as devastating as Republicans make it seem.

title: Mexican Official Links Massacre To Drug Rivalry
description: A massacre in September in which 19 men, women and children were fatally shot in a driveway in Baja California was a result of a drunken argument between the chieftains of two rival marijuana-smuggling gangs that turned violent, the authorities said today.

title: Accounts
description: * Tahoe Air Corp., Lake Tahoe, Nev., to CMG Communications, New York, as the first agency to handle advertising for the regional airline. Billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million.

title: Argentina Hears Rumors Of a Royal British Suitor
description: President Carlos Saul Menem returned from London last week without making any progress toward his goal of retaking the Falkland Islands. But if the gossip columns here are on to something, he may eventually come away with something else: a British son-in-law, none other than Prince Andrew.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARLOCK, SPRAGUE G.
description: GARLOCK-Sprague G. Of Bronxville, New York, 90 years of age, on November 9th, 1998. Brother of Eleanor Garlock & the late Roger Garlock. Service and interment are private.

title: Compaq to Sell PC's Directly to Consumers
description: Compaq Computer, the largest manufacturer of personal computers, will start selling its machines directly by telephone and over the Internet at prices lower than those now charged by local dealers, people close to the company's strategic planning said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ITZKOFF, JACK S.
description: ITZKOFF-Jack S. Of Ocala, Florida. In his seventieth year. Beloved husband of Isabel. Cherished son of the late Nathan and Jennie Itzkoff. Dear brother of Tedda Kessler and Felice Itzkoff. Loving uncle and stepfather. Graveside services Thursday, November 12, 10:30 AM, King David Cemetery, Putnam Valley, New York.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about Speaker Newt Gingrich misstated the background of a critic, Dr. James C. Dobson. He holds a doctorate in psychology; he is not a minister.

title: In Germany, Wal-Mart Touches Off a Price War
description: FRANKFURT  Unhappy German merchants already felt squeezed by a six-year slump before a fearsome new rival threatened to make things worse.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS AGREES TO BUY ROCKFORD INDUSTRIES
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Rockford Industries for $61 million in stock. Rockford, based in Santa Ana, Calif., finances and leases equipment for small businesses. It had revenue of $15.8 million in the nine months ended Sept. 30, American Express said. American Express, based in New York, provides travel and financial services. It had revenue of $14.07 billion in the nine months ended Sept. 30. The deal, which values Rockford shares at $11.88 each, is expected to close early next year. Shares of Rockford rose 43.75 cents, to $11.3125, in Nasdaq trading, and American Express fell $1.8125 a share, to $93.0625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STORCH, DR. MARCIA
description: STORCH-Dr. Marcia. The American Menopause Foundation Inc is deeply saddened by the passing of their first chairperson of the Medical/Scientific Advisory Board. She will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest sympathies to her family. Marie Lugano, Founder & President Lonnie Wollin, Secretary/Treasurer

title: A Puzzling Wooten May End Up an Ex-Giant
description: Giants free safety Tito Wooten, whose poor play this season has disappointed his coaches and irked his teammates and whose off-the-field troubles have unsettled the organization, may be wearing out his welcome with the team.

title: Early Lessons for Georgetown and Illinois
description: Temple is reloading for its 10th straight appearance in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. Georgetown is rebuilding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLSON, MARGARET UPTON
description: CARLSON-Margaret Upton. On November 9, 1998. Wife of the late Ernest. Devoted mother of Andrew (Robin) Carlson. Dear sister of Anne Von Bartheld. Cherished grandmother of Douglas. Reposing at the Urban Funeral Home, 42-17 69th St., Woodside, Thursday and Friday 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM. Religious Service Saturday 11 AM.

title: Decision Time: To Impeach or Not to Impeach
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GULKIN, ANITA KURMAN
description: GULKIN-Anita Kurman. Oh, how we miss our dear friend, Anita. Until we meet in Paris. Our hearts ache for you Sam. Barbara and Bob.

title: ST. JOHN'S 119, ONE WORLD BASKETBALL 84
description: In its final tune-up before the Chase National Invitation Tournament kicks off the regular season next Monday, St. John's easily defeated an overmatched One World Basketball squad last night. But the 119-84 victory at Alumni Hall did little to convince the Red Storm's new coach, Mike Jarvis, that his young team is ready for the real thing.

title: REPUBLICANS FEUD ON HOW TO HANDLE INQUIRY ON CLINTON
description: After their Election Day losses and growing public fatigue over the inquiry against President Clinton, House Republicans are still feuding about how the impeachment proceedings should play out.

title: Judge Says Phone Company Shortchanged City
description: A state judge has ruled that the phone company shortchanged New York City for years in commissions for pay phones located on public property, and city officials say they hope to receive as much as $100 million to make up the difference.

title: In 'Siege,' Seeing Beyond Stereotypes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARISH, SAMUEL N.
description: BARISH-Samuel N. Congregation Kol Ami records with sorrow the passing of our cherished member and conveys sincere condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Shira Milgrom Rabbi Tom Weiner Cantor Annie Bornstein-Howard Mark A. Hershey, President

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Dalai Lama Tells Clinton of Chinese Balkiness
description: The Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of Tibet, met with President Clinton at the White House today and said he was maneuvering to open talks with the Chinese Government aimed at gaining some degree of autonomy for his people.

title: Corporate Delete Keys Busy As E-Mail Turns Up in Court
description: Employees at Amazon.com, the popular on-line bookseller, recently received a directive from senior management that struck some as out of character in a company that had sprouted from the Internet's free-for-all culture.

title: Florence L. Walsh, 37, Lucent Finance Executive
description: Florence L. Walsh, a fast-rising executive at Lucent Technologies Inc. who helped engineer that company's split from the AT&T Corporation in 1996, died on Saturday at Morristown Memorial Hospital in New Jersey. Ms. Walsh, who lived in Bernardsville, N.J., was 37.

title: Do the Crime, Perish
description: To the Editor:

title: Coveted Collections Of Art At Auction
description: As Sotheby's and Christie's prepare for their big fall sales, which begin tomorrow night with Christie's sale of contemporary art, auction house experts are as concerned about the world financial markets as they are about the number of collectors prepared to buy art. More than any other segment of the art market, auctions rely on buyers' confidence. When the mood in a salesroom is buoyant, so are the prices. But nervousness can be equally contagious, making even those who came to bid get cold feet.

title: Brooklyn Man Charged In Hit and Run of Boy
description: A 20-year-old driver with 28 tickets on his suspended license was arrested yesterday for a hit-and-run accident in Brooklyn on Monday that critically injured a 7-year-old boy.

title: Judge to Hear Complaints on Jail Rules
description: A Federal district judge agreed yesterday to review complaints by lawyers for three men arrested after the bombings of two United States embassies in Africa that their jail conditions in Manhattan are unconstitutional and inhumane.

title: Children Study Longer and Play Less, a Report Says
description: Sketching a portrait of an increasingly stressed generation, new research indicates that American children spend more time in school, more time doing household chores and less time eating, watching television and playing than children did 16 years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REHBEIN, LEWIS B.
description: REHBEIN-Lewis B. Of Huntington, on November 9, 1998. Beloved husband of Violet. Loving father of Marilyn Stevenson and Lewis Rehbein Jr. Dear brother of Robert. Also survived by two cherished grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Visitation 2-5 and 7-9 PM today, at the A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home, Inc., 1380 New York Avenue, Huntington Station. Mass of Christian Burial, Thursday, 9:45AM, St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Huntington. Burial to follow in St. Charles' Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROCHSTEIN, SAMUEL S.
description: BROCHSTEIN-Samuel S. Nov. 9, 1998. The Board of Governors and the Members of Glen Oaks Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their esteemed member Samuel and extend their heartfelt sympathy to his wife Esther and his family. Board of Governors Richard A. Horowitz, President

title: A Record-Breaking Bat? Giuliani Says So
description: One of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proudest possessions, temporarily displayed on the mantel in his City Hall office, is the baseball bat given to him by Sammy Sosa after his parade on lower Broadway last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCORMACK, CATHERINE G.
description: McCORMACK-Catherine G. Devoted mother of Jane, Hugh and George III, loving mother-in-law of Corinne McCormack and William Lauck, delighted grandmother of Adam, loving aunt of Cathy Witt & Martha Brown, died peacefully on Nov. 8th, 1998. Born in Sioux Falls, South Dakota, she attended the Emma Willard School and Smith College. In New York she pursued a career in fashion which included being assistant to the editor of the Fashions of the New York Times. Her brave and loyal spirit, her loving heart, her elegance and style will always be remembered and missed by her family and friends. Funeral on Thursday, November 12th, at 10:30 AM at St. Vincent Ferrer Church corner of 66th and Lexington followed by reception at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66th Street. Donations in memory of Catherine G. McCormack may be sent to Memorial Sloan-Kettering, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: Agnellis Begin Exor Takeover Bid
description: The trust for the Agnelli family of Italy began a $1.6 billion takeover offer yesterday for the Luxembourg-based investment company Exor Group, which owns 19 percent of Club Mediterranee and 20.5 percent of Rockefeller Center Properties, among others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELITZ, MORRIS
description: BELITZ-Morris. The Board of Directors and Membership of the Glenhead Country Club announce with profound sorrow the untimely passing of our esteemed member, Morris Belitz. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. Martin Scheman, President

title: Commercial Real Estate; New Lease on Luxury Dining for the Four Seasons Restaurant
description: That celebrated restaurant at the base of the Seagram Building has signed up for another 68 seasons.

title: Battle Over No. 2 House G.O.P. Post Remains Uncertain
description: Representative Dick Armey of Texas appeared to be ahead today in his struggle to keep his job as House majority leader, the No. 2 leadership position, but a lingering dissatisfaction with him and his two current opponents prompted rumors of a fourth candidate's entering the race.

title: No Need to Act Yet on Changing Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: The Met Museum Names 2 Leaders
description: James R. Houghton, the former chairman of Corning Inc., was named chairman of the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday. Mr. Houghton, a member of the Met's board for 16 years and its vice chairman since 1984, succeeds Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, who announced his retirement from the post in September.

title: Zagat at 20: Populist, and Powerful
description: THE Zagat Survey turned 20 this week, grown from a two-page typed list of New York restaurants into a series of 35 gastronomic guidebooks, each devoted to a city or region, shaped like an upended legal-size envelope, written in a telegraphic style and wrapped in a claret-colored cover.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOGEL, EDWARD A.
description: FOGEL-Edward A. Distinguished Trustee, loyal supporter, dedicated volunteer. He loved the children and they loved him. Lewis B. Cullman, Chairman, Chess-in-the-Schools

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column yesterday, about a special 20th-anniversary issue of Adweek, misspelled the surname of the magazine's designer. He is Walter Bernard, not Berhard. The column also used an erroneous name supplied by the magazine for the typeface of its nameplate. The face is Anzeigen Grotesk Bold, not Ankzeiden Grotesque.

title: Mayor Offers Child Caseworkers 13% Raises
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani offered a large salary increase to New York City's child-welfare workers yesterday as part of a sweeping plan to reorganize their agency. City officials said the reorganization would help reduce job turnover and increase professionalism.

title: Olbermann's Move To Fox Is Official
description: Keith Olbermann officially became the primary anchor of cable's Fox Sports News yesterday and confessed that he never should have left sports when he quit ESPN last year to become the host of MSNBC's news program, The Big Show.

title: FOOTBALL: Keith Jackson's Change Of Seasons; At 70, the Voice of Autumn Prepares to Leave the Booth
description: Look around the Big House in the early morn, Keith Jackson said. Feel its emptiness. Then hunker down a while, watch the crowd fill Michigan Stadium, a sea of maize and blue washing over 92 rows of backless benches. Watch the players burst ebulliently from the tunnel. Watch the Michigan Marching Band warm up. They've got mommas and daddies as proud as if they were Big Uglies opening holes for scatbacks. Listen to them belt out ''Hail! to the conq'ring heroes!'' and get chills like those that made Jackson shiver 40 years ago on his first trip here as the University of Washington's football announcer, a half-dozen years before he went big-time at ABC Sports.

title: Deadline Extended For Indonesian Banks
description: Indonesia agreed yesterday to extend a deadline for banks to repay about 134 trillion rupiah, or roughly $16.7 billion, in emergency loans to four years, Bambang Subianto, Indonesia's Finance Minister, said; the deadline had been one year. The banks will be required to pay 27 percent of the total they owe in cash within the first year; the rest will be staggered over the remaining three.

title: Why Not a Wrestler as Governor?
description: To the Editor:

title: Redecorated, Ambitious and Neighborly
description: THE people at the next table study the menu gravely. ''What's this grana Padano stuff on the spaghetti?'' the man asks his wife. ''I don't know,'' she replies. ''I don't know what half this stuff is. Have you ever heard of bottarga?''

title: Brazilians Scale Back Pledges to Cut Budget
description: The Brazilian Government, which recently pledged to slash discretionary spending by $7 billion in an urgent attempt to bolster its economic credibility, has released new budget figures showing that the true reduction will run about half the promised amount.

title: Fraud Is Rare, But Check The Tab Anyway
description: LAST week, when a well-known New York chef was charged with falsifying the tips on receipts submitted to credit card companies, an alarm might have sounded for diners who don't think twice about the precise amount scrawled on the bottom of the bill. Some might even admit that, after a few glasses of wine and a couple hours of conviviality, they barely think once about it.

title: Sibling Resentment In North Yorkshire
description: This isn't quite what dressing up in Mommy's clothes used to be like.

title: Israeli Cabinet to Consider Delayed Peace Agreement
description: After a nearly two-week delay, the Israeli Cabinet will meet on Wednesday to approve the new Israeli-Palestinian accord, renewing deliberations suspended after a suicide bombing in Jerusalem last Friday, the Government announced today.

title: Journal; Say Cheese, G.O.P.
description: In a classic comedy routine long ago, Mel Brooks and Carl Reiner theorized that the original seven astronauts parading before the public were actually male models, hired by a P.R.-minded NASA to camouflage the fact that it had such ''ugly little astronauts.'' In the aftermath of its election disaster, the Republican Congress seems to be trying out the same strategy.

title: Constitutional Room for Censure
description: Even allowing for partisanship among some of the witnesses, the historians and constitutional scholars who testified before the House on Monday provided an elevated and enlightening discussion of the central issues now facing Congress in the impeachment debate. We disagree strongly, however, with those who argued that Congress, as it seeks to resolve President Clinton's case, has but one choice -- impeachment, or no punishment at all. This narrow reading of the Constitution fails to address both the political realities of the moment and the requirements of justice.

title: Lionesses as Metaphors, and Other Visions in Dance
description: When it was all over, when he had finished choreographing ''The Lion King,'' won his Tony Award and returned home to Rochester, Garth Fagan was relieved to be back with his dance company.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts and Ideas on Oct. 31 about Internet documentation of Israel's becoming an unacknowledged nuclear power misspelled the surname of a director of the Institute of the Future, a Silicon Valley forecasting company, who said the World Wide Web was ''reinventing traditional print.'' He is Paul Saffo, not Sasso.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: Trading Macho For Sensitive

title: U.S. Threatens Europe With 100% Tariffs
description: The Clinton Administration threatened today to place 100 percent tariffs on wine, cheese and other imports from Europe if the European Union did not lift its trade restrictions on bananas sold by American companies.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Shares of Intel Hit New High On Strong Profit Estimates

title: A Matter of Yards From Good to Great
description: TO the French, where a wine comes from is more important than what's in it. That a wine comes from Burgundy means more than that it's made from pinot noir grapes.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RAILING, LEWIS IRA
description: RAILING-Lewis Ira. A memorial service for Mr. Lewis Ira Railing, formerly of New York City, will be held on Friday, November 13, 1998, at 10:00 A.M., at the Drake Hotel, 440 Park Avenue. Mr. Railing died September 24, 1998 at the Newport Hospital, in Newport, Rhode Island. Mrs. Dorrie Richardson, sister of Mr. Railing, and Chip, Bill and Andrew Railing, sons of Mr. Railing, their wives, as well as his eight grandchildren invite you to share in honoring Mr. Railing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VITKIN, JEANNETTE
description: VITKIN-Jeannette. Beloved wife of Robert. Loving mother of Angela and Jeffrey Glosser and Pamela and Gerald Tulman. Cherished grandmother of Allison, Justin, Matthew and Stephanie. Service today 10AM at Temple Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, New York.

title: A 'Gay Mafia' in Whitehall? Sex Is Back in the Headlines in Britain
description: LONDON  Since Christine Keeler's affair with John Profumo almost brought down a government in 1963, sex has been a staple of British political life, selling newspapers by the millions and striking fear into the hearts of cabinet ministers.

title: At 71, Barbara Cook Shows The Way It Was and Now Is
description: Certain singers have the power to do more than just move us with their voices. As they grow and change over the years, they offer an emotional and artistic road map of how to mature with grace and style and transcend the past without rejecting it or re-evaluating it from an ironic distance.

title: Democratic Money Man Has Immunity From Starr
description: John Huang, a Democratic fund-raiser at the center of the 1996 campaign finance controversy, was granted immunity this year in exchange for his cooperation in another criminal case, Kenneth W. Starr's investigation of President Clinton's longtime Arkansas friend Webster L. Hubbell, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Instead of Impeachment
description: At all levels of legal, political and intellectual analysis, it is devilishly difficult to decide how to deal with the pending issue of impeaching the President. Starting with the constitutional interpretation of ''other high crimes and misdemeanors,'' respectable arguments can be made on both sides of whether perjury and/or obstruction of justice, if proved, are impeachable offenses. Most analysts appear to reach their legal conclusions on the side of their political preferences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, ADELE J.
description: SHAPIRO-Adele J. On November 10, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Nathan Shapiro. Loving mother of Elizabeth Ortman. Cherished grandmother of Heidi, Tonia and David and great grandmother of Jessie and Hanna. Loving companion to Bibi Khan. Services Thursday 1:15pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMONYI, ELMER
description: SIMONYI-Elmer, 97, of Southold, Long Island, NY, died on Tuesday, November 10, 1998. He was formerly of Great Neck. He was born June 20, 1901 in Budapest, Hungary, son of the late Sigmund and Frances Simonyi. He was a graduate of Columbia University in New York, NY. He retired as President of DCA Food Industries, Inc. He is survived by a son, Thomas Simonyi, of Morgantown, WV, and two daughters, Eve Blake of St. Louis, MO, and Rene Colletti of Oceanside, Long Island, NY, nine grandchildren; and six great grandchildren. He was preceded in death by his beloved wife of 62 years, Dorothy Ackerman Simonyi. Services will be held at the DeFriest Funeral Home, Southold, NY, on Thursday, November 12, 1998 at 10 AM. Burial will follow in the Cemetery of the First Presbyterian Church of Southold.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARF, FLORA
description: HARF-Flora. Beloved wife of the late Myrtil; beloved mother of Rolf and Ruth. Adored grandmother of Steven. Services private.

title: In Surprise, Russians Ask To Alter Orbit Of Outpost
description: NASA is considering a last-minute request from the Russian Space Agency to change the planned orbit of the international space station, officials said today.

title: King High Coach Is Suspended
description: The boys' soccer coach at Martin Luther King Jr. High School, the two-time city champion, was suspended indefinitely by the principal, Stephanie D'Amore, on Monday after Public School Athletic League officials determined that the team was in violation of two rules.

title: No Need to Act Yet on Changing Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Skirmishes Over Treaty On Warming
description: As negotiators from around the world worked on details of an international agreement to fight global warming, the Clinton Administration faced an intense debate among lawmakers today over whether to sign the pact during talks this week in Argentina.

title: Problems Beset Marines in Accident
description: Something was wrong, Capt. Scott R. Roys knew, with the way his Marine Corps squadron kept reference documents for planning flights in the Italian Alps. In secret testimony this summer, he said that the binder had been stuffed with information laughably old or relevant only to fighter planes the squadron did not fly.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VISTA ENERGY RESOURCES INC., Midland, Tex., agreed to buy oil and natural-gas wells in western Texas from an undisclosed seller for as much as $23.9 million in cash.

title: Just Switch Channels
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAULER, DAVID P., M.D.
description: LAULER-David P., M.D., 67, of Old Lyme, CT. died on Sunday, November 8, 1998 in Dallas, TX while attending a meeting of the American Heart Association. Dr. Lauler's medical career spanned over forty years in patient care, research, academia, medical education, and hospital staff administration. As a recognized pioneer in medical education, Dr. Lauler's lifelong and most recent work included the development and delivery of extensive lecture and seminars in the field of cardiology, endocrinology and medical ethics to medical audiences worldwide. In addition, as an avid user of computer technology, he recently initiated and directed several endeavors aimed at utilization of the World wide Web in postgraduate medical education. In 1996 he retired from the Lawrence and Memorial Hospital of New London, CT. from his position as Chairman, Department of Medicine and Director of Medical Education. In addition to his many medical and professional appointments, Dr. Lauler was a Knight with the American Association of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta. In 1997 he was awarded the Nobel Prize for Medicine in Stockholm, Sweden, in recognition of his lifelong dedication to medicine and education. Dr. Lauler received his M.D. and B.S. from Georgetown University. His postgraduate training included positions at Bellevue, NYC, and New York University as an American Heart Association Research Fellow. He conducted advanced fellowships in cardiology and endocrinology at the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Boston. He held faculty positions at the Harvard Medical School & Yale School of Medicine. He is survived by his wife, Joan O'Connor Lauler, daughters, Karen Hopkins of Califon, N.J., Maureen Sirna of Brooklyn, N.Y., son John Lauler of Old Lyme, CT., a brother, John Lauler of Old Lyme, sisters, Edith Kissell of State College, Penn. & Ruth Ann Hernandez of Brevard, N.C. and four grandchildren. He was predeceased by daughter Colleen Marie Lauler, a sister, Terri Sweitzer and a granddaughter Marie Lauler Sirna. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 11 AM on Friday, November 13, 1998 at St. Mary Star of the Sea Church, New London, CT. Burial will follow in Duck River Cemetery, Old Lyme. Friends may call on Thursday evening from 6-9 PM at the Fulton-Theroux Funeral Home, Beckwith Lane, Old Lyme. Donations may be made in his memory to Hospice of Southeastern CT, P.O. Box 902, Uncasville, CT 06382 or to St. Joseph's Abbey, 167 North Spencer Road, Spencer, MA 01562.

title: AT&T Official Is Qwest's Global Chief
description: Qwest Communications International Inc., the fourth-largest United States long-distance company, said today that it had hired Jack McMaster from the No. 1, the AT&T Corporation, to head its international operations.

title: Playoff-Minded Braves Trade Neagle for Boone
description: In baseball's first major post-season trade, the Atlanta Braves today took their first step in trying to reverse their post-season fortunes.

title: Monitor Israel, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Elections Vs. Mitch
description: More than 10,000 people died in floods or mudslides brought on by Hurricane Mitch in Central America, and the infrastructures of Nicaragua and Honduras were virtually destroyed. Big news story, right?

title: Picture of Aborted Fetus Seen As Possible Link to a Killing
description: On the eve of a holiday that has been linked to antiabortion violence, the authorities yesterday were investigating whether a picture of an aborted fetus sent to a Canadian newspaper was connected to last month's fatal shooting of a Buffalo doctor who provided abortions or to four similar attacks in western New York and Canada since 1994.

title: Wal-Mart's Quarter Profit Jumps 27%
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the world's largest retailer, said today that its fiscal third-quarter profit rose a better-than-expected 27 percent as the discount chain kept a lid on costs and sold more paper goods, cosmetics and other household items.

title: Hal Newhouser, 77, a Hall of Fame Pitcher
description: Hal Newhouser, the Detroit Tigers' Hall of Fame left-hander and the only pitcher to win two consecutive Most Valuable Player awards, died yesterday at Providence Hospital in Southfield, Mich. He was 77.

title: Sports of The Times; The Father Gave Hope To His Son
description: AMOS ZEREOUE was furious when his father sent him to a group home where the lights went out at 11 P.M. He was used to running the streets at that hour, drinking and fighting, dangerous pursuits for anybody, particularly a boy of 13.

title: Scripps Sells Papers
description: The E. W. Scripps Company said today that it had agreed to sell The Plano Star Courier and seven other Texas newspapers to Lionheart Holdings L.L.C. for undisclosed terms. The sale lets Scripps focus on its other businesses, which include 20 daily newspapers, nine TV stations and TV networks. Lionheart, based in Fort Worth, is a community newspaper group formed by Richard Connor; John Coots; Weiss, Peck & Greer's private equity group, and Waller-Sutton Media Partners L.P.

title: After Malaise, a New Mood in Nation's Capital
description: The District of Columbia is recycling trash again. Squadrons of work crews are busy fixing streets. New parking meters have replaced their vandalized ancestors. For the first time in years, residential real estate prices are going up.

title: Long-Term Capital Said to Earn A Small Profit for Its Rescuers
description: Helped by a sharp rebound in bond markets worldwide, Long-Term Capital Management has earned a small paper profit for the banks and brokerage firms that saved it from bankruptcy in September, people close to the hedge fund said.

title: Raising Pressure on Iraq, U.S. Rules Out Talks on Arms Search
description: The Clinton Administration stepped up its threats against Iraq today, ruling out a negotiated end to President Saddam Hussein's defiance of international arms inspectors while threatening to significantly reduce his ability to make chemical and biological weapons if he does not back down.

title: Special Education Teacher May Get Lesson From Jones
description: Otis Grant, a graduate of Concordia College and a special education teacher in Montreal, isn't stupid. However, some would question the wisdom of challenging Roy Jones Jr., arguably the best boxer in the game today.

title: Dow Drops 33.98 Points, but Technology Shares Surge
description: Stocks slipped again yesterday, as sellers emerged late in the day to push prices down for a second straight session.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, LEON
description: GROSS-Leon. The Board of Governors and members of Montammy Golf Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved member and extend their heartfelt sympathy to Henne Vilanch and the entire family. Kenneth R. Orr, President

title: Remember Global Warming?
description: Diplomats from more than 150 nations gathered in Buenos Aires this week to assess what they had done since the Kyoto agreement on global warming last December. The answer is, not much. They can be happy about one thing. Nobody has successfully challenged the urgency of their mission. Despite well-financed efforts by some industry groups to minimize the warming threat, the scientific consensus -- that the unchecked burning of fossil fuels could someday cause great damage to the environment -- remains intact. What is not intact is the spirit of common purpose that produced the Kyoto agreement.

title: Changes May Be Due For Miller Beers
description: Major changes may be in the works for the closely watched, much-discussed campaigns for the Miller Lite and Miller Genuine Draft beer brands, sold by the Miller Brewing Company.

title: Cone and Strawberry Seem Closer to Signing
description: David Cone and Darryl Strawberry, longtime fixtures in New York's baseball panorama, could each work out the details on a one-year contract with the Yankees today.

title: Clinton Warns U.S. Will Fight Cheap Imports
description: President Clinton said for the first time today that the United States would not tolerate the ''flooding of our markets'' with low-cost goods from Asia and Russia, particularly steel, that are threatening the jobs of American workers.

title: Some Say College Accreditation Is Out of Control
description: How do you draw the line between diploma mills and storefront ''law schools,'' on the one hand, and programs in higher education that meet at least minimum standards?

title: League Suspends Holik
description: Bobby Holik of the Devils was suspended for two games without pay and fined $1,000, the maximum allowed under the players' contract with the league, as a result of a tripping incident last Saturday against Paul Laus of the Florida Panthers.

title: A Not Entirely Happy Anniversary
description: At this particular anniversary party, no one was giving silver or diamonds. The only gifts that the guests cared about were human organs, and the difference between life and death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORGOSH, MILTON (MIKE)
description: FORGOSH-Milton (Mike). Beloved and worshipped husband of Irma. Devoted & cherished father of Helene and husband Edward. Adoring grandfather of Tracy, Sandi and Corey. Caring brother of Sylvia Eis, the late Gertrude Forgosh, Harold Forgosh, and Penny Gurfein. He was a remarkably strong, thoughtful and loving family man. We'll miss you, Bub. There will never be another Mike. Services 12 Noon, Thursday, November 12th, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: A Conceptual Approach: Fusion of All the Americas
description: FOR a long time, only a few outposts in New York offered the hearty, robust cooking of Central and South America. But the landscape has changed recently with the arrival of Patria and its Nuevo Latino menu, and the sprinkling of South American churrascarias and Argentine steakhouses. Now, the surge is accelerating with a new crop of restaurants, including three in Greenwich Village: L-Ray, which calls itself a Gulf Rim bistro; Casa, a homey Brazilian spot, and Campo.

title: HEINZ TO COMBINE UNITS AND LAY OFF NEARLY 400
description: In a move that had been expected by Wall Street, the H. J. Heinz Company said yesterday that it was laying off nearly 400 people and combining two of its frozen-foods businesses into one unit. The company also said it would take a $150 million charge in its third quarter, which ends on Jan. 27, to cover the costs of the reorganization. The units affected are Ore-Ida and Weight Watchers, which will be run by Neil Harrison. The move allows Heinz to consolidate expenses. About 200 jobs will be lost when the company closes a frozen-pasta factory in West Chester, Pa. Another 190 jobs will be eliminated by closing the headquarters of Ore-Ida in Boise, Idaho, and moving it to Pittsburgh, where Heinz is based.

title: Decision Time: To Impeach or Not to Impeach; Campaign Eyesore
description: To the Editor:

title: Hog Farmers Question Division of Pork Pie
description: With prices for hogs so low that farmers are being paid less than it costs to raise the livestock, Illinois agriculture groups today raised questions about why pork prices in stores are not also plummeting.

title: U.S. Productivity Up in 3d Quarter
description: The productivity of United States workers accelerated in the third quarter, offsetting an increase in labor costs and giving Federal Reserve policy makers room to cut interest rates if they see a need to buoy financial markets.

title: NINE WEST TO DISMISS 700 EMPLOYEES AND CUT PRODUCTION
description: The women's shoe maker Nine West Group Inc. said yesterday that it would dismiss 700 workers, close two factories and reduce the number of shoes it makes annually to about 3 million, from 5 million, in 1999 to cut costs. The company will close plants in Osgood, Ind., and at an undisclosed site in the Caribbean and reconfigure operations in Vanceburg and Hebron, Ky., and Vevay, Ind., starting in January. The company will take about $7 million in charges. The White Plains-based company, which sells shoes to more than 7,000 retailers, has seen profits fall for four quarters as weak sales and rising inventories forced it to trim prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, DR. DANIEL M.
description: YOUNG-Dr. Daniel M. November 8, 1998. Survived by his parents and sister of Woonsocket, R.I., his wife, Mary Monroe, of Yonkers, two daughters, two stepsons, and five grandchildren. Admired and cherished by his family, friends, and colleagues, and by the many whose lives he touched as Jungian analyst, Psychotherapist, and Clergyman. His was a rare and trustworthy soul, and his loss is deeply mourned. Memorial service on Sunday, November 15 at 2PM, at the Church of St. James the Less, Crane Road at Church Lane, Scarsdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Church of St. James the Less, the Church at Point O' Woods, Point O' Woods, New York, or to the charity of your choice.

title: Effort to Halt Blinding Disease Worldwide With Single-Dose Drug
description: The leading cause of preventable blindness worldwide can be effectively treated by a single oral dose of an antibiotic once a year, health workers said here yesterday, and they announced a major push to distribute the drug in five countries.

title: BUDDHA VS. BEIJING: A special report.; Booming China Threatens Spirit of Tibet
description: At daybreak, thousands of Tibetan worshipers march a path that circles this holy city, twirling prayer wheels and murmuring tributes of faith. Clad in dark Tibetan robes or silk tunics, they wind their way around a gold-roofed temple where the scent of smoldering juniper branches, a traditional offering, rises from a blackened shrine.

title: For Williams, a Search for Respect
description: As Bernie Williams prepares for what is perhaps the most critical decision of his career, the prevailing feeling is that the path will not lead back to New York. The question is, why not?

title: Indonesia Parliament Meets, and Demonstrators Protest
description: As opposing groups of demonstrators threw rocks and wood spears at each other, the Parliament met today for the first time since the ouster of President Suharto to chart a course toward a more democratic government.

title: HOCKEY; Stevens Is at Forefront Of Rangers' Onslaught
description: A week ago, six goals in one game seemed impossible for the Rangers. Tonight, they hit double figures.

title: INSIDE
description: A Giant Mail Fraud Scheme

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOUGHTY, NATHANIEL C.
description: DOUGHTY-Nathaniel C. on Nov 8, 1998. Retired Executive-N.W. Ayer. Memorial service will be held and announced at a later date.

title: Suspect Who Was Freed Is Charged in Park Theft
description: Seventeen days after he was arrested in connection with the robbery of a man at knifepoint in Central Park, but released after the charges were dropped, a 31-year-old man with a lengthy criminal record was arrested again yesterday for an almost identical crime, the police said.

title: OMNIPONT AND TWO COMPANIES SETTLE COLLUDING CHARGES
description: The Omnipoint Corporation and two small companies settled Federal charges yesterday that they used special codes to avoid competing for lucrative digital phone licenses. The Justice Department accused Omnipoint, Mercury PCS II L.L.C. and the 21st Century Bidding Corporation of colluding at a Federal Communications Commission auction that lasted from August 1996 to January 1997. While the Government raised $2.5 billion for 1,479 licenses, it said the payoff could have been larger without the collusion. The three companies that colluded used secret codes to alert rivals not to bid for the same licenses, the Government said. The three companies settled the charges by agreeing not to engage in similar practices in the future, and Federal antitrust enforcers are not expected to seek damages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENNYBACKER, MILES
description: PENNYBACKER-Miles, 97. Of Westport, CT., on Monday, November 9. Beloved husband of Jean Rodney Pennybacker, father of Anne Watts, Bruce Pennybacker and Claire Wilson. He is also survived by 6 grandchildren and 4 great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Red Barn Restaurant, 292 Wilton Road, Westport, CT Saturday, November 21 at 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to Community Funds, Inc. (mark for ''The Pennybacker Fund''), 2 Park Avenue, N.Y., NY 10016-9385.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Off the Menu column of the Dining Section on Wednesday about Rosario's, the pizzeria that is being forced to close after 34 years on East Houston Street, misstated the position of Salvatore Bartolomeo. He is the manager. The owner is his uncle Rosario Dispenza.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I love E-mail. I think it is changing the world. The problem is somebody can take it out of context and use it against you, and we have to guard against that.''

title: OFF THE MENU
description: A Hotel Updated

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, ALBERT HENRY, JR.
description: BERNSTEIN-Albert Henry, Jr. 84. In Boca Raton, Florida. Died on November 5, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Miriam (Mimi) Tannen. Devoted father of Ro Bernstein Welter and Janey Bernstein. Loving father-in-law of John Welter. Darling brother of Frances B. Wagner. Cherished by all.

title: Working Out as Acting Out; From Firefights to Ballet, Gyms Offer Fitness Fantasies
description: By day, Chad Klopotek, an investment consultant, lives a mild-mannered existence. But at least one night a week, he gets to play Firefighter Rookie No. 1, scaling a burning skyscraper, saving a life and keeping off that little roll around his waist that once came between him and his favorite pair of jeans.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AMORY, CLEVELAND
description: AMORY-Cleveland. A memorial service for Cleveland Amory will be held at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 111th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Thursday, November 12 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Fund for Animals.

title: In Inaugural Speech, Schroder Stresses Jobs and Environment
description: Proclaiming that Germany has ''come of age'' and should feel ''neither superior nor inferior to anyone,'' Chancellor Gerhard Schroder said today that the return of the capital to Berlin next year represented ''a new beginning'' for a country still divided and afflicted by high unemployment.

title: Why Not a Wrestler as Governor?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDIS, LEONARD R.
description: LANDIS-Leonard R. Age 75. On November 10, 1998. Beloved husband of Elayne. Loving and proud father of Carolyn, Dean and his wife Mara, Andrew and his wife Hilary. Devoted grandfather of Teddy. Dear brother of Donald. A resident of both Manhattan and Sagaponack, he was a leader in commercial finance, serving as the long standing President of United Credit Corporation. Friends may call Wednesday, 3-5 and 79PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Services Thursday, November 12th, at 12 Noon at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65th Street.

title: In 'Siege,' Seeing Beyond Stereotypes
description: To the Editor:

title: A Plain Menu With Fancy Tastes
description: IT'S hard to imagine a more prosaic-sounding menu than the one at MITCHEL LONDON FOODS . Hamburger, fried chicken, roast chicken and B.L.T. are just some of the choices; you can probably guess many of the others.

title: Inspections Cutting Back On Mail Fraud Based in Nigeria
description: There was the doctor from West Virginia who received an official-looking letter from the Nigerian Government, offering a business opportunity to export agricultural equipment. After some hesitation, he wrote several checks over a couple of years totaling $225,000. There were the three Amish farmers in Pennsylvania who heard about an offer for a lucrative oil pipeline contract. They, too, wrote several checks over time, parting eventually with $400,000.

title: Schumer Tries to Win Over Skeptical Upstaters
description: Charles E. Schumer ventured into a part of upstate New York today that both he and his hosts acknowledged was hostile political territory for him, areas that voted decisively for Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, who had criticized Mr. Schumer for voting against winter storm aid for the region.

title: CALENDER
description: Helping the Hungry

title: It's Spend Big, Win Big, Except for Orioles
description: The Baltimore Orioles increased their payroll by 14 percent to a baseball record $71.86 million this year but staggered to a losing record. The Yankees raised their payroll by 1 percent and won the World Series.

title: State Urged to Allow Heart Surgery at Hospital
description: Representatives of minority communities in central New Jersey yesterday asked the state to let Muhlenberg Regional Medical Center in Plainfield perform heart surgery, insisting that residents of the area lack access to the procedure.

title: Why Not a Wrestler as Governor?
description: To the Editor:

title: Property Tax Relief Proposed for Veterans
description: Voters would be asked whether to raise the property tax deduction for veterans to $500 from $50 under a bill introduced on Monday, the sponsor of the measure said yesterday.

title: N.F.L.: NOTEBOOK
description: KANSAS CITY

title: New Options Exchange to Start in 2000
description: A consortium of securities brokers and the on-line trading firm E*Trade Group Inc. yesterday announced the formation of a new electronic options exchange called the International Securities Exchange, which plans to begin operating in the year 2000.

title: Mets Turn Their Attention to Surhoff
description: On Day 2 of Frank Cashen's temporary return as general manger, the Mets didn't make any moves, but they apparently have been focusing on the free agent B. J. Surhoff, the Baltimore Orioles' left fielder last season.

title: 65 Years And Still Kicking
description: The Mayor proclaimed.

title: Decision Time: To Impeach or Not to Impeach; Polls Aren't Guide
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Score 1 for Cuomo

title: A Man in Tune With His Heritage; In His New Novel, Tom Wolfe Unearths His Southern Roots
description: There was a moment after the salmon with Brittany sea salt at the pillowy corner banquette at the Carlyle, after the triumphant stroll up Madison Avenue, where East Side matrons swooned like teen-agers spying Leonardo DeCaprio, after the brief tour of the 12-room symphony of mahogany and double-beveled glass where he lives, when, out of the blue, Tom Wolfe sounded like a man ready to let his red dog slip its leash.

title: Fed Up With Sprawl
description: Almost lost in last week's election results was an unmistakable mandate for elected officials to deal with an issue that affects everyone: unmanaged growth, better known as sprawl.

title: China Detains 140 From 2 Protestant Groups
description: The Chinese authorities have detained 140 Protestants and severely beaten more than a dozen church leaders in the last two weeks, a New York-based human rights organization said today.

title: THE CHEF
description: THIS simple apple loaf cake, made from a buttery batter and filled and topped with chunky apple wedges, is exactly the same cake my father created for his pastry shop in Nice 20 years ago. I wouldn't think of changing it and, the truth is, my father would never let me. To his way of thinking, a recipe should be changed only if customers don't like it. And his customers like his apple cake so much that, the first day he made it, he had to rush out and buy extra cake pans to bake more. Today, he still sells 100 of these small cakes a day.

title: Vouchers for Parochial Schools
description: The United States Supreme Court's decision not to review a Milwaukee case involving taxpayer-paid vouchers for religious schools sidesteps one of the most contentious political issues of the day. The Court's refusal to take up the case does not signal approval of the Milwaukee scheme. But the Court's silence leaves in place a plan that will directly harm the vast majority of the city's schoolchildren, namely those left in Milwaukee's public schools while others flee to the voucher program. The Court's denial of review will also embolden voucher supporters elsewhere to adopt similar plans that would funnel public money into religious and private education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUSMORINO, JOSEPHINE ZAFONTE
description: GUSMORINO-Josephine Zafonte. Born Sept. 9, 1917. Died November 9, 1998. Loving mother, attorney, fighter, innovator, entrepreneur, titan, who paved the way for women to follow and men, too. Services today from 2-5:30 and 7-9:30 at Simonson Funeral Home, 119-04 Hillside Ave., Richmond Hill, NY.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAY, CELIA H.
description: KAY-Celia H. Died on November 8th, at age 91 in Cleveland, Ohio. Formerly of Syracuse and Palm Beach, FL. Wife of the late Robert C. Kay; survived by her devoted children Richard and Lynn Kay and Jayne and Richard Jones; five grandchildren and five great grandchildren. She was adored by her family and numerous friends and she will be missed by all. Burial arrangements are private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Stone Gardens, Menorah Park Center for the Aging, 27090 Cedar Rd, Beachwood, Ohio 44122.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUXBAUM, HOWARD H., M.D.
description: BUXBAUM-Howard H., M.D. 70. Died on November 3rd, 1998. Born in Alendorf, Germany in 1928, he immigrated in 1938. A dedicated pedatrician, his greatest joy was his grandchildren: Sivan GordonBuxbaum, Harper and Marshall Feingold. He is survived by first wife, Diane D. Buxbaum, his second wife, Ina Kaplan, both of Brooklyn, and his children: Dr. Audrey Buxbaum of Brooklyn, Chuck Buxbaum of Albequerque, NM, Thea Buxbaum of New Haven, CT., his step-children Dr. Cheryl Feingold of Roslyn, Glen Kaplan of NYC, and his sister, Rene Bauman of Staten Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTGOMERY, LYNN DOUGLAS
description: MONTGOMERY-Lynn Douglas. Age 71, died peacefully November 9 at his home in Lake Placid, New York. Survived by his wife, Julie and his children Chris, Drew, Julia and Elizabeth, and grandson Ross. His intelligence, creativity, energy and spirit are within us all. He will be greatly missed.

title: EASTMAN KODAK CUTS 300 JOBS AT ITS COPIER DIVISION
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, the world's biggest photography company, said yesterday that it had cut 300 jobs at its copier-manufacturing division because of slowing sales to its main customer, the London-based Danka Business Systems P.L.C. A year ago, Kodak, based in Rochester, said it would eliminate one-fifth of its work force, cutting almost 20,000 jobs. Those cuts were a money-saving move to help Kodak compete with the Fuji Photo Film Company. These additional job cuts suggest that Kodak's chairman, George Fisher, may want to get out of the copier business. Kodak sold the division's sales and service operations to Danka two years ago for about $680 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSTER, FRANCIS JR.
description: FOSTER-Francis Jr., of Annisquam, MA., on Sunday, November 8, Francis ''F. Lee'' Jr., 77, husband of Mary (Chase) Foster of Annisquam. Father of Deborah Ebeling of Winchester, MA. and Robert C. Foster of Freeport, ME. Also survived by five grandchildren, two nieces & a grandniece. Memorial Service on Saturday, Nov. 14, 2 P.M. in Annisquam Village Church, 838 Washington St., Gloucester, MA. Memorial gifts to Cape Ann Historical Association, 27 Pleasant Street, Gloucester, MA. 01930.

title: Just Switch Off
description: To the Editor:

title: Dominican Cab Drivers Organize 2d Storm Relief
description: Building on their success organizing relief efforts for victims of Hurricane Georges on the island of Hispaniola, a group of Dominican taxi drivers are now working to aid people in Central America whose lives were shattered by Hurricane Mitch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOHMER, ROBERT G.
description: SOHMER-Robert G. Died November 8, 1998 in Rock, WV after a brief bout with cancer. He was born in Brooklyn, NY on August 16, 1925 to Laura Siecke and George F. Sohmer. He is survived by his wife, the former Helen Faulkner; three children, Robert G. Sohmer, Jr. of Fairfield, CT, Deborah Sohmer Wilson of Weston, MA and Paul R. Sohmer of Manhattan, NY; and by four grandchildren, Luke and Lianna Wilson & Elizabeth and Carolyn Sohmer. Funeral liturgy at Mt. Carmel R.C. Church, Tenafly, NJ Thursday 11AM. Visiting Thurs. 9:30-10:30AM at Riewerts Memorial Home, 187 South Washington Ave., Bergenfield, NJ. Interment Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Tenafly, New Jersey.
