title: Business Travel; New York Airports Embrace the Internet
description: Access to the World Wide Web is increasing at New York area airports, as the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey installs Internet kiosks at La Guardia and Newark International Airports, and Host Marriott Services experiments with similar computing equipment at several of its airport food outlets.

title: The Joy of Emeril
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets Turned Into Numbers Crunchers
description: Statistics do not tell the whole story, but numbers also do not lie. And the Jets during the Bill Parcells era have begun to put up numbers to compete with the better teams in the National Football League. In the process, they have begun to bury the paltry figures of their own past.

title: BANKAMERICA EXERCISING OPTION TO BUY HALF OF MARSICO
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the largest United States bank, said yesterday that it was exercising an option to buy 50 percent of Marsico Capital Management L.L.C., which has grown from zero to $2.8 billion in assets in its first 14 months. Terms were not disclosed. Marsico Capital, based in Denver, was formed in September 1997 by the former Janus Capital Corporation fund manager Thomas Marsico, 43, with backing from the Nationsbank Corporation, which merged with BankAmerica last month. Based on recent sale prices for two mostly institutional money managers -- Barr Rosenberg Investment Management Group and Rorer Asset Management -- Marsico would have been worth more than $110 million, or 4 percent of assets under management.

title: 'Boheme' With Italian Baton
description: For all its familiarity, ''La Boheme'' is a surprisingly challenging score to conduct. Puccini's orchestral music must shift and breathe with the antics and amorous outbursts of the singers. Yet the multiple, ever-changing components of this rhapsodic score must be fashioned into a musical and dramatic whole.

title: FLEET TO BUY $1.3 BILLION OF HOUSEHOLD CARD ACCOUNTS
description: Household International Inc. agreed yesterday to sell $1.3 billion of its credit-card portfolio to Fleet Financial Group Inc., the banking and financial services company. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. Household International, the consumer-finance company, said the receivables are part of its $4.7 billion Household Bank brand portfolio. Household International has begun selling some Mastercard and Visa activities. Fleet Financial, based in Boston, said the credit-card portfolio would be managed by its Fleet Credit Card Services L.P. unit, based in Horsham, Pa. Household International, based in Prospect Heights, Ill., has assets of about $30.3 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HERZ, JOHN W.
description: HERZ-John W. A memorial service will be held at the Ethical Culture Society of Westchester, 7 Saxon Woods Road, White Plains, New York, at 2 PM, Wednesday, November 11th, 1998.

title: There's No Biz ...
description: To the Editor:

title: News Corp. Offer Raises $2.8 Billion
description: The News Corporation yesterday completed the third-largest initial public offering in American history, raising about $2.8 billion with the sale of 124.8 million shares of Fox Entertainment Group Inc.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN FALLS. Japan's currency declined for a sixth day on speculation that the Government's plan to increase consumer spending and invigorate the economy would not work. The dollar settled at 122.52 yen, up from 121.57.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUMAN, ELIZABETH
description: YOUMAN-Elizabeth. Died November 7, age 85. She is survived by seven children, 25 grandchildren and 18 great grandchildren.

description: I WILL BEAR WITNESS

title: Questions About Future Of Those Many Ph.D.'s
description: Graduate students working on Ph.D.'s know that getting a job after graduation will be difficult.

title: An Absence of Essence
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUGGAN, STEPHEN P.
description: DUGGAN-Stephen P. The Institute of International Education joins the Duggan family in mourning the loss of Stephen P. Duggan, an extraordinary individual whose dedication to the Institute was unparalleled. Mr. Duggan served as a Trustee, and then as a Life Trustee for almost 50 years and was a tireless advocate of international education. Mr. Duggan continued the tradition of the active role of the Duggan family in IIE affairs. He was the son of Dr. Stephen Pierce Duggan, who helped found the Institute in 1919. Respected as an exemplary leader and a good friend, Mr. Duggan's wisdom strengthened the Institute immeasurably and his spirit inspired us. He was known and beloved by staff and trustees for his dedication to the Institute. His talent, companionship, warmth and leadership will be truly missed. The Institute wishes to extend its deepest sympathies to Mr. Duggan's family. Henry Kaufman, Chairman, Board of Trustees Victor J. Goldberg, Vice Chairman Diane Paton, Vice Chairman Thomas Johnson, Chairman, Executive Committee Allan Goodman, President & CEO

Great grandmother to Emma and Jennie. Services Wednesday, 1:30PM at ''the Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Cured of Insanity
description: To the Editor:

title: Philip Visits Ireland and There's Talk of the Queen Going, Too
description: In a gesture intended to advance the Northern Ireland peace effort, Prince Philip visited Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic today and said he hoped for an end to the ''rather artificial divisions'' separating the Irish people.

title: Drug Makers Say New Painkillers Work Without Side Effects
description: Two large drug companies say they have developed a new class of drugs that can relieve pain and inflammation without the gastrointestinal side effects of current drugs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHARFF, CONSTANCE KRAMER
description: SCHARFF - Constance Kramer. Wife of the late Harry. Mother of Matthew and Carol. Grandmother of Karen Scharff (James Coe), Thomas Zucker-Scharff (Sue) and David Scharff. Great grandmother of Aram, Ilana, Jonah and Rachel. Sister of Jack Kramer and the late Sybil Yedlin Ginsberg, Dorothy Greene and Leona Hart. She was a special person whose love for learning persisted throughout her life, and a gifted artist. Services at 11 A.M., Thursday, Larchmont Temple. Contributions to Larchmont Temple. For information, Plaza Memorial Chapel (phone: 800-227-3974).

title: 30 Happy Years as an 8-Foot-Tall Yellow Bird
description: GIVEN that Big Bird is about to celebrate his 30th birthday, one perhaps should not ask about disappointment and frustration. But as the scorpion said after attacking the frog, ''I can't help it -- I'm a scorpion,'' so let's get to it:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, WILLIAM E., JR.
description: PORTER-William E., Jr. On Nov. 7, 1998 of Baltimore, formerly of New York, beloved husband of the late Mary E. (nee Begley) Porter. Devoted father of William E. Porter, III of Catonsville, Carolyn Meier of Minneapolis, MN., and the late Jane P. Shea. Loving grandfather of Emily and Lily Porter, Max, Ian and Neal Shea, Kirsten, Sarah and David Poore. Friends may call at the Witzke Funeral Home of Catonsville, Inc., 1630 Edmondson Avenue, (1 mile west beltway exit 14) on Thursday from 4-7 P.M. Christian wake service 5 P.M. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Friday, 10 A.M. in Saint Mark's Catholic Church, Catonsville. Interment on Saturday at 12 noon, in Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Mt. Pleasant, New York.

description: In percent

title: Gates Quoted As Seeing Case 'Blow Over'
description: William H. Gates, the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, confidently told a group of industry executives in 1995 that the Government's antitrust investigation of his company would ''blow over'' with scant effect, an executive who attended the private meeting testified in court today.

title: A Plus: Rose's Rolodex
description: ''60 Minutes II'' is the name it was given, but there is nothing second-string about the on-air team assembled for the latest CBS News magazine program.

title: Leonard de Paur Dies at 83; Lincoln Center Administrator
description: Leonard de Paur, a conductor of choruses and orchestras, an arranger and an administrator who for 17 years was the director of community relations for Lincoln Center, died on Saturday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 83.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHALFIN, MIRIAM
description: CHALFIN-Miriam. Today is your birthday. Your memory will live in our hearts and minds forever. Your children and grandchildren

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDLER, PROF. MILTON
description: HANDLER-Prof. Milton. Beloved husband of the late Miriam Adler Handler. Devoted father of Carole. Loving grandfather of Alisa and Ilana Schoenbach, and dear uncle. Service Thursday, 11AM at Park Avenue Synagogue, 87th St and Madison Ave, NYC.

title: In Time for Holidays, Midtown Crackdown on Drivers Who Cause Gridlock
description: In an effort to stem holiday gridlock in the coming months, city officials said yesterday that they were planning to step up traffic enforcement in midtown Manhattan, with special attention toward towing illegally parked cars and catching drivers who block intersections.

title: U.S. Threatens To Hit EU With 100% Tariffs
description: BRUSSELS  A long-standing dispute over trade in bananas risked escalating into a trade war as Washington threatened Tuesday to impose punitive tariffs on hundreds of millions of dollars of European exports.

title: Jurors Convict Youth in Killing Of His Teacher
description: A 19-year-old former student of Jonathan M. Levin was convicted yesterday of second-degree murder in the May 1997 slaying of Mr. Levin, a Bronx public high school teacher, in his Upper West Side apartment. But in a setback for prosecutors, the jury acquitted the defendant, Corey Arthur, of first-degree murder, apparently unconvinced that Mr. Arthur fired the fatal shot.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: 9-Month Revenue Flat at AXA-UAP
description: The French insurance giant AXA-UAP said yesterday that its revenue for the nine months that ended on Sept. 30 rose just one-tenth of 1 percent, to 271.8 billion francs, or $48 billion, from 271.6 billion francs a year earlier. Life insurance income rose 1 percent, to 150.77 billion francs. Total property and casualty insurance revenue dropped 6.1 percent, to 67.94 billion francs, while reinsurance revenue fell 11 percent, to 7.85 billion francs. Revenue from financial services operations rose 10 percent, to 45.25 billion francs in the nine-month period.

title: Intel Sees Higher-Than-Expected Profits
description: The Intel Corporation said today that its fourth-quarter results will be above expectations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERNER, HARVEY
description: WERNER-Harvey. The Board of Governors of the Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member and dear friend, Harvey Werner, and offers its heartfelt sympathy to his family and friends. David L. Rudnick, President Robert S. Puder, Secretary

title: Conservatives Break Away From Southern Baptists in Texas
description: In a new sign of fracturing within the nation's largest Protestant denomination, Southern Baptists in Texas split yesterday when a group of strict theological conservatives voted to break away from the state's established Southern Baptist organization.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; When Bristol-Myers Squibb shakes up things, where are the executives likely to land?
description: THE Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, long known for its well-mannered culture, may soon see a battle royal for its top office.

title: A Half Dozen Pursue Perfection
description: Then, there were six -- undefeated teams, that is. Some have genuine national championship aspirations. Others know they are limited by how far perfection can take them. The following is a report from their camps.

title: C.I.A. CHIEF VOWED TO QUIT IF CLINTON FREED ISRAELI SPY
description: During the Middle East peace talks last month in Maryland, the Director of Central Intelligence told President Clinton he would resign if Mr. Clinton agreed to release the spy Jonathan Jay Pollard, according to several Administration officials.

title: Nissan Motor Posts $266 Million Loss
description: The Nissan Motor Company said today that it lost 32.55 billion yen, or $266 million, in the first half because of slumping sales and huge stock losses, forcing Japan's second-largest auto maker to predict its sixth full-year loss in seven years.

title: Decision Time: To Impeach or Not to Impeach; Where Is the Courage?
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Cabinet Is Set To Ratify Agreement
description: Israel announced that its Cabinet would meet today to approve the new Israeli-Palestinian accord, renewing deliberations suspended after a suicide bombing in Jerusalem last Friday. The Cabinet meeting was announced under intense American pressure to resume the process of ratifying the agreement. That process has been repeatedly postponed by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu since the accord, which calls for an Israeli troops withdrawal from 13 percent of the West Bank in exchange for a Palestinian crackdown on violent militants, was signed in Washington on Oct. 23.

title: About New York; An Artist Gets His Hooks On Some Cash
description: RICHARD MOCK has so much money scattered about his Red Hook studio that it looks as if an armored car exploded inside the cluttered space. Bags of the green stuff are tossed on the floor next to piles of magazines and videotapes. More is scattered in clumps atop tables. It dangles from three slender cables between the cages where his parakeets jump and chirp.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHKIN, GERALD (JERRY)
description: RICHKIN-Gerald (Jerry). It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of Gerald Richkin, 150 West 96th Street, New York, NY 10025. The funeral will be held on Wednesday Nov 11, 1998 at 12 noon at The Plaza Memorial Funeral Home, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Jerry was an actor and a teacher and he leaves behind his loving wife, Carmen, his three daughters, Jean, Valerie, and Beth, and his four grandchildren, Oren, Dana, Tali, and Jonah. We will miss him very much.

title: Carjacking, a Fatal Shot and a Mystery
description: An 84-year-old man's willingness to give his nephew and the nephew's girlfriend a ride evolved into a bizarre carjacking today in Newark that ended with the woman shot to death and the nephew mysteriously vanishing on the George Washington Bridge.

title: Newsweek Names Editor, And Promotes 2 Others
description: Mark Whitaker, who began his career at Newsweek as a college intern in 1977 and went on to expand the magazine's technology and business coverage and then oversee the pyrotechnics of the Monica Lewinsky story as managing editor this year, was named editor of the magazine yesterday.

title: Complaint From a Mainstream District
description: Shortly before Congress adjourned last month, Speaker Newt Gingrich approached Representative Brian P. Bilbray, one of the two dozen Republicans whom Democrats were concentrating on ousting in this year's elections, and asked what Republican leaders could do to help.

title: Liberties; Of Frogs and Newts
description: One show was about a frog.

title: California's Hidden Harvest; In the land of avocados, new and exotic varieties of rice are flourishing.
description: IT was late afternoon, the sun sat high over the Sacramento Valley, and Chuck Mathews Jr. was in a groove -- literally. With his right hand on the steering wheel, and his left eye trained on a helpful furrow, he kept the wheels of his bright-green harvester rolling in a perfect line, reducing acre after acre of rice plants to sawed-off stubble.

title: Housing Found for 279 Queens Elderly, City Says
description: Two months after the abrupt evacuation of a storm-damaged Rockaway Beach nursing home, New York City housing officials said that 279 residents of the home had been moved from temporary quarters at hospitals and other centers in the city and settled permanently in various public and private nursing homes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, ISIDORE
description: STRAUSS-Isidore. The Members and our entire personnel express our heartfelt condolences to our esteemed counsel, Arthur Strauss and his entire family, on the passing on November 7th, 1998 of Arthur's father, Isidore. His kindness and good humor are a legend shaping the lives of all who knew him. Herbert Rubin Herzfeld & Rubin, PC

title: Plane Flown By Colombia Had Cocaine
description: United States customs officials seized about 1,600 pounds of cocaine from a Colombian Air Force cargo plane that landed on Monday at Fort Lauderdale International Airport, prompting Colombia's air force chief to resign today.

title: A Memorial for Amory
description: A memorial service for Cleveland Amory, the best-selling writer and founder of the Fund for Animals, will be held at 11 A.M. tomorrow at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. Mr. Amory, who was the fund's unpaid president, died on Oct. 14 at his home in Manhattan at age 81.

title: 5 Men Arrested in Staten Island Couple's Murder
description: Acting on a tip, detectives have arrested five men in the execution-style murders of a Staten Island building contractor and his girlfriend in September.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HARRIS, SYLVIA BAKER
description: HARRIS-Sylvia Baker. May 15, 1906-November 11, 1966. Dearest loving wife of Joseph, dearest loving mother of J. Robert and James B., dearest loving grandmother and great grandmother. God bless You, Mom. You're the greatest ever, you're a legend in your own time, producer of hit Broadway shows ''Sweet Charity'' and ''Mame''. We all dearly love you and miss you so very much. All our love forever. Your loving and devoted sons, Bob and Ji

title: Enhanced Services For a New Multiplex
description: Loews Cineplex Entertainment announced yesterday that it would build a 23-screen multiplex next to a proposed mall in Elizabeth, N.J., with enhanced services that will include valet parking, special seating and a bar.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE PAUR, LEONARD
description: de PAUR-Leonard. It is with great sadness that The Board, staff and friends of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc. mourn the passing of Leonard de Paur, former Director of Community Relations for Lincoln Center, a position he held for 17 years. His creative vision and commitment to making the arts available to everyone lives on in the programs he created. Twenty-eight years ago Mr. de Paur founded Lincoln Center Outof-Doors which today thrives as one of the largest free public performing arts events in the country. Each summer Lincoln Center Outof-Doors makes accessible the highest caliber of dance, music, and performance artistry from around the globe to over 200,000 people. Mr. de Paur leaves an unparalleled legacy of passion for and devotion to the arts. His enlightening wisdom and guidance will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Norma, his son Leonard C., his daughter Norma Lynn and his three grandchildren. Beverly Sills, Chairman Nathan Leventhal, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc.

title: Red Seeds, Red Juice: Such Sweet Bliss
description: FOR the child in all of us, pomegranates make things easy. All you need are a metal skewer and a straw. Punch the skewer through the fruit's leathery red skin, slip a straw into the hole, and slurp up the sweet and sour juice.

title: Washington Talk; Social Security Is Issue, But Solution Is Elusive
description: Eager to show voters that Washington is not completely mired in partisanship, leaders of both parties have been proclaiming their enthusiasm in the aftermath of the elections to tackle the big issues, Social Security foremost among them.

title: Reckson-Alliance Deal
description: Reckson Service Industries said today that it had agreed to merge its executive-suite businesses -- Reckson Executive Centers and the Interoffice Holdings Corporation -- with the privately held Alliance National Inc. The new entity, which is yet unnamed, will operate about 150 executive centers and have 1998 revenues of about $170 million.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE FALLS 2.3 PERCENT. Prices slumped after Colombia confirmed it would probably harvest a significantly larger crop that will replenish low inventories. The December contract fell 2.8 cents, to $1.169 a pound.

title: SPINNAKER INDUSTRIES SEEKS BUYER OR MERGER PARTNER
description: Spinnaker Industries, a maker of adhesive-backed materials and industrial equipment, has hired the investment firm of Schroder & Company to assist it in evaluating options including a sale, a merger or other business combinations. Spinnaker is based in Dallas and had annual revenue of $232 million last year. The Lynch Corporation, based in Greenwich, Conn., owns 61 percent of Spinnaker and has announced a plan to sell its stake along with other assets.

title: I'm Bad. Bam! Bam!
description: To the Editor:

title: Gravlax Without Fear: A Stunning Dish Just Looks Hard
description: MOST chefs jazz gravlax up with sauces and side dishes -- how else could they justify charging $12 a plate?

title: Mayor Backs City Policy On Welfare
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday defended his policy of delaying the distribution of food stamp and Medicaid applications to the poor and denied that his Welfare Commissioner had ever said the policy would change.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELD, JUDITH (GOLDBERG)
description: FIELD-Judith (Goldberg). On November 3, 1998. Teacher, writer, talented colleague, steadfast and delightful friend.

title: Witnesses Say They Saw Murder Suspect and His Friend Washing Off Blood
description: On the second day of the trial of a Manhattan teen-ager accused of murdering an Upper East Side man in Central Park in 1997, witnesses described yesterday how the defendant and a female friend had cleansed themselves of blood at her apartment building after the killing.

title: A fledgling agency is aiming to show that big thinking can come in a small package.
description: TWO longtime creative executives who worked at big agencies producing campaigns for big brands such as Diet Coke and Kentucky Fried Chicken have quietly opened their own small shop.

title: Cargill Set to Buy Main Unit of Continental Grain, Its Chief Rival
description: For Floyd Schultz, yesterday's news that Cargill Inc. had agreed to buy the grain operations of its chief rival, the Continental Grain Company, was about as welcome as another drop in his already low corn and soybean prices.

title: Costly Iraq Sanctions
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft Media Chief to Take a Leave
description: The executive who has led the Microsoft Corporation's difficult foray into the world of interactive media and Internet content is taking a leave, and the company said yesterday that he would return to a different job next year.

title: To Aid Doctors, A.M.A. Journal Devotes Entire Issue to Alternative Medicine
description: As more and more Americans turn to herbal remedies, chiropractors and massage therapists, spending at least $27 billion a year on those and other forms of alternative health care, the medical profession is scrambling to catch up to the trend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLTZ, MILDRED
description: HOLTZ-Mildred. On November 10, 1998, at age 81. Loving mother to Helene Holtz and Gary Wood. Services are at Temple Bethel in Great Neck on Old Mill Road. Services 1 P.M., Thursday.

title: Emeril's Good. Bam!
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Tobacco And 8 States Are Near Deal
description: Negotiators for eight states and representatives of the tobacco industry have largely finished work on a deal to settle state lawsuits against cigarette companies and could announce it as soon as Friday, two lawyers involved in the talks said yesterday.

title: Guerrillas in Kosovo Rebound, Provoking Concern
description: The separatist Kosovo guerrillas, who sprang out of nowhere in the spring and then were pummeled by the Serbs in a summer offensive, are bouncing back, more resilient and better organized than expected, surprised Western officials say.

title: Tepid Isles Give Salo Little Help In Loss
description: After loafing through the first two periods tonight, the Islanders turned up the pressure on the Penguins, outshooting their hosts by 14-4 through the final 20 minutes. The scoring chances were plentiful, but the Islanders lacked polish around the net.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the House & Home section on Oct. 29 about home improvement experts who are seeking to emulate the success of Martha Stewart in publishing and on television misidentified one who plans to start a magazine within a year. She is Barbara Smith, not Chris Casson Madden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAGLE, SISTER MARY ROBERT
description: NAGLE-Sister Mary Robert. On November 9, 1998. Member of the Sisters of Charity, Mount Saint Vincent, Bronx, New York. Former Director of Saint Vincent's Hospital School of Nursing, 19671991. Primary Care Nurse, Deptartment of Community Medicine, of Saint Vincent's Hospital 19911998. Beloved daughter of the late Robert and Marion. Loving sister of Richard (Madelyn). Dear aunt of Richard, Jr. & Yvette. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14 Street, NYC Wednesday, 4-9PM and Thursday, 2-9PM in the Saint Elizabeth Ann Seton Chapel of Saint Vincent's Hospital. Please enter through 158 West 12 Street, New York. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10AM in the Hospital Chapel. Interment Saint Joseph's Cemetery, Yonkers, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Development Fund, Sisters of Charity, Mount Saint Vincent, Bronx, New York 10741.

title: Time to Rethink Buckley v. Valeo
description: The Supreme Court is expected to decide this week whether to accept a Cincinnati case that challenges the Court to rethink its disastrous ruling 22 years ago in Buckley v. Valeo. The nation's political system has suffered ever since from that decision, which held that mandatory limits on campaign spending unconstitutionally limit free speech. The decision did much to promote the explosive growth of campaign contributions from special interests and to enhance the advantage incumbents enjoy over underfunded challengers. The Court can now correct its original error.

title: Mercury Asset Funds Open
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that its Mercury Asset Management unit had opened two new mutual funds, the unit's first offering to United States investors. The first fund, Mercury Pan-European Growth Fund, will invest primarily in equity securities of European companies. The second, Mercury International Fund, will invest primarily in securities of companies outside the United States. The company raised $679 million for the funds in September and October. The London-based Mercury Asset, acquired by Merrill Lynch last year, manages $170 billion in assets.

title: LOCKHEED MARTIN SHARES FALL ON ACCOUNTING DISCLOSURE
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation, the second-largest aerospace and military company, disclosed in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that a quarter of its third-quarter per-share earnings came from an accounting adjustment. The disclosure was a factor as Lockheed Martin's shares fell $5.0625 each, to $101.9375. The Wall Street Journal reported the change's effect on net income yesterday. Analysts and investors said they were annoyed that the company was not more up front about the accounting adjustment. Lockheed said in its Nov. 2 quarterly filing with S.E.C. that the accounting adjustment increased net income by $78 million, or 41 cents a share, to $318 million, or $1.67.

title: Filter to Block Hate Speech On Internet
description: A prominent nonprofit human rights organization has developed and will sell to the public an Internet filter that blocks access to several hundred Web sites that the organization says advocate bigotry.

title: The Broadway Theater Still Awaits a Windfall Built on Thin Air
description: Nearly five years after a crucial deal lured the Walt Disney Company to 42d Street and jump-started the revival of Times Square, a coalition of Broadway interests is struggling to carry the economic gains to the heart of the theater district.

title: California Suspends License of a Major Logger of Redwoods
description: Citing continuing egregious violations, state forestry regulators on Tuesday suspended the conditional logging license of the Pacific Lumber Company, the largest private logger of old-growth redwoods.

title: As Trademarks Multiply, Infringement Does, Too
description: At first glance, Frederick Mostert appears to be a typically staid corporate lawyer.

title: After Storm, Immigrants Fear Returning May Strand Them
description: If she could fly, Reina Palacios says, she would flap her wings and soar above her apartment in Newark, fly across the country and south to El Salvador, where she would search for the three teen-age daughters she has been unable to reach since Hurricane Mitch devastated Central America two weeks ago.

title: Playing Short-Handed Is No Handicap to Devils' Offense
description: The Devils were up by a goal and down by two players when Scott Niedermayer broke away alone down the middle of the ice tonight against Montreal, seeking his first goal of the season. The Devils defenseman never got a shot off because he was tripped by a Montreal defenseman and awarded a penalty shot. This time, he converted with a crafty move from right to left and back to right. The Canadiens never recovered and the Devils skated off with a 3-0 victory before a crowd of 14,017 at Continental Arena.

title: Martin Seeing Little Daylight Against Multiple Defenders
description: Curtis Martin, the most gifted runner the Jets have had since Freeman McNeil in the 1980's, has a way of figuring out which defensive players are singling him out: they look him in the eye.

title: Two Sought in Beating That Left a Man in Coma
description: The authorities said yesterday that they were looking for two men in their 20's in the severe beating of a Syrian immigrant on Sunday morning as he delivered newspapers to homes in River Edge.

title: Argentina Joins War On Global Warming
description: In an important breakthrough, Argentina signaled that it would become the first developing country to adopt binding targets for controlling emissions of industrial waste gases that are believed to cause global warming. Until now, developing countries had presented a united front in resisting specific limits on their emissions of such gases, which are produced by the burning of coal, oil, wood and natural gas. Developed countries had agreed last December in Kyoto, Japan, to reduce emissions by an average of about 5 percent below 1990 levels in the period 2008 to 2012. However, poorer nations have refused to follow suit until industrial countries actually show results.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELLER, ALFRED
description: FELLER-Alfred. On November 10th, 1998. Beloved husband of Gloria; devoted father of Barbara and Jeffrey Cahn and Peggy and Jeffrey Feller. Cherished grandfather. Services Friday 11:30 at ''Gutterman's, Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery.

title: Bernstein And Rouse: Contrasting Eclectics
description: In its visits to Carnegie Hall, the Philadelphia Orchestra has generally kept close to the central symphonic canon, with occasional premieres as the exceptions that prove the rule. At any rate, programs like the one that David Zinman conducted on Tuesday evening are so rare as to seem out of character. Mr. Zinman devoted the program to works by Christopher Rouse and Leonard Bernstein, two American eclectics who have much in common philosophically but whose styles and accents are utterly different.

title: Metro Business; Ex-Ford Building Is Sold
description: SL Green Realty agreed to buy a 65 percent controlling interest in the Manhattan office building that is home to the CBS broadcast ''60 Minutes'' from Blackacre Capital Management for $66.7 million.

title: Looking at Pollock
description: ''Each age finds its own technique,'' Jackson Pollock said in 1951. The question remains whether each age also finds its own means of sight, the tools for witnessing a technique and a body of work as permanently startling as Pollock's. Pollock has been a given for nearly half a century, and yet to look back at the rapidity of his ascent during the late 1940's and early 1950's is to wonder about the velocity of our culture. It moves so fast, half-digesting everything in sight, abruptly shifting the terms in which Pollock's art, for instance, can be viewed. What hangs invisibly beside the canvases in the Jackson Pollock retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art is the legacy of response. It has yet to catch up with the paintings.

title: Front-runner for Gingrich Seat Emerges
description: The campaign to succeed Speaker Newt Gingrich as the Congressman from Georgia's Sixth District began taking shape today as Johnny Isakson, the chairman of the state school board and a fixture in state Republican politics, announced his candidacy and instantly became the presumptive front-runner.

title: Crime and Punishment (but not Dostoyevsky) on Line
description: Netizens who can't get their fill of true crime can try www.apbonline.com. The site, which made its debut yesterday from Manhattan, offers news about the criminal justice system, ''all the way from 911 calls to parole and rehabilitation,'' said Mark Sauter, the site's executive vice president in charge of content.

title: With Subway Ridership Up, Service Lag Draws Criticism
description: With new government reports showing subway and bus service growing increasingly irregular as the number of passengers soars, the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, called on the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday to invest its projected budget surplus in improving mass transit conditions. In response, transit officials said that had been their plan all along.

title: Accounts
description: * 20th Century Fox, Frankfurt, part of the News Corporation, to J. Walter Thompson Frankfurt, a unit of WPP Group P.L.C., to handle its theatrical and video advertising in Germany, which had been handled by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, Frankfurt, part of MacManus Group. Billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: Israel's Conditional Yes
description: It was no small achievement for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to obtain Israeli Cabinet approval of the Maryland peace agreement with the Palestinians. But yesterday's decision was hedged with unnecessary and disruptive conditions.

title: U.S. Calls Israeli Vote 'Step Forward' to Peace
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright today welcomed the Israeli Cabinet's approval of the Middle East accord ''as an important step forward in the peace process,'' the State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, said.

title: UNIT INSTRUMENTS ACCEPTS REDUCED BID FROM U.S. FILTER
description: Unit Instruments Inc., a computer chip equipment parts maker, said late on Tuesday that it had agreed for a second time to reduce the price at which it will be acquired by the U.S. Filter Corporation. Under the new terms, U.S. Filter, the No. 1 water-treatment company, will pay $8 to $10 in stock for each Unit Instruments share, or a maximum of about $40 million. That is down from $44 million in the previous agreement, announced on Aug. 5, which in turn was cut from about $50.5 million, the original offer announced on July 2. Unit Instruments shares rose 50 cents yesterday, to $8.375, and U.S. Filter rose 50 cents, to $21.

title: Driver Comes Forward After Hit-and-Run
description: A man who had been charged in a hit-and-run accident in Brooklyn that critically injured a 7-year-old boy was released yesterday after a friend came forward and confessed that he was the driver.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Heavy Reading

title: In Fact, It's Fiction
description: Let's stipulate that newspapers make mistakes. Let's stipulate further that newspapers have printed false stories. And let's stipulate that newspapers have the ability to correct their mistakes and their fabrications the next day. In book publishing, it's not so easy. The nonfiction fiction (or the fictitious nonfiction) is out there in the bookstores, perhaps hundreds of thousands of copies, extremely expensive if not impossible to recall and correct. Even if there is the will to do so.

title: A New Law, and Many Questions, for Believers
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Say Man Stole Truck Before a Deadly Carjacking
description: Before John Magee touched off a bizarre and fatal carjacking with his uncle's car in Newark on Tuesday, he drove around for a while this fall in another stolen vehicle -- his mother's pickup truck, the police said today.

title: PC's Just Cost Less
description: To the Editor:

title: A Painter In Movement Defies Bonds Of Gravity
description: Definitely an original, Garth Fagan and his splendid dance company returned on Tuesday night with the fables and visions that dance in Mr. Fagan's head. To note that he is the award-winning choreographer of a Broadway show, ''The Lion King,'' is to give him his due but not to define him in his totality. His creative range is symbolized by the range of movement he gives his dancers, from wondrously light springs high in the air to amazing off-balance tilts, held fast with gravity-defying assurance.

title: Astros' Dierker Wins N.L. Honor
description: Larry Dierker, a former pitcher and broadcaster, was voted National League Manager of the Year yesterday, after leading the Houston Astros to a team-record 102 victories and their second consecutive division title.

title: Essay; Saddam's Strategy
description: Forget the fascination with our semiannual military buildup in the Persian Gulf to persuade Saddam Hussein ''this time we're really, really serious.'' That point's been made with the U.N.'s evacuation of employees it does not want to be chained to suspected anthrax storage sites.

title: Your Call Is Important to Them
description: IT'S a popular myth that what counts in computer products is features, price and performance. But if you listen to the people who use computer products, or read what they're writing on message boards and news groups, you get a different picture. Just as important to customers -- and maybe more so -- is getting good technical support from a company once they have bought a product. And they are not always getting it.

title: Germany and U.S. Nurture Bond At a Mansion With a Few Ghosts
description: Private pain and public hopes came together in a Berlin mansion last week when the new American Academy was opened on a site marked by Nazi terror and now dedicated to the trans-Atlantic partnership that raised Germany from the ruins of war.

title: Mets Take a Big Step Back to the Future
description: He's baaaaack. But this time, the Mets insist, Bobby Bonilla will be a different person and a different player.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a carjacking in Newark misspelled the surname of a spokesman for the police department there. He is Sgt. Derek Glenn, not Glynn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICCOLINO, ALBERTA
description: PICCOLINO-Alberta. Turtle Bay Music School notes with sadness the death of our friend and staff member. Alberta died on November 8, 1998 at her mother's home after a long bout with cancer. The school extends its heartfelt condolences to her mother Joy Piccolino, and to her entire family.

title: Is Impeachment Congress's Only Choice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Impeachment Congress's Only Choice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft's New Turf: Digital Speakers
description: First it just made software. Then it made mice, joysticks and telephones. Now the company that gave the world the Windows operating system is getting into the speaker market.

title: The G.O.P.'s Chance to Reach Out
description: Conservatives got some good news earlier this week when the Supreme Court allowed Wisconsin to go forward with its public school voucher program. The question is, will conservative leaders in Washington capitalize on it?

title: Is Impeachment Congress's Only Choice?
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NORTHERN TELECOM, -- Brampton, Ontario, plans to announce that it has agreed to provide $170 million in financing for Net2000 Communications Group, a new private local communications company.

title: More Than a Soupcon of Trouble; Celebrity Chef With Money Woes Faces Fraud Charges
description: Even in the world of serious food, where dainty portions are de rigueur, the chef David Ruggerio always projected an air of abbondanza, the generous spirit of hospitality so ingrained in the Italian-American culture of his native Brooklyn.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Intel Outlook Bodes Well For the Sector
description: The Intel Corporation's announcement that its fourth-quarter results would exceed Wall Street estimates not only bolstered its stock to a new high yesterday, but analysts said it boded well for a broad range of technology stocks, particularly those whose fortunes are tied to the personal computer.

title: Linking the Computer and the World, the Clever Modem
description: PICK up a phone while your computer is connected to the Internet, and you hear what sounds like the braying of an electronic donkey. Somewhere inside that set of squawks might be a picture of your grandmother, an E-mail to your boss or perhaps the newest version of Doom slowly downloading to your computer. Bits and bytes have been turned into audio chatter by a technological workhorse: the modem.

title: U.N. Panel to Visit Cambodia to Study Khmer Rouge Atrocities
description: Three legal experts appointed by Secretary General Kofi Annan are to go to Cambodia to study documents on Khmer Rouge atrocities and recommend how and where a tribunal should judge those crimes.

title: Creating an Oasis In Inner City or Desert
description: WHEN Jackie Mullins suggested to her husband, Houston, that they celebrate their sixth wedding anniversary in East St. Louis, Ill., a largely black city known for its social problems, he didn't think there would be much worth seeing there. Gradually, she persuaded him, and the couple came up from Memphis and signed in at the Parker Garden Bed and Breakfast, a 1912 Tudor-style home owned by Herrett and John Parker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDLER, PROF. MILTON
description: HANDLER-Prof. Milton. Beloved husband of the late Miriam Adler Handler. Devoted father of Carole. Loving grandfather of Alisa and Ilana Schoenbach, and dear uncle. Service Thursday, 11AM at Park Avenue Synagogue, 87th St and Madison Ave, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROBSTEIN, JULIETT
description: GROBSTEIN-Juliett. The Board of Governors and members of Fenway Golf Club record with profound sorrow the passing of its long time member Juliett Grobstein and extend to the members of her family our sincere condolences. Joel Langer, President Marvin Leffler, Secretary

title: Closed-Door Policy
description: WHEN F. Scott Fitzgerald told the story of young Amory Blaine at Princeton University in ''This Side of Paradise,'' he wrote of ''the silent stretches of green, the quiet halls with an occasional late-burning scholastic light.'' Many of the same halls are still on the Princeton campus, but today the tenderness of the night is often shattered by shrill beeps and a klaxon-like speaker screaming in a robotic voice, ''Please close the door securely.''

title: 'Siege' Played To Anti-Arab Bias
description: To the Editor:

title: Disaster Aid Off Kilter
description: Despite years of ''best practices'' conferences dissecting what can go wrong with global disaster-relief efforts, history is repeating itself in Central America. The response of charity groups to Hurricane Mitch reminds me of what happened after Florida's Hurricane Andrew in 1992 and the Armenian earthquake of 1988.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, ROBERT
description: WEISS-Robert was born in Jersey City, New Jersey, and was a 1982 graduate of Teaneck H.S. He began his undergraduate degree at University of Southern California and graduated from the NYU Tisch School of the Arts. He received a masters degree from the American Film Institute in screenwriting. He later graduated from Loyola Law School in Los Angeles, and became a member of the California Bar. Robert was a board member at the Huntington Beach Art Center, Huntington Beach, California, and was an avid collector of contemporary art. Robert was more than simply an art collector; over the past few years he became an important supporter of many emerging and established Los Angeles artists. Given the chance, he would certainly have become one of the major figures of the west coast contemporary art scene. Robert was the Vice President and Director of Legal Affairs for the Anaheim Indoor Marketplace. Robert is survived by his parents Lois and Barry Weiss of Tenafly, New Jersey, his sister Janet Dwork of Jupiter, Florida, and his brother-inlaw Dr. Thom Dwork, and his nephews Teddy and Alex. Also surviving are loving grandparents Aaron Rothenberg of Bal Harbour, Florida, and Murray and Eadie Weiss of Malden, Mass., his uncles and aunts Jack and Carol Weiss of Teaneck, New Jersey, Ken and Anita Altman of Plainview, New York, Dr. Ken and Gillian Rothenberg of Tenafly, New Jersey, and Drs. Andrew and Trisha Roth of Beverly Hills, California. Barry and Lois are the owners of Sylvette Shops in Hudson County New Jersey. Donations may be made to the Huntington Beach Art Center Robert Weiss Memorial Fund or the charity of your choice. The Huntington Beach Art Center is located at 538 Main Street, Huntington Beach, California 92648.

title: N.F.L. Says Fans Like Internet Site
description: The National Football League reports that its Web site has been scoring high with sports fans during the first half of the season. But the league is careful to explain that the viewers aren't being drawn away from the television, and there's an $18 billion reason the league may want to hammer that point home.

title: Is Impeachment Congress's Only Choice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Critic of City's Foster Care System Leaves a Costly Mark
description: For 28 years, Bracha Graber has toiled in the back rooms and back alleys of New York City foster care, mastering the bureaucratic intricacies of the system but never forgetting the children at stake behind the rules. Yesterday, Ms. Graber, a 49-year-old city social worker, suddenly stepped into the public glare after her whistle-blower lawsuit against the keepers of the system brought her $4.9 million.

title: Mr. M.V.P. Puts Packers On Shoulders
description: He has been named the National Football League's most valuable player three times, which means Brett Favre has won the award more times than anyone, which obviously includes some rather familiar football names like Jim Brown, Johnny Unitas and Joe Montana, who were the league m.v.p. twice each.

title: A Classic Touch to Minimalism
description: What happens when minimalist design meets classic craftsmanship? The spare furniture, ceramics and glassware at the Furniture Company, which opened last month in Greenwich Village, offer a case study. ''I am interested in the reinterpretation of beautiful materials,'' said David Schaefer, a partner in the store and the designer of the pine farm table ($7,330), chair ($750) and stools ($1,385), above. Bill Katz made the armoire ($8,250). Rupert Spira's ceramic bowls start at $85. The Furniture Company, at 818 Greenwich Street (Jane Street). ELAINE LOUIE

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Only an HBO Agreement Is Needed to Make Holyfield-Lewis a Reality
description: Now that Don King has signed contracts with Lennox Lewis and Madison Square Garden on a heavyweight unification bout between Lewis and Evander Holyfield, he has to reach an agreement with HBO Sports, which will broadcast the fight on TVKO, before the fight can become a reality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STATELMAN, RICHARD T.
description: STATELMAN-Richard T. On November 10, 1998. Following his 15 year career in the banking industry, he dedicated his life to the struggle against AIDS. He headed first the Brooklyn then the Bronx AIDS network. He is the beloved son of Edward and Genevieve Statelman. Richard touched the lives of all who knew him. Donations may be made to St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center, 130 W. 12 St., Suite 6B, NYC 10001.

title: Harlem Man In Police Clash Dies in Coma
description: A 36-year-old man died on Tuesday night after spending nearly two weeks in a coma after a police officer who was chasing him down a Harlem street threw a walkie-talkie at him and knocked him off his bicycle, the police said yesterday.

title: Art Studio Offers Lots Of Layers
description: MAKE A MASTERPIECE

title: Temple Roars From Behind And Lives Up to Its Billing
description: Wake Forest Coach Dave Odom called it fool's gold. Temple sat back in a generous zone in the first half last night and the unfettered Demon Deacons rained six 3-pointers and shot 56.5 percent to take an 8-point lead. Temple Coach John Chaney confessed afterward that he simply did not know what to do yet. ''I had big guys standing there playing nobody,'' he said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Internet Stocks Fall Sharply As Investors Take Profits

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, MILDRED
description: SCHNEIDER - Mildred. Beloved wife of the late Emanuel. Devoted mother of Stephanie. Cherished grandmother of Cari and Eric. Loving great-grandmother. Funeral services Thursday, 10AM at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont.

title: March of the Sadly Bilked
description: Some two hundred people who had lost money in a multimillion-dollar futures-market scam held a protest in Beijing today, marching from Tiananmen Square down a major avenue. The police formed a human wall to prevent them from entering the square.

title: A Tribute With a Benefit
description: In the last five years, New York has lost four giants of the game: Jim Becker, Victor Mitchell, Edgar Kaplan and Judy Tucker. A Giants Game honoring all four was played Sunday night at Honors Club in Manhattan. It raised over $8,000 for the Chemotherapy Foundation, and there was an interesting twist. Each of 80 participating pairs elected to play on one of four teams named for the honorees, and the Becker team was victorious, based on average percentage score.

title: Cone Signs One-Year, $8 Million Pact to Stay With Yanks
description: David Cone waited in his Connecticut home last evening, pondering his future, waiting to see whether the Yankees would agree to his latest proposal. He had until midnight to decide whether he would immediately work out a one-year deal with the Yankees or opt for free agency.

title: Official in French Scandal Says He Will Not Resign
description: France dismissed the Monica Lewinsky affair as puritanical persecution of President Clinton, but it is in the middle of a sex-and-politics scandal of its own, the seamiest in years.

title: From One Fallen Speaker to Another
description: With the resignation of the second House Speaker in a decade, the first is hoping that historians will now come to see him as prophetic, rather than fallen and sullied.

title: China Tells Rowdy Sports Fans: Keep It Clean
description: British soccer louts they are not, but Beijing's boisterous fans have provoked a public campaign against their increasingly flagrant use of obscenities to berate opposing teams, referees and poorly performing members of their hometown professional team.

title: Harry Markson, 92, Colorful Boxing Director
description: Harry Markson, a soft-spoken and scholarly type who spent 40 years in Madison Square Garden's often garish and turbulent boxing world, presiding over it for a quarter-century, died on Tuesday night at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J. He was 92.

title: Bondholders of Failed Barings Reject Deal to Recover Losses
description: Investors holding the bonds of Barings P.L.C., the failed British bank, rejected a proposed settlement seeking to recover their losses yesterday, saying the amount was only a fraction of $1.3 billion lost in 1995 during a wild and unauthorized trading spree by one of the bank's Singapore traders.

title: Response to Baghdad: Military Muscle May Not Suffice
description: As President Clinton ponders a military strategy against Iraq, and the Pentagon once more picks its targets and programs its cruise missiles for an attack, the debate at the White House is whether to simply punish President Saddam Hussein, or to try to change his political course by force, American officials say.

title: A New Law, and Many Questions, for Believers
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Law, and Many Questions, for Believers
description: To the Editor:

title: Chance and Character In the Valley of Death
description: MASTER GEORGIE

title: Masur Accepts 2d Conducting Post, in London
description: Kurt Masur, the music director of the New York Philharmonic since 1991, will become principal conductor of the London Philharmonic Orchestra as well, starting in 2000, Mr. Masur and officials of both orchestras said yesterday.

title: Martin Falls Short
description: Casey Martin failed to qualify for the 1999 PGA Tour, nine months after he won the right to use a cart during PGA Tour-sanctioned tournaments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, LEON
description: GROSS-Leon. On November 9, 1998. Devoted father of Lisa Ellen and H. Richard. Longtime loving companion of Hennie Vilanch. Beloved husband of the late Rita. Memorial service Thursday 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: Dow Sinks 40.16 Amid Fading Hopes for a Cut in Rates
description: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday, reversing an early advance, as investors pondered what now seems little better than an even chance that the Federal Reserve will cut short-term interest rates again next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANSON, JULIUS J., PH.D.
description: MANSON-Julius J., Ph.D. We are saddened by the loss of our dear friend and President of our Humanist Chapter, Dr. Julius Manson, long associated with social justice and humanitarian causes and the international Esperanto movement. Chapter members will miss this kindly gentleman with his quick smile, his warm wisdom, and his perennial optimism, who presided since 1974 over our speakers program, The Humanist Dialogue. He will be missed also in his role as the American Humanist Association's NGO Representative to the United Nations, where he has for many years been vitally involved in Human Rights issues and matters pertaining to international law. Dr. Manson was long a Labor Negotiator for the New York State Board of Mediation. He lived for awhile in Ankara, while he was advisor to the Turkish Government on Labor Relations. He was a Professor Emeritus at Baruch College. Our thoughts are with his grieving family as we reflect on our memories of this fine gentleman. May they be comforted in some small way to know that he was revered by his friends and fellow chapter members of The Humanist Society of Metropolitan New York. A Memorial Service will be held on Sunday, November 29 at 2 PM at New York Society for Ethical Culture at 2 W. 64 St.

title: President of Museum to Lead the U.N. Association
description: William J. Luers, a former diplomat who has been president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art since 1986, is to be the next chairman and president of the United Nations Association of the USA, the association announced today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HAAS, RHODA WILLNER
description: HAAS-Rhoda Willner. Dearly beloved, you are always in our thoughts. Stella, Abbie, Jane and Jay

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, ELEANOR BATCHELDER
description: BELL-Eleanor Batchelder. The National Society of Colonial Dames in the State of New York records with deep regret the death of its distinguished former Board Member. Gillette M. Brown, President

title: Economic Scene; Why Rates Should Be Cut, and Why Not
description: Financial turmoil makes every meeting of the Federal Reserve an occasion for frenzied speculation about interest rate cuts. Wall Street turns out daily tomes of advice, mostly calling on the Fed to knock rates down a few pegs.

title: The N.B.A.'s Senior Owner Speaks Out, and Bluntly
description: Abe Pollin bought the Washington Wizards 34 years ago, when they were called the Baltimore Bullets, the National Basketball Association consisted of nine teams and the league was more than a decade from becoming a global marketing phenomenon.

title: A Worthwhile Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: As Bombay Piles Up Wealth, Gangsters Get Their Cut, Too
description: The man this city's top crime fighters call a mafia chieftain and a cold-blooded killer was decorously receiving supplicants at his tenement headquarters here one recent afternoon. Each of them reverently touched his feet before addressing him.

title: Encouraging Creativity, Without the Mess
description: THE future of artwork is on the computer. You might not like what computers produce, you might miss the intoxicating smell of oils or the tactile quality of a broken-crockery painting -- you might wonder whether electronic art is even fine art -- but tomorrow's works are bound to be created digitally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, IVAN
description: SHAPIRO-Ivan. The Board of Directors and the staff of the NY Civil Liberties Union (NYCLU) are deeply saddened by the death of our former board member, Treasurer and friend. We extend condolence to his wife Maria and his daughters Lisa Kubiske and Alexandra Shapiro. Ivan was a committed civil libertarian whose vision, strength and dignity assisted in the development of the NYCLU. We will forever be in debt to this special person. We will miss his leadership and humanitarianism. Steven J. Hyman, President Norman Siegel, Executive Dir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, SAM
description: STONE-Sam. On November 11, 1998. Beloved husband of Dorothy Stone. Dear father of Rebecca (Jan) Gomerman. Cherished grandfather of Adam (Wendy) Gomerman and Amy (Richard) Padow. Dear brother of Lillian Sadovnick and Evelyn. Service on Friday, November 13 at 1:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Sports of The Times; The Prodigal Met: Risk Or Reward?
description: NOW that Bobby Bo again is in a Mets uniform as an outfielder who will be age 36 by opening day, maybe he will fit that uniform better this time. Maybe.

title: The Pundit-Narcissists
description: To the Editor:

title: Hanging On to the Net
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Nov. 4 about Sarah Korein, a New York real estate investor, referred incorrectly to her financing arrangements. Mrs. Korein was represented from 1977 to 1995 by Ackman Brothers & Singer, in which Lawrence D. Ackman and Andrew J. Singer were partners. Mr. Ackman arranged her financing before and after that time.

title: A True Advance
description: To the Editor:

title: Iowa Governor-Elect Has New Best Pals
description: The first person to tell Tom Vilsack that he had been elected Governor of Iowa -- the first Democrat to hold that office in three decades -- was not his campaign manager, not the state party chairman, not even his wife, Christie.

title: The Banana as Billboard
description: LOOK carefully at the bananas you bought yesterday: we all know the Chiquita lady, but several million Dole bananas are now selling something else. Little stickers tout the film ''Babe in the City,'' the sequel to the popular children's movie, which opens Nov. 20. On other Dole bunches you may find the familiar yellow dots of ABC television's fall campaign. ''TV. Zero calories,'' one slogan reads. Even more inevitable perhaps is the banana sticker, produced with the California Milk Processor Board, that reads, ''Got milk?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRUTYN, EVA
description: ABRUTYN-Eva. On November 9, 1998, Eva (nee Honigberg) of Whitemarsh, PA., wife of the late Samuel. Mother of Dr. Elias Abrutyn and the late Michael Abrutyn. Sister of Irving Honigberg. Grandmother of Stephanie, David, Daniel, Adam and Alex. Relatives and friends are invited to Graveside Services Friday, 11:30 AM at Judean Memorial Gardens, Georgia Avenue & Batchellors Forest Road, Olney, Maryland. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Abrutyn Endowment Fund at Lombardy Center, C/O Vicki Abrutyn, 11217 Potomac Crest Drive, Potomac, MD 20854.

title: An Attacker's Statement at Issue in Central Park Slaying Trial
description: A police report that is part of a dispute between prosecutors and a defense lawyer in the trial of a teen-ager accused of killing a 44-year-old man in Central Park in 1997 provides previously undisclosed details about the relationship between the victim and one of his attackers.

title: CLINTON IS SENDING BOMBERS AND G.I.'S TO PERSIAN GULF
description: President Clinton today ordered substantial new forces to the Persian Gulf, including B-1 and B-52 bombers, and warned President Saddam Hussein that the United States is prepared to strike Iraq without further warning.

title: Mr. Theater Tells Of Egos Big and Small
description: Anyone with any concern for the history or future of the theater ought to make a beeline for the Douglas Fairbanks Theater, where Prof. Alexander H. Cohen is running a fast, funny, fascinating seminar on the subject. He calls it ''Star Billing,'' and it plays on Sunday nights at 7 and Monday nights at 8.

title: Carbon Paper Still Messy, Still in Use
description: ONE of the happiest moments of Norma Carey's life was the day she threw away her carbon paper. It was the early 1970's when her employer, a law firm in Washington, switched from carbons to copiers.

title: Medpartners Plans to Divest Itself of the Business of Physician Practice Management
description: In the latest admission of failure in the business of physician practice management, Medpartners Inc. announced yesterday that it was leaving the field.

title: A $5 Billion Revamping At Monsanto
description: The Monsanto Company, which for the last few years has aggressively pushed into biotechnology and pharmaceuticals, said today that it planned to raise about $5 billion by restructuring its operations, reducing its work force as much as 9 percent, or 2,500 jobs, and selling additional shares to the public.

title: Auction Universe Is Sold
description: Classified Ventures L.L.C., an Internet services company financed by eight leading media companies, bought Auction Universe today from the Times Mirror Company. Financial terms were not disclosed. Classified Ventures is financed by Central Newspapers Inc., the Gannett Company, Knight-Ridder, the McClatchy Company, The New York Times Company, Times Mirror, the Tribune Company and the Washington Post Company. Auction Universe provides on-line auction services through a network of over 30 newspapers and other media properties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HISKEY, CLARENCE F., PHD
description: HISKEY-Clarence F., PhD. 86. Of Guilford, CT. Chemist and Professor of Chemistry at University of Tennessee, Columbia University, Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute. Worked for Tennessee Valley Authority and Manhattan Project. Director of Analytical Research at Endo Laboratories. Survived by children Iris Hiskey Arno and Nicholas Sand, grandchildren Max, Zack and Sorrel, and long time companion Betty H. Freedman. His unfailing scientific curiosity, intelligence, humor, love, and unique personality will be missed.

title: Milton Handler, 95, Is Dead; Antitrust Expert Wrote Laws
description: Milton Handler, a leading antitrust expert and drafter of some of the nation's best-known laws, died on Tuesday. He was 95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORGOSH, MILTON (MIKE)
description: FORGOSH-Milton (Mike). Beloved and worshipped husband of Irma. Devoted & cherished father of Helene and husband Edward. Adoring grandfather of Tracy, Sandi and Corey. Caring brother of Sylvia Eis, the late Gertrude Forgosh, Harold Forgosh, and Penny Gurfein. He was a remarkably strong, thoughtful and loving family man. We'll miss you, Bub. There will never be another Mike. Services 12 Noon, Thursday, November 12th, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Earthweb Share Price Triples On the First Day of Trading
description: Shares of Earthweb Inc., an on-line provider of technical information for World Wide Web site designers, more than tripled yesterday on their first day of trading.

title: With Conditions, Israel Cabinet Approves Accord
description: The Israeli Cabinet, after a two-week delay, conditionally ratified the land-for-security peace accord tonight, attaching a series of stipulations and threats that the Palestinians interpreted as overtures to conflict, not resolution.

title: Funny Woman Is a Dangerous One
description: ''A guy I know is in a men's group: 'Single Heterosexual Men Who Harbor No Hostility Toward Women.' What is there, one member?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, SOL R.
description: LEVINSON-Sol R. I am deeply saddened by the passing of my friend, my mentor, & my partner. His wits, compassion, and loyal support will always be remembered. The lesson he taught me long ago will always be part of my life. My heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Belle, his daughter, Marcia, and Bonnie, and his grandchildren. Charles Uribe

title: The Food Stamp Fracas in New York
description: New York City's diminishing welfare rolls are a point of pride with Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. When he boasts around the country of his good deeds, the drop in welfare recipients rides triumphantly up there with a decrease in crime and a rise in civility. So it caused considerable consternation at City Hall when Federal officials questioned whether welfare applicants in the city were being told quickly enough that they could apply for food stamps and Medicaid, raising the possibility that the city was unjustifiably holding back Federal benefits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAGLE, SISTER MARY ROBERT
description: NAGLE-Sister Mary Robert. On November 9, 1998. Member of the Sisters of Charity, Mount Saint Vincent, Bronx, New York. Former Director of Saint Vincent's Hospital School of Nursing, 19671991. Primary Care Nurse, Deptartment of Community Medicine, of Saint Vincent's Hospital 19911998. Beloved daughter of the late Robert and Marion. Loving sister of Richard (Madelyn). Dear aunt of Richard, Jr. & Yvette. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14 Street, NYC Wednesday, 4-9PM and Thursday, 2-9PM in the Saint Elizabeth Ann Seton Chapel of Saint Vincent's Hospital. Please enter through 158 West 12 Street, New York. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10AM in the Hospital Chapel. Interment Saint Joseph's Cemetery, Yonkers, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Development Fund, Sisters of Charity, Mount Saint Vincent, Bronx, New York 10471.

title: From Senatorial Politics, a Passage to India
description: IF her husband had not decided to announce his retirement from the United States Senate last Friday, Elizabeth B. Moynihan would have been in the Bronx that very day, indulging one of her greatest passions. She has been overseeing a major archeological project near the Taj Mahal in India, and one of her colleagues, a paleobotanist at the New York Botanical Garden, had just returned from there with some new slides of the project site.

title: When Klutziness Is an Attribute
description: Straphangers on the shuttle at Grand Central may wonder who made the tile frieze of neat blue and red arches, towers and pyramids. Its creator, the sculptor Jackie Ferrara, has a show at the TZ'Art Gallery that includes a corner chair, below, of precisely joined wood sticks, and ''Red Arches,'' two walls with wood mosaics defining, yes, red and pink arches. The subtle variegation comes from what Ms. Ferrara calls her klutziness -- she stained each piece haphazardly by hand. Also in the show are photos of her work in pale rose, cream and beige marble on a bathhouse and lap pool in Coral Gables, Fla., with the architect William Bialosky. Through Dec. 24 at 470 Broome Street. JOSEPH GIOVANNINI

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. Japan's currency rose for the first time in six days on speculation that an income-tax cut and spending plan to be announced today will help overcome recession. The dollar fell to 121.72 yen from 122.52.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGMAN, ERIC
description: WAGMAN-Eric. On November 11, 1998. Of West Orange, NJ. Beloved husband of Phyllis (nee Jacobson). Devoted father of Tina (Dennis) Bobker, Gerald (Debbi) Wagman, Robert (Lisa) Wagman. Loving brother of Bernard Wagman. Devoted grandfather of Adam and Corey Bobker, Brett and Evan Wagman, Sean and Michael Wagman. Funeral from Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Avenue, Short Hills on Thursday November 12 at 10:00 AM. Interment Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, NJ. For further information, contact Bernheim - Apter - Gold sticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, Maplewood, NJ 973-763-3505.

title: Playing the New Angles in the Pocket Kitchen Game
description: SMALL kitchens are often efficient, but rarely airy. When Victoria Koppel, 36, bought a co-op on the Upper West Side, she was unfazed by the 8-by-10-foot kitchen. It was enormous by her standards. ''It's twice the size of my last kitchen,'' said Ms. Koppel, a producer with MacKenzie Cutler, a film-editing company in Manhattan.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEPHENSON, EDWIN A.
description: STEPHENSON-Edwin A. Retired Colonel US Army veteran WWI, WWII and Korea. Retired executive Chase Bank. Of NYC on November 9, 1998. Husband of the late Caroline. Father of George Stephenson. Grandfather of David. Memorial service at the Reformed Church of Bronxville on Saturday, December 5 at 1:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Everything Under One Roof
description: The slogan ''Furniture, Objects, Ideas'' runs across the windows of Olio, a new store in TriBeCa. The shop, opened last month by Robin Allen, below right, and Andrea Zeman, left, sells ready-made and custom-upholstered furniture; pieces like the large platter at right ($70; $28 for the small bowl); jewelry; toiletries, and accessories for adults, children and dogs. Olio also offers decorating and design consultations. ''We're a low-key kind of place,'' said Ms. Allen, an interior designer who used to work at the Rockwell Group, an architectural firm.

title: Draped in Chrome: Transforming Fabrics
description: If you accept that fabric can be made of stainless steel, chrome, paper or feathers, then you will be surprised only by the beauty in ''Structure and Surface: Contemporary Japanese Textiles,'' an exhibition of more than 100 textiles that opens today at the Museum of Modern Art. Reiko Sudo coated woven polyester with powdered chrome, nickel and iron to produce ''Stainless Steel Gloss,'' background left, a silvery fabric so soft it resembles silk. For ''Shutter,'' inset right, she sewed loopy strips of nylon tape onto a soluble base fabric, which was then dissolved, leaving behind transparent strands suspended in air.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELD, DORIS RABINOR
description: FELD-Doris Rabinor. Of Lauderhill, Florida, formerly of New City, New York died on Tuesday, November 10, 1998 after a long illness. She was 79 years old. She was born in Bronx, New York to Aaron and Esther (Enteen) Rabinowitz and was a graduate of Brooklyn College. Beloved wife of Joseph Feld. Loving mother of Elaine Feld of Chestnut Hill, MA. Devoted sister of Sylvia Saper of Phoenix, AZ., George B. Rabinor of Boca Raton, FL. and the late Samuel G. Rabinor. Dear aunt and great aunt. Funeral services will be held at Hellman Memorial Chapel, 15 State St, Spring Valley, N.Y. Thursday, November 12, 12:30PM. Shiva will be held at 9 Woodland Road, New City, New York through Sunday, November 15th.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUCHERMAN, BERTHA
description: SUCHERMAN-Bertha. The Sucherman family deeply mourns the passing of Bertha Sucherman, who was a light and an inspiration to her sons, Lowell & Stuart; her grandchildren, Greg, Matthew, Joanna and David; and her daughters-in-law, Janice, Betsy and Tracy. Her indomitable will, directness, honesty and unlimited abundance of good cheer and optimism will remain with us for years to come. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, November 11th at 11:00 am at Riverside Memorial Chapel (180 W. 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue). In lieu of flowers, the family has asked that donations be made to Hadassah Chaverot in Far Rockaway (donations may be mailed to 206 Seagirt Boulevard, Lawrence, NY 11559).

description: NEWMAN-Ruth. On November 11, 1998. Beloved sister of Gladys Morris. Adored aunt of Beth, Bruce, Steve and Sherry. Cherished great aunt of Stacy, Howard, Michael, Andrew and Jonathan. Loving great great aunt of Molly.

title: In America; After Moynihan
description: Senator Giuliani? It could happen.

title: London Journal; For Blair's Cabinet, These Outings Are Not Picnics
description: Agriculture Minister Nick Brown has always tried to keep his private life to himself. But when he heard that The News of the World, a Sunday newspaper specializing in sleazy sex stories, was about to publish a salacious interview with one of his former lovers, he took a deep breath and made a dramatic public confession. Yes, he said on Sunday, I am gay.

title: No News Is Not Good News As Players' Leaders Meet
description: After 27 locked-out players met in Manhattan yesterday to discuss labor strategy and reaffirm their solidarity, Billy Hunter, the executive director of the National Basketball Players Association, stood at a microphone to announce the union had no intention of detonating the season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, SABINA Z.
description: FEINBERG-Sabina Z., 95, of Teaneck, NJ on November 5, 1998. Adored wife of the late Dr. Clarence J. Feinberg. Beloved mother of Robert S. Feinberg and Carol Shapiro. Loving grandmother of Dr. Susan Reuter and greatgrandmother of Leah Spingarn. Services were Nov.8 at Louis Surburban Chapels, Fair Lawn, NJ.

title: Medical Concern Job Cuts
description: Molecular Biosystems Inc., a developer of ultrasound contrast agents for diagnostic imaging, will cut 40 jobs, or more than 28 percent of its work force, in an effort to save $5 million a year. Molecular Biosystems, based in San Diego, said it expected to make further cuts as it hires outside companies for various manufacturing operations. The company said it did not plan to eliminate positions critical to the introduction of its flagship cardiac ultrasound imaging agent, Optison.

title: Johns Manville Purchase
description: The Johns Manville Corporation, the second-largest United States maker of building insulation, has agreed to buy an industrial polyester-fibers unit from Hoechst A.G. of Germany for undisclosed terms. Johns Manville said it was acquiring Hoechst plants in Spartanburg, S.C.; Bobingen and Berlin, Germany; Limavady, Northern Ireland, and Shanghai, China.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about realistic themes in glossy consumer magazines misspelled the surname of the designer of sequins worn by a model in More magazine. He is Carmen Marc Valvo, not Valco. The article misstated the title of Charles A. Riley 2d at We magazine. He is the editor in chief, not the publisher.

title: Argentina Takes a Lead in Setting Goals on Greenhouse Gases
description: In an important breakthrough, Argentina signaled yesterday that it would become the first developing country to adopt binding targets for controlling emissions of industrial waste gases that are believed to cause global warming.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR JUMPS 4.1 PERCENT. Prices increased from 11-year lows after a report predicted that sugar output would shrink next year because farmers are likely to plant less. The March contract rose 0.33 cent, to 8.38 cents a pound.

title: Panel Democrats Press Hyde for Vote on Merit of Charges
description: Seeking to capitalize on the public's distaste with the inquiry against President Clinton, Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee called on the panel today to vote early next week on whether the accusations in the independent counsel's report are grounds for impeachment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VITKIN, JEANNETTE
description: VITKIN-Jeannette. The Board of Governors and members of Fenway Golf Club record with profound sorrow the passing of its long time member Jeannette Vitkin and extend to her bereaved husband Robert and the members of her family our sincere condolences. Joel Langer, President Marvin Leffler, Secretary

title: U.N. Orders Inspectors and Relief Staff Out of Iraq
description: After a warning from the United States that a military strike on Baghdad may be imminent, the United Nations abruptly evacuated more than 230 foreign staff members from Iraq today, including all weapons inspectors. Another 41 people from various agencies will depart on Thursday, leaving only essential staff members behind.

title: Behind a Seamless Facade, Clashing Opinions on Life
description: To a passer-by, this small town has an idyllic air. Its wide main street is packed with pickup trucks by day, empty and serene at night. Many of the women and little girls wear long skirts, even for riding bicycles. Crime is so rare that the police statistics include ''cat bite.''
