description: GENSER-Ruth. The Breast Cancer Research Foundation extends its most heartfelt sympathy to Barbara Zinn Moore on the loss of her beloved mother, Ruth Genser. She was an inspiration to all of us.

title: Storms Disrupt Transportation and Power
description: Many commuters here who went to work on Veterans Day were punished for their diligence with rain bursts and wind gusts that snarled traffic and held up trains today. But life was not much better for many of those who stayed home. People in more than 75,000 homes in New York and Connecticut woke up to dark, cold houses as power companies scrambled to repair downed lines.

title: Sports of The Times; A Baseball Love Affair Suffering a Breakup
description: EVERYONE needed an identification card. You couldn't go into a military zone without it. Even if you were on your honeymoon. As Marilyn Monroe was.

title: Bayer's Quarterly Profit Increases by 7.7%
description: Bayer A.G., the German chemical and pharmaceutical company, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit rose by 7.7 percent as higher sales in Europe and North America, cost- cutting and lower raw materials prices helped to offset declining sales in Asia. Bayer's net income climbed to 681 million marks ($405 million), from 632 million in the comparable quarter a year earlier, even though sales dropped by 6.5 percent.

title: For Customers, a Greenmarket Plan Still Stirs Suspicions
description: Fingering the piles of lolla rossa lettuce yesterday afternoon at the Greenmarket in Union Square Park, Sue Cowen said, with an edge in her voice, ''They'd better not touch it.''

title: NETSCAPE AGREES TO ACQUIRE ATWEB FOR $95.1 MILLION
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation, the No. 1 maker of Internet browser software, said yesterday that it planned to buy the closely held Atweb Inc., an on-line Web site services company, for about $95 million in stock and options. Netscape, based in Mountain View, Calif., said it would issue 3.36 million shares to buy all of Atweb, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif. That values the transaction at $95.1 million based on Netscape's closing price of $28.3125, up 18.75 cents. Atweb provides services that help small businesses communicate and advertise on the Web, as well as set up Web sites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANNES, BERNARD
description: MANNES-Bernard. He is survived by his loving wife, Estelle; his dear children, Lon and Susan, Jessica and Murray and Eric and Betty, and his five beloved grandchildren, David, Dayno, Aaron, Adam and Liane. He will be sorely missed by family and friends alike. Service Friday, November 13, 10:15AM at Riverdale Temple, 4545 Independent Ave, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorials be sent to the National Neurofibromatosis Foundation, the Jay Leonard Manas Foundation, 95 Pine Street, 16th floor, New York City 10005. description: Foote, Cone & Belding Worldwide in New York said yesterday that it had acquired Banks Hoggins O'Shea, a hot creative shop in London, and merged it with Foote, Cone's London operation. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERTZ, BRUCE
description: HERTZ-Bruce. Age 46. Died on Nov. 11, 1998 peacefully at home in Manhattan. Beloved husband of Berryl Fox; devoted father of Matthew; son of Phyllis Hertz and the late Milton Hertz; brother of Debra and Barbara Hertz, and Nancy Good. He was Senior Counsel at the Bank of New York and one of the foremost authorities in the securities field. An admirable man of great intellect and wisdom, avid outdoorsman and runner, and world traveler. All of his friends and family were blessed by knowing a wonderful, loving, generous man whom we have lost too soon. We will all miss you deeply, Bruce. Funeral Service will be held on Friday at 12:30 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions can be made to The American Brain Tumor Association or The Neuro Oncology Research Fund at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital.

title: Poll Finds Most Voters In State Support Clinton
description: Two-thirds of New Jersey voters approve of the job President Clinton is doing, compared with a one-third approval rating for Representative Newt Gingrich, according to a Quinnipiac College poll released yesterday that was taken after the Nov. 3 election but before Mr. Gingrich announced he would leave Congress.

title: Rangers Back to Normal After Brief Scoring Spree
description: Wayne Gretzky bristled when it was suggested that the Rangers looked tired tonight.

title: Serious Waterworks For Heavy-Duty Jobs
description: The words commercial, industrial and professional are catnip when people are renovating a kitchen. But trying to install a commercial kitchen faucet at home can get you into a jam, because commercial sink fittings are larger than those on a residential sink. If you want something similar to what the professionals have for washing big pots and pans, there is now the Semi-Pro by KWC, with all the proper fittings. The Semi-Pro has a powerful sprayer at the end of a four-foot flexible hose. It is $585 at Simon's Hardware and Bath, 421 Third Avenue (30th Street). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASSING, DOROTHY WOLLMAN

Cherished mother of Lois (David) Ratner, Betty (Paul) Catsikas. Adored grandmother of Bonniesue (Larry) Ward, Laurie (Baron) Philipson, Paul and Caryn Ratner. Devoted daughter of the late Fannie and Philip Wollman. Sister of Mollie Palatnik and the late Nathan Wollman. Sister-in-law of Vern Hoffnung. Very special aunt and treasured friend. Funeral services will be held Friday, November 13th, 10 AM, Bloomfield-Cooper Funeral Chapel, Manalapan, New Jersey. Interment Wellwood Cemetery, Pine Lawn, New York. Although our world is shattered, your love, wisdom and presence will sustain us. Until we meet again, Shalom.

description: IT'S a very special time for a computer game about anticompetitive business tactics. While the Department of Justice scrutinizes Microsoft, we can play Railroad Tycoon II on our Windows-compatible PC's, build simulated choo-choo empires on the Internet and wallow in the fantasy of untrammeled monopoly power.

title: Paint by Loom
description: Brick walls, Amish quilts and abstract art inspired Jeanne Heifetz, author of an alphabet of colors, ''When Blue Meant Yellow'' (Holt, 1994; $14.95) to make painterly rugs. Why the switch from writing to Penelope's art? ''Making a rug takes only a few weeks, but people can enjoy it for years,'' Ms. Heifetz said. $75 a square foot at A Loomful of Hues, 5 East 17th Street; 691-2821. JOSEPH GIOVANNINI

title: Prosecutors Begin an Inquiry Into Contributions to Vacco
description: Federal prosecutors have opened an investigation into a series of political contributions that Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco's campaign received from donors linked to a large car-leasing company on Long Island, lawyers involved in the investigation said yesterday.

description: A day after convicting Corey Arthur of second-degree murder in the shooting of his former teacher, Jonathan M. Levin, shaken members of the jury yesterday described two days of agonizing deliberations that culminated in the realization that they could not declare Mr. Arthur guilty of actually pulling the trigger.

There's a fireplace screen from France -- a simple wisp of wave-shaped stainless-steel mesh that holds one basic brass tool -- and a set of tools from Denmark so minimalist that it looks like a line drawing on the wall.

His Internet-derived collection of haiku-like verse inspired by Spam, the popular processed-pork product, is the sole listing under the subject heading ''Canned meat -- poetry.''

title: Czechs Say School Abused U.S. Children
description: PRAGUE  Czech police have arrested four people, including two Americans, on charges of physically abusing and imprisoning American youths at an unlicensed reform school for wayward teenagers.

Salinger and Philip Roth have been skewered by former lovers, and Paul Theroux has described every odd element in the character of V. S. Naipaul, nobody has suffered more from critical reappraisal than that onetime legend of raw, courageous integrity, Lillian Hellman.

title: A New PCMCIA Card For Cellular Net Connections
description: The good news is that a new generation of modems has emerged that enables handheld Windows CE devices to make wireless connections to the Internet over cellular telephone networks. The bad news is that the transmissions can be as finicky and limited as cellular telephone transmissions, and the modems are expensive to boot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRISHBERG, BERNARD H.

description: After decades of close calls with bankruptcy, a Federal Government bailout and finally a recent flood of profits from minivan and Jeep sales, the Chrysler Corporation will disappear as an independent company on Thursday, merging with Daimler-Benz A.G. of Germany.

title: In Private Homes, Itinerant Abortion Protesters Find Support
description: By outward appearances, Dorothy Hayes's life seems ordinary. She and her family live in a rambling old home on the shore of Lake Ontario, and every morning, she gives her husband, John, a peck on the cheek before he goes to work. She runs errands, like other suburban moms, and spends much of her day taking care of her children.

title: Singapore Sets Plans To Revive Economy
description: Singapore laid out plans yesterday to slash wages and reduce pension contributions as part of $6.1 billion in cost cuts aimed at reviving its shrinking economy. The total value of the cuts is equivalent to 7 percent of Singapore's gross domestic product and would reduce costs for the critical electronics industry by 15 percent, the Government said.

title: A New Law, and Many Questions, for Believers
description: To the Editor:

title: Hurst Looks Back
description: Pat Hurst has enjoyed her best season on the L.P.G.A. Tour, regardless of what happens at next week's PageNet Tour Championship in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: CONCENTRA SHARES UP 93% ON ORACLE'S $43 MILLION OFFER
description: The stock of the Concentra Corporation soared 93 percent yesterday after the Oracle Corporation said it would buy the engineering software maker in a cash tender offer for $43 million. Under the offer, Oracle must acquire 51 percent of Concentra stock at $7 a share. The tender offer is expected to close near the end of the year. Concentra, based in Burlington, Mass., had revenues of $13.7 million for its 1998 fiscal year. Oracle, a software company based in Redwood Shores, Calif., had revenues of $7.14 billion for the 1998 fiscal year. Concentra's stock closed $3.3125 a share higher yesterday at $6.875; Oracle's shares rose $2, or 6 percent, to $33.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, DAVID M.
description: BRODY-David M. Age 90, of Port Washington, L.I. on November 10, 1998. Beloved husband of Selma Blazer Brody. Devoted brother of Sylvia Axelrad of NY, NY and Ruth Goldblum of Delray Beach, Florida. Also survived by many nieces, nephews, grand nieces and grand nephews. Funeral arrangements are private.

title: Lots of Antiques on Line, but Not Many Rules
description: TRADING for antiques on the Web offers the opportunity to view, if not touch, an inexhaustible supply of items in a short time. But when it comes to buying, Mike Putzel, president of Trysail, a consulting concern that seeks to make technology easier for nontechnical people, warns that ''www'' stands not only for World Wide Web but also for Wild Wild West. ''There is ample opportunity in this Wild Wild West to rip people off,'' he said.

title: Campaign Promises Not Welcome by E-Mail
description: The staff members of Florida's Democratic Party have been cleaning up in the aftermath of Election Day, including clearing some boisterous complaints out of their E-mail In boxes.

title: Corrections
description: The Sky Watch star map on Sunday showed erroneous constellations for the week of Nov. 8 and misidentified the visible planets. The map illustrated the summer sky, rather than a fall sky. The planets to the south are Saturn and Jupiter, not Mercury and Venus. Readers wishing corrected copies of the map may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@nytimes.com. (Include a postal return address.)

title: Nissan, Losing Money, Seeks Public Loan
description: The Japanese Government is poised to come to the aid of the Nissan Motor Company, the nation's ailing No. 2 auto maker, by making loans from the Japan Development Bank available to it.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Compaq Computer's plan to sell directly to consumers misspelled the given name of the president of Tech Data, a computer wholesaler that could be affected. He is Anthony A. Ibarguen, not Antony.

title: O.E.D. Quality Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Californian to Shun House G.O.P. Race
description: Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California, has decided not to enter the race for House majority leader, the No. 2 leadership position, leaving three candidates battling it out.

title: Guttenberg Votes to Join Regional Fire Dept.
description: After staying out of a regional fire department formed by four neighboring communities in Hudson County, the Guttenberg Town Council has voted to join the department despite the Mayor's threat to veto the move.

title: Be Prepared; Making the Most of a Call for Technical Support
description: THERE are ways to get more out of that technical support phone call -- when you finally have to make it. Here are some suggestions:

title: Parolee Charged in Rape Of Girl, 16, in Harlem
description: A 23-year-old homeless man, on parole for criminal possession of a weapon, was arrested yesterday in Harlem after he apparently disabled his electronic ankle-monitor and then raped a 16-year-old girl at knifepoint, the authorities said.

title: Is Impeachment Congress's Only Choice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Vaughn Likely To Leave Red Sox
description: The eight-year relationship between Mo Vaughn and the Boston Red Sox apparently ended tonight. Vaughn, a free agent, rejected the Red Sox's offer, and General Manager Dan Duquette said the club would pursue another free agent to replace the production that Vaughn provided.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PYERON, JOSEPH J., SR.
description: PYERON-Joseph J., Sr. Died November 9, 1998 in his sleep after a full day of work. Husband of the late Tessie and survived by his two brothers, Stan and John and his two children, Ruth and Joseph, Jr. He served as a marine in WWII and was a machinist for a defense contractor by career. Viewing will be held at the Dalton Funeral Home Friday evening and funeral on Saturday morning. Donations in his memory may be sent to Bellerose Baptist Church, 240-20 Braddock Avenue, Bellerose, NY 11426.

title: New Chief for National Public Radio Network
description: National Public Radio's governing board announced yesterday that Kevin Klose, a former Washington Post reporter and editor and the current head of the Federal Government's overseas radio broadcasts, was the new president and chief executive of the public radio network.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWEITZER, DR. NANCY J.
description: SCHWEITZER-Dr. Nancy J. It's twelve years now, darling. Missing you, loving you and remembering the good years. How very special you were! Your Mom

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, DONALD L.
description: MILLER-Donald L. On November 11, 1998. His many friends were warmed by his love and are saddened by his death.

title: A New Law, and Many Questions, for Believers
description: To the Editor:

title: Seagram to Reorganize Its Spirits Business
description: The Seagram Company said this week that it would restructure its wine and liquor business by moving its top management to New York and focusing on its Chivas Regal and Crown Royal whiskies.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Great Sets, Great Acting, Terrific Verb Tenses
description: Two professors at Colgate University, in Hamilton, N.Y., have created an innovative technology to promulgate a simple teaching philosophy: feature films fun, textbooks boring.

title: CARGILL TO DISMISS 300 FROM FINANCIAL MARKETS GROUP
description: Cargill Inc., the largest privately held United States company, said yesterday that it would dismiss a third of 900 workers at a unit that trades securities and real estate, after a big loss from bad bets on the Russian ruble. The dismissal in the Financial Markets Group is part of the company's effort to reorganize the unit. Employees at the company, based in Minnnetonka, Minn., were notified about the job cuts yesterday, a day after Cargill said it would expand its crop business with the acquisition of a unit of the Continental Grain Corporation. Cargill employs about 80,600 worldwide.

title: Riding a Mouse On the Quest For Antiques
description: LYNNE STRAUSS has purchased at least $10,000 worth of antiques in the last three months. There was an 1870's Royal Doulton pitcher and wash basin from Southampton, N.Y., a marble bust from New Jersey and an art-glass lamp from Florida. Her pride and joy, a $3,300 carpenter's sample of a child's dresser, came from Chester, Conn. ''It's absolutely wonderful,'' said Ms. Strauss, who lives in Juneau, Alaska, and bought everything based on photographs she found on the Internet.

title: Free Internet Access Is an Expensive Gamble
description: The promise of advertiser-supported Web access has hit a few more roadblocks. Bigger.net, a company in San Jose, Calif., that offered free, advertising-supported Internet access, declared bankruptcy last month. The company had more than 18,000 customers who had been promised ''unlimited lifetime access'' in exchange for a one-time fee of $60 and their willingness to put up with constant advertising on the browser.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Blending Yin and Yang, Gloriously
description: I STARED at the Chinese tree peonies, almost resentfully.

title: Researchers Claim Embryonic Cell Mix Of Human and Cow
description: Venturing deep into uncharted realms of ethics and medicine, a small biotechnology company said yesterday that its scientists had for the first time made human cells revert to the primordial, embryonic state from which all other cells develop, by fusing them with cow eggs and creating a hybrid cell.

title: Man Sought as Slaying Witness Has New Jersey Tie, Ex-Boss Says
description: James Charles Kopp, the anti-abortion protester being sought by the Federal authorities as a material witness in connection with the sniper killing of Dr. Barnett E. Slepian in Buffalo last month, recently lived in New Jersey and worked for a restaurant delivery service in Hoboken, according to his former boss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCULLY, FRANCIS PAUL, JR
description: SCULLY-Francis Paul, Jr, age 73, of Marblehead, MA., & Stonington, ME. Died Monday, November 9 in Maine. He is survived by his wife Anne (Harmon) of Marblehead; a daughter, Tara S. Rockefeller of New York City; two sons, Francis P. Scully, III of Marblehead and John H. Scully of New York City. He is also survived by two grandchildren, Eliza and Alexander Rockefeller of New York City. A funeral mass will be held Sat., November 14 at the Star of the Sea Church, 85 Atlantic Ave, Marblehead, MA at 10AM. Burial will be private. Eustis-Cornell Funeral Home of J.S. Waterman & Sons, 142 Elm Street, Marblehead.

title: Collectibles From Off the Assembly Line
description: LAST Friday, as the dealers set up, Pier 88 looked more like a Salvation Army store than a taste-making scene. At the 20th-century design pier of the Triple Pier Expo, nicked chrome hanging lamps sat on scuffed bent-plywood desks and yellowing plastic chests shouldered dirty orange upholstered chairs.

title: Upshaw Cancels Recital
description: The soprano Dawn Upshaw has canceled her Nov. 22 recital at Carnegie Hall because her accompanist, the pianist Richard Goode, is undergoing treatment for tendinitis. The concert will not be rescheduled. Credit card subscribers will receive refunds automatically; others may return their tickets for a refund. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: Art Museum In Texas Gets Trove Of 700 Works
description: One of the largest and most important collections of Old Master paintings and drawings in private hands will soon have a new home at the Jack S. Blanton Museum of Art at the University of Texas at Austin, leaving two New York institutions somewhat the poorer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, SOPHIE GERLA
description: FREEMAN-Sophie Gerla. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a longtime friend who, with her late husband, Charles S., was a YU Guardian, Yeshiva College Fellow, and Founder of our Albert Einstein College of Medicine. We extend our heartfelt condolences to grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Air Display For Veterans Adds Fright To Festivities
description: A ''roaring'' noise interrupted Sheryn Jiggetts's morning yesterday, scaring her out of her chair and sending co-workers rushing to the windows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLITZER, JEANETTE
description: BLITZER - Jeanette. Gently passed away on November 10, 1998 at home. Loving wife of Myron. Mother of Ellen, Diana and the late Karen. Grandmother of Carolyn, Daniel, Peter and Lauren. Great-grandmother of Ellen, Steven, Michael, Christine and Elizabeth. She lived a simple life of giving to all she came in contact with. May the Almighty speedily join Jeanette with her daughter Karen and all her loved ones that are awaiting her. Services will be held Thursday at 1:30PM. Gutterman's Funeral Home, Brooklyn, 2576 Flatbush Avenue (corner Avenue V), 718-284-1500.

title: Residential Sales
description: MANHATTAN

title: Our Towns; Police Forces That Become Expendable
description: NEW YORKERS accustomed to waiting a half-hour for a police car to show up after a purse-snatching would be astonished at the personal service small-town and suburban residents routinely get.

title: Classic Responses to the Big Crash
description: I HAVE a very promiscuous computer. In the seven months since I bought my Micron Millenia, I have introduced it to no fewer than 100 new software programs -- including about three dozen shareware applications -- and nearly a dozen hardware gadgets. Electronic books, printers, digital cameras: if someone invented a computerized toothbrush, I'd probably try to hook that up, too.

title: Two Are Added To Front Office
description: Looking to improve the sales, marketing and exposure of the MetroStars, Metromedia, which owns the Major League Soccer team, announced yesterday the appointments of August Shtino as executive vice president and Jim Leahy as the vice president of sales and marketing.

title: Making Pictures Into Panoramas
description: EVEN the photograph-analysis machine that Harrison Ford used in the futuristic science-fiction classic ''Blade Runner'' couldn't tilt an image and circle around it as if the viewer were standing at the center of a panorama. But a new technology, now being offered to consumers, can do just that.

title: Cable and Wireless Ends Telecom Italia Plan
description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C., Britain's second-largest phone company, said yesterday that it had dropped plans for a European partnership with Telecom Italia S.p.A. because of management discord at Italy's No. 1 phone company. Cable and Wireless has been in talks with Telecom Italia about creating the world's second-largest carrier of international calls. Last month's resignation of Telecom Italia's chairman, Gian Mario Rossignolo, persuaded Cable and Wireless to change its plans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMINSKY, DAVID
description: KAMINSKY-David. Of Fort Lee, NJ, died of cancer Tuesday night, Nov. 10. He was a graduate of City College of NY. An accountant, he built a successful private practice of corporate and individual clients. He is survived by his wife Mildred, also of Fort Lee, a daughter Sue, and two grandchildren, who live in the Washington, D.C. area, and a brother and sister who live in Florida. For information ''Wien & Wien'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: More Than Just a Movie House; A Magnet for Brooklyn's Young Is in Place, but Will It Work?
description: When the Brooklyn Academy of Music opens its new cinema tomorrow after four days of previews and a ribbon-cutting party tonight, a lot more will be riding on it than the mere fate of the borough's first art-house movie theater.

title: Freeport Advances As Playoffs Begin
description: Freeport kicked off the playoffs on Long Island yesterday by defeating Baldwin, 12-7, in the Nassau County Conference I semifinal at Hofstra University. Hofstra will be the site for seven other Nassau County playoff games throughout the weekend.

title: Stackable, Pliable Fun In Tutti-Frutti Colors
description: Plastics were pretty dull stuff to have around the house until the early 1960's, when new technologies for mass production attracted the attention of home furnishings designers. Inspired by space-age innovations and Pop Art, the designers -- mostly European post-modernists not unfriendly to kitsch -- seized on the potential of plastics for bright, tutti-frutti colors, appealing surfaces and sexy, rounded shapes.

title: Conquering Mount Metropolis
description: In Jon Krakauer's best-selling book, ''Into Thin Air,'' he recounts a disastrous 1996 expedition to Mount Everest. Interspersed with the life-and-death drama on the summit are bits of climbing lore that make readers share the urge to climb the world's highest mountains. In one passage, Mr. Krakauer describes the Seven Summits, the tallest peaks on each of the world's continents. In 1990, a pair of adventurers set the seemingly unreachable goal of scaling all of them in seven months -- and they succeeded with only hours to spare.

title: Visions of a Land in Flux
description: An ambitious exhibition on the art of the Edo period in Japan (1615-1868) opens at the National Gallery in Washington this weekend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOTOROFF, MICKEY
description: SLOTOROFF-Mickey. The Board of Directors, Members, and Staff of the Falls Country Club extend with deep sorrow sympathy to the family of Mickey Slotoroff.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the United States' preparations for a possible attack on Iraq misstated the number of United Nations arms inspectors who left Baghdad on Wednesday. They totaled 103. The figure of more than 230 was for United Nations workers who left, including those from relief agencies.

title: Snapshots of a War And a Lost Cause
description: The Spanish Civil War pitted the well-equipped and well-trained nationalist armed forces, led by Franco, against the poorly armed and trained troops of the elected Republican Government. It was an unequal contest: Franco's forces were backed by Hitler and Mussolini, and the leftist-liberal Republicans, or Loyalists, were supported by the Soviet Union and the International Brigades, some 40,000 volunteers with little or no fighting experience from 52 countries who wanted to stop Fascism.

title: Melodies Grounded In Intuition
description: The effect of a room's layout on a jazz group is rarely quantifiable, but a set by David Ballou's quartet at the Internet Cafe on Wednesday night was an exception. The club is a long and narrow space with room for a band in the middle, and Mr. Ballou's group solved the problem of not being able to face the audience in both directions by splitting into two halves and facing each other. Mr. Ballou, a trumpeter, paired off with the tenor saxophonist Tony Malaby, and they played symbiotically and rather exclusively. The drummer Jeff Williams and the bassist Mark Dresser hooked up with similar single-mindedness on the other side.

title: 5 Unmarried Sisters in Postcard Ireland
description: Meryl Streep has made many a grand acting gesture in her career, but the way she simply peers out a window in ''Dancing at Lughnasa'' ranks with the best. Everything the viewer need know about Kate Mundy, the woman she plays here, is written on that prim, lonely face and its flabbergasted gaze.

title: Dell Reports Record Earnings and Revenues in Third Quarter
description: The Dell Computer Corporation reported record third-quarter revenue and earnings yesterday as it continued to grow at several times the rate of the personal computer industry as a whole.

title: Graf Headed to Garden; Ailing Williams Is Out
description: Circumstances took players in opposite directions today; Steffi Graf was jubilant about her 11th-hour qualification for the year-ending Chase Championships next week at Madison Square Garden, while fifth-ranked Venus Williams reluctantly withdrew from the tournament just before the draw was unveiled.

title: On a Journey Through a Maze, Contemplating Light and Color
description: The magic of Robert Irwin's installation ''Part 2 : Excursus: Homage to the Square3,'' at the Dia Center for the Arts, lies in its intense distillation of light, color and space. No video, no sound, no movable parts distract your attention. Yet from the minute you enter this remarkable suite of cubicles, everything outside it seems, for the moment, irrelevant.

title: CBS Plans a Sale Of a Radio Stake
description: The CBS Corporation plans to sell a 16 percent stake in its Infinity Broadcasting radio and billboard unit in an issue that could raise as much as $2.97 billion, which would be the third-richest United States initial public offering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOPHER, MORRIS
description: SOPHER-Morris. Passed away on November 11, 1998. The American Friends of Migdal Ohr deeply mourn the passing of our dear friend, Morris Sopher. He was a man whose sterling qualities, generosity of spirit, and profound compassion endeared him to all. He was a Board member, avid supporter of Migdal Ohr, and together with his dear wife, Marilyn, and children, Lisa, Barbara and Jonathan, who shared his noble journey of magnificent accomplishments, have provided the less fortunate and underprivileged youth of Israel with immeasurable opportunities. His irrepressible spirit, genuine love of humanity and unparalleled generosity are a blessed legacy. May the Al-mighty comfort the family in their time of deep bereavement and may they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Yitzchok Dovid Grossman, Founder and Dean, Migdal Ohr Chief Rabbi, Migdal Ha'emek Robert L. Fromer, Chairman of the Executive Committee Max Thurm, President Shalom Siegfried, Executive Director

title: Tim Greathouse, 48, Art Dealer and Artist
description: Tim Greathouse, a leading figure of the East Village art scene of the 1980's, died on Oct. 18 at his home in Manhattan. He was 48.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, FLORENCE L.
description: WALSH-Florence L. (Meg). It is wih great sadness that the Board, Staff and friends of Jersey Battered Women's Services, Morris Plains, NJ, mourn the sudden and untimely passing of Meg Walsh, our Director, and her infant son, Dixon. Early on, Meg showed a keen interest in and commitment to helping the victims of domestic violence. She will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her husband, Mark, son, Carter and family. Baxter W. Graham, President Deborah A. Callahan, Exec. Dir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAIGE, MURIEL M.
description: PAIGE-Muriel M. Resident of New Hyde Park, NY. Retired school teacher and alumna of the College of New Rochelle. Active member of AAUW Chapter. Ms. Paige donated her body to Stoney Brook University Medical School. There will be a Memorial Mass at St. Aidan's R.C. Church, 505 Willis Avenue, Williston Park, NY, at 11:15 AM on November 17, 1998

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIMELSTEIN, LIBBY R.
description: HIMELSTEIN-Libby R. (nee Rosenfeld). On November 11, 1998 of Garden City, LI. Beloved wife of Morgan. Devoted mother of Dr. Andrew and Dr. Rima, Dr. Bruce and Dr. Nita. Dear sister of Robert Rosenfeld. Cherished grandmother of Daniel, Robyn, Rebecca, Jeffrey and Miriam. Services today 12:15 PM at ''Gutterman's, Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Japanese Slump Aside, Profit Is Up at Honda and Mazda
description: Despite recent trouble in the Japanese auto industry, the Honda Motor Company and the Mazda Motor Corporation reported impressive profit gains today for the first half of the fiscal year.

title: Sweden's Central Bank Lowers 2 Key Rates
description: The Swedish central bank, the Riksbank, lowered two of its key interest rates yesterday, saying that Swedish inflation was on a path that would bring it below the bank's target within two years. The Riksbank cut its deposit rate by half a percentage point, to 3.25 percent, and its lending rate by half a point, to 4.75 percent. The more important repurchase rate, which was cut last week by a quarter percentage point, was left unchanged at 3.85 percent.

title: Recount Confirms Nevada Senator's Victory
description: After a recount of ballots here in Washoe County this week, Nevada officials announced today that the latest tally showed that the incumbent Democratic Senator, Harry Reid, had defeated his Republican challenger, Representative John Ensign, by 401 votes, or less than one-tenth of 1 percent of the total 435,787 votes cast in the Nov. 3 Senate race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALLAHAN, FREDERIC L.
description: CALLAHAN-Frederic L. Died on November 10, 1998 after a brief illness. Retired Associate Professor of Education and English, Lehman College, CUNY. Beloved husband of Louise (nee Samoyedna). Loving father of Siobhan, Alison and Evin. Dear brother of Lenore O'Shea and Paul, and the late Joan Fitzsimmons. Donations in his memory may be made to Boston College, Office of Development, More Hall, Room 220, Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts 02167.

title: Unbeaten Kansas State Is Woeful No More
description: Their quarterback has been muzzled and their most decorated player is a 5-foot-9-inch Argentine-born kicker. Their coach prefers chief executive officer-styled power suits over the warmups sported by most members of his fraternity. He doesn't eat until midnight, when his workaholic day is over, and he acts as if he would rather play the most important game in his program's history on Friday.

title: 1,000 Jobs Will Be Cut By Texaco
description: In the latest example of the effect that low oil prices are having on energy companies, Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it would cut 1,000 jobs worldwide, or about 5 percent of its work force, in its oil-exploration division as part of a cost-cutting effort that is intended to save $200 million a year.

title: Triumph Over Misfortune
description: ''Singing comes from the head, the vocal cords and the diaphragm,'' says the German bass-baritone Thomas Quasthoff. It also comes from the heart. Mr. Quasthoff, 39, among the most critically hailed and sought-after singers in Europe, was one of 5,000 children born with abnormalities after their mothers took the drug thalidomide. Yet he has embraced life without regret in a career that is a tribute to talent, optimism and tenacity. He performs tonight and tomorrow in Mahler's ''Knaben Wunderhorn'' with the New York Philharmonic under Sir Colin Davis.

title: Outsider Quits as Chief Executive At No. 6 U.S. Accounting Firm
description: While the nation's five largest accounting firms have been sprinting away from their accounting roots to become aggressive sellers of consulting services, most of the smaller firms have been slow to change.

title: Rockers Bullying and Squabbling Down Memory Lane
description: ''Hard Core Logo,'' a more straight-faced punk-rock descendant of ''This Is Spinal Tap,'' follows a fictional band from Vancouver on its chaotic, self-destructive farewell tour across western Canada. But unlike ''Spinal Tap,'' which cast a comically jaundiced eye on every nuance of the heavy-metal life style, this clever mock documentary, which opens today at the Screening Room, blends satire and sentiment in a way that keeps you emotionally off balance.

title: From a Rigid Culture To a Floating World
description: At the end of the 20th century, the art world is paying close attention to the 19th century, as if probing to see what reflections and cautionary predictions it might reveal.

title: $1.64 May Block Medical Use of Marijuana in Capital
description: For want of an estimated $1.64 in this city's perennial home-rule struggle with Congress, the Election Day result of a ballot initiative proposing the medicinal use of marijuana is being kept sealed as a secret from local voters.

title: Fraternal Loyalty, But in Vain
description: A combination of strong acting and missing substructure turn ''River Red'' into a mixed blessing.

title: A Schnitzel-Based Revolt In an Australian Dogpatch
description: The songs of Rodgers and Hammerstein, which saturate ''Welcome to Woop Woop,'' Stephan Elliott's nightmarish satire of Australian bourgeois provincialism, will certainly survive being dragged through the dirt of this desperately unfunny farce. Whether Mr. Elliott, who made his reputation directing ''Priscilla, Queen of the Desert,'' emerges unscathed is another matter.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Wall St. Unmoved by Possible Fedex Strike
description: Things have been looking pretty dire lately at Federal Express, the company that invented overnight delivery.

title: Zeneca Seeks Buyer For a Chemicals Unit
description: Zeneca Group P.L.C., Britain's third-biggest drug maker, is seeking a buyer for its specialty-chemicals unit, which could fetch at least $1.5 billion, joining rivals like Novartis A.G. in focusing on more profitable drugs and agrochemicals.

title: A Heel of a Shoe Salesman Can't Expect a Last Laugh
description: The unfortunate title of Eric Bross's first feature film, ''Ten Benny,'' is a slang term for the alleged shoe size of Paul Newman. Oh, don't ask why. It's not worth getting into, other than to note that the movie's leading character, Ray (Adrien Brody), is miserable in his dead-end job working in a shoe store in Bloomfield, N.J.

title: Chemical Element of Vinyl Toys Causes Liver Damage in Lab Rats
description: A chemical ingredient of vinyl, used by the toy industry since the early 1980's because an earlier compound caused liver damage in laboratory rats, caused essentially the same problems in rats in tests done in the mid-90's, a manufacturer of the chemicals acknowledged.

title: Stephen Duggan, Environmentalist, Dies at 89
description: Stephen Pierce Duggan, the founding chairman of the Natural Resources Defense Council and a leader in the fight that preserved the scenic Storm King Mountain from development, died on Sunday at Cornwall Hospital in Cornwall-on-Hudson, N.Y. A longtime Cornwall resident, he was 89 and formerly lived in Manhattan as well.

title: Kmart's Earnings More Than Double
description: The Kmart Corporation, the nation's No. 2 discount retailer behind Wal-Mart Stores Inc., said today that fiscal third-quarter earnings more than doubled as demand for Martha Stewart linens and towels and other household goods offset sluggish clothing sales.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Kongo Criollo'

title: When Death Comes to Call, Serve Peanut Butter
description: Oh, to die in a sugar-coated Hollywood movie while the spiritual schmaltz craze is under way! You look your best. You say wise things. Your loved ones cherish them. Perhaps there'll be a party with a dance band and fireworks in your honor. And you can spend as much time on your last farewells as it took to sink the Titanic, a ship that doubtless bears some responsibility for the rise of the four-star demise. You can even insist, as the oppressively lavish and snail-paced ''Meet Joe Black'' does, that the old wisdom about the rich man and the eye of the needle was dead wrong.

title: Will Vouchers Kill Public Schools -- and Ideals?; Spurring Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: POP GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Japan Moves to Thwart APEC's Free-Trade Plan
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Japan has mustered enough support from other Asian and Pacific countries hit hard by the region's economic crisis to derail a "fast-track" trade-liberalization plan that Washington says is critical if it is to combat protectionism in America, officials said Thursday.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NARDELLI, CAMILLO
description: NARDELLI - Camillo. Eleven years today on Friday the 13th. You are always in my heart. Love, Ka

title: It's Time To Repay America
description: Once again, America and Britain stand shoulder to shoulder against Iraq. Resolute in our determination to stop a dangerous dictatorship from developing weapons of mass destruction. Committed to upholding international law.

title: Pie Time
description: Fall is the time to think of fragrant, steaming pies like those served at these 12 restaurants. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: New Policy Planning Chief
description: Morton H. Halperin, a former White House and Pentagon official, will become the new director of policy planning at the State Department.

title: Should One Man Decide on Military Action?
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Big Guys' Have No Love for Big Apple
description: Most Americans shopping for hamburger or stewed tomatoes lately have probably noticed new kinds of grocery stores offering more kinds of exotic fruit, caseloads of staples, even Italian cooking classes. Unless, that is, they live in or near New York City.

title: Will Vouchers Kill Public Schools -- and Ideals?; 'Choice' Coalition
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Moving West To Surf for Dollars

title: Portray Arabs Fairly
description: To the Editor:

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Making Movies Their Own Way

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARREL, SADYE
description: BARREL-Sadye (Syd). The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society express profound sorrow at the loss of Syd Barrel of Palm Beach, Fla. A successful, self-made entrepreneur and investor, she was a long-time exemplary supporter of the American Technion Society, the Technion and Israel. As a Technion Guardian, she demonstrated the highest level of commitment, supporting many vital programs at the Technion, a dedication continued by her daughter and son-inlaw, Iris and Carl Apfel. We extend our heartfelt condolences to them. American Society for TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology Lawrence Jackier, President Irving A. Shepard, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive VP Richard Zaretsky, Palm Beach Chapter President Ileane Rayman-Kaufman, Palm Beach Chapter Director

title: Denmark's No. 1 Bank In Bid to Expand
description: Den Danske Bank, Denmark's biggest bank, raised its bid for Norway's Fokus Bank to 5.815 billion kroner ($775 million) last night, matching a bid from Svenska Handelsbanken as the No. 1 Swedish and Danish banks battle to increase market share in neighboring Norway.

title: In ABC Labor Dispute, Clamorous Picketing by 400 People
description: About 400 people drowned out rush-hour traffic on Columbus Avenue with blaring horns and screeching whistles yesterday afternoon in a protest of ABC's 10-day old lockout of its camera operators, technicians and editors.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Helen Keller As a Woman With a Feel For Money
description: If Helen Keller were alive today, she would probably have her own daytime talk show. That is one of the messages of ''Monday After the Miracle,'' a CBS movie to be seen on Sunday night. The other message is that sometimes a relationship between two people is too close to let anyone else share it.

title: Microsoft Tries to Discredit Intel Executive
description: Lawyers for the Microsoft Corporation made a broad and aggressive attempt today to discredit an Intel executive who has emerged as an important Government witness, portraying him as a resentful employee and introducing testimony from his own supervisor that differed from his memory of events.

title: BIG BEAR OFFERS $125 MILLION IN STOCK FOR BLUE RANGE
description: The Canadian oil and gas company Big Bear Exploration Ltd. offered yesterday to acquire the Blue Range Resource Corporation for $194 million (Canadian), or $125.5 million (United States), in stock, plus assumed debt of $105 million (Canadian). Blue Range, based in Calgary, Alberta, is a natural gas exploration, development, production and processing company, with natural gas liquids production of 1,611 barrels a day. Big Bear, also based in Calgary, is an oil and gas company with production of 2,198 barrels a day equivalent. In its offer, Big Bear would exchange 11 of its own shares for each Blue Range share.

title: History Catches Up
description: To the Editor:

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: If it has been a while since you've been to the Bowery, you are in for a surprise. The gentrification that started with hot spots like B Bar is starting to speed up. The latest example: Bop.

title: Dressed Up As the Law
description: Home video often leads the way to a small, noteworthy film that provokes more than the usual amount of thought about the concept and how it works or doesn't. Such is the case with ''Bang,'' an intriguing and well-reviewed movie about a nameless young Asian woman (Darling Narita) and her experience impersonating a Los Angeles motorcycle policewoman.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about the competition for House Republican leadership positions misstated the process by which some will be filled. Only the Speaker is first nominated by the Republican caucus and then elected by the full House. Other positions, like majority leader and majority whip, are filled by vote of the caucus alone.

title: Brothers Charged With Scheming to Sell Pieces of Fake Moon Rock
description: It was advertised by a Manhattan auction house in 1995 as ''the first substantial moon rock ever available for sale.''

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL UP 2.1 PERCENT. Prices strengthened on the possibility of a U.S. military strike against Iraq, raising fear of supply disruptions in the Middle East. The December contract rose 29 cents, to $13.84 a barrel.

title: Will Vouchers Kill Public Schools -- and Ideals?; France Found a Way
description: To the Editor:

title: You Really Can't Get a Cab When Rome Proposes Reforms
description: Ask cabdrivers in Rome if they like their jobs, and the uniform reply is an operatic screed about the petty bureaucratic rules, clogged traffic, high cost of gasoline and dearth of clients.

title: Modernism A Bit Early
description: The first designer who used his name as a marketing tool, a la Ralph Lauren, was probably Christopher Dresser, an English designer of household goods in the 1800's who stamped his name on most of his products. Sadly, a name that had wide currency in his time has had practically none in ours.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Veterans Day parade in Manhattan misstated the age of Sheryn Jiggetts, one of the people alarmed by the noise of two F-16 fighter jets flying over Madison Square Park. She is 51, not 57.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLUM, VIOLET
description: ROSENBLUM-Violet. Of Boca Raton, FL, on November 11th, 1998. Beloved wife of Robert. Loving mother of Barry (Saundra) and Nancy (Lester) Miller. Cherished grandmother of Steven Rosenblum, Michele Sand and Robyn Zweifach. Services held in Florida. Gutterman - Warheit Memorial Chapel, 1-800-992-9262

title: A Record Set In Wagering
description: Total wagering on the 10-race program from the Breeders' Cup Championship last Saturday at Churchill Downs rose 15 percent to a North American single-day record $91.4 million, organizers said yesterday.

title: Trying to Separate Ben Shahn's Art From His Politics
description: How popular will the show of Ben Shahn's paintings at the Jewish Museum be?

title: Paine Journal; Pinochet's Arrest Revives Buried Fears in Chile
description: The deadly political grudges of the past are rarely discussed in this town of grape and citrus growers. But ever since Gen. Augusto Pinochet was arrested last month in London on charges of human rights violations, the writing scrawled on Paine's walls has been anything but discreet.

title: Primark-Dow Jones Pact
description: The Primark Corporation agreed today to buy Dow Jones & Company's Edgar Direct unit, which electronically publishes Securities and Exchange Commission filings, for an undisclosed price. Primark, based in Waltham, Mass., a provider of financial and economic data, is buying Edgar Direct through its Disclosure Inc. unit, according to a Dow Jones statement. Edgar is the S.E.C.'s electronic system for company filings. Dow, the New York-based publisher of The Wall Street Journal, said it was cutting 30 jobs by selling Edgar Direct and restructuring its Federal Filings unit, which reports on filings to the S.E.C. and other Government agencies.

title: New Video Releases
description: The Land Girls

title: The Dow Ekes Out a Small Gain While Other Gauges Fall
description: Stocks were mixed yesterday after failing to sustain a morning advance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUDDY, LORETTA
description: CUDDY-Loretta (nee Cooper) of Garden City, NY. Gently passed away on November 11, 1998. Known also as Laura, she was the cherished wife of the late John F. Cuddy, devoted mother of John, Brian and Patricia, and loving grandmother of Victoria, Daniel, Catherine, Adrienne and Lauren. Reposing at the Fairchild Funeral Home on Franklin Avenue at 12 St, Garden City NY on Sunday, November 15, 2-5PM and 7-9 PM. Funeral Services at St. Anne's RC Church, Garden City NY on Monday, November 16 at 9:45AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Anne's RC Church of Garden City or American Lung Association.

title: U.S. and Italy Agree to Deregulate Air Fares and Frequency
description: After three days of intense negotiations, the United States and Italy initialed an agreement late on Wednesday to drop restrictions on air traffic between the two countries. There will be no Government control over fares or frequency of service.

title: Still No Decision on Winner of the Attorney General's Race
description: With teams of lawyers for Republicans and Democrats haggling over each tally and every stray pencil mark, elections officials yesterday continued the tense and tedious process of rechecking machines and counting paper ballots to determine the winner of the whisker-close race for State Attorney General.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Paul Pfeiffer and Nader

title: State's Death Rate From Bypass Surgery Hits 8-Year Low
description: New York State hospitals have achieved the lowest death rate for coronary artery bypass surgery in the eight years that state officials have been monitoring the procedure, a high-risk form of open-heart surgery in which a machine temporarily takes over the functions of the patient's heart.

title: This Comic Makes Fun of the Passengers
description: When Rene Foss's mother was a stewardess in the 1950's, she wore white gloves and served lobster thermidor to passengers. Today, Ms. Foss, a flight attendant herself, says, ''Some of us are wearing rubber gloves, and we have to learn how to put handcuffs on people.''

title: Off the Court, a Bigger Game for Ewing
description: Time is running out. And Patrick Ewing is backing into the paint with his hands stretched out like a man about to throttle someone. There is no mistaking this familiar stance: Ewing wants the ball, and he wants it now.

title: IMS HEALTH PLANS TO SPIN OFF ITS STAKE IN GARTNER GROUP
description: The health care information company IMS Health Inc. said yesterday that it would spin off its 47 percent interest in the consulting company Gartner Group Inc. to IMS shareholders. Gartner Group specializes in information-technology consulting. Separately, Gartner Group said it would pay a special one-time cash dividend of $300 million, or $2.75 a share, to its shareholders, immediately before the spinoff. After the spinoff, Gartner Group, based in Stamford, Conn., plans to buy back up to $300 million of its stock. Shares of Gartner's class A stock fell $2.9375, to $18.8125. Shares of IMS rose 25 cents, to $65.50.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Nov. 2 about Marcus Camby, a basketball player preparing for his first season with the Knicks, referred incorrectly to favors he received from a sports agent, John Lounsbury, while at the University of Massachussetts. The favors included gifts and cash, misdeeds that Mr. Camby acknowledged in newspaper interviews in 1996 and that Mr. Lounsbury acknowledged as well. But Mr. Lounsbury did not provide Mr. Camby with prostitutes.

title: Israel Calmly Readies Itself, Just in Case
description: They weren't battering down the doors today at the gas-mask distribution center in this quiet suburb of Tel Aviv, but a steady stream of people came by just the same, to be on the safe side.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERKOWSKY, PAUL B.
description: BERKOWSKY-Paul B., 1932-1998. V.P. of the Off-B'way League B'way and Off-B'way producer, Founder of School Theatre Ticket Program. Memorial Tribute 11/16 at 5 at the Lucille Lortel Theatre, 121 Christopher Street.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: James de la Vega

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''What Saddam is hearing now are the sounds of

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Observer; The Elagabalus Parallel
description: On hearing that Newt had fallen, I immediately ran to my Roman history books.

title: Will Vouchers Kill Public Schools -- and Ideals?; Cheaper and Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Speeding and Civil Liberties
description: The Supreme Court will review an Iowa law this term that gives the police what amounts to blanket authority to search an automobile after issuing the driver a citation for speeding or any other routine traffic violation. The case is important to anyone who cares about civil liberties, and for that matter to anyone who drives a car.

title: Red Sox Are Pursuing Belle
description: With Mo Vaughn prepared to leave Boston, Dan Duquette, the general manager of the Red Sox, embarked today on Plan B, as in Belle, Albert.

title: Israel Seeks Bids for Housing Opposed by Jerusalem Arabs
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu opened bidding today for a big state-run housing development in the predominantly Arab east side of Jerusalem that has been a flash point in relations between Israel and the Palestinians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ERIC G.
description: LEVINE-Eric G. Cherished son of Celia and the late Bernard S. Beloved brother of Mark and dear friend of Harold Goldstein, dear cousin of Heymans, Alperins, Rosens, Feldsteins, Groissers, friend of countless Sunnysiders for whom he built a commmunity with his spade, pruning shears, personal warmth, creativity, wit and wisdom. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Eric Levine Memorial Fund, C/O Alumni and Friends of LaGuardia High School, P.O. 1485, New York, New York 10023.

title: American Topics : Amish Toil Against Child Labor Laws
description: Daniel Mark Smucker spends each weekday working inches away from heavy presses that punch through several layers of tough leather. He is 15. In a corner of southeastern Pennsylvania where horse-drawn carriages charm the eye, the Amish teenager, who wears black britches and a pageboy haircut, toils quite happily at his father's harness factory.

title: Homelessness Tests San Francisco's Ideals
description: Three weeks ago, when someone started stalking homeless people here, bending over them as they slept in alleys and doorways and slashing their throats, a grim joke began making the rounds on the streets: the killer had been hired by the city.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: AS TENSION GROWS, FEW VOICES AT U.N. SPEAK UP FOR IRAQ
description: As the United States continued to build up its forces for a possible attack on Iraq, an eerie silence on the diplomatic front has made this crisis different from previous confrontations with Saddam Hussein.

title: Columbia Hospital Sales
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation said today that it had sold two Chicago hospitals to a closely held Arizona company for $63.4 million in cash as part of the hospital chain's restructuring plan. Columbia, the biggest United States hospital operator, said it had sold Michael Reese Hospital and Grant Hospital to the Doctors Community Healthcare Corporation of Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Diamondbacks Deny Making an Offer to Williams
description: The Mets' altered contingent left for home today with one expected trade made (Bobby Bonilla) and one expected trade not made (Todd Hundley). Their Yankee counterparts left having conducted no business, but confident that the upstart Arizona Diamondbacks had not blown them out of the uncharted Bernie Williams waters.

title: An Open Call for the Open Skies; Airlines Seek Diversity in Hiring Flight Attendants
description: For all the talk of New York's new civility, its inhabitants have not exactly made ''Service With a Smile'' their motto. So the city seems an unlikely place to find candidates for a job that turns on cheerful customer assistance.

title: Indonesia's Students: An Unrelenting Force for Change
description: In a last line of defense, riot police officers fired tear gas, water cannon and rubber bullets Thursday night to keep student demonstrators from invading the grounds of Parliament as they did six months ago when they helped force the ouster of President Suharto.

title: Courtside Memorial For Producer's Family
description: When Jack O'Hara, the former executive producer of ABC Sports, and his wife, Janet, perished with their daughter, Caitlin, in the crash of TWA Flight 800 in July 1996, friends and family tried to grapple with the tragedy.

title: Randy Newman's Songs Mix Humor and Barbs
description: Randy Newman made short work of his ostensible reason for performing at Town Hall on Tuesday night. He was opening a five-night festival of film music presented by the Knitting Factory, and since the 1980's, Mr. Newman has spent most of his career writing soundtracks for movies, including ''Ragtime,'' ''Parenthood,'' ''Toy Story,'' ''The Natural'' and, lately, ''Pleasantville'' and ''A Bug's Life.'' Writing film music, he said, is ''a well-paying job, but it hints of serfdom.'' But performing alone at the piano, he stuck to songs -- a few new ones and many from the 1970's -- rather than soundtracks. Nobody minded.

title: U.S. Welcomes Arab Statement on Iraq
description: The Clinton Administration welcomed a statement today from a group of eight Arab nations saying that Iraq bore responsibility for the consequences of its policies opposing arms inspections, and said it was a sign of the growing isolation of Saddam Hussein's Government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENSER, RUTH
description: GENSER-Ruth. Cherished and adoring wife for fifty years of the late Sidney (died October 8, 1998). Beloved and devoted mother of Barbara Zinn Moore (Jay). Services Sunday 12:30PM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Breast Cancer Research Foundation, 767 Fifth Ave, Ste 4600, NY, NY 10153

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Carroll Dunham

title: Yardsticks for Action Against Iraq
description: With an American strike against Iraq seemingly imminent, the Clinton Administration must clearly define its goals and the best military tactics for achieving them. Although diplomacy now seems exhausted, there is a faint hope that Saddam Hussein will blink at the last minute and start honoring his international obligations. But if Baghdad remains defiant, President Clinton would be fully justified in ordering an attack. The world cannot leave Mr. Hussein free to manufacture horrific germs and nerve gases and use them to terrorize neighboring countries.

title: On My Mind; The Road to Baltimore
description: ''If the inspectors are not permitted to visit suspect sites or monitor compliance at known production facilities, they may as well be in Baltimore, not Baghdad.''

title: Bobo Lewis, 72, Longtime Actress In Circle Repertory
description: Bobo Lewis, a screen and stage actress who performed with the Circle Repertory Company for 25 years, died on Friday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. She was 72 and lived in Manhattan.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Duke Gets Gift For Art Museum

title: Martin Short Times Eight In 'Little Me'
description: The fellow simply refuses to die. He's been down for the count any number of times already. The doctor at his side, monitoring his pulse, can tell you that, as can all those loyal subjects keening at the foot of his bed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, SOL R.
description: LEVINSON-Sol R. Charles Uribe and Jerome Gannon, the staff and members of AJ Contracting Inc, mourns the passing of its beloved ex-Chairman, Sol R. Levinson. He was a good friend and an inspiration to us all. He was indispensable to the growth of this firm, and his enduring wisdom and knowledge will be missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Belle Levinson and the entire family.

title: Will Vouchers Kill Public Schools -- and Ideals?; Rescue Operation
description: To the Editor:

title: Halfway-House Request By Killer of 2 Is Rejected
description: State correction officials sent a man convicted of killing two New Jersey police officers in 1963 back to a state prison yesterday.

title: Will Vouchers Kill Public Schools -- and Ideals?; Bottom-Up Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters fly fast and furious as the 2 associations representing agencies and advertisers square off.
description: A CONTENTIOUS dispute between the two associations representing advertisers and agencies, which began when the advertiser association unexpectedly extended membership to agencies, is growing more pronounced as some longtime agency executives express their qualms about the invitation.

title: Bowing to Competition, Deutsche Telekom Will Cut Prices
description: In the clearest sign yet of the competition now roaring through Europe's telephone industry, Deutsche Telekom A.G. of Germany said today that it would slash its long-distance prices by as much as 63 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROBSTEIN, JULIETT
description: GROBSTEIN-Juliett, age 93, on November 11th, 1998 after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Adored mother of Barbara and Eric Chazen and Susan and Victor Shedlin. Cherished grandmother of Lisa and David Levine, Gary and Debbi Shedlin, Karen and Tyler Zachem, Lauren Shedlin, Jamie Zimmerman and the late Dr. Geoffrey Chazen. Dearest GiGi of Molly, Noah, Lindsay, Zoe, Charlotte, Alexander and Alexis. Her love, strength and wit will live with us forever. Service today, at 12:30 P.M., at the Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBER, FRIEDA
description: WEBER-Frieda. Beloved wife of the late Harry Weber, died in Brooklyn at age 83 on November 10th, 1998, three months after suffering a major stroke. Loving mother of Cynthia, Nathan, Robert and Sheila; loving mother-in-law of Wendy, Lynn and Jeff; adored grandmother of Lisa, Dana, Rebecca, Vanessa and Seth; loving sister of Rose, Rae, and Gurty. We mourn her passing. Rest now, Mom, with Dad, in peace.

title: Smoke Risk Prompts F.A.A. to Order Inspections of MD-11's
description: The Federal Aviation Administration today abruptly ordered airlines that fly MD-11's to inspect two cockpit switches because one model in wide use can give off smoke at certain settings.

title: All I Want for Christmas Is a Porsche and a Purpose
description: Here's the good part about ''I'll Be Home for Christmas'': It's short.

title: Inquiry on Child Pornography Prompts a Resignation at Yale
description: The master at one of Yale University's undergraduate residential colleges has resigned after Federal officials seized two of his office computers and told him he was the subject of a child-pornography investigation.

title: Anwar's Trial Brings Tactics of Malaysia's 'Special' Police to Light
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Towering above the courthouse where a judge presides over the trial of Anwar Ibrahim, the former Malaysian deputy prime minister, is a tall white building that holds an eerie mystique for Malaysians. It is called Bukit Aman, the Hill of Peace.

title: Japan Drafts Economic Plan and It Is Met With Skepticism
description: The governing Liberal Democratic Party released a draft plan today to bolster the economy, but the financial markets greeted it skeptically and analysts described it as a hodgepodge of measures that would have little effect.

title: Cal Fed Is Set Back in Suit Against U.S. on Accounting Rule
description: California Federal Bank cannot recover potential profits it lost as a result of a 1989 accounting rule change that prompted its $1.6 billion ''supervisory good will'' lawsuit against the United States, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: U.S. SIGNS A PACT TO REDUCE GASES TIED TO WARMING
description: The Administration today signed the international agreement to fight global warming, affirming a crucial American role in a long environmental crusade but not raising any hope of Senate approval in the near future.

title: A First Step Against Sweatshops
description: A Presidential task force of apparel makers, human rights groups and consumer advocates recently agreed on how to put in place a voluntary code of conduct for domestic and overseas factories. Although not perfect, the accord should improve sweatshop conditions and give American consumers information so that they can choose not to buy goods produced in inhumane conditions.

title: Cable and Wireless Seeking Lines in U.S., Executives Say
description: Trying to increase control over its United States operations, Cable and Wireless P.L.C. of Britain is seeking to acquire more than $300 million worth of fiber optic communications lines from Qwest Communications International Inc., according to executives close to the talks.

title: Censure Is Spineless
description: To the Editor:

title: Meditative Music, Washed With Buddhism
description: Don't hate Duncan Sheik because he's beautiful. He is trying very hard to distance himself from that fact.

title: Isles' Forgotten Sniper Suddenly Finds His Range
description: In his first two seasons with the Islanders, Mariusz Czerkawski has grossly underachieved. He possesses the skills of an elite goal-scorer, but hasn't shown off those skills often enough.

title: No Negotiations In the Works
description: A month after the National Basketball Association canceled regular-season games for the first time, the parties in the labor dispute have shown no inclination to get back to the bargaining table.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Frankie Brimsek, 85, a Hall of Fame Goalie
description: Frankie (Mr. Zero) Brimsek, the Boston Bruins' Hall of Fame goaltender who was renowned for a remarkable string of shutouts during his first weeks in the National Hockey League, died Wednesday at his home in Virginia, Minn. He was 85 and one of the first American-born players to star in the N.H.L.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, ELSIE JACOBY
description: SUSSMAN-Elsie Jacoby, age 94. Widow of Sidney. Beloved mother of Sandy & Lois (Kampf). Grandmother of Larry and Michael Kampf, Stephan and Jordan Sussman, Jenny, Allie, Meri and Michael Axinn. Devoted great grandmother of Adam and Zachary Kampf. Services 10AM, Sunday, Nov. 15th, at Schwartz Brothers, Queens Boulevard. With burial at Maimonides, Elmont, New York. Donations to American Cancer Society in lieu of flowers.

title: Election by Number, Not Preference
description: To the Editor:

title: Should One Man Decide on Military Action?
description: To the Editor:

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Matthew Ritchie

title: ELTRAX AGREES TO BUY SULCUS FOR $66 MILLION IN STOCK
description: The communications-products provider Eltrax Systems Inc. has agreed to buy the Sulcus Hospitality Technologies Corporation, a maker of automated computer systems for the lodging industry, for $66 million in stock. The shares of Sulcus soared 60 percent, or 93.75 cents, to $2.50. Shares of Eltrax were unchanged at $6.50. Eltrax would exchange 0.55 share for each Sulcus share, issuing about 10.2 million shares. Sulcus has 18.5 million shares outstanding. Sulcus, based in Greensburg, Pa., makes automated computer systems for the hotel, legal and real estate markets. Eltrax, based in Southfield, Mich., designs and installs computer and communications networks.

title: Residential Real Estate; Middle-Income Tenants In Park Slope Addition
description: The first sizable rental building to be constructed in the Park Slope area of Brooklyn in more than a decade opened last week, as people began moving into the 52-unit building.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Learning the Art of Embroidery'

title: Trial Raises Fear on Hong Kong Autonomy
description: In the end, Cheung Tze-keung got exactly the verdict his lawyers feared: a death sentence, handed down today by a Chinese court that found the Hong Kong crime boss guilty of arms smuggling and kidnapping two of Hong Kong's wealthiest tycoons.

title: Paying A High Price For a Free Vacation
description: Some things to expect in a horror movie sequel: a higher body count, cruder shock effects, louder screams, vanishing credibility and loss of narrative coherence.

title: Golden Cycle Raises Its Offer for Global
description: Golden Cycle L.L.C. raised its bid today for shares of Global Motorsport Group Inc., the largest independent parts distributor for Harley-Davidson Inc. motorcycles, to $20 a share, topping a rival bid from Stonington Partners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOTOROFF, MURIEL R.
description: SLOTOROFF-Muriel R. November 12, 1998. Beloved wife of Irving (Jerry) Slotoroff. Loving mother of William and Louis Goldstein. Cherished grandmother of Erica, Theodore, Robyn, Brandon and Rachel. Services 1PM, Wednesday, November 18, at Mt Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about David Ruggerio, the chef and restaurateur in midtown Manhattan who is accused of having defrauded a credit card processing company, misidentified the magazine for which Gael Greene reviewed the restaurant, formerly called Le Chantilly and later given the chef's name. It was New York magazine, not The New Yorker.

title: Meditrust Will Split Into Health Care and Hotel REIT's
description: The Meditrust Companies said today that it would split into two real estate investment trusts, one owning health care properties and one owning its La Quinta Inns hotels, ending an ill-timed attempt to diversify.

title: INSIDE
description: Chicago vs. Gun Makers

title: Blue Eyes on the Set, Blue Streak at the Wheel
description: PAUL NEWMAN, purveyor of a dandy spaghetti sauce and a decent glass of lemonade, pours himself a cup of coffee. The threat of rain has delayed filming here on ''Where the Money Is,'' a Marek Kenievska caper co-starring Linda Fiorentino. So the man with two Oscars and a famous pair of blue eyes has a chance to sit in a hotel coffee shop and chat about one of his consuming passions, automobiles.

title: State Farm Given Charter To Deal in Loans and C.D.'s
description: Further eroding legal barriers that have discouraged insurance companies from entering the banking business, Federal savings regulators announced today that they had permitted the State Farm Insurance Companies, the nation's largest automobile and homeowners' insurer, to begin using its vast network of agents to sell such banking products as car loans, mortgages and certificates of deposit.

title: Pro Bowlers To Try Out Bryant Park, Off the Green
description: The Professional Bowlers of America would appreciate just a little respect, please. They have had it with the stereotype of the beer-guzzling, potbellied robo-athlete. And even though the group's headquarters are in Akron, Ohio, home of Goodyear, the famed Goodyear blimp has never deigned to show up at a bowling event.

title: A Goofball Guy's Guy
description: Move over, Jim Carrey.

title: PEPSICO APPROVES PLAN TO SELL STAKE IN BOTTLING UNIT
description: Pepsico Inc., the world's No. 2 soft-drink maker, said yesterday that its board had formally approved a plan to sell a majority stake in its bottling operations through an initial public offering. Shares of the Pepsi Bottling Group unit will be offered in the spring, the company said. A company spokesman declined to say what percentage of the bottling group would be sold. The move is part of an overhaul of Pepsi's bottling and distribution business aimed at helping it compete better with the Coca-Cola Company. The move will also remove a low-margin, cash-intensive business from its books.

title: Anita K. Gulkin, 59, Greenwich House President
description: Anita Kurman Gulkin, president and chief executive of Greenwich House Inc., a social-service and cultural community organization based in Greenwich Village, died on Sunday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 59, lived in Springfield, N.J., and also had an apartment in Chelsea in Manhattan.

title: Will Vouchers Kill Public Schools -- and Ideals?; Violation of Conscience
description: To the Editor:

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Henry Moore

title: Modest and Simple Handel, but With Certain Distinctions
description: Musicians with an interest in Handel seem particularly drawn to Merkin Concert Hall, and the hall's marketing department has noted this trend by offering three events under the series title ''Handelworks.'' The first, a performance of ''Acis and Galatea'' by the Four Nations Ensemble, opened the series on Monday evening. To come are an all-Handel recital on Dec. 2 by the harpsichordist Bradley Brookshire and the soprano Dana Hanchard and on Jan. 20 an installment of the Manhattan School of Music's Handel Opera Project, this time ''Tolomeo.''

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Ernesto Neto

title: Tactics in the Persian Gulf: From Diplomacy to Force
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Classic Russian Tale of Infidelity, Sparely Told
description: Shared Experience has long been in the business of compressing novels for the stage, and as with the product of any boutique operation of distinction, the craftsmanship shows. Paying its first visit to New York, the 23-year-old, London theater company has brought a worthy, finely honed adaptation of Tolstoy's ''Anna Karenina'' that thoroughly engages the imagination, even if it doesn't do quite as much for the heart.

title: Torre Takes A.L.'s Prize As Manager of the Year
description: Some might find it surprising that on a team that won 114 regular-season games and 11 more in the post-season, including 4 straight in the World Series, it's likely that only one member will be awarded a major individual honor: Manager Joe Torre.

title: People
description: Margot Tanner was named to the new position of director for response marketing at DDB Needham Los Angeles, part of Omnicom Group. She had been president at Direct Resources, Santa Monica, Calif., which closed.

title: Stake in Nigerian Bank for Saudi Prince
description: Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia has bought a 13.7 percent stake, worth about $12 million, in the United Bank for Africa P.L.C. of Nigeria.

title: House Schedule, and Divorce, Become Issues in the Race for Majority Leader
description: The matter of House members' schedules and the effect on their personal lives has become an issue in the down-to-the-wire race for House majority leader.

title: Council Speaker Appoints a New Chief of Staff
description: An unofficial, months-old change in the structure of the City Council's executive staff became official yesterday when Speaker Peter F. Vallone announced that Bruce Bender would succeed Mr. Vallone's longtime adviser, Kevin McCabe, as his chief of staff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRASSFELD, FRANK E.
description: STRASSFELD-Frank E. It is with profound sorrow that the Hollis Hills Jewish Center announces the passing of our beloved ''Shames'' Rev. Frank E. Strassfeld, at the age of 75. For 49 extraordinary years, Frank has served our community with devotion, sincerity and passion. He was and always will be in our hearts and in our souls. Funeral services will take place Friday morning, November 13, 1998, at 9:30AM, in our Center Sanctuary, 210-10 Union Turnpike, Hollis Hills, Queens, New York. Rabbi Doctor H. Joseph Simkes Cantor Sol Zim President Michael B. Wolkofsky

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Life Photographers: What They Saw'

title: A German Singer's Triumph Over Misfortune
description: Nothing happens without a reason.

title: Drug Dealer in Dublin Denies Any Role in Murder of Journalist
description: A 34-year-old Dublin drug dealer accused of helping to murder a prominent Irish journalist said at his trial today that he had nothing to do with the killing.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: A Change Of Scenery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, DANIEL
description: YOUNG-Daniel. ''Only a sweet and virtuous soul, Like seasoned timber, never gives; But though the whole world turn to coal, Then chiefly lives.'' (George Herbert) Leslie Friedberg

title: Gephardt Says Republicans Delay Inquiry On Clinton
description: The House Democratic leader, Richard A. Gephardt, harshly criticized the Congressional investigation of President Clinton today, accusing Republicans of wasting weeks when they could have been focusing on disputed material.

title: Should One Man Decide on Military Action?
description: To the Editor:

title: State Orders Takeover Of Camden Police Dept.
description: Attorney General Peter G.
