Verniero yesterday ordered a takeover of the Camden Police Department, finding that the force was understaffed and inefficient and had ignored state recommendations to improve. The move came less than a year after the state appointed a financial review board to oversee the city's budget.

title: Germany Said to Push Finance Minister for Top Post in Brussels : Rumor on Lafontaine Stuns Europe
description: FRANKFURT  - Politicians across Europe were caught off guard Thursday by reports that Bonn's new government might push for a German to become the European Union's chief executive.

title: Secret Service Director Retiring To Work for Pro Football Team
description: Lewis C. Merletti, the Director of the Secret Service who unsuccessfully tried to a establish a new right of confidentiality for Presidential bodyguards, is retiring to become director of security for the Cleveland Browns' expansion football team.

title: Gerald Long, 75, Who Turned Reuters Into a Profitable Service
description: Gerald Long, who as general manager of the Reuters news agency in the 1960's presided over its transformation from a hand-to-mouth wire service to a profitable, computer-age news organization, died in Paris on Sunday, Reuters said. He was 75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAFFNEY, EDWARD F.X.
description: GAFFNEY-Edward F.X. On November 11, 1998. Former Deputy Commissioner of Finance, Queens, New York. Beloved brother of Lawrence (CT), Katherine Feeley (MN), Sr. Rosemary DW, and Rev. Patrick SMM, and the late Eleanor, Margaret, and Sr. James DW. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Reposing at Francisco Funeral Home, 101 Ave, corner of 103 St, Ozone Park, NY. Mass of Christian burial Saturday, 10:15 AM at St. Mary Gate of Heaven RC Church. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery.

title: Yankees to Face The Mets Six Times
description: The World Series champion Yankees will open the 1999 regular season in Oakland on April 5 and close it in Tampa on Oct. 3, according to the schedule announced by the team yesterday.

title: Bank of America Settles Suits From California
description: Bank of America agreed today to pay $187.5 million to settle charges by California state and local governments that it mishandled hundreds of millions of dollars of bond payments between 1978 and 1995.

title: Brazil Is to Get I.M.F. Package For $42 Billion
description: After months of negotiations, the International Monetary Fund and more than a dozen countries are expected to announce a package of loans to Brazil totaling at least $42 billion to stabilize the country's economy, officials familiar with the plan said today.

title: Slaying of a Girl, 8, Tests Ties in Florida
description: For several years, Jim and Peggy Poston have toyed with the idea of moving from the working-class neighborhood where they have lived for the last 41 years to a more affluent one. But they could never quite bring themselves to make the change.

title: Chicago Is Suing Over Guns From Suburbs
description: The City of Chicago and Cook County filed a $433 million lawsuit against the gun industry yesterday, saying that a three-month police undercover operation found that firearms dealers in Chicago's suburbs were flooding the city with illegal guns with the knowledge of nationwide gun manufacturers and distributors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRODENCHIK, NATHAN
description: GRODENCHIK-Nathan. Beloved husband, father, and grandfather. The light from his love will shine forever in our hearts. Services on Friday, November 13, 10:30 AM, Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows.

title: Prosecutor Refuses to Enforce Subpoena in I.N.S. Case
description: Siding with Federal immigration officials in their effort to protect secret evidence in a sensitive deportation case, the United States Attorney's office here has refused an immigration judge's request to force a witness to testify about her contacts with law enforcement agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERLITZ, JONATHAN M.
description: ERLITZ-Jonathan M. On November 11, 1998. Loving brother of Joyce and Benjamin. Beloved partner of Paul W. Haug. Service Sunday, November 15, 2:45 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Will Vouchers Kill Public Schools -- and Ideals?
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC STORAGE IN $408 MILLION DEAL FOR RIVAL
description: Public Storage Inc., a real estate investment trust specializing in self-storage facilities, agreed yesterday to acquire a smaller rival, Storage Trust Realty, for $408 million in stock plus the assumption of $192 million of debt. The deal would create a combined entity with ownership interests in 1,300 storage complexes in 37 states and a market value of $5 billion. Public Storage, based in Glendale, Calif., is to swap 0.86 share for each Storage Trust share. Storage Trust, based in Columbia, Mo., is to become a unit of Public Storage. Public Storage's shares fell 68.75 cents, to $26, and Storage Trust rose 12.5 cents, to $21.875. In August, Storage Trust adopted a poison-pill takeover defense after receiving a $400 million bid from Public Storage.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 10.

title: Gonzalez Focuses on Tszyu (and Chavez)
description: Miguel Angel Gonzalez is in an interesting position. He has unfinished business with Julio Cesar Chavez but first he has to get past Kostya Tszyu in a World Boxing Council superlightweight (140 pounds) championship bout in Indio, Calif., on Nov. 28.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORAN, R. LAWRENCE
description: DORAN-R. Lawrence of Upper Brookville, New York on November 10, 1998. Loving husband of Carolyn (Bambi). Devoted father of Whitney and Christopher Cranis. Beloved brother of Valerie Wiegand. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, November 17, 1998 at 11:00 A.M., St. John's of Lattingtown Church. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Villanova University, 800 Lancaster Avenue, Development Office, Villanova, PA. 19085.

title: Clemente To Sosa, And Beyond
description: AS much as the number he faithfully chose to wear, it was the way Sammy Sosa moved, the way he carried himself, that made Roberto Clemente Jr. think Sosa had something special inside him that was destined to be shared.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINDELL, DR. JACK
description: MINDELL-Dr. Jack. November 11, 1998 at Bradenton, Fl., formerly of Schenectady, New York. Husband of the late Helene. Father of Alan, of Evergreen, Co., and Susan Mindell Blum (Michael) of NYC. Grandfather of two. Graveside services at the Temple Gates of Heaven Cemetery, Schenectady NY on Sunday, 10AM. Mourning period at the Blum residence, 235 East 22 Street, Apt. 10L, NYC, on Monday from 7-9. For information call the Levine Memorial Chapel, Albany, NY, 1-800-427-0280.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIGGS, THOMAS JEFFRIES
description: RIGGS-Thomas Jeffries, Jr. On November 5, 1998 at age 82. The husband of 50 years to Virginia Griggs Riggs. He was a decorated Veteran of W.W. II, serving as Commander of the 81st Combat Engineers Battalion of the 106th Infantry in the Battle of the Bulge. Colonel Riggs was central in the battle of St. Vith. His heroics in this battle earned him a Silver Star, Purple Heart and Croix de Guerre (Belgium, France). His battalion received a Presidential Unit Citation for its extraordinary heroism, gallantry & determination. He was a prisoner of war who escaped to return to his troops. After leaving the military, he was President of F.L. Jacobs in Detroit, Michigan, and Executive Vice President of Gabriel Company in Cleveland. He moved to Providence, RI in 1960 as a group Vice President of Textron, Inc. He lived in Providence, RI until his death. Among his honors, he was the 1989 Varsity I-Man of the Year at his alma mater, University of Illinois and Chairman of the National Small Business Advisory Council. He is survived by his wife Virginia, his six children and two stepchildren. He was buried with full military honors at Arlington National Cemetery on November 10, 1998. A memorial service was held in Providence on November 12, 1998.

title: British Swimmer Is Aiming For Justice
description: When Sharron Davies was at her peak, she won a silver medal for Britain in the 400-meter individual medley at the 1980 Summer Olympics. But Petra Schneider, an East German swimmer, still finished more than 10 seconds ahead of her to take the gold and set a world record.

title: Seton Hall Bars Award Event For Whitman, Over Abortion
description: Officials at Seton Hall University have ordered a student-sponsored event honoring Gov. Christine Todd Whitman at the law school to be moved to an off-campus site because of the Governor's support of abortion rights.

title: Kovalev's Return Is Shaky
description: In the aftermath of the Rangers' forgettable performance against the Florida Panthers Wednesday night in Sunrise, Fla., the awkward return of Aleksei Kovalev from a shoulder separation left open the question of where he fits in the lineup.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN ENDS LOWER. Japan's currency fell after the governing party introduced the latest economic-stimulus plan, which contained few surprises. The dollar rose as high as 124.10 yen before settling at 121.98, up from 121.72.

title: Svetlana Beriosova, Ballerina With Royal Ballet, Dies at 66
description: Svetlana Beriosova, an incandescent leading ballerina with the Royal Ballet of England for two decades, died on Tuesday at the hospice at St. Charles's Hospital in London. She was 66 and lived in London.

title: For Giants' Rookies, A Chance To Score
description: The offensive problems that have plagued the Giants all season are much the same as the ones that prompted them to select Joe Jurevicius and Brian Alford in the National Football League draft last summer.

title: ABRAXAS AGREES TO SELL NATURAL-GAS FIELDS TO G.E. UNIT
description: The Abraxas Petroleum Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its natural-gas fields in southwestern Wyoming to a unit of the General Electric Company for $60.2 million and said it might use the money for acquisitions or debt reduction. Abraxas would retain a 1 percent interest in the 11,300 acres, along with some tax credits. If the G.E. unit, the GE Capital Corporation, earns a certain level of profit from sale of the gas, Abraxas, based in San Antonio, will raise its stake to at least 35 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDERFER, JAYDE
description: RUDERFER-Jayde. The Congregation of The Community Synagogue in Port Washington, NY notes with sorrow the passing of its member and past Sisterhood President and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Funeral service graveside Friday, Nov. 13 at 2 P.M., Nassau Knolls Cemetery, Port Washington.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: American League

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: UTILICORP UNITED INC., Kansas City, Mo., an international gas and electric company, plans to buy back the remaining 18 percent of Aquila Gas Pipeline Corp. it does not already own for $8 a share, or $43.2 million.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: UTILICORP UNITED INC., Kansas City, Mo., an international gas and electric company, plans to buy back the remaining 18 percent of Aquila Gas Pipeline Corp. it does not already own for $8 a share, or $43.2 million.

title: Finding Emotional Depths In Broadway and Ballads
description: Judi Connelli, a big-voiced Australian contralto whose taste in material runs toward the semi-operatic, does everything short of rolling her r's when she emotes. Ms. Connelli, who is appearing at the Firebird Cafe through Nov. 28, delivers lyrics with the elocutionary flourish of a devoted phonics student. Imagine a cabaret hybrid of Jacqueline Bisset and Judy Davis with a dash of Julie Andrews, and you'll have a sense of the sort of theatricality she pumps into a ballad.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: State Farm Insurance Wins Savings Charter Approval

title: Political Briefing; Going Soon? No, Thurmond Says
description: At 95, Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina is not only the oldest person ever to serve in Congress but also holds the record for serving longest in the Senate: 42 years.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Show Time for Cowboys at the Edge of the Earth
description: GOD OF THE RODEO

title: About-Face for British Newspaper That Scourged Gay Laborites
description: On Monday, The Sun, Britain's most popular daily newspaper, printed a front-page editorial warning that Britain was being run by a cabal of gay men and urging gay members of Parliament to come out of the closet as quickly as possible. On Tuesday, it printed a photograph of Agriculture Minister Nick Brown, who had been publicly identified as gay over the weekend, wearing an unflattering blue hair net on a tour of a dairy farm.

title: Ames Reaches a Deal to Buy Hills Stores
description: Ames Department Stores Inc. agreed today to acquire the Hills Stores Company for about for $124 million, plus assumed debt of $206 million, creating the fourth-largest discount retailer in the nation.

title: Supersizing the Supermarkets in a Shift of Power; Discounters and Mergers Alter Balance of Power
description: When the natural order of a food chain is upset, the battle for survival intensifies. Such is the case in the nation's grocery business.

title: In Fast-Food Wars, A Toy Offensive
description: The fast-food wars are heating up for the holidays as two big chains begin a battle of the giveaway toys.

title: Armey Defends Post On the Left and Right
description: Representative Dick Armey seemed to have a premonition of the House leadership meltdown two years ago when, eyeing the majority Republicans slipping a bit from their halcyon days of 1994, he advised, ''Let's just dare to be not sensational.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, SYLVIA
description: GREENE-Sylvia. Beloved mother of Madeline & David and the late Lynne. Devoted wife of the late Casey. Adoring Grandma Sylvia to Jackie and Casey Max. Loving sister, aunt and friend. Services on Sunday, November 15, 9:30 AM at Riverside Funeral Chapel, Mount Vernon, New York. Interment at Mount Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Long Beach Memorial Hospital, Long Beach, New York.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: The Chairman of the Board Is Now Big Man on Campus
description: ''I've got to get myself a Bloody Mary,'' said the comedian and visiting lecturer Alan King, an oil painting of William S. Hofstra looming sternly behind him at a reception this morning. ''How can you have a Frank Sinatra conference without booze?''

title: Clinton Health Care Planner Asks Court to Clear His Name
description: Lawyers for Ira C. Magaziner urged a Federal appeals court today to clear him of a judge's accusation that he lied under oath about the work of President Clinton's task force on health care reform.

title: Police Shoot 2 Men In Buy-and-Bust Sting
description: Two men were shot and wounded by the police in the courtyard of a Bronx housing project last night after an undercover buy-and-bust sting turned violent, the police said.

title: Parcells and Cox Relax With Trainer at Track
description: There are mornings during the season when Jets Coach Bill Parcells enjoys bucolic moments, even smiling as in front of him the turf is torn up by pounding feet.

title: In Central America, Economies in Ruins
description: With more than 10,000 people believed drowned in floods or buried in landslides, Hurricane Mitch ranks as the deadliest natural disaster to strike Central America this century. But the storm also inflicted an economic catastrophe on an area already sadly familiar with calamity and privation, a crisis whose full extent will become evident only when survivors finish giving thanks just for being alive and try to resume their normal lives.

title: A Monarch Who Married Frequently, but Not Well
description: Very few actors could pull off a one-man show about Henry VIII, much less a one-man musical. Richard Burton, probably, with his ''Camelot'' voice, but not many others. Steeve Arlen, however, comes very close in ''Eight! Henry VIII, That Is!,'' and he does it on the tiny, bare stage of the TriBeCa Playhouse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENN, EDWARD P.
description: PENN-Edward P. On November 10, 1998. Survived by his nephew Michael and niece Pamela. Reposing at Walter B. Cooke-Kennedy Funeral Home, 117 West 72nd Street, NYC, Saturday 2PM-9PM. Memorial service on Wednesday, 11 A.M. at funeral home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STATELMAN, RICHARD
description: STATELMAN - Richard. The clients, staff and board of Bronx AIDS Services extend their condolences to the family of Richard Statelman. Bronx AIDS Services exists in a large part because of his vision.

title: Political Briefing; Moseley-Braun Ready For Life After Politics
description: Carol Moseley-Braun, who in 1992 became the first black woman to win a seat in the United States Senate, says she is through with politics.

title: Metro Business; G.E. Focuses on 2000 Bug
description: The General Electric Company plans to spend about $550 million to fix its computer systems so that they can identify dates after Dec. 31, 1999.

title: Graffiti Artist Makes Good: A Basquiat Sells for a Record $3.3 Million
description: A self-portrait by Jean Michel Basquiat that depicts the artist at 21 holding a spear in his left hand, his masked face drawn flat, brought a staggering $3.3 million at Christie's sale of contemporary art last night, a record for the 1980's graffiti artist.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a possible settlement between states' attorneys general and the tobacco companies omitted necessary attribution. The development was first reported by Bloomberg News, which cited unidentified sources. The Times's reporting then confirmed the main facts of the settlement plan. The second part of The Times's article was also based primarily on reports from Bloomberg News.

title: RUTHERFORD-MORAN SAYS ITS CREDIT IS NEARLY EXHAUSTED
description: The Rutherford-Moran Oil Corporation said yesterday that it expected to exhaust its cash and bank credit by January and that it was in talks with a potential buyer that it warned might offer less than its current share price. Rutherford-Moran, based in Houston, said that without an acceptable merger agreement, it might not be able to obtain financing for its oil and natural-gas exploration project in the Gulf of Thailand. The company's lenders, led by Chase Manhattan Bank, will not increase its credit line, Rutherford-Moran said. Its debt totals about $292 million. Shares in Rutherford-Moran fell $1.3125, to $2.8125, reducing its market capitalization to $72 million.

title: Editorial Ovserver; They Bought Salomon, Then They Killed It
description: On Wall Street, the Salomon Brothers culture long provoked admiration and dread. It was a gambling firm, quite willing to commit large amounts of capital on risky trades.

title: A Failure to Verify A Cancer Advance Is Raising Concern
description: Officials at the National Cancer Institute have begun to express frustration over their inability to reproduce the striking discoveries described a year ago by Dr. Judah Folkman, the Harvard researcher who reported that he and his colleagues had wiped out malignant tumors in mice by treating the animals with compounds that destroyed the tumors' blood supply.

title: Now Ruined Economies Afflict Central America
description: The highway network that is the backbone of the entire Central American economy has been severed in more than a hundred places. Bumper crops of bananas, coffee, rice, sugar and tobacco have been destroyed, power and telephone lines are down everywhere, and water, sewer and irrigation systems have been ruptured.

title: Political Briefing; Spotlight Not Dimming For This Mississippian
description: Mike Moore, Mississippi's Attorney General since 1988, has never been short on political ambition, a yen to be in the limelight or an aggressive willingness to use his office to promote and defend the interests of his state.

title: Daily News Names Editor For Editions On Sunday
description: Edward Kosner, a former editor of Newsweek, New York magazine and Esquire, was named Sunday editor of The Daily News yesterday.

title: Courage in the Face of an Uncertain Future
description: SANG LAN was in kindergarten in China when a recruiter from a state gymnastics school arrived to measure her arms and legs, just as he did with the other children. In her case, the numbers added up to the body of a potential gymnast -- and plucked her from one life into another.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEPHENSON, EDWIN A.
description: STEPHENSON-Edwin A. Holland Lodge #

title: N.F.L. Matchups -- Week 11
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: MATCHUPS
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: Florida Charges Scientology In Church Member's Death
description: Florida prosecutors filed criminal charges today against the Church of Scientology in connection with the death of a church member while she was under the care of Scientologists three years ago.

title: Global Warming: Costly Solutions?
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Counts the Ways to Spend
description: The deal has not been announced yet, but already there is no shortage of competing proposals for spending New York's $20 billion share of a reported $206 billion tobacco settlement: things like health care for the uninsured, stop-smoking programs and a cut in property taxes.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Singapore Adds Funds To Development Effort
description: Singapore said yesterday that it would put an additional $10 billion (Singapore), or $6 billion (United States), in the hands of private fund managers, stepping up its efforts to beat out Hong Kong to become the biggest Asian financial center outside Japan.

title: Starr Indicts Hubbell a 3d Time
description: With his sex and lies case against President Clinton losing momentum on Capitol Hill, Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, today returned to the Whitewater investigation, his original mandate, and announced the indictment of Mr. Clinton's longtime friend Webster L. Hubbell in connection with the real estate scandal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIESNER, ERIC PAUL
description: WIESNER-Eric Paul. 74. Of 139 Treetops Drive, Lancaster, PA., formerly of New York City, NY died on November 11th at the Lancaster General Hospital after a brief illness. He was the husband of Elisabeth ''Lisa'' Stammler Wiesner and they celebrated their 47th wedding anniversary on October 13th. Born in New York City, NY, the son of the late Paul Wilhelm and Elizabeth Wilhelmina Jacobi. He has lived in Lancaster County for the past seven years. Mr. Wiesner was a 1942 graduate of the Brooklyn Technical High School and was a machinist/technician for the New York Times for 28- 1/2 years, retiring in 1991. Prior he was employed by Mergenthaler Linotype. His career spanned 47 years. He was of the Lutheran faith and enjoyed fishing and was an expert machinist. He enjoyed many years of working in his shop producing fishing equipment and many types of machine parts for friends and family. He served in the U.S. Army in a field artillery unit. Surviving in addition to his wife is a son Eric C. husband of Andrea Wiesner of Victor, NY, a daughter Elisabeth ''Bette'' M. wife of Richard Armellino of Lancaster, PA and a sister Gertrude Herzog, Huntington, NY. Six grandchildren. Memorial service was held at the funeral home of Fred F. Groff, Inc., 234 W. Orange Street, Lancaster, PA on Saturday, November 14th. If desired, memorials may be sent to Christ Home, P.O. Box 308, Paradise, PA. 17562-1678.

title: Jones Delivers More Than Just Knockouts
description: There is a benevolent side to Roy Jones Jr. He is giving a portion of his purse from his bout against Otis Grant to a fund to benefit the family of the former boxer Gerald McClellan, who is blind and disabled.

title: Sports of The Times; An Ex-Player Has Learned A New Tune
description: AT 1 P.M. Thursday, cool melodies and shimmering chords floated over midtown Manhattan. These were the sweetest sounds to date from a deepening labor dispute between National Basketball Association players and team owners. The unlikely source of this music was the new NBA Store, on Fifth Avenue and 52d Street.

title: A Man Who Plays the Dobro, Making It Sing All Over the Map
description: Jerry Douglas, guitarist

title: Architects To Compete With Ideas For Cities
description: New York City has been chosen as the first site of a new international competition to help cities develop innovative visions in architecture and planning. Architects are to be invited to come up with plans for pivotal sites in major cities around the world. The program, called the International Foundation for the Canadian Center for Architecture Prize Competition, offers a $100,000 prize and will take place every three years in a different city.

title: Williams Buys the Rest of Volunteer Energy
description: The Williams Companies, the largest United States transporter of natural gas, said today that it had bought the remaining 50 percent of the closely held Volunteer Energy Corporation that it did not already own to expand its retail energy operations.

title: Brazil Gets a Loan
description: The $41.5 billion international package to support Brazil announced yesterday has several things going for it. It is larger than had been expected, which makes it less likely that speculators will bet against Brazil and therefore makes it less likely that the money in the package will actually have to be used. It includes commitments not only from the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, but also from the United States and other major countries. Finally, it is based on promises by the Brazilian Government that long-needed fiscal reforms will be put in place.

title: Cheers for a Referee on the Rebound
description: National Hockey League referees are never showered with affection before games, but Paul Stewart was greeted with cheers tonight at Continental Arena.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHERER, ESTHER
description: SCHERER-Esther. On November 12, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Philip. Loving mother of Judith S. Herz and Matthew. Adoring grandmother of Rachel, Nathaniel and Philip. Dedicated and longtime member of Hadassah. Services Sunday 11 a.m. at ''The Riverside'' 76th and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory to Hadassah.

title: A Suffolk Congressman Comes In From the Cold
description: These days, Representative Michael P. Forbes, a Republican from Suffolk County, has the pinch-me look of someone who was called a fool for betting his house on the ponies, and then, to the utter disbelief of his tormentors, won the trifecta.

title: KPMG Ends Suit Against a Rival
description: KPMG Peat Marwick, the accounting and consulting firm, has dropped a lawsuit accusing a rival, Stern Stewart & Company, of unfairly trying to stifle competition.

title: S.E.C. Warns Banks Against Overgenerous Reserve Levels
description: When Federal regulators become concerned about how banks account for loans, most often they worry that the institutions have not set enough money aside to cover expected losses.

title: The Word Liberals Don't Own Anymore
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas sent thousands of computer chips into action when he said on election night that he was giving the Republican Party a compassionate conservative face. Pundits pounding their laptops proclaimed, with the political scientist Larry Sabato, that a Republican move to the center was as obvious as a wart on the nose of Miss America. Others argued that the battle of 2000 will be Bush vs. ideological true believers.

title: HIGHEST-RANKING BLACK EXECUTIVE IS SET TO LEAVE
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that A. Barry Rand, its executive vice president for worldwide operations and its highest-ranking black executive, was leaving the company to ''pursue external C.E.O. opportunities'' full time. Xerox has expected Mr. Rand, 54, to leave since June 1997, when the company hired G. Richard Thoman, 54, from I.B.M. to be second in command -- and heir apparent -- to the Xerox chief executive, Paul A. Allaire. ''Barry's dream was to be chief executive of Xerox some day, and when Rick was hired, he knew that would never happen,'' said Judd Eberhart, a Xerox spokesman. Mr. Eberhart said Mr. Rand stayed on at Mr. Allaire's request, to help smooth the ''management transition.''

title: Versatile Player Leads an Unbeaten Team
description: He carries the ball. He tackles. He punts. MIKE TANNER of Springfield College in Massachusetts is a throwback. A very tired throwback.

title: Stocks Mixed On Uncertainty About the Fed
description: The stock market finished mixed yesterday as investors awaited the meeting of the Federal Reserve policy makers Tuesday to see whether the central bank would cut its target for short-term interest rates for the third time since September.

title: Bin Laden Was Target of Afghan Raid, U.S. Confirms
description: One of the clear but unstated objectives of last August's raid on Afghanistan was to kill Osama bin Laden and as many of his lieutenants as possible, Administration officials now acknowledge.

title: We'll Run the House, G.O.P. Women Say Nicely
description: The post-election consensus that Republicans need a nicer smile and a softer touch has left Representative Peter Hoekstra of Michigan feeling a little bit discriminated against in the race against three women for a lower-level House leadership position.

title: Queens Woman Is Shot After Startling Gunmen
description: A 60-year-old Queens woman was shot in the shoulder yesterday afternoon after she startled two men who were attempting to rob her 73-year-old neighbor, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAZELTON, THOMAS P.
description: BRAZELTON-Thomas P. Born July 18, 1958, Tuscon, Az, raised Glenview, Il; died November 11, 1998, New York City. A painter, Tom's work was shown in numerous exhibitions and, most notably, at the Fawbush and Julian Pretto galleries in New York; it is also included in the Julian Pretto Collection of the Wadsworth Atheneum, Hartford, CT. Once a gallery owner, Tom was cofounder, with Oliver Wasow and Karen Sylvester, of CASH/Newhouse Gallery in New York City. He is survived by his friends Joan Nelson and Donald Powley of Stamford, NY; Brian Bendlin and Robert McBrien of New York City and Copake Falls, NY; John Wilcox of Dallas, TX; and Gregory Montreuil and Yves Musard, Editha Mesina and David Sundberg, Catherine Lazure and Bill Gauthier, and Jackie Fazio, all of New York City. Donations in Tom's memory may be made to the American Foundation for AIDS Research. For information regarding a memorial service to be held at a later date, please contact Brian Bendlin, PO Box 232, Copake Falls, NY 12517.

title: Rutgers to Offer Benefits To Same-Sex Partners
description: Rutgers University said yesterday that it will extend health benefits to gay and lesbian partners of its employees in an effort to settle a discrimination suit brought by five faculty members.

title: Hurricane Relief Is Just a Band-Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: When a Conviction Brings No Closure
description: She has listened to more than 70 witnesses describe the most minute details of her son's murder. She has stared at the man accused of the crime throughout his three-week trial. And she has heard some of the city's best prosecutors and defense lawyers lay out their explanations of why it happened. But Carol Levin is still haunted by the question of why her son had to die.

title: N.A.S.D. Will Seek Global Market Ties
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers plans to pursue affiliations with eight international stock markets -- including those in Tokyo, Paris and Mexico City -- in an effort to forge links that would let companies trade their shares around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DIMSTON, BLANCHE
description: DIMSTON-Blanche. It's the white truffle season again and another birthday without you. We're doing the best that we can. Your Loving Family

title: Why New York's Water Supply Still Isn't Safe
description: In January 1997, government officials and five environmental groups signed an agreement intended to permanently protect New York City's water supply and save taxpayers from having to construct an expensive filter plant.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a biotech company's claim to have converted human cells to their primordial state by fusing them with cow eggs misspelled the name of a philosophy professor who said the technique would raise red flags in people's minds. She is Bonnie Steinbock, not Barnie Steinboch.

title: GLAMIS GOLD MAKES BID FOR RAYROCK RESOURCES
description: Glamis Gold Ltd., a United States gold producer, said yesterday that it had made an unsolicited offer to buy Canada's cash-rich Rayrock Resources Inc. for more than $150 million (Canadian), or $97 million (United States), in stock or a cash-and-stock combination. Rayrock, a gold and copper miner, said the companies had discussed the transaction, but said its board and advisers had found the Glamis offer unacceptable because of a substantial breakup fee and restrictions on other potential offers. The offer ranges from $8.80 to $9 a share (Canadian). Rayrock's healthy cash reserves, which totaled $85.2 million (Canadian) as of June 30, have made it an attractive target to Glamis, which is taking its bid directly to Rayrock's shareholders.

title: Living, and Working. With Dioxin in Newark
description: To the Editor:

title: Kyra Nijinsky, 84, Daughter Of a Dancer and One Herself
description: Kyra Nijinsky, a dancer who was the daughter of Vaslav Nijinsky, one of this century's greatest ballet dancers and choreographers, died on Sept. 1 at the Pine Ridge Care Center in San Rafael, Calif. She led a reclusive life in San Francisco and details of her death became nationally known only recently. She was 84.

title: Pilots Say Fedex Rebuffed Latest Bid to Avert Strike
description: Leaders of the pilots' union at the Federal Express Corporation said yesterday that the company had rebuffed its latest effort to restart contract negotiations, greatly increasing the chances that the pilots will strike during the peak holiday-package shipping season next month.

title: $728 MILLION IN STOCK IS BOUGHT BACK BY COMPANY
description: The Gillette Company, the world's top maker of razors and blades, bought $728 million in stock in the third quarter, as its shares dropped 44 percent on the company's first quarterly earnings decline in eight years. Gillette bought 15 million shares at an average price of $48.53, bringing 1998 purchases to 17 million shares, the company said in a regulatory filing. In late 1997, Gillette authorized the purchase of as many as 50 million shares. Gillette shares declined from $62.65625 on April 2 to as low as $35.3125 on Sept. 21. The share repurchases indicate the company is confident the earnings decline will be temporary, said Amy De Rham, an analyst at Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities.

title: Journal; Natural Born Shillers
description: Now that the national orgy of infotainment known as All Monica is nearing its end, one network was at last willing to come forward and say it has standards and will sin no more. Or so it seemed, for one brief but shining moment last week.

title: Paroled Rapist Says He's the Victim Now; Target of Gunman Contends 'Megan's Law' Has Stolen His Freedom
description: When Frank Penna was torn awake from a deep sleep on June 16 by gunfire thundering through his house, he knew immediately, he said, that the shots were meant for him.

title: CIGARETTE MAKERS AND STATES DRAFT A $206 BILLION DEAL
description: The nation's four biggest cigarette makers and officials of eight states have reached agreement on the outlines of a settlement designed to resolve all remaining state claims over health costs related to smoking, attorneys general and industry lawyers involved in the talks said yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: Red Holzman Is Dead at 78

title: 9 Percent of the City's Public Schools Are Failing, State Says
description: Citing declining test scores, state education officials added 21 New York City schools to the state's list of failing schools yesterday, bringing the total number in the city to 97.

title: A New Law Requiring Locks On Handguns Takes Effect
description: A new law intended to reduce injuries and deaths from accidental shootings takes effect today, requiring that all handguns sold in New York City have a safety locking device.

title: MacLean Scores Twice, but Rangers Blow Lead
description: Although he has been a Ranger for only a few months, John MacLean enjoyed a dignitary's treatment last night before his team played the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden. His new teammates presented him with a silver stick, in honor of MacLean's having played 1,000 games, most of them with the Devils, over 15 National Hockey League seasons.

title: Hurricane Relief Is Just a Band-Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Retail Sales Set Brisk Pace And Producer Prices Edge Up
description: Retail sales rose in October at the fastest pace in five months and producer prices crept higher, leading some economists to predict that the Federal Reserve's policy makers may refrain from cutting interest rates next week.

title: Salomon to Delay Bonuses For Review by New Managers
description: In a sign that the turmoil at Citigroup Inc. may be far from over, the financial giant's investment banking unit, Salomon Smith Barney, told employees yesterday that they will have to wait a month longer than usual to collect their annual bonus.

title: STONE CONTAINER HOLDERS DROP BID TO BAR TAKEOVER
description: Preferred stockholders of the Stone Container Corporation yesterday withdrew their request for a court order to block the proposed $6.51 billion acquisition by its rival paper company, the Jefferson Smurfit Corporation. The two holders of Stone series E preferred stock filed a suit on Oct. 20 in Delaware Chancery Court in Wilmington, Del., asking a judge to stop the merger, announced by the companies in May and scheduled for a vote by common stockholders on Tuesday. John Simley, a Stone spokesman, said, ''The stockholder vote on the merger will proceed as scheduled'' and ''the company expects the merger to close the following day.''

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. Economic reports showing higher retail sales and producer prices diminished prospects that the Federal Reserve would lower interest rates, sending the dollar up. It rose to 122.72 yen in New York from 121.98.

title: OTB Simulcast Signal Will Resume Today
description: The long dispute over fees that blacked out the simulcast television signal of races to off-track betting customers i the city ended last night when the New York City Off-Track Betting Corporation agreed on a four-year contract.

title: As Center-Field Pool Shrinks, Yanks Think It Over
description: Within two days last week, the Los Angeles Dodgers, Boston Red Sox and Colorado Rockies all signed center fielders, and the Yankees were well aware of the implication of the spree: There are very few quality center fielders available.

title: Redrawing The Free Market; Amid a Global Financial Crisis, Calls for Regulation Spread
description: In Western capitals there is a rush to rethink the world. At issue is the end of the so-called Washington consensus, which has held more or less unchallenged since the end of the cold war: that more open markets, freer trade and larger international capital flows are necessarily good.

title: On the Stampede of Ism's And Their Lasting Appeal
description: The spate of revivals of plays from the middle of the century over the last couple of seasons has confirmed the enduring merit of the innovative and imaginative work of playwrights like Camus, Sartre, Beckett and Ionesco. But it has also shown that civilization, as we optimistically call it, is just as absurd as the 20th century draws to a close as it was four or five decades ago.

title: Rehearsing Met's 'Figaro'
description: To the Editor:

title: Den Danske Bank Wins Fokus Bidding
description: Svenska Handelsbanken, Sweden's largest bank, said yesterday that it would not raise its offer for Fokus Bank, ceding victory to Den Danske Bank in a bidding contest for Norway's fifth-largest bank.

title: Stethoscope or Stratocaster?
description: Some years back, an acquaintance rang with a proposition he wanted to run by me. His son, a talented musician and thespian, had graduated from college and was thinking of starting a rock band. The father proposed to front the young man enough money to live on and pay rent for a year while he pursued a career in rock. What did I think, being a manager of rock bands and a lawyer?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMANOWITZ, EVA
description: ROMANOWITZ-Eva, 84. Beloved mother of Harry and wife, Sheila. Grandmother of Avra and Daniel, and devoted sister of Joseph Tenenbaum. Born in Tomaszow, Poland, she was a Holocaust survivor, a dear and cherished aunt, trusted friend and counsel to many. Services Sunday, November 15 at 10 A.M., Gutterman's/Parkside, 2576 Flatbush Avenue., Brooklyn, N.Y. Memorial contributions to United Jewish Federation, 1035 Newfield Ave., Stamford, CT 06905

title: A Baritone Of Ample Personality And Voice
description: Colin Davis, in his first series of concerts as principal guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic, has assembled an offbeat program of works more or less familiar from recordings but seldom heard in concert. And for the most part, he did a fine job with it on Thursday evening.

title: Beliefs
description: One of the biggest questions facing anyone interested in understanding American society, indeed the modern condition generally, is why conservative evangelical Christianity not only persists in this country but also positively thrives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOPHER, MORRIS
description: SOPHER-Morris. Your simplicity, brilliance, strength and love was our inspiration. We loved you so. The Kapper famly

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, MURRAY
description: GOLDSTEIN-Murray. A man for all seasons. On November 13, 1998. Beloved husband of Muriel. Devoted father of Leslie (Edward) and Rick (Laura). Loving grandfather of Amy and Michael.

title: Season Gets Shorter
description: Another day, another week of canceled games.

title: Student Protest in Indonesia Explodes in Violence, and 8 Are Killed
description: Students, thugs and soldiers fought pitched battles in the streets of Jakarta on Friday night, as Parliament adopted decrees intended to nudge this suffering nation toward a more democratic future. It was the worst violence since President Suharto resigned last May.

title: Elvis Stahr, 82, Army Secretary
description: Elvis J. Stahr Jr., an educator and environmentalist who was a Secretary of the Army in the Kennedy Administration and was later president of the National Audubon Society, died on Wednesday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 82.

title: WILLAMETTE INDUSTRIES AGREES TO SELL TIMBERLANDS
description: Willamette Industries, a maker of office paper and brown bags, agreed yesterday to sell its Washington State timberlands to the closely held investment firm Campbell Group Inc. for $234 million in cash. Willamette said it would use the proceeds to reduce debt and pursue new opportunities. Willamette has been looking for about two months to sell the 117,000 acres in southwestern Washington. It assumed the timberlands in 1996 as part of a larger purchase from Cavenham Forest Industries and said it did not need the wood. Shares of Willamette rose $1.125, to $32.8125, in Big Board trading yesterday.

title: Global Warming: Costly Solutions?
description: To the Editor:

title: Global Warming: Costly Solutions?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OVEREND, JOHN JAMES
description: OVEREND-John James. On November 13 of Plandome Manor, NY. Beloved husband of Jane (nee Olsen). Dear father of John, Bryn, James, Erin & Mark. Loving grandfather of four. Brother of William, Jean Whelan & Virginia Rogers. In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset on Saturday from 7-9PM and Sunday from 3-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Monday at 9:45AM, St. Mary's RC Church, Manhasset with interment to follow in Nassau Knolls Cemetery, Port Washington, New York.

title: Organ-Donor Shortage
description: To the Editor:

title: Global Warming: Costly Solutions?
description: To the Editor:

title: Marines Scold Officer Who Called Clinton an 'Adulterous Liar' in a Column
description: The Marine Corps decided today not to punish an officer who wrote a newspaper column rebuking President Clinton as an ''adulterous liar,'' in a case that focused attention on the military's prohibitions on public criticisms of the Commander in Chief.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORI, ALBERT H.
description: MORI-Albert H. 69. Died Thursday at his home in Hanover, NH. Graduate of Dartmouth College, 1951. Former investment advisor for Rockefeller Family and Associates, retiring in 1984. Survived by wife of 45 years, Dorothy (Wyman) Mori, Hanover, NH; son Stephen L. Mori of Manhasset, NY; two daughters Nina Mori Gorini, Florence, Italy, and Ruth Mori, Hanover, NH; sister Nina McNamara, Bedford, NY; five grandchildren Christina, Holly, Sanna, Alberto and Giorgio. Memorial Service Tuesday, November 17 at 2PM, First Baptist Church, Etna, NH. Memorial Donations to Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center, c/o Development Office, 1 Medical Center Drive, Lebanon, NH 03756.

title: Officials Watch for Trend in Slow Tally for Attorney General
description: New York's counties may be unable to meet a Nov. 28 deadline for reporting final results in the contest for state attorney general, state election officials said yesterday. But the officials also said they were hopeful that within a week a broad pattern would emerge that would show who had won the race.

title: Partners to Seek Rest Of Argentine Chain
description: Royal Ahold N.V. and Argentina's Velox Retail Holdings said yesterday that they planned to bid for the remaining 48 percent of the Argentine supermarket Disco S.A. in an offer worth about 159 million Argentine pesos ($158.9 million).

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DIAMOND, BETTY LOU
description: DIAMOND-Betty Lou. February 3, 1931-November 13, 1988. It's been ten years and we still love and miss you very much. Love, Your Family

title: Declarer Is 95, So Watch Out For That Double Squeeze
description: Whist is the ancestor game of bridge, and two centuries ago Charles Maurice de Talleyrand-Perigord, a Foreign Minister for various French governments including that of Napoleon, was an enthusiast. He once asked a young man if he played whist, and on receiving a negative answer showed dismay: ''What a dull old age you are saving up for yourself.''

title: Red Holzman, Ex-Maestro Of the Knicks, Is Dead at 78
description: Red Holzman, the Hall of Fame coach who led the New York Knicks to their only two National Basketball Association championships, died last night at Long Island Jewish Hospital. He was 78.

title: Jets Remember '97 (as If Parcells Would Let Them Forget)
description: It seems eerily similar for the Jets: twice as many victories as losses. The football world going giddy over the surprising club. A major victory over a hot team. A division opponent coming up.

title: Hundreds of Homes on Everglades Are to Make Way for Water
description: In a move that officials and environmentalists hailed as a significant step toward restoring the balance of water in the Everglades, Florida officials have decided to buy out hundreds of residents who live in an unincorporated area of west Miami-Dade County.

title: Glenn's Well-Worn Path Down Canyon of Heroes
description: The ticker-tape parade planned for John Glenn on Monday will be the third such celebration in a month, reviving a tradition that had all but died in the years since 1962, when Mr. Glenn first orbited the earth and New Yorkers showered him with affection.

title: Sprint Holders Back Plan on PCS Unit
description: Shareholders of the Sprint Corporation approved today the long-distance phone company's plan to assume full ownership of its Sprint PCS unit and create a separate class of stock for the business.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about lawsuits against gun manufacturers misspelled the given name of a professor at Harvard Law School who helped prepare some of the successful state litigation against cigarette companies. He is Laurence H. Tribe, not Lawrence.

title: LIVENT, MUSICAL PRODUCER, DELAYING FINANCIAL RESULTS
description: Livent Inc., the musical producer, said yesterday that it was delaying for the second time the restatement of past financial results. Livent now expects to have them ready by the end of November. The company behind the Broadway hits ''Show Boat'' and ''Ragtime'' is calculating the impact accounting problems it uncovered in early August will have on earnings and book value going back to 1996 or earlier. Last month, it said the results would be ready by yesterday, and before that, in late October. Livent, led by its chief executive, Roy Furman, suspended its founder and creative head, Garth Drabinsky, and co-founder, Myron Gottlieb, in connection with the irregularities.

title: D.R. HORTON, HOME BUILDERS, APPOINTS KEY OFFICERS
description: D.R. Horton Inc., one of the largest United States home builders, promoted Donald J. Tomnitz to vice chairman and chief executive and Richard Beckwitt to president. The company also announced its board had approved the buyback of up to $100 million common shares and up to $100 million of senior debt securities. The home builder, based in Arlington, Tex., said it expected to exceed fiscal first-quarter and 1999 earnings estimates of analysts because of a record sales backlog of $1.1 billion. Analysts polled by the First Call Corporation expected D.R. Horton to earn 38 cents a share in the first quarter ending Dec. 30 and $1.91 a share in 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUSTER, DR. MARVIN
description: SHUSTER-Dr. Marvin. On Nov. 12 in New Brunswick, NJ, beloved husband of Lorraine E. Talbot Shuster, devoted father of Neil Flanagan, Carol Glassman, Dr. Deborah Shuster, Andra Shuster; Ellen Nagy; loving brother of Lillian Fulmer; adored grandfather of Erica Kluger, Zachary and Alexandra Glassman & Lindsay Nagy. Funeral services on Sunday 11/15/98 at Temple Beth Mordechai, 224 High St., Perth Amboy, NJ. Interment in Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, NJ. Memorial contributions to Heart of Hope Hospice, Raritan Bay Medical Center, 530 New Brunswick Ave., Perth Amboy, NJ 08861 or to RWJUH Oncology Dept., 1 Robert Wood Johnson Place, P.O. Box 2601, New Brunswick, NJ 08901.

title: Youth, 16, Held in Stabbing of 5
description: A 16-year-old boy who was being kicked and punched during a fight over name-calling pulled out a pocketknife and stabbed and slashed five of his teen-age assailants Thursday night, the police said today.

title: Tex Johnston, 84; Pilot Ushered In Airline Era
description: Tex Johnston, a storied test pilot who ushered in the age of jet travel with such a heart-stopping flourish that some people in Seattle and the world of aviation are still shaking their heads, died on Oct. 29 at a nursing home in Mount Vernon, Wash. He was 84 and was recalled as the man who blithely barrel-rolled the nation's first jetliner into aviation history.

title: Whitman Has Appendix Removed, and May Go Home Today
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman underwent surgery late today at Morristown Memorial Hospital for the removal of her appendix after experiencing abdominal pain for the last three days.

title: The Case of Jonathan Pollard
description: Common sense set in after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel urged clemency for Jonathan Pollard in the final hours of the peace talks in Maryland last month. George Tenet, the Director of Central Intelligence, promptly threatened to resign if President Clinton complied, bracing the President to reject the misplaced plea. Then Republican Congressional leaders made it clear to the Israelis that clemency was unacceptable. Mr. Pollard gravely damaged American interests during the 1980's by selling some of America's most sensitive intelligence information to Israel. To release him now would compound that harm and not greatly advance peace in the Middle East.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, BERNARD
description: HALL-Bernard. Beloved husband of Annette. Devoted father of Peter and Eric and father-in-law of Lois. Also survived by many loving nieces, nephews, grand-nieces and friends. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck.

title: CLINTON TO PAY $850,000 TO SETTLE JONES CLAIM OF SEXUAL HARASSMENT
description: President Clinton agreed today to pay Paula Corbin Jones $850,000 to drop her legal claim that he crudely propositioned her seven years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, SYLVIA
description: GREENE-Sylvia. Beloved mother of Madeline & David and the late Lynne. Devoted wife of the late Casey. Adoring Grandma Sylvia to Jackie and Casey Max. Loving sister, aunt and friend. Services on Sunday, November 15, 9:30 AM at Riverside Funeral Chapel, Mount Vernon, New York. Interment at Mount Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Long Beach Memorial Hospital Auxiliary, Long Beach, New York.

title: Devils Win After Losing 3-Goal Lead
description: The game was for sole possession of first place in the Atlantic Division and a tie for the lead in the Eastern Conference, but the Devils were the only team that played tonight with the level of intensity necessary to win a game of such importance.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about local elections in Israel misstated the given name of a candidate for Mayor of Beersheba. He is Yaacov Terner, not Yitzhak. The article also misspelled the given name of a candidate for the Jaffa-Tel Aviv City Council. He is Rifat Turk, not Rifa.

title: U.S. Puts Trade Curbs on India and Pakistan
description: The United States imposed trade restrictions on more than 300 Indian and Pakistani Government agencies and private companies today as a result of the two countries' nuclear tests last May, Commerce Department officials said.

title: FIRST DATA TO BUY UNIFIED MERCHANT STAKE
description: The First Data Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy BankAmerica's 20 percent stake in Unified Merchant Services, giving First Data complete ownership of the processor of merchant credit, debit and check payments. Terms of the transaction, which is expected to close before the end of the year, were not disclosed. The sale was expected because BankAmerica and Nationsbank, which recently merged to form the nation's largest bank, announced in May that the combined bank would use its own subsidiary, BA Merchant Services Inc., as its primary processor of merchant transactions.

title: For Sunken Schooner, Sorrow and Lawsuits
description: All that remains of the cruise ship are two life rafts, seven life jackets, part of a wooden staircase, photographs s of the crew members clutched by mothers at a vigil and, eerily, images of the ship in full sail posted on the Internet as memorials by her former passengers.

title: Divided and Distracted, APEC Prepares to Meet
description: KUALA LUMPUR  As the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum prepares to admit three new members on Saturday, before heading into its annual summit meeting next week, the group appears more divided and distracted than at any time since it was formed in 1989.

title: About New York; From Streets, A Defender Of Methadone
description: THE bar wasn't on Felix Lopez's mind when he was at Yale Law School. The kitchen was. He so loved cooking that he traded torts for tarts in 1980. He left law school, enrolled in the French Culinary Institute and became a chef at Manhattan restaurants like Memphis and La Tulipe. By 1990, he was the chef to a United Nations ambassador, whipping up budget-busting banquets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRONICH, SILVIA LESSER
description: GRONICH-Silvia Lesser, age 88, on November 13th. Adored wife of the late Maxwell A. Gronich. Cherished mother and loving friend to Susan and Theodore. She was a classy lady. Services Sunday, 11:30 am, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam

title: What Happens if House Forgoes Impeachment?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Mezzo With Confidence And Power to Spare
description: Petra Lang

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEBAN, FRANCIS J.
description: KLEBAN-Francis J. In loving memory of a beloved husband, devoted father, loving grandfather and fond great-grandfather who passed away November 18, 1995

title: From Sauce to Side Dish, Chestnuts Aren't Just for Roasting
description: FRESH chestnuts come into the market in late fall, imported from Italy. Yet chestnut woods once covered the eastern United States from southern Maine to southwestern Florida in one direction to eastern Arkansas in the other.

title: Bank Plus Facing Closer Scrutiny by U.S.
description: The Bank Plus Corporation said today that its business would be more closely supervised by regulators after losses on credit card loans caused the savings and loan holding company to lose almost $60 million in the third quarter.

title: As L.I. Economy Booms, New Office Buildings Bloom
description: The steady growth of the Long Island economy, coupled with low interest rates and a renewed demand for office space, has led to a resurgence in office building construction in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, according to builders, real estate executives and public officials.

title: Request to Alter Space Station Orbit Is Dropped
description: NASA and the Russian Space Agency have agreed to set aside a last-minute Russian request to launch an international space station into an orbit closer to Mir, officials announced today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAFRAN, SHIRLEY
description: SHAFRAN-Shirley. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Adrienne Shafran-Hirschfeld and Myra Landau. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Died peacefully at her home Nov. 12. Funeral Sunday, Nov. 15, Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn at 11:30 AM.

title: Putting Frosting On Success; Scouts Make Millions on Cookies, They Need Advice?
description: Down a drab corridor in the basement of the Empire State Building, in an austere, glaringly lighted employee dining room, six security guards chatted at a table on Wednesday morning. In front of them sat a box of Girl Scout Thin Mints.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: A CROWDED PICTURE
description: World War II, on-line romance and the return of a talking pig: Hollywood is offering a full plate for its most competitive season. Holiday Movies: A special section with Arts & Leisure.

title: Waiting for the N.B.A. With the Body of a Man; Lockout Leaves Pacers' Rookie in Limbo
description: When Al Harrington drove to Bloomington, Ind., four months ago, he did not know that he was about to be rebuilt. Harrington, the Indiana Pacers' first-round selection in last summer's National Basketball Association draft, thought he was just going to lift some weights, run some sprints and shoot some jumpers. But Joe Abunassar, Harrington's newly hired personal trainer, had other plans. Having worked with many N.B.A. players, Abunassar knew that his client's soft, undeveloped, 18-year-old body would have to be reshaped if he was to stand any chance of surviving the pounding that an N.B.A. forward takes.

title: A Sales Pitch for the Liberal Arts: Is It Liberal? Is It Artistic?
description: To counter a decline in its enrollment, the College of Arts and Sciences at Indiana University hired an advertising agency to promote itself among this year's incoming freshmen. Slogans included ''Major in Arts and Sciences, Think for a Living'' and ''Do What You Want When You Graduate or Wait 20 Years for Your Midlife Crisis.'' In the November issue of Lingua Franca, various experts assessed the campaign. Here are excerpts from their responses:

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Wednesday about elaborate new workouts that are being staged by health clubs misidentified one in New York City where the ''boot camp'' workout is led by a former marine. It is the Reebok Sports Club, not Prescriptive Fitness.

title: Judiciary Committee Gets Starr's Evidence on Willey
description: The independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr today sent evidence concerning the former White House volunteer Kathleen E. Willey to the House Judiciary Committee, but he did not say the material constituted grounds for impeaching President Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUESTONE, SALLY
description: BLUESTONE-Sally. November 13, 1998 after a very brief illness. One month before her 96th birthday. Beloved sister, aunt, great-aunt and great great-aunt. Devoted daughter of the late Fannie and Joseph Bluestone. Generous, caring, loyal and gifted lady. Will be remembered for a lifetime of hard work, commitment to family and Judaism. Life Member and Past President of Hatikvah Chapter of Hadassah. She was A Presence. She will be missed. Service Sunday, November 15. Family to meet at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn at 1 P.M. and proceed to New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, N.Y. for graveside service. Shiva, 1718 Quentin Road, Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: Two Works, Opposite Forces: Centrifugal and Centripetal
description: Tokyo String Quartet

title: $10,000 Reward Offered for AIDS Victim's Lost Dog
description: Wanted: one German short-haired pointer with doe eyes and brown spots. Wandered away in Norwalk, Conn., two months ago. ''Ten thousand dollars for the safe return of this pet!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGAL, MAX M.
description: SEGAL-Max M.. Of West Orange, NJ, on November 12th, 1998. Beloved husband of Ruth nee Slawin. Devoted father of Peter Segal, Jane Segal and Carl Segal. Loving brother of Arnold Segal and Charles Segal. Loving grandfather of Oliver Segal, Leslie Segal, Erin Segal and Zachary Segal. Funeral from Bernheim-Apter-Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Ave., Maplewood, NJ, on Sunday, November 15, at 2 PM. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: Saudi Was Target In Raid, U.S. Says
description: Clinton Administration officials now acknowledge that one of the clear but unstated objectives of last August's raid in Afghanistan was to kill Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile who has been charged by Federal prosecutors with leading a global war against American interests and who has been linked to the Aug. 7 bombing of two American embassies in East Africa.

title: Firstplus Chief Sells Shares
description: Firstplus Financial Group Inc.'s chairman and chief executive, Daniel T. Phillips, sold 1.23 million shares of the home equity finance company last month, about a quarter of his holdings, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Phillips told the S.E.C. he sold his shares for $3 to $4.75 each between Oct. 16 and Oct. 30, leaving him with 3.33 million shares at the end of last month.

title: Music in Brooklyn
description: The second concert of the Brooklyn Philharmonic's season-opening program of contemporary music will take place tonight at 8 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, Brooklyn. Tickets range from $17.50 to $35. Information: (718) 636-4100.

title: U.S. Temporarily Suspends Deportations to 4 Countries
description: As four Central American countries struggle to recover from the catastrophe of Hurricane Mitch, the Clinton Administration plans to make it easier for people from those countries who are already in the United States.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: APACHE CORP., Houston, an oil and gas exploration company, agreed to acquire offshore western Australia oil and gas interests for $49 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHN, AIMEE
description: CAHN-Aimee. Temple Shaaray Tefila records with sorrow the death of our long time member. We extend our heartfelt condolences to all of her family. A memorial service will take place in our Morse Chapel on Monday, November 16 at noon. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum Dr. Ellen Saxl, President

title: Pressure Builds for Accord At Talks on Climate Change
description: Negotiators in the Buenos Aires talks on global warming were locked in a last-minute struggle last night to resolve key questions. The matters seemed merely procedural but in reality went to the heart of the politically charged issue of how fast the world can and should move to deal with the prospect of climatic change.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Hurricane Aid Is Just a Band-Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: KOHLBERG KRAVIS TRIMS ITS STAKE IN SAFEWAY
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the leveraged buyout firm, trimmed its stake in Safeway Inc. on Thursday by selling 20 million of the supermarket chain's common shares. The liquidation came in tandem with Safeway's joining the Standard & Poor's 500. Safeway said the sale was meant to put more of the company's shares into the public float. Of the 20 million shares sold, about 17 million were owned by Kohlberg Kravis outright and 3 million were owned by an affiliate, SSI Equity, Safeway said. The sale brings the firm's stake down to 13.2 percent from 16.7 percent. Based on Safeway's Thursday closing price, the Kohlberg Kravis portion of the sale would have generated $858 million, while SSI's would have garnered $151.5 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISKE, CHARLES S.
description: FISKE-Charles S., 86 years, on November 12, 1998. Devoted husband of Frances. Loving father of Roger. Beloved grandfather of Russell, Tracy and Kevin. Dear brother of Frieda. His love and good deeds will be with us forever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUSTIG, NATHAN
description: LUSTIG-Nathan. Young Israel of Oceanside expresses heartfelt condolences to our members Larry Lustig and Sybil Epstein upon the loss of their beloved father. May the families be comforted among those who mourn for Tzion and Yerushalayim. Evan Torczyner, President Jay Yaacov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: Fresh Debates On the Legacy Of Isaiah Berlin
description: The British philosopher Isaiah Berlin was knighted during his lifetime, but since his death a year ago he has achieved a peculiar kind of intellectual sainthood. The tributes are still reverential, but there are signs of debate and disagreement over the nature of his intellectual legacy.

title: Decision On Pipeline In Caspian Is Delayed
description: Buffeted by political and economic pressures, oil companies drilling in the Caspian Sea are postponing their much-awaited decision on where to lay their main export pipeline.

title: Lawsuits Against Handguns
description: Chicago has now joined New Orleans in a promising new legal offensive against gun violence. On Thursday, Chicago's Mayor, Richard Daley, filed a $433 million lawsuit against 22 gun manufacturers, 4 gun distributors and 12 suburban stores. The suit charged them with creating a ''public nuisance'' by knowingly flooding the city, which has some of the nation's strictest gun control laws, with illegal weapons.

title: I.M.F. Announces a $41.5 Billion Rescue Package for Brazil
description: Ending nearly three months of uncertainty here, the International Monetary Fund today announced a $41.5 billion rescue package for Brazil that will require a level of sustained economic discipline that Latin America's largest nation has never demonstrated in the past.

title: Jerome Robbins Memorial
description: The New York City Ballet is to hold a memorial service for Jerome Robbins on Monday at 7:30 P.M. at the New York State Theater. The evening is to include a performance of Robbins's ''Dances at a Gathering'' and remarks by Peter Martins, the company's artistic director.

title: Microsoft Is Said to Irk Some Big Users
description: Some of the nation's largest companies, including Citibank and Federal Express, view the Microsoft Corporation's strategy of integrating Internet software with the Windows operating system as a costly inconvenience with few benefits, according to an independent consultant serving as an expert witness in the Government's antitrust suit against Microsoft.

title: Deal Gives Slough Majority Stake in Bilton
description: Slough Estates P.L.C. declared victory yesterday in its bid of up to $:277 million ($460 million) for Bilton P.L.C. after Glenhazel Investment Trust agreed to sell Slough its 29.4 percent stake.

title: Autistic Boy Is Reunited With Family After 11 Days
description: A 15-year-old autistic boy who was found wandering in the Erie Lackawanna Terminal in Hoboken, N.J., on Tuesday but could not identify himself was reunited with his mother yesterday after she saw a news report about him on television. He had been missing from his home on Staten Island for 11 days.

title: Brazil Bailout: 2 Gambles for U.S.
description: With the announcement today of nearly $42 billion in aid to stabilize Brazil, the United States is taking two gambles: that its own part of the aid -- $5 billion in taxpayer money -- is a safe investment in a country in need of rapid reform, and a separate wager that its new strategy to calm the global financial jitters will succeed where others failed.

title: What Happens if House Forgoes Impeachment?
description: To the Editor:

title: TOYS 'R' US HALTING SALE OF SOME INFANT PRODUCTS
description: Toys ''R'' Us said yesterday that it would remove from its shelves all direct-to-mouth infant products, like teethers and pacifiers, that contain phthalates. The retailer said it was doing so while additional scientific data are gatherered on possible health hazards of phthalates, which are a class of chemicals used in vinyl. ''Although there has been no definitive scientific evidence that supports removal of these products, customer concern and the actions by some manufacturers to phase out phthalates have led us to this decision,'' said Robert C. Nakasone, the chief executive of Toys ''R'' Us.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Our Towns column on Thursday about the elimination of the police force in Cortlandt, N.Y., misstated the issue in a lawsuit that the town settled for $260,000. The suit, filed by the police department, was for overtime claims, not for free speech violations.

title: CLINTON SAYS IRAQ CAN AVERT ATTACK BY GIVING IN TO U.N.
description: President Clinton and President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today made clear the vastness of the differences between them, publicly offering contradictory analyses of the current crisis and incompatible solutions.

title: Hurricane Relief Is Just a Band-Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Plays Reside at a Small College
description: Jake Fay throws the passes. Matt Perceval catches them. Fay-to-Perceval has accounted for 12 touchdowns this season, seven of them in Wesleyan's 55-28 season-opening victory over Middlebury, a Division III record.

title: Air Force Scrambles to Send More Warplanes to the Gulf
description: As the Clinton Administration again called on President Saddam Hussein to back down, the Air Force scrambled today to send dozens of additional warplanes to the Persian Gulf, steadily building a force large enough to carry out what Pentagon officials described as a sustained bombing campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILMAN, BLUMA
description: GILMAN-Bluma. On November 12, 1998. Wife of Beryl. Stepmother of Amy Gilman Srebnick. Motherin-law of Walter. Grandmother of Joshua and Daniel. Memorial service Sunday, 2:30PM, ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Global Warming: Costly Solutions?
description: To the Editor:

title: Garden City to Face New Hyde Park
description: In the second day of the Long Island High School football playoffs at Hofstra University, Garden City (9-0) advanced to the Nassau County Conference II final next Friday by defeating Division (6-3), 40-0, last night. The Trojans were led by John Maloney, the game's top rusher, who carried 17 times for 122 yards and two touchdowns. .

title: Hurricane Relief Is Just a Band-Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, RICHARD
description: GOLDBERG-Richard. The Board of Trustees, Administration and the entire New York Community Hospital mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague Richard Goldberg, who served devotedly as a member of our Board of Trustees for eleven years and as Vice-Chairman for five years, until his death on November 12, 1998 in a fatal car accident in Florida. We express our deep sorrow and condolences to his wife Joan, their children and their families. Dick will be sorely missed by all of us. Services will be held on Sunday, November 15, 1998 at 1:00 PM at Riverside Chapel, 312 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, New York. George Weinberger, President, Board of Trustees Lin H. Mo, President & Chief Executive Officer

title: What Happens if House Forgoes Impeachment?
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Accused Officers in Louima Case Implicate a Third
description: Two of the four police officers facing Federal civil rights charges in the attack on a Haitian immigrant in Brooklyn last year have incriminated one of the other officers in the most brutal part of the assault, according to documents unsealed yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: Angelos Near A Redskins Bid
description: Peter Angelos, who owns 60 percent of the Baltimore Orioles, intends to bid on the Washington Redskins and is certain that if he acquires the football team, he will meet the National Football League's standards for dual ownership of sports franchises.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKELVEY, KAREN DEMPSEY
description: MCKELVEY-Karen Dempsey. Died November 11, 1998 of Rye, NY. Beloved daughter of David Dempsey of Rye, NY, loving sister of Ian Dempsey of New York City. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Just Strays, Box 27, Wykagyl Station, New Rochelle, NY.

title: Special Teams Star Claimed
description: The Giants today claimed Curtis Buckley, who has made a career out of impressive special teams play. Buckley, a first alternate Pro Bowl special teams player for the last three seasons, was waived by the San Francisco 49ers on Thursday to make room for the veteran cornerback Tyrone Legette.

title: Roman Cycowski, 97, Vocal Sextet Member
description: Roman Cycowski, the last surviving member of the Comedian Harmonists, a legendary German vocal sextet that was forced to break up by the Nazis because three of its members were Jewish, died on Wednesday at his home in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 97.

title: WHEN THEORY MET REALITY: A special report.; Teachings of Two Nobelists Also Proved Their Undoing
description: Two months ago Myron S. Scholes made a sentimental journey to the steel-manufacturing city of Hamilton, Ontario, to be honored as a local boy made good.

title: Sister Cities: Montclair and Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Poets Quit Board Of Academy in Protest
description: Two prominent American poets, both of them women, have resigned as chancellors of the Academy of American Poets, a venerable body at the symbolic center of the American poetry establishment, to protest the absence of blacks and other minority groups on the academy's board of chancellors. The chancellors, Carolyn Kizer and Maxine Kumin, both of whom have lobbied to admit minorities to the board, submitted their resignations to Jonathan Galassi, the academy's president, this week.

title: U.N. Chief in Last-Ditch Plea to Iraq on Arms
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan made a last-ditch appeal to Iraq tonight to make a ''wise decision'' and end its defiance of international arms inspections.

title: Speaking the Blues Clearly
description: The blues language developed at the turn of the century has spread in so many ways over the last 100 years that its beauty is now as ignored as an often-seen landscape. The small accumulation of its repeated ideas, the graceful rising and falling of melodies, its percussive drive, all have become familiar. The miracle of the blues riff -- the way it constructs narrative, its systemic coherence and its improvisational electricity -- is taken as simply improvisation, something tossed off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHELLER, ED
description: SHELLER-Ed. On November 13, 1998. Beloved husband of Naomi Sarna. Father of Chris & Alex Sheller, Sarah and Noa Schechter. Dear son of Robert and the late Helen Sheller. Adored nephew of Florence Shultz. Brother of Elly Rufer and her family, John, Daniel and Kate. Services Sunday, November 15, 12:30 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Ed was a man whose intellect and passion for reading enriched those around him. Contributions can be made in Ed's name to The New York Public Library, Friends Office, 465 Fifth Ave, Room M1, NY, NY 10018-2788 and The Summit School, 187-30 Grand Central Pkwy, Jamaica Estates, NY 11432.

title: Capacity Glut Likely to Spur More Auto Mergers
description: Further large mergers are likely among auto makers because of a worldwide excess of assembly plants and the just-completed marriage of Daimler-Benz A.G. and the Chrysler Corporation, industry leaders said in interviews this week.

title: Sister Cities: United States and Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief Says AMP Would Look at Other Bids
description: Robert M. Ripp, the chairman and chief executive of AMP Inc., says AMP would have to consider any offers for the company that exceeded the $9.8 billion hostile takeover bid by Allied Signal Inc.

title: Global Warming: Costly Solutions?
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect in Rapes Faces Charges in Other Attacks
description: An East Orange man who was charged two weeks ago with abducting and raping five women over the last 15 months was accused yesterday of attacking four other women, county prosecutors said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about alternative medical treatments misstated the name of a condition for which a mixture of Chinese herbs was found beneficial. It is irritable bowel syndrome, not inflammatory bowel syndrome.

title: For Wheatley, a Kickoff Cameo?
description: With the likely absence of David Patten, who is experiencing some back stiffness, the Giants may finally have a role for Tyrone Wheatley this weekend: returning kickoffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDERFER, MARIETTA ''JAYDE''
description: RUDERFER-Marietta ''Jayde''. On November 12, 1998. Beloved wife of Leonard. Darling mother of Mindy & Edgar, Dean and Diane. Dear grandmother of Jordan, Cory, David and Doug.
