Donations may be made to the L.I. Alzheimer's Foundation Memory Lane Club, 3333 New Hyde Park Road, New Hyde Park, New York 11042. Interment was private

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ECHOLS, GEORGE R.
description: ECHOLS-George R., 38, of Howell, NJ on November 11, 1998. Surviving are his wife, Angela Durante Echols; two sons, Steven and Christopher and a daughter, Jennifer; his parents, George R., Sr. and Margaret Mozine Echols; two sisters, three brothers-in-law and a sister-in-law, Patricia and Charles Bingham, Jr., Barbara and George Monahan, and Nick and Linda Durante; his grandmother, Florence Echols; a nephew, Michael Bingham; three nieces Kathleen and Victoria Bingham, and Nancy Monahan; and his father and mother-in-law, Dominick and Jeanette Durante. The Funeral Liturgy will be celebrated at St. Catherine of Siena R.C. Church, Farmingdale, NJ on Saturday at 11 A.M. followed by interment at St. Rose of Lima Cemetery, Freehold, NJ. Memorial donations to the Howell Pop Warner Football League, PO box 183, Howell, NJ 07731 would be appreciated.

title: A Tribute to a Choreographer, Jazzy and Funny but Also Bleak
description: Anna Sokolow's Players' Project

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOGEL, EDWARD
description: FOGEL-Edward. The Fund for Peace mourns the passing of its fellow Board member, Edward Fogel, where he served for 18 years. He was a senior partner of Pryor Cashman, Sherman and Flynn and was active in many civic associations including The Chess-In-The-Schools. Our condolences to his wife, Barbara, children and grand children.

title: Arrests Break Drug Ring In the Bronx, Police Say
description: With a series of arrests, a well-organized gang that did more than $2 million in business selling drugs throughout the Bronx, including packets of heroin called ''Bad Medicine,'' has been dismantled, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Mexico Expects 3% Growth Next Year
description: In a bid to outstrip the United States in economic growth next year despite the uncertainties in global markets, Mexico proposed one of the leanest federal budgets in its history today and said it would impose some unpopular taxes to keep the deficit down.

title: If Mets Want Cook, It Will Cost Them
description: Not long after Alan Mills signed with the Los Angeles Dodgers yesterday for $6.5 million over the next three seasons, Pat Rooney was putting his own interpretation on the signing. Rooney, the agent for Dennis Cook, believed his client's value had shot straight up.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I just do not know what it's going to take to make this matter end. What I do know is that I don't know of any wrongdoing on behalf of the First Lady or the President, and nothing the independent counsel can do to me is going to make me lie about that.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A Settlement Is Reached With Four Tobacco Giants

title: Clowning and Creating, A Cuban Band Connects
description: NG La Banda, one of the great modern Cuban dance bands, reflects the connective genius of its leader, Jose Luis Cortes. In the late 1980's and early 90's, Mr. Cortes and his band revolutionized Cuban music by making black dance music popular in a way it hadn't been for years; its most influential album is called ''En la Calle'' (''In the Street''), and on it he made a claim for the power of collective music, inspired by its audience, which in this case is mostly black and mostly from what had been the lower class.

title: Inspiration From the Eye as Well as the Ear
description: The conductor Leon Botstein has always been fascinated by the connections that exist between the arts. The connection between music and the visual arts in the early decades of this century is especially striking, he feels. And on Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall, he conducted a program with the American Symphony Orchestra that intriguingly demonstrated his point.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HOGS FALL 3.2 PERCENT. Prices slumped to a four-year low on expectations that it will take slaughterhouses longer than forecast to reduce a record-sized herd. The December contract fell 1.1 cents, to 33.2 cents a pound.

title: The Rural Life; Before Winter Comes
description: I suppose that if I were a woolly bear caterpillar or a squirrel storing hickory nuts or one of the other creatures said to know in advance the severity of the winter ahead, I would be able to do just the right amount of work to get ready for it. Instead, I have to prepare for winter in the subjunctive, as if it were going to be severe -- as if I were a doom-saying squirrel. Like most people, I'm not a very good student of my own behavior, but I've noticed in myself a striking urge these days to get ready for winter. I noticed it because it led me down to the barn one morning and kept me hard at work for several days, stacking hay in the loft, preparing to heat the horses' water tank, making a place in the barn aisle where the horseshoer could work under lights and out of the wind.

title: The TV Screen as Mirror
description: To the Editor:

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Dean Johnson; Checking The Beat of Neo-Glam
description: DEAN JOHNSON, lead singer of the Velvet Mafia, sauntered into Bowery Bar on Tuesday night, brushed past Isaac Mizrahi and ran a gauntlet of kisses from doormen, friends and people he said he did not know at all. Despite the outpouring of affection, Mr. Johnson looked chagrined.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENCHNER, LINDA JOY
description: LENCHNER-Linda Joy, of New City, NY, died of ovarian cancer on Sunday, November 1, 1998. She was born on June 6, 1943, the daughter of Morris and Bertha Lipkin. She is survived by her husband Harvey, sons Daniel and Michael, mother Bertha Lipkin of Miami Beach, FL, twin sister Barbara Dresner of New City, NY and sisters Sheila Schweiger of Radnor, PA and Myrna Korsh of Scarsdale, NY. Mrs. Lenchner will be remembered for her love, honesty, devotion and kindness to her friends and family. She will be sorely missed. The world is a far lesser place without her. Mrs. Lenchner was interred at Sharon Gardens in Valhalla, NY on November 3, 1998. Memorial donations may be made payable to the Linda Lenchner Cancer Fund, and mailed to: Robert Fine, MD, c/o Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, College of Physicians and Surgeons, 650 West 168th St, Black Building, Room 20-05, New York, NY 10032

title: Enough Already! What Am I, Chopped Liver?
description: William Safire's On Language column was fun (Oct. 25). I could hear my grandmother, as she grated the liver. Yes, grated by hand. What's with a food processor? Not authentic. Besides the schmaltz, a little ''skin of knuckles'' added to the taste.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, RICHARD
description: GOLDBERG-Richard. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of Richard Goldberg, beloved husband of our esteemed colleague, Joan Goldberg. May his memory be for a blessing. Marlene E. Post, Nat'l President Dr. Laura S. Schor, Nat'l Exec Dir

title: We Have Liftoff
description: THIS NEW OCEAN

title: Status is ... for Long-Haul Truckers; Millions of Miles Without a Scratch
description: When a trucker takes the measure of a fellow trucker, the yardstick is a mile long.

title: Some Notable 'Firsts'; First Detergent Ban
description: Suffolk County stood alone from 1971 to 1981 as the only place in the United States where common household detergents were banned from market shelves.

title: Tobacco Agreement Skirts Regulatory Concerns
description: Because the $206 billion tobacco settlement that emerged on Friday was reached by cigarette makers and state attorneys general, rather than Federal officials, it does not deal with the issue that cigarette makers have feared most: regulation by the Federal Food and Drug Administration.

title: Beaver Creek, Colo.
description: It was slightly embarrassing, taking the outdoor escalator up through Beaver Creek's ever-fancier Mountain Village instead of resolutely clattering up the stairs. I absolutely drew the line at taking the moving sidewalk over the picturesque bridge that leads from the main base area to a less populated lift. But with two small skiers and all their equipment in tow, I quickly shed my disdain for Beaver Creek's easeful approach to skiing. What's not to like about delicious, inventive lunch offerings in the cafeteria at Spruce Saddle, the midmountain lodge, where hosts in Old West costumes equipped with walkie-talkies help you find an empty table? Or an enthusiastic ski school staff that makes sure the kids get to special spots on the mountain like a rigged-up bear cave, or a series of bumps guaranteed to make them whoop with surprise?

title: Crowded And Loud, But Mine
description: I'VE written nine novels, and four of them are set partly or mostly on Long Island. Consequently, I've become known in some publishing circles as ''The Long Island Author,'' whatever that means.

title: Corrections
description: The front-page contents listing today for section 2A, Holiday Movies, reverses two page numbers in some copies. Molly Haskell's article about women's films is on page 44; Michele Willens's article on mini-mainstream movies is on page 45.

title: Top Rating for Hospital
description: The Hudson Valley Hospital Center in Cortlandt has received accreditation with commendation from the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations, a rating that only 4 percent of the health care institutions in the United States receive. It is the highest level awarded by the Joint Commission, the country's oldest and largest accrediting body. The Hudson Valley Hospital Center received a score of 99 percent out of a possible 100 percent.

title: The Hollywood Forecast: A Six-Week Blizzard
description: THE holiday season is a scary time in Hollywood. ''Am I nervous? Is the sun going to come out tomorrow?'' said Jeffrey Katzenberg, the Dreamworks partner who has overseen ''The Prince of Egypt,'' the animated biblical musical opening Dec. 18. ''I'm not quite panicked yet, but that'll come, too.''

title: Williams Wins To Finish 8-0
description: Williams College completed an undefeated season today at 8-0 by beating its rival Amherst College, 35-16.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHEATE, ELSA ALLER
description: WHEATE-Elsa Aller. Of Cortlandt Manor, NY, died November 13, 1998. She was born on May 8, 1920, to Joseph Aller and Juliette Goldberg Aller. Mother of John J. Kail and Alexandra Kail Rundle. Sister of Therese Aller Cormack. Also survived by two granddaughters. Visiting Tuesday at Edward F. Carter Funeral Home, Inc, 41 Grand St, Croton, NY, from 5-7 PM only. Cremation will be private.

title: Kronos's New Order, a Quarter Century Old
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, a young violinist named David Harrington asked his composition teacher to write a piece for the new string quartet he was forming. The teacher complied, and Mr. Harrington paid him the commission he could afford: a bag of doughnuts.

title: Status is ... for Las Vegas Gamblers; Getting the Heave-ho
description: Ever hear of ''the smart money''? In the gambling community, where the expression was coined, it refers to people like Ronald B. -- a guy who possesses gambling smarts and has the money to prove it. He's a 50-ish sports bettor who shuttles between his homes in New York and Las Vegas and whose wardrobe tends toward silk shirts and loud shoes. Ronald B.'s game of choice is football: he keeps his own statistics, makes his own power ratings and has pipelines to locker rooms in every N.F.L. city. More important, he has great instincts. ''I just get a feeling in my gut,'' he says. All told, Ronald B. claims that he's right 58 percent of the time -- and for a gambler, that's huge.

title: Tug-of-War Over Hispanic Cultural Center Building
description: Members of the Charas/El Bohio Cultural and Community Center have embarked on a new strategy to preserve the center as a Hispanic cultural mecca providing rehearsal and studio space to struggling artists. They hope to persuade Gregg L. Singer, the man who recently bought the building housing the center, that completing the sale will be more trouble than it's worth.

title: Some Notable 'Firsts'; First Town Meeting
description: Puritans who settled the East End in 1640 held the first town meetings in what was to become New York State.

title: In Middle East, a Hesitant Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Blindsided by Matters Outside the Lines
description: The vultures wasted no time. ''A couple guys said, if you do start to look, they have interest,'' Frank Cashen said.

title: Chess; When the Same Delusion Befuddles Both Players
description: Double errors, where both players follow the same line of reasoning, except that one thinks he's winning and the other thinks he's losing, are usually the occasion of merriment among the spectators, but these occurrences are not as zany as they appear. After all, in a well-played game, the players must divine each other's intentions. Each has to know what the other is doing, up to a point.

title: Ideas & Trends; Mixing Up the Projects
description: A NEW law to revive the nation's troubled public housing had a simple goal when it was first proposed several years go: Allow more working poor families into projects that had become dominated -- some would say decimated -- by very poor welfare families.

title: Scrub-a-Dub-Dub, There's Money In That Tub
description: NEW YORK, no matter what Mayor Giuliani says, is still a filthy place. But fear not. All over town, professional dirt-busters are at the ready to purge the darkest, most forbidden corners of the Naked City, like behind the toilet and under the couch.

title: Designs for a Kennedy Rail Terminal Provoke Foes
description: The Port Authority last week unveiled designs for a new terminal linking a planned elevated rail line from Kennedy International Airport with the Long Island Rail Road and subway lines at Jamaica, Queens. The announcement prompted a coalition of community groups, supported by major airlines, to announce an effort to derail the proposal.

title: Had Enough Of Grandeur? Here's Relief
description: I'VE been meaning to lobby this newspaper for a series on secret vices. Critics, staunch in their advocacy of the pure and upstanding, would confess what they listen to, read or look at when no one is paying attention. It would be like Sottha Khunn eating Mars bars after a night cooking at Le Cirque 2000, or Oscar de la Renta sitting at home in his underwear.

title: Edmonds Has Yanks' Attention
description: With the possibility growing that the Anaheim Angels will soon sign Mo Vaughn, the Yankees are trying to maneuver into position to get from the Angels the center fielder they will need when Bernie Williams, as they expect, leaves the team.

title: AT THE MUSEUMS: MUSEUMS AT STONY BROOK; Presidential Paper Dolls
description: Bill Clinton is in his underwear. So are Hillary and Chelsea. Even Virginia Clinton Kelley is unclothed. You get to dress them.

title: Call It a Quarrel, or Call It Gridlock
description: Not that a good community squabble is anything new to the Upper West Side, but an internal Community Board 7 dispute has been unfolding like a soap opera in recent months. And because of it, some residents say, the board's important transportation committee has been hamstrung.

title: For Family Films, It's Survival of the Fittest
description: LIKE children elbowing one another for their parents' attention, Hollywood studios are vying for the holiday box office. The number of films targeting family audiences has set off the most intense competition among studios in years.

title: Through a Glass Brightly: Jackson Pollock in His Own Words
description: IN the autumn of 1950, the photographer Hans Namuth made a color film of Jackson Pollock -- now widely considered the most influential American painter of the 20th century -- painting outdoors at his East Hampton property.

title: Jersey City and Newark High in IV-Related AIDS
description: Jersey City has the second highest rate of AIDS cases caused by intravenous injection of drugs and Newark has the fourth highest rate, according to research on 99 metropolitan areas released last week by Dr. Dawn Day of the Dogwood Center, a research organization in Princeton that studies the impact of AIDS and drug policies.

title: A Tonic for Tired Taste Buds: L.I.'s Own Tap Water
description: WHEN cups are raised to drinking water that comes in little plastic bottles with designer labels, names like Perrier, Evian, San Pellegrino, Poland Spring, Great Bear and Deer Park come to mind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, SYLVIA
description: GREENE-Sylvia. Beloved mother of Madeline & David and the late Lynne. Devoted wife of the late Casey. Adoring Grandma Sylvia to Jackie and Casey Max. Loving sister, aunt and friend. Services on Sunday, November 15, 9:30 AM at Riverside Funeral Chapel, Mount Vernon, New York. Interment at Mount Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Long Beach Memorial Hospital Auxiliary, Long Beach, New York.

title: Valued Care Center to Close
description: Nerlande Henry, a patient at the Flatbush Community Family Care center, is one of its biggest supporters. ''They know us, they speak our languages and listen to our concerns,'' said Ms. Henry, who was born in Haiti. ''Like many women in the area, I am a working mother. The center offers flexible hours, so my children can get quality health care.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALANDRINO, SAMUEL P.
description: MALANDRINO-Samuel P. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Samuel P. Malandrino, associated with The Times from 1955, until retiring in 1982.

title: Rhode Island In the Mix
description: Atlantic 10

title: Status is ... for Humanities Profs; Being Post-Paglia
description: When asked what he planned to do with himself after leaving Oxford, where he'd distinguished himself as a brilliant classics student, the young Oscar Wilde replied, ''I don't know, but whatever it is, I won't be some dried-up old don.''

title: Minor Leaguer Hurts Knee Badly
description: The Rangers, who are in a rebuilding mode, got bad news from their farm system yesterday when they learned that Stefan Cherneski would miss the rest of this season and maybe more with a knee injury. Playing for the Hartford Wolf Pack farm club in the American Hockey League on Friday night, Cherneski shattered his kneecap in a home game against Springfield.

title: Tennessee's Title Drive Stays Alive, Just Barely
description: As the 106,365 fans filed out of Tennessee's Neyland Stadium tonight, cliches about destiny were thrown around liberally. People clad in orange rain gear talked about being ''lucky rather than good,'' about ''fate'' having a national championship trophy waiting for their football team. Even the Volunteer players, moments removed from a come-from-behind, 28-24 victory over Arkansas, could not deny the urge to talk about being guided by an unseen hand.

title: AN ELEGANT STOPOVER
description: WENDY LAMB, a Manhattan book editor, wrote the Oct. 4 Soapbox essay, chronicling milestones of her life that occurred in Grand Central Terminal. She suggested that others record their memories of the place. The City section solicited ''most memorable moments'' and here are a few:

title: Game Makers Are Trying To Turn the Year Around
description: WHEN the computer game industry envisions the holiday season, it sees fighter aces, Al Capone and a bizarre Swamp Thing-like creature called Abe.

title: Corrections
description: The Word for Word column on Nov. 1, with excerpts from phrases used by sports anchors on ESPN, misstated the Internet address for the fan-generated Web site where the phrases are collected. It is:

title: In the Region / Westchester; For Rye Brook, Intergenerational Housing
description: AN intergenerational approach to housing is taking shape at the Belle Fair development here, where work has begun on the first component, a combination of 170 detached houses and 46 duplexes on the site of the 140-acre former High Point Psychiatric Hospital on King Street.

title: The World; The Second Battle of Waterloo
description: THE English like to poke fun at the French, but much to their annoyance the French usually respond with indifference, which perhaps explains why an obscure Gaullist politician enjoyed 15 minutes of fame in England this month. Here at last was a patriot ready to defend his nation's honor in face of provocations by the perfidious Albion. English newspapers chortled with delight. At last, a reaction!

title: SOAPBOX; Four-Wheel Driven Crazy
description: I KNEW I had reached my limit when my social judgment began to deteriorate: I had taken to tapping on the windshields of Expeditions and Land Cruisers stopped at red lights and inquiring, with more than a hint of malice, ''Is the thing big enough for you?''

title: It's a Mad, Mad Hatter's World With Crazy Creations at the Ball
description: HALLOWEEN is over, but the spirit of costumed revelry lives on. Last weekend, the Neuberger Museum of Art at Purchase College had its annual fund-raising gala, this year called Mad Hatter's Fantasy Ball. Guests, who paid $250 each, were asked to wear black-tie outfits topped with the craziest, cleverest hats they could concoct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKOFF, ALEXANDRA
description: MARKOFF-Alexandra. Age 69. Wife of the late Harry. Loving mother of Jonathan and David Fenton. Grandma of Cole. Sister of Doris Hisiger. Daughter of Max and Margaret Kugler. Died November 6, 1998.

title: A Busy Season Of Cops, Spies And Aliens
description: KEVIN SPACEY plays a Hollywood casting director and the voice of a manipulative grasshopper. Jon Voight is an obsessed Irish policeman, a high school football coach and a homicidal spy. Bebe Neuwirth turns up as a prostitute and as a high school teacher possessed by aliens. And they say there aren't any good roles for women.

title: Tulane's Versatile King Is Just Too Quick for the Cadets
description: After losing to Notre Dame and Air Force on consecutive Saturdays, Army could have used a breather today. Instead, it had to contend with a third straight top-25 team in Tulane.

title: Ethics of Research
description: Saying that he is ''deeply troubled'' by the creation of part-human, part-cow embryonic stem cells reported last week, President Clinton has directed the National Bioethics Advisory Commission to consider the implications of the research at its Tuesday meeting and report to him ''as soon as possible.'' Mr. Clinton also asked for a review of embryonic stem-cell research in general.

title: Protect the Artist
description: To the Editor:

title: An A-List Writer, Minus the Attitude
description: ASK a studio mogul, top producer or agent for the names of the superior screenwriters in Hollywood, and Steven Zaillian will be near the top of the list.

title: Playing God In the Garden
description: I always look to The Times to give me something new to worry about. This article certainly fills the bill. Monsanto is giving us a self-sterilizing seed! What happens when Monsanto goes out of the seed business or jacks up the price? Starvation, anyone?

title: BOOKEND; An Idea Whose Time Still Hasn't Come
description: I have spent the last four years on an all-consuming quest to find a topic on which I can write a book. Like a desperate love seeker who enters every supermarket or elevator with the hope of finding a future spouse amid the Muzak, I spend each waking moment of my life hoping to stumble across something that will merit 250 pages of nonfiction worthy of a Barnes & Noble window display. Over the years I've written tens of thousands of words that I believed would emerge as a proposal for the book that would transform my byline from ''freelance writer'' to ''author.'' I've hammered out sweeping generalizations about Gen X anomie, urban loneliness and Reagan-era adolescence. Shouting ''This is it!'' I've handed my agent multitudinous pages of unbearably dry ruminations on contemporary feminism, a meditation on my obsession with National Public Radio and, in a recent moment of derangement, a promise to go undercover as a flight attendant and report on the inside story of airline debauchery. These ideas are almost always instantly abandoned, either by virtue of advice from wise colleagues or, in the case of the flight-attendant career (I thought this one was so sure-fire that I went so far as to obtain an application from American Airlines), my realization that I was, in fact, afraid of flying.

title: H.M.O. Report Card
description: The Department of Health and Senior Services has issued its second annual report card on the biggest managed health care companies in the state. It rated 12 health maintenance organizations and 8 point-of-service plans, which allow members to get care outside the network at additional cost. The report rated them compared with other plans in the state.

title: Status is ... for Washington TV Pundits; The Last Word on Absolutely Anything
description: In the punditocracy's golden era, before all-news cable networks exploded onto the airwaves and robbed the pontification business of much of its cachet, the job of opinion-maker was considered serious and dignified. Then, Walter Lippmann was still more of a model for the aspiring pundit than Ralph Kramden. Television was not entirely shunned, but the written word counted for more than the clever quip. As recently as the early 1980's, television was seen as a means of increasing the visibility of one's newspaper or magazine column rather than the other way around.

title: Mixing Young and Old, Connecticut Rolls Again
description: Already ranked third in the country, Connecticut served notice this weekend that it might be better than advertised.

title: Fighting Over the Future of an American Arden
description: THE Bok Amphitheater here lies below the library, a Georgian brick building on Main Street. A graceful double flight of stairs leads down from the library to the amphitheater's lawn, green as the Emerald City of Oz and ringed by a tiered horseshoe of low stone terraces, its symmetry broken by huge mossy boulders. The open end of the horseshoe overlooks Camden harbor across a park sloping to the shore. Around the closed rim, trunks of birches tilt at bold white angles among stands of hemlock and black spruce.

title: Ho! Ho! Ho! Boohoo-hoo!
description: The holiday season seems to bring out the best and the worst in bosses. We've all heard stories about workers who are fired on Christmas Eve, but then again, Scrooge himself ended up giving the long-suffering Bob Cratchit a raise. What holiday horror stories have emerged from your workplace? Or, to give the management world's guardian angels their due, how have the holidays melted the coldest corporate hearts? Send your anecdotes to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: A Woman Whose Work Is Never Done
description: Hurry, Hurry, Mary Dear

title: Q and A
description: Sampling Beaujolais

title: YIPPIE DAYS
description: WENDY LAMB, a Manhattan book editor, wrote the Oct. 4 Soapbox essay, chronicling milestones of her life that occurred in Grand Central Terminal. She suggested that others record their memories of the place. The City section solicited ''most memorable moments'' and here are a few:

title: November 8-14; Where Walter Mitty Works Out
description: In Manhattan, where main street is Broadway and people get bored in a New York minute, acting out is the most popular new way to work out.

title: No Longer at Home Wherever
description: In his second novel, TURNING JAPANESE (Permanent Press, paper, $16), David Galef captures the allure and peril of living as an expatriate. And through the eyes of his young narrator, a 22-year-old aspiring writer named Cricket Collins, we see the experience not just for Cricket and his fellow Americans but also for those Britons and Australians who join them as English teachers in Japan, flocking to the Orient in search of an alternative to the traditional European adventure. It is the late 1970's, when life in Japan is particularly enticing to an aimless recent college graduate, and Cricket and his peers find the elegant beauty of the tea ceremony, the calming discipline of Aikido and the politeness of the Japanese people to be both alien and irresistible. But Galef adds a layer of complexity to this account of Cricket's adventures, revealing the vulnerability that may result from too rapid an effort to shed one's own cultural skin. When Cricket hooks up with a Japanese girlfriend, he hopes their relationship will increase his sense of well-being, making him feel more firmly established in her country. Not surprisingly, and much to his chagrin, his contentment is brief -- and is followed by a breakdown that leaves him weakened and shamed. In the months that follow, as Cricket must choose between returning to a homeland where he no longer truly feels at home and remaining in a place where he may never be truly accepted, Galef produces a chilling denouement for this nicely detailed exploration of cultural dislocation. Paula Friedman

title: Reading This Story Might Strain Your Eyes
description: F SCOTT FITZGERALD, the patron saint of rich, bored Jazz Age cosmopolites, looked back wistfully to the years before World War I, when, he said, Americans had not yet been ''corrupted by advertising.'' One can only wonder what he would say now, when the messages from Madison Avenue suddenly seem larded with cynicism.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Vigil in Westport

title: Sports of The Times; Another No. 23 Who Plays Like Mike
description: THE player they call Meek has apparently inherited another women's college basketball season. And if the locked-out men's professionals ever inspire David Stern to open his doors, there will, according to the leading indicators, be an abbreviated return engagement by the marketing machine named Mike.

title: Britain's Docusoaps Transfix a Nation Of Flies on the Wall
description: IN the last year or so, British television viewers have been introduced to a traffic warden who sadistically sings ''Another One Bites the Dust'' when he finds an illegally parked car. They have met a middle-aged woman who, having failed her driving test six times, spreads terror among the local populace as she doggedly continues with her driving lessons. And they have watched as an airline steward, asked by a passenger why you can't smoke the duty-free cigarettes you purchase on the plane, replies: ''You can buy condoms in Boots. Need I say more?''

title: What Triggers the Bloom of House Plants?
description: TOO often, gardeners complain that they cannot grow anything. Their plants do not bloom and they are tired of tossing out dead ones.

title: Robin Kiam, Jonathan Aviv
description: Robin Leslie Kiam, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor K. Kiam 2d of Palm Beach, Fla., was married last evening to Dr. Jonathan Enoch Aviv, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David G. Aviv of Las Vegas. Rabbi Marcello Bronstein officiated at 55 Wall Street in New York.

title: Rhapsody in Black And White
description: Long before Gershwin's travels to the Carolinas in the 1930's to absorb African-American music for his compositions in ''Porgy and Bess,'' he had the ''blues'' instilled in him in synagogues in the wailing sounds of the cantors of the Lower East Side. ''Rhapsody in Blue'' was written years before ''Porgy and Bess,'' and Gershwin's original intentions were to write for the Yiddish theater.

title: The Types and Uses of Wood Stain
description: MANY woodworkers frown upon the use of stain for coloring wood. They feel that it is too often used to disguise inferior and uninteresting wood (pine or poplar) to make it appear more like high-quality wood (walnut or mahogany). Still, many professional cabinet makers and furniture craftsmen find that there are a number of legitimate reasons to color wood with stain.

title: Correction
description: A film listing and a picture caption on Nov. 1 about the documentary ''A Place Called Chiapas'' misstated the year of a revolt by the Zapatista National Liberation Army in Mexico. It was in 1994, not 1974.

title: BACK HOME TO MOM
description: WENDY LAMB, a Manhattan book editor, wrote the Oct. 4 Soapbox essay, chronicling milestones of her life that occurred in Grand Central Terminal. She suggested that others record their memories of the place. The City section solicited ''most memorable moments'' and here are a few:

title: Who Is the Real Savage?
description: THE WILD BOY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORKOW, ALTHEA KLEIGER
description: BORKOW-Althea Kleiger. On November 12, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Ben A. Borkow. Devoted mother of Joan Cleveland, Dr. Stephen and Susan Borkow and Susan and Dr. Richard Ulin. Loving grandmother of David and Rae, Allan and Renee, John and Mary, Michael and his fiancee Dana Klein, and Alice and her fiance Dr. Michael De Billes. Great-grandmother of Curtis, Noah, Christine, Robert, Victoria and Sophie. Sister of Kate K. Gluck and the late Dr. Barnard Kleiger. Service Sunday, November 15, 1:45PM at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be sent to Alzheimer's Association of New York City, 420 Lexington Ave, S. 610, NYC 10170

title: On the Ice, Stones Skid and Brooms Sweep, as Curling Heats Up
description: Curling is similar to boccie or shuffleboard, except that it takes place on ice. Players slide 42-pound ''stones'' of polished granite from one end of a rink or frozen pond to the other, trying to make the stones end up in a target area painted on the ice and to knock their opponents' stones out.

title: Children's Books in Brief
description: Who ordered the

title: Status is ... for Arab Immigrants; Taking Care of the Folks Back Home
description: Every two or three months, Ali Alfatimi packs up some shirts, or blue jeans, or some vats of the honey he sells in his small Brooklyn store, and sends them to relatives back home in Yemen. Every month he sends them money -- even though he has a wife and five children to support. By doing so, he shows that he cares about his mother, his brothers and the other relatives he left behind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHN, AIMEE
description: CAHN-Aimee. Beloved wife of the late Aron Cahn, loving sister of the late Benola Schloss and the late Ruth Cornell. Good friend & loving aunt of Richard J. Schloss (Julia), dear great aunt of Reina Warren and Duncan Schloss. She had a great love for life that inspired many. She will be greatly missed. Memorial tribute on Monday, November 16, 12 noon at Shaaray Tefila, 79 St and 2nd Ave, NYC.

title: Status is ... for Evangelical Teen-Agers; Jewelry for Jesus
description: Teen status symbols are all about desperation: If I don't get a pair of big-cuffed jeans soon, everyone will make fun of me! I need that tummy tattoo or I'll die! For Christian teen-agers, the stakes are even higher: who wants to dress like Rod and Todd Flanders, Bart Simpson's dorky Christian next-door neighbors? To make Christianity cool, the key is to create something as simple and iconic as the cross, but with the secret-code quality of invisible ink. For many kids, W.W.J.D. merchandise fits the bill.

title: Four Who Flew Remember the Nest
description: I LOVE Long Island. I wanted to name my son either Peconic or Manhasset, after my two favorite bodies of water. I'm sure George will someday thank his father for talking me out of it. I love all of the bays and beaches of Long Island; my best childhood memories are all of the water: Damp and sandy breakfast cookouts with my family at Jones Beach; the scary thrill of swimming under the dock at our neighborhood beach on Manhasset Bay to look for eels; rooting my brother on to win the Snapper Derby on the Port Washington Town Dock; clamming with my sister and my grandparents on the sandbars off Robert Moses State Park; racing around Sands Point on hot summer days with my friends Emily and Amy, ditching our bikes to swim in the Long Island Sound any time we got hot; the weeks I spent with my friend Joni in Montauk the summer ''Jaws'' was released, the only time in my life I can remember not wanting to swim; bike trips all along the craggy North Shore to Kings Point, Lloyd's Neck and Sea Cliff; jogging near my grandparents' house on Shelter Island out onto Silver Beach, crunching on jingle shells and looking over Noyack Bay to Peconic Bay; reggae dancing at the Pridwin Hotel at the old Oyster Factory on the docks in Greenport; retracing the steps of the pirate Captain Kidd on Fishers Island; falling in love with my husband and spending weekends at his parents' place (''Clam-a-Lot'') in Mattituck, dancing to Bruce Springsteen on the jukebox at the Blue Top, the best potato farmer bar left on the North Fork.

title: Downtown Church Turns Neighborly
description: For more than 300 years, the Parish of Trinity Church, the landmark that sits at the head of Wall Street, has been a force in the development of the city.

title: Akhmatova Reads
description: To the Editor: Regarding Francine Prose's ''In St. Petersburg, the Sacred and the Profane'' (Oct. 11), in the final room at the Anna Akhmatova Museum on a small table stands a dual cassette recorder. I assumed it belonged to the staff. When the charming attendant approached me and offered it, I thought for a moment that this last room might be her personal garage sale.

title: In Middle East, a Hesitant Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Do Pet Pigs Belong in the Neighborhood?
description: THERE is no other word to describe it but surreal. To be seated in Dawn Kusznir's kitchen -- clean, bright, airy and perfectly average -- and to have her two Vietnamese potbellied pigs come trotting into the room certainly constitutes a bizarre experience.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Toyota Solara; Risk-Free Balm for Boomers
description: IT was last January at the Detroit auto show, and Toyota had just pulled the wraps off its Camry Solara. The gleaming coupe, yet unseen by the public, spun slowly on a turntable. But a glance over one's shoulder, across the convention center, found a strikingly similar car rotating on another turntable a couple of displays away. That coupe, a Honda Accord, was already for sale. Given the two cars' close resemblance, from the lines of their front ends to the flow of sheet metal along their sides, a casual observer could be forgiven for thinking these were two versions of the same car.

title: INSIDE
description: Indonesia Orders Crackdown

title: Culture Zone; Hauling Your Cool Around
description: I was big, bad and beautiful, cruising down Fifth Avenue at noon in a brand-new fire-engine-red Dodge Ram. Outside Bergdorf's and Bendel's, automotive drool syndrome was in full bloom. High fives, admiring stares, whistles of appreciation came my way. I was riding high on the wild side, and the fact that there was no gun rack on the back of the cab was irrelevant. As far as everyone was concerned, it might as well have been there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, GAD (GODL)
description: JACOBSON-Gad (Godl). Age 89 of Hallandale, FL on September 30. Beloved husband of Leah and father of Joel (Pauline Watona), Beryl (Roberta), Rose (Ronald Novak) and Fred (Beverly). Adoring grandfather of Daniel, Rebecca, Mara, Leila, Talia and Ezra and great-grandfather of Gareth, Zoe and Thomas. He loved literature and music and was devoted to social justice, Israel, and above all else to Yiddishkeit.

title: November 8-14; Israel Ratifies The Peace Accord
description: The Israeli Cabinet, after a two-week delay, ratified the Wye peace memorandum almost begrudgingly and with a string of riders attached.

title: An Immigrant's Vision Created Garden City
description: THE Hempstead Plains was a flat, treeless 12-mile tract stretching from New Hyde Park to Farmingdale when Alexander Turney Stewart acquired the pasture from the Town of Hempstead in 1869 for $55 an acre. Aside from a small cemetery, it was a wasteland. For Stewart, an Irish immigrant who became a multimillionaire merchant and founded the modern department store, the barren land was a blank canvas upon which he could build a city.

title: Commercial Property / 275 Seventh Avenue; A Medical Clinic Leases Lower Floors to Modernize
description: THE clinic in the sky is coming down closer to earth. For decades the Union Health Center has occupied six floors near the top of the 27-story building at 275 Seventh Avenue, between 25th and 26th Streets, in an area that is at the confluence of the Garment District and Chelsea.

title: Corrections
description: The On Washington column on page 40 of The Times Magazine today misspells the surname of a former Republican Senator from Michigan. He was Arthur Vandenberg, not Vandenburg.

title: Creator of the On-Line Swap Meet
description: WHAT really captivates him, Pierre Omidyar says, are computer-programming challenges. But he says he never expected to get rich tackling them, and recalls that most of his efforts to make money on them failed.

title: LEADING THE BLIND
description: WENDY LAMB, a Manhattan book editor, wrote the Oct. 4 Soapbox essay, chronicling milestones of her life that occurred in Grand Central Terminal. She suggested that others record their memories of the place. The City section solicited ''most memorable moments'' and here are a few:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  INDOVINO, PETER
description: INDOVINO-Peter. 1969-1997. Your absence has created such a void in our lives. We miss you. Love, Mom and Dad

title: Ethnic Albanians Recount Massacre of a Family in Kosovo
description: Some of the closest combat in the half year of the Kosovo conflict, to the point of fighting room to room and floor to floor, occurred near this village six weeks ago, in the days before 21 women, children and elderly members of the Delijaj clan were massacred by Serbian forces, their mutilated bodies left strewn on the forest floor.

title: Transforming Death's Wound: A Healing Art
description: IN the doorway of the room that houses ''The Letter Writing Project,'' a graceful, meditative installation by the 34-year-old Taiwan-born artist Lee Mingwei, you duck under a noren curtain. The noren -- a common feature in Japanese architecture -- is a translucent white scrim that lowers the height of the doorway by about a foot. Your head nods, your back bends, and suddenly you are bowing.

title: Rivals Say Tennessee Is Still the Team to Conquer
description: The beauty of sports is that no matter how unbeatable someone looks, there is no sure thing. The 49ers and the Packers lose. Tiger Woods and Martina Hingis lose. Later or maybe sooner, the Yankees and the Bulls will lose.

title: Big Turnout, Small Effort As Islanders Fall to Caps
description: The fans came back to Nassau Coliseum tonight, but they did not have much to cheer.

title: Rape Suspect In 4 Attacks Is in Custody
description: A man wanted in connection with four rapes at subway and bus stops in Brooklyn, has been found on Long Island, where he was arraigned yesterday on charges in two sex crimes there, the police said.

title: Margery Feinzig, Mark Califano
description: Margery Beth Feinzig, a daughter of Diane and David S. Feinzig of Newton, Mass., is to be married this evening to Mark Gerard Califano, a son of Trudy Kendrew of Washington and Joseph A. Califano Jr. of Roxbury, Conn. Rabbi Mark Newton will officiate at the Fairmont Copley Plaza Hotel in Boston.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: The Djinn in the Nightingale's Eye: Five Fairy Stories

title: AT THE MUSEUMS: NASSAU MUSEUM OF ART; Louis Comfort Tiffany
description: Once his contemporary, Thomas Edison, invented the electric light bulb, Louis Comfort Tiffany no longer had to depend on sunlight to create magic with illuminated glass. Hence, the inimitable Tiffany lamp from the master of the art of light. Created around 1900, the Peacock lampshade is a swirl of green, orange, yellow and blue peacock feathers with the quills etched in lead on a graceful base. In the reproduction, like the original, each piece of glass was hand cut and joined together with copper foil. The original is at the Nassau County Museum of Art's ''Louis Comfort Tiffany and Stanford White and Their Circle'' show. The copy is $220 in the gift shop. Nassau County Museum of Art, 1 Museum Drive, Roslyn Harbor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROHAN, JOHN J.
description: ROHAN-John J. Age 83, of Siesta Key, FL, died November 12, 1998. John was born in NYC, September 12, 1915, and moved to Florida from Garden City, LI, 16 years ago. He retired as President of J. F. Jelenko and Co., a division of Pennwalt. He had served as an Army Captain in WW II and was a member of the 6th Port. Survivors include his wife Rita, his five sons, Patrick, John, Vincent, Robert and James; his daughters-in-law Mary and Yuko, his sister Marie, his sister-in-law Agnes and his grandchildren Mary, John, Scott, Sean and Misa. Funeral services were held in Florida. Memorial donations may be made to Kinnick Falls Alcohol and Drug Abuse Services, 900 South Orange St, River Falls, WI 54022.

title: Tax Delinquents
description: For the first time in four years, Mount Vernon will foreclose on tax-delinquent properties, Mayor Ernest D. Davis said last week. He said it was necessary for the city to increase revenue and reclaim abandoned buildings. The last foreclosures were in 1994. By 1997, Mount Vernon's tax-collection rates had dropped to 93 percent.

title: EARLY RETURNS POINT TO THE CARDINAL
description: Joe Drapt chooses 16 teams with the weapons and the nerve to make a run at the Final Four, which will be at Tropicana Field in St. Petersburg, Fla. (Last season's record in parentheses.)

title: Jury Awards $12.7 Million In Disabling Subway Accident
description: Seven years after it happened, Francisco Martinez Jr. has no memory of the freak subway accident that almost cost him his life and left him disabled. At the time, he was only 20 months old.

title: Hit Rapper Dreams of Becoming Hip Hoop Artist
description: He started the game as a thoroughly anonymous celebrity. By the end of the night, he was perhaps the richest bench warmer ever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRONICH, SILVIA LESSER
description: GRONICH-Silvia Lesser. Age 88, on November 13, 1998. Adored wife of the late Maxwell A. Gronich. Cherished mother and loving friend to Susan and Theodore. She was a classy lady.

title: F.B.I. Slows, but Hasn't Stopped, Wily Safecrackers
description: SLOWLY but surely, the office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation here has been chipping away at a well-organized, highly disciplined group of commercial safe burglars, based in the Bronx and southern Westchester, which has been linked to hundreds of crimes around the country.

title: Take a Left Onto Nowhere Street
description: IT'S a fair bet that if you have been at the mercy of homemade directions to ''our place'' more than once or twice, you have also gotten lost. When this happens, your first impulse is to blame your own stupidity. Forget that. It's their fault -- that sweet old guy, that nice young couple who invited you for dinner or the weekend have given you the wrong directions. Just one error can keep you driving back and forth over the same stretch of alien turf for hours, switching among panic, frustration and fury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, ELSIE
description: SUSSMAN-Elsie. We mourn the loss of our grandmother and great-grandmother. Rest in peace. Larry, Michael (Robin), Adam and Zachary Kampf

title: Never Underestimate the Power of a Puff
description: It's Townsville. And a country-fed and furry villain named Fuzzy Lumpkins is on a rampage. Using his meat ray, he is quickly turning the city's buildings into giant slabs of beef and pork. Who shows up to fight? Not Batman, not Superman, but the Powerpuff Girls, three pre-school-age heroines with an array of superpowers, large doe eyes and heads shaped like, you guessed it, powder puffs.

title: Tuggle and Falcons Reach New Heights
description: Lean has not made Jessie Tuggle mean. His last 11 seasons as middle linebacker for the Atlanta Falcons have been so lean. A mere 58 Falcons victories, a lousy 113 Falcons defeats. The playoffs? Two seasons in, nine seasons out.

title: Children's Books in Brief
description: YOU CAN'T TAKE A BALLOON INTO THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM

title: Getting to Know the Serious Peggy Guggenheim
description: DAFFY DUCK dressed in slinky silk: the image of Peggy Guggenheim as glamorous but lightweight -- and oversexed -- has not faded since her death in 1979. The fact that she was one of the great patron-collectors of contemporary art is buried under a mountain of gold-spangled gossip. Yes, she could seem like a ditzy duck, but Guggenheim was also an art-world swan. Her early support of Jackson Pollock -- in the 1940's she owned 28 of his works -- was crucial. ''She gave first showings to more serious new artists than anyone else in the country,'' the critic Clement Greenberg wrote.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKINSON, ANNE
description: PARKINSON-Anne. Died in peace with dignity and serenity on November 6. Loving mother of Tony, Nina, Michael, and Peter. Grandmother of Stephanie, Dana and Troup and great-grandmother of Nick. Until we meet again. Donations in her memory can be made to the Central Park Conservancy.

title: Voice of Inexperience
description: He will tell you that the expectations will not bother him, that he can handle the burden placed on his slender shoulders, shoulders that, up close, are clearly those of a freshman. But when Erick Barkley launched his first shot of the preseason, his first as a starting point guard for the St. John's Red Storm, the 3-point attempt left his hands a bit too quickly, even though no defender was near him.

title: Beaujolais, Italian Style
description: Crave total fruit, all the time? First, savor - no, slurp - a northern Italian version of Beaujolais nouveau, Cavit's vivacious '98 Terrazze della Luna Novello, a red nosh made from the teroldego grape. It's $7 at Pete Milano's Wines and Liquors, 1531 Forest Avenue, Port Richmond, Staten Island, and is widely available.

title: Even the Rich Can Suffer From Income Inequality
description: THE trend is painfully evident in the statistics. Over the last quarter century, the incomes of millions of Americans have grown farther apart, so much so that a phrase, income inequality, has been coined to describe what has happened. Income inequality has persisted, undented so far, through the economic expansion of the 1990's. Now social scientists are beginning to assess the damage that it inflicts on Americans -- the rich as well as the much less rich -- in their daily lives.

title: Eloise Is Ready to Skip Out of Her Creator's Shadow
description: THE only good author is a dead author,'' says a sign hanging in the office of a Manhattan publishing house, an old joke born of the squabbles between writers and publishers. So what was the reaction at the offices of another publisher, Simon & Schuster, when one of its most difficult authors, Kay Thompson, died in July in her 90's?

title: Joining Helping Hands on the Internet
description: An accountant in Clifton wants to volunteer his services to a good cause, but isn't certain which of the thousands of nonprofit groups and service agencies in New Jersey can best use them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHMAN, SIDNEY
description: LEHMAN-Sidney. The Chairman, the Board of Trustees, and the Staff of the Brooklyn Museum of Art record with deep sorrow the passing of Sidney Lehman and extend their deepest sympathies to his beloved family: his son Museum Director Arnold L. Lehman and daughter-in-law Pamela Gimbel Lehman; grandson Nicholas and his wife Tracy; and to grandson Zachary, his wife Amy, and their son Mitchell. Sidney Lehman, husband of the late Henrietta Lehman, was 89 years old at the time of his death. He lived until recently in Hollywood, FL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONOVAN BUTLER, MARION
description: DONOVAN BUTLER - Marion. Passionate inventor, died November 4, at Lenox Hill Hospital, NYC. Marion O'Brien, born October 15, 1917, in South Bend, Indiana. Beloved wife of John F. Butler who died July 22, 1998. Awarded dozens of patents in a 60 year career devoted to solving practical problems in personal health and household and financial conveniences, and industrial design. Master Degree, Yale University Architecture School, 1958; B.A., Rosemont College, PA, 1939. Active member of Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club Women's Committee. Loving mother of Christine Donovan, NYC; Sharon Donovan Dodd, New Orleans; Dr. James F. Donovan, Jr., Oklahoma City; and grandmother of Laura O'Brien Dodd, Edward Seamus and William Miles Donovan. Memorial Mass will be given on December 7, 1998, at 10:30 AM, at St. Jean Baptiste Catholic Church, Lexington Avenue at 76th Street.

title: AT THE MUSEUMS: VANDERBILT MUSEUM; 'Votes for Women'
description: Alva Vanderbilt Belmont -- who would visit Eagle's Nest, her son William K. Vanderbilt II's 24-room summer home overlooking Northport harbor -- became a militant suffragette after she divorced his father, William K. Vanderbilt, for his infidelities.

title: POSTINGS: Historic Districts Council's Annual Preservation Award; Honoring a Landmarks Lion
description: ''Landmarks Lion'' is the name of the Historic Districts Council's annual award to devoted, aggressive preservationists. In its choice of James Marston Fitch this year, the council found a lion with a considerable mane and formidable roar.

title: U.S. Says It Was Just Hours Away From Starting Attack Against Iraq
description: The United States had prepared to begin a huge campaign of air strikes on Iraq today, but called off the attack after a last-minute flurry of diplomatic activity brought an Iraqi announcement that it would allow United Nations weapons inspectors to resume their work, Clinton Administration officials said.

title: Contributors
description: Sherman Alexie, a novelist, is the author most recently of ''Indian Killer.''

title: McGwire And Sosa, Swinging Sound And Bats
description: THOUGH he has been a professional musician for 25 years, Clark Eno was still amazed when he heard his single ''King of Swing'' on television. The swing song honors this summer's home run race between Mark McGwire, a St. Louis Cardinal, and Sammy Sosa, a Chicago Cub, and has received national attention. ''The feeling was incomparable,'' he said.

title: Backing Off (a Little)
description: Less than a week before he is scheduled to testify before the House Judiciary Committee, Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, has apparently abandoned his inquiry into the President's sex life, the portion of his investigation that repulsed most Americans.

title: Scheherazade in Vienna
description: THE TALE OF THE 1002ND NIGHT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, BEATRICE
description: HECHT-Beatrice. Wife of recently deceased James, died Wednesday afternoon while residing at her son's home in Greenwich, Ct. Born, raised, and until recently, living on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. She is survived by her 2 sons, David Hecht and his wife Marie of Greenwich, Ct, Arnold Hecht and his wife Neva of Virginia Beach, Va. She will be sorely missed by her 7 grandchildren and 1 great grandchild. Graveside services will be Sunday, November 15, 1998 at 12:30PM at the Mt Hebron Cemetery in Flushing, NY.

title: A Distancing Stance
description: To the Editor:

title: Status is ... for Psychiatrists; Really Getting Inside a Head
description: Twenty-five years ago, an acclaimed psychiatrist was a master clinician, someone who worked in a mental hospital and was draped in a mantle of perspicacity and humility. His tools (less often hers) consisted of a way with patients, an ability to teach and a distinctive turn of mind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STORCH, MARCIA M.D.
description: STORCH-Marcia M.D. Died November 9, 1998 of ovarian cancer, in Tenants Harbor, Maine, cared for by her beloved partner Jeanne Hewitt. For a generation of women, via her practice and her public, TV and radio appearances, she destroyed myth and introduced dignity and openness into the GYN treatment room. She remained to the very end an always-current repository of medical research, practice and referral. In addition to Jeannie, she is survived by hundreds, if not thousands, of friends and former patients who survived because of her. We grieve. Edie Windsor and Thea Spyer

title: Art to Go, an Idea Whose Time May Have Come
description: NORMALLY when you're invited to join in an experiment thought up by an Ivy League professor, you expect to be ingesting radioactive isotopes, or maybe racing a genetically altered mouse through a maze. What you don't expect is something involving Minotaurs, hors d'oeuvres and a Yankee Doodle doorbell.

title: In Self-Defense
description: Ossining Village officials are seeking a new law to protect themselves from personal liability in civil rights cases. ''We want our officials to be free to act with the best interests of the village in mind and not in fear of punitive damages,'' Penny Markowitz-Moses, a member of the village board of trustees, said last week. Other communities that have enacted similar laws include Croton-on-Hudson and Scarsdale.

title: Seized by Fame, And Jarred by It
description: ''CAN I have your autograph?''

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Teen-Ager Is Charged In Halloween Slaying
description: A Brooklyn teen-ager has been charged with the murder of a man shot on Halloween night as he drove his girlfriend and her 9-year-old son home from a children's party in the Bronx, the police said.

title: Susannah Baruch And Seth Green
description: Susannah Abigail Baruch, the daughter of Franklin Baruch of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Grace Baruch, is to be married today to Seth Green, the son of Prof. Judy Green and Prof. Paul Green of Silver Spring, Md. Rabbi Arthur Blecher is to officiate at the Car Barn, a party space in Washington.

title: Jennifer Delfoe, Chris Fleissner
description: Jennifer Marie Delfoe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Delfoe 3d of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Christian Fleissner 5th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fleissner 4th of Summit, N.J. Msgr. Charles Ribaudo performed the ceremony at St. Dominic's Chapel in Oyster Bay, N.Y.

title: Brazilian Team Defeats D.C. United
description: Felipe's goal in the 69th minute gave the Brazilian club Vasco da Gama a 1-0 victory over D.C. United last night in the first leg of the Interamerican Cup in Washington. United is the first U.S. team to play in the annual two-leg championship between the CONCACAF and South America's club champions.

title: Life Imitates Art in 'Music Man'
description: IN Kurt Vonnegut Jr.'s short story ''Who Am I This Time?'' the lead character in a community production is a clerk in the local hardware store. In the community production of ''The Music Man'' here, the lead character owns a hardware store.

title: Welding Worlds Together
description: OUTSIDE Isaac Witkin's turn-of-the-century house here in South Jersey is a 22-acre blueberry farm where Mennonites from Pennsylvania can be seen picking fruit every summer and human-scaled metal sculptures dot the land. Inside is a collection of African tribal sculptures that provides a direct link to his native South Africa.

title: Status is ... for Chicago Sports Aficionados; Watching the Cubs From the Roof of 1038 Waveland Avenue
description: They used to be the cheap seats. A couple of guys would scrabble up a ladder to the roof of their apartment building on a sultry sweet Chicago summer afternoon. They'd pop open a beer or two and settle in for a serendipitous view. There, just across the street, was Wrigley Field, home of the heartbreakingly hapless Chicago Cubs. And from the asphalt rooftops of those run-down North Side three-flats and graystones, a faithful fan could see all the action.

title: Julia Griner, Pino Ficara
description: Julia Louise Griner, a daughter of Jane and Norman Griner of New York, was married last evening to Giuseppe Ficara, the son of Concetta and Santo Ficara of Milan, Italy. The Rev. James Burns performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: The Types of Wood Stains, and Their Uses
description: MANY woodworkers frown on the use of stain for coloring wood. They feel that it is too often used to disguise inferior and uninteresting wood (pine or poplar) to make it appear more like high-quality wood (walnut or mahogany). Still, many professional cabinetmakers and furniture craftsmen find there are a number of legitimate reasons to color wood with stain.

title: Status is ... for Retirement-villagers; A (Still!) Valid Driver's License
description: In retirement communities, everyone starts over. Where you went to school, what job you held, the community and professional recognition you may have acquired -- these are the things you can't take with you. So when my 77-year-old father, Irving Rimer, and my mother, Joan, moved from Pennsylvania to a retirement community in North Carolina six years ago, he started cramming for the most important test of his new life: his driver's exam. He was more scared of failing, he confided in me, than he was when he was 16 and took it for the first time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIGGS, THOMAS JEFFRIES, JR.
description: RIGGS-Thomas Jeffries, Jr. On November 5, 1998 at age 82. The husband of 50 years to Virginia Griggs Riggs. He was a decorated Veteran of W.W. II, serving as Commander of the 81st Combat Engineers Battalion of the 106th Infantry in the Battle of the Bulge. Colonel Riggs was central in the battle of St. Vith. His heroics in this battle earned him a Silver Star, Purple Heart and Croix de Guerre (Belgium, France). His battalion received a Presidential Unit Citation for its extraordinary heroism, gallantry & determination. He was a prisoner of war who escaped to return to his troops. After leaving the military, he was President of F.L. Jacobs in Detroit, Michigan, and Executive Vice President of Gabriel Company in Cleveland. He moved to Providence, RI in 1960 as a group Vice President of Textron, Inc. He lived in Providence, RI until his death. Among his honors, he was the 1989 Varsity I-Man of the Year at his alma mater, University of Illinois and Chairman of the National Small Business Advisory Council. He is survived by his wife Virginia, his six children and two stepchildren. He was buried with full military honors at Arlington National Cemetery on November 10, 1998. A memorial service was held in Providence on November 12, 1998.

title: A Quieter Isle of Wight
description: IN late fall, many British seaside resort towns have a haunting charm. In the damp chill of early dusk, a festive air lingers in the scattered lights of a few year-round restaurants, the muted clamor of Star Wars games from an open arcade, the glimmer of Victorian lamps over a deserted boardwalk. Alluring signs -- ''Fudge and Salt Taffy,'' ''Postcards, Souvenirs, Maps'' -- still hang above closed shops. Shuttered and secluded, these towns have a hushed feeling, as if they were waiting for something to happen. In the lull between mellow autumn and the battering of winter storms, they offer a brief sense of suspended time.

title: U.S. REJECTS PLAN
description: Faced with an imminent American military attack, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq made a show of backing down today, saying in a letter to the United Nations that his Government would resume full cooperation with arms inspectors.

title: Finally, a Dandy of a 'Pimpernel'
description: NOT in my memory has Broadway witnessed a resurrection comparable to the one on view at the 1,700-seat Minskoff Theater where, one year ago, the critical consensus was that the musical adaptation of ''The Scarlet Pimpernel'' was DOA. You might have expected that the show, with book and lyrics by Nan Knighton and music by Frank Wildhorn, would have been interred with dignity, then forgotten. But no.

title: Report Unscrambles Some of Air Fare Puzzle
description: In the first three months of this year, the 7,690 passengers who flew from Cincinnati to New York on Continental Airlines paid an average fare of $255 one way. But few if any passengers paid the average fare. In fact, 8 percent of them paid $51 to $75, and 26 percent paid $426 to $450.

title: Less Chopin's Opposite Than His Complement
description: GARRICK OHLSSON is a big American pianist with a sheaf of glowing reviews that might not squeeze into the airport sizer for carry-on luggage. He plays Mozart, Brahms, Grieg, Rachmaninoff and Gershwin with whatever it takes to grace a particular piece: drop-dead evenness, slam-dunk bravura, or sweet sensitivity and chamber music courtesy. Yet there is still room on his capacious musical plate for more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENSER, RUTH
description: GENSER-Ruth. Cherished and adoring wife for fifty years of the late Sidney (died October 8, 1998). Beloved and devoted mother of Barbara Zinn Moore (Jay). Services Sunday 12:30PM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Breast Cancer Research Foundation, 767 Fifth Ave, Ste 4600, NY, NY 10153

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: LARRY HOLMES: AGAINST THE ODDS

title: Coaches Try To Keep Up With Game
description: There are enough familiar schools at the top of the preseason men's polls (Duke, Connecticut) to comfort college basketball aficionados. There are some names on the all-America lists (Elton Brand, Richard Hamilton) that promise electrifying drama as the season arcs toward one more show-stopping national tournament.

title: The War Over Bluefin Tuna Limits
description: For more than two decades, the Atlantic bluefin tuna fishery has been one of the most hotly debated fisheries in the world. As the annual meeting of the International Convention for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas begins today in Santiago de Compostela, Spain, contention is rising over such issues as quota reductions and a lack of compliance with existing agreements. According to United States delegates, American fishermen are shouldering the brunt of the conservation effort, while European nations are cashing in on the Atlantic bluefin fishery.

title: Grrrrr, Grrrrr, Grrrrr
description: CIRCLE DOGS

title: Getting In
description: Just think of the graveyard gates as the last velvet rope. And think of the mausoleum as the last V.I.P. room the fabulous will ever enter. And think of Tyler Cassity as the cemetery set's Steve Rubell, who keeps the list of those who have been admitted to rub elbows with the famous -- in perpetuity. Finally, someone is creating a home for those who are, literally, terminally trendy.

title: Romance With the Sun as a Backdrop
description: ON a late September Saturday, the names ''Suze and Marcel'' were foot-stamped in large letters on the sand along the shore-front of the Crescent Beach Club in Bayville. Nearby, a white-haired photographer prepared to take photographs of a wedding party that, besides the traditionally dressed bride and groom, included several bridesmaids in fashionable black gowns and tiny flower girls in billowing white dresses.

title: Some Legal History Still Being Overturned
description: Some artists who posted signs on city lampposts in August, documenting often hard-fought rights cases in the city during the last 50 years, have encountered their own legal struggles, first in getting their signs up, now in keeping them up.

title: Barbara Thornton, 48, Singer Who Championed Medieval Music
description: Barbara Thornton, a singer and musicologist who, with Benjamin Bagby, founded and directed Sequentia, the medieval music ensemble, died last Sunday at the Caritas hospice in Cologne, Germany. She was 48 and lived in Cologne.

title: Trouble With Words
description: To the Editor:

title: Streetscapes / The Emmanuel Baptist Church in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn; An Offshoot Founded by an Offended Millionaire
description: THE 1887 Emmanuel Baptist Church, at 279 Lafayette Avenue in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn, has one of New York's most spectacular church interiors, a rich mixture of stained glass, wood and elaborate stencilwork. Early next year the church, whose congregation has changed over the years from white to predominantly black, will begin to restore its interior, with an African accent.

title: Our Towns; A Spoonful Of Training For the Nanny
description: MARIE SCHWARTZ is a working mom. When she comes home from her day as a marketing executive, she wants to spend time with her children.

title: E.T.
description: PROBABILITY 1Why There Must Be Intelligent Life in the Universe.By Amir D. Aczel.230 pp. New York:Harcourt Brace & Company. $22.

title: Free Fall in the Financial District
description: They call it getting ''whacked'' -- mob talk for a contract killing -- which nicely describes the psychological violence occurring on Wall Street these days. One day you're making millions; the next day you're being called into your boss's office and told you've got the afternoon to clear out. A secretary comes in to make sure that your confidential files (those secrets you might share with competitors) are thrown out. During monster lay-offs, like those across the industry in the early 90's, dumpsters littered the halls.

title: Musical Theater in the Round
description: It's not every day that a potentially definitive recording of a legendary Broadway musical comes out of New Jersey. But there it is, now availabe on CD: the Paper Mill Playhouse production of ''Follies,'' the 1971 show by Stephen Sondheim and the late James Goldman about a reunion of aging former show-girls, their lives and their regrets. Billed as ''The Complete Recording,'' the two-CD set is in fact a good deal more complete than the several previous recordings of the score. An appendix after the finale of the show as presented in Millburn last spring includes eight numbers cut from various productions of the show (although two from the 1987 London production are still unaccounted for), sung by the Paper Mill cast members and recorded under Mr. Sondheim's acute ear. Liner notes include full lyrics and three short essays, and the cover art faithfully depicts the Millburn cast, right down to Ann Miller in her slit-to-the-thigh blue-sequined sheath. ''Follies,'' released by TVT Soundtrax, has a suggested list price of $25.98 but can be found for less in record stores.

title: Deeds Delayed, Loans Lost
description: In a room inside the Essex County Hall of Records, stacks of boxes are filled with unopened envelopes containing property deeds and checks covering recording fees that officials say easily total hundreds of thousands of dollars. For those trying to make the most of low interest rates by buying a hew home or refinancing their old one, the ''unopened'' part has left them furious, and maybe poorer.

title: Torch Bearers
description: Twenty-five years ago, self-expression through clothes was at its peak; today it is a rarity. At the recent Paris collections, a few people boldly carried the torch, like Anna Piaggi (top), an editor at Italian Vogue, and Isabella Blow (far left), a London stylist. In New York, a woman and baby (right) stood out as beacons of individualism.

title: THE WAY TO SUMMER CAMP
description: WENDY LAMB, a Manhattan book editor, wrote the Oct. 4 Soapbox essay, chronicling milestones of her life that occurred in Grand Central Terminal. She suggested that others record their memories of the place. The City section solicited ''most memorable moments'' and here are a few:

title: It's Cold, but Island's Bounty Still Fits the Bill
description: THE glory days of the Island's bounty arrive in summer and early fall, but the culinary traditions, some centuries-old, take hold as the leaves fall and fields turn pale with frost.

title: In the Trade Wars, Self-Interest Is All
description: Is what's good for the banana good for the steel? Not to the Clinton Administration. In a space of 24 hours, it threatened to slap 100 percent tariffs on European wines, cheeses and other products unless the European Union scrapped its restrictions on low-cost bananas shipped there by American companies, and then turned around and warned that it would not tolerate the ''flooding of our market'' with low-cost steel and other goods from Asia and Russia.

title: Rhapsody in Black And White
description: It is ironic that Herbie Hancock, a musician whose indifference to ''the big blur of those guys who wrote the standards'' chooses to ''illuminate the cultural range of Gershwin's music'' on his new record (David Hajdu, Oct. 25). It is ironic because Gershwin is part of that ''big blur.'' The milieu in which Gershwin developed is also the milieu in which Irving Berlin, a Russian immigrant, discovered ragtime; Jerome Kern, an exponent of English operetta, helped invent American musical comedy; Harold Arlen, the son of a Jewish cantor, wrote jazz music for the Cotton Club, along with Duke Ellington.

title: Stranger in Town
description: William Inge's PICNIC (1955) toes the mark as a study of a young drifter (William Holden, above with Kim Novak) and his effect on a Kansas community. The story plays out a little better spread across neighbrohood fields and silos - a background panorama that the stage play did not have. Kim Novak, as a local beauty who absconds with the drifter, is not quite convincing. Neither is the premise of the play, but a good cast and director make the picture work. Rosalind Russell, who received top billing, does well as a repressed schoolteacher, and the other cast members, including Cliff Robertson in his film debut, and Arthur O'Connell, respond admirably to Joshua Logan's direction - Saturday at 8 P.M. on TCM.

title: Thousands of Ordinary Lives
description: THERE ONCE WAS A WORLD

title: Playing God In the Garden
description: The Mormon farmer who feels corporate America's noose around his neck, the potato grower who knows better than to eat his own potatoes -- these people have a story to tell.

title: A Really Old Mill
description: To the Editor: Thank you for spotlighting Hartford and its suburbs, where I have enjoyed living for many years (''What's Doing in Hartford,' Oct. 11). Since you recommended one restaurant in a historic grist mill, I would like to suggest another. The Hop Brook Tavern, 77 West Street, Simsbury, is a beautifully restored mill dating from 1680 on a picturesque site. The food is delicious, too. MARY JANE SPRINGMAN

title: BUSINESS: DIARY
description: Farmers' options shrank by one when Cargill announced a deal to buy the grain operations of its chief rival, Continental Grain. Combined, the companies handle more than a third of the nation's grain exports and competed head to head to buy farmers' crops in much of the Midwest. . . . Texaco, whose profits are down sharply because of low oil prices, said it would cut costs by $200 million a year and shed 1,000 workers from its exploration unit. . . . State Farm Insurance won regulators' permission to use its network of agents to sell banking products like car loans, mortgages and certificates of deposit. . . . Monsanto announced a restructuring plan and layoffs intended to raise $5 billion. Analysts said the company found itself short of cash after a planned merger with American Home Products fell apart last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKMAN, ESTELLE
description: DICKMAN-Estelle. On November 14, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Irving, devoted mother of Lewis and Erwin, cherished grandmother of Roni, Alyse, Paul, Felicia, Randi and Marah, adored greatgrandmother of Michael and Melissa. Services on Sunday, November 15, 1998, 11:30 AM, at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer, 114-03 Queens Blvd, at 76th Rd, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Death in Surgery Reveals Troubled Practice and Lax Hospital
description: Lisa Smart's presence on the operating table at Beth Israel Medical Center on a Friday afternoon last November began in an utterly unremarkable way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, IVAN
description: SHAPIRO-Ivan. On November 5, 1998 at age 70 after a long illness. Beloved husband of Maria. Proud father of Lisa J. Kubiske and Alex Shapiro. A prominent real estate attorney, civic leader and civil libertarian, Ivan inspired those who knew him. His commitment to ethical and moral issues and to solving social problems are evident in his years of Board membership for NARAL, Center for Reproductive and Sexual Health, the New York Civil Liberties Union and Asia Watch. He served as President and Board member of the Ethical Society of New York and Chairman of the Ethical Culture Schools. His strong interest in New York City was shown in his membership on the Board of the Graduate School and University Center of City University of New York and on the Board of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation. He served as President of the Board of Urban Pathways, which named a residence for homeless people after him in 1996. A memorial service will be held on Monday, November 16th, 11AM at New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64 Street, New York, NY.

title: Playing God In the Garden
description: Michael Pollan's article reveals a biotech industry every bit as clever in the political arena as in the laboratory (Oct. 25). What a wondrous land of legislative newspeak and doublethink we encounter, as your writer makes the rounds of F.D.A. and E.P.A. offices seeking to find out why the labeling of Monsanto's New Leaf Superior potatoes gives no indication that they are genetically engineered or that the potatoes contain an insecticide. There is something wildly comic, yet tragic, about the results of the so carefully engineered rules and guidelines he bumps into, summarized by the boffo conclusion that gives the chemical industry what it wants: the F.D.A., presumably with straight face, does not regard the Bt potato as a food. The potato developed, raised, marketed, purchased, prepared and eaten as a potato is not a potato.

title: THE CHALLENGE OF TENNESSEE MOUNTAIN
description: Frank Litsky chooses 16 teams that might have what it takes to reach the women's Final Four at the San Jose Arena next March. (Last season's record in parentheses.)

title: Insurance Shortcuts, On Line
description: DURING a lunch break at work this summer, Allen Crane tapped into the Internet on his desktop computer, looking for life insurance.

title: Swept Away by a Show of Beauty
description: RIGHT now, the New Britain Museum of American Art, a large but plain-spoken converted house, and the Bellagio, the $1.8 billion casino cum art gallery that just opened in Las Vegas, each have a share of Dale Chihuly.

title: Different Boardwalks, Different Beaches
description: IN every career there is a word that sets the heart atingle. For Joseph Lescinski it is ipe. Or more precisely, ''ipe bethabera'' (pronounced ip-PAY beth-a-BEAR-a). Mr. Lescinski is the Superintendent of Jones Beach State Park, as well as the director of waterfront state parks on Long Island. Ipe is a Brazilian hardwood that has just started to be used on boardwalks.

title: The Long Life of Old Westbury Gardens
description: THIS was just a place where we lived -- this was home.''
