So says Peggy Phipps Boegner, 92 years old and radiantly beautiful with baby blue eyes, porcelain skin and silvery white hair, as she sits in the west porch of the 66-room mansion in which she was raised. Looking out on the 135-year-old beech tree just outside the floor-to-ceiling windows, and out on the breathtaking vistas of what is now known as Old Westbury Gardens, Mrs. Boegner reminisces about the past and her life in Westbury House.

title: House Proud
description: Not so long ago, it didn't take much to impress the neighbors: all you had to do was build a Florida room or plot a pool in the backyard. Now, such amenities have become commonplace -- forcing status-seeking suburbanites to embrace the grandiose.

title: Status is ... for Hollywood Deal Makers; Making Them Come to You
description: Status in the entertainment business is measured by who will get in their cars and drive. Since the Kingdom of Hollywood encompasses more than 400 square miles -- cutting a swath from Burbank to the Pacific Ocean -- how far an executive/writer/producer/ agent will ''travel,'' and for whom, usually reveals his place in the hierarchy.

title: Ivan Shapiro, An Advocate On Social Issues
description: Ivan Shapiro, a real estate lawyer and former president of the Ethical Culture Society, who was also a leader in organizations concerned with civil liberties and the homeless, died Nov. 5. He was 69 and lived on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: City's Perverse Welfare Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Insider Buying: Beyond The Spin
description: Delivering its third-quarter results 10 days ago, the management of CNA Financial, a large Chicago company that sells life, property and casualty insurance, had bad news and good news.

title: Miss. Loves Nev.
description: THE SCRAMBLED STATES OF AMERICA

title: A Third-Period Collapse Spells Doom for the Devils
description: After playing the Flyers even for the first two periods, the Devils collapsed in the third, allowing five goals. It was their worst defeat of the season, a 6-1 thrashing at the First Union Center that ended the Flyers' seven-game streak without a victory.

title: Ideas & Trends; Where The F.B.I. Fears To Tread
description: IN the aftermath of last month's deadly sniper attack on an obstetrician in upstate New York, Attorney General Janet Reno announced last week that she was setting up a new investigative unit to examine the possibility that the doctor was the victim of a broader anti-abortion plot.

title: ALL TOO GRAND
description: WENDY LAMB, a Manhattan book editor, wrote the Oct. 4 Soapbox essay, chronicling milestones of her life that occurred in Grand Central Terminal. She suggested that others record their memories of the place. The City section solicited ''most memorable moments'' and here are a few:

title: In Vermont, More Skier Accommodations
description: VISITORS to the ski regions of Vermont this winter will find more accommodations and -- for those considering the purchase of a newly built vacation home -- higher prices than ever before.

title: Possible Neglect
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: SAVAGE LIFEBy James Rogers.Serpent's Tail, paper, $12.99.

title: He Made His Point, Whatever It Was
description: Mutual fund shareholders keep a sharp eye on managers for ''style drift'' -- straying outside stated investing practices -- but rarely has a manager's personal style drifted as far as Peter Young's. Mr. Young, 40, a former manager of several Morgan Grenfell mutual funds, showed up in a London court last week dressed as a woman.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: NO SAFE PLACE

title: The Last Roundup
description: THE RIVER WARREN

title: Status is ... for Navy Fighter Pilots; An Air-to-Air Kill
description: Among United States Navy fighter pilots, there are many ways to separate star pilots from the merely great. Who bombs targets most accurately? Which flier in an 18-pilot squadron can land on a moving aircraft carrier most gracefully -- in the dark? But for the Navy's 600 fighter pilots, one achievement bests all others, even rank.

title: HOLIDAY FILMS; The Race Is On For Award Givers And Award Getters
description: AS every devout moviegoer knows, we are now approaching the season of excess. These final weeks of the year occasion a tidal wave of new pictures, followed soon after by an avalanche of awards. We're not just talking Oscars here. Oscar, of course, is the royal prince of prizes. Before that epic March 21 event seizes the world's attention, those who find eternal pleasure in any awards ceremony can look forward to Golden Globes and Golden Apples and Golden Satellites and Golden Popcorn Buckets, to name a few of the honors awaiting the women and men judged the most deserving talents of the big screen.

title: AT THE MUSEUMS: GUILD HALL; Schnabel in a Poster Box
description: Attention, bargain hunters. For practically less than the price of framing, it is possible to form a collection by the artists of the East End by rifling through the poster box at Guild Hall's museum shop.

title: EZ-Pass Makes Its Debut On Atlantic City Expressway
description: With the exception of mixed-up signs, the new EZ-Pass automatic toll collection system on the Atlantic City Expressway has worked well its first few of days. The system had its New Jersey debut last week at toll plazas in Egg Harbor Township and Pleasantville. Drivers pay a minimum of $25 in advance, and the money is deducted as a plastic tag on the windshield is read by a scanner.

title: Status is ... for Catholic Priests; Heavenly Cuff Links
description: Back when I was in a Roman Catholic seminary in the 1980's, it became very obvious, very early on, that the would-be priests who also aspired to be bishops always wore cuff links. Every morning, while I guzzled coffee, sat around in sweat pants and tried to figure out why anyone would be awake (let alone wish to pray) at 7 A.M., there would be some ambitious seminarian with cuffs so heavily starched you worried that if he turned his wrist too quickly he would cut himself as he sipped his tea. He'd be perfectly groomed and coifed with the air of having just returned from a morning photo shoot. And shining in the morning sun coming through the refectory windows, from just below the sleeve of his jacket, glittering with that deadliest of the seven deadly sins, were the cuff links. It turned my stomach. I couldn't eat breakfast. I became a chain smoker instead.

title: Status is ... for Manhattan Parents; A Kid Who Curls Up With the Classics
description: A few months ago, I traveled from Manhattan to Mantova, a small city in northern Italy, where I gave a talk alongside other novelists at a literary festival. At the last minute, my husband couldn't come, and I took my 11-year-old son, Tommy, instead. Tommy is always an asset, except for those rare moments when he isn't, and he is an excellent traveling companion, except for those rare moments when he isn't. So I looked forward to showing off my charming American child -- complete with copies of Mad magazine and Electronic Gaming Monthly, Adam Sandler CD's and ''South Park'' T-shirts -- to the Italians.

title: No Birds, No Bees
description: ''It's estimated that a record number of PC's will be sold to parents with children this holiday season,'' the publicist for Watchsoft Inc. said in an E-mail to the news media last week (while staying strictly mum on expected sales to parents without children).

title: Atop the Garden City Hotel, Luxury at $1,500 a Night
description: TAMI LACERTOSA and Anna Peroutka, two of the eight concierges at the Garden City Hotel, are used to unusual requests, especially from guests in the three penthouse suites. For the pleasure of their guests, who of course picked up the tab, they have helped hunt down wild boar, alligator and Oriental kobi beef, arranged surprise engagement parties and dentist visits, bought ''I Love You'' balloons, Gummi Bears, cigarettes, tuxedos, even underwear.

title: The View From/Mount Kisco; On the Road Again: Putting a Price on a '68 Dream Machine
description: JOE DeFRANCESCO, 38, and his wife, Sherry, 31, are blind, unable to perceive even the faintest fluctuations in light and shadow -- as Mrs. DeFrancesco puts it, ''We are always in the dark.''

title: No Remote Can Fix This Screen
description: The giant long-neck Budweiser bottle, framed in red neon, swung back and forth mechanically on Tuesday afternoon, and the Dow Jones electronic zipper predicted a chance of showers. But something was conspicuously missing from the north face of 1 Times Square, the tower at Broadway and 43d Street.

title: A BROTHER'S BURDEN
description: WENDY LAMB, a Manhattan book editor, wrote the Oct. 4 Soapbox essay, chronicling milestones of her life that occurred in Grand Central Terminal. She suggested that others record their memories of the place. The City section solicited ''most memorable moments'' and here are a few:

title: The Ascension of Deacon Olive
description: It is Eleanor Olive's belief that her husband, Cornelius Olive, was invited to join the Board of Deacons of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem because ''he's so tall.'' The pastoral authorities at Abyssinian say that they had more spiritual attributes in mind when they asked Olive to join the select circle of ordained laymen who carry out many of the church's ministerial functions, but there is no question that, at 6 foot 7, Cornelius Olive cuts a very striking figure as he gazes out over the congregation from the rear gallery. Deacon Olive is also Abyssinian's chief usher, president of the Senior Men's Usher Board and head of the Sunday Morning Prayer Band, which convenes from 7:00 to 8:30. He is, within the conservative and tradition-bound world of the black church, a figure of real authority and respect.

title: From Red Hook to Cypress Hills: When and Where the Community Boards Meet
description: DISTRICT 1 -- Greenpoint, Williamsburg; meetings usually held on second Tuesday of month, but the next meeting is Dec. 1, 7 P.M.; 211 Ainslee Street, corner of Manhattan Avenue, Williamsburg. Board chairman: Vincent V. Abate; District manager: Gerald Esposito; (718) 389-0009. Agenda: To be announced.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 15, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Following the Wonderful Logic of 'Wonderland'
description: FOR years, Justin G. Schiller, a New York dealer in children's books, was certain that he knew most everything about the publishing history of ''Alice in Wonderland.'' The story had intrigued him since childhood, and so in 1960 when he became a bookseller while still in high school, he began buying and selling early printings of the book. Then, in 1974, he became a founding member of a collectors' group, the Lewis Carroll Society of North America.

title: AT THE MUSEUMS: POLLOCK-KRASNER HOUSE; Jackson Pollock's Floor
description: Visitors to Jackson Pollock's studio have to take off their shoes in the studio anteroom and put on nonabrasive foam slippers. That is because the floor of the Pollock-Krasner House and Study Center of East Hampton is covered with the abstract expressionist's famous painting drips. Those swirls, drops and splotches have been reproduced on a mouse pad, available for $15. And on a T-shirt, $25, that changes color with exposure to sunlight. Indoors, the T-shirt depicts a graphic with a partial design of the floor. Outside, it bursts into colors. Pollack-Krasner House and Study Center, 830 Fireplace Road, East Hampton.

title: Does Spurt in Optimism Foretell a Market Fall?
description: These days, when the bulls run, they really sprint. That's the gist of the most recent data from Investors Intelligence, a newsletter in New Rochelle, N.Y., that conducts a weekly poll of the market sentiment of some 130 private investment newsletters.

title: Alexandra Wolf, Mark Hamblett
description: Alexandra Hilary Wolf and Mark Manning Hamblett were married yesterday at Little Dix Bay, the resort on Virgin Gorda in the British Virgin Islands. The Rev. Cecil O. A. Weekes, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

title: Frequent Flier
description: SEASONS OF HER LIFE

title: Liza Norton and Jason Jordan
description: Elizabeth Cannon Norton, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald P. Norton of Washington, was married yesterday to Jason Reams Jordan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. J. Jordan of Stedman, N.C. Bishop Jane Holmes Dixon, the Episcopal Suffragan of Washington, performed the ceremony at the Washington National Cathedral.

title: Offering Clothes For the New York Silhouette
description: It's a familiar tale. While Evelyn Daniel was an undergraduate at Loyola University in Chicago, her parents wanted her to go to law school. But Ms. Daniel had different ideas, and while she was studying political science, she was also apprenticing with a dress tailor.

title: Beckett's Many Mercies, Abounding Mercies
description: MANY members of the audience at Hartford Stage are wondering just what Samuel Beckett's ''Happy Days'' -- in which a woman named Winnie is submerged waist-deep and then neck-deep in a mound of earth -- is all about.

title: V.A.T. Refunds
description: To the Editor: On Sept. 28, we bought shoes from Fratelli Rossetti in Florence, Italy, for 380,000 lire, or about $205. We got a refund form indicating a refund due of 68,000 lire, or $36, and were told to have the forms processed at the airport Customs office.

title: Status is ... For Alternative-Rock Bands; Charting in Dusseldorf
description: The alternative band Dead Moon hasn't won a Grammy, never went platinum. In fact, you've probably never heard of them. But the band has made it big -- really big -- in Europe. In the Netherlands, for instance, Dead Moon is so popular that a club called De Effenaar once organized a Dead Moon contest, in which bands were invited to play their favorite Dead Moon cover songs. De Bossen, from Belgium, did a killer version of ''Dagger Moon.'' After 10 years of limited success at home, overseas fame is the band's perverse badge of status: they are just too alternative for the U.S. market.

title: Home for the Holidays at Radio City
description: DURING my elementary school years at the Yeshiva Flatbush, the closest I ever came to joining in the joy of Christmas was sitting in the front row of the Radio City Music Hall Christmas show. For me, there has always been no place like the Music Hall for the holidays. I was shocked to learn in fifth grade that every church and school pageant didn't include a tap-dancing manger.

title: Turn! Turn! Turn!
description: To Everything

title: Updating the Classics: A Time-Honored Craft Takes On a New Look
description: QUILTING is not what it used to be. The daughters-in-spirit of Colonial New Jersey women who huddled before the hearth on cold winter nights, enjoying the sociability of a quilting bee, now run their own businesses, zip down the Garden State Parkway to meetings and, sometimes, do their stitching on machines.

title: Revival of Indian Cycle Runs Into a New Barrier
description: IF it comes off, the rebirth of the legendary Indian motorcycle, last produced in 1953, will be remarkable in many ways.

title: Former Players and Peers Fondly Recall Holzman, a Friend and a Professional
description: Before Walt Frazier won championships and was enshrined in the Basketball Hall of Fame, he was a young guard unsure of his place in the National Basketball Association -- and fresh off a horrendous game against the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: Harold Ford Jr. Storms His Father's House
description: Is it mere coincidence that your photograph of Harold Ford Jr. and Sr. has them standing in a street's left-turn-only lane?

title: In Middle East, a Hesitant Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHAFRAN, BARNEY
description: SHAFRAN-Barney. Daddy, It's 15 years since you've left us-and never, not for one second, are you out of our hearts and minds. We miss you so much. Edith, Wally, Harriet, Roni

title: Just Say 'Uh-Oh'
description: GO ASK ALICE

title: Children's Books in Brief; The Fast Lane
description: ZOOM CITY

title: For Some Folks, a Marathon Isn't Enough
description: AS runners stumbled across the finish line at the New York City Marathon two weeks ago, many looked for a place to collapse. While the band of foil-wrapped competitors scattered across the grassy knolls of Central Park, struggling to catch their breath, Dick Opsahl was ready to go around again.

title: A Friendship Formed During a Changing of the Guard
description: THE composer William Schuman liked to tell about the time he heard one of his works performed in Macon, Ga. After the concert, he was approached by a woman of a certain age and social standing who told him that while she did not generally approve of atonal music, she had enjoyed his piece.

title: Limiting a State's Sphere of Influence
description: To some, it may smack of flower-power idealism that in recent years two dozen American cities have passed sanctions against foreign countries, roaring like local mice against the ruling regime of Nigeria or political repression in Tibet.

title: Children's Books in Brief
description: ARLENE SARDINEWritten and illustratedby Chris Raschka.Orchard, $15.95.(Ages 3 to 8)

title: Columbia's Tillotson Is Too Much for Cornell
description: Chris Tillotson, a safety and wide receiver for Columbia, began the season by being suspended for two games for disciplinary reasons. Since then, the senior said, ''I've been struggling to get into the mix.''

title: Correction
description: The Correspondent's Report column on Oct. 25, about bargain air fares to Asia, misstated two prices for JAL/Pacifico Creative Service package tours. The $1,015 price cited for five nights in Tokyo is good only from Los Angeles or San Francisco, not for all four cities mentioned; from the two other cities, New York and Chicago, the price is $1,100. The three-night, business class package at $5,050 is offered from Los Angeles or San Francisco only, not from all five cities mentioned; from Chicago it is $6,200, from New York or Atlanta, $6,450.

title: He Didn't Do It
description: Holes

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-20

title: Lauren Katz, Matthew Kluger
description: Lauren Pam Katz and Matthew Jay Kluger, criminal defense lawyers in the Bronx, were married last evening by Rabbi Louis Frishman at the Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday tracing the growth of gambling in the United States misstated the amount of money gambled during the last decade. It has risen from about $250 billion in 1987 to about $600 billion last year, not from $250 million to $600 million. A map with the chart labeled North Carolina, North Dakota, Oklahoma, Tennessee and South Carolina incorrectly. They do not have state lotteries.

title: On Washington; Hollywood, D.C.
description: I came to Washington, I always thought, with all the right stuff: an Ivy League degree, a job on a big-time newspaper, a belly full of skepticism and a brain littered with assorted information on throw-weights, T-bills and reapportionment. I knew who George W. Norris and Arthur Vandenburg and Rexford G. Tugwell were, and I knew the difference between grands crus and grand larceny. I had once had tea at Alice Roosevelt Longworth's.

title: 'Pictures Great,' His Publisher Told Him
description: N. C. WYETH

title: Los Angeles Police Watchdog Resigns; City Set for Debate
description: The first person to serve as a public watchdog over the Los Angeles Police Department resigned from the position this week, criticized her bosses for undercutting her authority and touched off concerns that the city's commitment to overhauling the police was wavering.

title: For Sehorn, 3,000 Stairs and Not a Fan in Sight
description: These days Jason Sehorn spends more time inside Giants Stadium than he ever did. But it is nothing like the time he used to spend there.

title: AIDS Stalking Africa's Struggling Economies
description: At one time, Barclays Bank here was losing 36 of its 1,600 employees a year, 10 times the death rate at most American companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, FERN
description: COHEN-Fern. On November 12, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Seymour. Loving mother of Thomas and Matthew. Adoring grandmother of Spencer and Justin. Service Sunday, 12 Noon at ''The Riverside''

title: Deadline Set To Form Rules For Reducing Gas Emissions
description: After an all-night session in Buenos Aires, negotiators from more than 150 countries early yesterday set a deadline of two years for adopting operational rules for cutting emissions of waste industrial gases that are believed to cause global warming.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: RIVERDALE

title: Playing God In the Garden
description: I almost cheered as I read Michael Pollan's article about the engineered potatoes. On the edge of my seat, I devoured the final paragraphs: Will he or won't he eat the potaBtoes?

title: Kyra Nijinsky, 84; Danced in Father's Shadow
description: Kyra Nijinsky, a dancer who was the daughter of Vaslav Nijinsky, one of this century's greatest ballet dancers and choreographers, died on Sept. 1 at the Pine Ridge Care Center in San Rafael, Calif. She led a reclusive life in San Francisco and details of her death become nationally known only recently. She was 84.

title: Pamela Kirschner, Mark Weinfeld
description: Pamela Beth Kirschner, the daughter of Frances and Robert Kirschner of Lakewood, N.J., is to be married today to Dr. Mark Stephen Weinfeld, a son of Beverly D. Weinfeld of Newton, Mass., and the late Dr. Marvin S. Weinfeld. Rabbi Richard Hammerman is to officiate at Doolan's, an inn in Spring Lake Heights, N.J.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: AN oustanding entry in the crime genre, a snappy musical production, a realistic melodrama and a classic jolter lend sparkle to the lineup of films on television this week.

title: More Internet Offerings Waiting in the Wings
description: Investors kicking themselves for not being in on last week's initial offerings of Earthweb and Theglobe.com -- which finished the week up 378.6 percent and 605.6 percent, respectively -- may want to keep this thought in mind: There's more where those two came from.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, JAMES
description: WHITE-James. Born in New York City, September 6, 1929. Moved to Plantation, FL, 1971. Parishioner of St. Gregory's Catholic Church. Died November 12, 1998. Survived by his wife Mary, his children Eileen, Patrick and Michael, and his sisters Margaret Sheehan and Ann Marie Reilly.

title: City's Perverse Welfare Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Take on Seizing Benefits
description: The courts have long interpreted Federal law to prohibit seizure of workers' compensation benefits to pay back taxes. But a Federal judge in Texas has ruled differently, allowing the Internal Revenue Service to keep $10,000 seized from an elderly widow whose husband was murdered at work.

title: Diversified Pillows for Resting Easy in Storms
description: ''WE are not trying to hit home runs,'' said Benjamin W. Thorndike, the lead portfolio manager of the Scudder Pathway Series of funds. ''We are trying to do well and sleep well at night.''

title: Making Their Hair Not Curl
description: SOME call it an addiction. They must have it once, twice or three times a week.

title: Terfel Does the Improbable
description: 'IF EVER I WOULD LEAVE YOU'

title: A Not-So-Proper Kenneth Branagh Has Some Fun
description: KENNETH BRANAGH has driven to the Hotel Bel-Air in a red Mustang convertible similar to one he rented when he first came to Hollywood eight years ago to direct and star in the detective movie ''Dead Again.''

title: Pillars of Modern Architecture That Stand the Test of Time
description: THE East End of Long Island may be famous as a proving ground for modern architects, but so many would-be Modern, post-Modern and coyote-ugly Modern beach houses have been built there in recent years that it has given Modernism a bad name.

title: A Touch of the 1940's Woman in the 90's
description: IN the legendary women's films of the 30's and 40's, much-loved throb specialists like Bette Davis, Margaret Sullavan, Joan Crawford and Barbara Stanwyck played gallantly miserable women in stories where love was a vocation with its own rules and heroics. Vexed relationships and outsize emotions claimed center stage, and the tears they generated provided catharsis for female moviegoers who felt trapped by fate and domesticity.

title: The View From/The Pediatric Ward; A Couple of Guys in White Coats, But, Oh, Those Faces! (And Shoes)
description: IN nearly 30 years as a performer, nothing has touched Joe Barney, he says, quite as much as his work with sick children. A 39-year-old father of five (with a sixth on the way), Mr. Barney is boss clown at the Yale-New Haven Children's Hospital.

title: Sports of The Times; Arms and Man in New Light
description: WITH Catfish Hunter, it was always what he did with his arms and hands. He gripped a baseball with his right hand and threw it with his right arm. Threw it for 224 victories before he stopped pitching at the relatively early age of 33, threw it for five World Series championship teams, threw it for 328 innings in 1975 after he joined the Yankees as a $3.35 million free agent.

title: Bialystok
description: To the Editor: The reference to the New Yorkers' memorial to Rabbi Chaim Herc Halpern, chief rabbi in Bialystok for more than 50 years, in ''Bialystok Guide Recalls a Center of Polish Jewry'' (Oct. 18), thrilled me since I am his great-great-granddaughter.

title: 'The Who, Ahead of It's Time'
description: 'THE WHO: ISLE OF WIGHT'

title: 'The Shape of the River'
description: To the Editor:

title: Bringing B.C. to D.C.
description: JOHN RUSSELL POPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARSON, EUGENE
description: GARSON-Eugene. November 12, 1998, at age 72. Beloved husband to Gloria. Loving father of Roberta and Heidi. Dear father-in-law of Peter Hirsch. Adored grandfather of Emilie. His vast practical wisdom and deeply caring ways will be remembered by his family and the many others touched by his presence. His legacy lives on in all the individuals and organizations that he gave his love and spirit to. Memorial service Sunday, December 20, 2 PM, New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 W. 64 St, NYC. Contributions in his memory to Nature Conservancy, 570 7th Ave., NY NY 10018; New York-New Jersey Trail Conference, 232 Madison Ave., NY NY 10016; St. Margaret's House, 49 Fulton St., NY NY 10038; South Street Seaport Museum, 207 Front St., NY NY 10038.

title: Jones's Lesson Makes An Impression on Grant
description: Otis Grant must have felt as though he was back in his classroom at Lindsay Place High School in Montreal. Except Roy Jones Jr. was the proctor and Grant was the student. And the lessons were in physics (velocity and force of punches), geometry (angle of punches) and pain.

title: The Next Superweapon: Panic
description: Once again we have found it necessary to call on our armed forces to limit the power and ambition of Saddam Hussein's military machine. Behind the scenes, a longer term struggle is also beginning. It is so novel, it warrants what all fresh military ideas need -- a new acronym. My proposed acronym is NEW -- nonexplosive warfare.

title: 20's Movie Palace to Reopen With DeMille Classic
description: The historic Egyptian Theater, a Hollywood movie palace that has been closed for renovation since 1992, will reopen early next month for three public showings of Cecil B. DeMille's 1923 silent classic ''The Ten Commandments,'' accompanied by a live orchestra.

title: Why Do Chip Makers Look So Chipper?
description: AFTER three tough years, it seems that things are looking up in Chip Land.

title: The N.B.A.'s Owners Continue to Line Up Behind Commissioner Stern
description: Donald Sterling, the principal owner of the Los Angeles Clippers, cannot understand why David Stern is being portrayed as the villain by National Basketball Association players in the league's labor dispute.

title: Annual and Perennial: Adapting to Nature's Rules
description: A FRIEND with a newly dug flower bed wanted advice last spring on what to plant in it. She wanted something that would not only bloom profusely from spring to fall, with little care, but would also come up again of its own accord the following year.

title: Taking the Starch Out of Status
description: Of all the inequalities around us, those involving status are surely the most benign. Status's main rivals -- wealth and power -- are, to those who want them badly enough, worth killing for. No wonder those who study economics and politics tend to be, in William James's term, ''hardheaded, hardhearted and hardfisted.'' Pursuing wealth or power means treating the world as composed of isolated individuals, each seeking a cutthroat advantage over everyone else.

title: Red Holzman, Hall of Fame Coach, Dies at 78
description: Red Holzman, the Hall of Fame coach who led the New York Knicks to their only two National Basketball Association championships, died on Friday night at Long Island Jewish Hospital. He was 78.

title: November 8-14; Questions About the Promise Of a Cancer Cure
description: Officials at the National Cancer Institute said they have been unable to reproduce the striking discoveries described a year ago by Dr. Judah Folkman, the Harvard researcher who reported that he and his colleagues had wiped out malignant tumors in mice with compounds that destroyed the tumors' blood supplies.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 28 of the special Holiday Movies section today, about the film ''Hurlyburly,'' misstates the given name of the director and the period in which the film is set. The director is Anthony Drazan, not Jonathan, and the time is the 1990's, not the 1980's; the David Rabe play on which the movie is based was set in the 80's. The article also misstates the occupation of the character portrayed by Robin Wright Penn. She is a costume designer, not a photojournalist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADNER, JOHN H.
description: BRADNER-John H. Of Warwick, NY, on November 8, 1998. Survived by his children, Michael, Melissa, Andrew and Patrick; his sister, Frances Bradner Masefield; his former wife, Susan Hull Stage. Loomis School; Amherst 1950. Musician, author, world traveler. ''He followed his own star.''

title: A Long Way From the Light Bulb
description: AT ANY COSTJack Welch, General Electric,and the Pursuit of Profit.By Thomas F. O'Boyle.Illustrated. 449 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf. $29.95.

title: Welcome to the New Los Angeles: It's on the Hudson
description: BIG, whitewashed art galleries in low industrial buildings, their garage-style doors giving onto broad, sunny streets that are dead quiet except for the fit-for-life types in-line-skating westward toward the water.

title: HOLIDAY FILMS: UP AND COMING -- Famke Janssen; Transformations As a Way of Life, Not Just on Screen
description: IN ''The Faculty,'' which opens on Christmas Day, Famke Janssen plays a timid, bespectacled high school teacher, a woman whose voice quavers when she urges a promising but wayward student to apply himself. Since the movie is a thriller directed by Robert Rodriguez (''Desperado'') and written by Kevin Williamson (''Scream''), it is safe to expect that the shy educator will undergo a radical shift in personality and appearance before the final reel. Then it should be easy to recognize Ms. Janssen as the confident actress who has given a series of witty, engaging performances in relatively small parts: the Russian-born owner of a gambling joint in ''Rounders,'' the bitter, alcoholic ex-wife of a Southern lawyer in ''The Gingerbread Man'' and a tough, blue-collar Bostonian in ''Monument Avenue.'' In ''Celebrity,'' a Woody Allen film that opens on Nov. 20, she plays a sophisticated editor in love with a neurotic, on-the-make writer played by Kenneth Branagh.

title: Ms. Goldsmith And Mr. Fallon
description: Alexandra Eve Goldsmith, the daughter of Katherine and Clifford H. Goldsmith of New York, was married last evening to Daniel Richard Fallon, a son of Carol and Gerald Fallon of Massapequa, N.Y. Rabbi Charles J. Davidson officiated, and the Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony at the University Club in New York.

title: After a Loss, a Campaign for Safer Camps
description: SOME day there may be Jeremy's Law, the way there is Megan's Law and Jenna's Law, laws enacted in the aftermath of tragic deaths of children and meant to prevent repeat occurrences of similar events. For now, there is Jeremy's Camp Safety Guide for Parents, written by Jodi B. and Robert C. Scheinfeld of New Rochelle, whose 10-year-old son Jeremy drowned last summer while at sleep-away camp.

title: Status is ... for The 90's Nouveau Riche; Getting What you Want In a Snap
description: A young investor of my acquaintance who made millions in the swelled financial markets of the 90's was recently complaining about having trouble turning his new Ferrari around in the narrow driveway of his $3 million Bridgehampton, N.Y., vacation home. He had four foreign sports cars parked in an underground garage (dug into one of the Hamptons' most luxuriant potato fields), and the inconvenience of his driveway's cramped width so aggrieved him that one Saturday morning he called a local contractor and asked how much it would cost to have the driveway widened 10 feet -- by the end of that day. The contractor, by now imperturbable to the demands of the Hamptons' nouveau riche for instant gratification, named an exorbitant price, and by late afternoon it was done, stonework and all. ''That's the velocity of money,'' the banker bragged. ''Money is about getting things done.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GULKIN, ANITA KURMAN
description: GULKIN-Anita Kurman. Urban Pathways notes with sorrow the death of Anita Kurman Gulkin, a founder and long time board member. Her energetic support and committment to quality services are part of her legacy. Our condolences to her family. Gerald W. Blume, President Joan E. Ohlson, Exec Director

title: For Getting a Lobster in a Hurry, It's Worth the Trip to Island Park
description: IT was a maitre d's worst nightmare. Someone at Smith & Wollensky in Manhattan had neglected to put the party for 50 in the restaurant's reservation book. ''I called Jordan,'' said Danny Kissane, Smith & Wollensky's food purchasing director. ''I told them it was an emergency -- they had me 50 lobsters in one hour, one hour -- from the Island!''

title: POSTINGS: Castle Clinton, Brownstones, Victoriana; Preservation And History
description: Programs on the restoration of both private and public buildings that are parts of the city's heritage -- a panel discussion on brownstone restoration, a slide presentation on Victorian interiors followed by a talk on wallpapering, and a symposium on the redevelopment of historic Castle Clinton in Battery Park -- are to be offered over the next few days.

title: Inspirational Soccer Team Is Threatened by Sloppy Paperwork
description: A sentimental inner-city saga of immigrant teen-agers finding hope through soccer as their coach sought personal redemption took a dark and confusing turn last week. Martin Jacobson, who has hugged and hectored the Martin Luther King Jr. High School team to two city championships, has been indefinitely suspended by the school and forbidden to speak to his players. Two league games have been forfeited.

title: Airlines Try to Tuck In Their Upper-Class Fliers
description: THERE'S a revolution under way among the upper classes on international flights. Demand for business-class seats is so strong that airlines are dividing into two ranks, those that are eliminating first class to make room for more business-class seats and those that are telling their first-class passengers to lie down and go to sleep.

title: Four Who Flew Remember the Nest
description: DON'T ask me about the best things on Long Island. I don't know. I'm never there.

title: German Nazism Was No 'Aberration'
description: To the Editor:

title: Triggering Blooms Indoors
description: TOO often, gardeners complain they cannot grow anything. Their plants do not bloom and they are tired of tossing out dead ones.

title: The Great White Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: Status is ... for SunBelt Trailer-Park Residents,; Movin' On Up
description: In the beginning was the mobile home -- the truly mobile home -- a metal balloon with louvered windows and built-in eating areas, lugged along behind the family sedan in the golden and prosperous postwar years when the country dreamed of being on the move. Then came a momentous fork in the road -- one path leading toward the RV, that Whale of the Highways, which drew its status from greater and greater displays of comfort on the move, and the other toward the modern trailer park, which came to look more and more permanent. Both kinds of mobile homes, however, had to fit under the nation's highway overpasses or they were not, in fact, mobile; consequently, their roofs retained that distinctive, flattop look.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 47 of the special Holiday Movies section today, about the reissued film ''The Last Emperor,'' misstates the opening date. It is Dec. 4, not Nov. 25.

title: THE GUIDE
description: 'Pulse!' in Dobbs Ferry

title: The World: Boxed In; Guns to Butter: Six Fraught Ways To Contain Iraq
description: IT was not supposed to turn out this way. Tough sanctions linked to aggressive arms inspections were intended to keep Saddam Hussein boxed in, not to drive the United States into a corner.

title: So Far, the State's Having Its Warmest Year Ever
description: So far, 1998 in New Jersey has been warmer than any other year since meteorologists began keeping records 104 years ago, said David Robinson, the state climatologist, at Rutgers University. Unless temperatures through December drop far below normal, the year will be the warmest on record, he said.

title: Catherine W. Pillsbury, Philanthropist, 92
description: Catherine Wheeler Pillsbury, a philanthropist who with her husband, Evans S. Pillsbury 2d, owned and operated cattle ranches in the Santa Ynez Valley of California from the 1930's to the 50's, died Friday at her home in Montecito, Calif. She was 92.

title: Legal Team's Withdrawal Crucial in Jones's Decision to Settle
description: For Paula Corbin Jones to agree to settle her sexual misconduct lawsuit against President Clinton, she had to be convinced that the best time to strike a deal was now. Her many advisers worked to make her realize that even if she went ahead with the lawsuit and won a jury verdict she would probably get only a small amount of money.

title: AT THE MUSEUMS: PARRISH MUSEUM; Lichtenstein's 'LaLaLa' on a Towel
description: The ocean is the draw. The ''Sea Change'' exhibit on the walls at the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton celebrates this primary resource of the East End.

title: Chamber Ensembles At Center Stage
description: CHAMBER ensembles of 2 to 16 musicians are performing this afternoon. At 3, the Yale Faculty Artist series brings the violinist Erick Friedman and the pianist Peter Frankl to Sprague Memorial Hall for a free recital of sonatas by Grieg and Dohnanyi and, with the New Haven Symphony cellist Steven Thomas, the Tchaikovsky Trio.

title: The Draw of the New
description: To the Editor:

title: Body of Jazz Pianist Is Found; Police Seek Cause of Death
description: The police are awaiting a medical examiner's report to determine what caused the death of Kenny Kirkland, the jazz pianist, who was found dead Friday morning in his home in Springfield Gardens, Queens.

title: Claiming Transportation Woes, the Disabled Sue the City
description: ''I was in tears,'' said Betty Tolliver. She was remembering the fear that struck her at 2:30 one morning at a nearly deserted La Guardia Airport as she waited for a long-overdue van. It never did arrive.

title: City's Perverse Welfare Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Orienteering
description: THE CHAN'S GREAT CONTINENTChina in Western Minds.By Jonathan D. Spence.279 pp. New York:W. W. Norton & Company. $27.50.

title: Green, an Intense Tackler, Strengthens the Jets' Defense
description: The statement was simple. Last year, in looking at the tattered defense he inherited, Bill Parcells intoned, ''If Victor Green leads this team in tackles again, we're in trouble.''

title: Woodstock, Vt.
description: No one can argue with the statistics. In Vermont, Killington is king; it has more lifts, more trails, more services, more apres-ski than any other resort in the state. But bigger and brasher may not be what you're longing for -- especially if you are traveling with children who are new to skiing or snowboarding. To find a quieter, less frenetic take on winter recreation, look east to Woodstock, the Christmas card-picturesque historic village about 20 miles from Killington.

title: A Market with Fewer Thrills, and Chills
description: IN bemused tones, the Oct. 19 internal memo from the chairman of the Coldwell Banker Hunt Kennedy residential brokerage to his company's 110 sales agents said: ''We actually have sellers out there deciding whether to accept offers and buyers deciding whether they should make an offer based on what the Dow is doing that morning or afternoon.''

title: Who's Trespassing On Whose Land?
description: Re the article (''Inviting Hunters Home to Cull the Deer Herd,'' last Sunday): In the city I knew the enemy. I could identify the rabid wild life. Big fat subway rats. Overly aggressive squirrels. And the ever-present cockroach. There was nothing remotely cute about any of them.

title: Now That SoHo Has a Hotel, the Idea Is Moving South
description: Looking for a place to stay downtown? With plans for two separate lodging projects recently filed with Community Board 1 in lower Manhattan, it appears that New York hoteliers will soon be able to oblige.

title: Thank the Politicians
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GRAHAM, GORDON
description: GRAHAM-Gordon. Memorial Service, Tuesday, November 17, 1998 11AM at the City Church, New York in the Ethical Culture Building, 2 West 64 Street, NYC.

title: Big Sky, Mont.
description: There are only three things I look for in a ski area: good snow, good terrain and no lift lines. This doesn't seem too much to ask. Yet of the more than 600 resorts in the United States, I can count on one hand those that consistently satisfy all three.

title: An Ambitious Actress Comes Out of Africa
description: CHARLIZE THERON doesn't have much time. A car is coming to the posh Four Seasons Hotel in Manhattan in exactly 1 hour and 10 minutes to take her and her rock star boyfriend, Stephan Jenkins of Third Eye Blind, to his concert in Connecticut. This is not unusual. Ms. Theron may be only 23 and riding the crest of a movie career most blond starlets would kill for, but she has goals -- and fears she might not be able to accomplish all of them. She has two high-profile movies coming out. She plays a sulky, club-trotting supermodel in Woody Allen's ''Celebrity'' and stars in a Disney remake, ''Mighty Joe Young,'' but she's not one to sit back and congratulate herself. ''I've always felt the clock ticking,'' she said. ''I've always been surrounded by death. I've been to way more funerals than weddings in my life. There's always a time issue for me.''

title: Providence Sweeps At Van Cortlandt
description: Keith Kelly and Larissa Kleinmann were the men's and women's gold medalists as Providence swept the two team titles in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Northeast Regional Cross-Country Championships at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. BERNIE BEGLANE

title: A Value Player Finds An Advertising Bargain
description: When William H. Miller 3d buys a stock, many investors take notice, because it usually means he thinks a company is a good bet for years to come. Last year, Legg Mason Value Trust, the $5.7 billion fund that Mr. Miller has watched over for 16 years, had a turnover rate of just 13 percent -- meaning that the fund still owns about seven of every eight stocks that it held a year ago.

title: Livery Driver Is Accused Of Attacking Inspectors
description: A man who was thought to be operating an unlicensed livery cab was arrested on Friday after attacking two Taxi and Limousine Commission inspectors with a screwdriver and his teeth, the police said.

title: Some Pepperoni on Your Little Boy?
description: PETE'S A PIZZAWritten and illustratedby William Steig.Unpaged. New York:Michael di Capua Books/HarperCollins Publishers. $13.95.(All ages)

title: Unbeaten Kansas St. Finally Has Nebraska's Number
description: KANSAS STATE 40, NEBRASKA 30

title: Pilgrim America Bank and Thrift
description: OVER the summer, it seemed, bank stocks came a cropper. Investors recoiled at the banks' emerging-markets exposure, their hedge fund loans and the potential damage from an impending recession. By Oct. 8, the sector had dropped 40.3 percent from its high on July 15.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: Hip Hop America

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPANO, NICHOLAS
description: SPANO-Nicholas. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Nicholas Spano, associated with The Times from 1958, until retiring in 1989.

title: The Joint is Jumping, Cuban Style
description: Cafe Habana, a two-week-old cafeteria-style restaurant at 17 Prince Street (at Elizabeth Street), takes its inspiration from the glamorous history of Cafe La Habana in Mexico City, says Richard Ampudia, an owner. The Mexican spot, still extant, drew famous Cuban musicians in the 1940's because of its proximity to a major radio station.

title: Seeing the Fruit Of One's Labor
description: Q. I recently switched from a small, hands-on company to a large, hierarchical one. Adjusting has been a bit of a struggle. Before, I had a say in all aspects of the business, and I saw the impact I had. Now, I'm a widget handler and wonder if I am adding any value to the company's products. What should I do: stay put and work my way up to a position where I'll clearly make a difference, or go back to being a big frog in a small pond?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TRACT, HAROLD M.
description: TRACT-Harold M. Of blessed memory. Passed away November 18, 1991. He was a truly noble man. The Tract Famil

title: The Current States of Status
description: In his 1959 book, ''The Status Seekers,'' the muckraking journalist Vance Packard blasted Americans for being inveterate social climbers, always looking ''to find new ways to draw lines that will separate the elect from the non-elect.'' Packard's critique stings even more today. Which culture has been more obsessed than ours with defining the ins and outs of Who's In and Who's Out? And yet, as the nation has become more diverse, its sense of social hierarchy has been scrambled. Few Americans seem to agree anymore about what's impressive, noble or cool.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: TALKING BACK TO EMILY DICKINSONAnd Other Essays.By William H. Pritchard.University of Massachusetts, $29.95 .

title: With a Friend Like Microsoft . . .
description: The Microsoft antitrust trial has shifted from how William H. Gates and company treat their enemies to how they treat their friends. An Intel vice president, Steven McGeady, testified that Microsoft bullied Intel into shelving its own software development with repeated threats that Microsoft would stop supporting new generations of Intel microprocessors. He described Mr. Gates, Microsoft's chairman, as becoming ''enraged'' at Intel for daring to encroach on territory Microsoft claimed as its own.

title: Playing God In the Garden
description: Your article on genetic engineering was fabulous, as was the cover art. It would be wonderful if you could do a similarly thorough piece on the power the meat industry exerts over government. You've told us where french fries come from. Please do the same for hamburgers.

title: Status is ... for Vegetarians; Eating it All Raw
description: Vegetarianism, long considered a hippie hallmark, is now mainstream. But the traditional no-meat-no-fish menu is being upstaged by competing practices that advocate a far greater rigidity. In crunchy subcultures in which a ''my diet is better than yours'' attitude quietly prevails, coolness is gauged by culinary austerity. And the question abstemious eaters like to grill one another with nowadays is this: How ''raw'' are you?

title: Winding Down on Tour, 'Barrymore' the Rogue
description: LAST stop: New Haven. And the last chance to see a one-of-a-kind bravura performance, unless you plan to travel to London where Christopher Plummer may take his solo ''Barrymore'' play -- John Barrymore, that is, the aging dissolute, delusional John Barrymore, a , ''a clown prince.''

title: A Poet, at 70, Ventures Into the Unknown
description: IT is just after 8 A.M. on a cloudy, drizzly Sunday in early October, so dank and depressing that this stretch of West End Avenue is nearly empty. If you walk into a certain building, however, and knock on a particular door, things will change in an instant.

title: How Much Soda Pop?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Boys of War
description: SOLDIER'S HEARTBeing the Story of the Enlistmentand Due Service of the BoyCharley Goddard in theFirst Minnesota Volunteers.By Gary Paulsen.106 pp. New York:Delacorte Press. $15.95.(Ages 12 and up)

title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL; Brooklyn Tech Outlasts Tottenville in Overtime
description: Jim DiBenedetto, Brooklyn Tech's football coach, has said all year that his team is almost impossible to stop from 10 yards out.

title: Enough Already! What Am I, Chopped Liver?
description: I'm sure it's delicious, but the chopped liver recipe is not kosher.

title: Chestnuts, In Sauce and Side Dish
description: FRESH chestnuts come into the market in late fall, imported from Italy. Yet chestnut woods once covered the eastern United States.

title: Saving A Life but Crossing a Line
description: ART HELMS, a software project manager for Applied Management Systems of Rockville, Md., must be one heck of a boss.

title: Venice on the Bay Journal; Sand and Surf. And Human Ashes?
description: Ah, the beauty of Venice on the Bay.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Nov. 1 about a woman whose sketch of Yankee Stadium has joined the permanent collection at the Baseball Hall of Fame misstated her given name. She is Shirley Winthrope Rivo, not Mary.

title: The Dock in Fair Harbor Is the Place to Meet
description: WHILE growing up in Jericho about 25 years ago, Jeffrey Delott had a crush on a pretty little dark-haired girl named Joanne who was a year ahead of him in school. After she graduated, he didn't see her again until a summer night five years ago, when he and a friend joined about a hundred others watching the sunset from the Fair Harbor dock on the Fire Island National Seashore. Joanne, now an electrologist, was with someone else, but Jeffrey, alawyer, remembered her.

title: November 8-14; Big Push to Curb A Blinding Disease
description: The eye infection trachoma dims the vision of six million people, making it the world's leading cause of preventable blindness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWARD, MARGARET EVANS
description: HOWARD-Margaret Evans. Age 103, died November 6, 1998. Wife of the late Graeme K. Howard, one-time executive with General Motors Overseas. Survived by children Reese E. Howard, Southport, CT and Boca Grande, FL, Sally H. Hollaman (Mrs. R.B.), Exeter, NH, Graeme K. Howard, Jr., Rock Hall, MD. Also 11 grandchildren and 19 great grandchildren. Mrs. Howard graduated from Castilleja School & Stanford University. Former member of the Colony Club (New York) and Francisca Club (San Francisco). Services will be in Norfolk, CT. at the family's convenience.

title: Must-Win Packers Have No Pity for the Giants
description: As if the Giants don't have enough problems, when they play Green Bay today, they will be facing a very angry Packers team. In particular, a very angry LeRoy Butler, the outstanding safety who said this game is a must-win for his team.

title: Fired From One Job Because He Tried to Seek Another
description: In the Democratic primary in September, James E. Davis stunned Brooklyn politicians by coming close to toppling the Democratic Party leader, Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr. And Mr. Davis, who won 45 percent of the vote to Mr. Norman's 55 percent, was on a high, insisting that his political future in Crown Heights was bright.

title: Pamela Goebel, Scott Kornfeld
description: Pamela Aime Goebel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Goebel of Syosset, N.Y., was married last evening to Scott Michael Kornfeld, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Kornfeld of Edison, N.J. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas officiated at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, N.Y.

title: Fire Brings Out 'Barn-Raising' Spirit, and Concerns
description: No one is sure what happened, but a fire started in a first-floor bedroom at Bullet Space, an artists' collective and gallery on Third Street, last Saturday around 9:20 A.M. Residents said it was Diva, a house dog, who saved them.

title: November 8-14; Simpson Loses Appeal
description: Should a man acquitted of killing his wife get custody of the children? There seems no reason why he shouldn't. But here's a thornier question: What if the man is O. J. Simpson?

title: Can Big Houses Be Too Big?
description: ''IT is a change of attitude,'' explained Diane Fox, the town planner of Greenwich. ''For old money, the more money you had, the more you hid it.''

title: Status is ... for Gay Men; The Baby
description: My little status item spat up on me this morning. He was sitting on my shoulders and threw up on my hair, so I passed him off to the boyfriend. Good parents try to keep these moments in perspective. Head in the sink, I reminded myself that it could have been worse: all he'd eaten was a little formula and, from the smell of it, some strained banana. Organic-spinach-with-potato spit-up, which I've also scraped off the top of my head, is lot more colorful and a lot less pleasant.

title: The Ruling Class
description: IF any part of New Jersey still justifies the name Garden State, it is the Somerset Hills, a lush region of farms and estates about 50 miles west of Manhattan. Here, on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Saturdays in autumn and winter, a field of as many as 80 scarlet-jacketed riders from the Essex Hunt chase foxes over the countryside of Bedminster and Oldwick.

title: W. C. Moloney, 91, Early Specialist In Blood Diseases
description: William Curry Moloney, who studied and treated blood diseases well before hematology became a medical specialty, died on Nov. 3 in Boston at Brigham and Women's Hospital, where he was a former director of hematology. He was 91 and lived in Chatham, Mass.

title: A Forgotten Maker of the Unforgettable
description: IN 1938, the director Victor Fleming made a movie about a Kansas farm girl who gets swept into the air and enters a dizzying world of excitement and heartbreak. It was called ''Test Pilot,'' it starred Myrna Loy, Clark Gable and Spencer Tracy, and it was an enormous hit.

title: November 8-14; Court Sidesteps School Voucher Debate
description: The Supreme Court declined to get involved in the national debate over whether it is constitutional to use taxpayer-financed vouchers to send children to religious schools.

title: 'Two for the Seesaw' at Fleetwood Stage
description: THE 40th anniversary this year of ''Two for the Seesaw'' has justifiably gone unacknowledged. Whatever possessed Fleetwood Stage here to attempt the resuscitation of a moribund play?

title: From East to West, an Island of Landmarks
description: Providing focal points for their communities, Long Island's landmarks include eccentric structures like Riverhead's Big Duck and monumental edifices, from Castle Gould in Sands Point to the Montauk Lighthouse. This small selection surveys their locations, styles and meanings. HELEN A. HARRISON

title: As College Costs Increase, Scholarship Fraud Follows
description: Wesley Watkins 4th, a 23-year-old Stanford University graduate from Oakland, Calif., was accepted to a doctoral program in music education in England. But, unable to afford the $17,000 annual fees at Reading University, he searched the World Wide Web for scholarship possibilities.

title: Moynihan Reflects on Career As Scholarly, Puckish Power
description: It seemed only yesterday, though it was really 10 years ago, that Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat, believed he could run a campaign his way -- or more precisely, the way of his wife and chief political adviser, Elizabeth.

title: V.A.T. Refunds
description: To the Editor: Regarding refunds on purchases overseas (Practical Traveler: ''V.A.T. Refunds: Vexations Added,'' Oct. 11), readers might be interested in my recent experience.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN; Whistler
description: If you think getting there is half the fun, the Sea to Sky Highway, a scenic two-hour drive linking Vancouver and Whistler shared by logging trucks, limos and sport utility vehicles, is for you. Exhilarating and harrowing, the hairpin turns on British Columbia's coastal cliffs are a warm-up for a long climb through two-lane chutes, eventually disgorging into an alpine valley designed as a very large, very serious playground at the bases of Whistler and Blackcomb Mountains.

title: The Nation; A Party So Happy It Could Burst
description: THERE were cheers in the White House when this year's election returns came in. Across Capitol Hill and across the nation, Democrats seized on the results -- five new seats in Congress, the toppling of some of the nation's most conservative Senators, a few gains across the South -- as if they were the first signs of spring.

title: Charles Brush 4th and Diane Hess
description: Diane Marie Hess, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald T. Hess of Garden City, N.Y., was married yesterday to Charles Francis Brush 4th, the son of Dr. Brush 3d and Dr. Ellen S. Brush of Manhattan. Msgr. Thomas Leonard performed the ceremony at the Church of the Holy Trinity in Manhattan.

title: What Triggers the Bloom of House Plants?
description: TOO often, gardeners complain that they cannot grow anything. Their plants do not bloom and they are tired of tossing out dead ones.

title: Tricks for Varying the Pay To Motivate the Ranks
description: EMPLOYEE incentive plans are not just for motivating top executives any more, a new survey has found; they are spreading to cover workers on lower rungs of the organizational ladder. But that doesn't necessarily mean that the plans are working.

title: Status is ... for Surfers; A Key to California's Best Private Beach
description: About a million California surfers don't own land on the private and utterly sublime Hollister Ranch, located on Point Conception, just up from Santa Barbara, Calif. A hundred do. That ratio helps explain why Ranch surfers are so often described in impolite terms -- as self-indulgent trust-fund brats, bloodsucking ''beach wear'' industrialists or even retired drug dealers. They're floating on a hydrosphere of empty, sparkling surf, near pastoral green hills and oak-filled canyons, while the lumpen surfetariat is stacked five to a wave at Rincon, Trestles and Huntington Beach, shouting over the traffic noise and condo construction and stewing in have-not hostility.

title: In the Region / New Jersey; In Elizabeth, Outlets and Entertainment in a Mall
description: WHEN the 1.3-million-square foot mall now rising on a former landfill in Elizabeth is completed next October, it will be the first in New Jersey to combine manufacturers' outlet stores and large discount retailers, as well as traditional large mall stores, with entertainment.

title: Habitats / 419 East 140th Street; Wandering U.N. Aide Finds a Home in South Bronx
description: SAM OGLESBY had worked overseas in economic development for the United Nations for 25 years, living in Thailand, Burma, Indonesia, Bhutan and Bangladesh.

title: Corrections
description: A heading in the Vital Statistics chart on page 14 of the Travel section today, for the ski resort of Whistler in British Columbia, refers incorrectly to to hotel rates. The rate shown for an average room for two with tax, $164.34, is for the regular season, not the off season.

title: America Stops Listening To One Of Its Own
description: IN 1941 Aaron Copland wrote, in his book ''Our New Music,'' of ''a man who, at the moment at least, is more frequently played, more praised and more condemned than any other living American composer.'' Samuel Barber? Howard Hanson? William Schuman? Virgil Thomson?

title: Duke's Big Man Is Also an Agile One
description: Elton Brand laughs a lot. He smiles even more. Not on the basketball court, of course.

title: Updating a Classic, and Revealing, Wardrobe
description: ASK almost any woman what she remembers about ''Rear Window'' -- Alfred Hitchcock's stylish and morally ambiguous 1954 thriller, featuring James Stewart as a laid-up photographer who spies on his neighbors out of boredom until witnessing a possible murder -- and sooner or later she will mention the nightgown. The term is misleadingly utilitarian. Less an article of clothing than a gauzy two-piece outfit (the word peignoir comes to mind), the gown, which is accessorized by cunning go-with satin slippers, belongs to Grace Kelly, who plays Stewart's fashionable girlfriend. She spends much of the film and many costume changes assiduously auditioning for the role of wife.

title: The Genius of J
description: THE HIDDEN BOOK

title: Shielding Vulnerable Plants From Cold
description: The Old Farmer's Almanac predicts a colder than normal winter, so think about extra protection for your most vulnerable plants -- especially newly planted or marginally hardy shrubs. Wrap plants individually with burlap or a new polypropylene fabric called Bush Jacket, which is sold at garden centers and is light, easy to handle and durable. Anti-desiccant will also give broad-leaved and needled evergreens some protection from drying winds; apply only when temperatures are above 40 degrees.

title: Full Circle For a Restaurateur
description: Tino Scarpa, who owned Tino's restaurant on East 58th Street from 1973 to 1988, says his life ''has come full circle'' with the opening of a new Tino's two weeks ago. The name of this one has been updated to Tino's.com, and the location is 40 West 56th Street (between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas).

title: Julie Margolis, Ross Yustein
description: Julie Lynne Margolis, a daughter of Roberta and Stephen Margolis of South Salem, N.Y., was married last evening to Ross Leonard Yustein, the son of Jackie and Mark Yustein of Glen Ridge, N.J. Rabbi Steven M. Rosman performed the ceremony at the Manhattan Penthouse in New York.

title: For State's Small Ski Areas, It's Downhill
description: A conglomerate bought the Vernon Valley Great Gorge ski area in Vernon, renamed it Mountain Creek and is pouring $20 million into snow-making equipment and new lifts as well as a general face lift. Such areas, with their size and amenities, have overshadowed the state's smaller ski hills. And with an extra shove from recent warm winters, two of those areas have announced they will not open this winter.

title: Status is ... for Math and Science Researchers; Writing a Paper With a Big Shot
description: In a world where most people broadcast their status to all who care to listen, scientists seem decidedly out of step. They drive beat-up cars and work in cluttered labs. They dress like the students they once were -- in scruffy T-shirts and faded jeans. (Or, in the case of mathematicians, they don socks and sandals, even in the bitter cold of winter.) But of course, no insular society could exist without its pecking order. The status clues may seem opaque to outsiders, but to those who have walked the halls of science, they are as clear as a test tube.

title: Corruption Remains In Carting, F.B.I. Says
description: AGENTS of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who have been investigating organized crime's influence on the carting industry in Westchester say they have credible allegations that corrupt practices of the past are still going on. This includes bribes to government officials, violence and intimidation of potential competitors.

title: From New Zealand, Five With Flair
description: WELLINGTON, at the southwestern tip of New Zealand's North Island, is the country's political and cultural capital. Home of the national museum, library, theater and opera, it also sponsors a biennial arts festival and reputedly has more bookshops per person than any other city in this nation of avid readers.

title: Ba-Doom Sss: Did You Hear The One . . .
description: THE SETTING A group of aspiring comedians trading punch lines from yesteryear, at a stand-up comedy class for the elderly at Intermediate School 44 on West 77th Street. The instructor of the Sunday class, sponsored by the Jewish Association for Services for the Aged, is Tim Davis, who also teaches at Stand Up New York, the comedy club on West 78th Street. But last Sunday, Mr. Davis learned a thing or two himself about old-school comedians.

title: Oh Dad, Poor Dad
description: THE LITTLE SCARECROW BOY

title: Finding Her Stage In the Costume Racks
description: IT wasn't fear that made Suzy Benzinger pass out on stage 26 years ago, during her high school's production of ''Fiddler on the Roof'' in Orchard Park, N.Y., a Buffalo suburb. It was exhaustion. Not only was she acting in the play and running the box office, but she had designed the sets and posters and, with a teacher, sewn the costumes.

title: Angel on Toast
description: Dawn Powell

title: Children's Books in Brief; Let's Misbehave
description: First, let's give David Shannon his due as a deeply serious illustrator of children's books. He has collaborated with the estimable Jane Yolen on such worthy volumes as ''Encounter,'' the story of Columbus's discovery of the New World as recounted in halting English by a native Taino boy, and the based-on-fact proto-feminist fable ''The Ballad of the Pirate Queens.'' His portrayal of America's mythic giant, Paul, avec famille et ox in Audrey Wood's book ''The Bunyans'' earned an ABC Children's Booksellers' Choice award. And the sports fable Shannon wrote and illustrated, ''How Georgie Radbourn Saved Baseball,'' was a 1994 New York Times Best Illustrated Book. So it is with great relief for children everywhere that I can now report David Shannon is applying his considerable talents to the sillier side of life. To wit: earlier this year ''A Very Bad Case of Stripes'' (a colorful ode to self-acceptance) and now his latest book, NO, DAVID! (Blue Sky/Scholastic, $14.95; ages 2 to 6) -- a hilarious compilation of toddlers' wrongdoings. As the author's note explains: ''A few years ago, my mother sent me a book I made when I was a little boy. It was called 'No, David' and it was illustrated with drawings of David doing all sorts of things he wasn't supposed to do.'' Shannon remains true to the spirit of this earlier work with a restrained prose style -- ''No, David!'' ''I said no, David!'' and ''That's enough, David!'' Likewise, the quasi-stick-figure drawings of little David are a clearly humorous homage to his original depictions. Parents might weary of the chastising tone -- until they start chuckling, probably about where I did, at the two-page spread of an open-mouthed David hollering through a mouthful of vegetables. Children, on the other hand, will recognize immediately that they have found a kindred spirit. M. P. Dunleavey

title: Sports of The Times; Red Holzman, the Modest Assistant, Always Had a Plan
description: ZORBA THE GREEK taught a young man to dance. Red the Coach taught New York fans to chant ''Dee-fense! Dee-fense!''

title: Benefits
description: For Musicians in Need

title: Bennett Kleinberg, Elaine Goldberg
description: Elaine Goldberg, the daughter of Barbara Burke of Bellerose, Queens, and Samuel Goldberg of East Norwich, N.Y., is to be married today to Bennett Jonathan Kleinberg, a son of Eileen and Arthur Kleinberg of Verona, N.J. Rabbi Norman R. Patz is to officiate at the Maplewood Country Club in Maplewood, N.J.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: Josanie's WarBy Karl H. Schlesier.University of Oklahoma, $22.95.

title: Norman's Team Is One Stroke Back
description: Greg Norman could not have written the script any better at his Shark Shootout.

title: Children's Books in Brief
description: THE 20TH CENTURY

title: BEST SELLERS: November 15, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Deborah Cooper, Marquis Gilmore
description: Deborah Jeanne Cooper and Marquis Doyle Gilmore were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. R. Maurice Boyd, in an ecumenical ceremony at the James Burden Mansion in New York.

title: Country Inn With an Ambitious Menu
description: ALMOST picture perfect, Cobb's Mill Inn in Weston is the quintessential country inn, complete with waterfall and resident waterfowl. So pretty as a backdrop for celebrations, this 200-year-old gristmill-turned-restaurant has often coasted on its charm, with food a distant, secondary reason for a visit.

title: A-mounting to Something In the Wild, Wild East
description: WHEN Easterners learn you're from Nebraska, you can divide them into three irritating groups: those who wonder if you can milk a cow, those who assume you can ride, and those who ask, ''Did you live in a town, or . . .?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROCHSTEIN, SAM
description: BROCHSTEIN-Sam. With heads bowed, we mourn the loss of our good friend and former Executive Committee member, Sam Brochstein. Always an ardent supporter, Sam was instrumental in establishing programs of Jewish educational outreach. May his memory be for a blessing. We shall miss him. Irving M. Rosenbaum, National Chair Eric G. Heffler, Executive Vice President American Friends of The Open University of Israel

title: AT THE MUSEUMS: VANDERBILT PLANETARIUM; Shepherd's Watch
description: The sun, moon, planets, stars and celestial coordinates are projected onto the 60-foot hemispherical dome at the Vanderbilt Planetarium, and the special effect reproduces their motion in accurate time scales.

title: For Readers And Revelers
description: Celebrating the library, charities, scholarships, the arts and a birthday.

title: Small World
description: Errant behavior and Freudian secrets tilt a repressed village in Sam Wood's KINGS ROW (1942), a gripping drama with Robert Cummings, Ann Sheridan and Ronald Reagan as the compelling young leads. Reagan, a rewarding surprise as the local Lothario, who undergoes amputation, has the film's best-known line in his screaming entreaty to Ms. Sheridan: ''Randy, where's the rest of me?'' The picture was sensibly adapted by Casey Robinson from a popular novel by henry Bellamann. The film's tone is one of intelligent restraint, and the dark doings, never lurid, are further dignified by one of Hollywood's most famed scores, from the great Erich Wolfgang Korngold - Monday at 10 P.M. on TCM.

title: Little Engines That Could
description: WINDOW MUSIC

title: The Elusive, and Tasty, Beach Plum Jelly
description: THE makers of beach plum jelly don't find their main ingredient on supermarket shelves. These cooks court danger, foraging over windswept dunes and fragile beach banks, warding off ticks, poison ivy, chiggers, craggy bushes and even cranky landowners. The chalky purple fruit, which is about the size of a large marble, is as a elusive as the finished product -- a tangy jelly produced by a dwindling number of individuals and specialty retailers.

title: President for Life
description: THE LAST KING

title: The Annual Dance Around Capital Gains
description: For tax reasons, investors are often advised to avoid buying a mutual fund just before it distributes its dividends and capital gains for the year. But what if you need to sell a fund? If your fund's value has fallen this year, are there advantages in selling it before the distribution date, which often falls in December?

title: The Guru of Doing It Right Still Sees Much Work to Do
description: IT is hard to believe that Joseph M. Juran is 93 years old.

title: German Nazism Was No 'Aberration'
description: To the Editor:

title: Four Who Flew Remember the Nest
description: I MOVED to the North Fork from upstate New York in 1977 when I was 12. For the next 20 years or so, my family lived in Mattituck, next to a potato field and across from Deep Hole Creek.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEGENSTEIN, CHARLES B.
description: DEGENSTEIN-Charles B., 92, business and civic leader, humanitarian and philanthropist, died at 7:45 am Wednesday, November 11, 1998, at his home in Selinsgrove, PA. He was born March 18, 1906, in Atlantic City, NJ, a son of the late David and Bertha (Beckman) Degenstein. Mr. Degenstein's family moved in 1906 from Atlantic City to Philadelphia, where his father established D. Degenstein & Company, a ladies' coat and suit manufacturing company. Mr. Degenstein married the former Claire Elizabeth ''Betty'' Weis, who died February 25, 1978. On January 3, 1980, he married the former Lore A. (Tromsdorf) Stock. Mr. Degenstein was a graduate of the Charles Morris Price School of Advertising and Temple University, both of Philadelphia. He began his career at Stern and Company, Philadelphia, with a brief stint at Progress Manufacturing Company in New York City. During his Philadelphia days, he met Claire Elizabeth Weis and her father, Sigmund, both of whom cast an important influence upon Mr. Degenstein's life. Following his marriage to Betty Weis, he moved to Sunbury, PA, where he was an executive at Weis Pure Food Stores, later called Weis Markets, Inc. He continued in that company's work as it grew to a most successful chain of supermarkets now serving a six-state area. Mr. Degenstein was a member of the Sunbury Rotary Club since 1950 and was past president; president of Susquehanna Valley Chamber of Commerce and the Sunbury Industrial Drive; member of the board of the Sunbury Youth and Community Center during the construction of the pool and skating rink; director of the YMCA; member and past president of the Susquehanna Valley Country Club; served on the Susquehanna University Board of Directors and was an honorary member of the Susquehanna University Board of Directors at the time of his death; and was recently named an honorary life member of the Americus Hose Company, Sunbury. He was a member of B'Nai Zion Temple. He was chief benefactor of the Degenstein Foundations, which have benefited Pennsylvania's Susquehanna Valley since the 1970s. He was chief benefactor of the Lore Degenstein Gallery at Susquehanna University through an endowment made by him in honor of his wife. He was also chief benefactor of the Degenstein Scholars Program which benefits students in the university's Sigmund Weis School of Business. In addition to his wife, surviving are three stepsons, Marlin Stock of Orwigsburg, Steven Stock of Selinsgrove and Charles Stock of Santa Barbara, CA, one stepdaughter, Nancy Stock Hunsinger of Danville; three step-grandchildren; one brother and sister-in-law, Lester and Lila Degenstein of New York, NY; sister-in-law, Janet C. Weis; four nieces, Susan Mindel, Nancy Wender, Ellen Goldstein and Jane Zweifler; and two nephews, Walter Zweifler and Lee Degenstein. He was preceded in death by one sister, Anita Zweifler, and one brother-in-law, Sigfried Weis. The funeral was on Friday, November 13, at the Degenstein Center Theater at the Charles B. Degenstein Campus Center, Susquehanna University. Burial was in B'nai Zion Cemetery, Danville. Contributions may be made to Susquehanna University, 514 University Avenue, Selinsgrove, PA 17870; Penn State-Geisinger Medical Center, 100 N. Academy Avenue, Danville, PA 17821; the Harry and Sigmund Weis Wing of Sunbury Community Hospital, 350 N. 11th Street, Sunbury, PA 17801; the John R. Kauffman Jr. Public Library, 228 Arch Street, Sunbury; or a charity of the donor's choice. V.L. Seebold Funeral Home, Selinsgrove, Pennsylvania.

title: The Nation: Impeachment Maneuvers; Wrapping Things Up, in Knots
description: CALL it ''No Exit,'' the Capitol's own existentialist drama. The American public has signaled that it wants the drive to impeach President Clinton to end. So do most House Democrats. So do many Republicans. Yet the Republicans and Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee have such a strange synergy that they just cannot seem to stop egging each other on and on and on.

title: Status is ... for Gourmets; The Coolest Heat
description: The ultimate status symbol for gourmet food nuts is a Viking Range. I know this is true because I am one and I want one. Bad. The one I want is the Lamborghini Diablo of stoves: a sleek, stainless-steel cook vault with double roasting ovens, a Gourmet Glo infrared broiler and a cooktop fairly bristling with fire-breathing, 15,000 B.T.U. mongo-burners. When you turn 'em on high, you get a cone of fire approximating the output of a space-shuttle thruster. This thing will bring a huge lobster pot to a boil in a matter of a few moments, rather than the good hour and 10 minutes it takes the 1957 lame-o suburb-o-range I'm cooking on right now. It'll crank up a saute pan so hot you can put a crust on a blackened halibut steak that would turn well-coifed heads at Moomba. In fact, I want a Viking so bad I've gone to the trouble of seeking one out in friends' houses and offering to come over and cook up a fine dinner just to get near it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAGE, SUSAN R.
description: PAGE-Susan R., M.D. peacefully November 9 Shokan, NY. Columbia Univ, Pace Univ, Case Western Medical. Survived by husband Sherret Chase, Page Chase.

title: Food; Brownie Points
description: The discovery of a new dish, wrote Brillat-Savarin, does more for the happiness of man than the discovery of a new star. You could also say that maintaining a national favorite does more for society than holidays and patriotic pledges. Women with reputations for the ''best'' chowder or chili, brownies or apple pie, are accorded a certain status in America. They are like latter-day wizards, assumed to have a secret ingredient or a special touch. It is their recipes that become the standard-bearers, as well as the lodestars for entire communities. And like anybody famous, they are treated with equal measures of gratitude, envy and awe.

title: State Urges Schools to Begin Random Search of Students' Lockers
description: The State Attorney General, Peter G. Verniero, urged school officials today to start authorizing random searches of student lockers for drugs and weapons.

title: The Honeymooners Amid the Storm
description: HEMMED in by large windows overlooking St. Peter's Lutheran Church in midtown Manhattan, the fourth-floor library shared by the two men running the world's largest financial services concern is a study in contrasts.

title: November 8-14; Lost, and Gained, in the Translation
