description: One of the reasons movie studios make so many action pictures is that they do well overseas. There are no translation problems when Bruce Willis is firing an Uzi or fleeing a fireball.

title: Status is ... for Native Americans; Fancy Footwork
description: With the current swing-dancing craze, American kids have decided that it's hip to learn the footsteps of their forebears. But this kind of ancestor worship has long been part of the American Indian community, where traditional tribal dancing has been the rage for centuries. The best traditional dancers are Elvises in braids. (With their left-foot-right-foot 4/4 rhythms, they were among the first to appreciate the rock beat.) But tribal dancers are more than just cool: they're figures of respect, admired for their reverence of Indian tradition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILLIGAN, ROSE R.
description: GILLIGAN-Rose R. On November 13, 1998. Retired professor, Hunter College. Beloved sister of Eleanore and the late Kathleen Gilligan, and Celestine Frankenberg. Dear aunt of James, Gregory and the late Michael Gilligan, Susan Sckittone, Kathleen and William Crosby, and Kathryn Malone. Friends may call at the Adrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave (at 20th St), NYC, Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Epiphany R.C. Church, Tuesday, 10 AM. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, MARGARET T.
description: GALLAGHER-Margaret T. Died in her sleep early Sunday morning, November 8. The cause of death was pneumonia. Margaret, known as Nancy throughout her life, was 82 years old. She is survived by her loving daughter, Nancy M. Gallagher, a financial consultant, and her son, Thomas A. Gallagher, a patent attorney. She was married to James T. Gallagher, General Counsel to the Long Island Railroad, who passed away in 1972. An active member of the Epiphany Roman Catholic Church in NYC, she devoted many hours to volunteer work and was beloved by parishoners for her kindness and her keen wit. She was the author of many short stories and poems. She will be remembered by all who knew her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOPHER, MORRIS
description: SOPHER-Morris. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family mourns the passing of our dear friend and benefactor, Morris Sopher. He was a wonderful humanitarian who will be greatly missed. With his beloved wife Marilyn, they shared their concern for others facing a cancer diagnosis through their generous support of many programs and services and Beth Israel's Cancer Center. To Marilyn, the entire Sopher family and all of his loved ones, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman Chairman, Board of Trustees Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President & CEO Marilyn Halper, Executive Director, Cancer Center

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: FLORA'S SUITCASE

title: Harold Ford Jr. Storms His Father's House
description: Rep. Harold E. Ford Jr. says, ''I'd have a message'' (Dana Milbank, Oct. 25). But it appears that there is no message and no vision other than political expedience behind the junior Ford's drive to help move the Democratic Party to the center (hardly an original idea in itself). Ford's aspiration in fact smacks of privilege. Perhaps his father shouldn't have given him that ''silver BMW'' while he was still in prep school.

title: Optical Allusions
description: LOOK-ALIKESBy Joan Steiner.Photographs by Thomas Lindley.Unpaged. Boston:Little, Brown & Company. $12.95.(Ages 3 and up)

title: Women, Yes. Democrats, No!
description: Marjorie M. Scardino, chief executive of Pearson P.L.C., is used to the slights that come from being the only woman executive in the room. In January 1997, when she became the first American and the first woman to head Pearson, the British media group that owns The Financial Times and Penguin publishing, eyebrows rose in the male-dominated City and the stock fell 2.4 percent.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Franklin Township, N.J.; A Town Acting to Preserve Its Farmland
description: EARLY this month residents of Franklin Township voted 6,092 to 2,834 to raise their property taxes by 3 cents per $100 of assessed valuation to preserve open space. Mayor Joan I. Bottcher said the new funds would be used to buy some local farmland before it is snatched up by developers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SILBERFARB, MELINDA
description: SILBERFARB-Melinda. She was a devoted wife, mother and friend. It's her first anniversary in Heaven. She flies with the angels. You will be forever in our hearts. Love, The Uribe Family

title: Coretta and Yokama Cruise to Victory
description: The Long Island Handicap, with an overflow list of 24 horses, was split into two divisions at Aqueduct yesterday, and the winners, surviving the numbers and the traffic, were Coretta, a 4-year-old filly bred in Ireland, and Yokama, a 5-year-old mare bred in Florida.

title: CORRECTION
description: A credit was omitted last Sunday for a picture with the Streetscapes column showing St. Marks Place in 1910. The picture was from the Ransom Humanities Center of the University of Texas.

title: Privately, Inspections Seem to Be Less of a Hassle
description: Jennifer Ciambrone was taking her Toyota Celica for its annual inspection here Thursday morning when she noticed something odd about the staff. ''They were actually nice and said hello to me,'' Ms. Ciambrone of Oceanport said. ''They usually don't say 'boo.' They just grunt at you.''

title: The Nation: Dreams of Fields; The New Politics Of Urban Sprawl
description: WHAT the author Tom Wolfe did for radical chic in the 1960's, narcissism in the 70's, and greed in the 80's, he may now be doing for runaway real estate development in his new novel on America at century's end. Urban sprawl, with all its strip-mall excess and soul-deadening homogeneity, is not just a central backdrop, but almost a character in ''A Man in Full,'' the author's latest pen poke at contemporary life.

title: Indonesian Chief Takes Tough Line on Protests
description: Faced with a huge student protest and a wild outbreak of rioting and arson today, President B. J. Habibie said he would take ''firm action'' to curb what he called subversive movements that threaten the country's stability.

title: Q&A/Dr. Janis Abrahms Spring; Coping With the Aftermath of Infidelity
description: HEALING the pain of infidelity is the life work of Dr. Janis Abrahms Spring. A marriage therapist, a clinical supervisor in Yale's psychology department and the author of ''After the Affair'' (HarperCollins, 1997), she fields questions about why adultery happens and how to cope with the aftermath. Her research shows that infidelity is one of the most common -- ''I think the numbers here are huge'' -- and most difficult to treat problems in human relationships.

title: Ideas & Trends; The Herbal Potions That Make Science Sick
description: IN San Diego on Tuesday, two major drug companies rolled out studies showing the safety and effectiveness of a new class of prescription pain relievers; they had been duly tested on thousands of patients, some for up to a year. Such testing was a minimum requirement before the drugs could be prescribed to millions of Americans. If the Food and Drug Administration approves, the drugs can be sold.

title: Overdue Appreciation
description: To The Editor:

title: Best Illustrated Books 1998
description: The illustrations on these pages have been taken from the Book Review's choices of the 10 best illustrated children's books of 1998. Since 1952, the Book Review has annually asked a panel of judges to make a selection from among the several thousand children's books published each year. The judges this year were Starr Latronica, from the Four County Library System in Vestal, N.Y.; Chris Van Allsburg, the author and illustrator, whose books include ''The Polar Express'' and ''The Mysteries of Harris Burdick''; and Roger Sutton, the editor of The Horn Book magazine. As a matter of note, William Steig has been a winner three times before; Barbara McClintock, twice; Richard Egielski, Mordicai Gerstein and David Shannon, once before.

title: A Woman and a Jockey and She Doesn't Flinch From Either Role
description: CHECK this for a Long Island resume: Diane Nelson, 33 years old, single, 5 feet 6 inches tall, 110 pounds, born in Rockville Centre, raised in Holtsville, studied at Sachem High School, lives in Oceanside, has done major-league modeling but prefers horses and makes her living as a jockey, riding 1,200-pound racehorses at 35 miles an hour for big bucks.

title: Ski clubs provide camaraderie, and discounts
description: For many skiers, ski clubs have long provided a relatively low-cost way to reach the slopes. The clubs are usually nonprofit local groups that charge nominal membership fees (generally between $20 and $50 a year) and provide activities year-round. But the high point for most members is the ski trips to domestic and foreign resorts, which also provide chances to meet people.

title: IN MY...BRIEFCASE -- STEPHEN R. COVEY
description: Stephen R. Covey, author of the best-selling book ''The Seven Habits of Highly Effective People'' (Fireside/Simon & Schuster), keeps spare briefcases under his desk just in case the one he carries falls apart or gets left behind in an airport lounge. As he tours the country promoting his books and lecturing to clients, Dr. Covey carries a heavy load of reading material. A devout Mormon, he is never without a Bible, and he has lately added a Sunday School manual for a course he is teaching on the Old Testament.

title: Marcia Storch Dies; Womens's Health Pioneer
description: Dr. Marcia L. Storch, an innovator in women's health care, died Nov. 9 at her home in Tenants Harbor, Me. She was 65.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, HOWARD A.
description: BERNSTEIN-Howard A. Lovingly remembering you on your birthday. In our hearts forever. Our family

title: Stubborn Belief in Duty Guided Slain Doctor
description: Everyone who knew Dr. Barnett A. Slepian knew that the slight, graying physician endured a measure of stress that would exhaust, even break, most people.

title: Status is ... for Middle-class 8-year-olds; A Stay-At-Home Mom
description: Eight-year-olds are deeply conservative. True, they embrace strange and arbitrary fads, but only those driven by the cultlike collective will of the third-grade class. (''Beanie Babies are over, Mom. We all collect yo-yos now.'') They don't like newfangled food on their dinner plates. And when it comes to their mothers, they are steadfastly retrograde, shunning the new, self-fulfilled model. Especially now, when 70 percent of mothers work, a stay-at-home mom has become the ultimate trophy, reflecting prosperity and proving to the children that they are, in fact, the center of the universe.

title: Mary Reynolds, Michael Gilmore
description: Mary Kathleen Reynolds, the daughter of Patricia and Eugene J. Reynolds of New Hyde Park, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Michael Patrick Gilmore, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Gilmore of Westbury, N.Y. The Rev. Anthony Stanganelli performed the ceremony at Holy Spirit Roman Catholic Church.

title: 'The Big Mac of Medicine'
description: Prozac DiaryBy Lauren Slater.203 pp. New York:Random House. $21.95.

title: Taking the Starch Out of Status
description: In the spring of 1996, two young men named David Filo and Jerry Yang, both still in their 20's, became overnight multimillionaires. They did it, of course, the way everybody becomes an overnight multimillionaire nowadays. They started an Internet company in their spare time --just for fun, they called it Yahoo! -- and after securing some venture capital, they completed an Initial Public Offering, or I.P.O., to use the initials that even schoolchildren can now toss off on the playground. Yahoo! stock opened for business at $4.33 a share (split-adjusted, I scarcely need to mention), and by the end of that first day, the stock had risen 154 percent. That's a bigger first-day gain than even during Netscape's fabled I.P.O. Presto! Filo and Yang, who held 31 percent of the stock, were suddenly worth a combined $270 million. If that's not the classic definition of ''New Money,'' I don't know what is.

title: Karen Idra, Paulo Kaiser
description: Karen Pola Idra, the daughter of Sara and Menashe Idra of Rego Park, Queens, was married last evening to Paulo Francis Kaiser, a son of Roberta and Marcio Kaiser of Sao Paulo, Brazil. Rabbi Meyer H. Leifer officiated at the Rihga Royal Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Surveillance Comes Under Cloud
description: WHEN is a kiss just a kiss, and when does it become a matter of public record?

title: HOLIDAY MOVIES; For Every Home, A Video Theater
description: HARDCORE videophiles are a suffering lot. Determined to re-create in their homes an experience akin to that of the local movie theater -- minus the sticky floor and ringing cell phones -- these enthusiasts can spend $100,000 or more pursuing cutting-edge equipment that promises to deliver the nuance and impact of celluloid. They log endless hours on the World Wide Web debating the merits of the latest wide-screen projector or surround-sound processor, and they pay technicians hundreds of dollars to calibrate their televisions so the image is just so.

title: Southern Roads Lead to Harlem
description: CHARLES' SOUTHERN-STYLE

title: Editorial Observer; The Shifting Meanings of 'Black' and 'White'
description: The proof that Thomas Jefferson fathered a child with Sally Hemings has embarrassed historians who saw him as too noble for sex with a slave -- and vindicated black descendants who knew all along that he was as lusty as anyone else. Genetic tests have linked Jefferson to Hemings's final child, Eston, born in 1808. But even historians who defended Jefferson for decades are finding it hard to believe that he avoided Hemings while the two were young and vital and made her his lover only as he approached the grave. The emerging consensus is that the two became lovers earlier and that the affair went on longer than we yet know.

title: When Children Fly Alone
description: THE holidays bring an increase of children flying by themselves -- to see the other parent in case of divorce, to visit grandparents, to return home from boarding-school vacations.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEBAN, FRANCIS J.
description: KLEBAN-Francis J. In loving memory of a beloved husband, devoted father, loving grandfather and fond great-grandfather who passed away November 18, 1995.

title: Baddies or Butlers
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Notable 'Firsts'; Firsts by Rail
description: ''People say the automobile created the suburbs, but it was really the railroad,'' said Ron Ziel, a rail historian from Water Mill. ''The automobile just messed them up.''

title: Stumbling Bookstore: The Case of the Near-Empty Shelves
description: It looks like another SoHo landmark is about to fall victim to the red-hot commercial real estate market downtown. Maybe, that is.

title: Carol Platt and Frederic Liebau Jr.
description: Carol Andreae Platt and Frederic Jack Liebau Jr. were married last evening at the Church of SS. Michael and George in St. Louis. The Rev. Gary D. Hamp performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Science Fiction
description: It's a tough job, but someone has to do it: bring the crime-and-thriller genre known as ''noir'' into the 21st century. Fortunately, K. W. Jeter is up to the task, and in NOIR (Spectra/ Bantam, $23.95) he lays out the future with a cheerless tenacity Raymond Chandler might have applauded.

title: Sealing Off The Wintry Weather
description: IF there was a one-inch hole in an exterior wall of your house that hole would get plugged pretty quickly this time of year, right?

title: Children's Books in Brief; Here, Kitty
description: Two new picture books with the same title, CAT UP A TREE, could not be more different. The one by Ann Hassett, illustrated by John Hassett (Walter Lorraine/Houghton Mifflin, $15; ages 3 to 8), is funny and whimsical and engaging, while the one by Anne Isaacs, illustrated by Stephen Mackey (Dutton, $15.99; ages 3 to 5), is just pretentious. The Hassetts' Nana Quimby, plump and bespectacled in sneakers, apron and purple polka-dot house dress, is in the middle of baking chocolate chip cookies when she sees a cat who needs help. Five, then 10, then 15, on up to 40 cats end up in the tree outside Nana Quimby's window. She calls the Fire Department: '' 'Sorry,' said the firehouse, 'we do not catch cats up a tree anymore. Call back if that cat starts playing with matches.' '' The police are interested only if the cats rob a bank, and the pet store says, ''Call back if the cats wish to buy a dog.'' The zoo, the post office, the library, City Hall, nobody wants to help, so Nana Quimby throws the telephone out the window and into the tree, and the cats walk across its wire and into her arms. When the town that wouldn't help finds itself overrun with mice and calls her, they find out just how much help they can expect in return: '' 'Sorry,' said Nana Quimby, 'the cats do not catch mice anymore. Call back if you wish to hear cats purr.' '' John Hassett paints a delightful world with grape jelly-bean clouds and noodle cats with spaghetti tails who curl and drape and leap in every which way and every which color. This is a book to read and reread, with cats to count and recount, and little visual details like satellite dishes and mice on windowsills to spot with each new pass. Sadly, Anne Isaacs, the author of the Caldecott Honor book ''Swamp Angel,'' loses her footing with her collection of poems about a cat up a tree. The verse is filled with embarrassing metaphysical vocabulary: how does one explain phrases like ''Pour down your cold, transmuting fire'' to a small or medium-sized child, and why would one bother? John Donne meets T. S. Eliot this ain't; and Stephen Mackey's murky oil paintings of poets, pyramids and moonlight lack spark and wit. What's in a name? Jen Nessel

title: Why Are the Grown-Ups Crying?
description: NO PRETTY PICTURES

title: Steel, Sweat and Tunnels
description: SURE, trying to get out of the city using the Queens-Midtown or Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel sans E-Z Pass can be a chore, but at least you're not digging your way through. An exhibition of more than 40 photographs and renderings at the New York Transit Museum documents the efforts of those who did.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOGLE, ELSTON EDGAR
description: FOGLE-Elston Edgar. Died on November 9, 1998, two days following his 91st birthday in Ocean Ridge, FL. Born in Barnesville, Ohio, he was the eldest son of Rev. Charles E. Fogle and Emma Edgar Fogle. A member of Phi Beta Kappa, he graduated Magna Cum Laude from Marietta College in Marietta, Ohio in 1930 and immediately joined the Union Carbide and Carbon Chemicals Company as a research fellow at Pittsburgh's Mellon Institute. Beginning in 1940, he was promoted through District, Regional and National Sales manager positions. On loan from Union Carbide during the Korean War, he served for a year as Director of the Rubber, Chemicals, Drugs and Fuel Division of the U.S. Office of Price Stabilization in Washington, D.C. In 1957, he was promoted to President of Union Carbide Chemicals Company and ultimately to Vice President of Union Carbide Corporation, a position he held until his retirement in 1968. With Doris (Clendenin) Fogle, his wife of 52 years who passed away in 1987, he was a long-time resident of Rowayton and Darien, Connecticut. For many years, he served as a Deacon of the United Church of Rowayton and was President of the Wee Burn Country Club from 1958-61. In 1961, he was awarded an Honorary Doctorate from his alma mater Marietta College. Since 1968, he has resided in Ocean Ridge, Florida, where he served as a Governor of the Ocean Club and President of The Little Club from 1979-81. He is survived by his beloved wife of ten years, Lois (Sundberg) Fogle of Ocean Ridge, his brothers French R. Fogle and William Fogle, his sister Faye Casey, his sons and daughters-in-law Robert C. and Patricia Fogle of Woodbury, Connecticut and John E. and Jean C. Fogle of Marblehead, Massachusetts, his four grandchildren Gregory E. Fogle of Albany, New York, Robert M. Fogle of Georgetown, Massachusetts, Lauren F. Fogle of Washington, D.C. and Jenna C. Fogle of Marblehead, and his great-granddaughter Charlotte Fogle of Albany. Local funeral services will be private, but an open memorial service to celebrate his wonderful life will be held in Rowayton, CT. at a later date. For additional information, contact Lorne & Sons Funeral Home, Delray Beach, FL.

title: FYI
description: Orphan Building

title: Corrections
description: The On Language column on page 34 of The Times Magazine today misstates the surname of the Secretary of Commerce. He is William Daley, not Paley.

title: Take Two Stocks and Call Me in the Morning
description: IT should come as no surprise that investors out to shield themselves from the recent market volatility would dive into the stocks of drug makers. After all, people get sick regardless of market conditions. But what no one could have predicted was that some investors would pass up such comet stocks as Warner-Lambert, up 76.5 percent this year, and Schering-Plough, up 64 percent, for the likes of Johnson & Johnson and Bristol-Myers Squibb.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the Food column on Nov. 1 misidentified three types of mushrooms. Those with yellowish stems were girolles, not yellow oysters. Those with white stems were yellow oysters, not girolles. The black mushrooms were black trumpets, not gray oysters.

title: Fans Who Do Much More Than Applaud
description: LITTLE FEAT'S gig at Club Bene in Sayreville on Saturday night will be just another stop on a two-month tour for the 29-year-old rock and blues band. But for the state's Little Feat fans, the concert will be much more than a display of enthusiasm: the group has placed much of its professional survival in their hands.

title: Arcade Idea Dropped
description: A plan for a $1 million arcade and superstore to fill a long-empty storefront in the Galleria mall in White Plains was dropped this month when the man who was seeking it ended an 18-month fight with the city's Common Council. The sticking point, according to city officials, was the refusal by Danny Levin, owner of the Boston-based Dream Machine Company, to restrict the content of games in the proposed arcade.

title: Loco for logos
description: Some people derive status from owning works of art. Others find that labels on clothes and accessories confer all the status they need. While the ''designer'' artworks shown here would seem to satisfy everyone, they're for purposes of parody only. They were made by Tom Sachs, a young artist who has been obsessed with labels since he was old enough to participate in the suburban cult of Lacoste alligators in the late 1970's.

title: Four Who Flew Remember the Nest
description: MY friend Elizabeth is not a native New Yorker, let alone a Long Islander. So I was quite curious when last year she told me she had bought a house -- a weekend retreat from her Brooklyn co-op apartment.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: LEONARDO'S MOUNTAIN OF CLAMS AND THE DIET OF WORMS

title: Some Notable 'Firsts'; First Mass-Housing Suburb
description: Troops returning home to the New York metropolitan area after World War II stepped into a housing crisis. Apartments were scarce and houses, when they could be found, were too expensive for veterans.

title: How the Jet Brought Christmas (and a Profit)
description: SO you have this 73-foot Norway spruce that has to get from Cleveland to New York. Hauling it 500 miles in a tractor-trailer or a boxcar isn't an option: It would arrive in no shape to wow crowds as Rockefeller Center's Christmas tree. And a ship would be too slow.

title: Chanel, No. 1
description: On an autumn evening in Paris in 1970, Coco Chanel was preparing a dinner party for the Duke and Duchess of Windsor. Elegant in a white suit, surrounded by crystal, mirrors and candlelight, Chanel commandeered the entranced former king for an intimate talk, barely interrupted by dinner. She was nearly 87 at the time. So begins CHANEL: Her Style and Her Life (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $35), a fascinating and visually stunning biography by Janet Wallach, the author of ''Desert Queen,'' a biography of Gertrude Bell. Born into poverty in 1883 and motherless before her 12th birthday, Chanel spent her adolescence in an orphanage, abandoned by her father. At the age of 18, she was sent as a charity student to a convent boarding school where she learned to sew. Chanel started making pared-down and simply styled clothing for herself, and began a career. Already an established figure by the start of World War I, she came to include in her circle Picasso, Matisse, Cocteau and Diaghilev; Stravinsky was yet another lover. Wallach wryly observes that while Chanel pursued painters, poets and musicians, she ardently desired the extravagance that only aristocrats could provide. She was an inveterate snob throughout her life. Arrested after World War II for her liaison with a German officer, she escaped imprisonment and public humiliation, Wallach surmises, ''perhaps with the help of Churchill,'' an early acquaintance. About her Nazi lover, Chanel said feistily, ''At my age, when a man wants to sleep with you, you don't ask to see his passport.'' Lynn Karpen

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, ANNE
description: GOLDSTEIN-Anne. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Devoted mother of Natalie and Bernard Weiss, Edward and Ina Goldstein, and Lenore and Harvey Pearlman. Loving sister, adored grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: November 8-14; America Reduces Its Thirst
description: Water use has grown in lockstep with America's population and economy, and many have thought it would always be that way. But according to the United States Geological Survey, the nation used 9 percent less water in 1995 than in 1980, while the population grew by 16 percent. The reversal may reflect a shift in focus away from finding ways to expand the water supply and toward reducing demand. WILLIAM K. STEVENS

title: A Cluster of Restaurants Rated Excellent
description: IT is Great Gatsby country, the Gold Coast and a millionaire's playground. But the North Shore of Nassau County is also a treasure trove of outstanding restaurants. There is a greater density here than anywhere on the Island, with the possible exception of the Hamptons.

title: Reader's Digest Parts With Cherished Art
description: THE art auction scheduled for tomorrow and Tuesday nights at Sotheby's, when the Manhattan concern puts the renowned Reader's Digest Impressionist and Modern collection on the block, has been building suspense for nine weeks.

title: When Two Wheels Are Faster Than Four
description: WHEN a bicycle rider broke his collarbone along a narrow, winding trail at Cranbury Park in Norwalk during the Jackrabbit Run mountain bike race in September, he did not have to wait long for medical assistance.

title: A Show of Photographic Sleights That Also Reveals a Sense of Humor
description: THE premise of ''Through the Lens: Time Space and Matter'' at the Rye Arts Center here is hardly a novel one. The show, subtitled ''Camera Art at the Turn of the Millennium,'' argues that photography has changed radically over the course of the century and so it is no longer that hallowed window on the world. Rather, pictures can be made up or constructed and because of technological advances, many photographers perform these sleights convincingly.

title: Playing, Singing, Speaking and 'Doing Politics'
description: THE inevitable epidemics of runny noses and daydreaming aside, the Far Hills Country Day School kindergarten is a happy, lively place, where children are kept busy learning to play games, sing, feel good about being away from home, and ''share.'' In this regard, it is a typical kindergarten.

title: A Fresh Look at Cuba
description: Nearly 40 years after Fidel Castro came to power and a decade after the end of the cold war, a reconsideration of American policy toward Cuba is overdue. President Clinton was recently given a surprising and irresistible invitation to do exactly that. It came from a bipartisan group of senators and an impressive roster of former Republican national security officials. He should respond promptly and positively.

title: WATCHING TV WITH: Simon Doonan; No Emmy Yet for Men's Style
description: THE ratings are bad. The reviews are worse. There is, however, a bright side to the otherwise dim lineup of network shows that made debuts this fall: television has finally discovered a sense of men's style.

title: '99 Budget Hearings Scheduled
description: THE Board of Legislators has scheduled three public hearings on the county's proposed 1999 budget.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Status is ... for Contemporary Painters; Getting into MOMA -- In Miniature
description: Artists may spend their days staring into the heart of darkness, but they are hardly indifferent to the bright trappings of success. A museum retrospective, a teaching stint at Yale, the news that your painting has fetched some ridiculous sum at auction -- these are not distinctions to sneeze at. Status is often big and noisy. But there is also the status of small, silent things. And I know of no prize quite as lovely as the one that measures just 4 by 6 inches and grants a work of art a new 60-cent life as a museum postcard.

title: The Show Within The Show
description: A fashion show is like any other spectator sport. Keeping your eye glued to the ball -- or the runway -- can mean missing a lot of the action. Here is a replay of some the New York fashion week's reigning looks, worn by the editors, stylists and other players.

title: Susan Skipper, Daniel Burke
description: Susan Eileen Skipper, the daughter of Jean Skipper of Kinderhook, N.Y., and the late Robert Lee Skipper, is to be married this afternoon to Daniel Christopher Burke, the son of Jean and Richard Burke of Holbrook, N.Y. The Rev. Steven Peterson will perform the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in East Islip, N.Y.

title: HOLIDAY MOVIES: UP AND COMING -- Natasha Gregson Wagner; Nobody's Fool, in Need Of a Little Mothering
description: THE actress Natasha Gregson Wagner says she likes iconoclastic filmmakers, and not just because they have raw imaginations, offer unfiltered opinions and give her last-minute script changes filled with things she would never do or say.

title: How Toronto Keeps Its Edge
description: DECEMBER is 13 months long, July's one afternoon, the poet Alden Nowlan boasted in ''Canadian Love Song.'' It's an attitude Canadians embrace, taking a perverse joy in the length and severity of their winters, inventing or adopting defiant, robust pastimes to heat their blood from November to March.

title: Correspondence: Middle America in China; Funny, I Moved to Beijing And Wound Up in Pleasantville
description: I AM a product of America's cities. For the first 40 years of my life, I had never been to anything like Price Club. Dairy Queen was a once-a-year pit stop on vacations. I had never car-pooled to a soccer game. In fact, but for a brief period a decade ago, my husband and I never owned a car.

title: 'Partners in A Loft Venture'
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Notable 'Firsts'; Firsts by Air
description: Charles A. Lindbergh's 1927 trans-Atlantic flight from Roosevelt Field to Paris is remembered as an important historical first with Long Island roots.

title: Q. & A.
description: Security Deposit In a Co-op

title: Snowbird, Utah
description: As skiing holidays go, Cinco de Mayo doesn't rank with Christmas, New Year's or Presidents' Day. But at Snowbird, Utah, where about 500 inches of snow falls every year, what must have been inches 501 through 506 fell last May 5 as I was visiting -- just enough for a few die-hard skiers to leave their tracks in Utah's famed powder one last time before the summer.

title: DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: A Nonstop Party for South Asian Homeboys
description: Om Malik, whose father was an Indian Army officer and whose mother was a professor of Sanskrit, sounds almost apologetic when he talks about partying. ''I'm a grown man and

title: Status is ... for C.E.O.'s; Having a Networked Secretary
description: You're the C.E.O. of a major company. Your pay is in the eight figures. You've had a Gulfstream jet for some time now -- way before Myhrvold got his -- and, along with several of your peers, you're thinking about hiring someone to help you get dressed in the morning. If only your executive assistant were a member of the Seraphic Society. But alas, she can't even apply. She must wait to be asked to join.

title: Widow of Lennon, Guardian of Myth
description: AT a glance, the just released four-CD ''John Lennon Anthology'' looks very much like an ambitious collectors' trawl. Lavishly packaged and copiously annotated, this ''Anthology'' (Capitol) brims with studio outtakes, concert performances, private composing tapes and assorted spoken bits -- 94 selections in all. The thriving bootleg market has proved that the Beatles, collectively and individually, have a following that voraciously snaps up material of this kind.

title: Tide Turns in the Tobacco Wars
description: The $206 billion tobacco settlement that emerged Friday, designed to resolve state claims over health costs related to smoking, is a creation of state attorneys general, with no involvement by Federal officials.

title: Fighting for His Father, on Screen and Off
description: It was the bushy-haired intruder who did it after all.

title: Playing God In the Garden
description: Pollan's choice not to eat the fruit of his labors is his to make.

title: Rutgers Comes Back to Reality in Loss to West Virginia
description: The five victories that Rutgers brought into today's game against West Virginia have helped erase the stigma of last year's season without a victory. But as the Scarlet Knights were driving toward the Mountaineers' end zone in the final minutes of the third quarter, with a tie score just 13 yards away, the fans at Rutgers Stadium were beginning to believe what only those in the locker room had believed before.

title: 'Don't Ever Listen to a Talking Bug'
description: SQUIDS WILL BE SQUIDSFresh Morals, Beastly Fables.By Jon Scieszka.Illustrated by Lane Smith.Designed by Molly Leach.Unpaged. New York:Viking. $17.99.(Ages 8 and up)

title: Jailed Carlos, The Terrorist, Is Continuing Hunger Strike
description: The terrorist who calls himself Carlos has been on a hunger strike for 11 days, protesting his four years of solitary confinement in a French prison, where he is serving a life sentence for murder.

title: Mount Vernon Exhibit Opens in New York
description: Highlights from Mount Vernon, George Washington's estate, will tour the nation in observance of the 200th anniversary of his death on Dec. 14, 1799. And the official kick-off of the bicentennial will be in the city where Washington was sworn in as the first President: New York.

title: Four Who Flew Remember the Nest
description: CALL it perverse, but when I think of Long Island, my stomach starts rumbling. Get me a slice of that pie and I'm home. In the Midwest, where I spent 10 years, they refer to neither slices nor pies. And in the Northwest, where I have served the last two years, pizza is only an appetizer to a double-tall mocha latte.

title: Ilissa Shimony, Brian Levine
description: Ilissa Joy Shimony, the daughter of Martelle and Jerome Shimony of Dix Hills, N.Y., was married last evening to Brian David Levine, a son of Ellen and Harold Levine of Jericho, N.Y. Rabbi Stanley Steinhart performed the ceremony at the Jericho Jewish Center.

title: We Know What You'll See Next Summer...
description: LAST year's teen slasher smash, ''I Know What You Did Last Summer,'' proved that each generation of adolescents is new to the genre's creaky conventions. The formula calls for invincible, barely visible villains (Jason of ''Friday the 13th,'' Michael Myers of ''Halloween,'' Freddy Krueger of ''Nightmare on Elm Street'') shrouded in malevolent headgear (goalie mask, Halloween mask, felt brim fedora) and wielding sharp, shiny implements (hunting knife, carving knife, razorlike Lee press-on nails). The most important convention is the sequel, the ceaseless serializing of serial killing.

title: His Wife Might Be All for It
description: When Robert L. Crandall retired as chief of American Airlines in May, he said he wanted to take a year off. But already, Mr. Crandall, 62, is popping up on radar screens of companies looking for a new boss. People close to Electronic Data Systems, the computer-services giant founded by H. Ross Perot, say Mr. Crandall is being considered as the new No. 1.

title: From Video Store to Pizza Cafe, a Senator in Their Midst
description: Robert Carlucci describes himself as ''strictly Brooklyn,'' but that doesn't mean he's enthusiastic about the recent election of Brooklyn's own Charles E. Schumer to the Senate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, ANNE M.
description: SMITH-Anne M. (nee Seitz). Of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, on November 12, 1998. Graduated St. Joseph's College for Women, 1935. Past president of St. Joseph's College Alumni Association. Former English teacher for over 20 years at Bushwick High School, Brooklyn. Active member of Catholic charites. Beloved wife of 54 years to Edwin V. Smith. Loving aunt of Stephen E. and James M. Visiting Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 11:45 AM, St. Anselm's Church. Donations to Nursing Sisters Home Visiting Service, 500 19th St, Brooklyn, NY 11215, would be appreciated.

title: For New-Fashioned Romance, Click Here . . .
description: WHEN last we saw Tom Hanks with Meg Ryan, they fell in love before ever setting eyes on each other. ''What if someone you never met, someone you never saw, someone you never knew was the only someone for you?'' asked the advertisements for what seemed like a far-fetched fairy tale, ''Sleepless in Seattle.'' Five years later, people are falling in love with strangers across a crowded chat room, and E-mail has woven itself into the fabric of our day-to-day lives, an adult equivalent of passing notes in grade school.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KAPLAN, GEORGES
description: KAPLAN-Georges. November 22, 1897-November 15, 1990. Toujours dans nos coeurs. Ta famille

title: A DATE, AND POETRY
description: WENDY LAMB, a Manhattan book editor, wrote the Oct. 4 Soapbox essay, chronicling milestones of her life that occurred in Grand Central Terminal. She suggested that others record their memories of the place. The City section solicited ''most memorable moments'' and here are a few:

title: From a Modest Start to a Threat to the Presidency
description: When the young woman stood before the microphones here on Feb. 11, 1994, and accused Bill Clinton of having made sexual advances toward her, not much of the world noticed or cared.

title: Attention, Shoppers
description: In Sam We Trust

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NETTLETON, JIM
description: NETTLETON-Jim. July 8, 1947November 15, 1990. Missed, loved and always remembered.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There is a very

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOLCKHAUSEN, JESSIE
description: VOLCKHAUSEN-Jessie. Died on November 7, at age 90. Wife of the late W. Louis Volckhausen. Survived by sons Robert and William, and grandchildren Sharon, Alex, Jeannie, and Jeffery. Memorial service on November 22, 1:30 PM, All Souls Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Avenue, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations to American Cancer Society.

title: A PLACE FOR A MAKEOVER
description: WENDY LAMB, a Manhattan book editor, wrote the Oct. 4 Soapbox essay, chronicling milestones of her life that occurred in Grand Central Terminal. She suggested that others record their memories of the place. The City section solicited ''most memorable moments'' and here are a few:

title: Let the Inner Poet Emerge
description: Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the chief executive of I.B.M., is touchy about his reputation as a tough manager. Fortune magazine found that out after it ran a generally glowing cover article on his resurrection of the company in April 1997: ''He's Smart. He's Not Nice. Lou Gerstner Isn't Easy to Love, but You Have to Respect Him.'' Ever since, Mr. Gerstner has banned I.B.M. employees from cooperating with Fortune.

title: A Generation Unafraid of the Dark
description: TWO years ago, Peter Shankman had what he called the ''coolest job in the world'': working in the digital newsroom at America Online. It was a coup for Mr. Shankman, a self-described techno-geek who had been a journalism major, and he hoped to stay awhile.

title: Clinton Asks Study of Bid to Form Part-Human, Part-Cow Cells
description: Saying that he is ''deeply troubled'' by the creation of part-human, part-cow embryonic stem cells, which was reported last week, President Clinton has directed the National Bioethics Advisory Commission to consider the implications of the research at its meeting on Tuesday and to report back to him ''as soon as possible.''

title: SOME 'AMAZING GRACE'
description: WENDY LAMB, a Manhattan book editor, wrote the Oct. 4 Soapbox essay, chronicling milestones of her life that occurred in Grand Central Terminal. She suggested that others record their memories of the place. The City section solicited ''most memorable moments'' and here are a few:

title: . . . For the Old Kind, Sharpen Your Pencil
description: AT least Nora Ephron steals from the best. ''You've Got Mail,'' the writer-director's forthcoming romantic comedy with Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan, is a cyberspace remake of ''The Shop Around the Corner,'' one of the swellest movies ever to waft its way out of Hollywood.

title: Where Russians Are Hurting, Racism Takes Root
description: Here, along Russia's southern border, where refugees from a crumbling empire have settled in the ruins of the local economy, it does not take much to disturb the festering sores of Russian nationalism.

title: Wine Makers Raise Glass to the Other Guys
description: TASTING all the wines made every year on Long Island is possible. Theoretically. Doing it properly -- slowly and thoughtfully -- might take a week or more. But the opportunities to arrange and carry out such a complex exercise are rare, even for the wine makers: time is short, responsibilities long.

title: Red Cross and Mitch
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOOLSKY, ROBERT
description: SCHOOLSKY-Robert. November 5, 1998. Wine writer, lecturer and consultant. Former Vice Chairman of the ''Wine Media Guild'' and a member of Burgundy's Compagnon de Beaujolais. Survived by his sister Esther and brother-in-law Harvey Kircsh, nephews Steven and Jonathan, grandniece Ellie, and his beloved longtime companion Bernice (Bunny) Blaine. Memorial services to be held in Denver, CO, at a later date to be announced. Donations in Robert's memory may be made to the American Lung Association.

title: Three Cheers for the Cheerleader Champs
description: THE crowd cheers as the team members take the field. Superb athletes, smiling broadly, they show the discipline and well-conditioned bodies of seven months of rigorous practice, of three-hour-a-day, six-day-a-week sessions.

title: In the Region / Long Island; A Planned Community Progresses in Smithtown
description: FOR now, a 11.5-acre parcel on Terry Road is still a sea of sand, but it will soon become the site of a 29-house development called Coventry Village at the Galleria, where sales of the first 11 houses began last weekend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLLON, IRVING
description: STOLLON-Irving. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Irving Stollon, associated with The Times from 1973, until retiring in 1983.

title: In Middle East, a Hesitant Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: House Fire in Queens Kills 9-Year-Old Boy
description: A 9-year-old Queens boy died yesterday morning, hours after being pulled from a fire in his home, police and fire officials said.

title: The Crime of the Century, but Not This One
description: IF you believe that Lizzie Borden did her dad and stepmom in with those fabled 81 whacks, just wait till you see her perform the unkind est act of all upon an audience of hundreds of strangers.

title: Miss d'Ablemont And Mr. Smith
description: Noel-Ann d'Ablemont, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene T. d'Ablemont of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Douglas Patrick Smith, a son of Katherine M. Hering of Savannah, Ga., and Cornelius C. Smith Jr. of New Milford, Conn. John Cardinal O'Connor performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York.

title: It's Academic
description: Europa

title: My Open Space or Yours? It's Time to Duel for Dollars
description: For years, this state's politicians and pressure groups have found reasons to argue and disagree about nearly every possible political issue but one. Abortion, gun control, school vouchers, unions, auto insurance, welfare, environmental regulation -- the list is all but endless. About the only things the state's political leaders agree on without quibble are the sanctity of the flag, motherhood and apple pie, and the importance of preserving open space.

title: The World: Beyond the Dalai Lama; His Successor Could Be the Solution
description: IN a small movie-and-noodle house on a side street in the Tibetan portion of this holy city, a pair of young monks in red robes were watching a Hong Kong kung fu movie and slurping bowls of the house special when the Dalai Lama's name came up.

title: Marc Landis, Judith Enteles
description: Judith Sara Enteles and Marc Andrew Landis are to be married today at the Lincoln Square Synagogue in Manhattan. Rabbi Herschel Cohen is to perform the ceremony.

title: When Is Big Too Big?
description: When the developers of Jamaica Estates bought 503 acres of wooded land in 1904, they set out to create a ''residential park'' of handsome Tudor and colonial houses on bucolic lots. Now a trend among new property owners is threatening to erode its stately character, members of the Jamaica Estates Association say.

title: In America; A Child's 'Confession'
description: Lacresha Murray is a 14-year-old prisoner at the Giddings State Home and School in Giddings, Tex., about 60 miles east of Austin, the state capital.

title: Playing God In the Garden
description: The real issue, and one that Pollan ignores, is sustainable agriculture and the growing food demand here and abroad. Today, we meet the world's food needs with a limited resource base (six million square miles of land in production) that is not likely to expand significantly, unless we destroy more rain forests and wetlands. Simply to feed an increased population, that base will need to produce 60 to 100 percent more food in the next 30 years, and to do so without causing irreversible environmental damage. Today, the productivity of that land is being degraded through massive erosion (25 billion tons of topsoil lost each year), promiscuous irrigation (causing salinity and mineralization of soil) and unsustainable use of chemicals.

title: JOURNEY'S BEGINNING
description: WENDY LAMB, a Manhattan book editor, wrote the Oct. 4 Soapbox essay, chronicling milestones of her life that occurred in Grand Central Terminal. She suggested that others record their memories of the place. The City section solicited ''most memorable moments'' and here are a few:

title: Lives; The Importance of Being Busy
description: I'm talking on the phone with one of my closest friends, whom I haven't seen in weeks. It's Saturday night -- the ''social equivalent,'' he says, ''of prime real estate'' -- and he's feeling irritable. Some acquaintances from Washington are in town, and two weeks ago he agreed to have dinner with them. Now he wants to cancel, but knows that he can't. It's not that they're particularly good friends; it's that they aren't. He's going out and I'm staying in, and he's the one who is jealous. He wouldn't rather see me, his truly good friend. He's exhausted after a week of business lunches and dinners and wants to stay home, too.

title: Arabs in 'The Siege'
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberties; The Pink-Poodle Blues
description: New York is a tough town.

title: Playing God In the Garden
description: There are egg banks, sperm banks, in-vitro fertilization, serious work on human DNA manipulation and human cloning. Someone is worried about a potato?

title: HOLIDAY MOVIES; Independent Film, But With a Catch: A Corporate Logo
description: INDEPENDENT film is getting less independent. The forces that have transformed studio action flicks into billboards for Pepsi and PowerBook are turning to low-budget movies. And the indies hope to form tighter bonds with sponsors than Hollywood ever has.

title: Getting a Shine With Soul at Penn Station
description: NAOMI KARTEN of Sheepshead Bay stood at the entrance to a shoeshine shop in Penn Station, Soleman, a broad smile on her face. ''I think it's fantastic,'' she exclaimed as she swayed to the music of ''Soul Man'' coming from a speaker inside the store.

title: Inside The Head Of the Fed; Alan Greenspan's Journey To the New World Economy
description: JUST before 9 on Tuesday morning, if tradition holds, Alan Greenspan will stride through a doorway behind the desk in his private office and into the Federal Reserve's ornate board room. He will take his seat at the head of the 27-foot-long mahogany and granite table and then, for the 91st time in his 11 years as chairman of the central bank, call to order a meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the group that sets interest rate policy.

title: UConn Has Physical Edge, and Seeks a Mental One
description: The reasoning goes like this: A team that finished with a record of 32-5 last season and returns five starters should be great this season. Maybe even a national champion.

title: Grand Targhee, Wyo.
description: The first time my husband, daughter and I arrived at Jackson Hole, in northwestern Wyoming, several years ago, we fell in love at first sight. The fierce Tetons and the valley's vast empty space hint at this continent's vanished wilderness. The Jackson Hole Ski Area is equally addictive, and although people had told us about Grand Targhee and its powder snow on the other side of the mountains, it wasn't until last winter that a friend persuaded us to cross the Teton Pass and ski there.

title: Republican Chairman Fights to Stay at Helm
description: Congress is not the only place where Republicans are looking for leaders to blame, and maybe dump, because of the party's embarrassing setbacks on Election Day. The chairman of the party, Jim Nicholson, also is coming under some fire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUESTONE, SALLY
description: BLUESTONE-Sally. November 13, 1998 after a very brief illness. One month before her 96th birthday. Beloved sister, aunt, great-aunt and great great-aunt. Devoted daughter of the late Fannie and Joseph Bluestone. Generous, caring, loyal and gifted lady. Will be remembered for a lifetime of hard work, commitment to family and Judaism. Life Member and Past President of Hatikvah Chapter of Hadassah. She was A Presence. She will be missed. Service Sunday, November 15. Family to meet at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn at 1 P.M. and proceed to New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, N.Y. for graveside service. Shiva, 1718 Quentin Road, Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: Concerts Offer Fusion Of Classical and Folk
description: THREE concerts today at 4 P.M. offer fusions of folk and classical styles. When the new Candlelight Concerts season opens in the Presbyterian Church of Mount Kisco, the 12 women who make up the chorus Parthenia XII will juxtapose Bach's Magnificat with Irish chants from the 16th-century Book of Sarum. ''Celtic music has become very popular in this country,'' Parthenia's director, Mary Jane Newman, said, ''and we are so pleased to bring this accessible music to Westchester.''

title: Loving the Unlovable Greeks
description: THE GREEKS AND

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, ROBERT A.
description: WOLF-Robert A. Principal design engineer of the first jet engine in the United States, the first Bell Helicopter, and recipient of the prestigious Elmer A. Sperry Award for ''Distinguished Engineering Contribution to the Art of Transportation,'' died November 5, 1998 in Columbia, S.C. at the age of 91.

title: The Real Ally McBeal?
description: To the Editor:

title: Just What Do Writers Read?
description: AS the air turns crisp and pumpkins replace strawberries at roadside stands, the tranquillity that attracted so many writers to Long Island has returned. Now that the season of house guests, barbecues, exhibition openings and movie previews has ended, the literary minded can return to the solitary pursuit of writing -- and reading.

title: Waiting for Mr. Livingston
description: With the accession of Robert Livingston as the next House Speaker, Republicans have proclaimed a new order in Washington. But so far Mr. Livingston remains trapped in the old issues, unwilling to assert himself. He says he wants to settle the possible impeachment of President Clinton this year, but he is standing by while Judiciary Committee Republicans squabble with Democrats and among themselves over how to proceed. As a way of exerting his leadership and defining how it will differ from Newt Gingrich's, Mr. Livingston needs to help guide the Judiciary Committee and its chairman, Henry Hyde, in finding a way through the impeachment crisis. He can then clear the way for a pragmatic Republican approach on Social Security, health care and issues the public cares more about.

title: With A Click, A New Era of Music Dawns
description: A SPECTER is haunting the music business: the prospect of listeners getting the music they want directly from the Internet, free of charge. Right now, all it takes to make a recording executive nervous is the mention of MP3, a powerful piece of software that allows users to zap music all over the Internet, unchecked and untithed.

title: Top Chefs You Never Heard Of
description: CHEFS have become international celebrities. They have TV shows, write best-selling books, own companies that distribute their specialty dishes and make guest appearances at restaurants all over the world.

title: Track Coach at the Starting Line for 41 Years
description: LOOKING south on a fall day from Peter K. Oley's third-floor deck, high above Irvington, there is a view all the way to the Manhattan skyline. Look west and there is a view of Irvington's business district and the Hudson River. About the only landmark that cannot be seen is Irvington High School's all-weather track, officially named the Peter K. Oley Track.

title: Divisive Gym Now on Track
description: Putting the lid on a two-year battle between local residents and the Berkeley Carroll School, the city's Department of Buildings gave the private institution final approval last week for a plan to build a $5 million gymnasium in the playground behind its elementary school.

title: WEDDINGS: VOWS; Honor Prouty and John Brodie
description: YOU can take them out of the East, but you can't take the East out of them. Honor Prouty and John Brodie were born six years apart at New York Hospital but discovered each other in Los Angeles, in what Mr. Brodie terms ''a decrepit corner of the empire.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, HOWARD
description: SCHNEIDER-Howard. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Howard Schneider, associated with The Times from 1976, until retiring in 1997.

title: MEETING A QUIET MAN
description: WENDY LAMB, a Manhattan book editor, wrote the Oct. 4 Soapbox essay, chronicling milestones of her life that occurred in Grand Central Terminal. She suggested that others record their memories of the place. The City section solicited ''most memorable moments'' and here are a few:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLZMAN, WILLIAM (RED)
description: HOLZMAN-William (Red). The Officers and Trustees of the New York Sports Museum & Hall of Fame regret the passing of a charter member of the New York Sports Hall of Fame on November 13 in New Hyde Park, NY. Bill Shannon, President Jordan Sprechman, Secretary

title: American Arias Find a Groove
description: SINCE the dawn of the recording era, collections of songs and arias have held a special place in the hearts and on the shelves of music lovers. Early on, listeners themselves bunched 78's together to form extended programs. But with the advent of the long-playing record in the late 1940's, full-length recitals and concept albums arrived prepackaged.

title: Referendum May Mean Higher Price For 2 Race Tracks
description: The first effects of the constitutional amendment approved by voters, which gives the Legislature the authority to regulate horse racing, are likely to be felt soon, in the increased purchase price of Freehold Raceway and Garden State Park, in Cherry Hill.

title: Dean Ottinger to Resign
description: Former United States Representative Richard L. Ottinger, the dean of Pace University's School of Law for almost five years, plans to step down, and a search committee has been appointed to find a replacement for him, said Dr. Susan Merritt, chairwoman of the committee and dean of the School of Computer Science and Information Systems.

title: Lorrie Pownall, Stephen Savas
description: Lorrie Jean Pownall and Stephen Dean Savas were married yesterday by the Rev. Thomas J. Donahue at Trinity Lutheran Church in Tenafly, N.J. A Greek Orthodox ceremony was held later in the day, performed by the Very Rev. Ernest Blougouras at the Cathedral of St. John the Theologian in Tenafly.

title: HOLIDAY FILMS; Made in Iran: Films About (Not for) Children
description: HALFWAY through ''The Mirror,'' a 1997 film by the Iranian director Jafar Panahi, the audience finds itself at a startling juncture. We have been following a little girl named Mina as she makes her way across Teheran. A grade-schooler whose mother didn't arrive to pick her up after school, Mina has elected to find her own way home, beginning a journey that -- however slight the premise may sound -- is fascinating to follow, alternately hilarious, suspenseful and rich in offhand documentary details. Then, during a scene on a bus, she says she's had it. She's fed up with filming.

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: SKIING THE WEB

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: Growing up in England, I used to hear a phrase that is still likely to evoke a wince from me when uttered in the right accent. ''Where are you from?'' the stranger would inquire, eyebrows arched, knowing that as soon as I opened my mouth, an entire closetful of baggage -- class, region, schooling, lineage -- would come tumbling helplessly out. Which is why, I suppose, it came as something of a relief when I arrived in America, and people began to ask the question out of genuine curiosity, as if it might be a source of earnest conversational interest, or merely a means for them to ask me if I knew their cousin who once lived in Hemel Hempstead.

title: HOLIDAY FILMS; A Woman of Donegal, at Least by Adoption
description: THE sheep tethered to the front of Leo McLoone's pub, the Rainbow Bar, ignored the proceedings. Their backs were turned to the bunting and brass band in the main street -- the only street -- of this County Donegal town.

title: Camera Links U.S. Judge to Rural Romania
description: Entering the United States Courthouse in downtown Brooklyn, you see the trappings common to a court lobby: metal detector, security guards, pictures of President Clinton and Vice President Gore.

title: The World; For Now, the U.S. Calls Russia's Bluff
description: WHEN the Kremlin finds itself in a tight economic squeeze, it acts a lot like the sheriff in the Mel Brooks comedy ''Blazing Saddles.'' Pursued by a furious lynch mob, the sheriff puts a gun to his own head and threatens to pull the trigger if the crowd doesn't back off.

title: November 8-14; Human, Cow Cells Mixed
description: A small biotechnology company announced that it had fused human cells with cow eggs, forcing the cells to revert to the primordial, embryonic state from which all other cells develop.

title: A Celebration of the Spiritual Where Some See Sin
description: LIFE is a battle for the human soul between the forces of the sacred and the profane. Or so it would seem even to a casual voyager through theological musings on dance over the last four centuries. Dance, like sex, was marginally allowable as a duty, a way of maintaining a healthy body. Otherwise, dancing led to perdition. ''Of the 500,000 fallen women in the United States, over 300,000 started from the ballroom,'' W. W. Hamilton, a Baptist minister from Virginia, stoutly proclaimed early this century.

title: Fashion Cracks a Smile
description: KATE MOSS wasn't feeling particularly gorgeous a week ago. The London press reported that the 105-pound supermodel, her hair recently dyed shocking pink for the Donatella Versace fashion show in Milan, had booked herself into a $:300-a-day rehab clinic. Ms. Moss, 24, was quoted as telling The Mirror she was exhausted from working and partying too much, and wanted to reassess her life.

title: Fighting Low Ratings, WNEW Fires Deejay Who Fostered Rock's Revolution
description: Scott Muni, an FM radio pioneer who introduced New Yorkers to the Beatles and Led Zeppelin and became a gravelly voiced legend of his own, was dismissed on Friday by WNEW, the station he joined 31 years ago and helped build into a music trendsetter.

title: The Works of Art That Inspire the Artist
description: WHILE a number of major artists pursue their careers on Long Island, they often bring with them experiences absorbed at some earlier point, particularly their memories of works from other eras that have made a special impact. When several were asked recently about their favorite work of art from an earlier period, the answers spanned many centuries and revealed much about the power of creative forces over time.

title: Eclectic Regional Fare in Port Chester
description: LINED with semicircular banquettes, the upstairs dining room is both dramatic and romantic at Two Moons. Mellow lighting and blooming hibiscus complement the Southwestern decor. From polished sandstone floor and walls etched with primitive hunting scenes to animal sculptures, wrought-iron candleholders and pottery looking recently unearthed, this place could be a destination in itself.

title: Dithering in Central America
description: Our Own Backyard

title: Long And Short of It Is Long and Short of It. Then There's the Bar.
description: Most of the visitors at this trade show arrived in limousines, as one would expect. Some then tried to sell the limousines, and some shopped for more limousines. Those not too hung over from the toga party or the beach bash reported for morning seminars on topics like chauffeur training tips.

title: From 'Hello, Central' to 'Hello, Conglomerate'
description: MORE than 60 years later, John T. Steck still vividly remembers the day he rescued a man clinging to a tree amid floodwaters near the Housatonic River in New Milford.

title: A Dispatch From the War Against Women
description: IN all its grinding biliousness and the sharp, ugly discomfort of its spiritual misery, ''Hurlyburly'' is set for release on Dec. 25, presumably just in time to puncture any false seasonal cheer. A most eloquent portrayal of the banality of misogyny, it will surely provoke, as did the 1984 play by David Rabe from which it is adapted, a voluminous amount of talk -- at best, cathartic diatribe; at worst, contentious chit-chat -- about female-bashing in life and art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITT, MARVIN
description: LEVITT-Marvin, of Brooklyn, in Miami Beach, on October 23rd. From the old neighborhood, wandering, wondering, smiling, taking ''Fortune's buffets and rewards with equal thanks,'' and moving on with music in his soul. HES/LMH

title: Of Thee I Sing
description: THIS LAND IS YOUR LAND

title: Not (Yet) Gone the Way of All Asia
description: First Thailand, then Malaysia, Indonesia and South Korea collapsed. Then Hong Kong and Singapore fell ill. Japan, the onetime powerhouse, sank back into recession. Not to mention neighbor Russia's fall into the gutter.

title: The Market Hesitates, Then Regains Hope
description: After three robust weeks, the market was taking a breather last week. Then favorable international developments sent it off and running again. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 89.85 points on Friday, to close at 8,919.59 -- still down 55.87 points for the week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELSON, RICHARD. DDS.
description: ADELSON-Richard. DDS. On November 8th, 1998. Of St Paul, MN, formerly of St. James, New York and Washington, D.C. Attended Columbia College -'56 and the University of Pennsylvania Dental School -'60. He practiced dentistry in Smithtown, New York, and later became Assistant Dean for Continuing Education at SUNY, Stonybrook. He most recently held the title of National Coordinator for Performance Improvement of the Employee Education System of the Department of Veterans Affairs. Loving husband of Jean. Devoted father of David and Barbara Adelson, Nancy and Martin Hauser. Beloved brother of Helen and Sidney Bender, Martin and Darlene Adelson. Cherished ''Grampa Grampa'' to Sam. Special uncle to many nieces and nephews. His enduring wisdom and knowledge will be missed by all. Funeral services were held on Tuesday, November 10th, 1998. A Memorial service will be announced. A Memorial fund will be established in his memory.

title: Mount Hood, Ore.
description: When Franklin D. Roosevelt presided over the dedication in 1937 of the great stone-and-timber lodge on Mount Hood, some 50 miles southeast of Portland, he predicted: ''Those who will follow us to Timberline Lodge on their holidays and vacations will represent the enjoyment of new opportunities for play in every season of the year.''

title: A Pair of Monsters At the End of the Line
description: FAR more than in Tennessee Williams's greatest plays, the lifeline of ''Sweet Bird of Youth,'' now at the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival here, is a grand, grand star turn.

title: Status is ... for Orthodox Jews; Studying, Studying and More Studying
description: Yehuda Brecher, a 26-year-old Orthodox Jew in Brooklyn, has been in school as long as he can remember -- and has absolutely no desire to graduate. He's a student at Rabbi Chaim Berlin Yeshiva, a school where you can study the Talmud your whole life. ''From kindergarten, Orthodox children, both male and female, are cultivated to internalize the ideal that greatness results from foregoing materialism in the pursuit of scholarship,'' Brecher says. ''This is our status symbol.'' In the fervently Orthodox and Hasidic communities, it's not a doctor who inspires admiration but a dayan (rabbinic court judge). And a lawyer is less impressive than a lahmdan (scholar).

title: A Candidate Keeps His Divorce Quiet
description: It was a campaign tightly focused on the great political theme of the year, personal conduct, a campaign with props that included one of those happy-couple pictures, talk of kids in college, promises of ''honesty and integrity.''

title: California Scrambles After Measure Fails
description: Ever since California voters defeated an obscure ballot measure called Proposition 3 on Election Day, the state's election officials and party leaders have had an almost panicky look about them. Here's why:

title: A SHOWY ENTRANCE
description: WENDY LAMB, a Manhattan book editor, wrote the Oct. 4 Soapbox essay, chronicling milestones of her life that occurred in Grand Central Terminal. She suggested that others record their memories of the place. The City section solicited ''most memorable moments'' and here are a few:

title: After Tragedies, Some People Rise Up to Find Their Calling
description: THE Phoenix factor'' is what Dr. Janice Stefanacci calls it -- the quality that allows some people to rise above grief and anger in the aftermath of a personal tragedy.

title: Congressman Fears Famine Is Decimating North Koreans
description: A Congressman who visited remote parts of North Korea this week said today that the food and health situation there was desperate and deteriorating, and that millions of North Koreans might have starved to death in the last few years.

title: Sunday River's Peaks and Bowls
description: TIME was, early this century, when a downcountry aristocrat with a case of frayed nerves could retreat to the wilderness of Bethel, in western Maine, to cure what ailed him. The prescription: Vigorous exercise in the outdoors, and perhaps a little golf at what is now the Bethel Inn and Country Club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENNYBACKER, MILES
description: PENNYBACKER-Miles. On November 9, 1998. Beloved father, grandfather and great-grandfather. Memorial service Saturday, November 21 at 11:30AM, The Red Barn, Westport, Conn.

title: Judie Lifton and Ronald Bobman
description: Judie Beth Lifton, the daughter of Ellie and Martin Lifton of Old Westbury, N.Y., was married last evening to Ronald David Bobman, the son of Rita and Herbert F. Bobman of Wynnewood, Pa. Rabbi Marc Gellman officiated at the Plaza in New York.

title: MOTHERS CAN RUN
description: WENDY LAMB, a Manhattan book editor, wrote the Oct. 4 Soapbox essay, chronicling milestones of her life that occurred in Grand Central Terminal. She suggested that others record their memories of the place. The City section solicited ''most memorable moments'' and here are a few:

title: From World War I, a Gift Matures
description: WHEN Dr. Frederick Dearborn strolled across the deck of the Aquitania after sundown, he knew better than to light his cigar. It was the summer of 1918, and all the passengers on board understood that German submarines could spot the orange glow of burning tobacco, marking the transport ship as a target.

title: Is Paris Kidding?
description: FASHIONABLE NONSENSE

title: ALMS AND ICE CREAM
description: WENDY LAMB, a Manhattan book editor, wrote the Oct. 4 Soapbox essay, chronicling milestones of her life that occurred in Grand Central Terminal. She suggested that others record their memories of the place. The City section solicited ''most memorable moments'' and here are a few:

title: November 8-14; Jones Case Is Settled
description: President Clinton agreed to pay Paula Corbin Jones $850,000 to drop her legal claim that he crudely propositioned her seven years ago. The payment settles a lawsuit that Mr. Clinton's advisers had once mocked but that, by forcing his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky into public view, had begun to threaten his Presidency.

title: One-Design Rules Keep Helm in the Hands of Amateurs
description: New rules in one-design sailing are encouraging amateurs at the expense of professionals. But the seascape is as competitive as ever in yacht racing. Consider the names of boats entered this week in the 1998 Mumm 30 World Championship: Instigator, Menace, Stinger, Trouble and Twisted Lizard.

title: The World; Britain's Of 2 Minds On Gay Sex
description: LAST month, the Daily Telegraph, Britain's most respected conservative newspaper, published a column by Tom Utley, one of its regular contributors. Mr. Utley said the time had come for him to make a public confession: He didn't like gay people.

title: On Language; Up the Down Ladder
description: Who are the Joneses, anyway, and why are we still trying to keep up with them?

title: Primary Color
description: BLUE LIGHT

title: Taking the Starch Out of Status
description: When I was in college, there was a guy famous for wrapping his brand-new Weejuns with duct tape so that it would look as though his soles were already flapping. He also, or so it was said, took brand-new shirts from Brooks Brothers and painstakingly frayed the cuffs with sandpaper. This was at Yale in the late 60's, during the last wheezing gasp -- the final catarrh -- of the patrician ethos that held that the ultimate status, the highest social perch, belonged to those who seemingly paid no attention to status. That poor Yalie, with his tape and sandpaper, made the fatal mistake, of course: he cared too much and, worse, was seen to care. But in other respects he understood the code perfectly. In those days, old was still good. Shabby was good. Instead of renting a tuxedo, for example, or even buying a new one, it was far cooler to borrow your great-uncle Ned's -- that hand-sewn mohair dreadnought, now mossy with age, that he wore to the Stork Club in the 40's while squiring tipsy debutantes. What recommended this mothy garment was not just its special flask pocket or the cigarette burn on the left lapel but that it (quietly) advertised you as someone who came from tuxedo-wearing stock, the sort of people who donned formal wear all the time and not just on self-conscious occasions.

title: A KODAK MOMENT
description: WENDY LAMB, a Manhattan book editor, wrote the Oct. 4 Soapbox essay, chronicling milestones of her life that occurred in Grand Central Terminal. She suggested that others record their memories of the place. The City section solicited ''most memorable moments'' and here are a few:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELBER, GABRIEL
description: GELBER-Gabriel. On November 13, 1998. Beloved husband of Esther and the late Jeanne Gelber. Cherished by Philip and Pat Gelber, Ellen and Joseph Gellert, and Barbara and Richard Moskowitz. Adored grandfather of Jacob, Toby, Jennifer, Matthew, Michelle, Stephen and Molly. Brother of Sylvan Gelber and the late Alvin Gelber. Services will be held on Sunday, November 18 at Noon at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset; (516) 482-3600.

title: The Emperor of Plate Glass
description: TRUTH COMES IN BLOWS

title: New Way to Build a Movie
description: WHEN ''Playing by Heart'' opens on Dec. 18, audiences are meant to exit the theaters drying their eyes. Here, after all, is a multi-generational, multi-character drama depicting numerous love stories in various stages of peril.

title: Lives of a Saint
description: JOAN OF ARC

title: Thomas More's World
description: To the Editor:

title: In Middle East, a Hesitant Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Honoring Past Beauty In Theaters of Present
description: IF the success of Theater Projects Consultants can be distilled into one philosophy, it's ''Back to the Future.'' That concept, in fact, served as the company's mantra long before the 1985 film that made Michael J. Fox a movie star.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, RALPH R., D.D.S.
description: BERGER-Ralph R., D.D.S., 71. November 13, 1998. Dr. Berger graduated from NYU School of Dentistry in 1952. He was in the military from 1952-1954 and served in the Korean conflict. He practiced dentistry and orthodontics from 1954 to 1984 at his ''Family Dental Center'' on the lower east side of Manhattan. He stayed busy with real estate investments after his retirement from dentistry. Dr. Ralph Berger was an Orthodox Jew who took great interest in religious studies. He was an active member of the Max D. Raskin Community Synagogue. He is survived by his daughter Madelyn, sister Edna B. Citrin, brother George Berger, nephew Dr. Paul Citrin, niece Carol Citrin, beloved great niece and nephew Jenny Rose and Max Louis, and all who loved and cared for him. Ralph was a man whose influence and love reached far beyond his direct family. He will be greatly missed from this world. Family will receive visitors from noon to 2 PM at the Gramercy Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Ave., New York, NY (between 9th and 10th). Interment Beth David Cemetery, Elmont.

title: Cathleen O'Donnell, Donald Tone Jr.
description: Cathleen Ann O'Donnell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. O'Donnell Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., and Donald R. Tone Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Tone of Boca Raton, Fla., were married yesterday at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville. The Rev. Carmine Rita performed the ceremony.

title: Cornering the Market On Ardent Young Swains
description: RALPH FIENNES devotees will recall that the 1992 television film, ''A Dangerous Man: Lawrence After Arabia,'' more or less introduced the actor to the United States. It's unlikely, however, that viewers also caught the fleeting presence of a younger Fiennes, Joseph, playing Ralph's onscreen brother. (So tiny is the part that the lesser-known Fiennes does not make the credit roll.)

title: THE LAST LONG HAUL
description: WENDY LAMB, a Manhattan book editor, wrote the Oct. 4 Soapbox essay, chronicling milestones of her life that occurred in Grand Central Terminal. She suggested that others record their memories of the place. The City section solicited ''most memorable moments'' and here are a few:

title: Meager Repast, but Books to Chew On
description: ONCE upon a time, when the nights seemed younger longer, it was possible to make a decent dinner from the food at book parties. There were always three or four parties each night to crash. You could trail Norman Mailer or Kurt Vonnegut, who went everywhere, into restaurants temporarily closed to the public, and when they headed to the bar you could rush the spread. Before you were diverted by drink or bookchat, you could fill up on nameless things with spears through their tiny hearts and mysterious mounds of soft protein on slices of bread no bigger than playing cards. Dieters stuffed themselves with clumps of raw cauliflower, although many people just used vegetables to stub out their cigarettes.

title: V.A.T. Refunds
description: To the Editor: Returning from Belgium in August, I failed to have my V.A.T. refund papers stamped, but found a way to get the refund after I got home. I wrote to the Belgian Ministry of Finance, and requested the tax refund, explaining that the tapestry pillows I bought in Brussels were in my checked luggage. Thus, I had been unable to show these purchases to the airport customs official, who refused to approve a V.A.T. refund for items he could not see. My letter included a photo of the pillows on my living room couch, and a sales receipt. The Belgium Tourist Office in Manhattan gave me the address.

title: More Signs of Strength In the Economic Data
description: Productivity of the nation's workers rose at a robust 2.3 percent annual rate in the third quarter, suggesting that companies have room to give raises without raising prices and increasing the scope for further interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. But producer prices skipped up more sharply than expected in October, in part because of energy prices, which after months of softness are rising again. Retail sales for October also rose more than economists had expected, suggesting less need for further economic stimulation. . . . Japan's economy, on the other hand, continues to languish, prompting Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi to issue a new stimulus plan for the country that might cost up to $165 billion. . . .
