The International Monetary Fund and more than a dozen nations announced a $41.5 billion package of loans to Brazil to help it stabilize its economy and currency.

title: A Hidden Jewel of a Garden in Mill Neck
description: THE grounds of many a Long Island estate have been given over to gardens of dazzling color and abundant acreage. But behind a nondescript wall in Mill Neck lies a garden of another kind, one whose small, studied precision provides an unusual experience for both eye and soul.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: A LIFE FOR A LIFE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILFSTEIN, MAX
description: HILFSTEIN-Max. We are deeply saddened by the death of dear friend, Founder and President of the New Cracow Friendship Society. Max also served as President of the Pelham Bay Jewish Center for 21 years. He was a man of great compassion and love for his fellow man. Our heartfelt sympathies to wife Erna, son Leon, daughter Simone and their families. For the last two weeks, Erna and Simone were at his bedside 24 hours a day. The New Cracow Friendship Society

title: TECHNOLOGY: Digital Commerce; A captive audience is seen for the receipt and payment of monthly bills on line.
description: PREPARE for the next Internet feeding frenzy. Sharks from several industries are already circling the nascent market for products and services that will enable consumers to receive and pay their monthly bills on line.

title: Communication Satellites in Peril as Cosmic Storm Approaches
description: Chicken Little would love this one. The Earth is hurtling into the path of a comet called Temple-Tuttle.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERKOWSKY, PAUL B.
description: BERKOWSKY-Paul B., 1932-1998. V.P. of the Off-B'way League B'way and Off-B'way producer, Founder of School Theatre Ticket Program. Memorial Tribute Today at 5 at the Lucille Lortel Theatre, 121 Christopher Street.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Seagram Expected to Oust Head of Universal Studios

title: The Giants Suffer a Debacle And Next Year Starts Early
description: Maybe it was the time the Green Bay Packers split a receiver wide at the goal line and the Giants didn't bother to send a defender out there to cover him.

title: Valerie Hobson, 81, Actress and Profumo's Wife
description: Valerie Hobson, a British movie star who stayed loyal to her husband, John Profumo, after he figured in a sex scandal as a member of Britain's Conservative Government in 1963, died on Friday at a London hospital. She was 81.

title: Brooklyn Orchestra Takes On Avant-Garde
description: In his first two seasons as music director of the Brooklyn Philharmonic, Robert Spano has had a revitalizing effect on the freelance players who make up the ensemble. But as telling as his work has been in programs that have danced around the periphery of the standard repertory, the assurance, solidity and polish these players brought to a difficult program of contemporary works on Saturday evening gave the impression that the orchestra had reached a new level. Whether it will be able to capitalize on this improvement in the long term remains to be seen: it is also currently facing a deficit problem that has led to a reorganization of its board and administration.

title: Media Talk; An Endorsement That Wasn't
description: The Charlotte Observer's publisher added one more surprise to this fall's election season when he scuttled his paper's endorsement of North Carolina's Democratic Senate candidate just before the election. Then, more than 40 journalists in The Observer's newsroom surprised him with passionate objections to the decision.

title: House Class of '98, a Seasoned Breed
description: Representative-elect Tom Tancredo flashed a good, long smile for posterity on the steps of the Capitol as he huddled with his freshman cohorts, but the usual exhilaration was not altogether there.

title: TENNIS: No. 2 and Bothered by It; Hingis Wants to Cap Lackluster '98 by Dominating Year's Finale
description: The sushi platter was heaped with fish, but it was not allowed to remain a marine still life for long. After doing an appreciative double-take at the size of her portion, Martina Hingis, a predator with stalking skills that extend from tennis trophies to tuna, activated her chopsticks and went spear-fishing from a restaurant banquette on East 60th Street in Manhattan last week.

title: A Truckload of 'Howevers' Burdens the Iraqis' Promise
description: Even before the Security Council resolved tonight to give Iraq a chance to prove that it really intends to resume cooperation with arms inspectors, some familiar code words for trouble were in the air.

title: Mary Main, 95, Author of Eva Peron Biography
description: Mary Main, a novelist who also wrote a highly regarded biography of Eva Peron, died on Nov. 8 at her home in Ridgefield, Conn. She was 95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISMAN, IRVING
description: REISMAN-Irving. Beloved husband of Sheila. Devoted father of Paula and Marcia. Cherished grandfather of Margie and Adam. Loving brother of Harold. He was a founder and original manager of the Aqueduct Flea Market for 25 years. Services Monday, 10:15 AM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: Red Storm Seeks Alaskan Recruit
description: While St. John's opens its season tonight against the University of North Carolina-Asheville at Alumni Hall in the Preseason National Invitation Tournament, the Red Storm's coaching staff is also keeping an eye on the future.

title: Opponents Find That Ousting Hussein Is Easier Said Than Done
description: President Clinton today all but called for a coup against Saddam Hussein, vowing to work with Iraqi opposition groups until ''a new government'' took power in Iraq.

title: Albright Visits With Wife Of Dissident In Malaysia
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright met the wife of a jailed Malaysian political leader here today in a gesture of solidarity that angered her hosts and suggested that politics could swamp economics at a meeting of Asian and Pacific Rim countries.

title: Stakes Are High in Fight Over A.T.M. Fees
description: Connecticut officials and two major banks will face off in court on Monday in a ferocious battle over a state rule -- one of just two in the country -- that forbids banks to charge noncustomers who use their automated teller machines.

title: Possible Parcells Tampering Investigated
description: Jets Coach Bill Parcells is being investigated for possible tampering by the National Football League over a telephone call he made to his former quarterback in New England, Drew Bledsoe. But Parcells said after today's game that he had made the call merely ''to thank him.''

title: National News Briefs; Federal Express to Begin Picketing in Labor Talks
description: The pilots union at Federal Express will begin informational picketing on Monday as the pilots move toward a possible holiday-season strike against the world's largest air-freight company, the pilots said.

title: What Price 'E.R.' Syndication?
description: When NBC decided to pay $13 million an episode to keep showing new episodes of ''E.R.'' this fall, it made history: no one had ever paid more for a show. And with the show's ratings still by far the best in television, the network is at least getting value for price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KILLIAM, PAUL
description: KILLIAM-Paul. On November 12, 1998, in Norwalk, CT. Husband of the late Joan Richards Killiam. Beloved father of Timothy Sculley Killiam of Amsterdam, The Netherlands, Lily Killiam Mitchell of Nantucket, MA, Theodore Richards Killiam of Guilford, CT, and Thomas Hartshorne Killiam of Clifton, VA. Loving brother to Faith Killiam Warner of Woodbury, CT, and Elizabeth Killiam Pilcher of Southbury, CT. Six grandchildren also survive. A memorial service will be held on Friday, November 20, at 11 AM, in the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the New Canaan Historial Society, Oenoke Ridge Rd., New Canaan, CT 06840, or the Chewonki Foundation in Wiscasset, ME 04578.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Sports of The Times; Packers' Favre Shows What the Giants Need
description: AS soon as Brett Favre's dart stuck in Tyrone Davis's hands for a 2-yard touchdown pass in the first quarter yesterday, a voice in the press box intoned: ''That is Favre's 200th touchdown pass; he's the second fastest to 200 in N.F.L. history. He did it in his 107th game; Dan Marino did it in his 89th game.''

title: Schools Told To Post Photos Of Offenders In Sex Cases
description: A Queens school board known for its staunchly conservative policies, including a ban on sex education, has ordered that photographs of released sex offenders be posted in school hallways or cafeterias to warn even the youngest children about convicts who have moved into their neighborhoods.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article on Thursday about a decline in the reputation of the writer Lillian Hellman misstated her contribution to the Leonard Bernstein musical ''Candide.'' She wrote the original book; the lyrics were by Richard Wilbur.

title: CLINTON ACCEPTS IRAQ'S PROMISE TO ALLOW WEAPONS INSPECTIONS
description: President Clinton said today that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq had unconditionally retreated and once again had vowed complete cooperation with United Nations weapons inspectors. That vow will be tested quickly, Mr. Clinton said, and American and British forces that nearly struck Iraq on Saturday will remain poised to act.

title: Mathis's Catch Seals Falcons' Rise to Top of West
description: Football is blocking and tackling. Simple. But tell that to a wide receiver. Try convincing him.

title: A Trial Will Test China's Grip on the Internet
description: The trial of a 30-year-old computer executive, soon to begin in Shanghai, heralds a new electronic battleground for China's political dissidents and security forces determined to preserve Communist Party control.

title: Sports of The Times; Holzman's Legacy Of Absolute Loyalty
description: THERE was one Red Holzman who was barely mentioned and certainly not eulogized in the newspapers this weekend, or yesterday at the Parkside Memorial Chapel in Forest Hills, Queens. This Holzman was not considered the architect of New York's most sophisticated sports team, or, as Dave Checketts lovingly called him, the ''patriarch of the Knicks.''

title: The Reading Room Reopens
description: When you request a book in the main reading room of the New York Public Library, the call slip disappears down a pneumatic tube into regions unimaginable and you are given a number. You take a seat at one of the long desks in the north or south hall and wait for your number to appear on a board at the front of the room. Nearly everyone spends the time gazing at the room itself, listening to the audible rumble of intellection, and wondering how to collect one's prize without stumbling or making too much noise or betraying a fit of self-consciousness during that long, deliberate walk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAND, HARRY
description: RAND-Harry. Retired Lieutenant Colonel, U.S. Air Force. Husband of Louise Larkin Rand. Interment service with full Military Honors at Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, VA, Wednesday, November 18, 1 PM.

title: The Words That Broke the Suspense: From Clinton and the Iraqis
description: Following are the text of President Clinton's statement today on Iraq, as provided by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service, and an unofficial translation of the first of two similar letters sent on Saturday by Nizar Hamdoon, the Iraqi representative at the United Nations, to Secretary General Kofi Annan:

title: Sports of The Times; Fattened Up for a Loss By a Diet Full of Praise
description: THEY were, surely, the lads of destiny. Yes, it was only halftime of the 10th game of the season, but, hey, let's start making reservations for when we check into Miami for the Super Bowl in two months. The Jets, at 6-3 and tied for the East lead in the American Football Conference, and winners of four straight games, had gone ahead of the Colts, 23-10, on the last play of the first half in the RCA Dome yesterday. And this was no ordinary play.

title: Falling From Grace With The Sea
description: Among opera singers, athleticism is typically confined to the vocal mechanism. So Steven Mackey cannot expect that many will be eager to take up his one-man opera, ''Ravenshead''; not, at least, the way Rinde Eckert played it on Friday evening at the Miller Theater on the campus of Columbia University. In addition to vocal athletics, including a number sung in falsetto, the role furnished a strenuous physical two-hour workout that evoked all too vividly the mortal threat to the character.

title: Accounts
description: Charlotte Hornets and Charlotte Sting to the Martin Agency, Richmond, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., to handle advertising for the National Basketball Association and Women's National Basketball Association teams, which had been handled in-house and on a project basis.

title: Pierre Trudeau's Youngest Son Believed Killed in Avalanche
description: The youngest son of the former Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau was swept into a mountain lake by an avalanche in British Columbia on Friday and is presumed drowned, police officials said today. Heavy snow has forced rescue teams to suspend their search.

title: Berkshire Hathaway Posts Drop in Assets
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the investment and insurance company led by Warren E. Buffett, had a 15 percent drop in assets in the third quarter, when the value of some of its biggest holdings plunged.

title: A&E to Create 2 Digital-Ready Spinoff Channels
description: Joining the small cadre of cable networks sticking their toes into the unclear waters of digital television, the A&E Network plans to announce two spinoff channels today, the Biography Channel and History Channel International, which will become widely available only when digital television does.

title: Despite Some Miscues, Flutie Continues Magic Show
description: Buffalo quarterback Doug Flutie is doing everything he can to make sure the magic doesn't run dry. Not a game goes by without one of those Flutie plays that causes jaws to drop throughout the stadium.

title: Wagner in Their Bones, and the Italian Side, Too
description: There is a lot of Italy in Wagner's early operas. As deep into his career as ''Lohengrin,'' melody hinged together with ornamental flourishes floats in the manner of Bellini. It is as if that most German of composers sucked musical sustenance from the south, biding his time until his own style was in place.

title: JAPAN ANNOUNCES $195 BILLION PLAN TO REVIVE ECONOMY
description: The Japanese Government has ratcheted up to a monumental $195 billion the size of a new economic stimulus package that it announced this morning, making this the largest package Japan has drawn up in eight years of economic malaise.

title: Glenn to Touch Down for a Parade
description: Now that he's the world's oldest astronaut, what on Earth will John Glenn do?

title: A Drive to Unionize Fast-Food Workers
description: In Pennsylvania Station, labor organizers have undertaken one of the biggest efforts in the nation to unionize fast-food workers.

title: Rejecting Warning, Albright Sees Anwar's Wife
description: KUALA LUMPU  Avoiding official talks with the Malaysian government, the U.S. secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, met Sunday with the wife of Anwar Ibrahim, the country's ousted deputy prime minister. The meeting was apparently a protest against the treatment of Mr. Anwar, who is in jail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ODABASH, ARTHUR
description: ODABASH-Arthur. Passed away on November 13, 1998. The Board of Trustees of Englewood Hospital and Medical Center deeply mourn the passing of our dear Association Member and friend Arthur Odabash. Heartfelt condolences are offered to his beloved wife Lois, and children Robin, Jamie, Melissa, Scott and Megan.

title: Mixing Up The Lineup
description: With his offense faltering in yesterday's 37-3 loss to the Green Bay Packers, Giants Coach Jim Fassel made four changes in the lineup late in the third quarter, removing right tackle Scott Gragg, left guard Greg Bishop, quarterback Danny Kanell and running back Gary Brown.

title: Stokely Carmichael, Rights Leader Who Coined 'Black Power,' Dies at 57
description: Kwame Ture, the flamboyant civil rights leader known to most Americans as Stokely Carmichael, died yesterday in Conakry, Guinea. He was 57 and is best remembered for his use of the phrase ''black power,'' which in the mid-1960's ignited a white backlash and alarmed an older generation of civil rights leaders, including the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about two men indicted in a scheme to sell fake moon rocks, which they said had been given to their father by the astronaut John Glenn, referred incorrectly in some editions to the NASA mission in which Mr. Glenn orbited the Earth. It was a Mercury flight, not an Apollo.

title: New Violence Puts Indonesia's Military at a Crossroads
description: ''Please don't break through the barriers,'' an army captain pleaded to a throng of student demonstrators. ''We are soldiers. We are not the enemy of society.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, SELMA
description: BECKER-Selma. Of Hollywood, FL. Passed away on November 14. Beloved wife for 69 years of the late Nathaniel. Loving mother to Richard Becker, Harriet and Ira Teper, and Joel and Dorothy Becker. Dear sister to Pearl Kohnop. Cherished grandmother to Melissa Teper, Laurie Becker and Paul Berkelhammer, Jeffrey and Joanne Levine, and Wendy and Michael Zucker. Loving greatgrandmother to Jennie and Bryan Levine, and Joshua and Sarah Zucker. This wonderful woman's life was a model of the selfless love that the name ''mother'' epitomizes. ''What matters is living, loving and enjoying life'' was her advice to those close to her. The influence of her giving personality will continue to have a profound effect on her many friends and relatives in New York and Florida.

title: Space Station, Long a Dream, To Soar at Last
description: After years of debate, hundreds of studies, thousands of pages of blueprints and billions of dollars, the United States and 15 other nations are ready to start building the largest, most complex structure ever assembled in space, the international space station.

title: G.O.P. Talks Big, but Doesn't Deliver; Geography Counts
description: To the Editor:

title: Boroughs Battle Over Trash As Last Landfill Nears Close
description: A sculptor who has lived in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, for 20 years says he is thinking of moving to get away from the garbage. A retired salesman in Hunts Point in the Bronx crinkles his nose as he describes the acrid smell of the endless garbage trucks. On the Brooklyn waterfront in Red Hook, a man rails against a plan to bring immense garbage barges to a newly created shipping hub for trash.

title: Time Magazine's One-Advertiser Issues Become an Issue for Debate
description: Mark Whitaker, the new editor of Newsweek, brought up the subject last week as one of his first acts as editor.

title: Back From the Brink With Iraq
description: The latest confrontation with Iraq has ended with another promise from Saddam Hussein to allow unfettered access for United Nations weapons inspectors. The apparent peaceful resolution is welcome, and can be credited to President Clinton's renewed willingness to back diplomacy with the threat of force. But this must be the last time that Iraq tries to manipulate the Security Council.

title: Stricter Oversight of Police Would Save Money, Report Says
description: With police brutality lawsuits costing New York City $96.8 million over the last four years -- nearly 10 cents of every dollar that the city paid in 1997 in personal injury cases -- the city has a big financial incentive to strengthen the independent agency that monitors and investigates allegations of police misconduct, according to a new report.

title: Beacon of Pride Extinguished; Eight Forfeited Football Victories Stun Asbury Park
description: In the end, none of it counts for the Blue Bishops football team.

title: 2 Records For Glenn
description: Aaron Glenn's 104-yard return of a field-goal attempt broke the National Football League record of 101 yards, set by the Eagles' Al Nelson against the Cowboys in 1971. It was the longest touchdown of any type in Jets history.

title: Patents; An entrepreneur hopes that sterilized dental floss will encourage people to keep their teeth cleaner.
description: ANY people dislike flossing their teeth and do so irregularly. Flossing has such a bad image that people tend to floss erratically even when they understand that it is only way to really clean below the gum line.

title: Art for Charity's Sake: A Day of Looking, Listening and Buying for a Good Cause
description: One of the groups from Artwalk NY, a series of tours through artists' studios, shuffled into Michael Brennan's little work space on the Bowery. As the visitors settled in, Mr. Brennan, 33, gamely tried to explain his paintings, rectangles of evenly applied scarlet paint framing smaller rectangles of wild brush strokes and dried ridges in blue and white.

title: Xcacel Journal; Voice of the Turtles Opposes a Hotel Development
description: This pristine Caribbean beach is one of the world's most important nesting areas for sea turtles, and Mexican environmentalists view its ivory sands and emerald waters as sacred terrain, on a smaller scale but a bit the way people in the United States see Yosemite or the Grand Canyon.

title: Market Place; Are Internet offerings sound investments or just raw speculation?
description: IN moonshots heard throughout cyberspace, the stocks of two newly public companies soared last week as investors again rushed to buy up the promise of the Internet. Small investors, especially those glued to their computer screens, pushed the prices of many Internet stocks to levels that seemed to defy gravity and common sense.

title: Compressed Data; Stanford Gave Writer A Start, but Not a Ph.D.
description: It turns out the name isn't the only thing made up about Robert X. Cringely, the writer and television personality whose program, ''Nerds 2.0.1: A Brief History of the Internet'' will be on PBS next week. Mr. Cringely, whose real name is Mark Stephens, has acknowledged that he exaggerated his academic credentials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARLINSKY, RAYMOND E.
description: KARLINSKY-Raymond E. Age 74, on November 14, 1998. Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of NYC. Beloved husband of Bette, loving father of Martin, Debi and Joanna. A lover of life, full of generosity, wit and vitality. We will miss his love and guidance greatly. Contributions in his memeory may be made to the Raymond Karlinsky Scholarship Fund-Little Village School-Jack Joel Center for Special Children, Bellmore, NY.

title: SOVEREIGN ISLANDS: A special report.; On Cruise Ships, Silence Shrouds Crimes
description: A Texas woman on a Caribbean cruise with her husband accused a waiter of drugging their dinner drinks and later raping her in their cabin.

title: Black and White in United States History: A Gray Area
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Film Setback Puts Universal Chief on Shakier Ground
description: ''Meet Joe Black,'' the lavish three-hour film made by Universal Studios, opened over the weekend to poor reviews and a disappointing box office, increasing the expectations in the movie industry that the studio's owner, the Seagram Company, planned to oust Frank Biondi Jr., Universal's chairman and chief executive, and overhaul Universal's corporate structure.

title: Honest Numbers on Capitol Hill
description: When Congress debates taxes and spending decisions, it is the Congressional Budget Office that sets the terms of the debate, with its estimates of just how much each provision will cost or bring in to the Treasury. That office has developed a reputation for impartial professionalism that must be preserved. With June O'Neill, the director of the office, stepping down at the end of the year, the appointment of her successor will provide an early indication of whether the new Republican leadership in the House will continue on the same disastrous course begun by Speaker Newt Gingrich and his colleagues last summer.

title: The Big City; The Junior Joy Rider Is Back in the Driver's Seat
description: HE had to wait 11 years after his first attempt, but yesterday Rocco Morabito finally drove his sister all the way to the beach. He was safe at last from the police, thanks to the learner's permit he got on his 16th birthday, and he handled the car even better than he had the first time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HODGES, E. PHILIP
description: HODGES-E. Philip. Of Scarborough, NY, passed away November 9 in California. He retired from A T & T after 43 years as a building engineer. He is survived by his wife Elizabeth, a son Philip, a daughter Elizabeth, and two grandchildren. Services December 3, 11 AM, St. Theresa's RC Church, in Briarcliff Manor, NY.

title: Media Talk; Art Criticism Recycled in Time
description: The nation's highest-profile art critic confessing to . . . cannibalism?

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column on Thursday, about the way publishers react when questions are raised about fictitious elements in a book labeled nonfiction, misspelled the surname of a sister of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who figured in a fictionalized scene in Joel McGinnis's book ''The Last Brother.'' She is Eunice Shriver, not Schriver.

title: Equity Offerings Planned
description: These equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTIMORE, JOHN TILLMAN
description: CASTIMORE-John Tillman. 75. Formerly of Scarsdale, NY. Died of cancer November 10, 1998, at his Waldorf, MD, residence. He was a retired marketing/advertising representative. He was a member of the Congregational Church of Scarsdale, NY, and served with the Merchant Marines during WWII. He was co-captain of his sailboat ''John Dog'' and loved music, woodworking and playing his harmonica. He graduated from Amherst College in Amherst, MA. Born October 20, 1923, in Brooklyn, NY, he was the son of the late Clarence Castimore and the late Elisabeth Tracy Castimore. He is survived by his beloved Judith Nathan; nieces Patricia Castimore, Marjorie Brian, nephew Thomas Castimore, niece Anne Castimore; sister-in-law Marjorie Castimore; grand-nephew Will Castimore; stepchildren Richard and Leslie Nathan, Karen Day and Hallie Holland and grandchildren Susanna and Benjamin Nathan, Lauren and Graham Day and Jesse Holland. Services were held November 13 in Waldorf, MD. Send contributions to National Institutes of Health-Cancer Research, 9000 Rockville Pike, Bldg. 31, Rm. 11A18, Bethesda, MD 20892.

title: Recapturing Past Delights While Making Them New
description: It's easy enough to preserve art that has been designated classic in the old high sense: the kind meant to reside in museums, concert halls and august theatrical spaces. Age cannot wither nor custom stale its infinite variety, we feel (or are told to feel). This art has history and eternity on its side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOROTKIN, THEODORE I.
description: KOROTKIN-Theodore I. On November 13, 1998. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Michael, Steven and Jeffrey, and father-in-law of Marcia, Beth and Cathy. Cherished grandfather of Darryl, Barron, Alan, Alyssa, Wendy, Neil, Julie, Eric and Samantha, and great-grandfather of Rachel, Jason and Lucas. He was a very special person. A service will be held on Monday, November 16, 1998, at 12 noon, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mount Vernon, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKS, ELLEN MERRILL
description: BROOKS-Ellen Merrill. Age 86, on November 13. Actress and wife of former New York Times Rare Books Editor Philip Brooks.

title: Coyote Hunt Splits Animal Advocates and Ranchers
description: The image of a howling coyote is a romantic symbol of the still untamed wild West to some, but to many hunters and ranchers it represents a persistent predator. And so in another Western tradition, hunters from several states gathered this weekend to compete in the annual National Coyote Calling Contest.

title: Cable and Wireless Buying Fiber Optics
description: Expanding its presence in Europe, Cable and Wireless of Britain has agreed to buy more than $100 million worth of fiber optic lines from Global Crossing Ltd., a small international communications carrier that went public in August, executives close to the deal said.

title: Grey to Handle 3 Margarine Brands
description: The Beatrice Foods unit of Conagra Inc. has expanded its relationship with Grey Advertising in New York by naming the agency to handle advertising for three margarine brands -- Blue Bonnet, Fleischmann's and Parkay -- that Conagra recently acquired from the Nabisco Inc. unit of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation. The assignment, with combined billings estimated at $15 million, had been handled by Foote, Cone & Belding in New York, a unit of True North Communications, when those brands were owned by Nabisco.

title: Laurence Gandar, Apartheid Critic, Dies at 82
description: Laurence Owen Vine Gandar, the South African newspaper editor credited with bringing investigative journalism to a country that desperately needed it, died Saturday in Pietermaritzburg.

title: America Online Has New Portal
description: When America Online bought the small Israeli start-up company Mirabilis last June for $287 million, people in the industry scratched their heads and wondered what the buyer was getting. Mirabilis makes a software program called ICQ for chat and instant messaging that has been distributed free to Internet users who give it a cultish dedication that one executive likened to fans' devotion to the Grateful Dead.

title: Media Talk; Slide Seen at NBC Nightly News
description: For most weeks in the last year, the competition among the network evening newscasts has been a one-sided three-way race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, RAYMOND S
description: BARON-Raymond S. Devoted husband of the late Harriet Baron, loving partner of Midge Grant, adored father of Ronnie and Fred Hirsh and Maggie and Richard Baron, cherished grandfather of Jodi, Lara and Alan Hirsh, and dear brother to Francine Leibler, Austin Baron and Jules Baron. We will love you forever. Service will be Tuesday, November 17, 11:30 AM, at the Boulevard Park West Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: Brazil Aid Package
description: To the Editor:

title: Catherine W. Pillsbury, Philanthropist, 92
description: Catherine Wheeler Pillsbury, a philanthropist who with her husband, Evans S. Pillsbury 2d, owned and operated cattle ranches in California's Santa Ynez Valley from the 1930's to the 50's, died Friday at her home in Montecito, Calif. She was 92.

title: The Wrath Of God?
description: At the beginning of the 17th century, the inhabitants of Leon, then the capital of Nicaragua, abandoned their city in a silent exodus. For almost 100 years they had struggled to keep their city on the spot originally chosen for its serene beauty: near the shores of Lake Managua, facing the magnificent volcano Momotombo.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Editorial Observer; A Democratic 'Ground War' Slips by the Radar
description: For all the surprises in the recent elections, one widely shared prediction turned out to be correct. Despite increases in those eligible and registered to vote, only 72.5 million Americans turned up at the polls, 2.5 million fewer than four years ago. It was the lowest voting participation rate since 1942 and the lowest outside the South since 1818.

title: Forget Crime: Iowans Grill Giuliani on Pigs and the Presidency
description: It was Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's second visit to this largely rural state, and for the second time, he came to boast about his success in cutting taxes, crime and the welfare rolls back in the big city. But by this morning, inquiring minds in Iowa had heard so much about New York that reporters decided it was time to question him about pressing local issues.

title: Survivors Make the Case Against Death Row
description: In the 22 years since the nation resumed executions, the anti-death penalty movement has been battered, bloodied and ignored.

title: When E-Mail Shows Up in Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Compassion and Mastery Are Part of Jones's Arsenal
description: Everyone thought that Roy Jones Jr. was the superior fighter when his light-heavyweight title bout against Otis Grant, a middleweight moving up in weight, was announced.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Iraq has backed down, but that is not enough. Now Iraq must live up to its

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Saturday with an article about an International Monetary Fund loan package for Brazil misstated the amount being provided in some editions. It is $41.5 billion, not $41.5 million.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SANTINO, RICHARD
description: SANTINO-Richard. November 16, 1945-August 28, 1994. In loving and joyous memory. Bob, Lisa, Dic

title: DNA and Destiny
description: These are the days of bio-shocks. Mapping the human genetic code. DNA fingerprinting. Cloning. And now, according to reports, the maintenance, in the laboratory, of human DNA fused with cow eggs. Not yet, but someday scientists may be able to introduce such hybrid cells into a needy body, where if persuaded to perform as required they could make healthy heart tissue, for example, or maybe even grow new limbs for amputees.

title: Oracle Data Base Takes Aim at Windows
description: Lawrence J. Ellison, chairman of the Oracle Corporation and longtime foe of Microsoft's chairman, William H. Gates, failed in his first effort to undermine the dominance of the Windows family of operating systems with a concept called the network computer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLANDER, GEORGE F.
description: FRIEDLANDER - George F. Passed away on November 14, 1998, after a bout with cancer. He leaves behind his wife Shirley, two loving daughters, Merri Gelbard and Dr. Susan E. Friedlander, and son-in-law Mitchell Gelbard, two grandchildren, Jonathan and Joanna Brynn Gelbard, and a brother Albert Friedlander, who will all miss him dearly. Services Monday, 12 noon, at RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: Without Banned Arms, a 4th-Rate Power
description: With his latest act of brinkmanship, some analysts and officials say President Saddam Hussein of Iraq is closer to what he wants most: keeping a secret cache of biological and chemical weapons while gaining support for an end to the economic sanctions crippling his country.

title: Pushing Harder for Access to Cuba
description: At a time when the volume of foreign news is dwindling, networks are eliminating foreign news bureaus and newspapers are playing down reports from overseas, a dozen news organizations are making considerable effort to open news bureaus in Cuba.

title: Media Talk; A Gore's Foray Into Secret Service
description: The second child of Vice President Al Gore has written an essay for The Harvard Lampoon in which she satirizes the type of person who might be drawn to the life of a Secret Service agent.

title: One Grand Play, One Inglorious Finish as the Jets Unravel
description: The Jets produced a spectacular play today Aaron Glenn's 104-yard score on the longest return of a field-goal attempt in National Football League history -- but they could not overcome dropped balls and missed tackles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, EDITH
description: BERMAN-Edith. November 10, 1998. A woman of surpassing qualities: extraordinarily devoted wife, exemplary mother, patient, adoring grandmother, loyal, unwavering, and generous in her love for those dear to her. In her gracious, lovely, and endlessly unassuming way, she occupied a place in our hearts so outsized, so far beyond the roles of sister-in-law and aunt. We will miss her ready laughter, her quick wit, her gifted brilliant mind. The joy and contentment she found in everyday life set a standard to strive for. Her loss is devastating to our family. Nothing will be the same without her, but she will live on forever in our hearts. Marlene, Richard, Jamie, Kerry, Kenneth, and Julie Grau, Neil, Carolyn, Marla, Adam, and Jennifer Berman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHORY, JUNE H.
description: CHORY-June H. On November 14, 1998. Resident of Pawling, NY. Former teacher at Jane Addams High School, NYC. Wife of William J. Chory. Mother of James, Robert and Susan Chory, and Cynthia Zavras. Grandmother of Jennifer, Ashley and Robert Chory, and Zachary Zavras. Visitation Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Horn & Thomes, 83 East Main St., Pawling, NY Funeral Tuesday, 10 AM, at funeral home. Burial Machpelah Cemetery, North Bergen, NJ.

title: Labor Party Gets to Work At Its Second Convention
description: If Anthony Mazzocchi's vision becomes reality, the United States will someday have a Labor Party that rivals Britain's.

title: Hinting Quietly at Zen and the Principles of Physics
description: Sounding not a bit hobbled by his chronic-fatigue syndrome, which has made normal concert hall touring impossible for him, the pianist Keith Jarrett seemed tonight to embody the Zen principle of leaping like a tiger while sitting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, RICHARD
description: GOLDBERG-Richard. The Board of Directors and the entire congregational family of Beth El J.C. of Flatbush mourn the tragic loss of our beloved Board member and benefactor, Richard Goldberg. With deep sorrow, we express our condolences to his wife Joan, a longtime Trustee of our Board, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jersusalem. Robert Behm, President George Green, Chairman, Board of Directors Pinchas Pearl, Rabbi

title: The heady world of automotive campaigns includes a spinoff, a consolidation and a blitz.
description: BIG news is being made with big changes involving three big auto makers: the Nissan Motor Corporation USA, Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America and DaimlerChrysler A. G., the behemoth formed by the merger of the Chrysler Corporation and Daimler-Benz A. G.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GARLICK, JOE
description: GARLICK-Joe. 1923-1978. As long as we live, he too will live, for he is a part of us. Anita, Children and Grandchildren

title: Southeast Asian Markets Calmer, but Peril Remains
description: Stock markets are up, currencies are stable, and bankers no longer live in dread of panicky runs on their branches. Even CNBC Asia, the cable news channel that offers minute-by-minute coverage of the region's malaise, has stopped using its pulse-quickening logo, ''Asia in Crisis.''

title: Devils Are Left to Analyze An Unsightly Breakdown
description: The third-period collapse by the Devils in the 6-1 loss to the Flyers in Philadelphia Saturday night came as no surprise. The Devils' way of living dangerously simply caught up with them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, JAMES E.
description: GALLAGHER-James E. On November 14, 1998, of Garden City, NY. Beloved husband of Eileen. Loving father of Kevin, Mary Grace and Stephen and father-inlaw of Sheila and Elizabeth. Dear Papa of Liza, Kara, Erin and Kelly. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th St., Garden City, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, Monday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Anne's Church, Garden City, 10:45 AM, Tuesday. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury.

title: A Sense of Communality But Without the Lock Step
description: Garth Fagan loves odd titles. Take those of two works his troupe, Garth Fagan Dance, revived on Friday night at the Joyce Theater. ''Telling a Story'' didn't do that, at least in any simple sense. And no winged insects flew through ''Moth Dreams.'' Yet the plotless dance was often implicitly dramatic. And ''Moth Dreams'' suggested something of the fragility of human relationships. Both pieces also concerned communities.

title: Flight-Planning Data
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Does Microsoft Want You To Go Today?; The New Strategy: Keep Web Surfers Busy With a Series Of MSN Sites
description: Haven't we seen this screen before?

title: Focus on Hiring at ABC
description: To understand the labor dispute between ABC and its union of 2,200 off-camera workers, grab the remote control and click. Now click again. And again.

title: Essay; Diddled Again
description: As President Clinton left the White House briefing room to escape questions, his national security adviser, Samuel Berger, stepped up, fiddled with electric lectern switches and muttered into a live microphone: ''How do we lower this damn thing?''

title: G.O.P. Talks Big, but Doesn't Deliver; Savior to Scapegoat
description: To the Editor:

title: To Bind the Faith, Free Trips to Israel for Diaspora Youth
description: In an attempt to rebuild religious identity among young Jews, who are marrying non-Jews and abandoning the faith in large numbers, Jewish organizations plan to start a program that will pay for any Jew in the world between age 15 and 26 to travel to Israel for 10 days.

title: Time to Fix Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Internet Governance Board Confronts a Hostile Public
description: Eight people found themselves at a crossroads in history today, visibly uncomfortable with their task of creating the first real government for an on-line world and intimidated by the level of distrust -- sometimes outright animosity -- they encountered when facing their constituents for the first time.

title: Giants' Defense Looks For Attitude Adjustment
description: Standing in front of his locker after the game, Phillippi Sparks tried to find the words for what he had just witnessed. But the 37-3 loss to the Green Bay Packers -- like an accident in which he could recall only a flash of light, something going past him quickly and loudly -- had left him stunned.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Monday about Stephen King's books referred incorrectly in some editions to the publisher of Robert Jordan's ''Path of Daggers,'' which had higher opening sales at the Barnes & Noble chain than Mr. King's ''Bag of Bones.'' And a related correction in this space on Tuesday was published in error. The publisher of the Jordan book is Tor/Doherty. (St. Martin's Press is the distributor.)

title: Duel for Top Two Spots Tighter
description: He is uncomfortable enjoying a warm moment. Distant, precise and calculatingly contrary, Kansas State Coach Bill Snyder found something to be troubled about in the afterglow of his program's greatest victory in the last decade -- if not ever. In a low voice, he wondered aloud what would have happened if Nebraska had beaten his team on Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KISSINGER, PAULA STERN
description: KISSINGER-Paula Stern. Age 97, on November 15, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Louis Kissinger. She is survived by her two sons Henry A. and Walter B., six grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Funeral services at 11 AM on Monday, November 16, at Hirsch & Sons, 1225 Jerome Ave. at 167th St., Bronx. The family requests in lieu of flowers that donations be sent in her memory to the Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital, Development Office, 622 West 168th St., New York, NY 10032-3784.

title: A Prospero or Lear? Nay, Verily a Falstaff; A Boisterous Tribute to Shakespeare
description: When Harold Bloom was 15, he saw the Old Vic perform ''Henry IV, Part 1'' on Broadway. Ralph Richardson played Falstaff and Laurence Olivier was Hotspur (doubling in ''Henry IV, Part 2'' as Justice Shallow). To this day, Mr. Bloom has no recollection of who played Prince Hal (it was Michael Warre), but seeing Richardson was, for him, a transcendent experience.

title: Who Backed Down?
description: Who blinked? Both of them, Bill Clinton every bit as much as Saddam Hussein, in the weekend showdown over Iraq's weapons of mass destruction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZANELLI, SUE
description: ZANELLI-Sue. Loving mother of Alice. May her soul be bound in eternal peace. Services private. Carl Grossman and Family

title: P. Kissinger, 97, The Mother Of a Statesman
description: Paula Kissinger, a refugee from Nazi Germany who held the Bible at the White House in 1973 when her first-born son, Henry, was sworn in as Secretary of State, the highest Cabinet post in her adopted land, died at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center yesterday in Manhattan. She was 97.

title: Either War or Peace: A Vocabulary Guide
description: With the threat of American bombing attacks against Iraq put aside, diplomats and military analysts conducted a war of words.

title: Man Saved From Ocean After Cycling Accident
description: Michael Ferto's mountain bike was made to ride over the most rugged terrain. It was not designed, however, to go in the ocean. Mr. Ferto had to be rescued from the chilly waters of the Atlantic yesterday when, the police said, he struck a guardrail at the end of Beach Eighth Street in Far Rockaway, Queens, flipped over it, banged his head on a wooden piling and fell unconscious into the water. He was later revived.

title: Bill Sale Today Is Only Auction Listed by Treasury This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: The Century Ahead for Science
description: WHAT REMAINS TO BE DISCOVERED

title: Corrections
description: The State of the Art column in Circuits on Thursday about the Yamaha Disklavier Grantouch digital grand piano misidentified the composer of the song ''Feelings.'' Morris Albert adapted it in 1975 from a song written by Louis Gaste in 1956; it is not by Barry Manilow. The column also misspelled the name of the label for the audio CD ''A Window in Time: Rachmaninoff Performs His Solo Works.'' It is Telarc, not Terarc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRIER, MARTIN PAUL
description: BRIER-Martin Paul. On November 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Bernice. Loving father of Suzanne and Lynne (Lenny). Adored grandfather of Lori. Cherished brother of Florence and Phyllis. Friend to many. Loved dearly. Services will be held Tuesday, November 17, 1998, at 12 noon, at the Riverdale Temple, West 246th St. and Independence Ave., Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to charity of your choice.

title: Iraq's Move From Brink Is Greeted With Relief
description: Iraq had found few Arab friends in its latest showdown with the United Nations, but its shift away from confrontation was greeted in the Arab world today with swift statements of relief that could complicate American efforts to maintain military pressure.

title: G.I.'s in the Desert Say 'Get It Over With'
description: It seems like the middle of nowhere, dunes dotted with little more than herds of sheep and the occasional camel carcass. But it is home to 1,500 American soldiers, roving the desert just 30 miles east of the Iraqi border, and some of them are getting sick of Saddam Hussein.

title: When E-Mail Shows Up in Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Jordan King, Recovering, Gets a Party In Absentia
description: Jordan threw a 63d birthday party this weekend for King Hussein, who could not attend but said that he is completely cured of the cancer he has been battling for the last four months at the Mayo Clinic in Minnesota.

title: 3 Days After Surgery, Whitman Is Set to Work
description: Three days after emergency surgery to remove an inflamed appendix, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey is scheduled to return to work today. She spent the weekend with her husband and two college-age children at her farm in Oldwick, about 50 miles north of Trenton, the state capital, said Pete McDonough, her spokesman.

title: G.O.P. Talks Big, but Doesn't Deliver
description: To the Editor:

title: Using Visits to Israel To Win Young Jews
description: In an attempt to rebuild religious identity among young Jews, who are abandoning the faith in large numbers, Jewish organizations are ready to pay for any Jew in the world between 15 and 26 to visit Israel.

title: For Missing Woman's Family, No Answers
description: Few dream cruises have turned into the nightmare experienced by Iva and Ron Bradley of Richmond, Va., on a cruise last March through the southern Caribbean with their son, Brad, and daughter, Amy. Midway through the cruise, 23-year-old Amy, a recent college graduate about to start her first full-time job, disappeared.

title: PLUS: SOCCER -- Big East Men; St. John's Defeats Georgetown
description: St. John's won its fifth Big East men's soccer championship yesterday, defeating Georgetown by 4-1 at the Rutgers Soccer Stadium. The Red Storm, ranked ninth in the nation and seeded second in the tournament, earned the conference's automatic bid to the 32-team N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Depth of Rift Over Software Is Disclosed
description: The Microsoft trial is not merely a legal prizefight. With its parade of witnesses and mountains of documents, it has opened a window to the inner workings of the Microsoft Corporation and how it deals with the rest of the computer industry, raw material for a digital-age ''Dynasty.''

title: A Couple in Love Amid Iraq's Hardships
description: Tonight's return to Iraq of Arthur Kent, who covered the Persian Gulf war, is largely given, as the program's title reveals, to ''A Wedding in Basra.'' It's a colorful if not especially revealing look at a young couple, Sahar and Ali, and their extended family, celebrating a love match in a country where there is not much to celebrate, particularly as American ships, planes and missiles were once again being gathered for an attack.

title: Desert Storm's Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: Crisis With Iraq: Clinton Accepts Iraqs Promise to Allow Weapons Inspections
description: WASHINGTON--President Clinton said today that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq had unconditionally retreated and once again had vowed complete cooperation with United Nations weapons inspectors. That vow will be tested quickly, Mr. Clinton said, and American and British forces that nearly struck Iraq on Saturday will remain poised to act.

title: Media Talk; Robert Ludlum Signs With St. Martin's
description: Robert Ludlum, master of international intrigue and weaver of grand-scale conspiracy plots, is departing his paperback publisher of more than two decades. But the reason seems rather dull for an author whose spies are constantly foiling world takeovers.

title: It's Back to the Beginning For Caminiti and the Astros
description: The acquisition of Ken Caminiti signaled the rebirth of the San Diego franchise four years ago, but now the third baseman is headed back to Houston. Caminiti, the National League's most valuable player in 1996, agreed to a two-year, $9.5 million contract with the Astros yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: Giuliani on the Hog Problem

title: Compressed Data; Reporters Get the Story On Silicon Real Estate
description: In what could be the start of a new trend among computer industry chiefs, both John Chambers of Cisco Systems and Larry Ellison of Oracle have invited reporters to their homes for private social events in the last two weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PARADNY, ROBERT, M.D.
description: PARADNY-Robert, M.D. Bob/ Dad, each and every day we remember how lucky we are to hold you in our hearts. With our everlasting love, Adelle, Robin, Andrea and Stewart

title: UConn Gives Quinnipiac a Division I Hello
description: Taking a cue from Duke, which it is expected to rival for supremacy in men's college basketball this season, UConn today also posted an opening-game rout over a school from the state of Connecticut.

title: Censure Is Not An Option
description: Conventional wisdom says that, the people having spoken in this month's elections, Congress now has no choice but to abandon the current impeachment inquiry. Pressure is building for a deal, most notably censure, plus something else like a fine.

title: Rising Congressional Leader Experienced in Self-Defense
description: In Washington political circles, Representative J. C. Watts Jr. is considered one of the Republican Party's brightest stars, a leading voice for conservative principles and, more recently, a candidate for Congressional leadership.

title: Shut Out Time Makes It 3 Straight
description: Shut Out Time, a 2-year-old colt bred in New York, won his third straight race yesterday when he outran Twenty Three Red in the $100,000 Great White Way Division of the New York Stallion Stakes at Aqueduct.

title: East Is East, West Is West, But Which Merits the Blame?
description: In bridge post-mortems, the name of the game is blame. Sometimes the verdict requires subtle analysis, as on the diagramed deal played in the Tri-State Regional Championships in Rye, N.Y., in January. Study the defense and decide whether any blame should attach to East or West after the given opening lead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRD, HELEN READY
description: BIRD-Helen Ready. Of New York City. Age 92. Died at home on November 13. Beloved daughter of the late Mary D. and Michael L. Bird. Niece of the late Francis P. Duffy, Chaplain, 69th Regiment, 165th Infantry of World War I fame. Dear sister of Francis and Gerald Bird and Agnes McCormack, and the late Grace Marion and Lawrence Bird. Loving aunt of Daria and Andrea, and greataunt of Angela. Memorial mass Epiphany Church, 22nd Street and First Avenue, New York City, at 10 AM on Wednesday, November 18. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to The Catholic Worker, 36 East First St., New York City, 10003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, CAROLE
description: THOMAS-Carole. Nassau Suffolk Home Care and Aides, Inc., expresses our condolences to the entire Thomas family on the loss of our President, Carole Thomas, who showed great courage in her battle against breast cancer. She will be sorely missed. Donations in her memory may be made to Adelphi University, Breast Cancer Hotline, where Carole was a volunteer. Funeral service will be held at Gutterman's in Woodbury on Tuesday, 3 PM. Suzanne G. Olivet, Assistant to the President Nassau Suffolk Home Care and Aides, Inc.

title: Choose What? Nihilism Among the Down and Out in Edinburgh
description: At least no one can accuse the playwright and director Harry Gibson of making heroin addiction seem like fun. In his lugubrious stage version of ''Trainspotting,'' taken from the same Irvine Welsh novel that inspired the hit film of 1996, Mr. Gibson presents being down, out and substance-abusing in contemporary Edinburgh as a grim tour through a societal hell. There is all too clearly no high to lift the play's characters out of the lower depths they inhabit.

title: Campaign Finance Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Time to Fix Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, IRVING N.
description: WEINBERG-Irving N. Washington Heights Congregation is deeply saddened at the loss of their esteemed Rabbi Emeritus, Rabbi Irving N. Weinberg. He was the former principal of the Yeshiva Rabbi Moses Soloveichik and in the past years the active Rabbi of the Congreation Hechal Moshe, Natanya, Israel. His memory will be cherished forever. Ellis Bloch, Rabbi Aaron Bullman, President

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, HELEN
description: RYAN-Helen. Age 93 of Cootehill, County Cavan, Ireland. On November 14, 1998. Beloved wife of the late James. Loving mother of Evelyn, James, Bridget, John, Helen, Patrick, grandmother of ten and great-grandmother of ten. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Monday, November 16, 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Jean Baptiste R.C. Church, Lexington Ave. at 76th St., Tuesday, 11 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Williams Optimistic
description: Brian Williams, the Giants center who has been sidelined since being poked in the eye during training camp a year ago, was in the locker room after the game and expressed optimism about resuming his career next year. Williams, who is 32, hopes that his third and latest surgery will correct his double vision. ''I'll know something by Christmas,'' he said.

title: Compressed Data; New Bills Slow the Laundry As Well as the Counterfeiters
description: When the Treasury Department issued a redesigned $20 bill in September, officials said that the new notes would help thwart counterfeiting by keeping ahead of digital printing technology. But are they also thwarting digital automation?

title: India's Christians
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Candidates Are Rounding Up Votes in Race for Majority Leader
description: With House Republicans picking their new leaders on Wednesday, Representative Dick Armey's aides say he is confident of keeping his job as majority leader, but his opponents doubt he has the votes, and a nascent movement to draft a fourth candidate is still alive.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BOSTON FINANCIAL INC., Boston, a real estate investment trust, will buy Schroder Real Estate Associates L.P., a pension real estate adviser, from its senior executives and its parent company, Schroder U.S. Holdings, for undisclosed terms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSTIKA, MIRIAM
description: KOSTIKA-Miriam. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue mourns the death of the mother of our esteemed member, Sharon Goldring and extends to her and the bereaved family our heartfelt condolences.

title: Excerpts From Gates Deposition at Antitrust Trial
description: Following are excerpts from an hour of videotaped testimony shown today in United States District Court during antitrust proceedings against Microsoft. David Boies and other lawyers for the Justice Department questioned the chairman and chief executive of the company, William H. Gates.

title: Slate's Coverage of Microsoft Trial Is Proving Difficult
description: When Michael Kinsley -- editor of the on-line magazine Slate, which is owned by the Microsoft Corporation -- first heard that Microsoft was going to trial in an antitrust lawsuit filed by the Justice Department, he knew he would not emerge unscathed. How does a magazine owned by a giant corporation cover its parent's antitrust trial?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VON REZZORI, GREGOR
description: VON REZZORI-Gregor Memorial for Gregor von Rezzori Thursday, November 19, at 7:00 p.m. The Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street. Readings and reminiscences by Michael Ondaatje, Robert Hughes and Isabella Rossellini among others. The public is invited to attend.

title: Anguish Makes the Heart Grow Weaker
description: Marital spats do more than bruise feelings and break hearts. They also narrow blood vessels, increase heartbeats, raise blood pressures and encourage hypertension, atherosclerosis and acute coronary heart disease, a University of Utah researcher says.

title: Judge Plans to Inspect Conditions in Jail
description: A Federal district judge in Manhattan said yesterday that he would make a personal visit to the Metropolitan Correctional Center in lower Manhattan to inspect jail conditions that lawyers for three defendants arrested after the bombings in the embassy attacks in Africa have said are unconstitutional and inhumane.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I can see no advantage to the Queen or the public if the Lord Chancellor

title: Democrats Plan to Cut Utility Rates by 15%
description: Assembly Democrats yesterday offered their own energy deregulation bill, which they said would offer bigger savings than a Republican proposal by limiting how much utilities could recover in debt amassed under the regulated system.

title: Science Takes Its Seat for the Night of the Meteors
description: By the time the Earth collides with a dense swarm of meteoroids tonight to unleash what may be the heaviest meteor bombardment since 1966, many orbiting satellites will have maneuvered into positions facing away from the storm to avoid damage. But scores of instruments on the ground and aboard airplanes will be aimed right at the blazing trails left by the meteors, gathering information about these visitors from space and what they do to the upper atmosphere as they burn up.

title: From the Brink to the Blink: Washington's Iraq Weekend
description: Defense Secretary William S. Cohen told the President to attack Iraq. Her aides said Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, who was then en route to an economic summit in Malaysia, would agree.

title: An Urban Folk Hero, Captive to the Drums
description: YOU can be an artist in New York or a voodoo drummer from Haiti and when you try to explain why you do what you do, only the words will be different.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOTTO, ROSE (NEE) CLEMENTE
description: SCOTTO-Rose (nee) Clemente. Devoted wife of the late Pasquale. Adored mother of Terry Spinelli and Salvatore (Buddy). Loving grandmother of Debra and Mark. Dearest sister of Yolanda Cardone. Also survived by nieces and nephews and so many devoted friends. Reposing Scotto Funeral Home 106 First Pl. (Near Court St) Brooklyn, until Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial. St. Mary Star Of The Sea RC Church 10:15 am. Visiting hours, Tuesday and Wendesday 2-5 & 7-9:30 pm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLAND, MITCHELL
description: FRIEDLAND - Mitchell. Marc Hochlerin and the staff of ACE audiovisual Inc. mourns Mitchell's passing and extends our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Maura Friedland and the entire family. Mitchell was a beloved friend of our firm who taught us the meaning of true inner strength and love. He was an inspiration to all of us and he will be missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOBEL, SHELDON
description: LOBEL-Sheldon. On November 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted father of Debra Lobel, Lisa Samuels and Mark Lobel. Loving father-in-law of Dr. Mitchell Samuels and Dr. Melissa Cohen. Adored and adoring grandfather of Cara, Dana and Michael Samuels. Dear brother of Millicent Haber and the late Irv Lobel. CoFounder of Lobel Chemical Corporation. His indomitable spirit and incredible courage throughout his epic struggle against cancer was truly inspiring. Services Wednesday, November 18th, 11:30AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. Interment Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale. Contributions in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He will always be loved and missed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FEUCHTWANGER, PIERRE
description: FEUCHTWANGER-Pierre, of Paris, France, left us on November 18, 1994. His presence, wits and love of life remain irreplaceable to his nephews, niece, grand nephew and grand niece. Let all his friends remember him affectionately.

title: A Handful of Nuts and a Healthier Heart
description: Good news for nut lovers -- and anyone who wants a simple way to help lower the risk of heart attack.

title: Trial Begins for 4 Tied To Stealing $10 Million
description: Three members of a Hasidic community in Rockland County and a man from Brooklyn went on trial in Federal District Court yesterday to face charges that they stole more than $10 million from various Government benefit programs, including student grants, housing subsidies, loans to small, minority-owned businesses and Social Security benefits.

title: Dispute Over Concealing Evidence From Wiretaps in California
description: A judge has refused to ban a much-disputed procedure used by the Los Angeles District Attorney to conceal from defendants the fact that some cases originated in wiretap surveillance from other investigations.

title: Man Accused of Arson Is Ordered Held on Bail
description: A Maplewood man was ordered held on $50,000 bail yesterday after he set fire to his repossessed house five days before he was scheduled to be evicted, the Essex County prosecutor's office said.

title: TEMPLE-INLAND TO ACQUIRE HF BANCORP FOR $120 MILLION
description: Temple-Inland Inc., a paper, building-products and financial services company, has agreed to buy HF Bancorp, a savings-and-loan holding company based in Hemet, Calif., for $18.50 a share in cash and stock, or a total of $120 million. Temple-Inland, based in Diboll, Tex., is the parent of Guaranty Federal, which has 135 banking centers in Texas and California and assets of $11 billion. HF Bancorp is the parent of Hemet Federal Savings and Loan, which has assets of $1 billion and 18 branches in Southern California. Its shares rose 12.5 cents, to $17.125. Temple-Inland fell 37.5 cents, to $49.5625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDIS, LEONARD
description: LANDIS-Leonard. The staff and leaders of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services and its Child Development Center mourn the passing of Leonard Landis, the husband of an esteemed friend and supporter of CDC, Elayne Landis. We extend our deepest sympathy to Mrs. Landis, a member of the CDC Divisional Committee; their three children, Andrew, Carolyn and Dean; and other members of the Landis family. Joseph S. Kaplan, President, JBFCS Alan B. Siskind, Ph.D., Executive Vice President, JBFCS Renee S. Ward, Chairperson, CDC Alice Kross Frankel, M.D., Director, CDC

title: On Tape, Gates Seems Puzzled by Words Like 'Market Share'
description: William H. Gates, the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, stubbornly debated the meaning of words like ''we'' and ''concern'' during an hour of his videotaped deposition shown in court today. Even ''market share'' seemed a curiously alien term to a man whose company owns just about all of the market in major product categories of the personal computer software business.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about statements made by police officers who are facing Federal civil rights charges in the Abner Louima assault case misstated a charge against one of them, Thomas Bruder. He has also been charged with lying to the authorities about the arrest of another man, Patrick Antoine, not of Mr. Louima.

title: Art Owned by Reader's Digest Auctioned for $86 Million
description: Reality chilled the enthusiasm last night at Sotheby's in Manhattan, where 37 works from the Reader's Digest collection, being sold along with Impressionist and modern art from various owners, kicked off the first session of this week's four-night auction marathon. Despite the record-breaking crowds that packed Sotheby's York Avenue headquarters all weekend to see art by masters including Modigliani, Cezanne and Picasso, bidding in the jammed auction room was surprisingly thin, and the mood was somber.

title: Nicotine's Image Takes A Turn for the Worse
description: If a biographer wanted to write about a spectacular comeback from notoriety to respectability, and the tenuous natures of comebacks, a good subject might be nicotine.

title: Mighty Muscles Built in Slow Motion
description: At Inform Fitness in Massapequa, N.Y., there is no piped-in music, no blaring televisions and, above all, no clanging and banging of weights. There are no treadmills, bicycles or rowing machines. A sign on the wall warns exercisers not to drive for at least 30 minutes after a workout.

title: A Merger of Muppets and Religion
description: Can Kermit (the frog), Merlin (the wizard) and Trapper John (M.D.) coexist on the same cable channel, cheek by jowl with ethicists and professors of religion?

title: A World of Ideas
description: The debate featured here last week regarding science and the limits of what can be learned (''Resolved: Science Is at an End. Or Is It?'') provoked a volley of letters from readers. Most begged to differ with John Horgan, author of ''The End of Science'' (Helix Books, 1996), who argued, ''We are down to the details now.'' Instead, many threw their weight with Sir John Maddox, former editor of the journal Nature, who asserted, ''Nobody can tell what lies ahead.''

title: Influencing Doctor's Orders
description: Pharmaceutical companies are increasingly souping up their advertising for prescription drugs in a style more commonly associated with products sold from open shelves in drugstores and supermarkets.

title: Industrial Output Registers Fourth Drop in Five Months
description: Industrial production unexpectedly fell in October, the fourth drop in five months, prompting many analysts to predict that the Federal Reserve's policy-setting panel will cut interest rates again at its meeting on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, JULIAN M.
description: COHN-Julian M. On November 15, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Vivian. Father of Cary and Joan. Grandfather of Paul and Richard. Services Tuesday, 10AM Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard (76th Road), Forest Hills, N.Y.

title: Hyde May Seek Broader Clinton Inquiry
description: In a move that could widen the investigation of President Clinton, the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee will ask fellow Republicans on the panel to seek testimony from a former Democratic Party fund-raiser, a senior Republican Congressional aide said tonight.

title: Ethical Cell Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Abroad at Home; A Kangaroo Court
description: For most Americans, impeachment is a dead issue. But that is not the reality in Washington. Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee are pressing on, by all signs as determined as ever to approve an impeachment resolution.

title: Time Brings Wisdom
description: The debate featured here last week regarding science and the limits of what can be learned (''Resolved: Science Is at an End. Or Is It?'') provoked a volley of letters from readers. Most begged to differ with John Horgan, author of ''The End of Science'' (Helix Books, 1996), who argued, ''We are down to the details now.'' Instead, many threw their weight with Sir John Maddox, former editor of the journal Nature, who asserted, ''Nobody can tell what lies ahead.''

title: Island of Mystery In Uncharted Seas
description: The Met Orchestra under James Levine produced two events of extraordinary interest at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon. They could not have been more different. One was the premiere of Milton Babbitt's Second Piano Concerto, the second a performance of the Dvorak G Major Symphony, the likes of which we may never hear again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  URSTADT, CLAIRE JORDAN
description: URSTADT-Claire Jordan, 96, a long-time resident of Mamaroneck, New York, on November 14th, 1998. Widow of the late Charles G. Urstadt and beloved mother of Charles J. Urstadt of Bronxville, NY and J. Jeffrey Urstadt of New Canaan, CT. She was the grandmother of Charles D. Urstadt, Catherine U. Biddle, Bryant E. Urstadt, J. Jordan Urstadt and Elizabeth C. Urstadt, and greatgrandmother of Elinor and Dana Biddle. Interment will be private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Dartmouth College, Hanover, New Hampshire.

title: Time to End Iraqis' Suffering; Hussein's Overthrow
description: To the Editor:

title: Time to End Iraqis' Suffering; Cat-and-Mouse Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Time to End Iraqis' Suffering; How to Test Baghdad
description: To the Editor:

title: German Giants Spinning Off Big Businesses
description: The streamlining of corporate Germany, which has been under way in fits and starts for several years, has accelerated. In the last two weeks, three of the biggest conglomerates have announced plans to spin off huge chunks of their empires, which employ tens of thousands of people.

title: South Africa's Press to Face Bias Inquiry
description: Sending a shiver through many of South Africa's newsrooms, the country's Human Rights Commission said today that it would open an investigation into racism in the press and that it would use its powers of subpoena and arrest if need be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILKINSON, FREDERICK D.
description: WILKINSON-Frederick D. Jr., the Founding Co-Chair of our Board of Overseers, died peacefully on Sunday. We will miss his friendship and his leadership and will not forget him. Our heartfelt sympathies to Fred's beloved wife, Jeane, and to their children, Sharon, Ambassador to Burkina Feso; Dayna of Weston, Virginia, and Frederick III of Los Angeles. The Board and Staff Brookdale Center on Aging of Hunter College

title: Microsoft Develops Software to Improve Appearance of Screen Text
description: Microsoft Corporation researchers have developed a software technique that improves the appearance of fonts displayed on color liquid-crystal display screens to a level that approaches the visual quality of text printed on paper.

title: Library's Reading Room Reopens in Blaze of Glory
description: One visitor said it reassured her that grandeur did not always fade, but sometimes came roaring back. Another visitor called it an affirmation that New Yorkers still cared about the majesty of their public spaces.

title: Catching Up With S.U.V.'s
description: Not all passenger vehicles are created equal, especially when it comes to the amount of pollution that flows from their tailpipes. Minivans, sport utility vehicles and light-duty pickup trucks -- all now wildly popular with Americans -- throw off higher levels of nitrogen oxides and other smog-causing gases than cars do. This happens because they are not subject to the same emissions standards that ordinary cars are. California wisely did away with this inequality on Nov. 5, issuing new, more stringent emission limits that will also apply to minivans, S.U.V.'s and light-duty trucks of up to 8,500 pounds, starting with the 2004 model year.

title: Built to Breed. Or Are We?
description: The debate featured here last week regarding science and the limits of what can be learned (''Resolved: Science Is at an End. Or Is It?'') provoked a volley of letters from readers. Most begged to differ with John Horgan, author of ''The End of Science'' (Helix Books, 1996), who argued, ''We are down to the details now.'' Instead, many threw their weight with Sir John Maddox, former editor of the journal Nature, who asserted, ''Nobody can tell what lies ahead.''

title: Judge Backs Law Requiring Rent Deposits in Evictions
description: In a decision prompting both landlords and tenants to claim at least partial victory, a state judge has upheld a New York State law requiring rent deposits from tenants fighting eviction, but he ruled that the law could be challenged case by case.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Average Tops 9,000 On Hope for a Rate Cut

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEL CAMPO, CRISTINA ERHART
description: del Campo-Cristina Erhart, representative and head of Christie's Argentina, passed away on October 19, 1998 in Buenos Aires after a short but valiant struggle with lung cancer. In addition to her position at Christie's, Ms. del Campo was very active as a member of the Multiple Sclerosis Society of Argentina and worked closely with her husband during his career as Minister of the Argentine Embassy in Tel Aviv and then later as Ambassador to Ireland and Sweden. In addtiion to her husband, Cristina is survived by her parents and her children, Angie and Juan Diego, as well as many adoring friends and colleagues. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, November 22, at 2:00 p.m., St. Vincent Ferrer, 869 Lexington Avenue at 66th Street.

title: Fugitive Kurdish Rebel Is a Headache for Italy
description: Facing his first real foreign policy test, Prime Minister Massimo D'Alema must decide what to do with a prominent Kurdish rebel leader who was arrested at the Rome airport on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLIKEN, MINOT K.
description: MILLIKEN-Minot K. The Board of Trustees and the Women's Board of The Boys' Club of New York regret the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend, Minot Milliken. As an active Trustee for the past 50 years, Minot worked tirelessly to help improve the lives of inner city boys giving them an alternative to the city's mean streets. He served with distinction as President for 25 years providing the vision, the financial and human resources to help make The Boys' Club of New York a safe haven for many generations of disadvantaged boys. He was the motivating source and benefactor in the expansion of the Pitt Street Clubhouse. In his honor this newly built facility is appropriately renamed the Milliken Clubhouse. A wise counselor, a stalwart friend, an energetic worker, a leader, his impact on The Boys' Club of New York will live on. Minot Milliken made a difference. He will long be remembered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, CAROLE
description: THOMAS-Carole. Nassau Suffolk Home Care and Aides, Inc., expresses our condolences to the entire Thomas family on the loss of our President, Carole Thomas, who showed great courage in her battle against breast cancer. She will be sorely missed. Donations in her memory may be made to Adelphi University, Breast Cancer Hotline, where Carole was a volunteer. Funeral service will be held at Gutterman's in Woodbury on Tuesday, 3 PM. Suzanne G. Olivet, Assistant to the President Nassau Suffolk Home Care and Aides, Inc.

title: Corrections
description: The introductory paragraph yesterday with the text of a letter from Nizar Hamdoon, the Iraqi representative at the United Nations, referred incorrectly to the letter. It was sent to Peter Burleigh, the American representative, in his capacity as president of the Security Council this month, not to Secretary General Kofi Annan. It was the second of two letters from Mr. Hamdoon, not the first.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, MILTON
description: GOLDMAN-Milton. 84. Of Monroe Township, (formerly of Brooklyn) on November 15, 1998. Survived by wife Jennie (Fogel); children Joanne and Hector Duke and Barry Goldman: grandchildren Jaimie, Traci, Richard, Joshua and Jennifer. Funeral Tuesday 12PM, Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, East Brunswick, NJ. Burial Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge.

title: Amazon Stretching Beyond Its Roots in Books
description: Amazon.com, the on-line retailer that already dominates the Internet sales of books and, increasingly, music, is about to start offering a much broader array of merchandise.

title: Man Moving Transplanted Hand
description: An Australian man who received a transplanted hand and forearm in France seven weeks ago has begun moving each finger of the donor hand and is gaining function with surprising swiftness, his doctors said last week. They said that so far the man, Clint Hallam, had not shown any signs of rejection and had escaped adverse effects of potent immune-suppressing drugs.

title: Cyclist Who Died After Arrest Is Mourned in Harlem Funeral
description: In a stately Gothic Revival church just a block and a half north of the Harlem street where he was hit by what witnesses said was a walkie-talkie thrown by a police officer trying to arrest him on drug charges, Kenneth Banks was mourned yesterday at a service in which his death was denounced as a murder.

title: Replacement for Suspect Plane Part Has Cracks
