description: After two Boeing 737's crashed in a way that suggested rudder malfunctions, the Federal Aviation Administration ordered the replacement of rudder-control valves in all 737's. Now, cracks have been found in several replacement valves that have not even been installed.

title: Yankees Focusing on Belle (or Are They Goading Williams?)
description: If Bernie Williams's ultimate intent is to re-sign with the Yankees, he may be running out of time. The Yankees may replace him in their lineup by week's end, with the slugger Albert Belle.

title: University of Texas to Reopen Clock Tower Closed After Suicides
description: After being closed 23 years ago because of a series of suicides, the observation deck of the 307-foot clock tower at the University of Texas will be reopened to the public, perhaps by next spring.

title: Jean Dalrymple, Persuasive Dreamer Who Brought Theater to City Center, Dies at 96
description: Jean Dalrymple, who abandoned a nascent acting career to become a successful publicist, then an even more successful manager of concert artists and finally a dynamic producer of musicals and plays for City Center and other stages, died on Sunday at her Manhattan home, across the street from City Center. She was 96.

title: Marijuana Votes: Bane or Benefit?
description: Q. Voters in Alaska, Arizona, Nevada, Oregon and Washington have approved initiatives to legalize marijuana for medical use. Does this application encourage marijuana abuse? ALISHA BERGER

title: Report on McCain's Remarks About Tip-Off Angers Paris
description: Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine reacted angrily today to remarks by Senator John McCain that Mr. Vedrine interpreted as a charge that France had tipped off Iraq that American bombers were on their way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKHOLD, ELLEN
description: BUCKHOLD-Ellen. Beloved wife, mother, and grandmother, on Sunday morning, Nov. 15, 1998. She is survived by her husband, Werner, her daughters, Leslie SchweitzerMiller, and Emily Andelman, and her grandchildren, Marc and Gillian Schweitzer, and Ethan and Matthew Andelman. In addition to her devotion to her family, she was a role model to those who knew her, and leaves behind a legacy of concern and caring for the less fortunate. She volunteered her time to childrens' causes, served as President of both the Glen Cove and Long Island Chapters of B'nai Zion, and received a certificate of Congressional recognition for her other philanthropic work. She was blessed with many talents: a beautiful lyric soprano voice, an artistic eye, a love of language and great literature, and a soaring and fertile imagination. She had music in her heart and poetry in her soul, and though all her memories were stolen, we will always remember. Services will be held Tuesday, Nov. 17, 1998 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street in New York City. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to The Alzheimers Association, or B'nai Zion, 130 E. 39th St, NY, NY 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STEIN, HELENE
description: STEIN-Helene. January 31,1904November 17, 1993. Missed, loved, always remembered. Brenda, Stuart and Famil

title: ALLMERICA RAISES OFFER FOR REST OF CITIZENS CORP.
description: The Allmerica Financial Corporation, an insurance and financial services company, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $195.9 million for the 16.8 percent of the Citizens Corporation, a property and casualty insurer, that it does not already own, sweetening a bid it made last month. Both companies are based in Worcester, Mass. Allmerica said it would pay $33.25 cash for each of the 5.89 million Citizens shares; it offered $29 a share on Oct. 27. Citizens, a publicly traded unit of Allmerica, said a special committee of its board had agreed to recommend that Citizens shareholders tender their shares to Allmerica at the higher price. The deal values all of Citizens at $1.16 billion. Citizens last traded at $30.4375, up 6.25 cents, before being halted.

title: Time to End Iraqis' Suffering; Send Iraq the Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Dalton School Selects Longtime Educator as Head
description: The headmaster of a private school in Rochester has been appointed head of the Dalton School, one of New York City's most prestigious private schools, the school announced yesterday. Richard M. Blumenthal, 53, the head of the Harley School for seven years, is to join Dalton on July 1. He replaces Gardner P. Dunnan, who resigned the post in March 1997 after 23 years when Board of Trustees members raised questions about his leadership and his personal relationship with a married teacher.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KISSINGER, PAULA STERN
description: KISSINGER-Paula Stern. Age 97, on November 15, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Louis Kissinger. She is survived by her two sons Henry A. and Walter B., six grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. The family requests in lieu of flowers that donations be sent in her memory to the ColumbiaPresbyterian Hospital, Development Office, 622 West 168th St., New York, NY 10032-3784.

title: Suing Gun Makers Tramples on Our Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Bringing Haydn to Hanoi; Orpheus, With Its Collective Approach, Fills a Newly Redone Opera House
description: The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, the conductorless ensemble from New York, performed before sold-out audiences this weekend at the newly refurbished Hanoi Opera House. It was the first American orchestra to play in this country since the Vietnam War ended in 1975.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Endless Love

title: Iraq, Outsmarted Again
description: The President's decision to call off the air offensive against Iraq can be seen as the first public act of the new ''post-political'' Bill Clinton. For the first time in his adult life, Mr. Clinton is not running for office or preparing to do so. He can therefore risk making foreign policy decisions that displease the public.

title: A Fast Start Takes Denver To 10-0
description: Who will derail the Denver Broncos' frolicking ride toward an unbeaten, untied season? Not the Kansas City Chiefs. Not tonight, anyway.

title: 3 Seton Hall Groups Honor Whitman, Off Campus
description: At a reception in a private club adjacent to the Seton Hall University School of Law, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman accepted a medal of honor tonight from three student groups that were forced last week to move the event off campus because of the Governor's support of abortion rights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORD, KATHLEEN CAREY
description: FORD-Kathleen Carey. 58. Died Friday, November 13th. Graduate of Mt. Holyoke College, 1962. Received a Master of Divinity, 1984, and a Master of Sacred Theology, 1991, from Union Theological Seminary. Member of the faculty and clinical supervisor at the Blanton-Peale Graduate Institute, and psychotherapist in private practice. Appointed to the Liturgical Commission of the Archdiocese of NY, and member of Friends of Liturgical Music. Survived by her husband Harry Ford, of New York City; and two sisters, Helen Carey Eramo of Concord, MA, and Alice Carey of San Francisco, CA. Service Friday, Nov. 20th, at 10:00 am, Corpus Christi Church, 535 W. 121st St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Medical Center, 16th St. & 1st Ave, NY, NY 10003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOREIN, SARAH
description: KOREIN-Sarah. The Board of Trustees, faculty, and students of the Rabbinical College of America mourn the passing of our dear friend and generous supporter, Sarah Korein. She was a shining example of hard work and perseverance, combined with graciousness and generosity, in a society thirsty for genuine role models and leadership. In 1997 the Rabbinical College conferred upon her an honorary doctoral degree. In a quiet and distinguished manner, she has contributed immensely to the development of a better society. May the Al-mighty bless Dr. Julius, Elysabeth, James, Jonathan, Beth, Peter, and the entire family with only good tidings and ''nachas'' in the days ahead. Rabbinical College of America Morristown, NJ David T. Chase Chairman of the Board Rabbi Moshe Herson Dean

title: HUD Plans Nationwide Inquiry on Housing Bias
description: Acknowledging that it did not know the scope of housing discrimination around the country, the Department of Housing and Urban Development announced today that it planned to conduct a nationwide investigation of the problem.

title: A Writer Takes a Turn Reading Sermons in Stone
description: John McPhee, 67, a New Yorker writer best known for taking long looks at small things, has recently published ''Annals of the Former World,'' a 696-page look at the geologic history of a large thing: North American.

title: INSIDE
description: Marijuana Arrests on Rise

title: Taking Up Crucial Relief Efforts
description: United Nations workers began to head back to Iraq today to open yet another act in the long and stormy drama between the Baghdad Government and the people who enforce United Nations rules.

title: New York State Would Receive $25 Billion From Tobacco Deal
description: New York State would get $25 billion over the next 25 years from a proposed settlement of litigation brought by states against the tobacco industry, Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco said today. Of that money, New York City would get more than $6 billion.

title: Scrambling For Coverage; Medicare H.M.O. Cutbacks Strand Thousands of Clients
description: A few years back, when they envisioned their retirement, John and Mary Greenan saw themselves relaxing on Cape Cod's pristine sands in the summer and viewing Vermont's glorious foliage in the fall.

title: Arrests Soar In Crackdown On Marijuana
description: Arrests on marijuana charges have jumped to a record number this year, driven by the Giuliani administration's ''zero tolerance'' approach that has police officers pursuing anyone found possessing, selling or smoking even small amounts of marijuana.

title: The Inspection Agenda in Iraq
description: The days ahead must see the resumption of an aggressive program of weapons inspections in Iraq. That is the only way to test Saddam Hussein's latest pledge of full cooperation with United Nations investigators responsible for uncovering and eliminating Baghdad's chemical and biological weapons and missile delivery systems. There can be no return to last spring's misguided American policy of reining in the inspectors to head off objections from Iraq or its allies. Inspections can be a more effective disarmament tool than air strikes, but only if U.N. specialists can look wherever they need to and get honest answers about what Iraq has done with its mass-destruction weapons, many of which it acquired before the Persian Gulf war.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BORDERS GROUP INC., Ann Arbor, Mich., named Philip M. Pfeffer chief executive, succeeding Robert F. DiRomualdo, who continues as chairman. Mr. Pfeffer was president and chief operating officer of Random House, the publisher in New York, until its acquisition by Bertelsmann A.G. earlier this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEANEY, DONALD V.
description: MEANEY-Donald V. age 78 of Brielle, NJ on November 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Ruth Donegan Meaney. Devoted father of Christopher and Andrea Meaney. Loving grandfather of Justin. Funeral 9 a.m. Thursday, from the O'Brien Funeral Home, Hwy 35 & New Bedford Road, Wall, NJ. Mass 10 a.m. at St. Denis R.C. Church, Manasquan, NJ. Burial Hillside Cemetery, Plainfield, NJ. Visiting Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Defibrillator Foundation, c/o Adriana Peters, Esquire, Law Offices of Andrew Vecchione, 212 Morris Avenue, Spring Lake, NJ 07762.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRINE, RUTH
description: BRINE-Ruth, 1919-1998. Memorial service Thursday, November 19 at 6 PM, New York University, Fales Library, 3rd Floor, Bobst Library and Study Center, 70 Washington Square South.

title: Insane or Just Evil? A Psychiatrist Takes a New Look at Hitler
description: Adolf Hitler is often referred to as a madman, in part because most people are loath to accept such enormity of evil as anything other than the byproduct of psychosis. Yet just how ''mad'' Hitler was, and how much of the evil he perpetrated can be attributed to illness, either physical or mental, has been a subject of disagreement among historians.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Two Depart at Fox and Universal After TV and Film Setbacks; Network Program Chief Had Scored Some Hits
description: Peter Roth, the head of programming for the Fox television network, announced his resignation yesterday, becoming the second entertainment division president to depart a network in the last three weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALRYMPLE, JEAN
description: DALRYMPLE-Jean. The Board of Directors of the American Theatre Wing is deeply saddened by the death of their cherished friend and beloved, long-time officer. After an association of 58 years, her words of knowledge and wisdom sadly are no longer heard. Among her other contributions, she was well known as a comoderator on the Wing's long-running ''Working In The Theatre'' Seminars. She will be remembered for her wit, insights and love of theatre. Isabelle Stevenson Chairwoman of the Board American Theatre Wing Roy A. Somlyo President

title: In Line of Parades, One for Glenn and the Crew of Discovery
description: With golden sunlight glazing the autumn leaves and a light breeze sweeping down Broadway, it seemed a great day to honor John Glenn, and for tens of thousands of people, it was.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEOPOLD, EDITH H.
description: LEOPOLD-Edith H. Formerly of Hanau, Germany. Devoted mother of Lilo Heuman. Cherished mother-in-law of Ernest Heuman. Loving grandmother of Karen Bernson and Claudia Heuman. Services Beth-El Cemetery, Emerson, NJ, Wednesday, 10:30 AM. For information, ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' 800-522-0588.

title: COMFORT SYSTEMS SAYS IT HAS ADDED SHAMBAUGH & SON
description: Comfort Systems USA Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired Shambaugh & Son Inc. for about $50 million in cash, $30 million in notes and $30 million in common stock to become the nation's leader in the industrial heating, ventilation and air-conditioning installation and maintenance business. The Houston-based Comfort Systems has added more than 70 companies since going public in June 1997. Shambaugh & Son, of Fort Wayne, Ind., services pharmaceutical, food and industrial companies.

title: Fairness on Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Judge Upsets New York Law On Granting Permits for Parades
description: A Federal judge struck down New York City's law governing permits for parades and rallies yesterday, saying it was unconstitutional because it lacked firm guidelines for when the police must respond to requests for permits.

title: Many Surprises to Come
description: The debate featured here last week regarding science and the limits of what can be learned (''Resolved: Science Is at an End. Or Is It?'') provoked a volley of letters from readers. Most begged to differ with John Horgan, author of ''The End of Science'' (Helix Books, 1996), who argued, ''We are down to the details now.'' Instead, many threw their weight with Sir John Maddox, former editor of the journal Nature, who asserted, ''Nobody can tell what lies ahead.''

title: Dow Back Above 9,000 on Expectations of Fed Rate Cut
description: Stock prices rose yesterday, pushing at least one key measure to a level not seen since late July, on hopes that the Federal Reserve Board will lower interest rates at a policy-making meeting in Washington today.

title: German Central Banker Opposes Rate Cut Now
description: A member of the Bundesbank council, Guntram Palm, said yesterday that it would not be appropriate now to reduce official German interest rates, an action that has been repeatedly called for by members of the new German Government. Mr. Palm also rejected establishing foreign-exchange target zones for the United States dollar, the euro and the Japanese yen.

title: Starr's Work May Last Through Clinton Term
description: The new indictment of Webster L. Hubbell, the longtime friend of the First Family, means that the Whitewater independent counsel will almost certainly remain in business through the last months of the Clinton Administration and that his final report may not be made public until after the President leaves office, lawyers involved in the inquiry said today.

title: THOMAS H. LEE INVESTS $300 MILLION IN DIRECT MARKETER
description: The Metris Companies, a direct marketer, has received a $300 million investment from the Thomas H. Lee Company, a private equity investment firm in Boston. Metris, of St. Louis Park, Minn., markets credit cards and other fee-based services. It was spun off this fall by the Fingerhut Companies, a direct marketer based in Minnetonka, Minn. In the quarter ended Sept. 30, Metris had net income of $17 million. It said much of the proceeds from the investment would be used to complete financing of the purchase of a $1 billion credit card portfolio from the PNC Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh.

title: All-Star Weekend's Jam Session Latest Victim of N.B.A. Dispute
description: The National Basketball Association, while expressing hope that an All-Star Game could still be played, yesterday canceled Jam Session, its five-day interactive event leading up to the All-Star weekend's festivities this February in Philadelphia.

title: Doctors' Warning: Beware of Herbs' Side Effects
description: Gardeners know valerian as a hardy perennial with fernlike leaves and pinkish white flowers considered excellent for cutting. Herbalists value its carrot-shaped root, which some call nature's tranquilizer, believing it delivers relief for a variety of complaints like insomnia, shingles and menstrual cramps, even though it smells like dirty socks.

title: Ivory Tower Of Babel With an 'A' In Nastiness
description: Menaces to society rarely declare themselves. The pilot of the DC-10 to Miami: is he secretly an alcoholic? The baby sitter who always shows up on time: does she neglect her own children? The young man who scoops ice cream at the corner hangout: has he been to a doctor about that rash?

title: Two Depart at Fox and Universal After TV and Film Setbacks; Shifting Priorities Lead To Biondi's Dismissal
description: Frank Biondi Jr., the Seagram Company's highest-ranking Hollywood executive and chairman of Universal Studios, was ousted today by Seagram's chief executive, Edgar Bronfman Jr., who said he would take more hands-on control of the company's growing entertainment operations.

title: ICAHN TO BID FOR BIGGER SHARE OF REAL ESTATE CONCERN
description: The investor Carl C. Icahn said yesterday that he planned to begin a tender offer for as many as 10 million units of American Real Estate Partners L.P. at $10.50 a unit. After Mr. Icahn's offer, shares of American Real Estate gained $2.50, to $9.75. Mr. Icahn now owns 68 percent of the company's 46.2 million units outstanding. If completed fully, the tender offer would raise his stake to 89.7 percent. American Real Estate Partners, which is based in Mount Kisco, N.Y., buys and manages real estate. Its holdings include a stake in the Stratosphere Corporation of Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on Nov. 3 about an inquiry by the Elizabeth, N.J., school district into a threat supposedly made to a student by an elementary school vice principal misstated the outcome. The school district has not cleared the teacher; the superintendent has yet to reach a decision.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERINGOFF, LEO
description: MERINGOFF-Leo of Tamarac, Fl, formerly of NYC, passed away November 15, 1998. Beloved Husband of Evelyn. Loving Father of Stephen (Joanna) Meringoff and Paul (Carol) Meringoff. Cherished Grandfather of Victoria, Katie, Charlotte, Sophie, Jay, Todd and Brett. Dear Brother of Chuck Meringoff. Mr. Meringoff was a member of The American Stock Exchange and the Institute of Certified Public Accountants. Chapel services will be held Tuesday November 17, 1:15 P.M. at Gutterman Memorial Chapel, 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, N.Y. 516-626-1926

title: CHATTEM ADDING DEXATRIM AND 5 OTHER THOMPSON BRANDS
description: Chattem Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Dexatrim, Sportscreme and four other over-the-counter drug brands from the privately held Thompson Medical Company of West Palm Beach, Fla., for $95 million. Chattem, a health and beauty concern based in Chattanooga, Tenn., owns Ban antiperspirant and Gold Bond medicated powder. It said the brands it was buying from Thompson -- the appetite suppressant Dexatrim and the pain-relief creams Sportscreme, Aspercreme, Capzasin-P, Capzasin-HP and Arthritis Hot -- would add 65 cents to 75 cents a share to fiscal 1999 earnings. The brands will have sales of $55 million this year. Shares of Chattem rose $3.9375, to $36.4375.

title: High Court Limits Scope of Arbitration Pacts
description: Vaguely worded clauses in labor contracts that require submitting workplace disputes to arbitration cannot be invoked to deprive individual employees of the right to bring employment discrimination cases in Federal court, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today.

title: Arafat and Netanyahu Trade Threats as Tensions Rise on the Peace Accord
description: Breaking free of the restrained, statesmanlike demeanor that has recently characterized his public persona, Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, this weekend threatened another Palestinian uprising, complete with rifles, if the peace effort stumbles.

title: An Erotic Fable That Leads to Ominous Portents
description: THE TALE OF THE 1002d NIGHT

title: Sports of The Times; There Are Plenty of Voices But Who Speaks for Team?
description: BRYAN COX stood in the middle of the Jets' locker room yesterday afternoon, calmer than he had been on Sunday after the Jets' unexpected loss to the Indianapolis Colts. Still, the 30-year-old linebacker was perturbed.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Tongue in Cheek? Not Exactly
description: At the beginning of ''De Flor,'' dancers stationed themselves around a curving and gently glowing translucent sculpture as if peering with wonder into a crystal ball. Whatever oracular messages this object may have proclaimed to them never became apparent in the production that Margarita Guergue, a choreographer from Barcelona, Spain, offered on Sunday night at Performance Space 122.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STAR, LEON D.
description: STAR-Leon D., M.D. In everlasting memory of a loving husband, father and grandfather on his birthday.

title: Reaching Out to Opponents, Pragmatist Wins Over House
description: Hours after his swift emergence last week as the presumptive new Speaker of the House, Representative Bob Livingston telephoned an old friend, former Representative Jimmy Hayes, for advice. He did not ask Mr. Hayes how best to keep his Republican flock in line, or for counsel on issues. Instead, he quizzed his fellow Louisiana Republican about how he could best build a relationship with Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Democratic leader.

title: Two Brokers Admit Taking Insider Data
description: Two former brokers pleaded guilty yesterday to taking secret stock information, another victory for New York State prosecutors in one of the biggest insider trading cases of recent years.

title: London Journal; Peer Sheds Breeches but Finds Wig Won't Budge
description: All Lord Irvine wanted was the right to change his pants.

title: Andreychuk Returns to Practice
description: Dave Andreychuk practiced with the Devils yesterday for the first time after missing four games because of a bruised sternum. He said afterward that he was hoping to play on Thursday, when the Carolina Hurricanes visit New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRESCHNER, THERESE RUTH
description: WRESCHNER-Therese Ruth. On Thursday, November 12, 1998. Beloved sister of the late Ida Dhami, Fay Offenbacher, Hannah Cohen and Yvonne Wreschner. Mourned also by aunts, nieces, nephews, and friends. Memorial service to be held at a later date. Shivah at Fay Offenbacher, 1320 51 St, #

title: CD Radio Gets Backing for Car Network
description: CD Radio Inc. said yesterday that it would receive an investment of as much as $200 million from affiliates of Apollo Management L.P., headed by the investor Leon Black, as it seeks more financing for its satellite-to-car digital radio network.

title: Patterns
description: A Rising Designer

title: What to Do About the Gridlock?; Yellow-Cab Abuses
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Brazil's dozen phone spinoffs come to trade in New York.
description: BOLSTERED by the rescue agreement reached between the Brazilian Government and the International Monetary Fund last week, the 12 holding companies spun off from the telecommunications giant Telebras during its privatization this summer began trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: Hewlett-Packard's Earnings Exceed Wall St. Estimates
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported fourth-quarter earnings today that exceeded analyst estimates but said that revenue and growth in orders remained weak.

title: Theory and Fact Clash
description: The debate featured here last week regarding science and the limits of what can be learned (''Resolved: Science Is at an End. Or Is It?'') provoked a volley of letters from readers. Most begged to differ with John Horgan, author of ''The End of Science'' (Helix Books, 1996), who argued, ''We are down to the details now.'' Instead, many threw their weight with Sir John Maddox, former editor of the journal Nature, who asserted, ''Nobody can tell what lies ahead.''

description: FLAMES 5, RED WINGS 3

description: EUROPE

title: What to Do About the Gridlock?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pair of Warhorses Come Trotting Down From Canada
description: The curtain rose at 7:40, but the Stratford Festival did not unveil its capabilities until an hour later.

title: What to Do About the Gridlock?; Second Ave. Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: Random Drug Testing Comes Home
description: On a weekday afternoon in 1992, Sunny Cloud, an insurance saleswoman and single mother in Marietta, Ga., dropped by her home unexpectedly and found her 16-year-old son, Ron, smoking marijuana. Stunned, Ms. Cloud hustled the boy off to the nearest hospital emergency room, where she asked doctors to screen his urine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACCARD, HANKA
description: SACCARD-Hanka. Beloved wife of the late Alexander Saccard, loving mother of Yvonne, devoted grandmother of Louann and Archie, cherished sister of Genia Palatin. She will be greatly missed by them, her friends, and all her nephews and nieces. Funeral services at noon on Thursday, Nov 19, at Grammercy Park Memorial Chapel 152 Second Ave. NY, NY.

title: A Move to Increase Research in the Region
description: Hoping to recapture the New York region's pre-eminence as America's center of medical and biological research, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is expected to announce today that the city will commit $12 million to a major research study on cancer that will involve 300,000 residents whose health and lifestyle will be tracked for two decades.

title: Fassel Considers a Switch at Quarterback
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel said today that he had not decided whether to bench the starting quarterback Danny Kanell, but people in the organization indicated he was leaning toward replacing Kanell with Kent Graham against the Philadelphia Eagles this weekend.

title: Father Is Dead, but the Torment Lives On
description: Anyone who has ever known conflicted grief will recognize the emotional struggle going on in ''My Father's Shadow: The Sam Sheppard Story,'' a fact-based movie on CBS tonight.

title: VITAL SIGNS: TECHNOLOGY; Where to Turn When the Asp Bites
description: An old problem with medical textbooks is that research moves faster than printing presses, making texts out of date before they reach the shelf.

title: Joblessness Rises In Hong Kong
description: Hong Kong's unemployment rate rose to a higher-than-expected 5.3 percent in the August-October period, as businesses continued to cut workers to adjust to a slowing economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODIN, ANNE S.
description: RODIN-Anne S. On November 15,1998. Beloved and devoted wife of the late Carl, loving mother of Richard, Judith Lilly, and Susan Rodin Rosenfeld. Dear mother-inlaw of Ellen Rodin, John Lilly and Jeffrey Rosenfeld. Adored grandmother of Andy (Lydia), Rachel (Josh), John (Rachel), Brian and Jordan. Devoted sister of Alice Gordon and George Sabrin. Respected sister-in-law and aunt to her nieces and nephews. Dear friend of Victor Blitzer. She was the ultimate role model. Services Tues. Nov.17,1998 at Sinai Chapel, Fresh Meadows, N.Y. 12:30PM.

title: A Ringside Vantage On History And a Hero
description: On a gentle night in late September 1976, a dark-haired 17-year-old high school senior from Hillside, N.J., scraped together $25 to buy a ticket to watch Muhammad Ali successfully defend his world heavyweight championship against Ken Norton at Yankee Stadium. This cheapest seat available was so high and far away, he recalled recently, that ''the two fighters in the ring looked like ants.''

title: Sure, Devoted to His Wife: Question Is, Which One?
description: How's this for an idea for a play? A powerful, charismatic man of 50-some years has a strong, smart helpmeet of a wife, an adoring daughter and a reputation for social idealism. Unfortunately, he has these character flaws, too: an ungovernable sexual appetite, a dangerous love of risk and a tendency to believe that he exists outside the law. The result: he lands in a career-shattering sex scandal that is played out in front-page headlines.

title: Research May Redefine 'Good' Audience
description: A new study suggests that if you have to make a speech at a stockholders' meeting, give your first piano recital or do the tango in a dance contest, you may want to have Mom and Dad -- and anyone else who wants you to excel -- stay home.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL PLUNGES. Oil prices fell sharply as the United States and Iraq avoided a military confrontation. Crude oil for December delivery fell 75 cents, to $12.82 a barrel, its lowest since Aug. 13.

title: Q & A
description: Yogurt, Threat or Not?

title: Whatever Love May Be, At Heart It's Ever Powerful
description: Love is salvation, Jewel insists on her new album, ''Spirit'' (Atlantic). It can be, if it doesn't wreck your life first, Whitney Houston warns on her new album, ''My Love Is Your Love'' (Arista).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVA, MERCEDES
description: NOVA-Mercedes. The City University of New York community mourn the tragic death of our colleague, Mercedes Nova. All who knew her in the years she worked in the Central Office Personnel and Budget Offices admired her cheerful spirit, her dedication to her work and her loving care of her two daugthers. She was a graduate of Bronx Community College and Lehman College. She will be sorely missed. We offer sincerest and heartfelt condolences to her family. Christoph M. Kimmich Interim Chancellor

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNAN, FRANCIS M.
description: BRENNAN-Francis M. Reverend Msgr., founding Pastor of the Church of the Holy Child in Staten Island, died November 15 at the age of 85. He was born on March 19, 1913 in Darlington, NJ to Luke and Catherine Brennan, fifth of seven children. He attended Sacred Heart School in Suffern, NY, Cathedral Prep in Manhattan and St. Joseph Seminary in Dunwoodie, NY. Msgr Brennan served as Associate Pastor at St. John's Kingsbridge in the Bronx from 1938-1945; Prefect of Discipline at Cathedral College from 1945-1950 and was Associate Pastor at St. Philip Neri in the Bronx from 1950-1966. In 1966, Francis Cardinal Spellman appointed Msgr. Brennan as founder of a new parish in Staten Island. Msgr. Brennan chose to name the parish ''The Church of the Holy Child''. Under his leadership from 1966-1988, the parish grew to include a Parish Center and School of Religion. Pope Paul VI, gave Monsignor Brennan the dignity of Honorary Prelate of His Holiness in 1970. After retirement in 1988, he lived with his family in Suffern, NY. He is pre-deceased by his brothers Joseph, John, Martin and Richard. He is survived by brother Luke of New Canaan, CT and sister Mary of Suffern, NY, seven nephews and one niece, fourteen grand nephews and fourteen grand nieces. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered on Wednesday at 12:30 P.M. at the Sacred Heart R.C. Church in Suffern, NY. Burial will take place at St. Lukes Cemetery, HoHoKus, NJ. Friends may call on Tuesday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Scarr Funeral Home, Route 202, Suffern, NY.

title: Female Condom: a Market Wallflower
description: ''Do you sell Reality?'' a customer asked uncomfortably this month at a busy Manhattan drugstore. Then, a clerk stooped down and pulled a box from deep behind the counter.

title: In a New Attempt, States Unveil a Proposed Tobacco Settlement
description: In a muted reprise of last year's ultimately failed tobacco settlement, state officials today unveiled a $206 billion proposal to end state lawsuits against cigarette makers over the cost of treating smoking-related illnesses.

title: Yellow Cabs and Black Cars: A Quick Lesson
description: Until the 1950's, yellow cabs (though they weren't all yellow then) were the only private cars that picked up passengers and transported them for a fee. But as yellow cabs focused more of their business in the lower two-thirds of Manhattan, neighborhood car services, which can pick up passengers only by prearrangement, began to spring up in other parts of the city.

title: Husband Wants Doctors and Salesman Charged in Fatal Surgery
description: Lawyers for a New York City police officer whose wife died after a botched surgery at Beth Israel Medical Center last November called on the State Attorney General and the Manhattan District Attorney yesterday to file criminal charges against two doctors and a salesman for a medical supply company involved in the procedure.

title: Reaching Out From Home
description: The Slovenian mezzo-soprano Marjana Lipovsek is not a well-known name in the United States, but she enjoys a busy operatic career in Europe, especially in the weightier roles of Verdi, Strauss and Wagner, and has a large discography, including some major recordings, like Sir Georg Solti's of Mahler's ''Lied von der Erde,'' a live performance from 1992 with the Concertgebouw Orchestra.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE MARK GAINS. The dollar was lower as tension eased in the Middle East and uncertainty continued about further reductions in interest rates. In New York, the dollar settled at 1.6677 marks, down from 1.6841 marks late Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANSON, JULIUS
description: MANSON-Julius. We mourn the loss of our long time Vice Chairman whose social idealism motivated a highly purposeful career. Reunion For Tomorrow J. Sheinkman, Pres. William Stern, Secretary

title: Defendant Facing Death in a Queens Triple Slaying Questions a Survivor of the Attack
description: From the moment she walked into the courtroom in Queens yesterday afternoon, Zakiyyah Holliman seemed unable to keep her eyes off the man sitting at the defense table in the far right corner.

title: Immortality, Of a Sort, Beckons To Biologists
description: In the Greek myths, a terrible price is always paid by humans who seek to live forever, as if to discourage people from even the thought of sharing in the defining attribute of gods. Tithonus, a youth with whom Aurora, the goddess of the dawn, fell in love, was granted immortality, but as he grew more bent and decrepit longed only for one other gift, the relief of death.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Reject Appeals in Two Cases Involving Limits on Political Money
description: The Supreme Court today sidestepped the issue of campaign finance, turning down appeals in cases from Ohio and Arkansas that questioned the constitutionality of limits on campaign spending and contributions.

title: In Truth, Even Those Little Lies Are Prosecuted Once in a While
description: A Texas judge was convicted of perjury for declaring that he had used political contributions to buy flowers for his staff when, in fact, the flowers went to his wife.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: He's Young, Gifted And Made to Order
description: Successful teams are often a happy blend. It is usually good to have a few veteran stars, and the Rangers have these in Wayne Gretzky, Brian Leetch and Mike Richter. It is also necessary to have a few grinders and role players, and the Rangers have several of these, too.

title: Sanchez Vicario Loss Seals Top Ranking for Davenport
description: It was opening night at the Chase Championships, but the fatigue factor was already operating at full force in this year-ending tennis event, which invites the world's top 16 women to fight it out on the blue carpet at Madison Square Garden to determine the world champion for 1998.

title: Op-Art
What About Soft Science?
description: The debate featured here last week regarding science and the limits of what can be learned (''Resolved: Science Is at an End. Or Is It?'') provoked a volley of letters from readers. Most begged to differ with John Horgan, author of ''The End of Science'' (Helix Books, 1996), who argued, ''We are down to the details now.'' Instead, many threw their weight with Sir John Maddox, former editor of the journal Nature, who asserted, ''Nobody can tell what lies ahead.''

title: At Crossroad, Jets Still Ask For Directions
description: Back in Indiana, they are talking about Peyton Manning coming of age, while here in the Jets' locker room some players wondered today just when the Jets would grow up.

title: House Democratic Caucus Chooses Leadership Team, All Men
description: Buoyed by their ballot box victory two weeks ago, the Democratic caucus held its own elections today and promoted two longtime House Democrats to top leadership positions.

title: 'The Good Earth' and the Bad Breaks
description: With Valerie Harper, it's the voice. Even if she's not doing her Rhoda Morgenstern nice-Jewish-girl-from-New-York accent, the tone and the knowing, contemporary rhythm of her voice send signals: this is a savvy, neurotic late-20th-century woman and she's probably about to say something funny -- ideally to Mary, Lou, Brenda or Joe. (For readers without television sets, those are characters from ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' and ''Rhoda,'' the two 1970's sitcoms in which Ms. Harper starred.)

title: Return to Los Angeles? N.F.L. Has Options
description: Since the Rams and the Raiders fled four seasons ago, the Los Angeles market has been a black hole for the National Football League.

title: Minot K. Milliken, 82, Textile Company Officer
description: Minot K. Milliken, who was treasurer and chief financial officer of Milliken & Company, the country's largest privately owned textile company, died at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in New York on Saturday after a three-month illness, his eldest son, M. K. Milliken, said. He was 82 and lived in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARLINSKY, RAYMOND E.
description: KARLINSKY-Raymond E. Age 74, on November 14, 1998. Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of NYC. Beloved husband of Bette, loving father of Martin, Debi and Joanna. A lover of life, full of generosity, wit and vitality. We will miss his love and guidance greatly. Contributions in his memeory may be made to the Raymond Karlinsky Scholarship Fund-Little Village School-Jack Joel Center for Special Children, Bellmore, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, JOSEPH GEORGE
description: FRIED-Joseph George. Husband of Belle and the late Mimi. Father of Barbara and Howard Tecklin. Stepfather of Beth and Gary Sachs, Sharon and Bennes Warshavsky, Barry Alyn. Grandfather of Stacy and David Tecklin, Stacy and Mark Benhar. Step-grandfather of Stacy and Scott Sachs and Danielle Kaplan. Great-grandfather of Miranda, Myles, Ian, Sydney. Services Wednesday, November 18, 1998, 12:30, The Boulevard Chapel, Broadway, Hewlett, N.Y.

title: Allies See Bombing of Iraq as Inevitable
description: The United States, its allies and past defenders of Iraq said yesterday that they did not expect President Saddam Hussein to cooperate with United Nations weapons inspectors and that breaking his promise would set off a military response without a Security Council debate.

title: Toys 'R' Us Posts A Profit Decline
description: Toys ''R'' Us Inc., the world's biggest toy retailer, said today that its third-quarter operating profit fell 57 percent, its fourth straight drop amid slow sales and competition from discount chains like Wal-Mart Stores Inc.

title: Clemens Sweeps To Fifth Cy Young
description: Yesterday was another memorable day for Roger Clemens, a day when he became the first pitcher in history to snare five Cy Young awards. Clemens won the American League Cy Young unanimously, won it for the second straight year with the Toronto Blue Jays and marched even closer to his eventual place in Cooperstown, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JURIST, ROSALYN
description: JURIST-Rosalyn of Brooklyn and Tucson, Arizona, on November 12, sister of Nathan, sister-in-law of Florence. Interment took place November 15, Menorah Gardens, West Palm Beach, Florida.

title: Bois Blanc Island Journal; Community Struggling For a One-Room School
description: A giant wind churned up eight-foot swells in the Straits of Mackinac, which separate this rugged and beautiful northern Lake Huron island from the mainland. But even as the storm knocked out power and downed trees across the Midwest, Lani White and her four students were cozy inside the one-room Bois Blanc Pines School, the smallest in Michigan.

title: Spitzer Widens Lead on Vacco In Latest Count
description: With at least three-quarters of the 250,000 paper ballots counted in the razor-thin race for state attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer, the Democratic challenger, has pulled nearly 22,000 votes ahead of Dennis C. Vacco, the Republican incumbent, state election officials said yesterday.

title: Bin Laden as Target
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDRON, ROBERT E.
description: WALDRON-Robert E. Age 67. On November 15, 1998. CEO of Waldron Associates Ltd. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Father of Eric, Clifford, Robert E. Jr. and Susanne. Grandfathr of six. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Thursday 2-5 and 7-9PM with service Friday, 11:30AM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Judge Restrains Union at Post From Slowing Publication
description: Less than a day after a pressmen's job action kept four out of five copies of yesterday's New York Post from homes and newsstands, a Federal judge yesterday evening issued a temporary restraining order barring the union representing the pressmen from further interrupting publication of The Post.

title: U.S. Forces Set to Strike Iraq in Hours If Called On
description: All of the weaponry that the United States was prepared to let loose against Iraq on Saturday remains in the Persian Gulf and could be used to strike within hours of receiving notice, senior Administration and Pentagon officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Saturday about Girl Scout cookie sales reversed the identifications of two scouts. Beverly Addison was at the left and Kandis Bennet at the right.

title: Cable and Wireless to Build New Network
description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C. said today that it would spend $1 billion over five years to build a high-speed European telecommunications network.

title: With Mediator's Aid, ABC and Union Will Resume Talks
description: ABC and its union of 2,200 off-camera workers have agreed to resume contract negotiations, perhaps as early as this week, with the help of a Federal mediator, officials on both sides said last night.

title: Indonesian Leader Cracks Down on Critics
description: In its first crackdown on political opponents since taking office six months ago, the Government of President B.J. Habibie is interrogating prominent critics and banning them from leaving the country.

title: Time to End Iraqis' Suffering
description: To the Editor:

title: New Charge Against Officers in Louima Case
description: A Federal grand jury yesterday expanded the case against three New York City police officers accused of attacking a Haitian immigrant in Brooklyn last year by charging that they conspired to keep one of the officers from being implicated in what prosecutors say was the most brutal part of the assault.

title: In Defiance Of Reforms, Crime Rises In Mexico City
description: At the beginning of this month, the Mexico City Government turned over control of the police to civilian officials and announced a war on crime. Since then, the Mexico City Police Chief announced today with great annoyance, the violent crime rate has soared 25 percent.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday about a conference in Cambridge, Mass., on Internet governance misstated the given name and the role of a participant. He is Jonathan Zittrain, not Joseph; he was a conference moderator, not an Internet advocate.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Saturday about the bombing of the headquarters of Osama bin Laden, the suspected organizer of the attacks on American embassies in Africa, referred incompletely to the Clinton Administration's objectives. Officials say that one clear objective of the raid by cruise missiles was to kill Mr. bin Laden and as many of his lieutenants as possible. They did not say Mr. bin Laden was the sole target.

title: Too Much Of A Good Thing
description: Last summer's collapse of the financial markets is fading into distant memory. The Fed has become more accommodating, and investors are again pouring money into stocks. But before we assume that the economy is out of the woods, we might ask why the markets so completely lost their bearings in the first place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELD, IRENE
description: FIELD-Irene Ph.D. November 14th, in Rome, Italy, where she lived for many decades and had a very distinguished career with theFood and Agricultural Organization. She will be deeply missed by her relatives and her many friends and colleagues throughout the world. Robert Newman

title: By Design; Up to Her Neck in Color
description: A favorite accessory worn by the fashion flock at the recent spring shows was the muffler or long scarf wrapped several times around the throat. It is a good way to add a touch of color, as well as extra warmth, to winter clothes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPERBER, SUE
description: SPERBER-Sue. Our devoted sister, aunt and great-aunt. When beset by trouble and sorrow, Sue put on the armor of faith and fortitude. She found the strength to challenge her illness with quiet courage and unshaken will. She will always remain a part of us. The Paul Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, SHIRLEY TOPAL
description: LEVIN-Shirley Topal. On November 14, five days before her 101st birthday. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Jane and Renee and sons-in-law, Gil and Wheeler. Adoring grandmother of James, Martha, Polly and Daisy and her grandson-in-law, Cliff. Dear great-grandmother of Will and Nick. Her life was rich with laughter, family and friends. A celebration of her life will be held on a date to be announced. We wish her love.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, RAYMOND S.
description: BARON-Raymond S. Devoted husband of the late Harriet Baron, loving partner of Midge Grant, adored father of Ronnie and Fred Hirsh and Maggie and Richard Baron, cherished grandfather of Jodi, Lara and Alan Hirsh, and dear brother to Francine Leibler, Austin Baron and Jules Baron. We will love you forever. Service will be Tuesday, November 17, 11:30 AM, at the Boulevard Park West Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: Sports of The Times; Was Public Confession Necessary?
description: WE see it all over the television set -- morning, noon and night -- real people admitting just about every sin and character flaw, sometimes to the face of the person they harmed, in the name of healing for the parties involved, to say nothing of high ratings.

title: Goldman Partner To Retire Soon
description: Eric Dobkin, founder of the equity capital markets unit Goldman Sachs Group L.P., will step down as a partner at year-end, the latest top Goldman, Sachs & Company executive to retire.

title: St. John's Opens The Jarvis Era With a Bang
description: In the moments before the start of last night's game and the start of a new era at St. John's, members of the Red Storm's coaching staff stood nervously in the hallway outside the court at Alumni Hall.

title: Time to End Iraqis' Suffering; War-Crime Indictment
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer Is Shot in Hand in a Clash With 2 Men at a Brooklyn Project
description: A police officer was shot in the hand and a second officer was shot through the left pants leg, but not hit, after a sudden confrontation last night with two apparently armed men during a floor-by-floor search of a Brooklyn housing project, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBOWITZ, RUTH
description: JACOBOWITZ-Ruth. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Jacob Jacobowitz. Devoted mother of Leila and Albert Attia, Arlene and William Fullerton. Adoring grandmother of Evelyn and Marcel Laufer, Larry and Sue Attia, Alison and Andrew Adler, and Elizabeth Fullerton. Great-grandmother of William, Jacob, Benjamin, Robert, and Samantha. Loving sister of Edith Cohen and Helen Kleinman, and cherished aunt and friend. Services on Tuesday, November 17, 1998, 11AM, at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, N.Y.

title: AMERICAN TOWER TO ACQUIRE 2 RIVALS FOR $525 MILLION
description: The American Tower Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire two owners of wireless communications towers for around $525 million plus assumed debt. American Tower will buy OmniAmerica Inc. for stock valued at $369.9 million, plus an undisclosed amount of debt. American Tower's class A shares rose $3.50 each, to $22.50. Shares of OmniAmerica, based in Cedar Crest, N.M., jumped $6, to $23.50. American Tower will also buy the privately held Telecom Towers L.L.C. of Arlington, Va., for $155 million in cash and stock plus $30 million of assumed debt. American Tower, based in Boston, owns more than 2,600 broadcast and wireless telecommunications towers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BAKER, JACK
description: BAKER-Jack. November 17, 1994. Dearest Dad, remembering you with love, affection and devotion. We miss you. Paula and Beau and Bobby

title: Celebrating Claire McCardell
description: Staring out from a photograph taken when she was a young woman, Claire McCardell resembles the ideal her fashions would come to embody: an easy, confident, athletic American woman, free and optimistic. McCardell's work is the subject of an exhibition that opened recently at the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology.

title: Compromise Is Sought On School Choice Plan
description: The chairman of the State Senate Education Committee postponed a vote yesterday on a scaled-back school choice plan and instead met with his Assembly counterpart and the State Education Commissioner to work out a compromise.

title: Some Old, Some New, Some All at Once
description: ''Jimmie Lunceford and Tommy Dorsey: Then and Now,'' the Carnegie Hall Jazz Band's Thursday night concert, nodded in the direction of the swing revival with shifting subtexts. Ostensibly it was a tribute to two bands, one black and one white, that popularized swing and that played to more or less different audiences. But as the opening remarks by the band leader, Jon Faddis, made plain, the concert was as much about the brilliant arranger and composer Sy Oliver, the primary reason both bands have any kind of enduring legacy. Dorsey hired Oliver away from Lunceford's organization in 1939, and the musical effect was immediate: as Mr. Faddis joked, it ''changed the complexion'' of Dorsey's music. Oliver gave the rhythm section more power and emphasized riffs; a close watcher of Ellington, he also developed the timbral combinations needed to make art out of pop.

title: Constellation Prizes
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Japan's Plan: A Big Shrug
description: Although the $195 billion economic stimulus plan announced by Japan today is the largest ever announced here, many investors yawned and shrugged. They have been disappointed in Japan so many times that they are hard to impress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOSIOSKY, DR. ISSAI
description: HOSIOSKY-Dr. Issai. On Sunday, Nov. 15th, 1998. Resident of Manhattan and Somers, NY. Beloved husband of Dr. Ellen N. Hosiosky, practicing Periodontist in Manhattan. Dr. Issai Hosiosky was born in Libau, Russia on Feb. 17th, 1906. He received his Gymnasium degree in Libau in 1923 and his Doctor of Economics Degree in Berlin in 1928. After a distinguished career in Germany, France and England, he arrived in the United States in 1938 where he headed the Business Consultation and Loan Division of the National Refugee Service and then its Central Loan Trust. From 1943 to 1971 he was associated with the New School For Social Research. He served as Treasurer, Officer and Board Member of the New School. In 1971, he joined the Lucius N. Littauer Foundation where he served on the Board of Directors as Secretary and Vice President. Since his retirement in 1993, he has remained an Honorary Director of the Foundation. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science of the New School For Social Research, 65 Fifth Avenue, NY, NY 10003.

title: Livery Cabs Get the Blame For Increase in Accidents
description: As taxi accidents have risen steadily in New York City over the past decade, the most recognizable image of the danger has been that of a yellow cab wrecked on a Manhattan sidewalk, debris strewn about, perhaps a pedestrian pinned against a light pole. But an analysis of newly released accident data shows that car services and livery cabs are actually responsible for the increase.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZANELLI, SUE
description: ZANELLI-Sue. Beloved mother of Dorothy, Patricia and Alice. Devoted grandmother of Lisa and Karla. Adored great grandmother of Raye/Lani. May she rest in peace.

title: Students Accused of Plotting Mass Slaying
description: Five boys in this town in southeastern Wisconsin have been accused of plotting to shoot to death their high school principal, the assistant principal, a teacher, a police officer stationed in the school and as many as 20 students, the police said today.

title: A Weak Tobacco Deal
description: The deal negotiated by eight state attorneys general and the tobacco industry would do far too little to combat teen-age smoking, the primary goal that any legal settlement should advance. Instead, this proposal is mostly a financial agreement in which the companies would pay off state lawsuits for Medicaid costs incurred for smoking-related diseases. The states that were not at the negotiating table have been given until Friday to accept the settlement. That is an unreasonably short time for the public to review a deal of this magnitude. At a minimum, there needs to be opportunity for comment and input from health experts.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: They Call Gates Bet-a-Hundred

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, PETER G.
description: HOROWITZ-Peter G. of Flushing, N.Y. Loving son of Alice Horowitz of Lake Worth, Florida suddenly on November 14, 1998. Services ''Boulevard - Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. Tuesday, 12:30PM.

title: The Mets Return Phillips To General Manager's Job
description: A week after the Mets announced that General Manager Steve Phillips was taking a leave of absence to deal with a sexual harassment allegation and other problems caused by extramarital affairs, the team came up with another surprise yesterday: Phillips is back on the job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERMAN, SAUL
description: GERMAN-Saul. Died November 15, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Fran, loving father of David and Michael, cherished by his grandchildren Amanda, Emily, Harry and Ian, and daughters-inlaw Linda and Susan. Services November 17th, 11 AM, Gutterman's Funeral Home in Boca Raton, FL.

title: Diana's Biographer And ABC's Walters Get Lewinsky Deals
description: After months of angling for a lucrative book deal and a television forum, Monica S. Lewinsky has agreed to an interview with Barbara Walters of ABC News and a book from St. Martin's Press tentatively titled ''Monica's Story.''

title: GORE, IN MALAYSIA, SAYS ITS LEADERS SUPPRESS FREEDOM
description: Vice President Al Gore today rebuked the Malaysian Government for suppressing freedom and championed the growing protest movement here as tensions between the United States and Malaysia boiled over at a meeting of Pacific Rim countries.

title: No Penalty Likely in Parcells Inquiry
description: All signs point to a quick resolution, with the likelihood of no significant disciplinary action, in the National Football League's investigation of Bill Parcells in the possible violation of a rule against contacting a player from another team.

title: Suing Gun Makers Tramples on Our Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, MARY BRIDGET
description: RYAN-Mary Bridget. Age 90. Of Royal Palm Beach, FL. Died Nov 15, 1998. Born in NYC. Survived by sister Jane Holmes, brothers Jimmy and Johnny, nieces, nephews, grand and great-grandnieces, nephews and cousins. Services Thurs, in Wellington, FL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHELDON, BEULAH
description: SHELDON-Beulah. On November 5, 15th, 1998 in Island Park, NY. Wife of the late Walter Sheldon, beloved mother of Jeffrey Sheldon and Harriet Izower, loving grandmother to Hillary, Aron, Rachel, Adam and Elizabeth, dear sister to Dr. Joseph Bandes. Services at Gutterman's in Rockville Center. Nov. 17, 1998 at 11:30 am.

title: Profit Below Forecasts At Telefonica of Spain
description: Telefonica S.A. of Spain, the biggest telephone company in the Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking world, implied yesterday that its third-quarter profit rose a lower-than-expected 14 percent, stunted by reduced earnings in Latin America and increased competition in Spain. The company said profit rose to 163.3 billion pesetas ($1.1 billion) in the first nine months of the year, from 141.79 billion a year earlier. That implies that third-quarter net income, which was not broken out in the report, was 65 billion pesetas.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about ABC's lockout of 2,200 off-camera workers misstated part of the name of their union. It is the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians, not Engineers and Technicians.

title: Personal Health; Heading Off a Nation Of Teen-Age Smokers
description: Hollywood is once again sending young Americans a pernicious message: Smoking is O.K. It relieves anxiety and tension, breaks the social ice and, if Holly Hunter is an example, helps a woman maintain a stick-thin figure. After seeing Ms. Hunter's new movie, ''Living Out Loud,'' in which she plays a chain-smoking divorcee, I had to hold my breath as I plowed through a horde of cigarette-smoking teen-agers gathered outside the theater.

title: Meteors Stage A Light Show, And a Comet Swings By
description: Hoping for clear skies, astronomers and amateur stargazers in many parts of the country are trekking to hills and open fields before dawn today and tomorrow as the Earth plows through the tail of a comet, offering the most spectacular meteor storm in decades.

title: Surveying the Scientists
description: The debate featured here last week regarding science and the limits of what can be learned (''Resolved: Science Is at an End. Or Is It?'') provoked a volley of letters from readers. Most begged to differ with John Horgan, author of ''The End of Science'' (Helix Books, 1996), who argued, ''We are down to the details now.'' Instead, many threw their weight with Sir John Maddox, former editor of the journal Nature, who asserted, ''Nobody can tell what lies ahead.''

title: Seeded 5th, St. John's Is Banking On Depth
description: St. John's has been in the limelight in collegiate soccer since winning the national title in 1996 and appears to be peaking at the right time going into this tournament, having captured its fifth Big East title with victories over Rutgers and Georgetown.

title: Moody's Decides to Downgrade Its Financial Ratings for Japan
description: Japan lost its top ''Aaa'' credit rating from Moody's Investors Service, as the nation remains mired in its worst recession in five decades.

title: Suing Gun Makers Tramples on Our Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Ways to Make the Most of Your Money
description: LIKE wine, beer and pate, giving money away is an acquired taste. But just as the palate can graduate from the shallow sweetness of youth to appreciating nuances, givers can learn how to enhance the value of their gifts, even modest ones, and make them more effective.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, MOE
description: SCHWARTZ-Moe. Beloved husband of Ida, devoted father of Bernard and Gerald, dear brother of Anne, cherished grandfather of Scott, Holli, Ellen, and Mindy. Loving great grandfather of Spencer, Justin, Devon, Brooke, Samantha, and Trystan. Services today 1 P.M. at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island.

title: The convergence of hip: Calvin Klein's newest campaign features a crucial Internet component.
description: CALVIN KLEIN is going on line.

title: Old-Time Hispanic Luncheonette Sleekly Updated
description: SEAN Meenan and Sam Martinez already owned two places on a single block of Elizabeth Street -- Rialto, the crowded, fashionable American restaurant, and Bread and Butter, a stylish little sandwich shop -- so when they also took over the site of Bella's, a longtime luncheonette at the Prince Street end of the block, some people in the neighborhood expressed alarm. Here would be one more blow to their longtime tranquillity in an area already uneasy with the eastward expansion of trendy shops and restaurants from SoHo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RENNIE, JEAN TOWER
description: RENNIE-Jean Tower. Mother of Missie Rennie Taylor of New York and of Roxburgh Rennie of Providence, RI. The memorial service will be held Wednesday, November 25 at 4PM at the Episcopal Church of Bethesda-by-the-Sea Church, Palm Beach, Florida.

title: Kuwaitis Are Puzzled By Lack of U.S. Action
description: There is much affection in this rich little kingdom for the United States, still seen widely as liberator and protector after the events that began -- many Kuwaitis feel the need to cite the exact date -- on Aug. 2, 1990. That was the day when Iraq invaded Kuwait and then sacked it.

title: Without Joy, Netanyahu Wins Vote to Adopt Peace Agreement
description: The Israeli Parliament approved the American-brokered peace plan today by a significant majority, reflecting the widespread, pragmatic acceptance here of partitioning the Land of Israel.

title: CHASE MANHATTAN TO BUY BACK UP TO $3 BILLION IN STOCK
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the second-largest United States bank, said yesterday that it would buy back as much as $3 billion worth of its stock, or 6.1 percent of its outstanding shares. The bank's authorization to repurchase shares replaces one that is expiring on Dec. 31. It is intended to give Chase the opportunity to use extra capital to increase the value of its stock. Chase's shares jumped $3.375 each, to $61.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Candy to Satisfy A Sweet Tooth And a Cause
description: WHAT: Fund-raising candy bars.

title: Microsoft Hampered OS/2, I.B.M. Official Tells Court
description: A senior I.B.M. executive accused the Microsoft Corporation today of imposing contract restrictions on software developers that prevented OS/2, I.B.M's computer operating system, from effectively competing with Microsoft Windows.

title: Whimsical Songs and Gawking Pedestrians
description: At least as intriguing as the songs the English folk-rocker Robyn Hitchcock performs in Jonathan Demme's intimate concert film ''Storefront Hitchcock'' are the surreal vignettes the singer spins out between numbers. A typical flight of fancy is his meditation on the gradual disappearance of the Isle of Wight as its shoreline is steadily eroded.

title: Mystery of the Generous Monopolist
description: AMONG the mysteries that shadow the life of John D. Rockefeller Sr., perhaps none teases posterity quite so maddeningly as the question of how this fiercely enterprising monopolist ended up as the most enlightened philanthropist of his day, setting a bench mark that might never be surpassed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METZGER, LOYA FERGUSON
description: METZGER-Loya Ferguson. On November 13, 1998, in New York City. Loved and loving: wife of Walter P. Metzger, mother of Hilary K. Metzger and Gillian E. Metzger, sister of Nan Jones, Dallas E. Ferguson and Philip M. Ferguson. Medical sociologist and journalist. Warm and compassionate friend. Time and place of memorial service to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

title: Smoking by College Students Is on the Rise, Research Finds
description: Smoking among American college students has increased substantially in recent years, a national survey of about 15,000 students by the Harvard School of Public Health shows.

title: The Pumpkin Escapes From the Pie
description: THE pumpkin, during its brief season, lives literally for the holidays. Most people know it as pie -- flaky pastry with a dark, miraculously heavy filling of spices, cream, pumpkin and sugar. Traditional, yes. But the pumpkin has much more to offer.

title: The 'Lifestyle' Phenomenon:Pills to Enhance Well-Being
description: PARIS  Disease, pain and life-threatening conditions have been the usual reasons people turn to prescription drugs. But aging baby boomers, interested in continuing to feel and look good as long as possible, have recently fueled a vigorous new phenomenon in the pharmaceutical industry going by the name of "quality of life" or "lifestyle" drugs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAKAS, WILLIAM J.
description: TAKAS-William J. Loved friend and swinging bass player died on November 8 at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 66. Bill will be missed very much by his brothers, his friends, and by a number of excellent piano players.

title: Students' Success Depends On Teachers Most, Poll Says
description: Although Americans rate poor quality among teachers as a less serious education problem than student drug use and school violence, they see the quality of the classroom teacher as the most important element in lifting student achievement, ahead of stronger curriculum and stricter discipline, according to the results of a poll released yesterday.

title: Kariya Gets Comfortable As Rangers Pay a Visit
description: Paul Kariya did not think it would take so long. Free from the aftereffects of a fourth concussion, the Mighty Ducks' captain assumed he would work through training camp, improve during the exhibition games and then start the regular season in fine form. That is not quite the way it worked out.

title: Town Drops Plan to Set Holiday Lighting Periods
description: Two weeks after introducing an ordinance that would have limited holiday lighting from within 30 days before to 20 days after any holiday, Bedminster officials have decided not to impose the limit after all.

title: Marion Donovan, 81, Solver Of the Damp-Diaper Problem
description: Marion Donovan, a onetime Connecticut housewife who had to change one damp diaper too many, died on Nov. 4 at Lenox Hill Hospital near her home in Manhattan. She was 81 and had helped spearhead an industrial and domestic revolution by inventing the forerunner of the disposable diaper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKOLD, ELLEN
description: BUCKOLD-Ellen. Beloved wife, mother, and grandmother, on Sunday morning, Nov. 15, 1998. She is survived by her husband, Werner, her daughters, Leslie SchweitzerMiller, and Emily Andelman, and her grandchildren, Marc and Gillian Schweitzer, and Ethan and Matthew Andelman. In addition to her devotion to her family, she was a role model to those who knew her, and leaves behind a legacy of concern and caring for the less fortunate. She volunteered her time to childrens' causes, served as President of both the Glen Cove and Long Island Chapters of B'nai Zion, and received a certificate of Congressional recognition for her other philanthropic work. She was blessed with many talents: a beautiful, lyric soprano voice, an artistic eye, a love of language and great literature, and a soaring and fertile imagination. She had music in her heart and poetry in her soul, and though all her memories were stolen, we will always remember. Services were held Tuesday, Nov. 17, 1998. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to The Alzheimers Association, or B'nai Zion, 130 E. 39th St, NY, NY 10016.

title: Sports of The Times; The Coach Who Always Knew More
description: AT the Pro Football Hall of Fame weekend in Canton, Ohio, it is traditional for all those who return to the site of their bronze busts to gather at a luncheon mostly for them. Several Hall of Famers are chosen to speak to the others, and during last summer's reunion, 91-year-old Wilbur (Weeb) Ewbank stood up and looked around.

title: When a Murder Mystery Turns Into an Allegory
description: THE WIDOW KILLER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANT, STEPHANIE
description: GRANT-Stephanie. An extraordinary woman. Beloved and devoted mother, daughter, grandmother, godmother, sister and aunt; loyal and cherished friend and employee. Her spirit will guide us and her memory will be a blessing. Funeral services Friday November 20th at 12 noon at the Convent Avenue Baptist Church. Marilyn S. Lashin

title: Book on Breast Cancer Diet Is Misleading, Critics Assert
description: A dispute has arisen over a best-selling book promoting a diet that purports to prevent breast cancer.

title: Mergers Give Industry Boost in Developing New Products
description: LONDON  To an industry afflicted with excess production capacity, a fragmented market and unforgiving regulatory regimes that put pressure on prices, corporate deal-making has been a useful tonic. The logic of combining operations has been compelling enough to generate more than $150 billion of mergers and acquisitions among pharmaceutical companies in the last six years.

title: Germans Tighten Grip on DaimlerChrysler
description: Shares of DaimlerChrysler A.G. began trading officially today as further signs emerged that German executives from the former Daimler-Benz A.G. would be the senior partners in the merged company.

title: Inside Peek at Next Year's Offense
description: The assumption by the Giants that their offensive line would play as ably this season as it did in 1997 has probably been the most deleterious miscalculation of the off season. The Giants are trying to insure they do not repeat that oversight.

title: Weeb Ewbank, 91, Hall of Fame Coach of Jets, Is Dead
description: Weeb Ewbank, who coached the Baltimore Colts of 1958 and the New York Jets of 1968 to pro football championships in monumental title games, died yesterday at his home in Oxford, Ohio. He was 91.

title: Lawsuits Over Ouster of Adelphi Chief Are Settled
description: Adelphi University agreed today to a settlement with its ousted president, Dr. Peter Diamandopoulos, that leaves him with $1.4 million before taxes and resolves all the suits and countersuits over his removal last year.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading on Monday with an article about the Security Council's view of Iraqi pledges on arms inspections misstated the affiliation of the inspectors. They work for the United Nations, not the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALRYMPLE, JEAN
description: DALRYMPLE-Jean, was the ''Mother'' of City Center and we will miss her. It's been a great comfort to think of her on opening nights -across the street from the theater-looking down from her apartment at the arriving crowds, and of the audiences who have thrilled to the art on our stage since City Center's founding in 1943. This theater is a living, breathing memorial to Jean's memory. The Board of Directors and staff of City Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOTTO, ROSE
description: SCOTTO-Rose. The Board of Regents, Administration and staff of Long Island College Hospital (LICH) mourn the passing of Rose Scotto, beloved mother of Regent Salvatore (Buddy) Scotto. To Buddy, the entire Scotto family and all of Mrs. Scotto's loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. John Wren, Chairman of the Board of Regents Peter A. Kelly, Interim President Daniel D. Ricciardi, M.D., President, Medical Staff

title: Disarmament of the I.R.A. Losing Some of Its Priority in Ulster
description: In a gradual but distinct change in policy, the British and Irish Governments are relaxing pressure on the Irish Republican Army to disarm.

title: A Prudent Move by the Fed
description: The world's financial markets have calmed down since the Federal Reserve first moved to lower interest rates seven weeks ago. But economic problems remain, and the Fed acted wisely yesterday when it imposed its third cut in two months.

title: Big Thunder Marine Survives Trouble
description: Big Thunder Marine, a 46-foot offshore catamaran, won the world Superboat title last weekend off Key West, Fla., despite a breakdown in one of the boat's four 1,000-horsepower engines.

title: Carrot and Stick on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, RAYMOND S.
description: BARON-Raymond S. We extend our sympathy for a wonderful person, Raymond Baron, to his family and friends. Trustees of the Hewlett-Woodmere Public Library

title: Sharpton Is Injured In 4-Car Accident
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton was injured last night when a car he was riding in was involved in a four-car accident in Manhattan, an aide to Mr. Sharpton said.

title: 6 Are Indicted in Youth Rally Violence
description: A Manhattan grand jury has decided not to indict Khallid Abdul Muhammad for his actions at the end of a Harlem rally in September that erupted in violence, prosecutors said yesterday. The decision angered city officials, who had said Mr. Muhammad tried to incite a riot at the event.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about accidents involving yellow cabs and livery cabs in New York City referred incorrectly to a proposal to require each yellow cab owner to post a $100,000 personal injury bond. It is not on the agenda of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission, an agency official says, and will not be voted on tomorrow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIZZO, MARIE ASSUNTA (NEE GENUA)
description: RIZZO-Marie Assunta (nee Genua) on November 16, 1998. Beloved wife of Lee for 61 beautiful years. Mother of devoted children Gerald Lee and Anna S. Rizzo, Carolyn and John Morano, Mary Lou and Luis Artime and grandmother of adoring grandchildren Joan Marie, Michele and Lenny, Laura, Karen, John, David and Cristina, Marc, Nicole, Carolyn Louis, and loved by her great-grandson Andrew. She was the loving sister of Rose, Mildred, and the late Teddy and Charles. Loving sister-in-law of Stella Genua. She celebrated more than 85 wonderful years with us, beloved by all who touched her life. Her intelligence, fortitude and dignity will always be an inspiration to her family and to all those who would lead a compassionate, meaningful life. There will be a private family mass on Thursday, November 19, 10 AM at the Church of the Assumption, Tuckahoe. The family requests in lieu of flowers donations may be made to a charity of your choice and also requests you remember her love of the little children of this world and to help them when you can. For information contact Westchester Funeral Home, Inc. in Eastchester, 914-337-4585

title: In Budget Pact, Giuliani and Council Drop a Tax Surcharge
description: The Giuliani administration agreed yesterday to release most of the $150 million that it had withheld from nonprofit groups since July, completing a budget deal with the City Council that also eliminates a 12.5 percent surcharge on the personal income tax of New York City residents.

title: Expansion Of Program For Recycling Is Announced
description: Weekly pickups of recycled waste will be extended to all of New York City by April 15, 2000, under a plan announced yesterday by the City Council. The deal ended a long battle with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has opposed expanding the program any faster.

title: Acquisition From Abitibi
description: Miami Computer Supply has agreed to acquire the Canadian computer-supply business of Abitibi-Consolidated Inc.'s Axidata unit. The terms were not disclosed. Miami Computer distributes computer and office-automation supplies and accessories. The operations to be acquired, which are based in Toronto, have annual sales of $150 million and offices in Montreal, Quebec City, Ottawa and Vancouver. Abitibi-Consolidated, based in Montreal, is the world's biggest newsprint producer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEVY, MARLENE T.
description: KEVY-Marlene T. Beloved wife of Larry, cherished daughter of Joan & Seymour, loving mother of Matt, dear sister of Barbara Katz and Michael Trager. A wonderful person-loved by all. Services ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engle St, Englewood, NJ, Wed., November 18, 1998, at 10:30 AM. Contributions to Valley Hospice, Paramus, NJ or Twenty First Century Children's Fund, 1 Patriot Center, Englewood NJ, would be appreciated.

title: And Stay Out of My Mailbox!
description: Dear Plover Fund,

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, LOIS M.
description: FREEMAN-Lois M. On November 16, 1998. Loving mother of Matthew and Melinda. Devoted teacher and educator. Private funeral. Friends may visit Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, November 19, 7-9 PM.

title: But Consumer Groups Unhappy
description: WASHINGTON  Until last year, pharmaceutical companies wishing to advertise on radio or television faced an odd conundrum.

title: It's One Way to Spend All of Labor Day
description: WHAT: The Jerry Lewis Labor Day Telethon, which raises money to benefit the Muscular Dystrophy Association.

title: Safety Panel Cites Poor Oversight Of Buses Used in Public Transit
description: Reviewing a fatal bus crash on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan last year, as well as bus crashes in three other cities, the National Transportation Safety Board said today that the Federal Government cannot spot hazardous conditions for public transit buses because data collection and oversight are poor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MADONICK, BEATRICE
