description: MADONICK-Beatrice. Died November 16, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Moses J. Madonick, beloved mother of Millie and sonin-law Steven Besner and adored grandmother of Diane and David.

title: Fabulous Feasts on the Quick
description: ONCE, a home-cooked meal was a holiday prerequisite. Now, it seems as if almost every restaurant and carryout specialist is offering Thanksgiving to go, including these six takeout shops. Some offer turkeys that are uncooked but ready for the oven. Others offer complete meals, ready to eat. Or you can just buy some side dishes. In any case, you can put together today's holiday prerequisite, the home-served meal.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COTTON DROPS SHARPLY. Cotton prices fell steeply amid speculation that the poor quality of the smallest crop in nine years will lead to few takers. Cotton for December delivery fell 1.98 cents, to 63.58 cents a pound.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: Arts Abroad; A Rascal Philosopher Seduced by the Spirit of His Era
description: Poor Casanova! On the 200th anniversary of his death, even the city of his birth seems embarrassed to remember him for the single trait that made him famous. Instead, Venice has chosen to celebrate him not as the legendary libertine and Latin lover but as a traveler, writer, freethinker, diplomat, spy, mathematician, gambler, gourmand and emblematic dilettante of 18th-century Europe.

title: Failing Schools Need a Lifeline
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column on Thursday, about works published as nonfiction that include fictional scenes, and a correction in this space on Monday, misspelled the name of the author of ''The Last Brother,'' about Senator Edward M. Kennedy. The author is Joe McGinniss, not Joel McGinnis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLIKEN, MINOT K.
description: MILLIKEN-Minot K. For more than three decades, a good neighbor, for more than twenty years, a devoted member of the Board, and for more than ten years, distinguished President of the Corporation. We shall miss his company, his leadership, his energy and his smile. We extend deepest condolences to Armene and the whole Milliken family. The 19 E. 72nd Street Corporation Cary A. Koplin, President Stephen C. Owen, Former Pres.

title: PROLOGIS TO ACQUIRE MERIDIAN, A RIVAL LANDLORD
description: Prologis Trust, the largest owner of industrial and warehouse properties in the United States, agreed yesterday to buy Meridian Industrial Trust, based in San Francisco, for $862.5 million in stock. It will also assume $560 million of Meridian's debt and $50 million of preferred stock. Meridian will exchange each of its shares for 1.1 Prologis shares, valuing the swap at about $25 a share. The purchase will make Prologis, which is based in Denver, the largest warehouse landlord in Atlanta, Dallas-Fort Worth, and San Francisco and will add 36 million square feet of space to its 127.4 million square feet in the United States and Europe.

title: Hefty Reds as a Fair Match for the Bird
description: I SEE by the papers that the Dean of Westminster Cathedral in London wants to eliminate the Christmas tree. It's a pagan symbol, he says, never mind that the Queen donates two trees to the cathedral each year.

title: Raising More Than the Church Roof
description: CENTRAL SYNAGOGUE, New York's oldest Reform Jewish temple, has for years supported itself easily with membership dues, pledge drives and income from its $10 million endowment fund. But two years ago, it grew wary of that catch-as-catch-can approach. So it hired Holly Dorman, a trained fund-raiser, as its first full-time director of development.

title: As Phillips Returns, Mets Move on Surhoff
description: On the day that Steve Phillips returned to work as general manager of the Mets after an eight-day leave of absence, one of Phillips's assistants, Jim Duquette, went to work on trying to plug one of the team's main holes.

title: Belle Is Up, Williams Is on Deck For Yanks
description: The Yankees' aggressive pursuit of the slugger Albert Belle appears to be accelerating negotiations with another free agent, Bernie Williams.

title: Gore Scolded In Malaysia For Defense Of Dissenters
description: Declaring that it would hold the United States responsible for outbreaks of ''lawlessness,'' Malaysia denounced Vice President Al Gore today for a speech here in which he praised simmering protests against Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad.

title: Jeffersonian Scholars
description: To the Editor:

title: As Jonsson Goes Down, So Go the Isles
description: The Islanders lost defenseman Kenny Jonsson to a concussion tonight, then lost to the Colorado Avalanche by 5-2 at McNichols Arena.

title: From Gascony, an Elegant Holiday Appetizer
description: AN elegant luxury, worth remembering for holiday entertaining, comes from a longstanding tradition in Gascony, a region in southwestern France. There, ducks are fattened to produce oversize livers. And around the town of Agen, deep purple plums are turned into big, black succulent prunes.

title: STARR REHEARSING SPEECH THAT GOES BEYOND LEWINSKY
description: Preparing for his appearance before the House Judiciary Committee on Thursday, the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr has rehearsed testimony that details a pattern of obstruction by the White House extending beyond the matter of Monica S. Lewinsky, lawyers familiar with his preparations said today.

title: Modern Conditions Placed on Traditions
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Armey's Rivals Maneuver in Leadership Race
description: In a last-ditch effort to block Representative Dick Armey of Texas from being re-elected on Wednesday as House majority leader, one of his two opponents tried to get the other to drop out and endorse him instead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOBEL, SHELDON
description: LOBEL-Sheldon. On November 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted father of Debra Lobel, Lisa Samuels and Mark Lobel. Loving father-in-law of Dr. Mitchell Samuels and Dr. Melissa Cohen. Adored and adoring grandfather of Cara, Dana and Michael Samuels. Dear brother of Millicent Haber and the late Irv Lobel. CoFounder of Lobel Chemical Corporation. His indomitable spirit and incredible courage throughout his epic struggle against cancer was truly inspiring. Services Wednesday, November 18th, 11:30AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. Interment Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale. Contributions in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He will always be loved and missed.

title: K-Tel Fails to Meet Nasdaq Listing Criteria
description: K-Tel International Inc., known for its television ads for gadgets and recorded-music collections, failed to meet the minimum tangible net asset requirement for trading on the Nasdaq national market and faces delisting, the company disclosed in its quarterly filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KADLAC, SARAH JANE
description: KADLAC-Sarah Jane, 88, of New York City. Daughter of Clark A. and Agnes Marie (Petersen) Conley; died October 26, 1998. She is survived by her nieces Linda (Conley) Kaye, Cheryl (Conley) Rohde and nephews Christopher E. and Peter S. Conley. Services have been held with burial at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings-On-Hudson, NY. Because of her kindness and loyalty, she will be greatly missed by friends and family.

title: He Turned Gossip Into Tawdry Power; Walter Winchell, Who Climbed High and Fell Far, Still Scintillates
description: Few indisputable points can be made about Walter Winchell. One is that in his day, from the late 1920's to the 50's, he added extraordinary zest to the language of tabloid journalism. In his abundantly syndicated column, newly married couples were ''welded'' or ''lohengrinned,'' or ''Adam-and-Eveing it.'' A pregnant woman was ''infanticipating,'' and with her mate would soon join ''the mom and population.'' If a couple broke up, Winchell found them ''sharing separate tepees.'' And all of this would assume huge importance if it happened anywhere near Broadway, which in his parlance was, of course, ''the main stem.''

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN FALLS. The dollar rose against the yen after Moody's Investors Service lowered Japan's credit rating to Aa1 from the top level, triple-A. In New York, the dollar settled at 121.00 yen, up from 120.07 yen late Monday.

title: Coolness Of New Star Transforms A Revival
description: Ute Lemper has a face that instantly turns to black and white in your memory. On the stage of the Shubert Theater, playing the murderous vaudevillian Velma Kelly in the hit revival of ''Chicago,'' this German-born cabaret star gives the impression that she has been personally lighted by George Hurrell, the old-style Hollywood portrait photographer who wrought such miracles in bringing out cheekbones.

title: INSIDE
description: No Warm Welcome in Iraq

title: South Indian Fare, Crisp and Distinctive
description: IS your entire party here?'' the hostess asks when I finally fight my way through the throng. ''Not yet,'' I reply.

title: FPL ASKS TO CANCEL PURCHASE OF POWER PLANTS IN MAINE
description: FPL Group Inc., Florida's largest utility, sought court permission yesterday to cancel its planned $845 million purchase of four power plants and 27 hydroelectric stations in Maine because regulators had made it harder for the company to sell its power profitably in the state. FPL agreed in January to buy the plants from CMP Group Inc., based in Augusta, Me., which is the parent company of the Central Maine Power Company. FPL, based in Juno Beach, Fla., had expected its purchase of the plants, which together can provide enough power for more than one million homes, to close by the beginning of next year. Central Maine was required under Maine's deregulation law to sell its power plants.

title: A Hard Sunday For 2 Jet Defenders
description: When Aaron Glenn caught a missed field-goal attempt 4 yards deep in the end zone and started running, crisscrossing the field on his way to a record-setting 104-yard touchdown as the first half ended on Sunday, he was certain as he finished the run that he had carried his team even farther than the tiring expanse of field.

title: Murder Charge in Bronx Stray-Bullet Death
description: A 26-year-old man was charged with murder yesterday in the death of a 55-year-old man struck in the neck by a stray bullet while he was driving down a Bronx street on Sept. 1, the police said.

title: Disaster Relief Money: Spread the Wealth
description: To the Editor:

title: Striking While the Mallets Are Hot
description: When Stefon Harris plays the vibraphone, he stands coolly, occasionally changing the angle of his body, not showing much emotion. Like a well-trained boxer, he is measured. You can almost see him thinking. He stops, deliberates, hits a steely note. Then for a second he breaks loose with a flurry of notes from all directions, pelting the range of the instrument.

title: Flawed Sweatshop Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Alaskan Schoolboy on St. John's Recruit List
description: IT is difficult to imagine that Carlos Boozer Jr. will reject a scholarship to distinguished, buttoned-down Duke for one to an open-collar commuter school like St. John's, but anyone who has ridden the Alaska Marine Highway would know why he might. For a reasonable fare, Boozer would have the luxury of moving from Queens to midtown, Alumni Hall to Madison Square Garden, on an express subway train.

title: Shanahan Wants to Be the Perfect Coach
description: Mike Shanahan is vice president and head coach of the Denver Broncos. It's the vice president title that's the thing. Shanahan picks his coaches, his players, his practice schedule, his offensive plays, the game plan and the Broncos' overall direction.

title: The Ideal Turkey? Well, It All Depends; For Perfection, Here's How
description: IF you insist on perfection, here is what I have learned after roasting 40 turkeys in search of it: You must brine the turkey in salt water the night before, and rotate it during roasting.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Fed Thinks Globally, Acts Locally, to Tepid Wall St. Response; Stock and Bond Investors Brace for an End to Cuts
description: The Federal Reserve Board bowed to investors' expectations with its rate cuts yesterday. But for its trouble, it earned only half-hearted applause from stock and bond traders.

title: Failing Schools Need a Lifeline
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fed Reduces Interest Rates By Quarter of a Point Again

title: Indianapolis Museum Buys 30 Gauguins From Swiss Collector
description: The heartland city of Indianapolis may have little in common with Pont-Aven, the picturesque village in Brittany that Paul Gauguin painted into art history more than a century ago, but yesterday the Indianapolis Museum of Art acquired 17 paintings and 84 prints by Gauguin and his Pont-Aven followers that will forever link the two towns.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAIFER, IRVING
description: LAIFER-Irving. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a dear friend, beloved husband of Dr. Thelma G. Warshaw, a YU Guardian and member of the Board of Directors of our Stern College for Women. We extend our heartfelt condolences as well to children, Dr. Audrey Kern and Joan Warshaw (and Robert Michel); brother, Sydney Laifer; grandchildren; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: THE HIDDEN CITY: A special report.; Hard Times for Russia's Nuclear Centers
description: When Andrei B. Sokolov came to this nuclear city more than 30 years ago, it was a bastion of privilege for the Soviet Union's scientific elite.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Human-Cow Hybrid Cells Are Topic of Ethics Panel
description: At the request of President Clinton, the ethical implications of creating hybrid human-cow cells were discussed by the National Bioethics Advisory Commission at its meeting yesterday in Miami, but at least in the public portion of their discussion, none of the commissioners voiced concern about the creation of the hybrid cells.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article yesterday about two plays being performed at City Center by the Stratford Festival misstated the curtain time for ''Much Ado About Nothing.'' It is 8:10 P.M., not 7:40.

title: Once Upon a Frenzy; Book Industry in Big Shift Focused on Product Delivery
description: The flat, sprawling warehouses of Nashville are leagues away from a Manhattan literary lunch and repartee with a prominent author, but this prosaic side of the nation's $8 billion consumer book market -- packing, shipping and delivery -- has become a key to its future.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WORLD SATELLITE NETWORK INC., Minneapolis, which delivers television programming to private cable systems by satellite, agreed to be purchased by WSN Acquisition Corp., a Texas company, for about $15.8 million in cash.

title: Icy Wind From Beijing Chills the Monks of Tibet
description: In a stony courtyard, in the shadows cast by a jumble of old walnut and cherry trees, a hundred young monks in blood-red robes squatted in small groups one recent afternoon to debate the deeper meaning of life.

title: What Can He Say About New York? Plenty
description: AS befits the co-author of a 1,383-page history of New York City -- and that's only Volume I -- Mike Wallace is not a man of few words. Just give him a topic: J.P. Morgan! The Erie Canal! Elizabeth Cady Stanton! And Mr. Wallace is off.

title: Business Travel; United Airlines is installing new passenger-friendly equipment at several domestic airports.
description: UNITED AIRLINES is installing new customer-friendly equipment at a number of United States airports as part of a $200 million, three-year program to improve airport processes and make travel easier for its passengers.

title: THE MINIMALIST: The Ideal Turkey? Well, It All Depends; For Ease, Roast Only the Breast
description: THERE are plenty of reasons to cook a whole turkey breast for Thanksgiving rather than an entire bird. It cuts roasting time at least in half, reduces the hassle of carving and makes the overabundance of leftovers somewhat less absurd. It also frees you to create interesting side dishes.

title: Malaysia Accuses U.S. of Inciting Lawlessness, But the Vice President Stands by His Remarks : Gore Opens APEC Rift With Praise of Reform
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Malaysia accused the United States on Tuesday of inciting the overthrow of a "constitutionally elected" Malaysian government, as the escalating dispute among Asian and Pacific nations over how to handle human rights issues deepened divisions on the opening day of a key regional economic conference.

title: Livent Weighs Its Options, One of Which Is Bankruptcy
description: Executives of Livent Inc., the financially troubled Broadway theater company, are discussing whether the company should file for bankruptcy protection or take another action to appease creditors who are owed hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUGARMAN, DR. ROBERT MARTIN
description: SUGARMAN-Dr. Robert Martin. Early pioneer in the field of personal computing, on November 16, 1998. Loving husband of Linda Funicello. Father of Bradley and Steven. Services Thursday, 12PM at ''The Riverside'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Food Network Switch

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We have made no

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Blair Backs Clinton's Call for Iraqi Opposition Groups to Topple Hussein
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair said today that Britain had evidence of growing opposition to President Saddam Hussein inside Iraq that would seem to give the Clinton Administration's new call for his overthrow a better chance of success than in the past.

title: A Unit of Grey Makes British Deal
description: The Mediacom Worldwide unit of Grey Advertising said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Media Business Group P.L.C. in London and would merge the agency with Mediacom's British operation to form Mediacom/TMBG. Financial terms of the all-cash transaction were not disclosed.

title: As Season Slips Away, Negotiators Try Again
description: After a week and a half of stalled talks, the National Basketball Association's labor dispute took a turn for the better yesterday when negotiating teams for both sides met and agreed to schedule a full bargaining session with owners and players on Friday in Manhattan.

title: PICKER INTERNATIONAL TO BUY AN ISRAELI IMAGING BUSINESS
description: Elscint Ltd. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its computed tomography division to Picker International Inc. for $269.5 million. Elscint, based in Haifa, Israel, is a medical imaging company whose products also include mammography systems. It is a publicly traded unit of Elbit Medical Imaging Ltd., also an Israeli company. Picker, based in Highland Heights, Ohio, is a provider of medical imaging equipment and a unit of the London-based General Electric Company P.L.C., which is unrelated to the General Electric Company of the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TRACT, HAROLD M.
description: TRACT-Harold M. Of blessed memory. Passed away November 18, 1991. He was a truly noble man. The Tract Family

title: Hardly a Reprise of '66, Meteor Storm Still Dazzles in Places
description: The much anticipated storm of Leonid meteors swept over Earth yesterday, a bit ahead of schedule, leaving many sky watchers disappointed but others dazzled by fireballs as bright as the full moon.

title: Pace Is Slow For Repairs To City Schools
description: With seven months left in the Board of Education's current five-year construction plan, school officials have completed only about a third of the major repair projects they identified as priorities when the plan was begun in July 1994, according to data released by the board this week.

title: Deal on City Budget Ends Tax Surcharge
description: The Giuliani administration has agreed to release most of the $150 million that it had withheld from nonprofit groups since July, completing a budget deal with the City Council that also eliminates a 12.5 percent surcharge on the personal income tax of New York City residents.

title: Judge Weighs Move in Allied-AMP Takeover Fight
description: A Federal district judge will consider lifting an injunction that prevents Allied Signal Inc., now engaged in a $9.8 billion hostile bid for AMP Inc., from trying to put its own directors and officers on AMP's board.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Melting Chocolate

title: Preview of 2000? Cuomo and Giuliani Spar
description: Fueling the widespread speculation about his political future, Andrew M. Cuomo, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said today that he had not ruled out running for the Senate from New York in 2000, and he said Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani would be a potentially formidable Republican rival.

title: Shares Rally, Then Sputter, After the Fed Trims Rates
description: Widely anticipated cuts in interest rates by the Federal Reserve Board did not invigorate the stock market yesterday. Prices, which have rallied sharply the last six weeks, closed mixed in moderate trading.

title: Next Job for Purdue: Keeping Itself Grounded
description: On Saturday morning, the Tennessee women's basketball team, winner of 46 consecutive games and the last three national championships, was flying high, literally and figuratively.

title: CARL MARKS TO PURCHASE UNIFLEX FOR $33 MILLION IN CASH
description: Carl Marks & Company, a private investment bank, agreed to purchase the bag and envelope maker Uniflex Inc., for $33 million in cash. Uniflex's stockholders will receive $7.57 a share. The New York-based Carl Marks is an investment bank specializing in management buyouts. Uniflex and Newco, a subsidiary of Carl Marks established for the acquisition, signed a nonbinding letter of intent. Uniflex said it expected the transaction to close in the second quarter of 1999. Uniflex, which is based in Hicksville, N.Y., makes paper and plastic specialty bags, medical-products packaging and tamper-evident envelopes.

title: Little Changed Except Mood
description: The rate cut completes a strategy that has helped rebuild American confidence but has not eased global turmoil. News analysis, page C1.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: MARKEL RAISES CASH OFFER FOR GRYPHON TO $127 MILLION
description: The Markel Corporation, a marketer and underwriter of specialty insurance products, said yesterday that it was increasing its all-cash offer for Gryphon Holdings Inc. to $19 from $18 a share. The new offer values Gryphon at $127 million. Gryphon rejected the offer of $18 a share earlier this month. Gryphon, formerly a subsidiary of the insurance broker Willis Corroon Group P.L.C., is the holding company for Gryphon Insurance Group, which provides specialty products such as earthquake insurance, coverage for architects and engineers, and professional liability insurance. It is based in New York and had assets of $589 million as of June 30.

title: A Little Judicial Humor On the Computer's Gender
description: The Microsoft trial is not all fireworks by any means. There are long stretches of tedium and droning testimony on the dry technical details of computing.

title: Rebuke for Threatening To Kill Unruly Pupil
description: The vice principal of an Elizabeth elementary school has been reprimanded for using inappropriate language when she threatened to ''kill'' a pupil if he would not sit down, the Superintendent said yesterday.

title: THE CHEF
description: AS a child in France, I had heard that Thanksgiving was a feast for family and friends, that it celebrated the harvest and that it always included a turkey. It wasn't until I came to America nine years ago that I realized that, to be a real Thanksgiving feast, the turkey had to be accompanied by stuffing (preferably with chestnuts), sweet potatoes (with or without marshmallows), cranberry sauce (with or without nuts) and pumpkin pie. Of course, we will have all those things on our Thanksgiving table, but this year I'm adding a newcomer: my squash and fennel tartlets.

title: 2 Would-Be Presidents in Argentina Make Corruption an Issue
description: The two leading opposition candidates vying to succeed President Carlos Saul Menem are pledging to begin wide-ranging corruption investigations into the current Government if they win the presidency.

title: Mnqaba Journal; South Africa Returns a Prophetess to Her People
description: One would not expect, perhaps, that a mild-mannered professor from Howard University would turn out to be the Indiana Jones of South Africa.

title: Reason Enough For Reno
description: The beauty of the independent counsel statute is its self-executing nature. It basically spells out the procedure Attorney General Janet Reno must follow when she receives information alleging illegal conduct by a senior Administration official.

title: SPECIAL TODAY: Giving
description: On the front lines of philanthropy, a relief worker chronicles the struggle behind the scenes to get help to refugees in Kosovo. On the home front, articles about Paul Newman's charitable empire, gala guests who bring in the bacon, a college's capital campaign and a guide to smart giving.

title: About New York; Latino Comic Breaking Out Of the Bronx
description: PEOPLE never know when to take Mike Robles seriously, especially when they bump into him on Fordham Road or at Orchard Beach. He wanders the Bronx with a microphone in hand and an earnest expression on his face, asking all sorts of ridiculous questions for ''Comedy Rhumba,'' a public access cable television show he dreamed up three years ago.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on page E5 in the Arts section today about the Indianapolis Museum's purchase of works by Gauguin and his Pont-Aven followers misstates the content of the collection. As noted in the article, it was priced at $30 million; it does not include 30 Gauguins.

title: Tradition, Tradition On Gridiron
description: They are traditional rivalries that are rich in tradition. Something important is usually at stake when they play -- a conference title or a major bowl bid, or sometimes even a national championship. And the bragging rights last for a year. Following is a look at Saturday's three rivalries that matter (with a nod to two rivalries that matter mostly to the principals).

title: New Blow to Japan
description: The decision by Moody's Investors Service to downgrade Japan's pristine credit rating has called into question whether more than $800 billion worth of Government financial stimulants aimed at reversing the country's prolonged economic decline has all been for nothing.

title: In Constitution, A Basis for Censure
description: To the Editor:

title: UBS Posts Loss In Hedge Fund
description: UBS A.G., the world's second-largest bank, posted a greater-than-expected third-quarter loss of 911 million Swiss francs, or $664 million, as its investment in the United States hedge fund Long-Term Capital Management evaporated, prompting the resignation of four top executives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELENDICK, THOMAS J., PH.D.
description: DELENDICK-Thomas J., Ph.D. Beloved brother of Rosemarie Mandella, Rev. John and Patricia Alexandra. Devoted uncle of Laurence and Patrick Alexandra. Reposing Scotto Funeral Home 106 First Pl. (Near Court St) Brooklyn, until Saturday. Mass of Christian Burial. St. Agnes RC Church 10:00 AM. Visiting hours, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Parsing the Buck

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILKINSON, FREDERICK D. JR.
description: WILKINSON-Frederick D. Jr., the Founding Co-Chair of our Board of Overseers, died peacefully on Sunday. We will miss his friendship and his leadership and will not forget him. Our heartfelt sympathies to Fred's beloved wife, Jeane, and to their children, Sharon, Ambassador to Burkina Feso; Dayna of Weston, Virginia, and Frederick III of Los Angeles. The Board and Staff Brookdale Center on Aging of Hunter College

title: Dinosaur Embryos Show Detailed Fossilized Skin
description: For the first time, paleontologists have found fossilized embryos of dinosaurs so well preserved that their delicate skin has survived in mineralized form, providing a glimpse of reptilian scales in patterns bearing a family resemblance to the skin of modern-day lizards.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOHL, DAVID L.
description: WOHL-David L. 1955-1994. Sweet boy, ''No matter where you are, you'll always be a part of me. Lullabies go on and on, they never die, that's how you and I will be.'' Love, Mo

title: Commercial Real Estate; Murray Hill Area Draws Companies in Publishing
description: The publishing industry has come on strong at 345 Park Avenue South, from the outside a relatively nondescript although fully modernized loft building looming over the east side of the avenue between 25th and 26th Streets. Its tenancy history in recent years, and a lease signed only last month, illuminate the rise in publishing activity in the Murray Hill area generally.

title: A Nocturnal Chopin, Followed by . . . Pow!
description: The music of Chopin seems to trigger in Mitsuko Uchida's playing something close to raw emotion. So refined in Mozart, so subtly introspective in Schubert, this estimable Japanese pianist plunged headlong into two Nocturnes, the 24 Preludes and the A-Flat Polonaise-Fantaisie on Monday night. The refinement and thoughtfulness were there for Chopin's more leisurely moods, but the big statement, often in the form of an up-tempo challenge, was met with impetuosity bordering on the heedless. Even the B-flat minor Prelude, one of pianism's most daunting races, set new standards for reckless driving.

title: Arms Inspectors Get Cool Reception in Iraq
description: As United Nations weapons inspectors prepared today to resume their work in Iraq, they were greeted with fresh denunciations in the official Iraqi press despite Iraq's new pledge to demonstrate full cooperation. The condemnation may have been intended primarily for domestic consumption, but it also showed that Iraq is hardly ready to roll out a welcome mat.

title: VULCAN VENTURES TO INVEST IN ZIFF-DAVIS'S ZDTV CHANNEL
description: Vulcan Ventures Inc., a company controlled by the billionaire investor Paul G. Allen, has agreed to invest $54 million in Ziff-Davis Inc.'s ZDTV, a 24-hour cable TV channel that deals with computing and the Internet. Ziff-Davis, the New York-based publisher of computer magazines, said the investment would make Vulcan Ventures a one-third partner in ZDTV, which is based in San Francisco. Ziff-Davis, a unit of the Softbank Corporation, based in Japan, also said it planned to exercise its option to purchase the TV channel from Softbank's MAC Inc. affiliate. MAC owns 43 percent of Softbank, Japan's No. 1 distributor of computer software.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIT, DUDLEY
description: FEIT-Dudley. The entire family of the Hebrew Academy of the Five Towns and Rockaway express their sorrow on the passing of Dudley Feit A''H, father of our immediate past president Elliot Feit. May the family be comforted among the mourners in Israel and know no future sorrow. Teddy Selinger, President

title: F.T.C. Guidelines Restrict Ad Claims for Supplements
description: For the first time, the Federal Trade Commission is issuing advertising guidelines aimed specifically at the nation's booming dietary supplement industry.

title: These Little Gifts Are Useful and Free, But Sticky With Guilt
description: WHAT: ''Free'' personalized return-address labels that arrive in the mail, with increasing frequency, with pitches from all manner of charities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDRON, ROBERT E.
description: WALDRON-Robert E. Age 67. On Nov. 15th, 1998. CEO of Waldron Associates Ltd. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Father of Eric, Clifford, Robert E. Jr. and Susanne. Grandfather of six. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, on Thursday from 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. with service Friday, at 11:30 A.M. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: The Judiciary Storm
description: When the 21 Republicans and 16 Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee convene tomorrow under the uncertain leadership of the committee's chairman, Representative Henry Hyde, the partisan interests will be easy enough to discern. Republicans will be trying to determine if recommending impeachment hearings to the full House will damage them politically. Democrats will be trying to defend a President whose conduct they find distasteful and shift criticism to an independent counsel they will depict as dangerous. The question for the rest of us -- and especially the next House Speaker, Bob Livingston -- is what outcome would serve the public interest.

title: Finding a World Inside Sing Sing
description: WHO: Sister Marian Bohen.

title: Novell and Cisco Set Broad Compatibility Accord
description: The Novell Corporation and the Cisco Corporation, two major players in the computer networking industry, will announce Wednesday that they have agreed to make their software and hardware broadly compatible.

title: Giving Is Easy, but Growing Is Hard
description: THE idea was too good to pass up: turning pennies salvaged from sidewalks and purse bottoms into thousands of dollars for charities. But from the start, Theodore F. Gross was ambivalent about pursuing the idea himself. He was a playwright, not a neighborhood do-gooder.

title: Behind Every Gift, a Careful Plot
description: OUTSIDE the windows of Old Chapel hall, the maple trees were ablaze, their leaves dissolving into crimson, tangerine and maroon. But for the half-dozen participants huddled around a cherrywood conference table -- most notably the man at the head, John M. McCardell Jr., the president of Middlebury College -- there was no time to notice the foliage.

title: Montclair Further Limits Filming for Commercials
description: The Montclair Town Council, responding to residents' complaints about the disruptions caused by the town's popularity as a location for filming commercials, has proposed changes in the local filming ordinance that would raise the fees, limit the number of consecutive days of filming and limit the number of shoots at a single home in a year.

title: Not Done Yet, Graf Upsets a Hobbled Novotna
description: Jana Novotna may be the defending champion of the Chase Championships, not to mention the reigning champion of Wimbledon, but Steffi Graf is the undisputed champion of the comeback, and last night at Madison Square Garden, a cramping Novotna became the latest victim of Graf's latest take-no-prisoners return to the women's tennis tour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTOR, STEVEN, MD.
description: KANTOR - Steven, MD. The Brooklyn Alumni Club PLK-MSAS mourns the passing of Steven Kantor, MD, and extends its deepest sympathy to Linda, Stacie, Robin, Lance, Alan and the family.

title: Microsoft Told to Stop Shipments Of Software at Issue in Rival's Suit
description: The Microsoft Corporation, whose business practices are being challenged by the Government in a major antitrust case, suffered a legal setback on another front yesterday when a Federal judge in California ordered the company to stop shipping its own version of Java, a programming language owned by a rival, Sun Microsystems Inc.

title: Lawyer in Louima Case Seeks Details of Suit
description: The lawyer for a police officer charged with attacking Abner Louima asked prosecutors yesterday for details of a lawsuit in which two men allege that Mr. Louima had filed fraudulent claims with an insurance company.

title: Chief of Xerox Stepping Down
description: The chief executive of the Xerox Corporation, Paul Allaire, said today that he would surrender that position at Xerox, the world's biggest copier company, next year while remaining as chairman, as is the custom at the company.

title: Federal Reserve Cuts Key Rates In Its 3d Attack on Global Slump
description: The Federal Reserve cut interest rates again by a quarter of a percentage point today to help keep a gradual economic slowdown from turning into a recession, but the central bank signaled it might hold off on further reductions in coming months.

title: The Ideal Turkey? Well, It All Depends; For Warm Feelings Of the Past, Dry It Out
description: LAST year, our Thanksgiving turkey was so perfectly cooked that it practically ruined dinner.

title: Failing Schools Need a Lifeline
description: To the Editor:

title: Joe Baum's Company Will Soldier On
description: WHEN Joseph H. Baum died last month, New York lost one of its great restaurant legends. But his company remains, as does his attention-grabbing flair in projects he had been developing with his partners.

title: S.U.V.'s and Sulfur
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a book deal and a television forum for Monica S. Lewinsky attributed the report about the size of the book deal incorrectly in some editions. It was publishing executives, not Ms. Lewinsky's lawyer, who said Ms. Lewinsky would receive a $600,000 advance, plus bonuses for best-seller rankings.

title: Stuffing Boredom? A Bold Antidote
description: THE great American gift for invention meets its match in the turkey, the great American bird.

title: Tom DeLay: A Savvy Survivor of G.O.P. Putsches
description: The phone calls rattled Representative Tom DeLay's Texas home for days, a jangling reminder of the post-election chaos he now faced as House majority whip and its third-ranking Republican.

title: Liberties; So Don't Like Me
description: The joke about Bill Clinton is: When he drives through a car wash in a convertible with the top down, somebody else gets wet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WROBEL, FRANCES
description: WROBEL-Frances. On Nov. 14th. Devoted mother of Linda and Marilyn. Cherished grandmother and loving great-grandmother and a classy lady. She will be missed forever. Services were held.

title: Hispanics Erase Myths With Money
description: GILBERT RIVERA did not think twice before making his recent $10,000 gift to the American Red Cross's relief efforts for victims of Hurricane Georges.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about critics of the Indonesian Government who are being interrogated misidentified one. She is Sukmawati Sukarnoputri, a sister of one of President B. J. Habibie's chief rivals, Megawati Sukarnoputri. Ms. Megawati has not been interrogated.

title: Scourge of the West Bank Arabs: Israeli Bulldozers
description: Uprooted fruit trees and flattened grapevines littered swaths of freshly bulldozed land today in this Palestinian village, where the Israeli Army has begun clearing the way for a road linking a Jewish settlement to a highway.

title: Bid to End Market Distortions : EU Weighs Lifting Of Price Controls
description: LONDON  After years of steadily rising complaints that tough regulations and price controls were harming the competitiveness of Europe's pharmaceutical industry, drugmakers appear to be gaining ground in their campaign for better treatment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KISSINGER, PAULA
description: KISSINGER-Paula. The Board of Directors, Residents and Staff of The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourn with profound sorrow the death of Paula Kissinger, a very special lady and cherished member of The Hebrew Home's extended family. Mrs. Kissinger's warmth, kindness and vivacious spirit will be missed by all of us who came to know her. We extend our sincere sympathy to her sons Henry and Walter, her grandchildren and great-grandchildren. We hope that your loving memories of times together will ease your sorrow during these days of sadness. Milton A. Gilbert, Pres. Bernard Goldberg, Chairman, Board of Directors Jacob Reingold, Vice Chairman, Board of Directors Daniel A. Reingold, Executive Vice Pres.

title: Small Companies Proliferate : New Biotech Drugs Transform Market
description: PARIS  For followers of last summer's Tour de France, the world's premier bicycle race was a sorry chapter. The competition was virtually ruined as officials discovered that some athletes were using EPO, a biologically engineered drug that stimulates the production of red blood cells, giving athletes a competitive edge.

title: Days and Nights in Kosovo: Relief Worker's Diary
description: SINCE September, Robert Turner has been coordinating the International Rescue Committee's emergency program to provide assistance to some of the 200,000 to 300,000 ethnic Albanians left homeless in the fighting that has gripped the Kosovo province of Serbia. The International Rescue Committee has been operating there since February 1997 through a community building program financed by the Swiss Government and two Swiss religious donor groups. From the city of Pristina, where he is based, Mr. Turner has been meeting with representatives of the United Nations and other relief agencies, preparing grant proposals and overseeing security for the International Rescue Committee team. He has also waited -- first for grant money that would allow his planning to become reality, then for a resolution of the standoff between the international community and President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, which could have led to bombing and curtailment of relief efforts in the area.

title: Peter Cotes, 86, Producer And Director of 'Mousetrap'
description: Peter Cotes, a British theatrical producer and director who staged the first production of Agatha Christie's ''Mousetrap'' in 1952, died on Tuesday at his home in Chipping Norton in the Cotswolds. He was 86.

title: THE MARKETS: Fed Thinks Globally, Acts Locally, to Tepid Wall St. Response; Part of the Game Plan In a Worldwide Defense
description: The Federal Reserve's decision today to cut interest rates again marks the completion of a three-part strategy, put together over the last seven weeks by the Clinton Administration and Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, to insulate the American economy from the worst effects of the global economic turmoil that a few weeks ago seemed to threaten to explode into something far worse.

title: 2 Youths Held in Beating Of Newspaper Driver
description: Two Oradell youths have been charged with beating a 40-year-old newspaper carrier into a coma following a traffic dispute on Nov. 8, the Bergen County Prosecutor's office said yesterday.

title: Protecting City's Water
description: To the Editor:

title: Nuveen Selects Fallon McElligott
description: John Nuveen & Company, the investment management company in Chicago, has named Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis to handle its account, which had been at the Chicago office of Publicis & Hal Riney, a unit of Publicis S. A., since 1989. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million, with the potential to grow further.

title: Championing Democracy in Malaysia
description: Malaysia's Prime Minister, Mahathir Mohamad, is fuming, and his countrymen should relish every second of his discomfort. Vice President Al Gore and other foreign leaders have used an economic summit meeting in Dr. Mahathir's capital to call for greater democracy and economic reform in Malaysia.

title: Mansion And Old 'Y' Are Named Landmarks
description: Two late 19th-century Manhattan buildings -- a Park Avenue mansion and a former Y.M.C.A. that became a work space for a string of noted artists -- were designated landmarks yesterday by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: In Constitution, A Basis for Censure
description: To the Editor:

title: Judiciary Committee Planning to Call More Witnesses
description: Republicans on the Judiciary Committee decided today to call more witnesses in the inquiry into President Clinton, and rejected a White House bid for more time to question the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr at the committee's first hearing on Thursday.

title: Schools in Jersey City Prepare For Possible Strike by Teachers
description: Officials of the Jersey City school district and its 36 schools were preparing last night for a possible teachers' strike, making plans to use substitute teachers and administrators for a four-hour school day if negotiations break down and the 2,600 members of the Jersey City Education Association walk off the job this morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, HANNA
description: KLEIN-Hanna. The Congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its devoted longtime member and extends sympathy to her bereaved family. Marjorie Miller, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Kenneth M. Chasen, Asst. Rabbi Laurie Katz Braun, Asst. Rabbi

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOUIS, JACK C.
description: LOUIS-Jack C. Beloved husband of Gloria. Loving father to Ashley, J.C. and Patricia. Devoted grandfather of Joshua, Ashley & Callan.

title: Shifting Strategies Play Out on a Capitol Hill Stage
description: Despite all of the distracting jockeying over witnesses and evidence today, one truth shone clearly about the House impeachment inquiry: A process once conceived as a matter of supreme seriousness has become just another piece of political theater on Capitol Hill.

title: Suspect in Shooting of Officer Admits to Killings, Police Say
description: A parolee charged with shooting a Brooklyn pawnshop owner to death on Monday and later wounding a police officer who went to a housing project to arrest him has confessed to those shootings as well as four unsolved homicides and several other violent offenses, Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRINE, RUTH
description: BRINE-Ruth, 1919-1998. Memorial service Thursday, November 19 at 6 PM, New York University, Fales Library, 3rd Floor, Bobst Library and Study Center, 70 Washington Square South.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVID, ANNE, NEE MENACHEM
description: DAVID-Anne, nee Menachem, of Morristown. Predeceased by her husband Edward A. Devoted mother of Sherry Ayche, Arthur David, and Melvyn David. Dear sister of Morris Menachem. Loving grandmother of Anne Sherman, Lisa and Michael Rosefarb, Edward David and Roxanne Davis. Loving great-grandmother of seven. Services Louis Surburban Chapels, Dover, Wednesday, 1PM.

title: The Only Authenic Barbecue Pit In New York City Is Losing Its Lease
description: LIKE a puff of smoke, Pearson's Texas Barbecue, the only authentic barbecue pit in New York City, will fade and vanish by the end of the year. The smoke, in fact, is part of the problem.

title: Making His Own Charity an Acquired Taste
description: PAUL NEWMAN is contemplating a pork chop, which will be followed by a grilled chicken breast, another chop and more chicken. The actor's stop at Sarabeth's, a restaurant on the Upper East Side of New York, is a working lunch, not a feast.

title: When Good Intentions Come Undone
description: FEW things in philanthropy are more painful than the high-profile implosion of a multimillion-dollar agreement between a donor and a cause -- a lesson that Edith and Henry Everett learned last year with the collapse of their plan to give $3 million for a children's zoo in Central Park.

title: In Constitution, A Basis for Censure
description: To the Editor:

title: In the 990's Fine Print, the Innards of Nonprofits
description: YOU'RE all set to contribute to a charity -- let's call it Worthy Cause. But there's a hitch: you have heard the stories about charity administrators spending more money on limousines and lunches than on helping the poor. You want to insure your money is put to good use.

title: Big Business: Helping the Helpers
description: ONE of the great ironies of the nonprofit world is that it has spawned a large and lucrative for-profit industry. After all, a nonprofit has needs -- especially if it is going to reach out to all those would-be donors and wannabe philanthropists who wouldn't know a worthy cause unless they heard from one.

title: Selective Spending at Contemporary-Art Auction
description: Buyers kept their feet firmly planted on the ground last night at Sotheby's auction of contemporary art. While six or seven people were often seen bidding on a work at once, buying seemed carefully controlled throughout the evening.

title: A Fight to Preserve Abandoned Asylums; Sales Seen as Threat to Landmarks Of Architecture and Idealism
description: More than a century ago, aproned nurses in starched white caps bustled along highly polished corridors in this city's elegant insane asylum, a limestone monument to the prevailing Victorian belief that mental illness could be improved with air, light -- and imposing architecture.

title: Where History Lives, a Special Thanks
description: THEY eat well all year on the Eastern Shore, never better than at Thanksgiving.

title: Catholic Bishops' Conference Elects Leaders
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops today elected Bishop Joseph A. Fiorenza of the Diocese of Galveston-Houston, a soft-spoken prelate known for his concern for the poor and immigrants, as president of the conference that serves as their collective voice. The bishops also elected Bishop Wilton D. Gregory of Belleville, Ill., as vice president, the first time that an African-American prelate has been chosen for one of the top two positions in the National Conference of Catholic Bishops.

title: Compassion, Delivered in Person
description: A CHILD cannot hug a check. A cash donation may pay for a dying man's Thanksgiving meal, but it cannot carry it to his door. When people think of charitable giving, they often think of money, but volunteers who donate their time make very essential contributions. Some volunteering requires training, but almost anyone can hold a child or read to an elderly person who is going blind. About 8,000 people have volunteered their skills and compassion in New York City for organizations like Hale House, God's Love We Deliver and Habitat for Humanity, pictured here in photographs by Linda Rosier and Nicole Bengiveno.

title: Journal; Starr's Secret Helpers
description: Poor Sally Quinn. As soon as she published her landmark Washington Post article about why Washington insiders despise Bill Clinton's trashy morals, other, no doubt envious Washington insiders had the gall to question her morality. ''Sally's had a very interesting sex life of her own,'' says Charles Peters, the editor of The Washington Monthly, in this week's New York magazine, though he didn't produce any tapes to back up his claim. Some capital refugees, of whom I'm one, remain incredulous when anyone mentions the phrase ''interesting sex life'' and Washington in the same sentence.

title: Rowland Offers the Patriots a New Stadium in Hartford
description: Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut has offered to build a stadium for the New England Patriots as part of a $350 million development project in downtown Hartford. The team's owner, Robert K. Kraft, who has failed to win a stadium deal from Massachusetts, flew to Hartford this week and spent five hours discussing the deal with Connecticut officials.

title: Fixing Potholes of the 21st Century
description: So now, without Alfonse M. D'Amato looking down from the Senate, what is to become of New York City's potholes? At a New York University conference called yesterday to tackle the city's vast needs in infrastructure repair, the answer seemed to be that technology, not Federal largess, could do the trick.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUTSHER, MILTON
description: KUTSHER-Milton. Owner and President of Kutsher's Country Club, a leading hotel in the Catskills, died on Monday, November 16th of a heart attack. Kutsher, and his wife, Helen, joined forces to build the business from a rooming house founded in 1907 by Louis and Max Kutsher, to its present status as a world-renowned resort. A Monticello native, Kutsher went on to graduate from the University of Pennsylvania in 1937 with a degree in journalism. Following his service in World War II, Kutsher, returned to Monticello to begin his stewardship of the resort with his brother Joe. A visionary leader and one of Sullivan County's most prominent citizens, Kutsher served as President of the Catskill Resort Association, was a founder and Chairman of the Board of Monticello Raceway, a Director of the Key Bank and the Trust Company of New Jersey, and as Chairman of the Publicity Commission of Sullivan County. An active alumnus, Kutsher was a member of the University of Pennsylvania's Benjamin Franklin Society. A devotee of sports and a man of great philanthropic character, Kutsher was one of the founders of the Maurice Stokes Memorial Fund Foundation. The hotel continues to host the annual classic basketball game, now in its 41st year, which raises monies for needy veteran NBA players. Kutsher was a Trustee of the National Basketball Hall of Fame in Springfield, MA. and was inducted into the New York City Basketball Hall of Fame in 1996. In addition to the hotel, Kutsher and his wife own and operate Kutsher's Sport Academy, a leading sports training center for youth. They also operated Kutsher's Camp Anawana for more than twenty years. The resort continues as a family business under the leadership of Helen, son, Mark and daughter-inlaw, Carla. In addition, he is survived by two daughters, Mady Prowler, of Philadelphia, PA. and Karen Wilson, of Bryn Mawr, PA; their spouses, Don Prowler and Jeffrey Wilson, and seven grandchildren. Services will be held in Monticello on Thursday, November 19, 1998, at 12:30 P.M. at the Landfield Avenue Synagogue.

title: The $20,000 Surprise and Other Foundation Shakers
description: ''IT'S become the Wild West,'' said Virginia Esposito, the president of the National Center for Family Philanthropy in Washington. ''The changes are seismic. It's the numbers of people involved, the diversity of interests and opportunity, with new foundations being created every day.''

title: Disaster Relief Money: Spread the Wealth
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARREL, SADYE (SYD)
description: BARREL-Sadye (Syd). The officers, board, and staff of the Smithsonian Institution National Museum of the American Indian express their condolences on the passing of Syd Barrel in Palm Beach, Fla. She was the beloved mother of Iris Barrel Apfel, a keen supporter of the National Museum of the American Indian, and sonin-law of Carol Apfel. Mrs. Barrel will be remembered and appreciated for her business acumen and generous support of many philanthropies. W. Richard West, Director John L. Colonghi, National Campaign Director National Museum of the American Indian

title: Voice That Shook Presidency Is Heard Around the World
description: A Presidential scandal that was never long on mystery or romance surrendered perhaps its last tantalizing secret today.

title: Rite Aid in $1.5 Billion Deal for Lilly Unit
description: Seeking to diversify into health services, the Rite Aid Corporation announced yesterday that it was buying the pharmacy-benefits management business of Eli Lilly & Company for $1.5 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINN, JOSEPH F.
description: QUINN-Joseph F. November 16, 1998. Beloved husband of Phyllis. Loving father of Andrew and Stephanie. Son of Estelle Quinn. Brother of Donald Quinn. Retired in 1997 as Senior Vice President and General Counsel of US Reinsurance. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 Street, Wednesday, November 18, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Thursday 10AM at the Church of Our Saviour, Park Ave at 38th St. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the American Cancer Society, 19 W 56 St, NY, NY 10019.

title: Three Council Members Call for Lawsuit Against Gun Makers
description: Taking a page from the litigation against the tobacco industry, three New York City Council members proposed yesterday that the city file a lawsuit against all the nation's gun manufacturers, trying to recoup millions of dollars spent treating shooting victims.

title: How It Felt To Grow Up As Castro's Daughter
description: The only daughter of Fidel Castro walks into a midtown French restaurant looking disheveled, out of sorts, lost.

title: It's All in Who You Know (and Who They Know)
description: HOW do two brothers who came from Queens get to mingle with Brooke Astor and other luminaries on New York society's A list? Well, first they become powerful publishing executives. Then they agree to be co-chairmen of one of the season's most sparkling benefits, the Municipal Art Society's fall gala at the renovated Grand Central Terminal.

title: Growing Gap Is Found in College Affordability and Grants to Needy Students
description: As college costs have risen and Federal grants to needy students have declined over the last two decades, higher education has become significantly less affordable for students from poor families, a new national survey shows.

title: Where French Fries Are the Main Course
description: An eye-catching sign with a twirling ''B,'' designed by Milton Glaser, announces B. Frites, 1657 Broadway (51st Street), a new Belgian-style french fry shop. Skel Islamaj, a Belgian native, who once cooked at Jean Georges, is the chef and an owner. He uses Marrist Piper potatoes, the closest to the Belgian Bintjes he prefers. The fries are as good as they look, golden and burnished, crisp and greaseless, with a smooth texture and good potato taste. They are $2.25, $3.50 or $4.50, with free mustard, ketchup and Belgian mayonnaise; special sauces, like herb and peanut, are 50 cents each.

title: Jeffersonian Scholars
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, CLARA (NEE HANDELMAN)
description: BERNSTEIN-Clara (nee Handelman). Died on November 16th, age 83, in Goshen, NY. Formerly of Eastchester, NY. She is survived by her loving family: her husband of 57 years, Dr. Alfred J. Bernstein, daughter Anne of Berkeley, CA., son Andrew of Wayne, NJ, brother Herbert Handelman of Boca Raton, FL, daughter-in-law Linda, son-in-law Conn Hallinan, grandsons Mark and Greg Bernstein and David Hallinan, stepgrandsons Sean, Antonio, and Brian Hallinan, sisters-in-law Yetta Handelman, Minerva Mandelkern, and Katherine, a large extended family and many friends. Funeral services will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York on Thursday, November 19 at 1 P.M., followed by interment at the Mount Hebron Cemetery.

title: A Tribute to a Perfectionist
description: The New York City Ballet paid tribute on Monday night to Jerome Robbins, a towering innovator in American ballet and musical theater and, with George Balanchine, one of the company's co-founding choreographers.

title: Bandwagon, No Beanbag
description: WHO: Lorri L. Jean.

title: 2 Arrested After Dispute Ends in Youth's Shooting
description: A youth was shot in the leg last night during a dispute with two men at 104th Street and Central Park West. Both men were arrested after a brief chase and the weapon, a .32-caliber, silver-colored revolver, was recovered, the police said.

title: Confronting a $1.4 Billion Blank Page
description: DORIS DUKE, reputedly the richest woman in the United States when she died in 1993 at the age of 80, loved jazz, modern dance, gospel music and Islamic art. She cared about children, animals and the great outdoors. She worried about people with heart disease, cancer, AIDS and sickle cell anemia.

title: YOGEN FRUZ OFFERS $35.5 MILLION FOR ESKIMO PIE CORP.
description: Yogen Fruz World-Wide Inc. said yesterday that it had made an unsolicited offer to acquire the Eskimo Pie Corporation for $10.25 a share, or $35.5 million. Eskimo Pie's shares rose $1.50, to $10.75, in Nasdaq trading. Eskimo Pie, based in Richmond, makes frozen novelty desserts, frozen yogurt, ice cream and sorbet. Yogen Fruz, based in Toronto, franchises frozen yogurt outlets and sells frozen desserts. Yogen Fruz said combining its Integrated Brands frozen dessert unit with Eskimo Pie would provide an ''extraordinary opportunity.''

title: Taking Turkey's Temperature
description: WHEN roasting turkey, some people prefer to wing it, relying on a ballpark feeling for doneness. Others -- especially on major holidays -- want precision. They want to know exactly what they're getting and when they're getting it. And beyond the big day, they want to keep track of subtle differences, so they can modify temperatures a few degrees each time until they achieve perfection.

title: Divorce Curb Is Dividing Feminists In China
description: Proposals to make divorce more difficult and to punish adulterers have stirred a rare and passionate public debate here, with opinions clashing in newspapers, radio call-in shows and television specials around the country.

title: CALENDAR
description: French Chef to Teach Class

title: Got a Match? If Not, You Lose the Grant
description: AT first glance, it seems an almost churlish way to make a charitable donation: a large foundation promises a community hospital $100,000 for a new wing, but only if the hospital raises $300,000 from other donors. And the hospital must be very clear to those donors that they are matching someone else's conditional generosity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNOFSKY, JULIUS E. DDS.
description: KUNOFSKY-Julius E. DDS. On November 11, 1998. Beloved husband of Judy, devoted father of Larry, loving brother of Edith Hirshon, cherished son-in-law of Sylvia Kaish, brother-in-law and uncle. Donations may be sent to YI of Far Rockaway, 716 Beach 9th St., Far Rockaway, NY

title: Gonzalez Pulls Out of Bout
description: Miguel Angel Gonzalez has pulled out of his Nov. 28 World Boxing Council junior welterweight title bout against Kostya Tszyu because of a bruised rib. The promoter Dan Goosen, of America Presents, and HBO, which was to broadcast the bout from Indio, Calif., are trying to get Diobelys Hurtado of Miami to replace Gonzalez. Hurtado is the W.B.C.'s fifth-ranked junior welterweight.

title: Mexican's Memoir of Alamo a Rage
description: A memoir purportedly written 150 years ago by an obscure Mexican military officer that details, among other things, the aftermath of a battle and the execution of one of the losing combatants, is expected to draw as much as half a million dollars when it goes on the auction block on Wednesday in Los Angeles.

title: As Congress Weighs Impeachment
description: To the Editor:

title: Tip Off Iraq? France Says It Couldn't, And Wouldn't
description: France was not told by the United States or by Britain precisely when the two countries planned to attack Iraq last weekend and could not have tipped off Baghdad, senior French officials said today.

title: LIFE BY DESIGN; Too Many Breakthroughs
description: The age of biotechnology is upon us. Each week brings breakthroughs in understanding and controlling living processes. Cloning of mammals has become a reality. Cancer is under siege. Researchers have cultivated all-purpose, eternally replicating stem cells, and are now learning to direct them toward tissue regeneration. Others have transplanted the gene for the immortalizing enzyme, telomerase, into ordinary cells. Cellular immortality lies within reach.

title: Beijing to Expel Foreign Reporter, 2d in a Month
description: China today expelled a reporter for the German news magazine Der Spiegel, one day after eight officials burst into his office and accused him of possessing secret documents. The reporter, Jurgen Kremb, said he was told he must leave China within 48 hours and could not return for five years.

title: Youth Tours Won't Save Judaism
description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey City and Teachers Talk to Avert a Strike
description: Officials of the Jersey City school district continued negotiating with representatives of the teachers' union last night over a new contract in hopes of averting a strike.

title: Patriots Are Set to Announce Move to Downtown Hartford
description: Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut and the owner of the New England Patriots scheduled a news conference at the Capitol today to announce an agreement to move the National Football League team from Massachusetts to downtown Hartford, a spokesman for the Governor said this morning.

title: Microsoft Quits A Media Venture
description: The Microsoft Corporation said today that it would sell its 10 percent stake in Real Networks Inc. in a move to compete head to head against the company, which is the market leader in technology that sends sound and video over the Internet.

title: Telefonica to Omit Dividend Altogether
description: Telefonica S.A., Spain's biggest phone company, said yesterday that it would drop its dividend altogether instead of merely cutting it to help to finance expansion in Latin America. The company, which paid more than 95 billion pesetas ($670 million) in dividends last year, said in March that it would reduce its dividend and hand out bonus shares instead. Now competition at home and an unexpected drop in profit could put pressure on the share price.

title: Spitzer Has Thin Lead as Vote Counting Nears End
description: With the counting of paper ballots nearly done in the attorney general's race, state election officials said yesterday that Eliot L. Spitzer, the Democratic challenger, was maintaining a thin lead, and aides to Mr. Spitzer said he was preparing to declare victory today over Dennis C. Vacco, the Republican incumbent.

title: Bonilla Feels Less Pressure Upon Return
description: In one breath, he insists he has learned from his mistakes and has not only matured, but also changed. In the next breath, Bobby Bonilla says, ''I'm the same guy.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''People look at me and think, 'How can you still smoke?' And God knows, I don't want to smoke. But I am like a slave to it. It rules your life.''

title: Bishops Take Bolder Stand In Battle Against Abortion
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops declared today that they have a pastoral duty to speak out to persuade public officials who support abortion rights, and Catholic officials in particular, to undergo ''a change of heart.''

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Tripp Is Shopping For an Agent

title: State of Salomon Bros.
description: To the Editor:

title: Serves Them Right
description: WHY is it that the annual November reconnaissance of the china cupboard always reveals gaps, at least in holiday serving pieces? On the bright side, few areas are as easy to freshen up with new and vintage items. Remember: If all your platters matched, it would be downright scary.

title: Davenport Gains; Seles Beats the Flu
description: She glared. She stared. She argued with the chair umpire over a slew of questionable calls and, more destructively, she argued with her own game, the same game that made her the world's No. 1 player.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAY, FRANCES
description: GRAY-Frances. Mother of JudyAnn Gray, Jane and Richard T. Andrias, and Jonathan and Nina Gray. Grandmother of Jennifer and Keith McClarren, Kate and Eve Andrias, Daniel and Efrat Gray. Great grandmother of Camille McClarren. Sister of Timmy Kabak Walsh, and Leona and Daniel Ariewitz. Services 10AM Thursday, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: On Growing Up in Public: A Young Vibraphonist's Musical Progress
description: The music Stefon Harris took to the Jazz Standard on Tuesday night sounded quite different from what this young vibraphonist played there a year ago. That swift progress is a rarity among young jazz musicians. His band had an extra percussionist a year ago, and the music was so clotted with drums that it got away from jazz and into African and Cuban rhythmic ideas in pleasing and sometimes pastiched ways.

title: West's Medicine Is Raising Bills For China's Sick
description: When Sun Lilin emerged from Beijing Children's Hospital, her pockets bulged with bottles of syrup and her hands juggled a tower of boxes containing powders and pills.

title: Excerpts From Starr's Prepared Remarks to the Judiciary Committee
description: Following are excerpts from the opening statement of the independent prosecutor, Kenneth W. Starr, prepared for delivery before the House Judiciary Committee on Thursday as it considers impeachment proceedings against President Clinton. The material was made available to news organizations.

title: A Slave of Smoke in an Anti-Smoke Land
description: It was not quite 8 A.M. as Jan Binder stood on the sidewalk in a cold Midwestern drizzle. Her fellow workers hustled past her toward the office, some of them shaking their heads in dismay.

title: Ambitious Plan Is Offered To Build and Repair Schools
description: The city Board of Education proposed a $10.9 billion school construction budget yesterday that would pay for 64 new schools and repairs to roofs, windows and walls at hundreds of other schools over the next five years.

title: F.C.C. to Ease Rules on Stations' Hiring of Women and Minorities
description: In the wake of a court decision invalidating its affirmative action requirements for broadcasters, the Federal Communications Commission will propose new rules to encourage television and radio stations to hire minority members and women. But it will no longer require an evaluation of how stations are achieving that goal.

title: The Cancer Battle: A Revolution Still in Progress
description: ONE RENEGADE CELL

title: Tiffany Names President to Succeed Chief
description: Tiffany & Company, the second-largest United States jewelry retailer, said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Michael Kowalski, would succeed William Chaney as chief executive on Jan. 31.

title: Hedge Funds May Have to Disclose More Data
description: As United States Government regulators tighten their scrutiny of hedge funds, officials say they will likely require the often secretive funds to reveal more about how much debt they use and the risks they take with their money.

title: Web Robots Offer Hands-On Experience From Afar
description: THE artist dipped his brush into a can of red paint. With one motion, he swiped a thick, fierce stripe across the middle of the canvas: a gooey, abstract landscape in primary colors. It had been a long afternoon, and the floor was covered with drips and splats.

title: Sony Offers On-Line Jukebox With 'Pay as You Play' Service
description: The jukebox is back -- on the Internet. Sony Music Online's new site, a partnership with Real Networks, has a ''pay as you play'' structure, allowing users to choose songs and play them through their computers. The songs selected from the site (www.sonymusic.com/jukebox) can be played an unlimited number of times in a 24-hour period.

title: As Congress Weighs Impeachment; Invasion of Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Won't Ease Jail Restrictions on Men Held in Bombings of U.S. Embassies
description: A Federal judge has refused to lift the highly restrictive jail conditions placed on three defendants arrested after the bombings of the United States embassies in Africa last August, according to a court transcript made public yesterday.

title: For Air Crash Victims, Solace Comes on Line
description: After the crash of Swissair Flight 111, the airline brought grieving families to Halifax, Nova Scotia, booked them into hotels and bused them to the crash site -- the customary help. But then it gave them something unusual: space on the airline's Web page to speak with one another.

title: North Korea Offers U.S. Access to Secret Plant, at a Steep Price
description: North Korea has demanded that the United States pay hundreds of millions of dollars for the right to inspect a huge underground center that American intelligence analysts fear houses a nuclear-weapons program, Administration officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORSARO, JOHN
description: CORSARO-John. The Segal Company mourns the passing of John Corsaro, one of its Senior Vice Presidents and a beloved colleague and friend for over 30 years. He was a loyal and skilled consultant and was dedicated to the clients he served. We extend deepest sympathy to his family. Martin E. Segal, Chair. Emeritus Robert D. Krinsky, Chairman Howard Fluhr, President and CEO

title: Tiptoeing Mournfully Through A Cemetery
description: The Vladimir and Estragon of Andrei Belgrader's elegiac new production of ''Waiting for Godot'' are so aware of the proximity of death that it seems at times as if they're tiptoeing between cemetery plots.

title: The Hearing on Television
description: Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, is scheduled to appear before the House Judiciary Committee on Thursday starting at 10 A.M. Five broadcasters -- CNN, the Fox News Channel, PBS, C-Span and MSNBC -- plan live gavel-to-gavel coverage. C-Span also plans to rebroadcast the day's hearing beginning at 7 P.M.

title: In America; How Did Jayla Die?
description: Dr. Linda Norton offers us a voice of sanity in the nightmarish case of Lacresha Murray, a 14-year-old in Texas who is serving a 25-year prison term after being found guilty of beating a 2 1/2-year-old girl to death. The killing occurred in Austin in 1996, when Lacresha was 11.

title: Hoechst Is Planning To Spin Off Celanese
description: Buffeted by slumping sales on many fronts, Hoechst A.G. intends to spin off Celanese, its big American chemical subsidiary, and another unit by issuing new shares to all its stockholders. The company said on Tuesday that it would give every stockholder one share in a new company made up of Celanese and Ticona, a smaller subsidiary, for every 10 Hoechst shares.

title: A Case for Pollard
description: To the Editor:

title: Program Notifies You of E-Mail If You Can Stay Off the Phone
description: Are you eager to know when an important E-mail has arrived but frustrated at having to dial into your Internet service repeatedly to check for messages? If so, Mailpush Express might calm your nerves.

title: A Gagdet to Guide The Parking Impaired
description: Safely threading a huge sport utility vehicle around the junk that infests many garages can challenge even the most skilled motorist. Park-Zone uses electronics to guide the process smoothly for any kind of kind of car or truck. ''The concept is to prevent bumper bashing and wall smashing,'' said Charles Balsamo, chief executive of Exeter Technologies, the company that developed the parking aid.

title: Allied Signal Case Back to Lower Court
description: In an advance for Allied Signal Inc., the company said yesterday that a Federal appeals court had given jurisdiction over the company's attempt to expand the board of AMP Inc. with its own directors back to a district court judge, who is likely to lift a preliminary injunction that had barred the board election.

title: Essay; Starr's Turn
description: After months of complaining that Ken Starr's initial referral was ''only about lying about sex,'' Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee now insist the impeachment hearings be limited to sex, the whole sex and nothing but the sex.

title: Brazil Output Falls; Full Recession Feared
description: Fanning widespread fears that Brazil is plunging into a full-fledged recession, the Government announced today that the economy contracted by 1.5 percent in the third quarter from the second quarter and said that key indicators pointed toward an even more pronounced slump over the next few months.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PROVIDIAN FINANCIAL CORP., -- San Francisco, a credit card company, agreed to buy 600,000 Bravo card customers and their $350 million in balances from Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, for undisclosed terms.

title: Rancorous Asia Pacific Talks End With a Pledge and a Sigh
description: With an almost palpable sigh of relief, the leaders of Malaysia and 20 other Pacific Rim countries wrapped up a contentious summit meeting here today by pledging to revive a region they said had been set back decades by the Asian economic crisis.

title: And Freedom for All
description: THE irony is rich. That's what makes the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum of the Smithsonian Institution different from other arty museums in the United States.

title: 'It Was, Like, Sex.' What Else Was It?
description: Given the language of the law, guilt was ordained. The four high school seniors charged with having sexual relations with three 14-year-old freshmen girls had committed statutory rape, and the prosecutor was only doing the state's duty in enforcing the law. But ''Cry Rape,'' tonight's ''48 Hours,'' gives a more nuanced account of the events that led these young men and women (boys and girls?) into the situation that damaged them all.

title: Patrick Clancy, 76, Founder of Irish Folk Group
description: Patrick Clancy, who helped start a folk revival as a founding member of the Clancy Brothers and Tommy Makem, died on Nov. 11 at his home in Carrick-on-Suir, County Tipperary, Ireland. He was 76.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERTIN, STEPHEN
description: BERTIN-Stephen. On November 17, 1998. Devoted husband of the late Rysia. Cherished father of Martine. Beloved grandfather of Alexandra. An engineer, classical scholar and historian. A survivor and fighter until the end. A tribute to his life will be held at a later date. He will always be loved, missed and remembered.

title: Jacques Medecin, 70, Dies; French Mayor
description: Jacques Medecin, Mayor of Nice from 1966 until 1990, when he fled to Uruguay to avoid prosecution on corruption charges that later landed him in jail for nearly two years, died in Uruguay on Tuesday after several heart attacks, his family said. He was 70.

title: Florida Broker Is Arraigned
description: A Florida broker from A. S. Goldmen & Company, a small-stock brokerage firm, was arraigned yesterday on state charges in New York that he made misleading statements about a company whose stock he was selling.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19

title: Metro Business; Company's Jobs Go South
description: The Curtiss-Wright Corporation said yesterday that it would move some of its aerospace systems manufacturing from Fairfield, N.J., to a plant in Shelby, N.C., a cost-cutting measure that will affect 90 jobs.

title: With Gingrich Out, G.O.P. Loses Top Fund-Raiser
description: With Newt Gingrich stepping down from Congress, the Republican Party is losing its top fund-raiser, a man who, by party accounts, raised more than $60 million for office-seekers this year and masterminded a strategy that helped Republicans take over Congress in 1994 and retain control ever since.

title: Real Queasiness In Virtual Reality
description: JANNICK P. ROLLAND was participating in a test of the physical side effects of head-mounted video devices intended for surgeons. The experiment went fine, and she could see and function in the augmented reality the gadget presented. Test done, she picked up a can of soda and brought it to her lips. Well, actually to her forehead -- she tipped the can back and nearly poured soda down her face.
