title: Brazil Preoccupied With Mystery Tapes
description: Washington and Wall Street may be breathing a sigh of relief now that a rescue package for the Brazilian economy has been stitched together. But the political leaders who will have to hold up Brazil's end of the bargain have suddenly become preoccupied with another troublesome question: Who fabricated the mysterious tapes and documents that implicate Brazil's President in potentially impeachable offenses?

title: Youth Tours Won't Save Judaism
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MILLIKEN, MINOT K.
description: MILLIKEN-Minot K. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, December 2nd, 11am at St. Thomas Church, 5th Avenue & West 53 St. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to The Boys' Club of New York, 287 East 10 St., NY NY 10009

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DARDIG, BEN
description: DARDIG-BEN. The Jewish Braille Institute of America is deeply saddened by the passing of a dear friend and highly respected professional colleague. As a consultant he contributed greatly to the enhancement of our services to the blind, visually impaired and reading disabled worldwide. To his loving wife Evelyn, his children and grandchildren we pray that they may be comforted in their loss. May his memory serve as a blessing. Barbara B. Friedman, President Dr. Jane Evans, Honoray President Gerald M. Kass, Executive V.P.

title: Starr Chose Not to Send Report on Whitewater to Congress
description: Late last year, Kenneth W. Starr wrote a draft impeachment report centering on President Clinton's purported involvement in the complicated Whitewater land deal but decided not to send it to Congress.

title: McNair Presents A Double Threat
description: Bryan Cox, who has launched himself into the upper echelon of Jets defenders with his recent play, wiped that off-the-field smile off his face today.

title: Once Again, Computer Users Are Way Ahead of the Industry
description: The computer industry has recently been pushing to make its products also serve as television sets. Windows 98 was designed to help support television drivers, and Panasonic and Compaq have just released a tuner card that even allows personal computers to display HDTV programs. Customers, however, may have already found a less complicated, and often cheaper, answer.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about James Allen Gordon, who is representing himself in a capital murder trial in Queens, referred incorrectly to the hiring of his two legal advisers. They were appointed by the court; he did not retain them.

title: GSD& M Is Chosen By Mirage Resorts
description: Mirage Resorts Inc. in Las Vegas, Nev., said yesterday that it had named GSD& M in Austin, Tex., to handle the creative portion of its account, with billings estimated at $30 million. The account had been handled for a decade by Publicis & Hal Riney in San Francisco, part of Publicis S.A., until Riney and Mirage mutually parted ways last month.

title: INSIDE
description: Bishops' Abortion Agenda

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUMACK, DR. IRVING
description: RUMACK-Dr. Irving, Beloved husband of Mildred. Loving father of Peter (Nina) and Lucy (Rod). Devoted brother of Ann Erdman and adored grandfather of 4 wonders. Memorial service Saturday, Nov. 21st. 11:30am. Unitarian Universalist Congregation, 48 Sheltor Rock Road, Manhasset, LI, New York.

title: Youth Tours Won't Save Judaism
description: To the Editor:

title: Nail-Biting Time In the Game Arena
description: Kurt Shimada is shaking with joy, disbelief and a twinge of guilt. Moments ago, in the preliminary round of the computer game championships, he didn't just beat but demolished Dennis Fong, who happens to be the Michael Jordan of computer games.

title: City Said to Use More Pesticides Than Farm Counties
description: New York City appears to use more pesticides to kill its rats, roaches and other urban pests than the state's major agricultural counties use to protect their apples, corn and potatoes from bores and bugs, according to a report issued yesterday by two environmental organizations.

title: Sensor Sensation
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILLAM, DOROTHY SCOTT
description: GILLAM-Dorothy Scott. Died October 26, 1998. Memorial service Saturday, November 21 3PM at Christ Chapel, Riverside Church.

title: Gene Identified as Major Cause of Deafness in Ashkenazi Jews
description: Scientists have identified a gene that is a major cause of inherited deafness among Ashkenazi Jews, a group that includes 90 percent of the six million Jewish people in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTENBERG, VIOLET A.
description: WALTENBERG-Violet A. (Pat). On November 17, 1998 in Leesburg, Fla. Survived by life long friend, Viola Fields, loving niece, Dorrie, and nephew, Robert and many many friends. For information call Page-Theus-Blanchard Funeral Home, 352-787-5511

title: The Other 'Other Cuomo' Says No to Politics
description: CHRISTOPHER CUOMO has just declared that he is having a ''bad camera day.''

title: Amaker Gets His Wish With Revival of Series
description: SETON HALL 83, DREXEL 70

title: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE COUNSEL -- 3 Men Who Will Query Starr; David P. Schippers
description: David P. Schippers, who will lead the questioning of Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, for the Republicans in today's Judiciary Committee session, has made much of being a lifelong Democrat.

title: People
description: * Meg Kannin and Jon Wyville were named co-creative directors at Arian, Lowe & Travis, Chicago, succeeding Mike Fornwald, who left to become a commercial director. Ms. Kannin had been senior copywriter and associate creative director at Arian, Lowe; Mr. Wyville had been associate creative director at Pagano Schenck & Kay, Boston.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENNYBACKER, MILES
description: PENNYBACKER-Miles. On November 9, 1998. Beloved father, grandfather and great-grandfather. Memorial service Saturday, November 21 at 11:30AM, The Red Barn, Westport, Conn.

title: The Cisco Whiz Kid; Young Deal Maker Is Force Behind Company's Growth
description: When top executives of Lightspeed International, a maker of software to manage voice transmission over data networks, walked into the headquarters of Cisco Systems Inc. last December, they were expecting to discuss a deal to let Cisco license two of the company's products.

title: Sports of The Times; Bonilla, Belle and Now What?
description: AT the news conference at Shea Stadium yesterday announcing his second coming as a Met, Bobby Bonilla remarked that, well, yes, controversy ''seems to follow me; I don't know why.'' Oh, someone asked, kind of like Albert Belle? For Albert Belle, the knight errant of the White Sox, has, strangely enough, been on the minds of New York baseball fans of late.

title: LIBRARY/COLLEGE-SELECTION GUIDES; CD-ROM's For Searches On a Budget
description: PETERSON'S COLLEGE QUEST PERSONAL EDITION(Peterson's Interactive; $24.95; bundled with ''Peterson's 4-Year Colleges''; Windows 3.1 and higher and NT, and Mac 7.0 and up.)

title: Monitors Get Skinnier, And a Phone for Your Tie
description: The Comdex trade show is the largest gathering of computer buyers and sellers in North America. In an annual ritual that dates to the earliest days of the personal computer industry, more than 200,000 people are gathered here in the desert to see the latest technologies put on display by hundreds of companies.

title: Member of Mohegan Tribe Sues U.S. for Liberty Island
description: For years, Timothy J. Stoddard has tried to be noticed in his campaign for American Indian rights. A member of the Mohegan tribe, he and other American Indians sought to celebrate tribal prayer and water ceremonies last year on Liberty Island, home to the Statue of Liberty, but Federal authorities prevented the news media from filming the Indians.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Big shareholders sold off Coca-Cola Enterprises stock, just as the company was buying it.
description: WHILE much of America spent its summer vacation lying on the beach or relaxing on a mountaintop, some key shareholders of Coca-Cola Enterprises spent theirs in a flurry of trading on the stock exchange.

title: The Big City; Private Profit: Could It Save Public Transit?
description: SUBWAY trains are running erratically, stations are dirty, buses are packed -- and Gene Russianoff has been very busy. The city's most quoted ''passengers' advocate'' has blitzed the subways with advertisements, lined up support from politicians and planned a little street theater for Monday's board meeting of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. A demonstrator in a turkey costume will urge the M.T.A. not to gobble up the budget surplus.

title: Black Sergeants Sent to Troubled Precinct Sue
description: More than a year after Police Commissioner Howard Safir announced that he would put more black officers into the Brooklyn police precinct where prosecutors charge Abner Louima was beaten and sodomized, two black sergeants transferred there have filed a Federal suit alleging that the move violated their civil rights.

title: As the Battery Goes, So Goes the. . . .
description: YOU'RE on a cross-country flight and your tray table is a nest of spreadsheets and scribbled notes, raw material for a due-yesterday report that you are banging out on your laptop computer. Then, somewhere over Ohio, the computer's batteries give out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOBEL, SHELDON
description: LOBEL-Sheldon. President and Co-Founder of Lobel Chemical Corporation. Pioneer in the international sales & marketing of American chemicals and related equipment. Master communicator. Shelly worked tirelessly for 44 years despite continual sickness since the early 1970's. His work ethic and indomitable spirit are inspiring. People all over the globe mourn his death. We miss him, and we are grateful. Lobel Chemical Coporation, New York

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Kung Fu Show Adds Star, Hoping For a Hit
description: ''Martial Law,'' a cartoonish kung fu series on CBS, has been one of the odder and more successful experiments on network television this fall, but now it is embarking on yet another experiment that speaks volumes about the immense pressures on the networks to conjure up hits: the show is undergoing the sort of midseason surgery previously reserved for dying shows, by adding the onetime talk show host Arsenio Hall as the co-star.

title: THE REPUBLICAN TRANSITION: MAN IN THE NEWS -- Julius Caesar Watts Jr.; A Republican of Many Firsts and Yet a Team Player
description: Representative J. C. Watts Jr. was in an expansive mood today, his 41st birthday, after being elected chairman of the Republican Conference and promising to put ''feet and words and message'' to his party's policies.

title: Davis Receives Little Interest
description: The free-agent outfielder Eric Davis said he is not a priority for the Baltimore Orioles, and has resigned himself to the possibility of playing elsewhere in 1999.

title: A Bronx Crew Puts Its Oars In the Water; Teen-Agers Build a Boat To Escape the Gritty City
description: As Craig Salazar walked into the basement, his face betrayed his pain. He was worried about his grandmother, who was gravely ill in the hospital, and annoyed that he had got himself suspended from school for fighting.

title: Alice McDermott Wins a Top Award for Fiction
description: Alice McDermott, the author of ''Charming Billy,'' a quiet novel about Irish-Americans and the way a lost love can continue to haunt a life, was the surprise winner of the National Book Award for fiction last night. The novel came up from behind Tom Wolfe's '' A Man in Full'' (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), a big, muscular book about race and real estate in the New South, which had seemed like a certain winner. It also beat another strong contender, ''Damascus Gate'' (Houghton Mifflin) by Robert Stone, the story of a conspiracy to blow up the Temple Mount in Jerusalem.

title: Guggenheim Plans a Branch At the Hudson
description: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum is quietly developing plans for a large new branch to be designed by the Los Angeles architect Frank Gehry and built at the Hudson River on Pier 40 off Houston Street, said people who were consulted on the project.

title: Executive Changes
description: SEAGRAM CO., New York, said Joseph W. Farrelly would become senior vice president and chief information officer.

title: Bikes, Boats and Scuba: A Taste of Home for U.S. Troops in Kuwait
description: Only a few American soldiers actually landed here before President Clinton called off air strikes against Iraq last weekend. Most of them are going home soon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EWBANK, WEEB
description: EWBANK-Weeb. The New York Jets have lost a great coach, a great mentor and a great friend. Weeb symbolized the best tradition and commitment and sportsmanship sought and admired in professional sports. His inspirational motivation and extraordinary management skills produced the unique record of winning championships in two leagues, and winning the hearts of everyone fortunate to have been associated with him over a 92 year lifetime. Leon Hess, Chairman

title: Immunity at U.N. Covers Divorce, Ex-Wives Find
description: They are mothers and grandmothers from Africa, Europe, Asia and the United States, now scattered throughout New York, and every month they meet in a First Avenue conference room across from the United Nations. They call themselves the United Nations Family Rights Committee, but one woman says ''the dumped wives club'' is more accurate.

title: THE REPUBLICAN TRANSITION: MAN IN THE NEWS -- Richard Keith Armey; Ideologue With Swagger
description: The House majority leader, Richard K. Armey, a man from North Dakota with Texas in his swagger, cannot help indulging in a hokey fishing tale or two when he is in a cheery mood. But seldom do they blossom into allegory.

title: Judicial Protection of Civil Rights; Delays in Parade Permits
description: People who hold views unpopular with Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and his administration routinely have to go to court to win the right to hold marches in New York City. This week a Federal District Court judge struck down the city's parade permit law as unconstitutional. Judge Leonard Sand found that the law violated First Amendment rights because it sets no time limits on when the Police Department must act on a permit request.

title: Farewell to Ewbank: Vignettes of a True Coach and Friend
description: John Schmitt, the Jets' center when they won Super Bowl III in 1969, recalled how his former coach and general manager took a chance on him when no one else was interested and eventually surprised him with a contract bonus.

title: The Republican Leaders Cast Off
description: The first appearance of the new House Republican leaders yesterday suggested that the party has incorporated all the easy parts of the message the public sent in the Nov. 3 elections. ''Teamwork'' and ''unity'' were the words of the day. There was no mention of the social issues so dear to the hearts of the party's right wing, and there were many nods to the importance of Social Security and health care. Representative Robert Livingston, who will be the new Speaker, announced that he regarded the party not as a ''big tent'' but a ''big ship'' that keeps moving steadily on course even when, on its decks, the crew is going in all different directions.

title: Citing Racism, Workers File Suit Against Huntington
description: Thirty-two current and former employees of the Town of Huntington filed a sweeping discrimination lawsuit against the town today, saying that officials fired minority workers without redress, refused to promote blacks and Hispanics to supervisory roles, and did nothing to eliminate a hostile working environment.

title: ELSCINT TO SELL UNIT TO GE MEDICAL FOR $100 MILLION
description: Elscint Ltd. agreed yesterday to sell its diagnostic imaging unit for $100 million to a General Electric Company medical-systems subsidiary as it sheds established technologies. Elscint, a subsidiary of Elbit Medical Imaging Ltd., is selling off business units to concentrate on guided-image therapy, which uses electronic imaging for treatment. The buyer, GE Medical, is the world's biggest maker of computer X-ray and magnetic-resonance imaging machines. Earlier this week Elscint, based in Haifi, Israel, agreed to sell its computer-tomography division for $269.5 million to Picker International Inc., a unit of the London-based General Electric Company P.L.C., which is not related to the General Electric in the latest deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIT, DUDLEY
description: FEIT-Dudley. The Israel and Fennie Feit Foundation mourn the irreplaceable loss of our President, devoted husband of Hattie, beloved brother of Herbert. Loving father of Elliot and Nikki, Joseph and Surella, adored grandfather of Laurie and Zvi Adler, Alison and Jordan Mann, Neal, Jeremy, Rebecca and Jeffrey. Great-grandfather of Tuvia and Elisheva Adler. May his memory be a blessing to all Klal Yisroel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MARION WOLFF
description: COHEN-Marion Wolff, in her 99th year, on November 18, 1998, of Sarasota, Florida, formerly of Cedarhurst, NY. Beloved wife of the late Jerome J. Cohen, loving mother of Florence and Aaron Steiger, Lois and Charles Imershein and Ron and Joan Cohen, adored grandmother and great-grandmother of nine grandchildren and thirteen great - grandchildren. Funeral Friday, November 20, 12PM at Temple Sinai, 131 Washington Avenue, Lawrence, NY. Donations can be made to Hospice of Southwest Florida, 5955 Rand Blvd., Sarasota, FL 34238 or the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISMAN, MARTIN L.
description: EISMAN-Martin L., on November 18, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Jan (nee Klein). Loving father of Valerie. Dear brother of Arthur and Susan. Cherished brother-inlaw of Joan and Bob Nadel. Devoted grandfather of Jenna and Emily. Memorial service will be held Friday, 11AM at Temple Israel, New Rochelle, New York.

title: Finessing the Right Way Leads to a Bermuda Bowl
description: The oldest world championship competition is the Bermuda Bowl, which dates to 1950. A fascinating account of some of the history is provided in a memoir by one of the best American players, John Swanson. It is called ''Inside the Bermuda Bowl'' and is available for $18.90, including mailing, from The Bridge World, (800) 599-0033.

title: Judicial Protection of Civil Rights; Vague Waiver in Labor Contracts
description: When one of the Supreme Court's most conservative members, Justice Antonin Scalia, writes a decision strengthening civil rights enforcement, it is worth taking note. It happened this week in a closely watched discrimination case from South Carolina.

title: Guilty Pleas in Fraud and Pyramid Scheme
description: Three officials of a small Millburn, N.J., brokerage firm pleaded guilty today to a securities fraud and pyramid scheme that bilked more than 7,000 people of more than $120 million during a 10-year period.

title: Corrections
description: A brief listing of restaurants and their hours in the Dining section yesterday, with an article about Thanksgiving on the Eastern Shore of Chesapeake Bay, misstated the location of Eastville Manor. It is in Virginia, not Maryland.

title: Wheels for Sipowicz?
description: FOR all of their diversity, the streetscapes of New York City can be boiled down to a few representative elements: a yellow cab, a hot dog stand and a steaming manhole cover. Throw in a light-blue and white police car, and the location is fixed beyond all doubt. Only in New York, kids, only in New York.

title: LIBRARY/COLLEGE-SELECTION GUIDES; For Scholarship Advice, Web Can Be Helpful or Treacherous
description: WWW.COLLEGEBOARD.COMWWW.FAFSA.ED.GOVATWWW.ED.GOV/OFFICES/ OPE/STUDENTS

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: As Congress Weighs Impeachment; Defining Perjury
description: To the Editor:

title: Living Boldly on the Event Horizon
description: NO matter how many rooms or closets you have in the house, there is seldom enough space for time. That's one reason why architecture continues to evolve. Architects have but a brief interval to greet the present before time slips away.

title: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE COUNSEL -- 3 Men Who Will Query Starr; Abbe David Lowell
description: Abbe David Lowell, the chief lawyer for the Democrats on the Judiciary Committee, is a Washington insider with a firm grasp of Congress and politics. He built his reputation defending Democratic politicians like former Speaker Jim Wright of Texas, who resigned in 1989 amid accusations of ethical violations.

title: Kraft Family Adds the Clash
description: The Kraft family, owners of the New England Patriots football team and the New England Revolution soccer team, is set to add the San Jose Clash soccer team of Major League Soccer to its lineup.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Tuesday with a front-page article about perjury cases in state and Federal courts showed incorrect figures in some editions for felony prosecutions in California from 1993 to 1997. The numbers were duplicates of those for Federal prosecutions for major offenses. The correct numbers for prosecutions in California are 326,768 in 1997, 328,168 in 1996, 345,125 in 1995, 342,321 in 1994 and 345,469 in 1993.

title: Foes of Mahathir See U.S. Misstep : Clinton Exhorts Asia To Pursue Reforms
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Opposition politicians said Wednesday that Vice President Al Gore's speech here supporting political reform in Malaysia had hurt their cause and strengthened Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad's rule.

title: Tripp's Last Tape
description: Office of the Independent Counsel

title: South Africa Goes Shopping for $5 Billion Worth of Weapons
description: Seeking to upgrade its aging military hardware, South Africa announced today that it would spend about $5 billion to buy warships, submarines, helicopters and jets from Britain, Germany, Sweden and Italy.

title: Gullible, Gullible: Arrests in Turkey Ploy
description: When it comes to crime, investigators say, one of the most common motives is pure greed, the desire to get something for nothing. So when the police came upon a list of people wanted for insurance fraud, they decided to lay a trap for them playing on that simple desire.

title: Shedding Light on Immigrant Folk Art
description: MINISERIES and documentaries have long explored the immigrant experience in the United States. But few if any scholars have addressed the connection between immigration and America's esthetic history. Luckily, until they do, there is the Fall Antiques Show. Opening today at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue (67th Street), and running through Sunday, this 20th annual exhibition of America's top dealers in rustic antiques and folk art sheds new light on a dim corner in the history of American decorative arts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASTERNACK, RACHEL
description: PASTERNACK-Rachel. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Devoted mother of Stanley Pasternack, Mayda Podell and the late Roy. Adored grandmother. Services Thursday, 12 noon, at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers.

title: Wild One, or Mild One: Whom Will Yanks Sign?
description: Most baseball decisions are based on numbers -- productivity, home runs, runs batted in. But amateur psychology has played a large role in the Yankees' decision to pursue the volatile slugger Albert Belle.

title: As Congress Weighs Impeachment; Monica's Media Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a Federal court order that stops Microsoft from shipping its own version of Sun Microsystems' Java programming language misstated the year the companies signed a licensing agreement at issue in their dispute. It was March 1996, not 1995.

title: Mets Re-sign Cook; Surhoff Could Be Next
description: Mets Manager Bobby Valentine wanted Dennis Cook back. And the Mets seem serious about signing B. J. Surhoff, too. Yesterday, Valentine got his wish when Cook, 36, agreed to terms with the Mets for $6.6 million over three years.

title: Public Barred From Hearing Murder-Case Details
description: A New Jersey judge barred the public and the news media today from hearing details of a suspect's statement in the ambush and murder of two pizza deliverymen at an abandoned house 19 months ago.

title: Perry H. Young Jr., 79, Pioneering Pilot, Dies
description: Perry H. Young Jr., an aviator whose career spanned more than 50 years and who was the first African-American pilot for a commercial airline in the United States, died on Nov. 8 at the Horton Medical Center in Middletown, N.Y. He was 79.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGRATH, ANNE ROGAN
description: McGRATH-Anne Rogan. 63. Of Hampton Bays, NY formerly of Chappaqua, NY at home after a long battle with cancer. Devoted wife of Dr. Terence J. McGrath and loving mother of Dr. Sarah McGee of Sturbridge, MA, Kathleen Dunn of New Rochelle, NY, Mary Donovan of Tullahoma, TN, and Maureen Svoboda of Lawrenceville, NJ. Cherished grandmother of eleven grandchildren. She is also survived by three sisters and two brothers: Sheila Raymond of Riverside, CT, Janet Pedlow of Chappaqua, NY, Elizabeth Brennan of Eastchester, NY, John Rogan of Overland Park, KS and Peter Rogan of Valparaiso, IN and 36 nieces and nephews. She will be remembered for her unwavering faith, wise counsel, fun-loving nature and courageous spirit. Reposing at Beecher Funeral Home, 418 Bedford Road, Pleasantville, NY on Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Friday, Nov. 20th At 10 AM at St. John and St. Mary, Chappaqua, NY. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Rosary Hill Home, 600 Linda Ave, Hawthorne, NY 10532 or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Surgical Metabolic Research Fund, P.O. Box E, 1275 York Avenue, NY, NY 10021.

title: VERIO LOWERS HIWAY TECHNOLOGIES BID TO $257.2 MILLION
description: Verio Inc., the Internet service provider, said yesterday that it would pay $257.2 million in cash and stock for Hiway Technologies under an agreement revised after a 37 percent drop in Verio's share price. Verio, based in Englewood, Colo., agreed in July to buy Hiway, which runs Web pages for companies, for $329 million. Verio has now increased the cash portion of the agreement to $176 million from $101 million, but decreased the number of common shares it will pay to 4.92 million from 8.67 million. Verio had an initial stock offering in May at $23 a share. It closed yesterday at $16.50, up 31.25 cents.

title: Fassel Found Kanell Lost His Composure
description: Early Monday morning, hours after his team's 37-3 loss to the Green Bay Packers, Giants Coach Jim Fassel examined the tape of the game in his office, staring soberly at the image of Danny Kanell. He knew Kanell had not played well, but he was looking for signs that Kanell was still seeing the field properly, still thinking, still in control.

title: A Night for Happy Feet And Happier Tummies
description: Just in case the sexy beats and rowdy antics didn't get every last person in Wetlands dancing on Sunday night, Digital Underground had plenty of gimmicks. The veteran hip-hop group's comic and musical mastermind, Shock G, and his mates tossed out ''party packs'' -- sandwich bags full of potato chips, breath mints, noisemakers and condoms -- during the anthem to earthly pleasure, ''Doowutchyalike.'' Then members showered everyone with Silly String and movie-theater popcorn. Free beer was offered from a cooler onstage. It was chaos as usual for this crew.

title: As Army Bows Its Head, Jakarta's Students Grieve
description: Jakarta belonged to the students today as traffic stopped and security forces fell back to allow two large processions to mourn 16 students killed by gunfire last week.

title: Two Dozen Pupils Hurt In School Bus Collision
description: A crowded school bus carrying 40 middle-school students in Yonkers careered out of control yesterday afternoon, bumping into another school bus and crashing into a fence, injuring most of the students.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTLER, MARION
description: BUTLER-Marion. The Women's Committee and Trustees of Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club mourn the passing of our long-time friend and women extraordinaire, Marion Butler. She will be sorely missed.

title: Feminist's Centennial
description: Before Betty Friedan, before Gloria Steinem, before Kate Millett, there was Millicent Carey McIntosh -- a feminist role model for women in the 1940's and 50's who wanted to combine family and career.

title: Grant Lifts Red Storm Into N.I.T. Semifinals
description: By the time the lights went out for the player introductions last night at Alumni Hall, Erick Barkley had been through this routine in two exhibition games and the regular-season opener. But as he stood on the floor greeting his teammates, he never stopped moving, jumping and fidgeting like a student before a big exam.

title: Big Board Firms Report Losses
description: Member firms of the New York Stock Exchange lost $117 million in the third quarter, down from a profit of $2.18 billion in the period a year earlier, according to a report yesterday from the exchange.

title: Demand Is Heavy for Offering by Argentina
description: Argentina raised $1 billion in seven-year debt yesterday, extending a bond-sale binge as interest rates fall and concerns ease over a financial calamity in neighboring Brazil.

title: As New Mexico Courts Spain, Both Sides Are Hoping to Profit
description: Four hundred years after Spain conquered New Mexico, the state this week sent its first trade mission here, along with American Indian religious dancers, to show there are no hard feelings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, ELLIOT
description: BARNETT-Elliot. The Congregation of The Community Synagogue in Port Washington, NY, notes with sorrow the passing of its member and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Funeral service at the Synagogue on Friday, Nov. 20, at 12:45 PM.

title: Starr to Accuse President Of Obstructing His Inquiries
description: Kenneth W. Starr will insist in the House impeachment hearing on Thursday that President Clinton abused his power to cover up his affair with Monica S. Lewinsky and time and again put up an array of ''roadblocks and hurdles'' that slowed the prosecutor's other investigations.

title: U.S. Agency Faults Hospital On Emergency Care Delays
description: Federal regulators have cited the Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn for serious flaws in how it decides who should receive emergency care and for treatment delays that may have jeopardized the health of some patients, according to a document released yesterday.

title: If You Can't Get Enough Talk, Tune Into New Internet Shows
description: Talk shows are undeniably successful staples of television and radio. So it's not surprising that Talkspot is attempting to adapt the format for the Web. Talkspot (www.talkspot.com), following the lead of Web-based audio services offering music, has four channels aimed at different tastes that are delivered using Real Audio.

title: Doubts Among Republicans
description: A small but growing number of House Republicans say they would vote against impeachment, barring new information. Page A32.

title: Younger Gotti Asks U.S. To Free His Property
description: John A. Gotti appeared in Federal court yesterday while his lawyers argued that the Government should release his assets, including his house, other properties and $358,000 in cash that he contends came from wedding presents.

title: Smart Thermometers Make Life Easier for Sick and Squirmy
description: IN the late 1800's, if a patient was thought to have a fever, a nurse or doctor might well have wedged a mercury thermometer a foot and a half long into the patient's armpit and waited. And waited.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, RAYMOND S.
description: BARON-Raymond S. The Officers and Directors of the Helen Matchette DeMario Foundation mourn the loss of our co-director, friend and colleague Raymond S. Baron. His dedication and decency will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest sympathy and condolences to his dear friend and companion, Midge Grant, his children, Ronnie and Fred Hirsh, and Margaret and Richard Baron, his grandchildren, and all his family.

title: Footlights; NEWS
description: Southern Cooking

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KISSINGER, PAULA
description: KISSINGER-Paula. The Board of Directors of the Lauri Strauss Leukemia Foundation expresses profound sorrow to our Honorary Board Member and Founder of the Ambassador Felix Schnyder Memorial Fund,Mr. Walter B. Kissinger and his brother Henry and their families on the passing of their beloved mother and grandmother. She was a truly remarkable lady. The Board of Directors, Donald E. Bindler, Chairman Sigrid Schnyder Evelyn I. Strauss Herbert H. Strauss

title: All Choked Up By Smoking Statistics
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Loyal and Game but Slowed, Graves May Be Near the End as a Ranger
description: Just up from the minor leagues and hoping to make a good impression, Marc Savard of the Rangers skated with energy and ambition early in the first period last week on the road against Tampa Bay. Aiming to discourage him, Enrico Ciccone of the Lightning charged toward Savard and elbowed his helmeted head against the glass above the boards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANZIG, FRIEDA
description: DANZIG-Frieda. 88. Born in Lithuania, beloved wife of the late Abraham, loving mother of Michael and Norman, mother-in-law of Roberta and Gail, grandmother of Jennifer, Sarah and Esther. Graveside services Thursday, November 19 at 11A.M. Cedar Park Cemetery, New Jersey.

title: As Congress Weighs Impeachment; No Match for Clinton
description: To the Editor:

title: At Long Last, Expanding Spain's Treasure Chest
description: The Government finally unveiled the winning design for the most controversial part of the long-delayed expansion of the Prado Museum, but on the day of the announcement last week, the winner, Rafael Moneo, was out of town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOPHER, MORRIS
description: SOPHER-Morris. The Yeshiva of Telshe Alumni and the Time For Torah Fellowship mark with sorrow the loss of our dear friend, Mr. Morris Sopher of blessed memory. Husband of Mrs. Marilyn Sopher, father of dear children Jonathan, Barbara and Lisa. His elegance and class, as well as his infectious smile, will long be remembered. His devotion to Torah study and his dedication to Torah causes are a legacy that he bequeathed to all of us and shall never be forgotten. To his beloved family, may you be comforted and spared from further sorrow. Harav Avrohom Ausband, Rosh Ha Yeshiva Rabbi Eli Melech Kohn Mr. Edward Chernoff, Chairman

title: News Analysis; In Livent's Bankruptcy, a Cautionary Tale for Broadway
description: Given its financial predicament, filing for bankruptcy protection -- a step taken yesterday after much agonizing -- may in some ways be the best thing that could have happened to Livent Inc. With a mountain of debt, its stock frozen and shareholders clamoring for redress, Chapter 11 reorganization buys the troubled company behind the musical ''Ragtime'' breathing space to try to get its house in order and keep its creditors at bay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EBER, JEANE
description: EBER-Jeane. On Tuesday November 17, 1998 (nee Shaker) of Boynton Beach, Florida. Beloved wife of Mortimer Eber. Devoted mother of Barbara Eber-Schmid and Richard Eber. Dear sister of Burton Shaker and Anne Robinson, loving grandmother of Noah Eber-Schmid, Michael and David Eber. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road Union, NJ on Friday November 20, 1998 at 11:30 AM. Interment King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, NJ.

title: After 3 Centuries, A Comedy Remains Up to the Minute
description: A dinner party at Harpagon's house probably wouldn't be a good time. Preparing for such a gathering in Act II of ''The Miser,'' he instructs one servant to pour the wine ''but only when people are thirsty'' -- that is, when ''they have asked several times.'' And, he adds, put water in it. As for the food: ''Prepare for 8,'' he tells the cook, ''and there's always plenty for 10.''

title: Livent Moves to a New Stage: Bankruptcy
description: Livent Inc., the Broadway theater company, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday, less than six months after Michael Ovitz, once widely considered the most powerful person in Hollywood, took over the company.

title: Credit Lyonnais Plan Wins First Approval
description: Credit Lyonnais S.A. won European Union approval yesterday to pay off its debt to the French Government in a lump sum instead of handing over a percentage of its profits for 16 years, in a first step toward its sale to private investors next year. France's fourth-largest bank agreed in 1995 to return up to 34 percent of its profits to the state until 2014. The state-owned bank now wants to buy back this obligation by issuing new shares to the state.

title: Economic Scene; There are wise and less wise ways to control cheap imports.
description: ASIAN, Latin American and Russian imports are pouring into the United States, trapping the Administration in an embarrassing trade hypocrisy.

title: BENEFITS
description: Music of Gershwin

title: MONY UNIT TO BUY U.S. FINANCIAL LIFE FOR $48 MILLION
description: The U.S. Financial Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the Mony Life Insurance Company, a unit of Mony Group Inc., for $48 million. Mony Group, based in New York, is a financial services provider with $23.6 billion in managed assets. U.S. Financial Life, based in Cincinnati, is a special-risk life insurance carrier with $150 million in assets and operations in 41 states. The acquisition gives Mony Life access to U.S. Financial Life's relationships with 205 brokerage general agencies.

title: Footwear Campaign To Saatchi & Saatchi
description: Just For Feet Inc., the athletic footwear retailer in Birmingham, Ala., has named the Rochester office of Saatchi & Saatchi as the first agency to handle advertising for a national branding campaign, with billings estimated at $25 million to $30 million.

title: Ex-Officer Is Charged With Abusing a Boy
description: A former school security officer was arrested yesterday after an 8-year-old boy complained that the man groped him as he was leaving an elementary school in Brooklyn a year and a half ago, the police said.

title: FIRST AMERICAN IN $111 MILLION DEAL FOR DATA COMPANY
description: The First American Financial Corporation, a provider of title insurance, agreed yesterday to acquire National Information Group for $111 million in stock. Investors will get 0.67 of a First American share for each National Information share, or $23.32 based on the closing price of First American shares on Tuesday. Shares of National Information, which provides interactive data management and underwriting services, surged 62 percent, gaining $7.25 each, to $18.875. First American, based in Santa, Ana, Calif., will issue about 3.2 million new shares to make the purchase. Its shares fell $1.5625 each, to $33.25, but is still more than double its 52-week low of less than $13.50 a share. First American, based in South San Francisco, Calif., provides real estate tax services and determines if properties are in flood-prone areas.

title: Sales Slide 4% At Drug Maker
description: Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C., the world's second-largest drug maker, said today that its 1998 sales through Oct. 31 fell 4 percent, within market forecasts, as increased sales of asthma drugs failed to offset slowing growth in sales of drugs for AIDS and migraines.

title: Even U.S. Sees Iraq Opposition As Faint Hope
description: The Clinton Administration, committed to renewed support for Iraqi dissidents, finds the opposition groups so weak and divided and penetrated by Iraqi agents that it is uncertain how to form a united front capable of toppling Saddam Hussein.

title: 'Butterfly' From Upstate, Staged Strikingly
description: The cooperative arrangement between the Glimmerglass Opera and the New York City Opera whereby new productions are first tried out at the Cooperstown, N.Y., summer company and then brought to New York makes a lot of sense. But sometimes productions that seemed ideally suited to the 900-seat Glimmerglass house have looked a bit lost in the 2,730-seat New York State Theater.

title: Sorenstam Is Swinging for a Triple Crown
description: Annika Sorenstam has a simple goal this week. She wants to end another great season with another impressive victory.

title: Australians Take Part In a Shower of Strauss
description: Is it related to the shower of Leonid meteors, this odd confluence of dubious works by Richard Strauss? Edo de Waart and the Sydney Symphony Orchestra presented the ''Symphonia Domestica'' at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening, a day before Christian Thielemann and the New York Philharmonic were to begin a run of performances of the ''Alpine Symphony'' at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Esther Rolle, 78, Who Played Feisty Maid and Matriarch
description: Esther Rolle, a pioneering African-American actress who gained national recognition in the 1970's for her role as Florida Evans on two television shows, first ''Maude'' and then ''Good Times,'' died at a hospital here on Tuesday. She was 78 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Microsoft Says I.B.M. Tried To Enlist Rivals in Collusion
description: In a series of attacks in Federal court today, the Microsoft Corporation accused I.B.M. of engaging in many of the same practices that led the Federal Government and 20 states to file antitrust charges against Microsoft.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRINE, RUTH
description: BRINE-Ruth, 1919-1998. Memorial service Thursday, November 19 at 6 PM, New York University, Fales Library, 3rd Floor, Bobst Library and Study Center, 70 Washington Square South.

title: Q & A
description: Q. What does it mean to partition a hard drive? Is it advisable to do so?

title: Co-op Tales: Naked Came the Cowboy
description: WHEN you're president of a co-op board, the complaints just flood in. ''It's always the little stuff, like the complaint last week about a guy who goes out in the hall every morning to get his paper -- wearing nothing but a cowboy hat,'' said Sylvia Shapiro, board president, lawyer and author of ''The Co-op Bible'' (St. Martin's Press), a new book subtitled ''Getting In, Staying In, Surviving, Thriving.''

title: Vermont Supreme Court Takes Up Gay Marriage
description: When Nina Beck went into labor and frightening complications developed, her lesbian partner, Stacy Jolles, tried to go into the emergency room with her. But she was stopped at the door, she said, and asked, ''Who are you? Do you have legal papers to be there?''

title: Eddie Elias, 69, Sports Agent And Founder of Pro Bowling
description: Eddie Elias, a lawyer who founded the Professional Bowlers Association in 1958 and later represented sports and entertainment celebrities, died on Sunday at Naples (Fla.) Community Hospital. He was 69.

title: Euro Disney Profit Up Despite Visitor Decline
description: Euro Disney S.A., Europe's largest theme park, said yesterday that its net income rose 34 percent in the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30, as increased spending and greater hotel occupancy helped to offset a slight decline in the number of visitors. Euro Disney said its profit rose to 290 million francs ($51.62 million) from 217 million francs a year earlier. Sales rose 7.5 percent, to 5.89 billion francs.

title: The Trials of Tech Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Voice Recognition and Other Advances
description: Asia Remains Strong Market for Technology, Despite the Downturn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSCHILD, RHONA S.
description: ROTHSCHILD-Rhona S. Passed away on November 17, 1998, at the untimely age of 52. She leaves behind her husband, Jay, son, Jared, daughter, Jordana Sontag, son-inlaw Richard Sontag, and grandson, Jacob Sontag. She will be always be remembered as a devoted and dedicated mother and grandmother, and as a person who unselfishly gave to others. Her family, friends, and pets will miss her dearly. Funeral services 1 P.M. Thursday November 19th at Riverside Nassau North Chapel in Great Neck. In recognition of her passing, the family requests donations to be sent to The Canavan Research Fund, 16 School Street, Rye, NY 10580.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDRON, ROBERT E.
description: WALDRON-Robert E. Age 67. On Nov. 15th, 1998. CEO of Waldron Associates Ltd. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Father of Eric, Clifford, Robert E. Jr. and Susanne. Grandfather of six. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, on Thursday from 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. with service Friday, at 11:30 A.M. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: As Congress Weighs Impeachment; Legal Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: H.M.O. Fiscal Incentives Linked to Doctors' Discontent
description: Many California doctors say the bonuses and other financial incentives that managed care organizations give them for speeding up office visits and restricting care compromise the quality of care, according to a survey of doctors reported in The New England Journal of Medicine today.

title: Accounts
description: * The Sonesta International Hotels Corp., Boston, to Irma S. Mann Strategic Marketing Inc., Boston, to handle advertising for its Sonesta International Hotels, Resorts and Nile Cruises unit, which had been handled in-house. Billings were estimated at $6 million.

title: Flight Crews Cancel Strikes Against Japanese Airlines
description: Pilots and flight attendants at Japan Airlines, Japan's biggest airline, and the Japan Air System Company, the nation's third-biggest airline, canceled symbolic one-day strikes today, though JAL employees failed to reach agreement with the company over a pay dispute.

title: Bush Brothers Provide Light to Republicans After a Dreary Election
description: In their debut appearance as heirs to the latest American political dynasty, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and his younger brother Gov.-elect Jeb Bush of Florida today stepped forward as models for what they described as a new ''compassionate conservatism.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAGRANGE, ISAAC
description: LaGRANGE-Isaac. On November 18, 1998 in his 96th year. Beloved husband of the Late Frances W. LaGrange. Loving father of Suzanne Ragland, John and Robert. Devoted Grandfather of seven and Great Grandfather of seven. Mr. LaGrange was the son of Isaac & Annie Fix LaGrange of Albany, N.Y. A graduate from Colgate in 1924, a member of Sigma NU Fraternity, a member of the Empire State Society of the Sons of the American Revolution. Mr. LaGrange lived in White Plains for 40 years and retired as an Officer of the Manufactures Hanover Bank, New York City after 42 years and moved to Stony Brook, L.I. in 1996 where he passed away at home. Reposing at the O.B. Davis Funeral Home, 4839 Nesconset Hwy, Port Jefferson Sta. L.I. Visitation Friday 2-4 PM & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass 9:45 AM Saturday at St. James RC Church, Interment Albany Rural Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHN, LEONORE
description: KOHN-Leonore. Beloved wife of Julius Kohn for 66 years. Loving mother of Barbara and Peter Brumberg and Deb and Dave Kohn, loving grandmother of six and devoted great-grandmother of six. Devoted sister-in-law. Services Thurs., November 19, 10AM at Temple Shalom in New Milford, CT. Graveside services at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island at 1:30PM. Visitation Thurs. to Sat. at daughters home. Sunday afternoon To Wednesday in CT.

title: Calendar; The Migrations of Style
description: Fashion Inspirations

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORN, MRS. RICHARD KAYE
description: KORN-Mrs. Richard Kaye. We mourn the loss of Peggy Korn, our Honorary Board Member and Past Board President. Peggy was one of a kind: smart, involved, cultured, and opinionated. She also cared a great deal about those in need, as exemplified by her long involvement with our social service organization. We will miss her and can't imagine that another like her will come along again anytime soon. Diana R. Quasha, President Nancy Wackstein, Exec Dir. Lenox Hill Neighborhood House

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Microsoft Accuses I.B.M. Of Attempted Collusion

title: She Loves Him Until She Hates Him Again
description: Max Ferra, the artistic director of Intar Hispanic American Arts Center, pays a nice tribute to Federico Garcia Lorca by including his 1929 farce, ''The Shoemaker's Prodigious Wife,'' on a bill of three works marking the playwright's centenary. Its 90 minutes of laughter is unexpected from a man usually associated with tragedy onstage and in life.

title: Paying for Mideast Plan, U.S. Walks Tightrope
description: President Clinton is promising Israel and the Palestinian Authority to pick up much of the bill for their new land-for-security plan. But buying peace will not be cheap, or easy.

title: A Needle in the Internet Haystack
description: WHEN it comes to homework assignments, the goal in my household is to avoid, at all costs, the diorama.

title: TRITON REVIVES $222 MILLION STOCK-PURCHASE RIGHTS SALE
description: Triton Energy Ltd. is reviving a sale of stock-purchase rights that is related to a plan by the buyout firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. to invest as much as $350 million in Triton. The Dallas-based Triton delayed the $222 million sale last week after starting talks with what it described as a widely known oil company that was interested in investing in Triton. But the talks are not moving quickly enough to justify further delay, Triton said yesterday. The rights offering now has a record date of Nov. 30 and expires on Dec. 22. Under the plan, Triton's shareholders will get the opportunity to buy $222 million in preferred shares that will eventually be converted into common shares. Hicks, Muse will buy any shares not sold in the offering. Triton's shares slipped 12.5 cents, to $9.625.

title: A surprising nonevent from some long and closely watched media services merger talks.
description: A MERGER that would have created a giant media services agency, ranking among the world's three largest, has unexpectedly been called off.

title: On Its Own Turf, It's Microsoft, Right or Wrong
description: Just as President Nixon found support among construction workers during the Vietnam War, it is here in the PC-filled aisles of the Microsoft Partner's Pavilion at the heart of the sprawling Comdex computer trade show that the Microsoft Corporation's besieged chairman, William H. Gates, finds his staunchest supporters.

title: South Africa Sharply Curbs Smoking and Tobacco Advertising
description: A bill to ban smoking in public, outlaw all tobacco advertising and regulate nicotine levels in cigarettes is about to become law here.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: The Real Mango

title: Clinton Says He'll Press Japan to Take Strong Action
description: Leaving Washington for an abbreviated five-day trip to Asia, President Clinton vowed today to press Japan to take ''decisive steps'' to open its markets and revive its economy in hopes of easing the global financial crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENNIS, MARIE JOYCE
description: ENNIS-Marie Joyce, on November 15, 1998. Loving wife of the late Edward J. Ennis. Devoted cousin of Maryiris Elbert and Franklin J. Carman. Memorial Mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84 Street, Friday, November 20, 11 AM.

title: Rangers Begin Trip With a Loss
description: It has become a pattern this season with the Rangers. They play hard, they keep the score low and close. But they lose. Tonight, they fell by 3-1 to the Mighty Ducks of Anaheim.

title: Security Cards on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Unseating Saddam Hussein
description: Weary of endless confrontations with Iraq, President Clinton, Congress and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain are now rallying around the idea of overthrowing Saddam Hussein. The thought is certainly alluring. The installation of a democratic government in Baghdad would probably eliminate the threat of Iraqi aggression. Unfortunately, the only sure way to reach that goal is for American troops to invade Iraq and capture Baghdad, a risky prospect few Americans would support.

title: Corrections
description: The ''Revisions'' column on Monday, about the revival of ragtime, misidentified the movie for which ''The Entertainer,'' by Scott Joplin, was the theme. It was ''The Sting,'' not ''Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid,'' which also starred Paul Newman and Robert Redford.

title: Stepping Back From the Brink With Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Microsoft Plans To Continue Java Support
description: The Microsoft Corporation has decided ''absolutely'' to continue to support the Java programming language in the wake of a ruling on Tuesday in which a Federal judge ordered the company to change its Java software, a Microsoft executive said yesterday.

title: Gonzalez Is Named The M.V.P.
description: The pattern seems apparent: the Yankees win the pennant and Juan Gonzalez captures the most valuable player award.

title: Chris Dundee, 91, a Promoter of Hundreds of Boxing Bouts
description: Chris Dundee, who promoted hundreds of fights and turned Miami Beach into a boxing center in a career that spanned six decades, died at the Miami Jewish Home for the Aged on Monday. He was 91.

title: World Briefs
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUTSHER, MILTON
description: KUTSHER-Milton. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the passing of Milton Kutsher, a long-time supporter of ADL. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Helen, children, and the entire family. Howard P. Berkowitz, National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman, National Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLINN, MARIE E.
description: FLINN-Marie E. On November 17, 1998. She was born in Pittsburgh, PA, and attended Holy Rosary High School and Robert Morris Business School. She worked as an executive secretary for Crucible Steel Company and its successor LTV. She retired from there in 1968 and moved to New York where she worked in the executive offices of DLJ. In 1995 she retired as a secretary to the President and CEO of Donaldson, Lufkin, and Jenrette. She is survived by her brother, Walter L. Flinn, Jr., of Arlington, VA and her sister, Ann Flinn Morris of Pittsburgh, PA and seven nieces and nephews. Family will receive visitors Thursday evening between 7 and 9 p.m. at the Dimiceli & Sons, Inc. Funeral Home, 182 Lex. Ave., NYC. A memorial Mass will be held on Friday at 9:30 a.m. at Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Church, 317 East 33rd St., NYC. Interment will be in the family plot in Pittsburgh.

title: Shopping on the Web? No, Still Just Browsing
description: Americans who let their keyboards do the walking when they go shopping remain a decided minority, two studies have found. Based on a survey of 2,500 households, Odyssey, a marketing company based in San Francisco, estimates that 88 percent of all American households won't buy anything through the Internet this year. Even 57 percent of families with on-line access will pass on cybershopping. ''For all of the hoopla surrounding E-commerce, it is still a retailing method in its infancy,'' said Nick Donatiello, Odyssey's chief executive.

title: Documenting 1900, a Time of Millennial Optimism
description: Because of a production error, this review was omitted from some copies yesterday. The program is to be repeated on Sunday at 1 P.M. on Channel 13 in the New York area.

title: Bartle Bogle Hires Team for New York
description: The new New York office of the British agency Bartle Bogle Hegarty has hired its first creative team: Stephanie Crippen, a copywriter, and Kilpatrick Anderson, an art director.

title: Man Firing Gun on Street Is Shot by Police Officers
description: A 19-year-old man who was firing a gun on an East Harlem street last night was shot four times by police officers after he turned toward them with the gun in his hand, the police said.

title: LIBRARY/COLLEGE-SELECTION GUIDES; Places to Get Started on the Road to College
description: PHILIP MICHAS and Adrian Gamerello are high-school seniors, classmates at the prestigious Browning School, just off Park Avenue in the heart of Manhattan's silk-stocking district. When it came to picking a college to attend next fall, they had the best help money could buy: a highly regarded guidance counselor and high-end computer hardware and software to aid a senior class of only two dozen.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE POUND FALLS. The dollar posted gains against its major counterparts on a report of a smaller-than-expected United States trade deficit. The pound settled at $1.6678, down from $1.6767 late on Tuesday.

title: Robert Popper, 90; Headed Office on Aging
description: Robert Lyman Popper, a retired business executive who was long active in civic affairs and philanthropy, died Tuesday at White Plains Hospital. He was 90 and lived in Armonk, N.Y., and Manhattan.

title: The Magic Is in the Marketing; Theaters Go Around the Critics and Straight to the People
description: ''Flavorless marshmallow of a musical.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYDER, DR. NORMAN
description: SNYDER-Dr. Norman, of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of Long Island, NY. Devoted husband of Natalie. Beloved father of Jonathan and Robert Snyder and Cynthia Bradford. Adored grandfather. Services Friday, 11AM, Menorah Cemetery, West Palm Beach, FL. I.J. Morris, Funeral Directors.

title: LIBRARY/COLLEGE-SELECTION GUIDES; Free Web Sites Help Students Whittle Down Their Choices
description: WWW.COLLEGEBOARD.COMWWW.PETERSONS.COMWWW.COLLEGEVIEW.COM

title: Stepping Back From the Brink With Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Small Sale at Christie's Yields Prices to Match
description: The dealers and collectors who jammed Christie's Park Avenue salesroom last night kept a watchful eye on prices as Impressionist and 19th-century artworks by masters like Monet and Signac, Cezanne and Bonnard, spun around on the turntable. Only when a top-quality work was offered did the room come alive with bidders. Even then, heads remained cool, and only 14 works out of the 43 offered exceeded expectation.

title: 4 Officers Are Indicted in Beating of a Man
description: Four New York City police detectives have been indicted on assault, evidence-tampering or other charges in the beating of a man last year who the authorities say later jumped to his death in front of a Brooklyn subway train, investigators said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary of the theater producer and director Peter Cotes yesterday misstated the date of his death. It was Nov. 10, not this Tuesday.

title: Turks' Anger With Italy Deepens Over Extradition of Rebel Kurd
description: Italy's refusal to extradite a Kurdish rebel wanted by Turkey has soured relations between the normally close allies, and as Government leaders in Rome and Ankara trade angry words, the United States added to the pressure today by calling for extradition of the Kurd, Abdullah Ocalan.

title: Java's Universality Is a Threat to Microsoft
description: Why is Java such a big deal?

title: Hitachi Data to Cut Staff
description: Hitachi Data Systems, owned by the Electronic Data Systems Corporation and Hitachi Ltd. of Japan, said today that it planned to cut its work force by 400 employees. Hitachi Data said the cuts were likely to affect all areas of the company. It attributed the reductions to changes in business conditions and global markets. Hitachi Data, based here, sells high-performance enterprise servers, storage systems and professional services. It employs about 2,750 workers worldwide.

title: Trade Deficit Ebbs, but Asia Toll Is Evident
description: As President Clinton left for Japan today declaring that ''our workers and our farmers pay the price'' for declining American exports to Asia, the Commerce Department reported trade figures suggesting that the price was not rising so quickly as many feared.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Giving section yesterday, about guests who make for successful charity galas, misstated the title of Richard D. Parsons at Time Warner Inc. He is the president, not the chairman.

title: Some Surprise Teams At the Top and Bottom
description: The surprise teams of the young season are Cornell in the Eastern College Athletic Conference, New Hampshire in Hockey East and Notre Dame in the Central Collegiate Hockey Association. All are first-place teams today while perennial titans that have started slowly include Boston University in Hockey East, Ohio State in the C.C.H.A. and Yale, the ECAC's defending regular-season champion.

title: Impeachment Doubts Erode Slim Republican Majority
description: Representative John Edward Porter, an Illinois Republican, is no friend of Bill Clinton. But Mr. Porter, a 10-term moderate, is one of a small though growing number of Republicans who say they will vote against impeaching President Clinton, barring any new information in the inquiry into his conduct.

title: Mix of Old and New Is to Lead House G.O.P.
description: After two weeks of bloodletting over their leadership, House Republicans sent a mixed message today about the image they want to project in the coming 106th Congress: they kept some leaders and threw out others, producing a team with a strong conservative cast that includes the party's first black leader.

title: Campbell Reports 4.8% Rise in Profit
description: The Campbell Soup Company, which makes about 75 percent of the soup sold in the United States, said today that first-quarter profit rose 4.8 percent because of cost cuts and higher-than-expected sales.

title: New York Studios Names Arnell Group
description: New York Studios Inc., which plans to build a high-technology film and television production studio at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, said yesterday that it had named Arnell Group Brand Consulting in New York to handle strategic brand development and marketing communications. Billings were estimated at $1 million for the first year. Arnell was awarded the assignment without a review.

title: Delta Sets 2% Raise For Workers in U.S.
description: Delta Air Lines Inc., the No. 3 carrier in the United States, said today that it would give its 50,000 American employees a 2 percent raise, part of an effort to appease pilots who made pay concessions in a 1994 cost-cutting plan.

title: Chile Prelate Asks Inquiry Into Abuses Of Pinochet
description: As a panel of the House of Lords in London decides the legal fate of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the Chilean Roman Catholic Church is pushing to reopen an investigation into the deaths and disappearances of activists during his regime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERPOINT, POWELL
description: PIERPOINT-Powell. Died on November 17, age 76, in NYC. He is survived by his daughter, Harriett P. Bos, her husband, Gerard A. Bos, and three grandchildren, Pier, Abbie and Evan Bos, all of Charlotte NC. A memorial servce will be held at St.James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue on Monday, November 23 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Andrew's School, Middletown, Delaware or Yale University.

title: 4th Senate Run Is Promised By Lautenberg
description: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, a three-term New Jersey Democrat who was widely thought to be considering retirement, said today that he would run for re-election in 2000, mainly because he believed that the Democrats would regain control of the Senate.

title: OAK TECHNOLOGY CHIEF MAKES $180 MILLION BUYOUT OFFER
description: Oak Technology Inc. said yesterday that it had received an offer to be purchased at $4.50 a share in cash from its chief executive and chairman, David D. Tsang. Based on the company's 40 million shares outstanding, the total price of the offer is $180 million. Oak Technology, the maker of semiconductors and software, said its board would take steps this week to review the offer. The company, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., had revenues of $157.1 million for its 1998 fiscal year. Its stock rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $4.094.

title: Ginkgo Chic: The Feel-Good Hotel
description: THE wellness biz is in strapping good health and growing like a weed -- or rather, a ginkgo tree. These days, invoking the word ''spa,'' with all of its Rorschach associations -- pampering, cleansing, oases, antitoxins and the leaf of that stinky tree -- can rejuvenate everything from shampoos and sheets to forks and furniture. And now the much-anticipated W, a business hotel and spa, is set to open on Dec. 1 within the shell of the modestly drab Doral Inn after an $80 million face lift.

title: A New Computer Microphone Is Able to Double as a Mouse
description: It's handy, it's dandy, and it's at least four tools in one. No, not a new Popeil Pocket Fisherman, but a device for your computer that is a new example of convergence, the morphing of several separate consumer electronic devices into one.

title: Sports of The Times; At St. John's, Manetta Sees Sun Shining In
description: ED MANETTA looked over a sea of empty seats at Alumni Hall yesterday afternoon and admitted that he felt more at ease than at any time in his three-year tenure as St. John's athletic director.

title: School's Dean Protests Treatment of Whitman
description: In a statement to students and faculty members, the dean of Seton Hall Law School has said that he disagreed with the university administration's decision to bar a student-sponsored awards ceremony honoring Gov. Christine Todd Whitman from the campus earlier this week because of her support for abortion rights.

title: Circling the (Station) Wagons
description: JAN and Dean sang its praises, and it was once the chosen method of transportation for summer vacations, tailgate parties and surfing pilgrimages.

title: Stepping Back From the Brink With Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE COUNSEL -- 3 Men Who Will Query Starr; David E. Kendall
description: David E. Kendall, the President's chief private counsel, has waited a long time for an opportunity to confront Mr. Starr. Mr. Kendall, 54, has represented Mr. Clinton in Whitewater matters for nearly five years but has rarely appeared in public to defend the President. His chief weapons have been legal briefs and scathing correspondence to the Office of Independent Counsel.

title: Angst and Anger Japanese-Style, With Wink
description: SHOGO calls to mind the old advertising slogan for Reese's Peanut Butter Cups: Two great tastes that taste great together. Take the game play of a first-person shooter like Unreal or Quake. Add the narrative and esthetic conventions of Japanese animation. Swirl together and voila, a pulse-pounding blast-o-rama with giant robots, huge-eyed heroes, omnipotent corporations and interplanetary war, interwoven with romantic themes and family psychodrama.

title: As Congress Weighs Impeachment; Hubbell's Testimony
description: To the Editor:

title: Youth Tours Won't Save Judaism
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: PALLADIUM UP SHARPLY. Palladium prices rose on continued concerns that Russia will reduce exports next year even as demand grows. In New York, palladium for December delivery rose $11.65, to $292.50 an ounce.

title: Late Surges Bring Wide Gains as Dow Climbs by 54.83
description: Late-session surges drove stocks to broad gains yesterday as investors more thoroughly digested the Federal Reserve's decision the day before to cut interest rates for a third time in seven weeks.

title: Fleet Reported About to Buy Unit of Sanwa
description: The Sanwa Bank Ltd., a Japanese financial giant mired in billions of dollars in bad loans, will in the next week announce the sale of a large American lending unit to the Fleet Financial Group for about $700 million, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Money Gram Hires Campbell Mithun
description: Money Gram Payment Systems Inc. in Denver said yesterday that it had named Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis to handle its account, which had been handled by MacNamara, Stewart & Saperstein in New York. Billings were estimated at $12 million to $15 million.

title: Inquiry Is Reported Into Contract Votes In Municipal Union
description: The Manhattan District Attorney is investigating allegations that officials at District Council 37, the umbrella group representing 120,000 New York City municipal employees, committed extensive vote fraud in 1996 to win ratification of a widely criticized contract that included a two-year wage freeze, lawyers knowledgeable about the investigation said yesterday.

title: A Journey of Hope and Self-Discovery for Two Hard-Bitten Souls
description: In Walter Salles's ''Central Station,'' a hit at Sundance and the winner of top honors at this year's Berlin Film Festival, a cynical, joyless woman crosses paths with a lonely young boy. There's plenty of room for sentimentality here, but the wonder of Mr. Salles's film is all in the telling.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Lotek and Peter Klare

title: Fish Mesh to Fashion Plate
description: Chiyoko Tanaka works alone in a cypress forest on the edge of Kyoto. She weaves decorative fabrics of linen and ramie, ''grinding'' their surfaces by hand with stones, bricks and dirt to achieve a timeworn appearance. She has, it would appear, not much in common with the high tech Bridgestone Metalpha Corporation, a subsidiary of the tire company, which produces -- with the aid of robots -- a stainless steel fabric called Alphatex.

title: A Troubled H.M.O. Agrees To Supervision by the State
description: Efforts to shore up the sagging finances of New Jersey's fourth-largest health maintenance organization took a bitter public turn today when the organization, H.I.P. Health Plan of New Jersey, broke its contract with the medical provider it hired 18 months ago. That provider then filed for bankruptcy protection.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ARDENT SOFTWARE INC. , Westboro, Mass., a data management software company, said that it had agreed to acquire Prism Solutions Inc., Sunnyvale, Calif., a producer of software for managing business information, for about $42 million in stock.

title: The Modern Seeks Money
description: Gearing up for its major expansion, the Museum of Modern Art announced this week that it had begun a $650 million capital campaign. It is believed to be the largest fund-raising effort by any museum in the country and possibly by any American cultural institution.

title: Monicagate: Did Press Do Its Job?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Posts 14.94-Point Gain On Hopes for Rising Profits
description: Stocks rose yesterday, led by demand for shares of Intel and MCI Worldcom on optimism that growing demand for personal computers and telecommunications will strengthen corporate profits.

title: Affirmative Action Voided at Public School
description: In the first Federal appeals court ruling on affirmative action in public school admissions, a three-judge panel in Boston yesterday struck down racial preferences at Boston Latin School, the city's most prestigious public high school.

title: Television, Finely Tuned
description: Many parents feel ambivalent about letting their children watch music television. But ''Musical Maniacs,'' tomorrow and Sunday at the Museum of Television and Radio, has no lewd singers, scantily clad women or episodes of violence. Opening the museum's Seventh Annual International Children's Festival, it is lower-case mtv, for 5- to 10-year-olds.

title: Paine Webber finds there's no time like the present to bring back a classic catch phrase.
description: FANS of advertising slogans that develop into catch phrases and enter the vernacular can gratefully start saying ''Thank you Paine Webber'' again. The reason? Paine Webber Group Inc. is bringing back that familiar theme after an 11-year hiatus.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELSTEIN, TIBY
description: EDELSTEIN-Tiby. We mourn the loss of Tiby, longtime employee and dear friend. Her many years with us proved her to be competent, dedicated and a wonderful, loyal worker. The handpicked greeting cards in her large, redinked handwriting will no longer arrive-we shall miss them. Along with the frequent calls we made, we shall also miss the yearly birthday, September 23rd, celebration we looked forward to eagerly. She will always be in our thoughts. Lee and Lou Kuhn Betty Schoenfeld

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KISSINGER, PAULA STERN
description: KISSINGER-Paula Stern. We extend heartfelt condolences to Dr. Henry A. and Walter B. Kissinger on the loss of their beloved mother, Paula. The Kissinger family involvement with the hospital dates back to ''The Central Committee for the Construction of a Jewish Hospital in Jerusalem'', established in Germany in 1873, and that commitment has continued until today. May the entire family have warm and loving memories of a very special, caring and righteous individual. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratkzer, President Stuart Tauber, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMERON, HOPE
description: CAMERON-Hope.(Bulkeley) Widow of Billy Friedberg, veteran actor of stage, film and TV, died November 18 at the age of 78, after a heroic fight against cancer. She played with Lee. J. Cobb, in ''Death of a Salesman'', on Broadaway for it's 96 week run, and continued acting up to this year in a performance at the Actors Studio. Survived by her family, friends, and her family of 500 fellow members of the Actors Studio. Memorial service at the Actors Studio, 432 West 44th St., on Friday, December 4th at 2PM.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY / Safety; Unbuckled Child? Punish an Adult
description: THE Transportation Department plans to announce a rule in a few days that will require standard hardware in cars and child seats to make the two fit together better, with the aim of lowering the annual death toll of about 600 children under age 5.

title: On Abortion, Church Teaching Isn't Absolute
description: To the Editor:

title: Fatal Crash Leaves Kentucky Grieving
description: The quarterback, Tim Couch, served as a pallbearer for his best friend and former teammate, Christopher Scott Brock. The starting center, Jason Watts, has been charged with second-degree manslaughter and drunken driving in connection with Brock's death and the death of another teammate, Arthur Steinmetz.

title: Opportunity Has Arrived, And Graham Is All Business
description: In his first day of practice as the starting quarterback for the Giants, Kent Graham wanted to be sure it was a full day. So Jim Fassel was not surprised to see Graham in his office at 5:50 A.M. asking about the game plan for Sunday.

title: A Village With Music In the Family, And in Class
description: While many public schools, struggling under budget constraints and competing academic interests, are marginalizing arts programs, if not eliminating them altogether, the opposite is happening in the small village of Greenport at the tip of the North Fork on Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, MYRA SEIDEN
description: HIRSCH-Myra Seiden. On November 18, 1998. Beloved wife of Barry. Loving mother of Terry, Neil and Nancy. Devoted sister of Carolyn Miller. Dear daughter-in-law of Emanuel Hirsch, sister-in-law of Eugene and Dee Hirsch.Aunt of Barbara and Joel Behar, Jane and Andrew Bursky. Services Friday, November 20, 12 noon at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65 Street. Interment New Montefiore cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: We Have a Winner! Too Bad He's Dead
description: The delightful ''Waking Ned Devine'' takes place in the picturesque Irish village of Tulaigh Mohr (or Tully More). There are 52 souls here, and 51 pairs of eyes twinkle. (One sour old woman is the unofficial town witch.) There also happens to be a winning lottery ticket somewhere in the village, and the film starts with a tireless campaign by Jackie O'Shea (Ian Bannen) to root out the luckiest of his neighbors. Leading questions (like ''So tell us, are you going to take a holiday this year?'') don't turn up any obvious mad money, though.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about the possible financial cost of the Middle East plan to the United States departed from the preferred rendering of the Hebrew name of a leader of the Jewish settler movement. He uses Pinchas Wallerstein, not Pinkhas Valer shtein.

title: The Walls Have Ears, and Eyes and Cameras
description: Though ''Enemy of the State'' finds a flimsy excuse for setting one scene amid lingerie models, babes have nothing to do with its notion of sex appeal. Instead, it's the gigahertz that are hot in a thriller that treats technology as its biggest turn-on. High-tech surveillance (''Enhance, then forward frame by frame!'') is at the heart of this latest splashy collaboration between Tony Scott and Jerry Bruckheimer (''Top Gun,'' ''Crimson Tide''), with its premise that privacy is imperiled by runaway electronics. In a week that finds the nation listening to surreptitiously taped Washington telephone calls, who's to say that ''Enemy of the State'' doesn't have a point?

title: Alice McDermott Wins A Top Award for Fiction
description: Alice McDermott, the author of ''Charming Billy,'' a quiet novel about Irish-Americans and the way a lost love can continue to haunt a life, was the surprise winner of the National Book Award for fiction on Wednesday night. The novel came up from behind Tom Wolfe's '' A Man in Full'' (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), a big, muscular book about race and real estate in the New South, which had seemed like a certain winner. It also beat another strong contender, ''Damascus Gate'' (Houghton Mifflin) by Robert Stone, the story of a conspiracy to blow up the Temple Mount in Jerusalem.

title: Metro Business; Housing Bias Is Alleged
description: The story was the same again and again, according to the Open Housing Center, a nonprofit fair housing organization in Manhattan.

title: Rare Trade Talks by Israel and Arabs
description: Israel's chilly trade relationship with Jordan and the Palestinian Authority warmed slightly this week as the three neighbors held their first face-to-face discussions of import barriers, border customs disputes and obstacles to regional investment.

title: Japan's Ruling Party Agrees To Coalition With Archrival
description: Politics took a turn to the usual here today as the governing Liberal Democratic Party opted for political expedience and agreed to form a coalition government with its archenemy, Ichiro Ozawa, and his Liberal Party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, ELLIOT C.
