description: BARNETT-Elliot C. on November 18, 1998, of Boynton Beach, FL and Port Washington, NY. Beloved husband of Morrine. Dear father of Brenda and Carl, David, Lisa and Larry, and Susan. Adored grandfather of Daniel and Andrew, Julia, and Marilyn and Georgia. Services today 12:45 pm at The Community Synagogue of Port Washington, 150 Middle Neck Rd, Sands Point, NY.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: While Boston Points Fingers, Hartford Claps Hands in Glee; The 'Magic Dust' for Redevelopment
description: Business owners answered their telephones with bold greetings today, boasting that they were in the home of the Hartford Patriots. News dealers at Old State House Square hawked souvenir issues of the local paper with headlines worthy of a war or a Presidential election.

title: Police Say a Prostitute Is Slain in a Motel Room
description: A 30-year-old Newark woman who the police said was a prostitute was killed early yesterday in an Irvington motel, raising to 16 the number of prostitute slayings being investigated by a task force in the Essex County Prosecutor's office.

title: Schumer, in Unique Role, May Get 3 Impeachment Votes
description: As the House Judiciary Committee opened hearings on the impeachment of President Clinton today, one member, Representative Charles E. Schumer, found himself in a position to do something unique in American history: vote on an impeachment proceeding in committee, on the House floor and in the Senate.

title: N.F.L. Matchups: Week 12
description: Game of the Week

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTTER, HELENA
description: POTTER-Helena. The Board of Directors of The Grenfell Association of America expresses its deep sorrow and sympathy to Dr. Robert Potter, the Association's President, and his family at the untimely passing of his wife, Helena, whose wisdom and unique contributions to the organization are greatly appreciated and will be sorely missed. David C. Oxman, Vice-President R. Keating Hagmann, Treasurer Debra R. Anisman, Secretary

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Help wanted: Electronic Data Systems and Nike have been seeking finance chiefs for months.
description: A COMPANY that goes for some time without a chief financial officer may be raising a red flag for investors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHILL, ANTHONY B., SR.
description: CAHILL-Anthony B., Sr., age 68, of Bonita Springs, Florida and Nantucket, Massachusetts, died on November 18, 1998 after an extended illness. Born in New York City on November 19, 1929, son of the late Russell B. Cahill and Estelle Forhan Cahill. He was the husband of Karen Butler Cahill. He grew up in Pelham Manor and Mamaroneck, New York and was educated at Iona Prep School and attended Iona College in New Rochelle, New York. He resided in various towns in Westchester County, namely White Plains, Bedford Village, Chappaqua, and Somers until he retired in 1990 moving to Florida and continuing to summer on Nantucket Island, Massachusetts as he had since the 1960s. Mr. Cahill worked in the heavy construction industry in the 1940's during summers while a student and after serving in the U.S. Marines from 1950-1952 continued in the construction business throughout his business life, primarily road construction including public projects such as the New York State Thruway built in the early 1950s where he was deeply involved in the construction of the Tappan Zee Bridge and Westchester Toll Plaza in Tarrytown, New York. Having the foresight to follow the major trend of the development of the upper portion of Westchester County, New York in the late 1950s into the 60s, Mr. Cahill, in 1963, founded Cahill Paving Corporation originally in Katonah, New York, soon after moving his company to Bedford Hills, New York where it remained for many years. Seeing the value of an asphalt plant in northern Westchester and Putnam Counties he started Putnam Asphalt Corporation in Patterson, New York as well as Harlem Valley Materials, Inc in Wassaic, New York, all doing business throughout Westchester, Putnam and Dutchess Counties. He continued to successfully run his businesses until his retirement in 1990. Mr. Cahill served for 15 years as a Trustee for the Pension Fund of the Local 137 Operating Engineers Union. He was a member of Sankaty Head Golf Club, Nantucket, Massachusetts and Bonita Bay Golf Club in Bonita Springs, Florida; an officer in the Westchester County Contractor's Association, a member of the Westchester Bituminous Asphalt Association. In addition to his wife, Karen, he is survived by three sons, Richard F. Cahill of San Diego, California, Anthony B. Cahill, Jr. of Ridgefield, Connecticut and James E. Cahill of Nantucket, Massachusetts, and his brother, John J. Cahill of Vero Beach, Florida. He is also suvived by five grandchildren, his former wife Valerie, many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews, two stepdaughters and two stepsons. Friends may call on the Cahill family on Friday, November 20, 1998 from 5-9:00PM at the Hodges Funeral Chapel, 3520 Tamiami Trail North. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Saturday, November 21, 1998 at 9:00AM at Saint John the Evangelist Catholic Church. Interment will be in Prospect Hill Cemetery in Nantucket, Mass. Mr. Cahill is a parishioner of St. Mary's (Our Lady of the Isle) Church in Nantucket, Massachusetts and St. John's the Evangelist Church in Naples, Florida. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Sankaty Head Caddy Camp Fund of Sankaty Head Golf Club, Nantucket, Massachesetts which helps young boys earn scholarships for college.

title: Some Digital Services Face 5% U.S. Tax
description: Adopting a middle ground between the industry and consumer groups, the Federal Government today imposed a 5 percent fee on some of the money that commercial television broadcasters may someday generate from the new digital spectrum.

title: Brooklyn Boy Dies in Fall From Bed Onto Lamp
description: A 12-year-old Brooklyn boy who was trying to prevent his younger brother from falling off a bunk bed died yesterday when he fell off the bed and impaled himself on the metal spike of a lamp, the police said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fed Minutes Show Concern Over Perception of Cuts

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGRATH, ANNE ROGAN
description: McGRATH-Anne Rogan. 63. Of Hampton Bays, NY formerly of Chappaqua, NY at home after a long battle with cancer. Devoted wife of Dr. Terence J. McGrath and loving mother of Dr. Sarah McGee of Sturbridge, MA, Kathleen Dunn of New Rochelle, NY, Mary Donovan of Tullahoma, TN, and Maureen Svoboda of Lawrenceville, NJ. Cherished grandmother of eleven grandchildren. She is also survived by three sisters and two brothers: Sheila Raymond of Riverside, CT, Janet Pedlow of Chappaqua, NY, Elizabeth Brennan of Eastchester, NY, John Rogan of Overland Park, KS and Peter Rogan of Valparaiso, IN and 36 nieces and nephews. She will be remembered for her unwavering faith, wise counsel, fun-loving nature and courageous spirit. Reposing at Beecher Funeral Home, 418 Bedford Road, Pleasantville, NY on Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Friday, Nov. 20th At 10 AM at St. John and St. Mary, Chappaqua, NY. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Rosary Hill Home, 600 Linda Ave, Hawthorne, NY 10532 or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Surgical Metabolic Research Fund, P.O. Box E, 1275 York Avenue, NY, NY 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DARDIG, BEN
description: DARDIG-Ben. On November 18, 1998. Loving husband of Evelyn. Dear father of Jill and Scott. Caring father-in-law to William Heward. Devoted grandfather of Lee, Lynn and J.T. Services Sunday 11AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions, to the Jewish Braille Institute, 110 E. 30th Street, New York, NY 10016

title: Starr Struck
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Late Into Night, the Prosecutor's Forbearance Begins to Fade
description: It was not until the 11th hour of a long and grueling day of testimony that Kenneth W. Starr's measured, unflappably academic performance before the Judiciary Committee began to wear thin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORN, MRS. RICHARD KAYE
description: KORN-Mrs. Richard Kaye. The board and staff of Planned Parenthood of New York City are deeply saddened by the death of our honorary board member, Mrs. Richard Kaye Korn. Peggy joined the PPNYC board in the late 1940s and served with distinction on nearly every agency committee. She inspired generations of board members by extraordinary generosity and her enthusiasm for fundraising. We will long remember Peggy for her unwavering commitment to this agency, and the health and rights of women in New York City. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to her entire family. Wendy Mackenzie, Chair, PPNYC Board of Directors Alexander C. Sanger, President Barry Ensminger, Exec. Director

title: Committee Members Barely Wait for the Gavel Before They Take Off the Gloves
description: It took 60 seconds for civility to vanish in a whirl of acrimony today as Republicans and Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee faced President Clinton's accuser for the first time.

title: Arbitrating Civil Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Budget Commission Hires First Full-Time President
description: The Citizens Budget Commission announced yesterday that Diana Fortuna would become its first full-time president on Dec. 1.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Tony Oursler

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Uh-oh. Here comes the hamburger. The waitress dare not take her eyes from it as she carries it, walking very carefully, to the table. Will it topple before she arrives? Ah, she's made it without a mishap. Setting the burger down, she beats a hasty retreat.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMINGHAM, THOMAS V.
description: BERMINGHAM - Thomas V., Priest of the Society of Jesus; teacher and scholar of the classics; dearest brother of Jack, Peggy and Bob Bermingham, Mary Byrne, Betty Stevens, Edith Cavanagh, Helen Keller and the late Suzanne Harrington; and a source of joy, love and inspiration to so, so many others. Contributions in his memory may be made to the T.V. Bermingham Scholarship Fund, Fordham University, 113 West 60th St, New York, NY 10023. BERMINGHAM-Rev. Thomas V., S.J. Beloved brother of John H., Robert A., Mary Byrne, Elizabeth Stevens, Edith Cavanagh, Margaret Bermingham and Helen Keller. Reposing at The Loyla Hall Chapel, Fordham University, Bronx. Visitation Friday 3-5 and 7-9PM, Saturday, 3-5PM. Mass of Christian Burial Fordham University Church, Saturday 8PM. For further information contact Farenga Bros., Inc., Directors.

title: Van Gogh Self-Portrait Sells for $71.5 Million
description: A new chapter in auction history unfolded at Christie's last night when a haunting van Gogh self-portrait from 1889 was sold for $71.5 million, nearly three times its high estimate. It was the second highest price for a van Gogh at auction and the third highest price for any artwork ever sold at auction.

title: Williams Companies Plans Stock Offering
description: Trying to exploit the stock market's enthusiasm for new fiber optic long-distance companies, the Williams Companies said yesterday that it would offer stock in its communications operation to the public next year.

title: Managed Care Has Failed Us All
description: To the Editor:

title: As Teachers Begin Strike, Jersey City Schools Erupt in Chaos
description: Several public schools here degenerated into chaos this morning when teachers went on strike, leaving the district's 32,000 students in the hands of principals and too few substitute teachers.

title: Berlin Debates Spielberg Holocaust Video Offer
description: As the debate intensifies over how to recall Hitler's destruction of European Jewry in the emerging new center of Berlin, the Jewish Museum here has begun talks with Steven Spielberg over the possibility of housing his vast video history of the Holocaust.

title: Federal Judge Blocks Internet Smut Law
description: A Federal judge yesterday temporarily blocked a new Federal law intended to shield children from on-line pornography. Free-speech advocates had asserted that enforcement of the measure, which was to have gone into effect today, could violate the First Amendment.

title: Berlin Cameron Wins Cadillac Assignment
description: The Cadillac division of the General Motors Corporation has named Berlin Cameron & Partners in New York to handle the broadcast television introduction for its 1999 Escalade luxury sport utility vehicle. Billings have not been determined.

title: INSIDE
description: Alan Pakula, Movie Director, Dies in Highway Accident

title: People
description: * Michael Perlis was named president of Ziff-Davis Publishing, New York, a unit of the Softbank Corp., succeeding Claude Sheer, who was named to the new position of chief Internet strategist. Mr. Perlis had been president and chief operating officer at TVSM Publishing Inc., New York, now owned by the News Corporation.

title: Citing Strike Threat, FDX Halts Plane Work
description: The FDX Corporation canceled the conversion of four passenger aircraft into cargo planes because of a possible strike by pilots at its Federal Express division, its chief financial officer, Alan B. Graf, said today.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about trends in the prosecution of perjury referred incorrectly to a case against a Texas judge. The judge, not named in the article, was indicted by a grand jury on a perjury charge in a case involving political contributions, but the trial judge quashed the indictment. The judge was not convicted. Prosecutors are seeking a reinstatement of the indictment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, BETTY IVEY
description: MARTIN-Betty Ivey. Born Bellevue, Washington, died November 17, 1998 in New York. Much loved aunt of Susan Procter Dusenberry, great aunt of Benjamin Procter. Lover of life, lover of children everywhere. Miss Martin studied voice at the the Juilliard School of Music. She had a long distinguished career as head of the educational departments at Columbia, RCA and MGM Records. She is Trustee Emeritus of the Professional Children's School and was on the board for over 25 years. She joined the New York Metropolitan Committee for UNICEF in 1980, and in 1991, received the Metro Angel Award for her special commitment. Contributions in her memory may be made to either institution. A memorial service will be held Thursday, December 17th at 4 PM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERNO, EUGENE J.
description: KERNO-Eugene J. A New York City Attorney. On November 18, 1998 at age 86. Beloved father of Raymond E. Kerno and loving grandfather of Annija. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St, Sunday, November 22nd, 6PM. Interment Monday, Evergreen Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Baltic Association to the United Nations, 203 E. 82 St, N.Y. N.Y. 10028.

title: Barnes & Noble Loss Exceeds Estimates
description: Barnes & Noble Inc., the largest United States bookseller, reported a loss in its third quarter that was wider than expected as expenses at its fledgling Internet unit offset higher sales at its chain of bookstores.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESSING, BARBRAH
description: MESSING-Barbrah. On November 13, 1998. Warm heart, big smile, and indomitable spirit at Chelsea Theatre Center, Lorimar, and Warner Brothers Studios. Survived by father, Hy, stepmother, Bea, sister, Rita, and a host of loving friends. Memorial December 1, Falcon Theatre, 4252 Riverside Dr., Burbank, CA, 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, 818-623-0438 for donation information. We miss you, Barb. You are one of life's true originals.

title: Mets and Brewers Discussing a Trade
description: The Mets need an outfielder, an infielder and a leadoff hitter, and there appears to be a chance they could solve all their needs by signing the free-agent outfielder B. J. Surhoff and trading for one of their former prospects, Milwaukee second baseman Fernando Vina.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDRON, ROBERT
description: WALDRON-Robert. We wish to express our sincere sympathy to Dorothy Waldron and family. A man who was bigger than life, he will be greatly missed. Jeffrey Degen Gary Majka

title: Internet Group Urged to Action
description: The Clinton Administration today told the new nonprofit group that hopes to manage the Internet to make itself more open and accountable to the public and to do it soon.

title: Uncovered Short Sales on Big Board Fall 5%
description: On the Big Board, the short-interest figure for the month ended Nov. 13 represented 1.6 percent of the total shares listed on the exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPPER, ROBERT LYMAN
description: POPPER-Robert Lyman. Age 90 of Armonk, NY and Manhattan, died peacefully at White Plains Hospital on November 17, 1998. He was a graduate of Philips Academy Andover, class of '26 and Yale University, class of '30. He was the grandson of Lyman Gustav Bloomingdale, founder of the department store. He was born to Arthur W. Popper and Corinne Bloomingdale Popper in New York City on October 21, 1908. He worked at Bloomingdales and later became a Vice President at Dellwood Dairies. He served as a Captain in the European Theater of Operations from 1942 to 1945. He retired at the age of 54 to devote his life to the welfare of others and served as a working member on many boards on the state, national and local levels. He was a gentle and modest human being giving to others and wanting nothing for himself. He was respected, loved and admired by all who knew him. He loved to travel, swim, play tennis and was an avid student of history all his life. He passionately loved music and art and supported them. He was truly a Renaissance man. He enjoyed his many beloved nieces and nephews, grand nieces and nephews and his two great grand nieces and a great grand nephew. He is survived by his wife of 30 years, Ellen Goldberg Popper. His first wife Hermine Isaacs Popper died in 1968. A memorial service will be announced later.

title: Microsoft Accused of Keeping Prices Artificially High
description: The Microsoft Corporation has kept the price of personal computer software ''significantly'' higher than would be expected if the company faced real competition, an economic consultant testified today in the Microsoft trial.

title: Cendant Said to Near Sale of Software Division
description: In one of its first moves to bail out of some of its troubled businesses, the Cendant Corporation is close to selling its software division to Vivendi S.A., a French utilities group, a person close to the marketing and franchising company said last night.

title: Monicagate: Did Press Do Its Job?
description: To the Editor:

title: More Than a Simple Fling: Ultimate Frisbee
description: My wife doesn't stroke my ego the way she did before we were married. I told her I was going to play ultimate Frisbee, for the first time since college 10 years ago. She said, ''Wait, I wanna buy more life insurance first.'' Then she felt bad and offered to help me find my moldy old cleats, which hadn't been worn since the Iran-contra hearings. ''I don't need cleats,'' I said. ''This is a mellow game. They even said beginners are welcome.'' Fran looked at me with what I'm pretty sure was pity and told me to drink plenty of water.

title: Surreal, But Not Taking Chances
description: Start with the name Man Ray and you have the crux of Man Ray's working method. His real name was Emmanuel Radnitzky. But he cropped it, and cropped it well. He didn't become Manny Radnik or Manuel Nitzy. He folded and trimmed his name so that the new one would have a shiny new meaning, half human, half light. Man Ray cropped with flair, and chance had nothing to do with it.

title: Rare Half-Year Loss Reported by Toshiba
description: The Toshiba Corporation reported yesterday that it had its first half-year loss in 23 years but said that stronger sales of notebook computers in the United States should allow it to break even for the full year. Toshiba posted a net loss of 23.64 billion yen ($199 million) in the six months that ended on Sept. 30, compared with a profit of 9.55 billion yen a year earlier. The company said its sales fell by 5 percent, to 2.498 trillion yen.

title: 'Egg-o-Centric' View
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGNER, VICTORIA
description: WAGNER-Victoria. The Board of Trustees and the Ethical Culture Fieldston School note with sadness the death of Victoria Wagner, devoted and vital member of our school community for almost 40 years. Teacher, principal of the Ethical Culture School, and director of the Ethical Culture Fieldston School, she is remembered as a beloved and legendary educator. We extend heartfelt condolences to her daughter Eve Barnett (Fieldston class of '52) and her entire family. The family has requested donations in Mrs. Wagner's memory be made to Ethical Culture Fieldston School, 33 Central Park West, New York, NY 10023-6099. Sara E. Nathan and S. Donald Sussman Co-Chairs, Board of Trustees Joseph P. Healey, Ph.D. Head of School

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT IS LOWER. Prices fell on concern about weak demand for American exports. Sales so far this year are about 11 percent below the levels a year earlier. Wheat for December delivery declined 2 cents, to $2.91 a bushel.

title: Israel's Right Wing Turns From Fury to Resignation
description: From the picture windows of his office atop a commanding hill, Pinchas Wallerstein has a sweeping view of the chiseled limestone of Ramallah. But he sits with his back to the Palestinian city, snug behind barbed wire in this Jewish settlement. The Palestinians may be a fixture on his horizon, he said, but that does not mean he wants to stare them in the face.

title: Judge Allows Statement Of a Murder Suspect
description: A suspect's statement about his role in the ambush and killing of two pizza deliverymen on a rural roadside in April 1997 was admitted as evidence yesterday for his murder trial in February.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECK, JUDITH E.
description: PECK-Judith E. of Tenafly, NJ. Beloved wife of Arthur, devoted mother of Robert, Wendy and Amy. Loving grandmother of Benjamin, Jazmine, David, Sarah and Jeremy. Services ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engle St, Englewood, NJ, Sunday 3pm.

title: A Woman Careering Out Of Control
description: Anna Thomson delivers a wrenching portrait of a psychologically disordered woman in the new Amos Kollek film, ''Sue.''

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Wojtek Ulrich

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Jannis Kounellis

title: Taking the Children; Football Showdowns And Even Scarier Kinds
description: The Waterboy

title: Entergy Bid of $80 Million Wins Massachusetts Nuclear Plant
description: The Entergy Corporation, a major utility company in the South, emerged as the winning buyer yesterday in the first multiple-bid auction for an American nuclear power plant, a 26-year-old reactor on the Massachusetts coast that sold for $80 million cash.

title: 'Our Investigation Ran Into Roadblocks and Hurdles,' Starr Tells Committee
description: Following are excerpts from Kenneth W. Starr's remarks about the conduct of the investigation of President Clinton from his opening statement to the House Judiciary Committee yesterday, as recorded by Federal News Service, a private transcription service:

title: No New Evidence
description: On the core question of whether President Clinton's misconduct in office merits impeachment, the testimony of Kenneth Starr brought more clarity than most Americans could have expected. The independent counsel outlined his case that Mr. Clinton lied under oath, obstructed justice and tampered with witnesses, but he brought the House Judiciary Committee no new evidence beyond that offered in his Sept. 9 referral. Now, as then, that information provides what Representative Bill McCollum called ''a compelling picture'' of a President failing in his sworn duty to see that the law is faithfully executed.

title: U.S.-German Pact for On-Line Trading
description: The Ameritrade Holding Corporation and Deutsche Bank A.G., Germany's largest financial institution, have formed a joint venture to let their customers trade on line in European and United States securities markets.

title: In Japan, Clinton Is Questioned On His Public and Private Acts
description: President Clinton arrived in Japan today to push its leaders for a plan to fix their battered economy. But in a town-hall-style discussion televised nationwide late tonight, he found himself pressed to justify his own policies on trade, land mines, and Iraq -- and to explain how he apologized to his wife and daughter for his affair with a former intern.

title: Frost Tries to Find Place As Jet and Way as Pro
description: After 10 weeks of drawing a Jets paycheck, the best that Scott Frost, the former quarterback of co-national champion Nebraska, can hope for is that he ''will play some this week.''

title: A Self-Proclaimed Joe Friday Just Plays It Straight
description: It's the law of the political jungle: spin or be spun. And throughout the 10 months of the Lewinsky investigation, Kenneth W. Starr's spin has been that he has none. He has portrayed himself as the image of rectitude, comparing himself with Joe Friday in his devotion to just the facts.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You are disrupting the continuity of this meeting with these adversarial --

title: The Future of Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Beer Made the City Famous; Revival Keeps It Bubbling
description: Sometimes, from some angles, Milwaukee can fool you. Is this Chicago? There's the lake: the same immense lake, Lake Michigan, stretching to the horizon, bigger than all of Switzerland. There's Wisconsin Avenue, the main drag, which crosses the Milwaukee River on a bridge that looks a lot like the one that carries Michigan Avenue across the Chicago River.

title: For Patriots' Players, The Future Is Now
description: How about the Los Angeles Patriots?

title: Pandolfo's Overtime Goal Gives Devils 10th Victory
description: In contrast to their previous two games, when they collapsed in the third period, the Devils rallied for a 3-2 overtime victory over the Carolina Hurricanes tonight at Continental Arena.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MARION WOLFF
description: COHEN-Marion Wolff, in her 99th year, on November 18, 1998, of Sarasota, Florida, formerly of Cedarhurst, NY. Beloved wife of the late Jerome J. Cohen, loving mother of Florence and Aaron Steiger, Lois and Charles Imershein and Ron and Joan Cohen, adored grandmother and great-grandmother of nine grandchildren and thirteen great - grandchildren. Funeral Friday, November 20, 12PM at Temple Sinai, 131 Washington Avenue, Lawrence, NY. Donations can be made to Hospice of Southwest Florida, 5955 Rand Blvd., Sarasota, FL 34238 or the charity of your choice.

title: Prosecutor and Judge
description: I have often heard prosecutors denounce defendants in the kind of indignant terms that Kenneth Starr used on Thursday before the House Judiciary Committee. But those prosecutorial speeches have always come in closing arguments in a court of law, after a full opportunity for the defense to question and refute the prosecution's proof, and after a judicial admonition that what the prosecutor is saying is not evidence.

title: Williams Rejects $60 Million Yank Offer
description: The Yankees offered Bernie Williams a five-year, $60 million deal within the past week, according to two members of the organization, an offer that was rejected, an offer that some in the organization said would not be increased.

description: Kara Walker

title: CBS to Show Kevorkian Video of Man's Death
description: The CBS newsmagazine ''60 Minutes'' plans to broadcast on Sunday a videotape provided to them by Dr. Jack Kevorkian showing the physician administering a fatal injection to a patient who then dies on camera.

title: On Very Long Day, Many Across U.S. Stifle a Yawn
description: Glenn Cartwright stood before the cash register with his lips pursed, unable to decide between a Lightnin' Hopkins and a Clifton Chenier CD, but he was certain of one thing: When he got home, he was not going to turn the House Judiciary Committee's impeachment hearing back on.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Arledge Honored

title: Ford Focus Is Off to a Rousing Start
description: THE Ford Focus, a subcompact that is replacing two distinct Escorts manufactured in Europe and North America, is Europe's car of the year.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Spitzer Declares Victory, but Republicans Question Count
description: Not waiting for confirmation from election officials or a concession by his opponent, Eliot L. Spitzer, the Democratic challenger in the race for state attorney general, declared himself the winner of the tight contest yesterday and announced that he was putting together a transition team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRAGER, SIGMUND GODFREY
description: PRAGER-Sigmund Godfrey. November 12, 1998. Beloved husband of 60 years to the late Eleanor (nee Bernson). Devoted father of Nancy Kamel and the late Judith. Much loved grandfather to Lara Benett Adler, Andrew Benett and Ariane Benett and joyous greatgrandfather to Caroline Grace Adler. He will be greatly missed.

title: Taxi Commission Approves Stricter Penalties for Cab Drivers
description: Taxi drivers with six penalty points for traffic violations would be penalized by suspension of their hack licenses for 30 days, and those with 10 points would have them permanently revoked under a rule passed yesterday by the Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: Some China Help Seen in Curbing Beetle
description: After weeks of resistance, China has begun efforts to comply with the coming American ban on imports containing untreated wood-packing material, a visiting United States agricultural official said today.

title: As Sculptor of Nature, the Man Thinks Big
description: THE idea of casting a wild elephant and making its image in bronze came to the sculptor known as Mihail one night in the 1970's in his Chelsea loft.

title: Elections Chief's Ballot Disqualified
description: New York State's stringent election laws claimed a high-profile victim yesterday: Daniel DeFrancesco, the executive director of the city's Board of Elections. Elections officials in the Bronx disqualified the absentee ballot he filed in the Nov. 3 election.

title: RANCOROUS HOUSE PANEL HEARS STARR'S CASE FOR IMPEACHMENT
description: Across a long day and well into the night, Kenneth W. Starr fought off Democratic assaults on the conduct of his office on Thursday and repeatedly sought to return attention to what he described as President Clinton's pattern of obstruction of justice.

title: U.S. Tobacco Industry Looks Longingly at Chinese Market, but in Vain
description: As cigarette sales threaten to decline precipitously in the United States, American tobacco companies are counting on China as a land of extraordinary potential for growth, business analysts say. But the American companies' plans are being thwarted by China's government monopoly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISMAN, MARTIN L.
description: EISMAN-Martin L., on November 18, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Jan (nee Klein). Loving father of Valerie. Dear brother of Arthur and Susan. Cherished brother-inlaw of Joan and Bob Nadel. Devoted grandfather of Jenna and Emily. Memorial service will be held Friday, 11AM at Temple Israel, New Rochelle, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILKINSON, FREDERICK D., JR.
description: WILKINSON-Frederick D., Jr. The Boards, Faculty and Staff of the Weill Medical College of Cornell University and the New York Presbyterian Hospital are deeply saddened by the passing of our friend and esteemed Life Overseer Fred Wilkinson. A founding member of the Board of Overseers, Mr. Wilkinson was a man of great charm, dignity and wisdom. He will be greatly missed. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his wife, Jeane, and the Wilkinson family. Weill Medical College of Cornell University Sanford I. Weill Chairman, Board of Overseers Antonio M. Gotto, Jr., M.D. Dean New York Presbyterian Hospital Daniel B. Burke John F. McGillicuddy Co-Chairmen, Board of Trustees David B. Skinner, M.D. Vice Chairman and CEO William T. Speck, M.D. President and COO

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: George Stoll

title: At the Movies; Ron Howard Back to Comedy
description: In one scene in Ron Howard's forthcoming movie, ''edTV,'' a loutish character played by Woody Harrelson stands in front of a television camera and delightedly discloses that his sister is dating a man who plays the piano so badly that during a gig at a bar his head was cracked open by someone throwing the tip glass. More, he blabbers, how funny that the couple met in a bar, because his sister is an alcoholic. Hah-hah!

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HORCHLER, KEITH
description: HORCHLER-Keith. 11/20/95. An invaluable friend, three years gone. Missed, mourned and remembered. Shane

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTLER, MARION
description: BUTLER-Marion. The Board and staff of Lighthouse International mourn the loss of Marion Donovan Bulter, a valued advisor for many years whose commitment and dedication was highly regarded. Our deepest condolences to her family. Barbara Silverstone, President Timothy Knipe, Chairman, Board of Directors

title: ATTRACTIONS
description: Museums and Sites

title: How a Lesbian Curse Made a Gay Bar Suffer
description: The first time I saw ''Burning Habits'' -- with its gay vampires, catatonic bartenders and nuns who swear like sailors -- was at a bar off Avenue A. Every Monday night for eight weeks a new episode was presented as the audience, which had paid $5 a head, drank beer or vodka tonics and strained to see the actors, who performed without benefit of a stage. It was always a good idea to arrive early so you could sit in one of the first three rows. And there unfolded the multiple story lines of Kidd Gottahave (''an angry young lesbian teen who has yet to experience love''); Priapus Columns, the bisexual (maybe); a lapsed Roman Catholic vampire, Vonda Von Vickers (described in the program as ''evil Catholic witch'') and a host of others.

title: Monicagate: Did Press Do Its Job?
description: To the Editor:

title: In M.V.P. Voting, Sosa Is the Man Over McGwire
description: Sammy Sosa finally found a way to get ahead of Mark McGwire and stay ahead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIT, DUDLEY
description: FEIT-Dudley. Beloved husband of Hattie, father of Elliot and Joseph Feit. Beloved father in law, grandfather and great grandfather. Founder of the Young Israel of Flatbush Chevrah Kadisha/Cemetary Committee, and Chairman of both for 50 years. Member of the Young Israel of Flatbush Board of Trustees. Interment was at Beth David Cemetery, November 18, 1998. Sam Wietschner, Chairman of Chevrah Kadisha

title: Managed Care Has Failed Us All
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 10.

title: Observer; Don't Believe It, Kids
description: We will soon be inundated with nonsense about how wonderful it is to be old. The baby-boom generation, now becoming long in the tooth, thick in the middle and sparse on the scalp, will demand it.

title: Revving Up Japan
description: Of all the economic events of the 1990's, the decline of Japan's financial colossus was perhaps the least expected. A decade ago the Japanese appeared to be in command of the most successful economy in the world. Now, as President Clinton concludes his Tokyo visit, it is hard to be optimistic about the financial condition and future of the world's second-largest economy.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKOLD, ELLEN
description: BUCKOLD-Ellen. The Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Ellen Buckold, loving wife and devoted mother and grandmother. We extend our sympathies to her husband, Werner, a long-time supporter and honorary chair of the Men's Neckwear & Accessories Division of UJA-Federation; and daughters, Emily and Leslie. Our deepest condolences to her entire family and all those whose lives she has touched. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: On Wall Street, Pursuing the Mighty Dollar for Charity
description: Wall Street's young, ambitious financial analysts routinely work into the night plotting strategies to help their companies make money. Last night, dozens of them gathered to plot strategies for giving money away, to those who need it.

title: Highlights of Criticism and Defense of Starr
description: The independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr answered a broad range of queries about the tactics of his prosecutors, his motives and evidence he gathered. The quotations were provided by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DEL CAMPO, CRISTINA ERHART
description: DEL CAMPO-Cristina Erhart. Representative and head of Christie's Argentina, passed away October 19, 1998, in Buenos Aires after a short but valiant struggle with lung cancer. In addition to her position at Christie's, Ms. del Campo was very active as a member of the Multiple Sclerosis Society of Argentina and worked closely with her husband during his career as Minister of the Argentine Embassy in Tel Aviv and then later as Ambassador to Ireland and Sweden. In addition to her husband, Cristina is survived by her parents and her children, Angie and Juan Diego, as well as many adoring friends and colleagues. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, November 22nd, at 2:00 P.M., St. Vincent Ferrer, 869 Lexington Avenue at 66th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KRAKAUER, BILLIE
description: KRAKAUER-Billie. 11/20/94. Sadly on this day four years ago you were taken away from us. Missed by your family and friends. Always remembered with love that does not diminish as time goes by. Davie and family

title: Residential Real Estate; In TriBeCa Conversion, Design-Your-Own Condos
description: In a sign that the conversion of old industrial buildings to expensive housing continues at a steady clip in TriBeCa, a 1929 brick warehouse 50 yards from the entrance to the Holland Tunnel is being reborn as a loft condominium in which buyers will be able to design their own spaces.

title: Fallon McElligott Quits Beam Account
description: Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis said yesterday that it had resigned the Jim Beam Brands Company account after a decade, citing strategic differences.

title: Wrapping The West In Eastern Mystery
description: Modern art in the West is inconceivable without the salutatory effects of outside influences. African sculpture was basic to the invention of Cubism; the woodcuts of Japanese printmakers like Hiroshige, Utamaro and Hokusai inspired numerous Impressionists and Post-Impressionists, most famously van Gogh.

title: Memorial to an Insider Recalls a Genteel Era
description: It was an accident of timing: two events, coinciding by merest chance, each of which threw the other into relief.

title: Democrats Challenge Starr on Delayed Exoneration
description: Kenneth W. Starr today provided the public with a wide-ranging portrait of his four-year, $40 million investigation, announcing that he had not found any evidence of impeachable wrongdoing by President Clinton in Whitewater, the travel office and the personnel files of hundreds of employees.

title: NATO Warns Time Is Short For Talks On Kosovo
description: As deadly tension appears to be building again in Kosovo, where 385,000 civilians remain uprooted, NATO officials warned today that a shaky cease-fire might soon dissolve.

title: Home Video; Amazon Joins The Film Fray
description: The Web wars heated up considerably this week among several leading purveyors of tapes and digital video disks on the Internet. On Tuesday Amazon.com entered the field, adding videos to its books, music and other products. The merging of different goods into a unified shopping source is a trend in so-called E-commerce. For example, the former Videoserve.com this week became a part of a diversified operation called Buy.com, which carries merchandise in five categories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINDER, MILDRED
description: FINDER-Mildred. On November 19, 1998. Beloved wife of Milton; loving mother of Vickie (Weinreb) and Edmund; dear mother-in-law of Alan and Elizabeth; cherished grandmother of Jason, Lindsay, Jacqueline, Adam, Matthew & Andrew. Graveside services Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Queens, today. She will be greatly missed.

title: Eyeing the Glitter-Crazed In Manhattan's Dolce Vita
description: ''Celebrity'' was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 25. The film opens nationwide today.

title: WITH DEMAND FOR TRACTORS DOWN, DEERE PLANS LAYOFFS
description: Deere & Company, the world's largest farm-equipment maker, said yesterday that it would lay off about 2,400 workers for several weeks because of weakening demand in North America. Most employees at the company's Waterloo Works tractor plant in Waterloo, Iowa, will be laid off for two to three weeks in December. The plant will also extend its traditional weeklong holiday shutdown for an extra two weeks, through Jan. 19. Deere, based in Moline, Ill., and its competitors are scaling back production as crop prices slump. Deere's shares rose 87.5 cents yesterday, to $39.

title: Elisabeth Owens, 79, Pioneer at Harvard Law
description: Elisabeth A. Owens, who helped to shape the field of international tax law and in 1972 became the first woman ever granted tenure at Harvard Law School, died on Sunday at Falmouth (Mass.) Hospital. She was 79 and lived in Falmouth.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies yesterday about the winners of the National Book Awards quoted incorrectly from lines recited by Gerald Stern, the winner of the poetry award, from his work ''The Bite.'' They should have read:

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: New Delhi Journal; Bats in a Dreary Lodge Where Life Imitates Poe
description: Their mother, whom they called Her Highness, killed herself with the ''drink of silence,'' a toxic mix of powders that included crushed remnants of the family diamonds and pearls.

title: Barney Frank
description: One of the more liberal Democrats from one of the more liberal states, Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts is known for his quick wit and his expertise in parliamentary maneuvering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOWKES, ROBERT A.
description: FOWKES-Robert A. of Bronxville, NY on November 18, 1998. Husband of Angela Vescio Fowkes, father of Robert Jr., Richard and William, grandfather of six, greatgrandfather of three. Calling hours at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9 pm Friday and Saturday. Services at the funeral home on Monday, November 23 at 12:00 noon. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to NYU Scholarship Fund or St. David's Society of New York.

title: Hindu Party Faces Test As Prices Anger Indians
description: Elections in New Delhi and three Indian states next week have turned into a referendum on the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, which has led India's shaky, 18-party coalition Government for the last eight months.

title: Monicagate: Did Press Do Its Job?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Nov. 5 about the expected selection of Senator Phil Gramm as the next chairman of the Senate Banking Committee referred imprecisely to derivatives regulation powers of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which some lobbyists believe he would want to restrict. The commission regulates derivatives traded on exchanges, like futures contracts, but does not have sweeping authority over derivatives.

title: While Boston Points Fingers, Hartford Claps Hands in Glee; Failure of Political Leadership Is Seen
description: In Boston, the saying goes, there are only three things that count: sports, politics and revenge. And the announcement today that the New England Patriots will leave suburban Boston to play in Hartford combines all three, revealing that underneath the sheen of its economic boom, Boston is often still a city of tribal neighborhoods and vendettas without strong leadership.

title: Excerpts From Remarks in Panel Hearing
description: Barney Frank

title: Excerpts From Starr's Questioning by the President's Personal Lawyer
description: Following are excerpts from responses by Kenneth W. Starr to questions by David E. Kendall, personal attorney for President Clinton, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Clinton Warns Japan to Keep Its Markets Open to U.S. Goods
description: President Clinton warned Japan today that the United States might feel pressure to restrict some markets if the American trade deficit keeps rising and Japan continues to limit American imports.

title: Charles T. Canady
description: A nightmare for Bill Clinton would be a House full of lawmakers like Representative Charles T. Canady, who said the evidence amassed by the independent counsel ''sets forth in great detail a pattern of calculated and sustained misconduct by the President of the United States.''

title: Toyota's Other Businesses; As Company Branches Out, Investors Spin Their Tires
description: For years, investors have nagged the Toyota Motor Corporation to put its huge pile of cash -- some $20 billion at last count -- to work.

title: China, a Land of Heavy Smokers, Looks Into Abyss of Fatal Illness
description: For the first time, scientists have calculated the devastating toll of cigarette smoking in China and declared the country to be on the verge of a calamitous epidemic of smoking-related disease that could ultimately result in the deaths of 1 in 3 Chinese men.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EINSTEIN, HENRY
description: EINSTEIN-Henry. Aug. 1920Nov. 20, 1988. In loving memory. Dr. Ulrike Heller Kirchhain, Germany

title: BankAmerica Sells a Unit To Managers
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the newly merged banking giant, has sold a mutual fund company it bought only a year ago to its managers.

title: Accounts
description: * Access Graphics, Boulder, Colo., to Barnhart/CMI Marketing, Advertising and Public Relations, Denver, as the first agency to handle advertising for the company's Sun Business Group. Billings were estimated at more than $1 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINTANO, EUGENE S.
description: QUINTANO-Eugene S., 90, of Tuxedo, New York on November 16, 1998 at his residence. Beloved father of Eugene F., Ann T., and Francesca X. Quintano-Mattson. Also survived by 4 grandchildren. Mass of Christian burial on Friday (today) at 9:30 a.m. from St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Avenue, NYC. Interment will be in Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, NY. For information, Quackenbush Funeral Home, 117 Maple Avenue, Monroe, New York

title: Attack by the President's Lawyer At Length Ruffles a Cool Witness
description: President Clinton's lawyer, David E. Kendall, tonight finally got his chance to confront Kenneth W. Starr, and he used his entire hour not to defend the President's actions or his veracity but to attack Mr. Starr and the conduct of his investigation.

title: Three Sets and a Flashback: Graf Outlasts Seles
description: On the fifth match point of her excruciating quarterfinal battle with the flu-ridden Monica Seles, Steffi Graf blew on her serving fingers, not to cool them down but to insure a death grip on her racquet. And then she unfurled the serve that backed Seles into a corner where -- despite her determination to prolong this diva-driven prizefight -- she lost her last bit of leverage and merely fumbled the ball into play.

title: Frenchglen Journal; Old and New West Clash in Oregon
description: In some ways, the high-desert region known as the Malheur has never had any problem attracting visitors.

title: Klan Case Transcends Black vs. White
description: The two men could not be more different racially, politically, philosophically. Yet Barry Elton Black, a white member of the Ku Klux Klan, and David P. Baugh, the black lawyer who is defending him in a Virginia court, are united these days in a defense over what they see as the constitutional right of free speech.

title: Raising Orphans to Atone for Their Loss
description: It's the sort of thing that happens when you're exhausted, fed up and have been holding something back. It happens to Ian Bedloe one night when his wacky sister-in-law, Lucy, asks him to baby-sit for an hour, then doesn't come back. This causes him to miss a romantic dinner date with his girlfriend, Cicely. So by the time Ian's brother, Danny, turns up and drives him to Cicely's house, Ian is steaming. He lets the accusations rip: Hasn't Danny noticed that Lucy goes out a lot, supposedly with her girlfriends, and comes back late, and that she seems to be buying a lot of things she can't really afford? The clues make it all too clear: she's being unfaithful. Danny, who has had suspicions, is now convinced. He lets Ian out of the car and promptly drives into a tree, killing himself. Ian will spend the rest of his life atoning.

title: Alan J. Pakula, Film Director, Dies at 70
description: Alan J. Pakula, a director of many psychologically penetrating and celebrated films including ''Sophie's Choice,'' ''All the President's Men'' and ''Klute,'' died yesterday in a freak accident on the Long Island Expressway. He was 70 and had homes in Manhattan and East Hampton, N.Y.

title: New York City Transit Has $174 Million Surplus
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said in its quarterly financial report yesterday that New York City Transit, its division that oversees subways and buses, had a $173.7 million surplus in the first nine months of the year.

title: Noel Coward's Patter and Heartbreak
description: When the cabaret star Andrea Marcovicci flashes a melting smile and flicks away the suggestion of a tear from eyes that shine with a fervent nostalgia, pop music history opens up like a treasured scrapbook full of pressed flowers and faded photographs. Shopworn dreams of old-time Hollywood gentry shed their tarnish, and the fantasy of a lost and glorious show business past materializes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOBEL, SHELDON
description: LOBEL-Sheldon. President and Co-Founder of Lobel Chemical Corporation. Pioneer in the international sales & marketing of American chemicals and related equipment. Master communicator. Shelly worked tirelessly for 44 years despite continual sickness since the early 1970's. His work ethic and indomitable spirit are inspiring. People all over the globe mourn his death. We miss him, and we are grateful. Lobel Chemical Coporation, New York

title: Morgan Stanley Will Build Glass Tower Near Times Sq.
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company signed a deal yesterday to build a million-square-foot office tower on Seventh Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets, creating a pinstriped corporate campus in what was once the unlikeliest of locations: the Times Square area.

title: Boy Finds His Laser Tip Projects Swastika Image
description: In an incident that New York City's Department of Consumer Affairs said underscored the need to outlaw the sale of all laser pointers to minors, a 12-year-old Jewish boy bought a pointer at a kiosk in Manhattan only to find that it came with a special tip that projected the image of a swastika.

title: American to Buy Reno Air For $124 Million in Cash
description: American Airlines said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Reno Air, a struggling, low-fare company, for $124 million in cash.

title: Iraq Has Network of Outside Help on Arms, Experts Say
description: A network of outside help involving front companies and smugglers is being used by Iraq to supply centers around the country with parts for illegal weapons systems, arms control experts said this week. Iraq has also made efforts to produce some components abroad.

title: Museum Plan For West Side Is Arousing Opposition
description: Preliminary plans by the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum to build a large new branch on a Hudson River pier face major legal, political and community obstacles, not the least of which is almost certain opposition from the Giuliani administration.

title: Merck K.G.a.A. to Add CN Biosciences of U.S.
description: Merck K.G.a.A., the German pharmaceutical and specialty chemical company, said it had agreed to acquire the United States biotechnology company CN Biosciences Inc. for $25 a share in cash, or a total of around $150 million. CN Biosciences, based in San Diego, manufactures more than 9,300 life-science products, including biochemicals, immunochemicals and molecular biology reagents. The company has 264 employees and annual sales of around $50 million. Its shares rose $1.4375, to $24.5625, yesterday.

title: Monicagate: Did Press Do Its Job?
description: To the Editor:

title: AVADO BRANDS SELLS 36 RESTAURANTS FOR $48.3 MILLION
description: Avado Brands Inc. said yesterday that it had sold 36 more Applebee's Neighborhood Grill and Bar restaurants for $48.3 million. Avado, based in Madison, Ga., operates more than 200 casual-dining restaurants under the names Canyon Cafe, Don Pablo's, Hops Restaurant and McCormick & Schmick's. The company, which changed its name last month from Apple South Inc., was the largest Applebee's franchisee. Last December, it announced plans to divest itself of its 264 Applebee's. In the latest deals, Avado sold 23 Applebee's restaurants in Chicago to the Apple Illinois Corporation. It also sold 13 restaurants in Mississippi and Tennessee to Delta Bluff L.L.C. of Memphis.

title: Livent Gets $5 Million From Board
description: Some of Livent Inc.'s wealthy board members came to the Broadway theater company's rescue yesterday, lending it $5 million, enough to keep the curtain up for 10 days.

title: Where Mood Is King
description: A reviewer tends to write as if he's the only member of the audience at a musical performance. But, of course, he's not.

title: French Agree to a European Stock Exchange
description: Struggling to avoid being sidelined in the Continent-wide equities market promised by Europe's soon-to-be-introduced single currency, French authorities said today that the Paris stock exchange would join an alliance between London and Frankfurt that is seen as the precursor of a pan-European market.

title: Handshake on Deal to Move Patriots to Hartford
description: A team owner spurned at home and an eager Governor next door shook hands today, promising the New England Patriots a new home in downtown Hartford and infusing Connecticut's blighted capital with big-league cachet. Gov. John G. Rowland agreed to build a $350 million football stadium for the Patriots' owner, Robert K. Kraft, who said he felt the Massachusetts Legislature had been too stingy with him.

title: Traveling on Foot, but Well Shod, Through Africa
description: THE SHADOW OF KILIMANJARO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHEN, YU CHING
description: CHEN-Yu Ching. Died November 17, 1998. Beloved husband of Hsi Sheng Yue; loving father of Patricia and Harry; devoted grandfather of eight. Respected scholar, journalist and political leader. Editor-in-chief of the Chinese Journal in New York City for many years. He served the government of Taiwan, Republic of China, with great skill and distinction, as Minister, Dept. of Overseas Affairs, Minister, Dept of Information, member of the UN delegation, and close advisor to the President of Taiwan. Professor of Asian Studies and received an honorary doctorate from St. John University, NYC. Until his death, he was the president, Chinese Culture Renaissance Society of New York. Memorial service on Saturday, November 28, 1PM, True Light Lutheran Church, 195 Worth St.

title: Livingston Wants Early Close To It All, 'if It Could Be Done'
description: Representative Robert L. Livingston, soon to be Speaker of the House, said today that he wanted the Clinton impeachment inquiry to be over by the end of the year, before he takes that office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDWEIN, ARTHUR
description: BRANDWEIN-Arthur. We mourn the passing of the brother of our member, Helen Weinberg, and uncle of our member Irwin Adelsberg and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck

title: A Hovering Self, Not Man or Woman
description: An encounter between two bare-chested men is defined by embraces in slow motion and the wordless commentary of five other performers, four women and another man: that is the ruling image in ''Raga: In Search of Femininity,'' a 90-minute work by the Indian choreographer Chandralekha.

title: Image Isn't Everything
description: Kenneth W. Starr's testimony had two purposes today, to restore his once shiny professional reputation and to revive an impeachment inquiry that has lost momentum. On his reputation, he probably did himself some good. On impeachment, there was little sign he moved anyone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREINDLER, HANNAH HASKEL
description: KREINDLER-Hannah Haskel. On October 15, 1998. Age 95. Beloved wife of the late Charles Kreindler. Sister of Charles (deceased), Harry and Benjamin Haskel. Loving aunt to seven and great aunt to 13. Secretary to three presidents of ILGWU. Champion of labor. A respected and loved woman.

title: Ballerina Gone Bad: Unsought Swan Song
description: A 12-year-old student at the Paris Opera Ballet school fears that her idol, the company's star, will be replaced by a Russian ballerina, and she causes an accident that ends the visiting rival's performing career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERPOINT, POWELL
description: PIERPOINT-Powell. Died on November 17, age 76, in NYC. He is survived by his daughter, Harriett P. Bos, her husband, Gerard A. Bos, and three grandchildren, Pier, Abbie and Evan Bos, all of Charlotte NC. A memorial servce will be held at St.James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue on Monday, November 23 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Andrew's School, Middletown, Delaware or Yale University.

title: As Evil as Welles Intended
description: Orson Welles's last laugh must be heartier than ever, now that ''Citizen Kane'' shines bright at the brand-new United Artists Union Square 14 and ''A Touch of Evil'' continues its hit run at the Film Forum. Anyone familiar with Welles's 1958 film noir landmark knows that it could just as well have been called ''A Truckload of Evil,'' and that its crazily sinister plot turns and breathtaking camera work remain astonishingly fresh.

title: Excerpts From Questioning of Starr by Congressmen and Party Counsels
description: MR. LOWELL. -- Mr. Starr, part of the word -- a key word -- in your title is ''independent'' counsel, correct? ''Independent.''

title: Citing Possible Dangers, Groups Seek Ban on Vinyl Toys
description: Twelve consumer, environmental and religious organizations asked the Consumer Product Safety Commission today to ban vinyl toys for small children, four days after Canadian officials advised parents of small children to throw away vinyl teethers and rattles, because of possible kidney and liver damage.

title: RAYROCK ACCEPTS TAKEOVER OFFER FROM GLAMIS GOLD
description: Rayrock Resources Inc., a Canadian gold and copper producer, agreed yesterday to accept an unsolicited takeover offer from Glamis Gold Ltd. for as much as $163.3 million (Canadian), or $105.6 million (United States). The deal would add producing gold mines to Glamis's development projects. The combined company would have five operating gold mines and an exploration and development program in Central America, according to Glamis, which is based in Reno. Under the agreement, Glamis is to pay either 2.2 shares or 1.5 shares plus $3 (Canadian) for each of Rayrock's 18.938 million shares outstanding. Glamis's stock was unchanged yesterday at $2.4375.

title: A Sibling Takes a New Rival for a Ride
description: Dil Pickles is not the first baby whose resentful older sibling wanted to return him to the hospital, but he's probably the only one who has such an interesting trip back. A talking wagon named Reptar takes him down the street, through the playground, into the back of a Night Night Mattress truck and into the forest, which is pretty scary and, as his big brother, Tommy, says, ''biggerer than the park and the backyard put together.'' Luckily the whole ''Rugrats'' gang is with him.

title: On Stage and Off; House Hunting Can Be Tricky
description: The battle over the Helen Hayes Theater ended this week with the announcement that ''Band in Berlin,'' a new musical about a singing troupe in Nazi Germany, would open there in late February.

title: TV Weekend; Reviving A Snooper Sleuth
description: Let's be blunt about the average viewer's response to the very idea of Christopher Reeve in a remake of ''Rear Window'': it sounds like a cruel joke. Mr. Reeve has accumulated an immense amount of good will for his strength and tenacity after a riding accident left him paralyzed from the neck down three years ago. Still, it's one thing to watch James Stewart, in the 1954 original, play a man in a wheelchair with a broken leg who spies on his neighbors and thinks he spots a murderer. It's another to imagine Mr. Reeve taking over a role he would seem to be living rather than acting. How can anyone overlook that difference?

title: The Centipede Expert
description: As I was watching Kenneth Starr do his star turn yesterday and trying to compose my thoughts on the usual legal pad, I suddenly heard a familiar voice. It was muffled and distant but unmistakably that of my former impeachment client, Richard Nixon.

title: Pataki Plans Bill to Protect Abortion Clinics From Harassment
description: Describing the slaying of an abortion doctor in Buffalo last month as a ''heinous act of terror,'' Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he would introduce state legislation to protect abortion clinics from harassment and potential violence.

title: Rangers Rev Up Power Play Against the Powerless Kings
description: It took a journey to the opposite corner of the continent for the Rangers to find a team playing worse than themselves. That team was the injury-riddled Kings and the Rangers beat them by 5-1 tonight in the Forum. The result ended a three-game streak without a victory for the Rangers, and it extended the Los Angeles losing streak to six games.

title: Profit Slides 45% At Societe Generale
description: Societe Generale S.A., one of the largest banks in France, said yesterday that the worst was behind it after reporting that its third-quarter operating profit slid 45 percent, hit by losses from bond trading in Asia and Russia.

title: U.S. Refuses to Buy North Korea Access
description: SEOUL  A U.S. special envoy, Charles Kartman, said Thursday that he had flatly rejected a North Korean demand for a reported $300 million for access to an underground facility in which the North is suspected of developing nuclear weapons.

title: All the Questions Regarding the Lockout Lead Back to Money
description: The National Basketball Association's labor dispute entered its 143d day today. While the league and the players union have broken their two-week stalemate and will meet in Manhattan today for a bargaining session, more than 120 games have already been lost. The earliest the season can start is the third week of December. Players' salary losses will soon top $300 million, and the owners' losses, through gate revenue and local television rights alone, are in the tens of millions of dollars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAW, CAROL HENNING
description: SHAW-Carol Henning. Died at home on November 19, 1998 after a long battle with ovarian cancer. Carol was employed by the Style Department of The New York Times. Burial service will be private. There will be a memorial service at St. Luke's in the Fields on December 5 at 2:30 PM. Friends are invited to her home starting on the evening of November 20, 1998. She is survived by Donald H. Shaw, Victoria Louise Shaw-Williamson, Donaly F. Shaw, her loving husband and stepdaughters, Martha Henning and Jean Cockcroft, her mother and sister and Tristan and John Cockcroft, her nephews. Remembrances may be made to Mothers' Voices, 165 West 46th Street, New York, NY 10036. She was the loving stepmother of Pamela Shaw through whom she became involved with Mothers' Voices.

title: Fed Was Worried About Misinterpretation
description: The Federal Reserve decided to limit its interest rate cut on Sept. 29 to a quarter of a percentage point because it was worried that a bigger reduction might exaggerate its concerns about the risks of an economic slowdown, according to minutes of the deliberations released today.

title: Partisan Dispute Over Plan To Reshape Social Security
description: The Clinton Administration and the Republican leadership in Congress say they are ready to take on the complex and politically sensitive job of reshaping the Social Security system for the next century.

title: Excerpts From Questioning by the Committee's Republican Counsel
description: Following are excerpts from responses by Kenneth W. Starr to questions by Abbe D. Lowell, the minority counsel for Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee, David P. Schippers, the Republican chief counsel, and Representatives Barney Frank, Jerrold Nadler, Charles T. Canady, Bob Inglis, Melvin Watt and Maxine Waters, all members of the panel. The exchanges were recorded by Federal News Service, a private transcription service, and The New York Times.

title: Folk Art As Fine Art
description: Before movies and television, Americans knew how to entertain themselves. One way was through folk art, an engrossing pastime for the maker and a continuing delight for the viewer.

title: Monicagate: Did Press Do Its Job?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUBEN, OSCAR
description: HAUBEN-Oscar. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Men's Club mourn the passing of the beloved father of their devoted member Benjamin Hauben and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, President

title: Thanksgiving Menus
description: Still no Thanksgiving plans? Here are 12 restaurants among the many that offer special holiday menus. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: New Video Releases
description: Dr. Dolittle

title: More On the Hearings
description: EXONERATION, IN PART -- Kenneth W. Starr said he had no evidence of impeachable wrongdoing by President Clinton on the Whitewater land deal, F.B.I. files or the White House travel office. Page A25.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the use of pesticides in New York City misspelled the surname of an exterminator in some copies. He is David Lemke, not Lemkey.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN GAINS. Japan's currency strengthened after the governing party said it would consider deeper cuts in taxes to help stimulate the economy. The dollar settled at 119.99 yen, down from 121.65.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, RAYMOND S.
description: BARON-Raymond S. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the loss of Raymond S. Baron, a cherished friend of the Jewish community. As past president and a member of the Board of Directors of the Herman Goldman Foundation, a staunch supporter of UJA-Federation, Mr. Baron has left a legacy of hope for all those touched by his generosity and concern. His philanthropic traditions live on in the selfless dedication of his son, Richard, who is executive director of the Foundation. We extend our sincerest condolences to Richard and his wife, Margaret; Mr. Baron's daughter, Ronnie Hirsh, and her husband, Fred; and his grandchildren, Jodi, Lara, and Alan. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: Metro Business; Grand Union to Grow
description: The Grand Union Company, which owns 221 supermarkets in the Northeast, said it would spend $290 million in the next four and a half years to add 18 new locations and remodel others.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NEIL, PAULA
description: NEIL-Paula. Dearest Paula, you are in our thoughts and prayers especially at this time. May the peace and love of God be with you always. We Love you. Mom, Myrna and Ke

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EWBANK, WEEB
description: EWBANK-Weeb. The New York Jets have lost a great coach, a great mentor and a great friend. Weeb symbolized the best tradition and commitment and sportsmanship sought and admired in professional sports. His inspirational motivation and extraordinary management skills produced the unique record of winning championships in two leagues, and winning the hearts of everyone fortunate to have been associated with him over a 92 year lifetime. Leon Hess, Chairman

title: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM CUTTING 1,040 JOBS AT 3 OFFICES
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation is cutting 1,040 jobs, or 25 percent of the staff at its various headquarters, as part of a plan to reduce costs by $200 million by 2000. The cuts will affect the corporate headquarters in Los Angeles; oil and gas offices in Bakersfield, Calif., and its chemicals-business headquarters in Dallas. The company said yesterday that it had already cut 540 of the positions. Like other oil companies, Occidental has felt the pressure of depressed oil prices, which are down at least 25 percent from levels a year ago, and of a decline in the petrochemicals business.

title: Japan Stocks Rise Sharply
description: Japanese stocks soared to their highest intraday level in a month after Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi agreed to consider deeper income-tax cuts and revisions to the sales tax as measures to lift the economy out of recession.

title: Ability to Sell Luxury Seats Is Called Key To Success
description: The New England Patriots' proposed move from the Boston area to the much smaller Hartford market could make the team much richer, but only if the team can sell out the luxury seating planned for a 68,000-seat stadium, stadium experts say.

title: Labor Board Backs ABC in Lockout of Strikers
description: In a major setback to ABC's off-camera television workers, a Federal official dismissed their union's unfair labor practices complaint against the network yesterday, declaring the company's 17-day-old lockout of 2,200 workers legal.

title: First of Israel's Pullbacks in West Bank Starts Today
description: Israel is to start transferring 200 square miles of the northern West Bank to Palestinian control by early Friday morning, in line with a Cabinet decision today giving final clearance to the first of three pullbacks under the new peace plan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDWARDS, VERONICA GREEVEN
description: EDWARDS-Veronica Greeven. In New York City, on November 18, 1998. Devoted wife of thirty years to James Edwards. Loving mother of Nina and Philip Edwards. Dear sister of Christine, Rainer, Michael, John and Patrick Greeven. Mrs. Edwards was a designer with Skidmore, Owings & Merrill. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Pay Raise of 21 Percent Is Sought for State Judges
description: New York State's Chief Judge proposed a 21 percent raise for state judges yesterday as part of an annual budget proposal that the Judge submits to the Legislature and Gov. George E. Pataki for approval.

title: Starts of Housing and Building Permits Climb
description: Housing starts recorded their largest increase in 13 months during October, and building permits rose to their highest level in almost nine years, bolstered by low mortgage rates and improved weather in the southern United States.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Yoyogaga'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUTSHER, MILTON
description: KUTSHER-Milton. The National Adoption Center extends condolences to the Kutsher family. Milton Kutsher's loving memory will continue to warm and strengthen his family and friends.

title: Metro Business; Keyspan to Expand Its Energy Services
description: The Keyspan Energy Company, which owns gas and electric utilities in New York, has bought Philip Fritze and Sons of Whippany, N.J., for an undisclosed price to expand its energy services business, Keyspan announced on Wednesday.

title: Sports of The Times; Campbell Knows All The Tricks
description: THROWING the odd elbow. Clutching a stick while the referee is preoccupied. Mashing a sweaty glove in the face of some foe-man. Truth be told, Colin Campbell might even have done them himself.

title: American Topics : Hats for Cowboys With Deep Saddlebags
description: The cowboy hat, now an internationally recognized symbol of America's Old West, started out as a joke.

title: SUNGLASS HUT SAYS IT HAS SHUT 149 UNPROFITABLE STORES
description: Sunglass Hut International, the world's largest retailer of sunglasses, said yesterday that it had closed 149 stores because they were unprofitable or were not meeting expectations and would close as many as 76 more by the end of January. The company, based in Coral Gables, Fla., would not give the locations of the stores to be closed and said the additional closings would bring the total in the fiscal year ending on Jan. 31 to 200 to 225. Sunglass Hut operates 2,003 stores and mall kiosks worldwide. It also has 107 Watch Station stores, several of which are among the stores being closed.

title: PLUS: BOXING; King Returning To New Jersey
description: The promoter Don King was in Manhattan yesterday, doing what he does best, stirring up a buzz about one of his boxing events.

title: Monicagate: Did Press Do Its Job?
description: To the Editor:

title: On My Mind; What We Can't Do
description: American voters can put any citizen in the Presidency. But they cannot make him a leader, not the kind a free country needs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGESCH, MOLLIE KELLY
description: BERGESCH-Mollie Kelly. In Beverly HIlls, California, on November 16. Beloved wife of the late Charles Frederick Bergesch, II and mother of Leslie Manning (Mrs. Richard T. Perkin), Allison Kelly and Charles Frederick, III. Also survived by her three devoted grand-daughters and two sisters, Anne (Mrs. Julian Hemphill) of Rumson, NJ, and Cass (Mrs. Thomas B. Armistead, IV) of Los Angeles. Services private.

title: Qwest-Dutch Deal On Phone Service
description: Royal KPN N.V., the dominant phone company in the Netherlands, said today that it had formed a $1.2 billion joint venture with Qwest Communications International Inc., the No. 4 United States long-distance company, to offer high-speed data services to European businesses.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: MEN'S ROUNDUP
description: UCONN 77, RICHMOND 57

title: Court Lets City Cancel Its Contracts With Group
description: In a setback for the confrontational nonprofit group Housing Works, a state appellate court has unanimously ruled that the Giuliani administration had a right to cancel its contracts with the organization while a lawsuit over allegations of fiscal mismanagement by the group is pending.

title: Davies Looks Strong With a Two-Shot Lead
description: After struggling to qualify for the PageNet Tour Championship, Laura Davies looked capable of winning it yesterday in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEFRIEST, MARGUERITE A.
description: DeFRIEST-Marguerite A. of Southold on November 19, 1998. Wife of David I., Mother of Shirley Danowski and David E. Also survived by six grandchildren and four great grandchildren. Visiting hours today 2-4 and 7-9 pm at DeFriest Funeral Home, Southold, NY Funeral Service Saturday 11am at the Funeral Home. Interment First Presbyterian Cemetery, Southold.

title: When a Printer's Mistake Is a Painter's Opportunity
description: With so much postwar abstraction in New York just now -- Pollock, Rothko, de Kooning drawings -- it's a good time to consider some of the genre's contemporary masters. One is the German painter Sigmar Polke, who has a show of two dozen strange, beautiful, sort of abstract new paintings at Michael Werner Gallery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAIN, GEORGE H.
description: BAIN-George H. Beloved husband of Gladys. Loving and endeared father of Constance and Fabienne. Proud father-in-law of Michael H. Moskow. Cherished, devoted grandfather of Robert (Holly), Eliot (Veronica), and Lisa. Caring uncle, loyal friend, a true gentleman for all seasons. His goodness lives after him and will be remembered by those whose lives he touched. Services Monday November 23, 11:30 a.m., Riverside Memorial Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

title: A War of Words
description: Both Kenneth W. Starr and the White House agreed today that the independent counsel had ''exonerated'' Mr. Clinton on several matters that Mr. Starr had long been investigating.

title: Nationals Begin in Orlando, Site of a Gem by Hamman
description: Some 1,500 began play here today in the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals, which will continue for 10 days. The array of events concludes with the Reisinger Board-a-Match Team Championship.

title: Yefim Geller, Grandmaster Of Daring Attacks, Dies at 73
description: Yefim Geller, a Ukrainian-born grandmaster whose penetrating technical analysis, inspired innovations and brilliant play helped the former Soviet Union almost totally dominate international chess for decades, died on Tuesday at a hospital near his home in Moscow. He was 73.

title: Calcutta Journal; Living Up to Mother Teresa's Legacy
