description: Sister Nirmala padded into the austere room on bare feet, a small brown sparrow of a woman, and alighted next to a hauntingly lifelike statue of another tiny nun, an ancient, wrinkled woman sunk in prayer and dressed in the same simple white sari edged in blue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, CATHERINE
description: O'BRIEN-Catherine. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Catherine O'Brien, associated with The Times since 1993.

title: When Quitting Smoking Proves Too Tough
description: To the Editor:

title: Deal Is Near On New Home For Big Board
description: After months of negotiations, city and state officials have reached the outline of an agreement with executives at the New York Stock Exchange to build a new trading complex and office tower across the street from the market's 96-year-old home on Wall Street.

title: Jakarta Troops Stand Aside as Students Mourn Protesters' Deaths
description: As if they were Boy Scouts doing a good deed, soldiers stopped traffic today to allow student demonstrators in bright yellow college jackets to hand out purple orchids in a gesture of peace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BICKFORD, ALBERT CONDE
description: BICKFORD-Albert Conde, 96, on November 18, 1998 at home in Ardsley-on-Hudson, NY. Husband of the late Esther H. Bickford. Survivors are his son, Robert C. Bickford and daughter-in-law, Margaretta Murphy Bickford of Cold Spring, NY, his son, Nathaniel J. Bickford and daughter-in-law, Jewelle Wooten Bickford of New York City, his granddaughters, Laura C. Bickford, Emily Bickford Lansbury and Elisabeth C. Bickford, his grandsons, Louis N. Bickford, James J. Bickford and Robert H. Bickford, his great granddaughter, Elizabeth Laura Lansbury and his great grandson, Eli Benjamin Bickford. Services at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church, Main Street, Irvington, NY at 3 PM on Sunday, November 22, 1998. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to the Dobbs Ferry Library, 153 Main St, Dobbs Ferry, NY 10522 for its Audio Tapes for the Blind program.

title: Crew Takes on Broad Powers in Bedford-Stuyvesant District
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, moving to restore order in a Brooklyn school district saddled with academic failures and political disputes among the members of its governing board, installed a new superintendent yesterday and placed half of the district's schools under the Chancellor's supervision.

title: Nomura Securities Shuffles Top Management of U.S. Unit
description: Nomura Holding America, the American unit of Japan's biggest securities company, has named a new executive team to decide the fate of Capital Company of America, Nomura's once high-flying but now money-losing mortgage trading operation.

title: Queens Man Is Charged With Killing His Mother
description: A 56-year-old Queens man was arrested yesterday and charged with killing his mother early yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Bertelsmann Signs a Deal Springer-Verlag
description: The media conglomerate Bertelsmann A.G. deepened its wide-ranging investments in books yesterday, signing a 1 billion German mark ($597 million) deal to buy a majority stake in a top international publisher of scientific and medical books. The acquisition will allow Bertelsmann to make new inroads into the United States market.

title: Progress Seen in Setting Up Key Ulster Council
description: Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of the Irish Republic and David Trimble, the First Minister of the new Northern Ireland Assembly, said today that they had made significant progress toward setting up a council that would give Roman Catholic Ireland more influence in the predominantly Protestant British province of Northern Ireland.

title: Guliani Sees A Lesson In Boston
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani warned yesterday that the likely loss of the New England Patriots by Massachusetts should stand as an object lesson for New York City in its dealings with the Yankees and the Mets over proposals for new stadiums in the city.

title: Does Clinton Deserve Censure?; Impeachable Indeed
description: To the Editor:

title: F.C.C. Lets Apartment Renters Install Satellite Dishes
description: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday gave apartment renters the right to install television satellite dishes on their balconies, patios or other private outdoor spaces.

title: Seeing Red Over the Greenmarket
description: Four glorious days a week, New York City's largest Greenmarket converts a stretch of tarmac into a grand agricultural oasis at Union Square. Mounds of sweet yellow peppers, tubs of newly cut roses, crusty black bread, fish, eggs, honey, mushrooms -- such delicacies entice discerning buyers, schoolchildren, even tourists to inspect some of the best and most photogenic produce in the city. These same four days a week, the market also serves as my neighborhood grocery. It is our outdoor community center, and ever since a cow appeared one day at the milk stand, I think of the Greenmarket as our answer to a weekend place in the country.

title: The High Price of Happiness
description: When Gov. John Rowland ran for re-election, he promised to make the rejuvenation of Connecticut's cities a top priority for his second administration. Now the state has learned that Mr. Rowland was secretly negotiating to bring the New England Patriots to Hartford as the centerpiece of his urban development. This week the Governor and the Patriots' owner, Robert Kraft, stunned both Massachusetts and Connecticut by announcing a deal to move the football team into a new $350 million, publicly financed stadium. This is a story in which almost every position deserves to be regarded with both sympathy and a degree of skepticism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANREDER, JULIUS S.
description: ANREDER-Julius S. Beloved husband of the late Paula Anreder. Devoted brother of Henrietta, Harriet, Florence and Marvin, Jean and Steven. Adored uncle of Lynn, Gail, Lewis, Michael, Scott, Eric, Emily, Sandy, Michelle, David, Laura, Susan, Lawrence, Rebecca and eighteen great nieces and nephews. Funeral service Sunday, November 22nd, 1998, 12:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Bure Deal Discussed Again
description: The Islanders have what the Canucks want. And today, Brian Burke, the Vancouver general manager, came all the way to Texas trying to get it.

title: Mexico Rebels Emerge, and Start Complaining
description: Top leaders of the Zapatista rebels, wearing their trademark black ski masks, emerged from their jungle hide-outs to appear in public today for the first time in two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORN, PEGGY
description: KORN - Peggy. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York mourns the passing of Peggy Korn, the beloved wife of our late revered member of the Board, Richard K. Korn. A woman of great strength, she lived her life with extraordinary dignity. Her concerns for the betterment of humanity were translated into concrete acts of righteousness. Along with her family, it is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to her life. David E. Marrus, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the writer and editor David Remnick and his new book, ''King of the World: Muhammad Ali and the Rise of an American Hero,'' misidentified his hometown. It is Hillsdale, N.J., not Hillside.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTLER, MARION DONOVAN
description: BUTLER-Marion Donovan. The Directors and Honary Directors of the National Horse Show are deeply saddened by the loss of Marion Donovan Butler, wife of deceased long time Director of the National, John Butler. Our deepest condolences to her family.

title: Jersey City Police Officer Guilty in Beating Death
description: A Jersey City police officer was found guilty yesterday of aggravated assault and official misconduct in the fatal beating of a 22-year-old man in 1995.

title: Just a Storefront, or an Affront?; In Carnegie Hill, a Big New Drugstore Irks Neighbors
description: Certainly, there are neighborhoods in New York where a Duane Reade drugstore with 2 1/2-foot-high sign of glowing red letters would fit in nicely, said Elizabeth Ashby, a longtime Upper East Side preservationist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSO, ERNST
description: MARSO-Ernst. Beloved husband of Blanche. Stepfather of Gerald Hirschfield, and Eliane Kern. Grandfather of Karen Hirschfield, Mark Hirschfield, Francis Kern, Muriel Ory. Services 10:15 AM Sunday at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City

title: Ethics Panel Is Guarded About Hybrid Of Cow Cells
description: Struggling to respond to President Clinton's request for immediate advice on the hybrid cow-human cell announced earlier this month, the National Bioethics Advisory Commission has delivered a guarded and somewhat tentative reply, based on the few facts available to it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREY, MARCY, DDS, COL. USA, RET
description: FREY-Marcy, DDS, Col. USA-ret, of W. Hartford, CT, b. Dec. 18, 1904 in Brooklyn, NY, died Nov. 19, 1998. He leaves behind a loving family-his wife Deborah (Levy); his children, Joshua, Barbara, Amy and Sara Frey; their spouses and six beloved grandchildren. Funeral services Sunday, Nov. 22 at 1:30 PM in the chapel at Cong. Beth Israel, 701 Farmington Ave., W. Hartford, CT. Burial at Fairview Cemetery, W. Hartford. In lieu of flowers, please make donation to charity of choice.

title: Putting Down the Big Shots While Snuggling Up
description: Stanley Tucci delivers a high-energy charge as Walter Winchell in tonight's fast-breathing account of the sensational rise and abrupt decline of America's pioneering gossip columnist. And in sharp glimpses along the way, Paul Mazursky's movie digs into the connection between popular-front patriotism of the 1930's and 40's and the right-wing populism of the brief-lived but powerfully disruptive McCarthy era.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEAVY, EDWARD T.
description: LEAVY-Edward T. November 21, 1979. Lovingly remembered always. Your children and grandchildren.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECK, JUDITH E.
description: PECK-Judith E. of Tenafly, NJ. Beloved wife of Arthur, devoted mother of Robert, Wendy and Amy. Loving grandmother of Benjamin, Jazmine, David, Sarah and Jeremy. Services ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engle St, Englewood, NJ, Sunday 3pm.

title: Journal; Go for It!
description: Its love affair with Monica at long last over, TV has turned nasty. Only 15 minutes into Kenneth Starr's two-hour-plus monologue -- the ''Meet Joe Black'' of testimony, as one Hollywood observer described it -- the NBC affiliate in New York pulled the plug and switched to Sally Jessy Raphael. The same happened on other channels, in other cities, including Washington itself. In Seattle the local NBC station had to yank the impeachment hearings to quell a popular uprising: viewers were on the phone demanding a return to regularly scheduled programming.

title: Iraq Needs Effective Incentives to Comply
description: To the Editor:

title: Starr's Remarks Sway Few, Polls Show
description: The independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr's appearance before the House Judiciary Committee on Thursday had no significant immediate impact on the nation's view of whether President Clinton should be impeached, two overnight polls released today showed.

title: BAGHDAD DISRUPTS ARMS INSPECTIONS
description: Iraq threw up a new roadblock to the work of United Nations arms inspectors yesterday, less than a week after agreeing to cooperate.

title: Jets Plan To Disrupt The Oilers' Disruption
description: A powerful and confident Jets attack rehearsed the two-minute drill today for the all-or-nothing Tennessee Oilers defense. If it works for the Jets when the teams meet Sunday in Nashville, they will decode the strategy that has helped the Oilers win three straight games and five of their last six.

title: Hide That College Fund!
description: ''The more impoverished you look, the more aid you get,'' counsels ''College Financial Aid for Dummies,'' a popular guide to financing higher education written by Herm Davis and Joyce Lain Kennedy. ''If you have assets of $50,000 or more,'' the authors instruct, ''make major purchases before December 31 of a child's junior year in high school.'' They suggest buying a computer or a car.

title: Tetsuya Fujita, 78, Inventor of Tornado Scale
description: Dr. Tetsuya Fujita, a meteorologist who devised the standard scale for rating the severity of tornadoes and discovered the role of sudden violent down-bursts of air that sometimes cause airplanes to crash, died on Thursday at his home in Chicago. He was 78.

title: Renovated Library Is a Paradigm
description: To the Editor:

title: Davenport And Hingis Use Wits To Gain
description: There was a method to their madness. Last night revenge was the password that pushed Lindsay Davenport and Martina Hingis into the semifinals of the Chase Championships at Madison Square Garden.

title: GERMAN DEAL SEEN FOR NO. 8 U.S. BANK
description: Deutsche Bank A.G., Germany's biggest bank, is on the verge of signing an agreement to acquire the Bankers Trust Corporation, the eighth-largest American bank, for somewhere between $7.5 billion and $8 billion, executives involved in the talks said yesterday.

title: Renovated Library Is a Paradigm
description: To the Editor:

title: CENDANT TO SELL DIVISION TO FRENCH CONCERN
description: The Cendant Corporation, the marketing and franchising company trying to recover from an accounting scandal, announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell its software business to the French utilities and communications company Vivendi S.A. for nearly $1 billion. Vivendi will give Cendant $800 million cash and make payments of up to $200 million through 1999. Cendant Software makes educational and entertainment software. It is expected to report sales of around $600 million this year. The software unit was part of CUC International Inc., which merged with HFS Inc. to form Cendant in December 1997. Cendant later learned that CUC had posted phony profit data. Cendant, based in Parsippany, N.J., said it would see a $450 million gain.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A Late Surge Propels Dow Closer to July 17 Record

title: Dangerous Delays in Indonesia
description: After 32 years of dictatorship under President Suharto, Indonesians are understandably eager for free elections. President B. J. Habibie must move faster in providing them, and avoid the Suharto-style repression he has flirted with in recent weeks.

title: Does Clinton Deserve Censure?; Not Meant to Punish
description: To the Editor:

title: Steinbrenner Is Said to Be Close To Sale of Yankees to Cablevision
description: George M. Steinbrenner 3d is close to completing a deal to sell a majority interest in the Yankees to Cablevision, a media company that owns the Rangers, the Knicks and Madison Square Garden, two business associates of Mr. Steinbrenner's said yesterday. The sale will probably be concluded early next year, they said, and will keep Mr. Steinbrenner in charge of the team.

title: Applying Drum Rhythms to the Piano
description: One of the many ways to take on the protean work of the pianist Marcus Roberts is to approach the music the way he does in part, and that's to think like a drummer. On Tuesday night at the Village Vanguard (178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street in the West Village), where he performs through Sunday, Mr. Roberts was in theory playing an unaccompanied set of Scott Joplin and rag timelike compositions. But their rhythmic complexity and the self-conscious applications of drumming ideas, the rhythmic play of his two hands, made the music roil with tension and association.

title: Train Passenger Injured When Pole Hits Window
description: A 52-year-old woman riding on the Morris and Essex rail line of New Jersey Transit was critically injured yesterday morning when her train ran into a metal electrical conductor dangling from a disabled train on an adjacent track, knocking the window of her rail car onto her head.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEITNER, SYLVIA (TZIPPY)
description: LEITNER-Sylvia (Tzippy). In 1940, I was blessed with a beautiful bride. Children and grandchildren made us thrive. Then, in 1989 came the accident and you did not survive. In 1998, precious memories are all that remain, like an antidote for the loss and the pain. With love, Nat

title: Victory Would Cap Siedlecki's Rebuilding Effort
description: One of the Ivy League's surprising developments has been Jack Siedlecki's rebuilding job in New Haven. After a 1-9 season, the second-year coach has guided the Elis to a 5-4 record (4-2 Ivy). If Yale wins at Harvard (4-5, 3-3) in the 115th edition of The Game this afternoon and Cornell beats Penn, Yale will capture a share of the conference title.

title: Letter of Resignation From Ethics Adviser, and Starr's Letter in Response
description: Following are the letter of resignation submitted today by Samuel Dash, ethics adviser to the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr, protesting Mr. Starr's decision to testify in the House impeachment hearing against President Clinton, and Mr. Starr's letter in response:

title: Rugged to Romantic, A Prizewinner's Range
description: Axel Strauss, violinist

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MIAMI COMPUTER SUPPLY CORP., Dayton, Ohio, a provider of computer supplies and audio-visual products, will acquire Dreher Business Products Corp., a Cleveland-based distributor of computer supplies with $80 million in annual revenue, for an undisclosed price.

title: Renovated Library Is a Paradigm
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHAPIRO, ROSE
description: SHAPIRO-Rose. Mom, it's thirteen years since you passed away. Sadly missed, much loved, always remembered

title: $71 Million for van Gogh Portrait
description: A new chapter in auction history unfolded at Christie's on Thursday night when a haunting van Gogh self-portrait from 1889 was sold for $71.5 million, nearly three times its high estimate. It is the second highest price ever paid for a van Gogh at auction and the third highest for any artwork sold at auction.

title: MATCHUPS
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, ABRAHAM (AL)
description: WEINSTEIN-Abraham (Al). On November 19, 1998. Beloved husband of Frances. Loving father of Robert. Dear brother-in-law of Goldie Weinstein. Devoted uncle of Elinore and Allen. Tireless community activist, dedicated member of the United Nations staff for 40 years. We love him and he will be greatly missed. Service Sunday, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Kings' Johnson Gets Even and Then Gets a Suspension
description: Dan Cloutier is likely to make a second consecutive start in goal Saturday night, when the Rangers finish the California phase of their tour with a game against the San Jose Sharks. But most of the conversation surrounding the team today did not concern the rookie goaltender and his fine performance in a 5-1 victory against Los Angeles on Thursday night. Nor were tongues wagging that much about Aleksei Kovalev's first two goals of the season in a well-rounded display of his enormous potential.

title: R. H. Whitstock, 68; Led Guide Dog Group
description: Robert H. Whitstock, a retired vice president of the Seeing Eye organization in Morristown, N.J., which trains guide dogs and those who use them, died on Oct. 16 at the home of a daughter, Holly Seeger, in Palisades, N.Y. He was 68 and lived in Cortland, N.Y.

title: Microsoft Finds Silver Lining in Tokyo Reprimand
description: After a yearlong antitrust investigation, Japan's Fair Trade Commission told the Microsoft Corporation yesterday to change permanently one of its marketing practices and pointedly warned the company to watch its step in the Internet browser market.

title: Four More Witnesses Called For Impeachment Inquiry
description: Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee sent subpoenas today to four witnesses in the expanding impeachment inquiry, setting up possible new conflicts with lawyers over privilege claims even as panel members planned a firmer timetable that could result in a full House vote on impeachment by mid-December.

title: Iranian Film Is Canceled After Protest By Salinger
description: Under the threat of legal action by representatives of J. D. Salinger, the Film Society of Lincoln Center announced yesterday that it was canceling a screening of an Iranian film adapted from Mr. Salinger's 1961 book ''Franny and Zooey.''

title: Takeover of Troubled H.M.O. Complicated by Federal Court
description: The state takeover of the H.I.P. Health Plan of New Jersey was complicated today by proceedings in a Federal bankruptcy court in Delaware.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a memorial service for Clark M. Clifford, the lawyer and adviser to Presidents, referred incorrectly to a fellow Washington political strategist, Senator Albert Gore Sr. Mr. Gore, the Vice President's father, is not ''late''; he is 90 and lives in Carthage, Tenn.

title: Arab Town Celebrates As It Sheds Occupation
description: All day long the Palestinian people of Qabatiya lined the dusty streets of this quarry town, waiting to be liberated. They strung streamers, hung flags, dressed their pint-sized children in khaki uniforms and plastered their bicycles with pictures of Yasir Arafat.

title: Amid U.S. Suit, Northwest Buys Stake in Rival
description: Northwest Airlines acquired a controlling stake in the rival Continental Airlines for $430 million in cash and stock yesterday, despite a lawsuit by the Justice Department that says the deal violates Federal antitrust laws.

title: When Quitting Smoking Proves Too Tough
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUG, JULIA F.
description: HUG-Julia F. Of Garden City, NY on November 19, 1998. Beloved wife of Arthur Jr. Loving mother of Julie Carney, Jeannette and Joanne Powers. Dear Nana of three grandchildren. Devoted sister of Jean Fowler. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th St. Garden City. Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Interment private. Memorial service Garden City Community Church, Tuesday. 10 AM. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Lung Association appreciated.

title: Does Clinton Deserve Censure?; Not 'Weak' at All
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York; Once Makers, Now Students Of History
description: JOHN GLENN proved that a 77-year-old politician and former astronaut could pull a few levers of power and once again explore the final frontier. He returned to Earth and New York, where the modest flurry of ticker tape could have been outdone had people showered him with shredded copies of the articles about how his trip was a victory for the elderly. Gina Liebow would now like to have the final two words on all this.

title: STARR ETHICS AIDE QUITS TO PROTEST HOUSE TESTIMONY
description: Samuel Dash abruptly resigned today as Kenneth W. Starr's ethics adviser to protest the independent counsel's decision to testify before the House Judiciary Committee as ''an aggressive advocate'' for the impeachment of President Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERNO, EUGENE J.
description: KERNO-Eugene J. A New York City Attorney. On November 18, 1998 at age 86. Beloved father of Raymond E. Kerno and loving grandfather of Annija. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St, Sunday, November 22nd, 6PM. Interment Monday, Evergreen Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Baltic Association to the United Nations, 203 E. 82 St, N.Y. N.Y. 10028.

title: THINK TANK
description: For nearly 500 years, kings, Parliamentarians, business executives, worldly men and women have turned to ''The Prince,'' by Niccolo Machiavelli, for advice on the ins and outs of getting power and keeping it. Now there's even a version for children. Claudia Hart, a visual artist who lives in New York City, has combined maxims from ''The Prince'' with illustrations from such children's classics as ''The Little Prince'' and ''Peter Rabbit'' in ''A Child's Machiavelli'' (Viking Penguin).

title: WORLD BRIEFINGS
description: EUROPE

title: Sports of The Times; After the Apologies, the Humiliation Remains
description: IN Hampton, Va., and Lubbock, Tex., a calm has been shattered. A women's college basketball game canceled. Two communities, one largely black and one largely white, are left to wonder whether games are all they have in common, whether this latest wound will ever heal.

title: CONTINENTAL AIRLINES BUYS 10 PLANES FROM BOEING
description: Continental Airlines Inc., the fifth-largest United States carrier, bought 10 of the Boeing Company's 767-200 planes for flights to Europe and South America in an order valued at as much as $930 million. The airline said the long-haul planes, seating 176 passengers, would replace Boeing 747's and DC-10's that the carrier plans to retire. The new planes will begin arriving in 2000. The contract is a boost for Boeing's wide-body jet program, which is struggling because a recession in Asia cut sales in what was one of the fastest-growing plane markets. The airline also has the option to buy another 28 wide-body planes, typically used for longer flights, between 2000 and 2005.

title: U.S. Breaks a Huge Alien-Smuggling Ring
description: Federal agents have cracked an international ring that made hundreds of millions of dollars smuggling thousands of Indians and other Asians into the United States over the last three years, the Government announced today.

title: Striking Teachers Defy Judge's Order
description: Teachers here defied a judge's back-to-work order today and extended their strike to a second day, crippling the state's second largest school district, where five public high schools were closed and grammar schools were open only half a day.

title: Toyota Earnings Decline by 20%
description: Not even solid sales in the United States and a weak yen that made those sales more valuable could save the Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest car maker and one of its most financially sound companies, from a decline in profits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZFELD, MICHAEL D.
description: HERZFELD-Michael D. On November 18, 1998. Son of the late Saul and Sharlye Herzfeld. Father of Anna. Graveside services Sunday, November 22, 1:30 P.M., Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENSTOCK, EDITH B.
description: ROSENSTOCK-Edith B. On November 19, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Jesse M. Loving mother of Robert, mother-in-law of Gerda, adoring grandmother of Elisabeth, Thomas and Nicholas. She will be deeply missed. Service private.

title: William McCarthy, 79, Former Head of Teamsters
description: William J. McCarthy, a New England labor leader who served a term as national president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters when the union was fighting Federal racketeering charges, died on Thursday at Symmes Hospital in Arlington, Va. He was 79 and lived in Arlington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, ELIZABETH (NEE LIZZIE)
description: FOX-Elizabeth (nee Lizzie). On Nov. 19, 1998 in New Canaan, CT. Wife of the late Heywood Fox, beloved mother of Elizabeth Fisher of Menlo Park, CA, Ginny Wagenseller of Westport, CT, and Henry Fox of Rocky River, OH. Seven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren also survive. Funeral services will be held at 2 PM, Dec. 5, 1998 in St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan followed by inurnment in St. Mark's Memorial Columbarium. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Old Sturbridge Village, Sturbridge, MA 01566 or to Westover School, Middlebury, CT 06762.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMINGHAM, THOMAS V.
description: BERMINGHAM - Thomas V., Priest of the Society of Jesus; teacher and scholar of the classics; dearest brother of Jack, Peggy and Bob Bermingham, Mary Byrne, Betty Stevens, Edith Cavanagh, Helen Keller and the late Suzanne Harrington; and a source of joy, love and inspiration to so, so many others. Contributions in his memory may be made to the T.V. Bermingham Scholarship Fund, Fordham University, 113 West 60th St, New York, NY 10023.

title: Songs in a Liquid Key With Afro-Brazilian Rhythms
description: Virginia Rodrigues, vocalist

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, MYRA SEIDEN
description: HIRSCH-Myra Seiden. My Beloved Sister, love is eternal, but I will miss you forever. Carolyn

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: A GOOD LAST PLACE
description: Many Americans dread nursing homes and dying in one, but more homes are finding ways to care for disability with dignity. A report by Sara Rimer, Section 1.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about doctors' discontent with managed care groups misstated the surname of an author of an article in The New England Journal of Medicine on the subject. He is Dr. Kevin Grumbach, not Brumbach.

title: Discord Turns Academe's Hot Team Cold
description: If ever an academic department was hot, it was the English department at Duke University in the late 1980's and early 1990's, when it was famously reinventing itself. Recruiting star professors, it bounded up the national rankings and became for a time the capital of cutting-edge literary studies as well as many a conservative's favorite example of academic excess.

title: Does Clinton Deserve Censure?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN RIPER, PETER
description: VAN RIPER-Peter. On November 18, 1998. Artist/Musician. Loving partner to Dina Helal. Dear collaborator to Xenia Balcells and Simone Forti. Brother to Hendrieka Van Riper and uncle to Lindsay. Reposing at The Evergreen Funeral Home Inc., 131 Nassau Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11222 on Sunday, November 22 from 2-5pm and from 7-9:30pm. Cremation on Monday, November 23, Fresh Pond Crematory.

title: Religion Journal; Leaders Offer Guidelines For Life in Larger World
description: When leaders of major religious organizations believe their flocks to be facing a matter of overarching importance, they may decide guidance is best given through a formal pastoral statement, a nuanced and reflective document sent to all congregations under their care.

title: When Quitting Smoking Proves Too Tough
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARHI, PAMELA ANN
description: FARHI-Pamela Ann. In New York City, on Nov. 19, 1998. Beloved daughter of Jean-Pierre and Carol; devoted sister of Jacques, Paul and Jane-Iris. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, on Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street, on Sunday, Nov. 22, at 9:45 A.M.

title: 2 More Men Are Sought In the Slaying Of a Doctor
description: The F.B.I. has sent a notice to Police Departments across the country asking them to look for two men in connection with the slaying of a Buffalo doctor who performed abortions, The Hamilton (Ontario) Spectator reported in today's edition.

title: REMAINING STATES APPROVE THE PACT ON TOBACCO SUITS
description: The largest legal and financial threat to the tobacco industry ended yesterday when 46 states accepted a $206 billion plan to settle state lawsuits filed against cigarette makers to recover Medicaid money spent treating diseases related to smoking.

title: FPL GROUP AGREES TO SELL TURNER FOODS' CITRUS UNIT
description: FPL Group Inc. has agreed to sell its Turner Foods' citrus division to a private partnership that includes the King Ranch of Texas. Terms were not disclosed. Several newspaper reports in Florida said, however, that Turner Foods, based in Punta Gorda, Fla., could fetch as much as $200 million. FPL Group said the partnership, made up of King Ranch's Running W Citrus unit and Collier Enterprises, based in Naples, Fla., would buy 29,000 acres in seven southern Florida counties containing more than two million orange, grapefruit and specialty trees. FPL Group, based in Juno Beach, Fla., is the holding company for Florida Power and Light, an electric utility.

title: How Even 'Good' Stereotypes Can Be Bad; Myriad Subjects With a Common Thread: The Images We Build to Define Ourselves
description: When ''The Bell Curve'' was published in 1994, black groups angrily protested the authors' suggestion that because black people score lower on intelligence tests, they have genetically inferior mental capacities. But amid the outcry, Sander Gilman spotted what he thought was an equally insidious assumption about Jews. Although the book seemed to pay Ashkenazi Jews a compliment by implying they are smartest because they score highest on intelligence tests, Mr. Gilman, who studies stereotypes, was troubled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRENCH, MARGARET HOENING
description: FRENCH-Margaret Hoening. On November 18, 1998. Artist and widow of artist Jared French. Reposing Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home. Burial private.

title: SUNY-Buffalo Making Jump To Big Time
description: Chicken wings. Lake-effect snow. Pro hockey. Flutie Flakes. College football.

title: Report of Plot to Kill Tycoon Leads Yeltsin to Call Inquiry
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin ordered an inquiry today into spectacular charges leveled earlier this week -- so far without evidence -- that Russia's equivalent of the F.B.I. plotted to kill one of the country's most influential tycoons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAKULA, ALAN J.
description: PAKULA-Alan J. The New York Public Library expresses its deepest sympathies to Hannah C. Pakula on the tragic and untimely passing of her husband, Alan J. Pakula. As one of America's most celebrated filmmakers, Mr. Pakula's important work as director, screenwriter and producer has been an inspiration to many millions. The Library is proud to include his work among our collections. He was a devoted friend and supporter of the Library, and we will miss him greatly. Mrs. Vincent Astor, Honorary Chairman Marshall Rose, Chairman Paul LeClerc, President Elizabeth Rohatyn, Chairman Emeritus Andrew Heiskell, Chairman Emeritus

title: Spitzer Still Leads Race As Ballots Dwindle
description: State election officials said yesterday that Eliot L. Spitzer, the Democratic challenger in the race for state attorney general, had a 19,646-vote lead over Dennis C. Vacco, the Republican incumbent, with fewer than 10,000 paper ballots left to count.

title: Bowl Championship Series Looking Closely at 4 Games
description: The simplest way to think of them is as playoff games -- four pivotal clashes today that will go a long way in determining which teams remain alive for a national championship game.

title: Liberal Bishop Signals Moderation
description: Coming from the Rev. John P. Croneberger to his congregants at the Church of the Atonement in Tenafly one Sunday morning, the question seemed deceptively simple: what did they think was the most important book in his life? ''They bit,'' he said, a wry smile inching across his face. ''They said the Bible.'' But the sermon was about ''the use and abuse of time,'' and to illustrate the point he held up not the Good Book but his date book.

title: Sides Soften Their Stances Over Lockout Talks
description: Fearing that the season was in jeopardy, National Basketball Association players and owners resumed negotiations yesterday for the first time since Oct. 28. In their longest bargaining session during the nearly five-month-old labor impasse, both sides made compromises.

title: Man Accused of Murder Of His Estranged Wife
description: A Brick Township man was arrested yesterday and charged with the murder of his estranged wife, whose body had been discovered hours earlier in the trunk of her car on a street in Paterson, county prosecutors said.

title: Guidelines on Sentencing Are Flawed, Justice Says
description: Justice Stephen G. Breyer, an architect and longtime supporter of the Federal sentencing guidelines, issued a detailed critique this week of how the guidelines were working and called for Federal judges to regain some of their traditional discretion to make the punishment fit the crime.

title: SPEEDFAM WILL ACQUIRE INTEGRATED PROCESS EQUIPMENT
description: Speedfam International Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Integrated Process Equipment Corporation for $195.9 million in stock. Speedfam, based in Chandler, Ariz., and Integrated Process, based in San Jose, Calif., supply wafer processing systems to the semiconductor industry. Speedfam had revenue of $36.4 million in the three months ended Aug. 3, while Integrated process reported sales of $25 million for the quarter ended Sept. 30. Shares of Speedfam were up $1.9375, to $16.8125, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of Integrated Process rose 56.25 cents, to $11.4375, also in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERPOINT, POWELL
description: PIERPOINT-Powell. Died on November 17, age 76, in NYC. He is survived by his daughter, Harriett P. Bos, her husband, Gerard A. Bos, and three grandchildren, Pier, Abbie and Evan Bos, all of Charlotte NC. A memorial servce will be held at St.James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue on Monday, November 23 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Andrew's School, Middletown, Delaware or Yale University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTZMAN, JULIUS
description: SALTZMAN-Julius. Of Fort Lauderdale, FL and N.Y.C. Much loved brother, brother-in-law, uncle, and great-uncle, passed away peacefully on November 28 at age 81 to join his beloved companion, the late Moe Fine, his cherished sister, the late Helen Pepose, and his dear brother, the late Murray Saltzman, after a brave battle with melanoma at the home of his niece, Maura Copeland and her husband, Paul of Swampscott, MA. Also survived by his brother, Irving Saltzman, and sisters-in-law Rae and Beatrice; nephews, Alan Saltzman, Robert Saltzman and wife Kathy, Jay Pepose and wife, Susan Feigenbaum, and niece, Arlene Berkman and husband Milton. He was adored by ten grandnieces and grand-nephews; Lysa, Lauryn, Seth, David, Marnine, Daniel, Maxwell, Samuel, Morissa, and Harry. He will be greatly missed. Services at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Sunday, November 22 at 12 P.M. Most appreciated donations in his memory to the FineSaltzman Nursing Fellowship, c/o Jimmie Holland, M.D., MemorialSloan Kettering, 275 York Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GITHENS, WILLIAM FRENCH
description: GITHENS-William French. A pioneer in producing and popularizing newsreels, died of complications following a stroke. He is survived by his stepson John Lawrence Githens, his stepdaughter Marianne Githens and his grandson Jonathan Githens-Mazer. Memorial service will be held at Vinson Hall, Virginia, and burial at Saint Mary's Cemetery in New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Nothern Virginia Hospice, Arlington Virginia.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the presidential race in Argentina reversed the posts held by two candidates. Fernando de la Rua is the Mayor of Buenos Aires, and Eduardo Duhalde is the Governor of Buenos Aires province. The last name of a third candidate was misspelled. She is Graciela Fernandez Meijide, not Meijilde.

title: Davies Extends Her Lead To 4 Shots
description: If Laura Davies continues to dominate the par-5 holes at the Pagenet L.P.G.A. Tour Championship, she will be difficult to catch.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HOGS AT 18 1/2-YEAR LOW. Prices fell as heavy supplies of market-ready animals overwhelmed demand from meatpackers supplying pork for the holidays. The December contract fell 0.7 cent, to 29.925 cents a pound.

title: No Easy Out for Anyone in House
description: If Kenneth W. Starr forcefully restated his case against President Clinton on Thursday, he did nothing to resolve the political dilemma facing the Republican-controlled House: whether to defy public opinion and impeach Mr. Clinton for his efforts to cover up his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, ANNA
description: FRANKEL-Anna. On Nov 20, 1998. Loving mother of Barbara and Norma. Cherished mother-in-law of Dan. Devoted grandmother and great-grandmother. Services to be held Sunday 11am at the Nieberg Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Avenue.

title: Weaving a Harmony Of Teachers and Students
description: University of Iowa Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FURST, JANET (BOTWINIK)
description: FURST-Janet (Botwinik) of Manhattan. Devoted mother of Anne Ramsden of Wakefield, MA. Loving sister of David Botwinik of Port Washington, L.I. Dear grandmother of Matthew and Benjamin. Donations in her memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Assn.

title: Pilgrims' Progress to Eager Connecticut Stirs Rancor in Bay State
description: New England is generally viewed as a bastion of civility, a place where Frostian musings about good fences making good neighbors do not immediately elicit cries to shut up. But in recent days, trash talking has replaced poetry recitals in the meadows and mill towns to the east.

title: Bring a No. 2 Pencil and $6,000
description: The American school system is diverse by design. An ''A'' from Bronx Science does not compare with one from Ozark High. Hence, the common yardstick of standardized exams like the Scholastic Assessment Test. But ever since these tests were introduced, they have been bad-mouthed. They are said to discriminate by sex, race and culture.

title: Witnesses Trace Brutal Killing of Gay Student
description: Before savagely beating Matthew Shepard with a pistol butt, one of his tormentors taunted him, saying, ''It's Gay Awareness Week,'' a police investigator has testified at a hearing in Laramie, Wyo., for one of two men accused of the murder of the gay college student.

title: Corporations and Ticket Buyers Signal Strong Interest in Hartford Stadium for Patriots
description: The day after the Governor of Connecticut announced a deal to build a football stadium for the New England Patriots in Hartford, a Patriot official said today that the team had received 3,000 requests for 10,000 season tickets, and business leaders said they were interested in leasing the luxury suites that would be critical to the team's success.

title: Mets Trade a Catcher Not Named Hundley
description: The Mets traded their backup catcher yesterday. And no, he was not Todd Hundley.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about the House impeachment hearings misstated the surname of an aide to the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, in some copies. He is Charles G. Bakaly 3d, not Beckly.

title: The Plot Keeps Thickening Like a Well-Made Irish Stew
description: You Irish! (to borrow a phrase from the dashing English captain in ''The Shaughraun''). What else can one say about a people who make parties of their funerals and whose sons have kept the theater alive for 300 years, even if they had to go to London to do it.

title: Statistics and Stories For the Hockey Fan
description: For years, baseball, pro football and pro basketball have had coffee-table encyclopedias encompassing their histories and heroes. Now hockey has joined in with the publication of Total Hockey, a 1,878-page, 6i-pound compendium with detailed major league and minor league statistics of the 4,959 players who have played in the National Hockey League since 1917.

title: LIFE BY DESIGN; The Life Sciences, on a Tear
description: There is nothing like a good scandal to blunt the edge of scientific discovery. Simply consider what science news was announced between Sept. 11 (the day Kenneth Starr sent his report on President Clinton to Congress) and yesterday (when he appeared before the House Judiciary Committee). In those 10 weeks, there has been an extraordinary torrent of reports from laboratories over the world hinting at the prospect that the nervous system may be renewed, that the foundations are being laid for the regeneration of worn-out organs and that there may yet be systematic ways of extending the human life span.

title: Steinbrenner Tells Williams's Agent: Show Me the Offers
description: The agent for outfielder Bernie Williams says there is a lively market for the services of his client, that he has offers of seven and eight years in hand. George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, does not believe him.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday, about companies that have not filled the post of chief financial officer in many months, misstated the reason for a recent slowdown at one such company, the Electronic Data Systems Corporation. Its earnings have suffered from cost-cutting by customers, particularly the General Motors Corporation, not from the global financial turmoil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDWARDS, VERONICA GREEVEN
description: EDWARDS-Veronica Greeven. In New York City, on November 18, 1998. Devoted wife of thirty years to James Edwards. Loving mother of Nina and Philip Edwards. Dear sister of Christine, Rainer, Michael, John and Patrick Greeven. Mrs. Edwards was a designer with Skidmore, Owings & Merrill. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Garnes's Fast Healing Gives Hope to Defense
description: The extraordinary recuperative powers of Sam Garnes are again complicating matters for the Giants.

title: A Literary Sherman in Pastels, Tom Wolfe Takes Atlanta
description: You might have the grandest house in all of Buckhead and the summer place on Sea Island and the biggest private jet and the ranch or two in Wyoming, every toy a man could possibly long for -- and yet your failure to make the roster of the Piedmont Driving Club would always be hanging over you, like a reproach.

title: Head of a City Workers' Local Pleads Guilty to Kickbacks
description: The head of a municipal union local pleaded guilty to embezzlement yesterday in the first criminal charges in a corruption investigation of District Council 37, the umbrella group of New York City municipal workers.

title: Taliban Proclaim Bin Laden Innocent in Embassy Attacks
description: The militant Islamic fundamentalists who rule most of Afghanistan today declared Osama bin Laden, accused of masterminding the bombings of two American embassies in Africa, an innocent and free man.

title: BLUE RANGE REJECTS BID BY BIG BEAR EXPLORATION
description: The Blue Range Resource Corporation, a petroleum company in Calgary, Alberta, yesterday rejected Big Bear Exploration Ltd.'s takeover offer, saying it expects to receive a higher bid. Blue Range said the company's assets are worth more than Big Bear's offer of about $5.50 (Canadian) a share, or a total of $194 million (Canadian). Big Bear also said it would assume debt of $105 million. The actual offer by Big Bear, which is also based in Calgary, is 11 of its shares for each Blue Range share. Blue Range has now made its financial and operating records available to would-be bidders. Gordon Ironside, the company's chief executive, has said he is hoping for a bid of at least $8 a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURIEL, DAVID N.
description: TURIEL-David N. Services Sunday November 22, 12:30 p.m. at the Riverdale Temple, Riverdale, Bronx NY. Interment Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Italy Rejects Turkey's Bid For the Extradition of Kurd
description: An Italian court of appeals today rejected Turkey's request for the extradition of a Kurdish rebel leader, deepening tensions between Italy and Turkey.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I never try to fill her shoes. I have to wear my own small shoes. I don't have to be Mother Teresa, just Sister Nirmala, and

title: A Bow With a Bite, Both Fun and Serious
description: Janice Martin, violinist

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Breaks Ring That Smuggled Asians

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPPER, ROBERT L.
description: POPPER-Robert L. New York Citizens' Committee on Aging mourns its beloved former Chairman and longest-serving Associate. We will not see his like again. Doris L. Rosenberg, Pres. Jerry A. Shroder, Exec. Dir.

title: HOCKEY; Now Salo Has Security, And Isles Have a Goalie
description: In his first three seasons as an Islander, Tommy Salo was always looking over his shoulder. There was always a young, promising goalie waiting behind him for an opportunity to play. Salo knew that even when he did play well, the slightest error could be his last.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, HANNA
description: COHN-Hanna. Beloved wife of the late Cantor Richard Cohn. Loving mother of Margit, Ruth Stern, Susan, the late Ilse and Heather Pressler. Devoted grandmother and great-grandmother. Adored sister of the late Amy Geisenberg. Services Sunday 1:00 at The Astoria Center of Israel, 27-35 Crescent Street.

title: Does Clinton Deserve Censure?; Starr Served Country
description: To the Editor;

title: 'Zarya' Is Up, and Space Jigsaw Puzzle Starts
description: The first piece of the international space station was orbiting Earth today, sprouting antennae and unfolding solar power panels as it awaited other segments, which will eventually grow into the largest orbital laboratory in history.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Opening Door Policy; Latin America Leads Way in Emerging Markets' Revival
description: The door to the global bond market has opened a crack, and Argentina and some Latin American companies are starting to slip through. Their success in borrowing money in the last few weeks is a sign that the financial crisis that seemed so severe in emerging markets and elsewhere just two months ago is easing.

title: Renovated Library Is a Paradigm
description: To the Editor:

title: Samuel Ramey Lets a Nice Guy Mingle With His Demons
description: Samuel Ramey spends so much of his time playing blackguards, uneasy kings and devils that he is bound to take the opportunity of a recital to try on other roles. But he is just so very good at what he does regularly. His natural vocal color is matte black. And the force of his singing not only provides him with authority but sounds like ice from hell.

title: COMPX INTERNATIONAL WILL ACQUIRE THOMAS REGOUT
description: Compx International Inc., a maker of ergonomic furniture and computer supplies, has agreed to acquire Thomas Regout Holdings N.V., a closely held Dutch maker of ball bearing furniture slides, for $53 million. Compx, based in Mauldin, S.C., had annual revenue of $108 million last year. Thomas Regout has annual sales of about $59 million. Its main plant is in Maastricht, the Netherlands. It also has a plant in Grand Rapids, Mich., which accounted for 29 percent of the company's sales this year. Compx also said yesterday that it had closed its acquisition of Timberline Lock Ltd., a maker of office-furniture locks, for $7.9 million.

title: CHAMPION ENTERPRISES IN DEAL TO ADD HOMES OF MERIT
description: Champion Enterprises Inc., the top United States maker of manufactured homes, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Homes of Merit Inc. for an undisclosed price to expand in Florida. Homes of Merit is the largest builder of manufactured homes in Florida, with 1997 sales of about $120 million. The acquisition will add six plants to Champion's existing 60 and expand its high-end production. Champion, based in Auburn Hills, Mich., has bought or agreed to buy 15 companies, including Homes of Merit, since December and is now the third-largest United States retailer of prefabricated dwellings. Champion's shares rose rose 75 cents yesterday, to $21.3125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN WEAKENS. A rally in Japan's currency faltered after Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa dashed some hope that the Government would cut a sales tax to stimulate the economy. The dollar rose to 120.30 yen from 119.99.

title: BEA SYSTEMS SHARES FALL ON SALES GROWTH WARNINGS
description: The stock of BEA Systems Inc., the No. 2 maker of software for airline reservation systems, lost about half their value yesterday after the company issued a surprise warning that sales growth would slow because customers had delayed orders. Shares plunged $13.0625, to $13.9375, in trading of 20.2 million shares, making it the most active United States stock. The company, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., blamed recessions in Asia and economic slowdowns elsewhere for the delay in corporate purchases. BEA was founded in 1995.

title: U.S. Questions The Placement Of City Pupils
description: The Federal Education Department's Office of Civil Rights has challenged Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew to show evidence that thousands of black and Hispanic students are being properly placed in special education programs, saying that a Federal analysis shows evidence of discrimination that Dr. Crew has failed to report or investigate.

title: Does Clinton Deserve Censure?; Democrats' Right Call
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWARK, ELEANORE Y.
description: NEWARK-Eleanore Y. 82. Jacksonville, FL. On November 16, 1998. Retired Principal of East Plain Elementary School, Massapequa, N.Y. Survived by John and Patricia Newark, and Jennifer and Colin Allen.

title: City Board Asks to Step In To Oversee Jail Health Care
description: The chairman of the City Board of Correction proposed yesterday that his agency step in to monitor a new health care contract in city jails, contending that the Health and Hospitals Corporation was failing to oversee it properly.

title: Iraq Needs Effective Incentives to Comply; We Blinked and Lost
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about performances by the conductorless Orpheus Chamber Orchestra of New York at the newly refurbished Hanoi Opera House referred incorrectly to the precedents. Orpheus was not the first American orchestra to play in Vietnam since the war ended there in 1975. The Long Island Youth Orchestra performed at the Hanoi Opera House in 1992.

title: Fedex Pilots Decide to End Strike Threat
description: Leaders of the pilots' union at Federal Express crumbled under intense pressure from the company yesterday and withdrew their threat to strike during the peak holiday season.

title: A Comic Opera Becomes a Classroom at Juilliard
description: Opera productions at the Juilliard School, like the one on Wednesday night, are approachable from several directions, and it is always a puzzle deciding which one to take. One alternative regards ''Il Cappello di Paglia di Firenze,'' currently at the Juilliard Theater, as a professional undertaking, handsomely staged and audience-worthy. Another would remember that these are essentially students and that Nino Rota's comic opera is an elaborate classroom put there to teach them theatrical skills.

title: LIVENT RESUMES TRADING AFTER NEARLY 4 MONTHS
description: Almost four months after the stock was halted because of accounting irregularities, Livent Inc.'s shares opened far lower when they resumed trading yesterday. In the United States shares traded briefly before being halted again. Shares on the Toronto exchange closed at 50 cents (Canadian), or 32 cents (United States), down from $10.15 (Canadian) when trading was halted on Aug. 7. Two days ago, the Toronto-based producer of ''Ragtime'' and other Broadway shows filed for bankruptcy and restated more than two years of financial results, wiping out $85.1 million of earnings.

title: Carol Shaw, 59, Leader in AIDS Education
description: Carol Henning Shaw, an early organizer of Mothers' Voices, a national group working for AIDS prevention and cure, died Thursday at her home on the West Side of Manhattan. She was 59.

title: Crew Wants Sex Offender Photos Removed
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew yesterday ordered the superintendent of a Queens school district to remove photographs of released sex offenders from school hallways, overruling a decision of the local school board to defy an earlier order from the chancellor.

title: Plenty of Verdicts Already In on Gates Testimony
description: If William H. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, is serving as an effective witness for his company at the Government's antitrust trial, it is hard to find anyone other than Microsoft employees who hold that view.

title: Keep the Ninth Circuit Intact
description: For years, conservatives have been trying to break up the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit because they have been unhappy with some of the court's rulings on environmental issues and death penalty cases. Republicans in the Northwest have been particularly vocal in clamoring for their own circuit, believing that the San Francisco-based appeals court does not understand their values.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Clinton Ends Japan Trip With No Sign of Economic Progress
description: President Clinton and Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan ended two days of talk and ceremony here tonight with an affirmation of their national partnership but no evidence of progress on trade and other economic disputes that are festering between their countries.

title: Tales From Head to Toe
description: There are no untold stories. Art that works tells the old stories in new ways, in dance through a fresh choreographic voice or the individuality of performers. That was the message of a program presented on Tuesday night at the Clark Studio Theater by Ginger Thatcher, the assistant choreographer for Matthew Bourne's ''Swan Lake.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARFINKEL, GEORGE
description: GARFINKEL-George. The Members, Board of Governors and Officers of the Preakness Hills Country Club mourn the loss of a good friend and fellow member of long standing and extend their deepest sympathies to the family. Melvin Fand, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DULTZ, MELVIN WILLIAM
description: DULTZ-Melvin William, 71, Owner of Travcoa World Tours and a Chicago native died Tuesday, November, 10 in Seoul, South Korea. Mr. Dultz is survived by his daughter, Olga; sisters, Selma (Arnold) Ekerling and Betty Phillips; and nieces and nephews. A memorial service is planned for 11 a.m. Saturday at Pacific View Memorial Park and Mortuary, 3500 Pacific View Drive, Newport Beach, Ca.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Board Seeks a Dismissal After Forfeited Games
description: The Asbury Park Board of Education has taken legal steps to dismiss the high school athletic director, whose decision to allow two academically ineligible students to play football forced the school's team to forfeit an undefeated season.

title: N.F.L.: ROUNDUP
description: CLEVELAND

title: How Not to Conduct an Impeachment Hearing; Not Enough Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Gallagher, Mr. von Lengerke
description: Suzanne Berk Gallagher was married yesterday to Justus B. von Lengerke at the Audubon House, a historic house in Key West, Fla. Judy Terrell, a notary public, officiated.

title: How Not to Conduct an Impeachment Hearing; Unfair Question?
description: To the Editor:

title: From Culinary Institute To a Diner Named Dizzy's
description: ''We call it a finer diner,'' said Matheo Pisciotta, a Culinary Institute of America alumnus who recently opened Dizzy's, at 511 Ninth Street (at Eighth Avenue) in Park Slope, Brooklyn, with Ben Hoen, a graduate of Peter Kump's Culinary School. Serving classic but contemporary American diner food, Dizzy's was named after a friend of the owners' who was named for the trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie himself.

title: Soup, an Easygoing Start for Thanksgiving Dinner
description: PIE may be the classic Thanksgiving dessert. And we all know what the main course will be. But how about the first course? Soup is often the choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDWARDS, VERONICA GREEVEN
description: EDWARDS-Veronica Greeven. In New York City, on November 18, 1998. Devoted wife of thirty years to James Edwards. Loving mother of Nina and Philip Edwards. Dear sister of Christine, Rainer, Michael, John and Patrick Greeven. Mrs. Edwards was a designer with Skidmore, Owings & Merrill. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the founding of Garden City misidentified one of the village landmarks shown. The Victorian-style building is the former St. Paul's School, not the Apostle House.

title: How Not to Conduct an Impeachment Hearing; Attacking Starr
description: To the Editor:

title: There'll Never Be Another Bobby Simone
description: This much we know: on Tuesday night Jimmy Smits will end his four-year run as the detective Bobby Simone on ''N.Y.P.D. Blue,'' the highly rated police drama now in its seventh season on ABC at 10 P.M. What we don't know, and won't learn until Tuesday, is what happens to Bobby, who as of last week's episode was at death's door and about to be wheeled to the operating room.

title: A Guided Introduction to the Hasidic Way
description: ALTHOUGH some of Williamsburg's newest arrivals are hipsters and artists, David A. Edelstein will tell you that it remains ''the mother country'' for another group: Hasidic Jews. Next Sunday, as he has done on Sundays for the last 17 years, this native son will lead a walk through the neighborhood's Hasidic district (the first in the United States) to ''show how Jewish life is lived in an intense manner in contemporary New York.''

title: Munich
description: Come to Germany in December, and you'd think this was the place that invented Christmas. And in some ways, you'd be right. After all, didn't the Christmas tree arise from the medieval German custom of draping evergreen branches in the home with sausages and apples? And doesn't our image of Santa Claus stem largely from the pen of Thomas Nast, the 19th-century political cartoonist who was born in Landau, Germany?

title: Corrections
description: A review of ''Dawn Powell: A Biography,'' by Tim Page, in the Book Review last Sunday, included an erroneous reference, based on the publisher's catalogue, to the person controlling the sale of publication rights for the estate of Dawn Powell. They are controlled by Peter L. Skolnik of the law firm of Lowenstein Sandler of Roseland, N.J., not by Tim Page.

title: An Airport Hangar For G.E. Is Debated
description: THE debate surrounding a proposal to build a General Electric Company hangar at the Westchester County Airport near the Greenwich border continues to set environmentalists and some of the airport's residential neighbors against construction and business interests and G.E.

title: Sensing a Rising Tide, Lautenberg Puts Oars In
description: Ending speculation about his political future, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg publicly declared last week that he would run for a fourth term in 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANELLIS, THELMA
description: KANELLIS - Thelma. Beloved daughter of Mildred Epstein and the late Dr. Herman Epstein. Wife of Thomas Kanellis. Sister of the late Sandy Nachamie. Mother of Linda, Janice and Gary and grandmother of Jacqueline. Dedicated family member and nurse. She fought a valiant battle with breast cancer. We will miss her. The Nachamie Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLAGG, NICHOLAS
description: FLAGG-Nicholas. On November 19, 1998. Beloved son of Elliott C. and Anne, and step-son of Marian Flagg. Devoted brother of the late Jennifer Anne and dear friend of Jackie Glassthal. Funeral services at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave (at 20th St), NYC, Tuesday, 10:30 AM. Interment Whitneyville Cemetery, Hamden, CT.

title: Schoolteacher Arrested In Purchase of Heroin
description: A New York City public schoolteacher from Westchester County was arrested yesterday after the police said they saw her buy heroin on a South Bronx street corner.

title: IN MY... SATCHEL/ROBERT W. MacDONALD
description: Robert W. MacDonald, chief executive of Life USA, an insurer in Minneapolis, often hands his airplane seatmates a business card identifying himself as sales manager for Casper's Casket Company.

title: Meena Natarajan and Michael Elliott
description: Dr. Meena Natarajan, the daughter of Sarada and Bala Natarajan of Chicago, was married there yesterday to Dr. Michael David Elliott, a son of Elizabeth and David O. Elliott of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Hickey performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Clement.

title: Apartment Hunt Isn't That Hard; Simple Plaque Would Help Meet a Father's Request
description: To the Editor:

title: Hayes's Library
description: To the Editor: The table ''Libraries and Museums: Hoover to Bush'' (Oct. 11) did not reach back to the very first one.

title: Gore Had It Right
description: Vice President Al Gore was widely chastised last week for publicly criticizing the Malaysian Government at an Asian economic meeting in Kuala Lumpur. The Star, a Malaysian newspaper, took offense at Mr. Gore's ''gall,'' while Singapore's The Straits Times fumed that he had chosen ''the wrong place, wrong time [and] wrong tone'' for his remarks.

title: November 15-21; A New Blow To Affirmative Action
description: The national debate over affirmative action in education moved from the realm of higher education to the public-school level when a three-judge Federal appeals panel in Boston struck down racial preferences at Boston Latin School, the city's top public high school.

title: Rationed Indents
description: THE END OF A FAMILY STORY

title: Arthur Crowley 3d, Nancy Slaymaker
description: Nancy Lynn Slaymaker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur Slaymaker of Lancaster, Pa., was married on Friday to Arthur Manning Crowley 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Crowley of Spring Lake, N.J. The Rev. Charles Murr performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's of Yorkville Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Clinton Says He Still Suffers Privately Over the Lewinsky Affair
description: In his most extensive remarks in weeks about the scandal shadowing his Presidency, President Clinton said with a sad smile today that he was still suffering privately over his affair with Monica S. Lewinsky, but that his political punishment was strictly up to Congress.

title: A Wish List of Changes For the Federal Tax Code
description: If you could make just one change in the Federal tax code, what would it be? RIA Group, a publisher of tax information for lawyers, accountants and other professionals, posed that question to subscribers to its on-line research service. The answers showed that people who deal with taxes for a living are concerned about the same issues as the taxpaying public.

title: Stories of Faith, of Consolation
description: IT was a heady, glamorous time. Kenneth S. Lewis had just produced and directed a television documentary in New York City, during which he had worked alongside the pop music icons Sting, Bruce Springsteen, Elton John, Paul Simon, James Taylor and Billy Joel. But through the pop riffs, a personal theme kept recurring: Is this all there is?

title: OPINION; A Grandfather's Advice to D'Amato
description: SENATOR D'AMATO, you don't know me, but we have a lot in common. We're both 61, grandfathers, recently fired after working for the same employer for 18 years and wondering where our next paycheck is coming from.

title: Growing Pains; The Midtown Direct Line, a Victim of Its Own Success, Leaves Riders Grumbling About the Rush-Hour Madness
description: ON Monday mornings, when the 8:09 Midtown Direct rolls out of the neat brick station in the upscale suburb of Summit, there are still a few open seats. Three stops and 11 minutes later, when the train, New Jersey Transit No. 6620, leaves Maplewood, suited bodies cover every bit of brown vinyl upholstery, filling even the least desired seats in the middle of the bench. Passengers try to read their papers standing; some overflow into the vestibules, those forbidden areas between the cars. Even the conductors, who greet people with compelling geniality, as if desperate to maintain morale, sometimes just give up.

title: November 15-21; The New Alamo Battle
description: History is a blood sport in Texas, with the latest battle over a diary by a disgruntled 19th Century Mexican officer. Among other things, Jose Enrique de la Pena, who fought on the winning side at the Alamo, said that Davy Crockett did not go down swinging, as popular myth would have it, but was captured and tortured to death. And not before trying to talk his way out of it.

title: Spreading the Credit For Breast Cancer Project
description: In ''Transformed by Passion and Politics, Breast Cancer Movement Gains Power,'' Lorraine Pace was interviewed regarding her role in the nation's first breast cancer mapping project. The article implied that only Mrs. Pace managed to survey more than 8,700 homes in West Islip. This undertaking was done by dozens of volunteers, not just Mrs. Pace.

title: Trying to Strike a Competitive Balance as the Disparity in Payrolls Grows
description: When general managers gather each November a couple of weeks after the World Series, they spend several days in meetings discussing issues that affect their game and their teams. The post-season is often on their agenda of topics.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: HISTORY IN OUR TIME

title: Japanese Zen Master Honored by Her Followers
description: Enveloped in the faint sweetness of incense and their own hypnotic singing, eight Buddhist nuns and their abbesses from the cloistered Imperial convents in Japan yesterday transplanted a medieval ceremony of veneration for the first female Zen master to St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZFELD, MICHAEL D.
description: HERZFELD-Michael D. On November 18, 1998. Son of the late Saul and Sharlye Herzfeld. Father of Anna. Graveside services Sunday, November 22, 1:30 P.M., Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, N.Y.

title: Opposing a Ban
description: To the Editor:

title: As City Evolves, So Do Places of Worship
description: IF someone wanted to tell the story of this city, founded in 1853, a good place to start would be with the development of places of worship.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: INGENIOUS PAIN

title: Clinton Appeals To North Korea For Closer Ties
description: President Clinton made an unusual direct appeal to North Korea today to set aside any nuclear ambitions in favor of strengthening ties to South Korea and the United States. The appeal came during a meeting with reporters at which he also counseled patience over Iraq's refusal to comply with a request from weapons inspectors.

title: Big Pockets, No Pants
description: HERE are some of the things you can fit into Helmut Lang's holster bag, though not all at the same time: a Penguin paperback, a rolled-up decorating magazine, a reporter's notebook, a cellular phone, a peanut butter and jelly sandwich, a box of Uniball pens, a banana, your hand. (It will not hold a newspaper or a legal pad or a can of soda or a laptop computer.)

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: New Superintendent of Board
description: SO what if many local school superintendents no longer view the top job at a regional Board of Cooperative Educational Services as the ultimate way to cap a career? For the newly designated Superintendent of the Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services, Stacy Holmes, it does not get much better.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, IRA
description: GOULD-Ira. On November 19. Beloved brother of Larry, Alfie and the late Kal. Brother-in-law to Doris. Loving companion of Mary Ellen. Uncle to Patty, Robbie, Mark, Shelly and Mickey. We will miss you.

title: Brooklyn College President Rebuked for Criticizing CUNY
description: In a letter that some City University of New York officials criticized as an effort that could curb free speech, the chairwoman of the CUNY board rebuked the president of Brooklyn College for remarks he made at last June's commencement.

title: Correction
description: A listing of cruise ships on Oct. 4 misstated the original names of two ships, the date one ship entered service and the tonnage of another, all based on information from the operators. A letter from a reader dated Oct. 7 points out that the Enchanted Isle was originally the Argentina, not the Brasil, and that the Flamenco was originally the Spirit of London, not the Sun Princess. The letter also points out that the Monterey entered service as a passenger ship in 1957, not 1952, and that the tonnage of the Rotterdam was 62,000 gross tons, not 59,652.

title: Bosnia Economy Still at Mercy of Political Leaders
description: Bosnian political leaders are so good at resisting changes needed to revive the economy that diplomats and foreign officials say their governments now face the choice between providing large amounts of financial aid for years and watching the country collapse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLECKMAN, LORRAINE ROTHBARD
description: GLECKMAN-Lorraine Rothbard. Poughkeepsie. Adored by Ernest, children. Literary scholar. Her beautee wol sustene.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: GREENWICH VILLAGE

title: Guilt by Association
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region / New Jersey; Another Step in Downtown New Brunswick Revival
description: LAST Monday ground was broken for the latest addition to New Brunswick's reviving downtown -- a $25-million government and academic building that will rise over the next year and provide another anchor for the southern end of downtown.

title: Held in Greece
description: To the Editor: On Sept. 26, I was honeymooning at the Porto Elounda Mare Resort on Crete. Greece is the country of my heritage, and my wife and I were excited about our trip.

title: Where Aviation History Comes Alive
description: Re: ''Keeping Alive Our Aviation History'' [Opinion, Oct. 25], about a new aircraft museum at Republic Airport and its place among other aircraft museums in the region, you forgot to mention one of the very active aircraft museums in the New York area. I mean the Historic Aircraft Restoration Project at Brooklyn's Floyd Bennett Field.

title: Editorial Observer; Trying to Break the Cycle of Revenge in Bosnia
description: Yugoslavia, it has been said, always produced more history than it could consume. Bosnia today has not one history of the recent war, but one each for Muslims, Croats and Serbs, all contradictory. The division of memory along ethnic fault lines has produced a cycle of killing and revenge in the Balkans for more than a thousand years. To try to break the cycle, some citizens' groups in Bosnia are proposing a commission to write a common history. The goal may be elusive, but is well worth a try. The idea shows how more and more nations emerging from tyranny or war are designing independent groups, commonly known as truth commissions, to examine the causes and tell the full story of past crimes. But each country is adapting the idea to its own circumstances.

title: Apartment Hunt Isn't That Hard; A Resurgent Synagogue Lives Up to the Memories
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberties; My Exit Strategy
description: It was many, many, many hours into the dullest day in Washington history.

title: The Unforgettable Afternoon
description: On this day 35 years ago, the ''ceremony of innocence was drowned,'' to borrow Yeats's phrase. At midday on that Friday, John F. Kennedy was assassinated in Dallas.

title: Life Is Just One Rolling Parody, Tra La
description: TAKE the larger-than-life guru of style Martha Stewart and skewer all absurdities. Season with plenty of cayenne pepper. Barbecue to a crisp. Garnish masthead with three lawyers, all experts on the First Amendment. Self-publish homemade parody.

title: How Not to Conduct an Impeachment Hearing; Comparing Counsels
description: To the Editor:

title: Painted Mansions Of Shekhawati
description: THE promise of an oasis in the Thar desert of Rajasthan lured us off the beaten path. A travel agent assured us that a four-hour drive would take us from New Delhi to the small town of Mandawa. Once there, we would stay in an enchanting castle from the time of the maharajahs and wander through crumbling mansions richly painted with images of kings and Hindu gods, gramophones and Victorian touring cars.

title: Hanging 10, but Often Paying a Price
description: MOMENTUM advisers are the surfers of the investing arena. They constantly look for waves that are strong enough to carry them a long time.

title: New Canaan Deer, Other Views
description: Linda Howard Clark's letter (''Who's Trespassing on Whose Land?'' last Sunday) was interesting, but the part about the deer kills is not quite clear. Deer may not realize in time how fast vehicles are moving, especially around curves; fawns do not yet understand the concept. Deer can also be frightened into the road by something, and not see the vehicles until too late.

title: Secret, Persistent Negotiations Lured the Patriots to Hartford
description: During a campaign debate just five weeks ago, Gov. John G. Rowland was asked what he was willing to do to lure the New England Patriots to Connecticut. The Governor smiled and dismissed that as ''a hypothetical question, so it's very difficult to plug in hypothetical holes,'' then talked about other economic development ideas he considered more realistic.

title: Debate Over School Alternatives
description: AS if the public schools did not have enough to worry about, like trying to meet higher standards required by the State Board of Regents, curriculum mandates and other reforms, along comes a growing movement to offer alternatives that some observers say nibble away at public education.

title: Actors With a Cause
description: With Ossie and Ruby

title: New Home on the (Texas) Range
description: THE second-richest woman in America is now apparently the second-richest Texan.

title: For Youngsters, New World Is on Line
description: Never has the good old Model United Nations, popular for so long among the earnest high school set, seemed so pallid, so retro, so (to be read with teen-age disdain) 20th century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, BETTY IVEY
description: MARTIN-Betty Ivey. Born Bellevue, Washington, died November 17, 1998 in New York. Much loved aunt of Susan Procter Dusenberry, great aunt of Benjamin Procter. Lover of life, lover of children everywhere. Miss Martin studied voice at the the Juilliard School of Music. She had a long distinguished career as head of the educational departments at Columbia, RCA and MGM Records. She is Trustee Emeritus of the Professional Children's School and was on the board for over 25 years. She joined the New York Metropolitan Committee for UNICEF in 1980, and in 1991, received the Metro Angel Award for her special commitment. Contributions in her memory may be made to either institution. A memorial service will be held Thursday, December 17th at 4 PM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: F.Y.I.
description: The Team That Wasn't

title: Flights of Fancy In Internet Stocks
description: IT was a sunny afternoon in Tucson last March when Mary Meeker sprinted past a cluster of computer executives chatting at PC Forum, an annual gathering of the digirati. Ms. Meeker, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, is best known for her coverage of Internet companies.

title: Ho! Ho! Ho! Boohoo-hoo!
description: The holiday season seems to bring out the best and the worst in bosses.
