We've all heard stories about workers who are fired on Christmas Eve, but then again, Scrooge himself ended up giving the long-suffering Bob Cratchit a raise. What holiday horror stories have emerged from your workplace? Or, to give the management world's guardian angels their due, how have the holidays melted the coldest corporate hearts? Send your anecdotes to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Where's The Poetry?
description: The encyclopedic folklorist B.A. Botkin had a small section in his big book on American folk legends devoted to ''seen the elephant'' (On Language, by William Safire, Nov. 1). It was the mid-19th-century equivalent of ''been there, done that,'' with an added connotation of ''didn't like it.'' Pioneers returning along the Oregon Trail painted ''We've seen the elephant'' on the sides of their covered wagons.

title: When Big Wheels Keep On Turning
description: To the Editor:

title: Harvard Wins Stats, but Not Game
description: Harvard had a victory over Yale wrapped up and almost sealed today. But then a series of twists and turns went against the Crimson in the fourth quarter, and the Bulldogs wound up winning the 115th game in the series, 9-7.

description: KLEIN-Beatrice R. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Marc and Peter Rubinger. Loving sister of Marion Sells and Harry Sklar. Adored grandmother of Lauren, Rachel, Benjamin, Andrew and Jonathan. Graveside Services Sunday 11AM at Cedar Park Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 8 about a Superfund site on Lister Avenue in Newark, where dioxin-tainted material from the manufacture of Agent Orange is to be walled off and capped, referred incompletely to a representative of the current and former owners. He is N. Scott Jones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOPHER, MORRIS B.
description: SOPHER-Morris B. A New York real estate developer and philanthropist died on Nov. 11. The cause was cancer. Born on April 6, 1928 to Russian immigrants, Mr. Sopher joined the Ringling-Bros.-Barnum and Bailey Circus during 1944 where he performed as a perch and trapeze acrobat. A skilled body builder and runner, Mr. Sopher later completed 16 NYC marathons. After many businesses he found his niche in commercial real estate. He and his wife eventually amassed a large portfolio of commercial properties in the Bronx. Mr. and Mrs. Sopher's philanthropic undertakings included Beth Israel Medical Center and the Phillips Cancer Center. Mr. Sopher was a member of the board of directors & a benefactor of the American Friends of Migdal Ohr, which educates & cares for underprivileged youth in Israel. He and his wife helped sustain every orthodox Jewish institution in Riverdale. Mr. Sopher, who was buried in Israel, is survived by his wife Marilyn, his three children, Barbara, Jonathan & Lisa, four grandchildren, his sister Selma Berson of Riverdale, & his brother, Abe Sopher of Rockland County.

title: How Not to Conduct an Impeachment Hearing; Absent Impartiality
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAKULA, ALAN J.
description: PAKULA-Alan J. Community Access's Board of Directors, Staff and Consumers express profound sorrow at the loss of an extraordinary man. Recently he and his family opened their hearts to share with us their goodness, warmth, generosity and remarkable support of people with mental illness. His memory will always light up the lives of those who knew him and his work as he lit up our Gala. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Hannah, his son Robert O. Boorstin and his entire family. Alfred Cave, President, Board of Directors Steven V. Coe, Exec. Director Wendy Rothstein, Dev. Director

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TUTTLETON, PROF. JAMES W.
description: TUTTLETON-Prof. James W. The Dean of the Faculty of Arts and Science and the Faculty of the English Department of New York University mourn the death of our colleague and friend James W. Tuttleton. As Chairman of our Department and Associate Dean of the Graduate School he strengthened our academic programs. As an essayist on literature and culture and as a scholar of the work of Henry James and the novel of manners, he earned international distinction. His inspired teaching and wit played a unique role in our lives. The James W. Tuttleton Fellowship Fund established in his honor will accept contributions sent to the English Department. A memorial service will be held on Monday, December 7, 1998 from 5 PM to 7 PM in the Greenberg Lounge of the Law School, Vanderbilt Hall, 40 Washington Square South.

title: Checkout Time?; As S.R.O. Owners Make Way for Tourists, Long-Term Tenants Say They're Left in the Lurch
description: A CHILL wind blows through the eighth floor of the Broadway American Hotel, a single-room-occupancy building on West 77th Street and Broadway. Leah S. Porter, who lives in Room 809, pulls her coat closer as she steps out of the elevator into the hotel's gutted interior. Renovations have reduced her floor to its raw elements. There are no sockets, just exposed wires. There are no walls, only wooden frames.

title: Soup, an Easygoing Start To Thanksgiving Dinner
description: PIE may be the classic Thanksgiving dessert. And we all know what the main course will be. But how about the first course? Soup is often the choice.

title: Florida City's Hopes For Airport Bog Down
description: IN the six years since Hurricane Andrew devastated this agricultural city south of Miami, officials here have struggled to jump-start the economy. But nature seems to be against Homestead, again, as plans for turning the closed Homestead Air Force Base into a commercial airport -- a major project that could bring dollars and jobs -- have bogged down over the possible environmental damage to two nearby national parks.

title: Dance Music Enlists A New Sound: Voices
description: AS a rule, modern dance-club music -- the soundtrack that DJ's employ to set a crowd in motion -- has a limited need for vocalists. A soul diva or rapper may appear fleetingly on a track to chant a phrase or two, perhaps delivering a lusty come-on or an exhortation for dancers to pick up the pace. But in the after-hours world of techno, breakbeat and drum-and-bass, where music is designed to wring sweat from bodies, the primary language is rhythm. Lyrics just get in the way.

title: Islanders Get a Victory That They Needed Badly
description: The alarms were sounding. The Islanders were without their top defenseman, and they had lost three straight games.

title: BUSINESS: DIARY
description: Northwest Airlines finished buying a controlling stake in Continental Airlines, though in response to regulatory concerns it bought fewer shares than it originally wanted. . . . AMR, parent of American Airlines, agreed to acquire Reno Air, a struggling discount carrier in the West. . . . The threatened pilot's strike at Federal Express was put off by 60 days, until well past Christmas, to allow more time for negotiations. . . . A meteor shower that some experts feared would disrupt satellite communications passed harmlessly.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 22, 1998
description: Weeks

title: November 15-21; Most Valuable. But to Whom?
description: When the nation's baseball writers voted on Thursday to give the National League's Most Valuable Player award to the Chicago Cubs slugger Sammy Sosa rather than the St. Louis Cardinals' Mark McGwire, they demonstrated that the term ''value'' in baseball is as malleable as ''truth'' is in politics.

title: Streetscapes / 92d and 93d Street Between Park and Third Avenue; 4 Wooden Houses With a Mid-19th-Century Feel
description: FOUR little wooden houses on 92d and 93d Street in Carnegie Hill are signature elements of the neighborhood, like the brownstones of Brooklyn Heights or the Tudor houses of Riverdale. Three of the houses are between Park and Lexington Avenues, the fourth between Lexington and Third. And as the new owners of one of the three off Park, the 1871 clapboard house at 120 East 92d, finish a renovation, they are hoping someone will undertake an even larger task -- moving the fourth house diagonally across Lexington and onto their block.

title: Pay No Mind to the Package
description: All around the ginkgo tree there was a rotting stink. An old Chinese man picked around the trunk, which was ringed with yellow leaves. When he found a cherry-sized, orange-colored and rather smelly seed, he popped it into a plastic bag, using a hand sheathed in a surgical glove.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEGERSON, HARRY JOSEPH, M.D.
description: GEGERSON-Harry Joseph, M.D. Of Atlantic Beach and Boca Raton, Florida. On November 18, 1998 in his 89th year. Loving father of Robert, Peter, Roy, Andrew and Gary. Fond grandfather of 12 grandchildren, Shari, Steven, Jaime, Angie, Joel, Kenneth, Michael, Jonathan, Scott, Lisa, Todd and Kara, and one great-grandchild, Trevor. In lieu of flowers, donations to North Broward Hospital District, 201 East Sample Road, Pompano Beach, Fl 33064.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERNO, EUGENE J.
description: KERNO-Eugene J. A New York City Attorney. On November 18, 1998 at age 86. Beloved father of Raymond E. Kerno and loving grandfather of Annija. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St, Sunday, November 22nd, 6PM. Interment Monday, Evergreen Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Baltic Association to the United Nations, 203 E. 82 St, N.Y. N.Y. 10028.

title: Larger Vehicles Are Hampering Visibility
description: As sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks become bigger and more common, their height and high-mounted headlights are making visibility on the road more difficult for other drivers, particularly at night. Federal regulators are growing concerned.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''She learned the lesson that she couldn't be co-President. She stoically went through the Monica stuff and has come out shining -- and come out swinging. She's become the one beacon of light in the entire Administration.''

title: Far Downtown, Food's Looking Up
description: AMERICAN PARK *

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVE, DR. H. JANET
description: EVE-Dr. H. Janet. Henrietta Janet Eve, a practicing physician in New York for over 40 years, died at her home in Sarasota, Florida on November 16, 1998. Dr. Eve was born June 6, 1923 in Hot Springs, Arkansas. She was a graduate of Fisk University and the Howard University College of Medicine. An internship at Harlem Hospital in NYC was followed by a residency at Freedmen's Hospital, Washington, D.C. Dr. Eve returned to New York and joined the medical staff at the NY Board of Education, later becoming the first African American woman to serve as Medical Director. She was also a partner with the Yorkville Medical Group of the H.I.P. of New York. Upon her retirement in 1992, she had been medical director of the East Harlem Branch of the Yorkville Medical Center for a number of years. Dr. Eve was a most compassionate and generous person, giving tirelessly to her patients and community. She served on the Executive Committee of the community effort of the Harlem YWCA, and was member of the New York County and State Medical Society and the Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority. She is survived by her sister and brother-inlaw, Della E. Hale and Dr. Edward H. Hale; many devoted family members and loving friends. A memorial service was held in Sarasota on Nov. 20. Memorial gifts may be made to the Howard University College of Medicine, 520 W. St, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20059.

title: Warrick's Heroics Help Lift Florida State in Showdown
description: Florida Coach Steve Spurrier smugly noted before today's game that winning here was not at the top of his coaching wish list.

title: Police Arrest 29 in Raid on Bar
description: Twenty-nine people were arrested early yesterday in a police raid on a midtown bar long cited by neighbors as a haven for prostitution.

title: Pinochet Case Spurring Debate on International Laws
description: As judges in Britain deliberate the fate of the one-time Chilean dictator, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the rarefied world of international law has been sent into a flurry of activity, with lawyers issuing papers and opinions on what they see as a case with enormous legal implications.

title: How Not to Conduct an Impeachment Hearing; Where Was Debate?
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Star Wars' Fanatics, The Trailer Is With You
description: WHO doesn't remember feeling an electrifying zing up the spine at that majestic blast of trumpets and the ''Star Wars'' title appearing on the big screen for the first time? With innovative special effects and a classic good-versus-evil theme, the ''Star Wars'' series became an instant classic of pop culture. For ''Star Wars'' enthusiasts, the hottest film shown last week had its sneak preview announced on the Internet and sent a small army of fans into theaters around the country to watch it over and over again.

title: Our Towns; Defending A Basic Right: Holiday Lights
description: THIS normally genteel township had a people's revolution the other day.

title: Sic 'Em, Eeyore
description: Lately the gray wolves in Montana's Ninemile Valley have developed a taste for red meat -- not too gamey. Since April, wolves have killed four calves and maimed a fifth one. In response, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service ''initiated lethal control,'' killing four adults from the pack. Wildlife biologists have been searching for ways to protect cattle in a way that doesn't involve lethal force. (Aside from the obvious benefits to wolves -- they wouldn't get shot -- their range of potential habitat would increase if they could coexist peacefully with ranchers and their livestock.) Mike Jimenez, a University of Montana doctoral candidate studying the problem, has been experimenting with various nondeadly aversion strategies, including a few ''harebrained ideas.'' Here's a look.

title: For These Nerds, It's Beans to Billions
description: On July 20, 1969, the Apollo 11 mission landed the first men on the Moon, an event that was the summit of years of research and the beginning of a new era in science. Two months later, another technological landmark was reached, less visible at the time, but in hindsight perhaps just as important. Bit by bit, a single message was arduously transferred from a computer at U.C.L.A. to another at Stanford, hundreds of miles away. It was the birth of the Internet, decades before anyone knew what the Internet was.

title: Lords Defy Commons And Labor Sees Red
description: A more unlikely band of guerrillas cannot be imagined than the ermine-caped members of Britain's House of Lords.

title: When in Paris
description: Mayor Timothy C. Idoni is answering the phone these days with an enthusiastic, ''Oui'' -- expressing his hope that a new free-fall ride housed in a replica of the Eiffel Tower will attract tourists to downtown New Rochelle. Up to 12 riders at a time will be propelled as fast as 45 miles an hour and experience several moments of weightlessness -- as though they were riding in space.

title: Susan Lauer, Raymond Pena
description: Susan R. Lauer and Raymond Pena are to be married this afternoon by Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel at the Orienta Beach Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Our Hollow Hegemony
description: Perhaps the best rejoinder to Fareed Zakaria's call for activism is found in the quotation from John Quincy Adams in Zakaria's article: ''She might become the dictatress of the world. She would be no longer the ruler of her own spirit.''

title: Martha Rand, Steven Keller
description: Martha Riddick Rand and Steven Morse Keller were married yesterday in Winston-Salem, N.C. The Rev. Dr. Jeffrey White performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: Layover or Mini-Vacation?
description: THE layover from Sydney to Boston will be 12 hours in Hawaii. Irritation brims as I face 12 hours of exhaustion and nothing to do but kill time. I envision the layover in the airport as something like being confined in a bad relationship where everything is too well known and too small. Twelve hours! I must get out. But what will I do?

title: Ideas & Trends; Double Talking on Wall Street
description: FORGET E. F. Hutton. These days, when the markets speak, everyone, even Alan Greenspan, listens.

title: A Student's Expulsion for an Off-Campus Offense Is Upheld
description: EDUCATORS and legal experts across Connecticut say that a recent ruling by a state hearing officer holding that the town of Trumbull school officials can expel an 18-year-old star athlete for an off-campus offense could set a precedent for other school districts.

title: Cranky at Dinner
description: To the Editor: in response to the article about the couple who took their newborn to Anguilla, (''An Island in a Sea of Calm,'' Oct. 25), I found one of their comments alarming. When they had taken their child to Oliver's Seaside Grill, ''a moderately priced restaurant,'' they wrote of ''the waiters' obvious impatience with Jack, who happened to be cranky that night.''

title: Sometimes the Player's the Thing
description: IT will come as no surprise to Nicole Kidman's screen admirers to learn that she also looks sexy and beautiful on stage, not least when scantily dressed. Yet this unremarkable discovery threw British newspapers into a veritable swoon this fall when she made her first stage appearance in 11 years.

title: Lawyers for Terry Nichols Request New Trial
description: Terry L. Nichols has asked the Federal appeals court in Denver for a new trial in the Oklahoma City bombing, contending that the Federal judge who presided over his case erred at both his trial and his sentencing.

title: Apartment Hunt Isn't That Hard; Lots of Good Places, If You Leave Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENT, STANFORD F.
description: BRENT-Stanford F. Devoted man and loving father. Died unexpectedly on November 14, 1998. He is survived by a daughter Mrs. Helene Splan and a son Stanford F. Brent, Jr. He was the former husband of Helene Klotz Brent and Margaret Reventlow. He will be deeply missed by everyone.

title: A Dozen Artists at Work Within a Challenging Space
description: THE curators of the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield must often wish they had an abandoned factory with no interior walls or columns, a garage door and a huge elevator for bringing in the art. Instead they have a cunning white building that had served in various genteel capacities -- post office, church, home -- before it became a museum.

title: Inside the Third Reich
description: I WILL BEAR WITNESS A Diary of the Nazi Years 1933-1941. By Victor Klemperer. Translated by Martin Chalmers. 519 pp. New York: Random House. $29.95.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Oct. 11 with an article about the influence of the Aga Kahn on world architecture misidentified a building and its architect. The building, with an orange and yellow facade, is the headquarters of the Pan-African Institute for Development in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, designed by Adaua Burkina -- not the National Assembly Building in Sher-e-Bangla Nagar, Dhaka, Bangladesh, designed by Louis Kahn. A reader's letter dated Nov. 2 reported the error. This correction was delayed by the search for a misplaced book showing the building.

title: Game, Set, Glamour
description: THE sneakers are off. The stilettos are on. Tennis's most marketable sweethearts since Chris Evert are seeking the kind of supermodel clout bestowed on those creatures famous enough to be known by first names only: Martina and Venus and Anna are in full orbit.

title: Style; Stark Raving
description: I know that it's such a cliche at this time of year, but I don't care. I have reached the end of my tassel. There's simply no place left in this sorry, trendy, makeover-mad world for a stylist who is a nihilist -- like me. Stylists don't doubt. They create. They shop. They decree. They expense. They Polaroid and Fed-Ex. They obsess over thread counts and cashmere. Me? I just negate. How did it come to this? How did I go from being filled with opinions to this state of perpetual ambivalence?

title: Eda McLaughlin, Alex Nussbaumer
description: Eda McLaughlin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. McLaughlin of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Alex Ernst Nussbaumer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ernst Nussbaumer of Rumson, N.J. The Rev. Joseph Reilly performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York.

title: A GOOD LAST PLACE -- A special report; Seattle's Elderly Find a Home for Living, Not Dying
description: It was Saturday night at the Providence-Mount St. Vincent nursing home. Marie Swegle, 96, and her friends on the fifth floor were lingering at the dinner table in their wheelchairs, watching the news. John Glenn had safely returned to Earth.

title: INSIDE
description: Behind a Big Bank Deal

title: Latest Issue In G.E. Bid For Hangar
description: THE debate surrounding a proposal to build a General Electric Company hangar at the County Airport in Harrison continues to set environmentalists and some of the airport's residential neighbors against construction and business interests and G.E.

title: Our Hollow Hegemony
description: I found myself nodding in agreement as I read Fareed Zakaria's lucid and sobering assessment of United States foreign policy (Nov. 1). Some fundamental attitudes, I believe, converge in our culture that render an enlightened, consistent approach to foreign policy so difficult. The first is the inability of the American public to see political and historical outcomes in terms other than winning and losing. The fact that we have only two political parties reinforces this simplistic thinking. Citizens of countries with a multiparty system are accustomed to the necessity of cooperation and alliances, such as the Socialist-Green coalition that won the recent German elections. The American public, on the other hand, has little patience with the complex multilateral process of today's international relations.

title: Spreading the Credit For Breast Cancer Project
description: ''Transformed by Passion and Politics, Breast Cancer Movement Gains Power'' [Nov. 8] was excellent and informative but left out some very important information about the West Islip breast cancer mapping project. The project could not have been accomplished without the support of the West Islip Breast Cancer Coalition and the efforts of the volunteers who spent many hours at my home each day for 18 months to complete the map. The mapping also could not have been accomplished without the help of my oncologist, Dr. Michael Feinstein, the support of the Suffolk County Department of Health and the personal encouragement of my radiation oncologist, Dr. Allen G. Meek of University Hospital, Stony Brook. It also would never have taken place without the support of Michael LoGrande, chairman of the Suffolk County Water Authority, who obtained the map for me and strongly supported and encouraged our efforts. Good Samaritan Hospital was instrumental in lending its name and supporting our work, as was Lou Grasso, editor of Suffolk Life Newspapers, who put the breast cancer survey on the front page of the West Islip edition.

title: Innovative Method
description: Peekskill is counting on a $540 investment in 45 grass-eating sterile carp to pay off in Lake Mitchell, where the weeds have grown out of control. With a permit from the State Department of Environmental Protection, the city recently stocked the three-acre lake with the fish.

description: Hearth Dining in New York

title: Entrepreneurs' Role in Foreclosed Housing Expands
description: WE are not in this alone,'' Kristina Hosch said. Which is a good thing, because she and her husband, owners of a small real-estate management business in the Bronx, have signed personally on a $13 million city-guaranteed construction loan from European American Bank.

title: William Githens, Newsreel Pioneer, Dies at 92
description: William French Githens, a newsreel pioneer and tennis-playing society figure, died on Nov. 10 at a hospice near his retirement home in Arlington, Va. He was 92 and is credited with opening the world's first all-newsreel movie theater in 1929.

Bartenstein of Lexington, VA; John C. Bartenstein of Lexington, MA; Thomas W. Bartenstein of Owego, N.Y., and seven grandchildren. Funeral services at graveside in the Stonewall Jackson Cemetery in Lexington, VA, 11 A.M. Saturday, November 28. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Historic Morven, 55 Stockton Street, Princeton, N.J. 08540. For information contact Bailey Funeral Home, Inc., Mendham, N.J.

title: In Bayou Country, Music Is Never Second Fiddle
description: ALPHONSE (BOIS SEC) ARDOIN, an 82-year-old accordion player and farmer, is checking his hogs on a muggy, mosquito-ripe autumn afternoon. ''Allez, cochons,'' Mr. Ardoin chants as dragonflies dart above the hog pens. ''Allez.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RENNIE, JEAN TOWER
description: RENNIE-Jean Tower. Mother of Missie Rennie Taylor of New York and of Roxburgh Rennie of Providence, RI. The memorial service will be held Wednesday, November 25 at 4PM at the Episcopal Church of Bethesda-by-the-Sea Church, Palm Beach, Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUG, JULIA F.
description: HUG-Julia F. Of Garden City, NY on November 19, 1998. Beloved wife of Arthur Jr. Loving mother of Julie Carney, Jeannette and Joanne Powers. Dear Nana of three grandchildren. Devoted sister of Jean Fowler. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th St. Garden City. Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Interment private. Memorial service Garden City Community Church, Tuesday. 10 AM. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Lung Association appreciated.

title: Stats With Impact
description: Baseball broadcasters routinely use radar guns to tell fans how fast each pitch is being hurled. Now the National Hockey League has hopes for another nifty sports-stat technology, one that uses principles similar to global positioning systems. The system, currently in development by a Somerville, Mass.-based company called Trakus, relies on a radio tag in each skater's helmet, which transmits signals that are read by antennae positioned throughout the arena. The data are dispatched to central computers for crunching and sorting.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 1 about United States foreign policy misstated John Quincy Adams's title in 1821. He was Secretary of State, not President.

title: The Artless Art Of Painting With No-Mind
description: REMEMBER ''Zen and the Art of Archery''? At the peak moment of this perennially popular book by the German philosopher Eugen Herrigel, the Zen archer hits the bull's-eye, although he shoots the arrow in total darkness. ''Melodramatic'' is how the composer John Cage assessed this story, and he offered another. A Japanese friend, he said, told him of a highly esteemed archer who had never hit the bull's-eye even in broad daylight.

title: Test Me Nine Times
description: Don't expect to see the hardest of bodies in action at the first ''enneathlon,'' a nine-event sporting contest created by and for the Phoenix, Ariz., law firm of Gallagher & Kennedy. For one thing, opening ceremonies for the contest consisted of a cocktail party in a boardroom. And an enneathlete's physical challenges include fly fishing, golf, gin rummy and bocce -- to be completed over the next four months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMERON, VINCENT
description: CAMERON-Vincent. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Vincent Cameron, associated with The Times from 1972, until retiring in 1983.

title: Put Out the Bulbs, Take In the Herbs
description: Continue planting bulbs until soil is frozen. It is better to plant late than wait until spring, when the period of cold treatment will be too short for good bloom. (Tulips need 14 to 16 weeks.) Remove bulb debris that will attract squirrels to the newly dug spot.

title: Thanksgiving at Plymouth, 377 Years Later
description: In the autumn of 1621, 51 Pilgrims and 90 Indians in the colony of Plymouth held the three-day harvest feast now known as the first Thanksgiving. This year both the town of Plymouth and Plimoth Plantation, the living-history museum that recreates daily life in the 17th-century colony, will have Thanksgiving celebrations.

title: In a Mozart Opera, A Perky Character Out of Rossini
description: IS it desperation among music marketers or just the nature of celebrity that has turned career building into such spasms of sudden success and sudden obscurity? Selling and buying the star is a musical process as old as Franz Liszt, but the ascent to belovedness has become more vertical. A certain hysteria is in the air, with audiences needy for something to love and promoters eager to supply it.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PRICE, BARRY
description: PRICE-Barry. A beautiful boy away from us 23 years. You're always in our hearts. Love and kisses. Mommy, Daddy, Jodi and Blair and Mark too.

title: Before the Renovation, Consider the Returns
description: IT seems that every house in my neighborhood is being renovated. All summer, Dumpsters occupied one driveway after another, and an angry hive of power saws started buzzing every morning, though politely waiting until 8.

title: Does He Ever Sit Still? Well, Maybe Sometimes When He Plays Cello
description: IT'S hot -- an afternoon in late August. In the chamber music shed at Tanglewood, a student cellist and her pianist are playing Brahms's Opus 38 in E minor. The cellist has been chosen to stay on after the Music Center closed for the season, preparing for this master class with Mstislav Rostropovich, the legendary cellist and conductor.

title: A Searching Journey Into the Heart of Brazil
description: ONE morning in late 1996, the Brazilian director Walter Salles was waiting for a flight in Rio de Janeiro when he was approached by a 9-year-old shoeshine boy. At the time, Mr. Salles was preparing to shoot his third feature film, ''Central Station,'' the tale of an older woman and a boy who meet at Rio's train station and then strike out on a journey into the hinterlands to find the boy's father.

title: Milton Kutsher, Catskills Hotelier, Dies at 82
description: Milton Kutsher, who built Kutsher's Country Club into one of the leading resorts in the Catskills and kept it successful even as many other top hotels in the region lost their allure in the 1980's and 90's, died Monday in Monticello, N.Y. He was 82 years old.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: Two for Thanksgiving

title: A Discerning Eye on the Myriad Forms of Play
description: IN the ways that exhibitions come into being ''We were exploring toys and science,'' said Marianne Smith, curator of science at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Dennis Quaid; Movies 101, Then on to 'Bilzaboob'
description: ON Thursday, Dennis Quaid was in New York for what might be the least glamorous movie premiere ever. His $5.5 million Bosnian film, ''Savior,'' opens here at two theaters on Wednesday. With a budget like that there's no party. Thursday night found him talking to students at Richard Brown's Movies 101 course at the Cineplex theater on 50th Street near Eighth Avenue. The floor was sticky, the amps were misbehaving, Mr. Quaid had to buy his own popcorn.

title: Jets Open Stretch Run With Big Test in Tennessee
description: This is the difficult position the Jets find themselves in, and they are not alone: they are in a stretch run, and yet for the race to remain on a level course, they need a victory here against the Oilers.

title: Backtalk; Harnisch a Reluctant Role Model
description: Opening day of the Mets' 1997 season is still a blur to Pete Harnisch, who started the game thinking he had a firm grip on both the baseball and his life. Within weeks, he was one of the most public of the estimated 19 million Americans who experienced depression that year. His willingness to reveal his illness and his solid comeback last season with Cincinnati have made him something of a mental health role model, if a slightly edgy one.

title: Oppressed by an Idol
description: A LIKELY STORY One Summer With Lillian Hellman. By Rosemary Mahoney. 275 pp. New York: Doubleday. $23.95.

title: From Brooklyn to Kosovo, With Love and AK-47's
description: Asingle photograph decorates the office walls of Triangle Contractors in an old house on Cortelyou Road in Brooklyn. It depicts a young man with a Kalashnikov slung across his chest, a pistol tucked into his belt and another automatic weapon in his hands.

title: Japan Rail Helps A Pilgrim's Progress
description: NAMU! Daishi! Henro! Kongo! At 6 in the morning, a time when my usual mantra is Get! Me! Coffee! Now!, I squirmed, cross-legged, on the chilly floor of Shojoshi-in Temple at Koya-San monastery in Japan, enthusiastically chanting Buddhist sutras.

title: His Brush Is a Needle And Skin Is His Canvas
description: IN the last decade, tattoos of birds, flowers, angels, unicorns, dragons, rainbows and historical figures have blossomed on human arms, shoulders, ankles, bellies and other more private parts, an increasingly popular fashion accouterment embraced by celebrities including Kate Moss, Johnny Depp, Cher, Whoopi Goldberg and Dolly Parton.

title: One Million Mark
description: Playland Park in Rye, Westchester's largest family amusement complex, topped the one-million-visitor mark this year, recording its best attendance in a decade. The park also had the highest revenues in its 70-year history, County Executive Andrew J. Spano said.

title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL; Chaminade Wins Battle of the Titans
description: Chaminade and Monsignor Farrell are not exactly strangers to the Catholic High Schools Football League championship.

title: After Papers Merge, Readers Speak Out
description: PERFORMING a ritual that thousands of other Westchester residents do daily, Aaron Norris walked out of his White Plains home early one morning last month and picked up the newspaper from his doorstep.

title: Lessons In Fielding Harassment Accusations
description: CORPORATE America often looks to the world of sports for inspiration on everything from teamwork to persistence to leadership. But what lesson can be drawn from the way the New York Mets recently handled its general manager's public acknowledgment that he had had sexual relations with an employee?

title: Congressional Memo; For Speaker-to-Be, Defining Moment Moves Closer
description: Even before he assumes the Speaker's chair in January, Representative Robert L. Livingston faces a decision that could define his tenure as leader of the House and could alter the course of the nation.

title: Gerard Grisey, 52, a Composer And Pioneer in 'Spectral Music'
description: Gerard Grisey, one of the most important French composers of the generation after Pierre Boulez, died Wednesday in a Paris hospital. He was 52.

title: Lauren Katz and Matthew Kluger
description: LESS than a week before Lauren Katz's wedding, she was in court defending a lawyer charged with arson. Her fiance, Matthew Kluger, was representing a Bronx man charged with attempted murder. It should come as no surprise then that Ms. Katz and Mr. Kluger fell in love on the 11th floor of the Manhattan building housing Yeshiva University's Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law, where Mr. Kluger worked in Barry Scheck's criminal law clinic and Ms. Katz helped immigrants in landlord disputes. It was, in its way, romantic.

title: Privileges That Come With Age
description: MOST people of a certain age know about the air fare discounts we fall heir to when we pass 62. But now, like almost everything else available to the increasing older population, the small type, while surely getting smaller, is also growing longer, and the asterisks are proliferating. More than that, airline programs are much less alike than they used to be.

title: Spanish Treats for the Discriminating ...
description: THE Laguna Cafe in Roslyn is a surprise for residents familiar with Heads and Tails, the casual pub formerly at this address, and for Long Islanders used to other Island Spanish restaurants that hedge their bets by augmenting Spanish choices with a roster of popular Mexican selections. Laguna is strictly Spanish with no enchilada interlopers.

title: Counting Blessings and Putting Tools Away
description: THANKSGIVING is a time to reflect on the seasons gone by as well as the bounty of the harvest. The growing year of 1998 was glorious with abundant bloom and plenty of sunshine. In most months, there was even adequate rainfall to keep the ground moist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYTON, PEGGI MARGARET
description: KAYTON-Peggi Margaret. Died November 19, 1998. Beloved wife of Ralph. Devoted mother to Daniel (Esther), Debra (Ronald) Peters and Karen Kayton. Loving grandmother to Jason and Andrew Peters and Gabrielle Kayton. Service noon, Wednesday, November 25, ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapel,'' 55 No. Station Plaza ''opposite LIRR,'' Great Neck, NY. Interment at New Montefiore.

title: Correction
description: A report on Nov. 8 about the marriage of Wendy Elizabeth Stone and Arthur Scott Long misspelled part of the name of the law firm the bride is to join next month, and omitted reference to a Roman Catholic priest who toook part in the ceremony. The firm is Kirkland & Ellis, not Kirland. The priest was the Rev. Gerald E. Murray.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Daniel Patrick Moynihan misstated the given name of the subject in a portrait hanging in the Senator's Capitol Hill office. It is John Butler Yeats, the father of the poet William Butler Yeats, not Jack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TENENBERG, HARRY
description: TENENBERG-Harry. On November 16 in NYC. Teacher, union organizer, civil rights activist, founding member of Encounter. Funny, good, generous friend. He is survived by his loving family: daughter, Nancy Ferleger, sister, Pearl Boxer, brothers, David and Daniel Tenenberg, son-in-law, Len Ferleger, grandson, Ben Ferleger, nephews, Alan and Joseph Boxer, Jerry and David Tenenberg, and niece, Betsy. A memorial service will be held Friday, December 11 at 6 PM at the Greenwich House Music School, 46 Barrow St., NYC.

title: Budget Cuts Draw First Protests
description: WESTCHESTER residents had their first chance Wednesday night to have their say on the proposed $1.13 billion county budget, and they came out strongly, grumbling about proposed cuts to the county's four neighborhood health centers, applauding increased aid for day-care programs and saying the county could do still more for children and women.

title: Rangers and Sharks Tie, 2-2
description: Battered and bloodied, the injury-depleted Rangers squandered a two-goal lead tonight against the Sharks. Playing their third game in four nights of a California tour, they withstood a furious San Jose attack in the final minute of regulation and a frantic extra five minutes and settled for a 2-2 tie.

title: How Not to Conduct an Impeachment Hearing; Photogenic Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; Without Evidence
description: The prosecutors who brought homicide charges against 11-year-old Lacresha Murray for allegedly killing a 2 1/2-year-old girl now concede that Lacresha's so-called confession, obtained during a lengthy grilling by the police in Austin, Tex., was worthless.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLIFFORD, FRANK E.
description: CLIFFORD-Frank E. Died peacefully November 19, 1998 in Atlanta, GA. Born in Fairport, NY June 8, 1908. Resident for many years of Mountain Lakes, N.J. and Atlanta, GA. Survived by his wife Jane W. Clifford of Sebring, FL, his children Polly C. Skinner, Dean W. Clifford, Sarah C. Cook and Julie G. Clifford, numerous nieces, nephews, grandchildren and great grandchildren. Predeceased by his son David C. Clifford. He retired from E.I. duPont Nemours after 35 yrs. There will be no services. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Once a Political Debit, Now a Powerful Force
description: As a withering year draws to a close with her husband's threatened impeachment, Hillary Rodham Clinton prevails above the American landscape in all her signature duality.

title: Martha Harris, James Caron
description: Martha W. Harris, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David Harris of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Arthur Caron, the son of Margarita and Arthur Caron of New Bedford, Mass. Justice Betty Weinberg Ellerin of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court officiated at the Union Club in Manhattan.

title: Leslie Felton, Howard Sklar
description: Leslie Gail Felton, a daughter of Susan Felton of Lawrence, N.Y., and the late Robert Felton, is to be married this evening to Howard Mark Sklar, the son of Naomi and Elliott Sklar of Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Gilbert Klaperman is to officiate at the St. Regis in Manhattan.

title: Red Grooms's Merry New Merry-Go-Round
description: CHILDLIKE wonder is among the hardest of all emotions for adults to recapture. But if there is one new work of public art guaranteed to inspire that elusive response, it is Red Grooms's ''Tennessee Fox Trot Carousel,'' a full-scale, functioning merry-go-round that will be inaugurated at 10:30 A.M. on Friday in the artist's birthplace, Nashville.

title: POSTINGS: $110 Million Condominium at Former Site of Sign of the Dove; Designed by Stern, but No Shingles
description: Robert A. M. Stern, master of the postmodern shingle-style bungalow, is coming to Manhattan -- and it isn't to build bungalows.

title: Landmarking Newark
description: The words landmark and Newark don't often appear in the same sentence. But they should, in the view of the Newark Preservation and Landmarks Committee (and they have, here, in two consecutive sentences). To make it case, the committee has opened an exhibition observing its 25th anniversary, to continue through next month at the Newark Public Library, 49 Washington Street. Photographs, documents and artifacts demonstrate that the committee has helped establish three historic districts in the city and has worked to have 60 buildings, parks, cemeteries and sculptures listed on the national and state Registers of Historic Places. Among them are Gutzon Borglum's 1916 sculpture ''Indian and Puritan'' at Washington Park, shown here. Drawings of seven landmarks by Richard LaRovere of Jersey City are available as note cards (some as postcards) at the Newark Museum gift shop, or by mail by calling (973) 622-4910. The exhibition is open during library hours: Mondays, Fridays and Saturdays from 9 A.M. to 5:30 P.M., and Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Saturdays from 9 A.M. to 8:30 P.M.

title: Reno Moves Closer To First Decision Over Fund-Raising
description: Attorney General Janet Reno must decide by Tuesday whether to seek an independent counsel to investigate Vice President Al Gore, in the first of three decisions likely to determine whether there will ever be an outside investigation of Democratic fund-raising in 1996.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'Nutcracker' Updated

title: Dance -- Honoring The Founding Vision, and Moving On; At 50, City Ballet Is Looking To What's Next
description: IT isn't a trivia question to ask which of George Balanchine's ballets were on the first program when the New York City Ballet officially came into existence on Oct. 11, 1948. As virtually every City Ballet subscriber knows by heart, the triple bill consisted of ''Concerto Barocco,'' ''Orpheus'' and ''Symphony in C.'' The same program will inaugurate the City Ballet's mammoth 50th-anniversary year on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater, just as it did the 40th anniversary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, HAROLD
description: GROSS-Harold. Loving and beloved brother, uncle, cousin and friend. Passed away gently on Thursday, November 19. Lived in London Terrace and will be remembered as a good neighbor and great lover of K-9's. Graveside service on Sunday 12:30pm at Temple Israel in Hastings.

title: Painting My Religion
description: Last December, when Darcey Steinke decided to organize a show of religiously influenced art -- called ''Transfiguration,'' which just opened at the Bronwyn Keenan Gallery in New York -- she decided to skip standard iconography of saints and angels and go mod. Steinke, a novelist (''Jesus Saves'') whose father is a Lutheran minister, began writing letters to artists, visiting studios and looking at slides. Nine months later she selected 17 pieces of art that collectively present a strange perspective on the varieties of religious experience.

title: Behind the Jokes, a Life Of Pain and Delusion; For Letterman Stalker, Mental Illness Was Family Curse and Scarring Legacy
description: Although she spent much of her time in the thrall of delusions, Margaret Mary Ray wrote her last missive to her mother in what seemed to be a moment of clarity.

title: Still Waiting
description: A Dream Deferred

title: Taking a Remodeling Beyond Skin Deep
description: FOR many homeowners, the strategy for planning a home renovation project is like the one used when planning a visit to the dentist: fix whatever's broken, please, and leave everything else alone.

title: Party Pointers
description: The folks at Executive Communications Group of Englewood, N.J., which describes itself as ''an international leadership and communications consulting firm,'' want to help business people everywhere be the life of the holiday party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BICKFORD, ALBERT CONDE
description: BICKFORD-Albert Conde, 96, on November 18, 1998 at home in Ardsley-on-Hudson, NY. Husband of the late Esther H. Bickford. Survivors are his son, Robert C. Bickford and daughter-in-law, Margaretta Murphy Bickford of Cold Spring, NY, his son, Nathaniel J. Bickford and daughter-in-law, Jewelle Wooten Bickford of New York City, his granddaughters, Laura C. Bickford, Emily Bickford Lansbury and Elisabeth C. Bickford, his grandsons, Louis N. Bickford, James J. Bickford and Robert H. Bickford, his great granddaughter, Elizabeth Laura Lansbury and his great grandson, Eli Benjamin Bickford. Services at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church, Main Street, Irvington, NY at 3 PM on Sunday, November 22, 1998. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to the Dobbs Ferry Library, 153 Main St, Dobbs Ferry, NY 10522 for its Audio Tapes for the Blind program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, CELIA ''ZELDA
description: SCHWARTZ-Celia ''Zelda.'' Beloved mother of Melvin. Dear sister of Sol Schreck. Loving grandmother of Robert, Frank and Michael. Loving mother-in-law of Bruni. Services Sunday, 1 PM, at Parkside Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue.

title: How Americans See Themselves
description: Regarding your statement, in ''The Likes and Dislikes of Today's Everyfamily,'' that the average couple have sex about once a week ''for an average of 39 minutes,'' we are wondering: what exactly is included in those 39 minutes (Nov. 1)? Are you referring only to ''the act'' -- or might it be the time from the first smooch to the first snore?

title: Watch for Ill-Timed Gains As 1998 Draws to a Close
description: A WARNING to mutual fund investors who may already be struggling through a tough year: You won't really know how bad it is until you receive your funds' year-end capital gains distributions.

title: America's Crown Jeweler
description: IT'S been a nervous fall for the initiates of Verdura, one of the last of the bespoke jewelers, which for most of its 60 years has operated almost as a private club. In its plush New York showroom, 12 floors above Fifth Avenue near 57th Street, an appointment was required until recently.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, ABRAHAM
description: WEINSTEIN-Abraham (Al): Sutton Place Synagogue mourns the loss of our longtime member. Our sympathies to his devoted wife Frances and adored son, Robert. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Robert W. Berend, President

title: Symbols at an Exhibition
description: FREUD

title: Love Me, Love My Exotic Pet
description: I NEVER met an animal I didn't like. But not every creature in God's creation seems equally qualified to be a household pet. Tigers, for example, are even more demanding than domestic cats and take up a lot more space in the living room. Yet, a couple of years ago, The Times interviewed a man who kept a 250-pound tiger in the genteel suburb of Dix Hills, causing his neighbors some uneasiness. Pot-bellied pigs, house rabbits and tree frogs have become almost commonplace, and a big goat used to live just up the road and go for walks on a leash.

title: Christina Murphy, Anthony Addison
description: Christina Ann Murphy and Anthony Pearson Addison were married last evening at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. Mark C. Hallinan performed the ceremony.

title: Word & Image; Macho Man Vs. the News
description: The news media stand accused of succumbing to what is loosely being called ''entertainment.'' We are said to have yielded to commercial pressures that value violence, sex and gossip above meaningful and useful information. And indeed, there is much cause for concern given the nightly mix of mayhem and mirth on the local ''news,'' the scandal mongering and celebrity chasing by ''newsmagazines'' and the flood of glib opinion on ''all news'' channels. Lazy reporting, hokey melodrama and ill-informed commentary masquerade as journalism, particularly on television.

title: As Ill Luck Would Have It
description: Armadillo

title: Muse, Interrupted
description: Around 1950, give or take a year or two, George Balanchine, the great choreographer and (with Lincoln Kirstein) founder of the New York City Ballet, fell in love -- a significant occurrence in anybody's life but in his case one that would have important consequences for the culture of this century. Over the course of the next several years, the man who made ballet a modern art enshrined the woman who would become his fifth wife in a series of roles that bear her imprint to this day. Since his arrival in America in 1933, journalists had been asking Balanchine what constituted the ideal body for a dancer. He replied that he was looking for long legs, a strong back, light bones (''like a bird's'') and a small head. In his other ballerinas he had found two -- maybe three -- of those qualities; in Tanaquil Le Clercq he hit the jackpot.

title: Engineering an Icon
description: MARILYN MONROE

title: A Rainbow Of Grays
description: The grays that have swept fashion this fall have little in common with the gray flannel look of the early 1950's. Today, ombre shading creates the excitement, as at near right. Even fur trim, like chinchilla and silver fox, highlights the gradations in gray suits. An occasional touch of violet echoes the Edwardians. One man used it in his coat lining with five shades of gray -- in his suit, topcoat, tie, vest and shirt. Another added a mauve hat and tie to his shadow-plaid suit. And a woman covered in grays accented her hat with a mauve bird of paradise feather.

title: The Nation: Power Bargaining; Walking the Picket Line in Gucci Loafers
description: JUDGING from this month's explosion of labor disputes, class struggle has gone upscale. Marxism seems to have given way to Nieman-Marxism. Basketball superstars earning $10 million a year are locked in battle with management. Federal Express pilots pulling in $130,000 or more a year have repeatedly threatened to strike. And cameramen at ABC who, with overtime, frequently make $125,000 a year or more, have been walking the picket lines for close to three weeks.

title: Fixed-Rate Mortgages Decline
description: Fixed mortgage rates dropped last week as the Federal Reserve cut short-term interest rates a quarter-point again. A survey of 200 lenders by Bank Rate Monitor found the average rate on a 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage fell 0.08 percent, to 6.81 percent; the 15-year rate slipped 0.05 percent, to 6.48 percent.

title: The World: Second Acts, and Beyond; Check Out the 'Me, Reborn' Generation
description: LOOKING for a role model for your career? How about Jesse Ventura, the menacing wrestler turned blustery radio host turned straight-talking Minnesota Governor-elect?

title: Jordan Is Not a Brave Yet
description: The belief that Brian Jordan will sign with the Atlanta Braves and become their right fielder is in error, his agent said yesterday, leaving open the possibility that Jordan could still sign with the Mets or the Yankees.

title: Davenport Stops Graf's Big Charge
description: Steffi Graf, relentless in her return from wrist surgery, had been the queen of mean on every tennis court she touched lately. She knocked off a trio of the world's top-ranked players, including No. 1 Lindsay Davenport, in the last two weeks as if they were little more than pretenders to her throne. The 12th-ranked Graf seemed to have their number, no matter what that number happened to be.

title: Reviving an Operatic Immortal
description: ONE HUNDRED years ago today, Pietro Mascagni's opera ''Iris'' had its premiere at the Teatro Costanzi in Rome, the same theater in which, eight years before, his first and most famous opera, ''Cavalleria Rusticana,'' received 60 curtain calls at its premiere. But whereas ''Cavalleria'' ushered in the era of verismo, which sought to dramatize the lives of ordinary people, ''Iris'' came at the height of the ''japonisme'' that swept the arts in Europe in the second half of the 19th century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, ARNOLD J.
description: FRANKEL-Arnold J. Age 76. Died peacefully in his home on November 20, 1998, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Miriam D. Frankel for 54 years, devoted father of Hinda Squires, Janet Staub, and Alan, adoring grandfather of eight grandchildren; loving brother of Edith Frankel and Doris Dunn. He is also lovingly remembered by daughter-in-law Jodi Frankel and son-in-law Shalom Staub. Arnold was born on March 17, 1922, in New York City. He graduated from CCNY, having majored in Chemical Engineering. He later completed his M.S. from Polytechnic University. He was co-founder and former Chairman of Aceto Corporation, a chemical company located in Lake Success, NY. Arnold's retirement from Aceto in May, 1997, also marked 50 years of the company's growth and success. He will be remembered for his many philanthropic efforts and his active participation on the Boards of the Queens Child Guidance Center, the Jewish Museum, and HIAS. He was a Trustee of the City College Fund, and a member of the Advisory Board of the Chemical Heritage Foundation in Philadelphia. He received awards from the American Jewish Committee and the UJA. He was a member of AAAS, American Chemical Society, American Institute of Chemists (for which he had served as past President of the NYC Chapter), Chemist's Club, and Sigma Xi. Arnold will be remembered for the ethical and responsible way in which he conducted himself as a businessman, a community leader, and pater familias. Service Sunday, 10:45 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: November 15-21; A New Tobacco Deal
description: The nation's biggest tobacco companies agreed to a deal with state attorneys general under which they would pay $206 billion over 25 years to the states in exchange for ending state lawsuits against cigarette makers based on health costs associated with smoking.

title: How Not to Conduct an Impeachment Hearing; A Bad Example
description: To the Editor:

title: Grim, Shocking, Didactic, a New New Wave Rolls In
description: THESE days a mood of optimism and brash confidence has once again taken hold of French filmmaking. A new generation of films -- ''My Sex Life,'' ''Irma Vep,'' ''The Dreamlife of Angels'' and ''I Stand Alone'' -- is causing an international stir with its uninhibited depictions of contemporary society, and taking festival prizes and even finding American distribution. Some are calling it the new New Wave, the Next Wave or the Re-New Wave; others, more skeptically, a hype-created ripple.

title: New Canaan Deer, Other Views
description: For the sake of accuracy, I would like to clear up a few items that appeared in the article (''Inviting Hunters Home to Cull the Deer Herd,'' Nov. 8).

title: How Not to Conduct an Impeachment Hearing; Impeachment Is Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Dawn Lisak, Brian Byck
description: Dawn Ilyse Lisak, a daughter of Carol and Barry Lisak of Cedarhurst, N.Y., was married last evening to Brian Stewart Byck, a son of Beverly Byck and Dr. Carl Byck of Haddon Heights, N.J. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn, N.Y.

title: San Francisco Expands Onto an Old Naval Base
description: Treasure Island in San Francisco, which recently opened to the public for the first time in nearly 50 years, will be illuminated by thousands of twinkling lights during a holiday fair next month. The free fair will run from 5 to 10 P.M. every weekend between Dec. 4 and 20, and will include choral performances, a Christmas tree and wreath market, a bazaar featuring the work of local artisans, and an illuminated procession of boats on opening night. There will also be a flea and antiques market, which will continue every Sunday throughout 1999, from 6 A.M. to 4 P.M.

title: Shrinking Network TV Audiences Set Off Alarm and Reassessment
description: For many who work at the broadcast television networks, the new season of prime-time programming that began in September with the usual high hopes for a batch of 37 new weekly series has already degenerated into a disheartening and increasingly panic-stricken game of ''what's wrong with this picture.''

title: Political Memo; Republican Governors Long for a Broader Role
description: While their peers in Congress were steeped in the impeachment hearings this week, the nation's Republican governors gathered here, happily oblivious to the biggest political story in Washington. Most of them did not even tune in.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Date With a Dog's Dr. Spock
description: THE SETTING -- The ornate Conrad Suite at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where veterinarians, dog trainers and assorted friends of man's best friend came to hear Dr. Ian Dunbar, an animal behaviorist and veterinarian, Monday night. His topic? Bad behavior, which, he intoned in a scholarly British accent, is ''the No. 1 killer of dogs in America today.''

title: By Howard Thompson
description: A sweeping desert adventure, a courtroom thriller and two melodramas featuring one of Hollywood's most talented duos are among the escapist delights on television this week.

title: Talking Cure?
description: MADNESS ON THE COUCH

title: Window on the Wilderness
description: FOUR or five times a year, my husband, two dogs and I drive from Omaha to a defunct potato farm we own in far northeastern Minnesota. On these trips, we mostly stay around the place, but we always find an excuse to go into Ely (pronounced EE-lee), a 30-minute drive on Highway 169, which winds through emerald forests and along the shores of lapis lazuli lakes. Ely is 112 miles north of Duluth, just on the edge of the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness, which in turn adjoins the Quetico Provincial Park in Canada -- each of which covers a million acres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWARK, ELEANORE Y.
description: NEWARK-Eleanore Y. The officers, Board of Governors and members of the Archaeology Institute of America/Long Island Society, mourn the passing of our former President, Eleanor Y. Newark, on November 16, 1998, in Jacksonville, FL, and extend their heartfelt condolences to her children John and Jennifer. Joseph J. Lepelstat, President AIA/LIS

title: If the Kings Are in the Open, Get Ready for a Donnybrook
description: When the pawn cover has been shot away and the two kings are exposed on an open board, the action is bound to be explosive. What counts is who will land the heaviest stroke soonest.

title: Improving Efficiency of Fireplaces
description: A RECENT survey of homeowners found that there are more than 35 million fireplaces in homes throughout the United States, and that each year homeowners light more than one billion fires in those fireplaces.

title: A Story With Multiple Personalities of Its Own
description: FOR three more weeks, the Paper Mill Playhouse here is offering a rare chance for musical-theater game-playing of the trivia-pursuing kind. Whoever has nothing better to do may compare a Broadway hit (''Jekyll and Hyde'') with yet another variation (''Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde'') on the same story, and then decide which is worse.

title: Diana's Former Shoemaker Opens a Store in Midtown
description: There's a waiting list for a shoe named Tosca, a flat that comes in gray flannel, black leather or black velvet and can be ordered at Jimmy Choo, a shoe store that opened this month at 645 Fifth Avenue (at 51st Street).

title: Asian Crisis Pushes Down U.S. Gasoline Prices
description: Asia's economic collapse will depress oil and gasoline prices for nearly a decade, saving motorists in the United States about 13 cents a gallon in 2000 alone, the Energy Department said this week.

title: Jets Show Female Fans the Ropes
description: IF you toss a woman a pigskin, the chances are pretty good that she'll catch it. When she does, she'll head for the end zone just like any man.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; News That Stayed News
description: This ragtag century of ours is getting to seem like a garrulous uncle who keeps coming back with his same old stories: his great wars and his great depressions, evils daunted and lessons sorely learned. Crowds cheering the troops into World War I, the folly of the Treaty of Versailles, the masses on their feet in Nazi salute at the 1936 Olympics in Berlin -- and on and on. THE CENTURY (Doubleday, $60) is comprehensive, balanced, eminently readable and fairly onerous, taken cover to cover. The narrative by Peter Jennings, the broadcaster, and Todd Brewster, a former editor and writer at Life, is a good textbook history of the American experience of the 20th century, told from the perspective of the American 1990's, rather than what might have been more interesting, the century as seen from each of its successive eras. Important phases and events are captured in a series of first-person accounts, most filling a single page, with a boxed biography of the speaker and several photographs, often snapshots; together these form an effective, and in some ways more satisfying narrative, and are the real meat of this book. The photo selection of Katherine Bourbeau is excellent, with an eye for the unfamiliar image (John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon in a handshake that separates rather than brings them together; students at Harvard mourning Kennedy's murder), while a familiar image like Dorothea Lange's ''Migrant Mother'' is treated as subject rather than illustration, and captioned with a quotation from the photographer, describing the circumstances of the shot. With so much to browse and relive, there will be something here for everyone. David Walton

title: Productive Talks Yield Guarded Optimism
description: Chris Dudley looked haggard, like a trader whose stock was stuck on a roller coaster. While he managed to emerge upbeat from a negotiating session late Friday night, he was like most of his peers: he had no idea when he would be paid to play basketball again.

title: POSTINGS: Programs Broaden; City Mails Out Tax-Cut Forms
description: A deadline of Jan. 5 has been set for the filing of applications from New York City residents for next year's New York State School Tax Relief Program (STAR). The applications have recently been mailed to all owners of homes in the city, including co-ops and condominiums.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 1 about a Boston exhibition of work by the Italian artist Carol Rama misstated the political philosophy of the Christian Democratic Party in Italy, which closed an exhibition of Ms. Rama's work in 1945. It is a centrist party, not a fascist one, that has dominated Italian politics since World War II.

title: Works From China, Many Political but Conveyed With Wit
description: THE Lehman College Art Gallery here has a history of mounting shows of the art of different cultures. The current exhibition, ''Contemporary Chinese Art and the Literary Culture of China,'' is focused and lively. Little of the writing is on the usual surfaces: it is embedded in all sorts of sculpture installations, many of which use communications technology.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANSOM, MARJORIE
description: RANSOM-Marjorie. Age 72, on November 1, 1998. The American Museum of Natural History mourns the loss of Marjorie Ransom Emeritus 1946-1991. Wake will be held Monday, November 23rd, Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 West 72nd St at 9:30AM with services at Noon.

title: Defensemen Help Fill In the Gap for the Devils
description: The Devils found themselves two men short for two minutes midway through the third period, but they escaped unscathed thanks to the heroics of Scott Stevens, Scott Niedermayer and Ken Daneyko.

title: Urnings
description: I appreciate the problem of trying to sell ''Uncle Buck's'' ashes (Sunday, Nov. 1). A few suggestions for the auctioneer:

title: Q. & A.
description: Board's Actions In a Co-op

title: Pathetic Fallacies
description: We all make mistakes. Some of them are modest bloopers, others mortifying whoppers. They appear not only in ephemeral newsprint but also in books, which we must live with and then be haunted by in the grave. All mistakes hurt the fastidious author, even those by the editor, copy editor or typesetter. The wary author realizes that the reader will always blame the writer, as if the poor scribe had total control over what appears under his or her byline.

title: What of Italians?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, JOEL
description: ROSEN - Joel. Internationally known concert pianist and teacher, died on November 17, 1998. He leaves behind a loving family; his wife Joy, children Jeffrey and Linda, their spouses Daphne Hsu and Rob Macomber, and three grandsons Bobby, Michael and Jamie. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to the Performers of Westchester or the Mid-Westchester YM-YWHA Ceramics Art Department in Scarsdale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANDSEN, EJVIND
description: FRANDSEN-Ejvind. November 20, 1998. Beloved husband of Birgitta. (Bitten) Services to be held in Denmark at a later date.

title: Henry Hyde's Confusion
description: The decision by Henry Hyde, the House Judiciary Committee chairman, to subpoena additional witnesses for reasons he could not explain outside executive session is a singularly bad idea for a very specific reason. It sends the Judiciary Committee hurtling down paths already meticulously explored by Kenneth Starr when Mr. Hyde and the committee's Republican majority ought to be searching for an exit strategy that would serve two valuable public needs. One is to allow Congress to move on to other business. The other and more immediately important need is for Congress to find a way to write into the historic record a condemnation of President Clinton for failing in his constitutional duty to uphold the rule of law.

title: Perspectives on a Brave New World and Some Familiar Ones
description: 'Embryoworlds'

title: Gramercy's Gilded Cage
description: THIS year, I am giving thanks for the pigeons and squirrels of Gramercy Park. Do not think of them merely as pests that litter and befoul, but as cherished symbols of class conflict, generational warfare and real estate boom in the neighborhood I live in and call Grapus.

title: Apartment Hunt Isn't That Hard; Lots of Good Places, If You Leave Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MALLIS, MEYER
description: MALLIS-Meyer. 10/18/16-11/30/90. Always remembered, always missed, and always loved. Dad, rest in peace.

title: Q&A/Melody Cope; Coaching College-Bound Women Athletes
description: AS head softball coach for six years at the University of North Carolina, Greensboro, Melody Cope took her women's teams to the Big South Conference title four times, won the school's first-ever N.C.A.A. Division I Collegiate Softball Championship in 1997 and was named conference Coach of the Year.

title: Bus Companies Resent Being Run Off the Road
description: Is it stealing from Peter to pay Paul?

title: Word for Word / Bombs, Away!; Pop Quiz for the Caller Who Says He's Going to Blow the Place Up
description: GOVERNMENT agencies, private companies, schools and abortion clinics receive more bomb threats than the authorities like to admit. And in a city, say, like Washington, the Government alone gets 20 or 30 mostly crank calls every week. The threats are usually made over the telephone, but employees who take the calls are often shaken by the experience and seldom prepared to ask the right questions or note the details that can help investigators track down the caller.

title: On Language; Impacting Status
description: ''You can now status your transfer request 24 hours a day,'' Fidelity Investments wrote Yvonne Freund of Bellevue, Wash. She immediately statused her vocabulary and wrote me, ''Is this English?''

title: Q&A/Kenneth A. Shouler; Ranking Baseball's Best and Telling Why
description: KENNETH A. SHOULER is the first to admit it: the probability of anyone out there agreeing with all of his choices for the best 100 baseball players of all time is pretty remote. Mr. Shouler, 42, a White Plains resident, is a philosophy teacher at City University of New York and senior editor for Total Sports, a sports publishing company in Manhattan, which publishes books on individual sports and maintains a Web site. He is the author of ''The Real 100 Best Baseball Players of All Time . . . And WHY!'' (Addax Publishing Group).

title: A New Food and Wine Coalition Promotes Hudson Valley Visits
description: PUFF pastry shells filled with veal and mushrooms, accompanied by vintage Zinfandel wine and finished off with fondant au chocolat for dessert. This may not sound like anyone's idea of a diet meal, but calorie counters seemed to be in short supply among the 300 guests who crammed the Putnam Country Club in Mahopac earlier this month for a food and wine tasting event that featured offerings from 21 restaurants, 10 wineries and 7 food producers from the Hudson Valley.

title: In the Region / Connecticut; A House-Size Proposal Is Scrapped in Westport
description: IN a packed public hearing late last month the Westport Planning and Zoning Commission saw its 24 pages of proposals for new zoning regulations torn to shreds. The measure covers many kinds of structures, but its provisions for limiting the size of homes in an effort to halt the spread of so-called ''trophy houses'' drew the most attention.

title: Man Questioned in Killing Of Buffalo Doctor Is Released
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has interviewed and released one of two men being sought last week for questioning in connection with the sniper slaying of a doctor in the Buffalo area who performed abortions.

title: Melissa Van Royen, Robert Kyle Jr.
description: Melissa Ann Van Royen, the daughter of Judith and William Van Royen of Tampa, Fla., was married there yesterday to Robert Johnston Kyle Jr., the son of Elisabeth Sherwood of Annapolis, Md., and the late Mr. Kyle. The Rev. Dr. John DeBevoise performed the ceremony at Palma Ceia Presbyterian Church. The Rev. John Price, an Episcopal priest, took part in the service.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Books From The Times
description: Insects preceded people on this earth by about 300 million years, and may well survive mankind by longer than that. Such a prospect deserves respect, and that is what insects (and a few other arthropods) receive in THE SCIENCE TIMES BOOK OF INSECTS, edited by Nicholas Wade (Lyons, $25), a selection of nature reporting, from The Times's weekly science section, about insects and the scientists who study them. Intriguing new findings concern, for example, the recycling tactics of dung beetles, without whom this planet would be a mess; the invasive habits of the Halloween ladybug, an innocent aphid eater that can alarm whole suburbs with its vast October swarms; and, perhaps best of all, research at Cambridge University that appears to have determined how the proverbially unairworthy bumblebee manages, in defiance of conventional aerodynamics, to fly.

title: A Grand Entrance, In Your Own Helicopter
description: COMMUTING by helicopter can be tough. Just ask Harrison Ford, the actor. In September, he wanted to fly his new helicopter to Alexandria, Va., where he was about to begin shooting his latest film, ''Random Hearts.'' But the city had an ordinance banning nonemergency choppers. So he ended up driving instead.

title: Police Settlement
description: The village of Elmsford and one of its police officers who was dismissed a year ago for sleeping on the job, have settled a $150,000 lawsuit brought by the officer against the village. One-third of the settlement to the officer will be paid by the village, and the rest is to be covered by the village's insurance company.

title: Truck Driver Is Sought In Death of Filmmaker
description: The Suffolk County police are seeking the driver of a truck they suspect was carrying a pipe that caused the death of the film director Alan J. Pakula on Thursday. The pipe crashed through Mr. Pakula's windshield as he drove on the Long Island Expressway.

title: Community Board Meetings: Where and When
description: DISTRICT 1 Battery Park, Civic Center, Financial District, South Street Seaport, TriBeCa; third Tuesday of month; next meeting Dec. 15, 5:30 P.M.; location to be determined. Board Chairwoman: Anne Compoccia. District Manager: Paul Goldstein. (212) 442-5050. Agenda: To be announced.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS with ANTHONY MAZZOCCHI; Rebuilding a Platform For the American Worker
description: AS the driving spirit behind the Labor Party, a fledgling left-of-center group that hopes someday to be a political heavyweight, Anthony Mazzocchi presided over its constitutional convention last weekend in Pittsburgh.

title: A Third Cut in Rates, But Don't Expect More
description: When the Federal Reserve cut short-term interest rates on Tuesday, its third cut in seven weeks, it also signaled that it was done cutting for now, because the markets had largely stabilized and because widespread hints that the economy was slowing remained just hints.

title: V.A.T. Refunds
description: To the Editor: There's another situation when a V.A.T. refund is unavailable (''V.A.T. Refunds: Vexations Added,'' Oct. 11). I took a train from Munich (which is within the European Union) to Prague (which is not). I had all my receipts and merchandise together. But nobody in the Munich railroad station or on the train was available to validate the receipts.

title: Government of, By and for The Comfortable
description: Lemann's article on the new American consensus is on target in describing an important political trend. But I find it curious that he chooses to make the case that the opposite of selfishness is Big Government. He overlooks the possibility that the real antidote to our inward focus may be a revival of community. We may be looking for a model of decision-making where citizens make choices for themselves, in a revival of ''face to face'' democracy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOWKES, ROBERT A.
description: FOWKES-Robert A. of Bronxville, NY on November 18, 1998. Husband of Angela Vescio Fowkes, father of Robert Jr., Richard and William, grandfather of six, greatgrandfather of three. Services at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, on Monday, November 23, at 12 noon. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to NYU Scholarship Fund or St. David's Society of New York.

title: London Disk
description: Sir Christopher Wren might not have known what to make of it, but Choice Way Guides sells a London CD-ROM with over 55 maps, 58 video clips and 350 color photographs, along with travel advice. The disk provides direct Internet links, too. The price is $24.95 plus $3 shipping. Contact (408) 323-1546 or www.choiceway.com.

title: If Deflation Hits, It's a Whole New Game
description: DEFLATION? Don't be ridiculous.

title: Mayor Has Little to Say About a Possible Sale of the Yankees to Cablevision
description: With a deal reported to be near for the sale of the Yankees, their No. 1 fan -- Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani -- was uncharacteristically reticent yesterday about what that might mean for the team and its possible move from the Bronx.

title: Seekers of Fame and Traffic Tickets
description: For most people, traffic tickets are as welcome as dental work. But this is Hollywood, and Jeremiah Gerbracht and his dog, Lady Harley, think of them as tickets to fame.

title: November 15-21; Freeh's Invitation to Speculate
description: F.B.I. Director Louis J. Freeh's inner circle has always regarded him as a potential Republican candidate back home in New York, although Mr. Freeh has shrugged off talk of a political future, citing his 10-year term, which expires in 2003.

title: PULSE; Dungaree Do-Gooder
description: He braves a tornado to rescue a kitten, leaps a cliff to save an infant from a fiery car and survives a plane crash after the pilot bails out with the only parachute. He's Buddy Lee, star of the new Lee Jeans television commercials. Buddy, a bowlegged doll first used in window displays in the 1920's, was hauled out of a 36-year retirement in July for a Lee advertising campaign that put him in magazines like Details and Mademoiselle and on posters around New York. Now Buddy has developed into an underground celebrity, a cross between Mr. Bill and the Taco Bell Chihuahua. He gets about 75 fan letters a week on www.buddylee.com, his Web site message board. A woman in Caldwell, N. J., proposed marriage. An electricians' union local in Pueblo, Colo., wrote: ''Not 10 minutes pass before once again we hear someone yell: 'Hit the breaks, Buddy.' '' Alonzo Wilson, the costume designer for ''Dawson's Creek,'' put a cast member in a Buddy T-shirt for a coming episode. ''We talk about him all the time,'' he said. People want to know where to buy the doll and when the movie's coming out. Lee has no such plans. But fans can track down the original dolls at vintage toy dealers and auctions, where $500 to $600 buys a Buddy in good shape. NANCY MACDONELL SMITH

title: Alicia Tamres And Ian Stone
description: Alicia Meryl Tamres, a daughter of Trude L. Tamres of Lido Beach, N.Y., and Herbert J. Tamres of Oyster Bay, N.Y., was married last evening to Ian Howard Stone, a son of Myrna E. Stone of Little Neck, Queens, and Herbert A. Stone of Lido Beach. Rabbi Nathaniel Schwartz officiated at the Parker Meridien Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Overhauling The Fields Of Dreams
