description: Deborah Romano, an organizer with the Prospect Park Alliance, said many young baseball players at the park's Parade Grounds take pride in fielding bad-hop grounders off its gravelly, grass-less infields. But still, she said, when they get a chance to play at a well-maintained field in other parts of Brooklyn, they love it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, ROBERT HENRY
description: STERN-Robert Henry. Beloved husband of Irene; loving father of Ronnie and Randy Strause, Stacey and Richard Block; devoted grandfather of Jackie and Brett Strause, David and Daniel Block. Fond brother of William H. and Sharon Stern, Ellin and Fred Satloff and the late Morty Solomon. Services today, 12 noon, ''Boulevard-Riverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: No Winners in a Game Of Asset Shuffling
description: When Eli Lilly & Company's stock dipped $1 last Tuesday, to $82.8125, the move might have left investors scratching their heads.

title: Our Gangs: Wars, and Warriors, Go Local
description: IT was 8:30 on a cool October evening at South Franklin Street and Marvin Avenue, a street corner in a neighborhood of storefronts and small single-family houses in the Village of Hempstead, when the tranquillity was punctured by the sound of gunshots, shattering glass and squealing tires.

title: Government of, By and for The Comfortable
description: First, with Andrew Sullivan's ''The Scolds'' (Oct. 11), you attack those who would uphold traditional moral values.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOTT, KATHERINE ANNE
description: SCOTT-Katherine Anne ''Kit''. 28 years old of Livingston, NJ, died Wednesday, November 18, 1998 in Buenos Aires, Argentina. Ms. Scott was a Senior New Markets Analyst for Prudential Securities in New York. She was Committee Co-Chair of the Junior League of New York; member of Pi Beta Phi Sorority; and member of Colonial Dames of Nebraska. She is survived by her mother and stepfather, Jean and Robert F. Jennings of Denver, CO; father, Douglas H. Scott of Arvada, CO; brothers, William and Robert Scott of Lincoln, NE, stepbrother and sister-in-law, Robert and Kellye Jennings of Dunn Loring, VA; stepsisters and brother-in-law, Lacey Jennings of Arlington, VA and Lisa and Bob Brinker, Jr. of Scottsdale, AZ; grandparents, William and Anne Porter of Lincoln, NE and Olive Jennings of Key Largo, FL; and special friend, Anthony Nittolo of Livingston, NJ. Memorial service is scheduled for 2 PM, Monday, November 23, 1998 at First Plymouth Congregational Church in Lincoln, NE. Memorials to the Porter Foundation at 233 S. 13th, Suite 1708, Lincoln, NE 68508 or Doctors Without Borders, The Junior League of Lincoln and The Junior League of New York City.

title: For Unions, a Holiday Turkey Is Starting to Look Like an Albatross
description: Distributing turkeys to union members has been a holiday tradition at District Council 37 for more than a decade. Some years, frozen turkeys were packed to the ceiling at the council's headquarters while 1,000 or more union members lined up to receive their bounty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, HENRY
description: LEVINSON-Henry. 1907-1998. In Dania, FL. A remarkable man, a loving husband, a devoted father. Lucy Warshaw (Robert), June Nemchin (Robert), Rose Carelli (John). A proud grandfather, an adoring great-grandfather, a very distinguished graduate of Cooper Union. Hank loved NYC and spent most of his adult life making a better life for others in NY and everywhere else he traveled. Contributions in memory of Henry Levinson may be made to: The Cooper Union Alumni Fund, Class of 1929, Cooper Square, NY NY 10003.

title: Art Stakes New Ground, In Meatpacking District
description: For decades, the block of 14th Street between Ninth and 10th Avenues was known chiefly as part of the meatpacking district by day and as a hangout for transvestite prostitutes at night. But now both new and established art galleries, lured by sizable spaces and low rents, are moving into the area and converting former meat coolers into galleries.

title: Delays at Grand Central
description: Forty thousand Metro-North commuters must wait until mid-February or possibly later for the opening of four new entrances on the north side of Grand Central Terminal -- in part because of a delay in the delivery of light fixtures and tile.

title: FILM; Kitschy as Ever, Bollywood Is Branching Out
description: WHEN I was growing up in Bombay, one of my earliest passions as a child was going to the movies with my family. The attraction was not only the films but also the appearance of the pistachio seller at intermission (Indian films are long), rattling packets of the freshly roasted and salted nuts. Later, when I would go to the cinema with my school and college friends, often we would have only enough money for one ticket between us, so we would take turns watching portions of the films, slipping the single ticket to one another at intermission. In this way, and over time, we would eventually see the complete film.

title: High on the Hog
description: The political frieght train that was Newt Gingrich has been derailed, thanks in no small part to what many House Republicans view as his shameful kowtowing to the Administration during last month's budget battle. But Newt is leaving behind at least one legacy guaranteed to please even the most die-hard conservative: an additional $9 billion for defense financing. At an Oct. 15 press conference announcing the deal, Speaker Gingrich crowed, ''I am very proud that this is the first time since 1985 that in peacetime we have increased defense spending, because our young men and women in uniform deserve the support of the United States of America.''

title: November 15-21; A Light Show In the Night Sky
description: For most meteor fanciers, the Leonid show Tuesday night was mediocre; at most, some 2,000 shooting stars blazed across the sky per hour.

title: Memory, Atmosphere and How They Connect
description: NOSTALGIA and reverie are on display in two current exhibitions at Aljira: A Center for Contemporary Art here. So you can indulge in those qualities as obtained through a realist style, or abstract, according to taste.

title: Teri Silvers, Steven Betensky
description: Teri Diane Silvers and Steven Michael Betensky, both lawyers, were married last evening by Rabbi Renni S. Altman at the St. Regis in New York.

title: With Interest Rates Pared, Stocks Surge
description: Markets are perverse. After chilling out last summer, stocks have suddenly turned hot again, with the Dow Jones industrial average up 18 percent since Oct. 8 for its best six weeks since 1982. The Dow, which ended the week at 9,159.55, up 239.96, or 2.7 percent, for the week, has recovered 90 percent of the 1,799 points it lost in July and August.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: ONCE AGAIN FOR THUCYDIDES By Peter Handke. New Directions, $18.95.

title: Apartment Hunt Isn't That Hard; Lots of Good Places, If You Leave Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: Narrow Shelves, Depths of Knowledge
description: QUICK! Where can you find a 1959 Girl Scout handbook, the first book in English about dogs or a Butterick sewing pattern from 1900? Try one of New York's hundreds of little specialized libraries, where materials like these abound but not a single book by Stephen King is in sight.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL; It's Park vs. Parking as School Defends Its Patch of Asphalt
description: As it is, Boerum Park is hardly a park, just 40,000 square feet of asphalt surrounded by a 15-foot chain-link fence with a lone white basketball backboard at the east edge. On weekdays, teachers at the Cobble Hill High School of American Studies next door use the space to park their cars. At night, when the gates on Warren Street and Baltic Street are locked, Boerum Park becomes a dim, desolate island.

title: Government of, By and for The Comfortable
description: Lemann's argument that there is a ''working consensus between the political parties on most major issues'' may be supported by anecdotal evidence, but it is contradicted by empirical evidence.

title: Newark Looks at Site For Sports Complex
description: The Newark City Council voted last week to look into building an arena for the New Jersey Nets and a soccer stadium for the Metrostars on part of a 118-acre site near the Ironbound section. Monday's 8-0 vote directs the Central Planning Board to determine whether the area is in need of redevelopment, the first step in eventually clearing the area, said Frank Bell, chief analyst for the City Clerk's office.

title: How Not to Conduct an Impeachment Hearing
description: To the Editor:

title: An Owner's Clarification Of His Travel Agency
description: With reference to the article on Oct. 11 (''A Travel Agency Keeps Its Ties to Ireland''), I would like to point out, lest the comments of Alan Rich [head of the Westchester chapter of the American Society of Travel Agents] be thought relevant to Grimes Travel:

title: Junk Art Roils a Garden
description: The junk sculpture on Sixth Street and Avenue B looms above the surrounding tenements like a psychedelic treehouse. From its limbs of raw lumber hang a huge headless Godzilla, a gold mannequin with a horse's head, stuffed animals and other motley objects. For the community garden that houses Eddie Boros's growing sculpture, it has become a source of controversy along with the artist himself, a self-described alcoholic and trash picker who finds his materials in garbage cans and Dumpsters.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing on page 49 of the Arts & Leisure section today about a concert by the Festival Chamber Music Society is erroneous. The concert, at Merkin Concert Hall, was last month.

title: PULSE; Shrug It On
description: The shrug, essentially a shawl with sleeves, seemed to have gone the way of the dickey and the leg warmer. But now designers have revived this partial body covering, which was first worn in the 1930's over evening gowns and in the 50's to the office. Donna Karan offered a cashmere version in her fall collection, and now more people are doing the shrug than at any time since it was a Warhol-era dance craze. Meghan Kinney, a designer with a boutique at 312 East Ninth Street, who had 50 bell-sleeve shrugs and sold them all in a month, said it's the replacement for last year's ubiquitous cardigan. At Anna, 150 East Third Street, it may be last year's cardie (below). There, vintage sweaters are cleaned, cut down and resewn into the new shape, which is often worn over little T-shirts. ''Our customers say they are perfect for wearing on planes,'' said Carole Bayeux, a manager at Calypso St. Barths, 280 Mott Street, where the tiny knits sell for $60. And they keep on shrinking. Susan Cianciolos's current collection has unattached gray knit sweater sleeves, which are simply safety-pinned to the wearer's shirt. DANA DICKEY

title: The Nation: Quiz Show; The Case (if Any) Against the Prosecutor
description: AS the Judiciary Committee hearing wore on into the night last Thursday, Kenneth W. Starr came to resemble not so much a Congressional witness as a defendant in the dock. It was a display of how much President Clinton's supporters have succeeded in turning the issue before the nation from the impeachability of the President to the behavior of Mr. Starr, the independent counsel.

title: November 15-21; A Landmark's Second Chance
description: Twenty-three years ago it became one of the most infamous towers in the country when a student, Charles Whitman, barricaded himself on the observation deck of the 307-foot University of Texas clock tower and started spraying gunfire at passersby below. By the time police killed him an hour and a half later, 14 people were dead and 31 wounded.

title: Misstated Facts
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Defense Strategies Emerge In Louima Brutality Case
description: Lawyers for four police officers charged with brutalizing a Haitian immigrant in Brooklyn plan to challenge crucial aspects of the man's horrific account, and at least one lawyer is seeking information for use in impugning his honesty, court papers indicate.

title: The Debacle That Buried Washington; Long After the S.& L. Crisis, Courts Are Handing Taxpayers a New Bill
description: IT'S alive! The savings and loan debacle, which has cost taxpayers $165 billion, is about to become more expensive.

title: Bad Faith Is Charged as Talks With Mexican Rebels Open
description: There is no sign of peace between the Government and the Zapatista rebels in the southern state of Chiapas, and little reason to hope for a settlement any time soon.

title: Still No Sign of Those Darn Gazelles
description: Howard Patterson, who collected money from scores of car dealers after promising to deliver vehicles that in some cases didn't exist, was arrested on Nov. 9 in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on charges of writing bad checks to acquire vehicles. Mr. Patterson, whose activities were the subject of an article in The New York Times in September, was in an Acura NSX sports car with stolen license plates when the police, acting on a tip, stopped him, Detective Mike Reed said. They confiscated a loaded pistol and arrested two female companions after a scuffle.

title: Gangs a Source of Violence, Not Protection, Study Finds
description: A new Justice Department study challenges conventional wisdom about gangs, saying that those who join them for protection from neighborhood violence often suffer serious brutality in the assaults that are part of their initiation rites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEMEL, CLARA
description: SEMEL-Clara. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Martin and Barbara, Robert and Frances, and Frances and Ned Meyer. Cherished grandmother of Deborah, Richard, Rhonda, Scott, Michael, Charles and Rodney. Adored great grandmother of Lindsay, Brian Joseph, and Samuel. Fond sister of Thelma Sachs. Services today, 1:30 PM at ''Boulevard-Riverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Eastward, Ho! Westchester's Still a Pioneer of Cartoons
description: THIS is not the frog and the princess. This is a story about the mouse and the queen, and a host of other characters who emerged from a land called Westchester to cast a spell over generations of young people.

title: Gleaming, Dangling and Patriotic, CD's Soar as Car Decor
description: It's time to throw away those fuzzy dice, box the baby shoes and prune that evergreen air freshener. The stylish item to hang from one's rear-view mirror is the compact disk.

title: Higgledy-Piggledy Images Spring From Illustrator's Past
description: YUMI HEO remembers details of nature from her Korean childhood -- small things that now loom large in the children's books she writes and illustrates.

title: Needling Ex-Spouses
description: Acupuncture is so popular these days that the current Journal of the American Medical Association contains studies taking it seriously. People are going under the needles for everything from arthritis to nicotine withdrawal. But what if your most nagging pain is a former spouse? The Sirene Spa at 1044 Madison Avenue (79th Street) has that covered. When Sirene discovered that roughly 20 percent of its customers were going through divorces, it designed an acupuncture program. Dr. Helen Zhang, a physician who is Sirene's chief acupuncturist, says the treatments ($55 for a 45-minute session) focus on the kidney, liver, spleen and skin meridians for common complaints associated with divorce: irritability, anger, anxiety, depression, insomnia. Chip Brown, author of ''Afterward, You're a Genius,'' an investigation into alternative medicine due from Riverhead Books in January, said that while acupuncture can treat problems that often come up on an analyst's couch, divorce acupuncture cleverly packages a general tonic. ''Given the array of anxieties that this is supposed to treat, it sounds like it's just as good for marriage as divorce,'' he said. ''Or even a first date.'' ELLEN TIEN

title: Afloat in a Kerala Dreamscape
description: SOME of the most extraordinary meals we ate in a month's travel in India were cooked on two little kerosene burners in the minuscule galley of a houseboat. My husband, Phil, and I were spending a couple of days on the inland waterways of Kerala in southwestern India, the country's most tropical state. Before this trip, I never would have believed that such unusual and varied dishes could be prepared by one man working in a dollhouse-size kitchen. But Madhu's virtuoso cooking was only one of the many surprises about this cruise.

title: Saying Farewell to Fido
description: When Lorian Baker learned that her wire-haired terrier, Piccola, had inoperable cancer, she was devastated. ''I was so not ready for anything like this,'' said Ms. Baker, a technical writer who lives in Los Angeles. ''This dog was the center of my life.'' Ms. Baker, whose dog died on Sept. 28, said she was helped by logging onto the Web site of the Association for Pet Loss and Bereavement. ''Strangely enough it worked,'' she said. ''It was something to grip onto.''

title: The World: Pursuing Peace; Netanyahu and His Party Turn Away from 'Greater Israel'
description: FOR well over half a century, the political contours of the Zionist movement and Israel have been defined by a division between those who are prepared to share the biblical Jewish homeland with the Arabs, and those who claim it all.

title: Killing Shocks Russia
description: The killing of Galina V. Starovoitova, a defender of democratic reforms, unsettled her old allies, who claimed her as the latest victim of Russia's corrupt political climate. Article, page 9.

title: Personal and Political Fights for Stripers
description: My friends and I fish all summer in the shadow of Old Barney, the 140-year-old, 165-foot lighthouse that looms over Barnegat Bay at the northern tip of Long Beach Island, N.J. It's a rare day when we don't bring back something for lunch or dinner, be it fluke, blues or weakfish.

title: Yeltsin Tells Of His Anger Over Killing Of Lawmaker
description: The killing Friday night in St. Petersburg of Galina V. Starovoitova, a leading liberal politician and tireless defender of Russia's democratic reforms, shocked her old allies who claimed her as the latest victim of the country's lethally corrupt political climate.

title: China Sets the Stage For a Birthday Party
description: No, that big blue fence surrounding Tiananmen Square is not the latest Christo project. The vast square in the heart of Beijing, the scene of many of Communist China's greatest and worst moments and a popular starting point for both Chinese and foreign visitors to the city, will be closed until May for renovations. The brick surface, too familiar to many a tourist's sore feet, is being replaced with granite. And the street lights, decorative lights and public address system will all be improved.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARRATT, GRAHAM
description: GARRATT-Graham. On November 18, 1998. Devoted husband of Catherine. Visitation Sunday, 2-4 PM, Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave, NYC. Mass Monday, 10:30 AM, St. Ignatius Church, Manhattan.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Giving Up America

title: Athletic Conference Bars Aluminum Bats
description: Baseball teams at New Jersey's 10 state colleges and universities became the first in the nation to switch from aluminum to wooden bats to protect players from fast-flying balls.

title: Just a Bump In Capitalism's Long Road
description: THIS does not seem to be free enterprise's finest hour.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Four Humorists on Writing

title: Clear Cut
description: Today's crystal has all the elegance of old glass, but none of the froufrou.

title: Government of, By and for The Comfortable
description: We are witnessing not the rise but rather the fall of the middle class in American politics. The evidence is everywhere, from the distribution of wealth to the decline of the quality of health-care service, associated with the advent of managed care. Once-accessible resorts like Aspen are now priced out of reach of the middle class. Campaign-finance reform seems to be in a perpetual holding pattern, while campaign donations are dominated by an ever smaller and wealthier group.

title: How Americans See Themselves
description: Not even one Jewish family represented in ''a nation's studio portrait.'' One can only surmise that Jews are so well ''therapized'' these days that we feel no need to be photographically portrayed as ''faux'' ideal family units. What a relief.

title: The Outsiders
description: It can be a cold, cruel world without a princess coat to keep you warm.

title: 'Who, Me, Officer? Oh, No, I Never Speed. No, Sir.'
description: IT is 2:30 in the afternoon, Friday the 13th of November, and State Police Trooper First Class Mario Caruso is standing by his cruiser parked just off Interstate 95 in Westbrook and aiming a laser speed detector at cars and trucks as they come into range in the southbound lanes.

title: Greenbelt Fans Want Routes Off the Maps
description: A coalition of nine environmental and civic groups on Staten Island is mounting a campaign to persuade Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Giuliani to undo the long-planned but largely unbuilt Richmond and Willowbrook Parkways. If fully built, the roads would crisscross the Greenbelt, a 2,500-acre city park of woodland and serpentine hills in the middle of the borough.

title: Food; Fowl Play
description: Turkey advocates went to federal court yesterday, seeking to enjoin the Office of Meaningful and Appropriate Rituals from paying subsidies to quail farmers. The payments, discovered in a secret memorandum leaked to Pullet News, touched off a firestorm of protest in Washington last week. Not since the writer Calvin Trillin proposed that spaghetti carbonara replace turkey as the official Thanksgiving dish has OMAR been at the center of such a holiday scandal.

title: Man Dies Leaping From Fire and 2 Are Injured
description: A Brooklyn man died early yesterday after he and his wife jumped from a second-floor window while trying to escape a fire raging in their Flatbush apartment.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUBY, DR. ARTHUR
description: RUBY-Dr. Arthur. Memorial service for Dr. Arthur Ruby, Sunday, December 6, 12 Noon, 550 1st Avenue, Farkas Auditorium, NYU School of Medicine. Contributions may be made to the Saul J. Farber Scholarship Fund. Eleanor Ruby

title: Government of, By and for The Comfortable
description: I felt chastised after reading Nicholas Lemann's article, even though there is plenty I care about, passionately. I think most of us understand our reciprocal obligations quite well.

title: Heat Over Billboards Rises
description: As billboards proliferate in Manhattan, opponents are striking back against the signs, which they say are more suited to Route 66 than West Broadway.

title: Another Route to a Badge Via the Police Academy
description: It's 7:30 A.M. on an overcast November day and the recruits here at Union County's John H. Stamler Police Academy have already been drilling for two hours, a typical morning in the 22-week regime of physical and classroom training required before they write their first speeding tickets, investigate burglaries or do any other police work.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARTER, DAVID
description: CARTER-David. Five years in heaven and not one day passes without us thinking of you. Your memory enlightens us, inspires us, makes us laugh and saddens us with remembrance that we can't just call you up or go over to see you. Thanks for all your help this year and all good things that happen to us and the kids are forever dedicated to your memory. You're in my heart and you're in my soul. Love, Donny & Nancy

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Diane A Signature Life. By Diane Von Furstenberg with Linda Bird Francke. Simon & Schuster, $25.

title: Ralph Wickiser, 88, Painter and Professor
description: Ralph L. Wickiser, a painter and teacher who founded the fine arts graduate program at the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, died on Oct. 27 in a nursing home in Riverhead, N.Y. He was 88.

title: GO BAG
description: In rural America, a tiny brown paper sack is the au courant container for a cold can of beer consumed vehicularly. If such a concept can be upscaled, Weekend 2000, an Austin, Tex.-based manufacturer, has done it, taking the traditional sippin' sack, lining it with insulation, imprinting it with a logo and marketing it as the Sip Sac. The company won notice a few years back for the Candom, a beverage cozy that rolls onto a can like . . . well, like a condom. That caused some problems. ''The Candom was too risque for the Bible Belt,'' says Blake Snow, Weekend 2000's sales manager. ''But no one can refuse the Sip Sac.''

title: New Chef but Same Coziness in Yorktown
description: A VISIT to Peter Pratt's is particularly pleasant in solstitial months. On a long summer evening, the terrace with its rolling lawn and bosky prospect is a delight. On a frosty winter's night, the cellar Tack Room, with its hand-hewed timbers (the cellar dates to 1781), low ceilings and blazing hearth especially, makes a cozy retreat.

title: In Canada, One Province Stands Alone Vs. Tobacco
description: In the days since British Columbia became the first Canadian province to file a lawsuit to recover medical costs from tobacco companies, Penny Priddy, the province's health minister, has been traveling across Canada looking for allies.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SOLOMON, SHIRLEY L.
description: SOLOMON-Shirley L. 3/31/46-11/22/93. You are missed more than words can express. You are in my prayers every day. May God bless you forever. Ver

title: Lives; The Art Critic
description: I admit I spend most of my day looking out my window. I look down at the intersection where Christopher and Ninth Streets meet Sixth and Greenwich Avenues. I watch people crisscrossing all day, men selling books, an occasional bride and groom in the garden of the Jefferson Market Library. And at the center, the Ruth Wittenberg Triangle, named for the ''ardent Greenwich Villager'' and ''courageous leader.'' Worlds converge there. It seems as powerful as a great pyramid. Nothing can disturb its controlled chaos.

title: The Fresh Prince
description: The royal train, sleek and black with pencil-thin red trimming, is hurtling toward Newcastle, and inside one of the armored middle cars, Charles, the Prince of Wales, is taking his breakfast. He's dressed down in an open-collar white-and-burgundy striped shirt, blue cardigan and khaki trousers, and as I enter the cabin, his look of welcome is mixed with one of concern. ''I do hope you managed to get some sleep,'' he says, motioning me to sit across from him. Gales and lashing rain had rolled in from the North Sea as we made our midnight departure from Perth, and the heir to the throne seems to be apologizing for turbulence in the realm. ''Ghastly night,'' he says.

title: A Tuna Boat Whose Catch Is for Studying, Not Eating
description: Tucked among the pleasure boats and fishing boats at the Gardner's Basin marina in Atlantic City is a sporty looking white vessel subtly marked with the New Jersey State Aquarium emblem. It is the Pelagica, which means open ocean.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRATT, C.
description: FRATT-C. K. Poe. November 22, 1988. Ten years already. Your legacy continues. Missed by your children and grandchildren.

title: Davies Struggles as Mallon Narrows the Gap to 2 Strokes
description: When she teed off today, Meg Mallon was 10 strokes off the lead. When the day ended, Mallon was in contention.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FELDMAN, HENRY, KISLEV
description: FELDMAN-Henry, Kislev 19. Beloved. Still missed-still loved. Toujours dans nos coeurs. Your wife Helen and son Leonard.

title: Reins on Executive Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Brandi Shapiro, Adam Goldenberg
description: Brandi Michelle Shapiro, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gary E. Shapiro of Woodbury, N.Y., was married last evening to Adam Scott Goldenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Goldenberg of Long Beach, N.Y. Rabbi Charles Klein officiated at the Roosevelt Hotel in New York.

title: Image That's Hard to Shake
description: Since the murder last year of Jonathan M. Levin, a teacher at William H. Taft High School and the son of Time Warner's chairman, the company and its employees have donated more than $800,000 to the school for a new athletic field, a computer networking class and a media career training lab. On Nov. 13, the state removed Taft from its list of failing schools.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/BMW 328i; The Benchmark, Now Rebuilt
description: ONE is always anxious when a dear friend has major surgery. Did the doctors make the correct diagnosis? What if the scalpel slips? After recuperation, will the patient have the same old zest, or will the cure prove worse than any minor ailments it was supposed to remedy?

title: The Indignation and Naturalization Disservice
description: I SET my alarm for 4:15 A.M. I had to be at the Peter Rodino Federal Building in Newark well before dawn.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CONHEIM, SUE
description: CONHEIM-Sue. November 19th, 1950. In ever loving memory. Daughter, Marilyn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAIN, GEORGE H.
description: BAIN-George H. Beloved husband of Gladys. Loving and endeared father of Constance and Fabienne. Proud father-in-law of Michael H. Moskow. Cherished, devoted grandfather of Robert (Holly), Eliot (Veronica), and Lisa. Caring uncle, loyal friend, a true gentleman for all seasons. His goodness lives after him and will be remembered by those whose lives he touched. Services Monday November 23, 11:30 a.m., Riverside Memorial Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN RIPER, PETER
description: VAN RIPER-Peter. On November 18, 1998. Artist/Musician. Loving partner to Dina Helal. Dear collaborator to Xenia Balcells and Simone Forti. Brother to Hendrieka Van Riper and uncle to Lindsay. Reposing at The Evergreen Funeral Home Inc., 131 Nassau Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11222 on Sunday, November 22 from 2-5pm and from 7-9:30pm. Cremation on Monday, November 23, Fresh Pond Crematory.

title: Co-ops That Don't Own Their Land
description: PEOPLE who invest in real estate typically do so secure in the knowledge that their little patch of land can be theirs -- or their heirs' -- forever.

title: Journals Solve a School Mystery
description: As the archivist for Public School 158's Parent Association, Laurie Mulligan took on the task of cleaning out an old storage room in the school's basement in January. Ms. Mulligan wasn't sure what this had to do with archives, until she found a yellowed manila folder holding two journals. On the first page of one, in fine calligraphy, was written March 4, 1895.

title: BASKETBALL: Minister Without Portfolio; As the Bulls Turn, the New Man Works and Waits
description: Some 35 cardboard boxes, many already sagging under their own weight, are piled high against a wall outside the coach's office on the second floor of the Berto Center, the Chicago Bulls' training facility. They have occupied that spot for nearly four months, and belong to a man who is, more or less, neither here nor there. He is Tim Floyd, Basketball's Man Without a Definite Capacity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEPSON, EMIL
description: LEEPSON-Emil. Beloved husband of Lenore and the late Betty. Father to Peter Leepson. Stepfather to Lorna Braunschweiger and Susan Kooper. Grandfather to Jonathan, David, Brian and Jennifer Leepson, Michael and Holly Sosnowitz, Jay and Keith Kooper, and Julie, Matthew and Dana Braunschweiger. Brother to Sally Sherman and the late George and Arthur. Died on Friday, November 20. He was 91 years old. Born to Morris and Pauline Leepson on July 8, 1907. Emil Leepson graduated from Brooklyn Law School and began practicing real estate law in 1928. His last position was of Counsel at Warshaw, Burstein, Cohen, Schlesinger and Kuh in Manhattan. He was past President of The National Realty Club and active with the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale, NY. Funeral services for Emil Leepson will be held today at 12:30 PM at Riverside Memorial, 76th and Amsterdam. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Jewish Home for the Elderly in Fairfield, CT, 175 Jefferson St., Fairfield, CT 06430, to establish the Emil Leepson Memorial Music Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MILLIKEN, MINOT K.
description: MILLIKEN-Minot K. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, December 2nd, 11am at St. Thomas Church, 5th Avenue & West 53 St. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to The Boys' Club of New York, 287 East 10 St., NY NY 10009

title: Financial Engineering 1.0
description: The wondrous innovations of America's technology companies make them the envy of the world. But for some of the biggest names in technology, one of the most profitable inventions is not about computer hardware, software or microchips. It's about finance, and it is generating hundreds of millions of dollars -- tax-free -- a year.

title: Not Paradise to Everyone
description: When the Paradise Motel started going up on Jamaica Avenue last month, parents who drop their children off at two nearby day-care centers started worrying that it would be a hot-sheets place with rooms rented by the hour.

title: Portrait of Two Museums
description: INDIA, vast in size and rich in culture, is a country full of museums. Some are tiny, dusty rooms near an archeological site; others are imposing buildings. As for their contents, they too vary, from a few broken pieces of stone sculpture to the bronze masterpieces found in the small southern Indian town of Thanjavur. Some museums are particularly strong in one subject -- Mughal miniatures in Bombay, for instance, or Gupta sculpture in Sarnath. And then there are two long-established museums whose collections are both rich and varied enough to make them worth a lengthy visit: the Indian Museum in Calcutta and the Government Museum in Madras.

title: A Sweep of Stocks At Long-Term Capital
description: Long-Term Capital Management L.P. reported that its stock portfolio was worth just $6.9 million at the end of September -- a drop of almost 99 percent from the value reported to Federal regulators three months earlier.

title: Kimberly Saul and Aaron Tighe
description: Kimberly Ellen Saul, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew M. Saul of Bedford, N.Y., is to be married today to Aaron Mathieson Tighe, the son of Mary Ann Tighe and stepson of Dr. David A. Hidalgo of New York. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein is to officiate at the Georgian Suite in New York.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Stillest Day

title: Playing the Classics With the Dash Of the Contemporary
description: ARTICLES on Peter Serkin often mention his satisfying life, now that he is acknowledged as a pianist unsurpassed in the wide-ranging repertory he embraces and is happily married, with a houseful of children.

title: The Men Who Beat Hitler
description: THE VICTORS

title: Is $400,000 Too Much To Pay for Paradise?
description: Mitchell C. Hochberg's ''new urban'' community, Belle Fair, in Rye Brook [''New Housing Based on a Colonial Tradition,'' Oct. 25] does indeed sound close to perfect with its village green, pedestrian friendliness and common areas to foster human interaction.

title: SOAPBOX; A Mind Is a Terrible Thing to Baste
description: I HAVE a confession to make: I am afraid of turkeys.

title: From Bach to 'Butterfly,' A Very Full Day
description: TODAY may be the busiest concert day of the year. ''Beauty and the Beast,'' the classic tale retold with classical music and puppets as well, is an entertainment suitable for children at 1, 3 and 5 P.M. this afternoon at Jorgensen Auditorium in Storrs.

title: For Art and for Life
Culture Zone; Sorority Sisters
description: I'm glad I never met Julia Margaret Cameron. She seems to have been the sort of woman who craved the company of powerful men but had little use for women. She spoke of her male friends as if they were gods; her art was her ticket into their kingdom. Cameron, one of the leading portrait photographers of 19th-century England, captured the illustrious figures of her time -- Darwin, Longfellow and Tennyson among them. And which women did she photograph? Mainly the maids who dusted her curtains and served her tea.

title: Cooper Able to Wrest a Rare Game Ball Away From Michigan
description: Many of the 94,339 fans at Ohio Stadium could not wait for today's game to end. With 30 seconds remaining and the Buckeyes kneeling their way to victory, they stormed the field.

title: In Catskills, Resort's Death Darkens the View
description: It wasn't supposed to end this way. Not this personally. Not this jarringly.

title: Apartment Hunt Isn't That Hard; Lots of Good Places, If You Leave Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: How Americans See Themselves
description: Are we in such a feel-good era that we want to see nothing but sunny scenes? In this fantasy world, farmers are scrubbed clean, the 1950's nuclear family prevails and pets stand proud. Conspicuous wealth, whether real or make-believe, is featured in many of the photos, and the attempts to showcase ethnic diversity only add to the artificiality. I find it hard to believe that this is the way all of America wants itself to be seen.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 1 about sexual harassment in Japan referred incorrectly to an association whose official commented on the situation. Nikkeiren, the Japan Federation of Employers' Associations, is a business association, not a labor union.

title: Alternatives Offered To Trapping Animals
description: We condemn the actions of James Dreisacker, the trapper who asphyxiated one coyote in New Rochelle and left another one running loose with a leg-hold trap dangling from its leg. (''Growing Numbers of Coyotes Lead to Traps and Fear for Pets,'' Oct. 11.) The Fund for Animals offered to pay for the remaining coyote to be humanely captured (by another company) and treated by a local veterinarian, but the city of New Rochelle refused to terminate Mr. Dreisacker.

title: A Fidelity Bet on Intel Has Found a Huge Payoff
description: Who's been making a killing in the Intel Corporation's stock as it has run up over 30 percent since the end of third quarter? The mutual fund giant Fidelity Investments, which spent much of the last four months building on its already substantial Intel position.

title: THEATER; Making Sex In Schnitzler Less Cynical
description: ANYONE who looks closely at the posters outside the theater for ''The Blue Room'' will find themselves still uncertain as to whether they are about to see an old play by Arthur Schnitzler or a new one by David Hare.

title: For the Hardy: Arctic And Antarctic Tours
description: Trips to either the bottom or the top of the globe will be available through August. Marine Expeditions of Toronto will conduct 16 Antarctic expeditions lasting 13 to 24 days each from November to March, and Quark Expeditions of Darien, Conn., will circumnavigate the Arctic Ocean beginning July 1.

title: No More Loitering At the Palazzo Vecchio
description: The City of Florence has begun enforcing an old ordinance that bans sitting, eating and drinking on the steps of the Palazzo Vecchio. For a few months, traffic police and volunteers have been patrolling the steps to enforce the law, politely asking tourists to move along.

title: Cory Russell, Kevin Leahy
description: Cory Catherine Russell, a daughter of Susan R. Marcus of Redding, Conn., and Dr. Lewis F. Russell Jr. of San Antonio, was married yesterday to Kevin Lawrence Leahy, a son of Maureen Leahy of Lakewood, N.J., and Jack Leahy of Spring Lake Heights, N.J. The Rev. Timothy Franklin Tate, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony in the chapel at the Southwest Craft Center in San Antonio.

title: Therapy For the Family Business
description: AFTER 25 years of running their own business, Jack and Alyce Schmidt had a vision: When they retired, their three children would take over and work together happily, each getting equal pay.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / College Point, Queens; Small Enclave Feels Pressures of the City
description: THERE is always a jetliner somewhere on the horizon of College Point, a low-rise, blue-collar Queens outpost on Flushing Bay where maintaining small-town virtues rooted in the 19th century is a struggle.

title: Apartment Hunt Isn't That Hard; At Kingsbridge Armory City Demolishes by Neglect
description: To the Editor:

title: When Big Wheels Keep On Turning
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharing the World of Kipling on Stage
description: IN an age of computers and video games, students at Korn Elementary School in Durham are reading stories written by Rudyard Kipling.

title: INVESTING WITH: Robert H. Perkins; Berger Small Cap Value Fund
description: WITH his professorial rumpled suits and gray, tousled hair, Robert H. Perkins, 58, looks every bit the parsimonious value player. And Mr. Perkins, the manager of the Berger Small Cap Value fund, has had plenty of time to hone his image: He has been trolling the markets for 30 years.

title: Columbia's Long Drives End in Frustration
description: Paul Roland, the Columbia linebacker, knelt at the 42-yard line and rested his chin in one hand. Time had expired. The teams had shaken hands after a brief shoving match. And most of the 4,600 fans had filed out of Wien Stadium, eager for shelter from the raw afternoon.

title: The View From/St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center, Hartford; How Art, and an Artist, Join in the Healing Process
description: ONCE upon a time, and not too long ago a time, St. Francis Hospital in Hartford was a prototype of the Catholic hospital of the Northeast -- somber and quiet, with paintings of saints here and there, and sisters in black habits passing silently through the corridors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTLER, CHRISTOPHER BLAIR
description: BUTLER-Christopher Blair. Age 47, on November 21, 1998. Executive with Mobil Oil Corporation. Beloved son of W. Jack and Patricia Butler, father of Ross, and brother of Peter Butler. Memorial service to be announced. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of one's choice.

title: Raising the Stakes On the Waterfront
description: THE megaships are coming. But where will they dock?

title: TURKEY TOWN
description: * Per capita, Barron, Wisc. -- home of the Turkey Store turkey-processing company -- may have the densest concentration of turkey workers in the United States. Local population: 3,174. Turkey Store employees: 2,150. * Positions on the ''evisceration team'' start at $7.25 an hour, 401k included. * Among the devices in use: the automatic scalder, the bird washer and the eerily named ''automated lunger.'' * Oddly, the Turkey Store does not produce Thanksgiving turkeys. It specializes in year-round ''value-added'' products like Italian (turkey) sausage links. * One challenge for the future: capturing the lucrative Chinese market for chicken feet. ''Turkey feet don't cut it there because they're larger, and in Chinese the translation of turkey is 'fire chicken,''' says Gregg Gleichert, executive vice president of the company. ''But we haven't given up.''

title: PULSE; TO DIAL FOR
description: Droog: (800) 443-7664 or www.droog.com

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIESNER, ERIC PAUL
description: WIESNER-Eric Paul. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Eric Paul Wiesner, associated with The Times from 1961, until retiring in 1990.

title: A Plum Assignment For a Late Bloomer
description: GIUSEPPE DI STEFANO, the longtime partner of Maria Callas, was in a rage. On a visit to Buenos Aires in 1994, he had encountered a very fine but green tenor by the name of Marcelo Alvarez.

title: Backtalk; A Star Recalls His Role in a 30-Year-Old Drama
description: Twenty-five years before Tommy Lee Jones won the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor for his role in ''The Fugitive,'' he was a senior offensive guard on the Harvard football team that was undefeated entering its final game, a Nov. 23, 1968, matchup against Yale, which was also 8-0. Harvard was paced by the backfield of Ray Hornblower and Vic Gatto, but both played hurt during the critical game. The highly regarded quarterback Brian Dowling and Calvin Hill, the future Dallas Cowboys running back, led Yale.

title: November 15-21; The Fed Decides To Take No Chances
description: The stock market has rebounded in the last few months, and the global financial crisis seems to have eased. But the Federal Reserve remained sufficiently concerned about the economic outlook for the United States that it cut interest rates for the third time in two months.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE LONG-WINDED LADY Notes From The New Yorker. By Maeve Brennan. Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, paper, $13.

title: She's No Guru
description: To the Editor:

title: Camden, a Troubled City at War With Itself
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: A Newly Confident White House Is Seeking Ways to Exit the Impeachment Process
description: A senior White House official, surveying the events of the past week, sighed in relief and quoted Churchill on his experience in the Boer War: ''Nothing in life is so exhilarating as to be shot at without result.''

title: Injured Birds Hook Fishing In a Conflict
description: In Central Park, one of the city's only inland fishing spots and a way station for more than 170 species of migrating birds, bird watchers have tangled with anglers in a dispute over lost hooks, stray lines and abandoned sinkers that have killed birds. Some birders want fishing banned, but anglers argue that a prohibition wouldn't solve the real problem for birds, which they say is litter.

title: Washington and Baghdad Agree on One Point: Sanctions Hurt
description: Even as they trade charges of duplicity and, yet again, brace for a possible military showdown, Bill Clinton and Saddam Hussein can agree on this much: The economic sanctions imposed on Iraq more than eight years ago, which Iraq has cited as the cause of the latest crisis, have devastated its economy and its people.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Family Is Family, at First and at Last
description: Michael Lowenthal's deeply felt first novel, THE SAME EMBRACE (Dutton, $23.95), portrays the conflict between 24-year-old twin brothers whose divergent passions threaten to separate them forever. Jacob Rosenbaum is a gay activist, yet he is more successful in accepting his sexuality than in sustaining intimate relationships. In contrast, his brother, Jonathan, has embraced the strictures of Orthodox Judaism at a yeshiva in Israel. Although Jonathan expresses disgusted hostility when confronted with his brother's life as a gay man, Jacob still cares for him and mourns the loss of the closeness they once had as children. Reconciliation becomes possible only when their beloved grandmother falls into a coma after a severe stroke, precipitating a family crisis and exposing secrets that have shaped the lives of all her loved ones ever since she and her husband fled the Holocaust for America. As he blends the past and the present, Lowenthal uses luminous language that often imbues ordinary gestures and events with deeper meaning. ''The Same Embrace'' is an eloquent exploration of the nature of faith, the consequences of judgment and the stubborn endurance of family ties. Linda Barrett Osborne

title: Waste Not: Recycled Fur
description: LAST year, Angela Voulangas found the mink cape she had inherited from her grandmother years ago. Actually, it was more of a capelet, and Ms. Voulangas, a 33-year-old graphic designer, had no idea what to do with it. ''Where am I going to wear a capelet?'' she asked. The 40-year-old mink seemed ''too incongruous with my life,'' she added. And yet, it also seemed like ''exciting raw material.'' She decided to dye it blue and burgundy, and cut it up into two collars and a bag. That way, she said, ''I don't feel I went out and clubbed a baby seal.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE BEATLES

title: Comeback Time For Latin America?
description: BATTERED by the panic that swept emerging markets in the wake of Asia's financial crisis and Russia's default, Latin America is a region that seems more sinned against than sinning.

title: More Exploitation
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Finding Life in the Lives of Wild Creatures, and Sharing It
description: IT was no ordinary garden party. The fragrance of South African-style barbecue wafted through the chilly air of a New Canaan backyard while a group of children stared pie-eyed at the gambols of leopard and lion cubs.

title: There She Is, and Never Mind the Wrinkles
description: MOST of them auditioned on a whim. To highlight a lifetime of accomplishments, add another notch to their resumes or just to look their crow's feet in the eye and laugh, spicing up their golden years. Though they had reached the age of elegance, the women gathered in Ethel Bennett's Amityville living room on a recent afternoon were, after all, just children at heart. Children with wrinkles.

title: Job Crunch Spurs Child-Care Benefits
description: ON a crisp Wednesday afternoon recently, Rob Eifert of Bay Shore and his 22-month-old son, Jacob, stood on the beach at Cold Spring Harbor, skipping rocks into the sailboat-lined water. They walked into the park-like grounds of Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory that overlook the harbor and gazed into goldfish ponds scattered amidst the lush greenery.

title: Jonathan Cohen and Allison Morrow
description: Allison Barbara Morrow and Jonathan Little Cohen were married yesterday in Manhattan. The Rev. John Brown Macnab performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: How Not to Conduct an Impeachment Hearing; Starr Wins!
description: To the Editor:

title: The World; Tongue-Lashings And Backlashes
description: THIS city has always kept an unwritten list of foreign leaders dictators, unfriendly authoritarians and consistently annoying allies -- who it thinks can make an enormous contribution to peace, security or America's agenda by taking early retirement, at a minimum. In the 1950's, the leftist leaders of Iran and Guatamala made the Top 10, in the '60's it was populated by Diem and Sukarno and other Southeast Asians. President Nixon and his advisers infamously agreed at a secret meeting in the '70's that the best way to deal with the Government of Salvador Allende Gossens in Chile was to ''make the economy scream.''

title: The Man That Got Away
description: Escapism

title: Born of Illness, a Grand Metamorphosis
description: THE exhibition of paintings and works on paper by Kendall Shaw at the Gallery of South Orange affords a palpable sensation of a triumphant fresh start. Of course, it's not necessary to know elements of Mr. Shaw's life story to appreciate his work, but they help explain why it acquired extra verve and dimension in recent years. In the late 1980's and the early 90's Mr. Shaw battled a rare form of hepatitis that threatened his life. Because he was forced to find treatment on his own, said Judy Wukitsch, the gallery's assistant director, his painting career was halted in those years.

title: Beset at Home, Japanese Banks Abandon American Footholds
description: The giant Japanese banks, whose forays into the United States struck fear into American bankers' hearts not so long ago, have been brought so low by crushing overhangs of bad loans at home that they are selling off American operations at a rate approaching desperation. Executives close to the talks said Sanwa Bank was about to sell its American lending unit to Fleet Financial Group for $700 million, a third of the original asking price. Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi said a big chunk of its majority shareholding in Unionbancal, a California bank holding company, would go on the block, though the Japanese bank would retain a controlling stake. Fuji Bank and Sumitomo Bank have also unloaded United States operations this year.

title: Sports of the Times; Outfielder, Then College Valedictorian
description: HE was known as Tito Landrum back in the 80's. He stood in against Nolan Ryan and Doc Gooden when their fastballs buzzed under his chin, but he never knew fear until he sat in a classroom at New York University.

title: Survival in the South Atlantic, Thanks to Boston E-mail
description: It was not the first time in the history of solo yacht racing that computer technology saved the life of a sailor in distress. But E-mail assistance provided recently by a physician in Boston reached out as never before to an ailing yachtsman at sea.

title: How Not to Conduct an Impeachment Hearing; It Was an Ugly Job
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rangers' Enigmatic Aleksei Kovalev Is Soaring to New Altitudes
description: Now that Aleksei Kovalev is flying airplanes in his spare time, he is approaching literally what his hockey style has always suggested in the figurative sense: that he is a space cadet, a daredevil Russian cosmonaut, drafted on the first round from Dynamo Moscow in June 1991.

title: Eyes Closed, Point Anywhere on the Menu
description: FOLLOWING the comings and goings of chefs can be a distracting pastime. But Christian Bertrand -- formerly of Lutece (in Manhattan), Bertrand (Greenwich) and Stonehenge (Ridgefield) -- is one chef whose peregrinations are definitely worth tracking.

title: NATIONAL / INTERNATIONAL ARTS GUIDE
description: Chicago

title: Kanell's Demotion Provides Cherry an Opportunity
description: Mike Cherry made news this past week by not doing a thing.

title: Off the Slopes of Xerox, And Seeking New Mountains
description: For someone facing the great unknown, A. Barry Rand sounds awfully upbeat. He and Donna, his wife of eight years, have rarely taken vacations, almost never with their two children, and he intends to rectify that. ''We'll go golfing, we'll go skiing, we'll travel to new places,'' he said. Mr. Rand, 54, announced this month that he was leaving the Xerox Corporation, where he was a front-runner to succeed Paul A. Allaire as chief executive until the company hired G. Richard Thoman from I.B.M. last year and made him the heir apparent. So Mr. Rand, Xerox's highest-ranking black executive, quit to look for a job as chief at another Fortune 500 company. He has no idea whether his race will help or hinder his search. ''It's like an election,'' he said. ''Until the votes are in, you don't know whether your traits are perceived as advantages or disadvantages.''

title: Pollin's Capitalism
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: November 15-21; For U.N. Inspectors, It's Back to Iraq
description: International arms inspectors went back to work in Iraq, at least to restart a system interrupted by Iraqi bans and the withdrawal of monitors in advance of expected American bombing. Short-notice inspections of new sites awaited the formation of expert teams from around the world.

title: Water Plan Is Under Fire
description: A coalition of environmental groups has criticized a preliminary plan issued last week by the state Department of Environmental Protection to protect the state's drinking water supply from pollution, saying it is little more than an inadequate compilation of old data.

title: Cablevision Lines Up To Be Sports Leader
description: Adding the Yankees to its ownership of the Knicks and Rangers would further escalate Cablevision Systems' growth into one of the most powerful forces in sports and would expand the Woodbury, N.Y.-based company's entertainment diversification.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAFERSTEIN, LESLIE J.
description: SAFERSTEIN-Leslie J. 1933-November 22, 1985. You are missed by all who love you. Sheila, Paul, Mother, family and friends

title: The Left Bank
description: CENTRAL SQUARE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTER, JEANNE N.
description: CARTER-Jeanne N. of Lloyd Harbor on November 18,1998. Beloved mother of Nancy Farrell and Susan Thompson. Cherished sister of Robert Nehrbas. Loving grandmother of 4. Memorial service 11 am Wed. November 25, 1998 at the Old First Presbyterian Church, 125 Main St, Huntington. For information A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home, Inc. Donations may be made to Charity of your choice.

title: To Some, Food Store Cornucopia Looks Like a Glut
description: Many people would consider a new grocery store that stays open around the clock to be a neighborhood amenity. But some residents think the Food Emporium that is scheduled to open next month in the Ansonia building, at Broadway and 74th Street, might be more of a nuisance.

title: Row, Row, Row
description: MIND OVER WATER Lessons on Life From the Art of Rowing. By Craig Lambert. 184 pp. Boston: A Marc Jaffe Book/ Houghton Mifflin Company. $22.

title: Spreading the Credit For Breast Cancer Project
description: I was saddened to read that Nancy Blakeman felt that she had no place to turn when she was diagnosed with breast cancer in 1996 [''Transformed by Passion and Politics, Breast Cancer Movement Gains Power,'' Nov. 8]. How I wish she would have called me or any of the 95 other volunteers at the Adelphi New York State Breast Cancer Hotline and Support Program, right here in Garden City (800-877-8077).

title: Stacey Cohen, Stuart Meissner
description: Dr. Stacey Beth Cohen, a psychologist, and Stuart David Meissner, an assistant New York State attorney general, were married last evening by Rabbi Kenneth Hain at Temple Israel in Lawrence, N.Y.

title: Global Trend Seen in German Bank Deal
description: As the board of the Bankers Trust Corporation meets today to vote on the sale of the bank to Deutsche Bank A.G. of Germany for about $9 billion, Wall Street is rife with speculation about whether a new round of megamergers is at hand.

title: Apartment Hunt Isn't That Hard; A Park Slope Eyesore Is Not the Only One
description: To the Editor:

title: Government of, By and for The Comfortable
description: Nicholas Lemann paints a picture of a middle-class-dominated electorate that has turned its back on broad national interests, including the needs of the poor (Nov. 1). It is a reasonably accurate picture. But so is an alternative view that past failures of Government programs, like the War on Poverty, have produced justifiable skepticism.

title: In a Cutting Garden, Snip a Little, Leave a Lot
description: THERE is something compelling about the notion of a cutting garden, conjuring visions of a figure moving gracefully down large pathways of flowers, bending here and there to snip a bloom for the willow basket on an arm, gathering flowers to fill the house with thoughtfully arranged bouquets. Unfortunately, most people these days have neither the space for such a garden nor the time to maintain it.

title: Without Coach, King Wins Title Again
description: On the field, the players from the Martin Luther King Jr. High School soccer team were celebrating yesterday, jumping about and hugging one another, with one of the players, Oral Bullen, spinning past the pile in a combination of somersaults and cartwheels.

title: Unpleasantville
description: Billy Dead

title: Cozying Up to a Sailing Behemoth
description: I HAD never been on a cruise, so the idea of sailing the Caribbean on the largest passenger ship in the world, the new 109,000-ton Grand Princess, seemed irresistible. My husband, considerably less enchanted, voted to stay home. ''Wasn't Titanic once the largest passenger ship in the world?'' he said.

title: Habitats / 49 East 12th Street; Expanding a Triplex, Step by Step by Step
description: ON top of their Greenwich Village apartment building, Lily and Jack Momeyer have their version of a suburban backyard. They can dribble a basketball in a wide arc and shoot toward the sky into a regulation-size hoop. Or they can kick around a soccer ball, so long as they don't do it so powerfully that the ball soars over the top of their protective netting and lands on some hapless passer-by six floors below.

title: 'SoHo, TriBeCa And Now Dumbo'
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A credit was omitted last Sunday with a photograph of Jackson Pollock painting on glass in November 1950. It should have said $; 1998 The Museum of Modern Art and Hans Namuth Ltd.

title: How Not to Conduct an Impeachment Hearing; Not a Performance
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERSTEIN, ANNA (NEE RICHMAN
description: KERSTEIN-Anna (nee Richman). In Southbury, CT. on November 19, 1998. Beloved and devoted wife of Charles L. Kerstein. Beloved sister of Norma Golumbic of Bethesda, MD. Private services. Memorial contributions to the Brookyn College Foundation, Inc., 2900 Bedford Ave, Bklyn, N.Y. 11210.

title: A Liquid Corsage
description: On Thanksgiving, Simi's winning '97 pink-coral California rose of cabernet sauvignon can give the table a Martha Stewart-like flair and whet the appetites of white-meat fans. Chilled 15 minutes, this seriously frivolous, tangy, featherweight dry wine becomes a liquid corsage. At $9, it's a fine buy at Beekman Liquors, 500 Lexington Avenue (47th Street).

title: PULSE; Tom Tofu Takes Off
description: While carnivores decide between white and dark meat on Thursday, many vegetarians have little to be thankful for. But there's a protein alternative, Tofurky, made of tofu, wheat gluten and turkey flavorings and sold at health food stores. For $24.99, a box comes with a Tofurky roast stuffed with rice and bread crumbs, four tempeh drumsticks (left), a sack of golden mushroom gravy and a plea to join a save-a-turkey program. Seth Tibit, co-founder of Turtle Island Foods, which makes Tofurky, said sales have more than tripled every year since the vegan meal hit the market in 1995. In an informal test feast, the roast was basted, as directed, in orange juice, soy sauce and brown sugar. Stephanie Beldotti, a graduate student at New York University and a vegetarian, liked the drumsticks because they tasted like veggieburgers but complained that the Tofurky ''breast'' tasted like rubberized fat. Liz Keen, an interior designer and meat lover, retreated to the kitchen to make pancakes. LOLA OGUNNAIKE

title: November 15-21; Meanwhile, Out West, Microsoft Loses a Round
description: For Microsoft, the main event is its antitrust showdown with the Justice Department in Washington, but that isn't the only stage on which allegations that it engaged in anticompetitive practices are being heard. The company suffered a stinging legal setback in Silicon Valley when a Federal judge in San Jose told the computer software giant it could no longer ship Internet software that violated its contract with a rival, Sun Microsystems. The judge gave Microsoft 90 days to modify its products.

title: Protection for Abortion Clinics
description: Gov. George Pataki of New York took an important stand by proposing new state legislation to protect women and doctors against violence at abortion clinics. The Democratic-controlled State Assembly has passed similar legislation every year since 1993, but it has repeatedly died in the Republican-controlled Senate. The Governor has voiced support for such legislation in the past. Now he must demand that the Senate take up and approve this measure.

title: Nigeria Combustible as South's Oil Enriches North
description: Deep in the mangrove swamp of the Niger River Delta, Bello Orubebe pressed his nose against the window of a deserted houseboat once used by Shell oil workers. Peeking inside, he saw a simple room the size of a big closet, with bunk beds, metal lockers, an air-conditioner and a fan.

title: Sect Disappears, Awaiting the Millennium
description: Denver did not disappear in an apocalyptic earthquake on Oct. 10, as predicted by a Christian sect leader. But now he has disappeared with about 75 followers and their children.

title: Defining Hogarth
description: 'HOGARTH'S PROGRESS'

title: Parallel Lives
description: THE HOURS

title: Tara Kennedy, Jeffrey Fishman
description: Tara Marie Kennedy, a daughter of Mary Lou and Francis J. Kennedy of Crestwood, N.Y., was married last evening to Jeffrey Kessler Fishman, a son of Louise and Elliot J. Fishman of Charlotte Amalie, V.I. The Rev. Michael B. Harris, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at Tavern on the Green in New York. Rabbi Joel S. Goor took part in the ceremony.

title: The Nation; In an Odd Turn, Officials Are Pushing Welfare
description: DON'T gasp, but the bureaucrats are rolling out the welcome mats at some of the nation's welfare offices again.

title: Tara Rabine and Steven Merson
description: Tara Leigh Rabine, a daughter of Sally and Joel Rabine of Melville, N.Y., was married last evening to Steven George Merson, the son of Catherine and Andrew Merson of Woodcliff Lake, N.J. Rabbi Andre Ungar officiated at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Manhattan.

title: How Not to Conduct an Impeachment Hearing; Biased Report
description: To the Editor:

title: $90.5 Million for Reader's Digest Art
description: TWO Modigliani portraits accounted for more than a fourth of the total of $90.5 million reaped over two days from the sale of Reader's Digest art at Sotheby's last week.

title: How Americans See Themselves
description: While your magazine defines the family portrait as ''an artificially sunny moment,'' the word ostentatious comes to mind (Nov. 1). Those pompous portraits are over the top. Surely the Vincentis of Pasadena are toasting us with sparkling apple juice, since their son had a glass in hand.

title: Czar Vasily?
description: THE ESCAPE OF ALEXEI

title: There's No Crises Like Show Crises
description: Everything about theater people seems larger than life, including their meltdowns.

title: Commercial Property / Long Island; Demand Spurs Construction of Spec Office Buildings
description: BOLSTERED by a decreasing vacancy rate and rising rents, Long Island developers are once again starting speculative office buildings -- those without a signed tenant -- after a decade-long pause.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUTTICK, ALICE M.
description: HUTTICK-Alice M. (nee Boyce). On November 19, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Robert. Loving mother of Robert, John, Edward and Alice Warden. Adored grandmother of Robert, Ryan and Allison. Loving mother-in-law of Tracey Huttick and Joseph Warden. Fond sister of Elizabeth McHugh, Raymond Boyce and the late John. Reposing Riverdale Funeral Home, 5044 Broadway (W 214 St), NYC. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10AM, Our Lady Queen of Martyrs R.C. Church. Interment Saint Raymond's Cemetery. Visiting Sunday and Monday 2-5 and 79PM.

title: Reins on Executive Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Paranoia Personified
description: THE SHAMEFUL LIFE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERPOINT, POWELL
description: PIERPOINT-Powell. Died on November 17, age 76, in NYC. He is survived by his daughter, Harriett P. Bos, her husband, Gerard A. Bos, and three grandchildren, Pier, Abbie and Evan Bos, all of Charlotte NC. A memorial servce will be held at St.James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue on Monday, November 23 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Andrew's School, Middletown, Delaware or Yale University.

title: Sports of The Times; Cool, Curt and Not at All Done
description: ABOUT the softened and vulnerable Steffi Graf I have been hearing so much about; does this evolved persona of the tennis legend really exist? Lindsay Davenport, wisely suspicious, played it conservatively deferential, not giving Graf any more incentive than she already had yesterday.

title: ... and Tapas for the Passionately Inclined
description: SPANIARDS are passionate about tapas, the appetizer-snack-hors d'oeuvre-like tidbits served in most of their restaurants and bars. They meet in the evening to talk, drink sherry, Malaga, Manzanilla or wine and nibble on everything from olives and cubes of ham and cheese to seafood in sauce or tiny sandwiches as a prelude to dinner or as dinner itself. In this country, tapas are something of a litmus test of Spanish authenticity. There are relatively few Spanish spots and strangely, most of them do not offer tapas. The sparkling Laguna, a new Spanish-Basque restaurant in Roslyn does, 11 of them, all in a row on the bar just as they are in Madrid or Barcelona.

title: Vols Leave Little Doubt About Who's No. 1
description: In a manner as subtle as his gray suit and as soft as the touch on his 55-yard touchdown bomb, Tennessee quarterback Tee Martin explained yesterday how his Volunteers had destroyed a distracted Kentucky team, 59-21. And how they had made a businesslike claim on the title of the nation's best college team.

title: November 15-21; A New Kind Of Space Flight
description: A new era in human space exploration opened as another closed, both with great fanfare.

title: Apology Made in Race Bias Case
description: A controversy over allegations of racial discrimination at the Eagle, a gay bar at 11th Avenue and 22d Street, has been resolved, after the owner of the bar, Jack Modica, agreed to take out newspaper ads to apologize and to donate $3,000 to two gay groups. Last week, Councilman Philip Reed, who first made the allegations, withdrew the complaint against the bar that he had filed with the city's Human Rights Commission.

title: Preholiday Sunday Laden With Concerts
description: THIS pre-Thanksgiving Sunday may be the busiest concert day of the year. Among the events are Winnie the Pooh and his entourage re-created in a marionette production at the North Castle Library in Armonk at 1:30 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUCHER, FAY
description: SUCHER-Fay. Beloved wife of the late Philip. Devoted mother of Cheryl Sucher and Joe and Debra Sucher. Cherished grandmother of Sara Sucher and Charles Sucher. Dear sister-in-law of Mrs. Leona Kleiner. Services Sunday, 11 AM, ''Boulevard-Riverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI. In lieu of flowers or other gifts donations to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, 733 3rd Ave., NY NY 10017 would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINLAN, GEORGE E.
description: QUINLAN-George E. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of George E. Quinlan, associated with The Times from 1970, until retiring in 1986.

title: Ideas & Trends: No Deus Ex Machina; First Read the Directions, Then Do No Harm
description: WITH thousands of new tools and techniques introduced into medicine each year, doctors face constant pressure to stay abreast of technology. And savvy patients shop around for those who will perform the latest procedures advertised in newspapers or discussed at dinner parties. But what most patients don't know as they're wheeled into the operating room is how skilled their doctors are with the new equipment. The physicians using it, sometimes for the first time, may have taken only a three-hour course or watched a video or chatted with the manufacturer's sales representative.

title: Evidence of Hatred
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANREDER, JULIUS
description: ANREDER-Julius. Oscar Gruss & Son, Incorporated honors the life of Julius Anreder, our partner for over thirty years. Julius helped build our firm and stood with us in good times and bad. An uncle to Laura Anreder and a friend, teacher and confidante to many of us here... Julius' life was defined by hardwork and outstanding courage. He lived with a commitment to honesty, to loyalty, to modesty and intelligence.

title: A Samson With a Black Belt
description: THE travel and the long hours were starting to catch up with him; Jose Cura sounded low, gravelly and untenorial on a recent morning. ''Excuse me,'' he growled, ''as I use my double-bass voice.''

title: Mining the Relics of Journeys Past
description: FOR the legions who drive sport utility vehicles to work on Wall Street, wear high-tech mountain gear to suburban barbecues and keep Jon Krakauer's Everest adventure story, ''Into Thin Air,'' on the best-seller list, another spectator sport is catching on: collecting exploration art.

title: Cover-to-Cover Coverage, Except On Certain Shelves
description: THE words book and television tug against each other in a fairly obvious way, but I still can't help smiling at the sassy paradox implicit in the designation Book TV. That's what C-Span 2 calls the round-the-clock weekend programming it introduced in September, displacing reruns of the United States Senate, the estimable show this cable network carries live on most weekdays.

title: Basque Highlights
description: The influences of Basque culture in the United States go beyond jai alai. To learn more, there's ''A Travel Guide to Basque America'' (University of Nevada Press, $18.95). It lists businesses and institutions, like the many Basque restaurants in Bakersfield, Calif., and has a calendar of Basque summer festivals. The author is Nancy Zubiri, a Basque-American. To order: (877) 682-6657. Shipping is $4.50 extra.

title: Jet Lag
description: GANG GREEN An Irreverent Look Behind the Scenes at Thirty-eight (Well, Thirty-seven) Seasons of New York Jets Football Futility. By Gerald Eskenazi. Illustrated. 333 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $25.

title: Campaign Rancor Lives On
description: They are political races designed to have an apolitical tone. Opponents are prohibited from speaking ill of each other -- or, for that matter, from speaking of each other at all. And their ads are supposed to be utterly free of invective.

title: Dance -- Honoring The Founding Vision, and Moving On; When A Company's Creator Is Gone
description: THE king is dead. Long live . . . who? America's major modern-dance companies have traditionally been fiefs, each headed by a formidably gifted creator who functions as artistic director, sole choreographer and -- for as long as he or she can walk onto the stage -- leading performer. The New York City Ballet, ruled by George Balanchine from its founding until his death in 1983, was conceived as a jewel box of dancers sufficiently musical and fleet-limbed to display his choreographic treasures. When a company so resolutely reflects the vision of a single person, can it survive that person's death?

title: St. John's Advances
description: St. John's won its first-round game in the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's soccer tournament yesterday when a Brown defender, Andy Dixon, scored an own goal with 1 minute 3 seconds left in the second overtime. A crossing pass from the Red Storm's Stefani Miglioranzi deflected off Dixon and past Brown goalkeeper Matthew Cross.

title: Soccer (Playing) Moms
description: Her first-grade son ensconced at school, Ginger Steuart pushed 3-year-old Gwendolyn across the grass in Brookdale Park one chilly but sunny morning last week, and parked the stroller on the perimeter of a small field marked by plastic orange cones. She placed a white blanket over her daughter, handed her a small box of crackers and gave her a kiss. ''Mommy will be right over there,'' she said, pointing to a growing circle of women who, like her, have crossed the great divide separating soccer mom from soccer player.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASTEN, LILLIAN
description: KASTEN-Lillian. On November 19, 1998. Devoted daughter of the late Bessie. Loving sister of the late Sylvia. Cherished cousin to many. She will be missed by all. Services Sunday 10:15am at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', Rockville Center.

title: A Hollywood Good Guy Talks Tough
description: Paul Newman, founder of Newman's Own Inc., told a group of Harvard Business School students that he planned a hostile takeover of the H. J. Heinz Company, according to The Harbus, the student newspaper. The actor-entrepreneur also gloated about putting a rival food venture started by Frank Sinatra out of business. He was kidding on both counts, of course. Mr. Newman, whose company has contributed more than $90 million to charity since its founding in 1982, enthralled his audience with his unorthodox musings about business. He started his venture as ''a joke,'' he said, and decided to give its profits away after putting his face on bottles and realizing how tacky it looked. But James Austin, chairman of the school's Initiative on Social Enterprise, saw an important business principle at work. Newman's Own, he said, enjoys a competitive edge because its do-goodism attracts customers, inspires loyalty among suppliers and employees and gets favorable press. ''Newman's Own reveals the synergistic relationship between the social purpose and the commercial operations,'' he said.

title: Will Indian Wealth Benefit Norwich?
description: IN 1994, when the Mashantucket Pequots announced plans to put $18 million into downtown Norwich, it seemed the dawn of a new age for the longtime down-on-its-luck river community. But recent tribal announcements have raised questions about whether the city will ever actually see much benefit from the Pequot wealth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWIGHT, RICHARD W.
description: DWIGHT-Richard W., M.D. Age 95, of Westwood, MA, formerly of Chestnut Hill, MA, died Friday, November 20, 1998. Son of the late Dr. James Dwight and the late Marie (Iasigi) Dwight. He is survived by his nephew Philip T. Dwight of Hancock, NH, and his niece Veronica Richard of Ft. Myers, FL. Also survived by several great-nieces and great-nephews. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held Tuesday, November 24, 1998, at 11 AM, at the Church of St. Lawrence, Rte 9, Brookline, MA. Interment at Forest Hills Cemetery, Jamaica Plain, MA. Remembrances may be sent to the American Cancer Society, Massachusetts Divison, 255 Bear Hill Rd., Waltham, MA 02154. For information call J. S. Waterman & SonsWaring, 592 Washington St., Wellesley, MA.

title: Never Mind the Name; The Food is All-American
description: ''It's a New Age mom and pop restaurant,'' said John Greco, who along with his wife, Suzanne, opened Philip Marie at 569 Hudson Street (at West 11th Street) two weeks ago. ''We consider it our first baby,'' Mr. Greco said as proudly as any new dad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YUDESS, MARGARET
description: YUDESS-MARGARET. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to our dear friends Larry & Linda & their family on the loss of their beloved mother and to Sidney on the loss of his partner in life Margaret. You are in our hearts & thoughts. Your friends: Mike & Carol, Stuart & Carole, Orin & Barbara, Alan & Susan, Bruce & Mary

title: The World; Chile Renders a Verdict on Pinochet: Let's Move On
description: SNAPSHOTS from Chile: Shortly after Gen. Augusto Pinochet was arrested in London five weeks ago on a Spanish warrant, neighborhood officials cut off garbage pickups at the Spanish and British embassies here. But a couple of days later cooler heads prevailed and garbage removal resumed.

title: The View From/Pleasantville; Young Voices Ring Out: Next Stop, Maybe, Fame
description: MAYBE it is a coincidence, but the youngsters in the Dreamcoat Singers all seem unusually nice. The nonprofit, professionally trained group was rehearsing in a rented hall here on a recent Saturday and not one of the 34 members was even slightly snobbish, sour or snidely hip, the way preteen-agers and teen-agers can sometimes be around strangers. In fact, they were eager to talk about their singing, their budding social consciences and their performance season.

title: Marchibroda Is Not the Only Coach in Trouble
