description: Few people in the National Football League will say anything negative about Coach Ted Marchibroda of the Baltimore Ravens. He is a good man, but he is a good man in trouble.

title: Keeping Cool, Without a Net
description: Q. My boss was fired, and, as his right-hand man, I have reason to believe that I will also get my walking papers as soon as his replacement is hired. Meanwhile, I am a manager without any sort of contract to protect me. My media agency is small and needs me to keep things running until the new boss arrives. Should I use this opportunity to get a contract that promises me a severance should I be dismissed? Or could such a request be interpreted as bad faith?

title: Knife, Fork and Ski Mask
description: Dining Out

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHORR, MARTIN M.
description: SHORR-Martin M. Died November 20, 1998. Survived by loving wife Ruth; sons Milton A. Shorr of Roslyn, NY, and Edward Shorr; and five grandchildren. Memorial service today, 1 PM, Roosevelt Memorial Park, Trevose, PA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOULIHAN, DANIEL J.
description: HOULIHAN-Daniel J. Of Crestwood, NY, on November 21, 1998. Husband of Kathrene Blish Houlihan. Father of Kathrene H. Clark, Rita L. Houlihan, Dorothy H. Soklaski, Daniel J. Houlihan, Jr., Joseph B. Houlihan, Mark J. Houlihan, Barbara H. Hecht, Gerry Houlihan and Elizabeth H. Genovese. Brother of Joseph T. Houlihan, Sister Rita Anne Houlihan, R.C., and Janet Houlihan Kain. Grandfather of 18. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 24 and 7-9 PM, Sunday and Monday. Mass of Christian Burial Annunciation Church, Crestwood, on Tuesday, November 24, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Annunciation School, Crestwood, NY 10707.

title: The Post-Khomeini Generation
description: As a Persian woman, born in Shiraz and raised in the United States since the age of 4, I was happy to see fellow natives of Iran portrayed in a positive light rather than as individuals who demonstrate hatred for the United States (Elaine Sciolino, Nov. 1). It was refreshing to read an article that is truly representative of a generation that expects and hopes for better educational, career and social opportunities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUSSEINI, ALAYNE (ENGELBERG
description: HUSSEINI-Alayne (Engelberg). On November 20, 1998. Survived by uncles Lazar Engelberg and wife Irene, John Hauser and wife Lee. For information ''Wien & Wien'', 1-800-322-0533

title: BEST SELLERS: November 22, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Deborah Gruber, Michael Sanders
description: Dr. Deborah Beth Gruber, the daughter of Dr. Susan P. Feldman and Dr. Michael L. Gruber, both of Englewood, N.J., was married last evening to Dr. Michael Sanders, a son of Dr. Arlette F. Sanders of Great Neck, N.Y., and the late Bernard Sanders. Rabbi Abraham B. Eckstein officiated at Bridgewaters, a catering hall in New York.

title: Where the Voice Came From
description: EUDORA WELTY

title: A Modest Star Shines Brightly
description: IF you missed Martin Short when he made his Broadway debut in Neil Simon's ''Goodbye Girl,'' you probably have no idea of his heft as a performer in the theater. Among other things, he has the ability to dominate a Broadway stage as easily as he fills the television screen. He's a singing, dancing actor of legitimate style. He's someone who can change his appearance as easily without makeup as with a fake beard or jokey eyeglasses or even, I suspect, a bulbous red nose that honks when squeezed.

title: The Real Villains
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILL, JASON
description: WILL-Jason. A purple heart veteran of WWII. Died September 20. Today it will have been his 74th Birthday & he would be preparing his annual trip to his home in the Caribbean. No one could have had a more honest, loyal & dedicated friend. We will miss him daily. Budd Calisch & Robert McKenzie

title: Cemetery Bans Mementos on Child Graves
description: DIANE O'BRIEN has some holiday gifts in mind for her son Eric, who died just a week after he was born two years ago. But a recent crackdown by officials at the Cemetery of the Holy Rood may change her shopping plans and result in a more spartan Christmas around her son's grave.

title: A Tale of Two Dickenses
description: You could call him a ghost of Christmas past. From Dec. 13 to 15 in Hershey, Pa., Gerald Charles Dickens, the 35-year-old great-great-grandson of Charles Dickens, will perform the voices of 26 characters in his own version of ''A Christmas Carol.'' The Evening With Dickens takes place during a Victorian Christmas dinner at the Hotel Hershey. With dinner, it's $65, $30 ages 3 to 8. With accommodations, it's $149 a person, double occupancy. Call (717) 534-8800 for reservations. A shorter reading at tea time each day is $25, $15 for children.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Nov. 1 with an article about the changing art scene in the Chelsea section of Manhattan misidentified a gallery with an interior described as ''antiseptic and awkward.'' It is Leslie Tonkonow Artworks and Projects, not the Andrea Rosen Gallery.

title: New Center Puts Ethics At the Fore
description: HEALTH care workers must help patients move through every stage of an illness, including death,'' Stephen Unger, a chaplain at Stony Brook University Hospital, told more than 300 people assembled at Long Island University's C. W. Post campus here on Nov. 5.

title: Smile! You're Back On 'Candid Camera'
description: ON a rainy Saturday morning, in a rented storefront a few yards from Cannery Row, a crew from the CBS series ''Candid Camera'' prepares for a long day. The ''gag'' they're attempting is deceptively simple: unwitting citizens who drop off film at a one-hour photo-developing shop will return to find that establishment inexplicably transformed into a dry cleaner. The shop's mock proprietor -- in both cases, Peter Funt, the show's executive producer and co-host (with the sitcom actress Suzanne Somers) -- will profess benign noncomprehension of his customers' quandary. Said customers' reactions will be secretly recorded by a hidden camera and microphone.

title: Sports of The Times; Steinbrenner's $600 Million Piece of Cake
description: NOBODY is supposed to be able to have his cake and eat it too, but George Steinbrenner is about to do just that. And it might be a $600 million cake.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Shadow Wars

title: A Pioneering Dialogue Between Actress and Image
description: ANDY WARHOL has so become his own trademark -- and is so much a one-name synonym for the culture of celebrity -- that it can be a shock to realize just how brilliantly original he was as a visual artist. A case in point: The double-screen video-based film installation ''Outer and Inner Space'' at the Whitney Museum (through Nov. 30), which places his glamorous, doomed superstar Edie Sedgwick in a dialogue with her own video-taped image.

title: Freshman Tailback Keeps Bruins in Running for a National Championship
description: U.C.L.A.-Southern California is a rivalry rich in tradition, but it was a newcomer who stole the show today.

title: Music as an Aid To Digestion
description: IF I were playing a late-night lounge for miserable alcoholics,'' said Steve Regan, 45, a deejay who makes custom tapes for upscale restaurants, ''I'd alternate Billie Holiday with Hank Williams.''

title: Self-Defense and Speedboats Are on Trenton Agenda
description: The Statehouse bustled with lawmakers, aides and lobbyists on Monday, when committees of the General Assembly and the Senate met. Here are some of the measures they considered:

title: The First Defectors
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANREDER, JULIUS S.
description: ANREDER-Julius S. Beloved husband of the late Paula Anreder. Devoted brother of Henrietta, Harriet, Florence and Marvin, Jean and Steven. Adored uncle of Lynn, Gail, Lewis, Michael, Scott, Eric, Emily, Sandy, Michelle, David, Laura, Susan, Lawrence, Rebecca and eighteen great nieces and nephews. Funeral service Sunday, November 22nd, 1998, 12:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Now Playing: Two New Minutes of 'Star Wars'
description: The opening title reads: ''Every generation has a legend. . . . Every journey has a first step. . . . Every saga has a beginning.'' Then the John Williams music starts, the opening chords so unmistakable that movie audiences burst into applause.

title: Davies Shuns an 'Idiot's Grin' for a Radiant Smile
description: It was an impressive victory, and for Laura Davies, it was a relief.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Yanks' Hunt for Outfielder Delays Pursuit of Johnson
description: The Yankees' plodding pursuit of their targeted free agents could turn into a sprint today after a meeting of the team's brain trust in Tampa, Fla. Randy Johnson's agents, for two, would welcome the change, if, that is, Johnson remains one of the Yankees' targets.

title: Ballot Tactics Used by Vacco Are Assailed
description: As the final ballots are being counted in the tight race for state attorney general, Democratic leaders are charging that the campaign of Dennis C. Vacco, the Republican incumbent, has mounted a concerted effort to invalidate paper ballots in black and Hispanic areas, particularly in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, PAUL A.
description: KING-Paul A. Age 85. November 21, 1998. Beloved husband of Janet. Loving father of Carrie King and Kathy Simmons (Brent). Stepfather of Jonathan and David (Patty) Schimmel. Cherished grandfather of Michael and Rachel Simmons; Jesse, Nathan and Noah Schimmel. He was a man of great imagination and many talents. We will miss him deeply. Services Tuesday, November 24, at 11 AM, Clark Funeral Home, Katonah. Contributions in his memory can be made to Alzheimer's Association, Westchester Chapter.

title: A Woman With a Torch And Power in a Union Vote
description: 'Sweatshop'

title: Gina Blau, 92, Dancer in Classical Indian Style
description: Gina Blau, an American dancer who was an early exponent of Indian classical dance in the United States, died on Oct. 23 at Forest View Nursing Home in Forest Hills, Queens. She was 92.

title: U.S.C.'s Super Fan Dies at 797th Consecutive Football Game
description: Giles Pellerin never scored a touchdown before a huge crowd, never struck out a batter, never dunked a basketball, but he compiled one of the most remarkable streaks in sports history.

title: Jose Figueroa, 94, a Violinist With the Puerto Rico Symphony
description: Jose Figueroa, a leading Puerto Rican violinist and teacher, died on Nov. 9 at his home in San Juan, P.R. He was 94.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Michael Todd; Wine Magazine Publisher, 51
description: Michael Todd, publisher of Grapezine, a magazine about winegrowing, died on Saturday at Winthrop University Hospital in Mineola, N.Y. He was 51 and had homes in midtown Manhattan and Sag Harbor on Long Island.

title: Week's Treasury Sales Include 2-Year Note
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week offers today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and the auction of a two-year note tomorrow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, ARNOLD
description: FRANKEL-Arnold. The Board and Staff of the Queens Child Guidance Center are deeply saddened by the death of their past President, whose wisdom and generosity were decisive in enabling the agency to better serve the children of Queens. The Arnold Frankel Clinic of the Center will perpetuate his memory. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his widow Mimi and the entire family. The Board and Staff of the Queens Child Guidance Center Hank H. Auffarth, President Sandra Hagan, Exec. Dir. Walter O. Michael, Past President

title: 'Leave the Guy Alone,' Troops Say as Clinton Visits Korea
description: On a near-freezing pale-gray day on the tarmac of this U.S. Air Force base south of Seoul, President Bill Clinton did not have to offer any explanations for his conduct to GIs, most of them here on one-year tours without their families.

title: G.O.P. Leadership Isn't Diverse; Anti-Choice Wing
description: To the Editor:

title: Maxxim Medical To Buy Circon
description: Maxxim Medical Inc., which makes and markets specialty medical products, agreed today to buy the Circon Corporation for $243 million in cash and assumed debt to expand its range of products and reduce costs.

title: One Good Half for the Jets, and One Big Victory
description: In this season of possibilities, the Jets broke out with three impressive second-half touchdowns against the Oilers after being frustrated in the early going today, and they went on to produce one of their best games of the year.

title: TECHNOLOGY: Prospectus; At Cybersuds events, members of New York's new-media community look for partners, strategic and otherwise.
description: IN October, the New York New Media Association held Cybersuds, its monthly networking event, in an empty office space downtown provided by the real estate firm of Cushman & Wakefield.

title: Compressed Data; Start-Up's Shareholders Hold Meeting on Line
description: In the age of the Internet, the proxies and mahogany-lined board rooms typical of important company meetings might give way to quirkier variations. Such was the case with Travelzoo.com, a budget travel company that held its first company meeting on line on Friday. No jacket was required; shareholders just logged on, entered their passwords and cast their electronic ballots for the board.

title: Rancor Rules Out Progress At Peace Talks in Mexico
description: After exchanging angry invective for two days, mediators from the Mexican Congress and top leaders of the Zapatista rebels managed today to salvage some semblance of peace talks, but only barely.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, LEONARD
description: GORDON-Leonard. On November 20, 1998, at age 71. Retired Vice President at Merrill Lynch. Devoted husband to Roberta. Beloved father of Dana and Paul. Loving son of Eva and Abe Gordon. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Students Raise Voices In Israel
description: While their counterparts abroad have often led movements for social change, university students in Israel have had a well-earned reputation for indifference when it comes to political protest.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLOOM, BERNARD D., D.D.S.
description: BLOOM-Bernard D., D.D.S. April 11, 1922-November 23, 1992. Six years ago today. Alive in our hearts always.

title: 13 Die in Muslim-Catholic Riots in Indonesia; Churches Looted
description: A gang fight between Muslims and Christian migrants erupted into fierce rioting today in this tense city. Officials reported that six people were killed and nearly a dozen churches burned or damaged.

title: IRAQ RATCHETS UP RENEWED DEFIANCE OVER INSPECTIONS
description: A week after it narrowly escaped an American military strike, Iraq signaled yesterday in a series of defiant statements that it has little intention of cooperating with international arms inspectors and is still on a collision course with the United States.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in Science Times on Tuesday referred incorrectly to a research study on the medical uses of marijuana. The study, by Dr. Donald Abrams of the University of California at San Francisco, involves AIDS patients, not cancer patients. Participants in the study continue to take a regimen of anti-H.I.V. therapies; they are not required to forgo them. Recruitment for the study has been going as expected; it has not been difficult.

title: Mediocrity Works for the Rangers
description: The Rangers have completed their three-game California trip with a 1-1-1 record and a hat trick of injuries. As they finish their road swing with games in Buffalo on Wednesday and in Pittsburgh on Friday, they will await the recovery of three regular players: Ulf Samuelsson, Jeff Beukeboom and Todd Harvey.

title: Reliving History Through Writing
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: No. 2 on the Computer Only: Hingis Overcomes Davenport
description: The No. 1 ranking was out of range for the moment. So Martina Hingis, second-ranked by the computer but forever a first-rate contender in her own mind, took aim at the next best target: the season's last title and its $500,000 paycheck.

title: Yes, Tough Guys Dance and Sing Blues in the Night
description: WHY SINATRA MATTERS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARKIN, STEPHANIE
description: ARKIN-Stephanie. Born May 31, 1945, died November 20, 1998. Daughter of the late Edward and Irma Arkin. Sister of Kay Arkin. She will be remembered for her generosity. Services will be held today, 10 AM, at Hirsch & Sons, Jerome Ave and 167th St, Bronx. Donations to any homeless charity in her name would be appreciated.

title: Better Transportation Planned for Disabled
description: Under the pressure of a discrimination lawsuit and years of complaints by the disabled about poor service, New York City Transit has agreed to sharply improve its Access-a-Ride program of door-to-door transportation for thousands of disabled people, the city's Public Advocate, Mark Green, said yesterday.

title: The Big City; Rejections Put Wolfe In Elite Ranks
description: TOM WOLFE has long aspired to be the Balzac of his age, and up in Washington Heights it is clear that he has at least partially succeeded. He, too, has been spurned by the Academy.

title: Talks Continue in Strike By Jersey City Teachers
description: By Negotiations were continuing early this morning to end a strike by Jersey City teachers that began on Thursday.

title: Death of a Russian Democrat
description: The Russian reform movement has produced few leaders with an uncompromising dedication to democracy. Galina Starovoitova was one, and her murder in St. Petersburg on Friday was a terrible loss for Russia. In a bleak season of economic collapse and political timidity, the killing can only heighten fears that Russia is slipping into an ugly era of intolerance and political violence.

title: Patents; A radical policy shift opens the door to a variety of herbal preparations with medicinal purposes.
description: THREE years ago, the United States Patent Office published new guidelines that loosened its standards for granting certain medically related patents.

title: Vote in Quebec May Be Last Fling With Secession
description: Both men left the confines of Quebec for federal politics years ago. Both served in the Cabinet of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. Both later switched parties and both have come home to fight for the future of Canada's French-speaking province.

title: Scope of Smuggling Ring Stuns an Enclave
description: On a crisp November Sunday, Oak Tree Road here was the picture of a thriving South Asian immigrant enclave. The windows of gold jewelers sparkled with 22-karat necklaces. Shoppers went in and out of the markets, arms loaded with sacks of vegetables and spices from home.

title: When Cultures Clash, the Results Are Fatal
description: In June 1982, a Chinese-American named Vincent Chin was given a bachelor party at a bar in Detroit. An argument broke out between Chin and two men who had been employed by the Chrysler Corporation. They thought Chin was Japanese and saw in him an opportunity to strike a blow for the failing American automotive industry. They later drove around looking for Chin, found him in a McDonald's parking lot, and beat him to death with a baseball bat. They were given suspended sentences on manslaughter charges and fined $3,780 each.

title: Executive Changes At 2 Agencies
description: Two agencies owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies have made top-level executive changes.

title: B.C.S. Ranking Is Solving Little
description: It took a while, but this college football season may finally have short-circuited the computers. How? After the three undefeated teams at the top of the polls played big games Saturday, all three -- Tennessee, U.C.L.A. and Kansas State -- remained undefeated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIM, STEPHEN K, M
description: TIM-Stephen K-M. On November 21, 1998. Beloved husband of Nancy (nee Shopis). Brother of Phonyin Tim of Victoria, BC, and Peter Tim of Johannesburg, South Africa. Also survived by three nephews. Reposing Tuesday 2-5 and 79 PM, at Henry McCaddin & Son Funeral Home, 24 7th Ave, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Church of St. Augustine, Wednesday, 9:45 AM. Interment Middlebury, CT. In lieu of flowers donations to St. Augustine's Food Pantry, 116 6th Ave, Brooklyn, NY, 11217, appreciated.

title: INSIDE
description: A Mayor Eyes Kremlin

title: A Singer Gives a Rare Display Of Just What It Takes
description: Kenny Lattimore

title: Flat Top Makes Case For Eclipse Award
description: Flat Top jumped to the lead over the final fence and then staged a powerful stretch drive to win the $100,000 Marion duPont Scott Colonial Cup in Camden, S.C., yesterday, making his case for the Eclipse Award as steeplechasing's Horse of the Year.

title: Oilers Wear Dunce Cap After Lesson From Jets
description: The Jets had won six of seven games and four in a row and then crashed last week at Indianapolis. Lesson learned. The Oilers had won five of six and three in a row and then crashed here yesterday against the Jets. Lesson learned?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUCHINS, ALAN J.
description: KUCHINS-Alan J. On November 20, 1998, of Garden City, NY. Beloved husband of Anne Beckert. Loving father of Alexis and Neil. Cherished son of John and Thea. Dear brother of Ronald. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th St, Garden City, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, Sunday and Monday. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Anne's Church, Garden City, 9:45 AM, Tuesday. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village.

title: Heed the Arthropods; They May Have the Answers
description: By next weekend it will be evident that we are all, to quote Woody Allen's closing lines in ''Antz,'' getting in touch with our inner maggots. No need to go to the ant, thou sluggard. The ants are coming to us. No sooner has colonialization been given new meaning by the Dreamworks fall movie fantasy, than Disney and Pixar are polishing off their creatures' mandibles for Wednesday's release of ''A Bug's Life.''

title: Fassel Stays the Course
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel did not hesitate, in the moments after the Giants' 20-0 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles yesterday, to name Kent Graham the team's starting quarterback for next week's game at San Francisco.

title: Prosecutor to Weigh Possibility of Charging Kevorkian
description: A Michigan prosecutor said today that he would carefully review videotape of Dr. Jack Kevorkian injecting a terminally ill man with a lethal series of drugs, which was shown on television tonight, and other evidence before deciding whether to prosecute him.

title: Political Briefing; Front-Loading 2000, A Headlong Rush
description: All that talk about spreading out the Presidential primaries and caucuses in Election 2000 turns out to be just talk. If anything, the process next time is going to be more front-loaded than ever.

title: For an N.C.A.A. Champion, a Long Road Back
description: A year ago, after winning the National Collegiate Athletic Association cross-country title, Carrie Tollefson of Villanova was determined to have a rare tumor in her left heel. She was told by doctors that she might never run again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, JANET
description: RICHMAN-Janet. Adored wife of David. ''Tiger'' lost her courageous battle against cancer on November 21, 1998. Beloved daughter of Helen and Robert Gross; sister of Debbie Solomon; mother of Jerri Strauss and Steven Albrecht, and devoted nana to Josh and Doug. Service Wednesday, November 25, 10 AM, at Ballard-Durand, 2 Maple Ave, White Plains. Interment at Sharon Gardens in Valhalla. Donations to The American Cancer Society in the hope that a cure will be found for this horrible disease which took the life of someone with such vitality.

title: NETSCAPE BID SEEN BY AMERICA ONLINE
description: America Online Inc. is on the verge of agreeing to purchase the Netscape Communications Corporation, the Internet pioneer at the center of the Government's antitrust suit against the Microsoft Corporation, executives involved in the talks said yesterday.

title: Overthrowing Hussein: Plan Without Principle; A Democratic Ally?
description: To the Editor:

title: Marie Curie and a Century of Radiation
description: When Marie Curie died on July 4, 1934, Albert Einstein remarked that she was, ''of all celebrated beings, the only one whom fame has not corrupted.'' It has been a century since Curie and her husband, Pierre, who died in 1906, discovered polonium and radium, just a century since she coined the word ''radioactivity.'' Their discoveries brought the Curies worldwide fame, and yet fame, ironically, made the name Curie a byword for modesty. The laboratory in which their most important work was done was only a former storeroom and machine shop, and they always refused, Marie Curie wrote, ''to draw from our discovery any material profit.''

title: Giants Quietly Keep Victory In Perspective
description: There was no music in the Giants' locker room afterward. No strut, no attitude, no festivities whatsoever.

title: Reporters Left in Cold
description: Claiming that the visiting locker room at Vanderbilt Stadium was too small to accommodate the 40 or so members of the news media, Coach Bill Parcells risked a league fine by barring them from interviewing players there after the game.

title: Devils Savor Goal Rush Against Hurricanes
description: Five goals is almost a week's worth of production for the Devils, so no one could blame the team for celebrating in the dressing room after a 5-2 victory over the Carolina Hurricanes this afternoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDBRIL, LEO
description: EDBRIL-Leo. On November 21, 1998. Dear husband of the late Shirley (nee Sorkin). Dear father of Diane and Steven. Devoted grandfather of Matthew and Jessica. Dear brother of Walter. Services today, November 23, 11 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions can be made in Leo's name to Montefiore Childrens Hospital Fund, Montefiore Medical Center, 111 E. 210th St, Bronx, NY 10467.

title: Armed Man Holds Boy Hostage In an Apartment in Brooklyn
description: An armed man surrendered to the police early this morning after holding a boy hostage for more than 12 hours in a Brooklyn apartment, the police said. The boy was unharmed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOULIHAN, DANIEL J.
description: HOULIHAN-Daniel J. Of Crestwood, NY, on November 21, 1998. Husband of Kathrene Blish Houlihan. Father of Kathrene H. Clark, Rita L. Houlihan, Dorothy H. Soklaski, Daniel J. Houlihan, Jr., Joseph B. Houlihan, Mark J. Houlihan, Barbara H. Hecht, Gerry Houlihan and Elizabeth H. Genovese. Brother of Joseph T. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOWKES, ROBERT ALLEN, PH.D.
description: FOWKES-Robert Allen, Ph.D. The St. David's Society of the State of New York records with profound sorrow the death of its much beloved past president (1955-1958), Professor Robert A. Fowkes. Born in Harrison, NY, on April 7, 1913, he married Angela Vescio in Yonkers, NY on June 17, 1939. He died in Valhalla, NY, on November 18, 1998. Interment will be in Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings, NY. To his wife, Angela, his sons, Robert, Jr., Richard, and William, his grandchildren and great-grandchildren, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Mary Lynne Bird, President James W. Thomas, Secretary

title: Chinese President Setting Out for Visits to Both Russia and Japan
description: President Jiang Zemin left China today for consecutive visits to Russia, where he is to meet with the ailing President, Boris N. Yeltsin, and Japan, for the first visit by a Chinese Communist head of state.

title: Pentagon Ready to Shrink Arsenal of Nuclear Bombs
description: Driven by budget constraints as much as diminishing security threats, Pentagon officials are quietly recommending that the Clinton Administration consider unilateral reductions in the nation's nuclear arsenal.

title: Finding Depth In Society's Shallow End
description: Alan J. Pakula's career was notably overlooked by the book ''Easy Riders, Raging Bulls,'' Peter Biskind's warts-and-all look at filmmaking in the 1970's. Mr. Pakula was one of that decade's most eminent directors, but he wasn't part of the wild bunch. His style was more thoughtful, efficient and adult than that of his more flagrantly experimental colleagues, and it wound up having more staying power than most. For nearly 40 years, as both producer (''To Kill a Mockingbird,'' ''Inside Daisy Clover'') and director (from ''The Sterile Cuckoo'' in 1969 to ''The Devil's Own'' last year), he survived devastating changes in the film industry with his dignity and intelligence intact.

title: Media Talk; Police Officer As Journalist: Behind the Pseudonym
description: In his personal essays for The New Yorker magazine, the author known only by the pseudonym ''Marcus Laffey'' has written eloquently about the sorrows of potters' field and the daily grind of a New York City police officer's beat; he has revealed his occasional satisfaction in snapping on handcuffs; explained the slang of police officers, and told wrenching stories about practically murderous neglect.

title: Charles McCartney, Known for Travels With Goats, Dies at 97
description: You take a fellow who looks like a goat, travels around with goats, eats with goats, lies down among goats and smells like a goat and it won't be long before people will be calling him the Goat Man.

title: People
description: * Julio Deulofeu was named president of the San Francisco office of Wunderman Cato Johnson, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., succeeding Paul Jandreau Smith, who resigned earlier this year. Mr. Deulofeu had been president at Publicis Dialog, San Francisco, part of Publicis S. A. Also at Wunderman Cato, Michael Hughes was named to the new post of president at the Irvine, Calif., office; he had been managing director for relationship marketing at Team One Advertising, El Segundo, Calif., part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C.

title: Compressed Data; Scissors Cut Paper, So You'll Kick Off
description: Mike Rosenfelt has always been known as a creative marketing type. He was the mind behind the advertising and stunts performed by Power Computing, the upstart maker of Macintosh clones. Now, as the marketing director at Micron Electronics, which is trying to revive its personal computer business, he has gone over the top. Micron is sponsoring the Micron Bowl in Miami on Dec. 29. Known last year as the Blockbuster Bowl, the event is a collegiate football championship game. As part of Micron's ''New Rules, New Tools'' campaign, Mr. Rosenfelt is trying to persuade college athletic officials to change the rules and replace the coin toss with a game of paper, scissors, stone. JOHN MARKOFF

title: A Steinbrenner Twist
description: George M. Steinbrenner 3d continued to deny that he was close to an agreement to sell the Yankees to Cablevision, but he said his family would retain control of the team if he should sell. He also hinted at the possibility that he could wind up running the Knicks and the Rangers, which are owned by Cablevision. Article, page B1.

title: Latest Pitch Sites: Baggage Carousels
description: The growing popularity of what is known as place-based media has filled sites like airports with all sorts of advertising. Now travelers waiting for their luggage will see oversized moving billboards affixed to the metal plates of the carousels in baggage claim areas, pitching everything from hotels and restaurants to watches and airlines.

title: Equity Offerings for Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEEHAN, WILLIAM J., III
description: SHEEHAN-William J., III. On November 21, 1998. Beloved husband of Dorothy (nee Hyde). Dear father of Ellen Kuhner and Laura Sheehan. Cherished brother of Carol Pfeiffer. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday, 10:30 AM, at St. Barnabas Church. The family will be present Monday and Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc, 732 Yonkers Avenue, Yonkers, NY.

title: Stanford Holds On to Topple Top-Ranked Purdue
description: For the second consecutive week, the top-ranked team in women's basketball lost in stunning fashion.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: FOOTBALL

title: Complex Allegory With Arab and Western Music
description: The French modern-dance choreographer Michel Hallet Eghayan founded his company in Lyons 21 years ago, shortly after he had studied in New York with Merce Cunningham.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VERMONT, RENEE
description: VERMONT-Renee. Remembering the laughter and the kindness of your generosity. Love, Vik

title: A Systems-Management Deal That Computes
description: Nothing raises a company's profile like a billion-dollar deal. So it is that the spotlight now shines on BMC Software Inc. and Boole & Babbage Inc., two companies that have long labored in the obscure world of systems management.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: EXTRA POINTS
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel did not hesitate, in the moments after the Giants' 20-0 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles yesterday, to name Kent Graham the team's starting quarterback for next week's game at San Francisco.

title: Media Talk; The Highs and Lows Of Newspaper Readers
description: Are adults living in the Wilkes-Barre-Scranton, Pa., area better read than most other people? They are when it comes to newspapers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FENNELL, GABRIEL, RUBY
description: FENNELL-GABRIEL-Ruby. November 23, 1996. 2 years today, but you are still here. I see your beautiful face, I hear your lovely voice. I miss you terribly. My love endures. Pete

title: The Price of Censure; Partisanship Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Steinbrenner May Sell, but Says He'll Stay the Boss
description: George M. Steinbrenner 3d continued to deny yesterday that he had reached agreement or was close to an agreement to sell a majority share of the Yankees to Cablevision. But he made one thing perfectly plain and said another was possible.

title: Editorial Observer; Women: Many Are Called, Few Are Promoted
description: In the history of women in politics, November may go down as the month Representative Deborah Pryce of Ohio was re-elected secretary of the Republican House leadership conference. Ms. Pryce won by a unanimous vote, possibly nailing down the secretary job for years to come.

title: Congressional Memo; Hyde Presses On With Complex Inquiry
description: There is often a kernel of insight in Representative Henry J. Hyde's ripostes as chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, and they typically refer to his state of mind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAVIN, MARVIN ''PETE.''
description: SAVIN-Marvin ''Pete.'' Age 69, husband of Elaine (Sneirson) Savin of 1011 Mountain Road, Bloomfield, CT. Died November 22, 1998. For more than 40 years Mr. Savin was prominent in Hartford business, civic, sports and political affairs. In addition, he had owned race horses and was an avid golfer. Besides his wife, he is survived by a son John Savin; daughters Stacey Savin Chatigny, Nina Savin Scott, Stephanie Savin McCauley, Terri Savin Docal and 13 grandchildren. Funeral services and burial will be Tuesday in Hartford, CT. Call Weinstein Mortuary of Hartford for more information.

title: Transit Is on Par With 3 'Model' Systems, Study Finds
description: While London, Paris and Tokyo are often praised for the quality of their public transportation systems, a new report suggests that the New York region fares surprisingly well in the efficiency of its trains, buses and subways when compared with these cities.

title: N.B.A. Negotiators to Meet
description: After a weekend of digesting each other's proposals, negotiating teams from the National Basketball Association and the players association are scheduled to meet today or tomorrow in Manhattan.

title: City Settles Workers' Lawsuits for $1.3 Million
description: The city has paid $1.3 million to settle two lawsuits stemming from allegations of racism in the office of the Staten Island Borough President, Guy V. Molinari, officials confirmed yesterday.

title: Packers Fail to Find An Answer For Moss
description: After spending all week playing down what was obviously a huge game against Green Bay, a group of Minnesota Vikings players dropped all pretenses and showed up this morning dressed in battle fatigues. They weren't going to war, just playing the Packers, or was it the same thing?

title: Media; TV News Wary of Lawsuits, Study Says
description: One out of every five local television news directors around the country say their stations have declined to broadcast some news reports in the last year because of fears of possible lawsuits, according to a recent survey conducted by the University of Miami.

title: Trying to make video-game characters like Crash Bandicoot familiar to mainstream consumers.
description: MAYBE Crash Bandicoot, Lara Croft and Sweet Tooth will never be household names. But after years of aiming sales pitches at serious video game enthusiasts, Sony Computer Entertainment is introducing a campaign for the Playstation game system meant to familiarize mainstream consumers with those colorful characters.

title: Sports of The Times; 'Just Throw Me the Ball,' Johnson Said. And the Jets Do.
description: IN the huddle at the Jets' sideline, Keyshawn Johnson was telling Bill Parcells, ''Let's call the play, let's call the play.''

title: Two Men With a Plan: Revitalizing Schenectady
description: The only name that used to count in Schenectady was General Electric. Now the new names to reckon with are Roger and Neil.

title: Defense a Concern for Isles
description: The Islanders broke a three-game losing streak with a victory against the Predators on Saturday, but there was some concern after the game.

title: Austria to Return Some Art Seized by Nazis, but Disputes Remain
description: Austria, whose Parliament has just given final approval to a law permitting restitution of hundreds of artworks seized by the Nazis, expects to return some works to their owners by late December. But the law will not resolve some of the toughest cases involving many of the most valuable works.

title: Back to the Drawing Board in Coney Island
description: Brooklyn sports enthusiasts -- not to mention economic development proponents -- were overjoyed when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced in September that the Mets would bring a minor league baseball club to Coney Island. Then they noticed what was missing and were horrified.

title: Gore Rejected C.I.A. Evidence of Russian Corruption
description: When the Central Intelligence Agency uncovered what its analysts considered to be conclusive evidence of the personal corruption of Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia in 1995, they sent it to the White House, expecting Clinton Administration officials to be impressed with their work.

title: Overthrowing Hussein: Plan Without Principle; Devastating Sanctions
description: To the Editor:

title: Media Talk; Has '60 Minutes' Punted Its Ratings?
description: Timeout: referee's decision needed. Has the addition of National Football League games to CBS's Sunday schedule helped ''60 Minutes,'' the news magazine institution that follows football on Sunday evenings? Or hurt it?

title: Dick Sisler, 78, Whose Homer Won '50 Pennant for Phillies
description: Dick Sisler, a member of a prominent baseball family who gained his own niche in the sport's history with a pennant-winning home run for the Philadelphia Phillies' 1950 Whiz Kids team, died on Friday in his hometown of Nashville. He was 78.

title: Eyeing Kremlin, Moscow Mayor Jump-Starts Bandwagon
description: All fall, as Russia drifted from crisis to crisis, Yuri M. Luzhkov, the pugnacious and energetic mayor of Moscow, kept trying to jump-start his undeclared campaign to succeed President Boris N. Yeltsin, using every opportunity to muscle his way onto the national stage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZACHARY, MARY
description: ZACHARY-Mary, 88, on Oct 25, 1998. Retired federal employee. She is sorely missed by: niece Hilary Bessieres and husband Michel and son Clovis; niece Malyne Sagerman and husband Robert and children, Roger, Jason, Evan, Eric; nephew Martin Frederick and wife Erica and children, Shara, Jessie, Benjamin; nephew Lawrence Baron and wife Vicki and children, Brooke, Maximillian; nephew Mark Baron and wife Carol and children, Jossef, Miriam, Gordon, Bradley; nephew James Baron and son Todd; her many cousins, including William Waks and wife Bella and Henry Goodfriend; and her legions of friends, including Libbie Licata. Of her many trips, her longest was from 42nd St to 42nd St. She will always be our beloved ''Auntie Mame''. Her wit, grace and indomitable spirit serves as inspiration. She was the glue that kept us together; it is up to us to carry on. Memorial services will be held at 2:00 P.M. Sunday, November 29, 1998 in the Kensington Room of the Crowne Plaza Hotel at the U.N. at 304 E. 42nd St in Manhattan. Donations may be made in Mary's name to American Cancer Society and the Amer Friends Service Committee.

title: Duke Energy to Buy U.S. Gas Business Of Union Pacific
description: The Duke Energy Corporation said today that it would buy the United States natural gas gathering, processing and marketing business of the Union Pacific Resources Group for $1.35 billion, making Duke one of the largest companies gathering and selling natural gas.

title: Expressing the Spiritual by Motion's Beauty
description: Choreographic images can be powerful to watch yet difficult to summarize in words. So, too, religious experiences, though intense, can resist rational analysis. It is no wonder, then, that choreographers sometimes express spiritual convictions by letting the beauty of moving bodies serve as signs of mysterious creative powers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDRON, ROBERT E.
description: WALDRON-Robert E. The sudden loss of our longtime friend and associate whose presence always lit up the room is deeply felt. Bob-go on and try and net lease the Heavens. Amen. Norman L. Brickell Bob Bookbinder

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPER, MURRAY GELLES
description: SAPER-Murray Gelles. Formerly of NYC, on November 21, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Charlotte Saper. Loving father of Jeffrey and Jordan Saper, cherished grandfather of Kimberly, Daniel, Amy, Julia, Jennifer, Douglas and Robert Saper. Former President of the First District Dental Society. A man who cherished and immersed himself in the lives of his family, friends and colleagues. He lived his life with warmth, wit, caring and unwavering support for and interest in the lives of others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAFF, SHIRLEY
description: RAFF-Shirley. Of Hewlett Harbor. Beloved wife of the late Bertram. Devoted mother of Sally, Linda (David) and Amy (Richard). Cherished grandmother of Lauren, Marcy, Erica, Kenny and Michelle. Sister of the late Bernard and also sister of Miriam. Died peacefully on November 22, 1998. Services at Boulevard Park West, Hewlett, on November 24, 9:30 AM. She will be missed by all of us whose lives she touched in so many special ways; her spirit remains a part of us forever.

title: Eltingh Concludes His Career With One More Doubles Title
description: Not many athletes leave their sport at the top of their game. But Jacco Eltingh, the world's top-ranked men's doubles player, did so today. And he did it by teaming with his longtime doubles partner and Dutch countryman, Paul Haarhuis, to win their second world doubles championship by beating Mark Knowles of the Bahamas and Daniel Nestor of Canada, 6-4, 6-2, 7-5.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, LEONORA (NEE ATKATZ)
description: MILLER-Leonora (nee Atkatz). Of Fair Lawn, N.J. Beloved wife of the late Bennett. Devoted mother of Dora and Wendy. Loving sister of Melvin. Doting grandmother of Bennett. Services at Louis Suburban Chapels, Fair Lawn, on Tuesday, at 12 noon.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If the House should decide to proceed with articles of impeachment, which means all they do is to charge the President, then the plea bargain in my mind seems to me more appropriately a question for the Senate rather than for the House.''

title: Lonnie Pitchford, 43, a Musician Who Nurtured the Delta Blues
description: Lonnie Pitchford, a Mississippi bluesman who was dedicated to reviving early Delta blues, died on Nov. 8 at his home in Lexington, Miss. He was 43.

title: Sanity Restored In a Fun House
description: This, as you probably know, is Thanksgiving week, the week signaling the headlong rush toward the holidays that increases the exasperation factor in most New Yorkers' lives tenfold. It's the time when you have to shop and you least want to, when traffic moves at mere inches a minute, when pedestrians start bumping into one another like bats without radar.

title: Pay Days in Albany
description: The temptation, when considering a pay raise for New York's State Legislature, is to ask, ''What for?'' Many legislators would have trouble making a case that they deserve more pay for their drone-like performance at these part-time jobs. That may be why they waited like poltroons until after the election to announce plans to give themselves more of the taxpayers' money. Nevertheless, if we hope to entice decent public servants in the future, we need to start offering a better pay package now.

title: Head of Deutsche Bank Faces Wall Street Culture Shock in a Bankers Trust Acquisition
description: As chairman of Deutsche Bank A.G., Rolf-Ernst Breuer has few illusions about the risks of a big expansion.

title: Navigational System Awaits Jamming Test
description: An improved navigational system for airplanes is nearing completion, though no one seems certain how well the satellite-based technology meets the aviation industry's extraordinary need for reliability.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACKENZIE, DOUGLAS C.
description: MacKENZIE - Douglas C. Of Brooklyn and Eastport, on November 20, 1998. Survived by his wife Yvonne, daughters Maureen C. MacKenzie and Deirdre MacKenzie, sister Margot Cunningham and granddaughters Adriana and Daniela. He was a retired teacher from the Bayshore High School and the Regis High School. Mass of the Resurrection Tuesday, 10 AM, at the Church of the Immaculate Conception, Westhampton Beach, New York.

title: Love in a Hurry on a Busy Shore Leave
description: The city that never sleeps is feeling drowsy in the opening moments of ''On the Town.'' Leonard Bernstein's score for this 1944 show begins with the musical equivalent of a yawn and a stretch, the sense of dormant urban energies slowly surfacing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, M. BLAKE, II
description: JOHNSON-M. Blake, II. Age 83, of Delray Beach, FL, died November 21, 1998. Theatrical producer, 1940's (North Shore Players, Marblehead, MA); television producer, 1950's and '60's (Producer's Showcase, et al). Very beloved husband of Cherry Hannan Johnson and father of Robin Johnson. Memorial services, First Presbyterian Church, Delray Beach, Tuesday, November 24, at 1 PM; Lorne and Sons Funeral Home, Delray Beach, FL.

title: Political Briefing; A Kennedy Drops Thoughts of Senate
description: Representative Patrick J. Kennedy, overwhelmingly re-elected to a third term by his constituents in Rhode Island's First Congressional District and just named head of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, says he has ''found a home in the House'' and given up all thought of running for the Senate.

title: Title for a California Couple In Life Master Open Pairs
description: Married couples very rarely win major titles, but it happened here on Saturday night at the start of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals. The Life Master Open Pairs was won convincingly by Lew and JoAnna Stansby of Castro Valley, Calif., who were having their first big win as a partnership.

title: The Price of Censure
description: To the Editor:

title: Diller's Latest Tele-Vision; First, a Network of Cubic Zirconium. Now, a Station of Lips and Hardbodies.
description: How would you promote a television show called ''10'' that visits the beaches of Miami seeking the best-looking guys and girls and lets audiences vote for their favorites?

title: Episcopal Bishop Faints At Ceremony in Newark
description: Bishop John S. Spong, the departing leader of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark, fainted during a consecration ceremony for his successor Saturday and was treated at a hospital and released the same day, officials said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, ISAAC
description: KAPLAN-Isaac. Beloved husband of Frieda. Devoted father of Natalie Mathison and Susan Sidewater. Dear brother of Sarah Wexler. Loving grandfather of Nicole, Jason, Jeffrey and Jessica. Fatherin-law of Donald Mathison and Jeffrey Sidewater. Service 10 AM, Tuesday, November 24, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Bertelsmann Denies EMI Merger Report
description: Bertelsmann A.G. denied a report today that it was considering a $:6 billion ($10 billion) proposal to merge with the entertainment company EMI Group P.L.C.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREIDIE, MUNIR R.
description: KREIDIE-Munir R. Retired Assistant Commissioner General of the U.N. Relief Works Agency. Died November 19, 1998, at age 84, in King of Prussia, PA. Survived by wife Lisa, sons Munir, Marwan and Hamid, daughter Linda Freiser, and two grandchildren. Graduate of Cairo and Columbia Universities, he had been associated with the United Nations from its inaugural session in San Francisco. His posts included Director of its Postal Division. He also served on the U.N. delegations of Lebanon, Saudi Arabia and Syria. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Arab-American Foundation, 918 16th St, N.W., Washington, DC 20006.

title: Political Briefing; California to Vote On Gay Marriages
description: When it comes to ballot initiatives, no state outdoes California. Got something the Legislature won't pass? Start gathering signatures.

title: The Many Davy Crocketts
description: Davy Crockett is in the news again, thanks to last week's sale of a diary by a Mexican army officer that includes a description of Crockett's execution after the battle of the Alamo in 1836.

title: THIS WEEK
description: Shifting Scenes

title: Casual About Dress, but Not Technique
description: Eighth Blackbird, a superb contemporary music sextet formed at Oberlin College in 1996, won the Concert Artists Guild Competition this year, and as part of its prize, the group was presented in its New York debut at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday evening. Its name refers to the eighth verse of the Wallace Stevens poem ''Thirteen Ways of Looking at a Blackbird.'' (The verse ends with a phrase that the ensemble must see as a motto: ''the blackbird is involved in what I know.'')

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBOWITZ, RUTH
description: JACOBOWITZ-Ruth. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue records with sorrow the death of the sister of our esteemed member Edith Cohen, and extends to her and the bereaved family our heartfelt condolences.

title: Late Night Battling With Acerbic Barbs and Goofy Tricks
description: When David Letterman is bugged about something, he doesn't let it go easily. He begins ''The Late Show With David Letterman Fifth Anniversary Special'' by noting that this special celebrates ''Five years on CBS or, if I had played my cards right, 17 years on NBC.''

title: Government Blamed for Property Glut : Too Many Cranes Spoil View of Malaysia Future
description: KUALA LUMPU  A city's vitality has often been gauged in Asia by the number of construction cranes dotting the skyline, and by that measure this city would seem to have one of the region's healthiest economies.

title: The Price of Censure; Congress's Fig Leaf
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay
description: At the House Judiciary Committee, Ken Starr succeeded in documenting the President's premeditated series of perjuries. Even The New York Times, in favoring censure over impeachment, referred to Bill Clinton's ''habitual mendacity'' (a phrase nicer than, but little different from, my old ''congenital liar'').

title: News In Future Tense
description: For all the griping about the tabloidization of American news, there's a subtler shift going on in news coverage that's arguably even more corrosive: increasingly, stories no longer report on the past, they report on the future.

title: Clinton, in South Korea, Sees 'Signs of Danger'
description: In a green aviator jacket and black cap, President Clinton spent the day today visiting American troops stationed in South Korea. He promoted a private, sang ''Happy Birthday'' to a sergeant major and described the threats to his hopes for peaceful engagement with North Korea.

title: Overthrowing Hussein: Plan Without Principle; Israelis and Iraqis
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO BASKETBALL: And the Winner Is: Apathy; N.B.A.'s Problems Won't End When the Games Begin
description: Lawrence Gould used to settle into his midcourt seat at the old Coliseum in Cleveland as if it were a favorite easy chair. It was comfortable and familiar, and it made it easy to sit through a Cavaliers loss, no matter how lopsided, as long as he was surrounded by the friends he had been cheering beside for two decades.

title: In Admissions Case, Fairness Lost
description: To the Editor:

title: '60 Minutes,' Kevorkian and a Death for the Cameras
description: It is not a gracefully composed camera shot: Dr. Jack Kevorkian blocks the camera's view as he injects his incurably ill patient, Thomas Youk, with lethal drugs. Sitting upright, wearing his glasses and a plaid shirt, Mr. Youk has been given a sedative and his head has lolled back out of camera range; perhaps because we cannot see his face, the off-camera voices commenting as they watch this videotape are more chilling than anything on screen.

title: A Livingston Legacy Revived; Speaker-to-Be Has Rich Bloodlines in North and South
description: Before the Kennedys, before the Roosevelts, before the Vanderbilts, there were the Livingstons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAGEN, ROBERT REED
description: NAGEN-Robert Reed. Died on November 22, 1998. Devoted son of Beatrice and the late Eli Nagen. Nephew of Alexander Rubin. Dear cousin of Sylvia Novick and Marilyn Resnikoff. Services Tuesday, 11 AM, Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, corner Avenue M.

title: Edwige Feuillere, an Actress Beloved in France, Dies at 91
description: Edwige Feuillere, a much-loved French actress whose 60-year career took her from sensual screen beauty to grande dame of the Paris theater, died here on Nov. 13. She was 91 and lived in Paris. She was buried on Wednesday in a family tomb at Beaugency, near Orleans.

title: Market Place; It Sliced, It Sentimentalized, but Now Can It Surf?
description: It slices! It dices! But no matter which way you cut it, K-Tel International has been keeping investors awake at night, much as its commercials for gadgets and records once did for late-night television viewers.

title: Sports of The Times; The Giants Play Out the String Without Giving Up
description: LATE November in the National Football League is a season of wildly different themes and textures. Places like Denver, Minnesota and Green Bay are bursting with variations of playoff fever; teams like the Jets, Bills, Steelers and Falcons are up to their necks in hotly contested conference races.

title: Live Testimony by Gates Would Pose Risks for Both Sides at Antitrust Trial
description: Since the case is about digital technology, it seems apt that the most heated debate in the Microsoft trial is about the virtual witness -- William H. Gates on videotape.

title: Frederick Wilkinson Jr., 77, Executive at Macy's
description: Frederick D. Wilkinson Jr., one of the first black executives at Macy's, the City of New York and, later, at the American Express Company, died at Mount Vernon Hospital on Nov. 15. He was 77.

title: Taking Two Mozartean Roles And Making Them Their Own
description: 'Nozze di Figaro'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICKMAN, HARRY
description: GLICKMAN-Harry. Of Bayside, Queens. Beloved husband of Florence. Devoted father of Robert and Jeffrey. Loving fatherin-law of Debi and Debbie. Loving grandfather of Julie, Steven, Jacob, Rachel, and Sam. President Emeritus of Starcraft Press. Devoted his great skill as an educator in graphic arts.

title: Media; A Year of Living Dangerously
description: In most industries, if a company's sales dropped 40 percent from one year to the next, not only would the chief executive be dismissed, but the company might very well go out of business.

title: Police Charge Parolee With 8 Holdups in Queens
description: A 36-year-old parolee was charged yesterday with eight armed robberies in Queens, mostly of elderly people, dating to July.

title: In Admissions Case, Fairness Lost
description: To the Editor:

title: Church and Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Media Talk; MOMA Shuts Its Doors On 'Sunday Morning'
description: This is not an abstract dispute. But it is one that might well bestir the spirit of William S. Paley.

title: Uncensored TV Coming to Russia
description: A communications satellite that will beam the first uncensored television programs into western Russia and Siberia began orbiting the Earth today after being sent into space atop an unmanned Delta 2 rocket.

title: White House Renews Push for Impeachment Deal
description: With the House moving quickly toward a series of critical decisions on whether to impeach President Clinton, the White House signaled today that it was open to any ''serious and reasonable'' compromise that would allow the President to put the yearlong scandal behind him.

title: Accounts
description: * Montana Creation S. A., Paris, to Frierson Mee & Kraft, New York, to handle the fashion house's advertising, which had been done in-house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COONEY, DAVID O.
description: COONEY-David O. In Laramie, WY, on November 20, at age 58. Professor of Chemical Engineering at the University of Wyoming. Devoted husband of Peggy, and father of Eric and Jonathan. Survived also by his father, Edward Cooney of Winchester, MA, his sister, Kathleen Corrigan of Southport, CT, several nephews and a niece. David was predeceased by his brother Edward Cooney, Jr. Memorial service November 28, 11 AM, at the University of Wyoming Concert Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EDLIN, PATRICIA CARROLL
description: EDLIN-Patricia Carroll. November 23, 1997. You are gone but not forgotten. Always in our hearts and prayers. God will keep you in his loving care forever. Loving Brothers, Pat, Eddie and Donald, and Family and Dear Friend, Ursula

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTLER, CHRISTOPHER BLAIR
description: BUTLER-Christopher Blair. Age 47, on November 21, 1998. Executive with Mobil Oil Corporation. Beloved son of W. Jack and Patricia Butler, father of Ross, and brother of Peter Butler. Memorial service to be announced. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of one's choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEPSON, EMIL
description: LEEPSON-Emil. You were a wise counselor, a valued friend and a respected mentor. You will be deeply missed. Jerrold P. Fuchs

title: Op-Art; Taking On Big Tobacco
Father Expected to Testify Against Son in Slaying Trial
description: Hostile testimony from his own father, bitter relatives of the dedicated police officer he is accused of killing, as well as a sea of blue uniforms are expected to greet Scott Schneiderman today at the opening of his trial on first-degree murder charges in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: In Prison for Three Decades, Man Is Rid of Bars, Not Fears
description: Hayes Williams is haunted by closed doors. In the long, narrow house on Lopez Street, what people here call a shotgun house, every inside door is ajar, cabinets are open, kitchen drawers are pulled half open.

title: Smaller Cable Companies Homing In on the Internet
description: Attempts to transmit Internet data over cable television wires have generally focused on only the largest cable system operators. But high-speed data options for smaller cable companies and their customers are set to expand over the next few weeks as Internet companies move into rural areas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SISSELMAN, SHIRLEY REINBERG
description: SISSELMAN-Shirley Reinberg. Of Cresskill, NJ, died peacefully in her home, Saturday morning, November 21, 1998. Shirley left behind her devoted husband Milton, loving children Robert, William and Patricia, and her grandaughters Julie and Sara. Shirley was a loving and devoted wife, mother, daughter, sister, surrogate sister, aunt, cousin and dear friend. To kindle and safeguard her spirit in our hearts, may all those fortunate to have known her join us in remembrance of a remarkable woman. Service will be held on Monday, November 23, at 1 PM, at Temple Beth El, Closter, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Shirley R. Sisselman Memorial Fund, Temple Beth El of Northern Valley, 221 Schraalenburgh Rd, Closter, NJ 07624.

title: Compressed Data; For Year 2000 Gnats, A Scented 'Bug' Spray
description: It was only a matter of time. With all the anxiety among those trying to head off computer chaos when the year 2000 arrives, some computer-savvy entrepreneur was bound to come up with a less solemn approach. And now, sure enough, a ''Y2K Bug Spray'' has appeared.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARMON, ALINE GREENEBAUM
description: MARMON-Aline Greenebaum. Age 76. Of White Plains, NY. Died Saturday, November 21, 1998, at White Plains Hospital Center. Born in NYC, Aline was the daughter of the late Milton Joseph Greenebaum, founder of Kirby Block & Co. and co-founder of P.A. Bergner's Department Stores and of the late Sylvia Samler Greenebaum of Philadelphia. She was the loving wife of the late Dr. Martin G. Marmon, a respected dermatologist of Westchester and Scarsdale who died in 1984. A 1939 graduate of the Calhoun School in NYC, she attended Skidmore College and then began working as a part-time buyer for Kirby Block & Co. until she married. She later volunteered for the American Red Cross and assisted with the bookkeeping in her husband's medical practice. She also was a member of the Phelps Memorial Hospital Women's Auxiliary. She was a member of Temple Emanu-El of Westchester. She is survived by James and Leah Marmon of Greenwich, CT; Gary and Karen Marmon of West Palm Beach, FL, and Lawrence and Beth Marmon of Larchmont, NY. She is also survived by five grandchidlren Lane, Nicole, Megan, Emily, and Andrew. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Red Cross, 106 N. Broadway, White Plains, NY 10601. Funeral services will be held Monday, November 23, 1998, at 5 PM, at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave, White Plains, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREED, HERMINE E.
description: FREED-Hermine E. Passed away on November 21, 1998. Artist, gourmet cook. Beloved wife of James Ingo Freed. Mother of Dara Michaella Freed. Sister of Alan Gerberg and Betty Weiner. Daughter of Israel Gerberg. She will last in the loving memory of her many friends and her family. Private funeral services Tuesday. Memorial services to be announced. Donations in her memory to a Leukemia Foundation of your choice are welcomed.

title: G.O.P. Leadership Isn't Diverse
description: To the Editor:

title: Saatchi to Handle New Toyota Account
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation has expanded its relationship with the Saatchi & Saatchi unit of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. by naming the agency's London office to handle the European introduction of a small car to be called Yaris. Billings were estimated at $100 million.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: America Online Said to Be In Talks to Buy Netscape

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Slain St. Petersburg Lawmaker Mourned
description: Mourners bearing flowers and candles gathered today outside the house on Griboyedova Canal where a Russian legislator, Galina V. Starovoitova, was shot to death on Friday night.

title: Clues on Sudden Infant Death Syndrome
description: Thousands of years after medical scholars believe the Bible inaccurately reported on it, scientists have begun to find real clues to Sudden Infant Death Syndrome, a medical condition that has killed millions of apparently healthy infants with the speed and stealth of a dart that leaves no trace.

title: Reno's Aides Split on Merits Of Need for Gore Prosecutor
description: Several of Attorney General Janet Reno's close aides advised her today in a private meeting at the Justice Department that Federal law required her to seek an independent counsel to investigate Vice President Al Gore's political fund-raising efforts, law-enforcement officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EARLE, VICTOR MONTAGNE
description: EARLE-Victor Montagne. Age 92, on November 21. Father of Victor III and the late MaryAnn Scatch; and grandfather of Jane, Susan and Anne Earle and John Scatch. He was active in New York City in the work of Alcoholics Anonymous and was a member of that organization for over 50 years.

title: How Fedex Made Its Pilots Blink; Culture Colored by Chairman's Resolve Overwhelms Union
description: Callers to the message line of the Federal Express pilots' union just last Thursday were reassured that the pilots had Fedex on the run.

title: NEWS
description: Art Trove

title: Abroad at Home; Pattern Of Deception
description: Kenneth Starr was a smooth witness, a seeming Mr. Straight Arrow. But when you look at what he actually said -- look at his answers to questions -- he was as straight as a corkscrew.

title: Corrections
description: A brief entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page on Thursday about an executive appointment at the new Midwest office of Brand Dialogue, a unit of Young & Rubicam, misstated the origin of the office. It was created from the interactive division of Wunderman Cato Johnson in Chicago, not from the entire Wunderman Cato Johnson operation in Chicago.

title: Why Did Dash Wait to Resign?; Suggestion of Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title: Make TV Smarter
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Observer; Faith in Stocks: The Dow Hits a Record High
description: Wall Street panicked this summer, but Main Street doubted the sky was really going to fall. So far, at least, those who kept their heads -- or at least their stocks -- have done better than those who sold.

title: A Book Award Dark Horse, but Not to Her Faithful
description: At the National Book Awards ceremony on Wednesday, all bets for the Fiction Award were on ''A Man in Full,'' Thomas Wolfe's flamboyant novel weighing in at 742 pages, full of larger-than-life characters. In case Mr. Wolfe won, his publisher, Roger Straus, the president and chief executive of Farrar, Straus & Giroux, was ready to read Mr. Wolfe's acceptance remarks for him. Mr. Wolfe was in Atlanta.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, ARNOLD
description: FRANKEL-Arnold. The Board of Directors of The City College Fund express their deepest sympathy to the family of Arnold Frankel. A graduate of the class of 1942, Mr. Frankel was a loyal and generous alumnus of City College. All of us will miss him. Stanley H. Kaplan, '39B, Chairman Herbert Robinson, '37L, President

title: Now, So Long, Bobby Simone
description: When a major character in a series is placed in mortal danger, the question is not ''Will he die?'' but ''How will he escape?'' But when Jimmy Smits decided to leave ''N.Y.P.D. Blue'' after five episodes this season, the show took full advantage of the freedom his departure offered. Mr. Smits's character, Detective Bobby Simone, has quickly faded from a heart infection and at the end of last week's episode was about to receive a transplant. The plot has energized the series with the kind of unpredictability usually limited to films.

title: By Design; Grown-Up Booties
description: Ankle-high boots -- call them booties, if you prefer -- are the perfect grounding for this winter's long skirts and trousers. Heel heights range from flat to high, to fit just about every preference.

title: Details Given On Charges Of an Attack By Detectives
description: Eleven months after a schoolteacher was attacked at a Brooklyn bar and later killed by a subway train , an indictment handed up yesterday gave details of charges that four New York City detectives carried out the attack by stomping on the man, and then tried to cover up their actions by destroying evidence and intimidating a witness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMARGO, FLORENCE S.
description: CAMARGO-Florence S. On November 22, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Ralph J. Camargo. Mother of Felice C. Meyer and Victoria Wyndham. Grandmother of Christopher P. Meyer, Darian Minnick and Christian Camargo. Sister of Helen Skeels Fowler and Herbert Skeels. Service and interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to High Ridge House, 5959 Independence Avenue, Riverdale, N.Y. 10471.

title: New York Is Assailed For Welfare Delays
description: While Federal officials pursue their inquiry into New York City's welfare program, advocates for the poor testified before a City Council committee yesterday about the difficulties poor people encounter when seeking food stamp and Medicaid applications in city welfare offices.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Media Talk column of Business Day yesterday about the Museum of Modern Art's refusal to allow a CBS segment on a major exhibition there misspelled the surname of the artist involved. (The name was also misspelled on Nov. 8 in the Dining Out column of the Connecticut section; on June 29 in a fashion review from Milan; and in an Arts & Ideas article on June 20 about the state of arts criticism in America.) The artist is Jackson Pollock, not Pollack.

title: UNION CHIEF SAYS VOTES WERE FAKED ON CITY CONTRACT
description: The executive director of the union representing 120,000 New York City municipal workers acknowledged yesterday that there was vote fraud in the 1996 ratification of his union's contract, which included an unpopular two-year wage freeze.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Media Talk column of Business Day yesterday about the Museum of Modern Art's refusal to allow a CBS segment on a major exhibition there misspelled the surname of the artist involved. (The name was also misspelled on Nov. 8 in the Dining Out column of the Connecticut section; on June 29 in a fashion review from Milan; and in an Arts & Ideas article on June 20 about the state of arts criticism in America.) The artist is Jackson Pollock, not Pollack.

title: Fassel Supports Graham And Compliments Jurevicius
description: A day later, Giants Coach Jim Fassel did not try to sell Sunday's 20-0 victory over Philadelphia as anything more than progress for a team that had been adrift. But Fassel was not letting go of what worked for his team against the Eagles either.

title: In the Realm of Early Music With Some Double-Stopping
description: Romanesca

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Still a Health Threat
description: The tobacco agreement signed yesterday by the nation's attorneys general does not drive a stake through the heart of the big tobacco companies. It does not even change the status quo dramatically. Still, it is a victory for the states and their attorneys general.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK WEAKENS. The dollar rose to a two-month high against the mark as Germany's top central banker bolstered optimism about the possibility of an interest rate cut. The dollar settled at 1.7031 marks, up from 1.6927.

title: Sensing a Storm
description: Q. Why can my dog sense when a storm is coming an hour before it arrives?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, MARGARET WOODHULL DAVISON
description: JOHNSON-Margaret Woodhull Davison, 97, at Rhinebeck, NY. Resident of Millbrook, NY and formerly of NYC. Survived by son Vansel Stanley Jr. and daughter Janice Chesebrough Lamuniere and also three grandchildren. For information Allen Funeral Home, Millbrook, NY.

title: Tyco Agrees to Buy AMP for $11.3 Billion
description: Tyco International said yesterday that it had agreed to buy AMP Inc. for $11.3 billion, or $51 a share, topping a $9.7 billion hostile takeover offer by Allied Signal for the company.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; BROAD RALLY PUTS WALL STREET BACK IN RECORD TERRAIN
description: Glee shoved gloom aside yesterday in the nation's stock markets as two of the main gauges surpassed their July peaks and reached new highs.

title: Careful Courtship Brought Bankers Trust to Deutsche Merger
description: Over the past year, companies as diverse as the Bank of New York, Mellon Bank and the State Street Corporation approached the Bankers Trust Corporation, the New York bank, about buying portions of its business.

title: Stephens Settles Bribery Cases In Florida, Paying $5.4 Million
description: Stephens Inc. agreed to pay $5.4 million to settle Federal ''pay to play'' lawsuits contending that employees of the brokerage firm had paid bribes to win municipal-bond business in Florida.

title: Hygiene Poll Bares Source Of the French Je Sais Quoi
description: The French invented perfume because they had to. In the 17th century, even Louis XIV seldom bathed.

title: A Misunderstood Artist, Counting the Idiots
description: When Danny Gold, misunderstood performance artist, does an act in Washington Square Park, the crowd is completely enchanted. They laugh; they applaud; they throw money into a hat while gazing at him with adoration. This may be too much to ask of extras.

title: Singapore Trades Hong Kong Index
description: The Singapore International and Monetary Exchange introduced its Hong Kong stock index futures today amid opposition from the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong.

title: A Medical Education for Ordinary People
description: In New York City, 2,200 people vie for the 600 seats available each night at the mini-medical school at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine to hear lectures on topics such as infectious diseases, neuroscience and physiology. The mini-medical program at the University of Colorado in Denver sells out every year. And on eight consecutive Tuesdays this fall, more than 500 people attended the mini-medical school at Emory University in Atlanta.

title: Volvo Car Unit Plans To Eliminate 1,000 Jobs
description: Volvo Cars will reduce its salaried staff by about 1,000 worldwide, a company spokesman said yesterday. The reduction may include layoffs, said Ingmar Hesslefors, head of information at Volvo Cars, a subsidiary of the Swedish auto maker Volvo A.B..

title: Uprooted Lives Grounded in Song
description: The American soprano Constance Hauman has immersed herself in the cabaret and operatic music of composers who fled the Nazis in the 1930's and wound up in Los Angeles working in the movie business. Theirs is a story of lives tragically disrupted and of artists forced to adapt their talents to commercial American tastes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERSON, THE REV. MARTIN, C.M.
description: PETERSON-The Rev. Martin, C.M. On November 23, 1998. Father Peterson served at St. John's University for many years as a librarian. He also served in the libraries of many Vincentian seminaries on the East Coast. Father is survived by his sister Margaret Papa and many nieces and nephews. Visiting Tuesday 7-9PM at St. John's University faculty residence. Mass Wednesday, 11AM, St. Vincent's Chapel in the faculty residence. Interment St. Joseph's Seminary, Princeton, N.J.

title: In a Lyric Vision, Danger Casts a Long Shadow
description: OPENED GROUND

title: BellSouth Is Seen Preparing For Next Financial Battles
description: Wall Street has been waiting months for the BellSouth Corporation to do something dramatic in response to the consolidation that is happening among phone companies all around it. So far, BellSouth has not obliged.

title: Letting the Sadness Slip Out In a Program of Sonatas
description: Kyung-Wha Chung, violinist

title: Rangers Give Start To Cloutier
description: Dan Cloutier, who has started the Rangers' last two games, is scheduled to start again against the Sabres on Wednesday. But Coach John Muckler insisted today that Mike Richter remained his No. 1 goalie.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Media Talk column of Business Day yesterday about the Museum of Modern Art's refusal to allow a CBS segment on a major exhibition there misspelled the surname of the artist involved. (The name was also misspelled on Nov. 8 in the Dining Out column of the Connecticut section; on June 29 in a fashion review from Milan; and in an Arts & Ideas article on June 20 about the state of arts criticism in America.) The artist is Jackson Pollock, not Pollack.

title: Nostalgia Vying With Glamour
description: The cries of excited recognition began at the doors of the New York State Theater as men and women of all ages swept into the theater on Sunday night, eyed by small clusters of longtime ballet fans waiting in the chill night air to see the heroes of another time. And the squeals continued inside, where some 1,100 former and current members of the New York City Ballet milled about the promenade at a dinner and party to celebrate the company's 50th anniversary. ''Totally illegal,'' Peter Martins, the director of City Ballet, said with a smile as he surveyed the crowd.

title: GE FANUC AGREES TO PURCHASE TOTAL CONTROL PRODUCTS
description: GE Fanuc Automation Inc. agreed yesterday to purchase Total Control Products Inc. for $11 a share, a total of about $100 million. It will also assume $20 million in debt. Total Control, a maker of industrial automation products, said the shareholders with about 50 percent of its outstanding stock had already agreed to tender their shares. To succeed, the offer requires the tender of at least two-thirds of the stock outstanding. GE Fanuc, maker of products to operate electrical equipment, is a joint venture of the General Electric Company and Fanuc Ltd., a Japanese industrial-machinery maker. Total Control, based in Melrose Park, Ill., earned $4.1 million on sales of $60.6 million in its latest fiscal year. Its shares rose $1.25 yesterday, to $10.75, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEPSON, EMIL
description: LEEPSON-Emil. The partners, Associates and Staff of Warshaw Burstein Cohen Schlesinger & Kuh, LLP, mourn the loss of our beloved colleague Emil Leepson. He was a renowned attorney, esteemed mentor and valued friend. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Lenore and son Peter, and his entire family.

title: 4 Brazilian Officials Resign As Bid-Rigging Scandal Erupts
