description: Four senior Government officials resigned today, scalded by accusations that two of them might have tried to influence bidding on the giant telephone system this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUNSON, LAROM B.
description: MUNSON-Larom B. The members of the Art Dealers Association of America mourn the passing of their distinguished colleague, an ADAA member since 1976. He was committed to the artists he represented and an active participant in many activities devoted to the improvement of the Sante Fe community in which his gallery was located for more than 20 years. Our deepest sympathy and condolences to his wife, Barbara, his children and his many grandchildren. Richard Gray, Pres. Gilbert S. Edelson, Admin V.P.

title: Henry Hampton Dies at 58; Produced 'Eyes on the Prize'
description: Henry Hampton, an Emmy-winning documentary filmmaker whose series ''Eyes on the Prize'' was hailed by many critics as the definitive look at the nation's early struggle over civil rights, died on Sunday in Boston. He was 58.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Crazy! Oil is produced here. We should buy oil cheaper, because we are the oil-producing community. But we pay the highest price.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEMEL, CLARA
description: SEMEL-Clara. Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, records with sorrow the passing of its member, beloved mother of our Board member, Martin Semel and extends its condolences to the bereaved family. Bruce Ginsburg, Rabbi Brian C. Rappaport, President Dr. Saul I. Teplitz, Rabbi Emeritus

title: Assembly Passes Bill On Trash-Hauling Pacts
description: Municipalities and individuals could renegotiate contracts with trash haulers to save money in the state's newly deregulated solid-waste industry under one of several bills approved by the Assembly yesterday.

title: Lawyer Admits Defendant Killed Officer, but Says It Wasn't Intentional
description: The emotionally charged trial of a 35-year-old man accused of killing a police officer after a botched attempt to rob his own father in a Chelsea penthouse in May opened yesterday with the defense conceding that the defendant, Scott Schneiderman, committed the acts of which he stands accused.

title: Waste Management Chief Has Surgery
description: Waste Management Inc. said its chief executive, John Drury, underwent surgery on Friday to remove a small tumor from his brain.

title: Why Did Dash Wait to Resign?; Rehearsal Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Did Dash Wait to Resign?; Lame Legal Point
description: To the Editor:

title: Clintons' Friend Found Not Guilty Of All 9 Embezzlement Charges
description: Susan H. McDougal, President Clinton's former partner in the Whitewater deal, was acquitted today on all nine counts that she forged checks and credit card receipts to steal $50,000 from the conductor Zubin Mehta and his wife, Nancy, and then failed to pay state income taxes on the money.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL FALLS. Oil futures plunged as members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries offered little hope of cutting production further to ease a supply glut. In New York, oil fell 44 cents, to $12.45 a barrel.

title: Pearson Receives U.S. Approval To Buy Simon & Schuster Unit
description: Pearson P.L.C., the British media conglomerate, announced yesterday that it had received Federal approval of its $4.6 billion purchase of the education unit of Simon & Schuster, but it is moving forward without a major investor, Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, which backed out of its part of the deal to buy the reference and business publishing divisions for $860 million in cash.

title: CONCORD EFS TO PURCHASE ELECTRONIC PAYMENT SERVICES
description: Concord EFS Inc., a credit card service company, agreed yesterday to acquire a smaller rival, Electronic Payment Services Inc., for about $920 million in stock. The Memphis-based Concord will buy the closely held Electronic Payment Services by issuing 32.31 million shares. The purchase will help Concord, which services supermarket chains and other retailers, expand its credit card processing business. Electronic Payment Services, based in Wilmington, Del., handles about 2.7 billion transactions annually and is currently owned by the Bank One Corporation, the First Union Corporation, Keycorp, the National City Corporation, and the PNC Bank Corporation.

title: Bledsoe Disarms Dolphins in Final Minute
description: Drew Bledsoe was throwing interceptions. The New England defenders were committing crucial face-mask penalties. This was no way for a team that was trying to keep its season alive to play.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a week-old television program listing appeared yesterday in place of the current one. (Correct listings appeared in the weekly Television section distributed on Sunday.) The Times regrets the inconvenience.

title: 18-Year-Old Takes On Some Tricky Shostakovich
description: The program in which Gerard Schwarz conducted the New York Chamber Symphony on Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall offered many attractions, not the least of them being a pair of the rugged pre-1950 American scores that have become Mr. Schwarz's specialty. But the most captivating performance, and certainly the most memorable, was an account of the Shostakovich Cello Concerto No. 1 (Op. 107), with Daniel Lee as soloist.

title: C&D TECHNOLOGIES TO ACQUIRE UNIT OF JOHNSON CONTROLS
description: C&D Technologies Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Johnson Controls Inc.'s Industrial Battery unit for $135 million in cash and assumed debt. C&D, with annual sales of $308 million, is a producer of electrical power storage and conversion products. The Milwaukee-based Johnson Controls makes automotive systems and controls. Its Industrial Battery unit has annual sales of more than $87 million. Shares of C&D rose 50 cents yesterday, to $29.25, on the New York Stock Exchange, where shares of Johnson Controls rose $3.0625, to $60.0625.

title: Why Did Dash Wait to Resign?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bankers Trust Deal Near, Deutsche Bank Confirms
description: FRANKFURT  Deutsche Bank AG said Monday it was in the final stages of forming the world's biggest financial-services firm with the acquisition of Bankers Trust Corp.

title: Condemning Our Kids to Life on Mars or Venus
description: As a mother of a 2-year-old child, I am rather too intimately acquainted with a large, purple TV dinosaur named Barney. I know the lyrics to a number of the show's exhortatory songs (my personal favorite: ''It's time to CLEAN UP! CLEAN UP! 'Cause we want to do our share!''), and I've attended to the carefully selected multisociocultural cast. The rotating group of children has included whites, blacks, Chinese, Koreans, Hispanics, Arabs, kids in wheelchairs, a blind girl, a boy with a hearing aid, chubby kids, identical twin kids.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOKAL, BLANCHE
description: SOKAL-Blanche. AMIT is deeply grieved by the passing of the beloved mother of our dear friend and supporter, Dr. Myron Sokal, and cherished mother-in-law of our most dedicated National Treasurer, Sondra Sokal. A ''True Woman of Valor,'' caring educator and consummate volunteer, Blanche Sokal epitomized the highest ideals of Torah values and piety. Heartfelt condolences to her loving children, Vivian and Myron, beloved sister Gertrude, and the entire family. Evelyn Blachor, National Pres. Marvin Leff, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  IGNATOW, ARCHIE
description: IGNATOW-Archie. Two graduations, two weddings make us miss you more than ever. Remembered with love, Gene, children and grandchildren

title: Turks Are Furious Over Rebuff From Italy on Kurd Rebel Chief
description: The Turkish Government is expected to fall this week, but the country is caught up in such an intense wave of emotion that even the fall of a Government seems almost insignificant.

title: Union's Problems Don't Taint the Mayor
description: There was that campaign television commercial in 1997 that depicted a prominent member of District Council 37 embracing the candidate, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. There was the endorsement of Mr. Giuliani's re-election that same year by the council's top official. Above all, there was the council's ratification of a city contract with a two-year pay freeze in 1996 that turned out to be a mayoral coup.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKEON, JOHN J.
description: McKEON-John J. On November 22, 1998. Husband of Catherine. Also survived by two sons, John J. and James, three brothers and five grandchildren. Mass of Christian burial 1 PM Wednesday, at St. Cecilia Church in Monmouth Jct. Visitation Tuesday, 2-4, 7-9, M.J. Murphy Funeral Home, 616 Ridge Rd. at New Road, Monmouth Jct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMPTON, HENRY
description: HAMPTON-Henry. The Board and staff of the Charles H. Revson Foundation deeply mourn the passing of our Board member, colleague, and friend, Henry Hampton. Henry brought to the craft of film making the conviction of the educator, the eye of the artist, the subtle intelligence of the historian, the determination of the inspired messenger. His masterpiece documentary of the Civil Rights era, ''Eyes on the Prize,'' will endure as the definitive visual history of that mid-twentieth century struggle, and will inform and inspire generations of young people around the world into the next century. A quiet man, whose humanism radiated from his entire being, Henry's capacity for empathy and friendship ran deep. The nation has lost a great filmmaker; those of us who knew him have also lost a respected colleague and an unforgetable friend. Charles H. Revson Foundation Robert S. Rifkind, Chairman Eli N. Evans, President

title: Incorrigible Iraq
description: Iraq has gotten off to a shaky start in honoring its latest pledge to cooperate with United Nations arms inspections. By promising Washington that it would halt all interference with the inspectors' search for biological and chemical weapons and prohibited missiles, Baghdad won a last-minute reprieve from American air and missile attacks.

title: Janet Reno's Way Out
description: Attorney General Janet Reno's resistance to the obvious need for an independent counsel on the Clinton Administration's campaign fund-raising scandals is about to be put to a series of tests. Today Ms. Reno is to rule on whether to ask for the appointment of a counsel to investigate Vice President Gore's fund-raising calls. Soon she must also decide on Harold Ickes's alleged misstatements about his own campaign role and whether the Democrats illegally used their ''soft money'' war chest. The public is weary after months of impeachment talk, but that weariness cannot be an excuse for shortchanging the rule of law.

title: VITAL SIGNS -- BEHAVIOR; Thinking, With a Wave of the Hand
description: Some people do it a lot, some hardly at all. But everybody talks with their hands sometimes, even children blind since birth, researchers have found, raising the question of whether we not only talk but also think with out hands.

title: Guam Extends Big Welcome To Clinton
description: Just for the words ''my fellow Americans,'' President Clinton received an ecstatic ovation today in a sun-soaked rally on this speck of an island in the central Pacific, a United States Territory that seemed thrilled with the Presidential recognition provided by his afternoon visit.

title: Why Did Dash Wait to Resign?; Adviser's Integrity
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 12 of Science Times today, about a study of sudden infant death syndrome, misstates the nature of the research at one point. The study was based on blood samples of infants who had some of the known risk factors for the syndrome; it was not based on autopsies.

title: Contract Passed Despite a Pay Freeze
description: Long before any allegations about vote fraud, the five-year contract negotiated for the 120,000 New York City municipal workers in District Council 37 was controversial.

title: Clues To Redwoods' Mighty Growth Emerge in Fog
description: Always an awe-inspiring sight, the giant redwoods that tower along the California coast are perhaps at their majestic best on foggy days, when these ancients, among the botanical wonders of the world, can be glimpsed through wisps of swirling mist.

title: 2 Big Assignments For Messner Vetere
description: Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG in New York has been awarded two assignments that together have combined billings estimated at $60 million to $80 million.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Metro Business; CMS Buys Into Power Plant
description: The CMS Energy Corporation has bought Consolidated Natural Gas Company's 35 percent stake in a Lakewood, N.J., power plant for an undisclosed sum, and said it might expand the plant's generating capacity to meet rising demand for electricity in the Northeast.

title: Library Can't Filter Internet, Judge Rules
description: In a decision supporting unfettered access to the Internet in public libraries, a Federal judge struck down yesterday the Loudoun County, Va., library's policy of using filtering software on all computer terminals.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Media Talk column of Business Day yesterday about the Museum of Modern Art's refusal to allow a CBS segment on a major exhibition there misspelled the surname of the artist involved. (The name was also misspelled on Nov. 8 in the Dining Out column of the Connecticut section; on June 29 in a fashion review from Milan; and in an Arts & Ideas article on June 20 about the state of arts criticism in America.) The artist is Jackson Pollock, not Pollack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, LEONORA
description: MILLER-Leonora. Dear cousin and friend. We will miss you very much. Marilyn and Shelly

title: Big British Stock Swap to Create World's Top Industrial-Controls Maker
description: In a deal that would create the world's largest maker of industrial controls and automation equipment, Siebe P.L.C. of Britain announced today that it would buy a rival engineering company, BTR P.L.C., in a $:3.7 billion, or $6.13 billion, stock swap.

title: Entergy Is Selling Australian Unit
description: The American Electric Power Company agreed today to buy the Entergy Corporation's electric distribution unit in Australia for $1.1 billion, continuing its push to expand in that nation.

title: Mexico Rebels Turn Down Peace Proposal
description: At the end of three days of rocky peace meetings, a Government representative tried today to deliver new peace proposals directly to top rebel commanders here but was rebuffed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, WARREN H.
description: SMITH-Warren H., 93, of Geneva, N.Y. and formerly of New Haven, CT. Died peacefully at home on November 22, 1998. An editor, author and philanthropist, he devoted his life to editing the letters of Horace Walpole at the Yale Library and to interests in local history, libraries and Hobart and William Smith colleges in Geneva. Services will be held Wednesday, November 25th, at 10 AM at Trinity Church, Geneva, N.Y. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Geneva Free Library, 244 Main St., Geneva, N.Y. 14456

title: He Keeps Cars and Helps Others
description: No, he has not sold the Mercedes.

title: Yeltsin, Back in Hospital, Meets China Leader
description: After six weeks of labored effort to rebound from bronchitis, most of it spent at resorts and dachas far from the Kremlin levers of power, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia developed a high fever and pneumonia on Sunday and spent today in Moscow's best hospital.

title: Helping AIDS Patients Have Safer Sex
description: The patient was running late; he was due at work in 20 minutes and didn't have time to chat, but he did need the doctor's help with a couple of quick problems.

title: Little Diplomacy in Malaysia
description: To the Editor:

title: Rome ... Paris ... Capri ... Condoms ...
description: The adage ''when in Rome . . .'' may be more likely to describe women than men, according to a study of British travelers published in the current issue of The Lancet.

title: State Board Says Spitzer Holds a Lead
description: Calling its count of machine and paper ballots in the race for attorney general virtually complete, the State Board of Elections said yesterday that Eliot L. Spitzer remained in the lead, with 21,191 more votes than Dennis C. Vacco, the Republican incumbent.

title: It's Never Too Late to Be a Surfer Chick
description: I spent my youth on a beach in Southern California gazing out to sea, where my brother or my boyfriends surfed some of the best waves in the world. Clad in a string-bikini and puka shells, I carefully timed my tanning sessions and applied lemon juice to my sun-bleached hair, which insured me the identification of ''surfer chick,'' even though I had never ridden a board.

title: Death 'Appeared a Homicide,' State Says
description: The nationally televised death of a Michigan man at the hands of Dr. Jack Kevorkian appeared to be a homicide, the prosecuting attorney in Pontiac, Mich., said yesterday, but a decision on whether to prosecute Dr. Kevorkian will not rest on televised excerpts of the videotapes.

title: Kula Journal; Oil Wells, Oil Wells Everywhere; Scarce Gasoline
description: At ease in a speedboat shooting up a narrow mangrove creek in the Niger Delta, Anthony Diepiriye, fuel smuggler, could not stop grinning.

title: Open Door for a Neighbor, But With No Welcome Mat
description: St. John's biggest November game in years looms tomorrow, but last night the Red Storm had to take care of local business. St. John's had been criticized for scheduling just two area teams in the previous season, fueling the perception that it fears it has too much to lose in local nonconference games. This season, the Red Storm has five opponents within a short bus ride, and the first beneficiary of its good-neighbor policy was Columbia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, DOROTHYE
description: FRIEDMAN-Dorothye. Young Israel of Harrison mourns the passing of Dorothye Friedman, beloved mother of its devoted member, Elayne Riskin, and extends its heartfelt condolences to Elayne and Marty. Yaakov Bienenfeld, Rabbi Ed Leventhal, President

title: Cost of Mental Illness
description: To the Editor:

title: Patterns
description: Leaving 'Irrelevant' London

title: Rally Produces Records as Mergers Feed Enthusiasm
description: Stock prices vaulted to record levels yesterday, furthering a recovery that as recently as two months ago seemed nearly unthinkable.

title: Metro Business; Gas Workers Strike as Contract Expires
description: About 300 union workers at the NUI Corporation's Elizabethtown Gas Company unit have gone on strike because of a dispute over the company's proposal to outsource some work and other issues, according to NUI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAREY, WILLIAM P. JR., MD.
description: CAREY-William P. Jr., MD. The residents, staff and faculty of the Ronald O. Perelman Department of Dermatology at New York University Medical Center mourn the sudden, tragic death of our alumnus. Bill graduated from the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine and was an outstanding member of our 1998 residency class. At the time of his accidental death he was a Fellow in Dermatopathology at the University of Pennsylvania with a brilliant career awaiting him. We share this great sorrow with Bill's wife Lisa, his parents, family and friends. Irwin M. Freedberg, M.D. MacKee Professor and Chairman

title: A Cultural Windfall Sets a City Astir; $50 Million Gift for Performing Space
description: Onstage between songs during a recent concert at the Civic Center here, Lyle Lovett was seeking a way to explain to the audience why he likes coming to Madison. It's friendly, he said. Accommodating. That afternoon, he said, he and his girlfriend were walking along State Street, the main thoroughfare connecting the University of Wisconsin campus and the State Capitol.

title: Study Casts Doubt on the Benefits of S.A.T.-Coaching Courses
description: The College Board, sponsor of the S.A.T., the nation's leading college entrance exam, has found in a comprehensive new study that test preparation courses, a multimillion-dollar industry, fail to produce anything other than minimal score increases.

title: Of a Gallic Intensity In the Spirit of Piaf
description: Karen Akers

title: A Megadeal In PC-Land Now?
description: On the surface, it seems odd for high-tech companies like America Online, Netscape Communications and Sun Microsystems to be talking this week about mergers and the redistribution of products just when the Microsoft Corporation seems to be struggling so in the antitrust suit being tried in Washington.

title: South Korea to End Pohang's Steel Monopoly
description: South Korea said yesterday that it would end the state-run Pohang Iron and Steel Company's three-decade monopoly of the primary steelmaking business by allowing competition for the first time. Pohang makes steel from iron ore, unlike the nation's 13 other steelmakers, which use scrap as their base and employ electric arc furnaces. It used its monopoly to become the world's second-largest steelmaker, after the Nippon Steel Company of Japan.

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: Bouncing and Rapping On City Streets

title: Muckler Has His Health and Hockey
description: John Muckler suspects that getting fired as general manager of the Buffalo Sabres may have saved his life. This was in 1997, around the time he lost sight in his right eye during a scouting trip to Regina, Saskatchewan. The vision returned after about 10 seconds, so Muckler did not tell many people about the episode. But after he lost his job, Muckler took his wife's advice to get a routine eye test. When he told the doctor about the temporary blindness, the doctor put his hand on a carotid artery in Muckler's neck.

title: Iraq Gets Reprieve as U.S. Tries Policy of Patience
description: A week after threatening rapid and unannounced military action if Iraq failed to cooperate fully with arms inspections, the Clinton Administration has adopted a more cautious policy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, JANET
description: FISHMAN-Janet. Our dear neighbor and friend, we will always remember her intellect, wit and joie de vivre. Our deepest sympathy to Steve, Alexandra, Josh, and the entire Fishman and Klausner family. Ina, Stan, Barrett and Darren Lane

title: Board of E.spire Ousts Its Chief Executive
description: Jack E. Reich, the chief executive and president of E.spire Communications Inc., resigned yesterday, less than three weeks after the small but fast-growing communications carrier announced disappointing financial results for the third quarter.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PRO & CON; When to Say When To Breast-Feeding
description: Q. The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends that babies be breast-fed for at least one year and beyond ''for as long as mutually desired.'' Do you agree? DOROTHY J. BARNHOUSE

title: N.B.A. Talks Set for Saturday
description: National Basketball Association management and the players' union will not meet for their next bargaining session until Saturday, which makes it virtually certain that the season will not start before the beginning of next year.

title: Germany Irks U.S. on NATO Atom Policy
description: As NATO defines the new strategy it will unveil on its 50th anniversary next year, Germany's new Government of Social Democrats and Greens has irked the United States by tentatively suggesting that NATO should renounce the possible first use of nuclear weapons.

title: Courting Women Big and Small
description: The name Max Mara doesn't resonate with American women the way Giorgio Armani's does, but the Max Mara company outsells Armani around the world. At last count, it was $906 million to $846 million annually. Why? Because the clothes offer timely fashion in luxury fabrics at less than astronomical prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANDSEN, ELVIND
description: FRANDSEN-Elvind. Died on November 20, 1998. Beloved husband of Birgitta (Bitten). Mr. Frandsen worked as a Treasurer and Personnel Director for the New York office of Maersk, Inc. Shipping Company of Denmark. Then, when retired, he managed their Bermuda office for several years. Services will be held in Denmark at a later date.

title: A Tribute Without Words: Remembering the Rhythms
description: 'Soul Serenade'

title: Condom-Adorned Christmas Tree Canceled
description: A plan to raise a Christmas tree adorned with condoms in the Central Park skating rink for an AIDS-prevention event was canceled yesterday after a Catholic group urged the rink's private operator not to allow the tree, the group said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAILEY, DOLORES (NEE MAZZOTTI)
description: BAILEY-Dolores (nee Mazzotti). Died at her home in Manhattan on November 23, 1998 at age 62. She is survived by Earl (Bill) Bailey, her husband of 32 years. Born in Syracuse, N.Y., she spent her childhood in Patchogue, N.Y. A graduate of City University of New York, she made a career in the computer systems field and retired as a Vice President of the Equitable Life Assurance Society in 1991. Service and interment private. Donations can be made in her memory to The Endowment for English Language Learning Programs, The New York Public Library, 5th Ave at 42nd Street, New York, New York 10018.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Curing the Iron-Poor

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in some editions on Friday about an appearance by Robert De Niro and Harvey Keitel at New York City's third annual Juror Appreciation Day misstated their experiences on jury duty this year. Mr. De Niro was not chosen for a jury, but he was impaneled. Mr. Keitel was chosen, but the case settled before his jury had a chance to deliberate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, KLAUSNER, JANET, DR.
description: FISHMAN-KLAUSNER-Janet, Dr. Beloved wife of Stephen, devoted mother of Alexandra, loving daughter of Sarah Fishman, dear sister of Sheila Natale and Jack Fishman. Services on Wednesday, 9 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: 44 Mexico City Policemen Held in Graft Case
description: In an anticorruption crackdown ordered by Mexico City's new police chief, detectives arrested 44 city officers today on charges that include extortion, abuse of authority, murder and rape.

title: Assembly Votes to Create Panel to Examine Salaries of Lawmakers, Judges, and the Governor
description: Moving with a nervousness and stealth exhibited only by lawmakers about to grant themselves a pay raise, the New Jersey State Assembly yesterday voted to establish a commission to review the salaries of all three branches of state government, including the Legislature itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSER, MAX
description: WEISSER-Max. 88. A well known trial attorney in the state of New York. Died on Sunday, November 22, 1998 at Ormond Beach Memorial Hospital. He was born and raised in New York City and was graduated from St. John's University and Brooklyn Law School. He served in the U.S. Army during WWII. Mr. Weisser was in Daytona Beach for several months visiting with his brother Herman M. (Hy) Weisser, the builder and former owner of the Desert Inn Resort Hotel in Daytona Beach and sisterin-law Betty Jane Boone (Weisser), a retired nationally known realtor and a former Daytona Beach City Commissioner, as well as other local friends. Services will be held Wednesday, 1:30PM, at Louis Hirsch & Sons, 1225 Jerome Avenue at 167 Street, Bronx.

title: After Objections to a Book, A Teacher Is Transferred
description: A teacher at a Brooklyn elementary school was transferred yesterday after parents complained that a book she was using was racially insensitive, education officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUBEN, OSCAR
description: HAUBEN-Oscar. Age 93. On November 18, 1998. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. A Holocaust survivor who managed successfully to bring his family to the U.S. and build a shoe business and a comfortable and loving home. He was adored by his family and he will be greatly missed. He is survived by his wife Frida Hauben, daughter Cyla Klein and son-inlaw Neal Klein, son Ben Hauben and daughter-in-law Lana Hauben and grandchildren Michael and Jeffrey Klein, Alissa Appel, Laura and Jill Hauben, and Jonathan and Alan Goodman.

title: Little Diplomacy in Malaysia; Who's Rude Now?
description: To the Editor:

title: Conquering the Internet
description: With its proposed purchase of the Netscape Communications Corporation, America Online Inc., the nation's largest on-line service, hopes to beat the Microsoft Corporation in the race for dominance of on-line media and electronic commerce.

title: Why Did Dash Wait to Resign?; Improper Rebuke
description: To the Editor:

title: Kiss And Makeup: The Act
description: Perched on a chair at the Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., on Sunday night, a small boy in a black fright wig and silver makeup watched the fireworks. His companion, probably his father, excitedly snapped photographs of the four living wonders onstage: the bassist dressed as a dragon, the singer with the star painted over his eye, the spaceman guitarist and the feline drummer. The boy just stood quietly, taking it all in. This must have been his first Kiss concert, his initiation into the fellowship of rock-and-roll.

title: For Tobacco Stocks, a Session of Surges
description: With the $206 billion tobacco settlement freshly signed and record price increases looming, shareholders who have come this far may be wondering what's next for tobacco stocks?

title: Doctors Who See the Benefit of Clergy
description: It seems that sometimes even doctors refer to a higher authority. Eighty percent of 438 family physicians who participated in a University of Kansas survey say that at one time or another they have advised patients to seek religious counsel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURTZ, IRVING
description: KURTZ-Irving, 87. Prominent Civil Engineer & businessman in the structural steel business on Long Island for 40 years. Died in Palm Beach, Florida on November 5, 1998. He is survived by his wife Tilly, children Harold, Robert and Phyllis, grandchildren Pamela, Mark, Rachel, Daniel and Abigail and sister Reba Knopp.

title: Mets Lose As Jordan Joins Braves
description: As expected, Brian Jordan wound up signing with the Atlanta Braves, agreeing yesterday to what is believed to be a five-year, $40 million deal.

title: Livery Driver Is Accused Of Assaulting a Woman
description: A 47-year-old woman was held captive for five hours by a livery-cab driver who then dragged her into Central Park and sexually assaulted her early yesterday, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, IRVING
description: KATZ-Irving. Born May 22, 1913, died November 22 at age 85. Retired from the U.N. since 1974. He is well remembered for excellence in linguistics and his vast knowledge of history. He is missed by his wife of 51 years, Elaine, son Robert, daughter-in-law Florence, and two granddaughters, Laura and Alison. Services today, 10 AM ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Europe Votes To Let British Resume Sale Of Their Beef
description: The European Union voted today to lift its 32-month-old worldwide ban on Britain's beef exports, saying that the country had finally put sufficient measures in place to halt the spread of ''mad cow disease.''

title: Transit Agency Has an Enviable Problem: Too Much Cash
description: For an agency that has been maligned for decades as a worst-case study in corporate inefficiency, New York City Transit has an oddly recurrent problem: the custodian of subways and buses is making a profit.

title: Iraq Writes U.N. a 3d Time Explaining Why It's Resisting
description: For the third time since international arms inspectors returned to Iraq last week, Baghdad sent the Security Council a letter today explaining why President Saddam Hussein has no intention of giving the inspectors documents they are seeking to round out their knowledge of his weapons programs.

title: Teachers Fight for Darwin's Place in U.S. Classrooms
description: Cissy Bennett, a high school biology teacher in Birmingham, Ala., has to use a textbook with a disclaimer in it.

title: A Composer in Control Of Saxophone Nuances
description: There's rigor throughout the pieces Julius Hemphill wrote for saxophone choirs. The composer, who died in 1995 at the age of 57, had perfect control; there are no accidents in his work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAKULA, ALAN J.
description: PAKULA-Alan J. The 188,000 members of the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill and its Campaign to End Discrimination extend their condolences to the family of Alan J. Pakula and especially to his wife, Hannah. With his stepson, Robert Boorstin, Mr. Pakula brought the story of his family's successful struggle with mental illness to important new audiences. We are grateful for the efforts of this generous and compassionate man, and we will echo his strong voice in carrying forward the message of fairness for people with mental illness. Laurie Flynn, Exec. Dir. Jackie Shannon, Pres., Board of Directors Rona Purdy, Campaign Chair

title: 2 Leading U.S. Disability Insurers Plan Merger
description: Creating a disability insurer that will dominate the business, the UNUM Corporation and the Provident Companies agreed yesterday to merge in a deal that valued Provident at $4.75 billion.

title: Latest Bankruptcy Filing Threatens Services at H.M.O.
description: Efforts to maintain uninterrupted services to the 194,000 customers of the financially troubled H.I.P. Health Plan of New Jersey hit a new roadblock today when the company providing medical services to the plan's members sought to liquidate itself in bankruptcy court.

title: Culture Clash Seen in Merger Of Companies
description: When Marc Andreessen and his fellow whiz kids from the University of Illinois arrived in Silicon Valley in 1994 to found the Netscape Communications Corporation, the brash new darling of the digerati was the antithesis of America Online, widely perceived as a shelter for technical ''newbies'' unprepared for the brave new world of the Net.

title: Meredith Gourdine, 69, Athlete and Physicist
description: Meredith (Flash) Gourdine, the 1952 Olympic silver medalist in the long jump and later an engineer and physicist with 70 patents that deal with thermal management and the conversion of gas to electricity, died Friday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Houston. He was 69.

title: West Side Man Is Found Fatally Shot in Head
description: A 37-year-old Manhattan man was found fatally shot through the head on the couch in his apartment on the West Side yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: New Data Help Explain Crystals That Defy Nature
description: A team of physicists has found evidence that a new kind of atomic jigsaw puzzle, in which identical puzzle pieces are allowed to overlap each other to form complex structures, may explain why a peculiar class of compounds exists in defiance of long established geometric rules.

title: Jacksonville Adds Spice To a Tight Tournament
description: N.C.A.A. MEN

title: Police Union Pickets Over Abrupt Transfers
description: The city's police union staged a series of demonstrations outside 10 station houses yesterday to protest the abrupt transfer of about 100 patrol officers last month. The union said they were unfairly reassigned as a disciplinary measure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, JACK
description: COHEN-Jack. Young Israel of Manhattan records with profound sorrow the passing of its member and former president in Israel. Condolences to his widow, Ida, and the bereaved family.

title: Et Tu, New Jersey Nets?; Meadowlands Sports Complex Faces Franchise Unrest
description: For generations, New Jersey officials have excelled at peddling their proximity to Manhattan, using the promise of tax abatements, new buildings and ample parking to lure New York businesses and sports franchises west of the Hudson.

title: NFO WORLDWIDE BUYS GERMAN MARKET RESEARCH COMPANY
description: NFO Worldwide Inc., the largest custom market research company in the United States, bought a closely held German company, Infratest Burke, for $120 million in cash. The transaction will create the world's sixth-largest market research firm. NFO, based in Greenwich, Conn., also assumed $28 million in Infratest debt and will pay $3 million more in the next two and a half years for Infratest, which has annual sales of about $165 million. NFO said in October that it planned to expand into international markets. The combined company will operate in 31 countries and have more than 13,000 full- and part-time employees. Shares of NFO, which changed its name from NFO Research last month, rose $1, to $8.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSSMAN, HERBERT J.
description: ROSSMAN-Herbert J. On November 22, 1998 of Franklin Lakes, N.J. formerly of Long Island. Beloved husband of Miriam (nee Fanelli). Devoted father of Janet Baron, Ellen Rossman, Richard H. Rossman, and Robert J. Rossman. Dear brother of Dorothy Martens, Charles Rossman, and Raymond Rossman. Also survived by four grandchildren. Funeral Wednesday from Vander Plaat-Vermeulen Memorial Home, 530 High Mountain Rd, Franklin Lakes, N.J. at 9:30AM and Funeral Mass at Most Blessed Sacrament R.C. Church, Franklin Lakes, 10AM. Cremation at the convenience of the family. The family will receive their friends on Tuesday, 2-4 and 79PM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Transplant Foundation, 2000 Hamilton Drive, Suite 201, Philadelphia, PA 19130 in memory of Herb Rossman.

title: New Hotel for Times Square Gets European Financing
description: Three European banks will finance the construction of a 455-room hotel to be built on top of an entertainment and retail complex in Times Square, state officials announced yesterday.

title: Bias Recedes, Letting Jews Look Inward
description: SENIOR figures from American Jewish groups, including a large New York contingent, gathered last week in Jerusalem for a conference with a recurring theme that could have been borrowed from the old ''Pogo'' comic strip: 'We have met the enemy and he is us.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORGERON, VIOLET
description: FORGERON-Violet. Of Baldwin, Long Island. On November 21, 1998. Beloved wife of Harry Forgeron (Retired Sports Makeup Editor of The New York Times). Loving mother of Bonnie Ryan, Anita Zaccardi, Laura Warren and Robert E. Forgeron. Dearest sister of Carl Vossberg. Dear sister-inlaw of Charlotte and Robert N. Forgeron. Also survived by five grandchildren and several nieces & nephews. Reposing at Weigand Bros. Funeral Home, 2283 Grand Avenue, Baldwin. Visiting Tuesday 2-4PM and 7-9PM. Funeral Wednesday 10AM. Cremation at Fresh Pond Crematory, Middle Village, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Leukemia Society or The American Heart Association would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARFINKEL, GEORGE J.
description: GARFINKEL-George J. Of Fairfield, N.J. and Boca Raton, FL. On Friday, November 20, 1998 from Gutterman's Funeral Chapel, Hackensack, N.J. Loving father of Lynn Gaines and Peter Garfinkel. Also survived by his sister Florence Shustak, brother Stanley Garfinkel and four grandchildren. He was the owner of Cater-Mat Systems, Fairfield, N.J.

title: Nicotine Anxiety
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, PATRICIA MURDOCK
description: DAVIS-Patricia Murdock, age 65, died on November 21st, 1998 in Scarborough, NY. Loving wife of Robert W., beloved mother of Thomas O. Williams, Jr., Phoenix, Md and Marjorie W. Vandenberg, Rye, NY. Also survived by her adored brother John J. Murdock, III of London, a wonderful daughter and son-in-law Nancy and Fred, as well as her second-tonone sister-in-law Elizabeth. She also leaves five cherished grandchildren, Lindsey and Owen Williams and Halsey, Jeremy and Rebecca Vandenberg as well as three dear nieces Merrick Greenhaus of Reston, VA., Lee Murdock of San Antonio, Tx. and Bronwen Murdock of London, England. She was the daughter of the late Marjorie and Abraham Bienstock and the late John J. Murdock, Jr. A memorial service will be held at St. Mary's Church, Rt. 9, Scarborough, NY on Saturday, December 12th, at 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations in her name to the Putnam County Children's Committee, P.O. Box 187, Carmel, NY 10512, will be greatly appreciated.

title: Villanova Women Narrowly Win Title
description: In the closest three-way race ever, the Villanova women's team won the National Collegiate Athletic Association cross-country title for the seventh time in 10 years yesterday in Lawrence, Kan.

title: Accounts
description: * Allegro Resorts Corp., Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, to Yesawich, Pepperdine & Brown, Orlando, Fla., to handle advertising and sales promotion, which had been handled on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $7 million to $9 million.

title: Thais Weigh Increase In Government Spending
description: Thailand is considering a plan to increase Government spending -- widening its 1999 budget deficit to more than 3.5 percent of economic output -- in an attempt to raise incomes in the country, a top aide to the Prime Minister said yesterday. The Government of Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai will propose the increase next week to the International Monetary Fund, said Abhisit Vejjajiva, Minister to the Office of the Prime Minister.

title: Boy, 12, Is Released After a 12-Hour Standoff
description: A 12-hour hostage standoff in Brooklyn ended peacefully early yesterday when a distraught man released his ex-wife's nephew and surrendered, the police said.

title: 3 at Riney to Open Rubin Postaer Office
description: Three top executives from the Chicago office of Publicis & Hal Riney, part of Publicis S. A., have left to open an office in Chicago on Jan. 4 for Rubin Postaer & Associates.

title: Sports of The Times; Imbalance In Baseball Costs George
description: HOW can the New York Yankees not be worth, say, four times as much as the new Cleveland Browns? The answer to a question I continue to hear and have wondered about myself is found in a subtext to the widely speculated sale of George Steinbrenner's team.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: For Pavarotti And the Met, 30 Years Of High C's
description: As a cultural icon and a partner in The Three Tenors Inc., Luciano Pavarotti has been doing just fine in recent years. But his appearances in opera during this period have been another story, even at the Metropolitan, where he has sung, to date, 359 performances in 20 roles, more than with any other company.

title: A Day for Mergers, With $40 Billion in Play
description: It looks like the old days are back. The heady mergers-and-acquisitions wave that crashed in August has returned in full force, with nine combinations worth $40.4 billion either announced or under negotiation yesterday.

title: Stanford Is Building On the Four-Year Plan
description: As the clock wound down on Stanford's 76-51 victory over Southwest Missouri State on Friday night, the rambunctious student section at Maples Pavilion decided to give its team a proper send-off to one of basketball's biggest stages. It began chanting, ''New York City! New York City!''

title: How Much Therapy Is Enough? It Depends
description: In 1946, two Chicago psychoanalysts, Dr. Franz Alexander and Dr. Thomas French, observed that while some of their patients required years of therapy, others got better after much briefer treatment, sometimes even ''as the result of a few consultations.'' The therapist's task, the analysts asserted in ''Psychoanalytic Therapy,'' should be to provide ''flexible'' and ''efficient'' treatment, ''adjusted to the individual nature of the great variety of neurotic patients.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'AMICO, MABEL
description: D'AMICO-Mabel. In Amagansett, NY on November 22, 1998. The Board of Trustees of The Victor D'Amico Institute of Art/The Art Barge mourn the loss of Mabel D'Amico. We will sadly miss her inspiration and creative energy. Burial service at Cedar Lawn cemetery, Easthampton, NY on November 28, 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Art Barge, PO Box 1266, Amagansett, NY 11930. C. Kohan, President of the Board of Trustees, The Art Barge

title: Microsoft Says Proposed Netscape Deal Supports Its Case
description: The Microsoft Corporation argued in Federal court today that the proposed acquisition of the Netscape Communications Corporation by America Online seriously undermined the Government's antitrust suit against the software giant.

title: Banta Going to Big Board
description: The Banta Corporation, a printing and digital-imaging concern, received formal approval today to switch its stock to the New York Stock Exchange from Nasdaq, starting next month. Banta, which has a market value of $744.8 million, said its shares would begin trading on the Big Board on Dec. 18. Banta provides printing and digital-imaging services to publishers of educational and general books, special-interest magazines, consumer and business catalogues and direct-marketing material.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUELS, ARTHUR
description: SAMUELS-Arthur. Age 94. Loved by family and friends. Died November 22, 1998. He is survived by his beloved wife Lotte Samuels, two sons, Arthur Jr., Lee and five grandchildren. Interment private.

title: Akzo Nobel Shares Jump On Report of Asset Sale
description: The shares of Akzo Nobel N.V. of the Netherlands jumped yesterday after a British newspaper reported that the company, Europe's No. 6 chemical maker, planned to sell a recently acquired packaging unit to Schroder Ventures, the venture capital operation of Schroders P.L.C. of London. The unit had been part of the British chemical company Courtaulds P.L.C., which Akzo Nobel bought in the summer.

title: Cigarette Makers Announce Large Price Rise
description: Smokers will soon feel the effect of the new $206 billion tobacco settlement deal, as leading cigarette makers said yesterday that they would raise wholesale prices by the largest amount in history.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Georgia's High Court Voids Sodomy Law
description: Twelve years after the United States Supreme Court upheld Georgia's anti-sodomy statute in a landmark decision, Georgia's own Supreme Court invalidated the law today by ruling that private consensual sodomy between adults is protected under privacy rights guaranteed by the State Constitution.

title: Little Diplomacy in Malaysia; The Easy Shot
description: To the Editor:

title: China May Sell Bonds Soon, Bankers Say
description: China may begin to sell as much as $1 billion of international bonds this week, its first such sale in more than a year, according to bankers close to the planning. China is mulling over whether to proceed with the bond sale -- originally announced in June and then delayed as Asian and European markets tumbled -- and will probably make a decision today, the bankers said yesterday.

title: More Mergers
description: TYCO BUYING AMP -- Tyco, the No. 1 maker of security systems, agreed to buy AMP for $11.3 billion, topping Allied Signal's hostile $9.7 billion offer for the company. Page 11.

title: Police Search Yields Nothing In Gacy Case
description: More than two decades after his arrest and four years after his execution, the serial killer John Wayne Gacy again captured the attention of this city today as the Chicago Police Department dug up the yard of an apartment building where they believed more of his victims may have been buried.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Soar to Records On Investors' Optimism

title: Baby's Death Attributed To Accidental Crushing
description: A baby girl who died in a cramped Newark apartment on Sunday appears to have been crushed when her mother rolled on top of her while they slept on a couch, the police said yesterday.

title: Turkey Brought Kurdish Problem on Itself
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Fan's Pitches Before the Serves

title: A Hero Identifies
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Tape of Death Is Sought

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLEHER, RUTH
description: KELLEHER-Ruth. Dearly loved wife of Joseph died quietly in his arms on November 15, 1998 in Florida. She passionately loved cooking, New York, theater and politics. Ruth will be sorely missed by her husband, close friends, son Cameron, daughter Loren, granddaughter Ariel and her cherished cat Shadow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNARD, BOBBY
description: BERNARD-Bobby. Of New York City and Margate, NJ. Died after a lengthy illness on November 22, in New York City. He was born in New York City and a graduate of Boston University and Emerson College. He was a theatrical manager for most of his life and retired eight years ago. He lived in Lowell, Mass for many years before moving to New York City in 1949. He was a summer resident of Margate, NJ for the past 40 years. He is survived by his wife, Rosita, his son, David of Jackson, NJ and four grandchildren. Funeral services will be Tuesday, 12 noon, at the John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Ave., NYC. Interment New Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Bklyn, NY.

title: Light Sentence In Mercy Death Is Overturned In West Canada
description: An appeals court today overturned a light sentence in a mercy killing case and ruled that a Saskatchewan farmer, Robert Latimer, must serve at least 10 years in prison for killing his 12-year-old daughter, Tracy.

title: Connecticut Cuts a Risky Deal
description: When Connecticut Gov. John Rowland offered the New England Patriots a sweet deal to build a $350 million stadium in Hartford last week, he must not have done his research about the many sweet deals in the National Football League.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMINSKY, MARTIN
description: KAMINSKY-Martin. On Nov. 22, 1998, at age 77. Loving husband to Anita and cherished husband to the late Lorraine Kaminsky. Devoted father to Eileen Galindez, Mitchell, Paula Davis, and David. Loving brother to Diane. Also survived by loving grandchildren and great grandchildren. Services were held at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', on Monday, November 23, and interment was at New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: 3 Female TV Executives Plan to Create Cable Channel for Women
description: Oxygen Media, the cable television and on-line company formed by Geraldine Laybourne, the former president of Nickelodeon, has entered into a partnership with Oprah Winfrey and the Carsey-Werner-Mandabach Company to create a cable television network aimed at women.

title: Dismaying Experts, H.I.V. Infections Soar
description: AIDS virus infections worldwide have risen 10 percent over the past year, showing a disturbing lack of progress in prevention, the United Nations AIDS Program in Geneva said in a report issued yesterday. The document, released as a prelude to World AIDS Day on Dec. 1, also reported that the spread is largest among young people and more women are becoming infected.

title: Reduce Class Size
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting Family Life Ahead of a Senate Seat
description: IN the political scrum set off by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan when he announced earlier this month that he would not seek re-election in 2000, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. was an obvious choice for the seat. It was once held by his father, he is one of the most visible environmental lawyers in the state, and his last name is Kennedy. But Mr. Kennedy, 44, said almost immediately that he would not run because he wanted to see his five children grow up.

title: Drunk on Liquid Candy, U.S. Overdoses on Sugar
description: If you're looking for a growth market to invest in during these economically volatile times, try the soft drink industry. Consumption of what the Center for Science in the Public Interest calls ''liquid candy'' in a new report has outpaced that of every other beverage, with per capita consumption of soft drinks by Americans doubling in the last quarter century and increasing by 43 percent since 1985.

title: Odd Couple of Cyberspace
description: America Online's possible purchase of Netscape shows how much the gulf between Internet sophisticates and neophytes has narrowed. Page C1.

title: Little Diplomacy in Malaysia; Public Relations Visit
description: To the Editor:

title: Ticktock: The Flying Boy and His Shadow
description: It was during the ''Ugg-a-Wugg'' Indian number that the little girl in the rainbow-colored cardigan turned and flashed me the A-O.K. sign. I might have been quick to suspect her as an audience plant by the ''Peter Pan'' public relations people. Except that she was my own daughter.

title: From the department of old dogs and new, on-line tricks that need the old dogs' expertise.
description: IN another demonstration of the blurring of the lines between on-line and off-line advertising and media realms, a leading Internet marketer is naming the world's ninth-largest agency to handle duties ranging from global brand-building to creating campaigns for television, magazines and newspapers.

title: Thyssen and Dover in $1.1 Billion Deal
description: Thyssen A.G., the fifth-largest elevator and escalator maker in the world, said today that it had agreed to buy the elevator business of the Dover Corporation for $1.1 billion as it seeks to expand in North America.

title: Some Depressions Aren't So Bad
description: A s the Dow Jones industrial average surged yesterday past the peak it reached last July, I was reminded of the English historian A. J. P. Taylor's remark that the only thing men learn from history is how to make new mistakes. Nothing demonstrates how easy it is to draw the wrong lessons from the past than the overheated talk of a second Great Depression following the short-lived drop in the stock market last summer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTRAUB, RUTH
description: WEINTRAUB-Ruth on November 22, 1998. Beloved wife of Paul, loving mother of Susan Goldfarb and Roy Weintraub, cherished grandmother of Robin, Adam, Allison, Traci and John, sister of Lillian Treach and Bill Schiff. Funeral services on Tuesday at 11:00 AM, at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck at 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the heritage of the Livingston family in the Hudson Valley was published in error in some copies. The pictures, with the continuation of the article, actually showed two signs and a stone marker from Columbia County, N.Y., commemorating the family and its founder, Robert R. Livingston. (The erroneous caption, referring to Mr. Livingston and his descendant Robert L. Livingston, who is about to become the Speaker of the House, was intended for a different picture grouping, in the national edition.)

title: $4 Billion Deal Would Arm Microsoft Rivals for Business Battle on Net : AOL Says It's Seeking to Buy Netscape
description: America Online Inc. said Monday it was negotiating to buy Netscape Communications Corp., the Internet-browsing software pioneer, in a $4 billion deal that would provide the leading on-line service with a powerful arsenal in its quest to dominate business on the Net.

title: Public Health Group Debates Managed Care
description: Members of the American Public Health Association -- some 14,000 doctors, nurses, educators and administrators in the nation's largest group of public health-care workers -- convened in Washington last week to answer two questions: Has managed care given the country the health care it needs at a price it can afford? And if not, can it be fixed?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, BETTY
description: FELDMAN-Betty, of Bal Harbour, Florida, formerly of Forest Hills, New York, age 91, on November 22. Beloved wife of the late Sidney Feldman. Much loved mother of Joan, Robert and Linda. Devoted sister to Grace, David and the late Herman. Adored grandmother of Jane, Gerald, Andrew, Liz, Andrea, Stephen, Wendy and Karen and great grandmother of Cole. Private services. Shiva will be observed at the home of Linda and Robert Feldman. Contributions in her memory may be sent to the Betty and Sidney Feldman Memorial Fund, John Carter Brown Library, Brown University, Box 1894, Providence, Rhode Island 02912.

title: Police Say Men Died In a Murder-Suicide
description: A man who had been barred from contacting his estranged wife went to her house here Sunday night and used a shotgun to kill her male companion and himself, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOULIHAN, DANIEL J.
description: HOULIHAN-Daniel J. Manhattan College acknowledges with profound sorrow the passing of Daniel J. Houlihan, Sr. '41, renowned alumnus, generous benefactor, valued advisor and good friend. Educated by the Christian Brothers at Manhattan, Dan devoted his extra time and energies to Catholic educational causes. One of a long line of Jaspers, including his father Joseph '09; Dan's love of faith, family and community was truly admirable. We at Manhattan College extend our heartfelt condolences to Dan's wife, Kathrene, and their nine children.

title: Impeachment Panel Sets Hearing on 'Consequences of Perjury'
description: Seeking to keep the public focused on charges that President Clinton undermined the legal system, the House Judiciary Committee today scheduled a public hearing for next week on the ''consequences of perjury and related crimes.''

title: Is Evolution Just Monkey Business?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Slow Motion: Not So Fast
description: To the Editor:

title: CITADEL TO BUY 16 RADIO STATIONS FROM WICKS BROADCAST
description: The Citadel Communications Corporation said yesterday that it would buy 16 radio stations from the closely held Wicks Broadcast Group for $77 million in cash, to accelerate its eastward expansion and increase cash flow. Citadel, which is based in Tempe, Ariz., and had $89.8 million in sales last year, said it would buy eight stations in Charleston, S.C.; five in Binghamton, N.Y., and three in central Indiana. Citadel is entering each market for the first time. The bulk of its stations now are in midsized markets in the West. It has added about 35 stations since its initial stock sale in July at $16 a share. The stock rose $2.75 a share, to $25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: At Last, a Politician Who Knows Quantum Mechanics
description: One of the upsets of the Nov. 3 election was the defeat of the incumbent Republican, Michael Pappas, in New Jersey's 12th Congressional District by Dr. Rush Holt, who had never held elected office. Mr. Pappas was best known nationally as the Congressman who once sang, on the floor of the House of Representatives, a tribute he had composed to the special prosecutor, ''Twinkle, twinkle, Kenneth Starr, now we know how brave you are.''

title: Goodrich in Deal To Add Coltec
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company agreed today to acquire Coltec Industries for $2.2 billion in stock and assumed debt, making the former tire maker the No. 1 supplier of landing gear and other aircraft parts.

title: CUNY Approves Stiffer Test Intended to Gauge Writing Ability
description: Adding yet another test to insure the English proficiency of graduates, the trustees of the City University of New York yesterday began requiring that students pass a new writing examination before they enter the third year of studies at senior colleges or transfer as upperclassmen from other colleges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRENCH, ANTOINETTE F.
description: FRENCH-Antoinette F. Services are to be held at 12:30 P.M., on Tuesday, November 24th, 1998, at the Little Church of the Flowers, at Forest Lawn Glendale, Forest Lawn Mortuary.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CONOCO INC., Houston, the oil company, said it had received $200 million for oilfields, natural-gas fields and related assets in Utah and Colorado that it recently sold to Coastal Corp., Houston.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARLSTEIN, JULES
description: PEARLSTEIN-Jules. Manhattan Day School/Yeshiva Ohr Torah records with profound sorrow the passing of Jules Pearlstein, father of Rona Kellman, wife of our esteemed board member, Ira Kellman. May the entire family be comforted in this hour of their untimely loss. Manhattan Day School Yeshiva Ohr Torah Rabbi David Kaminetsky, Principal George Karasick, President Elliott Gibber, Chairman of the Board

title: On the New European Economic Road Map, There's Not Much Left of the Left
description: PARIS  Europe's leftist governments have produced a document outlining their ideas on economic reform that they call The New European Way. It is no 10-lane highway to the horizon, but largely a familiar road, signposted less in pink than gray.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Inside Art column in Weekend on Friday, about four works that failed to sell at Sotheby's Nov. 16 auction but were then sold privately for $15 million, misidentified one. The Cezanne was a watercolor, ''The Park at Chateau Noir With the Well,'' not the painting ''Bridge and the Barge at Pontoise.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPPER, ROBERT L.
description: POPPER-Robert L. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, Inc. mourn the loss of Robert L. Popper, former Board member and cherished friend. Mr. Popper served on our Board for 24 years, and was an avid supporter of our efforts to assist disenfranchised groups, particularly the elderly. Our profound condolences go to his wife of 30 years, Ellen Goldberg Popper, and his many nieces and nephews. Rev. Dr. Herbert Anderson, Board Chair Megan E. McLaughlin, Executive Director/CEO

title: Long a Leader, U.S. Now Lags In High School Graduate Rate
description: A major new international study shows that American high school graduation rates, for generations the highest in the world, have slipped below those of most industrialized countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEUBERT, CELESTINE C. (TINEEY)
description: LEUBERT-Celestine C. (Tineey). Died peacefully on November 21, 1998 surrounded by family in Sun Valley, ID. Loving mother of Eloise (Cronin) & Susan. Cherished grandmother of Brian, Colleen, Kama. Sister of Frank Capka, Bernice Olt, the late Cyril Capka. Employee of FDIC, volunteer at Donnell Library. Formerly of Manhasset, LI, where she was involved in numerous philanthropic & social organizations. Her zest for life despite insurmountable odds will always be an inspiration to her extensive international family of friends. Through prolific correspondence and thoughtful generosity, she communicated her boundless capacity for love and friendship. Funeral mass 10 AM, Saturday, November 28 at St. Paul the Apostle Church. Reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her name may be made to St. Paul the Apostle Church, 415 West 59th Street, NY, NY 10019.

title: William Douglas, 76, the Doctor For the Seven Early Astronauts
description: William Kennedy Douglas, the Air Force doctor who cared for Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. and the nation's six other original astronauts, died on Nov. 15 at Lewisville Medical Center in Lewisville, Tex., near Dallas. He was 76 and lived in Albuquerque, N.M.

title: A Death on Videotape
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian is daring prosecutors to try him for euthanasia now that he has gone on CBS's ''60 Minutes'' with a tape showing him giving a lethal injection to a man suffering from Lou Gehrig's disease. They ought to oblige him. His actions are almost certainly illegal and can only disrupt the important debate over physician-assisted suicide.

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: Soldiering On, Despite Eccentricities

title: Turkey Brought Kurdish Problem on Itself
description: To the Editor:

title: For Yanks It's Plan B, As in Belle
description: All along, Bernie Williams has been Plan A for the Yankees. But now the Yankees are fully committed to pursuing Plan B, as in Albert Belle.

title: Gates Gives Millions To Seattle Libraries
description: William H. Gates, the Microsoft Corporation chairman, and his wife, Melinda, will give $20 million to the Seattle Public Library system on Tuesday, officials of the William H. Gates Foundation said today. The gift is believed to be one of the largest donations from individuals to a public library system.

title: Steinbrenner Said to Seek A $100 Million Contract
description: Bargaining like a free-agent ballplayer after setting a home run record, George M. Steinbrenner 3d is negotiating a lucrative contract to run the Yankees after he sells a majority stake in the team to Cablevision, three of his business associates said yesterday.

title: Peggy Lehman Korn, Philanthropist, 78
description: Peggy Lehman Korn, a New York philanthropist, died Nov. 17 at her home on Manhattan's Upper East Side. She was 78. The cause was cardiac arrest, her family said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTUREN, MANOLO
description: BARTUREN-Manolo, 72, entrepreneur, of a heart attack on November 22. Remembered for his loyalty and generous Christian spirit. Visiting, Tuesday 4-6 and 79PM at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 2080 Boston Post Rd, Larchmont, New York. Mass, Wednesday 11AM at Holy Family Church, New Rochelle, NY. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Little Progress Seen in Talks As Teachers Strike 3d Day
description: After negotiators failed to come up with a settlement in a nine-hour session that ended shortly after 3 A.M. today, public school teachers stayed off the job for a third day, leaving schools with few adults in charge and high absences.

title: A New Baby Picture Of the Southern Sky
description: Borrowing an exploratory technique from geology, astronomers have learned to take ''core samples,'' not of Earth but of the great depths of time in the universe. In 1995, astronomers aimed the Hubble Space Telescope for 10 days of concentrated observations of a single patch of the northern sky. The long camera exposures, in effect, bored through space and time to produce views filled with thousands of galaxies at various ages and stages of evolution, some appearing as they existed when the universe was only 10 percent of its current age.

title: Jets Can Thank Pats For a Spot At the Top
description: Admitting for the first time this season that he would be ''pretty hard pressed to find somebody who didn't play well,'' Coach Bill Parcells turned his attention today to the Jets' final five games.

title: Investor Response Shows Quirks of Internet Deals
description: Does the stock market know something the rest of us do not about the terms of America Online's proposed purchase of Netscape Communications?

title: Johnson Likes Jets' Chances In Stretch
description: After the Jets' impressive victory over the Tennessee Oilers, Keyshawn Johnson allowed himself to get caught up in the moment and begin to dream of the possibilities that used to be fantasies for the once downtrodden franchise.

title: Is Star System Good for Academia?
description: To the Editor:

title: Violetta And Alfredo, With Decor Rampant
description: Gorgeous to look at but virtually uninhabited, the Metropolitan Opera's new ''Traviata'' seems to have been the victim of a neutron bomb. Whatever happened during the process of preparation, Monday night's opening performance found Franco Zeffirelli's sets still standing but not an opera character left alive. We have had periodic reports on the progress of the Met's new production and have crossed our fingers in hopes that bad luck and bad judgment would somehow be overcome. I am afraid they haven't. Mr. Zeffirelli reverts to his worst instincts in the last two acts, but his new look at Verdi's masterpiece remains waiting and ready for a cast strong enough in personality to compete with its director's illusions of grandeur.

title: Creating Better Nursing Homes
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Resigns At Cliff Freeman
description: David Angelo, executive vice president and co-executive creative director at Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York, has resigned from the agency after four years.

title: Luba Elianoff, 96, Maker of Elegant Linens
description: Luba Elianoff, a Latvian-born little old linen lady whose bearing was a bit too regal, whose spirit was a bit too fiery and whose embroideries were a bit too elegant to be called that to her face, died on Nov. 17 at her apartment on Riverside Drive. She was 96 and had much preferred to be called the Queen of Linens.

title: Journal; Tick, Tick, T. . .
description: The day after they broadcast a tape of Dr. Jack Kevorkian killing a terminally ill 52-year-old man by lethal injection, Don Hewitt, the executive producer of ''60 Minutes,'' and Mike Wallace, who reported the story, sat in Mr. Hewitt's office on West 57th Street watching one of their many critics hold forth on TV. Howard Kurtz was making the point on CNN that had ''60 Minutes'' not aired the tape, Dr. Kevorkian ''simply would not have gotten the same attention.'' Though the remark was not meant as a compliment, Mr. Hewitt and Mr. Wallace vigorously nodded their heads in approval, taking it as one.

title: Ahold Profit Growth Slowed by Dutch Sales
description: Royal Ahold N.V., the sixth largest supermarket owner in the world, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit rose 22 percent -- lower than the 26 percent analysts had expected -- as slow domestic sales curtailed profit growth, and expansion in the United States and Asia cost more than had been anticipated. The compan's net income for the quarter rose to 256.5 million guilders, or $133.2 million, from 209.7 million guilders a year earlier.

title: Business Travel; An airline limit on travel agency fees for overseas flights may cost the flying public millions.
description: IF travel industry predictions prove accurate, the public can expect to pay millions of dollars more in air fares as the result of the $100 limit that the major airlines recently imposed on travel agency commissions for booking international flights. American Express has warned that those increased costs could amount to $500 million, and the industry consensus is that business travelers will pay the lion's share.

title: First Lesson in Hype
description: Even Nickelodeon, the cable network parents would least expect to disappoint their children, could not resist a Hollywood-hype gimmick last week that may have done exactly that.

title: Bridge Match Produces Team Titles
description: Players from New York, California, Texas and Canada shared the honors in two major championships here on Monday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

title: Boy Killed by Shark in Florida In First Such Death in Decades
description: Flailing his arms was the only sign of distress that 9-year-old James William Tellasmon was able to send before he disappeared under the ocean waters off Vero Beach on Saturday while on an outing with his mother and a family friend.

title: Suffolk Lawmakers Turn Down Bond for Minor-League Ball Park
description: Just weeks after approving a state-financed ball park for the minor league Long Island Ducks baseball team, the Suffolk County Legislature in Hauppauge voted down a $5 million bond to pay for additional costs on the project.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEDER, JENNIE
description: FEDER-Jennie. 89. Died November 21st in Miami. Beloved aunt, sister, teacher. She will be sadly missed.

title: Slovakia's Democratic Turn
description: Recent parliamentary elections in Slovakia have freed the country from the heavy boot of Vladimir Meciar, its dominant figure since the end of Communism. Mr. Meciar engineered the breakup of Czechoslovakia, turned Slovakia's institutions into his political machine and allowed his friends to loot the treasury. The coalition of parties that defeated him has made a promising start, but it will need sustained unity and help from the West to solve the many problems Mr. Meciar left behind.

title: THE CHEF
description: I HEARD a story that may or may not be true, but it certainly makes a point. After World War II, inspectors were going through the food depots somewhere in France and discovered that most of the supplies had been ravaged by rats. One observant inspector was supposed to have said: ''We can be sure of only one thing -- the rats were French. The cinnamon is untouched.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOKAL, BLANCHE
description: SOKAL-Blanche. The Board of Trustees, the Administration and the Medical Staff of the Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center express great sorrow on the passing of Blanche Sokal, beloved mother of Myron M. Sokal, MD, our esteemed Director of NeoNatal-Perinatal Medicine. We extend our profound and heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Edwin L. Schulman Chairman, Board of Trustees Frank J. Maddalena President and CEO Alvin I. Kahn, MD Sr. Vice President, Medical Affairs I. Akiva Wulkan, MD President, Medical Board

title: Vladimir P. Demikhov, 82, Pioneer in Transplants, Dies
description: Vladimir P. Demikhov, a Russian surgeon whose pioneering work in performing organ transplants on dogs set the stage for similar operations on humans in later years, died on Sunday. He was 82 and lived in a small apartment on Moscow's outskirts.

title: Concerns on Profit Outlook Help Deflate the Dow a Bit
description: Stocks fell yesterday on concern that the euphoria that sent the Dow Jones industrial average up 21 percent in six weeks was unjustified by the outlook for corporate profits.

title: Indonesia Panel to Study Reports Of Army Slayings in East Timor
description: Indonesia's National Commission on Human Rights will investigate accusations that soldiers executed as many as 50 people in East Timor earlier this month in a military operation against armed rebels in the troubled province, the Government said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, GERRY RED
description: WILSON-Gerry Red. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club mourn the loss of their esteemed Member, Friar Gerry Red Wilson on November 22, 1998. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Visitation will be held November 25 and 26 2-5PM and 7-10PM at Frederick's Funeral Home, 192-15 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, N.Y. Funeral services will be held on November 27 at 10AM at St. Anastasia Church, 45-14 245 Street, Douglaston, New York. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Exec Director

title: Chinese Enterprise Makes Bond Payment
description: Guangdong Enterprises (Holdings) Ltd. made a coupon payment of almost $22.2 million on a $500 million 10-year Yankee bond due 2007, Merrill Lynch & Company said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Betting on Wired Future, Internet Pioneers Combine

title: Home Is Where the Bath Is: Finding Happiness
description: Francesco and Marta are one of those hip couples: young, busy, fashionable and good-looking. They live in Rome in a great apartment with a terrace, work together as decorators and don't seem particularly unhappy, but maybe they are.

title: School Officials Support Teacher on Book That Parents Call Racially Insensitive
description: New York City school officials yesterday backed a white third-grade teacher's use of what black parents asserted was a racially insensitive book, but the teacher said she feared returning to her classroom because of threats from parents.

title: 3 Yuppies, All Downwardly Mobile
description: Why are these people not smiling? Michael, Jonathan and Jenifer, the anxious trio at the heart of ''Snakebit,'' David Marshall Grant's solid and savvy new yuppie melodrama at the Grove Street Playhouse, should have found a measure of contentment by now. Bright, good looking, capable, they present themselves as a group that is as likely as any in the culture to attain full and rewarding lives.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Holiday Tomorrow; Thanksgiving
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRONIN, JOHN JOSEPH
description: CRONIN-John Joseph. On November 24, 1998. Beloved husband & best friend of Beverly. Devoted father of Patricia O'Malley and John Michael. Funeral Mass on Friday, 10 A.M., Epiphany Church, 22nd Street and 2nd Avenue, N.Y.C. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in the name of John Cronin to Msgr. James Murray, Catholic Charities, 1011 First Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10022.

title: Seeking Balkan Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESSER, DORIS
description: LESSER-Doris. Beloved sister of Lawrence & Caroline Lesser and Jerome & Florence Lesser. Loving aunt of Stacey, Jill and Craig. She was a former administrator at Long Island Jewish Hospital and admired by all. She will be deeply missed. Services on Wednesday, at 1 PM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: International Paper to Buy Union Camp in a $5 Billion Deal
description: The International Paper Company, the nation's largest paper maker, announced yesterday that it would buy a rival, the Union Camp Corporation, for $5 billion in stock in one of the first consolidations in an industry that has consistently lost money because it produces too much.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, MICHAEL SAMUEL
description: ISRAEL-Michael Samuel. Beloved son of Jo List Levinson and David Israel. Father of Miriam. Brother of Dinse, Zenia, Peter, and Milly Israel, and Deborah, Daniel and Jonathan Levinson. Grandson of Vera List. Service at the ''Riverside'', 180 W. 76 St., Wednesday, November 25, 11:00 AM. Shiva at Joe Levinson's, 263 West End Ave., 19B, Thursday, and Sunday through Wednesday. In lieu of flowers contributions to Normal, 1001 Connecticut Ave, NW, Suite 1710, Washington, DC 20036.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWGARDEN, ROSE (NEE SCHWARTZMAN)
description: NEWGARDEN - Rose (nee Schwartzman), passed away on November 24th, 1998. Beloved mother of Jeanne Slutsky; cherished grandmother of Fred, Frank and Steve Slutsky; adored greatgrandmother. Graveside service on Friday, November 27, 1998, Mount Pleasant Cemetery.

title: Pecans From Heaven: The Georgia Harvest
description: THIS year, say those who tend the stately groves of pecan trees here in central Georgia -- or ''middle Georgia,'' in local parlance -- the pecans ''did not show up for work.''

title: Crisp Views At Lofty Heights
description: New York Philharmonic Avery Fisher Hall

title: Sonic Automotive Seeks More Dealers
description: Sonic Automotive Inc. plans to take advantage of a slide among rival auto-dealership stocks to buy up independent dealers ahead of its competitors, its chairman and chief executive, Bruton Smith, said today.

title: Hamilton's Marijuana Charge
description: Giants defensive tackle Keith Hamilton was stopped by Port Authority police for speeding on the George Washington Bridge early Monday morning and later charged with possession of marijuana, driving under the influence of a controlled dangerous substance and possession of drug paraphernalia, according to the Port Authority police spokesman Bill Cahill.

title: Foxes, Hedgehogs and the Defense of Freedom
