description: ISAIAH BERLIN

title: Security Council Hears Report on Iraq and Takes No Action
description: The chief arms inspector for Iraq, Richard Butler, told the Security Council today that he was disappointed with Iraq's cooperation with resumed inspections, particularly the refusal to produce any documents that the inspectors requested.

title: Mediterranean Tastes and a Flavor of the Old Village
description: IF Acquario, a small Mediterranean restaurant on the western edge of the East Village, seems familiar, chances are you've visited Il Buco, around the block on Bond Street. Il Buco, a quirky, romantic little restaurant that serves a mixture of Spanish and Italian specialties, is known both for its former identity of antique shop by day, restaurant by night, and for its exceptional food.

title: Senate Leadership Challenged Soon After Upheaval in House
description: The Republicans' post-election power struggle spilled into the Senate today as Senator Chuck Hagel of Nebraska said he would seek the leadership post overseeing campaign fund-raising and election strategy.

title: In Jersey City, Teachers Strike and Parents Cope
description: Arlene Pacheco and her two children walked past Public School 9 on Brunswick Avenue here, where teachers were marching in a circle and carrying signs that said, ''Dignity, not Dollars.'' It was 9 A.M. and her children were not in school.

title: Liberties; Cucumber Candidate
description: Bill Clinton has been an exhausting President. He requires too much work and stirs up too much sturm und drang. After Mr. Clinton leaves, everyone will surely be in the mood for a little peace and quiet.

title: Tiny Step to Help the Cease-Fire in Kosovo
description: There was a small advance today in the effort to prop up the fragile cease-fire between Yugoslav authorities and ethnic Albanian rebels in Kosovo Province. After American diplomats had interceded, a Serbian police officer whom rebels kidnapped a week ago, Goran Zbiljic, was released.

title: DEAL IS CONCLUDED ON NETSCAPE SALE TO AMERICA ONLINE
description: Envisioning a networked world in which the Internet is a limitless marketplace of information, entertainment, products and services, America Online Inc. laid out the details of an agreement, formally announced yesterday, to buy the Netscape Communications Corporation for $4.2 billion.

title: People
description: * Torie Clarke was named to the new position of president of Bozell/ Eskew, Washington, part of the BSMG Worldwide unit of True North Communications. She had been vice president for public affairs and strategic counsel at the National Cable Television Association, Washington.

title: A Close Race For Top Ratings
description: With only tonight left in the November ratings sweep period, the final standings are still very much in doubt; what is not in doubt is that millions were spent to doctor some prime-time schedules that will enter the holiday season still looking pale and sickly.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Being the Sturgeon General Has Its Perks
description: ON Thanksgiving Day some six decades ago, Barney Greengrass on Amsterdam Avenue shipped an order of smoked sturgeon to its finest customer ever: President Franklin D. Roosevelt. The President was spending the holiday in Warm Springs, Ga. Back then, the Greengrass mailing labels had basic instructions: ''If not delivered in three days, never mind.''

title: Metro Business; Downtown Building Sold
description: Amtrust Realty Corporation won approval from a bankruptcy court yesterday to buy a downtown Manhattan office building, at 59 Maiden Lane, for $75 million.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: New Chelsea Outpost

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAILEY, DOLORES (NEE MAZZOTTI)
description: BAILEY-Dolores (nee Mazzotti). Died at her home in Manhattan on November 23, 1998 at age 62. She is survived by Earl (Bill) Bailey, her husband of 32 years. Born in Syracuse, N.Y., she spent her childhood in Patchogue, N.Y. A graduate of City University of New York, she made a career in the computer systems field and retired as a Vice President of the Equitable Life Assurance Society in 1991. Service and interment private. Donations can be made in her memory to The Endowment for English Language Learning Programs, The New York Public Library, 5th Ave at 42nd Street, New York, New York 10018.

title: Calendar
description: Chocolate Blowout

title: South Africa Embroiled in Dispute Over Registration for '99 Vote
description: In 1994, South Africa's first all-race elections were sloppy, but everybody was too happy to care. This time they care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOORHEES, RUTH SUYDAM
description: VOORHEES-Ruth Suydam. Age 100 of Far Hills, NJ on Monday, November 23, 1998. Wife of the late Edward LeRoy Voorhees. Mother of Stephen Coerte Voorhees of Merry Point, VA, Ann V. Haab of Franklin, NY and the late Peggy V. Reppert Martinez. She is also survived by eight grandchildren and 13 great grandchildren. Burial will be at Hillside Cemetery followed by a memorial service at 2PM Saturday, November 28, 1998 at St. John on the Mountain Church, Bernardsville, N.J. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests memorials be made to Morristown Memorial Hospital, 100 Madison Ave., Morristown, NJ 07960 or St. John on the Mountain Church, Mt. Harmony Road, Bernardsville, NJ 07924. For information please call Bailey Funeral Home Inc., Peapack, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLE, LARRY
description: CARLE-Larry. Age 58. Died on November 23, 1998. He is survived by his mother Sylvia, his wife Ruth, two sons David & Jonathan and one grandson. Services will be Friday, November 27 at 1PM at Temple Covenant of Peace, 15th and Northampton Streets, Easton, PA. Contributions may be made to Leukemia Society of America, 600 Third Avenue, NY, NY 10016.

title: Surhoff Planning A Meeting With Mets
description: B.J. Surhoff is coming home. At least for a visit.

title: Ex-Parole Board Aide Accused of Lie in Inquiry Into Political Gifts
description: Federal prosecutors have charged that a former official of the New York State Parole Board tried to hamper their investigation into whether the campaign of Gov. George E. Pataki promised favors to inmates in return for political contributions.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column on Friday, about a revival of the ''Thank you, Paine Webber'' campaign, by the Saatchi & Saatchi agency, referred imprecisely to the campaign's origins. The original version, in 1975, was created by Marshall Karp and Andrew Langer, not by Saatchi.

title: In the Butchery of Bosnia, a Killer Becomes a Humanitarian
description: In ''Savior,'' Dennis Quaid has the role of his career as a hard-bitten American mercenary fighting for the Serbian side in the Bosnian war. The actor's familiar rakish smile has faded into the hollow-eyed gaze of a weather-beaten soldier who long ago discarded his humanity in the muck of some forgotten battlefield. Although the movie, directed by Peter Antonijevic, a Serbian filmmaker, is set in the former Yugoslavia, it has no interest in exploring the history of conflict in the Balkans, and it refuses to take sides, or even to name sides.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: An Elegant Taste of Paris Is Coming to New York

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NORSTAN INC., -- Maple Grove, Minn., a communications services company, said it was eliminating about 200 jobs, or 7 percent of its work force, and warned that it would not reach 1999 fiscal year sales and earnings targets.

title: Thomas Manning, 86, Explorer Known as Lone Wolf of Arctic
description: Thomas Manning, an explorer known as the lone wolf of the Arctic who followed his dog sled and camped in igloos to map desolate reaches of the far north of Canada, died on Nov. 8 in the hospital in Smiths Falls, Ontario, near the gentleman's farm that he had in Merrickville. He was 86.

title: Time for a Union Takeover
description: New York City's largest union, District Council 37, is in a colossal mess. The Manhattan District Attorney, Robert Morgenthau, is investigating charges against union officials ranging from embezzlement to falsifying records to kickbacks for Thanksgiving turkeys. Now comes an even more serious charge, of vote fraud in the crucial 1996 ratification of an unpopular city contract. The contract, which became the linchpin of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's budgetary and labor policy, imposed a two-year pay freeze on most municipal workers.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Pulse column of Sunday Styles this week about Droog, a clothing catalogue aimed at teen-age boys, misstated the toll-free telephone number for orders. It is (877) 443-7664.

title: GOLDEN BOOKS PRESIDENT RESIGNS TO TAKE POST AT MARVEL
description: The struggling publisher Golden Books Family Entertainment Inc. said yesterday that its president, Eric Ellenbogen, had resigned to become president and chief executive at Marvel Enterprises Inc. Golden Books said Mr. Ellenbogen would not be replaced. The company said it was ''streamlining'' management and trying to cut costs to focus on its core children's book business. Golden Books, the publisher of such children's classics as ''Pat the Bunny,'' was acquired for $65 million in May 1996 by an investment group that included the former Simon & Schuster president Richard E. Snyder. Last week, the company said that it might file for bankruptcy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERT, MILTON M.
description: SILBERT-Milton M. On Nov. 24, 1998. Loving husband of Marion L. Devoted father of Steven and Kenneth, & father-in-law of Barbara. Dear brother of Jean Gilbert. Beloved grandfather of Melissa. Adored uncle to many nieces and nephews. Dedicated board member and former treasurer of Opengate. Service Friday, November 27th, at 12:30PM, at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard (at 76th Road), Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMPTON, HENRY
description: HAMPTON-Henry. The Board and staff of the Charles H. Revson Foundation deeply mourn the passing of our Board member, colleague, and friend, Henry Hampton. Henry brought to the craft of film making the conviction of the educator, the eye of the artist, the subtle intelligence of the historian, the determination of the inspired messenger. His masterpiece documentary of the Civil Rights era, ''Eyes on the Prize,'' will endure as the definitive visual history of that mid-twentieth century struggle, and will inform and inspire generations of young people around the world into the next century. A quiet man, whose humanism radiated from his entire being, Henry's capacity for empathy and friendship ran deep. The nation has lost a great filmmaker; those of us who knew him have also lost a respected colleague and an unforgettable friend. Charles H. Revson Foundation Robert S. Rifkind, Chairman Eli N. Evans, President

title: Mr. Starr's Tactics
description: To the Editor:

title: Finn Wins Ivy Award
description: Jim Finn, the 240-pound runing back who gained a school-record 1,450 yards rushing this season for the Ivy champion Pennsylvania, was voted the Asa S. Bushnell Cup as the Ivy League's player of the year by the eight head coaches.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They are killing our comrades, they are killing our friends. Do they want to stop us? Do they want to frighten us? It won't work. I want to say this at the coffin of our comrade, absolutely clearly and absolutely firmly: They will not succeed.''

title: A Fresh Beaujolais Nouveau Season
description: Beaujolais Nouveau 1998, Georges Duboeuf. About $9 until Dec. 1 and $7 thereafter, when delivery to stores shifts from air to ship.

title: Couple Plead Not Guilty In Kidnapping of Boy, 6
description: A Brooklyn couple pleaded not guilty yesterday to kidnapping a 6-year-old Hasidic boy with cerebral palsy whom the woman used to babysit.

title: Miller and Visa join the ranks of edgy marketers that like to re-examine their agency rosters.
description: TWO big advertisers are asking agencies for ideas on large, significant portions of their accounts.

title: Striking Down the Sodomy Laws
description: When Michael Hardwick looked up from the privacy of his apartment in Atlanta one day 16 years ago, he was stunned to see a policeman standing in the door. ''What are you doing in my bedroom?'' he asked. It is a question that took on a special bitterness for gay men and lesbians after the United States Supreme Court in 1986 upheld the Georgia law against sodomy under which Mr. Hardwick was arrested that day. The law was 170 years old. It prohibited oral and anal sex by anyone, homosexual or heterosexual, and like all such laws in the United States it was modeled on old English law, which was shaped by religious teachings.

title: Police Overtime Costs Rise Sharply
description: Police overtime costs rose sharply in the first quarter of the fiscal year, officials said yesterday, driven up by increased arrests and a host of events that included visiting heads of state, heightened security in Lower Manhattan and the heavy police presence at Yankees games.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Despite Strong Business, Luxury Hotel Renovates
description: The hotel business is still booming in New York. According to the latest figures from PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting firm, the hotel occupancy rate in the fourth quarter is expected to be 84 percent this year, up from 82 percent last year.

title: Job Cuts at Sensormatic
description: The Sensormatic Electronics Corporation has cut 100 jobs in the United States and plans to eliminate 200 more in Europe by year-end as part of a plan to increase profits. Besides the job reductions, amounting to 5 percent of Sensormatic's work force, the plan also includes the closing of 18 warehouses outside the United States by the middle of next year. Sensormatic, based in Boca Raton, makes shoplifting-detection devices and other electronic security systems.

title: Swedish Central Bank Cuts Key Interest Rate
description: Sweden's central bank cut its key interest rate yesterday for the second time in a month, saying that Swedish inflation was on course to fall below its target of 2 percent. The Riksbank cut its repurchase agreement rate, the rate at which it supplies funds to the banking system, by a quarter percentage point, to 3.60 percent, its lowest level since 1994.

title: Building A Business Behind The Screen; America Online's E-Commerce Goals
description: America Online built itself into the most potent force in cyberspace largely by appealing to families with chatty teen-agers who want to flirt on line and adults looking for an easy way to send electronic mail while checking the weather and sports scores.

title: A Sure Cure for the Gravy Jitters
description: TOMORROW, with an entire Thanksgiving meal marshaled and ready, countless cooks will quake over the last detail: the gravy. When it's a once-a-year thing, there are no guarantees that the gravy will come out perfectly smooth, deeply flavored and nicely browned. There is an alternative, though. And, unlike the concoctions that come out of jars, it requires no apologies.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CANNON, VICTOR, JR.
description: CANNON-Victor, Jr. November 25, 1991. Always remembered. Ellen and David

title: A Plasticized 'Nutcracker' In 3-D, With Little Ballet
description: ''The Imax Nutcracker'' opened commercially last year. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Nov. 26, 1997. The film reopens today at the Sony Theaters Lincoln Square, 1998 Broadway, at 68th Street.

title: GLOBAL MOTORSPORT REJECTS GOLDEN CYCLE OFFER
description: In a letter yesterday, Global Motorsport Group of Morgan Hill, Calif., rejected an offer by Golden Cycle L.L.C. to buy substantially all of the company's outstanding shares for $20 each, or about $103 million. Global Motorsport, the largest independent parts distributor for Harley-Davidson motorcycles, has accepted an offer of $19.50 a share in cash plus the assumption of debt from Stonington Partners. Golden Cycle, which reported holding 10.2 percent of Global Motorsport's common shares, initially bid $18 a share in March for shares it did not already own. It raised its offer to $20 this month.

title: Kevorkian Story
description: To the Editor:

title: A Night to Remember, Or, if Possible, to Forget
description: ''Very Bad Things,'' written and directed by the actor Peter Berg, is about as funny as the character who winds up a double amputee in its closing scene. And that's the way Mr. Berg seems to want it. Inspired by the insight that packs of guys visiting Las Vegas can behave stupidly, Mr. Berg creates dull middle-class buddies in the throes of a bachelor party. Then he watches a little bitty mishap (the stripper's violent death) escalate into big trouble.

title: Mom's Recipes: The Ingredient Beyond Measure
description: WHEN I asked my mother to give me all her recipes, she was offended.

title: Luxurious Lookout for the Parade; San Remo's East Rooms Are Thanksgiving Sky Boxes
description: If things go the way the police say they will, something like 2.5 million people will clog the streets to watch the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade tomorrow. Roughly 60 million more will take in the festive event on television. And 90 of them will watch it from the windows of Julie and David Tobey's apartment.

title: Stringer Copes With a Family Crisis
description: It could not be happening again. Not to C. Vivian Stringer. Not during this week of Thanksgiving. But it was her choked voice on the phone from an airplane heading to Raleigh, N.C., on Sunday night. And it was her longtime confidant on the other end of the call, Temple Coach John Chaney, trying to gently comfort her while letting her know that, once again, she would have to be strong for her family. Once again, during Thanksgiving.

title: Mr. Starr's Tactics
description: To the Editor:

title: Hedge Fund Seeks Buyer or Partner for a Major Part of Its Business
description: D. E. Shaw & Company, a big New York hedge fund and broker, is seeking a partner or buyer for its stock-related trading business, an indication that the shakeout in the hedge fund world continues despite resurgent markets.

title: New Data Show That Economy Remains Strong
description: The latest snapshot of the United States economy showed yesterday that the long-predicted slowdown is still more forecast than fact.

title: Terminal TV
description: Our culture slid further away from respect for human life when Dr. Jack Kevorkian killed Thomas Youk by lethal injection and CBS, on Sunday, broadcast the macabre videotape of the act to the nation.

title: You Can Sink Teeth Into Holiday Games
description: Thanksgiving Day games have become such a tradition in the National Football League that teams other than Detroit and Dallas would like a special serving of the day's sweets -- especially the competitive edge that they say is allowed the hosts.

title: Protesters Say Politics Dictate Parade Permits
description: The Giuliani administration is wielding its power to grant or deny permits for parades, marches and protests as a political weapon, contend several groups that say they have struggled to get permits.

title: SOUTHERN TO BUY ORANGE AND ROCKLAND PLANTS
description: The Southern Energy Inc. unit of the Southern Company, agreed yesterday to acquire all the electric power plants of Orange and Rockland Utilities Inc. in a deal valued at $480 million. The sale includes the Bowline Point Generating Plant in West Haverstraw, N.Y., which is one-third owned by Orange and Rockland and two-thirds owned by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York. Orange and Rockland will receive $345 million in the transaction and Con Ed $135 million. The Southern Company, based in Atlanta, is the parent company of five electric utilities. The divestiture is part of a New York State-mandated program to introduce competition to the retail power market.

title: A Light Step On That Legendary Stairway
description: William Bolcom and Joan Morris

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACSO, GEORGE
description: BACSO-George. The USPTA mourns the passing of distinguished colleague, past president and USPTA Hall of Fame member George Bacso. We fondly remember his his enthusiasm for life, his years of dedication to our sport and his impact on thousands in the tennis world. His character and commitment were essential to our organization's success and will greatly be missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family and others who loved him, as our association did. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the USPTA Foundation, (for George Bacso, 3535 Briarpark Drive, Houston, TX 77042 to establish a tennis fund for children and provide education for needy teaching professionals. Members of the United States Professional Tennis Association

title: MERCK PLANS 2-FOR-1 STOCK SPLIT, ITS FIRST SINCE '92
description: Merck & Company, the world's biggest drug maker, said yesterday that it would split its stock two for one in February in its first split since 1992, as prospects for its new painkiller pushed shares to record prices. Merck said on Monday that it had filed with the Food and Drug Administration for approval of its drug Vioxx, which appears to treat pain and swelling without irritating the stomach. Analysts estimate that annual sales of this drug could top $1 billion. ''The stock split is a reflection of the hot move that Merck has made to the magic level of 150,'' said David Saks, an analyst with Gruntal & Company. Merck, based in Whitehouse Station, N.J., rose $2.625, to $158.625. Merck said the split would apply to shares held as of Jan. 25.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Flours: The Hard and the Soft

title: Reviews Follow Ban on Library Internet Filter
description: A ruling by a Federal judge on Monday that barred public libraries in Loudoun County from limiting how patrons use the Internet is binding only in eastern Virginia, but it seemed sure to have national implications as librarians across the country began to review their own Internet policies in the wake of the decision in the closely watched case.

title: INSIDE
description: Breakdown in Talks On Sale of Yankees

title: A Steamy Bowl Of Happiness
description: HOUSE special almond tea'' at the Sweet-n-Tart Cafe in Chinatown may be one of the most unexpected restaurant experiences in the city.

title: Man Is Charged in 1996 Killing of Philanthropist
description: A wealthy philanthropist who originally appeared to have died of natural causes in 1996 had actually been killed, the police said yesterday in announcing that someone had been charged in his death.

title: Even a Visionary Needs Time Off
description: HE was the Peter Pan and Ariel of wine; a man who described one of his own commentaries as ''a critique of pure riesling,'' and who advised on a label that ''this wine will accommodate all manner of game and wild beasts, including the sloth.''

title: C.I.A. Denies That It Withheld Reports on Russian Corruption
description: The Central Intelligence Agency said today that it had provided many reports on the corruption of senior Russian officials to the Clinton Administration.

title: Court Expands Liability of Landlords in Attacks on Tenants by Intruders
description: In a series of decisions, New York State's highest court yesterday expanded the opportunity for tenants to obtain damages from landlords when they are attacked by intruders who gain access to buildings because of broken or nonexistent locks.

title: BITS AND BYTES
description: A Noodle Theme Park And Virtual Bike Carts

title: Irish Set to Challenge
description: It is almost a secret that Notre Dame has a hockey team, one sharing the campus with the more celebrated football team. The Fighting Irish skaters have never been good enough to qualify for the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, but this year they might.

title: Seeking Balkan Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COELHO, JAIME B., M.D.
description: COELHO-Jaime B., M.D. Formerly Associate Director of Clinical Research at Ayerst and Sterling/ Winthrop Laboratories. On November 23, 1998. Beloved husband of Mary Conrow Coelho. Father of Daniel, Christian, and Sarah. Grandfather of Michael and Stephen. Brother of Jose and Augusto, Malena Sanchez-Pelaez, Anna deElia & Susana Luna. Memorial service on Sunday, 2 P.M. at Edgehill Church, 2570 Independence Avenue, Bronx, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, GERARD J.
description: WILSON-Gerard J. The Board and the staff of The Spanish Institute extends their deepest condolences to Gerard and Joan Wilson for the loss of their beloved son Gerard, who enriched the lives of everyone who knew him. Our sympathy to Gerard's fiancee Kathleen; his brother Michael; his sister-in-law Lynn and their daughter Ashley, Gerard's god-daughter; and to the entire family. We join them in thought and prayer. Funeral Mass, Friday, 10AM at St. Anastasia's Roman Catholic Church, Douglaston, New York.

title: Williams and Yankees Near a Final Separation
description: Bernie Williams last night gave Yankees officials perhaps a last chance to match a seven-year offer worth about $90 million from the Boston Red Sox, and unless the Yankees increase their five-year, $60 million pitch, Williams appears poised to join the Red Sox.

title: Levi Strauss Cancels Condom-Adorned Tree
description: A day after its plan to raise a condom-adorned Christmas tree in the Central Park skating rink was canceled under pressure from a Roman Catholic group and the Parks Department, Levi Strauss & Company decided yesterday to get rid of the tree.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Are Off on Nasdaq
description: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq stock market fell 2 percent in the most recent monthly period, the National Association of Securities Dealers, which oversees the market, reported yesterday. It was the first time in the last 12 months that short-interest positions have declined for two consecutive periods.

title: Arbitrator Sought in Suit Against Port Authority
description: The Newark City Council yesterday asked for a court-appointed arbitrator in a lawsuit charging that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey cheated the city out of millions of dollars in rent over the last 40 years.

title: Goodbye, Green Acres; Hello, Wild Side
description: Babe the pig, he of the sweet voice and twitchy pink snout, spends his second film in considerably more daunting surroundings than those of the Hoggetts (James Cromwell and Magda Szubanski) and their farm. In ''Babe: Pig in the City'' his new friends include chimps and a pit bull, signaling the obviously less lighthearted quality of this sequel.

title: Albert C. Bickford, 96, Antitrust Lawyer
description: Albert Conde Bickford, a retired Manhattan antitrust lawyer who represented Paramount Pictures during the filmmaker's divestiture of its chain of movie houses, died last Wednesday at his home in Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y. He was 96.

title: A Day of Hostile Questions In U.S. Trial of Microsoft
description: An economist testifying on behalf of the Government in its antitrust suit against the Microsoft Corporation sat through another day of hostile cross-examination today, but Microsoft's lawyer failed to budge him from his opinions.

title: Grace Is Planning Charges of $50 Million
description: W. R. Grace & Company, a specialty chemicals producer, expects to take about $50 million in pretax fourth-quarter charges for environmental cleanup at a Grace site and other costs.

title: With an Eye on Newark, Nets Sign a New Lease
description: The New Jersey Nets, whose owners would like to move to a proposed arena in downtown Newark, now have a better lease at their current home through 2008.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Charged With Beating a Boy, 14
description: A 51-year-old Brooklyn man was charged last night with beating a 14-year-old boy in his home in Bedford-Stuyvesant, and detectives were investigating complaints by three other children in the house that the man abused them.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BIRNBAUM, JACK
description: BIRNBAUM-Jack. 1/8/19-11/25/87. Iggy. Babe. Jakey. D'Dad. All one spectacular human being. Missing you, your wisdom and your heart everyday.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Can Rhone-Poulenc and Hoechst be equal partners?
description: AFTER engaging in one of the slowest-moving courtships ever between two companies, the French drug maker Rhone-Poulenc S.A. and Hoechst A.G. of Germany are expected to announce their merger as early as next week.

title: Is Star System Good for Academia?; Shaping the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A book review in Weekend on Friday about ''The Shadow of Kilimanjaro'' by Rick Ridgeway misstated an estimate of how long it would take to walk from the top of Mount Kilimanjaro in Tanzania to the Indian Ocean. Mr. Ridgeway wrote that he was told it would take ''a little over three weeks' time,'' not three days.

title: Damage in Central America Stirs Debate on Immigrants
description: The devastation wrought by Hurricane Mitch in Central America has kicked up a political and policy storm over the Clinton Administration's policy toward illegal immigrants and refugees from that region.

title: Creating Better Nursing Homes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERIN, JOSEPH G.
description: HALPERIN-Joseph G. On November 23, 1998, of NYC, formerly of Staten Island, NY and Freehold, New Jersey. Adoring husband of the late Gertrude. Beloved father of Michael and Nancy. Cherished brother of Sally Goldenblatt, Ruth Yarbrough, and Sol Halperin. Dear friend and companion of Lois Karp. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Services Wednesday, 12 Noon, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: N.B.A. Players Will Be Home For Christmas
description: First, the National Basketball Association informed NBC that it was canceling its Christmas Day doubleheader -- featuring the Bulls vs. the Knicks -- meaning that the season will not start until 1999. Then, the players withdrew their agreement with the league on an escrow plan -- a major issue in the five-month-old lockout.

title: Decision Time for Davie
description: Coach BOB DAVIE has not said whether it will be ARNAZ BATTLE or ERIC CHAPPELL in place of the injured JARIOUS JACKSON at quarterback, but whoever is playing will use a simplified game plan for the No. 8 Irish's game at Southern Cal (7-4, 5-3 Pacific 10) on Saturday.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Bragging of a Snub For 'Dr. Death'

title: Oil Pipeline Agreed On for Caspian Area
description: Russia, Kazakhstan and major oil companies today agreed to build a multibillion-dollar pipeline to link the oil-rich Caspian Sea region with the Black Sea.

title: Woman's Police Escort Kills Her Boyfriend
description: A police detective who was escorting a woman home after she filed a domestic violence report shot and killed the woman's 27-year-old boyfriend yesterday when the man opened fire at them, the police said.

title: Mr. Starr's Tactics
description: To the Editor:

title: Palestinians Walking on Air At Opening of Gaza Airport
description: Euphoric Palestinians celebrated the long-delayed opening of their international airport today as a parade of planes swooped down from cottony skies and glided to a landing in the flatlands of Gaza.

title: Sale of Yankees Said to Hit Snag Over Role of Steinbrenner
description: Just when it appeared that Cablevision was on the verge of buying a majority interest in the Yankees, talks between the cable company and George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the team's principal owner, have broken down over the amount of control Mr. Steinbrenner would retain over the team, two people close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Germany Drops Call to NATO On Nuclear Use
description: Germany's newly elected Government today backed away from a threat to press NATO to renounce a central tenet of its strategy and to pledge never to be the first to use nuclear weapons.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Nov. 17 about a dispute over a new book by Dr. Bob Arnot, ''The Breast Cancer Prevention Diet,'' omitted a description of the finances of the American Council on Science and Health, an organization critical of the book. The council, a nonprofit group, receives 40 percent of its financing from corporations, including food manufacturers. The rest of its support comes from private foundations, individual contributions and sales.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Boris N. Yeltsin's health problems attributed a statement to Mr. Yeltsin wrongly in some copies. While his meeting at a hospital with President Jiang Zemin of China was a signal that he did not intend to allow his frailty to further loosen his grip on the Russian Presidency, Mr. Yeltsin did not explicitly say that.

title: No Time for Stardom on Teheran's Busy Streets
description: School has just let out, and a little girl named Mina (Mina Mohammad-Khani) stands scowling at the curb of a crowded thoroughfare in the heart of Teheran while waiting for her mother. When no one comes, Mina, who has one arm in a sling, becomes impatient. A friend of a teacher volunteers to take her by motorbike to a bus stop. But before they arrive, Mina impulsively dashes off and hops on a bus that proves to be heading in the wrong direction.

title: Dread Pervades Rites for a Slain Russian Lawmaker
description: Thousands of mourners waited hours in the bitter cold today to pay an emotional and politically charged farewell to a liberal legislator whose killing on Friday has turned into a call to arms for Russia's frayed democratic forces.

title: A Close Call For the Good Guys
description: 'Ordo Virtutum'

title: The United States in a "School Daze"
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Semifinals Gravy for St. John's
description: Mike Jarvis could not be happier. His St. John's team is playing excellent basketball, and he is about to make his Madison Square Garden debut in a situation that will almost certainly work in his club's favor.

title: Like Celebrities, but They Throw Chairs
description: Jerry Springer, playing himself in all but name in ''Ringmaster'' (here he is Jerry Farrelly), wants us to believe that he is the great all-caring conduit for the voices of America's oppressed common people. The only time he loses his temper in ''Ringmaster,'' a behind-the-scenes fictional comedy about two groups of guests who collide on his television talk show, comes when an outraged member of the studio audience stands up and dismisses his feuding participants as wild animals.

title: Ocean Energy and Seagull Set To Create Major Oil Concern
description: Ocean Energy Inc. and the Seagull Energy Corporation have agreed to merge in a stock swap creating the nation's 10th-largest independent oil company, executives said last night. The deal is expected to be announced today.

title: Businessman Pleads Guilty In Obstructing Fraud Inquiry
description: Two weeks before the chief financial officer of the Bennett Funding Group is to stand trial on charges that he bilked investors out of hundreds of millions of dollars, his brother admitted in court yesterday that they conspired to thwart a Federal investigation into their company.

title: Competition on the Internet
description: America Online's effort to acquire Netscape and set up a partnership with Sun Microsystems is a reminder of how rapidly the corporate landscape can change in fast-moving technical fields. But it does not lessen the need for the Justice Department to vigorously pursue its antitrust suit against Microsoft, the dominant player in software. The department has presented solid evidence that Microsoft has used its monopoly in operating systems to muscle rivals and partners so as to head off competition in other software realms.

title: EMI Operating Profit Down 22% in First Half
description: EMI Group P.L.C., the world's third-largest recorded music company, said yesterday that its profit from operations fell 22 percent in the first half of its fiscal year as a recession in parts of Asia and a slumping economy in Brazil dragged down sales. EMI, whose recording artists include Garth Brooks, Janet Jackson and the Beastie Boys, said profit for the six months that ended on Sept. 30 fell to $:39.8 million, or $65.9 million, from $:50.9 million a year earlier. The figures exclude HMV, a music company that was sold earlier this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITE, ARLENE
description: LITE-Arlene. Great Neck Synagogue notes with sorrow the passing of our member, Arlene Lite, and extends its heartfelt condolences to the entire bereaved family. May they be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dale Polakoff, Rabbi Dr. Ephraim Wolf, Rabbi Emeritus Mark Bunim, President

title: Creating Better Nursing Homes
description: To the Editor:

title: Shevack/Wolf Wins New Scotts Brands
description: The Scotts Company in Marysville, Ohio, has named Partners & Shevack/Wolf in New York to handle advertising for the Roundup and Ortho herbicide brands, with combined billings estimated at $20 million. The brands were handled by BBDO West in Los Angeles, part of Omnicom Group, when they were owned by the Monsanto Corporation; Scotts acquired the brands earlier this year.

title: Out-of-Step Ant Sails Out to Save the Hill
description: It looks as if ''A Bug's Life,'' from the computer-animation outfit Pixar and some of the personnel behind ''Toy Story,'' is the best ant colony movie of the year. And that's no small distinction, considering the bug-eat-bug movie rivalry under way. Both this and the uncannily similar ''Antz'' are sophisticated, entertaining feats of animation, but ''A Bug's Life'' has the conceptual edge as a clearly defined family film (as opposed to the more verbally adult, yet visually youth-oriented ''Antz''). As directed by John Lasseter, who directed ''Toy Story,'' and Andrew Stanton, who collaborated on the ''Toy Story'' screenplay, ''A Bug's Life'' makes jaunty, imaginative use of both extraordinary technology and bold storytelling possibilities within the insect world.

title: Europe to Study AT&T Venture
description: The AT&T Corporation and British Telecommunications P.L.C. are expected to face four more months of scrutiny by the European Union for their planned $3 billion venture, a senior European Union official said today. The delay is a sign the companies may have to scale down their plans to secure regulatory approval.

title: Clinton Critic Seeks Censure Rather Than Impeachment
description: President Clinton's fiercest Democratic critic in the House called on Speaker Newt Gingrich today to abandon the impeachment process in favor of a strong censure against Mr. Clinton.

title: Furor Over Book Brings Pain and Pride to Its Author
description: When Carolivia Herron was 5 years old, in the back yard at family feasts, her Uncle Richard would tell the story of her nappy hair.

title: Deal-Making Fever Sweeps Across Europe
description: Deutsche Bank A.G.'s $9.7 billion bid for Bankers Trust of New York is merely the most visible sign of a much broader upheaval in European finance.

title: 2d Broker Charged in New York Inquiry
description: New York State prosecutors have charged a second former broker at A. S. Goldmen with violating New York State general business law, a spokesman for the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau. said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, KLAUSNER, JANET, DR.
description: FISHMAN-KLAUSNER-Janet, Dr. Beloved wife of Stephen, devoted mother of Alexandra, loving daughter of Sarah Fishman, dear sister of Sheila Natale and Jack Fishman. Services on Wednesday, 9 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Diocese Head Condemns Unauthorized Autopsies
description: The head of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Metuchen has condemned the legal defense of a diocese-owned hospital where autopsies were performed on two fetuses without the parents' permission as contrary to church doctrine.

title: But Is It Art? Well, Yes; A Trove of Pinups at the University of Kansas Is Admired by All Sorts, Including Feminists
description: Maria Elena Buszek, self-described nerdy graduate student who reads comic books, recalls having a drink in a Chicago bar when her eyes were drawn to a pinup girl tattooed on the arm of the bartender.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WITHERS, ROSAMOND F.E., MD.
description: WITHERS-Rosamond F.E., MD. Quintessential consort, I will keep you with me forever. Donal

title: A Law School Where Jesus Is the Ultimate Case Study
description: A towering cross dominates the sweeping hillside of the Pepperdine University campus here, perched in the Santa Monica Mountains northwest of Los Angeles with a view of the glittering Pacific.

title: A Quarterback Tossup: It's a Catch-22
description: Jim Fassel is in a bad spot. He cannot win for losing. He can, however, lose for winning.

title: Consumer Group Lists Toys It Deems Dangerous
description: As parents prepare for the official start of the holiday shopping season, a consumer advocacy group announced its annual list of the 20 most dangerous toys of the year yesterday.

title: Rice and Its Worldly Guises
description: WHEN you read one of Jeffrey Alford and Naomi Duguid's cookbooks, there is no sense that they have been home in their kitchen dreaming up novel book ideas and recipes for Americans. Instead, they seem to take you on the road with them, weighed down with a backpack, scribbling notes, eating with your hands and wondering what day of the week it is.

title: As Stock Prices Rebound, Investors Return to Equity Funds
description: Mutual fund investors had little stomach for making new investments while the stock market was jittery and share prices were down, but money is flowing into equity funds again now that stocks have returned to near-record territory.

title: Incense, Peppermint, Etc.
description: It took nerve for Moby Grape to start with ''Hey Grandma'' at Wetlands on Thursday night. When Moby Grape recorded the song in 1967, it was a come-on to a hippie girl in granny glasses. But now, with gray in the musicians' hair, Moby Grape could be chasing a real grandma. The song declares, ''This time 'round, everything's upside-down'' and so it was. The music created by brash young men three decades ago sounded almost as eccentric and vital now as it did when it was written.

title: Local Units Urge Takeover Of Union for City Workers
description: The presidents of several union locals in District Council 37, New York City's largest municipal union, called yesterday for the parent union to put the council into trusteeship and force the council's executive director, Stanley Hill, to step aside.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the Public Lives page yesterday with a profile of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and his work in environmental law misidentified the model of a fish he was holding. It was a striped bass, not a sturgeon.

title: Vacco's Claim Of Votes Cast By the Dead Is Disputed
description: Democratic officials yesterday bitterly assailed an accusation that as many as 1,000 ballots might have been cast in the race for State Attorney General in the names of voters who had died before the Nov. 3 election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, MARY
description: LEWIS-Mary, 81, died peacefully and without pain at home Monday evening, November 23rd, lovingly surrounded by her family and close friends. Mary's lifetime dedication to help make the world a better, healthier and safer place for children and other living things enabled her to do extraordinary work as a nurse (psychiatric, training, teaching) at Mt. Sinai Hospital, Hillside Hospital and International House. She also helped to develop nursing communities in countries as far afield as Afghanistan and Honduras under the auspices of CARE/MEDICO. Not least of her accomplishments was as Director of Mohegan Colony Day Camp where she influenced the lives of hundreds of young people. She was mentor, guru, role model, advisor and crone to so many of us. And to the privileged few, she was mother, grandmother, mother-inlaw, grandmother-in-law, newly blessed great grandmother, cousin, sister-in-law, aunt, great aunt, best friend and lots more. On Saturday, November 28, at 12:30PM, there will be a memorial celebration of Mary's life at the International House, 500 Riverside Drive, one block north of 122 Street.

title: Concern Grows Over DiMaggio's Health
description: Joe DiMaggio, hospitalized here since Oct. 12, turns 84 on Wednesday amid mounting concern over his condition.

title: Strong Network System Sales Help Novell to Top Estimates
description: Novell Inc. reported fourth-quarter earnings that exceeded estimates by Wall Street analysts, and attributed the performance to strong sales of the new version of its network operating system, Netware 5.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN DECLINES. The Japanese currency fell after a report showed a rebound in United States consumer confidence. In New York, the dollar was trading at 121.18 yen, up from 120.99 late on Monday.

title: Too Sweet to Eat? A Proposal for the Pie
description: IT'S classic. It's irresistible. And it's a killer.

title: Much Ado About Nothing vs. Hasek
description: During a practice today in preparation for Wednesday night's meeting with Dominik Hasek and the Buffalo Sabres, the Rangers largely ignored set patterns and plays. Instead, they crowded players in front of the goal, swatting rebounds and loose pucks repeatedly against the goaltender.

title: About New York; Killing Leaves A Void On 106th St.
description: GLORIA DENARD is a jazz singer, so she knows how to improvise. Thirty-one years ago she relied more on ingenuity than income to start Manna House Workshops, an East Harlem school dedicated to jazz and dance. Grants helped her buy a five-story building on East 106th Street, where the school occupies the first two floors and the rest are rented to tenants.

title: Canadians Raise Concerns About Mexican Labor Law
description: Mexican officials have acknowledged that their labor laws do not adequately protect the rights of Mexican workers, according to documents obtained by Canadian union officials who have filed a complaint against Mexico under the North American Free Trade Agreement.

title: Sentences Issued In Gambling Case
description: Four participants in a Northwestern University basketball point-shaving operation were sentenced in Federal court in Chicago yesterday, with each receiving a short prison term and two years of probation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PODOLSKY, FLORENCE (NEE ROSENTHAL)
description: PODOLSKY - Florence (nee Rosenthal). Of Fort Lee, N.J. Beloved wife of Alvin. Devoted mother of Judy Salb and Richard. Mother-in-law of Dr. Richard Salb and Clare Tully. Loving grandmother of Rachel, Lauren, Harry, Jacob and Alice. Services ''Wien & Wien'', Hackensack, N.J. Wednesday, 11:30AM (1-800-322-0533).

title: Schroder's Morning After: Winning the Vote Was the Easy Part
description: Less than a month after he swept into office with a ready smile and talk of a ''new middle'' that would revitalize Germany, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder has lost much of the momentum and good will that propelled his ascent.

title: India to Let Foreigners Own Stakes in Insurers
description: India plans to let foreigners own as much as 40 percent of insurance companies in the country. Foreign insurers will be allowed stakes in ventures with Indian companies of as much as 26 percent, a finance ministry spokesman said yesterday. Foreign institutional investors and expatriate Indians will be able to own another 14 percent in the ventures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACKER, DR. IRVING W.
description: PACKER-Dr. Irving W. The Friends Of AKIM USA and AKIM Israel mourn the passing of their Director a man of rare humanitarian qualities.

title: Excerpt From Reno's Report Rejecting Independent Counsel in Gore Case
description: Following is an excerpt from Attorney General Janet Reno's notification to a special Federal court today that she had decided against seeking appointment of an independent counsel to investigate the campaign fund-raising activities of Vice President Al Gore:

title: DOW JONES TO DISMISS 118 WORKERS TO REDUCE COSTS
description: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that it would cut costs by dismissing 118 employees, closing offices and using an outside company to handle subscription telemarketing for The Wall Street Journal and Barron's. The move is part of a plan to stem rising expenses as Dow Jones faces an uncertain advertising market. The New York-based publisher said it expected to take an after-tax charge against fourth-quarter earnings of about $2 million, or 2 cents a share, mostly for severance and closing offices. The job cuts, affecting about 1.4 percent of Dow Jones's work force, will be made at nine sites in eight states. Dow Jones shares fell 81.25 cents, to $49.125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, MICHAEL
description: LEVINSON-Michael. Son of Jo List Levinson. See obituary under ''Israel''.

title: Creating Better Nursing Homes
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about an auction of contemporary art at Sotheby's misstated the price paid for a Brice Marden painting, a record for the artist. The painting, ''Yellows,'' sold for $1.4 million, not $992,500.

title: Cloud of Inquiry Lifted, Gore Has Wind at His Back
description: Attorney General Janet Reno's decision against seeking an independent counsel to investigate Al Gore frees the Vice President from a daunting political millstone just as he is gearing up to begin soliciting millions of dollars for his Presidential campaign in 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STATTER, JULIA BROKAW
description: STATTER-Julia Brokaw. A lifelong New York resident died November 22, 1998 in her home in Manhattan. She was 94. Mrs. Statter was active in many organizations: The American Red Cross, Girl Scouts, U.S.O., Huguenot Society of America, National Institute of Social Sciences, Metropolitan Museum, de Young Museum of San Francisco and the Colonial Dames of America. During her long career as a fashion consultant, she worked at various fashion salons including Saks Fifth Avenue and Elizabeth Arden. She was a member of The Women's National Republican Club and The Colony Club. Mrs. Statter was the daughter of Howard and Edna (Loew) Brokaw. Her father, an accomplished polo player, was coowner of Brokaw Brothers Clothing, a retail store on Fifth Avenue near The New York Public Library. She was a graduate of Miss Porter's School in Farmington, CT. She had two children from her first marriage to James Russell Lowell, Dolly (Mrs. Lowell Leib) and James Russell Lowell, Jr., both deceased. After the death of her first husband, she married Manhattan lawyer Humphrey Statter in 1964. In addition to her husband and several great grandchildren, she is survived by her grandchildren Melissa Leib Veghte (Salem, N.J.) and James Russell Lowell, III, and Howard Brokaw Lowell, both living in the Boston area. The funeral service will be held at Saint Thomas Episcopal Church, 1 West 53 Street, 10AM Friday, November 27th.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SISSELMAN, SHIRLEY REINBERG
description: SISSELMAN - Shirley Reinberg. We mourn the passing of Shirley Sisselman, beloved wife of our friend and colleague Milton Sisselman of the Faculty Practice Association of Mt. Sinai Medical Center. To Milton and Shirley's entire family, we offer our profound condolences. Robert G. Newman, MD, President Continuum Health Partners, Inc. Wendy Z. Goldstein Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center

title: For Laughs, A Murder By Fright
description: Every time a movie like ''Home Fries'' appears, you can sense Hollywood's eagerness for a smart screwball comedy that hits the commercial bull's-eye and proves that there really is a place for sophisticated humor in a market dominated by the dumbed-down capers of the Farrelly brothers, Jim Carrey and Adam Sandler. ''Home Fries'' probably isn't that movie. But this absurdist satire of sex, sibling rivalry, Oedipal ties, homicidal fantasies and fast food in the American heartland at least has the right attitude. It just isn't funny enough in its particulars to make you break up laughing.

title: 10 Million Playpens Have Deadly Flaw, U.S. Warns Public
description: The Government announced today that nearly 10 million playpens must be repaired or destroyed because children could strangle themselves if their clothing became caught on metal rivets protruding from rails and hinges atop the pens.

title: RENO ENDS INQUIRY INTO FUND-RAISING BY VICE PRESIDENT
description: Attorney General Janet Reno concluded today that there was insufficient evidence to seek the appointment of an independent counsel to investigate Vice President Al Gore's fund-raising role in the 1996 re-election campaign.

title: Intuit Reports a Seasonal Loss: $49.2 Million in First Quarter
description: Intuit Inc. reported a fiscal first-quarter loss today, reflecting the costs of developing tax preparation products to sell in coming months. The loss had been expected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERGER, MARJORIE H.
description: GREENBERGER - Marjorie H., Retired teacher, 94, on November 24, 1998 at New Rochelle Nursing Home. Beloved aunt of Richard, Laura, Carol, James, Neil and Constance. Services will be private.

title: Please, Don't Call It Health Food
description: DREW NIEPORENT'S original concept for the menu at the restaurant he is planning to open on East 49th Street was true fat-free food. The chef he hired to create the menu, Michel Nischan, tried to please. Eventually, he conceded defeat. Thank goodness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHRANZ, EVA KARP
description: SCHRANZ-Eva Karp. Sutton Place Synagogue extends heartfelt condolences to our esteemed Rabbi Allan Schranz, his wife Ellen and children Molly and Asher on the loss of their beloved mother and grandmother. Our sympathies to the bereaved family, Bernice (Bennett) Pleeter, Esther (Alan) Cohen, Toby (Fred) Rusgo, Dr. Howard (Hedy) Schranz, Rabbi Mitchell (Channa) Schranz, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Services are today 10 A.M. United Hebrew Community Chapel, 201 East Broadway. Robert W. Berend, President Philip Sassower, Executive Committee Chair

title: Witnesses Tell Of Gunshots In a Killing
description: A police officer killed at a Chelsea apartment last year clearly identified himself before the suspect in his death opened fire, two witnesses testified yesterday at the suspect's trial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYDE, NATALIE RUBINSTEIN
description: HYDE-Natalie Rubinstein. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of Natalie Rubinstein Hyde, beloved mother of our esteemed colleague Judy Swartz. Our deepest heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May her memory be for a blessing Marlene E. Post, Nat'l President Dr. Laura S. Schor, Nat'l Exec Dir

title: The Season Runs On as the Tour Limps On
description: At least on the surface, women's tennis shut down for the season at Madison Square Garden on Sunday, and did so with a flourish:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Creating Better Nursing Homes
description: To the Editor:

title: J.C. Penney to Buy Genovese, Expanding Its Drugstore Chain
description: J. C. Penney Company, the Texas-based retailer, has agreed to buy Genovese Drug Stores Inc., a leading chain in the metropolitan region, for $492 million in stock and debt, the two companies announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIM, EARL
description: KIM-Earl. We mourn the passing of our friend and colleague. Composer, devoted teacher, musician extraordinaire, Earl brought to music colors we only dreamed existed but had never before heard. Creative and imaginative, he was truly inspired. We extend our condolences to his beloved wife, Martha, his daughters Shawna Kent and Eva. He will be missed. Itzhak and Toby Perlman

title: Death of Suspect Hit by Radio Ruled a Homicide
description: The death of a 36-year-old man who was hit in the head last month by a radio a police officer threw at him was ruled a homicide yesterday by the Chief Medical Examiner's office.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GASOLINE PLUMMETS. Unleaded gasoline futures dropped to a 12-year low on expectations that OPEC would leave production levels in place. In New York, unleaded gasoline fell 1.49 cents, to 35.29 cents a gallon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, EDNA F.
description: COHEN-Edna F. Beloved wife of the late Harry M., loving mother of Howard and Roslyn, and the late Roberta Bonomo. Cherished grandmother and great grandmother.

title: A Televised Death: Prurient or Newsworthy, or Both?
description: They're ganging up on ''60 Minutes.'' In the pile-on are Roman Catholic prelates, medical ethicists, editorial writers, television reviewers and teachers of journalism, all expressing indignation, shock, outrage that the pre-eminent news magazine should have run a video of Dr. Jack Kevorkian giving lethal injections to Thomas Youk, who suffered from Lou Gehrig's disease.

title: FEDERAL-MOGUL TO SELL STOCK TO CUT DEBT IN COOPER DEAL
description: The Federal-Mogul Corporation, one of the most active consolidators in the automotive parts industry, plans to sell 14 million shares of stock in an offering worth $703.5 million. The company, in Southfield, Mich., will used the proceeds to reduce debt related to its $1.9 billion purchase last month of the automotive parts business of Cooper Industries of Houston. Reflecting a series of huge acquisitions, sales of Federal-Mogul more than doubled in the third quarter, to $1.12 billion from $424.2 million. The stock slipped 25 cents a share yesterday, to $58.3125.

title: F.C.C. Says Sprint and Telmex Overcharged on Some Rates
description: The Federal Government said today that it had received significant evidence that a joint venture created by the Sprint Corporation and Telefonos de Mexico, or Telmex, had committed anticompetitive practices in the long-distance market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREED, HERMINE
description: FREED-Hermine. Died on November 21, 1998. Artist, teacher, extraordinary cook, mother, wife, friend. You are deeply missed and will never be forgotten. Barbara Zucker Gina Zucker Mannie Lionni

title: Sports of The Times; DiMaggio, Failing, Is 84 Today
description: IN the press room of Yankee Stadium not long ago I saw Joe DiMaggio sitting at a table with a few friends. Even in repose he looked elegant, still trim in his dark suit, hair graying and thin but neatly coiffed. I was reminded of a remark by Henry Kissinger when he sat near DiMaggio in the owner's box in Yankee Stadium. The Yankees had lost a playoff game and Kissinger, on the way out, had said, ''Joe, put on a uniform -- they can use you.'' In the mind's eye, Joe still could lope after a fly ball.

title: ROUSE AND J. P. MORGAN IN $930 MILLION VENTURE
description: The Rouse Company in Columbia, Md., has taken on J. P. Morgan Investment Management as a partner to help finance its purchase of four malls for about $930 million. J. P. Morgan will hold a 65 percent stake in the joint venture as it invests $270 million in cash and assumes about $334 million of debt. The sites -- Bridgewater Commons in Bridgewater, N.J., and malls in Denver, Baltimore and Salt Lake City -- are part of a package of seven that Rouse agreed to buy earlier this year for $1.11 billion from the TrizecHahn Corporation of Toronto. Separately, Rouse sold its Metro Plaza office complex in Silver Spring, Md., to TrizecHahn for $91 million in cash.

title: Is Star System Good for Academia?; Clarify the Mission
description: To the Editor:

title: London Journal; Hereditary Peers Feel the Winds of Obsolescence
description: Among the snubbed were the Silver Stick in Waiting, Maltravers Herald Extraordinary, Blackrod, Portcullis Pursuivant, the Crown Equerry and the Gentleman Usher of the Sword of State.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, RANDY
description: FOX-Randy. The Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member, Randy Fox, and extends heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Abby, and the entire family. Rabbi Stanley Platek Dr. Norman Doctor, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, GENE
description: MOORE-Gene. It's been a ''merry-go-round''. Much love, Your lunch dates, Jenny & Liz

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WULFE, NOAH
description: WULFE-Noah. 86. At his home on Nov. 23, 1998. For over 30 years, he owned Noah Wulfe Guitars, NYC, where he sold and repaired string instruments. Also repaired instruments for the H.S. of Music and Art. Survived by wife Lillian and two sons, Daniel and Martin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNCH, MATTHEW J.
description: LYNCH-Matthew J. On November 23, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Anne (nee Kelly). Loving father of Kevin, Christine Ivins, Marie and the late Kathleen Egan. Cherished grandfather of four and great grandfather of two. Dear brother to Robert Lynch and Doris Camlin. Reposing Wednesday 7-9 PM and Friday 2-4 and 7-9PM at Riverdale - on - Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue (W. 261st St.), Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial 10 AM Saturday at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Teacher Cites Threats Over Children's Book
description: School officials supported the use of the book ''Nappy Hair'' by a white third-grade teacher, but the teacher said she feared returning to her classroom because of threats from parents. Some parents at Public School 75 in Brooklyn have said the book, written by a black writer and scholar, is racially insensitive. Page B10.

title: Revenge of the Wampanoags
description: A few years ago my mother and I drove to Plym outh, Mass. home of the Rock -- on one of our notorious history road trips. We drove past the sea, past cranberry bogs, to the main history-can-be-fun tourist destination, Plimoth Plantation, where it's always 1627. When planes fly overhead, women in dark bonnets and cotton leggings look to the sky, shield their eyes and say, ''Ay, 'tis a newe type of byrdde.'' My mom and I eat this stuff up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POMERANCE, NORMAN
description: POMERANCE-Norman, 72, former book publishing executive and engineer, on November 23, 1998. Husband of Paula Diamond and the late Carol Joan Raynor. Survivors include his son John and daughter-in-law Marcy Parlow Pomerance of Wellesley, Massachusettes; his daughter Jane and son-in-law Whit Gallagher of Yarmouth, Maine; his son Jason of Los Angeles, California, and his six grandsons, Jared, Justin, and Luke Pomerance and Jake, Bart and Nate Gallagher. Services at 10:45 AM on Friday, November 27 at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory may be made to the American Diabetes Association. Friends are welcome at the family residence on Friday from 4-7 P.M., and on Saturday from 1-4 P.M.

title: Holyfield and Lewis End Talks and Put Up Fists
description: The Champagne has been chilling for so long it has frostbite. After six weeks of haggling over such things as the shape of the bargaining table, the deal for the heavyweight unification bout between Evander Holyfield and Lennox Lewis is finally done.

title: Accounts
description: * SmarterKids.com Inc., Needham, Mass., to Darwin Digital, New York, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., as the first agency to handle consumer advertising for the reseller of children's educational products. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'AMICO, MABEL
description: D'AMICO-Mabel. In Amagansett, NY, on November 22, 1998. The family of Mabel D'Amico mourns the death of our beloved aunt. She inspired us to see the beauty in every day things in the world about us. Her gentle grace and enthusiasm will be sorely missed.

title: In Interview, Starr Says Control of Tripp Was Lax
description: Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel who has recommended that Congress impeach President Clinton, has acknowledged that his investigators should have kept closer watch on Linda R. Tripp, the Government employee whose furtive tape recordings precipitated the criminal investigation of the President.

title: In TriBeCa, More French Than Ever
description: THE sommelier is standing by our table. ''Excuse me,'' he says, ''but some people in the next dining room have ordered the '79 Chateau du Tertre you are drinking. We have one bottle left; will you be wanting more?''

title: A Bathroom That Makes You Want to Stay Home for the Day
description: I WENT in search of a universal garden and found a universal bathroom instead. I stared at the sleek, legless white chair hanging on the rail of the elegant shower in the ''Unlimited by Design'' exhibition now at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum of the Smithsonian Institution, and ''Ode to Joy'' starting playing in my head. I love it when Manhattan crashes into the old homestead.

title: Metro Business; Workers in Lockout Lose ABC Benefits
description: Escalating a bitter labor dispute, ABC has discontinued benefits for the estimated 1,600 to 1,800 off-camera employees the company locked out early this month.

title: N.B.A. Cancels Next Bargaining Session
description: This dispute is beginning to play out like the final scene of the bitter divorce movie ''War of the Roses,'' in which the couple fight until they are left sprawled and dying in the debris of a crystal chandelier.

title: Centrist Ruler, Under Fire, Is Voted Out In Turkey
description: The Government of Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz, plagued since its inception 17 months ago by competing pressures from Islamic groups and the rigidly secular military, fell today when it lost a confidence vote.

title: Former Ally Of Netanyahu May Return To Cabinet
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is ready to bring his former Foreign Minister, David Levy, back into his Cabinet in an effort to shore up his disintegrating coalition and to fortify his chances at either re-election or assembling a unity Government.

title: A Virtual Grandma Helps With Dinner
description: WHERE is the recipe I followed last Thanksgiving, when it was my turn to cook the turkey: after ordering a freshly killed bird that weighed slightly more than a Chevy Geo, I phoned my husband at work. In the course of a completely innocuous conversation, I may have casually reminded him that the last fowl I roasted (in 1989) had turned out slightly dry, not unlike sand. So once again, my husband cooked the turkey. I highly recommend this method.

title: Today's N.F.L. Matchups
description: PITTSBURGH (7-4) at DETROIT (4-7)12:35 P.M. TV: CBS

title: XTRA CALLS OFF SALE TO INTERPOOL AND APOLLO
description: The Xtra Corporation, which leases trailers and freight containers, said yesterday that its sale to Interpool Inc. and Apollo Management L.P. had been terminated and it was renegotiating the transaction. When the deal was announced in June, the price was $65 a share, a total of $965 million in cash. Adding debt that was to be assumed, the total obligation was $1.9 billion. Apollo, which is headed by Leon Black, and Interpool planned to finance the transaction with junk bonds and bank loans, but the spread between Treasury bonds and average junk-bond yields has widened since the announcement in June. Xtra rose $1.6875 a share yesterday, to $49.125, while Interpool's shares rose 56.25 cents, to $14.50. The announcement was made after the close of trading in the United States.

title: Umbilical Cord May Be Lifeline in Marrow Cases
description: For people who need bone-marrow transplants to fight leukemia or other deadly diseases, but who lack a compatible marrow donor, doctors are salvaging hope from a curious source, one that is normally thrown away: blood left in the umbilical cords and placentas of newborn infants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, LEONARD
description: NEWMAN-Leonard. Of New Jersey on November 24, 1998. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. Services on Friday 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Crockett: Weighing Legend and Fact
description: To the Editor:

title: Cox Accuses the N.F.L. of Racism After $10,000 Fine
description: Bryan Cox, believed to be the most heavily fined player in pro football history, has been on his best behavior since joining the Jets in August and, as a result, had been enjoying a fine-free season.

title: Johnson Shares Fall on Lower '99 Estimate
description: Johnson & Johnson, the world's largest maker of medical devices, said yesterday that its 1999 profit would be less than the $3 a share estimated earlier, sending shares down 3 percent. Johnson & Johnson's shares fell $2.625 to close at $82.625. The company, which is based in New Brunswick, reached a record high of $89 just last Friday.

title: Garth Brooks, The Music Man
description: Last Tuesday became known in the music business as Super Tuesday after a glut of major records were released simultaneously for the holidays by superstars like Garth Brooks, Whitney Houston, Mariah Carey, Jewel, Method Man and Seal.

title: Murder Suspect Shot to Death After Chase and the Wounding of 2 New Jersey Officers
description: A man wanted on murder charges in Maryland wounded two New Jersey police officers this morning and was later shot to death by the police after a chase through at least five towns in Union County, the police and local prosecutors said.

title: British Trade Deficit Is at Record Level
description: Britain's trade deficit widened to $:2.5 billion, or $4 billion, in September from $:1.28 billion in August, the highest since records began, as the slump in world markets reduced overseas demand for British goods.

title: Investors to Fight $2 Billion Prison Merger
description: Three of the nation's largest pension funds said today that they would vote against the Corrections Corporation of America's planned $2 billion merger with a sister company, CCA Prison Realty Trust.

title: Book Bound, or, Trapped by the Page
description: There is no need to wait for the end of Abelardo Estorino's ''Parece Blanca'' (''She Looks White'') to see how it all comes out. In the first two minutes a jealous tailor rams his scissors through the heart of a rich young man at the altar as he is about to be married and a woman who had been his mistress screams ''Not him, not him; kill her!'' Then all the characters, dead and living alike, regroup and spend the rest of the play trying to figure out how their ambition, lust, guilt and multiple betrayals -- all quite normal in Havana in the 1840's -- brought them to this tragedy.

title: Lehigh Quarterback Is Player of the Year
description: The Patriot League coaches have voted Phil Stambaugh, the Lehigh quarterback, as their player of the year. Stambaugh led the Mountain Hawks to an undefeated season and a place in the Division I-AA playoffs beginning Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WUNDERLICH, LILLIAN
description: WUNDERLICH-Lillian, 84 years old, on Nov. 24, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Loving mother of Beth and Frank Wal and Lewis and Sharon. Cherished sister of Anne Volk. Services on Friday, at 10:30 A.M., at Schwartz BrothersJeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard (76th Road), Forest Hills, New York.

title: Brooklyn Replies
description: To the Editor:

title: Salo Withstands 46 Shots As Islanders Defeat Flyers
description: As the Philadelphia Flyers swarmed around the Islanders' goal, seemingly sending wave after wave of players nearly uncontested in front of the net, the Islanders might have felt as if they were playing at least a man down all game long.

title: Composting, Well, Philosophically
description: TOOLS OF THE EARTH

title: Essay; What Russia Needs Now
description: During the spring primary elections in Chicago in 1928, candidates were machine-gunned and bombs at polling places terrorized voters. Desperate to prevent political violence in the November election, the head of the Crime Commission went to the city's most powerful gangster, Al Capone, to plead for help.

title: Steam Meets Silicon In New Toy Trains
description: IT'S never too late to have a happy childhood!'' suggests a colorful magazine advertisement from Lionel, the world's best-known manufacturer of toy trains. And between Thanksgiving and Christmas, tens of thousands of relatively inexpensive electric train sets will be bought by parents and grandparents, ostensibly for boys and girls who will never see an actual New York Central steam engine belching black smoke.

title: The Scene Shifts: Enter Elgar
description: When a flurry of activity surrounding, say, Beethoven falls unbidden from the sky, you can chalk it up to the law of averages. But Elgar?

title: Hitting the Virtual Slopes All Year Round
description: SNOW skiing in cyberspace has certain advantages over the traditional winter pastime of sliding down a powdery slope that may be booby-trapped with moguls, rocks and ice. Carving turns among the hundreds of Internet sites that are devoted to the sport is no more chilly than room temperature, and unlike waiting in most chairlift lines, downloading a Web page can take just a few seconds.

title: Giants' Hamilton Apologizes
description: Giants defensive tackle Keith Hamilton had little comment today on his Monday arrest on a charge of marijuana possession.

title: Gray Wolf Killed in Arizona; Was Last in Reintroduction Test
description: The rapid beeping of a radio collar on the yearling male wolf recently signaled the end of Mexican gray wolves in the wild -- for now, at least.

title: He Caught Folk On the Rise And Held On
description: It was Veterans Day, and as Harold Leventhal ducked into Carnegie Hall through the back and followed a yellowish strip on an Indian red floor, you got the feeling he had been here before.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAAYANI, EDNA
description: MAAYANI-Edna. Bnai Zion, the 90 year old American Zionist Fraternal Organization, mourns the passing, after a long and courageous battle against cancer, of its long time Associate National Director Edna Maayani, a valiant worker and devoted supporter of Jewish causes and the State of Israel. She was a talented artist and graphic designer who brought these special skills to her work, augmenting the administrative responsibilities of her position. To her children, parents, sister and grandchildren we offer our heartfelt condolences. Funeral services to be held at Bnai Zion House 136 East 39th Street, New York City, at 9:45am on Friday November 27th. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Bnai Zion Foundation. Alan G. Hevesi, National President Mel Parness, Executive VP

title: In Free-Agent Poker, Williams Takes the Pot
description: Restless in his room at 1 o'clock yesterday morning, Bernie Williams called the Yankees' general manager, Brian Cashman, who was staying in the same Tampa, Fla., hotel.

title: What's a City Without a Tiff?
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Send Out Circulars Warning of a Child Killer
description: Following the system of community alerts that ''Megan's Law'' provides for paroled sex offenders, the police in Jackson Township, N.J., have circulated fliers about a 40-year-old man convicted of murdering a 12-year-old girl in Virginia in 1982.

title: The Many Alternatives to Impeachment
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, LEWIS R.
description: KAPLAN-Lewis R. On November 25, 1998. Adoring husband of Lilly. Beloved father of Dr. Ruth Treiber and Harriet Suvall. Also survived by his sons-in-law Dr. Eric Treiber and Marc Suvall and four grandchildren. He enriched the lives of everyone who knew him. Funeral at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, Friday, November 27, 9:30AM, 1000 Pinebrook Blvd., New Rochelle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, GENE
description: MOORE-Gene. Great Artist. Gentle, magical friend, Ciao Amore Mio. I will miss you. Love, Gioconda Crivelli

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''International law has made plain that certain types of conduct, including torture and hostage-taking, are not acceptable conduct on the part of anyone. This applies as much to heads of state, or even more so, as it does to everyone else. The contrary conclusion would make a mockery of international law. ''

title: 5 Men Rob Supermarket In Brooklyn of $15,000
description: Five armed men robbed a Brooklyn supermarket crowded with Thanksgiving shoppers of $15,000 yesterday, the police said.

title: Mr. Pinochet Loses a Round
description: A British appeals court yesterday greatly bolstered the possibility that Gen. Augusto Pinochet of Chile will face justice -- a quarter-century after most of the crimes of his military coup. The 3-to-2 decision that Mr. Pinochet's status as a former head of state does not give him immunity in Britain makes it likely that British courts will agree to Spain's request for his extradition. The decision will rest in the hands of Home Secretary Jack Straw. Unless General Pinochet's health worsens drastically, Mr. Straw must resist the temptation to decide that he is too frail to stand trial.

title: Exxon Talks With Mobil Are Reported
description: The Exxon Corporation and the Mobil Corporation have held discussions about combining their business operations, a person involved in the talks said yesterday.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK CLIMBS. The mark rose against the dollar as two German central bankers made clear there would be no interest rate cut by the end of the year. In New York, the dollar traded at 1.7035 marks, down from 1.7053.

title: Cellularvision Sells Licenses To Winstar
description: Cellularvision USA Inc., a small communications company based in Brooklyn, said yesterday that it had completed the sale of most of its New York wireless licenses to Winstar Communications Inc. The sale, for $32.5 million, ends Cellularvision's troubled life as a competitor to cable television.

title: Pass the Turkey. And the Stir-Fry.
description: This year, my family will be sitting down to a salt-cured Thanksgiving turkey stuffed with sticky rice, shiitake mushrooms, Chinese sausage and dried shrimp. On the side we'll have baked yams and corn stir-fried with scallions and soy sauce. We've adapted an American tradition, and we serve it Chang-style.

title: What's a City Without a Tiff?
description: To the Editor:

title: ADMIRAL ACCUSED OVER CONTRACTS
description: A one-star admiral serving at the Navy's headquarters in the Pentagon has been relieved of his duties and accused of improperly steering military contracts to a woman with whom he was having an adulterous affair, Navy and defense officials said today.

title: A Night to Celebrate and, Yes, to Dance
description: In the end was the beginning, as the New York City Ballet crowned its 50th-anniversary gala on Tuesday night with an especially festive look back at its first performance, on Oct. 11, 1948.

title: Encouraging an Early Taste for Fame
