description: SHORTLY after the birth of Chris Shows's first child in a Monroe, La., hospital earlier this month, he got a call from his brother, William, in Austin, Tex.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMPTON, HENRY
description: HAMPTON-Henry. The Board and staff of the Charles H. Revson Foundation deeply mourn the passing of our Board member, colleague, and friend, Henry Hampton. Henry brought to the craft of film making the conviction of the educator, the eye of the artist, the subtle intelligence of the historian, the determination of the inspired messenger. His masterpiece documentary of the Civil Rights era, ''Eyes on the Prize,'' will endure as the definitive visual history of that mid-twentieth century struggle, and will inform and inspire generations of young people around the world into the next century. A quiet man, whose humanism radiated from his entire being, Henry's capacity for empathy and friendship ran deep. The nation has lost a great filmmaker; those of us who knew him have also lost a respected colleague and an unforgettable friend. Charles H. Revson Foundation Robert S. Rifkind, Chairman Eli N. Evans, President

title: Beijing Says It Will Bid For Olympics Set for 2008
description: The city of Beijing announced today that it plans to bid for the 2008 Summer Olympic Games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, EDITH
description: BERMAN-Edith. November 10, 1998. A woman of surpassing qualities: extraordinarily devoted wife, exemplary mother, patient, adoring grandmother, loyal, unwavering, and generous in her love for those dear to her. In her gracious, lovely, and endlessly unassuming way, she occupied a place in our hearts so outsized, so far beyond the roles of sister-in-law and aunt. We will miss her ready laughter, her quick wit, her gifted, brilliant mind. The joy and contentment she found in everyday life set a standard to strive for. Her loss is devastating to our family. Nothing will be the same without her, but she will live on forever in our hearts. Marlene, Richard, Jamie, Kerry, Kenneth, and Julie Grau, Neil, Carolyn, Marla, Adam, and Jennifer Berman

title: Bank of Taiwan Cuts Interest Rates
description: The Bank of Taiwan has cut its prime lending rate by 2.5 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.375 percent from 7.4 percent, the bank said late yesterday. It has also slashed the savings rate by one-tenth to three-tenths of a percentage point on deposits maturing in one month to three years.

title: Sports of The Times; All It Takes Is One Team To Ante Up
description: TO understand how badly George Steinbrenner miscalculated Bernie Williams's worth, we should remember that he threatened to trade his center fielder last winter when Williams's agent, Scott Boras, laughed off a reported five-year, $37.5 million offer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERLING, ERWIN
description: HERLING-Erwin. Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem mourns the loss of an extraordinary man whose selflessness and kind heart helped to write a new and glorious chapter in the history of ''The Hospital With A Heart''. A Holocaust victim, he helped to build and strengthen vital institutions on the memory of the ashes, that would rebuild the Jewish nation's body and soul. Today, Shaare Zedek's Herling Building rises above the skyline as a beacon of hope to the thousands of patients who are cared for with ultramodern care, compassion and dignity. His overwhelming generosity will benefit the people of Israel for generations to come. Sincerest condolences to his beloved wife, Tova. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratkzer, President Lee Weinbach, President, National Women's Division

title: Leveling the Playing Field For Left-Handed Gamers
description: A good video game player needs good hand-eye coordination. But one company contends keyboards favor good right-hand-eye coordination.

title: The Boutique Look Comes Home (Part 2)
description: Edition II has arrived. The lower-cost sequel to Philippe Starck's wildly successful Edition I line of bathroom furnishings has just been introduced by Duravit. Based on humble archetypes -- the water pump, the earthenware bowl, the bathing barrel -- Mr. Starck's sleekly modern basins, toilets and tubs have become status symbols in boutique hotels.

title: Brooklyn Replies
description: To the Editor:

title: BESICORP AGREES TO BE ACQUIRED FOR ABOUT $105 MILLION
description: Besicorp Group Inc., a developer of independent power projects, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired for $34.50 a share by Lion Gate L.L.C., the investment vehicle for Thamer bin Said al-Shanfari, a citizen of Oman. Shares of Besicorp rose 50 cents, to $32.25. Based on the 3.04 million Besicorp shares outstanding as of Sept. 30, the deal has a value of about $105 million. Besicorp, based in Kingston, N.Y., also said it had agreed to sell two small power plants in which it owned partnership interests of 50 percent. The company said it would receive as much as $13 million from the sales. Lion Gate is based in the British Virgin Islands.

title: British Court Rules Against Pinochet; Now Cabinet Must Weigh Extradition
description: The House of Lords today rejected the claim by Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former Chilean dictator, to immunity from arrest and committed him to remain in custody here while Spain seeks his extradition on charges of mass murder and terrorism.

title: A Name So Smooth, the Product Glides In
description: NUON. Say it a few times. Roll it around on your tongue. Nnnnnnn. Nnnnnnuon. Nuuuu-on. Oooooh.

title: What's a City Without a Tiff?
description: To the Editor:

title: Europeans, But Not U.S., Rejoice At Ruling
description: Many European leaders applauded today's ruling against the former dictator of Chile, Augusto Pinochet, but within the United States Government and in some legal circles, there was a note of consternation at the potential power of a Spanish judge to transcend national borders in the name of international law.

title: New Plan to Protect Police Whistle-Blowers
description: The Police Department has instituted a new policy intended to protect whistle-blowers from retaliation from fellow officers. The move is an effort to chip away at the so-called blue wall of silence, the reluctance of officers to report corruption or misconduct by other officers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAIZEL, ROSALIE
description: MAIZEL-Rosalie. Beloved wife of Ralph for fifty-six years. Devoted mother of Andrew. Cherished cousin of Martin Slomka and Glory Kleiner. Services Sunday, 12 Noon, at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapels, 152 2nd Avenue, NYC, NY.

title: Yankees Capitulate, Keeping Williams in $87.5 Million Pact
description: Bernie Williams, the star center fielder, agreed to re-sign with the Yankees yesterday after the team caved in to his demand for a seven-year contract worth $87.5 million, in a stunning reversal. The Yankees, who won 125 games and the World Series this past season, will virtually field the same group of players in 1999, a rarity since the advent of free agency.

title: 5 Judges' Explanations
description: Following are excerpts from explanations today by the Law Lords on the Pinochet case, as distributed by The Press Association, the British domestic news agency:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILL, THOMAS D.
description: HILL-Thomas D. Jr. On November 25, 1998, of Pleasantville, NY. Retired senior Vice President of Chase Manhattan Bank. Husband of Frances. Father of five. Reposing at the Maher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY (914-769-2044) Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM where services will be held at 8 PM that night. Interment, Saturday morning, Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, Central Park West from 86th Street to Columbus Circle and Broadway from Columbus Circle to 33d Street will be closed today starting at 8 A.M.

title: Mortgage Buyers Lift Size Limits
description: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac said today that they would increase the limit on the size of single-family mortgages they will buy in 1999 by 5.66 percent, to $240,000 from $227,150.

title: N.F.L.: NOTEBOOK
description: GIANTS

title: India Vote Shows Disillusion With Hindu Nationalist Government
description: Indians were in a sour mood today as they voted in elections that are most likely to weaken further the wobbly Hindu nationalist-led coalition that has governed for eight months.

title: Impeachment Panel Starts Work On 3 Articles Against President
description: As the House Judiciary Committee moves into the final stages of its inquiry, Representative Henry J. Hyde's senior staff is beginning to draw up three articles of impeachment against President Clinton.

title: Getting Started; Trains for the Purist to the Newcomer
description: ELABORATE layouts that replicate real railroads in real places in great detail are typically the province of modelers using small-scale rather than traditional-size (O-gauge) trains, which are approximately 1/48th the size of the prototypes.

title: Lobbyist Named as Transportation Chief
description: New Jersey's Transportation Commissioner resigned today, and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman quickly announced that she would replace him with a lobbyist who represented a casino owner in his dealings with the state.

title: Griswoldville Journal; A Field of Honor at Last For a Ragtag 1864 Militia
description: The soldiers were not really soldiers at all, but old men and boys and others who were considered unfit for a real Confederate uniform, armed with squirrel rifles and shotguns and smooth-bore muskets that hurled a musket ball in the rough direction of the enemy. Their commanding general had no real experience in battle, and it was rumored that what courage he had came from a bottle of bourbon.

title: Political Fires Send Envoy to U.N. Hot Seat
description: It was an accident of politics that put Peter Burleigh in the American chair this fall when the Security Council grappled in its inimitably ponderous way through crises in Kosovo and then Iraq.

title: Inflation Hopes Lift Treasuries
description: United States bonds rose yesterday for the fifth time in six days, pushing yields to the lowest this month, on optimism that inflation will remain benign even as the economy keeps growing.

title: The Many Alternatives to Impeachment
description: To the Editor:

title: A Late Bloomer Joins the Marijuana Debate
description: LYNN ZIMMER wasn't even in the same room as a marijuana cigarette until 1980, when she was 33 years old.

title: The Many Alternatives to Impeachment
description: To the Editor:

title: Thanksgiving
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNIGHT, WILLIAM GARDNER
description: KNIGHT-William Gardner. Age 56. Of Delray Beach, FL. On November 21 when his private plane crashed near Annapolis, MD. Mr. Knight graduated from Wabash College and received an MBA from the University of Virginia. He went on to become a Wall Street investment banker and later turned his efforts to acting and writing, with roles in several films, notably ''Wall Street'' and ''Born on the Fourth of July''. He was an accomplished pilot and wrote many articles on vintage aircraft. Survivors include two sons William Gardner Knight, Jr. and Hunter Hamilton Knight, both of New York City; a brother, Milton F. Knight of Perrysburg, OH; and a sister, Barbara Knight Edwards of Naples, FL. There will be a memorial service at the Carranor Hunt and Polo Club in Perrysburg at 1:30PM on November 28.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Star Goes Public With His Illness

title: Hearing Aids: Smaller and Smarter
description: THE earliest hearing aid was simplicity itself and is still in use: a cupped hand behind the ear. But today's technology has made hearing aids much less obtrusive and much more helpful. While early hearing aids tried to improve upon the external ear, with devices to direct the sound coming from the front into the ear of the listener and block noise from the sides and rear, modern devices fit surreptitiously behind or into an ear while augmenting the sound coming in.

title: Kevorkian Case Difficult To Prosecute, Experts Say
description: Prosecutors are at a sharp disadvantage in the first-degree premeditated murder case they filed against Dr. Jack Kevorkian yesterday because a jury might find it easy to sympathize with the suffering of the terminally ill, experts in criminal law said yesterday.

title: Deutsche Telekom Improves Earnings
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G., Europe's largest phone company, said today that it had improved third-quarter earnings by narrowing losses in cable television and other divisions even as rivals took a bigger bite out of its long-distance business.

title: A Song in Your Pocket
description: TELEPHONES used to be more predictable. They were generally tethered securely to a wall, and when they rang, well, they rang. Today, telephones are adrift, floating like dandelion seeds throughout the environment, and they don't ring. They warble.

title: Visits to News Sites Decline, For Understandable Reasons
description: Major news organizations may wince at first glance at the latest figures on the decline in popularity of their on-line sites.

title: The Champagne Auction That Fizzled
description: TUESDAY morning saw the return of the Terror, at Christie's on Park Avenue in New York. Not since the Revolution have so many highly valued French heads rolled. Billed by the auction house as ''the most valuable and important collection of European furniture ever to come to auction,'' the French & Company sale of largely 18th-century furniture from aristocratic collections, including Versailles itself, was something of a blood bath.

title: More Spam Haiku
description: To the Editor:

title: A Village Evolving Searches Its Soul
description: IT is difficult to reconcile the watercolor renderings of pert Dutch-roofed houses and sprawling Tudor apartment complexes with the rocky forest that rings the very private enclave of Tuxedo Park. But if developers and town officials have their way -- and it appears they are close -- Tuxedo, with its population of 3,000, may quadruple in size over the next decade or two. Bulldozers and blasting caps will arrive in the next few years, and this sleepy town -- with its scattering of vacant shop fronts -- will get the development it has dreamed of and dreaded for the last 20 years.

title: Anger Over a Camp's Conversion
description: In a region filled with monasteries, churches and religious retreats of every stripe, one might think a Christian conference center could slip in with barely a ripple.

title: Yardley Brands Are Sold
description: The best-known brand names of Yardley, Britain's most famous perfume maker, have been sold by receivers to Wella A.G. for an undisclosed sum. Wella, a hair care and cosmetics company based in Darmstadt, Germany, that had revenue of $2.4 billion last year, is buying Yardley's Bath Luxuries division, including the English Lavender, Lily of the Valley and Sandalwood lines. Yardley, which is closely held, went into receivership in August amid mounting losses and debt of almost $200 million.

title: A Store Adds Vitual Floors
description: MOSS, a four-year-old interior design store at 146 Greene Street in SoHo, has added four new floors, but customers will not be climbing stairs to reach them. Instead, they will be clicking a mouse. That's because Moss's new floors exist within a computer program and can be reached only through what could be Manhattan's first virtual elevator.

title: Earl Kim, 78, Noted Composer Of Austere and Dazzling Works
description: Earl Kim, a composer whose music valued economy, precision and quietude, and who was an important mentor to younger composers during a 23-year career at Harvard University, died last Thursday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 78.

title: LUCENT TO BUY 80% OF WAVE ACCESS FOR $50 MILLION
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the remaining 80 percent of the closely held Wave Access Ltd. for $50 million in cash, giving Lucent, the No. 1 North American phone equipment maker, a technology for sending data on wireless networks. Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., paid $6 million in May for a 20 percent stake in Wave Access, based in Raanana, Israel. Lucent expects to take an unspecified charge for research and development at Wave Access. Wave Access's technology lets wireless users send and receive information over the Internet.

title: Viewing Windows By Using Windows
description: The seasonal tradition of creating lavish holiday displays in department store windows went digital this week when Bloomingdale's flagship store at 59th and Lexington Avenue began Webcasting its famously magical windows. Teaming up with the 3Com Corporation, Bloomingdale added images of the holiday windows (updated every 30 seconds) to the store's Web site (www.bloomingdales.com).

title: Gene Moore, 88, Window Display Artist, Dies
description: Gene Moore, a window dresser who worked such fanciful wonders with shoes and had such a whimsical way with diamonds that he had Fifth Avenue pedestrians doing delighted double takes for more than half a century, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88 and best known for turning Tiffany's five little windows into head-turning attractions.

title: City Reading Scores Fall in a State Test
description: Reading scores on a state test given to third- and sixth-grade students last spring plunged in school districts across New York City, casting doubt on the claims of Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew that achievement has been rising on his watch.

title: Wiesenthal Center Conference On Hate Speech on the Web
description: On Tuesday, the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles will hold a conference called ''Internet 2000: Promise and Peril,'' designed to address privacy, free expression and hate on the Net -- and how to reconcile these ideas.

title: OPEC Said to Be Near Agreement to Bolster Sagging Prices
description: After a day of meetings, members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries appeared to be nearing an agreement on what action they would take to try to keep oil prices from falling further, but a spokesman for the group said yesterday that there were still more issues to discuss.

title: The Neediest Cases; For Holiday, Deaf Teen-Agers Share Cooking and a Table
description: Long holiday weekends can feel like an extended stretch in solitary confinement for poor, deaf teen-agers. It matters little how many aunts and uncles come over to share the turkey when none of them use sign language.

title: German Official Restates Independence on Rates
description: The chief economist of the Bundesbank, Hermann Remsperger, reiterated yesterday that German interest rates were at low levels and said the German central bank would not allow any interference with its independence in the days before the introduction of the new European currency, the euro. ''Germany's interest rates are at low levels in nominal and real terms,'' Mr. Remsperger said in an interview with the German weekly magazine Boerse Online that was to be published today.

title: Humorous And Upbeat, Yet Practical
description: WWW.HYPERSKI.COM

title: Even Chairs Like Cashmere
description: O.K., we know that home and fashion are on parallel tracks. But a cashmere sweater for your armchair? The London emporium N. Peal is known for its exquisite Scottish cashmere knitted sweaters, scarfs and throws. N. Peal's first home collection features a pouf (above, $895) and an armchair (below, $1,595), each slipcovered in ribbed or cable-knit cashmere. (Pillows are $375 to $495.) The covers are hand-washable and won't snag. At N. Peal, 5 West 56th Street; (212) 333-3500.

title: Op-Art
Author Says Photo Confirms Mt. McKinley Hoax in 1908
description: In 1906, Dr. Frederick A. Cook took a photograph that made him famous and ultimately became perhaps the most controversial picture in the history of exploration. Now a historian has found the original, uncropped version of the picture, and it does not look good for Cook.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Stock, bond and commodity markets in the United States are closed today in observance of Thanksgiving. Banks and most businesses are also closed. Foreign stock markets are open.

title: Global Sales Slump to Slow Nestle's '98 Profit Growth
description: Nestle A.G., the Swiss food giant, has become the latest European company to feel the bite of the emerging-markets meltdown, announcing today that collapsing sales in Russia and Asia will drastically slow profit growth this year.

title: A New Little Pager That Also Handles E-Mail
description: Bell South has taken a page from the Lilliputians' book. Or a pager, rather.

title: Corrections
description: An opera review yesterday about ''La Traviata'' at the Met misstated the nationality of a young conductor who was at one point scheduled to appear in place of James Levine. The conductor, Simone Young, is Australian, not British.

title: HUD Starts Inspection Plan Intended to Repair Housing
description: The high-rise building at 5929 East Capitol Street here is a mess.

title: The Many Alternatives to Impeachment
description: To the Editor:

title: Cheating Is Just Another Part of the Game
description: THE hurried scribbles on miserly scraps of notebook paper are treasures, passed from hand to grimy hand at school bus stops, soccer practice and sleepovers. To the uninitiated their contents are unintelligible: ''C-left, C-right, repeated four times during game play,'' goes one making the rounds lately.

title: This Demure Day of Thanks
description: Thanksgiving is still a simple holiday, yet for most of us an occasion of genuine feeling in a crowded festal calendar. To judge by house and yard decorations in rural America, Halloween has spilled over its once-meager banks and washed away all of October and much of November. In cities, the Christmas season as we know it now -- an economic indicator with colored lights and eggnog -- can no longer be confined, as it used to be, within the month that begins on the day after Thanksgiving. But Thanksgiving sticks strictly to its allotted Thursday, and the power of this quiet holiday is evident in the trouble so many of us go through to get home in time to honor it. There is something invariably touching about a feast of thanks at which we all find our own reasons to be thankful, in which the feeling is named but not the cause.

title: Conservationists Who Oppose Tribal Whale Hunt Remove Boat
description: Ending a 57-day standoff, representatives of the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society today moved their second boat away from the reservation of the Makah Indians, where some society members had said they would come between the tribe and its plan to hunt whales.

title: The Many Alternatives to Impeachment
description: To the Editor:

title: Fast, but Reliable?
description: To the Editor:

title: Trading System Fails On Tokyo Exchange
description: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's futures and options trading system failed today for a second successive day as a programming error shut down trading in the last minute of business.

title: Crockett: Weighing Legend and Fact
description: To the Editor:

title: Like Sybarites on Beer-and-Nuts Budgets
description: Conspicuous consumption may be off a little this year, much like many a Wall Street bonus, but a bit of luxury and indulgence is definitely still in style. And for those on smaller budgets, the appearance of luxury -- in, say, fake fur trims and gold- and silver-colored candles, handbags and champagne flutes -- works just as well.

title: Making Home Glow Like Buffed Leather
description: LEATHER was bound to move out of the library, but who would have thought it would turn up on floors and walls, where it has hardly been seen since the 1920's, when designers like Jean-Michel Frank were using hides in unusual ways? At the American Craft Museum last month, the designer Jack Lenor Larsen used smooth, caramel-color leather floor tiles as a counterpoint to his intricate textiles in a model room.

title: On DiMaggio's 84th Birthday, Doctors Confirm Surgery for Lung Cancer
description: On his 84th birthday, a day spent with close family, Joe DiMaggio finally agreed to acknowledge that he had a cancerous tumor removed from his right lung.

title: Drug Inquiry Into a Governor Tests Mexico's New Politics
description: When federal drug agents swept past puzzled tourists in early November to seize three luxury hotels that line the powdery beaches of this Caribbean resort, it perhaps came as little surprise that the police had found evidence linking such properties to the biggest drug mafia in Mexico.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIFFLEY, JOSEPH F.
description: DIFFLEY-Joseph F. A former FBI agent, of Somers, NY, died on November 24, 1998. Husband of Lucille, father of Jill Herring, brother of John Diffley. Reposing Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY, Friday 2-4 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's RC Church, Croton Falls, NY, Saturday 10AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Sprawling Lavender

title: Corrections
description: A film review yesterday about ''The Mirror,'' which is set in Teheran, misidentified the theater where it opened. As noted in the list of credits, it was at Lincoln Center, at the Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, not at the Lincoln Plaza.

title: Editorial Observer
description: On the second day of tropical storm Mitch in Maria Salgado's house, the family watched in horror as the mud floor caved in and the bed was swept away. Then the refrigerator. Soon the walls, made of palm fronds and sticks of wood lashed together, and the corrugated tin roof collapsed. Ms. Salgado's youngest child, 1 1/2-year-old Victor Antonio, vanished in the debris.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Shares Rise for 5th Time in 6 Days, With Dow Up 13.13
description: Stocks in the United States rose yesterday as investors helped send the Dow Jones industrial average to its fifth advance in six days.

title: Mets Settle Claim of Harassment
description: Asserting that ''it was best for all concerned to put the matter behind us,'' the Mets announced yesterday that they had settled a sexual harassment claim involving General Manager Steve Phillips and a former employee who worked in the team's minor league offices in Port St. Lucie, Fla.

title: 2 Suspects in Disappearance Linked to Los Angeles Slaying
description: A judge yesterday delayed the credit card fraud trial of a mother and son suspected in the disappearance of an Upper East Side widow until Jan. 4 to give prosecutors more time to investigate their possible role in that case.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: China Said to Hold 70 Church Leaders
description: More than 70 Protestant ''house church'' leaders remain in detention after a crackdown on illegal church activities in late October and early November, a human rights group said today. One woman, it said, was beaten so badly in jail that she suffered brain injuries.

title: Economic Scene; Welfare to Work Partnership: Promises That Might Be Kept
description: A robust economy has provided a respite -- at least until the next recession -- from the fangs of the 1996 Welfare Reform Act, which threatens to withdraw aid from millions of poor families. But now a longer-term, if still partial, answer is slowly emerging.

title: Where Readers Shape Content
description: WWW.GOSKI.COM

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a planned merger of the UNUM Corporation and the Provident Companies misstated the date on which J. Harold Chandler, now chief executive of Provident, would become chief executive of the merged company. It is July 1, 2001, not next July 1.

title: FORD CREDIT PLANS TO BUY THE PRIVATELY HELD AMI LEASING
description: The Ford Credit Company, the financing arm of the Ford Motor Company, agreed yesterday to buy the privately held AMI Leasing Group as it extended its businesses into fleet management. Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed. AMI, based in Worcester, Mass., has more than 500 employees and leases cars, trucks and equipment to commercial fleets. AMI's fleet management services, which include managing, maintaining and servicing the vehicles leased to fleets, give Ford Credit, based in Dearborn, Mich., a business it currently does not have.

title: Ex-Labor Leader Urges His Successor to Resign as Chief of District Council 37
description: Stanley Hill, the head of New York City's largest municipal labor union, and Victor Gotbaum, his well-known predecessor, stepped up their attacks against each other yesterday as Mr. Gotbaum called on Mr. Hill to resign as head of District Council 37.

title: Scotsman Leads in Tourney For Blue Ribbon Pair Title
description: A transplanted Scotsman was leading after the qualifying stage of the Blue Ribbon Pair Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here today. Barnet Shenkin, who was one of Scotland's top players for many years but now lives in Boca Raton, Fla., is partnering Neil Silverman of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a former world champion.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Devils Stop the Stars On an Early Knockout
description: The Devils are beginning to send a message to the rest of the league that they are developing a killer instinct. After their most productive game of the season last Sunday, with five goals against Carolina, they took advantage of Dallas mistakes early tonight, scored three goals on their first five shots and went on to a 5-2 triumph over the Stars at Reunion Arena.

title: Group Warns of Possible Peril in Holiday Meals
description: In a year of finger-pointing, accusations and acrimony inside the Beltway, yet another target has emerged in the capital: the traditional Thanksgiving feast.

title: Investor Cancels Pact For Bouygues Stake
description: The French executive Vincent Bollore yesterday canceled a year-old pact with Bouygues S.A., Europe's largest construction concern. Shares in Bouygues, which have been falling for two weeks, rose 40 francs, to 1,120, as Mr. Bollore's exit was seen as removing an obstacle for other investors interested in buying into the company, which has interests ranging from water utilities to telecommunications.

title: Offering Tips For Skiers Of All Levels
description: WWW.SKINET.COM

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article yesterday about the propriety of showing the tape of a man's death on ''60 Minutes'' misidentified the newspaper that headlined an editorial ''Shame on '60 Minutes.' '' It was The Boston Herald, not The Boston Globe.

title: Nippon Life Cuts Japan Holdings
description: The Nippon Life Insurance Company, the nation's biggest life insurer, said today that it wanted to reduce its holdings of domestic securities in favor of higher returns abroad.

title: What's a City Without a Tiff?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARLSTEIN, JULES
description: PEARLSTEIN-Jules. Gesher records with deep sorrow the passing of the beloved father of our dear friend Rona Kellman. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Daniel Tropper, President Philip Schatten, Chairman Hillel Wiener, Exec Vice Pres

title: AOL Offering Cash To Lure Chat Users
description: America Online made headlines this week for its deals with Netscape and Sun Microsystems for $4.2 billion. Now the on-line giant has made another deal, one that could net its new customers . . . 50 cents?

title: Surfing Around The House
description: ANY sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic,'' the science fiction writer Arthur C. Clarke observed. Inevitably, wags have added corollaries like, ''Any sufficiently advanced magic is indistinguishable from technology,'' and my favorite, ''Any sufficiently advanced technology or magic is indistinguishable from a rigged demo.''

title: What's a City Without a Tiff?
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts Abroad: Scrutinizing a Legend's Studied Facade; A New Biography Rewrites the Heroic Stature of Marguerite Duras
description: As writers often do, Marguerite Duras used her life as raw material for her novels. More unusually, her literature then took over her life to the point that a fictional character called Marguerite Duras assumed control. The real Duras may have written her books, but increasingly she lived in an imaginary world of her own making. Unless, of course, she was merely playacting, which was possible.

title: Residential Sales
description: MANHATTAN

title: Two Sides of Santiago, Two Opposing Viewpoints
description: At one end of Santiago supporters of Gen. Augusto Pinochet cried and cursed the British but carried on with a party celebrating his ill-timed 83d birthday, anyway. At the other end detractors of the former dictator danced in the streets while waving British flags and posters with pictures of victims who disappeared in his 17 years in power.

title: Buyback Plan Resumed
description: UST Inc., the world's largest maker of smokeless tobacco like Skoal, said today that it would purchase as many as 20 million of its shares, resuming a buyback program suspended in June 1997. The repurchase plan, accounting for almost 10 percent of UST's shares outstanding, is worth about $620 million based on today's stock price of $34.5625, up 37.5 cents. The company said it had already bought about 2 million shares.

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column on Nov. 12, about works that have incorporated fictional scenes into factual narratives, referred incorrectly to an author's note in ''The Last Brother'' by Joe McGinniss, about Senator Edward M. Kennedy. The note, asserting that ''the quotations attributed to people throughout the book represent in substance what I believe to have been spoken,'' appeared in all published copies, not just the first-run copies. An earlier note, printed in a promotional excerpt circulated in advance of publication, said, ''Some thoughts and dialogue attributed to figures in the narrative were created by the author, based on such research and his knowledge of the relevant people, places and events.''

title: Calendar; Decorated for the Holidays
description: Little Luxuries

title: In America
description: If competence and integrity were the keys to survival, the criminal justice system in Austin, Tex., would have passed out of existence by now.

title: I.M.F. Agrees to Resume Pakistan Aid, Cut Off After Atom Tests
description: The International Monetary Fund agreed today to resume assistance to Pakistan, which had been cut off earlier this year after the country detonated nuclear devices.

title: Censoring Cyberspace
description: Federal District Judge Lowell Reed of Philadelphia has wisely issued an order temporarily preventing enforcement of a new Federal law restricting free speech on the Internet. The Child Online Protection Act, which was tucked into the omnibus budget bill passed by Congress last month, could greatly harm the right of adults to see or read anything that might be deemed unsuitable for children.

title: St. John's Takes Stanford to the Wire
description: They were supposed to be inferior, undersized and in deep trouble, a team with little hope of winning. At best, St. John's would give Stanford a decent game, avoiding a blowout but never coming close to victory. That was the prevailing sentiment when the Red Storm stepped onto the court against the highly ranked Stanford Cardinal last night.

title: Ex-Politician Sentenced in Murder for Hire
description: In Maryland, Ruthann Aron was known for her take-no-prisoners approach to business and politics. On Monday, the state where she was once viewed as a rising political star took her prisoner.

title: H.M.O. Lacks Funds to Cover Unpaid Claims
description: The HIP Health Plan of New Jersey, the state's fourth-largest health maintenance organization, has less than half the money it needs to pay more than $100 million in unpaid claims, the State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AARON, ROBERT S.
description: AARON-Robert S. In San Francisco on November 22, 1998 at age 56. Born in Brooklyn, N.Y. he was a graduate of Columbia University and Harvard Medical School. A prominent San Frnacisco Psychiatrist. Devoted husband of the late Mayre Rasmussen; beloved brother of Donna and Ken Wirt and William and Jean Aaron; loving & caring uncle and great uncle to 12 nieces and nephews; devoted sonin-law of Daryl & Thora Rasmussen; loving brother-in-law of Jan & Bruce Robinson, Craig & Sharon Rasmussen and Gail DeFries. Robert will remain in the hearts and memories of all who knew him. Funeral services were held Wed., Nov. 25th at Sinai Memorial Chapel in San Francisco, CA, with interment to follow at Green Valley Cemetery, Cameron Park, CA.

description: To the Editor:

Brother of Ann Williamson. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Friday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9PM with service Saturday 12 noon. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to a charity of your choice.

description: The man hired to write Monica S. Lewinsky's side of the Presidential scandal has become famous here in the last few weeks, maybe even more famous than she is. And from what Kenyans have seen, this much is clear: if she is looking for a sympathetic ear, she probably picked the right man.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GROSS, SIDNEY
description: GROSS-Sidney. November 26, 1986. We are thankful this day and every day for the love and laughter you gave us. You are closer in our hearts than ever. Zenith and the Family

title: MacArthur Airport Grows Along With Low-Cost Domestic Flights
description: MacArthur Airport at Islip on Long Island says it is still negotiating with Southwest Airlines, which was reported earlier this month to be planning nonstop service from the airport by early spring. Regardless of the outcome, the 33-year-old airport is busy gussying itself up with a $13 million renovation plan scheduled for completion next August.

title: Tech Help, on Paper
description: To the Editor:

title: Striking Teachers Reach Tentative Deal in Jersey City
description: Public school teachers tentatively agreed this afternoon to end their increasingly bitter five-day strike, which has brought chaos and disruption to the 32,000-student district.

title: KEVORKIAN FACES A MURDER CHARGE IN DEATH ON VIDEO
description: A Michigan prosecutor brought first-degree murder charges yesterday against Dr. Jack Kevorkian for administering a lethal injection last September to a terminally ill man who wished to die, a videotaped act of euthanasia that was nationally televised on Sunday.

title: Warren Smith, 93; Edited Walpole's Letters
description: Warren Hunting Smith, who devoted more than 50 years of his life to editing the letters of Horace Walpole, died on Sunday at his home in Geneva, N.Y. He was 93.

title: Officer Is Dismissed After Assault Conviction
description: A city police officer lost his job but is likely to avoid prison time, officials said yesterday, a day after a jury cleared him of the most serious charges in the beating of an elderly woman and her brother last year.

title: Flip Wilson, 64, Over-the-Top Comic and TV Host, Dies
description: Flip Wilson, the popular comedian who became the first black entertainer to be the host of a successful weekly variety show on network television, died last night at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 64.

title: 3-Way Alliance May Prove A Real Threat to Microsoft
description: Eight years ago Apple Computer and I.B.M. undertook a common software and computer chip development effort to challenge the Microsoft Corporation's dominance of personal computing and remake the computing industry at home and in the workplace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHSTONE, DAVID
description: RICHSTONE-David. July 22, 1912 to November 22, 1998. Teacher, horticulturist, unparalleled scholar of the English Language. Loving to and loved by all who knew him. A man without guile or deception, with no ambition other than excellence in all his pursuits. He leaves a grieving family with an unfillable hole. ''He was a man, take him for all in all, I shall not look upon his like again.''

title: Not Easy to Keep Being Outrageous
description: A big flashing sign spelled out ''DRUGS'' on the stage of the Hammerstein Ballroom on Monday night. And Marilyn Manson, wearing a sparkly red outfit with garters, thigh-high boots and a codpiece-thong combination that left his buttocks bare, did his parody of a preacher, declaring that God spoke to him and said that Jesus Christ invented marijuana, cocaine and LSD. Determined to offend both church and state, Mr. Manson was trying hard to hold on to his role as the corrupter of American youth. American youth may have other ideas, like treating him as mere entertainment.

title: ESCALADE CANCELS DEAL TO SELL SPORTING-GOODS BUSINESS
description: Escalade Inc. said yesterday that it had canceled its agreement to sell its sporting-goods business to Sportcraft Ltd. In June, Escalade agreed to sell its Escalade Sports assets to the closely held Sportcraft for $74.5 million. The companies, which mutually agreed to terminate the deal, cited financing market uncertainties as a factor. Sportcraft, based in Mount Olive, N.J., the sports products company, had expressed doubts in August about its ability to finance the deal. Escalade, based in Evansville, Ind., makes sporting goods, office and graphic arts products. Shares of Escalade closed yesterday at $19, down 6.7 percent, or $1.375.

title: APPLIED MAGNETICS IN $104 MILLION DEAL FOR DAS DEVICES
description: The Applied Magnetics Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire DAS Devices Inc. for about 13 million common shares, or about $104 million in Applied Magnetics stock. Applied Magnetics, a disk-drive component maker, also said it would raise $20 million, simultaneously with the closing of the merger, through a private sale of its stock to institutional investors. DAS Devices, based in Milpitas, Calif., is a thin-film magnetic head manufacturer. Applied Magnetics, based in Goleta, Calif., supplies drive heads that are used to read information on the disk drives in personal computers. The shares of Applied Magnetics rose 68.75 cents, to $7.625.

title: Petra Foundation Honors 3 New Yorkers for Human Rights Efforts
description: Three New Yorkers have been honored by the Petra Foundation for efforts to improve human rights in their communities.

title: Gnarly Trills, Honking Winds: The Future Beckons
description: The invaluable contemporary music ensemble Parnassus opened its 25th-anniversary season on Monday night with a bracing concert at Merkin Concert Hall. And on this night the gap between the world of Parnassus, playing an engrossing program of recent works at a 450-seat hall, and the mostly staid world of nearby Lincoln Center, with its palaces to the past, seemed a lot wider than a single city block.

title: In Union, a Feeling of Betrayal; Claims of Fraud in Contract Vote Anger City Workers
description: For the people who rake the leaves and answer the phones, the ones who drive the trucks and shelve the books, who empty the bedpans and sweep the floors and counsel the students and fill out the forms, it has been a week of ''I told you so.''

title: Searching the Net
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns; Soccer Coach As a Minister To Suburbia
description: FIVE days a week, William M. Murphy is another buttoned-down, Metro-North-riding litigator for another Manhattan law firm, toiling in such heart-thrilling fields as something his resume calls ''European derivative instruments.''

title: Living the Loft Life, Vicariously
description: Love 'em or chop 'em up. Lofts are the wide open prairies of Manhattan real estate. Hollywood portrays them as home to cutting-edge artists or knife-wielding psychopaths. But in researching ''Loft'' (Monacelli Press, $50), Mayer Rus found that lofts actually belong ''to the full demographic range of people who have money.'' From a loft with a cargo body of an old truck for a bed to one with 3,000 white-lacquered square feet of furniture-free space, ''Loft,'' with photographs by Paul Warchol, exposes the raw verve of a much-envied archetype.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE ADVANCES. Coffee futures rose sharply amid concern about shipping delays from the world's top producers, Brazil and Colombia. In New York, coffee for December delivery rose 3.15 cents, to $1.13 a pound.

title: The Sliver-Prone Need Not Fear
description: It looks like wood; it's even charmingly distressed. But the latest laminate from Formica, the Heirloom Collection, is made to look like wide-plank boards from pre-Civil War buildings. Wood-style laminates have been around, of course, but using antique planks for digital image reproduction is a first. The planks, 8 inches by 48 inches with a 15-year warranty, recall oak, chestnut or pine (left). Nostalgia has a price: at $3.59 to $3.99 a square foot (uninstalled), the line costs about the same as new wood; (800) 367-6422.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, MARION DANIELSON
description: CAMPBELL-Marion Danielson, of New York and Groton, Mass., former president and major stockholder of the Atlantic Monthly Company, died on November 24 in New York City at the age of 77. Mrs. Campbell's family acquired The Atlantic Monthly in 1938. Her own association with the venerable magazine began in 1943 as an editorial assistant. She was elected a director in 1953 and in 1957 became the major stockholder of the company and succeeded her father as president. She continued as president and director until the company was sold in 1980. She was also a director of the Providence (R.I.) Journal Company. A graduate of Foxcroft School and Vassar College (B.A. 1943) she worked in the editorial department of the Washington Post in 1944 and as a staff aid caseworker for the American Red Cross from 1944 to 1946. She was a major benefactor of many charitable institutions in New York, Boston and Groton and served on the boards of the Boston Museum of Science, The Deaconess-Nashoba Hospital, the Groton School and Lawrence Academy among other institutions. She maintained her family's ties to the Groton community, owning and successfully operating Gibbet Hill Farm, raising prizewinning black angus cattle, and Gibbet Hill Orchard. She was married to Douglass Campbell in 1962, formerly Vice President of the New York Central Railroad, and previously to the late Rev. Malcolm Strachan, who was Chaplain of Groton School. In addition to her husband she is survived by her sons, Richard Strachan of Portland, OR., & Stephen M. Strachan of Denver, CO, her daughter-inlaw, Deborah K. Strachan, and one grandchild, Kammer Douglass Strachan. A memorial service will be held at the St. John's Chapel of Groton School at a later date. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: You Can Search, but Can You Hide?
description: JENNIFER RAHEL CONOVER of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., found ''the most priceless gift'' for her husband, Ted, recently, just by surfing the Web, she said. For several years, she had worked through alumni associations, the Department of Veterans Affairs and regional newspapers to try to find David Granger, a college friend of Mr. Conover and a fellow World War II veteran. ''I was almost afraid that this Dave Granger, whom I'd never met, might have died,'' she said. ''Otherwise I was sure someone could have helped me find him.''

title: A Program That Saves Light Fare For Dessert
description: Karen Gomyo defied conventional wisdom when she assembled the program for her violin recital on Tuesday evening at the 92d Street Y. Instead of proceeding chronologically, with a Baroque or Classical work as an inviting introduction and the more challenging pieces later, Ms. Gomyo began with Janacek's acrid Sonata and moved on to the bitter, wintry textures of Prokofiev's Sonata No. 1. It was only after intermission that she lightened up, offering Mozart's Sonata in B flat (K. 454) and showpieces by Tchaikovsky and Wieniawski.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: OPEC Nearing Pact To Keep Prices From Falling

title: Mayflower Descendant Digs Deep Into the Lore
description: EVERYONE knows about the Mayflower. A group of Puritans were headed for Virginia but steered badly off course and landed far to the north. After dispossessing the Indians, they began an annual celebration of Thanksgiving, dressed in their buckles and all-black garb.

title: Exxon-Mobil Talks
description: The Exxon Corporation and the Mobil Corporation have held discussions about combining their business operations, a person involved in the talks said yesterday. It was unclear whether talks were still going on between the oil giants. Such a deal would create the largest oil company in the world and the biggest United States company ranked by revenue.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BERGEN BRUNSWIG CORP., Orange, Calif., the drug wholesaler, agreed to acquire JM Blanco Inc. a pharmaceutical distributor in Puerto Rico, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

description: Q. What do commercial uninstall programs do that I can't do by myself?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHSWENDER, WILLIAM J.
description: HOCHSWENDER-William J. Jr., 70, after a brief illness, on Nov 25 at his home in Sharon, CT. Survived by his wife, Mary Allen; his sister, Grace Bowen; his son, Woody, of Sharon; his daughter, Patricia Leri, of Lexington, NY; and three grandchildren. Loved by all. Memorial mass Dec. 5, 11AM, St. Bernard's Church, Sharon, CT.

title: The Boss Succumbs To a Master Bluffer
description: One week ago, Bernie Williams had only one public offer: a seven-year deal from the Reds for $1 million a year, a little joke on Cincinnati's part. Scott Boras, Williams's agent, continued to tell teams that Williams had offers for seven and eight years from clubs he would not identify. Several baseball executives figured Boras was bluffing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERT, CHARLOTTE
description: ALBERT-Charlotte. Of Boca Raton, formerly of Roslyn Heights, New York, on November 25, 1998 after a gallant fight against lung cancer. Beloved wife of 50 years to Jack; loving mother of Susan and Wendy; devoted grandmother of Daniel, Andrea and Gregory. May she find eternal peace free of pain at last. In lieu of flowers, donations to Hospice By the Sea, Boca Raton, Florida or your favorite charity would be appreciated. Services at 9:30 A.M. on November 27 at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Delray Beach.

title: Rangers Finally Give Up on Enigmatic Kovalev
description: The Rangers could wait no longer. Six years was enough.
