description: BASEBALL

title: Familiar Rite, Familiar Politics in Cambodian Assembly
description: After four months of infighting, bullying and bloodshed, Cambodia finally got its new National Assembly today, a smiling, bowing alliance of politicians who despise -- and in some cases have tried to kill -- each other.

title: Sports of The Times; It's Time to Post Some Thanksgiving 1998 Thank You Notes
description: IF it's Thanksgiving Day, it's time to thank those who make sports' little corner of the world a better place:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SISSELMAN, SHIRLEY REINBERG
description: SISSELMAN - Shirley Reinberg. The Physicians and Staff of Mount Sinai School of Medicine Faculty Practice Associates extend profound condolences to our friend and colleague, Mike Sisselman, on the loss of Shirley. Our thoughts are with Mike and his family as we mourn the passing of an extraodinary woman. Mount Sinai Faculty Practice Associates Board of Governors Kristjan T. Ragnarsson, MD, Chair Burton P. Drayer, MD, Vice Chair Sloane Elman, Executive Director

title: Tripping the Light Fantastically
description: TWILIGHT on the Brooklyn Bridge. A new moon has risen on silent wings as the setting sun envelops the harbor in a golden embrace.

title: Luxe Goes the Lounge
description: The architectural equivalent of ''you can never be too rich or too thin'' is that a minimal space can never be too luxurious or too exclusive. John Pawson, the British architect of sweet nothings like Calvin Klein's virginally austere flagship store in Manhattan, designed Cathay Pacific Airways' first-class and business-class lounges in Norman Foster's new Chek Lap Kok Airport in Hong Kong. Beneath the galloping vaults of Mr. Foster's lattice roof, luxury comes in the shape of a 100-foot Douglas fir bar (below), with views of the ocean, mountains and runways; a fully stocked library, and even cabanas with private terraces and cast-iron bathtubs set in granite. These ''personal living spaces,'' as Mr. Pawson calls them, provide amenities for the strapped (but not financially) traveler. ''I wanted everything I could want at home, but that I can't have,'' Mr. Pawson said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, EDNA
description: COHEN-Edna. Our dear friend and long time member of the Woodmere Club. Our deepest sympathy to the family. The Woodmere Club

title: A Marrow Alternative
description: Researchers have found that using blood from umbilical cords -- instead of bone marrow transplants -- may offer new hope for people with leukemia, lymphoma, other cancers or genetic diseases, even when the placental blood is not perfectly matched to the patients' tissue, according to a study.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUCATMAN, FRED
description: DUCATMAN-Fred. On Wednesday November 25, 1998 of Scotch Plains, NJ. Formerly of Westfield, NJ. Beloved husband of Shirley (nee Buchman). Devoted father of Dr. Alan and Dr. Stephen Ducatman and Dr. Amy Dunn. Loving grandfather of five grandchildren. Funeral services conducted from Temple Emanuel, 756 East Broad St, Westfield, NJ on Friday November 27, 1998 at 9:30 AM. Interment New Mt. Zion Cemetery, Lyndhurst, NJ. For information Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, NJ 07088.

title: Virtual Meeting Held For 4,000 Who Stayed Home
description: Thousands of journalists, techies and salespeople descended upon Las Vegas, Nev., recently for the sensory overload of a convention experience known as Comdex. A research consortium believes there is a much better way to have such a meeting of the minds, one that makes it possible for visitors never to leave their homes.

title: Foster Care Supervisor Is Charged in Sexual Abuse of His Children
description: A foster care supervisor for the New York City Administration for Children's Services was arrested yesterday on charges that he groped two of his adult adopted sons, officials said. In addition, his wife was charged with endangering the welfare of a 6-year-old foster child in their care.

title: Corrections
description: A film review yesterday about ''Babe: Pig in the City'' misidentified the director of the 1995 film ''Babe.'' He was Chris Noonan. (George Miller wrote the 1995 film with Mr. Noonan.)

title: Consumer Spending Rose Again in October
description: Buoyant consumer spending sent sales of big-ticket goods and previously owned homes higher in October, signs that the economic expansion will continue.

title: French Coalition Frays After 18 Months
description: The honeymoon is definitely over for the Socialist Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin, who made this plea on French news radio on Tuesday night: ''No impatience -- let us govern!''

title: Hutu Linked to Rwanda Massacres Said to Fight Congo Rebels
description: Soldiers of the former Rwandan army, many of whom took part in the 1994 massacres there, are playing a big role in putting down the latest rebellion in Congo, a United Nations report says.

title: What's a City Without a Tiff?
description: To the Editor:

title: Trust and Rugrats
description: ''The Rugrats have gone to Hollywood!'' So said the teaser that ran on the Nickelodeon channel in place of the ''Rug-rats'' program four nights last week. The purpose of the promotion was clear: to publicize the opening of ''The Rugrats Movie'' last Friday.

title: Hess Visits and Unveils Big Dream
description: Perhaps Leon Hess knows something. The 84-year-old owner of the Jets paid his annual Thanksgiving Day visit to practice today, and for a change he is allowing himself to think of the possibilities.

title: Valentin M. Berezhkov, 82, Interpreter for Stalin at Talks
description: Valentin M. Berezhkov, a Russian who interpreted for Stalin and Molotov at conferences that they, Roosevelt and Churchill attended during World War II, died last Friday at his home in Claremont, Calif. He was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZACKLER, PAULINE
description: ZACKLER-Pauline, 89. On November 25, 1998. Wife of the late Abe Zackler. Survived by two daughters and sons-in-law, Linda and Mel Solomon of Kansas City, MO; and Marsha and Joel Dowshen of Bordentown, N.J., and four grandchildren, Marc, Laura, Matt, and Jessica.

title: Telefonica Investing $3.8 Billion in Brazil
description: Telefonica S.A., Spain's biggest telephone company, said today that it would invest $3.8 billion next year to expand its telephone networks in Brazil.

title: Graham Has a Role In Mystery Of the Feet
description: Six years ago, Kent Graham did not approach his pro debut on Thanksgiving with cold feet.

title: No More Noise, No More Funk
description: Even as the slow burn at Livent continued to command the attention of Broadway's gurus and gossips, several shows have been taking stock of their own enterprises.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, LEONARD
description: NEWMAN-Leonard. The officers, directors and employees of DRS Technologies, Inc., mourn the passing of their founder, Leonard Newman, on Tuesday, November 24, 1998, and extend their heartfelt sympathies to his family. Leonard Newman was the former chairman and chief executive officer of DRS Technologies for over 20 years. Before founding DRS, a company focused on defense electronics, Mr. Newman was Division Manager at Loral Corporation. Earlier, he was Manager of Antisubmarine Warfare (ASW) Advanced Systems and Assistant to the President of the company. Prior to that, he was Associate Director of Research for Beckman Instruments' Infrared Gas Analysis Division and also was Group Leader at Singer-Kearfott. His work involved Doppler navigation, frequency trackers, servo instrumentation, analog computers, environmental testing of electronic equipment, ASW simulation, radar and medical electronics. Mr. Newman was a member of the U.S. Navy League, Armed Forces Communications and Electronics Association, National Security Industrial Association, Naval Helicopter Association and the New York Academy of Sciences, among other professional associations. He was born on June 14, 1924 in New York City and lived in Saddle River, New Jersey for over 10 years. Prior to moving to Saddle River, he was a long-time resident of White Plains, New York. Leonard Newman is survived by his wife, Mrs. Ruth L. Newman, four grown children, Mr. Mark S. Newman, Ms. Joan P. Newman, Mr. Ivan D. Newman, and Mrs. Allison S. Winter, and five grandchildren, Amanda E. Newman, Robyn H. Newman, Sara B. Newman, Harrison S. Newman and Elizabeth A. Winter. Services will be held on Friday, November 27th, at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., New York, NY. 212-362-6600. In lieu of flowers, the family request donations be made to the American Heart Association.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Monique Prieto

title: British Air Buys One of Its Partners
description: British Airways P.L.C. said today that it had bought a franchise partner, Cityflyer Express, for $:75 million, or $124 million, to expand its position at London's Gatwick airport.

title: Talk of Deflation Is Wishful Thinking
description: To the Editor:

title: S.U.V.'s Impair Quality of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Vikings Go Long and Then Keep Going
description: The Minnesota Vikings have no secret weapon. Their big play is the bomb. Every team throws it, but none use it with such devastating results.

title: Evocative Cells: Uptown, Downtown, All Around
description: There's a lot of Ross Bleckner to see in New York City right now, with two gallery exhibitions and a spate of Absolut Vodka ads in glossy magazines. Taken together they suggest an artist in search of diplomatic immunity, that is, easy travel to different artistic planets, from mystical light-filled abstraction to political art to popular illustration. They also provide a particularly clear view of Mr. Bleckner's strengths and weaknesses and his tendency to undermine and cheapen his own accomplishments.

title: Editorial Observer; When a Law Firm Is Like a Baseball Team
description: The state of Washington followed California earlier this month when it voted to eliminate state-sponsored affirmative action in education and government contracts. But the nation as a whole has moved in the opposite direction since California's Proposition 209 raised fears of a national movement that might re-segregate higher education and the professions, deepening racial divisions.

title: S.U.V.'s Impair Quality of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: New Video Releases
description: The Mask of Zorro

title: Priced Out Of Politics
description: I need $24 million. Based on this year's totals and the experts' projections, that's what it will take to run for the United States Senate two years from now in New York.

title: Family Fare
description: A Horse's Life: It's a Beauty

title: Chief Carver At Feast Of Forgotten
description: BERNIE WOHL learned everything he knows about carving turkeys from his brother, Stanley, who used to run a deli. ''The trick,'' Bernie said, ''is not to slice the meat off the bird. What you do is take the entire breast off the bone first, then slice it on the board.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOOKHALTER, SOPHIE, M.D.
description: BOOKHALTER-Sophie, M.D. We deeply mourn the passing of Dr. Sophie Bookhalter who was an ardent supporter of the American Friends of the Hebrew University through the establishment of the Rasha Ehrman Bookhalter and Sophie Bookhalter, M.D. Endowment Fund which provides scholarships for undergraduate and graduate Israeli students at the Faculty of Medicine; scholarships and stipends for students at the Melton Center for Jewish Education in the Diaspora; and for fellowships in Jewish Studies-at The Hebrew University of Jerusalem. In recognition, the name of Sophie Bookhalter, M.D. is inscribed at the University's Benefactors Wall on Mount Scopus. Through her efforts the Elsa Nikolic Scholarship Fund for Art History Students was also founded. We extend our sympathies to her family and especially to her niece, Barbara Joyce Bobbin, and cousin, Susan Steinberg Stearns. American Friends of The Hebrew University Keith L. Sachs, President Fred S. Lafer, Chairman of the Board Adam B. Kahan, Executive Vice President

title: Doctor Hurt In Stabbing At Hospital In Brooklyn
description: A surgeon who was on his way to visit a patient was repeatedly stabbed in an elevator of a Brooklyn hospital yesterday during an apparent robbery attempt, the police said.

title: Judge Is Asked To Let 2 Join Honor Group
description: A lawyer for two Kentucky high school seniors who said they were denied admission to the National Honor Society because they became pregnant has asked a Federal judge to force the society to admit the two students while they wait for their case to go to trial.

title: Sports of The Times; Recalling Red's Wit And Modesty
description: IN an early scrimmage in the Knicks' training camp in the mid-60's, the chief scout, Red Holzman, watched one of the rookies he had scouted -- the team had followed his enthusiastic advice to draft the player high -- and now anticipated that he would be a productive member of the team. On the sideline, Scout Holzman noticed a flaw in the player that he hadn't noticed before. He had trouble getting through screens on his left. During a break in the action, Holzman went onto the court to demonstrate to the player how it's done.

title: Did TV Death Hinder Debate?
description: To the Editor:

title: Winged Messengers From Fragile Forests
description: There was never a king like Solomon,

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOAN, GERALD
description: SLOAN-Gerald. Devoted husband of Adalaide. Cherished father of Barry Sloan and Patricia Katz. Adored grandfather of Allyson, Charles, Jeremey and Haley. Services to be held privately.

title: Cointreau Account To Bartle Bogle
description: Remy Amerique in New York, a unit of Remy Cointreau S. A., has named the new New York office of Bartle Bogle Hegarty of London to create what was described as the first major consumer campaign in the United States for the Cointreau brand of orange-flavored liqueur. Billings were not disclosed.

title: The Man in the Empty Suit Takes His Deadly Revenge
description: Aldrich Ames has been called the worst mole in the history of the Central Intelligence Agency. As played by Timothy Hutton, he is also something of a weasel. But mostly he is a cipher, a colorless bureaucrat, an empty suit who sells out his country and insures the deaths of at least 10 spies (probably far more), all because he is vaguely peeved at his bosses and wants to pay off some pesky debts.

title: Did TV Death Hinder Debate?
description: To the Editor:

title: Coolio Thrills German Fans With Gangsta Or Theft Rap
description: American rap stars have attracted big audiences in Europe for years, so it was not entirely surprising that teen-agers in the small southwest German town of Boblingen lined up along the street this morning to see Coolio, whose hits include ''Gangsta's Paradise.''

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Did TV Death Hinder Debate?
description: To the Editor:

title: Well, at Least the Popcorn Is Good
description: On Thanksgiving weekend, moviegoers crowd the multiplex and stay-at-homes may sweep the video-store shelves clean of the latest and best. (But does anybody realy want to watch ''Titanic'' on a 19-inch screen?) Even the 1930's and 40's classics could be hard to find. Which is why this is such a good time to rent a bad movie, like those on the list below. Some are excruciating. Some are better than their reviews might indicate. Some are so bad they're great. It just goes to prove there are a lot of ways to make a turkey.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Gregory Crane

title: OPEC Leaders Delay Decision On Further Cuts in Production
description: Ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, deeply divided over the best strategy for propping up sagging crude oil prices, took no action yesterday on making further production cuts, delaying any decision until March.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTO, JOHN T.
description: BARTO-John T. Age 71. On Nov. 23, 1998. Director 19th Precinct Community Safety Committee, member Community On Patrol and on Board of Directors of East 84th Street Neighborhood Association. Beloved husband of Ruth. Brother of Ann Williamson. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Friday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9PM with service Saturday 12 noon. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Diner's Journal
description: If, like me, you neglected to make your reservations at Danny Meyer's new restaurant, Eleven Madison Park, before it opened a few weeks ago, you may have to resign yourself to eating at odd hours. The restaurant seemed to be booked solid the minute it opened.

title: Montreal Journal; Canadians, Estranged, Even in Their Pop Culture
description: Anywhere he goes in Quebec, from a secluded restaurant on the east side of Montreal to the hardware aisles at the Canadian Tire store in suburban St. Leonard, Claude Meunier makes heads turn.

title: Racial Disparity Seen in Immigrant Housing
description: A report commissioned by the Fannie Mae Foundation, an arm of the federally chartered home-mortgage provider, shows the extent to which race plays a determining role in where immigrants live in New York City.

title: People
description: * Edmund Wittry was named to the vacant position of client services director at Pierson Hawkins Inc., Denver. He had been senior director for marketing at Boston Market Inc., Golden, Colo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, ANNE DAUGHADAY
description: ADAMS-Anne Daughaday. Of Jupiter Island, Florida. On November 24, 1998. Born on April 27, 1920 in Winnetka, Illinois. Beloved wife of John Quincy Adams, Jr. Adored mother of Anne Adams Laumont, Katharine Adams Venizelos, and John Brooks Adams. Loving mother-in-law to Philippe Laumont & Lisa Liebmann. Cherished grandmother of Julie and Laura Laumont; Kyriaco, Jake, Anna, Emily, and Selena Venizelos. She was predeceased by her dear granddaughter, Sophie Laumont. Also survived by Hamilton Daughaday, Jr. of Buffalo, N.Y., and Thomas Daughaday of Evanston, IL., her brothers. Service at Christ Memorial Chapel, Jupiter Island, Florida, November 28 at noon.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: A Precooked Primary Season
description: President Clinton is not yet halfway through his second term, but many party regulars believe the race for the Presidential nominations in the year 2000 is already over, and that only an unexpected political tsunami could keep Al Gore and George W. Bush from being the winners. Their positions on the issues and success as campaigners are obviously part of the reason. But another is the tactical importance of an accelerated schedule of Presidential primaries, which will require enormous sums of money and name recognition during the first few weeks of the election season.

title: Trading Losses Hurt ING Profit
description: ING Groep N.V., the Dutch financial-services company, today recorded an indicated earnings decline of 16 percent for the third quarter, hurt by trading losses at its investment bank, ING Barings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERTOG, HENRY M.
description: HERTOG-Henry M. Of Aventura, Fl. November 25, 1998. Beloved husband of Madeline Hertog. Dear father of Roger and Susan Hertog, Lance and Marjorie Roberts. Cherished grandfather of Allison, Justin, Jennifer, Adam, and David.

title: COMPUTER TROUBLE LOOMS FOR STATES IN 2000, U.S. FINDS
description: Most states are behind schedule in renovating their computers for the year 2000, and as a result it is likely that benefit payments will be delayed, or services interrupted, for some people who receive welfare, Medicaid, food stamps or other types of assistance, Federal and state officials say.

title: S.U.V.'s Impair Quality of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Romanian Avant-Garde: 1916-1947'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, DR. ARTHUR H.
description: GREEN-Dr. Arthur H. On November 25, 1998. Beloved husband of Carol J. Green. Dear father of Susanna and Jonathan. Cherished son of the late Lawrence and Sadye Green. Dr. Green was the founder of The Family CenterTherapeutic Nursery and Senior Psychiatrist at New York Presbyterian Hospital and Professor of Clinical Psychiatry at Columbia University. Services on Sunday, November 29, at 12:00 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MANSON, JULIUS J.
description: MANSON-Julius J. On Sunday, November 29, at 2:00 P.M., New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street.

title: Markets Closed
description: Stock, bond and commodity markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Thanksgiving. Foreign stock markets were open.

title: Suddenly Within Reach, Millions in Sunken Treasure
description: A Spanish galleon, known as the Santissima Trinidad, went down in a fierce 1711 hurricane, just a few miles west of Havana harbor. Loaded with $400 million worth of gold bullion, silver ingots and coins, the ship has lain undisturbed for centuries, guarded by Fidel Castro's gunboats since 1959.

title: Russia Raises Specter of a Loan Default
description: Russia has told Western bankers that it will renege on the terms of repaying $28 billion in Soviet-era debt to creditors, effectively paving the way for a default on interest payments next month, bankers said here today.

title: Budget Office Sends Out the Word: Cut Your Budgets
description: The Giuliani administration told city agencies this week to cut their budgets for next year, in part to offset an anticipated $500 million revenue loss from the elimination of an income tax surcharge on city residents' salaries, the Mayor's budget director said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Nov. 11 about Pvt. Jurgen Werner, a soldier seen at the memorial to troops of the First Infantry Division, misidentified his organization. It is Company D, 554th Engineer Battalion, which trains at Fort Belvoir, Va. (not 554 Delta Company). The caption also omitted the location of the memorial. It is in Washington.

title: Comfort Food
description: The term comfort food may be a cliche, but the familiar, hearty, nostalgic dishes that it encompasses never cease to appeal, especially when cold weather makes any kind of warmth more alluring. Here are a dozen restaurants that offer the comfort foods of many cultures. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Elmer Wavering, 91, Pioneer Of Auto Electronics, Is Dead
description: Elmer H. Wavering, who as a young man growing up in Quincy, Ill., tinkered in his radio shop and came up with what eventually became the first commercial car radio, died on Friday. He was 91 years old.

title: Flip Wilson, Outrageous Comic and TV Host, Dies at 64
description: Flip Wilson, the popular comedian who became the first black entertainer to be the host of a successful weekly variety show on network television, died Wednesday night at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 64.

title: New Serious Side to Child's Play on Web
description: For four years, children who visited the Cyberkids Web site have found puzzles, interactive stories and other activities intended to appeal to the 7- to 12-year-old crowd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRVIN, HILDA
description: IRVIN-Hilda on November 24, 1998. Devoted mother of Sue and Bob Marchand. Loving cousin of Fred and Adolph Brooks. Funeral service is private.

title: Spanish Judge Is Hoping To See Secret Files in U.S.
description: The Spanish judge who wants the former Chilean dictator, Augusto Pinochet, to stand trial, plans to go to Washington to try to see secret Government files, court officials say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, MAY
description: GROSS-May. On November 25, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Lee Gross. Dear mother of the late Morton Molin and loving daughter of the late Max and Pauline Fichman. Cherished sister of Murry Fichman. Adored aunt and great aunt. Services today, November 27, 12:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Sykora's Two Goals Not Enough
description: COYOTES 3, DEVILS 2

title: Fans Seeking Fame, Not Infamy, for Shoeless Joe Jackson
description: Nearly half a century has passed since Shoeless Joe Jackson died, yet fans still search out his grave here to leave mementoes: bats and balls and sometimes even white socks. They ride by the small brick house that was his in a working-class neighborhood and visit the ball park where he first picked up a bat.

title: Fun, Games and Some Real-Life Death, in Uganda
description: THE LAST KING OF SCOTLAND

title: In America's Schools, Latin Enjoys a Renaissance
description: Penny Cipolone's eighth-grade Latin students recently turned their classroom in Woodbury Heights, N.J., into a living hell. They covered the windows with black curtains, piped in dry-ice smoke and flashed red lights in their interpretation of Virgil's Underworld.

title: George McNew, 90, Botanist Who Led Research Institute
description: Dr. George Lee McNew, a plant pathologist who directed the Boyce Thompson Institute for Plant Research for 25 years and negotiated its move to Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., died on Oct. 30 at a retirement community in Las Cruces, N.M. He was 90.

title: Insurers Agree On Raised Bid
description: The Markel Corporation has agreed to acquire Gryphon Holdings Inc., a specialty and casualty insurance company, for $140.1 million, plus $53 million in assumed debt.

title: Blockbuster in Hong Kong
description: The Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation entered Hong Kong's video-rental market by agreeing today to take control of the territory's largest rental chain. Blockbuster, a unit of the American entertainment company Viacom Inc., signed a conditional agreement and has 30 days to buy some assets of the bankrupt chain, KPS Retail Stores Ltd. KPS had assets of $176 million (Hong Kong), or $22.7 million (United States), its liquidator, Ernst & Young, said earlier this month. Like other retailers, KPS has been hard hit by Hong Kong's recession.

title: Eliminating the Distance Between Two Points
description: Marco Polo did not get to China on frequent flyer miles. Travel in his day was arduous, dangerous, stressful, inconvenient (to say the least) and infinitely time consuming. Travel in our day is arduous, dangerous, stressful and inconvenient (to say the least -- try sitting for hours on a runway), but it only seems infinitely time consuming because the expectation of brevity is so high and the sense of time available to spend and waste has shriveled to a nubbin.

title: SPARE TIME
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Celeste Mendoza, 68, Cuban Rumba Singer
description: Celeste Mendoza, a Cuban singer who was known as the Queen of the Guaguanco, or street rumba, died on Sunday in Havana. She was 68.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Shirin Neshat

title: Pollock's Volcanic New York Circle
description: Looking at the Jackson Pollock canvases now on view at the Museum of Modern Art and thinking about the short, cometlike arc of Pollock's life and career, one seems to face an inscrutable proposition from the science of physics: naked energy, mass transformed by momentum and explosion, an explosion in this case whose laboratory was the body and psyche of a single person.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SUSSMAN, JACK R.
description: SUSSMAN-Jack R. Today is your birthday. Always lovingly remembered. Bette S

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTEIN, DOROTHY MILAN
description: GREENSTEIN-Dorothy Milan, after a long illness, passed away at her home on Thanksgiving morning. Beloved mother of Betsy, grandmother of Matthew, wife of Morris, daughter of Minnie, mother-in-law of Robert, aunt of Florrie, Brett and Gregg. Her courage and humor were an inspiration. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave., 10:45 AM, Sunday, November 29, 1998.

title: What Ails Yeltsin? No Two People Can Agree
description: ''The subject of the President's health should be closed. The subject does not even exist.'' Standing before cameras in the Kremlin last March 10, Boris N. Yeltsin looked hearty enough to make that command stick. He dared reporters to match him in swimming, tennis and track. A thorough physical five days before, he said, had shown ''no deviations, even as far as the smallest microelements.'' Then he spat over his shoulder three times and rapped a nearby table. ''Touch wood, of course!'' he added.

title: Did TV Death Hinder Debate?
description: To the Editor:

title: William Taylor Miller, 87, Organic Chemist
description: Dr. William Taylor Miller, an organic chemist and expert in fluorine chemistry who worked on the team that built the atomic bomb in World War II, died on Nov. 15 at the Cayuga Medical Center in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 87.

title: Snyder Acquires National Retail
description: Snyder Communications Inc. in Bethesda, Md., has acquired National Retail Services Inc. in Danbury, Conn., which provides marketing services to the pharmaceutical and consumer packaged goods industries, for stock valued at $24.4 million.

title: Employees Facing Steep Increases in Health Costs
description: Many working Americans will pay 8 to 20 percent more for health insurance premiums next year, the sharpest price increases since the early 1990's.

title: Balloons Reined In, but Paradegoers Rained On
description: The rain poured down in buckets, a third of the giant balloons had to be withdrawn for technical problems, and overhanging the whole affair was the stark memory of a terrible accident last year.

title: Leo Burnett is named one of the business leaders of the century.
description: LEO BURNETT, the adman behind the Marlboro Man, has been selected as one of the 20 most influential business leaders of the 20th century.

title: Teacher Threatened Over Book Weighs Switching Schools
description: A white third-grade teacher plans to decide by next week whether she will return to her old school, where she had been threatened by black parents for using what they considered to be a racially insensitive book, union officials said.

title: Ex-Big Scorer Is Happy to Find the Open Tar Heel
description: There was a time when Ed Cota was a scoring machine. He would penetrate and finish with dazzling layups, and make jump shots from all over the court. More than a few observers said Cota, who averaged 31 points at Tilden High School in Brooklyn and 21 points at St. Thomas More Academy in Oakdale, Conn., could not be stopped.

title: Metallica Drives Through a Night of Others' Songs
description: Metallica never hid its influences. Band members invariably praised the new wave of British heavy metal, a late 1970's movement of bands inspired by punk's do-it-yourself practices, along with American punk rock and British metal bands like Budgie. It played their songs onstage, and as early as 1984 started to record them for B-sides and EP's. Metallica released one group of metal and punk cover versions for its ''Garage Days Re-Revisited'' EP (Elektra) and has just released ''Garage, Inc.'' (Elektra), a more varied two-CD set.

title: New York's Capital Mistake
description: In drafting New York's death penalty statute three years ago, Gov. George Pataki and the State Legislature set out to avoid defects that could render it unconstitutional. Even so, they approved a flawed plea-bargaining process that now poses the first test of the new law before the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals.

title: Snyder to Acquire NRS
description: Snyder Communications Inc. said Wednesday that it would acquire the closely held marketing-services provider NRS Inc. for $24.4 million in stock. Both companies serve the pharmaceutical industry, and Snyder said the combined company would have access to virtually all pharmacies and drug retailers across the country. NRS, based in Danbury, Conn., handles in-store sales and promotion services for pharmaceutical and consumer packaged goods manufacturers.

title: Of Sotheby's And Saints
description: Some people wonder whether there are too many new saints under consideration these days. There are also hundreds of saints most of us don't know about, like St. Rosalie of Palermo, the protector against plague, smallpox, typhoid and earthquakes; the Holy Child of Atocha, the patron of travelers who risk capture by non-Christian enemies, and St. Isidore the Plowman, the patron of rain and good crops. Stanley Marcus's collection of carved images of these saints and others, made in the 1800's by Hispanic colonists, native New Mexicans and American Indians in the Southwest, are coming up for auction at Sotheby's next week, and they give new meaning to the term ''folk art.''

title: Scientists Looking to Improve Measure of Storm Dangers
description: As the Central American nations devastated by Hurricane Mitch struggle to pick up the pieces, meteorologists here are beginning to consider devising a new scale for measuring hurricanes in an effort to give the public a broader view of the potential danger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACH, NANCY
description: BACH-Nancy. November 25. Devoted sister of Joan Buck and aunt of Sherry Corazza. Services are on Friday, November 27, 1 PM, Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey. For further information, call Kirschenbaum Funeral Home, 718-859-2020.

title: Did TV Death Hinder Debate?
description: To the Editor:

title: Now What? Football and Turkey Flapjacks?
description: When the moon is in the seventh house and Jupiter aligns with Mars, then, and only then, peace will guide the planets and love will steer the stars.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Don Van Vliet

title: Did TV Death Hinder Debate?
description: To the Editor:

title: Yanks and MSG Remain A Study in Mutual Need
description: Does the collapse of the talks for Cablevision Systems to buy a majority of the Yankees mean that Cablevision is less likely to retain the team's cable-television rights on the MSG Network?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, ANNE
description: GOLD-Anne. On Nov. 26th, 1998. Beloved wife of Sol. Supermom to Tanya and Michael Romanoff, Stanley, Jay and Lorri Gold. Funloving grannie of Stuart and Jackie, Michelle and Alan, Darryl, Stephen, and Marc. GiGi to six great-grandchildren. Sister to Julie, Barney, and George White. She was a unique woman of strength and beauty and will be greatly missed. Services today, 10 A.M. at Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Hungry Museum In San Francisco
description: Few American institutions have made as serious a commitment to building an impressive permanent collection in a relatively short time as the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art.

title: After a Decade, Rap's Tribe Called Quest Goes Silent
description: Of current rap groups, only A Tribe Called Quest would end its last-ever performance with a song like ''Find A Way,'' which innocently wonders about the point at which friendship spills over into sex. Finishing a 75-minute set on Tuesday night at Hammerstein Ballroom, the band's D.J., Jarobi White, shut down his turntables, and the three rappers -- Q-Tip, Phife Dawg and Ali Shaheed Muhammad -- huddled together repeating the song's chorus. ''Now you caught my heart for the evening,'' it went. ''Kissed my cheek, move in, you confuse things/Should I just sit out? Help me find my way.'' As parting shots go, it was a remarkably delicate one.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Nov. 11 about Perry H. Young, an early African-American airline pilot, misstated the precedent he set. In 1956, he was the first black pilot for a regularly scheduled American commercial passenger airline. Another African-American, August Martin, had flown earlier for chartered passenger and scheduled cargo airlines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARDSON, CAROLINE WILLIS
description: RICHARDSON - Caroline Willis. Age 75. Died peacefully on November 24, 1998 at home in Bethlehem, Pa. Devoted wife of the late Wallace James Richardson. Loving mother of Caroline Richardson Mead, Ann Richardson Hagmann, and Helen Hope Richardson; and mother-in-law of Robert Keating Hagmann. Cherished grandmother of Peter Reindl Mead, Caroline Richardson Hagmann, and Elizabeth Keating Hagmann. Dear sister of Ann Willis Wirth and Jean Louise Willis. Also survived by 20 nieces and nephews. Predeceased by her parents, Dr. Benedict Patrick Willis and Caroline Mooney Willis; and brothers, Benedict Patrick Willis, Jr., and Thomas Charles Willis. Mass of Christian burial, at 9:30 A.M., on Saturday, November 28, Saint Anne's Church, 450 Washington Avenue, Bethlehem, Penn. Visitation at Connell Funeral Home, 245 East Broad Street, Bethlehem, 2-4 and 7-9 P.M., Friday, November 27. Contributions may be made to the Wallace J. Richardson Scholarship Fund, C/O The Development Office at Lehigh University, Bethlehem, PA.

title: DVD for Films Big and Small
description: From the rash of ''DVD is here'' notices in store windows, it's obvious that the digital CD with a movie on it is gaining ground. How much ground is debated by hardware dealers and video distributors, but there's no arguing that after a year of generally desultory performance, the new format has enough players and titles to claim a future and perhaps a substantial one.

title: Spectators' Strategy Shifts With the Weather
description: The Winkler family from Albany approached the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade with military precision. Rick and Patti Winkler, both accountants, are naturally organized people. Their four daughters, with the exception of 5-year-old Stephanie, are computer-literate. So when they all decided that this was the year to see Big Bird, the Rugrats and Santa Claus up close, they planned their parade trip with all the care of generals plotting an autumn offensive.

title: 2 Republicans Seek Inquiry Into District's Abortion Payments
description: Two Republican members of the House committee that handles the budget in the District of Columbia have asked a Federal prosecutor to investigate the use of local money to pay for abortions.

title: Shoppers May Find A Shortage of Help Over the Holidays
description: Black Friday, one of the busiest shopping days of the year, was looming across the mall like a dirigible. And with 85 hours to go, Harris Friedman's sportswear store was already a wreck.

title: Stolen Amulet Is Returned To Its Church in Brooklyn
description: Whether it was prayers or detectives that finally flushed the thief, no one can say. But two days after an amulet said to contain a sliver of bone from St. Jude vanished from a Roman Catholic church in Brooklyn, it was back home yesterday.

title: News Analysis; Crew Reacts to Latest Test Scores With an Unusual Silence
description: Three months ago, the Board of Education gave Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew a 25 percent raise and an extension of his contract, saying that the school system was on the way up. But new state data raise troubling questions about how much of an impact the Chancellor's policies have had on the lives of children.

title: Movie Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 10.

title: Past Champs Lead Pair Bridge Tourney
description: Several world-class partnerships were among the leaders going into the two final sessions of the prestigious Blue Ribbon Pair Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here this afternoon.

title: Hunter Admits Sale of Fake Gold Coins
description: The treasure hunter Mel Fisher has admitted selling several counterfeit gold coins at his gift shop here and has agreed to pay customers their purchase prices of $2,500 to $10,000.

title: From Twisters To Gorillas
description: By his own admission, Bill Paxton is a solid hitter who has not yet slammed any home runs.

title: Joy and Sentiment: Edgemont Seeks Title
description: Peter Koh, the senior fullback for Edgemont High School, limped along the sideline during practice earlier this week, watching his teammates run through the offense. Koh has played with many of them since the fourth grade, and the thought of having only one game left together bothers him more than his sprained ankle.

title: Inconsistency Continues To Plague Punchless Isles
description: Nearly two months into the season, it is becoming increasingly difficult to predict which Islanders team will show up a given night. One night, they find a way to beat one of the league's most talented teams in the Philadelphia Flyers. The next night, they cannot find the net against the less talented Ottawa Senators.

title: Accounts
description: * American Dairy Brands, Columbus, Ohio, a division of Dairy Farmers of America, to BBDO Chicago, part of Omnicom Group, as the agency of record for the company, which is licensed to market cheese and other dairy products bearing the Borden and Elsie trademarks. Those duties had been handled by Sive/ Young & Rubicam, Cincinnati, owned by Young & Rubicam Inc., which parted ways with American Dairy in December. Billings were estimated at more than $15 million.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm not sticking no feet in no shoes or frying burgers for six bucks an hour, period. Why should I? My dad's doing all right.''

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Kim Dingle

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGESIS, SAMUEL
description: MAGESIS-Samuel, 94. Died in Coral Springs, Florida on November 25. Loving husband of Esther, devoted father of Richard and Duffy, fond father-in-law of Peg, and beloved Pop Pop of Cassie and Nicky. Services on Sunday, November 29 at 1PM, BoulevardRiverside Chapel, 312 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Behind Exxon-Mobil Talks Lies a Humbled Oil Industry
description: Whether or not the talks between the Exxon Corporation and the Mobil Corporation lead to a merger or some other alliance, America's economic history is already being rewritten.

title: Boston, With Vaughn Gone, Now Can't Win for Signing
description: A year or so ago, the Yankees offered Bernie Williams $37.5 million for five years and the Boston Red Sox offered Mo Vaughn $20.2 million for two years. In the space of an hour or so Wednesday, Williams accepted the Yankees' offer of $87.5 million for seven years and Vaughn said I do to the Anaheim Angels' proposal of $80 million for six years.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Ed Ruscha

title: Helping Smokers Quit
description: To the Editor:

title: ON PRO FOOTBALL: More Than A Fast Mouth; With Jets' Johnson, Perception Is Not Exactly Reality
description: Turkeys, 250 of them, were being given to schoolchildren the other day in the Bronx. Keyshawn Johnson had bought them and was distributing them, showing his giving side. The calm, mature, quiet side. A rare time when he allows others to grab center stage.

title: Zimbabwe's Ex-President Convicted of Sodomy
description: The Rev. Canaan Banana, the former President of Zimbabwe, was found guilty of sodomy today by a court in Harare and faces up to 22 years in jail.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; One Big Bite After the Other Leads to Indigestion for Banks
description: Wall Street banks earn big profits greasing the wheels for companies to buy one another. But when banks merge, sparks often fly.

title: Ex-Parks Official Considers Bid To Be City's First Female Mayor
description: Betsy Gotbaum, executive director of the New-York Historical Society and a former New York City Commissioner of Parks and Recreation, has been in and out of city government for almost three decades without running for office. But yesterday, she said she was thinking of running for mayor in 2001.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Jackie Ferrara

title: Reporter's Notebook; Paradoxes Are a Recurring Theme at an Annual Conference on Gerontology
description: Robert L. Kane, a physician and gerontologist from the University of Minnesota, was talking about one of the paradoxes of modern aging: ''Here we are, spending megabucks to understand the genome, but at the end of the 20th century, we still don't have a basic system of care that responds to chronic disease. We can study these tiny molecules, and rearrange them to change the nature of life itself. But we can't come up with a health care system that really responds to what people need.''

title: CLINTON CENSURE GAINS AS OPTION
description: The idea of censuring President Clinton for his conduct in the Monica Lewinsky scandal, rather than impeaching him, is steadily gaining momentum in the House.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Hospital's Customer-Friendly Way
description: As she checked in, the elderly woman told the man at the concierge desk that she had a dog at home, Fifi, that needed to be walked. No problem, she was told.

title: Old Guard Repels Challenge At Staid Marks & Spencer
description: The clothes it sells are, mildly put, conservative. Its line in precooked food caters to everyone from brown-bag lunchers to dinner-party hosts too pressed to attend to the cuisine themselves. Marks & Spencer P.L.C. is -- in other words -- dependable.

title: Stuffed Animals With Attitude May Spur Modest Rise in Toy Sales
description: Furby? Fuhgeddaboutit.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Richard Prince and Martin Kippenberger

title: Some Role Reversal in East Asia; Singapore Freewheels While Hong Kong Curbs
description: When Lee Kuan Yew, the father of modern Singapore, wanted to transform this spit-and-polish outpost into a global financial center, he urged people here to mimic the freewheeling ways of Hong Kong.

title: S.U.V.'s Impair Quality of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: New Rules Alter Plans for Diesel Engines
description: The walls and roof are almost finished on a huge new General Motors diesel engine factory in southwestern Ohio. Several thousand engineers in Michigan, Indiana and Illinois are still developing new diesel engines for future cars, sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks.

title: S.U.V.'s Impair Quality of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan's Finance Minister May Step Down at End of the Year
description: Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa, a key figure in efforts to revive Japan's economy and stave off a global recession, suggested today that he would step down formally from politics and from his Cabinet post at the end of this year.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: On My Mind; Gift for Americans
description: Here I come bearing a lovely gift: proof that with the power of the passion for freedom, Americans can rise high above the government they elected and compel politicians to follow them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, MARION DANIELSON
description: CAMPBELL-Marion Danielson, of New York and Groton, Mass., former president and major stockholder of the Atlantic Monthly Company, died on November 24 in New York City at the age of 77. Mrs. Campbell's family acquired The Atlantic Monthly in 1938. Her own association with the venerable magazine began in 1943 as an editorial assistant. She was elected a director in 1953 and in 1957 became the major stockholder of the company and succeeded her father as president. She continued as president and director until the company was sold in 1980. She was also a director of the Providence (R.I.) Journal Company. A graduate of Foxcroft School and Vassar College (B.A. 1943) she worked in the editorial department of the Washington Post in 1944 and as a staff aid caseworker for the American Red Cross from 1944 to 1946. She was a major benefactor of many charitable institutions in New York, Boston and Groton and served on the boards of the Boston Museum of Science, The Deaconess-Nashoba Hospital, the Groton School and Lawrence Academy among other institutions. She maintained her family's ties to the Groton community, owning and successfully operating Gibbet Hill Farm, raising prizewinning black angus cattle, and Gibbet Hill Orchard. She was married to Douglass Campbell in 1962, formerly Vice President of the New York Central Railroad, and previously to the late Rev. Malcolm Strachan, who was Chaplain of Groton School. In addition to her husband she is survived by her sons, Richard Strachan of Portland, OR., & Stephen M. Strachan of Denver, CO, her daughter-inlaw, Deborah K. Strachan, and one grandchild, Kammer Douglass Strachan. A memorial service will be held at the St. John's Chapel of Groton School at a later date. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, BERNICE
description: ROSENBLATT-Bernice. Loving wife of Ralph. Beloved mother of Joseph and Beverly Rosenblatt; Sondra and Jacob Brandler. Dear sister of Arnold and Lawrence Bershad. Cherished grandmother of Rhonda and Robert Rich; Ethan Simon and Benjamin Brandler. Services Friday, 9:30 A.M. at Riverdale Temple, Bronx, N.Y. For information, call Nieberg's Midwood Chapel, 718-377-2700.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS: WEEK 13
description: Game of the Week

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Cellist Retunes, Recalling Another

title: A Radio Legend Searches for a New Gig
description: SCOTT MUNI , the legendary disk jockey recently unemployed, is agreeable to talk, but every 30 minutes, like clockwork, he has to excuse himself. This is not because of the usual 68-year-old male trouble, the bothersome prostate, but because of the toll Mr. Muni's 40 years of drinking took on his body. That period ended 13 years ago, after a stint at the Betty Ford Clinic, although giving up drink has not always been easy in a life of rock 'n' roll.

title: Rare Stamps Worth $1 Million Are Stolen After Show
description: What Jeffrey Forster considers art looks to most people like a stack of old mail. But in the rarefied world of philately, his collection of 1869 stamps -- most still affixed to their original envelopes -- are masterpieces worth an estimated $1 million.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19

title: Denmark's Central Bank Cuts Rates Again
description: The Danish central bank cut interest rates again today because three reductions in the last seven weeks had failed to weaken the nation's currency, the krone.

title: Wieden & Kennedy Gets Racing Account
description: The Pep Boys Indy Racing League in Indianapolis -- the open-wheel, oval-track racing series that includes the Indianapolis 500 -- has named Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., to handle its advertising and promotional account, which had been handled by various agencies on a project basis. Billings were estimated at more than $5 million.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Talks Between Oil Giants Reflect Global Realities

title: One Democrat Has Hat in Ring, and in Hand, for Presidency
description: Publicly, Vice President Al Gore refuses to acknowledge the obvious: that he is running for President. Other Democratic and Republican aspirants are also playing coy about their designs on the White House in 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, MICHAEL SAMUEL
description: ISRAEL-Michael Samuel. In memory of cousin Michael. Austin List and family

title: S.U.V.'s Impair Quality of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Fairy Tales That Cast Shadows on Sweetness and Light
description: You remember poor Ashputtel. Her wicked stepmother and ugly stepsisters wouldn't let her go to the prince's big dance; she was told to stay home and clean the fireplace instead. But after a magical transformation, she went to the dance in a glamorous new dress, won the prince's heart and lost her slipper.

title: Kellogg Expands Its Agency Roster
description: The Kellogg Company, searching for ways to reverse a slide in sales and market share for its ready-to-eat cereals, has expanded its agency roster by adding the Martin Agency in Richmond.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Kahn/Selesnick

title: A Ballet Once Dismissed Is Culturally de Rigueur
description: There were cries of horror and general consternation when the New York City Ballet announced that George Balanchine would create a ''Nutcracker'' for the company. How could that revered avant-gardist pander so to public taste? Could the chronically penny-counting company even afford to present a ''Nutcracker''?

title: Frank W. Newell, 82, Ophthalmology Authority
description: Frank William Newell, an eye specialist, teacher and head of many leading ophthalmologic organizations, some of which he helped found, died on Nov. 18 at his home in Chicago. He was 82.

title: INSIDE
description: What Ails Yeltsin?

title: Residential Real Estate; A Low-Rise Complex for Coney Island
description: Eighty-six attached single-family houses are to be built in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn over the next two years, bringing to a close an effort, begun 15 years ago, to attract moderate- and middle-income families to the waterside neighborhood.

title: China Gets An Apology From Japan
description: Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan apologized today to President Jiang Zemin of China for Japan's World War II conduct, but the two countries immediately became entangled in an uproar about the wartime memories that still haunt relations between the two great powers of East Asia.

title: Canadian Pipeline Gets Key Approval
description: Alliance Pipeline L.P., developer of a $4 billion (Canadian), or $2.6 billion (United States), natural gas pipeline linking British Columbia and Chicago, won a crucial approval today for the project from Canadian regulators.

title: RANGERS
description: Petr Nedved made no excuses after the Rangers' 4-2 loss to the Sabres in Buffalo on Wednesday night. Asked to assess his performance, he shrugged and said, I was a minus 3.

title: Revisiting Off Broadway Perennials
description: Absolutely convinced that I was going to be an audience of one, I arrived at ''The Fantasticks'' in the Village a little early. My thinking was, if the box office had tangible evidence of a bona fide ticketholder, the show positively had to go on.

title: PLUS: COLLEGE FOOTBALL
description: COLGATE

title: Buddhist Treasures for the Spirit and Heart
description: ''Days of Discipline and Grace: Treasures From the Imperial Buddhist Convents of Kyoto'' is a tiny exhibition -- if carefully packed, it could probably fit in a steamer trunk -- tucked away deep in the stacks of the C. V. Starr East Asian Library at Columbia University.

title: New Pop Music For Middle Age
description: Attention fellow dinosaurs, old fogies and senescent Beatlemaniacs. If you can hardly find any music on the radio to listen to nowadays, and the bouncy toy sounds of Brandy and Monica fighting over a boy don't speak to your soul the way Joni Mitchell's or Bob Dylan's records once did, there is still pop music being made that is worth caring about. Some of it is even made by musicians in their 20's. And some of it (although not much) is even very popular.

title: Did TV Death Hinder Debate?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pinochet's Case Moves to Realm Of Blair's Aides
description: The effort by Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former Chilean dictator, to escape extradition to Spain and a possible mass murder trial moved into the political arena today, with the British Government facing the decision of whether to go forward with the diplomatically volatile case.

title: Regulators Investigating Price Increases by Boeing and Airbus
description: Antitrust regulators in Washington and at the European Union in Brussels are conducting separate investigations into recent price increases announced by the Boeing Company and Airbus Industrie, the world's largest manufacturers of big commercial airliners.

title: Theater Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: In Assisi, a Survivor Recalls Rescue From the Holocaust
description: Graziella Viterbi is preparing to leave this city, which was devastated by earthquakes last year, and with her will go a piece of history that has produced some unexpected earthquake relief.

title: Enron to Acquire ICI Energy Units
description: The Enron Corporation of the United States said today that it had agreed to buy energy-generating units from Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. for $:300 million, or $497 million, expanding further into Britain.

title: Bergen Catholic Coach Earns His 100th Victory
description: Coach Fred Stengel won his 100th game yesterday when Bergen Catholic defeated Ridgewood, 34-7, at Ridgewood. Stengel, in his 11th season, has a 100-17 record. He will guide his team against St. Joseph of Montvale in the New Jersey Parochial Group 4 championship game on Dec. 4 at Giants Stadium.

title: Observer; Saps Of Now And Then
description: Return with us now to those dreary days of yesteryear when television was black-and-white, Dad was a hopeless sap and Mom was still the virgin mother of two.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, GEORGE ANTHONY
description: HECHT-George Anthony. Former bookseller. Died on November 25 in Rye Brook, NY. He was 88. He joined Doubleday & Co. in 1925 and became General Manager of Doubleday Book Shops in 1940. He bacame Vice President of Doubleday & Co. in 1948, President of the Old Corner Bookstore, Inc., in 1950, and President of Doubleday Book Shops in 1970, positions he held until his retirement in 1975. He was the Director of the Council on Books in Wartime and the Armed Services Editions from 1941 until 1946. He was the President of American Book Travellers in 1937 and President of the American Booksellers Association from 1946 until 1947; he was Board Chairman of the Association in 1948. He is survived by his wife, the former Dorothea Ackermann, and his daughters Karen Hecht and Dorothea Hecht, all of New York City; his son George Anthony Hecht, Jr., of San Leandro, CA; three grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Salvation Army or the New York Public Library. Private interment at Nassau Knolls Cemetery in Port Washington, New York.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: In Ireland, Blair Declares End to Centuries of Enmity
description: Speaking as the first British Prime Minister ever to address the Parliament of the Irish Republic, Tony Blair today declared an end to centuries of British-Irish hostility and said that London and Dublin must now work together to rescue the stalled Northern Ireland peace effort.

title: Agent 007, Your Armored Car Is In
description: IT looks like any other brand-new BMW 540i. But try firing a .44 Magnum at the ''540i Protection'' -- it handles bullets as blithely as Superman does. Still, no car can do everything that the Man of Steel can; the 540i Protection still has to be driven around tall buildings.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: FOOTBALL

title: Economic Growth Pace Slows in France
description: The French economy grew in the third quarter at its slowest pace in 18 months, and business confidence fell in November to its lowest level in 19 months, as companies cut their inventories, anticipating that exports will slow.

title: The Whimsy of a Snapshot, With a Calculating Eye
description: Using nothing fancier than available light, a 35-millimeter Leica camera and a superb eye for entrancing storytelling moments, Alfred Eisenstaedt produced some of the most memorable images of the 20th century.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the boxing promoter Chris Dundee on Nov. 17 misstated the name of the Miami Beach gym that was his headquarters. It was the Fifth Street Gym, not Fifth Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAAYANI, EDNA
description: MAAYANI-Edna. Bnai Zion, the 90 year old American Zionist Fraternal Organization, mourns the passing, after a long and courageous battle against cancer, of its long time Associate National Director Edna Maayani, a valiant worker and devoted supporter of Jewish causes and the State of Israel. She was a talented artist and graphic designer who brought these special skills to her work, augmenting the administrative responsibilities of her position. To her children, parents, sister and grandchildren we offer our heartfelt condolences. Funeral services to be held at Bnai Zion House 136 East 39th Street, New York City, at 9:45am on Friday November 27th. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Bnai Zion Foundation. Alan G. Hevesi, National President Mel Parness, Executive VP

title: Many Arabs See Double Standard for Israel
description: From her jewelry shop on a busy street here, Iman Khalidi is watching the confrontation between Iraq and the United States with growing frustration.

title: Chilean Foreign Minister Flies to General's Defense
description: As protests to the continuing detention of Gen. Augusto Pinochet in London mounted here, the Foreign Minister flew to London today in an 11th-hour bid to free the former dictator.

title: Corrections
description: A pop music review on Nov. 17 about new recordings by Jewel and Whitney Houston misstated the release year of Ms. Houston's first album. It was 1985, not 1987.

title: Hitachi Has First Half-Year Loss for Group
description: Hitachi Ltd., Japan's largest electronics company, posted its first group loss ever in the latest six months as prices for computer memory chips tumbled, consumers spent less on electronic goods and companies reduced capital investment.

title: Chic Has a New Address; World's Highest-Rent Retail Zone Is Now on Madison Ave.
description: As the holiday shopping marathon begins today, bells are ringing on Madison Avenue. There are Christmas chimes, of course, and the jingle of cash registers (or at least the whisper of platinum plastic). But the peal most audible to store owners and real estate agents is of celebration, tinged ever so slightly with alarm.

title: Mayor Solicits Donations in Nativity Scene Case
description: The annual tug-of-war between the Republican Mayor of Jersey City, Bret D. Schundler, and the American Civil Liberties Union over the display of holiday symbols in front of City Hall has become as predictable as the appearance of Santa Claus in shopping malls.

title: A Doctor's Stabbing Raises Security Concerns for a Hospital
description: Administrators at a Brooklyn hospital where a surgeon was stabbed four times in an elevator on Thanksgiving Day said yesterday that though the attack was an isolated crime, it left them grappling with how to balance concerns for safety with a desire to keep their hospital an open, inviting place for patients and their relatives.

title: Edgemont Wins Title Using Buddy System
description: The Edgemont Panthers, with 11 starters who have played on the same team since grammar school, earned the ultimate reward for their togetherness today.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday, about differences between Quebec and the rest of Canada, misstated the name of the province's most popular television show. It is ''La Petite Vie,'' not ''Le Petite Vie.''

title: RIVAL GETS OFFER FROM UNIDENTIFIED BUYER
description: The Rival Company, the maker of Crock-Pot and Pollenex products, said yesterday that it had received an unsolicited offer from an unidentified buyer and had hired a financial adviser to help it evaluate the bid. Rival, based in Kansas City, Mo., which had sales of $376.9 million in the year that ended on June 30, did not give the amount of the offer. Rival retained Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities L.L.C. to assist it in discussions. The company said it made the announcement in response to market rumors. Rival fell 93.75 cents yesterday, to $9.9375 on the Nasdaq, after rising $3.50 on Wednesday. In August, Rival, which makes appliances as well as industrial pumps and fans, said it planned to close two plants and two distribution centers to cut costs.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's a real test case. If the F.T.C. let this one go through without major divesting, then everything would be fair game. Why couldn't G.M. merge with Ford?''

title: Stumbling Upon a Race Secret
description: The uproar this week over a white teacher's use of a book called ''Nappy Hair'' in her third-grade classroom says more about many African-Americans' enduring discomfort with some of the physical features of blackness than about the book or the teacher. In using the book, Ruth Sherman, the 27-year-old teacher at Brooklyn's P.S. 75, stumbled onto a volatile race secret and uncovered a strain of self-hatred in African-American culture that in this instance made education an explosive issue.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Manners, Morals and a Hygiene Poll
description: To the Editor:
