title: Corrections
description: Charts with the continuation of a front-page article yesterday about changes in the oil industry and the talks between Exxon and Mobil misstated the companies' 1997 revenue. Exxon had $137.2 billion in revenue, not $120.3 billion, and Mobil had $65.9 billion, not $58.4 billion. A combined company would have had $203.1 billion in revenue, not $201.6 billion.

title: SBARRO FAMILY SEEKS ALL OF RESTAURANT'S SHARES
description: Sbarro Inc. said yesterday that the Sbarro family had made a new, $388 million offer to buy the 68.5 percent of the Italian-restaurant chain it does not already own. Under the offer, stockholders of the company, based in Commack, N.Y., would receive $27.50 for each of their 14.1 million shares outstanding. Last January, the Sbarro family offered to buy 13.3 million shares it did not own for about $380 million, or $28.50 a share, but negotiations ended in June. The company has annual revenue of about $370 million.

title: Is the Box Half-Full or Half-Empty?; Top Cereal Maker Fights To Retain Eroding Share
description: Those snap, crackle and pop folks have been asleep at the breakfast table.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOBAK, ROBERT R.
description: KOBAK-Robert R. Beloved husband of Shirley. Father of Jonathan Kobak and Susan Young. Cherished grandfather of Ellen and Laura Kobak and Jason and Daniel Young. Dear brother of Vivian Barry. Services 11:15 AM, Sunday November 29, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Russia to Lower Two Key Tax Rates
description: The Russian Government has decided to lower corporate and value-added tax rates to stimulate industry and encourage more consumer spending.

title: Drunken Driver Hits Patrol Van, Police Say
description: Two Pennsauken police officers assigned to a checkpoint to catch drunken drivers stopped nearly 600 cars on Wednesday night but found no one driving under the influence of alcohol. Instead, the police said yesterday, a drunken driver found them.

title: INSIDE
description: Death Row Inmate Flees

title: AUSTRALIAN MINER WMC SET TO SELL ITS POWER ASSETS
description: The Australian mining concern WMC Resources Ltd. has agreed to sell its electricity generation and transmission assets in Western Australia to a partnership of the Transalta Corporation and the Australian Gas Light Company for $230.2 million (Australian), or $147.2 million (United States). The assets include four gas-fired power generating stations, diesel backup generators, transmission lines and equipment, WMC said. The purchaser, Southern Cross Energy, is 85 percent-owned by Transalta, based in Calgary, Alberta, and 15 percent-owned by Australian Gas Light.

title: A New York Symbol of Openness Battens Its Doors
description: City Hall, the ornate, off-white building that has stood -- in symbol and in fact -- for open government in New York City for almost two centuries, has been virtually off-limits to the public for three months now, as part of an extraordinary security strategy imposed by the Giuliani administration.

title: Keith Van Horn Is Bulked Up for an N.B.A. Season That Just Keeps Crumbling
description: For a long time, Keith Van Horn would not allow himself to think that the National Basketball Association season was in jeopardy. While the first seven weeks of what was to be his second N.B.A. season were being canceled, the Nets' rising star was steadfast in his belief that eventually the games would begin.

title: Worldcorp Trading to End
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it would suspend trading of shares in Worldcorp Inc. by Dec. 14, because the company, which is based in Herndon, Va., has a market value of less than $8 million. The exchange said it would apply with the Securities and Exchange Commission to delist the stock after it is suspended. The company's shares, which closed at 28.125 cents yesterday, have traded between 9 cents and $1.6875 in the last year. Last week, Worldcorp, a holding company that provides services to the air transportation and telecommunications industries, said it planned to file a bankruptcy reorganization plan.

title: Providing a Physical Form for the Emotions
description: Kristin Marting probably won't care for this analogy, but ''The Women of Orleans'' made me think of ''Ally McBeal.'' Ms. Marting's play, set in New Orleans in the first half of the 19th century, is far more elegant than the Fox television series about an anxiety-plagued Boston lawyer in short skirts, but both works take unorthodox approaches to conveying their characters' emotions physically.

title: Conveying a Saint's Halo With a Thread of Sound
description: An arresting work by the composer Jacob Druckman, who had an important association with the New York Philharmonic, and an elegant performance by the violinist Pamela Frank in a Mozart Concerto were the highlights of the orchestra's concert on Wednesday night conducted by Andre Previn, a program that will be repeated tonight and on Tuesday. And if Mr. Previn's performance of Dvorak's Symphony No. 7 in the second half was not an unqualified success, it was rewarding to hear this vibrant, stormy work played with such sonorous beauty.

title: A POLICY STRUGGLE STIRS WITHIN NATO
description: The Clinton Administration has presented NATO with a far-reaching program that seeks to define what the alliance has become since the cold war ended, and sets out its goals for the next century.

title: Reports on Japan Economy Show Recovery Is Not Yet in Sight
description: A slew of economic reports released today indicated that Japan was unlikely to begin a recovery from its recession soon.

title: Belle Takes New Steps In Orioles' Direction
description: With Decision Day looming, Albert Belle remained undecided last night on his immediate future even as his agent moved closer to a deal with the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Javier Garcia Paniagua, 61, Mexican Ruling Party Loyalist
description: Javier Garcia Paniagua, a former senior Mexican official whose hard-line views exemplified those of a group within the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party known as the ''dinosaurs,'' died of a heart attack on Tuesday in Guadalajara. He was 61.

title: Hong Kong Says Economy Shrank 7% in Quarter
description: Posting the worst performance since the keeping of records began nearly four decades ago, Hong Kong said today that its economy shrank by an estimated 7 percent in the third quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASON, KATHARINE POST PALMER
description: MASON-Katharine Post Palmer, formerly Mrs. J. Culbert Palmer, of Stonington, CT, died Nov 26th. Born September 25, 1901, the daughter of Mr. & Mrs. A. Wright Post of New York and Bernardsville, NJ. A graduate of Chapin School, she was the widow of J. Culbert Palmer and Charles J. Mason. Active in New York social work, education committee of the Jr. League, the YWCA Board and Women's Board of NY Hospital, helped found the Yorkville Youth Council and served as Board member and VP of Colonial Dames of America. Survived by her sister, Mrs. Henry Howells; sons Gerard Palmer and A. Wright Palmer, five grandchildren, James, Lucius, Elizabeth, Mary Palmer, and Katharine Smith; a great-grandchild, Natalie Palmer. Funeral service at Calvary Church, Stonington, CT. on Tuesday at 11AM. Donations to Calvary Church or Stonington Historical Society Endowment Fund.

title: Lawmakers Scurry to Cut Cost of Patriots' Move to Hartford
description: Facing heavy pressure to approve an agreement to bring the New England Patriots to Hartford but boggled by the potential cost, Connecticut lawmakers are frantically searching for ways to trim some of the deal's many generous provisions without driving the football team away.

title: 'The Rum Diary'
description: My apartment in New York was on Perry Street, a five minute walk from the White Horse. I often drank there, but I was never accepted because I wore a tie. The real people wanted no part of me.

title: S.A.T.: Not Just a Numbers Game
description: To the Editor:

title: A Numbers Warrior Departs
description: For nearly two decades Raymond Horton has served as an indispensable nuisance for successive mayors, governors, lawmakers and labor leaders in New York State. That was not his official title, of course. Mr. Horton's job has been president of the Citizens Budget Commission and author of countless critiques of New York City and state budget practices. He retires Monday after a career of angering more people for more of the right reasons for longer than almost anyone else in the city.

title: Israel Is Rethinking Its Stand on Lebanon
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu cut short a trip abroad to reconsider the Israeli Army's 20-year occupation of southern Lebanon after the killing of seven Israeli soldiers there in the last week and a half.

title: Tony Dorsett, Move Over
description: It took a 24-yard field goal by Texas kicker Kris Stockton with nine seconds remaining before Ricky Williams, the Longhorns' magnificent running back, could celebrate his remarkable season.

title: Maine Banking Change
description: The Camden National Corporation, the holding company for Camden National Bank, Maine's fifth largest, said today that its president and chief executive, Keith Patten, will retire in May 1999. The company said Robert Daigle, the president and chief executive of Camden National Bank, would replace Mr. Patten, 59. After the change, Mr. Daigle will retain his current position at the bank.

title: S.A.T.: Not Just a Numbers Game
description: To the Editor:

title: City Workers' Contract
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FLIER, MILTON R.
description: FLIER-Milton R. 11/28/17-9/29/95. Today you are 81. No party but quiet reflection on how much you loved us and how we really miss you. Dorothy and our wonderful family.

title: Gently, China Flexes Strategic Muscles in Asia
description: SINGAPORE  Outlining a strategic blueprint for Asia that differs sharply from the approach of the United States, Defense Minister Chi Haotian of China said Friday that security in the region could not be achieved by military alliances.

title: EARTHLINK SHARES RISE ON REPORT OF BID BY SPRINT
description: Shares of Earthlink Network Inc. rose 37 percent yesterday on a report that the Sprint Corporation, the third-largest United States long-distance telephone company, may buy the remaining 71 percent of the Internet-service provider it does not already own. Earthlink shares jumped $19.50, to $71.875, in Nasdaq trading. The Dec. 7 issue of Business Week magazine reported in its ''Inside Wall Street'' column that unidentified people expected Sprint, which is based in Kansas City, Mo., to break an agreement signed in February that prohibits it from buying Earthlink for 39 months. Robin West, a money manager for the New Mexico State Investment Council, estimates Earthlink is worth $4.8 billion, or $120 a share.

title: DAIMLERCHRYSLER TO IDLE 348 AT MISSOURI PLANT
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G., the world's fifth-largest auto maker, will idle 348 workers at its minivan plant in Fenton, Mo., in expectation of a seasonal slowdown in minivan sales. The company employs about 4,700 workers at the suburban St. Louis plant, one of two North American plants that build Chrysler minivans. DaimlerChrysler said it did not know how long the Missouri workers would be laid off. The auto maker said on Wednesday that it would suspend production next week for one week at its 2,900-worker Sterling Heights, Mich., plant to keep inventories of its Plymouth Breeze, Dodge Stratus and Chrysler Cirrus small cars under control.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLESINGER, DOROTHY
description: SCHLESINGER-Dorothy. Will be missed by the loved ones to whom she devoted her life. Dotty, was a wonderful mother to son Joseph and daughter-in-law Bunny, and loving grandma to Jill and Robert. She passed away on November 26th, date of her wedding anniversary with Murray, whose memory she cherished always. We love and miss you very much.

title: Sorting Out the Subway Surplus
description: Politicians and rapid-transit advocates have issued wish lists imploring New York City Transit to spend most, if not all, of its 1998 surplus, now more than $170 million and rising, on improving subway and bus service. They are surely right that running more subways and buses, cleaning trains and stations more frequently and trying new experiments with Metrocard fare discounts deserve top spots on the transit system's priority list. But it would be foolish to treat this expanding pot of money as though New Yorkers have collectively stumbled across sunken treasure. The modest surplus can help improve service but is hardly enough to make major progress in meeting riders' needs.

title: S.A.T.: Not Just a Numbers Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSMANN, WALTER A.
description: MOSMANN-Walter A. Herman, DDS, FACD, Palmyra, New York. Formerly of Ridgewood, NJ. Died on Nov. 18, 1998. He is survived by his wife Mary Ellen Mosmann; daughters, Pamela Hayes, Sarah Christine (Michele) & Charles DeBoer, Linda Kepford; 5 grandchildren, Tanya Hayes, Elizabeth, Peter DeBoer, Lyle, Katherine Kepford. Friends may attend a memorial service 3PM Sunday, Nov. 29 at Grace Lutheran Church, 1200 River Rd, Teaneck, NJ at Rt. 4.

title: Urging Millennial Penitence, Pope Is Offering Indulgences
description: For Roman Catholics, the year 2000 offers early salvation.

title: Usinor Says Profits Won't Meet Expectations
description: The chairman of Usinor S.A., Francis Mer, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit would not meet expectations, causing shares in Europe's fourth-largest steel company to tumbled. In an interview with the French daily newspaper L'Agefi, Mr. Mer said Usinor's fourth quarter would not be ''in line with what we expected three months ago.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the election in Quebec on Nov. 30 referred to operations of the Alcan Aluminium company incorrectly. The company does not receive subsidized electricity from Quebec's hydroelectric plants.

title: Dick O'Neill, 70, Actor Known For Role in 'Cagney and Lacey'
description: Dick O'Neill, an actor best known for his work as Charlie Cagney in the television series ''Cagney and Lacey,'' died on Nov. 17 at St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 70 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Victory for Adaptable Player
description: A player who wins major successes with many different partners did so again at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here on Thursday night.

title: Jonathan Kwitny, 57, Author And Prize-Winning Reporter
description: Jonathan Kwitny, a journalist and author whose subjects were as varied as Mafia forays into board rooms and papal biography, died on Thursday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 57 and lived in Cuddebackville, N.Y., and Manhattan.

title: COLLEGES: FOOTBALL ROUNDUP
description: TENNESSEE

title: Black-Jewish Bond
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUPNICK, DAVID
description: KRUPNICK-David. Beloved husband of Linda Small. Devoted father of Scott. Cherished son of Ida (nee Rappaport). Dear brother of Sheldon. Funeral service Sunday 9AM, Kane St Synagogue, 236 Kane Street, Brooklyn. For info Raccuglia & Son 718-855-7737.

title: Things Are Getting Curiouser (and Also Furiouser)
description: ''Curious George'' is a best-selling children's book series. Furious George is a struggling punk rock band. You wouldn't necessarily confuse the two. George in the books is a monkey. George in the band is a person. But then again, maybe you might. The ''Curious George'' books have bright yellow covers with red lettering and pictures of George the monkey. The Furious George albums are bright yellow with red lettering and also likenesses of George the monkey -- in leather and sunglasses.

title: His Scoring Belittled, Kovalev Gets Revenge
description: After he traded Aleksei Kovalev to the Penguins earlier this week, Rangers General Manager Neil Smith said that Kovalev had not yet learned in seven seasons that the object of hockey was to score goals, even though Kovalev had scored at least 20 in four different seasons.

title: What to See First: Pig, Bugs or Babies?; Children, and Parents, Flock to Movie Theaters for All the Holiday Fare
description: Daddy and the pet bunny rabbit had to stay home, but the rest of the Kissel family was waiting patiently yesterday morning to see the new movie about Babe the talking pig, on one of the biggest family filmgoing days of the year.

title: TRANSACTIONS SYSTEMS ADDS NETHERLANDS CONCERN
description: Transactions Systems Architects Inc., a developer of banking software, said yesterday that it had purchased Media Integration B.V. of the Netherlands in a stock transaction valued at $29.2 million. Transactions Systems, a Omaha-based company that makes software used for automatic teller machines and other banking transactions, said it would acquire all of the closely held Media Integration for 740,000 shares of its class A common stock. Media Integration develops ''smart card'' systems for banks, telecommunication, insurance, travel companies and government organizations.

title: About New York; A Chinese Oasis for the Soul on Staten Island
description: OVER the last five months, a one-acre plot of land nestled in the Staten Island Botanical Garden has been slowly transformed into an outpost of China. About 40 Chinese craftsmen have toiled nonstop to build the Chinese Scholar's Garden, an exquisite collection of pavilions, bridges and ponds. They used traditional tools or just their hands as they put into place thick cedar columns, latticed door frames and hand-finished granite panels. A tablet over the entrance declares in red and gold Chinese characters, ''The Garden Where One Experiences Many Beautiful Things.''

title: Viag to Acquire Swiss Chemical Company
description: The reshuffling of corporate Europe lurched a step forward today as Viag A.G., Germany's third-largest utility, announced that it was acquiring Algroup A.G. of Switzerland in a stock swap worth $8.7 billion.

title: Devils' Oliwa Is Not Just Your Average Enforcer
description: Earlier in this decade, on workdays, Krzysztof Oliwa did not see much sunlight. Learning to repair machinery in the coal mines in Poland, he woke up at 4:30 A.M., boarded a train at 5:07 A.M., went underground at 6 A.M. and came up at 3:30 P.M. to go back and practice hockey. ''Dirty job,'' Oliwa said of his mining career.

title: American Topics
description: A 77-year-old Florida man with a sleepwalking habit awoke recently to find himself up to his armpits in alligators. When James Currens, of Palm Harbor, wandered from home, he stumbled into a pond and awoke in several feet of water, his legs stuck in the mud. Several gators, some longer than 3 feet, came to visit, he said. He fended them off with his cane  sleepwalkers, take note  until neighbors heard his cries and summoned police. Mr. Currens suffered no serious injury.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, PAULINE
description: RUBINSTEIN-Pauline (nee Lieberman), 91. Died on November 26, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Robert Rubinstein, M.D. Loving mother of Bernice Moskowitz and Rita Heller. Grandmother of Lisa Sloan, Richard Moskowitz, Stephen Heller, M.D., and Barbara Heller, and Great-grandmother of Jason Sloan. Proud mother-in-law of Robert Moskowitz, M.D., and Stanley Heller, M.D. Grandmother-inlaw to Randy Sloan and Pamela Beasley, M.D.

title: South Africa Panel Didn't Serve Truth
description: To the Editor:

title: For Livent, Bankruptcy Is Proving To Be Severe
description: On one level, Livent's filing for bankruptcy protection last week seemed to resolve many questions that had been swirling in the theater world about the financial condition of Broadway's public production company. But over the last few days, additional grim developments suggest how severe bankruptcy will be for the Canada-based company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WESTERMANN, DAVID
description: WESTERMANN-David, 78. On November 26, 1998. Loving husband of Edith. Cherished father of Nancy, John and David. Beloved grandfather of six. Dearest brother of Gertrude Castronuovo and the late John Jacob Westermann III. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue and 12th Street, Garden City, Saturday 7 - 9 PM and Sunday 2 - 4 and 7 - 9 PM. Mass of christian burial at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Garden City, on Monday at 10 AM.

title: Banks Without Boundaries
description: The global financial market can move trillions of dollars around the world within minutes, but the major players are usually viewed as being from one country or another. Even those companies that operate in many countries, such as Citigroup or Merrill Lynch, are still seen as basically American.

title: FPIC INSURANCE PLANNING TO ADD A LIABILITY INSURER
description: FPIC Insurance Group Inc., the largest medical professional liability insurer in Florida, agreed yesterday to pay $52 million to buy the closely held Administrators for the Professions Inc., the manager of New York's second-largest liability insurer for doctors. FPIC, based in Jacksonville, Fla., will pay $44 million in cash and 214,286 of its common shares for A.F.P. Based in Manhasset, N.Y., A.F.P. manages Physicians' Reciprocal Insurers, which provides liability insurance for more than 7,000 doctors and has annual premiums of about $125 million. FPIC also plans to buy Physicians' Reciprocal Insurers itself within the next 12 months, according to Robert B. Finch, chief financial officer.

title: GLB BANCORP AGREES TO BUY MAPLE LEAF FINANCIAL
description: GLB Bancorp Inc. agreed yesterday to buy a rival, Maple Leaf Financial Inc., a closely held Ohio bank, for $18 million in cash and stock to expand its business in the state's Lake and Geauga counties. GLB, based in Mentor, Ohio, the holding company for Great Lakes Bank, which has seven offices in Lake County, said it had issued 375,000 of its shares to Maple Leaf shareholders, valued at $13.50 a share. The combined bank will have assets of $203 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEHAYA, ERY W.
description: KEHAYA-Ery W. Of Jupiter Island, Hobe Sound, FL, age 75, died November 23, 1998, at his home in Florida. He was born in New York City on October 17, 1923, the son of Ery Kehaya Sr. of Turkey and Grace Whitaker of Winston-Salem, NC. He was educated at the St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and at Yale University. He was honorably discharged from the U.S. Army-Air Force where he served during World War II. Mr. Kehaya was known for his charity and his strong support for education. Among his many educational beneficiaries were Duke University; The St. Paul's School, where he was honored as a Shattuck Fellow; The Asheville School and St. Andrew's College, both of which he served as a member of their boards of trustees. Mr. Kehaya's father founded Standard Commercial Corporation in 1910. When he joined the company in 1945 it was a small, closely held tobacco merchant company with only three employees. Ery started out unloading oriental tobacco on the docks in New York. By the time he retired as Chairman of the Corporation, Standard Commercial Corporation was a New York Stock Exchange - listed multinational company with over 9,000 full and part-time employees and a world leader in leaf tobacco and wool trading. Mr. Kehaya is survived by his wife, Helga; a daughter, Elizabeth W. Kehaya of Boulder, Colorado; two sons, Ery W. Kehaya, II and his wife Sharon, of Wilson, NC and Mark W. Kehaya and his wife Hannah of St. Petersburg, Russia; and five grandchildren, James, Julian, Robert, Alex and Mary Louise. In lieu of flowers the family has requested that memorial contributions be made to the Jupiter Island Clinic, P.O. Box 375 Hobe Sound, Florida 33475. A memorial service will be held at 2:00 P.M. on Tuesday, December 1, 1998, at Christ Memorial Chapel, Jupiter Island, Florida. For further information contact the Aycock Funeral Home, 1112 Military Trail, Jupiter, Florida.

title: Christianity Is Diverse
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Plans Gaza Visit in a Move Arabs Call Historic
description: President Clinton will travel to Gaza next month to address Palestinian leaders, the White House said today. He is to speak at what the Palestinians are describing as an historic meeting to formally revoke anti-Israel clauses in the 1964 Palestinian charter.

title: Arms Agency's Computers Lacked Testing
description: The agency responsible for managing the nation's stockpile of nuclear weapons told the Pentagon last summer that it had no year 2000 bugs in three of its most important computer systems, but auditors say those systems were never independently tested.

title: S.A.T.: Not Just a Numbers Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Merger Tidings Carry S.& P. and Nasdaq to High Ground
description: It was new highs again for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock and Nasdaq composite indexes yesterday as anticipation of a new wave of mergers and a general rush by investors to join the equity rebound pushed stocks up.

title: Merrill Lynch Unit Expanding in Japan
description: Merrill Lynch & Company's four-month-old Japanese retail unit has opened more than 30,000 accounts with assets of 200 billion yen ($1.64 billion) but is still not expected to turn a profit until mid-2000.

title: Beliefs
description: Last Sunday, ''60 Minutes'' broadcast a step-by-step, close-up videotape of a killing and gave the killer, Dr. Jack Kevorkian, a national platform to explain his act as a humane deed rather than a crime.

title: Life Is Grim? Yes, but Good For a Laugh
description: ''Wa-SKAHN-sin,'' Lorrie Moore said, articulating the syllables carefully, a lesson in local linguistics. ''What you do, instead of breaking the syllables between the S and the C, you break between the A -- not usually in Wisconsin, of course -- and the S. So it's W-A, then there's a break, and there's S-K-A, with a nasal A.''

title: S.A.T.: Not Just a Numbers Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, JERRI
description: ROSENTHAL-Jerri. Died November 20, age 93. Beloved wife of the late Donald, dearest mother of Marci Roistacher (and Jules) and Joan Schorsch (John). Cherished grandmother of Kelly and Jeff Lampert, Fern and Dan Lampert, Kim Stone and Clifford Diamond. Great-grandmother of five. In our hearts forever.

title: Barclays Chief Quits After Bank Has Losses
description: John Martin Taylor, chief executive of Barclays P.L.C., quit today after the bank said it had suffered losses in investment banking and indicated that pretax profit this year may fall short of analysts' expectations, which sent its shares down 7.7 percent.

title: Infoseek Renegotiates Deal With Netscape
description: The Infoseek Corporation, the No. 3 Internet search service, said today that it had renegotiated its agreement with the Netscape Communications Corporation, reducing the number of times visitors to Netscape's Web site are offered Infoseek's service.

title: Israelis Are Reconsidering South Lebanon Occupation
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu cut short a trip abroad today to reconsider the Israeli Army's long occupation of southern Lebanon after the killing of seven Israeli soldiers there in the last week and a half.

title: Deutsche Bank Weighs Big Issues Prior to Bankers Trust Purchase
description: As the German banking giant Deutsche Bank A.G. prepared to announce its $9.67 billion acquisition of the Bankers Trust Corporation on Monday in Frankfurt, employees and investors awaited word on several important issues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, JEROME G.
description: PRICE-Jerome G. Of Lakewood N.J. on Thursday, November 26, 1998. At age 89. Beloved husband of the late Rebecca (nee Joffe). Devoted father of Matthew of N.Y. and Bennett of Oakland, CA. Dear brother of Irving of Montclair, N.J. and Lillian of White Plains, N.Y. Graveside funeral service Nov. 29 at 11:30 A.M. at Beth Israel Cemetery Woodbridge. Belkoff-Goldstein Funeral Chapel, Lakewood, New Jersey.

title: Voting System At City Union Is Tainted, Leaders Say
description: The admitted vote fraud at New York City's largest municipal union grows out of a system in which officials with a strong interest in the results usually oversee both the voting and the counting of the ballots, union leaders and labor experts say.

title: Not Just Governments Make War or Peace
description: Once history's stage was peopled with kings and princes. Now it seems that almost anyone with letterhead stationary and a tax identification number can crowd on as well. Private organizations increasingly play roles once considered the preserve of governments, from drafting peace treaties to waging war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SECOFSKY, ABE
description: SECOFSKY-Abe. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Shelley M. Limmer, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTEIN, DOROTHY
description: GREENSTEIN-Dorothy. The officers and members of Old Oaks Country Club mourn the passing of their dear friend and fellow member Dorothy Greenstein. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to the members of her family. Robert K. Low, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSO, DR. ERNST
description: MARSO-Dr. Ernst. We mourn with great sorrow the loss of our board member, past president of Men's Club of Hebrew Tabernacle Congregation.

title: Surveying a Collaboration in Comic Topical Songs
description: Early in ''The Story Goes On,'' a sadly undernourished little show surveying the music of David Shire and his lyric collaborator, Richard Maltby Jr., the singer Loni Ackerman, who performs most of the material with Mr. Shire accompanying her on the piano, speaks of ''honing my craft.'' This sort of thudding cliche, alas, is what passes for patter in the revue, which opened a three-week engagement at the Kaufman Theater, 534 West 42d Street in Clinton, on Tuesday evening.

title: New Data Point Blame at Gun Makers
description: As many as half the handguns used in crimes had been purchased from federally licensed dealers within the prior three years, passing far more quickly from manufacturer to dealer to criminal than previously believed, according to new Federal law-enforcement data that are expected to play a major role in suits against the handgun industry.

title: Britain Postpones Pinochet Hearing as Minister Meets With Chilean Envoys
description: Sticking to Britain's official hands-off policy in the Augusto Pinochet case, Prime Minister Tony Blair said today that he did not even expect to be consulted about it, and Foreign Secretary Robin Cook assured his Chilean counterpart that any decisions would be made free of political considerations.

title: Sports of The Times; Swaggering Quietly, Miami's Back
description: FINALLY, the Big East has a football game the nation can sink its teeth into: Miami at Syracuse in the Carrier Dome this afternoon for the Big East conference championship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLSTEIN, RAYMOND PHILLIP
description: MILLSTEIN - Raymond Phillip. Died peacefully at home in New York City on November 26th, 1998. Loved husband of Alissa. Devoted father of David Matthew. Dear son of Pearl and the late David Millstein. Loving brother of Janis Millstein-Rubin and her husband Gabriel. Adored uncle and brother-in-law. Raymond is a graduate of Fordham Law School and New York University. Admitted to the New York Bar, he practiced law in New York City. Services Sunday, November 29th, 11:00 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: France Rejects Calls to Try Congo Leader For Torture
description: As 34 African government leaders began a French-African summit meeting here today, prosecutors turned down requests by two French human rights groups to begin criminal proceedings against President Laurent Kabila of Congo on torture charges.

title: CLINTON RESPONDS TO HYDE'S QUERIES; YIELDS NO GROUND
description: President Clinton insisted once again today that he had not lied under oath about his affair with Monica S. Lewinsky, in terse, formal responses to 81 questions submitted by the House Judiciary Committee. But he reiterated that he had misled his family, his aides and the nation about the relationship.

title: Journal; My Turkey Problem
description: Now there is truly something to be thankful for: We have all survived Thanksgiving.

title: Census Chief's Dream: Grand Tally Minus Politics
description: Kenneth Prewitt, the new director of the Census Bureau, certainly talks like an intellectual, sprinkling his speech with Britishisms like ''full stop,'' when dramatically ending a thought.

title: N.F.L. Goes to the Audio Tape in Coin Controversy
description: The National Football League announced yesterday that it would review one of the most bizarre incidents in pro football history, a coin flip apparently botched by game officials that led to the Detroit Lions' victory over the visiting Pittsburgh Steelers, 19-16, in overtime, before a national television audience on Thanksgiving Day.

title: 49ers' So-Called Inconsistencies Have Fassel Worried
description: As part of his preparation, Jim Fassel, like any other coach in the National Football League, peruses the newspapers from the city of his upcoming opponent. When he thumbed through this week's stories from San Francisco, it stopped his leisurely breakfast.

title: Exxon-Mobil Talks Confirmed; Regulators Poised
description: Exxon and Mobil, the nation's two largest oil companies, confirmed today that they were discussing a possible merger, and antitrust lawyers, industry analysts and Government officials predicted that any deal would require the sale of important pieces of their businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIZEMORE, JOHN RANDALL
description: SIZEMORE-John Randall. Of New York City and East Hampton, died of AIDS at his Manhattan residence on November 27, 1998. He was 48 years old. Mr. Sizemore was the beloved partner for 25 years of Norbert Alan Anuskiewicz, as well as a devoted brother to Saundra Joe Sizemore of Southfield, Michigan, and loving son of Betty Gable Sizemore of Cullman, Alabama. Mr. Sizemore was an alumnus of Wayne State University, Michigan and worked for many years in Editorial Operations at ''Fortune'' magazine. Respects may be paid at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Saturday, November 28th from 2:004:00PM and 7:00-9:00PM. Funeral services will be at Dovin Funeral Home in Lorain, Ohio on Monday, November 30th with interment at Calvary Cemetery in that city. In lieu of flowers, it is requested that contributions be made to S.A.G.E., 212-741-2247.

title: Stop-Smoking Therapy
description: To the Editor:

title: Man With Loaded Rifle Shot by Police in Queens
description: A man brandishing a loaded M-16 rifle in Far Rockaway, Queens, was shot four times by the police yesterday after he refused to drop his gun, the police said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nasdaq and S.& P. Indexes Reach New Record Highs

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTEIN, DOROTHY MILAN
description: GREENSTEIN-Dorothy Milan, after a long illness, passed away at her home on Thanksgiving morning. Beloved mother of Betsy, grandmother of Matthew, wife of Morris, daughter of Minnie, mother-in-law of Robert, aunt of Florrie, Brett and Gregg. Her courage and humor were an inspiration. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave., 10:45 AM, Sunday, November 29, 1998.

title: Youthful North Carolina Outplays No. 3 Stanford
description: The young North Carolina Tar Heels are maturing quickly. Six victims in six games, most notably the third-ranked Stanford Cardinal, will attest to that.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COCA-COLA CO., Atlanta, said its Copenhagen-based Coca-Cola Nordic Beverages A/S unit, based in Copenhagen, had agreed to buy Iceland's Coke bottler, Vifilfell Ltd., for an undisclosed price.

title: Extradite Terrorist
description: To the Editor:

title: A Band Steeped in History Shows a Communal Swing
description: Tuesday's show at the Blue Note, under the leadership of the bassist Ray Brown and featuring the pianist Oscar Peterson, the vibraphonist Milt Jackson and the drummer Kareem Riggins, was redolent of history. Mr. Brown and Mr. Jackson were members of Dizzy Gillespie's seminal mid-1940's orchestra. And the three of them were the virtual house band for Norman Grantz's Pablo Records, making seemingly hundreds of recordings together, for decades.

title: Drug Dealer Guilty in Irish Journalist's Slaying
description: A Dublin drug dealer was convicted today by a three-judge panel in the 1996 murder of Veronica Guerin, a prominent journalist known for her aggressive reporting on Dublin criminals.

title: Robert Eisner, Steadfast Keynesian Economist, Dies at 76
description: Robert Eisner, former president of the American Economic Association and a staunch advocate of a view unpopular among an increasing number of academic economists that active Government spending is needed to achieve full employment and growth, died Wednesday at his home in Evanston, Ill. He was 76.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERGOLD, LEON
description: SERGOLD-Leon. We record with profound sorrow the passing of Leon Sergold, beloved husband of Eveline, devoted father of Audrey Levinson & Viviane and Steven Verstandig, loving grandfather of Adam, Michael and Lauren Verstandig. Services on Sunday, at 1P.M., at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street, New York City.

title: Seattle Bus Carrying 31 People Plunges From Bridge After Driver Is Shot; 2 Are Dead
description: A city bus carrying 31 people plunged off a bridge here and plowed through the outer edge of an apartment roof this afternoon after the driver was shot by a passenger. The driver, and a person suspected of shooting the driver, were both killed, the police said. The 29 others were injured.

title: New F.A.A. Computers Set for Long Island
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is about to begin replacing the mainframe computers that have been the workhorses of its 20 high-altitude, long-distance air traffic control centers, installing newer, more reliable models. And it is starting in New York.

title: Chase Will Sell Title Insurance
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it had formed an agency to sell commercial title insurance in hopes of taking advantage of its strong position in the commercial real estate lending market.

title: Turning Opera Into a Series of Frames; Jonathan Miller Brings Many Careers to the Direction of 'Figaro'
description: You can call him director, writer, actor, filmmaker, photographer, professor or doctor. But call Jonathan Miller polymath or Renaissance man and he will gag. Ask him for the common thread running through his varied interests, and he will reply that if he knew, he would be in desperate trouble.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MANSON, JULIUS J.
description: MANSON-Julius J. On Sunday, November 29, at 2:00 P.M., New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street.

title: Gunfight at Nightclub Kills Man, 19
description: One man was killed and another was critically injured in a gunfight early yesterday in the parking lot of a Scotch Plains nightclub, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, TOBIE
description: LEVINE-Tobie. Officers, Board of Governors, Members and Staff of The Muttontown Club mourn the passing of our beloved member, Tobie Levine, and express our deepest sympathy to her daughter, Myrna Feinbloom, and sons Lawrence and Bert, and families. Robert J. Capazzi, President Carol Rose, Women's President

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SOYBEANS ADVANCE. Soybean futures rose 1.9 percent after the Government reported that weekly export sales were unexpectedly strong. The January contract rose 11 cents, to $5.8225 a bushel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, ARTHUR H.
description: GREEN-Arthur H., M.D. The Division of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry at Columbia University and New York Presbyterian Hospital is deeply saddened by the loss of Arthur H. Green, M.D., Clinical Professor of Psychiatry (in Pediatrics). Dr. Green, a member of our faculty for two decades, was an internationally known pioneer in the research and treatment of child physical and sexual abuse. His compassionate understanding of the causes and effects of child maltreatment led to two major child abuse preventive programs at our medical center-the Family Center and Therapeutic Nursery, in which countless children and parents are treated, and numerous mental health professionals receive training. Dr. Green's work greatly influenced the manner in which child abuse cases are managed in the United States, and the programs he helped establish serve as models throughout the world. He will be sorely missed as clinician, teacher, colleague, friend, and mentor to many generations of students. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Carol, daughter, Susan, and son, Jonathan.

title: Education's Gender Gap
description: One of the most damaging consequences of the world's economic troubles is that parents are pulling their children out of school. Girls are the first casualty. In most poor and even middle-income countries, many girls stay home while their brothers go to primary school. Countries are now recognizing the harm caused by this educational gender gap, however, and some are trying new ideas to get girls into school and keep them there.

title: World AIDS Day Seen Regaining Old Fervor
description: On Tuesday, an advocacy group will march down Broadway to commemorate World AIDS Day, having successfully argued in court that the Giuliani administration showed more concern for a Yankees ticker-tape parade than about AIDS.

title: South Africa Panel Didn't Serve Truth; Disenfranchised Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: TABLOID HISTORY
description: Thomas Jefferson was just the beginning. Using DNA and other high-tech tools, scholars are ransacking the pasts of Beethoven, Emily Dickinson and Samuel Coleridge, among others -- looking for the historical equivalents of the blue Gap dress. A report by Philip Weiss, in the Times Magazine.

title: Red Storm Loses Late; Tar Heels Take Title
description: They noticed their layups rolling around the rim and out, their execution becoming forced and shoddy, their defense making little difference. Deep down, the St. John's players knew what was happening.

title: In New Panel Chairman, Ways of Old Pragmatist
description: Representative C. W. Bill Young of Florida, the new chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, need not map strategy for protecting his turf from empire-building Republican leaders. The outgoing chairman did the job for him.

title: The Ultimate Commodity
description: I was conceived in Silicon Alley in a bold bid to crack the infant market, then assembled in an offshore production facility in Malaysia. Disney and Pepsico were leading investors.

title: Clinton's Responses to Questions From the House Judiciary Committee
description: Following are President Clinton's answers to the 81 questions put to him by the House Judiciary Committee as part of its impeachment investigation, as made public today by the White House:

title: No New Talks Are in the Works
description: The waiting game continued yesterday as the 150th day of the National Basketball Association lockout passed with neither side attempting to set up a new bargaining session after a meeting set for today was canceled earlier in the week.

title: Assignment for Rookie Is to Keep Jets on Track
description: One is old and one is young. One has a reputation as the most flamboyant pass rusher in pro football, and one is, well, an offensive lineman. One is an elite player who does celebrity cameos in the wrestling ring; the other is, well, a rookie.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend yesterday about two gallery exhibitions of the work of Ross Bleckner misidentified a painting described as the best in the show at Lehmann Maupin in SoHo. It was ''Signaling Pathway,'' shown in a picture with the review, not ''Tolerance.''

title: Signs Point to a Bradley Presidential Run, His Former Aides Say
description: Although Bill Bradley has said he will decide next month whether to run for President, several of his former longtime aides and close advisers say they believe that he has already made up his mind to seek the Democratic nomination.

title: Insurers in Japan Are Put on Credit Watch
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said today that it had put six Japanese life insurers on credit watch for possible downgrade, citing deteriorating asset quality caused by a high level of loans to the country's troubled banks.

title: Devils Spurn Idea of Newark
description: Lou Lamoriello, the Devils' president, said today that the team would remain at the Meadowlands or move to a new arena in Hoboken even if the Nets relocate in Newark.

title: S.A.T.: Not Just a Numbers Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Death Row Inmate Pulls Off Escape
description: For the first time since the Dust Bowl days, when fedora-wearing G-men battled backroads bandits like Bonnie and Clyde, an inmate has escaped from Texas's Death Row using a daring, low-tech scheme involving dummies and a desperate sprint through a hail of bullets.

title: 727 Cargo Jets Face Repairs On Doors
description: The Federal Aviation Administration issued an emergency order today requiring eight cargo airlines to change the way cargo doors are attached to old Boeing 727's that had been converted to freighter use.

title: Faulty Treatment Is Found At Kings County Hospital
description: A Federal agency released a 26-page report yesterday citing several examples of serious mistakes in emergency treatment at Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn -- flaws that the hospital says it is now fixing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIEGLER, HELEN C.
description: ZIEGLER-Helen C. Widow of Joseph B. Ziegler, died at her home November 25 at age 96. She was a writer and speaker during World War II about women's contributions to the war effort in England. Her stories are on exhibit in Washington, D.C. at the American Museum for Women.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTO, JOHN T
description: BARTO-John T. Age 71. On Nov. 23, 1998. Director 19th Precinct Community Safety Committee, member Community On Patrol and on Board of Directors of East 84th Street Neighborhood Association. Beloved husband of Ruth. Brother of Ann Williamson. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Friday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9PM with service Saturday 12 noon. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, LEWIS
description: KAPLAN-Lewis. The leadership and staff of UJA-Federation of New York in Westchester note with sorrow the passing of Lewis Kaplan, beloved husband of Lilly, father of Harriet Suvall and Dr. Ruth Treiber, father-in-law of Mark Suvall and Dr. Eric Treiber and grandfather of Jonathan, Adam, David and Cara. A retired officer of the NYC Police Department and a committed Jew, he leaves behind a good name and a legacy of heroic deeds. His wisdom, guidance and loving prescence will be sorely missed. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen Solender, Executive Vice President Barry J. Effron, Chair Westchester General Campaign Martine Fleishman, Chair Westchester Women's Campaign Stephen G. Doochin, Director, Westchester Division

title: Panel Considers Perjury And Its Consequences
description: When the House Judiciary Committee holds a hearing next Tuesday on the consequences of lying under oath, Republicans will try to show that there is a double standard for President Clinton, while Democrats will say that perjury, while serious, is not an impeachable offense.

title: Boards Likely To Consider Exxon-Mobil Combination
description: The boards of the Exxon Corporation and the Mobil Corporation are expected to meet Tuesday to consider a possible merger agreement that would form the world's largest oil company, a person close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOROWITZ, SARAH GAYER
description: HOROWITZ-Sarah Gayer. November 28, 1967. We remember Mama.

title: F.D.A. WILL REQUIRE COMPANIES TO TEST DRUGS ON CHILDREN
description: The Government today issued new rules that require drug companies to conduct much wider testing of drugs in children, so the companies can write labels that provide detailed information to doctors and parents about the proper use of medications by children.

title: Volkswagen to Spend $36 Billion on Upgrades
description: Volkswagen A.G., Europe's largest car maker, said yesterday that it would spend 61.5 billion German marks ($36 billion) on improving its production plants and developing new models in the next five years. The investment will be used to develop and build a new luxury VW car, a sports utility vehicle in a joint venture with Porsche A.G., a smaller Bentley and other vehicles between 1999 and 2003.

title: Bargain Hunters Are Out Early in City and Mall
description: By midmorning yesterday, Steven Tamasy had found the perfect Christmas gift. Of course, it was for himself.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MIMI
description: Mimi. Twenty years have gone so fast each one faster than the last. As each year goes so swiftly by, I miss you so these words I sigh. I'll love you always, Lloyd. (apologies to Lloyd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTERST, HARRY B.
description: LITTERST-Harry B. Age 83, of Oakland, NJ on November 26, 1998. Beloved husband of Vivian (nee Hintze), loving father of Mary Litterst of Brookline, MA, Terry Litterst of Newbury, MA, Deborah Litterst Barbara of Alexandria, VA., and the late Stacy Litterst of Sonoma, CA. Stepfather of Arthur Congdon of New Canaan, CT., Warren Congdon of Vernon, N.J., Sandra Brockman of Kansas City, MO., William McGarry of Pleasantville, NY and Kathryn McGarry of Oakland, NJ. Mr. Litterst graduated from Duke University in 1937. During World War II, he served with the United States Horse Cavalry as a member of the Essex Troop. He worked briefly for NJ Public Service and then began a 27 year career with Merrill Lynch in 1947. In 1959, Mr. Litterst headed the new office in the Garden State Plaza where he continued to establish the presence for the firm in the North Jersey area. While with Merrill Lynch, Mr. Litterst became corporate vice president and limited partner. He was past president and longtime member of the Paramus Rotary Club and a member of the 200 Club of the Boy Scouts of Bergen County. He was active with the American Heart Association and the American Cancer Society. He was a founder of the Oakland Chamber of Commerce, a dedicated supporter of the Oakland Republican Club, and a member of the Bond Club of New Jersey. Friends may call Sunday, November 29, at Vander Plaat-Vermeulen Memorial Home, 530 High Mountain Road, Franklin Lakes from 2-4 & 7-9pm. Funeral service will be held on Monday, November 30, at 11:30 am at the funeral home with interment following at George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus. Donations may be made to American Heart Association or American Cancer Society.

title: MEDTRONIC SUES AVECOR TO BLOCK THIRD-PARTY TALKS
description: Medtronic Inc. has sued Avecor Cardiovascular Inc. to prevent Avecor's board from entering into third-party merger discussions. Avecor said yesterday that Medtronic had filed papers on Wednesday asking the court to bar Avecor's board from entering into discussions or negotiations with another company that submitted a bid of $13 a share earlier this week or from terminating Avecor's merger agreement with Medtronic. Medtronic's offer of $11.125 worth of Medtronic stock for each Avecor share, was approved by Avecor shareholders on Oct. 28. Avecor said the court had ruled that it could not terminate its merger agreement with Medtronic or enter into an agreement to be acquired by any other party before a temporary injunction hearing Dec. 7.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOVELL, LARRY LEBANUS
description: HOVELL-Larry Lebanus, Sr, 58, the son of Ellen Stewart, the founder and director of La MaMa E.T.C., of Green Bay, Wisconsin passed away on Monday, November 23, 1998. He was born to Larry and Ellen Stewart Hovell on October 25, 1940 in Chicago, Illinois. Larry attended DuSable High School in Chicago, IL and Upper Iowa University in Fayette, Iowa. Upon graduation from college he enlisted in the U.S. Army where he fought in the Vietnam war and received an honorable discharge. Larry moved to Green Bay in October of 1987 to become the owner of Bay City Chrysler Plymouth, Inc. While in Green Bay, Larry was a strong advocate of the greater business and civic community and was loved and respected by all that knew him. Larry's leadership in the business community was recognized by many, this was seen by him serving on the Board of the Green Bay Chamber of Commerce, as a member of the Green Bay Economic Development Commission and Daimler Chrysler National Dealers' Council, and as Vice President for Chrysler Minority Dealers Association. He was also a member of St. Bernards Catholic Church, Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity, Inc, Scottish Rite, the Lodge Council Chapter of Consistory Masons, the Red Cross, Big Brothers and Big Sisters, and the local Shriners. In addition he was a sponsor of the University of WisconsinGreen Bay Women's Basketball team and served on the St. Norbert Diversity team. Larry has received numerous awards from the Green Bay Community, including the Green Bay Chamber of Commerce Small Business Person of The Year Award in June of 1998. In October of 1998 after receiving the Sam Walton Foundation Business Leader Award, Mayor Paul Jadin presented him with the Key to the City of Green Bay. Larry leaves to cherish his life a loving and devoted wife, Yvonne, one daughter, Soraya Hovell of Chicago, IL. Three sons, Larry Jr, at home, Thomas Wynder, Detroit, and Rahsaan Peak, Durham, NC. A loving mother, Ellen Stewart Hovell, NY, NY. One sister, Norma Stallworth, Chicago, IL. One foster brother, Duk Hyung Yoo, Seoul, Korea. One grandchild, Samuel Tyler Robinson, Chicago, IL. Two aunts Ada Daniels, Las Vegas, NV and Agnes (James) Lewis, Chicago. Mother-in-law Kathryn Dawkins Worten, Green Bay, WI; a host of nieces, nephews, cousins, in-Laws and dear friends. He was preceded in death by his father Larry Hovell and a son Robert. Services were held in Green Bay and Chicago. Burial in Lincoln Cemetery, Chicago.

title: Wittily Exploring the Tap Vocabulary
description: The Jazz Tap Ensemble of Los Angeles got off to a fine start and ended triumphantly on Tuesday night, the opening of a weeklong 20th-anniversary season at the Joyce Theater. In between, however, there were stretches of dance and music so relaxed as to suggest these gifted artists were merely dreaming.

description: In percent

description: FOOTBALL

description: MANKIN-David S. Temple BethEl of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its long-time member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Shelley M. Limmer, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACH, NANCY
description: BACH-Nancy. November 25. Devoted sister of Joan Buck and aunt of Sherry Corazza. Services are on Friday, November 27, 1 PM, Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey. For further information, call Kirschenbaum Funeral Home, 718-859-2020.

title: Manners, Morals and a Hygiene Poll
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR CLIMBS. The dollar surged to its highest level against the yen in more than seven weeks as Japan's Finance Minister said he would step down. A dollar bought 123.07 yen, up from 121.73 yen on Wednesday.

title: CHIEF OF CABLE AND WIRELESS IN U.S. RESIGNS POST
description: Rich Yalen, chief executive of Cable and Wireless P.L.C.'s United States unit, resigned earlier this week, the company said yesterday, without giving a reason. The Wall Street Journal reported that Mr. Yalen, who worked for six years at C.&W. and was named chief executive in March, left because of a disagreement with his new boss, Carl Grivner. Mr. Grivner, former chief executive at Advanced Fiber Communications Inc.. joined C.&W. as head of its Western Hemisphere operations on July 13. Peter Eustace, a spokesman for C.&W., Britain's second-largest telecommunications company, declined to comment about the reported disagreement between Mr. Yalen and Mr. Grivner

title: Oil Pipelines From Caspian Lack Money From Backers
description: Prospects for quick construction of an American-backed oil pipeline from the Caspian Sea were set back further this week when a senior oil executive said the countries supporting it do not seem willing to help pay for it.

title: Shared Voyage of Discovery During an Opera in Concert
description: Mascagni's ''Iris,'' which was presented in concert on Monday night at Alice Tully Hall by Teatro Grattacielo, has enough interesting dramatic points to make one dream about how it might look in the theater. The first singing character in the piece, and the last, is the sun, enacted by a large chorus and heard only by the young woman who gives the opera its title. At the end, as she lies dying in a sewer after having been abducted into a brothel, the work performs a feminist critique on itself, and the three principal male characters come back, each as his own ''Egoism,'' to give paltry answers to Iris's question, ''Why?''

title: Poetry in Emotion
description: What do close friends talk about? Big issues like religion and family, love and health, but filtered through details of daily life. Alicia Suskin Ostriker, an English professor at Rutgers University who lives in Princeton, sees her poetry as a means to ''to fill the center'' those details surround, to strip away the censorship. Her latest collection, ''The Little Space: Poems Selected and New, 1968-1998'' (University of Pittsburgh Press, $16.95 in paperback), her ninth poetry collection, was a National Book Award finalist this year. Many of the experiences and emotions in it are told from a woman's perspective: events like pregnancy and childbirth, marriage and motherhood, aging and illness. Some perspectives are Jewish (one poem is titled ''Holocaust,'' another ''Diaspora''). Some are both. All are written so that readers who have been in these places feel a kinship with her and those who haven't can understand. Friends talk about the weather, too. A new poem, ''April One,'' begins:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; What Women Want
description: Female sexual passion is often portrayed as sophomoric romance or as the ecstasy following a high-end shopping spree. The Erotic Lives of Women (Scalo, $45) is different, and should be honored as one of the most gutsy and imaginative erotic books of the decade. Linda Troeller, an American photographer, and Marion Schneider, a German writer, photographed and interviewed 30 women from the Americas, Europe, the Middle East and Northern Africa. They include a Brazilian singer, a Japanese-American flower designer, a black American legal secretary, Islamic housewives and Moroccan belly dancers. None of these women are model look-alikes, but each is irrefutably seductive in her story and image. The honesty in the interviews is extraordinary. The kinds of excuses, politically correct slogans and gauzy fuzz that frequently suffocate erotic candor are simply not here. The women tell their stories straight out, and leave it to you to be aroused, disturbed or enlightened. The photographs and the interviews were done at the same time, to create a match between image and text, and the experiment proves to be unexpected and moving. One woman, Nadia, a 36-year-old cigarette vendor in Morocco, answered: ''Living by myself, earning my own money, that is most erotic for me. . . . Being able to smoke cigarettes wherever I like to and to smoke hashish when I feel like it gives me such a strong feeling.'' She is depicted spreading apart her djellaba like a pair of wings. Susie Bright

title: Heart Disease Deaths More Common in Appalachia, Study Finds
description: Residents of Appalachia, one of the poorest areas of the country, are more likely to die from heart disease than people living elsewhere, a new study by researchers at West Virginia University has found.

title: Symphony Space Shows Its Virtuosity in Art of the Deal
description: A high-rise on the site of a financially wobbly arts institution? Normally, this might mean a death knell for the arts group. But a deal completed last week for a 22-story apartment building above Symphony Space, the two-story theater on Broadway and 95th Street, will not only preserve the performance space, but also give a financial boost to the nonprofit group that runs it.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 8 about living in the Hudson Heights area of Manhattan misstated the size of Bennett Park. It is two blocks in area, not four.

title: Table for 10: The Dinner Party Leaves the House
description: A FIREPLACE cast its homey glow as 15 friends at a long wooden table clinked glasses. The women sipped Bellini cocktails, while the men, in jeans and French-blue shirts, fell to talking sports over ravioli alla salvia.

title: Memories of Paris And of One Who Saw It as It Was
description: NEXT Sunday, an exhibition of photographs by Brassai, called ''The Eye of Paris,'' will open at the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston. The result of 15 years of research by Anne Wilkes Tucker, the museum's curator of photography, it is the first major museum retrospective of Brassai's work to be held in this country since one at the Museum of Modern Art in New York in 1968.

title: Performers Duplicated, Like Sheep?
description: GENETICISTS have their Dolly. They also have the goods on Thomas Jefferson: the old miscegenator long suspected, now betrayed by his own DNA. Where the progress of science is concerned, art is rarely far behind, and now comes Sergei Rachmaninoff, dead since 1943, walking among us again.

title: In the Wee Small Hours in the County
description: IF life in Westchester were ruled by a time clock, most people would punch in for the morning shift and punch out at night. Such is life in a land that runs on the schedule of the rush-hour commuter and Metro-North.

title: Pamela Novell, David Koenig
description: Pamela Anne Novell, the daughter of Patricia Novell of Sayreville, N.J., and Donald Novell of Rye, N.Y., was married last evening to David Koenig, a son of Ann and Edward Koenig of New City, N.Y. Rabbi David Rosenzweig officiated at the 200 Fifth Club in New York.

title: Visual Voices in Many Cultures and Media
description: 'Asian-American Artists'

title: NASA's Mission To Nowhere
description: The International Space Station, assembly of which begins with a space shuttle mission scheduled for launching on Thursday, is being touted as a giant leap into space and a step toward the stars. In truth, the space station is little more than a Motel 6 in low earth orbit, and it marks a step toward the stars only in the sense that cleaning out your attic gets you closer to the Moon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKERMAN, LARRY
description: BECKERMAN-Larry. On November 19, 1998, in Tacoma, Washington. Dearly beloved son of Sylvia. Treasured brother of Ann and Dan. Loving father of Jace and Lori. Loving husband of Marilyn Mauer. Devoted teacher and advocate of children as their acting teacher and soccer coach. Always in our hearts. Always will be missed.

title: Q&A;/Tao Porchon-Lynch; At 80, Still Following Path of Yoga to Peace
description: TO see Tao Porchon-Lynch is not to believe she is 80. Petite and slender, the Indian-born former French fashion model, whose mother was Indian and father French, moves with a flexibility that most people decades younger than she will never have. Kicking off her shoes, she demonstrates what she can do: support her body with her hand, thanks to arm muscles that remain unusually strong, and stand on her head with arms and legs in the most unusual places. She can bend every which way, all the time smiling broadly.

title: Ingrid Forterre and Sheldon Bruha
description: Ingrid Marie Anne Claude Forterre and Sheldon Lee Bruha were married on Thursday in Paris. Nanne Beranger, the Deputy Mayor of the 16th Arrondissement, officiated at Town Hall. A Roman Catholic ceremony was performed yesterday by the Rev. Matthieu Rouge at St. Severin Church, also in Paris.

title: Vans, Just 15, In Middle Age
description: FIFTEEN years have passed since Lee A. Iacocca drove the first modern minivan off a Chrysler Corporation assembly line in Windsor, Ontario. That short trip, on Nov. 2, 1983, began a noteworthy journey in which the minivan dethroned the station wagon as the preferred utility vehicle of American families. But more recently, the minivan has become the object of snickers and has seemed at risk of being muscled aside by sport utilities, with their comparable space plus an outdoorsy image.

title: Leslie Zigman, Moshe Horn
description: Leslie Alison Zigman, the daughter of Felicia and Harold Zigman of Fair Lawn, N.J., was married on Wednesday to Moshe Horn, the son of Dena Horn and Rabbi William Horn of Summit N.J. The bridegroom's father, the rabbi of the Summit Jewish Community Center, officiated at the Toy Building in New York.

title: Has Gus Van Sant Gone Psycho?
description: It's audition night at the Bates Motel. In a large, darkened room on a studio lot in Southern California, three women are interpreting a pop standard. On a movie screen before them, a blonde showers. In succession, each of the trio emits a brutal string of screams becoming moans shifting to last-desperate-gasps that are meant to complement the sight of the shower curtain being ripped away, the knife, the blood swirling down the drain. Each scream is recorded, and the best will end up in the final picture. The scene rolls repeatedly, each of the trio able to withstand two, maybe three takes before her vocal cords are frayed and unable to release the curdled fear demanded.

title: Public Schools Confronting Issue of Racial Preferences
description: In Arlington, Va., when Lara Tito, a white preschooler, did not get into the kindergarten at a popular alternative school, her parents joined with two other families and sued the district, challenging an admission system that set aside half of the 46 slots for members of minorities.

title: The Man Who Would Be Papp
description: If the Public Theater is widely known as ''an artist-driven institution'' and ''a haven for creative exploration,'' as Alex Witchel asserts, why does she favorably paint Wolfe's brusque and dismissive treatment of his colleagues?

title: Political Memo; Whiff of Red Herring In Strategy for Vacco
description: It looks as if Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco lost his re-election bid by a margin narrower than the space between riders on a rush-hour No. 6 train. The Democratic challenger, Eliot G. Spitzer, has declared victory, and a growing number of Republicans are conceding the contest, albeit quietly.

title: Mementos Ease Pain Of Losing a Child
description: As the surviving parent of a child who died many years ago, I was deeply disturbed by the Diocese of Rockville Centre's decision to prohibit the placement of trinkets on the graves in the children's section of the Cemetery of the Holy Rood [''Cemetery Bans Mementos on Child Graves,'' Nov. 22].

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVEYRAC, GLORIA CARR
description: deVEYRAC-Gloria Carr. Nov. 23, 1998. Retired fashion director. Her career spanned many years in the international world of fashion. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. A memorial service will be announced at a future date.

title: HIGH SCHOOLS; Curtis Wins; Houdini Would Have Smiled
description: When South Shore high school's football team scored easily on its first two possessions in the Public School Athletic League semifinal against Curtis yesterday, it seemed as if the Vikings would breeze right into next week's final.

title: Man in the News: Harold M. Ickes; A Point Man Under Fire
description: In his three years serving President Clinton as staff trouble shooter and campaign financing strategist, Harold M. Ickes became enough of a lightning rod that he had to undergo 26 separate sessions of questioning under oath by investigators of the Republican-controlled Congress and the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, DR. ARTHUR H.
description: GREEN-Dr. Arthur H. The staff and trustees of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services mourn the passing of Dr. Arthur H. Green, psychiatrist at JBFCS' Child Development Center. Dr. Green's innovative work with abused children enriched the lives of many and made a lasting contribution to the Center. We extend our deepest sympathy to the Green family. Joseph S. Kaplan, President Seymour R. Askin, Jr., Chairman of the Board Alan B. Siskind, Ph.D., Executive Vice President, JBFCS Alice Kross Frankel, M.D., Director, CDC Robert Abramovitz, M.D., Chief Psychiatrist, JBFCS

title: Stephen Tim, 61, Plant Expert At Brooklyn Botanic Garden
description: Stephen K-M Tim, a botanist and illustrator who was a guiding force for many of the exhibits and publications of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, died on Nov. 21 at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 61 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Europe by Train, With Friends or En Famille
description: A new pass for train travel in Europe, aimed at families and small groups, will be available next year. This Europass Saverpass will give a discount of 15 percent a person off other Europasses to groups of two to five people traveling together.

title: The Word on 'Carrie'
description: To the Editor:

title: Elusive Deer Cape
description: This winter, just as big-game hunters go to bed with visions of wall-mounted antlers dancing in their heads, some big-game shoppers are dreaming of their own trophy: a floor-length deerskin cape by Hermes. The hand-stitched chocolate brown cape, at $9,895, is the most expensive item in Martin Margiela's first line for Hermes. Priced more to show than sell, it turned out to be one of the line's most sought-after pieces. At customer previews several months ago, they sold out before reaching stores. ''We were amazed that 20 of the most expensive items would be ordered in advance,'' said Ellen Niven, an Hermes spokeswoman. Demand remained so strong that the cape was reordered twice again in the fall. A few can still be tracked down, at (800) 441-4488 or by special order. ELLEN TIEN

title: Is Solitary Confinement Driving Charlie Chase Crazy?
description: How can you justify squandering seven pages of your magazine on this nasty human being? I guess you'll try anything to get a reaction from readers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORMAN, SHIFRA
description: FORMAN-Shifra. Wife of Isadore. Mother of Laurie (Russ), David (June). Bobe of Sam and Julia. A wonderful and warm human being who will be missed by all whom she touched. Funeral service at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam, 12:30 PM, Monday, November 30, 1998.

title: The Nation: Fire-Proofing Janet Reno; Job Security and the Independent Counsel Law
description: MORE than any other Attorney General, Janet Reno has been bedeviled by the independent counsel law. In just five years, she has ordered the appointment of seven independent prosecutors and turned down requests for a number of others, and is now considering two more investigations of Administration officials.

title: Belle Nearer To Joining The Orioles
description: The Baltimore Orioles, trying to recover from an expensive and disappointing season, inched closer yesterday to adding Albert Belle to their depleted lineup.

title: Bucolic or Upsetting, Suburbs as Locus
description: AT the Lyman Allyn Museum in New London, the paintings of Stephen Lack will both tantalize viewers and frustrate them. Mr. Lack has large ambitions: in diverse ways he is chronicling the age we live in, noting how occasions for seduction are everywhere, as are those for anxiety and fear.

title: White Sox and Belle Made $100 Million Pact Possible
description: What hath Jerry Reinsdorf wrought?

title: Rates Continue to Slip
description: Mortgage rates continued to slide last week, a consequence of the Fed's third quarter-point cut of short-term interest rates in two months. A survey of 100 of the country's largest lenders by the Bank Rate Monitor found that the average rate on a 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage fell 0.03 percent, to 6.78 percent, while the 15-year dropped 0.05 percent, to 6.43 percent.

title: Emery Mine Owner Goes Head to Head With Town
description: WHEN George Pacchiana graduated from Pelham High School in the late 1950's, his father, Guido, barred him from signing with the New York Yankees' farm system. He became a civil engineer and joined the family business instead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMARGO, FLORENCE S.
description: CAMARGO-Florence S. On November 22, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Ralph J. Camargo. Mother of Felice C. Meyer and Victoria Wyndham. Grandmother of Christopher P. Meyer, Darian Minnick and Christian Camargo. Sister of Helen Skeels Fowler and Herbert Skeels. Service and interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to High Ridge House, 5959 Independence Avenue, Riverdale, N.Y. 10471.

title: THEATER; Ancient Passions That Illuminate Today's Tragedies
description: NO togas or sandals here: this is a collapsed civilization, ancient, modern, ageless. As Orestes staggers toward his sister, arms bloodied to the elbows, Electra spits out her question about their mother: ''Is that foul woman dead?'' Impatient for the answer already known, she grips his arm and licks the gore. The audience's gasp is inevitable.

title: Dr. Posner, Mr. Pearlroth
description: Dr. Holly Beth Posner and Jonathan Spenser Pearlroth were married last evening by Rabbi Nilton Bonder at the Palisadium, a caterer in Cliffside Park, N.J.

title: November 22-28; Attack of the 2000 Bug
description: Americans have already been warned about that little millennial computer problem. Now, say Federal and state officials, let the real bad news begin. Benefit payments will most likely be delayed, or services interrupted, for some people who receive welfare, Medicaid, food stamps or other types of assistance; most states are lagging in upgrading their computer programs.

title: Man Stable After Falling Under a Subway Train
description: A man slipped and fell under a subway train at the station at 42d Street and Eighth Avenue last night, the police said. He was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center, where he was in stable condition late last night, hospital officials said.

title: University Head and Wife Spin Out CD's
description: WOULD it be fitting for the wife of the president of the eighth largest private university in the United States to excuse herself in the middle of a dinner party, change into a sequined outfit and head to a smoky club in the city to belt out a torch song onstage? Or would it be appropriate for Joan Steinberg to pursue a career on the road and send her husband, David Steinberg, president of Long Island University, to affairs alone while she played the diva at a club on 44th Street?

title: His Home's a Castle, With a Dragon of Sorts
description: BEDFORD, N.Y., Nov. 27

title: Social Security's Fate
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Solitary Confinement Driving Charlie Chase Crazy?
description: Porter neglected to include the slightest indication that he had interviewed the victims of this cowardly psychopath. It is a fundamental breach of journalism to print self-serving quotes and impressions from criminals, while ignoring victims and their families. You ought to interview a few victims of violent crime to inject a note of gritty reality into your unintended glamorization of criminals.

title: Political Briefing; More Turbulence For Stormy Campaign
description: Shortly before Election Day, when Representative Merrill Cook, a Utah Republican, figured he was right on the edge of losing his bid for a second term, his party began a get-out-the-vote campaign that made no mention of him but instead promoted the re-election of Senator Robert F. Bennett, who was in no political danger.

title: BENEFITS
description: For the Robeson Foundation

title: An Inspector Calls, With Rock-Climbing Gear
description: KENT DIEBOLT stood on the roof of Marble Collegiate Church in a grimy white jumpsuit, a red helmet on his head, Red Wing work boots on his feet. Behind him the steeple rose 150 feet in the air over Fifth Avenue and 29th Street, ropes dangling from the spire. Mr. Diebolt and his colleagues had spent the morning climbing those ropes and hanging off them as they inspected the bell tower facade inch by inch for signs of wear. But masonry details were not the only thing Mr. Diebolt noticed.

title: The Marshall Plan
description: THURGOOD MARSHALL

title: THE GUIDE
description: Jules Feiffer and Friends

title: African Nations Agree on Cease-Fire for Congo by December
description: Leaders of Congo and neighboring countries giving support to armed rebels in the central African country agreed today under United Nations auspices to sign a cease-fire agreement by mid-December, said President Jacques Chirac of France.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Cereus Blooms At Night

title: Mergers, Mergers Everywhere, But Do Shareholders Benefit?
description: Deutsche Bank and Bankers Trust, America Online and Netscape, perhaps Exxon and Mobil: It was a week of sizzling merger activity. Many investors believe that such combinations are key to creating shareholder wealth. But A. T. Kearney, a management consulting firm in Chicago, has just released a study that it says shows quite the opposite.

title: Flora, Fauna And Fettuccine
description: AMICI'S +++

title: Shelter for the Neediest
description: This is the time of year when thoughts turn toward home, when the very idea of home seems enriched by the holidays that now lie before us. The weather sharpens, and when it is at its worst, you understand for a moment what it is like to be grateful for something as basic as shelter. To most of us, that feeling is almost a luxury, but to far too many New Yorkers the question of shelter arises every day, a source of worry so fundamental that it suffocates the spirit. Some New Yorkers are homeless, and many more have shelter but lack heat, water, safety, privacy and a sense of independence, all the things that define our sense of home.

title: Monicagate: Who Knew What, When?; Military's Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Environmental Study
description: Making good on an earlier promise to protect the county's waterways, County Executive Andrew J. Spano recently announced that the New York City-based environmental concern of Black & Veatch has been retained to evaluate the administration, operation, equipment and maintenance of its seven waste water plants.
