Black & Veatch will be paid $284,000 to conduct a six-month study of the Yonkers, Peekskill, Ossining, New Rochelle, Mamaroneck, Port Chester and Blind Brook treatment plans. A report on the Yonkers plant -- the largest of the seven -- is due in 60 days.

title: Determined To Share The Wealth
description: THIS is a story about a very generous man named Jim Rogers.

title: Short Week's Climb to New Heights
description: It was a short week. But what a week it was.

title: Erik Nitsche, 90, Modernist Graphic Designer
description: Erik Nitsche, an art director, graphic designer, photographer, illustrator and book packager known for his posters, advertisements, logos and book designs, died on Nov. 10 in Danbury, Conn. He was 90.

title: Fort Mailbox
description: It is indeed tragic that a teen-ager died in a collison with a ''fortress'' mailbox, but surely the mailbox was on private property, or on a sidewalk and not in the middle of the road (Sunday, Nov. 8). And it is tragically absurd that a lawyer is trying to blame the mailbox. If someone driving a car hits a telephone pole, should we blame the pole?

title: The Man Who Would Be Papp
description: I have had the privilege of working with the best directors in the business -- Thomas Schlamme, Hugh Wilson and George C. Wolfe.

title: Postings: Going Up in Borough Park; 56-Room Hotel For Brooklyn
description: A 56-room hotel is being built atop a former bank building in Borough Park, Brooklyn, designed to cater to Orthodox and Hasidic Jews. Marcel Glick, the Borough Park developer who is behind the project, said that he and his partner were investing $6 million in the hope that the six-story, 4,000-square-foot structure at 47th Street and 13th Avenue will earn him more as a hotel than as rental apartments.

title: Among the Once-Stolid, Signs of Jangled Nerves
description: ONE of the surprises in the mutual fund numbers from this year's selloff is that investors acted differently than they did during the swoon in 1997, when the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 7.2 percent on a single day in October. This summer, investors were more willing to flee, or, put another way, less willing to tough out the market turmoil.

title: Transactions
description: HOCKEY

title: Ace Sleuths Driven by Honor Truth
description: Back in 1996, the programming people at NBC decided to cancel ''JAG,'' a military-adventure series with plenty of action, after only one season. The ratings just weren't there.

title: November 22-28; Call in the Mall: Anybody Work Here?
description: Shoppers this holiday season might find the going rough, not because of a lack of merchandise but one of help.

title: Putting a Human Face on Some Disturbing Ideas
description: IT'S all so simple, seemingly, when it works. Take two characters talking literate talk in a short, concise play that goes somewhere, building conflict, confrontation establishing contact. They learn; we learn. But this is not a lesson. It is dramatic, legitimate theater, and what we learn is about the possibilities of connection.

title: November 22-28; The French, Now Sniffing At Themselves
description: This is a delicate topic. It should probably not even be mentioned.

title: Two Faiths, One Goal for Life's Last Journey
description: SISTER DOROTHY MONKS remembers visiting a Jewish patient who she described as ''an erudite agnostic and a nature lover.'' Although close to death, the patient responded with gratitude and emotion when she read him a passage from Isaiah: ''Say to those whose hearts are frightened, be strong, fear not!''

title: Linda Srere and Jeb Brown
description: Linda Jean Srere and Jeremy Earle Brown were married yesterday at their home in Potomac, Md. The Rev. Clint Glenn, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Tanks and Planes. Cheap. Barely Used.
description: FORTRESS AMERICA

title: The World: Out of Time; Dictators (And Some Lawyers) Tremble
description: WHEN the Congo's President, Laurent Kabila, got ready for a trip to Europe last week, he sent an advance party to Belgium, his first stop, to seek assurances that there would be no nasty surprises waiting -- an arrest warrant, for example. Mr. Kabila, who seized power in a long march to Kinshasa in 1997 and who has resisted all international efforts to investigate how many lives may have been lost in massacres along the way, is now living in the post-Pinochet era.

title: In Tokyo, Four Where Food and Setting Are Special
description: THERE are times when you want to celebrate -- a birthday or anniversary, perhaps, or to treat yourself and someone special to an exceptional meal. If you find yourself in Tokyo on such an occasion, here are four restaurants worth remembering. All serve excellent food, and are also noteworthy for their attractive interiors and sophisticated ambiance.

title: Tougher Board Sought
description: Under a sweeping new plan submitted to Mayor Joseph M. Delfino, the White Plains Ethics Board would have increased powers, including the ability to subpoena evidence from City Hall and to remove officials from office.

title: The Man Who Would Be Papp
description: I am writing in response to Alex Witchel's article on my director, George C. Wolfe (Nov. 8). She painted a grim picture of his rehearsal process, where actors (or ''sloppy loungers'') visibly pale under his dictatorship. If she had opted for the less dramatic (but more realistic) joyous atmosphere that the cast has enjoyed since rehearsals began, her story would have been much more complete. In addition to being brilliant, Wolfe is one of the most giving and accessible directors an actor could hope to work with.

title: Giving Another Chance To Iceberg Lettuce
description: IT is hard to believe that not long ago mesclun salad was all but unheard of in the United States. Now it can be bought in the supermarket, though it often consists of inferior greens mixed with radicchio, which is added for color.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDOLFO, ANTHONY
description: MANDOLFO-Anthony. Died at home November 13, 1998. Devoted husband of the late Dolores (Dori) Mancini Mandolfo. Survived by a beloved sister Tina Shea of Cromwell, CT. Born in Middletown, CT. Tony was educated and worked in Boston. A noted interior designer, he worked at several major architectural firms in NYC, and was a principal in Owens & Mandolfo. Memorial Services will be in Middletown, December 5, 11 AM at St. Sebastian's Church and December 12, 10:30 AM at St. Joseph's Church, 371 Sixth Avenue, NYC. Reception will follow.

title: Christina Hidalgo, Christopher Baker
description: Christina Theresa Hidalgo, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alberto F. Hidalgo of Odessa, Fla., was married yesterday to Christopher John Baker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Baker Jr. of Convent Station, N.J. The Rev. Giles P. Hayes, a Roman Catholic priest and the headmaster of the Delbarton School in Morristown, N.J., officiated at the Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J.

title: Little Iron Horses Upstage the Garden Flora
description: Enveloped in the thick greenhouse humidity at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, 4-year-old Caleb Orange romped along the conservatory pathways, ignoring fascinating plants like the giant Burmese honeysuckle, otherwise known as Lonicera hildebrandiana.

title: After Cancer, A New Self-Image
description: LAST year, when Greta Carl, a 55-year-old lawyer in Chicago, was told by her doctor that she was nearly 100 percent clean from her bout with ovarian cancer, she grew her hair to her shoulders for the first time in her life, and dyed her gray hair Goldilocks blond. ''I love it,'' she said. ''It's flattering. It's sexier. It's a way of shouting, 'Hey, I'm alive!' ''

title: Why a Deal Played Badly In the Bond Market
description: News that B. F. Goodrich would buy Coltec Industries was greeted with cheers Monday by stock-market investors, who bid up the the companies' stocks by 9.2 percent and 10.8 percent, respectively. Both companies make landing gear and other aerospace equipment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEISER, PETER DIETRICH
description: PEISER-Peter Dietrich. Adored father, admired friend; died on Friday, November 27, 1998, at home in New York City, age 73. Born in Bonn, Germany, he moved with his mother to London aged 10, where he was raised and educated. At 28 he was employed by E.R. Squibb & Sons, and remained with them for the length of his career. During his tenure he worked in London, the British West Indies, Teheran, Cairo, Beirut, New York, Paris, and in 1979, moved to the headquarters in Princeton, NJ, to found the ConvaTec Co. As President, he was instrumental in the development of DuoDerm, a transdermal skin preparation now used worldwide for multiple applications. He is survived by his daughter Caroline, whose love for him is eternal. Donations may be made to the Humane Society or the ASPCA.

title: ON THE TOWNS: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: UNREGULATED CASH FLOWS INTO HANDS OF P.A.C.'S FOR 2000
description: Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska is engaged in the first test of the 2000 Presidential campaign: proving his ability to raise money. Like other Democratic and Republican hopefuls, he will have to raise more money than ever, at least $22 million, and earlier than ever before.

title: Janet Reno's Dwindling Choices
description: Attorney General Janet Reno's decision last week to clear Vice President Al Gore of campaign illegalities was hardly surprising. Mr. Gore's telephone soliciting from Government property was one of the Clinton campaign's more innocuous fund-raising activities, and the evidence was mixed. But Senator Orrin Hatch was right to send up a warning about Ms. Reno's motives. The need for an independent counsel with broad powers to examine the White House's 1996 fund-raising has been established by journalistic accounts and Congressional hearings, and by legal opinions from the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the former chief prosecutor of the Justice Department's campaign-finance task force. So far Ms. Reno has managed to avoid taking their advice by singling out subsidiary activities like Mr. Gore's phone calls and citing narrow legal grounds for preliminary inquiries. In the days ahead, Mr. Hatch warned, we will learn whether the Attorney General will undermine ''the rule of law and integrity of the Department of Justice'' by preventing an unbiased inquiry into the Democratic effort to circumvent campaign laws, to use White House invitations to entice donors and to collect suspicious foreign contributions.

title: With Leads Slipping Away, St. John's Looks for Stamina
description: This could very easily have been a memorable weekend for Coach Mike Jarvis. One more Red Storm rebound here or basket there and he and his players would have been the talk of college basketball. They would have been one of the lead stories on ESPN's ''Sportscenter'' and headed for a huge leap in the national rankings.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Sunday about the survival of dance companies after the deaths of their founders misspelled the given name of the woman who bought a building on East 63d Street for Martha Graham's company. She was Bethsabee de Rothschild, not Bethsabe.

title: Unrequited Loyalty
description: It has become rare to see many women wearing a single designer's suit ensemble, except for the striking success of Chanel. Most women will buy and wear separate pieces. This fall, Chanel's black-and-white long-skirted ensemble can be seen on women in New York and Paris. They have endorsed both the outfit concept and the ankle length. Some even wear the hat and the gardenias that were shown in Paris in March. The jacket is sometimes worn with pants. What confused observers at the Chanel spring collection last month -- many of them dressed in the fall outfit -- was the near absence of suit ensembles and of long skirts for day wear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, MERWIN
description: LEWIS-Merwin. One of New York's oldest practicing attorneys, died on November 27, 1998, two days before his 98th birthday. A graduate of CCNY and Columbia Law School, Mr. Lewis practiced Labor Law and Estate Planning in the firm of Olvany, Eisner, and Donnelly for 72 years. He was a member and past president of the Fresh Meadow Country Club, a member and director of the Lotus Club, and a member of the Harmonie Club. Mr. Lewis was also a director of the New York Mutual Insurance Company. Mr. Lewis is survived by his beloved wife of 66 years, Mollie; his son and daughter-in-law, Robert and Patricia; his granddaughters, Jessica Lewis and Kaitlynn Voigt; his great grandchildren, Jackson and Madison Voigt; his sister and brotherin-law, Serena and Max Freund; his sister, Frances Butterwick; his brother and sister-in-law, George and Joan Lewis; his sister-in-law, Bernice Lewis; and many nieces and nephews. Service Wednesday, December 2, 1998, 12:30 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Emil G. Reynolds War Photographer, 93
description: Emil G. Reynolds, a globe-trotting press photographer who covered World War II and other events, died last Sunday at Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch, N.J. He was 93 and lived in Long Branch.

title: A Fork in the Road for Kovalev
description: These scenes are common in the corridors of the National Hockey League arenas, the players from the opposing teams chatting briefly after games before going their separate ways. But this moment was a little special in its freshness as these old companions paused at the fork in the road.

title: The Man Who Would Be Papp
description: Witchel's article was generally fascinating. It did, however, contain the sort of comment that while pithy, is more than a little unfair. I refer to her suggestion that all actors who approach their director with an ''idea'' are doing it to pad their part.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOOKHALTER, SOPHIE, M.D.
description: BOOKHALTER-Sophie, M.D. November 25. Devoted sister of Kay Bobbin and aunt of Barbara Joyce Bobbin. She will be missed by her loving family and many friends.

title: Competition and the Internet
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region / Westchester; For Rye Brook, a Pfizer Sales Training Center
description: IN an unusual linkup of a company management training facility with an existing complex that serves a variety of companies, the Pfizer Corporation has broken ground on a 110,000-square-foot education center on the grounds of the Doral Arrowwood hotel and conference center.

title: College Fixture Must Roll On
description: Jenette Parks was confused. On Tuesday afternoon the hot dog cart she usually patronizes was no longer in front of New York City Technical College on Jay Street. Instead, it was around the corner on Tillary Street.

title: Holly Clark And James Emery
description: Holly Jacqueline Clark, a daughter of Patricia Clark and Dr. James N. Clark of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to James Michael Emery, a son of Ruth and Henry G. Emery of Woodstock, Vt., and Montgomery, Ala. Msgr. John Nickas performed the ceremony at St. Peter Claver Church in Montclair, N.J.

title: The Nation; Squaring Off, at Last, On Social Security
description: SINCE it was created in 1935, Social Security has been the centerpiece of the nation's social contract, an intergenerational commitment to provide at least a subsistence income to the most vulnerable of citizens.

title: Sports of The Times; Is the Jets' Time Bomb Ticking Once Again?
description: THROUGHOUT his tempestuous career, Bryan Cox has often talked about how he has to play football on the ''edge,'' about how he ''can't lose that edge.'' But now he has toppled over that edge, again.

title: Fuel Tanks Below Ground
description: LAST month, Randi Hutton spent nearly $3,000 replacing something at her Redding, Conn., home that wasn't broken.

title: Mets' Chairman M. Donald Grant, 94, Dies
description: M. Donald Grant, who as chairman of the Mets ordered the controversial trade of Tom Seaver in 1977 and whose decision to shun free agents at the start of the free-agent era helped send the team on a disastrous downward spiral, died at his home in Hobe Sound, Fla., yesterday. He was 94.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, DAVID A.
description: MURRAY-David A. Age 71, of Wainscott, LI on November 23, 1998. Beloved companion of the late Richard Camp. Dear brother of Edna Altshul Turi and the late Marjorie Bayha and Alexander (Bud). Also survived by nephews and nieces. Memorial service to be held at a future date. Donations to the Animal Rescue Fund, PO Box 901, Wainscott, NY 11975 would be appreciated.

title: Above and Beyond the Workplace Call of Duty
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Beginning, There Was Risk Taking
description: THE tube in my hand would have earned an F in glass-blowing class. It was thick and ungainly with stubby limbs extending at odd angles and was painted a kind of mustard yellow that Guldens would reject as unappetizing.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: FOR THE LOVE OF THE GAME

title: A Host of Harps, Only Harps
description: It was as if you had died and gone to heaven. How else could you account for hearing more than a dozen harps, many played by children, and no other instruments?

title: Auto-Theft Unit
description: District Attorney Jeanine Pirro and Police Commissioner Louis D'Aliso of Westchester County have announced the formation of a new unit in the District Attorney's office to handle auto theft and related crimes, including automobile insurance fraud. The unit will be a part of the District Attorney's Organized Crime and Criminal Enterprise Bureau and will be staffed by an assistant district attorney and a detective from the county's Department of Public Safety, who will devote full time to their new assignment. The unit is being financed by the state's Division of Criminal Justice Services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERGOLD, LEON
description: SERGOLD-Leon. We record with profound sorrow the passing of Leon Sergold, beloved husband of Eveline, devoted father of Audrey Levinson & Viviane and Steven Verstandig, loving grandfather of Adam, Michael and Lauren Verstandig. Cherished brother of Maurice Swergold and Cecile Platovsky. Services on Sunday, at 1P.M., at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street, New York City.

title: Ready to Return to Asia? A Prudent Path for Optimists
description: IN the last year, exposure to Asia has generally meant risking a bad case of the flu. The region's economic turmoil has weakened demand, and the health of many companies -- and their stocks -- has suffered.

title: Passengers Sound Off About N.J. Transit Trains
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends; Soul Mating: 'Paula, You Look Terrific'
description: NOT for nothing did Oscar Wilde declare that ''biography lends to death a new terror,'' and the famous have long forum-shopped for sympathetic chroniclers of their lives. But the recent batch of electronic Boswells and celebrity subjects drawn together by l'affaire Lewinsky sometimes seems like a parody of Spy magazine's gallery of improbable doppelgangers, ''Separated at Birth''

title: November 22-28; Dangerous Play
description: The Government announced that nearly 10 million playpens had a deadly hazard: protruding rivets that could snag the clothing of young children.

title: Sondheim's 'Follies,' The Uncut Version
description: IN a gorgeous, eerie moment from the new two-CD recording of Stephen Sondheim's score for ''Follies,'' an ancient star named Heidi Schiller (Carol Skarimbas) appears like the Ghost of Operetta Past at the emotionally fraught reunion of a group of long-retired Broadway showgirls. Lifting a ravaged voice that bears traces of the ethereal ingenue she used to be, Heidi sings ''One More Kiss,'' a soaring waltz in the style of Sigmund Romberg that is so marzipan sweet it almost makes your teeth hurt.

title: Hikers and Horse Packers Compete for Wilderness
description: Horse packers blazed many of the trails that pierce the dense pine forests of the Sierra backcountry, and since early this century they have been carrying sightseers and fishermen into the range's high reaches. But now packers are locked in a dispute with hikers and environmentalists over their access to some of California's best known wilderness areas.

title: U.S. Bolsters Housing Aid For the Elderly
description: With Thanksgiving weekend as a backdrop, President Clinton today highlighted two new housing programs that will provide $822 million for low-income people who are elderly or disabled.

title: Japan Swoons in the Spotlight; Hong Kong Winces in the Wings
description: Japan's woes take center stage in most mind's-eye views of Asian economic troubles. And not unjustly, considering the country's economic weight and the stubbornness of its recession. The latest indicators -- industrial production contracted 1.2 percent in October, retail sales plummeted 5.5 percent and unemployment remained stuck at a postwar high -- were as gloomy as ever.

title: Out of the Lab, Into a Labyrinth
description: JUST days after the election, Rush D. Holt, the victorious Democrat in New Jersey's 12th Congressional district, began telling friends -- only half jokingly -- that he had already delivered on a campaign pledge: to unseat the combative House speaker, Newt Gingrich.

title: November 22-28; Low Point in Crime
description: Prison building is hot. Politicians battle over who's toughest on crime. Parole is a four-letter word. A response to some horrifying crime wave? Not by a long shot. New Federal Bureau of Investigation figures show that serious crimes fell in 1997 for the sixth straight year, including a 5 percent drop in the Northeast; the murder rate reached a 30-year low. HUBERT B. HERRING

title: H. RUSSELL FRASER
description: Maybe it's the custom-made 10-gallon hat. Or the leather vest. Or the iguana-and-cowhide boots. But whatever the reason, to most of his Wall Street colleagues H. Russell Fraser looks more like a cowpoke than a chief executive who has been riding herd on municipal and corporate bonds for 35 years -- buying, selling, analyzing and insuring them.

title: Cracking Open Perennial Fantasies
description: It's ''Nutcracker'' season again, and dance companies are performing the ballet in New Jersey through early January.

title: Word For Word / Books on Dying; Death Be Not Unpublishable: The Literature of Good Grief
description: LET'S all share a sardonic chuckle over this cosmic paradox: At the height of its global ascendancy, supposedly optimistic and youth-obsessed America is now also increasingly fixated on death.

title: SAVING STRATEGIES: Roth I.R.A.'s are not just for boomers struggling to save for retirement; How to Make Millions for Grandchildren
description: Leon M. Singer, 70, Great Neck, N.Y.

title: Candy and a Taste of Home
description: The first day of business for what would later become Shaheen Foods and Sweets was anything but promising. Tucked inside the ground floor of a house on 77th Street and around the corner from a sari shop, the confectionery had receipts for the day totaling 25 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WENGER, MILTON B.
description: WENGER-Milton B. Beloved father, brother, grandfather, with the soul of a poet. May he find peace and feel eternal love.

title: Russia Loses a Voice
description: To the Editor:

title: Lucky Just to Win
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Beholder's Eyes
description: To the Editor: Apropos of ''mirages'' so special as to seem beyond reality, as discussed in ''In the Eyes of the Beholder'' by Martha Weinman Lear (Nov. 1): they can be experienced by more than one person.

title: SAVING STRATEGIES: Roth I.R.A.'s are not just for boomers struggling to save for retirement; Converting Once, Converting Twice
description: Dale E. Schmidt, 68, Lincoln, Neb.

title: A Thousand Points of Light Isn't Always a Good Thing
description: Paul Stanley, the glam guitarist for the rock group Kiss, has a reputation for being tolerant of his fans.

title: Violence Task Force
description: By a unanimous vote, the Board of Legislators has agreed to increase the number of members of the three-year-old Domestic Violence Task Force to 19, with the six additional members appointed by County Executive Andrew J. Spano. They will join members of the task force who now represent the District Attorney's office, the Police Chiefs' Association and the county's Office for Women, among other groups.

title: An Exhilarating 'On the Town' Spreads Some Joy
description: MANHATTAN is transformed. The potholes are gone, as are the cabdrivers who don't know that the Bronx is up and the Battery's down. Nobody is trying to sweep the place clean of corruption or sin. The women are free and easily available. The Coney Island cooch shows still feature girls who can pick up handkerchiefs with their teeth. The eccentrics are benign and even the bores walk in grace, which makes them good company. Manhattan is an uproarious, singing, dancing time-out city, where nothing is impossible and the future is without limits, at least for a single day.

title: Lives; Joy of Funerals
description: In the winter, everyone is matted down in thick wool coats, standing in a huddled mass of sniffles and tears. In the summer, the air rings full of sorrow as mourners sigh, their cotton jackets and black dresses blowing in the breeze. To me, it doesn't matter in what season a funeral takes place. I enjoy them just the same.

title: A Dozen Artists at Work Within a Challenging Space
description: THE curators of the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art here must often wish they had an abandoned factory with no interior walls or columns, a garage door and a huge elevator to bring in the art. Instead, they have a cunning white building, which served in various genteel capacities -- post office, church, home -- before it became a museum.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Purple Dots

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLAM, MARTIN
description: FLAM-Martin. On November 27, 1998. Devoted brother of George Flam and Marilyn (Herb) Fisher. Loving uncle to many nieces and nephews. A great friend to all. Served his country bravely during WW II. He will always be remembered and loved.

title: November 22-28; Aquitted of Embezzlement
description: After an 11-week trial and voluminous testimony about lives of the rich and famous, a jury in Santa Monica, Calif., acquitted Susan H. McDougal of all charges of embezzling $50,000 from the conductor Zubin Mehta and his wife, Nancy.

title: The Man Who Would Be Papp
description: George C. Wolfe is a living love letter to the theater. As for the uproar raging around ''On the Town,'' Wolfe has always been a controversial visionary. Shakespeare's ''Tempest'' comes to mind: the magician, Prospero, raises a storm and practices his ''art'' on those who have stumbled into his ''theater,'' and their lives are changed. We are all lucky to be invited onto Wolfe's ''island,'' despite the occasional storm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, ALLAN R.
description: JOHNSON-Allan R. November 26, 1998. Beloved husband Maria, devoted father of Jane Fell, Kathy Jones, Susan Johnson & Barbara Hobin, cherished grandfather of seven and great-grandfather of four, loving brother of Patrick Johnson, cherished Godfather of Steven Toia. With Saks Fifth Avenue for thirty-six years, ten of which he spent as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, he retired in 1981 as Chairman of the store's parent company BATUS, Inc. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Tuesday, December 1, 1998, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Religious service Wednesday, December 2, St. John the Evangelist Church, 55 Street and First Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions in his name may be made to The Boys Scouts of America.

title: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; Can't Live With It, or Without It
description: I ONCE heard one friend offer another this observation about romance: ''It's not serious until he reveals his paycheck.''

title: Passengers Sound Off About N.J. Transit Trains
description: To the Editor:

title: Robin Kash and David Kanefsky
description: Robin Felice Kash, a daughter of Harvey Kash of Great Neck, N.Y., and the late Rochelle Kash, was married last evening to David Howard Kanefsky, a son of Edythe Kanefsky of Jamesburg, N.J., and the late Bernard Kanefsky. Rabbi Robert Widom performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel of Kings Point, N.Y.

title: Editorial Observer; The Noble Ideal of Rationalism in Nazi Dresden
description: By October 1936, Victor Klemperer, a Jew, had been removed from his professorship at the Technical University in Dresden, Germany. He and his ''Aryan'' wife, Eva, lived in a small house of their own in a rural suburb of Dresden. They were ''virtually destitute,'' Klemperer notes in ''I Will Bear Witness,'' his diary of the years from 1933 to 1941. (A second volume, to 1945, will be published next year. Klemperer died in Dresden in 1960.)

title: Holes in a Net for Foster Children?
description: When families fall apart, children often suffer twice. They lose their parents, and if they are placed in foster care far from home, they lose their support network. That is why in June Mayor Giuliani said the city would introduce a new approach to child welfare, providing foster care and services to help keep kids out of foster care, in the neighborhoods in which they live.

title: The Grand Prix Approach to Paris
description: OUR trip started innocently enough. We rented a purple Opel Corsa near the Air France office at Les Invalides in Paris. The car had the acceleration of a golf cart and the structural integrity of an aluminum can, but we weren't worried.

title: The Neediest Cases; Children Write Letters to Santa Asking for Help, Not Toys
description: As the holiday shopping season began last week, shoppers had nearly unlimited choices, from the newest Barbie to Interactive Barney to an $18,000 toy Range Rover, for those with unlimited means.

title: A Trash Incinerator Finally Nears Its Goal
description: NEXT year, for the first time since a trash incinerator was opened to serve southeastern Connecticut, its customers predict they'll send a hefty amount of trash to match the amounts they promised in 1992.

title: The World; Suddenly, Hussein Feels Alone in the Arab World
description: IN the uneasy calm that has followed President Clinton's decision to call off the bombing of Iraq, diplomats watching for Saddam Hussein's next move sense something profoundly different in the Iraqi air. While clues do not add up to conclusions, some Arab and Western experts have seen signs that President Hussein is more isolated in his own region than at any time since his 1990 invasion of Kuwait, which drove fellow Arab nations into backing the American-led coalition in the subsequent Persian Gulf war.

title: A Woman in Black Fascinated by Rouge
description: IT takes the real thing to play the real thing. Tovah Feldshuh is a genuine, bona fide character actress and Diana Vreeland was the exemplar of artifice as heightened reality. In the Theater Works production of ''Full Gallop'' in Hartford, the two of them are one.

title: November 22-28; Kervokian Makes a Legal Point of Assisted Suicide
description: The man known as Dr. Death got what he wanted: a murder charge, a legal showdown and perhaps another national debate on assisted suicide and euthanasia.

title: Questions of Identity, In Culture and in Life
description: THIS exhibition's title plays off a se mantic scruple or quibble, depending on one's viewpoint. It's not African-American art; it's art by African-Americans. The idea, presumably, is to displace questions of identity from the work to its makers, and to avoid the questions of what, if anything, makes a work African-American other than the artist's self-identification.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, DANIEL L. (''LYNN'')
description: ZIMMERMAN - Daniel L. (''Lynn''), 75, on November 26, 1998, after a long and courageous struggle against Alzheimer's disease. Devoted husband of Shirley; beloved father of John, Thomas, Carrie and Barbara; loved father-in-law of Eileen, Patricia and Andrew, adored grandfather of Kerry, Katelyn, Matthew, Hallie and Alexi; and dear brother of Leland. Lynn, for thirty years a tax manager for W.R. Grace & Co., loved music and travel.

title: Corrections
description: A article on Nov. 15 about a stand-up comedy class for the elderly misidentifed a character, created by the comedian Fred Allen, that the class members fondly recalled. He was Senator Clag horn, not Colonel Blackhorn.

title: Series of Killings? Yes. One Serial Killer? No.
description: Concerns that a serial murderer was loose in New Jersey flared early this year when the Essex County Prosecutor's Office found 14 cases of murdered prostitutes in and around Newark since 1993.

title: VIEW; My Heart Belongs to Duane
description: I HAD to be the happiest consumer in New York when I heard that Duane Reade had plans to open 30 new stores by the end of this year. At around 2:30 A.M. on certain fidgety nights, I entertain the thought of boarding the A train from my apartment in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, to go shopping at the 24-hour Duane Reade store on the corner of 57th Street and Broadway. Just knowing I have this option provides a level of comfort otherwise missing from the life of an insomniac with a day job.

title: CALL ME
description: * December brings with it on-air pledge drives for public television stations nationwide. * In New York City, WNET (Channel 13) gets about 1,300 calls a night, many from prankish kids promising vast, nonexistent sums. * Celebrity guest highlight: in 1993 Placido (''Three Tenors'') Domingo dropped by unannounced to make a pitch. A security guard was about to toss him out when someone vouched for him. * Last year, the pregnant producer of a documentary about guide dogs went into labor during an interview. * The most popular pledge premium is the Channel 13 tote bag. Bill Baker, the station president, saw a fellow traveler toting one when he visited the North Pole. * Least popular: a used WNET transmitter tube, offered at the $1,000 patron level. ''We're still waiting for a taker on that,'' says a spokeswoman.

title: Passengers Sound Off About N.J. Transit Trains
description: To the Editor:

title: Survey Finds A Sweetening Of Severance
description: WAGES and salaries may not be rising much at many companies, but severance pay has grown so generous that even temporary employees are sometimes paid to leave, according to a new survey of personnel managers at more than 1,800 companies.

title: November 22-28; Sex and the Admiral
description: The Pentagon continues to be dogged by sex-related scandals. In the latest case, a one-star admiral at the Navy's headquarters in the Pentagon faces charges of, among other things, steering $150,000 worth of military contracts to a woman with whom he was having an adulterous affair.

title: The Chaste Elizabeth
description: To the Editor:

title: November 22-28; Dropout U.S.A.
description: The United States no longer leads the world in the percentage of students graduating from high school.

title: Made, Marketed and Sold Here
description: IN the early 90's, Hank Paine, whose family had owned the Howland-Hughes department store in Waterbury since 1922, ran a ''staying in business'' sale. Like other independent retailers, the store had been affected by a slow economy and the competition of malls, and so it was reinventing itself. A quarter of Howland-Hughes's original space would now house The Connecticut Store, all of whose products were made in the state.

title: Reasons to Listen
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding The Profits (And Fun) In Mergers
description: BACK in 1968, L. Dennis Kozlowski walked out of Seton Hall University with a bachelor's degree in finance and a certainty that numbers were the game to play and conglomerates the place to play them. So, he joined the ill-starred SCM Corporation as a financial analyst.

title: Hot Pink Boxes
description: Hermes orange. Tiffany blue. And now, Pink pink. The new status gift box is from Thomas Pink, the British shirt store, which opened last year on Madison Avenue at 53d Street. The deep azalea-colored box with a black border is nearly as coveted as the shirts, ties, cuff links and pocket squares they hold. Customers collect them. One woman in London who has her Christmas trimmings done by a decorator is having all the gifts under the tree swathed in silver paper, except for the packages from Pink.

title: Disintegration
description: AMERICAN BEACH A Saga of Race, Wealth, and Memory. By Russ Rymer. Illustrated. 337 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $25.

title: McNabb Enjoys a Blowout at Miami's Expense
description: For four years, Donovan McNabb has opened every Syracuse game behind center. He has won 35 of them. He has cocked his arm 938 times to throw spirals resulting in 8,389 yards. Seventy-seven of them have found an orange-helmeted receiver who found the end zone. Nineteen more times McNabb has found his way there by foot.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 29, 1998
description: Weeks

title: A Love Affair With Color
description: THE UNKNOWN MATISSE

title: Old London Brewery Makes Theatrical Champagne Now
description: A FORMER hops brewery might seem an unlikely source for Broadway. But the tiny Donmar Warehouse theater in London has over time become a powerful producing entity way out of proportion to its 251 seats.

title: An Anniversary Weekend With 25 Romantic Things
description: To the Editor:

title: Roth I.R.A., Much Ignored, Is Worth Getting to Know
description: FOR more than a year, advertisements from investment houses and articles in the financial press have touted the benefits of the new Roth I.R.A. Yet few people seem to be paying attention. Surveys find that no more than 1 in 20 eligible Americans has put retirement money into a Roth.

title: After 51 Years, Toasts, Tears and the Final Round
description: THE SETTING -- Last call at Penn Bar and Grill, a watering hole at Eighth Avenue and 31st Street that dated from another, thirstier era. After losing a protracted battle with the landlord, the bar poured its final drink at midnight Tuesday. Throughout the evening, old-timers celebrated Larry Bagell, the owner of the bar for 46 of its 51 years, with tears, laughter and endless toasts.

title: Books and Authors With Roots on the Island; Taking Pen in Hand On Life of Dr. Spock
description: THOMAS MAIER and his wife, Joyce, are raising three sons with the help of the latest edition of Dr. Benjamin Spock's ''Baby and Child Care,'' the 1946 text that revolutionized child rearing in America. Mr. Maier, a 42-year-old resident of East Northport, was himself a ''Spock baby.'' So who better to be the author of ''Dr. Spock: An American Life'' (Harcourt/ Brace), which came out this year?

title: November 22-28; Urge to Merge
description: Side by side they seem to be the corporate odd couple of cyberspace: America Online, a middle-brow service catering to on-line newcomers, and Netscape Communications, the Internet software pioneer founded by whiz-kid programmers. But America Online purchased Netscape for roughly $4.2 billion in stock.

title: Books and Authors With Roots on the Island; From Screenplays To a Book on a Giraffe
description: MICHAEL ALLIN describes success as ''not knowing whether you're working or playing,'' and he admits it would be difficult to categorize his own activities as one or the other.

title: Camden's Bond Rating Is Lowered to 'Junk' Level
description: The cost of Camden's long-awaited financial recovery went up last week when Moody's Investor Service knocked the city's bond rating down to the level of junk bonds.

title: Water Is Deemed Cleaner, So Clamming Areas Will Reopen
description: More than 2,000 acres of water will open for clamming on Jan. 1, some parts for the first time since the early 60's, the Department of Environmental Protection announced last week.

title: Beholder's Eyes
description: To the Editor: No. 1 on my personal list of extraordinary sights: Mont-St.-Michel rising out of the sea at high tide, and standing on land at low tide. One observes this spectacular abbey on the Gulf of St.-Malo in northwest France.

title: A Hero's Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWHOUSE, THEODORE
description: NEWHOUSE-Theodore. 95. Died on November 28, 1998, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Caroline. Loving father of the late Jane. Devoted grandfather of Julie and Amy, grandfather-in-law and great-grandfather of Joshua, Isaac, Jonathan, Sarah, Jill and Emily. Services Monday, November 30th, 11:30 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65th St. Interment to follow at Baron Hirsch Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Alzheimer's Association of New York, 420 Lexington Ave., NYC 10170.

title: Photos Open Up the Vision of Those Who Know by Touch
description: Stephen Erra, an amateur photographer, snaps self-portraits, but not just of his face. Because he sees the world partly through his hands, they are often prominent in his work, caressing faces, sculptures or textured objects. In one photograph, his cane also joined him in the frame.

title: Happily Ever After?
description: Maurice, Or

title: To Go With a Bargain Lunch
description: One enduring Manhattan bargain, the $19.98 prix fixe lunch menu at the Gotham Bar and Grill, 12 East 12th Street, is matched by a smart $19.98 lunch-only prix fixe wine card developed by the sommelier, John Gilman.

title: Australia: Where TV Gets a Second Chance
description: In 1956, when TV came to Australia, an expectant island nation sat around the box and suddenly realized it hadn't bothered to produce any programs. Ever the capitalistic helper, the United States was quick to the rescue. ''Except for the odd news program, everything came from the States at first,'' explains Steve Wood, executive producer of Australia's version of ''Today.'' ''Then we started making our own fairly hideous programs.'' The Aussies picked up speed over the years, but -- as seen below -- they still freely adapt American shows. How does this proud country handle the disgrace of borrowing ''The Newlywed Game''? ''We've had our revenge,'' says Brian Courtis, TV editor at The Age in Melbourne. ''We gave you 'A Current Affair.'''

title: Giving Salad Standbys Like Iceberg Lettuce Another Chance
description: IT is hard to believe that not long ago mesclun salad was all but unheard of in the United States. Now it can be bought in the supermarket -- but often it consists of inferior greens mixed with radicchio, which is added for color.

title: Ohio Hair Braiders Sue Over State Licensing Requirements
description: Faith Carey-Proctor's dream of expanding her hair-braiding business is on hold. More precisely, it is stacked against the inside wall of a building she rents downtown, where there are dog-eared cardboard boxes of lotions and sprays, desk drawers full of combs, and a shopping cart loaded with rollers and hair extensions, an occasional curl twined through the bars.

title: An Odyssey That Began In the Blues and Grew
description: EMERGING in the late 1960's as an anomaly -- one of the few young black musicians to embrace the folk-blues revival -- Taj Mahal flirted with rock stardom but quickly proved himself too much of a maverick to pursue the bottom line. Grounding himself in the folk blues of the Afro-American South and always returning to it, he followed his curiosity into an ever-widening orbit: the sounds of the Caribbean, Africa and the Pacific.

title: SAVING STRATEGIES: Roth I.R.A.'s are not just for boomers struggling to save for retirement; A Big Advantage in Starting Early
description: Leon C. Blair, 23, Chicago

title: Tailoring the Music to Fit Each Late Show Guest
description: IF you were to watch two weeks' worth of the three late-night network talk shows, as I recently did, thanks to the dubious miracle of videotape, you might begin to suspect that it's all the same show: the same monologue, the same format, the same guests plugging the same movies and fielding the same soft questions. You would probably find yourself grateful not only for the differences but also for whatever hidden pleasures you might be able to uncover beneath the surface.

title: A Satisfied Customer Of Bruegger's Speaks Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Briefing; A Winning Candidate Aspires to a New Job
description: Bobby Rush has been on the national stage, off and on, for the better part of 30 years. And now he has his eye on a bigger role.

title: Carrot for a New Manager: A Stake Worth Millions
description: Fund companies often tinker with pay to encourage their portfolio managers. But Davis Selected Advisors, which runs well-known funds like Selected American Shares and Davis New York Venture, has come up with an extraordinary plan.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Is Solitary Confinement Driving Charlie Chase Crazy?
description: Charlie Chase is in jail for murder and armed robbery and in the hole for trying to kill another inmate while in jail, but Bruce Porter seems to think we should feel sorry for him.

title: The County Fights For It's Share Of Tobacco Settlement
description: THE county stands to get $455 million under terms of the state's proposed allocation of revenue from the settlement of lawsuits with the tobacco industry, but a successful legal motion brought by the county could jeopardize the settlement by delaying its signing.

title: Scottish History Has a New Home in Edinburgh
description: Billions of years of Scottish history have been distilled into five modern galleries in a new museum in Edinburgh's Old Town, scheduled to open tomorrow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, ANNE
description: GOLD-Anne. On November 26th, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Sol. Super Mom to Tanya and Michael Romanoff, Stanley, Jay and Lorri Gold. Fun-loving Granny of Stuart and Jackie, Michelle and Alan, Darryl, Stephen, and Marc. GiGi to six great-grandchildren. Sister to Julie, Barney, and George White. She was a unique woman of strength, beauty and style, and will be greatly missed. Services were held November 27.

title: A Little Bit Of Baby Aids Zoo's Rebirth
description: After two miscarriages in less than a year, Ramsey and Cleo had their first baby on Nov. 3, a healthy thumb-sized cotton-top tamarin. Clinging to its mother's back whenever she leaves the nest to forage, the tiny tuft of fur has become Prospect Park zoo's newest star.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORPUEL, BELMA TEICH
description: CORPUEL-Belma Teich. Beloved wife of Jules; mother of Michael, Noel, Peter and Jeffrey, Kathy, Carol and Georgeann; sister of Elsie Seckel and the late Victor Teich; sister-in-law of Edythe Teich; brother-in-law of the late Robert Seckel; grandmother of Stacy, Adena, Josh, Alison, Jessica, Rebecca and great grandmother of Aaron, passed from our lives and we will dearly miss her. Belma was Director of Camp Wayne since 1952. Although she will not be with us physically, she will always be in our hearts. We have all gained strength, determination and love from her. A memorial service will be held at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel in Hewlett, LI on Monday, November 30 at 9:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Association for the Help of Retarded Children.

title: Mementos Ease Pain Of Losing a Child
description: As one of the parents quoted in the cemetery article, there are a few things I would like to make even clearer. All the grieving family members who visit the baby section in Holy Rood Cemetery want a final resting place for our children that is well-kept and maintained. There is not a family that I have spoken to that would agree that the weather-beaten items and overgrown bushes should be permitted to stay, but no one dreamed they would be punished for complaining about them. I'm sure that the intent of the complaints was to remove those things that cause the section to look disorderly, not to choose for us what are appropriate items to place on the graves.

title: The World; Germany Searches For 'Normality'
description: GERMANY is whole and free. The Allied and Russian troops have long since left Berlin. Next year, with Poland's entry into NATO, the country will be surrounded by allies for the first time in its modern history, and the German parliament will return to the Reichstag. A cycle has been completed, it would seem, a chapter closed, 53 years after the fall of Hitler's Reich.

title: A Thinking Man's Bruckner
description: IMAGINE the Bruckner symphonies shorn of sentimental piety, and you're at the starting point of a provocative cycle emerging on CD's. Through five symphonies, Georg Tintner, an 81-year-old conductor born in Vienna, casts Bruckner's grand, emotionally charged structures in a refreshing light of restraint and proportion. Reflected back is an aura of honest affection and with it a paradoxical exchange: a beguiling intellectual beauty where one often finds a cloistered spirituality.

title: Blair Finds Autonomy Only Whets Scots' Appetite
description: The questions were delivered in brash and burry Glaswegian tones. Who created the television, the telephone, penicillin, the bicycle, pneumatic tires, the breech-loading rifle, beta blockers and Oxford University?

title: His Next Global Investment: Gas, Oil and Lots of Tires
description: Jim Rogers, the former hedge-fund manager and author of ''Investment Biker'' (but definitely not the Jim Rogers profiled on page 13 of this section), is going for another long drive, this time in an odd-looking yellow car. Mr. Rogers, 56, will drive around the world in a concoction dubbed the Millennium Project that consists of a Mercedes SLK, a two-seater with a retractable top, attached to the chassis of a Mercedes Galaendawagen sport utility vehicle (not widely available in the United States). He will start his three-year journey in Iceland on Jan. 1 to commemorate Leif Ericsson's voyage to North America. Then it's on to Europe, Turkey, Iran, China, South Korea and Japan in 1999; Africa, India and Australia in 2000, and South and North America in 2001. He figures he'll cover 100,000 miles, more than the 65,000 he traveled on a motorcycle in the early 90's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHELTON, MICHAEL JOE
description: WHELTON-Michael Joe. Of Whelton's pub, Lislevane, West Cork. Loving father, devoted husband, loyal friend, admired athlete, Michael Joe is missed by all. RIP. Condolences to Maire, Pat, Josie & Batt, from your cousins in America.

title: Mike Wallace
description: Wallace, a history professor at John Jay College, is the co-author (with Edwin G. Burrows) of ''Gotham: A History of New York City to 1898.''

title: November 22-28; A British First
description: Tony Blair became the first British Prime Minister to address the Parliament of the Irish Republic, declaring an end to centuries of hostilities between Ireland and Britain.

title: The Man Who Built Time Warner Leaves a Legacy of Appreciation
description: People are still talking about his 1990 paycheck of $78.2 million. But if his widow hasn't exercised the options he left her, Steven J. Ross, the creator of Time Warner Inc., has ''earned far more money since he died'' than he did while chairman and chief executive of Warner Communications, says the compensation expert Graef Crystal.

title: The Age of Aquariums
description: Many fashion trends have the life span of a goldfish, even when the trend is goldfish, or their bowls. The novelty item of choice during fashion week, fishbowls served as hats on Julien Macdonald's runway and, filled with pink water and rose petals, as centerpieces at Betsey Johnson's party at Lot 61. At the same time, the SoHo Grand Hotel (right) started outfitting guests' rooms with vases filled with Poland Spring water and a black or calico goldfish. ''We just thought this was something natural that would have a calming effect and reduce stress,'' said Tony Fant, the hotel's general manager. Patrons often get so attached to their fish friends that they ask to take the bowls and their occupants home. The hotel obliges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, RANDY
description: FOX-Randy. The Officers and Members of New Generation, NCJW, Peninsula Section, mourn the untimely passing of the husband of its esteemed Co-President, Abby Fox, with our heartfelt sympathies. Shari Reisch, Co-President

title: Is Solitary Confinement Driving Charlie Chase Crazy?
description: I noticed the reproduction of the inmate's ''masterpiece,'' which I thought was interesting, albeit sick. That drawing is not my cup of tea; nevertheless, it appeared to be on a par with some work I have seen in galleries. I wonder if Chase is aware that offensive imagery is trendy. With his style and notoriety, he could make a ''killing.'' He should get hold of a list of ''cutting edge'' galleries and quit flushing his pictures down the toilet.

title: Capturing the Voices Of Others, or Being Captured by Them
description: AT first, she did only Shirley Bassey and Cilla Black. To entertain her friends on the schoolyard back home in northern England, Jane Horrocks would spend her lunch breaks warbling just like the legendary British song stylists. As she grew, so did her repertory; eventually this character actress, best known in the United States for her flashy supporting role as the braying secretary, Bubble, on ''Absolutely Fabulous,'' would add the likes of Marlene Dietrich, Edith Piaf, Judy Garland and Marilyn Monroe. Most often, it was she who summoned the celebrities. Occasionally, though, they'd show up unbidden.

title: Money Lessons for Children (and Parents)
description: WHEN John and Lisa Manuele of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., make cash gifts to their two sons for birthdays, Christmas and special events like first communion or confirmation, they emphasize how hard they worked to earn the money and urge the boys to use it wisely.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: EMPTY WITHOUT YOU

title: Fear and Loathing in San Juan
description: THE RUM DIARY

title: Unwelcome Fame
description: To the Editor: We locals are duly impressed to have such a lengthy article as ''A Town that Big Dreams Built'' by Christopher Hall (Oct. 18). Unfortunately, yours is only one of several such reports.

title: This Just In
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Celestial Theme, With Terrestrial Drinking
description: Lore has it that some of Bugsy Siegel's henchmen opened one of the first bars in Las Vegas, a place called the Venus Room. Recently, a more above-board spot with the same name, capturing a sleek, 1950's space-age look, opened at 1074 First Avenue, between 58th and 59th Streets. David Boldt and David Kravitz own the Venus Room and have been in the business for a number of years, at spots like Mortimer's and Luke's Bar and Grill.

title: Correction
description: A report last Sunday about the marriage of Susan R. Lauer misspelled the surname of the bridegroom and his parents. He is Raymond Pena, son of Carmen and Martin Pena, not Pena.

title: Delightful Surprises in Japanese Fare
description: ''THE menus at Japanese restaurants are all alike. Just look . . . '' My friend stopped in mid-sentence as her eyes locked in on the menu at Momoyama in Great Neck. It was something different. Sure, there were the expected tempuras, teriyakis, sushi and sashimi but rarely seen offerings like shrimp and avocado rolled in broiled salmon, hibachi lobster and multi-course tasting dinners are there as well. And it takes a restaurant with flair to present raw sea urchins as a complimentary opener.

title: When a Boss Turns Abusive
description: Q. I recently received a promotion, but my new boss dislikes me and has been verbally abusive, to the point of using an obscene term to describe me in front of my colleagues. (I reported the incident to the department head.) Obviously, this behavior can't go on. What are my rights? Can I sue?

title: This Green Is Their Green, Make No Mistake
description: FROM his law office high up in one of New Haven's tallest buildings, Charles Newton Schenck 3d has an absolutely magnificent view of the domain of which he is the master. There it is, 17 stories below, a 16-acre oasis of trees and grass accented by a street cutting through it and walkways crisscrossing it, with three churches all in a row, and the stately buildings of Yale University as a backdrop.

title: San Antonio
description: B. J. (Red) McCombs, the colorful San Antonio millionaire who owns several car dealerships, the Minnesota Vikings and a lot of other things, vividly remembers a conversation he had with the man who held a gathering a couple of years ago for Fortune 400 chief executive officers in the city. About 250 flew in for the event, and the sponsor was stunned to discover that two-thirds of them had never before set foot in the city.

title: The Economy Grows. The Smokestacks Shrink.
description: AMERICA is putting on an unusual spectacle: The economy keeps growing and thriving even while manufacturing suffers and falls behind.

title: An Epic That Gets Better as It Gets Longer
description: I HAD serious doubts before seeing a 3 hour 39 minute version of Bernardo Bertolucci's ''Last Emperor,'' thinking perhaps an already indolent film was to become absolutely, luxuriantly, corrupted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VUILLET, FRANCES JEANNE
description: VUILLET-Frances Jeanne. Died November 21 at Geer Nursing and Rehabilitation Center in Canaan, Connecticut. She was 91 years old. Born in Jersey City, New Jersey, Mrs. Vuillet lived for many years in London and Paris with her late husband, Samuel Vuillet. Since 1960, she had resided in Locust Valley and then Glen Cove, New York. Survivors include a daughter, Jeanne Poole of Huntington, NY, son, Robert Vuillet of Stanfordville, NY, six grandchildren and thirteen great-grandchildren. The family will hold a memorial service at Woodlawn Cemetery in December. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Geer Nursing and Rehabilitation, Canaan, Connecticut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHELTON, TALBOT
description: SHELTON-Talbot. Age 84, of NYC and Southampton, died Wednesday, November 25, 1998 after a brief illness. Born in Kansas City, Missouri, Mr. Shelton graduated Cum Laude from Stanford University in 1937 and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa and received a LLB from Harvard University in 1940. Joined Bethlehem Steel Corp. and served as Vice President of Finance and Law and was a Director until he joined Smith Barney in 1967 as Vice President and Director and was also the Chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee for the American Iron and Steel Institute. He is survived by his wife, Frances Brunel LaGatta Shelton; two sons, Talbot Shelton, Jr. of Oregon and Peter Laros Shelton of NYC; two step-children, Alexandra Brunel LaGatta, John LaGatta; and five grandchildren. There will be a service at St. James' Episcopal Church, Madison Ave. at 71 St. on Friday, December 4, 1998 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUPNICK, DAVID
description: KRUPNICK-David. The officers, management and staff of our company announce with deep regret the death of David Krupnick, who has been a devoted member of our firm for many years. We extend our sympathies to his wife, Linda and his son, Scott. Services to be held Sunday, 9 AM, Kane Street Synagogue, 236 Kane St., Brooklyn, NY, 9 AM. Baltic Linen Company, Inc.

title: State Cracks Down On School Bus Safety
description: AFTER driving a school bus for 14 years it still shocks Judith Pratt, a safety trainer for the Ryder Transportation Company in Naugatuck, how motorists continue to endanger the safety of students every day by speeding past school buses as children are crossing the street.

title: November 22-28; Pentagon Weighing Cuts In Nuclear Arsenal
description: With proposed reductions in nuclear warheads bogged down in Russia's parliament, some Pentagon officials believe the time has come for the United States to consider unilateral cuts in its strategic arsenal.

title: Data Offer No Hint Yet Of a Slowing Economy
description: Soak it, sleep in it, leave it out in a storm: Nothing seems to shrink or even much wrinkle the American economy.

title: A Week of Merging Exuberantly
description: If you've grown a good bit bigger lately on account of heroic feats of ingestion, well, you might just be a corporation. The red button has not yet popped up on two big deals in the oven, Exxon-Mobil and Deutsche Bank-Bankers Trust, but last week yielded plenty of other done-to-a-turn merger and acquisition announcements.

title: Gifted Group of College Quarterbacks Is Ready to Graduate to the Professional Game
description: One is famous for not being famous -- except among scouts who haunt Central Florida and project him as the quarterback for a new millennium. Another is a volatile and obsessive winner who has thrown passes 90 yards in practice with the help of Kansas's prairie winds.

title: Going Beyond Debate Over Assisted Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: UPPER EAST SIDE

title: The One Reasonable Solution
description: In the weeks since the midterm election, some of President Clinton's harshest critics and staunchest defenders have found something they agree on: impeachment or nothing. There is no third option, they say. Either Congress must vote on whether to remove Mr. Clinton from office or we must move on as if he had done nothing wrong.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 15 about mixing the poor with the very poor in public housing gave an incorrect surname for the deputy director of the National Housing Law Center, who commented on racial segregation in housing projects. He is David Bryson, not Bryce.

title: Two Men Are Shot by Police In Separate Queens Incidents
description: In separate confrontations on Friday night, police officers in Queens shot two armed men, one of them a mentally ill man who the police said was marching down a street in Far Rockaway with what appeared to be an M-16 rifle.

title: Ho! Ho! Ho! Boohoo-hoo!
description: The holiday season seems to bring out the best and the worst in bosses. We've all heard stories about workers who are fired on Christmas Eve, but then again, Scrooge himself ended up giving the long-suffering Bob Cratchit a raise. What holiday horror stories have emerged from your workplace? Or, to give the management world's guardian angels their due, how have the holidays melted the coldest corporate hearts? Send your anecdotes to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Skull Tapping
description: Ever worry that advertisers know too much about your moods and preferences? Help may be on the way -- for them. A Pennsylvania-based company called Capita Research Group is experimenting with a method for delving deeper into the minds of TV watchers. The goal is to measure an eerie-sounding new index of TV involvement called ''the engagement index.''

title: Forman's Gets Bigger, So Does Its Clothing
description: The name Forman's has been around for 60 years. The discount clothing stores, owned by Bernard Mittelman's family for some 20 years, added Forman's Plus Sizes at 84 Orchard Street, between Broome and Grand Streets, two weeks ago. The newest store, which Mr. Mittelman says ''is dedicated to larger-size women,'' includes items by Liz Claiborne and Jones New York, and claims to sells them for 25 to 30 percent less than department stores. The clothing ranges from about size 16 to size 24. Forman's has two more stores on Orchard Street: the original Forman's, at 82 Orchard, and a shop at 94 Orchard specializing in petites. ALEXANDRA McGINLEY

title: A Victory Provides Salve For Rutgers's Mounting Ills
description: Coach C. Vivian Stringer's return to the bench today after her son's arrest last week was supposed to be a respite from her family problems. The everyday rhythms of practice and the Scarlet Knights' drive to unseat Connecticut in the Big East and improve on last year's 22-10 breakthrough season should have been a welcome distraction.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: The Nine Lives of Sweaters and Glass
description: Housatonic, Mass., has long been a magnet for artistic souls bent on recycling the town's gritty mill buildings. But two young designers who share a recycled factory there are taking the idea in new directions.

title: Is Solitary Confinement Driving Charlie Chase Crazy?
description: I will never forget visiting a maximum-security, segregated unit for gang members, with 23-hour lock-down, when I was a graduate student in criminal justice. I was in the ''pod'' no more than a minute when I began to hyperventilate from claustrophobia -- not a regular condition of mine -- and told the assistant warden to ''get me out of here now.''

title: Touching Base With Cuckolds
description: We now inaugurate the Pundits Aid Society, committed to helping distressed columnists in search of roots.

title: . . . as Years of Brown Tide Leave Scallops Scarce
description: STUART HEATH, one of the few remaining baymen in Montauk, pulled the scallop dredges off his boat on Oct. 21, when the season for bay scallops in the waters off the Town of East Hampton was only two days old, and replaced the dredges with clam rakes.

title: The World: Beyond the Gaza Airport; Running the Economy Without a Country
description: WHEN their gleaming new international airport opened in the Gaza Strip last week, Palestinians saw it as one more step toward the national statehood their leaders have been promising.

title: Tourists Bypass Troops And Cross 38th Parallel
description: Tens of thousands of North and South Korean and American troops are still massed along each side of the demilitarized zone on the 38th parallel, but on Nov. 18 the first ship of tourists from the South sailed to the North to visit the Mount Kumgang region. The two Koreas are cooperating in developing tourism in the area and have begun building a resort complex.

title: Rude Rudy
description: If anything deserves to be at the top of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's ''zero tolerance'' hit list, it's probably this: the new Rude Rudy doll, a not-so-cuddly plaything designed to push across the editorial comment that the Mayor can be obnoxious. The Rude Rudy doll may not bear a striking resemblance to the Mayor (the doll's face was actually modeled after Boris Yeltsin, basically because its creator preferred Boris's face to Rudy's), but the name worn proudly on its T-shirt will surely settle any doubt. Squeeze certain parts of the doll's anatomy and Rudy (priced at $14.99 and just showing up in stores) makes rude bodily noises (including belches . . . and worse).

title: SAVING STRATEGIES: Roth I.R.A.'s are not just for boomers struggling to save for retirement; College Funds, Growing Tax-Free
description: Kenneth O'Hare, 56, and Denise Zaccardi, 50, Chicago

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANCIS, EDA BRUNN ANDERSON
description: FRANCIS-Eda Brunn Anderson. An educator and mentor of young women from 1926 to 1956, and a friend for a lifetime. The Berkeley Carroll School Brooklyn, New York

title: Be Afraid!
description: THE CRISIS

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: FREEDOM TO DIE People, Politics and the Right-to-Die Movement. By Derek Humphry and Mary Clement. St. Martin's, $24.95.

title: Avant-Garde Art Plus Institutional Ideas
description: IF you had to guess Jock Reynolds's passion -- given his neatly trimmed silver hair, clean shave, blue blazer, subdued tie and gray slacks -- avant-garde art is probably not the first thing that would leap to mind.

title: Karen Krieger, Patrick Renda
description: Karen Suzanne Krieger, a daughter of Erica Ged and Dr. Oscar Krieger, both of Wyckoff, N.J., was married yesterday to Patrick Blake Renda, a son of Patricia Renda of Los Angeles and Dominic P. Renda of Rancho Mirage, Calif. David Weinberg, a commissioner of California Superior Court in Orange, officiated at the Auberge du Soleil in Rutherford, Calif.

title: Purges Hint at Beginning of the End for Milosevic
description: In moves viewed here and by some in Washington as signs of weakness rather than strength, President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia has conducted an extraordinary purge of his innermost circle, dismissing the leaders of the army, the air force and the intelligence service, as well as one of his most trusted political commissars.

title: In America; A Wholesale Sellout
description: Stanley Hill cannot leave soon enough.

title: Bracing for the Cold to Come
description: Don't be tempted to compensate for dryness in the air by overwatering houseplants. Misting will not help, either, but humidity can be raised by placing plants together on a layer of pebbles in watertight trays: put only enough water in the bottom that will evaporate in a day or so, and be sure to raise pots above the water.

title: The Youngest Place on Earth
description: It is 11:30 P.M. Wednesday night at the Bridge Club, a disco in the center of Ulaan Baatar. A well-heeled crowd of 20- and 30-year-olds dances to Puffy Combs's rap version of Every Breath You Take. Just about everyone is smartly dressed: the young women in tight jeans and turtlenecks, the men in well-tailored suits. Around midnight, the deejay makes an announcement, and everyone sits down. A bawdy rap song starts up, and a woman who cannot be older than 20 takes the stage and begins to take off her clothes. The audience watches in a manner best described as nonchalant.

title: Backtalk; N.B.A. Lockout: Which Side Is Dropping the Ball?
description: On Nov. 12, The New York Times ran a profile of the Washington Wizards' owner, Abe Pollin (''The N.B.A.'s Senior Owner Speaks Out, and Bluntly''). Pollin was quoted as saying that the National Basketball Association's present economic system does not work and that the owners deserve a fair rate of return on their investments. The same day, Commissioner David Stern was quoted in USA Today as stating that the fundamental issue was a fair share for the owners.

title: Handling Pop-Up Stopper Problems
description: TODAY most bathroom sinks have pop-up stoppers instead of the old-fashioned rubber plugs. Generally pop-up stoppers work well, but over time they may become clogged with hair or other debris and fall out of alignment. Then they may not open or close properly.

title: Not His Worst
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinoiserie Meets Greenwich At an Annual Antiques Show
description: ANTIQUARIUS, the 41-year-old antiques show benefiting the Historical Society of the Town of Greenwich, always has a waiting list, with a few new dealers trickling in annually. But this year the name of the game is transformation.

title: The Man Who Would Be Papp
description: When Witchel pointed out that ''On the Town'' is looked upon by some as a ''dark piece -- the last day of life before probable death in the war,'' she made naval service in World War II seem like a kamikaze ride to almost certain death. In truth, losing one's life as a sailor on a United States ship during any of our wars has always been a possibility, but certainly never a probability.

title: From Sailing Solo to Teaching
description: Tania Aebi, once the youngest person to sail alone around the world, is 30-something now. But in spirit she is still the same spunky, outspoken teen-ager who left a bicycle messenger job in New York City to go cruising in exotic places.

title: Stacey Lewis and Joel Alsfine
description: THIS is a love story with one degree of separation. It began in April 1997, at a Sabbath dinner on the Upper East Side arranged so that Stacey Lewis, an elegant and take-charge editor at Mirabella magazine, could meet Joel Alsfine, a management consultant at McKinsey & Company with a resonant South African accent that American women, to hear his friends tell it, find hard to resist.

title: November 22-28; Managing Managed Care
description: After failing to slow several years of rising medical costs, health maintenance groups are pushing the costs on to the consumer. Americans can expect to pay 8 to 20 percent more for insurance premiums next year. The rise is the sharpest since the early 1990's and reflects big increases in the prices of prescription drugs, surgical devices and techniques and services to patients outside hospitals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UPBIN, CELIA
description: UPBIN-Celia. On November 27, 1998, at the age of 87. Devoted wife of the late Mortimer, loving mother of Sanford (deceased), Sol and Harry, mother-in-law of Jeanne and Joan. Cherished grandmother of Lori Abrams, Leslie Paparo, Bruce, Lisa, Stefanie, Brian, David and Daniel, greatgrandmother of Lucy, Annie, Nicholas, Isaac and William. Adored aunt and great-aunt. Service Sunday, November 29, 1:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Beholder's Eyes
description: To the Editor: I agree with many sights mentioned in the article and would have to add: my husband and I alone in the Sistine Chapel in late afternoon; morning walks through the Old City of Jerusalem, the mist lifting over Machu Picchu, the view of lower Manhattan as the ferry pulls away, the Grand' Place in Brussels lit up, almost touching the terra cotta warriors in Xian, and walking the Great Wall.

title: Will the Patriots Draw in Fairfield?
description: BELIEVING that his team needed corporate support from Fairfield County if it was to survive in Hartford, Richard Gordon, then the principle owner of the Hartford Whalers hockey team, invited 146 executives from the region to attend a reception, dinner and a Whalers' hockey game in February of 1992.

title: Handling Pop-Up Stopper Problems in the Sink
description: TODAY most bathroom sinks have pop-up stoppers instead of the old-fashioned rubber plugs. Generally pop-up stoppers work well, but over time they may become clogged with hair or other debris and fall out of alignment. Then they may not open or close properly.

title: A Familiar Conclusion As Rowan Celebrates
description: Buffalo State College's history has been littered with disappointments at the hands of Rowan University. Its season has ended at the hands of the Profs four times in the last six years. The Bengals had never advanced beyond the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division III quarterfinals, where they found themselves facing Rowan once again today.

title: Forget About the S.& P. 500; Consult the Hit Parade Instead
description: David Pullman, managing director of Pullman Group, made his fame on Bowie Bonds, in which he packaged future royalties from David Bowie's 300-some song catalogue as a $55 million bond. He followed it with bonds from the Motown producing-songwriting hit machine of Brian Holland, Lamont Dozier and Eddie Holland, authors of ''Baby Love'' and ''Ain't Too Proud to Beg,'' and from other songwriters with enough royalties to package and sell.

title: Police Action In '97 Haunts Government In Canada
description: It started out as little more than a brief spot on the nightly news, but the treatment of protesters at an international conference in Vancouver last year has turned into a recurring political nightmare for Prime Minister Jean Chretien and his Government.

title: Reflections of Whitman In a City He Loved
description: FROM the Starr Report to reviews of the Jackson Pollock retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan, Walt Whitman seems to be turning up everywhere. The poet has not been overlooked in his adopted hometown.

title: De-lightful, De-licious, De-ceitful
description: COLE PORTER A Biography. By William McBrien. Illustrated. 459 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: Noisy Cruise
description: To the Editor: In the cruise directory on Oct. 4, you included Royal Caribbean's new ship, Vision of the Seas. From July 11 to 18, a friend and I took a Mediterranean cruise on the Vision. I paid $3,059 for a ''premium ocean view'' cabin.

title: Proper Potting Mixtures for Indoor Plants
description: AS one's thoughts turn to the plants growing indoors, it might be helpful to consider the stuff that roots are in: potting soil. Any plant needs a good root system to thrive, and for plants growing in pots, a proper growing mixture is key.

title: Williams Gets a Record Beyond His Own Dreams
description: It could have been considered a victory lap, even though it was only halfway around the track at Darrell K. Royal-Texas Memorial Stadium, and even though it was done from the driver's seat of a black Chevy Tahoe.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 1 about a report by the Writers Guild of America on Hollywood's preference for young writers misstated the number of writers for the program ''Politically Incorrect.'' The program has 10 writers, not 22. (The Writers Guild report referred to all the writers employed by the show during a 14-month period.)

title: Where There's Life After 'The End'
description: IN the beginning, there was simply ''The End.''

title: Board Is in a Dispute Over Inspector General
description: EACH day, John S. Pritchard 3d goes to work as the Inspector General of Westchester County, but five months after he was named to the post he is still being paid from the Department of Social Services budget because the new office he heads has not been formally established.

title: Would It Still Make Sense To Pay Him With Wine?
description: It might seem irrational, what with the ignominy suffered by two famous economic professors who put their Nobel-winning knowledge to work trying to make billions at Long-Term Capital Management, the hedge fund that nearly collapsed in September. But that is not stopping Richard H. Thaler, a University of Chicago economics professor, from forming a money-management firm with his friend Russell J. Fuller.

title: Fab Four
description: INDIVISIBLE

title: DANCE; Missing Alvin Ailey As a New Era Dawns
description: WE knew that the North and South did rise again in the resonance of faith experienced in every heartfelt hallelujah on Sunday morning. The rhythms of worship were the same, and out of his persistent need to tell our story, we came together in one instant rush of risk, recognition and restless curiosity, knowing all to well, in the infinite hollow of the heart, a light shone so brightly, that we were compelled to dance in it.

title: How Toys Cleaned Up Urban Blight
description: FOR decades the industrial area just east of this city's downtown was an economic wreck -- 15 blocks of derelict prewar buildings abutting the flophouses, cheap hotels and unappetizing sights of skid row. But in recent years the area has come to boisterous life with voices in various South China dialects, Vietnamese, Korean, Farsi, Spanish and myriad other languages, all talking about toys.

title: After First-Half Scare, UConn Settles In to Its Spot at Top
