description: When Jamie Redd, the outstanding guard for Washington, hit a 3-pointer to give her team a 40-37 lead with 2 minutes 56 seconds left in the first half tonight, it looked possible that Connecticut could become the third No. 1 women's team to be beaten this season.

title: Baruch Builds An Urban Quadrangle
description: FROM a massive base almost a full city block in extent, the facade of the new Baruch College Academic Complex on Lexington Avenue bows outward and tapers inward, as if distorted by some gigantic fish-eye lens, its bare steel columns seeming to curve like bamboo trees under a steady gale.

title: Beethoven's Hair Tells All!
description: Dr. Alfredo Guevara is a urologist who practices in Nogales, Ariz., right on the Mexican border. In his office there are two busts of Ludwig van Beethoven and one of Abraham Lincoln, along with pictures of both men. I was looking at a bronze death mask of Beethoven balanced on a stack of issues of The Journal of Urology one afternoon last month when the doctor came into his office wearing blue surgical scrubs. A hearty, bespectacled man of 47, he sat down across from me and smacked his knees, the gesture doctors make to signal that they have only a few minutes to spend with you.

title: Dina George And Nick Khoury
description: Konstantina Maria George, a daughter of Georgia and James George of Portland, Ore., was married yesterday to Nael Kamel Khoury, the son of Samira G. Harb of Laguna Niguel, Calif., and the late Kamel L. Khoury.

title: Digitized Artifacts Are Making Knowledge Available to All, on Line
description: Boston was threatened by smallpox, and from his nearby headquarters in Cambridge, Mass., George Washington ordered his troops to stay out of the city. It was March 19, 1776, and the orders were written by hand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBB, LUCY HOFFMAN
description: WEBB-Lucy Hoffman. 71 years old. Died on November 21st after a long illness battling cancer. She was married to Lt. Colonial Charles Webb, Jr. and was the daughter of the late Colonial Albert Lincoln Hoffman and Elaine Sullivan Hoffman. Mrs. Webb was the granddaughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Francis Burrall Hoffman of New York and the late Mr. and Mrs. James Francis Sullivan of Philadelphia and descendant of Richard Nicolls, first British Colonial Governor of New York. She is survived by her three children, Charles Hoffman Webb, Lainey Webb Moseley, Livingston Rivers Webb and two grandchildren, Jack Moseley and Leta Moseley. Funeral services will be held at Arlington National Cemetery, on Thursday, December 3rd at 3PM, Fort Meyers Chapel.

title: Sheri Aschettino And Stuart Isler
description: Sheri Anne Aschettino and Dr. Stuart L. Isler were married last evening at the Pierre in New York. The Rev. Steven J. Yagerman, an Episcopal priest, officiated with Dr. Raymond Smolover, a cantor.

title: Note of Appreciation for 2 Wine Lovers
description: For five years, Michael Todd was, in the minds of many East End consumers, Mr. Long Island Wine. His highly personal Grapezine, an idiosyncratic magazine of opinion that did not stint in trumpeting his enthusiasms and dislikes, friends and feuds, delivered sassy reading to wine-loving fans of old-fashioned in-your-face journalistic criticism.

title: Commercial Property / 55 Wall Street; From Temple of Capitalism to an All-Suite Hotel
description: IT has been the home to a stock exchange, it was, as the Custom House, besieged by rioters during the Civil War and it has housed the headquarters of a major bank. Now the grand Greek Revival building that occupies the entire block bordered by Wall, William and Hanover Streets and Exchange Place is undergoing another transformation.

title: Voices Lift In Carols Of Old
description: VOCAL events usually overshadow other performances as the holidays approach, and so they do this week, beginning today at 2 with the traditional English carols that prevail during the Nebraska Theater Caravan's edition of ''A Christmas Carol'' at the Shubert in New Haven. The production then moves to Storrs for a show at 7:30 P.M. on Wednesday in Jorgensen Auditorium. The Shubert box office number is (203) 562-5666; for reservations at the Jorgensen Auditorium, call (860) 486-4226.

title: Eyes Turn To Nassau Land Use
description: IN crowded Nassau County, housing and commercial development long ago wiped from the map nearly all but the most expressly protected open lands and nook-and-cranny places.

title: Books and Authors With Roots on the Island; Taking a Fictional Life Just One Step Further
description: ERIC KRAFT will not admit to having a cult following. ''I hate to say 'cult' because it sounds like people who are waiting for aliens to come and take us to a better place,'' said the author of ''The Personal History, Adventures, Experiences and Observations of Peter Leroy.'' Mr. Kraft prefers to say his work has ''an enthusiastic following of people who are very interesting characters.''

title: Is Testaverde the Jets' All-Weather Quarterback?
description: Today may be the last time this season that Vinny Testaverde and the Jets enjoy a 50-degree game day. But even the onset of December may not hurt the Jets who, increasingly, are giving evidence that neither bad weather nor a month that has doomed them in the past will halt them this season.

title: Each Side Is Jockeying to Influence the Fate of the President
description: As the House impeachment inquiry enters its crucial final weeks, Republicans and Democrats are jockeying for an advantage that could influence President Clinton's fate.

title: Steven Rosen and Lauren Czuczka
description: Lauren Alyson Czuczka, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Peter S. Czuczka of Westport, Conn., was married last evening to Steven Andrew Rosen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Larry S. Rosen of Sudbury, Mass. Rabbi Robert J. Orkand performed the ceremony at the Glen Island Harbor Club in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: The Other Tradition: Reaching for Relief
description: ''TRY this pink stuff, it's very good.''

title: Helping Children Face AIDS With Hope
description: Like many typical 11-year-olds, Chris gets a kick out of climbing trees, riding his dirt bike, playing Nintendo and tinkering with cars. Wrestling, he says, thrills him. Beaming out from beneath a baseball cap worn backwards, his impish grin could warm the most hardened heart. When he speaks, his joyful manner puts listeners instantly at ease.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I don't want an industry to be made on the memory of victims, particularly because there are so few survivors out there who will

title: Girls Wrestle With Peer Pressure
description: DOWNSTAIRS the mothers sat and talked with bewilderment about the changes their teen-agers were going through. Upstairs their daughters talked about trying to communicate honestly with their parents.

title: To Dance, to Sing, To Live and Learn
description: Saluting high kicks and high C's, a university chief and a cancer fund, a radio station and brave writers.

title: Spanish Judge Investigating Rights Abuses In Argentina
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former Chilean dictator, is only one of several former South American strongmen being investigated by a Spanish judge for possible extradition to Spain.

title: Streetscapes / 'Morningside Heights: A History of Its Architecture and Development'; From an Empty Plateau to an Urban Neighborhood
description: BOOKS about local history are often amateurishly elementary or impenetrably arcane. But Andrew Dolkart's ''Morningside Heights: A History of Its Architecture and Development'' (Columbia University Press) combines recondite research with bare-knuckle history, interweaving the nuts and bolts of neighborhood-building with a messy human drama of rivalry, greed, marketing, bigotry -- and idealism.

title: The Wall Street Recruiting Bowl
description: JOSHUA COHEN, a senior at the University of Michigan, has a dozen folders in his file cabinet that are crammed with financial reports and news clippings about companies he is pursuing for a job. He bought a cellular phone so he would be available to recruiters 24 hours a day.

title: Social Security's Fate
description: To the Editor:

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: WILLIAM J. BRATTON; Prowling The Old Beat
description: WILLIAM J. BRATTON hasn't been on the New York City police force in two and a half years, but he still works the night shift. On a recent evening on the town, the famously social Mr. Bratton, now president of the Carco Group, a Long Island security company, cruised the police-party beat as if he'd never left.

title: Life After Sports
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Rejuvenated Fischer Strategy Leaves Its Mark on Olympiad
description: Of the many legacies that Bobby Fischer bequeathed to chess, his treatment of the King's Indian Attack is coming in for a revival lately. He was not its inventor but picked it up in 1956 just as he was achieving national prominence and perfected it as a brilliant winning weapon.

title: State Offers Aids to Decipher New Car Insurance Rates
description: The 69 car insurance companies selling policies in the state have begun using what is called tier rating to set rates, a system that could mean increased premiums for nearly half the three million drivers in New Jersey, according to Winnie Comfort, spokeswoman for the state Department of Banking and Insurance.

title: The Next Wave in Flying: 650-Seat Planes (Maybe)
description: The jetliner of the future will be a double-deck behemoth flying 500 to 800 people in three classes of service or the same old same old, perhaps with bigger fuel tanks to fly farther nonstop, say New York to Singapore. Airbus Industrie and the Boeing Company, the only makers of jumbo jets, have offered those two very different visions of the future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAVIN, PETER
description: SAVIN-Peter. Our deepest sympathy to the family of Peter Savin, a beloved husband, father and friend. Marilyn & Ben Ossman & Family

title: Static on Car Service's Message
description: The river of yellow cabs that flows through midtown slows to a trickle in upper Manhattan, and many Harlemites, unable to find a cab, rely heavily on car services. But callers to the Harlem Car Service, at 210 St. Nicholas Avenue, between 124th and 125th Streets, face another potential obstacle to getting a ride.

title: Competition and the Internet
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, two pictures on Nov. 8 with an article about Kiasma, a new museum of contemporary art in Helsinki, Finland, were printed in mirror image. In the larger picture, the interior ramp leading to gallery space should have appeared at the left; in the exterior photo, the museum should have appeared at the right.

title: It's Time for Fairy Tales With the Bite Of Reality
description: FEW children have been treated to what the novelist Margaret Atwood calls ''the complete Grimm,'' that unexpurgated collection of ''The Nursery and Household Tales'' in which ''every blood-stained ax, wicked witch and dead horse is right there, where the Brothers Grimm set them down, ready to be discovered by us.'' Our cultural definition of fairy tales as bedtime reading for children has blinded us to what was at stake when these stories were first told.

title: Transcendental Meditations On the Possibilities of Form
description: IN Europe, the choreographer William Forsythe is widely considered the most important dance maker on the planet. In his own country, the United States, his name is probably known only to dancers and a limited number of balletgoers who have seen his works in the repertories of the New York City Ballet, the San Francisco Ballet or the Joffrey Ballet, or perhaps performed by a touring company from across the Atlantic.

title: At the Ballet
description: To the Editor:

title: November 22-28; Europe Lifts Ban On British Beef
description: The crisis that alerted the world to the dangers of ''mad cow disease'' came to an end when the European Union declared British beef safe and lifted its 32-month worldwide ban on its export.

title: Pay-Pay-Pay-Per-View
description: While Max Frankel cries out for a great revolution to make a better place for politicians on TV, it's obvious he expects too much from television and not enough from the candidates (Word & Image, Nov. 8). Who created the negative ad? Yes, we gladly broadcast political spots (at rates far below what we usually get for the time period), but where is the responsibility to use that time wisely? Most ads we see are time-wasters. There are no specifics. There are no great initiatives. Most politicians promise to support education, to get tougher with criminals and to work toward a smaller, responsive government. Who can make a choice from that? And why is that TV's fault?

title: Political Briefing; Leaving Washington, Weighing Comeback?
description: When Senator Lauch Faircloth of North Carolina ran for re-election this year, he sometimes seemed to be running more against President Clinton, labor unions and the Rev. Jesse Jackson than against his Democratic opponent, John Edwards. He lost in one of the most galling defeats of all for Republicans.

title: BOOKEND; The Philosopher and the Critic
description: These excerpts are from a talk I had with Isaiah Berlin in London on the afternoon of March 27, 1991. I'd written to him that I was editing Edmund Wilson's last journal, ''The Sixties,'' and had begun a biography, and he suggested we meet at the Athenaeum Club. At a table in the elegant long drawing room, I proposed that he fill out the account of Wilson he had begun in a short memoir published a few years earlier. Berlin had offered there an impression of Wilson's ''curiously strangled voice, with gaps between his sentences, as if ideas jostled and thrashed about inside him,'' emerging in ''short bursts, emitted staccato, interspersed with gentle, low-voiced, legato passages.'' His own deep soft voice also came in bursts, trailing off at the end of a breath and emphatically resuming. For two and a half hours (with an intermission for tea) he displayed a penetrating intelligence, warmth of heart and moral seriousness that reminded me of the same qualities in his old friend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGESIS, SAMUEL
description: MAGESIS-Samuel, 94. Died in Coral Springs, Florida on November 25. Loving husband of Esther, devoted father of Richard and Duffy, fond father-in-law of Peg, and beloved Pop Pop of Cassie and Nicky. Services on Sunday, November 29 at 1PM, BoulevardRiverside Chapel, 312 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Kathryn Crosby, Arthur Staple
description: Kathryn Emily Crosby, a daughter of William and Marietta Crosby of Tampa, Fla., was married last evening to Arthur John Staple, a son of Nancy K. Fitzpatrick of Hilton Head, S.C., and the late Elliot Staple. Frederick Wiegel, a justice of the peace in Florida, officiated at the Carlouel Yacht Club in Clearwater Beach, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOBAK, ROBERT R.
description: KOBAK-Robert R. Beloved husband of Shirley. Father of Jonathan Kobak and Susan Young. Cherished grandfather of Ellen and Laura Kobak and Jason and Daniel Young. Dear brother of Vivian Barry. Services 11:15 AM, Sunday November 29, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Brodeur and Stevens Turn Back Avalanche
description: Martin Brodeur prevailed again against the Colorado goalie Patrick Roy, the man he idolized as a youth growing up in Montreal. Brodeur kicked and gloved the puck in crucial situations tonight to lead the Devils to a 3-2 victory over the Avalanche at McNichols Arena.

title: Watch for Sale Prices in Retailers' Shares
description: FINDING the right present for your fussy Aunt Agatha may seem a lot easier this Christmas than finding the right retailer in which to invest.

title: Applause and Anxiety In the Age of AIDS
description: A LIVE performance of Mark Dendy's ''Dream Analysis'' at Dance Theater Workshop has catapulted to its conclusion, and the audience is in a decidedly giddy mood. This dance-theater show is a comedy, after all, a thinking person's comedy peopled with multiple Martha Grahams and Vaslav Nijinskys. And it leaves one feeling lighthearted, buoyant, free.

title: Day Care a Priority
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has announced $2.8 million in grants for the creation, expansion and improvement of child day-care programs statewide.

title: N.B.A. May Take Page From the N.H.L. Guide to Labor Peace After a Lockout
description: Just four years ago, there was a grueling and emotional two-day session that saved a season as a deadline passed. The resolution left the insults that had been traded through five months of labor negotiations no more harmful than shots fired in a game of paint ball.

title: Regent and King in a Procession of New Forms
description: FRANK GEHRY has changed Philip Johnson's place in history, and both architects are the beneficiaries. If Mr. Gehry hadn't come along, Mr. Johnson's work might well be remembered as an emblem of a time when American architecture lost its way. His restless rovings from movement to movement and style to style offered giddy architectural entertainment, particularly during his high-flying days of big corporate commissions in the 1980's. But they demoralized many who think that architecture should stand for something more than a flirtation with forms.

title: Expiration Dates
description: Master Georgie

title: Gramercy Park Uses Poison That City Parks Avoid
description: To the Editor:

title: A Familiar Old Pond Still Brings Surprises
description: In late October and early November, my grandson Jesse Child and I went after the young bluefish, or snappers, that had been trapped in Tisbury Great Pond when its opening to the ocean closed in early August. On our first trip we finally found them on a shallow flat against the barrier beach on the pond's west end. They were small, about eight inches long.

title: New Year's Eve Canvases For Painting the Town Red
description: WITH New Year's Eve 1999 looming, it would be easy to dismiss the end of 1998 as a non-event. But for anyone who wants to make this New Year's Eve special by leaving town, traveling to one of the First Night celebrations being planned in 183 American cities this year might be a refreshing alternative.

title: Saints Hope Collins Is Turning His Life Around
description: A crucial step in the evolution of quarterback Kerry Collins came when he recently began counseling for alcohol abuse, according to several National Football League executives and people close to Collins. The quarterback, those people said, is taking drastic steps to change his life.

title: Lending a Hand
description: Travelers who want a truly heartfelt welcome from the strangers they visit should consider one of Cross-Cultural Solutions' volunteer vacations. The nonprofit company organizes three-week trips each month to villages in eastern Ghana and shanty towns in New Delhi. Participants work in health care, education, skills training or arts and recreation; no special skills are required.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: Creatures from a bygone era, a Broadway drama, a star showcase and a royal adventure highlight this week's movie menu.

title: Survivor Aid by 2 Groups Called Slow
description: Two of the Jewish groups that may play a major role in distributing money from the Swiss banks' settlement have had problems in the past getting aid quickly to aging Holocaust survivors.

title: Holiday Opportunities Begin to Accumulate
description: A GLANCE at the week's events should dispel any doubt that the holidays are fast approaching. On Wednesday at 12:35 P.M., the organist Mark Scholtz presents music for Advent at the Grace Episcopal Church in White Plains. His program dovetails Bach's setting of ''Sleepers Wake'' with other works based on the same Lutheran Chorale by Johann Krebs (1713-1780) and the contemporary Dutch composer Piet Kee. The number to call for more information is 949-0384.

title: BEST SELLERS: November 29, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Lighting Up With Ideas For Using Tobacco Money
description: The state's first payment does not arrive until April 15, 2000, but the debate has already begun here at the State House over how to spend the state's share of the $206 billion national tobacco settlement.

title: A New School Bridges Two Worlds
description: One hundred years ago, after the conquest of the West, American Indian schools were founded to encourage assimilation and stamp out indigenous culture. In the second half of this century, American Indian schools took the opposite approach, emphasizing their students' heritage. Neither approach fostered academic success.

title: 'S Gershwin, 'S Previn and 'S Wonderful
description: 'WE GOT RHYTHM: A GERSHWIN SONGBOOK'

title: A Noah Without an Ark
description: The idea: a data base of medical information on line for public consumption. The time: 1994, when the Internet was barely a twinkle in the consciousness of most Americans. The result was NOAH: New York Online Access to Health, a joint project of the City University, the New York Public Library, the New York Academy of Medicine and the Metropolitan Library Council, financed by the United States Department of Commerce.

title: A 70's Accessory Whose Time Has Come
description: IT'S a truism that trends don't seem to exist until they're given a label that gains wide acceptance. Think of Seattle grunge, New York minimalism or winter white.

title: Illusions Shattered in St. Petersburg
description: In this century, this city has made more than its share of history and seen more than its share of blood. It was here in 1917 that the Romanov dynasty fell and the Bolshevik revolution began. The murder here in 1934 of a local Communist commissar unleashed Stalin's campaign of terror, which sent millions to camps in Siberia and to their deaths.

title: In Quest for the Perfect Look, More Girls Choose the Scalpel
description: Standing in front of the full-length mirror, the girl fights back tears. Her thighs are too big, her breasts too small and her nose bumpy. Or so this 16-year-old thinks, comparing herself with ''Baywatch'' babes and Victoria's Secret models.

title: Still Burning To Compete, Daehlie Looks To 2002 Games
description: What do Paavo Nurmi of Finland, Larysa Latynina of the former Soviet Union, and Mark Spitz and Carl Lewis of the United States have in common?

title: L.I.E. Interchange Gets U.S. Design Honors
description: CURSED by rush-hour commuters and those fleeing the Hamptons on summer Sunday afternoons, the Long Island Expressway rarely receives high marks from drivers. But a revamped portion of the much-maligned roadway has just won top design honors from the Federal Highway Administration.

title: Ideas & Trends; Take This Car and Plug It
description: ONCE upon a time, 1998 was going to be the year of the electric car. In 1990 California announced that 2 percent of the automobiles sold in the state by major manufacturers in 1998 would have to be nonpolluting. New York and Massachusetts soon followed suit. The electric car was hailed as the route to clean air and the antidote to dependence on imported oil.

title: Low Wattage
description: Anyone can make a mistake, of course, but most try not to do so when the world is watching. Fear of embarrassment is a strong motive for most business people to double-check carefully anything they write or say for public consumption, like an advertisement or a product announcement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, ELANE
description: FELDMAN-Elane. We mourn the loss of a dear and courageous friend and altogether wonderful human being. A talented writer and publicist, she was the author of ''Going Bananas''; ''The Writer's Guide to Self-Promotion and Publicity'' and ''Fashions of a Decade: The 1990's.'' Our hearts go out to Dan, her loving and devoted husband of almost 35 years. Memorial service Monday, November 30, 1 PM, at Congregation Mount Sinai, Brooklyn Heights. Barbara and Abe Habenstreit

title: Is Solitary Confinement Driving Charlie Chase Crazy?
description: Chase certainly appears to be nuts, and solitary confinement is not at fault. As Porter himself observes, ''Few opponents of solitary confinement would argue for its abolition.'' Chase should be confined to solitary because nothing else has worked -- not incarceration, counseling, drug treatment or hospitalization.

title: Going Beyond Debate Over Assisted Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: Cart Art
description: SURROUNDED by bottles and cans, Robert Williams steers a V-shaped grocery cart -- to which he had tethered 14 plastic crates so it resembles a giant bug with wings -- along York Avenue on the Upper East Side. A former homeless crack addict, Mr. Williams, 41, said he built the cart so he could collect up to 5,000 cans for redemption, but has added many touches, both ornamental and functional. Red flags flap from poles. A felt dog dangles from a string. A tarp bearing the words ''Ernest & Julio Gallo,'' is strung over a broomstick frame to make a roof. A clock is built into a plywood panel, and a radio keeps Mr. Williams company.

title: PULSE; Suitcases Stay Fresher
description: The sign of an overprotective homemaker used to be plastic over the furniture. Now, overprotective travelers can be spotted by the plastic over their luggage. At six airports, including Los Angeles International and Kennedy International (left), SW-66 suitcase wrappers stand near check-in counters to dispense 30-inch tall webs of stretch polyethylene to shield bags from rough handling. At $4 a piece, the shrink wrap is used by those who want to keep the Gucci valise from being scuffed and by less glamorous fliers as an alternative to masking tape. Wendy Perrin, the author of ''Wendy Perrin's Secrets Every Smart Traveler Should Know'' (Fodor's, 1997), recently found her suitcase in the lost-luggage room at La Guardia Airport. ''Its lock had been broken, and it had obviously been rifled through,'' she said. ''That could have been avoided with this plastic wrap.''

title: Sound Is the Point
description: To the Editor:

title: Theodore Newhouse, 95; Helped Build a Communications Empire
description: Theodore Newhouse, who began a lifelong career in publishing as a manager of a family-owned newspaper, The Long Island Press, and helped his brothers assemble one of the nation's biggest communications conglomerates, died yesterday at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in the Riverdale section of the Bronx after a long illness. He was 95.

title: Belgian Chocolate As a Shopper's Pick-Me-Up
description: De Granvelle, a well-situated Belgian chocolate kiosk for those needing a little luxe pick-me-up on a grueling day of holiday shopping, opened last week in the lobby of the Trump Tower, Fifth Avenue near 57th Street. The selection of elegant-looking and wickedly rich chocolates, available by the piece or by the pound ($38 per pound), include three types of truffles and an array of liqueur creams, pralines and cordials. De Granvelle has a store at 347 Madison Avenue (45th Street).

title: Bill Limits Visitation By Sex Offenders
description: Several state Senate committees considered legislation Monday and the Assembly held a voting session. Here are highlights of the actions.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; A Mourning Interrupted
description: Over the course of a few giddy months, Olivia Bertolucci, a stylish 37-year-old milliner living in Manhattan's East Village, falls in love with and marries a charming industrial designer, David Henderson. ''A person doesn't have a right to so much happiness,'' Olivia tells herself one day while they're talking about buying a beachfront vacation cottage in Rhode Island. Naturally, soon after they take up residence, David goes out jogging and is killed by a reckless driver. At first, RUBY (Picador USA, $22) resembles one of those stories in which a tragedy-beset heroine is portrayed as bravely picking up the pieces. But Ann Hood's sly, incisive novel soon breaks free from this familiar ground, deftly exploring the strange rhythms of mourning, the unpredictable and unavoidable demands of sorrow. Months after David's funeral, a grief-numbed Olivia returns to the beach house, intending to tidy the place up before selling it -- only to discover that a pregnant teen-age runaway has taken up residence. Clever and voluble, Ruby quickly explains that she has been shunned both by her mother and stepfather and by the baby's frat-boy father. Olivia formulates a plan that feels to her like fate: She will take Ruby in, care for her and pay her medical bills -- if Ruby will let Olivia adopt the baby. While lies, betrayals and manipulations give the plot its undeniable page-turning pull, Hood's caustic wit, brightly detailed prose and thoughtful delineations of two women struggling with private, powerful regrets supply ''Ruby'' with rich and surprising emotional depths. Megan Harlan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, PAGE WRIGHT
description: SMITH-Page Wright. Of Palm Beach, Florida and Easton, Maryland died November 26th, 1998 at his residence in Palm Beach, Florida. He was 84 years old. He was the son of Paul and Marjorie Smith of Portersville, California. He was a well known hunter and fisherman. A graduate from the University of California, he attended the Naval Flying School in Pensecola, and was employed as a pilot for Pan American Airlines for 30 years. He established many of the current flying routes and made residence in Hong Kong and South America. Mr. Smith was a member of the Everglades Club, as well as the Palm Beach Bath and Tennis Club. He is survived by his wife, Jane Will Smith; three stepchildren, Brenda Callaway of Palm Beach, Jayne Keith of Palm Beach, and Walter Teagle of New York; and eight step-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am, on December 21, 1998, at the Episcopal Church of Bethesda-by-the-Sea, 141 South County Road, Palm Beach, Florida. Memorial donations may be made to the Animal Rescue League, 3200 North Military Trail, West Palm Beach, Florida 33409. Quattlebaum - Holleman - Burse Funeral Home, 1201 South Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach.

title: Family Follows the Recovery of a Fallen Rider
description: In a box in the stands at the small, handsome Springdale Race Course in Camden, S.C., last Sunday afternoon, a sweet, sunny day, Beasie Patterson, was watching her daughter, Bitsy, ride Raptor in an early steeplechase race, a prelude to the big race later in the day. Bitsy would ride Flat Top, a candidate for the Eclipse Award as steeplechasing's horse of the year, in the $100,000 Marion duPont Scott Colonial Cup.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPER, MURRAY, DDS.
description: SAPER-Murray, DDS. On November 21, 1998. The officers, directors, members and staff of The New York County Dental Society mourn the passing of their distinguished colleague, friend and past president. Murray's warmth, humility and love of the profession, his unselfish devotion to family, friends and community, combined to establish him as a man of honor and integrity. We wish to express our sympathy to his family on their loss. Jeffrey R. Burkes, DDS, President, NYCDS Mitchell G. Kuhn, Executive Director, NYCDS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIX, ANNE MASTERSON
description: NIX-Anne Masterson. On November 25, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Jack Nix. Loving mother of Barbara, Jack, and Joan. Devoted grandmother of Brian, Darren, the late Meryl, Courtney, and Kelly. Dear sister of Rita. We will always love you.

title: Protecting Forests In Private Hands
description: The article (''The Education of 35,000 Landowners,'' Nov. 8) touched on one of the most compelling but least known environmental issues of our times. Nearly half of America's 737 million acres of forest belongs to 9 million private landowners. Their actions as stewards of the land will determine in large part whether America's natural resources will flourish or fade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, MIRIAM
description: GOODMAN-Miriam. Of Boca Raton, FL, on November 27, 1998. Beloved wife of Samuel. Adored mother of Joan and David Sloan, Toni and Arnold Berliner. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother of Deborah Sloan and Richard Gang, Pamela and Andrew Karpen, Jennifer and Bo Laraia, Alison Berliner and Matthew Berliner, Marin, Sabine, Joshua and Zachary. Services on Monday, November 30, at 12:30 PM, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Paramus, NJ. In lieu of flowers, it is requested that contributions be made to Hospice.

title: Fantasy Arrives on Track 2
description: FIRST the bad news. You won't be able to get a seat on these trains -- but you're likely to enjoy the ride. Both the New York Botanical Garden and the Citicorp Center are celebrating the holiday season with model train exhibitions. Now through Jan. 10 at the botanical garden, 10 trains on more than 1,000 feet of track will weave through winter landscapes of castles, streams, rivers, mountains and New York landmarks, including a Brooklyn Bridge of birch bark and spruce cones. Tuesdays through Sundays from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. at 200th Street and Kazimiroff Boulevard in the Bronx. $6.50 for adults, $2.50 for children 2 to 12, and $4 for students and those over 65; (718) 817-8700.

title: At the Ballet
description: To the Editor:

title: Trojans Play the Spoiler to the Depleted Irish
description: With a nimble spin move and a quick burst, Chad Morton, Southern California's junior tailback, breathed life into what had been a mind-numbing defensive struggle between U.S.C. and Notre Dame tonight.

title: Los Angeles Alternative
description: Los Angeles is developing its underground: first a subway, and now a magazine catering to sub-mainstream culture. Glue, which comes out every other month, covers the alternative scene of East Los Angeles, ''cultural stuff that just slips through the cracks,'' said Laurie Pike, its editor in chief and owner.

title: Ruling That Saved Grand Central
description: To the Editor:

title: Jewish Groups Fight for Spoils Of Swiss Case
description: A battle is flaring between Jewish humanitarian groups, plaintiffs' lawyers and concentration camp survivors over the $1.25 billion paid by Swiss banks to settle Holocaust-related lawsuits, and potentially billions more from claims against companies in Germany, Austria and other countries.

title: Mets Miss Chance
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Facing a Potential Shortage, U.S. Considers Making Tritium
description: A potential shortage of tritium, a crucial ingredient of every nuclear weapon, has prompted the Department of Energy to consider whether to recommend starting one of the department's rare public-works-style projects to manufacture more of the radioactive gas.

title: Going Beyond Debate Over Assisted Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Oldsmobile Silhouette Premiere; The Minivan With In-Flight Movies
description: PUTTING televisions and videocassette players in vans is nothing new. Builders of custom vans have been doing it for years. But buying a custom van has often meant accepting all that goes with it: crushed velour curtains, for instance.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Toward The Sun

title: Civil Rights Leader Got Some Help at Terminal
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns; Suburbanites Heed the Call Of the City
description: SEVERAL years ago, John Acierno woke up in his four-bedroom Colonial in the prosperous Long Island community of Manhasset with the kind of primal scream heard in a growing number of suburban homes these days: ''What am I doing out here?''

title: More Than Hunting, It's Love of Wildlife
description: In ''As Hunters Stalk Deer, Critics Take Their Shots'' [Nov. 1], an opponent of hunting, John Turner, raises the question: why would anyone want to experience wildlife by killing? It is a good question, one that I have asked and up to just a few years ago not understood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBER, ALEXANDER
description: LEBER-Alexander. Friend and lover. Hero. Cherished life mate of Adam Waitt. Born Wiesbaden, March 19th, 1952. Son of Angelika. Brother of Thomas. Uncle of Simon. This most wondrous of German imports, Alex, had an unyielding passion for life. His courage and dignity awe inspiring. Death came peacefully on November 25th at his home in New York. We are grateful for your life, Alex. Goodnight, sweet prince.

title: Revenue Streams From an Old Source
description: IN a cavern cut deep into the granite bedrock of the Berkshires, two huge turbines spin, powered by two million gallons of water plunging 740 feet a minute through huge pipes from one reservoir on the Deerfield River to another. During the day, the turbines of the Bear Swamp hydroelectric plant produce up to 600 megawatts of electricity, enough to serve a small city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLEMOWITZ, ABRAM
description: SCHLEMOWITZ-Abram. Age 88. Sculptor and teacher. Died on November 13, after a long illness. He is missed by his wife Carol, his sons Henry Sanders, Peter, Jerry, Joel and Carl, his daughter Cili Shannon, his five grandchildren and one great-grandchild, his brother Leo and nephew Peter.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE AUTOBIOGRAPHY

title: Songwriters' Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Israel and the Bomb'
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Newman, Mr. Donath
description: Samantha Newman, a daughter of Jennifer and Peter Newman of Palma de Majorca, was married last evening to Dirk Donath, a son of Mariel and Eric Donath of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Manes Kogan officiated at Studio 450 in New York.

title: From Falling To Runaway In One Year
description: Andy Powell, who crawled across the finish line last year after collapsing with exhaustion, raced to victory yesterday in the Foot Locker Northeast Regional High School Cross-Country Championship at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Sunshine on UConn's Shoulders in Playoffs
description: Overshadowed for years by the school's successful basketball programs, the University of Connecticut football team finally got its day in the sun today.

description: The hereditary peers of the House of Lords got their eviction notice from the Queen herself while seated in their ermine-trimmed scarlet robes.

title: Sagaponack Seeks Its Independence
description: A GROUP of Sagaponack residents hope to incorporate their hamlet into a village, freeing them from the control of Southampton Town and enabling them to make sure that Ira Rennert's massive new home conforms to zoning regulations.

title: Cafe Offers a Taste of the East in Armonk
description: ON weekend evenings, it seems as though all of northern Westchester has discovered this third restaurant under the charge of Simpson Kalathara and his family. (India House in Montrose and Bengal Tiger in White Plains are the others.) Once occupied by Maddelena's, this new establishment sets the stage simply. What is there, however, is suggestion enough of the East. We were told that more atmospheric decor is planned in the near future.

title: The Merry Pranksters
description: Take a cue from the guys in green, and begin the holidays with happy feet.

title: Dodging Hippos on the Zambezi
description: THERE is a certain sense of grace I experience in the presence of wild animals, a peacefulness even, and whenever I return to Southern Africa, where I grew up, I seek out safaris that will take me deep into the wilderness.

title: The View From/Collin's Diner, Canaan; Giving a Voice to Poetry, Lebanese Zest to a Menu
description: COLLIN'S DINER of Canaan is a traditional place. The National Historic Landmark, built in 1941, is also a local landmark in the village's restored railroad depot center. The diner, which is open seven days a week, attracts plenty of regulars as well as travelers on Route 7.
