title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Valley Cottage, N.Y.; A Diverse, Close-In Rural Hamlet
description: WHEN Chinazo and Everett Cunningham began to feel a little cramped in their 1920's colonial in Nyack they looked for a bigger house on a quieter street in the same neighborhood.

title: Liberties; Sex And Self-Pity
description: I go to work, and I feel trapped in Bill Clinton's libido.

title: Awakening From a Football Slumber
description: This city has never really loved them, not the way Cleveland used to love its Browns, when it had them, or the way Pittsburgh loves the Steelers, and certainly not the way Green Bay loves its Packers. But then, as the cliche goes, it is easy to love a winner, even if the trophies have dust on them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOIACONO, MARGERY M.
description: LOIACONO-Margery M. Age 73, a longtime Fairfield, CT resident, formerly of New York passed away at her home on November 28, 1998 after a long battle with cancer. Born in Cheertsey, England, she saw service in the Women's Land Army in WW II, where she met and later married her husband at war's end and came to this country as a war bride in 1946. She is survived by her loving husband, Joseph; her daughters, Elizabeth and her husband, Dr. William Jones of Silver Springs, MD, and Madeline Warner of Fairfield, CT; her three sons, Nicholas and his wife, Lisa of San Francisco, CA, Joseph Jr. and his wife, Grace Paradise, and John of New York; her grandchildren, Daniel and Dr. Colin Shafer of Denver, CO, Bradley and H.B. Warner of Fairfield, CT, Francis X. and Christina Loiacono of New York and Hannah Loiacono of San Francisco, CA; her sister, Kay Pascoe and nieces, Jennifer and Gillian of Cornwall, England; her brother and his wife, Leonard Jeyer and Carroll of Yeovil, England. For information contact Shaughnessey Funeral Home, 50 Reef Rd., Fairfield, CT.

title: A Rousing Chorus Of the Song That Kept People Going
description: THE African work chant in the beginning is accompanied by pictures of advertisements offering ''the highest price,'' cash, for men, women and children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANKIN, DAVID S.
description: MANKIN-David S. After a brave, courageous fight battling cancer. Beloved husband of Janey. Devoted father of Beth, Mitchell and Howard. Cherished grandfather of Joshua, Elliot and Paige. Loving brother-in-law of Debbie, uncle of Judy, and many other relatives and dear close friends. Services Monday, 11 AM, at Temple Beth El, Old Mill Rd., Great Neck. David, your wings are ready.

title: New Invader on the Dance Floor
description: THE Esperanto of electronic dance music, trance is probably the most popular rave sound in the world. Although this kinetic, hypnotic music has maintained a presence on the American rave scene since the style emerged in the mid-90's, trance seems to be rising to a new level of prominence in this country.

title: For Dirt and Armchair Gardeners Alike
description: NOT all of a gardener's tools require sharpening, oiling and stowing for the winter. Some of them, in fact, get their heaviest workout in the off-season: a gardener's books. Many a winter's evening is happily spent leafing through the library when nothing else is in leaf.

title: A Holiday Confection Is Back on Its Toes
description: YEARS ago, during a workshop that George Balanchine conducted for choreographers, Jane Miller Gifford heard some memorable words from the founder of the New York City Ballet.

title: MUSIC; Seeing Broadway As Fertile Ground
description: FOR Stephen Sondheim, the most haunting ghost from the original Broadway production of ''Follies,'' a show awash in specters, was the cast album that got away. As he recently described it, a single-LP release put out in April, 1971 ''omitted part of the score, truncated other parts, and was poorly recorded.''

title: Physics for Immovable Objects (Students)
description: ASSIGNMENT: Invent or adapt a sport to be played on the moon to help future astronauts stay in shape.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIZEMORE, JOHN RANDALL
description: SIZEMORE-John Randall. Of New York City and East Hampton, died of AIDS at his Manhattan residence on November 27, 1998. He was 48 years old. Mr. Sizemore was the beloved partner for 25 years of Norbert Alan Anuskiewicz, as well as a devoted brother to Saundra Joe Sizemore of Southfield, Michigan, and loving son of Betty Gable Sizemore of Cullman, Alabama. Mr. Sizemore was an alumnus of Wayne State University, Michigan and worked for many years in Editorial Operations at ''Fortune'' magazine. Respects may be paid at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Saturday, November 28th from 2:004:00PM and 7:00-9:00PM. Funeral services will be at Dovin Funeral Home in Lorain, Ohio on Monday, November 30th with interment at Calvary Cemetery in that city. In lieu of flowers, it is requested that contributions be made to S.A.G.E., 212-741-2247.

title: Going Beyond Debate Over Assisted Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINT, MYRA (AUERBACH)
description: QUINT-Myra (Auerbach). Of Tucson, Arizona. Loving wife of the late Allan. Beloved mother of Larry and Eileen and Bruce Bernfeld. Devoted Nana of Susannah.

title: The Patron Saint Of Paradox
description: I read Dorothy Day's obituary in The New York Times when I was a sophomore at Fordham University (Paul Elie, Nov. 8). I count the five minutes I spent reading that obituary as perhaps the beginning of my lifelong conversion to an adult Catholicism. I was deeply moved that one woman could have so much courage and commitment to act on her faith, and not in a holier-than-thou manner, but rather with humility and an appreciation for the secular world while understanding its limitations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OVADICK, RUTH (NEE ROSENBAUM)
description: OVADICK-Ruth (nee Rosenbaum). On November 10. Of Delray Beach, FL. Devoted wife of Manny. The entire family deeply mourns her passing. She will be in our thoughts and prayers always.

title: Not Quite a 'Maker'
description: To the Editor:

title: It Tells Time? Who Cares.
description: The Spring Street Wine Shop in SoHo has a good selection of vintage items for sale. A bottle of 1978 Chateau Petrus Bordeaux, for example, goes for $760, and a bottle of Louis XV Cognac for $1,100. But the most valuable vintage in the shop is not a wine or spirit, it's a wall clock: a multicolored ball clock, designed by George Nelson and introduced in 1947 by the Howard Miller Clock Company at a cost of $30. While ball clocks are fairly common, this one, with its now-faded blue, green, orange and black balls, is quite rare, and in today's frenzied market for 1950's home furnishings, could fetch as much as $2,000.

title: Backtalk; Seizing Control, Even in Hartford
description: George Steinbrenner, Robert Kraft, Billie Jean King and Martin Jacobson tucked into full plates last week. Whether or not we join them in giving thanks is irrelevant; we don't sit at their tables.

title: Is Solitary Confinement Driving Charlie Chase Crazy?
description: While reading your article on Charlie Chase, I couldn't help thinking that if this were the account of a prisoner of war, we would be praising Chase for his resistance and spirit. Maybe the Massachusetts Department of Corrections could do a better job of persuading Chase that it is not the enemy.

title: Is Solitary Confinement Driving Charlie Chase Crazy?
description: The New York State Penitentiary at Auburn was opened in 1819. Two years later, administrators devised a bold experiment: 80 hardened criminals would be placed in solitary confinement and enforced idleness. The correctional thesis was that this would engender restored character and penitent behavior. Instead, so many committed suicide, succumbed to chronic illness or went mad that the experiment was ended and most survivors were paroled.

title: Traffic Corridors
description: County Executive Andrew J. Spano has announced that the New York Metropolitan Transportation Council recently selected the Route 202-Route 35 and the Route 9A-Route 119 traffic corridors for pilot studies on land use and transportation problems.

title: A Fake Tree Grows In Chelsea
description: THE new Hammacher Schlemmer catalogue is selling aluminum Christmas trees with rotating electric-light wheels that change the color of the tree every seven seconds. The odd thing is not that these gaudy inorganic trees are back in production, it's that I desperately want one. After a decade of celebrating a tasteful Christmas with freshly cut evergreens, I'm craving the over-the-top holiday artifice of my youth.

title: A Nibble of Caledonia in Africa
description: I AM nominally Scottish.

title: INVESTING WITH: Howard B. Moss; Harbor International Growth Fund
description: Y the time Howard B. Moss enrolled at the University of Liverpool in 1966, the Beatles had left town, moving out into the big wide world.

title: In Albany, Quiet Clamor For a Raise
description: With the cheery distractions of the holiday season at hand and even the most dedicated lobbyists paying scant attention to the business of state government, what better time for New York State lawmakers to take up an issue that has long inflamed voters -- legislative pay raises.

title: Judith Kelman, Ivan Wolff
description: Judith Kelman, a suspense novelist, and Ivan L. Wolff, a venture capital specialist, both in New York, are to be married this afternoon by Rabbi Yaacov Rone at the Carlyle Hotel in New York.

title: Zut Alors! An Eiffel Tower and a Landlord Dour
description: A bit of Paris has popped up for the holiday season on West 19th Street, in the form of a gaily lighted, garland-festooned, 30-foot Eiffel Tower. But not everyone is saying bienvenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDLER, CLARA SCHWARTZMAN
description: HANDLER-Clara Schwartzman, 88. Devoted sister of Sara Kaufman, loving aunt of Carol and Henry, doting grandaunt of Erica, widow of Leo for nearly half a century, riveter of ships in World War 11, bookkeeper by profession, seamstress, clothing designer and artist by avocation, published poet and author of a rich legacy of letters, inveterate European traveler, peripatetic aficionado of New York City's boundless offerings, with a style, mind and opinions always of her own, passed away peacefully at her home in Manhattan on Thanksgiving Day. Donations in lieu of flowers to the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: Circles Yield to Obsolescence
description: Before jug handles and Jersey barriers, freeways and toll roads (not to mention EZ-Pass), cloverleafs and flyover ramps there was the majestic, geometrically correct traffic circle.

title: Home Is Where Heart, And Jobs, Are
description: IAN HAMEROFF was a typical Rocky Point teenager who liked music, movies, and cruising on the Long Island Expressway, where he regularly drove by a sign near exit 58 that said ''Future Home of Computer Associates.''

title: Fast Forward; Please Hold For the. ...
description: This being 1998, i have a machine attached to my telephone line that answers the phone when I'm not there and records messages. (Let's call it an ''answering machine.'') So a woman identifying herself as ''Lisa,'' a Bell Atlantic sales representative, is able to tell me it is ''imperative'' that I get in touch with her right away. But how, Lisa? You work for that great black hole of modern communications, the telephone company.

title: Q and A
description: Bristol's Slave Trail

title: Cabby Hits Officer's Car to Foil a Robbery
description: A Brooklyn livery-cab driver thwarted a robbery by running a red light and hitting an off-duty police officer's car on Friday night, the police said.

title: Lisa Jassey, Kenneth Salzman
description: Lisa Rebecca Jassey and Kenneth Seth Salzman were married yesterday in New York. Rabbi Alex J. Goldman officiated at the Plaza.

title: An Insurance Benefit You May Never See
description: That big windfall you may have been counting on to help celebrate your 100th birthday seems likely to vanish.

title: The World: Smokescreen; The Ifs and Buts of the Tobacco Settlement
description: LAST week's $206 billion settlement between the tobacco industry and 46 states is supposed to put Big Tobacco on the run. The agreement requires cigarette makers to compensate states for the medical costs of treating smoking-related diseases. It's been hailed as a triumph of the public interest over special interests. But a closer look at the hard economics behind the agreement reveals something quite different.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLADON, SYLVIA MIRIAM (NEE GOLDSTEIN)
description: SLADON-Sylvia Miriam (nee Goldstein). Of New York and Florida, on Wednesday, November 25, 1998. Beloved wife of Sidney; loving mother of Judith, Carole Witpen, and the late Kenneth; adored grandmother of Elizabeth Witpen; loving sister and sister-in-law of Norma and Robert Katzenoff, and sister-in-law of Ruth Goldstein and sister of the late Seymour Goldstein. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave., 9:45 AM, Monday, November 30.

title: Stock Tournaments Find Ready Combatants in Younger Generation
description: PETER LYNCH, the mutual fund manager and stock investment analyst, wrote a book with John Rothchild, former financial columnist for Time, called ''One Up on Wall Street'' (Simon & Schuster). In it, he told about venturing into an elementary school where he interviewed youngsters on their favorite products: clothing, foods, toys. He then made investments based on those conversations. The result was alchemy. Mr. Lynch profited nicely.

title: Brynn O'Neill and Joe VanSchaick
description: Brynn Elizabeth O'Neill, the daughter of Mary Jo O'Neill of Westfield, N.J., and Leo C. O'Neill of New York, was married yesterday to Francis Joseph VanSchaick, a son of Mary and Francis G. VanSchaick of Wake Forest, N.C. The Rev. Marc A. Vicari performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Sorrows Roman Catholic Church in South Orange, N.J.

title: Home and Not Alone: a Foster Care Program for Grown-Ups
description: It's such an ordinary thing, really. A 71-year-old-man named Alphonse Oliva is sitting at a table in a house on a sunlit morning. A cat named Boo Boo jumps onto the table and leans his nose toward him. The man's angular features soften. He smiles sweetly, like a boy, and touches the cat's face with great tenderness.

title: What's Behind The Gush Of Oil Deals?
description: TIMES are tough in the oil patch. Still, it boggles the mind to accept the notion that hardship is driving profitable Big Oil to either merge, as British Petroleum and Amoco have already agreed to do, or at least to consider the prospect, as Exxon and Mobil are doing.

title: Corrections
description: The art reviews column on page 24 of the Long Island section today carries an incorrect byline. It is by Phyllis Braff, not Helen A. Harrison.

title: Chinese Buffet That's Sure to Satisfy
description: MY friend Irv loves Chinese food, buffets and bargains and Irv is not the only one. A fast-building wave of huge, all-you-can-eat Chinese buffets is moving across the Island and being greeted with almost instant success.

title: INSIDE
description: Fairy Tales With Bite

title: Food; Pass the Goulash
description: Looking like a tiny, white-haired beacon in a blizzard of chopping knives and steaming pots, Olga Peters stood in her small-town kitchen and delighted in the chaos enveloping her Formica counters and four-burner stove.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, HARRIET (NEE HOBERMAN)
description: BERNSTEIN-Harriet (nee Hoberman). Died November 28, 1998, peacefully, of Manhattan, West Palm Beach and the Berkshires. Will be dearly missed by those who loved and knew her. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Devoted mother of Myra and Michael Tweedy and Fran and Robert Krivit. Adored grandmother of Shana and Jeremy Tweedy, Illyana and Sam Krivit, Joshua, Robert and Melissa Bernstein. Loving sister of Kenneth and Tammy Hoberman. Her wisdom, guidance and loving presence will be sorely missed. Services today, November 29, 9:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: When One's Mouth Is Set for Seafood
description: OCEAN 211, a stylish new restaurant in Stamford, telegraphs its menu in its name: Ocean. Only two entrees on the short snappy menu (which changes daily) are non-seaworthy.

title: Grace Mulvihill, Robert Miller 3d
description: Grace Marie Mulvihill, an associate producer for ''Dateline NBC'' in New York, was married yesterday to Robert Jackson Miller 3d, an associate at Michael Graves Architect in New York. Msgr. Kenneth W. Roeltgen officiated at the Little Flower Church in Bethesda, Md.

title: Multiplex. Octoplex. Just Plain Perplexed.
description: NO, it's not just your imagination; we're being plexed to death. New Jersey now has one movie theater for every 3.6 residents. By the end of this year the state will have more square feet of movie screen than of public park, library, cornfield and classroom combined.

title: Biking for a Cause, and Kate
description: Ask Josiah Hobson, 29, about Kate Peterson, 3 1/2, and his eyes light up. ''The first time I met her,'' he said, ''it was love at first sight.''

title: Vision of the Void Behind the California Sun
description: THE first time Europeans got a good look at avant-garde New York painting, it was called American painting. The year was 1958 and the Museum of Modern Art's touring exhibition, ''The New American Painting,'' with works by artists like Willem de Kooning and Jackson Pollock, announced to eight European countries that the art world's power center had shifted west across the Atlantic.

title: Crime
description: Martha Grimes doesn't write them fast enough for me, so you'll excuse me while I savor for a minute the quirky charms of her new Richard Jury mystery, THE STARGAZEY (Holt, $25). There's the authentic English pub, of course, that gives the novel its title and a hint of its mood. This time, it's a spiffy neighborhood hangout in Fulham, a once seedy area newly gentrified by ''the chattering classes'' where Jury first catches sight of an elegant blond woman in a sable coat who disappears (perhaps to be murdered) on the grounds of Fulham Palace. Then there are the wondrously eccentric characters, including one grand old dame (the former owner of the sable coat) and a supremely self-centered little girl named Pansy. Finally, there are all the witty particulars that surface at the oddest times. ''Most people don't notice little things like this,'' a barmaid says to Jury about a curious postcard of a fish pie. ''You miss a lot in life if you don't notice little things.''

title: Competition and the Internet
description: To the Editor:

title: Shake-Up Fails to Stir Islanders' Offense
description: Mike Milbury shuffled the Islanders' forward lines and scratched two ineffective wings today in an effort to get more production from an offense that has suddenly slumped.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRLICH, ALEX
description: EHRLICH-Alex. In loving memory of Alex Ehrlich, the kindest, gentlest, sweetest man the world has known who will be greatly missed by his wife Gert, his sons Kenny & Andy, daughters-in-law Melinda and Marie and sister Rosalin and brothers Bob and Manny and grandsons Jay, Matthew & Mark who will always remember Poppy Al. He will also be missed by the Dropkin and Sheinberg families. Funeral services will be held today 12:15 at ''The Riverside'', 76th and Amsterdam.

title: From News Correspondent To the Witticisms of Talk TV
description: OST weekday mornings begin in much the same way for Meredith Vieira, moderator of the morning television talk show ''The View'' on ABC. First, there is a race to get the children out of bed, dressed for school and out of the house. Ms. Vieira plays the quarterback in this confusion, calling out directions. She then feeds the cats and dog and, dressed in jeans, shirt and a bomber jacket, hops in the car sent to her house at the same time each day. If one or more of her three children misses the bus, there is a stop at their school, then a stop for a second cup of coffee, and then into Manhattan to the studio where ''The View'' is taped before a live audience.

title: Teachers Lose Their Free Parking in a No-Parking Zone
description: Since 1995, when the Beacon School first opened, its teachers have enjoyed using the dozen or so parking spaces next to the high school even though it is a no-parking zone.

title: Yes, It's a Commune. Yes, It's on Staten Island.
description: MILDRED GORDON is an obsessive coupon clipper. Like a gambler addicted to The Daily Racing Form, she spends every morning poring over supermarket circulars and penny savers, jotting down sales and two-for-one giveaways. ''I watch money like a hawk,'' she said last week as she hunted for Thanksgiving bargains, noting particularly good deals on cashews, grapefruit and turkeys.

title: Sounds Heard in the Shimmering Bubble of the Present
description: WHILE listening to David Robertson conduct the Juilliard Orchestra recently in Gyorgy Ligeti's ''Atmo spheres'' -- a remarkable performance, by the way -- I started to understand something of the difference between live and recorded music. The orchestra got to that point where the sound becomes a kind of buzzing, and here -- with the piece's dynamic variation projected as strongly as its continuity, and the noise now quite loud -- the effect vividly called to mind the composer's reference of his music to a childhood dream: he was in bed, and his room was filled with a spider's web in which candles, damp cushions and insects were all held. Sometimes in this dream, he recalled, a cushion would tumble, the web would lurch, and some beetles would be set free for a moment, only to get themselves caught up again and emit ''a stifling buzz.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGLETON, GREEN, ALLAN
description: SINGLETON-GREEN-Allan. On November 24, 1998. Devoted husband of Patti Gill, loving father of Allanby and Hilary. Born in Manchester, England, raised in Yorkshire. Graduate of Hymer's College in Hull, the University of Cambridge (Clare College in 1951, with Honors) and Harvard Business School in 1953. Served as a Radio Engineer in the Royal Navy. Retired after 34 years as a Management Consultant and Actuary at Metropolitan Life Insuance Company. Securities firms Consultant and Professor of Mathematics at New York University, Pace University, Baruch College, Lehman College and the College of Insurance. His formidable knowledge, razor sharp wit, unique perspective, and exemplary decency will be sorely missed. A private family gathering celebrated his life on November 28, 1998. Donations in his memory may be made to the Cancer Research Institute.

title: European Deals Glow in the Dark
description: IT is the season of short, dark days, the time when the price drops for a weekend in Europe. If you have some uncommitted money and a valid passport, you can at least get a look at different scenery.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on Nov. 15 about Tino's, a restaurant owned by Tino Scarpa, misstated the address of Orsini's, a restaurant he managed from 1966 to 1972. It was at 41 West 56th Street, not West 46th.

title: Nature-Loving Indians Turn Poachers Into Prey
description: So the legend goes, 363 nature-loving Bishnoi villagers had their heads lopped off in 1730 as they hugged their beloved trees. A local maharajah had sent his army to cut timber, and when a woman named Amrita Devi stood in their way, soldiers decapitated her and threatened to do the same to anyone else so bold. Hundreds of others then embraced the trees in a sequence of defiant sacrifice.

title: Allan Johnson, 82, Who Led Saks in an Era of Expansion
description: Allan Raymond Johnson, a former chairman of Saks Fifth Avenue who helped shepherd the elegant department store through an era of rapid expansion, died on Thanksgiving Day at the Mary Manning Walsh nursing home in Manhattan. He was 82 and had lived in Manhattan.

title: Clusters of Treasures To Clothe the Soul
description: IN 1955, Oppi Untracht, a New Yorker who now lives in Finland, was spellbound by an exhibition of Indian textiles and jewelry he saw at the Museum of Modern Art. Since then Mr. Untracht (often with his wife, the Finnish glass designer Saara Hopea, who died in 1984) has spent years traveling the highways and byways of the subcontinent, studying jewelry-making techniques and buying jewelry. Trained as a photographer by Berenice Abbott, he also photographed people he encountered wearing their ritualistic finery.

title: Q. & A.
description: Making A 2-Family A 4-Family

title: Hello, Canada
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-27

title: Takeover Is Ordered At Troubled Union; Leader Steps Aside
description: The parent union of New York City's District Council 37 said yesterday that it was taking direct control of the 120,000-member council as of tomorrow in an effort to end a spiraling scandal that has involved vote fraud and embezzlement.

title: V.A.T. Refunds
description: To the Editor: Sometimes I am in the European Union months at a time on business, and it is my impression that the various jurisdictions try to weasel out of V.A.T. refunding (''V.A.T. Refunds: Vexations Added,'' Oct. 11).

title: The Patron Saint Of Paradox
description: Speaking for the Catholic right, Cardinal George of Chicago said that Dorothy Day never criticized ''the structure of the church.'' Speaking for the Catholic left, Robert Ellsberg said, ''People feel Dorothy's too good for the church.'' Speaking for herself, Day wrote: ''I loved the church for Christ made visible. Not for itself, because it was so often a scandal to me.''

title: ONE FOR ALL
description: Here's an interesting twist in gender equality: an ''Ally McBeal''-style unisex bathroom at, of all places, a metal-distribution company in Connecticut. Yarde Metals has just announced plans to install a unisex bathroom in a new facility going up in Bristol. ''It started off as a little bit of a joke,'' says Craig Yarde, the company president, ''but we think it sends a message that we're all in this together.'' The one-stop bathroom, which will feature a common hand-washing area with private stalls, is inspired by the Fox network show wherein annoyingly whimsical lawyers debate life's mysteries in a unisex bathroom. It might even be a trend. According to Andrew DuBrin, an industrial psychologist, space planners find that unisex facilities are increasingly popular among workers. ''Bathroom hand-washing among men has declined quite a bit in recent decades,'' he says, pointing to one possible benefit. ''Maybe this would get them to change that.''

title: Seeking Help For a Child Who Is Anxious
description: MAYBE it is a preschooler who suddenly decides not to get out of the car to go to nursery school unless her mother sings a certain song. Or it may be a third grader reluctant to leave home until he has made sure that all his toys are lined up on his bedroom shelves. Sometimes it can be a high school student unable to attend classes because he has to retrace his steps throughout the building before moving on.

title: Corrections
description: The Your Home column last Sunday, about co-op buildings on leased land, misattributed observations on the implications of such ownership. The comments attributed to Alan Kucker were from Andrew Brucker. (Mr. Kucker, another real-estate specialist, was interviewed for a different article.)

title: The Thanks From Three Tables
description: MARIANNE YOORS, Sharon Mear and Bill Hanousek, three Copers, each gave thanks last week for the small victories that give the strength to push on.

title: SOAPBOX; Let 500 Towns Bloom
description: HOME RULE, the near-absolute autonomy of each of the state's nearly 600 towns, is commonly believed to be an ancient political doctrine practiced by Jerseymen since Colonial times. But in fact, home rule's origins are much more recent.

title: Monicagate: Who Knew What, When?; Equal Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: Helen H. Malsed, 88, Creator of Slinky Toys
description: Helen Herrick Malsed, a lumber baron's daughter whose imagination gave rise to the popular Slinky Dog and Slinky Train toys, died Nov. 13 in Seattle, her home for almost 60 years. She was 88.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Festival of Trees

title: When Big Fish Eat Little Fish
description: News that Exxon and Mobil, two giants in the energy patch, were in merger talks last week is the biggest sign yet that corporate marriages are back in vogue. Even before that combination came to light, deal-making was fast and furious. On Monday alone, $40.4 billion in corporate acquisitions were either announced or declared imminent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDER, SIDNEY
description: BENDER-Sidney. Age 74. On November 26, 1998. Loving husband of Helen for 49 years. Cherished father of Rona & Arty, Bruce & Amy. Loving grandfather of Daniel, Pamela & Rebecca. Dear brother of Alice Stone. Beloved brother-in-law and uncle. His presence will be sorely missed.

title: Up And Coming: Penelope Cruz; A Spanish Siren, Heading West
description: SCREEN beauties are hardly a novelty, but even within the realm of celluloid sirens, the Spanish actress Penelope Cruz elicits unusual adoration from her directors.

title: Stuart Sutherland Dies at 71; Psychologist Told of His Illness
description: Stuart Sutherland, a British psychologist who analyzed his own brush with mental illness in the most remarkable of his insightful books, died on Nov. 8 in his home in Brighton, England. He was 71.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYARSKY, BEATRICE
description: BOYARSKY-Beatrice. Beloved wife of Irving. Devoted mother of Jerry, Allan and Neal. Loving grandmother of eight and greatgrandmother. Dear sister of Lillian Horowitz. Service today, 1:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMPTON, HENRY
description: HAMPTON-Henry. The Board and staff of the Charles H. Revson Foundation deeply mourn the passing of our Board member, colleague, and friend, Henry Hampton. Henry brought to the craft of film making the conviction of the educator, the eye of the artist, the subtle intelligence of the historian, the determination of the inspired messenger. His masterpiece documentary of the Civil Rights era, ''Eyes on the Prize,'' will endure as the definitive visual history of that mid-twentieth century struggle, and will inform and inspire generations of young people around the world into the next century. A quiet man, whose humanism radiated from his entire being, Henry's capacity for empathy and friendship ran deep. The nation has lost a great filmmaker; those of us who knew him have also lost a respected colleague and an unforgettable friend. Charles H. Revson Foundation Robert S. Rifkind, Chairman Eli N. Evans, President

title: Oysters R Not in Season Because of Parasites . . .
description: THESE are lean times for Long Island's oystermen. Just four years ago, oysters were so plentiful along the western half of the North Shore that hundreds could be dredged in a few hours, but beginning last year, two microscopic parasite pests have virtually wiped out oysters and the local industry that depends on them.

title: Wings Meet Deadly Glass
description: Two migrating black-eyed juncos flew toward 4 World Financial Center, where the yellow-orange morning light and the shimmering Hudson River reflected off the tower's windows. Standing in front of the building, Rebekah Creshkoff pointed to the birds as they flew above her head. A moment later Mona Payton gasped, as one bird hooked to the left, and the other flew straight. ''Oh God, he just hit the glass!'' she said.

title: Tempest Over Princeton Teacher
description: ''Infanticide at Princeton,'' read posters papering bulletin boards and lampposts across the Princeton University campus this fall.

title: A Passion for Old Bicycles Spun Into a Museum
description: Most people don't give a second glance to the rusty old bicycles offered at garage sales. To David Metz, however, a discarded bicycle is a piece of history. This antiques collector has 137 bicycles, the oldest dating from 1851. Museums from the United States and Europe have asked to purchase many of his pieces.

title: A Role in Movies
description: To the editor:

title: Melissa Manes, Michael Collett
description: Melissa Rachel Manes, a daughter of Barbara Manes and Dr. Harvey Manes of Melville, N.Y., is to be married today to Michael John Collett, a son of Bridget and John Collett of Bristol, England. Rabbi Helen Freeman is to perform the ceremony at the Liberal Jewish Synagogue in London.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHOLAKIS, JOHN ELIAS
description: CHOLAKIS-John Elias. Died at home November 27. Beloved husband of Betty Cholakis. Loving father of Elia Cholakis. Loving brother of Elly Koustefanou and her family. Memorial service to be anounced.

title: Passengers Sound Off About N.J. Transit Trains
description: To the Editor:

title: Postings: New Expanded Edition Includes Painters; A Directory For Restorers
description: Owners of historic and not-so-historic properties who need help in restoring their buildings can turn to the new seventh edition of ''Restoration Directory: A Listing of Services in the New York City Area,'' which offers 391 companies in 14 categories, including 80 concerns new since the last edition, and a new chapter on painting.

title: Habitats / Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn; An Apartment Seeker Becomes a Landlord
description: IN New York, many regular people -- meaning those who do not make hundreds of thousands of dollars a year -- do not think of landlords as being like them. They think of the stereotype: A landlord is someone who refuses to turn on the heat when it's cold.

title: Both Fox and Hedgehog
description: ISAIAH BERLIN A Life. By Michael Ignatieff. Illustrated. 356 pp. New York: Metropolitan Books/ Henry Holt & Company. $30.

title: Color These People Angry
description: The couple had enjoyed a Saturday afternoon of shopping at a mall in Wayne, but all that changed suddenly. As a young man was helping his fiance into his car, something whizzed by her head and splattered against the car window, leaving a pinkish paint splotch.

title: Monicagate: Who Knew What, When?
description: To the Editor:

title: The View From/Yonkers; Putting a Roof Over a Family in 5 Days
description: MICHELLE HAYES was welcoming people into her living room. ''Don't trip over the couch,'' she said, then laughed -- the couch was, as yet, nowhere to be seen. In fact, the walls had just gone up: it was a brand-new house, on the corner of Walnut and Porach Streets here and had been under construction only two days.

title: Trenton, a Capital In Search of a City; Education and Income Lag, and Getting Coffee Is Hard, but It's Trying
description: THE Governor's official residence is in Princeton. The New Jersey Legislative Correspondents' Club holds its annual banquet in East Brunswick. The Trenton Thunder baseball team puts up visiting teams at the McIntosh Inn in Lawrenceville.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Mary Mcgreevy By Walter Keady. MacMurry & Beck, $24.

title: A Teen-Ager's Legacy: A Cancer Lab
description: CHRISTINE FRISBEE decided to start a real estate consulting business a few months ago. It is, she thinks, time to move on. For the past nine years, the New Canaan mother of five has devoted most of her time to fighting cancer because, at his deathbed, she had promised her teen-age son that she would do that.

title: The World: Terrible Reputations; A Kurd's Arrest Slows Turkey's Path to Europe
description: THE Turkish novelist Orhan Pamuk remembers that when he was growing up in the 1950's and 60's, there was one sure way to end any argument about how to do something: ''You just had to say 'This is how they do it in Europe' and that was final. If things were done a certain way in Europe, then by definition that was the right way to do it.''

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about a trend in collecting artifacts from explorers' expeditions misidentified the captain of a ship photographed locked in ice in Antarctica. The ship, the Endurance, was that of the British adventurer Sir Ernest Shackleton, not Robert Scott.

title: SOAPBOX; Curbed
description: THE band has finished its next-to-last set and even though the lead singer, a cheerleaderish showman, implores you to stay, you draw upon your savoir faire and you know that the next set will be just 10 minutes long, leaving you with half a fresh drink while the lights are turned up and the players are gathering up coils of dusty cable.

title: Monicagate: Who Knew What, When?; Rule of Law?
description: To the Editor,

title: Q&A/Mark E. Sullivan; The When and How of Using Mediation
description: MARK E. SULLIVAN is head of the Mediation Certificate Program at the University of Connecticut in Storrs, which trains lawyers, businesspeople, public policy makers and others in the art of settling disputes without going either to court or to arbitration.

title: Cinema That Rolls With the Politics
description: BRAZIL has long been proud of its place in world cinema. But these days the country is quite simply film mad. Headlines appear on the front pages of the major newspapers every time a Brazilian film wins an international award or an Academy Award nomination. E-mail and the Internet are settings for debates over movies, like the one that erupted last year when Bruno Barreto's ''Four Days in September'' fueled complaints that it soft-pedaled Brazil's years of military rule.

title: OPINION; Historic Sites Need Their Heroes
description: THE abrupt end of the 350-year life of Plandome Manor [''Efforts Fail to Save Historic Plandome Site,'' Nov. 8] should be a wake-up call to all of us: could it be that somebody is looting our best heirlooms? The casual bulldozing of this living mirror of nearly four centuries of Long Island life points up not only the appalling numbness of its new owner's cultural sensibilities, but also Long Island's impotence in protecting the extant symbols of its rich history. The leveling of what many considered to be our region's pre-eminent historic building is the latest example of environmental vandals operating barely a step ahead of the law and just beyond the scrutiny of outraged neighbors.

title: F.Y.I
description: Don't Tell the Colonel

title: Rolando La Serie, 75, a Popular Singer in Cuba
description: Rolando La Serie, one of the great Cuban singers of his time, died last Sunday at Healthsouth Doctors' Hospital in Coral Gables, Fla. He was 75.

title: On Slow Pokes In the Fast Lane
description: As one who often drives the stretch of Interstate 95 from Branford toward the Rhode Island border, permit me to make a suggestion for improving traffic flow, especially with the new 65 mile-an-hour speed limit. (''Who, Me, Officer? Oh, No, I Never Speed. No, Sir,'' last Sunday.) State troopers should expend as much effort on educating slow drivers to keep right as they do in catching speeders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDHEIM, BEATRICE
description: FELDHEIM - Beatrice. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Devoted mother of Jenine and Richard. Adored grandmother of Andrew and Daniel. Services 11:30 AM, Sunday, at ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Is Solitary Confinement Driving Charlie Chase Crazy?
description: The recognition that isolation breeds violence is not news to behavioral biologists. Recent studies of mice demonstrate that even animals who are bred to be bullies show their aggressive stripes only after they have lived in solitary confinement. Housed in groups, they remain peaceable citizens.

title: Passage to America
description: EAST INTO

title: A Fan's Fan, but an Owner First; Decision on Patriots Put Economics Ahead of Emotions
description: The occasion called for Champagne.

title: Lethal Chemistry at Harvard
description: In death as in life, Jason Altom managed to be both extremely methodical and extraordinarily good-hearted. On the warm, humid day in mid-August when he ended his life, he walked up to the third-floor bedroom of the Somerville, Mass., house he shared with two fellow graduate students at Harvard University, drank a liquid laced with cyanide procured from the very chemistry laboratory where he was considered an unusually gifted student and lay down on his bed. Having accounted for the remote possibility that his own death might endanger others, the 26-year-old doctoral candidate left a warning note on the bed. ''Do Not Resuscitate,'' it read. ''Danger: Potassium Cyanide.'' As one of his roommates explained to me later, ''I think he was worried, in his meticulous way, that someone might try to give him mouth-to-mouth resuscitation.''

title: After You. No, After You. Ouch!
description: TWO men approach each other on a street. They quickly realize they are on a collision course. The first man, reading the body language of the second, steps to the right, then sees that the second man, attempting the same maneuver but responding a split second too late, has made the same move. The first man tacks the other way, but the second man has beat him to it. In an exquisite choreography of misinterpretation, the two men run right into each other on an empty sidewalk.

title: Like His Mentor at US Airways, The Chief Has an Eye for Details
description: TO appreciate the attention to detail of Rakesh Gangwal, who was recently promoted to chief executive of US Airways Group, consider this: While reviewing a training tape for flight attendants, he was dismayed to see the person portraying a business traveler lick her finger to turn a magazine page. Of course, she was not trying to model behavior for the flight attendants. But no matter: Mr. Gangwal said it should have been caught and changed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, BEATRICE R.
description: KLEIN-Beatrice R. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Cherished mother of Marc and Peter Rubinger. Devoted stepmother of the late Bette Pincous. Loving sister of Marion Sells & Harry Sklar. Adored grandmother of Lauren, Rachel, Benjamin, Andrew, Jonathon, Jason, Emily & Sharon. Services were held Sunday, November 22, at Cedar Park Cemetery.

title: Mixtures For Potting Indoor Plants
description: AS one's thoughts turn to the plants growing indoors, it might be helpful to consider the stuff that roots are in: potting soil. Any plant needs a good root system to thrive, and for plants growing in pots, a proper growing mixture is key.

title: Crime Is Key As Swiss Vote On Legalizing Hard Drugs
description: The Swiss are voting Sunday on whether to legalize everything from marijuana to heroin and cocaine, a measure that -- if passed -- would give Switzerland the most sweeping decriminalization of drug use, possession and production in Europe.

title: The Lady and the Tramp
description: OONA

title: Police Vehicle in Chase Kills City Rescue Worker
description: An off-duty emergency medical technician was struck and killed by an unmarked police car after he stepped off a bus in Brooklyn early yesterday, the police said.

title: Is Solitary Confinement Driving Charlie Chase Crazy?
description: Bruce Porter quotes Stuart Grassian, a Harvard psychiatrist (Nov. 8), as faulting the simplicity of the corrections paradigm that ''if the inmates are acting bad you punish them, and if you punish them hard enough they won't do it again.'' It should be noted that the paradigm is not as simple or as exclusively punitive as Grassian suggests. It also rewards inmates who behave well -- with a transfer to lower security, paying jobs, education and early release.

title: Giants Stadium Is Likely To Go Natural, Turning Turf Into Grass
description: There have been experimental summer grass fields at Giants Stadium, where for 23 football seasons the playing surface has been artificial. But the installation of a permanent grass field -- the hope of athletes and sporting purists alike -- has always been considered too risky for the only stadium that is home to two National Football League teams.

title: Roukema Named Co-Chair Of New Speaker's Team
description: Representative Marge S. Roukema, a dean of the New Jersey Congressional delegation whose political moderation often put her at odds with Speaker Newt Gingrich, has been named co-chair of the transition team for the newly elected Speaker, Bob Livingston.

title: Style; All of Me
description: I move through life as if it were a disappointing museum exhibit, according to people who have seen me when I had no idea they were looking. And that's when I'm in a good mood. Otherwise, I exude utter disdain or profound unhappiness. When all the other seats on the train are filled, the one next to me is empty. Strangers on the street solicitously tell me that life isn't so bad and then demand that I smile to prove it, which makes it impossible to smile.

title: Giving New Meaning To Endowing a Chair
description: At a time when colleges offer ''naming opportunities'' for donors willing to write big checks to have buildings named after them, Columbia University's business school has a supplemental strategy. It's making available classroom seats and student lockers for those who want to win public recognition for their support but don't have as much money to give.

title: Sally Christiansen, Mike Harris
description: Sally Gene Christiansen and Wilmot Louis Harris Jr. were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church of Greenwich in Old Greenwich, Conn. The bride's sister the Rev. Karin Christiansen Fowler, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony with the bridegroom's brother Bishop Rogers S. Harris, who is retired from the Episcopal Diocese of Southwest Florida.

title: Short-Handed Scarlet Knights Still Have Plenty
description: This is what late November is made for: A vulnerable nonconference opponent. An adoring home crowd. A chance to pad an impressive record.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANKIN, LEONARD J.
description: HANKIN-Leonard J. Age 81. On November 28, 1998. Retired Executive Vice President of Bergdorf Goodman. Beloved husband of Kathleen. Devoted father of Kim Hankin Barrett and Lyn Hankin. Adoring grandfather to Lindsey and Kendall Barrett. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Educational Alliance, 197 East Broadway, New York, NY 10002.

title: Editorial Observer; Republican Feuds Yield a New Party Dialectic
description: Mention the deep rift in American politics and everyone thinks of Republicans and Democrats. But the last election revealed a more subtle division between political professionals and voters. Indeed some Republicans feel that behind the party's destructive obsession with President Clinton was a larger structural problem: a centrally controlled fund-raising and attack strategy that lost touch with the electorate.

title: Future of Animation On a Wing and a Smile
description: Computer animation is pushing into new territory on the wings of an unlikely fleet of cartoon airplanes -- characters in a series for preschoolers that began Nov. 2 on the Learning Channel on cable television.

title: Rugrats and Status
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Mix Religion And Law School
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Agencies Begin New Operations
description: Three agencies are undertaking new operations.

title: Chilean Official Says His Country Will Pursue Justice Against Pinochet
description: Pressing an effort to persuade Britain to free Gen. Augusto Pinochet and let him fly home, the Foreign Minister of Chile said here today that his Government would pursue its own judgment of the former dictator.

title: Compressed Data; Get a Speeding Ticket, Head for the Internet
description: What do you get when you cross an Internet marketing guy with a lawyer? In one case, www.speedingticket.net, a new Web service for people nabbed for speeding and other traffic violations while away from home territory.

title: Don't Mix Religion And Law School
description: To the Editor:

title: Gretzky And Great Together Once More
description: In the first quarter of his 20th National Hockey League season, Wayne Gretzky's statistics weren't exactly Great Ones. He had only two goals, his shooting percentage was the worst among Ranger forwards, his plus-minus ratio was second-worst on the team and he led the league in turnovers. His foot speed, dwindling for many years, seemed about the same. But the deft hands that have created so many goals for so many others over so many seasons seemed to have lost some of their creative qualities. His name was nowhere near the top 10 scoring leaders.

title: Shifts in Symbol and Substance Muddy Quebec Vote
description: A Quebecer returning home this week after a few years' absence would be thoroughly confused by the campaign posters lining the highways leading to this provincial capital.

title: Compressed Data; 12 Nude Pictures Start A Copyright Extravaganza
description: As copyright battles go, this one just does not seem to have an end in sight. Just a few weeks after a Federal judge ruled that the Internet Entertainment Group could display 12 nude photos of Laura Schlessinger, the radio talk show celebrity whose program offers advice to both the lovesick and the just plain sick, on its Web site, the company finds itself caught up in a nasty fight to prevent other Web sites from doing the same thing.

title: Time Inc.'s Softest Sell; In Style, a Homage to Celebrities, becomes an Ad-Rich Hit
description: Ann Jackson remembers particularly vividly one meeting when she was trying to get In Style magazine off the ground for Time Inc. in the early 1990's. Ms. Jackson, now the publisher of the In Style Group of magazines, showed sample spreads of posing starlets to a group of Time Inc. senior editors, including the company's chief executive, Don Logan. After a ponderous silence, one of the men in the room -- and they were all men -- grumbled a question.

title: 2 Teen-agers Are Killed As Car Runs Into a Tree
description: Two Long Island teen-agers were killed and two others were critically injured late Saturday night when their car struck a tree in Ronkonkoma, the Suffolk County police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROOSEVELT, P. JAMES
description: ROOSEVELT-P. James. Investor, yachtsman, philanthropist. Beloved husband of Philippa; father of Lenore, Philip, Michael and Jean; grandfather of three. Died November 27, in Oyster Bay, NY. In nearly half a century on Wall Street, he founded or co-founded three investment firms. A cousin of Theodore Roosevelt, he served on the executive committee of the Theodore Roosevelt Association for 34 years. He also held leadership posts with The Holy Way, the Laymen's National Bible Association, the New York Diabetes Association, Youngs Memorial Cemetery, and other nonprofit organizations. He was a champion sailor, an expert in nautical history and a commodore of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club. He was born in New York City on August 22, 1928, a son of Philip J. and Jean S. Roosevelt. Brother of the late Philippa R. Jeffries and John E. Roosevelt. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, December 5, at 11 AM, Christ Episcopal Church, Oyster Bay. Donations may be made to The Holy Way, Baltimore, or the American Heart Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALMER, ELEANOR C. (NEE CONNELL)
description: PALMER-Eleanor C. (nee Connell). Wife of the late Robert F. Palmer. Mother of Robert F., Jr. (Claudia) Palmer of Long Island, NY, Mary Ellen (Thomas) Cody of Cincinnati, OH, and Nora (Robert) Leibman of Mahwah, NJ. Sister of Dorothy and John Connell. Also survived by 14 grand- and 3 greatgrandchildren. Died Thursday, November 26, 1998. Mass of Christian Burial was held in Cincinnati, OH.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Farming requires good management and capital. Unfortunately Russia does not have either. Food security is a big, big issue.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBERT, BARBARA M.
description: GILBERT-Barbara M. After a long illness. Mother of Susan and Jedd. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, November 30, 1 PM. Interment to follow at Beth David Cemetery, LI.

title: Duplicate Efforts
description: In 1938, two men in a dark, makeshift laboratory in Astoria, Queens, rubbed a handkerchief on a zinc plate coated with sulfur to give it an electric charge, placed a slide on it on which they had written the date and the site of the lab and exposed it to light.

title: Even in Vermont, the Ardor For Wood Stoves Has Cooled
description: In winters past, Molly Prescott recalled, when her daughters came in from sledding, cherry-cheeked and snow-crusted and clamoring for hot chocolate, they would bake their mittens dry next to the wood stove that had long heated the family house in the rural Vermont hamlet of Fletcher.

title: G.O.P. Vote Counter in House Predicts Impeachment of Clinton
description: The chief Republican vote counter in the House accused President Clinton today of trying to evade perjury charges ''on a technicality,'' and became the first member of the Republican leadership to predict that the House would impeach the President.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UPBIN, CELIA
description: UPBIN-Celia. On November 27, 1998, at the age of 87. Devoted wife of the late Mortimer, loving mother of Sanford (deceased), Sol and Harry, mother-in-law of Jeanne and Joan. Cherished grandmother of Lori Abrams, Leslie Paparo, Bruce, Lisa, Stefanie, Brian, David and Daniel, greatgrandmother of Lucy, Annie, Nicholas, Isaac and William. Adored aunt and great-aunt. Service Sunday, November 29, 1:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Media Talk; Internet News Fanatics Prefer Television Sites
description: News addicts who use the Internet are most interested in national and international news and are more likely to turn to broadcast and cable television news sites instead of newspaper sites for a quick look at breaking headlines, a report on Internet news has concluded.

title: Compressed Data; First Boston Moves To Polish Its Image
description: Credit Suisse First Boston's technology banking team -- led by the uber-banker Frank Quattrone, who moved from Deutsche Bank in July -- is turning the luxurious Phoenician resort in Arizona into a playland for clients at its annual conference starting today. And for the first time, reporters are invited to this most exclusive of parties, which will include four-wheeling in the Sonoran desert and a dinner show starring the comedian Dana Carvey.

title: One-Man University of Latin Music; A Record Salesman Wins a Following for His Knowledge
description: It's hard to get more than a few sentences out of Harry Sepulveda, though he would like to talk some more. When he's at work, perched behind the cash register at the Record Mart in the Times Square subway station, Mr. Sepulveda attracts a line of fans. Sometimes they are from Japan, video cameras in hand, hoping to take home some tape of a legend. Sometimes they're from France or Sweden, Latin music enthusiasts who have come to the heart of Latin recordings. They pick up hundreds of dollars' worth of CD's; the owner of the record store, the ever-patient Jesse Moskowitz, won't ring up their choices right away.

title: Quarterback Inexperience Costs Irish A Key Game
description: If Notre Dame proved anything in its listless 10-0 loss to Southern California here Saturday night, it was that it was tough to win with an inexperienced quarterback at the helm -- especially when a major bowl berth is riding on the game, as was the case in the 70th meeting between the two rivals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, JOSEPH
description: WEISS-Joseph. Age 83. Lifetime activist for freedom and justice, human rights and equality. Struggled for tenants' rights and against the privatization of city hospitals. Tutor for Coney Island Learning Center-Adult Literacy. Beloved companion of the late Victoria O'Mara. Joe will be remembered by his children, Carol Weinshenker (Mickey), Rachel Davidsohn, Annette, and the late Marcella, his many grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Contributions may be made in his memory to the Metropolitan Council on Housing or Cystic Fibrosis Foundation. Services will be held 6 PM, Monday, November 30, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn (near Avenue V). Family will be receiving visitors from 3 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVEYRAC, GLORIA CARR
description: deVEYRAC-Gloria Carr. Nov. 23, 1998. Retired fashion director. Her career spanned many years in the international world of fashion. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. A memorial service will be announced at a future date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, JOANN SOLOMAN (JST)
description: BROWN-Joann Soloman (JST). On November 27, 1998. Beloved wife of Steven. Loving sister of Dr. Kenneth Soloman and Billy Soloman. Also survived by nieces, nephews, family and many friends. Services Monday, 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Interment to follow in Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Dr. Robert Silber, 67, a Top Hematologist
description: Dr. Robert Silber, a hematologist and educator, died on Nov. 3 at his home in Durham, N.C. He was 67.

title: Confronting an Unfair Census
description: The Supreme Court will hear arguments today on the legality of the Clinton Administration's plan to use statistical sampling in the 2000 census. The purpose of the sampling is to correct for the predictable undercounting of poor minorities by conventional census-taking methods. The Court's judgment will be momentous, both for its immediate practical consequences and its symbolic message.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZOG, GRACE FEDER
description: HERZOG-Grace Feder. On Thursday, November 26, 1998, Grace Feder Herzog, beloved wife of the late Sol A. Herzog, extraordinary mother of Richard and Robert Herzog, devoted aunt to Bruce and Madeleine Sidelnik, loving mother-in-law to Barbara and Margot, adoring grandmother to Jeffrey Herzog, Kari AlperovitzBichell, Stuart Hunt, Stephanie Hunt Ma, great-aunt to Katharine Sidelnik, great-grandmother to Hendrik Moes Ma. She encompassed all the dimensions of love. Services will be Monday, November 30, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC. Memorial contributions may be made to the Muhlenberg Branch of the New York Public Library through the Library Friends Office, 212-930-0778.

title: Soviet Mindset Blocks Capitalism on Farms
description: Vadim Voloboyev's day begins before sunrise, when he scurries over to a weather-beaten barn to supervise the morning milking.

description: DIVISION III

description: EVENTS

title: Congo Rebel Chief, Citing Lack Of Details, Holds Back on Truce
description: The leader of the rebels in Congo said today that he had not heard the details of a cease-fire agreement announced on Saturday in Paris and could not yet commit to it.

title: Don't Mix Religion And Law School
description: To the Editor;

title: Vacco's Low-Profile Tactic Raises Brows of Politicians
description: In the swirl of events in the last month surrounding the race for state attorney general, one voice has been virtually silent: that of the incumbent, Dennis C. Vacco.

title: The B.C.S. Problem: 3 Teams, 2 Positions
description: Three big games remain in a wild college football season, and the things we know for sure can be counted on one hand.

title: Media Talk; Mademoiselle, the Search Engine Edition
description: When Money magazine decided to redesign its pages beginning with its September issue, designers chose a layout for some sections that offered the look and feel of a World Wide Web page. Now, Mademoiselle is taking that notion a step further, according to Elizabeth Crow, the editor in chief: with its February issue, not only will the magazine introduce a top-to-bottom redesign, but every article will suggest a Web site, chat room or home page on the Internet for readers to consult for more information.

title: Wrong Move on Campaign Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Media Talk; Is the N.B.A. Brand Losing Some Cachet?
description: Sure, the National Basketball Association -- which oversees a basketball business worth $2 billion a year -- is canceling its games in an official lockout as owners try to renegotiate elements of the collective bargaining agreement with players.

title: Wrong Move on Campaign Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Wrong Move on Campaign Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Compressed Data; More Fancy Prices For a Domain Name
description: And you thought the days of Internet squatting were over? Kevin Sinclair, who lives in a Silicon Valley suburb, is the lucky owner of www.computer.com, presumably one the most valuable domain names on the World Wide Web. And now he wants to sell it for at least $500,000. So far the highest bidder has offered $300,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, LOUIS
description: MAYER-Louis. Died at age 92 on November 28, 1998. Beloved husband of Lilo and beloved father of Steven and Ronny. Loving grandfather of Jennifer, Michelle, and Debbie. Funeral was held on Sunday, November 29.

title: Homes Built by Inmates Come to Aid of Small-Town South Dakotans
description: The railroad used to rumble through the cornfields and cow pastures here, braiding this southeastern South Dakota town into a necklace linked to the commercial cosmos of Chicago.

title: Valuing Separation at America Online
description: If America Online followed all the advice it was getting for how to take advantage of its pending purchase of the Netscape Communications Corporation, it would merge its AOL.com Web site with Netscape's Netcenter Web site, it would use Netscape's browser on its on-line service, and every time someone used the Netscape Communicator program to check for messages, it would chirp, ''You've got mail.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWHOUSE, THEODORE
description: NEWHOUSE-Theodore. 95. Died on November 28, 1998, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Caroline. Loving father of the late Jane. Devoted grandfather of Julie and Amy, grandfather-in-law and great-grandfather of Joshua, Isaac, Jonathan, Sarah, Jill and Emily. Services Monday, November 30th, 11:30 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65th St. Interment to follow at Baron Hirsch Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Alzheimer's Association of New York, 420 Lexington Ave., NYC 10170.

title: Two Locals to File Suit Over 1996 Vote Fraud
description: Two of the locals in District Council 37, New York City's biggest municipal union, plan to file a lawsuit today accusing the council's leaders of running a criminal enterprise and demanding hundreds of thousands of dollars in damages.

title: Taiwan and Its Troubles as an Underdog
description: In an age distinguished by mass cruelty wherever one looks, Americans may be forgiven if they have not given much attention, in the intervals between emergencies, to the decades of troubles of the people of Taiwan. Tonight, to repair the neglect, comes ''Tug-of-War: The Story of Taiwan,'' which offers a glimpse of history from the perspective of a perpetual underdog caught up in wars, occupations, power plays and other ills of the weak confronted by the strong.

title: Big Bonuses Expected With Merger of Deutsche and Bankers Trust
description: Deutsche Bank A.G. is expected to provide multimillion-dollar incentives to a handful of top Bankers Trust and Deutsche executives to secure their services once the German banking giant completes its $9.67 billion purchase of Bankers Trust.

title: Wrong Move on Campaign Money
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Officials Help the Patriots While the Jets Help Themselves; A Timely Interference Call Aids Bledsoe's Latest Heroics
description: The final play began at the Buffalo 26-yard line with six seconds left and the Bills ahead of the New England Patriots, 21-17. With the sky turning dark above Foxboro Stadium, the Patriots' season looked darker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANKIN, DAVID
description: MANKIN-David. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club mourn the loss of their esteemed Member, Friar David Mankin, on November 26, 1998. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Services will be on Monday, November 30, at 11 AM, at Temple Beth-El of Great Neck. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Exec Director

title: Another Pick For Glenn
description: They used to tease the diminutive Aaron Glenn as a rookie in 1994 because no matter how hard he tried or how high he jumped, he couldn't get an interception. He made the National Football League's all-rookie team without picking off a pass. In fact, he didn't get one until his second year, in his 27th game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURTHA, JOSEPH W.
description: MURTHA-Joseph W. Retired Colonel, U.S. Air Force. Of Bronxville, NY. On November 27, 1998. Husband of Margaret Devlin Murtha. Father of Joseph J. and Francis E. Murtha. Loving father-in-law of Eileen and Kathie. Beloved grandfather of Katie, Joe, Michael, and Kaitlin. Loving brother of Gene. Brother-in-law of James Devlin. Calling hours at Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Monday and Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Wednesday, December 2, at 10 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, SYD
description: GOLD-Syd. 91, a lifelong Manhattanite and bibliophile. Please join her family to grieve and honor her, Monday, November 30, noon at Kehila Chapel, 201 E. Broadway.

title: Corporate Campaign For Marsh & McLennan
description: The Marsh & McLennan Companies in New York, a professional services company that owns Lippincott & Margulies, the corporate identity consultant, has chosen Grace & Rothschild of New York to handle its first corporate advertising campaign. Billings were estimated at as much as $20 million.

title: Slavs and Albanians Form Unusual Coalition in Macedonia
description: With the war in neighboring Kosovo as the example of what could happen if they fail, the leaders of Macedonia's most radical ethnic political parties are forming a coalition to govern this fragile ex-Yugoslav republic.

title: Anthony Salvatore, 77, Recording Engineer
description: Anthony Salvatore, a Grammy Award-winning recording engineer, died on Nov. 18 at Hackensack University Medical Center in Hackensack, N.J. He was 77 and lived in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J.

description: BOYARSKY-Beatrice. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Men's Club mourn the passing of the beloved mother of their devoted member Neal Boyarsky and extend heartfelt sympathy to the members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua I. Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, President

title: Anahuac Journal; Alligator Farmer Feeds Demand for All the Parts
description: By the time Mark Porter is finished carving up one of his gators, there's nothing left but the fat and the guts, and if anyone can come up with a way to sell those he'd be eager to hear about it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORBERBAUM, SADIE
description: LORBERBAUM-Sadie. Beloved wife of the late Saul. Devoted mother of Robert and Lynn, Donald and Leah and Helene Wulwick. Cherished grandmother and great - grandmother. Graveside service today, 2 PM. For information call ''Boulevard-Riverside'' Chapel, 516-295-3100.

title: Bishops Appeal for Aid to Hurricane Victims
description: On the Sunday after Thanksgiving, the Archbishop of Honduras said he had come to St. Patrick's Cathedral mainly to give thanks.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: A PSYCHOTHERAPIST was hurrying to an appointment by cab when she realized she had left her purse at home. She told the driver, but reassured him that there would be someone at the other end who would lend her the money to pay the bill. ''That's all right,'' he replied. ''You look like a nice old lady, and I'm sure I can trust you.''

title: Shaky 'Ragtime' Producer Is Said to Find Lenders
description: Livent Inc., the corporate producer of the Broadway musical ''Ragtime,'' has found lenders willing to provide it with more money and save it from shutting down immediately, a person close to the company said yesterday.

title: New Program For Geocities
description: Geocities, which offers free personal Web pages to computer users, is introducing what is being described as its first major integrated communications program. The program, which includes print, Internet and radio advertising and a new corporate identity, begins tomorrow.

title: Subsidy for the Stock Exchange
description: New York City's economy is diverse, but no industry comes close to the financial business in its importance to the welfare of the city. The New York Stock Exchange, which has been on Wall Street for more than 200 years, is both the symbolic and actual center of that business. Now the exchange says it needs to expand its trading floor to make its operations more international and to remain competitive.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Officials Help the Patriots While the Jets Help Themselves; Four Games Stand in Way Of a New York Division Title
description: Now, the Jets say, they are getting serious. And today they proved it on the field.

title: CLINTON PROPOSES AID FOR DISABLED RETURNING TO JOBS
description: As part of his budget for the coming year, President Clinton will propose expanding Medicaid and Medicare to allow tens of thousands of people with disabilities to retain their health benefits when they return to work, Administration officials say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, MERWIN
description: LEWIS-Merwin. It is with sorrow that the Directors of Greater New York Mutual Insurance Company record the death of their dear friend and colleague, Merwin Lewis, in his 99th year. The Lewis family has been prominently identified with our Company since its founding 85 years ago. Merwin Lewis joined our Board in 1954. He was a compassionate and caring person deeply involved with the welfare of the Company's employees. A highly respected and experienced attorney, he carried on an active practice until his death. He was a wise and judicious counsellor to our Company and a valuable resource to the Bar of this city and to the community as a whole. We shall miss him. We extend our deepest sympathy to the members of the bereaved family. Alexander E. Rosenthal Chairman of the Board Warren W. Heck, President

title: Safety Is in the Driver
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: The power-drunk high-technology world seems to be trying to one-up itself in the cynicism department.
description: NO matter how cynical you become, it's never enough to keep up.''

title: Parents and Teachers Leery of New 4th-Grade English Test
description: A new reading and writing test will be given to fourth graders across New York State early next year, and it is so different from traditional multiple-choice tests that teachers and parents can barely contain their panic.

title: For Oil Workers, Merger Is Just Another Word for More Layoffs
description: They have been downsized, cut back and re-engineered. So when the 900 or so remaining blue-collar workers here at Mobil's largest domestic refinery, out of about 1,500 a decade ago, heard last week that their company was discussing a possible merger with Exxon, it was like a siren warning them that an already suspect valve might be about to blow.

title: U.S. to Increase Package Of Aid to Palestinians
description: The United States will pledge hundreds of millions of dollars in aid to the Palestinians this week and is pressing other wealthy nations to dramatically increase economic assistance to encourage the Palestinians to stick to the peace process with Israel, senior Clinton Administration officials said.

title: Giants' Special Teamer Faces a Special Game
description: At 180 pounds, the Giants' Curtis Buckley doesn't spend much time running into 300-pound linemen.

title: Not All Candy-Cane Sweet, a Ritual at Middle Age
description: In a changing world, it is reassuring to report that the majestic Christmas tree rose as expected on the stage of the New York State Theater on Friday night. The children at the Stahlbaum family's holiday party had near-exemplary manners and dancers small and grown filled the stage with the kind of delicate color that has brought generations of families back to ''The Nutcracker'' year after year. Yes, it is ''Nutcracker'' time again. The New York City Ballet will present George Balanchine's magical production through Jan. 3 at the New York State Theater. And if this year's opening performance was not quite magical, it got the ''Nutcracker'' season off to a good enough start.

title: Rivals in a Storybook World
description: The first thing one noticed about ''The Glint'' on Saturday night at the Kitchen was Nicole Eisenman's set. Figurines of tiny animals and people were crowded onto small platforms. Little racing cars were spaced along a strip of cloth that resembled a highway. Five plates on the floor held slices of bread.

title: Forsaking Her Lair Only in Stories
description: It's hard to get to Alice Munro, to the little town of Clinton, Ontario, where she lives in the rolling farmland of southern Canada. In the autumn light, Clinton seems bleak, a cluster of small undistinguished houses of wood or yellow brick set in rich black soil, overwhelmed by the landscape around it.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: FOOTBALL

title: Add Ventura to Players Orioles Battle Mets For
description: For a month or so, the Mets and the Baltimore Orioles have talked about a possible deal for Mets catcher Todd Hundley. But now, instead of being trading partners, they have a growing rivalry as they compete for the same free agents, Robin Ventura and B. J. Surhoff.

title: A Warm Holiday Gift
description: Forecasts of a cold winter add a measure of urgency to this year's New York Cares Coat Drive, which starts tomorrow. This valuable charitable program, now in its 10th season, collects ''gently used'' adult and child-sized winter coats for distribution to the homeless, the elderly poor and needy youngsters in New York and New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, ALLAN R.
description: JOHNSON-Allan R. November 26, 1998. Beloved husband Maria, devoted father of Jane Fell, Kathy Jones, Susan Johnson & Barbara Hobin, cherished grandfather of seven and great-grandfather of four, loving brother of Patrick Johnson, cherished Godfather of Steven Toia. With Saks Fifth Avenue for thirty-six years, ten of which he spent as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, he retired in 1981 as Chairman of the store's parent company BATUS, Inc. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Tuesday, December 1, 1998, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Religious service Wednesday, December 2, St. John the Evangelist Church, 55 Street and First Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions in his name may be made to The Boys Scouts of America.

title: News Analysis; What Led to the Takeover Of a Union, and What's Next
description: The takeover of District Council 37, New York City's largest municipal union, by its parent union in Washington is a stark indication of how far the council -- once a revered pioneer of public sector unionism -- has fallen.

title: Hall Lifts Accuracy With Kidd as Holder
description: John Hall, who hears thousands roar every time he kicks off, virtually put his hands over his ears after the Jets' big performance today against the Panthers.

description: MILLER-Trudy (Horowitz). On November 28, 1998. Beloved mother of Bill, Ronnie, and Paul. Grandmother of Jonathan, Elizabeth, Andrew, and Jared. Companion of Fred Jacobson. Resident of Lido Beach and Queens, NY. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Tuesday, December 1, at 11:30 AM. Interment will follow at Beth David Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to Cabrini Hospice, 227 East 19th St., New York, NY 10003.
