description: To the Editor:

title: Media Talk; Dot.com
description: David Lauren, son of the designer Ralph Lauren, has decided to close Swing magazine, his glossy monthly for 20-somethings . . . American Benefactor, previously a quarterly journal for philanthropists, has said it will now be published only twice a year. The reason: distribution problems encountered with 3,000 nonprofit corporations that buy subscriptions on behalf of their top donors, says W. Randall Jones, chief executive of Capital Publishing . . . An early sign of Newsweek's direction under Mark Whitaker, its newly appointed editor: the debut last week of a Science and Technology section . . . Who gained the most and fell the most in Fortune magazine's Power 25 Washington lobbyist rankings? The Credit Union National Association jumped from No. 70 in 1997 to No. 8 this year; the Children's Defense Fund plunged from 40 to 69 . . . Neatest job title: Lisa Caputo becomes vice president for Communications and Synergy at Walt Disney's Buena Vista Publishing Group . . . For the cautious: The CD-ROM ''Cosmopolitan Virtual Makeover: The Collection'' has sold more than 300,000 copies, Hearst Magazines says. It allows users to download a photographic self-portrait, then experiment with variations in hair styles, eyeglasses and eye color and even has a special segment for wedding veils . . . Bad timing: The December issue of Hachette Filipacchi's George magazine lists Newt Gingrich as the ninth-most- powerful person in Washington. He gets a very high three-thumbs-up ''mogul'' rating, better than two thumbs (''broker''); one thumb (''player), or three thumbs down (''outcast'').

title: The Web's Free Ride
description: With the holiday shopping season in full swing, many are predicting a merry year for Internet gift buying. The investment bank Volpe Brown Whelan has projected that fourth-quarter Internet sales this year will total $2.3 billion, up from $1 billion last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUR, BERTRAM H.
description: SCHUR-Bertram H. 80. Former Associate General Counsel to the Atomic Energy Commission and Department of Energy, died on Friday, November 27, 1998, at his home in Wilton, CT, after a lengthy illness. Schur attended Phillips Exeter Academy in New Hampshire, graduated from Harvard College and received his law degree from Syracuse Law College in Syracuse, NY. Following several years in private practice in New York, Schur was appointed Assistant to the General Counsel of the Atomic Energy Commission in 1961. He remained with the Commission and its successor, the Department of Energy, in capacities of increasing responsibility until his retirement. As Associate General Counsel of the AEC, he directed and supervised a legal staff of up to 150 attorneys assigned to Washington and various field offices. He was also appointed counsel to Vice Admiral Hyman Rickover, a position he held for over 13 years. In his years with the AEC, Schur was responsible for much major Federal Legislation, regulations, and papers, and also rendered major opinions for the Freedom of Information Appeals Panel on many ocasions. Schur was the recipient of many awards for his Federal service, including a special Achievement Award for his contributions to the Atomic Energy Program, and his work on the Energy Research and Development Administration Programs. He was a member of the New York City Bar Association, the New York County Lawyers Association, the Federal Bar Association, the Harvard Club in New York City, and the Alumni Council of Phillips Exeter Academy. He is survived by his wife, Adelaide Bishop, of Wilton, CT, a son, Peyton Schur, of Corona Del Mar, CA, and a grandson, Kyle Schur. Funeral services will be private, with a memorial service to be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Wittingham Cancer Center, Norwalk Hospital, Norwalk, CT.

title: Terreri Is Happy as the Backup to Brodeur
description: Martin Brodeur has already played 18 of the Devils' first 21 games this season. Chris Terreri, his understudy, has started only three games -- and won all three. But despite his success, Terreri has not appeared in the last seven games and, in all probability, he will not play in the next one either.

title: A Private World To Ward Off The Nazi Horror
description: The Royal Academy of Arts can hardly claim to have discovered a new artist with its current show, ''Life? or Theater? The Work of Charlotte Salomon.'' Salomon's paintings were first exhibited in Amsterdam in 1961, and they have since traveled to Germany, France, Japan, Israel and the United States. The Jewish Historical Museum in Amsterdam, which owns all her surviving works, has 60 of her paintings on permanent display.

title: The American Songfest: Updating the Old, but Gently
description: That vast musical territory the United States claimed about a century ago in the name of the American popular song has become a crowded mall of forms and styles. (And when you don't get what you want, you are left with the side effects that mall shopping can produce: nervous excitement, dizziness, irritability or nausea.)

title: Essay; King of Chutzpah
description: In blowing off the House Judiciary Committee's 81 interrogatories, a mockingly evasive Bill Clinton told the Congress of the United States: Take your impeachment process and stick it in your ear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERGOLD, LEON
description: SERGOLD-Leon. We extend heartfelt condolences to Eveline Sergold on the passing of her beloved husband, Leon. He was an extraordinary and humble man whose very being radiated kindness, dignity and modesty. As Chairman and founder of the medical center's Woodlands Country Club activities in Tamarac, FL, and as a Diamond Founder of Shaare Zedek, together with Eveline, his leadership and exceptional commitment to tzedakah and chesed played a vital role in providing world-class and compassionate medical care to the people of Israel, rooted in the spiritual and ethical precepts of Jewish tradition to which he devoted his life. May Eveline, his daughters Audrey and Viviane, his sister Cecile, his brother Maurice, a devoted patron and outstanding friend of the medical center, and the entire family, have loving memories of this wonderful and caring man, and may they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, President Lee Weinbach, President, National Women's Division

title: It Was Ugly, but Broncos Are Now 12-0
description: Even the great teams, every now and then, play a game so bad they want to burn the game film. The Denver Broncos are a great team, but they played in one of the ugliest games of the season against the San Diego Chargers tonight.

description: THE JEWELS OF TESSA KENT

title: In a country run by the military, a station manager sees talk radio as a democratic duty.
description: IN the scattered cities of Niger, they have talk radio of a different kind. It's more like walk-in radio. On Saturday and Sunday mornings, farmers and merchants and homemakers gather outside the independent stations run by Radio Anfani in Niamey, Maradi and Zinder to await the start of a two-hour program.

title: Toxic Cleanup Is Needed at Hartford Stadium Site, Officials Say
description: The riverfront land that is to be the site of a stadium for the New England Patriots is contaminated with toxic materials, regulators said today, which could threaten the state's promise to have the football field ready in 2001.

title: Shares of Telecom To Be Sold to Public
description: The French Government said over the weekend that it would sell France Telecom S.A. shares to the public for 390 francs, or $67.90 each, raising at least 36.8 billion francs, or $6.4 billion, in Europe's biggest stock sale this year.

title: Despite the Warmth, Some Shun the Sun
description: The sun was out. Again. And not everyone was thrilled.

title: M. Donald Grant, 94, Dies; Executive Angered Mets Fans
description: M. Donald Grant, a winning amateur competitor in hockey, squash and golf who became the controversial chairman of the Mets and enjoyed mixed success, died at his home in Hobe Sound, Fla., on Saturday. He was 94.

title: Accounts
description: * Dermot McNulty was named to the new position of vice chairman at Burson-Marsteller Worldwide, London, part of Young & Rubicam Inc. He had most recently been chief executive at Shandwick International P.L.C., London, leaving that post before the recent acquisition of Shandwick by Interpublic Group of Cos. Also at Burson-Marsteller, Clif Kagawa was named chairman and chief executive for the Asia-Pacific region, succeeding Ferry de Bakker, who was named vice chairman at Burson-Marsteller Worldwide. Mr. Kagawa, who will be based in Hong Kong, had been chairman and chief executive at Hill & Knowlton Asia, Hong Kong, part of WPP Group P.L.C.

title: In Suburbs, Deer Sprawl Meets the Deerslayer
description: The marksmen gulped a hasty dinner of pasta and salad before preparing to spend a chilly night stalking their quarry. Their quarters had the look of a wilderness encampment for commandos, with heavy wool socks hung to dry and foam-lined cases for custom-made rifles stacked near a fireplace. Telescopic sights and night-vision gear sat on a bed.

Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Chancellor Brig. Gen. (Res.) Yehuda Halevy, Executive Vice President Elaine Bloom, Florida Director

title: Hindu Nationalists Trounced in Backlash Over Onions
description: As vote tallies piled up here today in a series of important state elections, the humiliating defeat of the Hindu nationalists and the stunning resurrection of India's once-dominant political force, the Congress Party, became ever more starkly apparent.

title: The Big City; Rich and Poor, Consumed By Consuming
description: BEFORE the lunch at Lespinasse, Dr. Robert H. Frank's theory seemed unassailable. Dr. Frank, an economist with a radical proposal to reduce conspicuous consumption, thinks we would all be happier if we spent less money this holiday season, and he illustrated his point during a shopping expedition on Fifth Avenue.

title: Rep. Dante B. Fascell, 81; Headed Foreign Affairs Panel
description: Former Representative Dante B. Fascell, a Florida Democrat who was chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee from 1984 through 1992, died on Saturday at his home in Clearwater, Fla. He was 81 and had lived in Miami until June.

title: France Confronts Holocaust Claims
description: It has been carefully preserved in the archives for more than 50 years, a handwritten receipt from the French Internal Police for 51,135 francs -- worth about $13,000 today -- and $450 seized from Henri Israel of Limoges on his arrival in the French concentration camp in Drancy, north of Paris, on Oct. 30, 1943.

title: Several Titles Are at Stake In One Championship Event
description: Three separate battles were in progress within one event at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here today. Most of the top players in North America and a handful from other parts of the world were fighting for the prestigious Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams title, with two subplots.

description: Exxon-Mobil Talks Add To Oil Workers' Anxiety

title: Buenos Aires Mayor to Lead Opposition in Argentina
description: The Mayor of Buenos Aires, Fernando de la Rua, became the favorite to replace Carlos Saul Menem as President of Argentina by winning a landslide victory today in a primary election to carry the banner of the center-left Alianza opposition coalition in the general election in October.

title: Failed by a System Meant to Help Her; A Chronic Runaway's Journey Through a Foster Care Maze Ended in a Brutal Death at 14
description: Childhood was never an option for Marleny Cruz. At the age of 9, she was sent from her native Dominican Republic to live in New Jersey with her father, a man she would later say abused her. When Marleny was 10, her mother was killed in her homeland in an argument over drugs, cheating the young girl of the reunion she longed for. By her early teens, Marleny had felt the pull of drugs and had made several attempts at suicide.

A Torah scholar, a man of great dignity and charm, he graced our Congregation for many years. Shiva observed in New York at the Pollak residence, Wednesday evening through Friday noon. title: Suddenly, They Block
description: The Jets' offensive line has not only survived, it has also prevailed. A few games ago, Coach Bill Parcells was threatening to bring in some backups to get better play at guard. In workouts, he complained to the incumbents Matt O'Dwyer on the right side and Todd Burger on the left. The coach used Alex Bernstein in a rotation with O'Dwyer, and Doug Karczewski in Burger's place.

description: CIRKER-Sadie R. November 30, 1971. In loving memory of our dear mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother. The Childre

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, SAUL A., M.D.
description: SCHWARTZ-Saul A., M.D. 91. Professor Emeritus, New York Medical College. Formerly of Mt. Vernon, NY. Passed away Sunday in Cherry Hill, NJ. He practiced medicine in the Bronx for 65 years. He established a chapter of Alpha Omega Alpha, the honorary medical society. He worked with Dr. Burrill Crohn at Mt. Sinai and Montefiore Hospital. Dr. Schwartz was a Diplomate of the American Board of Pediatrics and the American Board of Internal Medicine and was past president of the Bronx Society of Internal Medicine. Father of Richard Schwartz, Cantor Michael Schwartz and Marilyn Axler. Brother of Irving Schwartz. Also survived by nine grandchildren. Funeral service is 12:30 PM today, ''Riverside Memorial Chapel,'' 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon. The family will return to the home of Cantor Michael and Diana Schwartz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, ALEX
description: HOROWITZ-Alex. We mourn the sudden and untimely passing of Alex Horowitz. Beloved husband of Muriel and the late Laura Horowitz. Devoted father of Dr. Alan Horowitz, of Farmington Hills, MI, and Dr. Richard and Mindy Horowitz of Roslyn Heights. Adoring grandfather of Andrew, Jeffrey, Alyson, Joshua, Jason, and Lee Horowitz. Alex was a caring stepfather to Richard, Randy, and Brad April and their familiies. His warmth and devotion to his family were a source of inspiration to all who knew him. He was deeply loved and will be sorely missed. Services at I.J. Morris Funeral Home, Hempstead, NY, 12 noon, Monday, November 30.

title: Studio Disappointed on 'Babe' Sequel
description: What happened to ''Babe: Pig in the City''? The family film, which cost about $90 million and had an initial gross of only $8.5 million, was not only the most high-profile failure over the Thanksgiving weekend, but it may cause the ouster of Universal Pictures' president, Casey Silver, several high-level talent agents and studio executives said.

description: A partial list for this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANT, MICHAEL DONALD
description: GRANT-Michael Donald. Of Jupiter Island, Hobe Sound, FL, age 94. Died peacefully on November 28, 1998, at home. Beloved husband of Alice Waters Grant for 66 years. Loving father of Sheila (deceased), Michael D. Grant, Jr., of Greenwich, CT, Thomas W. Grant, and Patricia G. Warner, both of Locust Valley, NY. Grandfather to ten grandchildren: Andrew, Luke, Michael, Bettina, Mimi, and Tim Grant, Jr., Alexander, Kate, Michael and Alice Warner. A native of Montreal, Canada, he became a partner of Fahnestock, Members of the NY Stock Exchange in 1937. He was managing partner from 1945 through 1985. Sole dissenting Director of the NY Giants Baseball Club when they moved from NY. With Joan Whitney Payson, actively sought major league baseball's expansion and became a cofounder and chairman of the New York Mets in 1962, serving until 1978. Longest serving director of the Hobe Sound Company (Florida). A competitive sportsman, notably in hockey, golf, and squash racquets. A gifted raconteur and popular master of ceremonies of charitable events. Memorial mass at St. Christopher's Church, Hobe Sound, FL, at 4 PM on Wednesday, December 2, 1998. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested memorial contributions can be made to Hobe Sound Little League, POB 1892, Hobe Sound, FL 33475, or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10021.

title: Treasury's Auction Offerings for This Week Will Be Limited to Three Bills
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week is confined to bills, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills. The Treasury will also auction a 14-day cash-management bill today.

title: U.S. Report on Net Commerce Set for Release
description: To many Americans, the name Ira Magaziner is synonymous with the ill-fated Clinton health care plan. But the Presidential adviser's more lasting legacy may prove to be the Administration's laissez-faire policy on Internet commerce: no taxes, no Government regulations.

title: Sports of The Times; Martin Stands on Two Pedestals; Jets Start Seeking Their Own
description: CURTIS MARTIN knew that Jets center Kevin Mawae had been teasing him not long ago, saying, ''We haven't seen you break a long one; we're starting to question your speed.''

title: Swiss Voters Reject Legalization of Heroin, Cocaine and Marijuana
description: Swiss voters today decisively defeated a measure to legalize marijuana, heroin and cocaine, turning aside arguments that a Government-managed narcotics network would curb drug-related crime.

title: Sports of The Times; 3 Differing Viewpoints On Jets' Final Stretch
description: KEYSHAWN JOHNSON stood outside the Jets' locker room late yesterday afternoon, holding forth for yet another wave of reporters in the wake of a 48-21 Jets victory.

title: Holiday Shopping Off to Good Start
description: While unexpectedly warm weather brought hordes of shoppers to malls during the Thanksgiving weekend, most department store executives expressed just cautious optimism yesterday about sales for the holiday season.

title: Patents; When Mom says, 'Eat your vegetables,' she may soon mean, 'Make sure you get your protein.'
description: IT'S well known that the turkey served at last week's Thanksgiving dinner offered more protein than the vegetables that accompanied it. But researchers have been working on bolstering the protein quotient of plants, using the same techniques that genetically enhance plants to make them disease- or pest-resistant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORBERBAUM, SYD
description: LORBERBAUM-Syd. To my mother and my best friend, I will miss you. Helene Wulwick

title: Candidate Carte Blanche
description: It's two years until the next Presidential election, but the ground rules are being written right now. And what they say, essentially, is that Presidential candidates will be able to violate the law at will and without consequence.
